column2: The Midtown Galleries have now completed their first year as an exhibiting organization. The policy adopted at the start called for twelve group and twelve one-man shows in the course of a season. The present offering is the thirteenth, which thus marks the beginning of a new cycle.

Resignation of some of the Harriman-Lehman representatives on the board of the Aviation Corporation will be considered by the board at a special meeting to be held here Wednesday. The resignations, it is understood, have been presented unofficially.

THIS charming story of a representative American family of the professional class covers the last quarter of a century and is delicately attuned to the changes in the spirit of the times that took place during the period. It is sentimental, refined and, like the family it depicts, grows out of the general background of an earlier America's democratic idealism.

THE discovery of a "living fossil" ant in Australia emphasizes anew the venerableness of the ant family. Ants are so old that their evolution had been completed before man appeared. One hundred million years ago they had developed a social order which might well have served as a model for man's.

FREE bed and board -- of heightened value in a period of scrambled economics -- are obtained by more than a third of the motor tourists going from one State to another. More interstate movement is made in the name of friendship than for any other cause.

THE schoolbooks tell us that oxygen is necessary to life and that carbon dioxide kills. This is true enough, in general. But there are circumstances when oxygen is fatal and when carbon dioxide will save life. What the circumstances are has long been the subject of study by Dr. J. Willard Hershey of McPherson College, Kansas.

Federal agents said yesterday that only desultory attempts were being made to watch for "private" gold shipments accompanying outgoing passengers on transatlantic liners. Customs men pointed out that there were no orders from Washington to search for gold, as was the case in the war, and that it was accepted here that the government knew where most of the country's gold was held.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 9. -- Strange as it may seem in the face of the 800,000 wet majority in California last November for repeal of the State enforcement act. the drys are making a fight against ratification of the Eighteenth Amendment repealer by the State Convention.

THE first performance In this country of Orazio Vecchi's "L'Amfiparnaso" will be given tomorrow night by members of Margaret Dessoff's Choirs at the French Institute. There is no easy label to paste upon this extraordinary work.

THE season of the Metropolitan Opera Association no ending has been one of e ceptional accomplishment, was shorter by eight weeks the seasons preceding, in which the average number of operas performs was forty-five.

Legislative changes, together with the current banking situation, have substantially affected refinancing plans of the Great Northern RailWay, the Baltimore Ohio and the New York, Chicago St. Louis (Nickel Plate) Railroads. The reorganization of the St. Louis-San Francisco, which was expected to have been facilitated by the passage of the recent amendment to the bankruptcy bill, may be delayed pending clarification of some of the bill's clauses.

To the Editor of The New York Times: You recently had a letter under your column of "Letters to the Editor" which described the origin of the derby hat. The letter does not give the authentic origin of the derby so far as this country is concerned, and therefore I thought you would be interested in publishing a few additional facts.

LOS ANGELES, March 11. -- A badly shaken array of major league baseball talent awoke this morning, felt of its limbs and wondered from which direction the next blow would fall. It was the squad of Giants and Cubs, recovering slowly from a night of considerable apprehension occasioned by the most severe earthquake Southern California has experienced in years.

PHILADELPHIA, March 11. -- Woodie Ludwig, a Penn substitute centre, prevented Princeton from engaging in an Eastern Intercollegiate Basketball League play-off with Tale for the title when he scored a field goal that beat the Tigers in the closing seconds of the final game at the Palestra tonight, 29 to 28.

ROME, March 10. -- Adolf Hitler's victory in Germany has introduced a new element in the European political situation and many people here are anxiously scanning the future to discern the effect it is likely to have on Italy's international relations.

ANDOVER, Mass., March 11. -- A suprisingly powerful Exeter swimming team completed an undefeated season today by defeating Andover, 34-30, in the eleventh renewal of the annual meet between the two schools. Exeter broke a losing streak of two years to put the series standing at Exeter 8, Andover, 3.

WASHINGTON, March 11. -- After conferring for two days in an effort to agree on a plan for dealing with the emergency in agriculture, organized farmer leaders, led by Secretary Wallace, went to the White House today and asked President Roosevelt to call on Congress for the same dictatorial powers which he requested for solving the nation's banking difficulty.

Under the "Virtue Made Easy" title Sydney Smith, more than a hundred years ago, reviewed the publications of the "Society for the Suppression of Vice." Some of the things he wrote then are pertinent now in connection with the letter "Stupidity in Censorship" in a recent number of THE NEW YORK TIMES, referring to the banning of Michelangelo as obscene.

BERLIN, EVERY year the Ufa digs down deep Into its gold bags and comes up with a super-special. Just think back to "Metropolis," "The Nibelungen," "The Woman In the Moon," "Yorck" and "Congress Dances."

SAN FRANCISCO, March 11 (AP). While a score of cities today dug out from under the wreckage and havoc caused by earthquakes which last night and this morning shook Southern California, the remainder of the State quickly mobilized to give relief.

As the result of comparing real estate values with the average 1929 prices of fifteen representative stocks and commodities with the 1933 price levels of those same stocks based upon Wall Street statistics. Ulysses G. Stockwell, president of the New York State Association of Real Estate Boards, says that "it would have taken $2,179.44 to purchase one unit or share of those fifteen commodities or stocks in 1929."

RADIO listeners sec no reason why as taxpayers they should be deprived of the music of the United States Navy and Marine bands, which were ordered off the air by the Navy Department following protests from union musicians.

THE scarcity of ready cash last week apparently did not catch any great number of New York motorists in embarrassing situation, or, if it did, they showed sufficient personal resourcefulness to cope with them without clamoring for assistance.

SYRACUSE, March 11. -- Syracuse University's boxing team. Eastern Intercollegiate champions, handed Navy its worst defeat in years today when it scored a 6-2 victory. Navy won only one bout and gained draws in two others.

MR. EDDY'S frequent visits to Soviet Russia as a guide for student groups have apparently had an unfortunate effect upon his method and style. He tries to do too much and to do it too quickly. He is inclined to dangerously sweeping generalizations.

WILFRID GIBSON, though not a major voice, can nevertheless be counted on for good poetic work: that is, he sees and feels poetically, and his expression uniformly has beauty, often great beauty. He does not strike so deep a chord as Sassoon; he is not so moving as Sassoon.

SHANGHAI, Feb. 13. -- While educationists and progressive leaders of China are doing their utmost to fight ignorance and superstition, the influence of the occult hangs heavy over this country of strange beliefs and age-long customs.

AIKEN, S.C. -- The coming week in Aiken will witness much sport activity. High-grade polo, featuring Tommy Hitchcock and other prominent international stars who have been playing in the matches of the past week, will continue on the local fields.

PHILADELPHIA, March 11. -- Rutgers Prep carried off the team honors in the national interscholastic swimming meet at the Pehn A.C. pool tonight with a total of 18 points as three Middle Atlantic States records were shattered.
I think George Bernard Shaw is one of the greatest men in the world today. But in some respects he Is wanting when weighed in the scales of supreme genius.

Possible traces of two attacks on the ancient biblical city of Lachish in Palestine by Sennacherib in 701 B.C. and by Nebuchadnezzar II in 586 B.C. have been brought to light by the Wellcome-Colt Archaeological Expedition, a British-American group, now engaged in excavating and exploring the ruins of the city.

HAUPPAUGE, L.I., March 11. -- After nine hours of running, during which fourteen brace and a bye dog were run, together with three heats of a second series, the judges of the annual Spring field trials of the Hauppauge Gunning Club tonight awarded first place in the all-age stake to Muscogee Frank's Ruby, a white and lemon pointer bitch owned and handled by George B. Gerard of Huntington, L.I.

A referendum in which exporters are asked to choose between the facilities of an Edge bank and government action for the protection of their interests, as a solution to financial and credit problems affecting the trade, was started here last week by the American Manufacturers Export Association.

LONG BEACH, Cal., March 11 (AP). -- The Villa Riviera, a 16-story apartment hotel, where most of the high-ranking officers of the navy reside, swayed violently in the earthquake, but suffered no more than a few cracks and fallen plaster.

The celebration of the 300th anniversary of the Collegiate School recalls the hardships of the first schoolmaster of New York, sole teacher in this school founded in 1633 by the Dutch Reformed Church for the early Dutch settlers in Manhattan and "dedicated to the youth of New Amsterdam."

None of the hazards of transporting live horses is being experienced by those submitting entries for the International Horse Show of Art to be held at the Knoedler Galleries from March 20 to April 1. According to those arranging the exhibit, it has been an orderly procedure comprising the temporary removal of effigies of King Horse from places of honor to the galleries where they will be stabled until the opening of the show.

DETROIT. THE nation-wide bank holiday brought a virtual production holiday in the automotive industry last week. Yet, even though it came on the eve of the Spring selling season and just when buying demand was beginning definitely to show itself, it failed to dampen the spirit of the industry's leaders.

LOVE of the "land" as a soul-satisfying, body-appeasing but exacting mistress is in the blood of most Englishmen born in the country districts south of the Trent. North of it the devotion of farmers to the soil they tend is apt to be blended with that nostalgia for fell and mountain that sends men back from moderate prosperity in cities to the wringing of a meager livelihood out of bleak upland acreage.

DUBLIN, March 10. -- Aside from Ireland's internal affairs, the people of the Free State are more deeply concerned with the financial situation in the United States than with any other world development.

CAMDEN, N.J., March 11. -- Mrs. Dorothea Abbott of Los Angeles, daughter of William Boettcher, city detective of Camden, telephoned to him this afternoon that she, her husband, William J. Abbott; their daughter, Irene, and her uncle and aunt, Mr. and Mrs. Adam Hunger, of Philadelphia, were all safe, following a night of terror caused by the earthquake there.

THE old problem of whether a woman should marry or follow a career purports to be the basis of this story -- but in actual fact, the manner of its setting forth is so far from being arresting that, even at the very end of the book, one is scarcely aware that any such problem has been set or any solution for it offered.

IT is possible now to take off at an airport, climb up through fog and storms and then, without once seeing the ground, to fly hundreds of miles to your destination, come down without seeing the ground and make a perfectly safe and normal landing That is made possible by radio."

MAKY PICKFOKD. whose new picture, "Secrets," will make its bow at the Rivoli on Wednesday, was born Gladys Smith, in Toronto, Canada, and began her stage career when she was 5 years old, playing a speaking part with the Valentine Stock Company in her native city.

HOLLYWOOD, Cal., March 11. -- Served with an ultimatum that union-labor workers in the studios would strike if the present wage scale was not maintained, motion-picture producers in Hollywood spent tonight at a closed session debating whether to close studios entirely during the emergency, try further to compromise or attempt to declare open shop.
The question of a reduction in mortgage interest rates continues as the most vital and important subject in the real estate situation today.

MILWAUKEE, March 11 (AP). -- Louis H.B. Gardner died here yesterday in his modest cottage, and with his funeral on Monday there will come to a close one of the unusual philanthropies of J. Pierpont Morgan, New York financier. His age was 50.

THE "extraordinary occasion" which led President Roosevelt to summon the Seventy-third Congress in special session is one of many such which have occurred since the Presidency of John Adams. Financial crises and war, or threat of war, have been the usual causes.

Lest the temperamental behavior of Spring dismay, it is well to remember that the season "in our northern climate," to quote BURROUGHS, "may fairly be said to extend from, the middle of March to the middle of June." It gives us days like a benediction in their serenity and luster, as well as rude winds, snow, sleet and rains that chill.

Plans for the opening of the Salvation Army United Appeal on Monday, April 3, in the Seventh Regiment Armory, at which George H. Dern, Secretary of War, will make his first public appearance in New York, were announced yesterday by James G. Blaine, president of the Marine Midland Trust Company and executive chairman of the united appeal.

SHANGHAI, Feb. 15. -- British residents of China are amazed at the bitter and discourteous reception which has just been accorded to the British Minister, Sir Miles Lampson, on his return to this country from six months' leave in Europe.

HOLLYWOOD, Cal. PRODUCTION at the Warners' studios of the fifth episode of the Bobby Jones golf series, "How to Break Ninety," was held up last week by reason of the leading man becoming entangled in the barbed wire of a German prison camp on Stage 1.

A movement to rezone extensive areas on the west side of Manhattan below Seventy-second Street has been launched by business leaders and property owners of the district with a view to protecting the residential developments which have grown up there and which predominate in many blocks despite the fact that comparatively few blocks now are restricted against business.

More than 3,500 junior high school teachers, representing six States, adopted yesterday a resolution against "hurried and hysterical cutting, of school budgets," citing the grave danger to the children "whose future is the welfare of every community, and of the nation as a Whole."

Chancellor HITLER has addressed a public appeal to his Nazi followers, urging them to refrain from acts of individual terrorism. The further progress of the "national uprising" must be guided from above. He was obviously brought to that step by the protest of his own allies, the Hugenberg Nationalists.

NANKING, March 11. -- The War Ministry revealed yesterday that it possessed a copy of a plan allegedly drawn by Manchukuoan and Japanese delegates at Changchun, Manchuria, two months ago for the conquest of China and restoration of the empire as "the Chinese Federated Empire" under Regent Pu Yi of Manchukuo.

Taking the offensive through emphasis on expanded credit facilities and the determination of cash retailers to carry on aggressively, local stores made distinct headway during the week in meeting a financial crisis and cash stringency unparalleled in twenty-six years.
WEST POINT, N.Y., March 11. -- Three straight victories in the foils bouts by Cadet Francis W. Honeycutt Jr. enabled the Army fencers to defeat Columbia today in a three-weapon engagement, 12 to 5.

WASHINGTON, March 11. -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended on March 4 made a total of 477,827 cars, the American Railway Association announced today. This was an increase of 18,748 cars, or 4.1 per cent, over the preceding week, but 81,652 cars, or 14.6 per cent, fewer than for the corresponding week last year and 245,388 cars, or 33.9 per cent, fewer than for the corresponding week two years ago.

TORONTO, March 11 ((AP)). -- The Toronto Stock Exchange's experiment of remaining open this week with the Wall Street market closed worked satisfactorily, and the market closed today with a firm and orderly demonstration. Most of the gains acquired have been held and in some sections of the board, particularly the base metals, they have been substantial.

TIENTSIN, Jan. 29. -- At more than a dozen stations south of here, along the Tientsin-Pukow Railway, the heads of executed train bandits are dangling in the wind from poles especially erected on railway station platforms. These gruesome trophies are supposed to have a deterrent effect upon train bandits who have recently been robbing passengers on third-class trains.

NOTHING, says Mr. Ludovici, is more praised in the modera world than the sense of humor. The man without it is looked upon as a poor thing, and nothing, in the immortal words of H.T. Webster, can be done about it.

GOGAMA, Ont. GOLD! Again, as in the Klondike in '98 and California in '49. the magic lure of the precious yellow metal has started a gold rush, and the prospectors are swarming like bees in a honeysuckle vine to the stern, Winter-bound wilderness of Central Ontario.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., March 11. -- Reviewing two groups of wage earner bankrupts, one from New Jersey, the other from Boston, Professor William O. Douglas of the Yale Law School urged today in an article in the Yale Law Journal a return of the bankruptcy power over wage-earners to the States.

WASHINGTON, March 11. -- Josephus Daniels, former Secretary of the Navy, to whom the chairmanship of the proposed transportation commission was offered, has indicated to President Roosevelt his desire not to assume the heavy duties that would be called for in such an important position.

LOUISVILLE, March 9. -- Kentucky's readiness to ratify repeal of the Eighteenth Amendment, even if taken for granted, will hardly expedite national action, as Governor Ruby Laffoon so far has turned a deaf ear to the persuasions of the anti-prohibition forces to call a special session of the General Assembly for the purpose of providing for a convention.

WASHINGTON, March 11. -- The full force of the Federal Government and of the American Red Cross were thrown Behind the relief work for the Southern California earthquake sufferers today as reports were received telling of the extent of the disaster.
SOUTH GATE, Cal., March 11 (AP). -- Eight thousand persons of South Gate's 20,000 population were being cared for today by relief agencies under supervision of the American Legion.

WASHINGTON, March 11. -- The wise maxim that no battle is won until it is over is animating tonight the strategy of the administration with reference to the budget balancing economy bill, which the House passed by an overwhelming majority today.

CAMDEN, N.J., March 11. -- The claim of David Graves George, a Virginia mountaineer, to authorship three decades ago of the poem, "The Wreck of Old 97," was upheld today by Federal Judge T. Boyd Avis after litigation which began more than two years ago.

THE SINNER" is a translation of the novel from which was taken Maurice Schwartz's remarkable play. "Yoshe Kalb," now at the Yiddish Art Theatre. The adaptation must have been difficult, for the novel Is decidedly epic in tone; it progresses in a great rush of episodes which are colorful but not dramatic, impressive but not built upon a single great tension.

BERLIN, March 11 (AP). -- While the Polish Government denied troop concentrations in the vicinity of Gdynia and the Free City of Danzig, the Taeglische Rundschau, organ of former Chancellor Kurt von Schleicher, declared today that it was reliably informed that not only were Polish troops being concentrated at various German border points but that unusual military activity was manifest throughout the Polish Corridor.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., March 11. -- Princeton's threat to check Yale's string of 111 consecutive college swimming victories since 1924, failed tonight when Coach Bob Kiphuth's Eli team outscored the Tigers, 48 to 23, for the Blue's 112th straight triumph against colege rivals.

Mrs. Helen Sumner Woodbury, sociologist and author, wife of Robert Morse Woodbury, economist, died late Friday night at their residence, 100 Morningside Drive, of heart disease after a fortnight's illness. She would have been 57 years old today.

Japan's newest misfortune, the earthquake that brought death and destruction and tidal wave on March 2, was born of the same geologic conditions that caused the even greater disaster of Sept. 1, 1923, when thousands of lives were snuffed out in the crowded cities of Tokyo and Nagasaki and the general region around Sagami Bay, says Science Service.

Women Interested In the Neurological Institute, in striving for the unusual in the way of enterprises for raising funds to meet unprecedented demands for aid, have hit upon a novel means in "The Doggie Fashion Show," which will be held at 5 o'clock Thursday, Friday and Saturday afternoons at the Murray Mayer Salons, 715 Fifth Avenue.

Two brilliant record-smashing performances by Louis Burns, Bryant half-mile ace, and Danny Taylor, New Utrecht High School sophomore shot-put star, featured the St. John's High School interscholastic track and field meet at the 106th Infantry Armory in Brooklyn last night.

WELLINGTON, New Zealand. WHATEVER may happen in other lands, in New Zealand the film censorship keeps us pure. In his comfortable little theatre with its $15,000 projection machine the government censor views every foot of film that Is sent to the film palaces, and the result, from the moral point of view, is eminently satisfactory.

SUMTER, S.C., March 9. -- At a time when echoes of the Middle Western agrarian trouble are beginning to be heard in various parts of the Southeast, the farmers of this immediate section are concerned right now with the outcome of the Ten-Year Plan.

In its issue of March 4 The Literary Digest asserts that forty-six States will ratify the prohibition repeal amendment now before the country. This statement is made on the authority of the prohibition poll conducted by The Digest a year ago, which reported wet majorities in all the forty-eight States save two.

AGITATION for compulsory legislation for unemployment insurance, or what might be better called the compulsory setting up of unemployment reserves, has reached the point where the question is no longer whether unemployment reserve legislation is sound or unsound, or whether it is desirable or undesirable.

With communication by telephone and telegraph seriously hampered and with rail transportation disorganized in the area of California isolated by the earthquake, the major air transport companies of the nation pledged their equipment and personnel for use in emergency and relief work, it was announced yesterday at the New York offices of United Air Lines, Transcontinental Western Air and the Air Express Corporation.

BRUSSELS, Feb. 19. -- The Grand Duchy of Luxemburg reports bad times, owing to the falling off of the iron, and steel trade. Railroad receipts have fallen 30 per cent for 1932 compared with 1929, raw iron production has fallen by 32 per cent, iron mineral, 57 per cent, and steel 27 per cent for the same period.

Antique furniture, tapestries and silver are among the objects that will be auctioned here this week. On Thursday, Friday and Saturday afternoons the American Art Association-Anderson Galleries, Inc., will sell French and English period furniture and other lots, including property belonging to A.U. Surprenant, Mayfair House, and to the estate of Edith Cornell Smith, also of this city.

MOSCOW, March 11 (AP). -- The chairman of the State Political Department announced today that thirty-five persons had been executed and that forty others had been sentenced to eight or ten years in prison for participating in "counter-revolutionary activity and sabotage in connection with farming in the Ukraine, North Caucasus and White Russia."

Former Supreme Court Justice Robert Lee Luce, one of the Sachems of the Tammany Society, died at 10:15 o'clock yesterday morning in the Home for Incurables, Third Avenue and 182d Street, the Bronx, after a long illness. He was 71 years old.

LOS ANGELES, March 11. -- With the known death list placed at 130, the injured at 5,000 and the damage to property at between $45,000,000 and $50,000,000, Southern California today was digging out of its earthquake ruins to the accompaniment of tremors of the still shaking earth.

PARIS, March 2. -- The report of Dr. G.J. Stefanopoulo of the Pasteur Institute on his work in Africa in studying yellow fever was read recently before the Academy of Medicine by Professor A. Pettit of the Pasteur Institute.

IN spite of inclement weather, financial and meteorological, Spring slipped into the New York art galleries last week. Quietly and unobtrusively Spring made itself evident-in purchases of pictures, in the flower painting and landscapes which made up many of the gallery shows, in a larger attendance at shows than for some weeks before.

IN his latest novel Mr. Frankau has abandoned the mood of slightly self-conscious sophistication which characterized his preceding tales. The subtitle to "The Lonely Man." "A Romance of Love and the Secret Service." gives one a sufficient index to its character.

Writing in The New Outlook, ex-Governor SMITH approaches the Federal patronage problem with his usual candor and understanding. He is a politician, but not a outrance, as Mr. CUBBY might say. "Civil service is far "from a perfect instrument of government, but on the whole it has worked well."
THERE are renewed reports that Japan will withdraw from the League of Nations. Exactly what Is the process of withdrawal? Section 3 of Article I of the League Covenant provides:

MR. FORD is a master of the time shift to tale telling. In his latest novel he has pushed the method to its extreme limits. When the novel opens. Henry Martin Aluin Smith is awaiting the hour which shall bring to consummation his deep-laid plans for commiting suicide by drowning himself in the Mediterranean.
WASHINGTON, March 11. -- The Bureau of Navigation issued the following orders today, dated March 9:

Frank Arnold, in a letter to THE TIMES, assails Former Secretary of State Colby for his recent letter to Matthew Woll of the American Federation of Labor, expressing sharp dissent to the proposal to recognize the Russian Soviet Govarnment.

The will of Mrs. Effe Van Vechten Knox, descendant of an old Dutch family and for years leader of a large Bible class founded by her late husband, Charles H. Knox, prominent lawyer and city official, provides for many large bequests to relatives, friends and employes.

MANILA, Feb. 10. -- An open question politically, Philippine independence on the terms offered by Congress was a closed one from the business viewpoint before the bill came to a vote. Responsible business men in the islands have been uniformly opposed to even the discussion of independence at this time, much less to its consummation.

Figures concerning the gas industry of the United States are favorable and encouraging, says Arthur Hewitt, president of the American Gas Association, who says that in the light of the history of businesses of all kinds in the last three years, the data demonstrate the vital position of gas as a basic industry.

PARIS. I HAVE already described for you, less than a year ago. a novel by Francois Mauriac called "le Noeud de viperes," a searing picture of the bate which can hide itself under the hypocritical and conventional surface of a bourgeois family.

PARIS. PARIS, in celebrating two centenaries in two of her national museums -- "Un siecle de carricature." at the Pavilion de Marsan, and "Souvenirs du Roi de Rome" at the Musee de l'Orangerie -- found an odd combination of events juxtaposed.

BALTIMORE, March 11 (AP). -- Governor Ritchie tonight attacked President Roosevelt's method of meeting the bank crisis, asserting that "there is neither the right nor the necessity to sacrifice or put in jeopardy" the non-Reserve State bank.

ST. LOUIS, March 9. -- The bank holiday caught Missourians unprepared for the complete stoppage of cash and currency, and this week has been unique in the State's history. Despite the general inconvenience it occasioned, due largely to the fact that many of the principal industries missed last Saturday's payroll, the situation has been accepted with general cheerfulness and patience.

BERLIN, March 10. -- It is too early for an appraisal of the full significance of the political overturn that has taken place in Germany at such a dizzying speed, but some major points emerge as clearly established.

IN another generation the present method of heating a house will be regarded as something almost ludicrously barbaric. Even though we use steam radiators, we still need hot fires. To be sure, the stove in the middle of the room Is almost obsolete, but putting It In the cellar where it may heat water which circulates as such or as steam through pipes is but one step removed from the open fire.

George M. Lott Jr. of Chicago, Davis Cup veteran and formerly the second ranking player of the country, found himself in danger of defeat in the national indoor tennis championship yesterday as the thirty-fourth annual tournament started at the Seventh Regiment Armory, Park Avenue and Sixty-sixth Street.

An announcement that pleased philatelists, to whom commemorative stamps are particularly interesting, is that the new administration has authorized issuance on April 19 of a 3-cent stamp commemorative of Washington's headquarters house at Newburgh, N.Y.

NORTHAMPTON, Mass., March 11. -- The "League of Nations Assembly" today recommended discouragement of financial loans to Japan and refused to hear a "representative of Manchukuo" who sought the admission of his country to the "League."
PALM BEACH, Fla., March 11. -- Mr. and Mrs. Maurice Fatio entertained tonight with a dinner at the home of her mother, Mrs. Charles Curry Chase. Their guests included:

UNDER the title. "Classical Affinities of a Modern Master," Georges Grappe discusses Rodin's drawings in Formes (No. XXX). The writer holds that these drawings should be regarded as, In themselves, works of beauty, quite apart from their relation to the Rodin sculptures.

D.W. GRIFFITH, creator of several cinema masterpieces in the days when silence was golden, has deserted his old love for the microphone. While Mr. Griffith describes himself as radio's schoolboy, he is a willing and a zealous pupil.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., March 11. -- Benjamin Meek Miller, Governor of Alabama, in an Interview today in which he defended the laws of his State and their administration promised ample protection and a square deal to the nine Negroes awaiting a second trial for an attack on two white girls near Scottsboro.

Coordination, of the government's foreign services under a plan which would eliminate duplications and waste without removing specialized work from the charge of those best trained to handle it is suggested in a memorial sent yesterday by fifteen foreign trade groups to the Secretaries of State and Commerce and to the Director of the Federal Budget.

BERLIN, March 11. -- Chancellor Adolf Hitler's iron broom will be wielded more vigorously than ever tomorrow when two more elections will be held throughout the Reich. They are the provincial and municipal-communal polls.

To the Music Editor: So the Metropolitan is coming to the public for aid! The boxholders, surrendering beneath a burden which, according to Deems Taylor, they never bore, can no longer support the palace of polychrome and plush.

When the time comes to supplement the emergency bank legislation enacted last week with a broader program of reform, consideration is certain to he given to the proposal for a more extensive system of branch banking. This was an important feature of Senator GLASS'S bill in the last session.

LONDON, March 11. -- Former Premier David Lloyd George bitterly criticized the government's domestic and foreign policies in an address today before 10,000 persons at Ashford, Kent, in support of the Rev. R.M. Kedward, Independent Liberal candidate in the by-election.

PALM BEACH -- Bearing out the early prophesy that this season would extend far into the Spring, carrying with it the social and cultural flavor that formerly belonged only to mid-winter, is the fact that the date for the annual costume ball at the Evergladss Club originally set for March 2, has been changed to Thursday night of this week, St. Patrick's Eve.

PORT OF SPAIN, Trinidad, March 8. -- A dispute which began when Surinam was exchanged with the Dutch for New York has just been amicably settled after more than 250 years of continual rivalry in the dense jungles and high mountains of South America.

CHICAGO, March 11. -- A sturdy band of thirteen athletes from Indiana again swept to championship glory in the Western Conference indoor track and field meet tonight, repeating their surprise triumph of 1932.

ANNAPOLIS. Md., March 11. -- In the final events of the Intercollegiate Swimming Association season. Navy routed Columbia at water polo and swimming today. The tniddie water poloists registered a 26 -- 12 victory and the natators scored by 54 to 17.

MIAMI, Fla., Starch 11. -- Twelve thousand persons hailed Charley O., 10-to-1 shot, and full brother to Mike Hall, as the best of the 3-year-olds in this area when he won decisively in the $13,975 Florida Derby, closing-day feature at Hialeah leah Park today.
WASHINGTON, March 11. -- The President's statement outlining the plan for reopening of banks reads as follows:
What should prove to be one of the most interesting tests of the current fencing season will be held tomorrow evening in the oblong salle of the Fencers Club.

THIS is the diary of a Russian girl, begun on her seventeenth birthday, at the end of 1916, and continuing until the Summer of 1920. It baa been published in German under the thriller title of "Students, Love, Cheka and Death," and baa been called a "Homeric book" by European reviewers.

BERLIN, March 1. -- A new process for sprouting grain within a few days so as to turn it into fresh fodder for cattle has been brought to the attention of German farm experts by Dr. Spangenberg, who believes that it will revolutionize cattle breeding by permitting industrial manufacturing of fodder.

WASHINGTON, March 11. -- An industrial policy for the United States expected to be urged upon Secretary Perkins was discussed tonight over a network of the National Broadcasting Company by Lewis L. Lorwin, authority on labor problems, of the Brookings Institute, and Otto S. Beyer, consulting engineer for the railway department of the American Federation of Labor.

THERE may be essayists of greater profundity than J.B. Priestley; there may be those who can plumb down more deeply into whatever hidden meaning there may be in life, and make more penetrating comments on literature, politics, or the cosmos in general; but there are few of our contemporaries who can discourse more charmingly on trifles, or illuminate the commonplace with greater urbanity, geniality and wit.

ROME -- Italy as a news centre today presents an aspect at once tantalizing and intensely satisfying. The achievement of Premier Mussolini in controlling the news for external as well as for internal consumption is as skillful an accomplishment in its way as getting control of the government.

The International Flower Show, one of the harbingers of Spring in New York, which is to be held at Grand Central Palace during the week beginning March 20, again will have among its features the picturesque tea garden, a refreshments rendezvous for luncheon, tea, dinner and supper.

IT is one thing for a novelist to assure the reader that this or that character is a genius; quite another for him to mold the character so that it assumes the distinct visualization of a genius. Failing to convince us quite that Mitzia is one of that rarest species. Miss Sandatrom has yet made this story of the erratic, temperamental girl a tale of marked interest, rich and varied in color, background and incident.

LONDON. HIGH political office has a way of baring men to the bone, and in Stanley Baldwin it has revealed an enigma. The "Baldwin enigma" seems indeed, to have become one of the permanent attributes of the Con servative party.

ALTHOUGH the pictorial translation of the play "Clear All Wires," the main attraction at the Capitol last week scarcely comes up to expectations thanks to the excellent performance of the principals, particularly Lee Tracy in the leading part, it is an entertainment above the aver age.

Owing to the necessity that it be both "small and large," the store of the future will be one of a chain of department stores, every department, of which will be one of a chain of similar departments, according to Edward A. Filene, president of William Filene's Sons Company, Boston.

Despite the banking situation, a spirit of confidence pervades the manufacturing field, it was stated yesterday by Kenneth Collins, assistant to Bernard Gimbel, president of Gimbel Brothers, Inc. Outlining the results of a personal survey, in which he talked with 104 manufacturers in widely varied lines, Mr. Collins reported that producers had taken marked strides in returning to a profit basis.

SHARP improvement in retail trade toward the close of the week testified to the gain in sentiment brought about by the swift steps taken by the national administration to deal with the banking crisis. From losses which, ranged from 40 per cent upward under a year ago, local stores reported a resumption of activity which brought sales levels in some cases up to the pre-moratorium period.

NEWTONIA, Neb., March 9. -- The old-fashioned family doctor isn't extinct yet. He lives right here in the person of Dr. H.V. Byers. At the age of 85 years Dr. Byers has ministered to the ailments of three generations and now and again he is called upon to mix his standard croup remedy for the fourth generation.

Ceremonies commemorating the 200th anniversary of the birth of Joseph Priestely, discovered of oxygen and founder of the Unitarian Church in America, will be held Tuesday at Dickinson College, Carlisle, Pa., under the auspices of the Mohler Scientific Club of the college, it was announced here yesterday.
OSLO, March 11. -- The Norwegian Antarctic expedition headed by Captain Hjalmar Riiser-Larsen, caught in a gale today, narrowly escaped complete disaster.

Riviera Book Note. It now seems that the autobiography of former Mayor JAMES J. WALKER will not be an outstanding event of the next book season. Progress on the work, according to the latest news from the Mediterranean, has been delayed.

L'ITTLE ROCK, Ark., March 9. -- Inheriting a deficit of approximately $1,000,000 when he assumed office on Jan. 10, Governor J. Marion Futrell immediately inaugurated a program of consolidation, elimination and failure to appropriate which not only placed the State upon a cash basis but provided for the retirement of the outstanding indebtedness of the general revenue fund within five years and without appreciably affecting the efficiency of any department.

The Italian chamber ballet season at the Casino of San Remo was inaugurated with an absolute novelty by the young modernist composer, Antonio Veretti. The work is entitled "The Gallant Marksman" and its plot was drawn by Riccardo Bacchelli from a Baudelaire poem.

WASHINGTON. AVOCATES of an immediate return to the time-honored two-cent postage stamp for letter mail are planning to press their fight in Congress, but whether they will be successful is held to be highly debatable by opponents of such a move.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., March 11. -- Harvard's varsity and freshman wrestling teams won the championships in the New England Intercollegiate Wrestling Association meet which concluded today in the Harvard indoor athletic building.
WASHINGTON, March 11. -- President Roosevelt announced tonight the plan under which national and State banks would begin to reopen progressively on Monday, Tuesday and Wednesday mornings.

In a buying mood that seemed only to be spurred by the banking moratorium, throngs of shoppers crowded leading stores here yesterday. In many instances counters featuring special offerings were swamped with customers. Charge account trade continued to increase, but cash transactions did not lag.

A middle-aged Negro brushed through the crowd of lawyers and witnesses in the Tombs Court yesterday to a table in front of Magistrate Burke, used by the prosecutor, and, slamming a loaded pistol on it, announced: "My conscience is bothering me.
PARIS, March 11. -- This week-end might have seen a great meeting of European statesmen, but it will be remembered in France as one of failure.

SOUTH BEND, Ind., March 11. -- Ralph Metcalfe, Marquette University's sensational Negro sprinter, ran to another world's record today, racing 60 yards in six and one-tenth seconds to better Loren Murchison's ten-year-old mark, in the annual Central Intercollegiate Conference indoor championship meet.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., March 11. -- Yale's Eastern Intercollegiate League basketball champions concluded their most brilliant season since 1923 with a decisive 48-to-20 triumph over Harvard in the Crimson indoor athletic building tonight.

THE foremost fact that emerges as one reads this thoughtful report on world agriculture is that neither in its causes, in its consequences, nor in its cures can the farmer or any national group of farmers segregate themselves from the fortunes of other industries and of other nations.

LONDON. SIR WALTER BESANT'S novels have few readers nowadays, but one piece of work he did lives after him, and lives with ever-increasing vitality. In his concern for the welfare of his fellow-writers, he founded a Society of Authors, for the purpose of placing their material interests on a more business-like footing.

The New York University girls' swimming team regained its winning form and triumphed over Savage and the Posse Nissen Schools of Physical Education in a triangular meet yesterday in the London Terrace's seventy-five-foot pool. The Violet tallied 34 points.

BROADCASTERS find practical experience a good teacher. The intricate communication system which the technicians wove throughout Washington to serve as the centre of the world-wide inaugural network taught several important lessons.

WASHINGTON, March 11. -- At the conclusion of conferences tonight dealing with the procedure for the reopening of banks, both national and State, next week. Secretary of the Treasury Woodin at 11:45 P.M. made public a statement addressed to the Bank Superintendents of each State.

AT THE Howard Young Galleries those in search of their youth may think for a moment that they have found it. A mirage. A rather slight and indeterminate mirage at that, yet oddly consoling. A group of paintings (sponsored, of course, by the College Art Association-did one ever know such energy?)
LOS ANGELES, March 11 (AP). -- Southern California trembled tonight as she measured her earthquake dead in scores, her injured in thousands and her property damage in tens of millions of dollars.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 9. -- To the financial leaders here and to a considerable part of the public the President's bank holiday proclamation came as a welcome relief from a threatening situation which grew out of the State moratorium declared by Governor Rolph three days before the President took action.

All the banks in New York City will be permitted to reopen tomorrow morning under President Roosevelt's plan of "progressive" reopening of banks, provided they obtain licenses to reopen from the Federal and State banking authorities.

EXETER, N.H., March 11. -- The Phillips Exeter Academy basketball team scored Its first victory over Andover in three years today, handing its time-honored rival a 29-to-20 setback. Exeter thus completed its season undefeated.

A track season that has surpassed all expectations, both as to drawing power and as a spectacle, will come to an end Wednesday night when the Knights of Columbus stage a meet that will be in every respect a fitting finale to one of the most illustrious campaigns in the annals of the sport.

Vivid descriptions of the horrors of the California earthquake were told yesterday from the heart of the stricken areas by radio men of Station KFOX, Long Beach, and KHJ. Los Angeles, who were eyewitnesses of various phases of the disaster.

THE new picture at the Paramount is "The Woman Accused," the story which enjoyed the collaboration of ten writers. George Palmer Putnam, head of Paramount's editorial board in New York, worked out the idea with Fulton Oursler, editor. The writers, beginning with Rupert Hughes, were provided with a brief synopsis of the general theme, and then each was given a specific sequence to enlarge upon.

MOSCOW, March 10. -- The Russians have a proverb, "The hungry dog does not worry about fleas," and, while it is asserted there is no hunger in Moscow, there are plenty of shortages of all kinds of food, clothing and housing to keep the inhabitants from indulging in the atavistic Slav melancholy.

SOMEWHAT less glamourous has Nell always been to American than to English readers. Granting all the wit and beauty and charm her biographers credit her with, we are still prone to wonder why the English write of her with such adoring admiration.

Contending that government statistics do not cover more than 8 per cent of the country's total monthly production and that many other business indices are inadequate, Paul S. Hanway, general manager of the American Waxed Paper Association, yesterday urged that the Department of Commerce become a central agency to develop a periodic "balance sheet" of general business.

STAMFORD, Conn., March 11. -- Professor Raleigh D. Morrill, Associate Professor of Experimental Engineering in New York University since 1926, died of a cerebral tumor here early this morning in Belltown at the home of his uncle, F.C. Avery, former principal of the local high school, with whom he resided.

POOR Harriet's advances were doomed to be repulsed from the very first, not because they were repellent or unattractive in themselves, but merely because they were so very simple-minded and straightforward -- whereas apparently the male of the species, if he is going to be caught, prefers that it be done with some small display of artifice.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Those movie directors who cannot resist the temptation to pack the entire gamut of human emotions in one picture must eventually kill their own goose, no less than their more recent counterpart -- the radio broadcast director.

NUMEROLOGY, whose devotees say that it is the science of the mystic qualities, or miraculous properties, of numbers, although unbelievers skeptically call it "blue bosh" and other uncomplimentary names, has recently attained some importance in current news and the public eye because of queer behavior it inspired in certain members of its cult.

TORONTO, Ont., March 11. -- The Kirkland Lake Gold Mining Company produced bullion worth $524,330 in 1932, compared with $586,250 in 1931. Exchange amounted to $68,121 and miscellaneous revenue to $14,510, making total income of $606,961, compared with $628,167 the year previous.

SINCE Doris Humphrey has signified her intention of abstaining from the indulgence of recital-giving during the present season, for reasons which must be obvious to those who care to give it a moment's thought, it is necessary if we would not be deprived of her creative activities for so long a time to follow her into those by-paths where she is now occupying herself.

SIOUX FALLS, S.D., March 11 (AP). -- Radio Station KSOO, made defendant in a test suit brought to determine whether The Associated Press could prevent the unauthorized use of its news dispatches today filed its answer in Federal District Court, asking for denial of an injunction sought and vacation of the temporary restraining order granted.

CHICAGO, March 11. -- Gold coin and gold certificates poured into the coffers of the Federal Reserve Bank, the Currency Exchange at 126 South La Salle Street and the big Loop banks today. Hoarders, fearful of actual and supposed regulations, rushed the gates, and extra police were required to keep the lines in order.

The New York Stock Exchange ended yesterday its first week of enforced inactivity since 1914 without any indication as to when trading would be resumed. None of the other security or commodity markets here have yet set a date for reopening, but the New York Cocoa Exchange announced that the board of managers had voted to extend the holiday up to and including next Tuesday.

SHANGHAI, March 11. -- The North China armies of the resigned Marshal Chang Hsiao-liang have been ordered withdrawn from the Manchurian and Jehol frontiers and sent southward for "rest and recuperation."

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., March 11 (AP). -- Bunched at the top of the pack with scores of 70 each, five of the country's leading professionals today led a crack field at the halfway mark of the 36-hole $1,500 Walter Hagen open golf tournament.

Importers of sterling silverware will be in attendance at the United States Customs Court on Wednesday to hear testimony in the action brought by the Sterling Silver-smiths' Guild of America and others against the United States and S.H. Kirby Sons, Inc., of New Haven, importers of antique silverware.
PARIS, Feb. 28. -- One Frenchman in twenty of active age is in one capacity or other employed by State or local governments, according to statistics given recently in Le Temps.

Several auction sales of rare books will be held here this week. First editions, autographs and manuscripts from the collection of Peter Smith of Brooklyn will be sold on Thursday evening at the Ritter Hopson Galleries. Books and autographs from the collection of Lieut. Col. C.J. Thoroton of London, England, which were to have been sold at the same galleries last week, will be offered on Wednesday evening.

THE uncertainty and doubt that lurked in the public mind as a result of the bank moratorium were responsible for the cancellation of at least one radio program. The sponsors of "The Great Moments in History" broadcast scheduled for last Sunday decided the sketch prepared might cause listeners to become unduly wary concerning the stability of the banks.

TEXTILES play an important part today in the well-decorated room. They may suggest a period or they may imply a mood -- gay, dignified, or fashionably smart. A wealth of new designs, inspired mainly by fabrics of the past, enables the decorator to achieve more varied and more artistic harmonies of texture, color and pattern than ever before.

THIS little book deserves to be called the definitive story of the event it describes, and it ought to put a complete quietus upon all the varied and mostly absurd tales about it that in process of time are getting themselves believed. For it is written by the man who was Sheriff Pat Garrett's deputy and who was with him at the time.

PARIS, Feb. 26. IT is difficult to describe, for an English-speaking public, the kind of play which may be called a "French, farce" without conveying an entirely false impression of the French theatre, of French conceptions of morality and of French social life.

A NEW line of lower-priced Chevrolets. somewhat smaller than the "Master" series and designed principally for maximum economy, was displayed throughout the country yesterday. The new models, known as the "Standard" six, have a wheelbase of 107 inches (three inches less than the "Master"), 60 horsepower and a speed of 65 to 70 miles an hour.

A.L. Burns won the High Scratch Cup over the Travers Island traps of the New York Athletic Glub yesterday, breaking 95 out of 100 targets. The second trophy was annexed by T.H. Lewis, who finished with 94.

Service on the Eighth Avenue subway will be extended to the Bergen-Smith Street station in Brooklyn on March 20, the Board of Transportation announced yesterday. The new link will carry the city subway, which was extended as far as Borough Hall on Feb. 1, another half mile into Brooklyn territory.

TO the author submitting the most Interesting and distinctive novel on or before March 1, 1934. the Atlantic Monthly Press and Little, Brown Co., Boston, Mass., will award $10,000, half of which will be an outright prize, while the other half will be an advance on royalties.

SEA ISLAND BEACH, Ga. -- The St. Patrick's Day dinner dance at the Cloister on Thursday will be the outstanding event of the coming week at Sea Island. It is expected to draw a large number from the residence colony as well as young people from Eastern colleges, who are coming to Sea Island to spend their Spring vacation.

MINEOLA, L.I., March 11. -- In a decision filed here today, Supreme Court Justice Charles J. Dodd granted summary judgment of $120,000 to Mrs. Estelle K. Smith of 420 Clinton Avenue, Brooklyn, in an action again Carlos W. Munson of Roslyn, and his brother, Frank C. Munson, officials of the Munson Steamship Line.

Talented youngsters, members o the Children's Theatre of Greenwich House, will present two new original plays next Sunday after noon at the Greenwich House Auditorium, 27 Barrow Street, in behalf of that organization. The plays to be given are "The Talisman of the Dervish Bey" and "Far Away and Long Ago."

HOLLYWOOD. AT attitude of internationalism such as he has adopted in his selection of stage plays is necessary for successful pictures, according to Gilbert Miller, who will make two pictures a year for Columbia.
Who climbs the grammar-tree distinctly knows Where noun and verb and participle grows.

THE uninterrupted flux of books about Wagner -- biographies, collections of letters, analyses and all the rest -- has already been increased and doubtless will be further increased this year because it is the fiftieth anniversary of his death Already four new biographies have appeared since November, and the year is still young.

STUDENTS of the Risorgimento have had to wait a long time for this book. It took the author thirty years to write it with half of that time spent in Italy gathering material. About 130,000 words are used and of these fully 50,000 furnish footnotes extracted from little known sources -- pamphlets, leaflets, documents, and rare monographs.

AN article dealing with "the career secretary," published in The Times Magazine of Jan. 8, has called forth comment from Brice Clagett of Washington, D.C. Mr. Clagett holds that the author, P.W. Wilson, was wrong in assuming that ambitious young English politicians who serve as private secretaries to eminent statesmen have no counterparts in this country.

WASHINGTON, March 11. -- President Roosevelt today won his first real test with the new Congress, retrieving an overwhelming victory in the House for his $500,000,000 economy program after a run-away caucus of his own party had threatened to take the force out of it.

WHEN the country is plunged into the midst of a dramatic crisis the stage drama takes second place. The newspapers, the rumors, the office forums, the community of interest, the astonishing good will, the suspense and the expectancy quicken life a good deal; and as Brown and Henderson, the meditative song-smithies, conclude in one of their "Strike Me Pink" tunes, "It's Great to Be Alive" no matter what the alarms may be.

LONG BEACH, Cal., March 11. -- A terrorized populace camped in the city's open spaces as earth shocks continued with sufficient violence to shake down debris from partially destroyed buildings tonight.

FOR its power to attract some, to infuriate others, and to lead still others to just such a fascinated contemplation as a biologist might bestow upon an entirely novel kind of jellyfish. Los Angeles is unique among American cities.

NEW ORLEANS, March 9. -- Southern banks have invested in cotton, at a conservative estimate, about half a billion dollars, and the closing of the New Orleans and other cotton exchanges during the Federal bank holiday has raised fears of events which may follow resumption of trading.

THE substantial total of nearly $50.000 paid for 162 lots in the first session of the Vickery sale shows that there is still an abundant life in rare books. Following hard upon the astonishing success of the Letter sale of Americana, which brought nearly $75.000, it gives encouragement to those who have faith in the commercial vitality of literary treasures.

CHICAGO, March 11. -- For the first time since the national banking holiday was declared a week ago, the larger Chicago banks paid out cash for payroll purposes today, meeting all reasonable demands of corporations with good credit standing.

MOSCOW, March 11. -- The Moscow Police Department has made great strides in recent years and the policemen are not only snappy and efficient but handle people with unusual suavity and good humor. There is an excellent training school for would-be "militiamen," as the police here are termed.

THE way American colleges and universities finance them-selves is anything but ideal. College presidents, immersed in financial difficulties and faced with annual deficits, have almost to sell their souls to raise enough money to avoid bankruptcy.

MAGGY ROUFF has chosen pink organdie for the frilly wrap (shown on this page) to accompany a chain-printed satin frock patterned with pink and pale gray flowers. She calls this ensemble "Let's stay for dinner"; actually it is dressy enough for almost any Summer evening party.

A dinner will be given on Wednesday night at the Cosmopolitan Club for members of the national board of Girl Scouts from all parts of the country. It will be followed by a celebration in the club auditorium by the Girl Scout Federation of Greater New York in observance of of the twenty-first anniversary of the founding of the organization.

THE enforced association in a hotel, on board a ship, or during a long railway journey, of persons who in the course of their everyday lives would probably never encounter one another is a field which the novelists of today are assiduously cultivating.

The Dollar liner President Lincoln arrived from the West Coast yesterday, inaugurating the line's new service of "special class," a class of accommodations which the Dollar Line conceived many years ago and which now will be placed on five of its coastal and transPacific ships.

PARIS, March 10. -- The shipping industry's own economic crisis is becoming steadily worse. It was frankly acknowledged at the regular Spring meeting of the Atlantic Conference just held here that 1933 is bound to be the leanest year in history for all North Atlantic steamship lines.

The supply of crude oil in January amounted to 69,822,000 barrels, the smallest for a January since 1926, and a decrease of 3.5 per cent from the 72,388,000 barrels of January, 1932, according to William J. Kemnitzer, petroleum technologist, from data of the United States Bureau of Mines.

BOSTON, March 11. -- Lawrence (Chu) Baldwin of Honolulu, captain of the Yale varsity polo team, suffered a broken collar-bone as his team registered a thrilling 7-to-5 victory over Harvard's trio in the Commonwealth Armory tonight.

ARMS and the woman" (with due apologies to Mr. Shaw) constitute an important phase of fashion's Spring drama. From the tips of highly polished finger nails to the ivory curves of rounded shoulders, arms are destined to be featured wherever a style conference is held.

A demonstration by 100 Communists and their sympathizers in front of the Young Women's Hebrew Association building at 35 West 110th Street ended in violence last night when several women, spurred on by then companions behind them, attempted to enter and reach the executive director.

WASHINGTON, D.C., March 10. -- The United States postal savings system gained $437,403,753 in the fiscal year ended June 30, 1932. This amount exceeded the aggregate deposits for the twenty-one years the service has been in operation. The number of depositors leaped ahead 774,331, practically doubling those already enrolled.

PRINCETON, N.J., March 11. -- The Triangle Club of Princeton University, 44-year-old undergraduate dramatic organization, announced today the election of officers for the next year and designated forty-four men as eligible to wear triangles as full members of the club.

The problems of reduced rentals and increased vacancies are being studied intensively by landlords and apartment managers who are seeking to smooth out as quickly as possible the difficulties which have arisen as a part of the general disturbed business situation

VIENNA, March 10. -- Southeastern Europe is already beginning to react to the advent of the Nazi Government in Germany. In Czechoslovakia the success of Hitlerism has encouraged the German Nationalists -- which means younger male members of Czechoslovakia's 3,000,000 German minority-and has simultaneously increased the fear, and therefore the aggressiveness, of the nationalistic Czechs.
WASHINGTON, March 11 (AP). -- In these days of debt moratoriums the folks back home on the farm in New York State pull out the old mortgage and tally up the debt.

ORIENTAL music, for so long known here only in fragmentary and popular forms, seems to be slowly making its way in the Occident. The musicians of ShanKar's troup of Hindu dancers, of recent memory, opened the ear to the beauties of authentic Hindu music.

Expressing the belief that restrictions imposed upon foreign trade by the bank holiday will be lifted to a large extent by Wednesday, Dr. Max Winkler, banker and economist, said yesterday that there is no sound reason for expecting United States dollars to show a sharp decline when trading in foreign exchange is resumed.

Princeton's varsity polo team strengthened its position as favorite for the coming intercollegiate pole championship with an impressive victory over the hard-riding Army team at Squadron A last night, winning by 8 to 3.

WITH the christening yesterday of the Macon, the second of the navy's giant dirigibles, by Mrs. William A. Moffett, wife of the flying chief of the Bureau of Aeronautics who has done so much for lighter-than-air as well as heavier-than-air development in the United States, we increase our world dominance in dirigible power.

CHICAGO, March 12. -- The unexpected closing of the banks and stock and commodity exchanges has disturbed all lines of business. There is a general disposition to restrict buying to necessities, in expectation that there will be inflation of the currency and that this will be reflected in prices of commodities and merchandise.

Admiral Osani Nagano and Tadeshi Yamada, members of the Japanese delegation to the League of Nations, are scheduled to arrive today from Geneva on the North, German Lloyd liner Bremen on their way back to Tokyo.

The refusal of Controller Charles W. Berry to authorize an expenditure of about $60,000 this year for engineering costs in connection with vesting title in land necessary for the State highway system in Queens is holding up an expenditure of about $3,500,000 by the State this year for construction of the State highway system in the borough, Borough President George U. Harvey of Queens declared yesterday.

PRINCETON, N.J., March 12. -- Five hundred and sixteen under graduates of Princeton University attained honor standing during the first term of the academic year, according to the announcement made today by Wilbur F. Kerr, registrar of the university.

Elizabeth Delza, assisted by a group of fifteen, made a successful debut as a concert dancer last night at the Guild Theatre before a large audience in which were many of her colleagues as well as practitioners of the other arts. The program was unusually long, containing eighteen numbers, one of them a seven-part cycle, and in all but two of them Miss Delza appeared.

BUENOS AIRES, March 12. -- Bolivia has recaptured Fort Alihuata, between Forts Saavedra and Arce, and Paraguay has routed a Bolivian division near Fort Toledo, with 2,000 casualties, in two days of fighting, according to dispatches which reveal that the undeclared Chaco war again is in full swing after several weeks of enforced quiet due to floods and heavy rains.

LONDON, March 12. -- The London Times devotes its main editorial tonight to an analysis by the economist, J.M. Keynes, of new proposals for the rehabilitation of Britain and the world which "this time possess a measure of official concurrence."

The swift flight of the Atlantic City Sea Gulls toward their second successive national amateur hockey championship continued unimpeded yesterday at Madison Square Garden, where a crowd of 10,000 saw the Gulls turn back the Bronx Hockey Club, 3 to 1.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., March 12. -- Corny Shields had one of his most successful days of the Winter today as dinghy sailors from the Westchester Shore of Long Island Sound gathered at the New Rochelle Yacht Club for a lengthy program of races.

PITTSBURGH, March 12. -- Steel producers expect recovery from, the recent slackening in trade to begin soon, possibly in the coming week. Production of steel ingots last week was at no more than 15 per cent of capacity, scarcely more than two-thirds of the peak rate early in February, just before the Michigan bank holiday was proclaimed on Feb. 14.

MIAMI, Fla., March 12. --Henry L. Doherty Day was a huge success for the Brooklyn Dodgers so far as the attendance and gate receipts went today, but the ball game was a bit of a disappointment to Max Carey. His men were held to six scattered hits by Lefty Grove, George Earnshaw and Rube Walberg and soundly trounced, 13 to 2, by the Athletics.

The cash position of the Westinghouse Electric and Manufacturing Company at the end of 1932 was better than the year before despite the continued depression, according to A.W. Robertson, chairman, and F.A. Merrick, president, in the annual report to be issued today.

LOS ANGELES, March 12. -- Floyd Caves Herman, the erstwhile Babe of Flatbush, performed prodigious deeds for the Cubs today. He smacked two homers and a single driving in five runs, but it was not enough, for a very determined band of Giants reared up in their might and flattened the Chicagoans, 10 to 7.
Small flats and dwellings comprised the bulk of the New Jersey realty trading reported over the week-end.

Funded debt of the National Steel Corporation was reduced by $1,233,333 last year, according to the pamphlet report for 1932. This brings it down to $41,799,999, of which $233,333 is that part of the Wierton Coal Company mortgage payable in 1933.

PALM BEACH, Fla., March 12 -- Mrs. Henry Morgan Tilford was a dinner hostess tonight at the Everglades Club in compliment to her house guests, Mr. and Mrs. Amory L. Haskell, Mr. and Mrs. Stanley Grafton Mortimer, Mr. and Mrs. David Wagstaff, Pierre Lorillard and Hunt Tilford Wagstaff.

Although the bank moratorium curtailed wholesale activity here last week, a fair number of orders and reorders was received on low-end and popular-price merchandise. Manufacturers have restricted production in most cases and are cutting only orders already on hand.

There is every reason why Americans should do honor to the Rev. JOSEPH PRIESTLEY on this, the two hundredth anniversary of his birth. His feet were set upon the path of science by FRANKLIN. He came to this country from his native England a voluntary exile, an object of persecution, a stanch and bold advocate of the political principles that had been applied in the founding of this Republic.

HAVANA, March 12. -- The Anall Stable's 4-year-old, Larranaga, today emerged victorious in the $50,000 added Cuban Grand National Handicap, closing-day feature of the fifty-one-day meeting at Oriental Park.

"Lone Valley," the new play by Sophie Treadwell, which opened on Friday night at the Plymouth Theatre, was among the closings on Saturday evening, having played but three performances. "Our Wife," the comedy at the Booth, which had been announced to close on Saturday night, will continue at that theatre.
WASHINGTON, Monday, March 13. -- A statement issued by the Treasury this morning explaining further the March 15 Treasury financing, reads:

Four free college centres for the unemployed, an innovation in emergency relief work which will enroll about 1,500 students, are being formed with the cooperation of the State Temporary Emergency Relief Administration, the State Department of Education and officials of State universities, it was announced yesterday.

VATICAN CITY, March 12 (AP). -- Pope Pius will voice open and sharp disapproval of King Boris and Queen Joanna of Bulgaria tomorrow morning, say Vatican prelates, when he delivers an allocution to the Cardinals in the Holy Year consistory.
The end of an arduous campaign will be reached tonight, when the finals in New York's outstanding amateur boxing tournament, the Golden Gloves, are staged at Madison Square Garden.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The presentation of the case for the gold standard by the financial editor of THE NEW YORK TIMES before a Senate committee is beyond all praise. Historically correct in every detail, Mr. Noyes is especially lucid in his exposure of the evils which have followed the action of every country in adoption of inflationary measures calculated to cure business depression.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., March 12. -- Although basketball is only a minor sport at Yale, undergraduates and alumni, it was learned today, will urge upon the Athletic Association that the members of the team that has just won the Eastern Intercollegiate League championship be awarded major "Ys."

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., March 12. -- With clear Spring skiea overhead but with the chill of Winter in the flying spray, eight tiny dinghies were sailed through six races today on Manhasset Bay. It was the regular Frostbite Yacht Club regatta under the auspices of the Port Washington Yacht Club.

With Bill Cook flashing the form that caused him to be selected on this season's mythical all-star team, the New York Rangers over-whelmed their city rivals, the Americans, in a National Hockey League game at Madison Square Garden last night.

BERLIN, March 10. -- In many respects the German market is taking a hopeful view of developments in America. This optimism is based on the circumstance that the United States, unlike England in September, 1931, has a foreign trade balance permanently in its favor and that there are no considerable short-term debts owing to its foreign lenders.

The New York Americans gained the Eastern final of the National Challenge Cup soccer competition by defeating the Philadelphia German-Americans, 3 to 2, at Starlight Park yesterday in the second game of their home-and-home series before a crowd of 2,000.

One of the unusual features of the entertainment in behalf of the Stage Relief Fund, to be given on the night of March 26 at the Metropolitan Opera House, will be the special revue organized by Mrs. Fair Vanderbilt in which young matrons and debutantes of this and recent seasons will take part.

WASHINGTON, March 12. -- Having laid before President Roosevelt their plan for clothing him with far-reaching powers for farm relief and production control, farmer leaders who called at the White House yesterday were confident tonight that Mr. Roosevelt would send another special message to Congress in the next few days asking for immediate action on emergency farm legislation.

WASHINGTON, March 12. -- Passage by the Senate of the $500,000,000 economy bill voted by the House yesterday was predicted today by Senate leaders. They told President Roosevelt that vigorous opposition to the reduction of veterans' benefits was indicated but that they expected the measure to be accepted by a substantial majority after three or four days' debate.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In his letter on ratifying conventions which appeared in THE TIMES, Thomas C. Spelling exhibits the same inability for logical deduction from basic facts or alleged facts so characteristic of most writers on this subject of ratifying conventions.

BERLIN, March 12. -- This was the German Memorial Day, the day on which all Germany, mourning her war dead, might theoretically be expected to meditate upon the past and take warning therefrom. And on this day the whole Reich took formal farewell of the Weimar republic and the regime built upon it.

WASHINGTON, March 12. -- Mrs. Roosevelt, wife of the President, attended the morning service today at St. Thomas's, walking to and from the church accompanied by Mrs. Frank Scheider, her secretary. St. Thomas's was the church home in Washington of the President and Mrs. Roosevelt when the former was Assistant Secretary of the Navy in the Wilson administration.

The Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra will be continued next season, the directors of the Philharmonic-Symphony Society announced yesterday. It appears, however, from a paragraph in the announcement, that the next season is likely to be crucial. The paragraph states:

WASHINGTON, March 12. -- Sixteen of the twenty-nine Democrats in the New York State delegation in the House voted against the Roosevelt economy bill, passed by the House yesterday. The bill called for cuts in the salaries of Representatives from $10,000 to $8,500, put other pay cuts in the hands of the President, and gave him power to reduce pensions for veterans.

What many hearers considered among the best planned tributes to Johannes Brahms that the composer's birth centenary has produced here was afforded by a gala benefit given by the Manhattan Symphony Orchestra last evening at the Waldorf-Astoria.

PHILADELPHIA, March 12. -- Twenty-one Philadelphia banks which are members of the Federal Reserve System and twenty-five non-members will reopen tomorrow morning for full-time business operation, it was announced tonight.

NEW ORLEANS, March 12. -- With cotton markets in the United States closed, the course of foreign markets and the unofficial reports of higher prices for spots in the South created the impression among traders here last week that contract prices would be materially higher when business is resumed at the end of the banking holiday.
KANSAS CITY, Mo., March 12. -- Twenty-four banks were authorized to reopen tomorrow morning by the Federal Reserve Bank and the State Finance Commissioner. These banks are:

Balancing our financial budget is not so important today as balancing the budget between our duties and opportunities, our blessings and resources, Dr. Dwight Witherspoon Wylie said yesterday in his sermon, at the Central Presbyterian Church, Park Avenue and Sixty-fourth Street.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., March 12. -- Entries for the national championship figure skating competition at New Haven Arena next Friday and Saturday were announced tonight by Heaton Robertson, referee of the tournament.

Pope Pius XI, "a great man who knows something of the world and also says his prayers," is Christ's answer to the need for a world leader, the Rev. Fulton J. Sheen of Catholic University, Washington, D.C.f declared yesterday in his second lenten sermon at high mass in St. Patrick's Cathedral.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., March 12. -- Walter Hagen won his own open golf tournament today, but he did not collect any of the prize money. Hagen, who said he hopes to sponsor the Hageir open every year, posted a sparkling round this afternoon, 34, 33-67, five under par, which with his 71 of yesterday gave him 138, two strokes better than his nearest competitors.

John H. McCooey, veteran Kings County Democratic leader, last night took the unprecedented step of repudiating the action of the Brooklyn delegation in Congress which voted on Saturday against the Roosevelt economy bill. Mr. McCooey sent a personal telegram to President Roosevelt, informing him of his action, and made public the statement here, at the same time.

Property owners, banded together to carry out a plan of rehabilitation in congested city areas, could induce the Reconstruction Finance Corporation to provide the necessary funds for a large-scale housing operation, Arthur C. Holden of the New York Chapter of the American Institute of Architects declares in a rehabilitation study reported to the institute.
BERLIN, March 12 (AP) -- In municipal and communal elections throughout Prussia, today Chancellor Adolf Hitler's National Socialists won an undisputed leadership.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., March 12. -- George B. Walls, Warden of Kilby prison, where eight of the nine Negroes accused of attacking two white girls on a freight train near Scottsboro two years ago are confind, explained today that they were held in the death house to protect them from other prisoners.

MOSCOW, March 12. -- Four Britons on the staff of Metropolitan-Vickers, a British corporation, and four Russian employes of the company were arrested in three raids last night and this morning by members of the OGPU [national secret police].

The Columbia crews will compete in an intensive campaign of short-distance races this Spring, according to the schedule announced yesterday by Manager Carry Post. Three regattas have been arranged for the varsity, junior varsity and freshman eights, while the champion 150-pound crew will compete in four races.

VIENNA, March 12 (AP). -- Countless rumors of imminent Nazi or Hapsburg "putsches" have led the Socialists to order the precautionary mobilization of the Schutzbund -- the republican guard -- to forestall any action from either direction.

WASHINGTON, March 12 (AP). -- The Supreme Court has reached a goal, being prepared now after years of hard work, to hear cases as rapidly as counsel can present them. When it convenes tomorrow only twenty-one cases will be awaiting hearing, and in its ordinary procedure the court could hear all of these in one week.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., March 12. -- The strong probability that the worst is over, that confidence will improve and that as the banking situation clears business men who have deferred buying will make up for lost time is the opinion of Dr. Sumner H. Slichter, Professor of Business Economics at the Harvard School of Business Administration.

ALBANY, March 11. -- Republicans in both the Senate and the Assembly are being lined up for New York City charter revision. The caucus, it necessary, may be invoked to insure a united party front on charter measures pending or to be introduced.

WATERBURY, Conn., March 12. -- Attributing all present-day economic and governmental troubles to post-war expansion, Governor Wilbur L.
