Cross at a meeting in the Second Congregational Church here tonight declared that national, State and municipal budgets must be balanced by curtailing the services expanded in the last decade.

Private bankers will be enabled to resume business at the same time as the large commercial banks in New York City today as a result of a ruling handed down by a special banking committee of the State Banking Department.

Dr. A. David Thaeler, a young physician who will depart for Nicaragua early in July to open a dispensary in connection with a proposed mission-hospital, occupied the pulpit of the First Moravian Church, Lexington Avenue at Thirtieth Street yesterday morning and outlined to the congregation the plan by which he hoped to carry on the work of the first Moravian missionaries in the Caribbean area.

MOSCOW, March 12 (AP). -- The British Embassy here made inquiries at the Foreign Office today concerning the arrest of four British subjects connected with Metropolitan-Vickers in raids last night and today. The Foreign Office said it had no information on the subject, but promised to investigate tomorrow morning.
The Federal Reserve Bank of New York at 12:30 o'clock this morning made public a list of the New York City member banks which it had authorized to open for business at the usual banking hours today.

Tenants are moving in the large Port Authority Commerce Building at 111 Eighth Avenue, between Fifteenth and Sixteenth Street, and construction work on the huge structure is expected to be wholly completed before May 1. announces John P. Galvin, chairman of the Port of New York Authority.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The three free institutions of collegiate grade in the City of New York are under the general supervision of the Board of Higher Education, a body of twenty-two members appointed by the Mayor. One of the three is Hunter College, whose president, Dr. James M. Kieran, is about to retire.

The license issued last night to banks and trust companies in this city by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York was a simple and laconic document, considering its magic potency in releasing many billions of dollars to restore normal banking operations.

LOS ANGELES, March 12 (AP). -- A gigantic relief organization, enlisting its support from Federal, State and community agencies, speeded ahead tonight in the task of caring for the hundreds of injured and homeless in the Southern California earthquake area and in rehabilitating stricken cities.

WASHINGTON, March 12. -- The total deposits of $269,000,000 in suspended member banks of the Federal Reserve system last year would have been cut down to not more than one-fourth of that sum if his bill to indemnify depositors had been a part of the banking laws, Senator McAdoo, former Secretary of the Treasury, said tonight.

Presenting a five-point national program that this nation must adopt if the unemployment and social crisis is to be overcome, the Rev. Dr. Sidney E. Goldstein declared yesterday in a sermon at the Free Synagogue, Carnegie Hall, that "unemployment has become one of the major catastrophies of our time."

LONDON, March 12. -- George S. Bailey, general manager of Metropolitan-Vickers, which, incidentally, will entertain tomorrow Yosuke Matsuoka, Japan's spokesman at Geneva, announced tonight that the four Britons arrested in Moscow were the company's senior men in Russia.
LONDON, March 12 (AP). -- The part Great Britain would play in the event of another European conflict attracted the attention of the London press today.

At the Reinhardt Galleries drawings by French and American painters make up a pleasing interlude in the many exhibitions of paintings and water-colors. For traits by Modigliani and Picasso hang side by side with Maurice Sterne's Benares studies, Viaminck's square-rigged vessel in dock and Sanford Ross's New Jersey "locals."

Shipwreck Kelly, Central Park Zoo's tree-sitting raccoon, was sneezing and sniffling late yesterday afternoon. Huddled in the sunniest corner of the coon pen, he shivered and shook and brushed a furred paw across a moist nose. Zoo strollers watched his convulsions and blew their own noses in sympathy.

Controller Berry's new plan permitting taxpayers to pay their taxes in instalments in advance and to obtain interest on the payments will become effective today, when the first of the city's "baby bonds" will go on sale at the Finance Department in multiples of $10.

PHILADELPHIA, March 12. -- President Roosevelt's program to reduce or eliminate pensions to ex-service men in cases where disabilities were not due directly to military service was endorsed today by the Philadelphia Chapter of the American Veterans Association.

Yehudi Menuhin's recital last night in Carnegie Hall offered as its principal attractions the Bach sonata in E major for piano and violin and Elgar's second violin concerto. The smaller pieces were announced as the adagio from Mozart's sonata in E flat major; Recitative and Scherzo Caprice, Fritz Kreisler; "The Bee," Francois Schubert; Serenade de Novia, Saenger; Souvenir de Moscou, Wieniawski.

Speaker Henry T. Rainey of the House of Representatives in an interview here yesterday said the Federal Government would issue the new currency from time to time, as the needs of the country required it, with $11,000,000,000 as the absolute maximum.

"Only this week," says The Manchester Union, "twenty-eight "thousand corkscrews from the "Rockwell Clough plant at Alton "were shipped to Denmark." All were "gold-plated." This seems to imply a regrettable sumptuosity on the part of too many Danes.

TOKYO, Monday, March 13 (AP). -- A Rengo (Japanese) News Agency dispatch from Chinchow, Manchuria, today said that after an allday battle Sunday at Sifeng Pass in the Great Wall, Major Gen. Heijiro Hattori's Fourteenth Brigade of Japanese infantry had repulsed a desperate Chinese attack.

In Joel Sayre's 'Hizsoner the Mayor," a Mayor popularly known as "the Boy Friend" preserves the five-cent fare by settling a traction strike with a put-and-take top, a minor episode in the 50,000 words of a book that has satire mixed with burlesque.

The total spent for home relief of the unemployed in this city in February was $4,013,131,60, an increase of $1,500,000 over the highest previous month, according to the monthly report submitted yesterday by Mary L. Gibbons, director of the Home Relief Bureau, to Frank J. Taylor, Commissioner of Public Welfare.

HOLLYWOOD, Cal., March 12. -- For the first time in the memory of even the oldest movie pioneers, not one camera will shoot in all Hollywood for at least one day, when the picture plants close their stages tomorrow as a step in the industry's effort to cope with a financial emergency.

The executive committee of the American Petroleum Institute suggested yesterday means for more effective administration of the oil conservation laws of the country through closer cooperation between units in the industry and the national and State Governments, according to The Associated Press.

Condemnation of the policies of The Columbia Spectator, student daily newspaper of Columbia, for being "not entirely in accord" with the best interests of Columbia College and the university, is found in the majority report, made public yesterday, of a committee of five, appointed last November by the Board of Student Representatives of the college to investigate Spectator.

CHICAGO, March 12. -- Closing of Chicago's grain futures market not only stopped trading in cash grain but also upset the grain trade of the world. Without operations on the Board of Trade here, it has been demonstrated, wheat prices the world over are affected.

The Preakness, the Maryland Jockey Club's mile-and-three-sixteenths test for 3-year-olds which annually is renewed at the Pimlico course, has received seventy-five nominations in forty-seven entries, according to an announcement yesterday from Frank J. Bryan, racing secretary.

OYSTER BAY, L.I., March 12. -- Former President Herbert Hoover was a guest at luncheon today of Mrs. Theodore Roosevelt, widow of the President, at her country place, Sagamore Hill. The luncheon was informal with only Mrs. Roosevelt's daughter, Mrs. Richard Derby, the former Ethel Roosevelt, as an additional guest.

The birthday of GROVER CLEVELAND, which falls on Saturday of this week, cannot be more appropriately celebrated by the State of Jersey than by the passage of the bill introduced by Assemblyman WAUGH (a Republican member of the New Jersey Legislature), providing for the appointment by the Governor of a board of trustees to take over for the State the house in which CLEVELAND was born and make it a State memorial.

Frederick T. Birchall, chief European correspondent of THE NEW YORK TIMES, told a nation-wide radio audience, in an address rebroadcast yesterday from Berlin, that there was no cause for general alarm in the ascendency to power of Adolf Hitler and his brown-shirted Nazis.

CHICAGO, March 12. -- Crusaders were called into action today to urge passage by the United States Senate of the President's veterans' economy bill. This organization, formed originally to combat prohibition, is now entrenched in the battle to save the nation's credit, two of its Vice National Commanders, J. Russell Forgan and Seymour Wheeler, announced today.

MEXICO CITY, March 12 (AP). -- The discovery and exploration of a twelve-century-old capital of the Mayan empire, whose ruins were described as being fabulously rich, were reported today by Enrique Juan Palacios, an archaeologist in the Department of Education.

There has been an encouraging subscription for the annual dance under the auspices of the Junior Federation of the Federation for the Support of Jewish Philanthropic Societies which will take place next Saturday night in the main ballroom of the Plaza.

BERLIN, March 12 (AP). -- The interest of the capital on Germany's memorial day was centred in ceremonies in the State Opera House, on Unter den Linden, that were attended by President von Hindenburg, Chancellor Hitler, Vice Chancellor Franz von Papen, Captain Hermann Wilhelm Goering, Minister without portfolio; Franz Seldte, Minister of Labor, and other notables.

BERLIN, March 10. -- The German business community received the news of Hitler's electoral victory calmly. Some business men even expressed enthusiasm, and a rather wild advance occurred on the Boerse, in which leading stocks gained 15 to 25 points within three days.
WASHINGTON, March 12. -- Senator Long gave today his version of an encounter off the Senate floor with Senator Glass, about which the capital was still talking today.

CHICAGO, March 12. -- Chicago's ''big five" Loop banks and ten other institutions at 10 o'clock tonight received formal authorization to reopen for business tomorrow morning at 9 o'clock. The order came from Secretary Woodin and was relayed to the banks by the Federal Reserve Bank of Chicago.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I was greatly interested in your editorial comment on the lines of Omar Khayyam upon the remolding of this "Sorry Scheme of Things Entire," , and of those by Dr. David Eugene Smith on what he would have done had he been "Lord of Cosmos,"
Swayed, but Impartial. The morning after the California earthquake we printed the following Associated Press dispatch:

The outlook in the iron and steel markets has been brightened by the prospects for an early improvement in the banking and currency situation, according to the magazine Steel, in its weekly review. The publication says in part:

WASHINGTON, March 12. -- Fleet manoeuvres on the Pacific Coast which were to have begun tomorrow have been postponed because of conditions in the earthquake area, Admiral Richard H. Leigh, commander-in-chief of the fleet, reported today to the Navy Department.

In asking Congress for authority and power to effect certain economies, President ROOSEVELT declared that he wished the thing done along Constitutional lines. The bill adopted by the House on Saturday was along those lines. Careful reading of its text will show that it did not set up the President as a Dictator.

SHANGHAI, March 12. -- Stripped of all vestiges of office and power since the Japanese capture of Manchuria and Jehol, China's former most-powerful war lord, Marshal Chank Hsiao-liang, arrived by airplane from Peiping this afternoon and immediately assumed the role of a private citizen, preparatory to traveling abroad.

Plans for a concerted, nationwide expression of indignation at the anti-Semitism of Adolf Hitler and his party were formulated yesterday by the national executive committee of the American Jewish Congress at the Hotel Commodore.

WALFISH BAY, South Africa, March 12 (AP). -- Victor Smith, 19-year-old flier who is attempting to beat Amy Johnson Mollison's time for a London-to-Cape Town flight, arrived here at 5:20 P.M. (Greenwich Mean Time) today (12:20 P. M. Eastern Standard Time).

Ray Thompson, Navy swimming captain, scored 12 points in his team's final meet against Columbia on Saturday to take individual scoring honors in the swimming competition in the Intercollegiate Swimming Association.
LA PAZ, Bolivia, March 12. -- Bolivian troops in the disputed Chaco region have captured Fort Alihuata and made impressive gains elsewhere in an extensive drive against Paraguayan positions.

CHICAGO, March 12. -- Chicago pastors are both puzzled and happy while at a loss to explain why their Sunday offerings have increased since the bank holiday brought on a money famine. Ushers passed the plate expecting poor results, but to the amazement of pastors and harried church treasurers, the plates have come in "heavier than usual."

ITHACA, N.Y., March 12. -- One of the highest honors in Cornell athletics was bestowed on Jose Martinez-Zorrilla of Jalisco, Mexico, All-American end, when he received varsity letters in three different sports.

MONTREAL, March 12. -- The financial statement of the Steel Company of Canada. Ltd., which has just gone forward to shareholders, reveals operating profit for 1932 at $1,435,873, after deducting charges for repairs and maintenance and all taxes but before providing for depreciation and bond interest.

The new edition of The Record of American and Foreign Shipping, issued by the American Bureau of Shipping, is being circulated this week in a new form and represents "an outstanding record of American shipping," according to the publishers.

The festival of Purim, described in the Book of Esther as the celebration of the deliverance of the chosen people from Haman in Persia, was the occasion yesterday for sermons in New York synagogues on the rise of anti-Semitism in Germany and Poland.

BUENOS AIRES, March 12. -- The bank holiday in the United States caused considerable confusion and some nervousness here, but had no serious effects on the Argentine markets. The government shifted from the dollar to the French franc as the basis for exchange operations.

DES MOINES, March 12 (AP). -- Militant agriculturists of the National Farmers Holiday Association in convention here today threatened another farm strike unless their legislative demands are approved by Congress by May 3.
GENEVA, March 12. -- Prime Minister MacDonald decided today he might remain in Geneva for a week, according to a British spokesman.

Rapidly growing demand from veterans' groups for support of President Roosevelt's economy program was noticeable yesterday throughout the city. Heads of veterans' posts, entire chapters of veterans' units, and ex-soldiers generally, seemed to be getting behind erans' units, and ex-soldiers generthe movement.

President McKEE of the Board of Aldermen is getting ready to press forward with his plan for broadening the Mayor's powers in the preparation of the city budget. It is now formulated, theoretically, by the Board of Estimate, with the aid of the Director of the Budget.

CHICAGO, March 12 (AP). -- With sessions in many States drawing toward a close, Legislatures of the nation are speeding consideration of State liquor enforcement and setting up machinery for citizens to express themselves on the national repeal proposal.
WASHINGTON, March 12. -- The text of President Roosevelt's radio address on the banking situation, delivered at 10 o'clock tonight from his study in the White House, was as follows:...

Willard S. Karn, contract bridge expert who is one of the holders of the national pair championship and of the Vanderbilt Cup, and who won the national individual masters championship in 1931, appealed yesterday for a change in the qualifying regulations for pair championships, designed to lessen the possibility of ranking players being eliminated in the early rounds.

PARIS, March 10. -- The index number of average wholesale prices in France during February, published by the Statistique Generate, stands at 390. This is unchanged from the index number of January and of December, and 7 3/8 per cent below a year ago.

The Rev. Dr. George P.T. Sargent, rector of St. Bartholomew's Protestant Episcopal Church, Park Avenue and Fiftieth Street, made a plea for self-analysis in his sermon yesterday morning, on the ground that hoarding of material things -- gold or otherwise -- interfered with loyalty to God and the consecrated duties of the citizens in the financial crisis.

All the fifty-nine savings banks in greater New York will reopen today without asking sixty days' notice of intention to withdraw funds. Withdrawals, however, will be temporarily restricted by order of the State Banking Board to $25 weekly for each depositor.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 12. -- Colonel Jacob Ruppert, owner of the Yankees, arrived today for the purpose of reaching an agreement on salary with Babe Ruth. He was accompanied by George Weiss, general manager of the club's farm system.

President Roosevelt's proclamation inaugurating a bank holiday has proved to be the one stroke most needed in effecting a change in the mental processes of leaders in the building trades and has cleared the atmosphere for a better outlook in this field, according to a cross-section of views expressed by construction men to Charles L. Eidlitz, director of the Credit Association of the Building Trades of New York.

PANAMA CITY, March 12. -- The United States embargo on gold exports may interfere seriously with the two unofficial wars in South America by preventing the supply of provisions and munitions for the troops and be a substitute for an arms embargo.

Radical revision of most of the industrial pension plans now in operation is indispensable if the pension movement is to be saved from failure as a voluntary industrial relation function of American industry, according to a report made public yesterday by Industrial Relations Counselors, 165 Broadway, a non-profit-making research organization.

Fresh-water fishermen, attention! Here is a note from up Westchester way, where lurk the trout and bass in streams and lakes and reservoirs, and there is sprightly hope expressed by this angler, hope which all fishermen will seize upon with great joy.

Vernon Brisco, former P.S.A.L. champion, registered a pair of brilliant victories in the sprints as he led the New York Evening High School to the team title in the inaugural track and field meet of the newly formed Metropolitan Evening High Schools' Athletic Association yesterday at the 102d Engineers Armory.

LOS ANGELES, March 12. -- The count of human lives lost in the earthquake disaster in Southern California beginning Friday evening was reduced today, following an official check by Coroner Nance of Los Angeles County and deputy sheriffs.

BERLIN, March 10. -- Notwithstanding the election of last Sunday, there is general expectation here that trade recovery will be resumed after the Reichstag has assembled. Among other indications, the number of unemployed workingmen in Germany decreased 45,000 during the second half of February.

LONG BEACH, Cal., March 12 (AP). -- Striking quickly to the heart of its emergency problems, the newly organized Civic Rehabilitation Committee acted today to provide food and pure water for the victims of the disastrous earthquake.

Resolved to continue their fight for more satisfactory cooperation from the stagehands' and musicians' unions than was obtained in the negotiations of Saturday, the members of the League of New York Theatres will assemble again today at 2:30 P.M. in the Paramount Building offices of the league.

ROSLYN, L.I., March 12. -- G.C. Schwalb, representing the Crescent Athletic-Hamilton Club, and G.C. Walsh, who shot under the colors of the Lido Country Club, tied for the North Shore trapshooting championship at the traps of the Engineers Club today.
WASHINGTON, March 12. -- Banking regulations issued today by Secretary Woodin were as follows:
WASHINGTON, March 12. -- The votes in the Senate and House by the delegations from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut on important roll-calls last week are given in the appended tabulation:

WASHINGTON, March 12. -- President Roosevelt explained the banking situation to the people of the United States in a fifteen-minute radio address tonight. The President's appeal for confidence in the government's program was made after preparations had been completed for the progressive reopening, beginning tomorrow morning, of banks classified as sound by Federal and State officials.
ALBANY, March 12. -- The Legislature will meet tomorrow for the first Monday afternoon session in years, to be ready to enact emergency banking legislation.
NEW YORK. Sir William E. Dudley of London has left the Ambassador for Vancouver, B.C.

LONDON, March 10. -- Security markets here have been unsettled during the week, reflecting doubts over the influence of the American crisis, the future course of sterling and the unwelcome intrusion of international politics. The German situation in particular caused uneasiness.
John J. Dunnigan, State Senate leader, and John T. McCall, head of the State Senate Committee on Banks, spoke over Radio Station WOR yesterday afternoon on the banking situation.

The sweeping measures, adopted at Washington to meet the banking crisis, will be regarded from two divergent viewpoints. In one respect, the action is altogether reassuring. A difficult situation had been rapidly growing worse; yet, because of the virtual interregnum at Washington, no executive or legislative measures, even of a strictly protective sort, had been either discussed or introduced.

BASLE, Switzerland, March 12. -- President Roosevelt's banking and economy program was found "very encouraging" by European central bank governors, who held their monthly meeting here today, preliminary to the World Bank board session tomorrow.

LONDON, March 10. -- In the week ending last Wednesday, as shown by Thursday's weekly statement, the Bank of England bought on the open market L9,726,146 gold, making the total purchased since the first fortnight of the year L40,160,355.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., March 12. -- Stirred by reports that some Senators were planning to attack the economy bill of President Roosevelt passed by the House, Major Silas Williams, national com- mander of the American Veterans, tonight urged that all veterans rally to the support of the measure and wire their Senators to get behind it.

The interest of college women in news events centres predominantly on international occurrences, with domestic political events and cultural developments as second and third choices, according to the results of a questionnaire submitted to members of the Panhellenic Association and made public yesterday at the Panhellenic Hotel, 3 Mitchell Place.

KINGS POINT, L.I., March 12. -- James Rowan, 22 years old, son-in-law of Egbert Moxham, a member of the brokerage firm of Shields Co., 52 Wall Street, was found dead of monoxide gas poisoning early this morning in the garage of the Moxham estate here.

PARIS, March 12. -- The great textile fair at Lyons was officially dedicated today by President Lebrun in the presence of a husre crowd. Arriving at Lyons yesterday afternoon, M. Lebrun attended a number of ceremonies last evening and all day today.

CHICAGO, March 12. -- Inadequate banking facilities, particularly in the interior, and uncertainty regarding banks here furnishing funds for bills of lading and for packers to pay for purchase of live stock, created an uneasy feeling last week and curtailed operations of smaller butchers and packers, as well as of the big packers.

GREENWICH, Conn., March 12. -- Two small boys, eager to get material for a story in connection with their studies at the Greenwich Country Day School, ran away at 3 o'clock this morning and alarmed two of the leading families of Greenwich.
Leadership demonstrated by President Roosevelt during his first week in the White House inspired optimistic sermons in pulpits throughout New York City yesterday.

The necessity for religion was discussed by the Rev. Dr. Charles L. Goodel, secretary of the Department of Evangelism of the Federal Council of Churches of Christ in America, in his sermon yesterday morning at the Collegiate Reformed Church of St. Nicholas, Fifth Avenue and Forty-eighth Street.

VOICE culture first. It is sometimes overlooked that the umpires as well as the ball players have to go through Spring training exercises. Bill Klem, the veteran masked marvel and Grand Wielder of the Whiskbroom (with palms), has changed his training program this season.

BOSTON, Mass., Monday, March 13. -- The Federal Reserve Bank of Boston announced early this morning that all its member banks in the city would open for business, on an unrestricted basis, at 9 A.M. today. The list follows:

The deadline for the return of hoarded gold has been extended four days or until Friday night, by order of the Federal Reserve Board, it was announced last night. Previously the board had ordered all Federal Reserve Banks and member banks of the system to report the names of those who withdrew gold since Feb. 1, and who had not returned it by tonight.
Yale and Frinceton gain two berths each and Columbia one on the Eastern Intercollegiate Basketball League's all-star team, selected by the six coaches for the Associated Press yesterday.
The New York Stock Exchange and all other security and commodity exchanges in this city will remain closed today, despite the restoration of banking facilities here and in many other cities.
Pedro Nieves, 137, Puerto Rico, received the decision over Sammy Binder, 136, Bronx lightweight, in the feature five-round bout before 1,000 persons at the New York Coliseum last night.
NEW YORK. Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Verner Reed have joined Mr. and Mrs. Samuel F. Pryor at the Waldorf-Astoria.

The proposed new transatlantic service between Philadelphia, Liverpool and Manchester, the operation of which has been temporarily postponed owing to the failure of the Postoffice Department to grant a mail contract to the Philadelphia Mail Steamship Line calling for an annual outlay of $1,000,000 for ten years, will be started this Summer, according to its promoters.

ALBANY, March 13. -- Not content with the economies asked by Governor Lehman in his Executive budget bill nor with the deeper cuts sought by the Republicans, the Democratic program contemplates balancing the 1933-34 budget without resort to any of the "oppressive" taxes recommended by the Governor in his quest for new revenues of $84,000,000.

BERLIN, March 13. -- Stocks and bonds exhibited opposite tendencies on the Boerse today. Bonds were in little demand and prices sagged, while stocks were bullish, with a considerably augmented volume of transactions. The advance was led by the potashes, Saldetfurth rising 8 1/2 points in the first hour.

Among the nominations of Ambassadors sent to the Senate yesterday by President ROOSEVELT, the only surprise is the selection of Mr. JOSEPHUS DANIELS for Mexico. It was understood that he was to have recognition by the Roosevelt Administration, but various other offices had been by Washington dispatches connected with his name.

Paul Herring, retired realty man and active in Jewish philanthropical, educational and religious circles, died of heart attack early yesterday morning at his residence, 220 West Ninety-third Street, after an illness of almost a year. He was 61 years old.

To Miss Margarete Dessoff and the Dessoff choirs the public of New York is indebted for the first American performance of Orazio Vecchi's composition of the late sixteenth century "L'Amfiparnasso," which took place last night in the French Institute, under Miss Dessoff's direction.

JOHNNY DE FOREST, British amateur golf champion, departed these shores some time ago with a bland smile and an amiable wave of his hand toward the Statue of Liberty. When and where he will turn up next, deponent saith not. Here is an engaging knight errant of the niblick who could match lives with any Bengal Lancer.
LIMA, Peru, March 13. -- Details of the revolt at Cajamarca Saturday were made public here today. A government communique this morning says:

When Latin mottoes were in favor, "Carpe diem" was often adopted by graduating classes. None could be more appropriate for the classes now forming to take advantage of the opportunity which this period of unemployment offers in the emergency colleges.

Irving T. Bush, who is seeking to regain control of the Bush Terminal Company, has sent a letter to the 5,250 common and debenture stockholders asserting that 702 employes have joined the appeal to stockholders asking for his return to the management.

The Moderator's Council of the Presbytery of New York, at a meeting last evening in the Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church, at Seventy-third Street, voted as a depression measure to recommend to the presbytery at its next meeting there be a "gentleman's agreement" that only half of the commissioners elected shall go to the general assembly of the Presbyterian Church the last week of May.

In the most laconic of his messages Mr. ROOSEVELT recommended to Congress yesterday immediate modification of the Volstead act by making legal the manufacture and sale of beer "and other beverages of such alcoholic content as is permissible under the Constitution," in order to provide by "substantial taxes " on, such beverages "a proper and much-needed revenue for the Government."

With the reopening of the banks here, retail trade yesterday reached practically a normal basis. The heavy rain during most of the afternoon proved more of a restrictive factor upon sales than any lingering effect of the cash stringency of last week.

The invasion of science by philosophical idealism is challenged by H. Levy, Professor of Mathematics at the Imperial College of Science and Technology, University of London, in "The Universe of Science," published by the Century Company today.

CHICAGO, March 13. -- Thirty-four Chicago banks, representing more than 97 per cent of the total banking resources of the city, reopened today in accordance with authorization by the Secretary of the Treasury and the State auditor.

CHICAGO, March 13. -- Gossip in the grain trade today was not so optimistic regarding advancing prices as it was last week, the weakness that developed in sterling being regarded as indicating the United States was likely to remain for some time well above a world's export parity on wheat.

LONDON, March 13. -- There is only one route up Mount Everest; so much was established on the first expedition which sought to reach the summit. The camps, with the possible exception of No. VI, will be in much the same position as in 1922 and 1924.

The Tammany Congress members who voted against President Roosevelt's economy bill were assailed by former Representative Ruth B. Pratt yesterday in an address before the school of politics of the Women's National Republican Club.
WASHINGTON, March 13. -- Because of the generally depressed condition of the country, there will be no "little season" for society folk in Washington this year.

The dollar proved its strength emphatically yesterday when official trading in the foreign exchange market was reopened. Despite the questions as to its status that had been raised last week by the banking crisis, the gold embargo and the authorization of billions of dollars of new currency not redeemable in gold, the United States monetary unit rose sharply above the levels at which it had sold just before the banking holiday.

The congregation of the Park Avenue Presbyterian Church, at Eighty-fifth Street, will meet Wednesday evening, March 22, to hear and act on a report of its special committee on a new pastor. That committee, it was learned yesterday, has voted unanimously to recommend that a call to the pastorate be issued to the Rev, Dr. Edmund Melville Wylie, one of the best known members of the Presbytery of Newark, N.J.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., March 13. -- Seventy candidates for next season's Yale football team reported today to Head Coach Reginald D. Root at the Yale Armory. A few took light running exercises or did some punting, but there was no organized practice.

MIAMI, Fla., March 13. -- A home run by Danny Taylor in the sixth inning was the high light of the Dodgers' 6-to-4 victory over the Athletics today. The drive, the only one of the exhibition series, rolled to the fence in deep centre field, and it paved the way for the second triumph in three starts against the Mackmen.

WASHINGTON, March 13 (AP). -- A bank balance on Feb. 28 of $57,256 and unpaid obligations of $751,290 were reported to the House today by the Democratic National Committee. The statement, filed by Ambrose O'Connell, assistant treasurer, covered January and February.
LOS ANGELES, March 13 (AP). -- Charges that Chester C. Conklin, film comedian, was cold and indifferent, were made in a divorce complaint by Mrs. Minnie V. Conklin on file in Superior Court today.

WASHINGTON, March 13. -- Although holding that "the surcharges, as such, should be brought to an end," the Interstate Commerce Commission in a decision handed down late today granted the railroads' request to be allowed to continue collecting the present emergency freight rates by extending the date of their application to Sept. 30, 1933.

About 200 families have been adopted since January, through the efforts of the adopt-a-family committee of the Emergency Unemployment Relief Committee, it was announced yesterday by Mrs. August Belmont, chairman. These families are in addition to those helped with funds collected last Fall in the campaign of the Emergency Unemployment Relief Committee.

HANOVER, N.H., March 13. -- Revised Spring schedules for Dartmouth varsity baseball, tennis, lacrosse and golf teams were announced by the athletic council today. Although no program has been arranged for the freshman baseball team it is expected that several games will be carded with near-by schools.
COMMERCIAL PAPER. Yesterday -- No trading. Friday, March 3 (last trading day) -- 3 per cent for the best names.

WASHINGTON, March 13. -- President Roosevelt, in a 72-word message to Congress today, urged immediate modification of the Volstead act to permit the manufacture and sale of beer and other beverages of such alcoholic content as is permissible under the Constitution, to provide additional taxes "much needed for the government."

MUNICH, March 13. -- Count Anton Arco-Valley, who killed Kurt Eisner, Socialist Premier of Bavaria, in 1919, was arrested today on a charge of plotting to assassinate Chancellor Hitler. No details were revealed by the police.

Philip Spitalery, 50-year-old jeweler at 543 Columbus Avenue, failed to carry a revolver yesterday for the first time in many years. Last night he Was nursing a bullet wound in his right leg while detectives searched for a gunman, whose unsteady nerves had resulted in the shooting and an unsuccessful holdup.

MONTREAL, March 13 (Canadian Press). -- Shares of Public Utilities were in fair demand today on the Montreal Stock Exchange and all closed with small gains, while the interlisted group drifted slightly lower in unusually light trading. The day's turnover was 6,556 shares.

LONDON, March 13. -- With the reopening of the American banks, the first dealings in the dollar in the foreign exchange market since March 3 took place today. Transactions began at 2:30 o'clock in the afternoon and the first quotation was $3.44, compared with $3.44 3/4, the last official rate prior to the American banking holiday.

WASHINGTON, March 13. -- Treasury officials today explained what will be the duties of the conservator of a closed bank, the officer to be appointed under the terms of the new emergency banking legislation to conserve the assets of any such bank for the benefit of depositors and other creditors.

A bridge party in aid of the Onteora committee for the Health Centre and Visiting Nurses of Tannersville, N.Y., will be held tomorrow afternoon in the roof garden of the St. Regis. It has been arranged by Mrs. Henry Gansevoort Sanford, Mrs. Harold G. Henderson, Miss Mary Williamson, Mrs. George Jarvis Coffin, Mrs. George D. Barron, Miss Justine Watson, Mrs. Louis Ott and Mrs. Ralph R. McKee.

George L. Harrison, governor of the New York Federal Reserve Bank, drew yesterday the first of the new national currency issued by the government to reach New York. He was at the head of the line at the teller's window at the Reserve Bank at 9 o'clock in the morning.

LONDON, March 13. -- Britain's embargo on arms shipments to Japan and China, which was imposed just two weeks ago, ended today when Stanley Baldwin, acting Prime Minister, announced in the House of Commons that as no other nation had consented to follow Britain's example, munitions shipments could be resumed.

The navy's new airship Macon was dedicated on Saturday "to the "air and to the service of the "nation." She may prove to the more useful to commerce than to the navy. The Los Angeles was acquired from the Germans on the condition that no military use would be made of her.
DALLAS, Texas, March 13. -- All banks in Dallas save one opened this morning, five being members of the Federal Reserve System, as follows:

NEWARK, N.J., March 13. -- David Lederman, 53 years old, a retired tailor and owner of a six-family tenement house at 104 Hunterdon Street, was found beaten to death in his bed in his second floor apartment at that address today. His wife, Fannie, 47 years old, who was beaten also, was unable to give a coherent account of what had occurred.

WASHINGTON, March 13. -- Corporations authorized by the Federal Reserve Board to do a general foreign banking business were added to the list today of organizations, including banks under the jurisdiction of the Federal Farm Loan Bureau, Home Loan Banks, Agricultural Credit Corporations and the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, which were permitted by Treasury regulations to open.

Six persons, one or them a gunman and another his victim, were injured last night when an ambulance in which they were being taken to St. Vincent's Hospital was in collision with a taxicab and turned over at Greenwich Street and Seventh Avenue as the ambulance was heading into the driveway of the institution.

PARIS, March 13. -- So far France has remained calm in the face of the hysteria which has developed across the Rhine since March 5 and the solidarity in the diplomatic efforts of the Italian and German Governments. But tonight Premier Daladier felt it necessary to broadcast a speech to his countrymen, reassuring them and asking that calm be maintained.
RICHMOND, Va., March 13. -- Richmond banks which opened today under Federal licenses were:

A nominal market for United States Government obligations was quoted yesterday, largely through the efforts of over-the-counter traders, including the bond departments of commercial and private banks, since Stock Exchange firms, although permitted by a ruling of the special committee of seven of the Exchange to settle some contracts and do some trading, did little if any new business.

Another Philharmonic Season. The Philharmonic-Symphony Society has taken for a model of how to behave under severe pressure the late Marshal FOCH. He said in his famous Marne dispatch that his right wing was falling back, his left wing was in trouble, he would attack in the centre.

WASHINGTON, March 13. -- President Roosevelt sent to the Senate today the nominations of Judge Robert Worth Bingham of Louisville to be Ambassador to Great Britain; Jesse Isidor Straus of New York to be Ambassado to France and Josephus Daniels of Raleigh, N.C., to be Ambassador to Mexico.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., March 13. -- The United States is on the eve of an era of greater prosperity than ever before, Norman S.B. Gras, Isador Straus Professor of Business History at Harvard University, declared in an interview today.
WASHINGTON, March 13. -- The Bureau of Navigation issued the following orders today, dated March 10:

One of the greatest exhibitions of serving seen in a championship match in recent years was witnessed at the Seventh Regiment Armory yesterday as Frank Shields defeated Frank Bowden of the New York A.C. in the thirty-fourth national indoor tennis tournament, 6 -- 4, 6 -- 1.

To the Editor of The New York Times: For years underlying bonds of hydroelectric and steam generating electric companies, paying about 5 per cent, have been regarded as one of the best receptacles in which to place the earnings of our people. Millions of our citizens are dependent on these investments.
WASHINGTON, March 13 (AP) -- Farm organization leaders today began forming a program to overhaul Federal agricultural credit agencies and provide emergency mortgage relief legislation.

ALBANY, March 13. -- Road construction in New York State can be greatly curtailed without harm to traffic, Colonel Frederick S. Greene, State Superintendent of Public Works, asserted in his annual report submitted to the Legislature today.

On the eve of the elimination tournaments leading up to the national championships, the officials of the Indoor Polo Association of America yesterday announced the results of the annual Spring handicap meeting, with several of the leading players of the game affected by the revisions in the ratings.

Plans for a campaign to make repeal of the Eighteenth Amendment effective by Thanksgiving Day were made yesterday by the board of directors of the Broadway Association after a discussion of this matter at its regular meeting in the Hotel Astor.

The unbeaten James Monroe High School basketball team clinched the Upper Manhattan-Bronx Division championship of the Public Schools Athletic League for the second straight year when it vanquished the De Witt Clinton representatives, 22 -- 17, at the Clinton Court yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 13. -- In a ruling of far-reaching importance the Supreme Court decided today that Appalachian Coals, Inc., selling agency for 137 coal producers, did not violate the Sherman antitrust act.

MONTREAL, March 13 (Canadian Press). -- The directors of the Canadian Pacific Railway Company took no action on the preferred and common dividends at a meeting here today. They thus passed the common dividend for 1932 and that on the preferred stock for the second half of that vear.

MIAMI, Fla., March 13. -- A track record was created, another was broken, and a third was equaled before a crowd of more than 5,000, which attended the opening of the seventeen-day meeting of the Gablas Racing Association at Tropical Park today.
PARIS, March 13 (AP). -- Occupation of the demilitarized German Rhineland by Chancellor Hitler's Nazis will be protested by the French Government.
The fortieth anniversary yesterday of the original Waldorf-Astoria found Oscar, its host, in "happy, healthy and contented" mood in his new surroundings at the Waldorf-Astoria of today.

WASHINGTON, March 13. -- Following up last night's radio address in which he promised to eliminate "bad banking practices," President Roosevelt acted promptly to get facts by suggesting that the Senate Banking and Currency Committee continue its investigation of the banking situation which brought to the fore some reprehensible conditions.

The Museum of Modern Art will open today, in its fourth-floor galleries, to members and their friends an exhibition of fruit and flower paintings by nineteenth and twentieth century artists. From tomorrow until the end of the month this work may be viewed by the public.

With the reopening of New York City banks and the resumption of normal Federal Reserve Bank operations yesterday, the money market underwent belated adjustments to the changed conditions of credit and banking.

LOS ANGELES, March 13 (AP). -- Stricken Southern California today was cleaning up its earthquake wreckage. Continuing shocks of lesser frequency and intensity helped shake down loosened bits of brick and parts of town buildings, as the yet incomplete survey indicated 116 dead and more than a thousand moderately and seriously injured.

WASHINGTON, March 13. -- In a sweeping indictment of the storage warehousing practices of Eastern trunk lines at New York by two of its attorney examiners, the Interstate Commerce Commission was urged today to "admonish" the carriers to abandon their present "wasteful and noncompensatory services" and to institute court action for violations of the interstate commerce and Elkins acts if they resisted.

MOSCOW, March 13. -- Complicity in a widespread "damaging plot" against important electric power stations in Moscow, in Chelyabinsk, in the Donets Basin and elsewhere forms the basis of the charge on which British engineers of Metropolitan-Vickers were arrested, according to a communique issued by the Ogpu [secret police] tonight.

ALBANY, March 13. -- Going through a long calendar, the Senate today passed a series of measures sought by the New York City administration to bring additional revenue and enable it more easily to meet obligations.

Resumption of most banking operations here yesterday made possible a renewal of transactions in foreign exchange, and for the first time since the Cotton Exchange was closed a comparison of prices of cotton in the United States with quotations in Liverpool.

Having conquered the air and having experienced all the thrills that such a conquest could provide, a group of noted fliers yesterday banded together in an organization which has for its purpose the conquering of the wily trout and the battling swordfish or other aquatic creatures.
CHICAGO, March 13. -- The Federal Reserve member banks reopened here today follow:
LONDON, March 13. -- Faith in the the dollar was rewarded today, when American exchange opened higher than a week ago and gathered strength throughout the afternoon.

PRINCETON, N.J., March 13. -- Major letters have been awarded to sixteen members of the Princeton hockey team, according to an announcement today by Asa S. Bushnell, graduate manager of athletics. A like number of freshmen have been honored, receiving numerals.

PARIS, March 13. -- The dollar was not officially quoted in Paris today, despite London's official opening and the resumption of banking activity in the United States. Considerable unofficial dealing went on, however, at prices varying from 25.25 to 25.58 francs.

HELENA, Mont., March 13 (AP). -- Governor John E. Erickson, a Democrat, resigned late today to become the successor to Thomas J. Walsh in the United States Senate. Frank H. Cooney, Lieutenant Governor, was sworn in as Governor of Montana.

WASHINGTON, March 13. -- Leaders of the Democratic Senators late today called a party caucus for 10:30 o'clock tomorrow morning with a view to binding the majority to the letter of President Roosevelt's $500,000,000 economy program, which the House adopted Saturday afternoon by an overwhelming majority.

WASHINGTON, March 13. -- After receipt today of the President's "message" on beer, members of Congress who were not sure of the fact beforehand admitted that they are dealing with a consummate politician. Speaking privately they rendered to Mr. Roosevelt the tribute which amateurs in an art pay to the leading professional.

In honor of Dr. Albert Einstein's fifty-fourth birthday today, an exhibition of his works together with rare and valuable first editions, autographs, medals and portraits of the scientists on whose studies he built, including Copernicus, Kepler, LaPlace, Galileo and Newton, will be opened today in Avery Hall, Columbia University.

TRENTON, N.J., March 13. -- By unanimous vote, the Senate adopted a resolution tonight requesting Governor Moore to reconsider his recent action in ordering Duane E. Minard, First Assistant Attorney General, dropped from the State payroll, effective Wednesday of this week.
The number of cash payments of Federal income taxes made yesterday in New York City was the largest on record, according to the collectors of internal revenue here.
SAN FRANCISCO, March 13 (AP). -- Thousands of unemployed men may be sent on a gold hunt in California to answer the nation's cry for more of the metal and to provide the men with a living.

James A. Farley, Democratic national chairman, showed slight disposition yesterday to accept the apologies offered for the votes cast by New York City Representatives in the House against the Roosevelt economy bill last Saturday.

Scoring a smashing victory in the ranks of women metropolitan fencers, Miss Muriel Guggolz of the Salle d'Armes Vince captured the district foils championship last night in a keenly fought competition at the Fencers Club.

Coach Richard J. Glendon continued his experiments with the Columbia varsity crew yesterday by sending Anson Fowler from No. 2 to No. 3 in place of Bill Love. Walter Higgins, a sophomore, came up from the junior varsity outfit to take over the No. 2 position.
VATICAN CITY, March 13. -- following is the text of the allocution of Pope Pius today before the consistory of Cardinals in Consistory Hall at the Vatican:

TIENTSIN, March 13. -- Renewal today of stubborn Chinese resistance at Sifeng Pass, where the Japanese repulsed a sharp attack yesterday, has already cost more in Japanese killed and wounded than all the rest of the Jehol campaign. It is causing such uneasiness in Japanese circles that they announce that if the resistance continues it will force the Japanese command to "make a most important decision."

Simon Stern, a partner in the Waxcraft Crayon and Candle Corporation, 80 York Street, Brooklyn, was taken from his home at 94-30 Eighty-sixth Road, Woodhaven, Queens, early this morning to the Poplar Street station, Brooklyn, for questioning in connection with the killing last night of his copartner, Hyman Berson, 55 years old, of 1,299 Ocean Avenue, and the wounding of the latter's nephew, Charles Berson, 43, of 1,953 Fiftieth Street, Brooklyn.
WASHINGTON, March 13. -- Despite the troubled banking situation, the government's March 15 offering of $800,000,000 in Treasury certificates was quickly subscribed.

CAIRO, Egypt, March 13. -- More discoveries giving a definite view of Nubia's artistic development between the seventh and twelfth centuries are revealed with the conclusion of three, seasons of work by Professor Ugo Moneret de Villard under the auspices of the Egyptian Government's Department of Antiquities.

TRENTON, N.J., Tuesday, March 14. -- State Banking Commissioner William H. Kelly announced at 2:15 o'clock this morning the list of State banks which would be permitted to reopen for business without restriction this morning in the clearing house areas of New Jersey. The list follows:
To the Editor of The New York Times: May I review the letter of Paul J. Phelan, entitled "Recognition of Russia -- Mr. Smith's View Held to Be Based on Two Delusions"?

TRENTON, N.J., March 14. -- Acting under suspension of rules in response to a plea for speed by Governor Moore, both houses of the Legislature passed two bills tonight enabling the Federal Government to create a national park at Morristown to commemorate the campaign of 1779-80 in the Revolutionary War, when General Washington and his troops were camped on the tract known as Jockey Hollow.
PALM BEACH, Fla., March 13. -- Mrs. Walter Hopkins gave a luncheon bridge today in the orange gardens of the Everglades Club.

Arrangements are being made to exhibit here for the first time the Working model of one of the most ambitious undertakings of American sculpture, the huge bronze gates by Paul Manship, which are to be given anonymously to the Bronx Zoo as a memorial to Paul J. Rainey, big game hunter, explorer and motion-picture photographer.

LONDON, March 13. -- The most significant thing that happened in the British Parliament today was the withdrawal of a question which had been put down for answering by the Foreign Secretary concerning the possible bearing on the Locarno Treaty of present German activities in the demilitarized Rhineland.
GENEVA, March 13. -- The United States notified the League of Nations informally today of its acceptance of the invitation to cooperate with the Manchurian advisory committee.

Responsibility for whatever unemployment may result from the threatened closing of many legitimate playhouses on Broadway was laid yesterday at the door of the stagehands' and musicians' unions by the League of New York Theatres. Concessions offered by the stagehands during the negotiations of the last week-end were termed "wholly inadequate" to meet the present emergency, and the closing of many theatres in the near future was forecast "unless conditions improve materially."

WASHINGTON, March 13. -- The United States has replied to the invitation of the League of Nations to cooperate with its advisory committee of Twenty-one on the Far Eastern emergency and is understood to have accepted. The text of the communication will be made public soon at a time mutually agreed upon by Washington and Geneva.

Declaring that no constructive purpose could be served by submitting specific proposals as to revisions to be embodied in a new contract, the Industrial Council of Cloak, Suit and Skirt Manufacturers, Inc., in a letter yesterday to the International Ladies' Garment Workers' Union, announced it was ready to attend a conference to formulate a labor program for the industry.
To the Editor of The New York Times: The obituary notices of Benjamin Stern omitted points so rare as to be worthy of recognition.

WASHINGTON, March 13. -- Senator McAdoo of California today introduced in the Senate a joint resolution authorizing the President to expend $5,000,000 on relief for earthquake victim;. The resolution, which was referred to the Senate Appropriations Committee, read:

Raymond B. Fosdick, internationally known lawyer and peace advocate, was among the passengers who arrived last night from Europe on the North German Lloyd liner Bremen after spending two months traveling on the Continent and in the Near East.
The opening of "Masks and Faces," a new comedy by A.J. Minor, which was scheduled for this evening at the Liberty Theatre, has been postponed until Saturday night at the same theatre.

The Federal Government moved yesterday to enforce the embargo on gold to the extent of watching departing passengers as they leave the country on ocean liners. An order from the Treasury Department received at the Custom House instructed the collector here to form a special squad of customs men to take over the new duties, which are similar in many respects to those of the Customs Intelligence Bureau established in war times.

Henry J. Haarmeyer, one of the most active civic workers of Queens, died in his sleep on Sunday night of apoplexy at his home, 119-35 166th Street, Locust Manor. He was in his sixty-fourth year. Survivors are his widow, Mrs. Imogene W. Haarmeyer, who was at one time a feature writer on The Kansas City Star, and a brother, Robert, of Scranton, Pa.

WASHINGTON, March 13 (AP). -- Florida's chain store tax was erased from its statute books today by the Supreme Court because a majority of the justices felt a provision increasing the tax in proportion to the number of counties covered by each chain was discriminatory.

Renewing its appeal for changes in the Greater New York charter to give the Mayor power to formulate an executive budget, the City Club wrote to Mayor O'Brien yesterday asking him to support the Municipal Assembly bill which was recently introduced by Aldermanic President Joseph V. McKee.

Former State Senator Howard Randolph Bayne, prominent Staten Island attorney, died yesterday at his home, 75 St. Mark's Place, New Brighton, S.I., at the age of 81. He was a native of Winchester, Va., and a descendant of one of the oldest families in that State.

CHATTANOOGA, March 13. -- Samuel S. Leibowitz, New York criminal lawyer, arrived here today and took charge of the defense of the nine Negroes held in prison for two years on charges of attacking two while girls in the now famous Scottsboro case.

New York City received yesterday assurance from Wall Street that its special corporate stock maturities tomorrow aggregating $27,000,000, would be taken care of. The refunding, according to plans drafted yesterday in banking circles and which are expected to be completed today, will be done through a group of a dozen or fifteen member banks of the New York Clearing House Association.

WASHINGTON, March 13. -- Reports from all parts of the country that the government's program permitting the reopening in the twelve Reserve Bank cities of banks classified as sound was working smoothly, caused obvious gratification at the White House and Treasury Department today. Officials, who have been working night and day during the emergency, were smiling, and while worn out by their efforts, went about their duties with renewed energy.

LONDON, March 13. -- The mysterious arrest of four Britons in Moscow started a loud anti-Russian outcry in London today and may conceivably result in a break-down of the present Anglo-Russian trade negotiations.

Major Gen. John F. O'Ryan, war-time commander of the Twenty-seventh Division and a leader in the membership drive of the National Economy League, joined with the founders of the organization yesterday in pleading for whole-hearted public support of the Roosevelt economy program.

Banks opened quietly in New York yesterday, and in the other Federal Reserve cities. Certain restrictions are still in force, but there is every evidence of restored confidence. It is the old story over again -- when people know that they can draw money from their bank, they don't want it.

Some tested methods to fit elderly persons for the speeded tempo of modern life, and to thus better their chances to stay self-supporting and content, are offered by Dr. Lillien J. Martin and Clare de Gruchy in "Sweeping the Cobwebs," published today by Macmillan.

BERLIN, March 13. -- Hitler's broadcast of a Chancellor rescript commanding the Nazi storm troops to put an immediate stop to acts of political terror, personal persecutions and interference with private business resulted in a visible relaxation of political tension throughout Germany today.
Figures compiled here by the Savings Banks Association of the State of New York showed yesterday that new deposits throughout the city were twice as great as withdrawals.

BELGRADE, March 13. -- Dr. Vladimir Matchek, the Croat leader who was recently interned in Southern Serbia, was arrested and brought to Belgrade yesterday and charged today with a breach of the law for protection of the State. He will be tried a second time before one of the special courts created by the royal dictatorship.

So great has been the demand from all sections of the country for details of the Venzke-Cunningham duel in the Columbian Mile at the Knights of Columbus games at the Garden tomorrow night that Casey officials have rearranged their program in order to permit a nation-wide radio broadcast of the event.

New York City disposed of $186,860 of its new baby bonds yesterday on the first day of their sale to taxpayers. Most of the sales were to residents of Manhattan. William Reid Jr., city collector, said the results indicated that the bonds would be popular with the public.

Following the publication of the report of the committee investigating The Columbia Spectator, the managing board of the Columbia student daily took immediate action yesterday by unanimously passing three amendments to the constitution of the newspaper.

LOS ANGELES, Cal., March 13. -- Tumbled out of their beds at 5:15 o'clock this morning by another temblor, the most violent yet experienced since the major earthquake that uprooted Southern California Friday, the Giants' training preparations once more were thrown into considerable confusion today.

WASHINGTON, March 13. -- Members of House committees were named today, the Democrats voting their selections in caucus and the Republican leaders fixing in conference, a partial list for their representation.

For all ordinary banking functions, the banks in New York City and in other Federal Reserve centres were reopened yesterday. The restrictions were to a large extent removed and business was conducted on almost a normal basis, here and elsewhere.

LONG BEACH, Cal., March 13 (AP). -- A blockade of the earthquake-ridden Long Beach area was set up today by the police to prevent outsiders from streaming into the city. More earth shocks, one of them a sharp convulsion, again shook the city and the authorities clamped down a drastic order to "keep out."

RAIFORD, Fla., March 13 (AP). -- Heavily guarded by a squad of National Guard machine-gunners, Joseph Zangara, the assassin who shot five persons in an attempt to kill President Roosevelt Feb. 15, awaits the electric chair here for the murder of Mayor Anton J. Cermak of Chicago.

WASHINGTON, March 13. -- President Roosevelt, refusing to listen to Senate opposition to his economy bill, insisted today that the legislation was required to balance the budget and lighten the people's burden of taxation.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 13. -- Colonel Jacob Ruppert, owner of the Yankees, and Babe Ruth had their long-awaited conference today and advanced no further than owner and player were when Ruth returned his contract in January, rejecting a $25,000 cut in salary.
Banks up-State and in New York Federal Reserve District, outside city, opening today, Page 3. New York enjoyed regular banking facilities yesterday, and was glad to get them.
WASHINGTON, March 13. -- Plans to have 200,000 to 300,000 of the unemployed put to work on great development projects under the administration relief bill were nearing completion today.

The Harriman National Bank and Trust Company of 527 Fifth Avenue was placed under a conservator yesterday in advance of the hour when most of the other banks of the city reopened and its doors remained closed during the day to all customers, save those of its safe deposit department.
To the Editor of The New York Times: "Though I speak with the tongues of men and of angels, and have not charity, I am become as sounding brass, or a tinkling cymbal."
WASHINGTON, March 13 (AP). -- What effect today's decision would have on the future of the Davis-Kelly coal stabilization bill was a question raised in coal circles.

VAN RHYN'S DORP, South Africa, March 13 (Canadian Press). -- Victor Smith, 19-year-old South African flier, has failed in his third attempt to wrest the London-to-Cape Town flight record from Mrs. Amy Johnson Mollison after he had traveled 6,045 of the 6,200 miles of the hazardous transoceanic and transcontinental journey.

If one has ever wondered vaguely about the many magazines brightening the news stands week in and week out, he may find the answer to a part of the puzzle in a lively little periodical called Writer's Digest. Writers and people who wish they were writers can find all kinds of encouragement in its pages.

The Department of Commerce publishes today its annual review of foreign tariffs and commercial policies. Summarizing events which occurred in 1932, the main theme is a costly tariff war in all parts of the world. More than half of the sixty-five commercially important nations increased their restrictions on international trade last year.

VATICAN CITY, March 13. -- Pope Pius at today's secret consistory delivered a strong allocution in which he reviewed the principal world events of the last two and one-half years with more than customary outspokenness and vigor.

HOLLYWOOD, Cal., March 13 (AP). -- The film industry's doors will open tomorrow after a one-day holiday. Resumption of work was made possible through a new salary-reduction agreement effected tonight. Under it the high-salaried contract employes will bear the brunt of the reduction, but for minor employes there will be no wage cut.

While banking conditions were beginning to clear yesterday, produce and meat markets settled down to conditions more nearly normal, and prices held steady, with one or two exceptions in the meat market, according to reports made to Jere F. Ryan, Commissioner of the Department of Public Markets, by Joseph A. Dunn, director of statistics.
WASHINGTON, March 13. -- Additional regulations issued today by Secretary Woodin through the Treasury Department and interpretations of earlier regulations were as follows:

The International Nickel Company of Canada, Ltd., reports for 1932 a net loss of $135,344 after all charges and taxes, including reserves for depreciation and mine depletion. This contrasts with a net income of $4,752,135 in 1931, after all charges and reserves and adjustments to cover losses on foreign exchange equal, after preferred dividend requirements, to 22 cents a share on the 14,584,025 common shares outstanding.

Metropolitan missionaries of the United Lutheran Synod of New York discussed the current financial limitations of church administration yesterday at their fifth semi-annual conference in St. Paul's Slovak Evangelical Lutheran Church, 1,410 Vyse Avenue, the Bronx.
Twenty-five candidates composed the New York University football squad which reported for the opening of Spring practice yesterday. At least twenty-five more are expected to attend today's session.

A plan for guaranteeing bank deposits through a nation-wide mutual insurance organization in which all banks would participate has been evolved by Herbert J. Tily, president of Strawbridge Clothier of Philadelphia, and Daniel Badger, a partner of Ernst Ernst, Philadelphia brokers.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Assemblyman Breitbart's bills, as expounded, by himself in a letter to THE TIMES, would raise the cost of mortgage money to home-owners and would insure the ruin of those owners when mortgages are foreclosed on them.

Eight scientific, religious and educational institutions receive bequests totaling more than $50,000, and three of them share in three-fourths of the residue of undetermined value, under the will of Miss Orrie I. Minasian of Brooklyn, who died Jan. 29 at Berneck, Switzerland.
PHILADELPHIA, March 13. -- The following member banks of the Federal Reserve System resumed business today:...

VIENNA, March 13. -- The Dollfuss Cabinet, whose alleged intention of anticipating Hitlerism by itself establishing a semi-dictatorship and suppressing Communism has kept Austria in a state of extreme nervousness for the past five days, apparently has decided to confine itself to the latter part of this program.

The annual Golden Gloves boxing tournament, New York's outstanding amateur extravaganza, came to a close at Madison Square Garden last night when final bouts in all classes from the flyweight to the heavyweight were conducted.

MEXICO CITY, March 14. -- Forty or more men, women and children lost their lives in a motion-picture theatre Sunday night in the small town of Ahualulco, State of Jalisco. as a result of a high-tension cable breaking.

Trading in the dollar in the foreign exchange market was almost normal yesterday. After its impressive rally against a trapped international short interest when trading was reopened on Monday, the exchange eased off quietly yesterday, but it continued to hold above the levels at which it had sold just prior to the holiday.

LIMA, Peru, March 14 -- The Cajamarca rebellion has been suppressed, according to government announcements, and its leader, former provisional president, Lieut. Col. Gustayo Jimenez has committed suicide.

MIAMI, Fla., March 14. -- The 6-year-old High Time mare Supreme Sweet won her first victory since last August when she captured the featured race at Tropical Park today. At the end of the five and a half furlongs the Superior Stable flyer was a length befora E.C. Grogan's Wise Count, with My Purchase third, three-quarters of a length back of the placed horse.

Business will be resumed in all the markets this morning. The Stock Exchange, the New York Curb and the principal Commodity Exchanges will start operations as usual after a prolonged holiday. It had been expected that the reopen ing would be delayed another day.

HARRISBURG, Pa., March 14. -- Dashing the hopes of those who had predicted Sunday baseball next Summer in Pennsylvania, the State Senate in a surprising action today defeated by a vote of 26 to 24 the Schwartz bill providing for modification of the blue laws of 1794.

Joseph W. Harriman, chairman of the board of the Harriman National Bank and Trust Company, which was placed under a conservator on Monday, was arrested late yesterday in his bed at his home, 2 East Seventieth Street.

CHICAGO, March 14 -- Trading In cash grain and futures will be resumed on the Chicago Board of Trade on Thursday, while transactions in the securities department will start tomorrow morning, it was announced today by F.C. Clutton, secretary.

A full day of play on the courts of the Junior League of New York yesterday carried the field of the women's annual invitation squash racquets tournament of the club through the first round and a part of the second with all four seeded players reaching the third round.

WASHINGTON, March 14 (AP) -- Cotton consumed during February was reported by the Census Bureau today to have totaled 441,663 bales of lint and 46.470 of linters, compared with 471.202 and 48.412 for January this year, and 451,239 and 54.241 for February last year.

GENEVA, March 14 -- Prime Minister MacDonald of Great Britain spent most of today trying to evolve a plan to save the Disarmament Conference, based on information he has copiously received from all sides in the past few days. Baron Pompeo Aloisi of Italy and Foreign Minister Benes of Czechoslovakia were among his few callers today.

DETROIT, March 14 -- The two Federal conservators who took over the affairs of the First National Bank-Detroit and the Guardian National made their first act a general discharge of all officers of both institutions above the grade of assistant cashier.
To the Editor of The New York Times: Anent your editorial concerning Dr. George David Stewart, in which you quote what he said to me concerning prayer, may I add an item or two?

Benjamin Winter, one of the largest and most active real estate operators during the boom days in Manhattan who came back in the market about ten days ago with a big purchase in the Bronx, closed a second deal yesterday. This was for the Hotel Hermitage in Seventh Avenue adjoining the southwest corner of Forty-second Street.
WASHINGTON, March 14 (AP) -- The Senate today voted to help California meet her earthquake relief needs and adopted and sent to the House a resolution providing for a $5,000,000 Federal fund.

Lightning may not strike twice in the same spot, but you couldn't get Jack Pitman of New York, young Yale graduate, to believe it after his experience yesterday in the national indoor tennis championship at the Seventh Regiment Armory, Park Avenue and Sixty-sixth Street.

The refocusing of public opinion on the importance of municipal charter revision, was urged last night by Samuel Seabury in an address before 200 members and guests of the Women's City Club of New York, 22 Park Avenue.

George Stockton Boudinot, who was secretary of the National Association of Manufacturers from 1907 to 1928 and thereafter secretary emeritus, died yesterday morning at his home, 225 West Eightieth Street, in his seventy-eighth year.

PRINCETON, N.J., March 14 -- Joseph T. Lambie of Washington, Pa., a member of the junior class, has been elected chairman of the board of directors of the Student-Faculty Association of Princeton University, it was announced today. Fifteen members of the faculty and administration department and twenty undergraduates have been elected to the board.

Colonel GREENE, State Superintendent of Public Works, has a way of saying what he thinks and often acting accordingly, which is highly disconcerting to the politicians. Not many moons ago he wrote a letter to THE TIMES calmly asserting that practically no applicants for responsible posts who came to him with political endorsements proved more than 30 per cent efficient.
WASHINGTON, March 14. -- The government's first order for new currency to meet the national shortage was $2,000,000,000.

The sixth and final concert In the second Philharmonic-Symphony Society series for children and young people will take place Saturday morning at Carnegie Hall, with Ernest Schelling conducting. Medals and ribbons will be awarded to ! the children who submitted the best notebooks of the season.

More than 80 per cent of the camera specialty shops in the metropolitan area have been looted in the last six months, some two and three times, dealers declared yesterday, after police reported that they had failed by a narrow margin last Sunday to catch three men attempting to rob Willoughby's Camera Store at 110 West Thirty-second Street.

The importance of the "new deal" in the administration of veterans' relief cannot be fully appreciated merely by considering its effect on the budget for the next fiscal year. Here it would save an estimated $400,000,000, or more than one-eighth of the entire current expenditures of the Government.

BERLIN, March 14. -- The French Ambassador, Andre Francois-Poncet, called at the foreign Office this afternoon to submit the protest of the French Government against the organization of an auxiliary German, police within the zone which, under Article 43 of the Versailles treaty, is to be kept free of military units of any kind.

LONDON, March 14 -- It is now regarded as probable by London officials that Prime Minister MacDonald will talk with Premier Mussolini in the near future. No definite arrangement has been made yet, but if their meeting takes place, it will most likely be in some town in northern Italy.

WASHINGTON, March 14 (AP). -- The New York State delegation poured in the bulk of its votes to swell the deluge that swept the beer bill through the House today. The delegation stood twenty-nine Democrats and eight Republicans for and six Republicans against.

A tariff policy of "common sense" and of "common decency" to other nations is the aim of the Roosevelt administration, Daniel C. Roper, Secretary of Commerce, declared last night in a radio broadcast over a National Broadcasting Company network.

PARIS, March 14. -- The French Ambassador in Berlin, Andre Francois-Poncet, protested today to the German Government against the recent occupation of Kehl by Nazi storm detachments. According to Berlin reports, he was curtly treated.
Small dwellings constituted yesterday's reported turnover in the New Jersey realty market.

Faster air passenger travel for European airlines than they have ever known before will be available this Summer on the main routes of the Deutsche Lufthansa which network Germany and connect with the Continental lines, according to official figures on a new transport airplane made public here yesterday by the representative of Dr. Ernst Heinkel's aircraft works at Warnemunde.

Luck and Skill. Political technologists are full 'of admiration' for Mr. ROOSEVELT'S tactical genius This was revealed in his coupling budget economy with beer reform. But another thing that does not hurt the President's economy program is the advent of March 15, which is income tax day.

Some of the most noted bass, trout and perch streams in this country are located in Pennsylvania, a State that long has set a fast pace in the work of stocking streams and lakes. Every year thousand of fresh-water fishermen visit the Keystone State, while it is estimated that close to 600,000 citizens enjoy angling during every season.

The New York State Athletic Commission at a meeting yesterday approved the world's heavyweight boxing championship bout between Jack Sharkey and Primo Carnera, which the Madison Square Garden Corporation plans to promote this Spring or Summer.

The autobiography of Lord Baden-Powell. founder of the Boy Scout and Girl Guide movement, is published today by Henry Holt under the title, "Lessons of a Lifetime." The larger part of the book describes the author's experiences as a British officer in far places of the British Empire.

The $10,000,000 commitment of the Delaware Hudson Company in New York Central stock, engineered last Summer by L.F. Loree, president of the D.H., has failed to win him the position that he desired on the board of directors of the New York Central Railroad, it was disclosed yesterday.

George Grosz, the well-known German artist, now established as a teacher in New York, is holding two exhibitions here. He is appearing -- until April 1 -- as a guest artist in the gallery of An American Group at the Barbizon-Plaza, and the Raymond Raymond Gallery, 40 East Forty-ninth Street, has installed a group of drawings and lithographs, which will remain on view until April 8.

Tuesday, March 14, 1933. Opening of the money post on the Stock Exchange, the first day's trading since the holiday went into effect on March 4 brought a rate of 5 per cent for renewals and new funds. This rate compares with 4, as of March 3, and is the highest for standing loans since Jan. 6. 1930.

As banks under the jurisdiction of the State Banking Department are permitted to reopen for business, a similar privilege, with a restriction as to limitation of payments to shareholders, is granted in the same localities by Superintendent of Banks Joseph A. Broderick to savings and loan associations, which also are under his supervision.

ALBANY, March 14. -- The Wald mandatory minimum wage bill was reported favorably by the labor and industry committee of the Senate today, and indications are that the Democratic majority in the upper house intends to pass both this measure and the minimum wage bill introduced by Senator Dunnigan.

WASHINGTON, March 14 -- The Roosevelt administration is planning to support moves in the World Monetary and Economic Conference for a system of regulating the production and export of wheat by agreements among the exporting nations.
The Ottawa Senators, proving more obstinate than expected, held the New York Rangers to a 3-to-3 tie in their National Hockey League game at Madison Square Garden last night.

Deposits exceeded withdrawals by a large ratio in New York banks yesterday, a survey of some of the chief institutions showed. Banking as a whole was completely normal, except that the volume of business was much greater than on average days, and the queues in front of receiving tellers' windows were far longer than usual.

LONDON, March 14. -- The British Government is determined to take what is officially described as "a firm line" with Soviet Russia over the arrests of six British subjects working in Russia for the Metropolitan-Vickers Company.
