Moving in concert with the program of progressive bank reopenings, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York expanded its operations yesterday to include check clearings and wire transfers of funds among the 250 clearing house cities in which member banks had been licensed to reopen.

LOS ANGELES, Cal., March 14. -- A brilliant four-inning pitching effort by the left-handed Cart Hubbell and some cooperative slugging by the Jayvee squad gave the Giants a 9-to-7 victory over the Cubs today in the concluding game of the exhibition series between these two teams.

LONDON, March 14 -- The dollar fluctuated sharply in the foreign exchange market here today. Opening at $3.39, the rate moved in favor of London, rising to $3.44, subsequently reacting, but closing at $3.44 3/4.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., March 14 -- A legal tilt in the battle to free nine Negroes, once condemned to death for an alleged attack on two white girls, is expected tomorrow when Samuel Leibowitz of New York, chief of defense counsel, demands the right to interview privately the eight defendants confined in the death house of Kilby prison.

With the consent of Charles D. Hilles and Adolph Zukor, receivers in equity for the Paramount Publix Corporation, Federal Judge William Bondy yesterday permitted Ralph W. Kuhn, treasurer of the corporation, to file a petition in bankruptcy for the concern.

Banks continued yesterday to reopen as financial confidence was restored. The resumption was on such a broad scale that business was almost on a normal basis. The security and commodity markets will start operating this morning, with the exception of the Chicago Board of Trade and the New York Cotton Exchange.

ALBANY, March 14 -- Friends and foes of vivisection clashed today before the Assembly Codes Committee at a hearing on the bill of Assemblyman William L. Vaughan, Democrat, of Richmond, which would prohibit experiments on living dogs.

The first theatre closings growing out "of the wage dispute between the League of New York Theatres and the stagehands' and musicians' unions, occurred last night. The scheduled performance of "Music In the Air" at the Alvin Theatre was canceled, and "Twentieth Century," at the Broadhurst, closed after last night's show.

NEW YORK. Mrs. George T. Maxwell and her daughter-in-law, Mrs. George Lascelles Maxwell, who are returning from Paris, will give a reception on the afternoon of March 23 at 14 East Seventy-seventh Street.
Back In New York for the first time since her husband's inauguration, Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt reported yesterday there was "nothing tiring" about life in Washington.

CHICAGO, March 14 -- Alderman Frank J. Corr, a native of Brook lyn, N.Y., was elected Mayor pro tern of Chicago tonight by the City Council, to serve until the post of the late Mayor Anton Cermak is filled by popular election in the Summer or Fail.

NEWARK, N.J., March 14 -- Banks here reopened quietly this morning, but with an unprecedented rush of deposits, compared with which, withdrawals were very small. The reports at all banks were that deposits were many times the amount on a usual business day, while withdrawals were about normal.

The United States Freight Company, which operates freight containers and does a consolidating and forwarding business on the New York Central Railroad, reported a profit of $127,523, of 43 cents a share on capital stock in 1932, against $339.840. or $1.13 a share in 1931. Gross operating income was $24,096,149, against $25,779,105.

The new customs squad formed on Monday to watch outgoing liners for illegal shipments of gold instituted their search last night before the departure of the North German Lloyd liner Bremen for Cherbourg, Southampton and Bremen.
WASHINGTON, March 14 -- The vote on the passage of the Cullen beer bill in the House today was as follows:

With quantities of produce glutting the New York market, wholesale prices began dropping again yesterday and moderate recessions were registered as well in the wholesale meat, butter and egg markets. Conditions were variable in other commodity markets and price changes were narrow.

Liquidations of Manhattan and Bronx properties were continued at foreclosure sales held by auctioneers yesterday. Although small dwellings and tenements provided the bulk of forced sales, there was some variety in the type of offerings. A tall upper west side apartment house and a thirteen-story office building in Forty-second Street were among the properties sold.

TRENTON, N.J., March 14. -- The members of the Republican majority in the Senate voted 11 to 2 in caucus today to support the resolution of Senate President Emerson L. Richards for a State convention of 226 delegates to act on ratification of repeal of national prohibition.

Further delay in the resumption of transit unification conferences, which were dropped eight months ago, will inevitably result in a fare of at least 10 cents on all rapid transit lines, Aldermanic President Joseph V. McKee declared yesterday in a letter calling upon the Transit Commission to resume at once its meetings with the Board of Estimate.

WASHINGTON, March 14. -- Another step to assure an orderly resumption of banking facilities throughout the nation was taken today when the Robinson bill to amend the emergency banking legislation by permitting State banks not members of the Federal Reserve System to apply directly to the Federal Reserve Banks for advances was passed by the Senate.

The closing of schools of nursing in "very nearly all hospitals having less than fifty patients, many hospitals with less than 100 patients, and at least a good many hospitals with more than 100 patients," is advised by the Committee on the Grading of Nursing Schools, which today will begin the release of the early findings of its second grading of 1,383 accredited schools of nursing.

Bach and Brahms appear to have become not only staples of the orchestral repertory, but composers whose works can be termed popular and effective. The works of Bach survive everything, even transcriptions.

"Marilyn's Affairs," a play by Arthur Ebenhack which was formerly tried out at the Sutton Theatre under the title of "Cinderella's Brothers," will have its Broadway premiere this evening at the Mansfield Theatre. There will also be a "revival" of the David Gray-Avery Hopwood comedy, "The Best People," at the Waldorf.

WASHINGTON, March 14 -- The Socialist program for publicly owned banks and a bond issue of $12,000,000,000, half of which would be devoted, to public works and the remainder to allowance for the unemployed, was presented to President Roosevelt today by Norman Thomas, the Socialist candidate for President in 1932, and Morris Hillquit, national chairman of the Socialist party.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., March 14 -- The first organized practice in Yale's Spring football campaign was held today when Coach Reggie Root sent seventy-five candidates through a preliminary drill which., included limbering up, running, blocking, group work and a few fundamentals.

New York City will receive $27,000,000 today from member banks of the New York Clearing House Association to meet its short-term maturities of that amount, and an additional loan, today or in a few days, of $6,000,000 for welfare relief, according to plans virtually but not finally completed yesterday.

PARIS, March 14 -- Taking advantage of changes in French opinion caused by President Roosevelt's tactful handling of the debt situation and the American financial situation, the French Government, it is being said here, will shortly pay out of the treasury account the half-year debt instalment of $19,000,000, payment of which was suspended by a vote of the Chamber of Deputies last December.
WASHINGTON, March 14. -- The text of the Cullen beer bill as passed by the House today was as follows:

ALBANY, March 14 -- The conviction of Bernard K. Marcus, president, and Saul Singer, vice president, of the Bank of United States, sentenced to from three to six years for misapplying funds of the Municipal Safe Deposit Company in New York City, was upheld by the Court of Appeals today.

MIAMI, Fla., March 14. -- Grinning happily, the stocky Lewis Robert Wilson, known to all baseball fans as Hack, entered into today's exercises at Miami Field with a new fervor. For last night he found a basis for agreement on salary terms with Vice President Joe Gilleaudeau and today formally affixed his signature to a contract.

Confidence that the theatre will survive the present economic crisis and emerge "with a newly-recovered dignity" was expressed yesterday by Marc Connelly, play-wright and director, in an address before the graduating class of the American Academy of Dramatic Arts at exercises held in the Lyceum Theatre.

Appealing on behalf of 15,000 unemployed found to be worthy of assistance by the Emergency Unemployment Relief Committee, Harvey D. Gibson, chairman, from Station WEAF last night, urged support of the women's division of the committee and its adopt-a-family movement.
PALM BEACH, Fla., March 14 -- Theodore Clarence Hollander gave an informal tea for twenty guests on the terrace of Villa Muriel.

A youth with a dollar bill clutched in his right hand, who kept jumping up and down as each new lot was announced, furnished amusement yesterday morning to a crowd gathered in the Police Department's garage at the foot of West Thirty-sixth Street, Brooklyn, for the public auction of the department's unclaimed and unwanted property.

CLARKSVILLE, Tenn., March 14 (AP) -- Arrested more than a month after their extradition to North Carolina was ordered, Colonel Luke Lea, Nashville publisher, and his son, Luke Lea Jr., were placed in jail here today pending a habeas corpus hearing Monday.

Efforts to amend the national bankruptcy act so as to permit a municipality unable to meet its obligations to institute a special and limited composition proceeding in the Federal court, whereby a settlement plan assented to by 75 per cent of its creditors would bind all creditors, are expected to be made at the present special session of Congress, according to groups of bondholders, including insurance companies, trustees and savings banks and municipal bankers.

The "United States Government began suit yesterday in Federal court to recover $18,600 which Thomas O'Connell, property clerk at Police Headquarters, surrendered last October, on the advice of the Corporation Counsel, to Lawrence Carney, at a time when a Federal lien was outstanding against this sum.

Isaac Roosevelt, great - great - grandfather of President Franklin D. Roosevelt, exactly 149 years ago today met other prominent merchants of the time to elect a president, a cashier and twelve directors of the Bank of New York, which was then in process of formation.

ALBANY, Maroh 14 -- More than 2,000 dairy farmers of the State converged upon the Capitol today to urge immediate enactment of legislation to save them from a disaster that they said was hanging over them.

Ernest A. Ash, prominent Brooklyn pianist and president of the Associated Music Teachers League, was found dead last night in his automobile in the Concourse Parking Space just inside the Ocean Avenue entrance to Prospect Park. Investigation disclosed that he had swallowed a quantity of poison.

Pointing out that the rate of operations of the company's plants was the lowest ever recorded, Myron C. Taylor, chairman of the United States Steel Corporation, in his report to stockholders for 1932 states that "the depression in industry which has prevailed has intensified activities in securing closer coordination and consolidation of operations, with resulting economies which should be reflected in relatively more satisfactory net income results upon improvement in business."

To the Editor of The New York Times: In the confusion which exists as to whether or not we are off the gold basis, the extremes may be covered by the decision of the government to issue its notes payable in gold of the present standard, and the fact that like Great Britain when forced off gold the government simply refused to pay out gold.

Regulations to permit those insurance companies under the jurisdiction of the State Insurance Department which have been affected by the banking holiday to resume business are being prepared by George S. Van Schaick, Superintendent of Insurance, who said yesterday he could not make any announcement as to the time when the regulations would be adopted.

WASHINGTON, March 14 -- The text of the statement given out today by the State Department relative to its acceptance of the invitation of the League of Nations to participate in the deliberations of its advisory committee on Manchuria is as follows:
F. Darcy Cooper, chairman of Lever Brothers, Ltd., is arriving today on the Cunarder Aquitania for a business visit. Also aboard are:

CHICAGO. March 14 -- Three major problems confront humanity today, Professor Albert Einstein said today in a luncheon address at the Standard Club, where many distinguished men and women gathered to honor him on his fifty-fourth birthday.

First reports on the recanvass of the vote cast for Joseph V. McKee for Mayor at the November election, as announced by the Board of Elections, showed that in eight Assembly districts in Manhattan, Brooklyn and the Bronx, complete save for one election district, the McKee vote totaled 9,956 instead of 8,693, as first reported.

BERLIN, March 14. -- A Nazi raid upon the apartment of the widow of President Friedrich Ebert, which, it is learned, took place Sunday, led today to the personal intervention of President von Hindenburg. The President ordered a thorough investigation, the results of which are to be reported to him.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., March 14 -- James Truslow Adams, historian, will say in the Spring number of The Yale Review tomorrow that if the Democratic party does not make the best of its present opportunity to become the liberal party of the United States, a reorganization of the country's constitutional and political machinery will take place, possibly by mass force, instead of deliberation and planning.

Nominations of two Columbia College students, Frederick H. Burkhardt of Glendale, L.I., and Gram C. Lovejoy of New York, as the Euretta J. Kellett fellows at Oxford and Cambridge, respectively, were announced yesterday by Uean Herbert E. Hawkes of Columbia College.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 14. -- Mr. William B. McKechnie paused beneath the shade of a sheltering palm to discuss certain matters touching on and appertaining to baseball as the Boston Braves hope to play it this season. Tampa Bay was sparkling in the offing, sea gulls were flying overhead. Players in uniforms were galloping hither and yon over the greensward at Waterfront Park.

While thousands of small income-tax payers jammed the offices of Collectors of Internal Revenue here yesterday making largely cash payments, the collectors hailed with satisfaction the announcement that the Bureau of Internal Revenue, on instructions from the Treasury Department, had extended to March 31 the limit for filing income-tax returns.

Subsidiaries of the Commonwealth and Southern Corporation in Illinois are to be combined into a single corporation, excepting the street railway properties in the area, according to an announcement at the annual meeting of stockholders of the Central Illinois Light Company on March 23.

The decision of the Interstate Commerce Commission on Monday, granting an extension to Sept. 30 of the freight surcharges that would have expired, March 31, leaves it optional with the railroads whether the proceeds of the imposts shall be pooled for the benefit of weaker railroads, Thomas P. Healy, associate general counsel of the New York Central, said yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 14 -- The understanding here is that Dr. Friedrich W. von Prittwitz, German Ambassador to the United States, in conformity with diplomatic usage in many countries, including the United States, when there has been a fundamental change in the government, has tendered his resignation to the German Foreign Office to give the Hitler regime an opportunity to replace him, if it so desires.

BALTIMORE, March 14 -- Baltimore, border city of the South, experienced an extraordinary event tonight when the Metropolitan Opera Company presented Gruenberg's "The Emperor Jones" at the Lyric Theatre here. At its conclusion Lawrence Tibbett, American baritone, in title role, received an ovation which, it was said, eclipsed the applause which greeted the great tenor, Enrico Caruso, when he sang here years ago.
NIAGARA FALLS, N.Y., March 14 (A.P) -- White newsprint paper made from Georgia pine trees only seven years old, a revolutionary discovery in paper-making, was announced here tonight.
ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 14. -- The Yankees opened their exhibition series against the Boston Braves at Waterfront Park today with negative results, losing by a score of 4 to 2.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., March 14. -- Announcement was made at Yale today of the election of captains of two varsity teams and one freshman team.

Richmond Hill captured the Queens division championship and rhomas Jefferson High assured itself of at least a chance to play off for the Brooklyn division title as the result of two of the eight games played yesterday in the city P.S. A.L. senior high school championship basketball competition.

A total of 1,779 entries has been received by the Saratoga Racing Association for twenty-four stakes, entries for which closed recently, according to an announcement yesterday by Racing Secretary Victor Schaumburg. The nominations, made in 109 separate interests, include practically all of the best known thoroughbreds which have raced in recent seasons.

Prices, of United States Government obligations rose sharply yesterday in the over-the-counter market as actual business was done, in contrast to the strictly nominal market on the previous day. The long-term Liberty loans and Treasury issues were up 24-32 point to 3 points above Monday's final bid and asked quotations, which in turn were up 2-32 to 26-32 from the last previous quotations, on March 4.

To the Editor of The New York Times: As a practically penniless, unemployed veteran of some eighteen years' service, over a year of which was spent with combatant units in France prior to the armistice, I, along with thousands of real veterans, spent what represents two days' food to telegraph the President my endorsement of his economy program respecting veterans.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Referring back to a lengthy article that appeared in THE TIMES last May, entitled "Lists Twelve Ways to End City's Din," it seems that street noises are increasing. The efforts of the Noise Abatement Commission thus far are not very apparent.
ALBANY, March 14. -- Bills to revise State control over two sports -- racing and boxing -- were introduced in the Legislature today.

BERLIN, March 14 -- Yesterday's spurt in the stock market grave place to reaction at today's session of the Boerse. The movements, however, were rather confused. While most of the active stocks suffered declines, some held their own, and others, including the potashes and Rheinbraunkohle, even bettered yesterday's closing quotations.

The career of Sir HENRY THORNTON, whose death in this city yesterday we much regret to record, was sufficient evidence that the Age of Romance has not forever gone. His varied executive positions and achievements in the railroad world constituted one of the marvels of his generation.

LONDON, March 14 -- J. H. Morgan, an authority on international law, in a letter to The London Times makes a stinging retort to David Lloyd George, Liberal leader, who in Sheffield yesterday, Mr. Morgan says, "went out of his way to fan the rising flame of militarism in Germany by imputing deliberate hypocrisy and equally deliberate animus against Germany to MacDonald, Simon and the whole British Government."

Those grave antiquarians, the Messrs. Wee and Leventhal -- whose degrees have been strung out in a neat line through the season -- last night brought forth the Daniel N. Rubin mystery, "Riddle Me This." They mounted it, as the saying goes, with a suitable flourish and on the boards of the Hudson Theatre.

An issue of $250,000 of bankruptcy trustee certificates sold last June to finance the search, for assets of Ivar Kreuger's bankrupt International Match Corporation, was called in yesterday and paid off by the Irving Trust Company, as official trustee in the bankruptcy.

BERLIN, March 14 -- Musical circles in Germany are acutely feeling repercussions of recent political developments. Opera houses, which are State or municipal institutions, have been increasingly subjected to pressure with respect to their administrative staffs and artistic personnel, and rumors point to even more extensive changes.

ALBANY, March 14 -- Spurred by passage of the Cullen beer bill in the national House, leaders in the Legislature renewed efforts today to complete bills for setting up of machinery for regulation and control of the manufacture and sale of beer in the State.
Commercial Paper Yesterday -- No trading. Friday, March 3 (last trading day) -- 3 per cent for the best names.

With the program embellished by a brilliant series of return meetings in every important event on the list, the Knights of Columbus will stage their fourteenth annual indoor track and field games at Madison Square Garden tonight. A crowd of 16,000 is expected to watch the track season brought to a spectacular finale as all the flaming rivalries of a complete campaign reach a climax.

To the Editor of The New York Times: There appeared in "Letters to the Editor" a communication which illustrates how much a good motive can be misunderstood, and how difficult the problems of this crisis are of understanding.

WASHINGTON, March 14 -- Faced with a series of amendments which threatened to endanger essential features of President Roosevelt's $500,000,000 economy bill, supporters of the measure agreed to a recess at 10:20 o'clock tonight after a day spent in debate, sometimes of a bitter character.

BERLIN, March 14 -- With the exception of sporadic flare-ups in various parts of the country, the Hitler-von Papen government may now be said to be in control of the physical facts of the situation. It is turning to some of the immediate political and parliamentary implications imposed by the outcome of the recent elections, especially in so far as they concern next week's convocations of the new Reichstag and Prussian Diet.

WILKES-BARRE, Pa., March 14. -- An appeal that those within and without the ranks of organized labor join to raise again the standard of living as a move toward recovery was made in an address at a banquet here tonight under the auspices of the Wilkes-Barre Central Labor Union by William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor.

WASHINGTON, March 14 -- The Cullen bill, providing beer of 3.2 per cent of alcoholic content by weight, went through the House today by an overwhelming vote of 316 to 97. the day on which bock beer formally made its appearance in the days when saloons were saloons and put on their swinging doors.

Judge Corrigan of General Sessions and the jury in the second-degree manslaughter trial of Michael Favaloro, 26 years old, a taxicab driver, at noone yesterday visited the East River at Twenty-third Street, where on the night of July 26, 1931, Favaloro drove his taxicab, with seven passengers, into the water, causing the deaths of four.

WASHINGTON, March 14 -- Direct Federal expenditures for unemployment relief, aggregating $2,000,000,000 above all money authorized for loans by the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, are projected in the Democratic relief program now being put into final form.

Following the adoption yesterday by the Board of Aldermen of a resolution pledging its "whole-hearted loyal support and unflinching cooperation" to President Rooseveit and Governor Lehman, Alderman Joseph Clark Baldwin denounced the measure as an exhibition of "petty politics."

The State Department has invented a new phrase to define the relation of the United States to the League of Nations. Invited to take part in the coming conferences respecting the Far East, our Government has accepted. But this time it is not to have an "unofficial spokesman" or an "observer" at Geneva.

TIENTSIN, March 14 -- General Yu Shueh-chung, the military governor of Hopei Province and commandant of the Tientsin area, declared today the utter impossibility of Chinese compliance with the terms which Lieut. Gen. Kotaro Nakamura yesterday announced as essential to avoid a Japanese incursion into North China.

The French Government will sponsor a campaign this Summer to develop tourist traffic between the United States and France and will send a representative to the United States to obtain information for its drive, according to Henri Morin de Linclays, general secretary of the French Line. M. de Linclays arrived in New Tork Monday night on the liner Bremen and will spend about two months studying the traffic situation of the French Line.

BOSTON, March 14 (AP) -- After violently protesting an overtime goal scored by the Boston Bruins, Manager Tommy German withdrew his Chicago Black Hawks tonight and automatically forfeited one of the wildest games ever played in the National

Mayor John P. O'Brien, guest speaker last night at the annual installation of officers of the Grand Street Boys' Association. 108 West Fifty-fifth Street, moved an audience of more than 800 men and women to enthusiastic applause with high praise for President Roosevelt.

Metropolitan-Vickers employes is closely connected with a decree issued by G.K. Ordjonikidze, Commissar for Heavy Industry, on Feb. 24, designed to prevent an outflow of foreign currency by curtailing Soviet imports by 21,000,000 gold rubles.

Colonel Ralph Heyward Isham, British war hero and owner of the largest collection of the writings of James Boswell, has been sued for separation by his second wife, Mrs. Margaret Hurt Isham, on the ground of cruelty and abandonment. The suit was disclosed yesterday when Mrs. Isham applied for $2,000 a month alimony and $15,000 counsel fees for her attorney, Richard A. Knight, pending the trial of the suit.

WASHINGTON, March 14 -- Laden with, specimens of weird animal forms, many of which spent their lives in the total darkness of ocean depths hundreds of fathoms below the furthest penetration of light, the yacht Caroline docked at the navy yard today with the Johnson-Smithsonian Deep-Sea Expedition.

A plea to bring the question of war debts "back within the bounds of reality" is made by Dr. Dorsey Richardson in "Will They Pay?" a brief "primer of the War Debts" published by Lippincott. Dr. Richardson's answer to the question in his title is that foreign governments will not pay their war debts to this country under present funding arrangements and that the United States cannot force payment.

WASHINGTON, March 14 (AP). -- Bishop James Cannon Jr. sat in the Supreme Court today and heard counsel arguing questions arising out of his indictment alleging violation of the criminal practice act by failing to report contributions received by his organization.
WASHINGTON, March 14 -- Plans for dealing with gold hoarders were given particular attention by Secretary of the Treasury Woodin today.

Although most of this city's exchanges will be reopened today, the board of managers of the New York Cotton Exchange decided yesterday to await the reopening of country banks, scheduled for today, and therefore postponed the resumption of cotton trading until tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, March 14 -- While approving "in a general way" the emergency farm relief program submitted to him by the leaders of national agricultural associations, President Roosevelt is not entirely satisfied with it and has suggested some changes, Secretary Wallace of the Department of Agriculture announced today.

After clashing yesterday with Deputy Controller Frank J. Prial over the proposal to extend the west side express highway, Joseph V. McKee, president of the Board of Aldermen, gained his point when the committee of the whole of the Board of Estimate approved an appropriation of $1,184,878 for the work.

One hundred and thirty-seven producers of bituminous coal in Kentucky, Tennessee, Virginia and West Virginia founded Appalachian Coals, Inc., as a selling agency. The demoralization of their industry was notorious. Their cooperative object was to enlarge sales and production, make marketing cheaper and wipe out injurious trade practices.

GENEVA, March 14. -- One of the most dangerous questions the Danzig trouble zone has yet produced was quickly and completely settled at a special meeting of the League of Nations Council this morning in a manner which its members agreed strengthened the League's authority at a needed place and time.

Daily average gross crude oil production in the United States last week was 2,115,850 barrels, compared with 2,147,900 in the preceding week, a decrease of 32,050 barrels, the American Petroleum Institute reported yesterday. A decline of 62,600 barrels in the average daily output of Oklahoma, due principally to the shutdown in the Oklahoma City field, and a rise of 19,300 barrels in the Coastal Texas district were the most important changes.
The 85,000 members of the American Legion in New York State will support President Roosevelt's economy program, according to an announcement yesterday by Dr. George W. Lawrence, State commander,

LONG BEACH, Cal., March 14 (AP) -- The earthquake death list was increased to fifty-eight today with reports of two additional victims. Mrs. Dinah Onsum died in the Community Hospital from internal injuries received when she was caught under a shower of falling debris, and Mrs. Amanda E. Herman died at her home following a heart attack attributed to fear.

Senators Royal S. Copeland and Robert F. Wagner were urged to support President Roosevelt's economy bill in a resolution adopted yesterday afternoon at a meeting of the Republican Committee of One Hundred, at the home of Mrs. Malcolm Stuart, 770 Park Avenue.

The Banking Situation. The New York Stock Exchange and most other exchanges throughout the country will reopen today; the New York Cotton Exchange and the Chicago Board of Trade, tomorrow. The closing prices on the Stock Exchange and the Curb on March 3 will be found in the financial pages of this issue.
WASHINGTON, March 14. -- The Bureau of Navigation issued the following orders today, dated March 11:

BERLIN, March 14 -- Although no official announcement has been made by Chancellor Adolf Hitler, The Associated Press was informed by high officials today that the German Government favored holding the Olympic Games in Berlin in 1936.

WASHINGTON, March 14 -- The Roosevelt administration decided today to press for passage of the resolution authorizing the President to declare arms embargoes applicable to any part of the world where war may threaten.

VIENNA, March 14 -- Reports of the torturing of Communist, Socialist, Radical and Jewish Deputies, newspaper men, lawyers and writers are printed daily in the newspapers of Vienna, which has become for Germany as for the Balkan nations an asylum for refugees.
GENEVA, March 14 -- The Advisory Committee of Twenty-one meets tomorrow afternoon and is certain to accept American cooperation on the basis suggested by Secretary Hull.

AUGUST, Ga., March 14 (AP). -- Miss Maureen Orcutt of Englewood, N.J., whose 83 was low in yesterday's qualifying round, won an easy 8 and 7 victory today over Miss Phyllis Shaw of Duluth, Minn., in the first round of the Augusta women's invitation golf tournament.

In an event of such suddenness and importance as the nation-wide moratorium -- followed by legislation restricting gold exports during the emergency and providing for an emergency currency redeemable in " lawful money " -- the probable action of the markets became a matter of high interest.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., March 14. -- Twenty-six persons were killed and more than 200 injured in a tornado that struck first in the Arkansas delta late today and then swept up the Tennessee-Kentucky line tonight. Property damage, estimated at $1,000,000, was especially heavy here, the largest city struck.

LONG BEACH, Cal., March 15 (AP) -- An appeal to the Reconstruction Finance Corporation to sweep aside red tape, send its engineers into the quake-stricken area and begin immediate plans for financing rehabilitation was made by Charles S. Henderson, chairman of the rehabilitation committee, today.

To the Editor of The New York Times: It is amazing to read that the Democratic program at Albany "contemplates balancing the 193334 budget without resort to any of the 'oppressive taxes' recommended by the Governor," only to discover that this is to be effected by levying a 2-per-cent sales tax.

Some of the tragedies attendant upon the discharge of employes of the Emergency Work and Relief Bureau, necessitated by lack of funds, were described last night by William H. Matthews, director of the bureau, at a meeting of the "adopt-a-family" committee at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

The Eastern presidents conference will take action today leading toward acceptance of the Interstate Commerce Commission's decision extending the life of the present freight surcharges but without continuing the pooling feature of the plan under which the surcharges have hitherto been imposed.

The Town Hall was crowded last night when Ossip Gabrilowitsch, pianist, and Albert Spalding, violinist, gave the second recital of their present series of programs of violin and piano sonatas. The pleasure of the audience, on this occasion as at the first concert of the series was manifest.

MIAMI, Fla., March 15. -- Attorneys for Mrs. James J. Walker and her husband, the former Mayor of New York, denied reports today that a settlement of $100,000 had been made and Mrs. Walker's divorce suit would be uncontested.

New York City obtained yesterday the $27,000,000 it required to meet maturing short-term obligations through the sale to a group of member banks of the New York Clearing House Association of 6 per cent corporate stock notes, dated March 15 and due on June 15.

WASHINGTON, March 15. -- The House had no business before it today, as the Senate had not acted upon the economy bill and had not taken up the Cullen beer bill. So Speaker Rainey and Representative Byrns, majority leader, decided to let the old and new members enjoy themselves in an oratorical field day.

MOSCOW, March 15 (AP). -- The Central Executive Committee of the Soviet Government today published a decree directing the Ogpu (the secret police) to deal with "special severity" with employes of State institutions guilty of subversive activities.

The movement in yesterday's stock and bond markets, on resumption of business by the Stock Exchange, was impressive -- the more so because experienced financiers had confessed beforehand their complete inability to predict what it would be.

The danger of marine disasters due to the failure of wireless operators to catch the distress signals of ships in trouble would be greatly reduced by newly devised apparatus demonstrated last night before the New York Electrical Society at a meeting at the Electrical Societies auditorium, 29 West Thirty-ninth Street.

WASHINGTON, March 15. -- Colonel Henry Latrobe Roosevelt, a retired marine officer and sixth cousin of President Roosevelt, was appointed Assistant Secretary of the Navy today. The selection was made by Secretary Swanson and without any suggestion from the President, according to a White House announcement.
In thirteen States, public purchase of beer awaits only its legalization by the Federal Government.
MANILA, March 15. -- Governor General Theodore Roosevelt concluded his second and final official farewell party tonight in an exchange of felicitations with Manuel Quezon, President of the Senate.

A plea for the support of the Metropolitan Opera Company was made yesterday by Queena Mario, Metropolitan soprano, in an address before delegates of 200 constituent branches of the Federation of Jewish Women's Organizations at the federation's monthly meeting at Temple Emanu-El Community House, 1 East Sixty-fifth Street.

Experience with the more than 500 pension plans in American industry, as analyzed by Industrial Relations Counselors, Inc., 165 Broadway, discloses that the operation of these plans to date has yielded to the employers scant benefit and much grief, even though there is the satisfaction of having provided to a limited extent for superannuated employes, according to the second of a series of articles summarizing the voluminous report, made public yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 15. -- A general reduction in the total acreage of crops to be harvested in 1933, amounting to about 9,000,000 acres, or 3 per cent under last year's total, was predicted today by the Department of Agriculture on the basis of reports from 41,000 farmers in all parts of the country giving their planting intentions.

Former President Hoover plans to leave this afternoon by train for his home in Palo Alto, Cal. He has been here since leaving office March 4. The hour of his departure remained uncertain last night, but he was expected to take either a 2 o'clock or a 5 o'clock train from Pennsylvania Station.

BERLIN, March 15. -- Trading on the Boerse today was animated, but prices were irregular, some stocks rising and others declining from yesterday's figures. The preponderant tendency, however, was steady, and, with few exceptions, price changes were moderate.

Nathan Straus Jr., president of the Park Association of New York City, Inc., inducted thirty-four Queens women as regional directors of the association at a meeting yesterday of the new directors in the offices of Park Commissioner Albert C. Benninger of Queens.

President MCKEE of the Board of Aldermen, rested after his strenuous weeks last Fall, has signalized his return to the public stage by a demand for early resumption of conferences over rapid-transit unification. His attack on Controller BERRY and his allies in the Board of Estimate for having "destroyed "utterly the only possible means "of preserving the five-cent fare "on the city-operated transit "lines" is not particularly convinc- ing.

SHORT HILLS, N.J., March 15. -- William Whetten Renwick, an architect specializing in ecclesiastical design and decoration, whose work is to be found in many important churches and church buildings in New York City, died at his home here today after a brief illness at the age of 68.

MIAMI, Fla., March 15. -- With a glint of battle in his eyes and his chin set at a stubborn angle, Joe Stripp, only remaining hold-out of the Dodgers, drove into Miami today from his Winter home in Orlando prepared to voice his emphatic objections to the $2,000 slash in his 1933 contract.

Beer, and real beer, too, just as good as and perhaps better than the preprohibition beverage of nearly forgotten days, is ready in abundance to quench the thirst of New York's lovers of the brew the minute the beer bill goes into effect.

One mother taking part in an informal inquiry into the relation of radio to family life expressed a typical point of view. She said, half sadly: "I don't think we can "eliminate radio from the modern "set-up." There it is, like automobiles and the movies, a wonderful modern tool.
Dr. Albert Einstein spoke as follows at the dinner given in his honor at the Hotel Commodore last night:

A revision of the Transportation Act of 1920 to provide for a greater measure of railroad consolidation and for coordination of all forms of transportation has been under discussion at meetings here of railroad officials, bankers and advisers to President Roosevelt.

It was the opinion of Wall Street, as expressed in the day's comment, that the governing authorities of the various Exchanges had acted wisely in refusing to apply any hampering restrictions to trading at the reopening. Even the government bond market, concerning which some unnecessary solicitude had been shown, joined spiritedly in the general advance.

AUGUSTA, Ga., March 15 (AP). -- Miss Kathryn Hemphill, the young South Carolina girl who has beaten two experienced campaigners in early rounds, today earned the right to play Miss Maureen Orcutt of Englewood, N.J., in the semi-finals of the Augusta women's invitation golf tournament tomorrow.

There are many writers, artists and actors, now comparatively well known and comparatively prosperous, who still remember with gratitude the generous buffet suppers that Mabel Dodge Luhan gave them. That was in the days just before the World War, when her home at 23 Fifth Avenue was open house for Lee Simonson, Lincoln Steffens, Jack Reed, Walter Lippmann, Emma Goldman, Max Eastman, Bill Haywood, Henry McBride and many others.

BOSTON, Mass., March 15. -- Harvard can become "the greatest university on earth" by adhering to a well-planned program. President A. Lawrence Lowell told more than 500 alumni at a dinner given in his honor by the Harvard Club at Boston tonight.

VIENNA, March 15. -- Defying the ban of the Dollfuss dictatorship, the Pan-German and Socialist members of Parliament held a rump session today, gathering a half-hour before the police expected the meeting. Police, rushed to the Parliament building, cleared the hall, but not before the session had voted to adjourn so that it might meet again.

Fourteen alleged henchmen of Arthur (Dutch Schultz) Flegenheimer, notorious racketeer, were arrested early last evening when police plain-clothes men raided a six-room flat at 550 West 146th Street, which they said was the clearing house for the policy racket.

The annual police report for 1932, soon to be published, will show an increase among youthful felony offenders ranging in years from 16 to 18, Commissioner Mulrooney declared yesterday at the luncheon of the Manhattan Chapter of the Reserve Officers' Association of the United States at the Army and Navy Club, 30 West Forty-fourth Street.

STATE COLLEGE, Pa., March 15. -- Thirty-nine bouts are scheduled for Eastern Intercollegiate Boxing Association title contenders in the tenth annual tournament of the association, which will be staged here Friday and Saturday. Drawings were completed by officials of the tournament today.

The widows of firemen and other dependents upon the city Fire Department's pension fund were revealed yesterday as having been cut off from more than $250,000 of the fund by the failure of the Harriman National Bank and Trust Company to open, following the end of the banking holiday, which began on March 4.

WASHINGTON, March 15. -- Norman H. Davis, chairman of the United States delegation to the general disarmament conference at Geneva, was a luncheon guest of President Roosevelt in the Executive offices at the White House today.

At the request of District Attorney Crain, the grand jury began yesterday an inquiry into the cir- cumstances under which John C. Ramsey, general manager of the Port of New York Authority, in June, 1931, obtained a loan of $10,020 from the National City Company, an affiliate of the National City Bank.

Led by the New York Stock Exchange, most of the security and commodity markets in the country reopened yesterday, and investors and traders promptly showed their approval of the reconstruction program of President Roosevelt by starting one of the most emphatic buying movements in many years.

Dr. Ellsworth Faris, chairman of the department of sociology of the University of Chicago, returned from Africa yesterday on the Dollar liner President Garfield after a seven-month study of primitive tribes in the Belgian Congo.

The New York State Commission on Alcoholic Beverage Control Legislation completed its beer bills, one relating to the sale and manufacture of the beverage and the second to taxes on beer, at a special meeting yesterday in the Park Lane Hotel, and rushed the proposed legislation to Albany for introduction in the Legislature today.

WASHINGTON, March 15. -- The first patronage conference of this administration, delayed because of the bank situation, was held tonight at the White House. President Roosevelt summoned Postmaster General Farley, Frank C. Walker, treasurer of the Democratic National Committee, and Edward H. Flynn of New York to discuss the major appointments, and especially jobs to be apportioned to New York.

Discussion of the economy bill urged by President ROOSEVELT has served one good purpose in establishing the fact that not all veterans are against it. So much has been heard of the "Veterans' Lobby" at Washington, and of the shower of protesting telegrams sent to members of Congress by ex-soldiers, that the other side of the case has not received due attention.

BOSTON, March 15. -- The Boston Canaries retained the Boston Indoor League polo championship, recording a 10-9 victory over Harvard in a game for the benefit of the Boston unemployment fund in the Commonwealth Armory tonight.
The address delivered by Dr. Harlow Shapley at last night's dinner in honor to Dr. Einstein follows:

WASHINGTON, March 15. -- The bill of Senator Robinson, the Democratic leader, passed yesterday by the Senate to amend the emergency banking law to permit State banks not members of the Federal Reserve System to obtain on approved security loans directly from Federal Reserve Banks, was withheld from action by the House today on request of Secretary Woodin, the Federal Reserve Board and Senator Glass.

Veterans' organizations and other groups joined yesterday in praising the New York State American Legion for backing President Roosevelt's economy program. Some attacked the national command of the Legion for failure to do likewise.

Hans Wagner, the great Pittsburgh Pirates' shortstop of years ago now returning to baseball as Pittsburgh coach, will receive a public reception on the steps of Borough Hall when the Brooklyn home season opens next month with a game between the Pirates and the Dodgers at Ebbets Field.

KARACHI, India, March 15 (By Wireless). -- Flight Lieut. McIntyre of the Mount Everest flight expedition, with Chief Cinematographer Bonnett as observer, today made a successful altitude test in the Westland Wallace, one of the two machines to be used in the attempt to fly over the world's highest peak.

With many gaps between the last closing prices for futures and the higher prices for spot transactions created during the banking holiday, the commodities markets here for the most part opened yesterday with vigorous rallies. All staples moved to substantially higher levels, with new high records for the year in volume and price established in some cases.
Rosa Ponselle, singing Sunday evening from 9 to 9:30 o'clock over Station WEAF, also will speak to her radio audience on behalf of the Campaign to Save Metropolitan Opera.

GENEVA, March 15. -- Prime Minister MacDonald of Great Britain will lay the complete draft of a disarmament treaty full of concrete facts and figures before the general commission of the disarmament conference tomorrow afternoon before his departure for Rome Friday.

It is up to the Board of Estimate to take the next step if transit unification conferences are to be renewed, the Transit Commission declared yesterday in a letter sent by William G. Fullen, its chairman, to Joseph V. McKee, President of the Board of Aldermen.

Professor Gerald E. SeBoyar, chairman of the committee on scholastic standing at the New York University School of Commerce, Accounts and Finance, announced yesterday that 150 students of that division have been named in the honor roll.

Ninety entries, representing eight colleges and universities, have been received for the annual Eastern intercollegiate wrestling championships, to be contested tomorrow and Saturday in the Columbia gymnasium, it was announced yesterday by Manager Newton Krumdieck.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 15. -- Ben Chapman is going in for the fast life again. That was the running story he told on the witness stand today, the witness stand being a wooden bench looking out over Tampa Bay.

The Association of the Bar of the City of New York made public yesterday a letter sent to Governor Lehman urging him to veto the Alterman bill, passed recently by the Assembly, which would permit lawyers who had been disbarred, and judges of inferior courts who had been removed, to "appeal as a matter of right" to the Court of Appeals.
COMMERCIAL PAPEK. Yesterday -- No trading. Friday, March 3 (last regular trading day) -- 3 per cent for the best names. The quotations are for three-four months' paper.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The comments in regard to Newfoundland's future which appeared in THE TIMES proved, I have no doubt, particularly interesting to thousands of Newfoundlanders residing here, as well as numerous Americans affiliated with "Old England's Oldest Colony" -- the name of which it would seem opportune to here remark is correctly pronounced Nu'-fund-land".

ALBANY, March 15. -- Two bills providing for State regulation of prospective manufacture and sale of beer will come before the Legislature tomorrow. One will be the bill sponsored by the State Commission on Alcoholic Beverage Control Legislation.

Attendance in the city's schools in January was under that in January, 1932, but above January, 1931, said the monthly report of average daily attendance made public yesterday by Dr. William J. O'Shea, Superintendent of Schools.

The estate of Miss Anna Sands, social leader in New York and Newport, R.I., who died April 9, last, was appraised yesterday at $299,885 gross and $267,511 net, of which $215,586 was in securities and $36,541 was the value of the property at the southwest corner of Fifth Avenue and 139th Street.

WASHINGTON, March 15. -- After the Senate passed the Sherley-Douglas economy bill tonight, it was generally agreed at the White House and on Capitol Hill that no measure will soon, if ever again, be offered by the administration which can be challenged as a grant of "constitutional dictatorship" to the President.

DETROIT, March 15. -- It was made plain today by Messrs. Keyes and Schram, conservators of the First National Bank-Detroit and the Guardian National Bank of Commerce, that the placing of those institutions under government control did not mean that 100 per cent liquidation of the two banks must be carried out and plans here for a new bank abandoned.

GENEVA, March 15. -- Prime Minister MacDonald and Foreign Secretary Simon will leave here for Rome Friday or Saturday for a "bilateral general talk" with Premier Mussolini. Although none of the details is yet fixed, the present probabilities are that they will leave here Saturday and remain in Rome two days, possibly traveling by air, and returning home by way of Geneva.

WASHINGTON, March 15 (AP) -- Railway employes in the United States, through A.F. Whitney, chairman of their railway labor executives' association, voiced their sorrow today over the death of Sir Henry W. Thornton in a message of sympathy to his widow.

A petition, pointing to the example of President Roosevelt in seeking to effect radical economies in the Federal Government, and emphasizing the need for similar rigid economies in State expenditures, was sent yesterday to Governor Lehman in Albany by Grover A. Whalen, as spokesman for a citizens committee composed of Leonor F. Loree, Peter Grimm, Lucius Boomer, Lawrence B. Elliman, Colonel George McCaffrey and Merwin K. Hart.
WASHINGTON, March 15. -- The principal provisions of the $500,000,000 economy bill passed tonight by the Senate are as follows:

WASHINGTON, March 15. -- As hundreds of banks in smaller communities reopened today in accord with the progressive resumptions which began on Monday, Secretary Woodin emphasized the point that the people of the country should not lose faith in those institutions which did not start business immediately.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., March 15. -- Seven of the nine Negroes accused of attacking two white girls on a freight train near Scottsboro two years ago will go on trial for their lives a second time at Decatur, Ala., the seat of Morgan County.

Albert Einstein, explorer of the cosmos and champion of humanity, arrived in New York yesterday from California, where he had been engaged in scientific work at the California Institute of Technology. Last night he received the enthusiastic greeting of nearly 1,000 admirers at a dinner given in his honor at the Hotel Commodore under the honorary chairmanship of Governor Lehman and Felix M. Warburg.

The investigation by the Senate Committee on Banking and Currency, which recently resulted in the resignation of Charles E. Mitchell as head of the National City Bank, will be extended immediately into the operations of private banks and investment bankers, according to Ferdinand Pecora, investigating counsel.

BERLIN, March 15. -- President von Hindenburg today decreed the removal of the black, red and gold stripes from the Reich's war flag, where they had been put when they became the official colors of the German Republic. They were incorporated in the old imperial war and merchant flags in the shape of a small inset in the upper left-hand corner.
Common Terms Defined. Popular notions on the arithmetic of ordinary things are astonishingly vague. Here are a few basic commodities that everybody is talking about nowadays:

PARIS, March 15. -- Replying to a pressing invitation extended by Prime Minister MacDonald when he passed through Paris a few days ago, which has since been repeated by Joseph Paul-Boncour, French Foreign Minister, Premier Edouard Daladier boarded a train for Geneva tonight.

TOKYO, Thursday, March 16. -- Local reinforcements have been sent to Major Gen. Heijiro Hattori's troops at Sifeng Pass, who are outnumbered and are unable to dislodge the Chinese from the vicinity and halt their counter-attacks.

CHICAGO, March 15. -- Higher prices for grains, provisions and cotton are expected tomorrow when trading in contracts for future deliveries of those commodities is resumed after the ten-day bank holiday. However, the limit of changes in the price of grains on the Chicago Board of Trade will be 5 cents a bushel on wheat, 3 cents on corn and barley, 2 cents on oats and 4 cents on rye.
The New York Curb Exchange announced yesterday the admission to its trading list of the following stocks:

While several major motion-picture companies were holding up their more important products because of the troubled financial situation, Warner Brothers announced release dates yesterday for six pictures. Major Albert Warner, vice president, said in a statement that the company had "confidence in America, in the exhibitor, in the President and in the company's product, and we are ready to do everything in our power to stimulate the early return to prosperity."

Customs officials in charge of watching at piers for passengers attempting to take gold out of the country said yesterday they thought the plan was working out well and that the steamship sailings were being well "covered."

Trading in the municipal bond market did not approach normal yesterday, as institutional buying was small and dealers were disinclined to cut prices to stimulate business. Quotations averaged slightly below those quoted on the preceding trading day, March 3.

ORANGE, N.J., March 15. -- W. Albert Manda, one of the most prominent horticulturists in the country, and winner of the prize offered by the Massachusetts Horticultural Society for the most outstanding work in horticulture in the United States during the year 1932, was found dead this evening, alongside the tracks of the Lackawanna Railroad at the McChesney Street crossing here.

Some nine years ago -- and what years they have been -- David Gray and Avery Hopwood brought forth an item called "The Best People." It concerned the indubitable worthies of that fair time, those who had the money and lived on The Avenue and were saddened by the antics of the children.

WASHINGTON, March 15. -- Administration officials are virtually convinced from Paris reports of the attitude of political leaders that France will soon pay the debt instalment she deferred on Dec. 15, and they welcome the move as making easier the path to debt revision negotiations.

Transition is always interesting -- doubly so when transit appears to be moving toward the soul's statelier mansions, of which one of our poets sang. Whether the new mansions of Philip Evergood's soul should be called statelier may invite argument, but at any rate they are ever so much brighter and with "a dome more vast."

Resumption of business on the Stock Exchange, coupled with broader banking facilities, resulted in a more normal money market than has been the case since the Exchange closed on March 4. Standing loans and new money went at 5 per cent, unchanged from Tuesday's rate, Street trades were arranged at 4 1/2 and Federal funds were quoted 3 1/4@3 1/2.

E.L. Cord and his associated interests yesterday took complete control of the Aviation Corporation as the result of additional purchases of the company's stock which have been made in the last few months. Eight of the company's directors, including the Harriman-Lehman representatives, resigned, including Richard F. Hoyt, who was elected president last November.

PALM BEACH, Fla., March 15. -- On the beach in front of their North Ocean Boulevard villa Mr. and Mrs. John H. Phipps gave a dinner tonight which included their house guests, Dr. and Mrs. Fuller Allbright of Boston, and Mrs. Phipps's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Eugene Klapp of Sandwich, Mass. Others present were:

Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt spent a busy day in New York yesterday, and before it had progressed far she demonstrated conclusively the dislike of fuss and formality that characterized her long before she went to the White House.

Stanislaus Patek, Polish Ambassador to the United States, returns today from Warsaw on the Italian liner Conte Di Savoia. Others aboard include Count and Countess Fumasoni Biondi, Count G. Garandini, Countess Gizycka, Senator J. Albertini, G. Doubleday and Enrico Caruso, son of the famous tenor.
Numerous Jersey City properties were included in the New Jersey realty turnover reported yesterday.

The committee on character and fitness of the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court made public yesterday the names of 119 applicants for admission to the bar, who have been instructed to appear before it for examination. Six women are on the list.

The horse as a symbol of man's dignity on parade will not materialize at the annual St. Patrick's Day parade tomorrow, although Roderick J. Kennedy, veteran chairman of the arrangements committee, who was elected grand marshal of this year's parade last month by a 2-1 vote over Mayor John P. O'Brien, wishes it were otherwise.

Mortgage loan companies under State Insurance Department supervision which came within the scope of the President's proclamation declaring a bank holiday are permitted to resume business with restrictions under regulations made public last night by Superintendent of Insurance George S. Van Schaick.

WASHINGTON, March 15. -- The beer bill was favorably reported out of the Senate Finance Committee today, but action was not taken upon it in the Senate because discussion of the economy bill had not been completed. Senator Harrison.

A new policy of stocking the fields and forests of Massachusetts has just been adopted. It involves the trapping and releasing of several thousand cottontail rabbits. The hunters in the Bay State for many years have sought the rabbit.

LONDON, March 15. -- With ten American-owned thoroughbreds still eligible, the field for the Grand National, greatest of all steeplechase races, today was reduced to thirtyfive, the smallest since 1926. Additional scratches are likely before the race at Aintree on March 24.

KANSAS CITY, March 15 (AP). -- Resumption of banking today saw a large majority of State and national banks in the Tenth Federal Reserve District resuming unrestricted business, and the launching of plans by authorities for rehabilitation of the comparatively few remaining closed.

The likelihood that the city will find a "white elephant" on its hands in the seven-block ChrystieForsyth Street area acquired for model housing four years ago developed yesterday when Herman H. Smith, chief engineer of the Board of Estimate made a report to the Sinking Fund Commission, stressing the difficulties in the way of putting the land into use.

Belief that the steel business will pick up sharply as an aftermath of the banking holiday is expressed by The Iron Age in its weekly review. The rising volume of business, according to this publication, should be accompanied by an increase in price.

In capitalistic countries, based on the system of profit, the private physician is the enemy of public health, it was said yesterday by Dr. Alexandre Roubakine of Moscow University, at the eleventh annual conference of the Advisory Council of the Milbank Memorial Fund, which opened at the New York Academy of Medicine.
GENEVA, March 15. -- The Manchurian Advisory Committee, meeting privately today, accepted American cooperation on the basis offered by the Roosevelt administration.

WASHINGTON, March 15. -- A consolidation of the railroads and the formation by the roads of a corporation to provide finances for weak systems are involved in a plan drafted by Frederic H. Prince of Boston and others.

Political control of public education was assailed yesterday by Dr. Frederick B. Robinson, president of City College, in a letter to the Legislature urging the defeat of the Pratt bill for the suspension of mandatory salary laws and educational expenditures.

PRINCETON, N. J., March 15. -- The schedule of the Eastern Intercollegiate Golf Association was announced today by Asa S. Bushnell, graduate manager of athletics at Princeton and executive secretary of the association.

Glenn Cunningham settled his score with Gene Venzke last night Before a gathering of more than 15,000 in Madison Square Garden the Jayhawk flier ran the fastest indoor mile of the season to win the Columbian Mile that featured the Knights of Columbus games in the brilliant figures of 4:12.

Kay Boyle, who writes steadily in her villa on a mountain overlooking Nice and the Mediterranean in the heart of a community which has very few other members who work at all, has turned out a fourth book, "The First Lover," which Harrison Smith Robert Haas publish today.
The banking holiday came to an end in State and nation yesterday, and business once more could be transacted with checking privileges on a nation-wide basis.

Franz M. Sachs, 35 years old, a real estate broker for Oserfa, Inc., and the O. and W. Realty Corporation, with offices at 136 East Fifty-seventh Street, was lodged in the Tombs yesterday on a bench warrant, issued several months ago when nineteen indictments were returned against him and others charging grand larceny and conspiracy.

LONDON, March 15. -- A sharp warning to the Soviet Government over the arrests of six British engineers was delivered in the House of Commons today by Stanley Baldwin, Acting Prime Minister, Hinting that "unfortunate consequences to Anglo-Soviet relations" might result from the arrests, Mr. Baldwin asserted the charges of sabotage against the engineers were wholly unjustified.

The Girl Scout movement has come of age, being twenty-one years old this week. But those enrolled in its membership -- 300,000 of them -- never cease to be girls in spirit. That is a more precious gift than the one which was granted by Apollo to the Sibyl.
Following is the address of Dr. Karl T. Compton at the Einstein dinner last night:

The dollar slipped sharply and then rallied in the foreign exchange market yesterday, closing lower in terms of almost all other currencies, but still above the levels quoted on the last day of business before the gold embargo was laid down.

It took a jury in Judge Corrigan's part of General Sessions only fifteen minutes yesterday to return a verdict of guilty of manslaughter in the second degree against Michael Favaloro, 27 years old, a taxicab driver, of 227 East 100th Street, in whose machine two men and two women were drowned at East River and Twenty-third Street at 1 A.M. on July 26. 1931.

Lawson Purdy, who has been secretary and director of the New York Charity Organization Society for fifteen years, presented his resignation at a meeting of the executive committee of that body yesterday afternoon at the headquarters of the organization, 105 East Twenty-second Street.

An upper east side deal was announced by Douglas Gibbons Co., brokers, who sold for Louis B. McCagg, architect, the four-story English basement dwelling with garden at 245 East Seventy-first Street. The property adjoins the new Junior League clubhouse and is in the same block with the new home of the Colonial Dames of America.
WASHINGTON, March 15. -- The Senate vote in detail on passage of the economy bill tonight was as follows:

William Catzeflis, 54 years old, an Oriental rug dealer of 191-11 Terrace Avenue, Hollis, Queens, and Charles Fleischman, 30, and David Yamron, 30, merchants, of 164-41 Boardwalk, Atlantic City, N.J., by whom Catzeflis was employed, were released in $1,000 bail each yesterday by General Sessions Judge Donellan after their arrest by Detective James J. McKittrick of the District Attorney's office.

Mayor John P. O'Brien was assailed last night by Alderman Joseph Clark Baldwin, Republican, for delay in carrying out his campaign promise to reduce the Sanitary Commission from three members to one and to effect other reorganizations in the Sanitation Department.

One must be "very careful these days in picking the theatre to which he wants to go unless he wants to feel somewhat soiled when he leaves," Joseph V. McKee, President of the Board of Aldermen, said last night in an address to the Girl Scout Federation of Greater New York in the Cosmopolitan Club, 129 East Sixty-fifth Street.

PRAGUE, March 15 (AP). -- Asked during a meeting tonight of the parliamentary military committee whether, "in view of the uncertain situation abroad," the Czechoslovak Army was ready for action, Defense Minister Bradac said he "had full confidence in the army's power of resistance."

Current rumors of impending war in Europe were characterized as "utter, complete nonsense" yesterday by Dr. Richard von Kuehlmann, former Foreign Minister of Germany, in a discussion of his country's problems and the future of Europe at a meeting in Town Hall under the auspices of the League for Political Education.

VIENNA, March 15. -- A graphic story of the conquest of Bavaria by the Nazi storm stroops that contradicted the German Government's version in almost every detail was printed today by the Vienna Reichspost.
NEW YORK. Eric H. Louw, Minister of the Union of South Africa, is arriving at the Ambassador today to meet his wife who is returning from Europe.

SHANGHAI, March 15. -- While General Chiang Kai-shek, the National Commander-in-Chief, is trying to retain control of the situation and terminate hostilities likely to cause the Japanese to extend operations on a large scale inside the Great Wall, General Sung Cheh-yuan, a former Kuominchun commander under Feng Yu-siang, has created a critical situation by persisting in attacks against the Japanese positions at Sifeng Pass.

LOS ANGELES, Cal., March 15. -- Having emerged more or less unscathed from a series of startling episodes, including bank closings, earthquakes and a six-game series with the champion Cubs, Manager Bill Terry settled back today to take another careful inventory of his natural resources.

Three witnesses testified yesterday at the trial of Alexander Forsyth for manslaughter in connection with the boiler explosion which wrecked the steamer Observation and killed seventy-two men on Sept. 9. Forsyth was part-owner of the vessel.

TRENTON, N.J., March 15. -- By a vote of 15 to 2 in the Senate and 48 to 0 in the Assembly, the Legislature passed today a bill providing for a State convention to act on ratification of repeal of national prohibition.

WASHINGTON, March 15. -- By a vote of 62 to 13 the Senate at 9:23 o'clock tonight passed the $500,000,000 economy bill, which gives the President practically dictatorial powers in reducing veterans' benefits and Federal salaries.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 15. -- The first sign that Babe Ruth, famous Yankee hold-out, is weakening came today when the mighty slugger, who has refused to accept a one-third reduction from his salary of last year, admitted that he is seriously considering signing for $55,000, if he can induce Colonel Jacob Ruppert, club owner, who is now sojourning here, to grant him that figure.

Sweeping advances in all departments of the listed bond market yesterday sent prices generally 1 to 7 points higher than the official closing prices on the preceding trading day on March 3. Transactions totaled $12,645,000 on the Stock Exchange, of which United States Government bonds accounted for $3,916,000.

PARIS, March 15. -- A different interpretation from that given in Berlin last night is voiced today in Paris as to the reason for and character of the action taken by Andre Francois-Poncet, the French Ambassador, regarding the appearance and attitude of Nazi forces in the demilitarized Rhineland zone.

WASHINGTON, March 15. -- Owing to the fact that a considerable amount of income tax payments will be postponed until March 31, Secretary of the Treasury Woodin today announced a new issue of $100,000,000 in ninety-one-day Treasury bills to be dated March 22.

Public interest was centred yesterday in the action of the security markets in which trading was resumed officially after the protracted shut-down occasioned by the banking holiday. The movement of prices fully justified the confident predictions that had been made in Wall Street in advance of the reopening.

BERLIN, March 15. -- German exports and imports in February virtually maintained the January level, which was extremely low. A slight increase in the export surplus -- 4,000,000 marks (about $960,000) -- bringing the total for the month to 7,000,000 marks, hardly improved the prospects of Germany's maintaining in full her foreign debt service.

The American Tobacco Company reports for 1932 a net income of $43,267,083 after all charges and reserves, equal, after dividend payments on its preferred stock, to $8.46 a share on the 4,740,946 combined common and Class B stocks outstanding.

WASHINGTON, March 15. -- President Roosevelt will send messages to Congress within twenty-four hours on unemployment relief and a bill to deal with the farm situation for one year, it was indicated today.

After an absence of almost two years from local exhibitions, Max Kalish is holding a one-man show of his sculpture at the Grand Central Galleries. It is an attractive show. Grace, dignity, naturalness his figures have and, within the limits of that naturalness, a certain suave power.

RIO DE JANEIRO, March 15 -- Prevented by Brazil from attacking Leticia by water, Colombia is reported to be concentrating 10,000 troops along the Putumayo River, chiefly at Caucayo, for an overland drive to recover the region seized by Peruvians last September.

The controversy between the managers of Broadway's legitimate theatres and the stagehands, and the case for each side, will be presented to the public at 8:30 o'clock this evening, when Brock Pemberton, representing the League of New York Theatres, and James J. Brennan, head of Theatrical Protective Union 1, will discuss the issues in a radio broadcast through Station WEVD.

WASHINGTON, March 15 (AP) -- Discovery of a new tie-up between storms on earth and spots on the sun, suggesting a new basis for long-range forecasting, was announced today by the Smithsonian Institution.

ALBANY, March 15. -- Representatives of utility companies appeared before a joint meeting of the Public Service Committees of the Senate and Assembly today to oppose a measure carrying out Governor Lehman's budget recommendation to levy the cost of rate proceedings on the utilities.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., March 15 (AP). -- The trail of a tornado's devastating fury from one end of Tennessee to the other was marked tonight by thirty-four dead, about 200 injured and piles of wreckage that used to be homes.
ROME, March 15. -- Prime Minister MacDonald of Great Britain and Premier Mussolini of Italy will meet to discuss disarmament some time over the week-end, it became known here tonight.

ALBANY, March 15. -- School teachers, policemen, firemen and other civic employes thronged the Assembly chamber today to protest against the Pratt bill suspending all State mandatory salary laws for two years.

WASHINGTON, March 15. -- As the first Japanese Government official to receive an audience with President Roosevelt, Vice Admiral Osamu Nagano, Japanese delegate to the disarmament conference at Geneva, expressed tonight his pleasure at a cordial message of goodwill which the new President had confided to him to take to Tokyo.

By the great and unquestioned success which Mr. ROOSEVELT has had in his first approaches to Congress, and in winning public confidence to so large a degree, politicians of the old school are puzzled. Washington dispatches represent them as rubbing their eyes and scratching their heads as they observe the new President at work.

MIAMI BEACH, Fla., March 15. -- An arm of the law which reached out 1,500 miles from Police Headquarters, New York, to an obscure bungalow near the northern limits of this resort city today trapped Harry Sidmore, 38-year-old "Raffles" of Miami Beach, and better known as Harry Sitamore, international jewel thief.

There is now a double reason for raising the age of leaving school. The good of children recommends it. The most effective way to limit child labor is to lengthen the school period. The boy in school is having the fullest opportunity that the State can give him to cultivate his faculties and so have not only a happier childhood and youth, but promise of an adult life of more worth to the State.

Among the passengers who arrived late yesterday from Europe on the Cunarder Aquitania was F. D'Arcy Cooper, financial secretary of the Unilever Company of England, soap producers, who has come over for a business visit. Speaking of the recent banking crisis in the United States, Mr. Cooper said:
The Guaranty Trust Company will be prepared on Monday to deliver Studebaker Corporation 6 per cent gold notes, due on Dec. 1, 1942, in definitive form in exchange for outstanding temporary notes.

Play reached the quarter-final round yesterday in the annual invitation women's squash racquets tournament at the Junior League of New York, with one upset changing the steady march of the favored players toward the final round.

DUBLIN, March 15. -- The Irish Free State Senate made a last effort today to frustrate the move of Eamon de Valera, President of the Executive Council, to have the oath of allegiance to the King removed from the Constitution.

ALBANY, March 15. -- The Senate passed today the Democratic program bill to set up bipartisan boards of election throughout the State. It was approved by a strictly party vote of 26 Democrats against 25 Republicans.
"Three-Cornered Moon," a comedy by Gertrude Tonkonogy, with Ruth Gordon in the starring role, will open this evening at the Cort Theatre.

MIAMI, Fla., March 15. -- E.R. Bradley's Blessed Event, by Happy Argo from Soul Mate, set a new seven-furlong track record of 1:25 at Tropical Park today when he was up to win by three-quarters of a length in the featured Granada Handicap.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The letter of Henry Taft in THE TIMES regarding the vacancy that will soon take place in the presidency of Hunter College touches upon so important a civic question that I venture to ask space for an additional word upon the subject.

BALBOA, C.Z., March 15. -- The ease with which the United States naval airship Akron handles under tropic conditions was demonstrated to the satisfaction of Commander Frank C. McCord, commanding, in her uneventful 23-hour flight of 1,020 miles from Miami to the Canal Zone, where she arrived at 9 o'clock this morning.

BERLIN, March 15. -- The Prussian Commissarial Government plans to pardon all those who have been convicted or jailed for crimes of a political nature in the course of the "struggle for national resurrection," in so far as they were actuated by patriotic considerations.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., March 15. -- In his room at the Central Young Men's Christian Association dormitory Erik Baumann, 27 years old, an athlete and gymnast, was found strangled to death today, trussed up securely from head to foot, so that his struggles to free himself slowly garroted him.

In his memorial address on Mr. COOLIDGE before the New Hampshire Legislature yesterday Mr. GEORGE H. MOSES spoke of the transfer of "the sceptre of political power" westward. The thought is ancient, and he must have been saddened by the remembrance of his own lost sceptre and gavel.
The city's economy program has so reduced the income of the American Museum of Natural History that its authorities have decided to close at least ten halls in rotation each day, beginning today.

Although extension until March 31 of the time limit for filing Federal income tax returns caused some falling off yesterday in the size of the crowds visiting the Internal Revenue Collector's offices to file returns in person, this decrease was balanced by a heavy increase in the number of returns coming in by mail.

Mrs. Alexander Hamilton and her Women's Committee of the Boy Scout Foundation are planning "the largest society circus in the history of New York," to be held on the night of April 25 at the Waldorf-Astoria for the benefit of the Boy Scout Foundation of Greater New York.

For the second successive day cotton quotations in Liverpool ended yesterday virtually unchanged after narrow fluctuations. Based on the recent parity between the two markets, an advance of about a quarter cent would be necessary when trading is resumed this morning on the Cotton Exchange here.

ST. LOUIS, March 15. -- Baron Paul von Gontard, former director-general of the Berlin-Karlsruher Industrielwerke, is the husband of the former Miss Clara Busch, daughter of the late Adolphus Busch, founder of the AnheuserBusch breweries.

To the Editor of The New York Times: It has been interesting to me to see that in the midst of all the news of banking regulation and the new Cabinet, prohibition repeal and earthquake, THE TIMES has given space and enlightened handling to the Scottsboro case.

After three days of strict adherence to the form charts the play in the national indoor tennis championship took an unorthodox turn yesterday to end the march of the seeded array with one of the most stunning turn-abouts the courts have known in recent years.
ALBANY, March 15. -- Governor Lehman announced today the reappointment of Howard S. Cullman as a commissioner of the Port of New York Authority.

The need for protection against claims for errors in service was urged yesterday by officials of the New York Telephone Company in the hearing instituted by the Public Service Commission into provisions in the tariff schedules requiring the customer to assume liability except in certain cases.
