Five men and a young woman, accompanied by two lawyers, late yesterday afternoon were taken from the headquarters of the Columbia Production Company, professional solicitor for charity movements, at 140 West Forty-second Street, to District Attorney Crain's office in connection with the complaint last Monday by Governor Lehman that some one had attempted to defraud Albert Warner of Warner Brothers, motion picture producers, of $500 through use of the Governor's name.

Small Grains: Winter grains made fairly good progress in the South and Southeast, while in the Middle Atlantic States some improvement was noted and Spring growth started. In the Ohio Valley condition of Winter wheat is still variable, with some deterioration in conditions due to the unfavorable weather of the past week or so.

WASHINGTON, March 16 (AP). -- In a letter to the Red Cross, President Roosevelt expressed hope today that citizens throughout the nation would respond generously to the relief organization's call for funds to aid the earthquake sufferers in Southern California.

With dozens of bags of late mail waiting yesterday morning in the offices of Internal Revenue Collectors to be sorted by the income-tax clerks who returned after working until midnight Wednesday, collectors estimated yesterday that the number of returns already filed exceeded the total number filed last year.

On Monday the Treasury invited subscriptions to two issues of Government securities, totaling $800,000,000. They were certificates of indebtedness, one issue maturing in five months and bearing interest at 4 per cent, the other in nine months and bearing 4 1/4 per cent.

Arrangements were made yesterday by Lawrence C. Thaw for the purchase of a seat on the New York Stock Exchange at $105,000, an increase of $5,000 from the price at which two memberships were sold on Wednesday. The seller was Russell E. Prentiss.

WASHINGTON, March 16. -- President Roosevelt today recommended to Congress sweeping emergency legislation to relieve agricultural distress, and accompanied his message with a bill setting forth the plan in detail.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Under the subterfuge of remedying two great evils existing in the taxi cab industry, Local Law No. 31, creating the Board of Control, was passed. Yet this law contains nothing whatever about two evils. One of these is that the public has not been protected to the extent required by law in the matter of compensation for property damage or personal injury.

It would have been better for the city if it had never embarked on the Chrystie-Forsyth Street housing venture. From the moment when Mayor WALKER, in his breezy way, embraced this enterprise without counting the cost, doubts were expressed, in these columns and elsewhere, as to the feasibility of erecting desirable low-cost apartment dwellings in that area.

WASHINGTON, March 16. -- Representatives of the Treasury Department and Reconstruction Finance Corporation are working on regulations dealing with the provisions of the emergency banking law which would permit national and, in some circumstances, State chartered banks to issue preferred stock.

Scoring six points in the second half while holding its opponents scoreless, Stuyvesant High School's basketball team rallied yesterday to defeat Seward Park High, 12 to 10, in the latter's gymnasium and win the Lower Manhattan-Richmond division championship in the city P.S.A.L. title competition.

Three players survive in the invitation women's squash racquets tournament of the Junior League of New York following play in the quarter-finals yesterday, and an all-American final is assured. Miss Anne Page of Philadelphia, last year's winner, plays Miss Marguerite Anderson of Plainfield, runner-up for the metropolitan championship, today for the right to enter the final round.
WASHINGTON, March 16. -- The beer bill, amended so as to provide beer of 3.05 per cent of alcohol by weight instead of 3.2 per cent, passed the Senate early this evening by a vote of 43 to 30.
VILLAMONTES, Bolivia, March 16. -- Bolivian detachments advanced in surprise attacks on the Paraguayan rearguards yesterday, according to a Bolivian communique today.

The belief that the Roosevelt administration will follow the foreign policy of the Hoover regime is expressed by Henry L. Stimson, former Secretary of State, in an article in the April issue of Foreign Affairs, in which Mr. Stimson reviews the basis of American foreign policy during the last four years.

MIAMI, Fla., March 16. -- Annulment today ended the marriage of Mrs. Maxine Rickard Dailey, widow of Tex Rickard, sports promoter, and Frank Dailey of New York less than a year after their wedding, which was not revealed until last November.

To the Editor of The New York Times: It is difficult to shed tears with your correspondent Mr. McMorrow over the spectacle of "legislative interference with the relation of lender and borrower" in a society which has long been accustomed to usury and bankruptcy laws.

The New York University girls' swimming team triumphed over the Savage School of Physical Education mermaids, 29 to 24, in the sixty-foot pool at the American Woman's Association clubhouse last night. The winners annexed three of the five events.

Supreme Court Justice Daniel V. McNamee of Hudson, N.Y., who was assigned last week by the Appellate Division to preside at the trials of ninety-two defendants, indicted election officials, appeared in the criminal branch of the Supreme Court in the Criminal Courts Building yesterday and called the calendar of the first batch of cases.

There are certain voices which the imagination naturally associates with textures or colors; they are smooth or dark, we say; rough or light or fibrous. Perhaps it is not taking too much license with analogy to say that Winifred Cecil's soprano, which revealed itself in a debut recital last night at the Town Hall, suggests an early morning Spring sky, very clear, very fresh, and predominantly cool, though faintly flushed with color.

Further relaxing the restrictions made necessary by the banking holiday emergency, Joseph A. Broderick, Superintendent of Banks, ruled last night to extend the maximum that may be withdrawn by savings banks depositors from $25 to $250 a week.

MIAMI, Fla., March 16. -- Bobby Reis's chances of becoming the Dodgers' regular third baseman were brightened today when Joe Stripp, only remaining Brooklyn holdout, hied himself back to his Winter home at Orlando unsigned and with no immediate prospect that a contract will be tendered him that he will sign.
PASADENA, Cal., March 16 (AP). -- Science placed its instrumental finger today on the spot from which originated the earthquake of last Friday night.

HOLLYWOOD, Cal., March 16. -- Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer is gravely concerned over "Gabriel Over the White House," one of the company's important Spring pictures, which dramatizes some of the country's current problems. A number of film leaders here felt that because of economic and political conditions it was unwise to show a film which might be regarded by the nation at large as subversive and by foreign countries as invidious.

Having witnessed a satisfactory test of the security markets on Wednesday, Wall Street became intensely interested yesterday in the movement of the important agricultural staples as trading was resumed on the New York Cotton Exchange and the Chicago Board of Trade.

To the Editor of The New York Times: March winds, of course, do service in the open spaces by quickening the flow of sap in the trees that they flex and render more supple, as well as by sweeping rubbish away. But they also have a stimulating function, in the city, in stirring it to fresh aspects of vitality and color, at least if one may judge from one afternoon's walk through their capricious turmoil.

ROME, March 16. -- Official announcement that Prime Minister MacDonald and Foreign Secretary Simon of Great Britain will be in Rome Saturday to discuss the international situation with Premier Mussolini is hailed with great enthusiasm by the press here, which sees therein renewed evidence of the important role played by the Italian Premier in the principal world events.

MONTREAL, March 16. -- Not a penalty was called In sixty minutes of hockey tonight as the Montreal Canadiens downed the New York Rangers, 2 -- 1, in a National Hockey League game before 9,000 spectators.

Disturbances at two Home Relief Bureaus in Brooklyn yesterday resulted in injuries to two policemen and the arrest of eleven persons. In both instances groups of fifty or more men and women stormed the doors of the bureaus demanding immediate relief.
WASHINGTON, March 16. -- The text of the administration's farm relief bill, which President Roosevelt submitted to Congress today, is as follows:

MOSCOW, March 16. -- Sir Esmond Ovey, the British Ambassador, had an interview lasting an hour and a half with Foreign Commissar Litvinoff this afternoon to convey to him the views of the British Government, as utlined by Acting Prime Minister Baldwin yesterday, on the arrests of six British subjects.

The Pennsylvania Railroad's dividend distribution this year may not exceed the $6,583,848 disbursed this week, a statement issued yesterday by the company indicated. This would compare with a distribution of about the same amount in 1932 and with $36,161,805 in 1931 and $52,030,987 in 1930.
GENEVA, March 16. -- Following is the official summary of the arms reduction proposals submitted to the Disarmament Conference today by Prime Minister MacDonald of Great Britain:

Formal acceptance of the Interstate Commerce Commission's ruling extending to Sept. 30 the collection of the freight surcharges that were to have expired on March 31 will be taken at a meeting of the advisory committee of the Association of Railway Executives in Chicago on March 22, it was said yesterday after a meeting of the Eastern Presidents' Conference.

Easier conditions were noted in several sections of the money market, as the rates for call and time loans and acceptances turned down from those posted on Wednesday. Stock Exchange call loans, after renewing at 5 per cent, dropped a full point to 4 in the last hour, outside money ruled at 4 and Federal funds at 3 1/4 @ 3 1/2.
WASHINGTON, March 16. -- The vote in the Senate today on the beer bill was as follows:

MIAMI, Fla., March 16. -- Following cabled instructions from James J. Walker, former Mayor of New York, now in Cannes, a general denial to all allegations in the divorce petition of his wife, Mrs. Janet Allen Walker, was filed in Circuit Court here today by Benjamin Cohen, Mr. Walker's attorney.

On Feb. 11 at Miami Chairman FARLEY expounded the system according to which loyal Democrats were to be appointed to Federal jobs. "Deserving members of our party" who wanted to get their reward at Washington must be certified by State leaders after consultation with county leaders.

A nation-wide survey of religious prejudice has been undertaken by the Institute of Social and Religious Research, it was announced yesterday. The project was suggested by the national conference of Jews and Christians and was approved by the institute in January.

PARIS, March 16. -- The British arms limitation proposal presented today by Prime Minister MacDonald of Great Britain at Geneva has been heard and read in France with very mixed feelings, dismay predominating. There are many who will approve it, for here as elsewhere there are many who believe in arms limitation as the real road to peace and in peace as a desirable aim.

BERLIN, March 16. -- With a further augmented volume of transactions, the Boerse presented today, as far as stocks were concerned, much the same aspects as yesterday, some rising and others declining, but with an upward tendency predominating.

HUNTINGTON, L.I., March 16. -- Stephen Pavlick, 19 years old, of 42 Chappel Street, Stamford, Conn., was recovering tonight in the Huntington Hospital here after having drifted across Lone Island Sound last night in a row boat. At the hospital it was said he would remain there, in all probability, for several days.

The two books which, in the judgment of The Parents' Magazine were the best books of last year for parents, are "Our Children," a symposium published by the Viking Press, and "The Parent and the Happy Child," by Dr. Lorine Pruette, published by Henry Holt.

PUTNEY-ON-THAMES, England, March 16. -- The Oxford and Cambridge crews today made their first appearance on the tidewater Thames and began strenuous training for the annual varsity boat race, historic eight-oared classic.

For the second time in two days, Mayor O'Brien found himself yesterday the target of charges that he had failed to carry out his campaign promises, when the City Affairs Committee accused him of "protecting corruption" in the Bureau of Weights and Measures by failing to remove Commissioner Joseph P. McKay and several inspectors.

Reinald Werrenrath, former concert singer, who made an agreement in 1927 for the support of his former wife, Mrs. Ada Werrenrath, and their children, Dorothy, 18 years old, and Reinald Jr., 17, when he was earning $60,000 a year, filed suit in the Supreme Court yesterday to have it changed because it was based on a "mistaken conclusion" that his earnings would continue at that rate.

A presentment urging the immediate installation of iron grille work and steel safety mesh in the new Central Courts Building in Brooklyn was handed up to County Judge Franklin Taylor in Brooklyn yesterday by the Kings County grand jury, following an investigation into the delay in moving the Kings County Court into the new building.

WASHINGTON, March 16. -- The Robinson bill amending the emergency banking act to permit State banks not members of the Federal Reserve System to apply directly to the Reserve Banks for assistance was scrapped today and a substitute said to bear administration approval was prepared by Representative Steagail of Alabama, chairman of the House Banking and Currency Committee.

LOS ANGELES, March 16. -- Having reached rather definite conclusions relative to the personnel of his ball team, William Harold Terry, the new manager of the Giants, today began to concern himself with the proper arrangement of his batting order.

Progress was made this week in the restoration of confidence in all branches of business and there now is more buoyancy to general commercial activity than has been in evidence in recent years, according to the weekly trade review of Dun Bradstreet, which says in part:

WASHINGTON, March 16. -- In a conference today with Senator Robinson of Arkansas, majority Senate leader. President Roosevelt indicated that he would decide later as to whether the interest of the country would be best served by having Congress take a recess after the farm and unemployment relief bills have been passed or remain in continuous session until the full legislative program, including permanent banking legislation and reorganization of the government departments, had been effected.
The demand indicated earlier in the week by housing deals in Manhattan, the Bronx and Brooklyn was continued in Manhattan yesterday.

If "Three-Cornered Moon" sounds thoroughly crack-rained you can be assured that it is the perfect title for Gertrude Tonkonogy's play, which popped up at the Cort last evening. For the Rimplegars are as mad a lot as has tumbled through this neighborhood for some time.

KARACHI, India, March 16. -- Lord Clydesdale, chief pilot of the Houston Everest flight expedition, accompanied by Colonel L.V.S. Blacker, made an altitude flight today in the Houston Westland machine, one of the two planes with which the attempt to fly over the world's highest peak will be made, and reached a height of 35,000 feet.
With their ranks swelled by dele gations from other cities, 20,000 or more Irishmen are to march up Fifth Avenue today in the St. Patrick's Day parade that is one of New York's annual observances.

The North German Lloyd freighter Donau, whose annual visit to New York harbor is the occasion of renewed discussion among shipping men because of her unusual construction, docked late Wednesday at Pier 42, North River, and unloaded about 1,000 tons of freight yesterday.

BERLIN, March 16. -- Dr. Hans Luther resigned as president of the Reichsbank tonight because, as he declared in a letter to President von Hindenburg, he felt, after several conversations with Chancellor Hitler in recent days, that close cooperation between him and the Hitler Cabinet would be difficult.

GENEVA, March 16. -- The first attempt at a world disarmament treaty complete with figures was laid before a highly attentive disarmament conference today by Prime Minister Ramsay MacDonald on behalf of the British delegation which alone was prepared for this surprise.

The resignation of Joseph W. Harriman as chairman of the board of the Harriman National Bank and Trust Company was announced without comment yesterday by Henry E. Cooper, president and-conservator of the closed bank. The resignation was accepted at a special meeting of the board late in the day.

WASHINGTON, March 16. -- President and Mrs. Roosevelt entertained this afternoon at tea in the Red Room of the White House the Chief Justice and Mrs. Hughes and the associate justices of the Supreme Court and their wives. Mrs. Frank Scheider and Miss Maguerite Le Hand assisted at the tea table.

WASHINGTON, March 16. -- More effective regulation of oil production, in the interest of the owner, the industry as a whole and of future generations, will be urged upon the Governors of oil-producing States, who will meet here on March 27.

VIENNA, March 16. -- The Dollfuss government, which against the wishes of half the Parliament has been seeking to curb the power of the Austrian Socialists by semi-dictatorial measures and thus convince the Austrian bourgeoisie that the job could be done without turning to Hitlerism, found itself in a complicated situation tonight as a result of the overenthusiasm of its Heimwehr allies yesterday.

Anton L. Trunk, president of the Real Estate Board of New York, predicted last night that real estate values would come back, possibly not to the levels of 1928 and 1929, but substantially, "because real estate is the fundamental basis of the wealth of this country."

The sharp upswing which occurred when the Stock Exchange reopened Wednesday was matched yesterday by spirited advances in the country's grain and cotton markets, which resumed trading after a holiday since March 3.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Sometimes we do things in a very funny way; for instance, when nuisances of various kinds assail us, we usually bear them more or less impatiently until the breaking point is reached, when we organize a committee of investigation, as we did some time ago to ascertain what kind of a noise annoys an oyster, so to speak.
Several flats were included in the New Jersey realty turnover reported yesterday.

"There will be no more irritating and oppressive taxes," Speaker Henry T. Rainey promised last night at a dinner at the Waldorf-Astoria. "We will be able to balance the budget without additional taxes."

Importers Ask Genaral Tariff Cut. A general reduction, in all tariff rates was urged upon the new administration yesterday by group chairmen and directors of the National Council of American Importers and Traders, Inc., through a resolution adopted at their regular semi-monthly meeting in the Hotel Astor.

WASHINGTON, March 16. -- As James M. Cox, Democratic candidate for President in 1920, has declined the offer of the post of Ambassador to Germany, it is reported that it will be offered to Dave Hennen Morris of New York.

Federal Land Bank bonds, which had been subjected to severe pressure for many weeks before the nation-wide banking holiday, suddenly came to life yesterday and prices were advanced from 13 to 14 points. Traders discovered an almost complete absence of offerings and found prospective investors willing to pay much higher than the 75-cents-on-the-dollar quotations previously named on many of the issues of this group.
WASHINGTON, March 16 (AP). -- The first airplane ride ever taken by a President's wife was a "perfectly good trip but very bumpy."

DAIREN, Manchuria, March 16. -- The Nanking Government as well as the Northern Chinese leaders find themselves in the gravest domestic predicament because of the widespread and deeply felt indignation over the grotesquely inefficient nature of the anti-Japanese resistance in Jehol Province.

A roll of fine white linen, woven from flax grown on the field, near Londonderry, on which she landed after her transatlantic flight, was presented last night to Miss Amelia Earhart by members of the Ulster-Irish Society of New York at its annual dinner at the Hotel McAlpin.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., March 16 (AP). -- Traces of alcohol in the blood of Erik Baumann, brawny victim of a mysterious torture death, led the authorities today to abandon the theory that the 27-year-old gymnast might have been killed in the performance of an escape stunt enacted in his room at the Central Young Men's Christian Association, where his body was found yesterday morning.

Sam Kaplan, former president and chief organizer of Local 306 of the Motion-Picture Machine Operators' Protective Union of Greater New York, and Theodore Greenberg, a former member of the executive board, who were convicted last week with eight others of coercion for expelling nine members, were sentenced to six months in the penitentiary yesterday by Judge Nott in General Sessions.
To the Editor of The New York Times: The foreign dispatches in THE NEW YORK TIMES this morning quote two remarks of eminent European statesmen that are peculiarly significant for us in America.

The New York, Chicago St. Louis (Nickel Plate) Railway filed yesterday an answer in the Supreme Court to a suit of Julius Lieb to collect $90,000 of notes due on Oct. 1, last, with $2,700 interest, which are part of an issue of $20,000,000 of three-year notes which were sold in 1929.

Although the usual number of games will be played in the Eastern Intercollegiate Baseball League during the coming season, the schedule announced last night by Ellwood W. Kemp Jr., secretary-treasurer, provides some interesting changes from former years.

Henry W. Rodney, a Secret Service agent, looked at the emaciated youth whom he had just arrested in Liggett's drug store at Broadway and Forty-second Street. The prisoner, Gerald Gregg, who has not had a job since he came here from Mangum, Okla., months ago, said that he was hungry.

BERLIN, March 16. -- The Philharmonic, the home of Germany's most renowned symphony orchestra, was turned into a forum yesterday evening before which a Jewish ex-service man pleaded the cause of German Jewry.
"One Sunday Afternoon," the comedy by James Hagan, which closed at the Little Theatre on Saturday night will re-open tonight at the Forty-eighth Street Theatre.

GENEVA, March 16 (AP). -- With a boldness and fervor that stirred the weary conference to fresh life, Prime Minister MacDonald of Great Britain submitted to the World Disarmament Conference today a new scheme for a disarmament treaty.

Not since Paavo Nurmi packed them in eight years ago have track fans responded in such great numbers as they have this year. In the four major meets at Madison Square Garden 60,000 persons watched the athletes of the nation vie in speed, skill and strength in a series of such spectacular performances that the recently concluded campaign will go down as one of the finest indoor seasons in the history of the sport.
WHEELING, W.Va., March 16 (AP). -- The peaceful Ohio River, swollen into a mud-red torrent by heavy rains, is spreading fear and ruin along its shores tonight as its waters rush to the sea.

BERLIN, March 16. -- The daily newsreel from Germany is compelled to depend upon a medley of happenings in all corners of the Reich, for while Berlin is the official domicile of the Hitler-von Papen government and the centre of this "national revolution," it Is the happenings in the provinces that supply the patches of color needed to fill in the general picture.

AUGUSTA, Ga., March 16. -- Already a double winner in Southern golf tournaments this Winter, Mrs. O.S. Hill of Kansas City will seek her third triumph of the season tomorrow against Miss Maureen Orcutt of Englewood, N.J., in the final of the women's Augusta invitation tourney.
NEW YORK. Ferdinand Veverka, Minister from Czechoslovakia, is at the St. Moritz.

DANVILLE, Ill., March 16. -- Ike Louis, who came here forty years ago tomorrow to take over for the Gimbel brothers the operation of their first venture in the merchandising business and who a year later became manager for the original Gimbel store, is receiving congratulations tonight on the eve of his anniversary.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 16. -- Manager Joe McCarthy started seven of his regulars against the Braves at Waterfront Park today, the largest representation of veterans nominated thus far, and the result was another Yankee triumph, the score being 5 to 2.

WASHINGTON, March 16. -- The Senate stock market investigation proved conclusively that "powerful interests operating on a large scale in a particular stock" can control its price under normal conditions, according to a report submitted today to the Senate Banking and Currency Committee by William A. Gray, its former counsel.

Army Day will be celebrated nationally on Thursday, April 6, the sixteenth anniversary of America's entry into the World War, and on April 8, New York City will hold its chief celebration, the annual Army Day parade with between 12,000 and 15,000 marching down Fifth Avenue.

ALBANY, March 16. -- Despite a strong plea from Governor Lehman for prompt action by the Legislature to provide machinery for regulation by the State of the manufacture of and traffic in legalized beer, it seems likely that passage of any of the bills drafted for the purpose is at least a fortnight off.

LOS ANGELES, March 16. -- Douglas Fairbanks Jr., motion picture actor, was made defendant in two suits filed in Superior Court today by Jorgen Dietz, who charged alienation of affections in one action and false imprisonment in the other.

VATICAN CITY, March 16 (AP). -- The red hat of the Roman Catholic Church was conferred today by Pope Pius in colorful ceremonies in St. Peter's on the six Cardinals created in a secret consistory last Monday.

Sunday performances for the legitimate theatre instead of a reduction of wages were suggested last night by James J. Brennan, head of Theatrical Protective Union No. 1, in a debate with Brock Pemberton, theatrical producer, broadcast by Station WEVD.

Surrogate James A. Foley handed down a decision yesterday setting aside a bequest of $100,000 in trust made by Robert Weeks de Forest, noted lawyer and philanthropist, to the Adirondack Mountain Reserve on the ground that it is a business and not a charitable corporation, and is not authorized to receive such gifts.

The New Jersey Fish and Game Commission yesterday announced the result of a survey conducted during the past several weeks in relation to the streams of the State. It was the desire of the commission to find out just how many miles of streams would be open to the anglers.

The combined statement of the twelve Reserve banks issued yesterday showed the system's note circulation to be the largest on record, being an increase of about $75,000,000 over that reached in the previous week. Rediscounts of the system revealed a decline from the total in the preceding week, while total gold holding's rose $327,000,000 above the aggregate in the previous week.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., March 16. -- Declaring that "the most powerful nations in the world cannot meet their obligations" owing to the economic emergency, counsel for Mrs. Evangeline Pinard of 11 Seneca Street, Dobbs Perry, asked Supreme Court Justice Frederick P. Close today for an injunction to restrain the sale of his client's property on a judgment of foreclosure until the economic emergency ceases to exist.
LONDON, March 16. -- The British Government's long-awaited White Paper on India will be published tomorrow, providing the first official draft of the new Federal Constitution.

Any indication of inflation or reduction of the value of the dollar in this country would start a "boom as mad as any that has been," and if the United States went off the gold standard it would force every country in the world to do so and would start a "race for the worst currency," Dr. Richard van Kuehlmann former German Foreign Minister, said last night.

WASHINGTON, March 16 (AP). -- The Washington Star said today it had verified reports that Representatives Clarence Cannon and Milton A. Romjue, Democrats from Missouri, engaged in an old fashioned fist fight last night in the House Office Building.

HAVANA, March 16. -- The explosion of a bomb early this morning badly damaged a large clock in a tower located in Fifth Avenue, Miramar a residential district. The police said a rebel group was responsible. The tower had been visited by thousands of American tourists.
PARIS, March 16 (AP). -- The weekly statement of the Bank of France shows the following changes in francs:

Young society women acting as manikins appeared In ensembles that matched the collars and leashes of their dogs at the opening of "The Doggie Fashion Show" at the Murray Mayer Salons, 715 Fifth Avenue, yesterday afternoon. The show will continue today and tomorrow at 5 P.M.

Herbert Hoover left New York at 5 o'clock yesterday afternoon from Pennsylvania Station. He planned to spend part of today and tomorrow in Chicago, then proceed to his home in Palo Alto, where he will "just take it easy for a month or so, maybe doing a little fishing in the California mountains," according to Lawrence Richey, his secretary, who, with the former President's son, Allan Hoover, accompanied him.

The report of the Western Electric Company for 1932 reflects, as usual, the trend of construction is the Bell System, according to Edgar S. Bloom, president of the company, who says the telephone system's requirements represent more than 90 per cent, of the company's sales.

PARIS, March 16. -- President Roosevelt's move toward the reduction of tariff barriers by reciprocal agreements with other nations received sympathetic comment here today. At the same time Commerce Minister Serre indicated that France soon would raise some tariffs against Germany.

LONDON, March 16. -- The stock markets were strong today following further improvement in Wall Street. The internationals were particularly active and British funds remained in demand under the influence of revenue returns. The tone in the foreign section was better, German bonds recovering further on a more hopeful view of the European situation.

Prices leveled off to some extent in the local commodity markets yesterday after the spectacular rally of the preceding day. Profit-taking was in evidence in several markets, but only in the case of sugar did this halt the upward trend entirely.

Following the regular weekly meeting of directors yesterday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York announced that Albert H. Wiggin, retired head of the Chase National Bank, had resigned as a director of the Reserve Bank. Mr. Wiggin is in Paris, having been abroad since January, when he went to Berlin to represent American creditor banks at the conference to renew the "standstill" agreement on German short-term debts.

Net income of the Allied Chemical and Dye Corporation for 1932 was $11,441,190 after depreciation, obsolescence, all taxes and other charges and expenses. This was equivalent, after payment of preferred dividends, to $3.62 a share on the 2,401,288 common shares.

Protests against the displacement by the city of regular engineering employes by emergency workers at lower wages were voiced yesterday at a mass meeting of employed and unemployed architects, engineers and technicians at the Washington Irving High School, Irving Place and Seventeenth Street.

It is commonly believed, and the record of his concerts bears out the assumption, that Arturo Toscanini is no warm admirer of Peter Tchaikovsky. For years the name of Tchaikovsky has been conspicuous by absence from Mr. Toscanini's programs.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., March 16. -- The body of Frank Wendowsky, 40 years old, of 44 James Street, South River, who had been missing since Tuesday, when he and three other men had been chased by prohibition agents in a raid on an alcohol plant at a farm on the Foxwood-Englishtown Road, Monroe Township, was found this morning in a brook near the farm.

A system by which lighterage in New York Harbor has sometimes been performed for railroads by outside concerns is about to be ended, according to a report made by a committee on competitive wastes submitted yesterday to the Eastern Presidents' Conference.

What now should be done? My conclusion is that the whole present policy should be scrapped; that this pretense of a general most-favored-nation system should be given up; and that the next practicable step is to make separate arrangements for reciprocal reductions of duty.
TORONTO, March 16. -- Possibility of a race between two old rivals of the Atlantic fishing banks from the Atlantic to Lake Michigan fired the imagination of salt and freshwater sailors alike tonight.

A political philosopher has said that the most useful laws are those which repeal useless or pernicious laws. But some are almost impossible to repeal. No historical precedent can be found for the Economy Bill which Congress with such record-breaking speed has placed before the President for signature.

The annual Eastern intercollegiate team and individual wrestling championships will get under way today at 2 P.M. in the Columbia University gymnasium. Second-round matches will be held tonight at 8 o'clock and the final bouts and consolation events will take place tomorrow at 2:30 P.M.

Bonds on the Stock Exchange pursued their upward course vigorously yesterday, and transactions amounted to $14,984,000, against $12,645,000 on the previous day. Many representative issues in all groups of domestic bonds rose 1 to more than 10 points.

LONG BEACH, L.I., March 16. -- An overdue note of the city of Long Beach for $554,853, held by the Bank of New York and Trust Company, was presented today for payment to City Treasurer Thomas J. Hogan by Lewis. L. Delafield Jr., attorney for the Long Beach Note-Holders' Protective Committee, an organization of unpaid creditors of this city.

PALM BEACH, Fla., March 16. -- The annual costume party, called this year a simplicity ball, taking place tonight at the Everglades Club as the major event of the late season, was a brilliant affair, attended by more than 400 members and guests.

Ambitious to regain third place in the international group of the National Hockey League, the New York Americans waged a desperate overtime battle against the Boston Bruins at Madison Square Garden last night.
WASHINGTON, March 16. -- The following orders were issued by the Coast Guard Service for the week ending March 15:

A swift rebound from the impact of the banking crisis is revealed in the weekly report of the Federal Reserve System, covering the week ended on Wednesday night, which includes the first three days of progressive reopening of banks.

ALBANY, March 16. -- Exercising the veto power for the first time, Governor Lehman disapproved today a bill authorizing removed magistrates and disbarred lawyers to take appeals to the Court of Appeals.

ALBANY, March 16. -- An amended rule covering the admission of attorneys and counselors at law to the bar was promulgated by the Court of Appeals today, whereby a law student who Is a graduate of an approved college or university will not be obliged to serve a clerkship in a law office before becoming eligible for admission to the bar.

All domestic life insurance companies doing business in New York are prohibited by rules and regulations Issued yesterday by George S. Van Schaick, Superintendent of Insurance, from declaring dividends to stockholders and policy holders during the present emergency.

Plans for making the return of legal beer a gala event gained momentum yesterday despite the fear that the action of the Senate may result in a beverage of 3.05 per cent alcohol by weight instead of the 3.2 per cent brew approved by the House of Representatives.
LONDON, March 16 (AP). -- The weekly statement of the Bank of England shows the following changes in pounds sterling:

While Wall Street's Interest was divided yesterday between the security and commodity markets, more attention was centred upon the latter for the reason that the Chicago Board of Trade and the New York Cotton Exchange reopened for the first time since the banking holiday was declared.

NEW ORLEANS, March 16 (AP). -- C.D. Ponamsky's Miss Careful, holding on through the stretch run with marvelous courage, nosed out Mrs. R.T. Flippen's Sweet Chariot in the best offering at the Fair Grounds today. Mrs. S.F. Murphy's Modesto was a close third.

Albert Einstein appealed yesterday for the moral intervention of the world against Hitlerism in Germany and the campaign of oppression waged by Hitlerites against the opposition. The noted scientist declared that while he did not see any imminent danger of war as a result of the advent of Adolf Hitler to power he feared that the influence of Hitlerism might be extended to other countries if not checked in Germany.
WASHINGTON, March 16 (AP). -- Leaders of prohibition organizations tonight assailed Congress for its approval of the beer bill and assailed the measure itself as unconstitutional.

Filling vacancies in the office of president in several of the great universities of America is not more important than the selection of the right person for the presidency of Hunter College in this city. Mr. HENRY W. TAFT and Dr. STEPHEN DUGGAN have, in letters to THE TIMES, called especial attention to the significance of this office.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., March 16. -- New York City's government has improved under Mayor O'Brien, and economies which never could have been brought about before have been effected, Samuel Seabury says today in an article in The Yale Daily News.
Jan Matulka, whose exhibition of new paintings is current at the Rehn Gallery, has not altered his accustomed course, though there is a certain freshness, always, in his manner of working.

Compulsory health insurance on a State-wide basis was urged last night by Albert G. Milbank, president of the Milbank Memorial Fund, at the annual dinner of the fund at the New York Academy of Medicine.

Einstein's Biggest Work. To say that Relativity is not' EINSTEIN'S principal achievement in science sounds to most of us like saying that CHRISTOPHER COLUMBUS has to his credit much bigger things than the mere discovery of a new world.

WASHINGTON, March 16. -- The Bureau of Navigation issued the following orders today, dated March 14:

WASHINGTON, March 16. -- President Roosevelt's national economy program received final Congressional approval this afternoon when the House accepted Senate amendments to the bill empowering him to reduce veterans' benefits and Federal salaries.

WASHINGTON, March 16. -- Following the presentation of the new British disarmament plan at Geneva today. Sir Ronald Lindsay, British Ambassador, called on President Roosevelt on instruction of his government to ask the support of the United States for the proposals made by Prime Minister MacDonald.

An advance of more than 1.7 points was recorded by The Annalist weekly index of wholesale commodity prices for the period of the tanking holiday. Provisionally computed, it stood at 82.2 on last Tuesday, compared with 80.5 on Friday, March 3, the day before the markets were closed.

An outstanding rental of business space yesterday was the leasing of the entire twenty-third floor in the Pershing Square Building, 100 East Forty-second Street, to William Esty Co., Inc., advertising agents. The floor contains 16,000 square feet of space and was leased from the Flintkote Corporation, represented by Cushman Wakefield.

The Bowery branch of the Young Men's Christian Association celebrated its sixty-first anniversary last night with a dinner at its building, 8 East Third Street. About 150 members of the board of managers and their guests attended. Police Commissioner Mulrooney and Colby M. Chester, president of the General Foods Corporation, were the chief speakers.

CHATTANOOGA, Term., March 16. -- Although Thomas E. Knight Jr., Attorney General of Alabama has consented to the transfer of eight Negroes in the Scottsboro case from the death house of Kilby Prison to the Jefferson County Jail at Birmingham, the actual moving of the prisoners probably will not take place before next week.

The heaviest accumulation of orders in several years awaited the resumption of business on the Cotton Exchange yesterday, and prices advanced $3 to $4 a bale. In New Orleans July contracts rose 99 points, and before a country-wide buying movement had been appeased some deliveries here showed a gain of 85 points, and final quotations were 51 to 61 points above those on March 3.

DETROIT, March 16 (AP). -- In a game marked by half a dozen fist fights, a near riot and a penalty to Lorne Chabot, Toronto goalie, the Detroit Red Wings battled to a 1-to-0 victory over the Toronto Maple Leafs tonight, winding up the home National League hockey season in a blaze of glory.

The United States liner Manhattan, due today from Hamburg, Havre, Southampton and Cobh, has on board a group of financial advisers of the League of Nations, coming here to confer in Washington. According to the United States Lines they are Sir Percy Thompson, who is Controller of the British Treasury; Henry Boissard, Paul de Peron, Herve Leroy and Hans Blau.
PALM BEACH, Fla., March 16. -- Mr. and Mrs. Samuel F. Streit entertained this afternoon with a large tea in the orange garden of the Everglades Club.

WASHINGTON, March 16 (AP). -- The daily average volume of Federal Reserve bank credit outstanding during the week ending March 15 was reported by the Federal Reserve Board tonight as $3,636,000,000, an increase of $17,000,000 compared with the preceding week and of $1,964,000,000 compared,with the same week in 1932.
PALM BEACH, Fla., March 16. -- Mr. and Mrs. Samuel F. Streit entertained this afternoon with a large tea in the orange garden of the Everglades Club.

WASHINGTON, March 16 (AP). -- The daily average volume of Federal Reserve bank credit outstanding during the week ending March 15 was reported by the Federal Reserve Board tonight as $3,636,000,000, an increase of $17,000,000 compared with the preceding week and of $1,964,000,000 compared,with the same week in 1932.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 16. -- It was late in 1928 that Charles Arthur Shires burst over the big league horizon by joining the White Sox, but it wasn't until the Spring training season of 1929 at San Antonio that he really blossomed out and was generally accepted, on his own recommendation, as The Great Shires.

Two women were shot and wounded, one of them seriously, and two men and a policeman were injured yesterday morning in a fight begun by Louis Dragon, 45 years old, a carpenter, at the home of his wife, Anna, 35, at 1,537 White Plains Road, the Bronx, where he had called to pay his alimony.

In conformity with the ranking and the seeding, Clifford Sutter of New Orleans, Frank Shields, Sidney B. Wood Jr. and Gregory Mangin reached the semi-final round of the national indoor tennis championship yesterday at the Seventh Regiment Armory.

In relinquishing his post in the Philippines, Governor General ROOSEVELT left behind him many friends among the natives, but the American colony was not demonstrative in bidding him good-bye. This attitude is not unusual. No recent Governor General has been popular with the Americans in Manila.

The emergency regulations under which life insurance companies have been operating in New York were modified yesterday by State Superintendent of Insurance George S. Van Schaick to permit the companies to advance funds for payroll purposes.

To The Editor of The New York Times: There are several evident objections to Assemblyman Breitbart's bill to make 4 1/2 per cent the maximum legal interest on mortgages. When people want to use other people's money to buy property for homes, investment or speculation, they ought to be willing to pay a reasonable interest rate for the use of the money.

Evidence that banks and other institutions which let go large blocks of their holdings of United States Government bonds before the start of the general banking holiday on March 4 are now engaged in replacing such holdings is furnished by the action of the government bond market in the last three days in leading the recovery in bond prices generally.

BERLIN, March 17. -- At a mass meeting of the Stahlhelm in Breslau, Vice Chancellor von Papen made a plea for ending violence and restoring the freedom of the individual. He received tremendous acclaim from the huge audience.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., March 17. -- The annual Yale freshman promenade was held in the New Haven Lawn Club this evening. About 350 persons attended. During the intermission the freshman quartet and the Howard twins entertained with vocal numbers.

MIAMI BEACH, Fla., March 17. -- Setting a record for the competition, Walter Everett of Tulsa, Okla., today won the first two heats of the annual Colonel E.H.R. Green Trophy race for outboard motor boats, feature of the Biscayne Bay regatta.

Treasures of painting, armor and tapestry have been bought by the Metropolitan Museum of Art from Clarence H. Mackay, chairman of the Postal Telegraph and Cable Corporation, who owns one of the greatest private collections in the world.
WASHINGTON, March 17. -- Income tax receipts for March 15 amounted to $13,659,901, as compared with 512,648,765 for the corresponding date last year, the Treasury reported today.

BERLIN, March 17. -- The Boerse was bullish today. With a few exceptions, the whole active stock list advanced, with gains of several points in many instances. The closing was at the day's highest levels. Bonds likewise moved upward, with the industrials most in demand, Vereinigte Stahlwerke rising 3 3/4 points.

WASHINGTON, March 17. -- Many national and State charter banks, now reorganizing their affairs to obtain an early classification as sound banks permitted to open under license and receive the full backing of the government, are planning to take advantage of that section of the emergency banking law which permits the issuance of 6 per cent non-assessable preferred stock for capital purposes.

DETROIT, Mich., March 17 -- A.L. Drum, former president of the Eastern Michigan Railways and other transportation companies making up the Eastern Michigan System, died today after a long illness. He was 58 years old.

By contrast with the swift advances of the two previous days, yesterday's setback on the Stock Exchange did not go beyond the limits of a "corrective movement." Sentiment in Wall Street showed little change, although business fell off sharply.

Pending the disposition of her application for a trainer's license, Miss Mary Hirsch, youthful daughter of Max Hirsch, is carrying on her work conditioning thorough-breds at Belmont Park, where many of the best-known racers in this district are being prepared for the coming season.

ALBANY, March 17. -- A program of State unemployment relief calling for jobs for 15,000 men a month in repairing and widening highways was revealed today by Colonel Frederick Stuart Greene, Commissioner of Public Works, and Captain Arthur W. Brandt, State Highway Commissioner, at a conference attended by all the district engineers of the high-way division.

BERLIN, March 17. -- The past week has made it abundantly manifest that "the National revolution" is translating into action one of its fundamental tenets: that only Germans of Germanic extraction are to be counted as full Germans and that all others must be excluded from those posts which would enable them to influence the public mind.

WASHINGTON, March 17. -- William D. Mitchell, Attorney General in the Hoover Cabinet and former Solicitor General of the United States, will become the senior partner in the New York City law firm of Mitchell, Taylor, Capron Marsh, it was announced today.

GENEVA, March 17. -- The League of Nations published today the text of the draft report under Paragraph 4, Article XV, of the League covenant, which the committee of three on Latin-American wars, headed by Sean Lester of the Irish Free State, will submit to the League Council tomorrow morning.

NEW HAVFN, Conn., March 17. -- A group of youthful skaters gained particular attention as the national figure skating championships started today at the New Haven Arena to decide the novice, junior and senior laurels.

ALBANY, March 17 (AP). -- The way was cleared today to link New York State's milk control plan with any broader plan which might he developed at Washington for aiding the dairy industry in the Eastern States.

Mr. and Mrs. John H. Vogel of Hempstead, L.I., yesterday announced the marriage of their daughter, Miss Kay Vogel, to George T. Dunlap Jr., member of the United States Walker Cup golf team, which took place last Tuesday in Elkton, Md.

LONDON, March 17. -- With the idea of reducing the floating debt, which jumped by u200,000,000 to u820,870,000 in the past twelve months, the treasury tonight invited tenders for a new 2 1/2 per cent conversion loan which will insure cheap borrowing for the next sixteen years.

WASHINGTON, March 17. -- House committee assignments were completed today when Republican leaders nominated their membership for the thirty-eight committees. The action completed the organization of the Seventy-third Congress, and all committees are now authorized to function.

Synthetic chemistry has so far made only a beginning in the production of powerful explosives, drugs, antiseptics, anesthetics and other substances, and is only waiting for industrial conditions to improve before proceeding to new achievements in these fields and others.

CHICAGO, March 17 (AP). -- Frederick Uhlmann, a leading member and former vice president of the Chicago Board of Trade, said today that the agricultural measure prepared by President Roosevelt was "the most fantastic bill ever proposed by any country in peace-time."

This is the time of year when the game fishermen begin to get anxious about their favorite spots where some big fellow is known to be lurking. Furthermore, this is the season when the fresh-water angler begins dreaming about three-pound trout and twenty-pound landlocked salmon.
