WASHINGTON, March 17. -- The House sent the Cullen bill as amended by the Senate to provide 3.05 per cent beer to conference today with the expressed hope that the House conferees would insist upon the original percentage of 3.2 of alcohol by weight.

ALBANY, March 17. -- Expressing hope that an agreement would be reached on a bill to provide for charter revision for New York City, Senator Thomas C. Desmond, Republican, of Orange, announced today that he would hold conferences in New York City over the weekend with leaders in the movement for charter changes.
WASHINGTON, March 17 -- President and Mrs. Roosevelt celebrated their twenty-eighth wedding anniversary with a small family party at dinner.

A field of white cross belts and a touch of green, worn by members of the Sixty-ninth Regiment in the centre pews of St. Patrick's Cathedral yesterday, lay below the choir loft as the annual pontifical military mass in celebration of the feast of St. Patrick was sung to the soldiers and a bordering host of loyal adherents which jammed the cathedral.

CHICAGO, March 17. -- President Roosevelt's farm-relief program is looked upon by stock yards and packing interests here as a "new allotment plan," with which they were far from being in harmony, but they did not voice today the bitter objections which the previous bill brought forth.

LONDON, March 17. -- The very day a report reached London from Washington of criticism of the appointment of Robert Bingham, Louisville (Ky.) publisher, as Ambassador to Great Britain on the ground that he was un-American, there appeared a letter in The London Times to the effect that Mr. Bingham.

The Board of Student Representatives of Columbia College proposed yesterday that Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of Columbia University, exercise control over The Columbia Spectator if, at any time in the future, the student daily newspaper "be guilty" of short-comings cited in the recent report of an investigating committee.

The last public act of Bear Admiral William Woodward Phelpe, commandant of the Third Naval District and the Navy Yard in Brooklyn, before his retirement on July 1, will be the launching of the new 10,000-ton treaty cruiser, New Orleans, on the morning of April 12. at the Navy Yard.

Cardinal Hayes will arrive home from Nassau, Bahama Islands, where he has spent the last few weeks, Tuesday morning on the Pan America of the Munson Line, which is due to dock about 9 A.M. at Pier 64, foot of West Twenty-fourth Street.

Friday, March 17, 1933. An expansion in the offerings of money for all classes of loans brought about a generally easier tone in the market, with consequent shading in rates. Stock Exchange call loans dropped to 3 per cent in the afternoon from a start at 4 and interval of 3 1/2.

Sales of houses continued to play a more important part in Manhattan real estate activity yesterday. Reports of brokers in the last few days indicate that changes in fee ownership are becoming more numerous than leaseholds, which up to this time have formed the bulk of trading.

Columbia's Forty-niners, a society comprised of graduates of the university when it was situated on Forty-ninth Street, held their twentieth annual reunion last night in the Columbia Club, 4 West Forty-third Street. About 100 members of the classes of 1895 to 1900 attended.

Although hungry and facing eviction from their home, a Brooklyn family of three has $2,000, detectives of the Clymer Street station learned yesterday when investigating illness in the family, at first thought to be food poisoning but later found to be malnutrition.

WASHINGTON, March 17 (AP). -- A new program of farm mortgage relief is being prepared by farm organization leaders, who said today it would be held in abeyance until the Roosevelt agricultural relief program has been acted on by Congress.

WASHINGTON, March 17 (AP). -- As a program of immediate action to complete the "new deal" legislative ideas of President Roosevelt was agreed upon by the President and Congressional leaders, a start was made on railroad legislation with the introduction of a far-reaching bill by Chairman Rayburn of the House Interstate Committee to regulate railroad holding companies and motor truck transportation and to consolidate the power and radio commissions into a commission on communications.

BOSTON, March 17 -- The field of advancing longevity and freedom from disease In persons past the age of 50 is still untouched and out of all proportion to the progress of sanitation in adolescence and early adult life, Dr. Louis I. Dublin, vice president and statistician of the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company, declared in the first of the annual Cutter Lectures on Preventive Medicine at the Harvard Medical School here this afternoon.

WASHINGTON, March 17 -- Right on the heels of the passage of the beer bill, the Department of Agriculture announced today that a long fight against downy mildew, the arch-enemy of hops, is at last near success.

One Item of $461,080 was withdrawn from the account of the International Magazines, Inc., in the Harriman National Bank and Trust Company without the knowledge of the company officials, Arthur Schwartz, Assistant United, States Attorney, discovered yesterday, as he continued a grand jury investigation of the bank and its former chairman, Joseph W. Harriman.

WASHINGTON, March 17. -- The Roosevelt administration intends to use every possible means to achieve some sort of definite and practical success at the General Disarmament Conference at Geneva and to prevent it from blowing up or producing a patchwork treaty.

A vivid picture of exactly what had happened on the eve of the banking moratorium, in the matter of gold reserves and note circulation, is presented by Thursday night's weekly statement of the Federal Reserve. Up to the declaration on Feb. 14 of the Michigan moratorium -- which was the spark that started the conflagration -- the system had been gaining gold.

Two of the oldest and best known book publishing companies in America, D. Appleton Co., founded in 1825, and the Century Company, founded in 1870, are to be united under the name of D. Appleton-Century Company, it was announced yesterday.

Albert Einstein spent a busy day yesterday acting as godfather to the new-born son of Mr. and Mrs. Jacob Landau of 1,200 Fifth Avenue, visiting associates at Princeton University, and calling on acquaintances. Mr. Landau is managing director of the Jewish Telegraphic Agency.
BERLIN, March 17. -- Dr. Alfred Hugenberg's Lokalanzeiger writes today in part:

The Westchester County Emergency College, which is being organized by Dr. Frederick B. Robinson, president of City College, at the request of the State Commissioner of Education, will probably hold its first session next Wednesday afternoon at the White Plains High School, Dr. Robinson announced yesterday.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, March 17 (AP). -- Leon Trotsky, exiled Russian revolutionary leader, believes that recent financial developments in the United States will result in ultimate centralization of the banking system and that the United States will soon emerge from the crisis more the master of world capital than ever.

BRADENTON, Fla., March 17. -- The Ruthless Yankees paid a social call on the St. Louis Cardinals today, and departed, figuratively, leaving ruin and destruction in their wake. They burled the Red Birds under a 16-6 score and had absolutely no respect for four of Gabby Street's pitchers.
WASHINGTON, March 17. -- Authority to borrow $22,000,000 from the Reconstruction Finance Corporation was asked of the Interstate Commerce Commission today by the Southern Pacific Company.

PRINCETON, N.J., March 17. -- R. Kenneth Fairman of Syracuse, N.Y., was elected captain of next season's Princeton varsity basketball team at a meeting of the letter-men today. Edward W. Lee of Mount Vernon, N.Y., was named manager.

PALM BEACH, Fla., March 17. -- In celebration of Mr. Clawson's birthday, Mrs. John L. Clawson entertained today with a luncheon at her Brazilian Avenue villa, inviting a large group of additional guests later for tea.

Four members of the subcommittee on allocation of the standing fiscal committee of the League of Nations arrived yesterday on the United States liner Manhattan to study tax problems here as a part of their investigation of double taxation in the larger nations.

WASHINGTON, March 17. -- The House today passed a bill authorizing the Reconstruction Finance Corporation to loan money to non-profit corporations organized for the purpose of financing repair or reconstruction in the Southern California earthquake area.

William Barnes, former Republican State Chairman, who died June 25, 1930, at his home, in Armonk, Westchester County, left an estate appraised yesterday at only $25,404 gross and $12,446 net. He had been owner of The Albany Evening Journal for many years, but sold it in 1925.

Paintings, silverware and rare books valued at $100,000, collected by the late Ivar Kreuger in the prosperous days when he was striving to establish a world match monopoly, were discovered yesterday in a vault of the Goodman Warehouse, on Bergen Avenue in Jersey City, by attorneys who made a visit of inspection under a court order.
Measures proposed for farm relief unsettled sentiment yesterday in the cotton market and liquidation brought declines of 30 to 36 points in prices on tne Cotton Exchange here.

Sailing today on the Red Star liner Belgenland for Channel ports are H. Reeves Smith, English actor; Captain W.J. Roberts, formerly of the old American liner New York; F.J. Blackman, the Rev. A. Hoverland, A.E. Lindley, the Rev. P.M. Filbrun, Dr. and Mrs. C.P. Huber and Mrs. William West.

Many letters from public schools in the city, pledging continued support to the school relief fund for needy children, have been received by Dr. William J. O'Shea, Superintendent of Schools, since his appeal to the teachers for "at least" $100,000 this month to match a similar amount contributed by the State.

TOKYO, March 17. -- Violations of official secrecy by an unnamed Cabinet member, who disclosed to the newspaper Asahl the draft j of Japan's resignation from the League of Nations aroused the anger of the Privy Council, whose vice president, Baron Ki-ichiro Hiranuma, today rebuked the government.

Members of the New York Stock Exchange were authorized yesterday to initiate or continue arbitrage transactions in securities or commodities between the United States and other countries, in a ruling by the special committee of seven formed by the governing committee to handle all matters arising out of the banking holiday and of recent legislation affecting foreign exchange and gold.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Now is the time for public opinion in support of the government economy bill to make itself felt in Washington to counteract the pressure which we know is being put upon Senators by groups whose personal interests are affected by the measure.

Progress in forming a readjustment plan for the Missouri Pacific Railroad has reached a point at which an announcement is expected next week. The financing will be undertaken with the help of the recent amendment to the bankruptcy act and any other amendments that may that made at the present session of Congress.
NEW YORK. Viscount and Viscountess Tarbat of Scotland, who had been at the Madison, sailed yesterday on the Alaunia.

The fight to keep control of the liquor traffic out of politics opened here yesterday, with the Women's Organization for National Prohibition Reform and the hotel industry of New York State, two militantly wet organizations, backing the plan of Governor Lehman's liquor control commission for non-political liquor-control boards.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., March 17. -- Improvement in the scholastic standing of Massachusetts Institute of Technology undergraduates is shown in the announcement today of the names of 725 students who in the first term achieved high records in their studies.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The outstanding aspect of the moment is the whole-hearted response to the leadership of President Roosevelt. Partisanship has been forgotten and selfishness has been subordinated to the common needs and the common good.

The five-year leadership of Lehigh in intercollegiate wrestling is threatened as the result of the semi-final-round matches last night in the twenty-ninth annual championship tournament of the Eastern Intercollegiate Wrestling Association in the Columbia gymnasium.
WASHINGTON, March 17 -- Authorities assert that real beer is in prospect, regardless whether the House alcoholic content of 3.2 per cent by weight or the Senate dictum of 3.05 per cent prevails.

STATE COLLEGE, Pa., March 17. -- By juggling figures a mathematician might be able to satisfy himself that Syracuse could lose its Eastern intercollegiate boxing championship when the finals of the tenth annual tournament are staged tomorrow night.

BOSTON, March 17. -- Expansion of needed public improvements was urged to "prime the pump of industrial resumption" by George H. Dern, Secretary of War, in an address before the Charitable Irish Society here tonight. Action to restore prosperity he held better than waiting, with the idea that recovery must be slow and painful.

Progress in reducing unnecessary expenses in passenger train operation, a point cited in the recent report of the National Transportation Committee, was disclosed in the report on progress made by the presidents' committee on preventable waste, which met yesterday in the Pennsylvania Station.
WASHINGTON, March 17. -- President and Mrs. Roosevelt celebrated tonight their twenty-eighth wedding anniversary with a family dinner party in the White House.

The Manhattan of the United States Lines arrived yesterday bringing a man with a load of disappointment to thousands of Americans who always have cherished the thought that beer was a food and full of vitamins. Tempering his announcement, however, Albert Fischer, a consulting engineer of Frankfort, Germany, brought with him a process which, he says, will "vitaminize" beer and make it what every one believes it to be.

NEW ORLEANS, March 17 (AP). -- After failing to win in thirty-four previous races, W.F. Lutz's Madame B.C. came through with her first victory today, defeating eleven other non-winners in a mile race at the Fair Grounds.

CLEVELAND, March 17. -- Changes in the American form of government to make it possible for the administration to assume responsible powers in time of crisis, such as President Roosevelt was able to fake in the banking crisis, were advocated by Newton D. Baker tonignt in an address over the National Broadcasting System.

JACKSON, Miss., March 17 (AP). -- Governor Sennett Conner said today that Federal legislation aimed at reduction of acreage in cotton and other key crops has the backing of the special committee of the conference of Governors of cotton-growing States.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Whoever performs a hitherto untried experiment, performs a service for humanity. He does so whether the experiment is a success or not. If it is a success, a new law has been discovered; if it is a failure, it has proved that an alleged law is not true.
WASHINGTON, March 17. -- The estate of Thomas F. Ryan of New York has obtained an estate tax abatement of $17,528,108, Commissioner of tnternal Revenue David Burnet announced today.

The approximate status of the municipal bond market is reflected in the following list of representative high-grade State, city and county bonds, legal for savings banks in this State, now offered by dealers:

Reorganization of the Emergency Work and Relief Administration, charged with the duty of supervising city work and relief projects, is imminent as a result of the resignation of the members of the administration, it was reported yesterday.
The stalwart figure of Frank Shields and his dreaded service passed out of the national indoor tennis championship yesterday.

CINCINNATI, March 17 (AP) -- Three research workers of the College of Medicine of the University of Cincinnati announced today the development of a serum that transforms the usually disabling undulant fever into something little more incapacitating than, a slight, common cold.

MIAMI BEACH, Fla., March 17 (AP). -- Charles Yacht, golf professional, was charged with being an accomplice of Harry Sitamore, confessed jewel robber, in an information filed today in Dade County criminal court.

WASHINGTON, March 17. -- Determined to speed his program for business recovery to the utmost, President Roosevelt decided today to push through Congress, without a recess, a permanent, constructive legislative program including railroad consolidation, unemployment relief, power legislation, and strengthening of the banking laws to prevent speculation.

MOSCOW, March 17 (AP). -- Replying to British protestations in connection with the holding of four British subjects for alleged sabotage in their work for a British electrical machinery company, Foreign Commissar Litvinoff in a communique tonight said:

SOUTH HADLEY, Mass., March 17. -- Announcement of the award of twelve fellowships for 1933-34 in the gift of Mount Holyoke College was made here today by President Mary E. Woolley. Of the twelve recipients, five are members of the present senior class and candidates for the A.B. degree, with honor this June.

BASLE, Switzerland, March 17. -- In Germany today Dr. Hjalmar Schacht has been taking up his duties as president of the Reichsbank. Dr. Hans Luther, the retiring president, has been gathering up his private papers, preparing to depart for the diplomatic post in a distant country that is said to have been promised him.

Dr. William McDougall, Professor of Psychology at Duke University, j has put into one volume what he considers the most essential parts of his two well-known books, "Outline of Psychology" and "Outline of Abnormal Psychology." The book has just been published by Scribners under the title, "The Energies of Man."

GREENWICH, Conn., March 17. -- Miss Marion McFadden, daughter of Mrs. Parmalee McFadden of Chicago and the late Mr. McFadden, was married here this afternoon to James Pickerall Hume of Chicago, son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas L. Hume of Washington, D.C.

Only $2,236,748 of new municipal bonds will be up for competitive bids next week, reflecting the recent banking holiday when municipal officials generally regarded as futile any effort to market new obligations. This week's revised total of new issues up for award was $7,288,404, of which only a small portion attracted any tenders.

PHILADELPHIA, March 17. -- Walter Spence, brilliant Rutgers star, was one of the outstanding performers as the twenty-seventh annual individual championships of the Intercollegiate Swimming Association opened in the Hutchinson Pool at the University of Pennsylvania today.

LONDON, March 17. -- The report that the British Government has actually told Soviet authorities trade relations between the two countries will end unless the charges against the four British engineers arrested in Moscow are dropped is more definite than justified by the diplomatic facts of the situation.

WASHINGTON, March 17. -- The value of United States exports declined in February to $100,000,000, compared with $120,593,000 in January, and represented the smallest month's shipments since August, 1904, when exports reached $92,254,000, preliminary figures by the Commerce Department showed today.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The Junior Employment Bureau of the Vocational Service for Juniors, which is situated in the West Side Continuation School, is in need of games and magazines for use in its waiting room for the older applicants.
PHILADELPHIA, March 17. -- Jacob Mathay, a lawyer, who was chairman of the ways and means committee of the State House of Representatives, was shot and killed today in the bathroom of his home.

The Cardinal Hayes Literature Committee made public yesterday its eighth "White List" of recommended books. The list was issued without a preface other than the following lines which appear on all the lists:
The Society of the Friendly Sons of St. Patrick gathered its members and their guests, numbering more than 1,500, at the Hotel Astor last night for the 149th annual dinner of the organization.

MIAMI, Fla., March. 17. -- The Carlaris colt Von Sion, which races for F.A. Forden, continued to roll up a consistent 1933 record when he was first in the St. Patrick's Day purse, feature at Tropical Park today. A maiden in 1932, Von Sion this year has won four of his six starts and has finished in the money the other two times.
VIENNA, March 17. -- The mobilization of the Heimwehr in Vienna yesterday, which led to the resignation of Chief of Police Brandl, caused stormy scenes in the Austrian Senate tonight.

The resignation of four additional directors of the Bush Terminal Company, making a total of seven, was announced yesterday by John A. Stephens, whose resignation as president and director was accepted recently to take effect on April 3. Those who resigned yesterday were F.J. Lisman of F.J. Lisman Co., Frank Bailey, chairman of the Prudence Company; Harry B. Lake of Ladenburg, Thalmann Co., and R.G. Simonds, vice president of Bush Terminal.

The Hamburg-American liner New York came into Quarantine yesterday afternoon flying the old imperial flag, black, white and red, instead of the black, gold and red ensign of the German Republic, which has been displayed on all German ships for fourteen years.

ALBANY, March 17. -- Hearing on the State beer bills was set today for next Thursday after Governor Lehman had protested to Senator Dunnigan against the postponement to March 28, ordered yesterday by Senator Kleinfeld.

LONDON, March 17 (AP). -- Yosuke Matsuoka, the chief Japanese delegate at recent League of Nations meetings at which the Chino-Japanese conflict was considered, declared today, before his departure for America on his way to Tokyo, that war between the United States and Japan "would be an act of madness."

WASHINGTON, March 17. -- Canada's imports from the United States were stimulated in the last week, but industry in the Dominion remains slack and collections continue dull, the Department of Commerce said today in its weekly review of business conditions abroad.

DECATUR, Ala., March 17. -- This little town on the south bank of the Tennessee River in Northern Alabama was preparing today for the trial of the most exciting criminal case that has been heard here since 1903, when three Negroes were executed for attacking a white girl.

Radio Debut Successful. President ROOSEVELT must find it gratifying that the volume of congratulatory messages elicited by his management of the business of the United States since March 4 compares favorably with the fan mail of the most popular radio stars.

BERLIN, March 17 (AP). -- Hermann W. Goering, Minister Without Portfolio and Commissioner for the Interior Ministry in the State of Prussia, told a convention of Prussian police officers today that with his accession organizations of officials or officers became unnecessary and that he would brook no interference.

The spread of financial difficulties throughout the country during the second half of Fabruary caused a more than seasonal decline in business activity last month, according to the monthly report yesterday of the conference of statisticians in industry, operating under the auspices of the National Industrial Conference Board.

With the investment banking fraternity devoting its efforts largely this week to re-establishing its market after the banking holiday, little effort was made to introduce new issues of securities to the public. However, two small short-term municipal offerings were made, one or $550,000 for Monmouth County, N.J., and one of $500,000 for the city of Utica, N.Y. Both were well received.

LINCOLN, Neb., March 17 (AP) -- Ray Page, pioneer aviator, in whose school Colonel Charles A. Lindbergh had learned to fly, died today after a long illness. He formerly owned the Lincoln Aircraft Company, which he sold in 1929 because of ill health.

WASHINGTON, March 17. -- Attorney General Cummings and United States Attorney George Z. Medalie of New York conferred here today on the banking situation in New York as disclosed by recent testimony before the Senate Banking and Currency Committee.

TAMPA, Fla., March 17. -- Sunburnt to a crisp, Manager Donle Bush was hitting grounders to his Cincinnati infielders and shouting "'Atta ol' pepper, boy! Make it snappy!" The chunky manager who will try to lead the celler-dwellers of the National League out of the dark basement into the light was displaying something new in baseball footwear.

The listed bond market yesterday held generally its gains of the two previous days, but failed, except in the case of United States Government bonds, to advance on the average. Foreign loans, particularly, were easier. Industrial and utility issues in the domestic corporation group showed a better tone than did the rails.

The program of farm relief placed before Congress by President ROOSEVELT is in large part a combination of measures familiar in theory but untried in practice. It includes much of the "domestic allotment" plan approved by the House of Representatives at the last session but sidetracked in the Senate.
LOS ANGELES, March 17. -- Joan Crawford and Douglas Fairbanks Jr. separated tonight. Announcement of the parting was made at Miss Crawford's home in Brentwood.

LONDON, March 17. -- Retiring as Ambassador, Andrew W. Mellon sailed for home today on the Leviathan, declaring he had heartily enjoyed his year in England and hoped to return. He was accompanied by David Flnley, honorary counselor of the United States Embassy, and Mrs. Finley.

WASHINGTON, March 17. -- Although the Roosevelt administration goal for our navy will be full London treaty strength, Secretary Swanson indicated today that any construction program would have to wait on Congressional action, which in turn would be dictated by the nation's financial condition.

Two witnesses admitted yesterday that they tried to withhold information from the authorities after the steamer Observation was blown to bits with a loss of seventy-two lives last Sept. 9 and a Federal steam-boat inspector gave contradictory testimony concerning his report on the steamer's boiler at the trial of Alexander Forsyth, part owner of the boat, who is charged with manslaughter, before Bronx County Judge Barrett.

PARIS, March 17. -- There will be no open tennis tournament under the sponsorship of the International Lawn Tennis Federation this year or for some years to come. The federation held its annual meeting today, and the delegates registered their opinions against the plan.

It was currently reported that President HOOVER, after the personal discussions on naval disarmament which he had at Rapidan with RAMSAY MACDONALD in 1929, reported that the British Prime Minister was "long on ideals but short on facts."

CHICAGO, March 17. -- Edwin D. Krenn and Edward S. Dato, who once did a real estate business under the firm name of Krenn Dato, with Mrs. Edith Rockefeller McCormick as a partner, have resigned as trustees of the Edith Rockefeller McCormick trust, it was disclosed today.
"Masks and Faces," a play by A. J. Minor, will open this evening at the Liberty Theatre.

CHICAGO, March 17 -- A warning to American women that "beer makes fat," that beer "will make trouble in politics, law enforcement and the home" and that "no nation ever drank itself out of a depression" was issued today by the National Woman's Christian Temperance Union.

Stockholders of the American Tobacco Company were notified yesterday that at their annual meeting on April 5 they will be asked to "ratify, approve and confirm" allotments of stock previously made to employes who were officers or directors and all acts of the latter in connection with the employes' stock subscription plan which was approved originally at a special meeting of stockholders on July 28, 1930.
BERLIN, March 17. -- Dr. Lion Feuchtwanger's Berlin residence in the fashionable Grunewald district was raided by Nazis a week ago, it was learned today.

A resolution calling upon actors and actresses to refuse to participate in any benefit performance if not paid for their work, unless it be for a cause of proved worth, or 25 per cent of the gross receipts be given to the Actors Fund of America for its charitable work, was adopted yesterday afternoon at the monthly meeting of the Catholic Actors Guild at the Hotel Astor.
BERLIM, March 17 (AP). -- The Reichsbank's statement as of March 15 shows the following changes in reichsmarks:

MIAMI, Fla., March 17. -- With only two dates on which exhibition games are not scheduled for the Dodgers from now until they open, their championship season at Philadelphia on April 12. Manager Max Carey today expressed great satisfaction about the condition of his athletes.
DUBLIN, March 17 -- The national observance of St. Patrick's Day in the Free State was on a more imposing scale this year than for many years past.

LOS ANGELES, March 17. -- It took the Giants some time today to make up their minds that they could beat the Hollywood Stars, but once they decided on the point they acted with neatness and dispatch. They clipped a pitcher named George Gardner for three runs in the seventh and thereby took the engagement, 6 to 5.

The rally came to a halt in the local commodity markets yesterday, and all staples except sugar closed with losses on the day. Sugar had reacted the day before. The general decline was attributed to further profit-taking and a feeling that the excited rallies of the first two days had gone too far for the present.
PARIS, March 17. -- Premier Daladier, on his return to Paris tonignt with Joseph Paul-Boncour, Foreign Minister, expressed the conviction that his trip to Geneva was "indispensable."

Mrs. Anna Roosevelt Dall, after delivering a radio address yesterday morning on the desirability of young married women combining their home life with outside endeavor, left with her grandmother. Mrs. Sarah Delano Roosevelt, for Washington to join the President at the White House dinner celebrating his twenty-eighth wedding anniversary.

WASHINGTON, March 17. -- A decision by the Senate Agriculture Committee to await action by the House on the administration's agricultural relief bill and possibly hold open hearings later marked the first break today in the rush of legislation through Congress.

A tireless manhunt staged by postal inspectors and New York detectives since the daring daylight robbery of a mail carrier and his armed guard in the Loop section of Chicago on Dec. 6 resulted last night in the arrest of three men here.

Clubs, restaurants and establishments that specialize In liquid refreshments were going ahead yesterday with preparations to sell beer when that beverage is legalized. Meanwhile brewery interests were in conference discussing beer legislation, concerning which they professed much uncertainty.

The directors of the Realty Stabilization Corporation, which was formed last month by local banks and mortgage companies for the purpose of rehabilitating the New York City real estate situation, will meet next week to vote upon a proposal for abandoning the plans for the corporation.

TIENTSIN, March 17. -- The conviction that Japanese Army leaders are determined upon an early attempt at subjugation of the Pelping-Tientsin area is growing among foreign military observers and in diplomatic circles in North China, as well as among Chinese officials.

ROME, March 17. -- Italy read with the greatest interest today the disarmament proposals submitted at Geneva by Prime Minister MacDonald of Great Britain because he and Foreign Secretary Simon will arrive here tomorrow.

A large turnover of housing in the New Jersey metropolitan area was reported yesterday, one transaction being the third resale of a flat since last September. This building, a four-story brick structure with stores at 322 Baldwin Avenue, north-east corner of Court House Place, Jersey City, was conveyed by Peter Kostick to Yeranig Kachanian.

PHILADELPHIA, March 17 (AP). -- Bill Carr, record-breaking Olympic champion In the 400-meter run, tonight suffered Injuries in an automobile accident in Bala, a suburb, which may mean the end of his athletic career.
WASHINGTON, March 17. -- The Bureau of Navigation issued the following orders today, dated March 15:

Banking conditions throughout the State and country continued to improve yesterday as scattered reopenings were announced, money rates relaxed further and the financial markets settled down into a quieter mood after their exuberant display of reviving hope and confidence earlier in the week.

HAVANA, March. 17. -- The explosion of a bbmb at noon yesterday in the building of the Compania Cubana de Electricidad, a subsidiary of the Electric Bond and Share, in the city of Cienfuegos, Santa Clara Province, started a fire which caused considerable damage, according to information received here today.

James A. Farley, Democratic National chairman, after participating yesterday afternoon in the St. Patrick's Day parade, returned to his suite in the Hotel Biltmore to plunge once more into the intricate task of apportioning the Federal patronage at the disposal of the national administration.
COMMERCIAL PAPER. Yesterday -- 4 per cent for the best names. Thursday -- 4 1/2 Per cent for the best names.

Plodding in desperately at every opportunity and pitting his heavy body attack against his rival's scintillating boxing skill, Ben Jeby of the east side succeeded in retaining his world's middleweight championship at Madison Square Garden last night.

VIENNA, March 17. -- Vienna was shocked today by newspaper accounts of the brutal treatment of a Socialist Reichstag member and a Socialist editor by Nazis in Germany and of the assassination in Berlin of an Austrian national, presumably by Nazi avengers.
To the Editor of The New York Times: Newspapers would do well to reprint the editorial of THE NEW YORK TIMES of March 13, "Not Dictatorship but Law."

LONDON, March 17. -- Limited self-government under a federal system, with a broad franchise, is offered to India in the White Paper published today, embodying all of the major recommendations of the three round-table conferences. These now become the official proposals of the British Government to Parliament.

By winning an exceptionally well-played five-game match in which two contrasting styles of play were pitted against each other. Miss Anne Page of Philadelphia reached the final round of the women's invitation squash racquets tournament of the Junior League of New York yesterday.

The Phelps Dodge Corporation, one of the leaders in the copper industry, reports for 1932 a consolidated net loss of $3,752,252 after all charges, inventory losses and provision for depreciation. This compares with a deficit of $5,057,378 in 1931 after similar charges.

HUNTINGTON, L.I., March 17. -- Bend Down Sister, white and lemon pointer, owned by William H. Hand of East Hampton, L.I., and handled by William Richardson, today, won the Derby Stake, major event of the first day of the seventh annual field trial of the North Shore Game Protective Association.

Lucrezia Bori and about half the Metropolitan Opera personnel of 770 artists and staff members took part in a post-season performance of Massenet's "Manon" at the opera house last evening, the proceeds going to the committee for saving the Metropolitan Opera.

WASHINGTON, March 17 (AP) -- The Cullen beer bill tonight was in the conference stage, with a quick compromise predicted. Nothing could be done formally until Monday because the Senate was in adjournment until then and had still to appoint its conference managers.

WASHINGTON, March 17. -- The Steagall bill to amend the emergency banking act, designed to permit non-member State banks to obtain loans from the Federal Reserve Banks directly instead of through member banks was sent back to the Banking and Currency Committee of the House late today, after the House had plainly indicated opposition to passing further important legislation without an opportunity for thorough study.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., March 17. -- South Side of Newark and Trenton will meet tomorrow for the Class Four high school championship of New Jersey. South Side gained the final in the Rutgers gymnasium tonight by defeating Paterson Central, 35 to 25, and Trenton rallied in the second half to down New Brunswick, 29 to 18.

A group of distinguished psychologists, neurologists and educators attended a meeting yesterday afternoon of the Advisory Council of the Normal Child Development Clinic, which is under the auspices of the Neurological Institute of New York, of Columbia University.

S. Howard Cohen, president of the Board of Elections, said yesterday that the exact form of the ballot to be used for the election of delegates to a repeal convention would have to be prescribed in the bill calling for the convention, as there was no precedent for such an election.

Mrs. John Williams Morgan gave a luncheon yesterday at the Ritz-Carlton. Her guests were Mrs. Charles Duncan Miller, Mrs. Robert H.R. Loughborough, Mrs. Donald B. Aldrich, Mrs. George H. Nettleton 3d, Mrs. Charles Lemaire Zabriskie and Miss Ann Donald.

Business in the Broadway play-houses will continue as usual and the possibility of a wholesale closing of shows after this evening's performances, as had been predicted earlier by the League of New York Theatres, has vanished.

That hive of industry, the New School for Social Research, opened three art shows yesterday. Six water-colorists are exhibiting in one of them. Boris Aronson has two dashing studies, "Gloucester Harbor" and "Evening, Provincetown," notable for their liquid freshness of color as well as for their unhackneyed treatment of familiar subjects.
GENEVA, March 17. -- Prime Minister MacDonald of Great Britain left tonight for Rome after having undoubtedly succeeded in the immediate objectives of his Geneva moves yesterday.

Reaction overtook the financial and commodity markets yesterday as speculative enthusiasm became chilled following the wide introductory advance with which trading was resumed on Wednesday and Thursday.

CHICAGO, March 17. -- Wheat made a strong start and a tame finish today on the Board of Trade here. A carryover of buying orders from yesterday resulted in opening sales at as much as 3 cents a bushel above the close on that day and around 7 cents higher than the finish on March 3.
Mrs. E.J. Selby Tanner, in the Sulgrave, Park Av. and 67th St.: Georce T. Wisner, in 28 E. 63d St.: Bigelow, King, Morris, Pendergast, Inc., broker.

SANTIAGO, Chile, March 17. -- Foreign Minister Cruchaga delivered notes this evening to the Ambassadors of the United States and Great Britain in reply to a query concerning the sudden removal by Chile of the financial guaranty backing an international loan floated in New York and London by Cosach, the nitrate corporation of Chile, now in process of dissolution.

Declaring that "Congress should not dare to recess" before enacting a comprehensive program of unemployment relief and other constructive measures, Benjamin C. Marsh, executive secretary of the People's Lobby, of which Professor John Dewey is president, told a luncheon meeting of the organization at the Town Hall Club yesterday that meetings were being planned in forty-eight State capitals and 160 other cities to arouse public opinion in support of the lobby's program.

Skirling war pipes, muttering drums and glittering brasses quickened the steps of 20,000 marchers yesterday in the annual St. Patrick's Day parade up Fifth Avenue and thrilled 400,000. watchers packed four deep alone the curbs.

The Committee on the Costa of Medical Care, after long study recommended "sickness insurance" as a voluntary and community provision. But Mr. ALBERT G. MILBANK, the president of the Milbank Memorial Fund, which has been serviceable to the public in making experiments in promoting community health in various centres, has urged that unless the scheme is compulsory and at least State-wide, the results hoped for will not be achieved.

PARIS, March 17. -- Experiments in a treatment of cancer with a serum made from cobra venom under a process originated by an American scientist, Dr. Adolph Monae-Lesser, were described in a paper read before the Academy of Medicine here by a noted French surgeon, Dr. Andre Gosset.

Four floors in the Grand Central Palace were being transformed rapidly yesterday into vistas of fragrant loveliness in preparation for the opening of the twentieth International Flower Show tomorrow at 2 P. M.

A poet had a witty complaint recently in one of the mazagines about the enormous amount of information distributed by publishers concerning the private lives and working methods of their authors. There is an amusing point in it: your genuine reader wants books from his favorite writers, not stories about how many eggs they like for breakfast.

PHILADELPHIA, March 18. -- The metropolitan team of Lathrop S. Haskins, Racquet and Tennis Club, New York, and Robert Goodwin, Greenwich, Conn., Field Club, furnished the major upset as the national squash racquets doubles championship tournament opened today.

BERLIN. AT Castle Doorn, across the frontier in Holland, it has been noted that the woodpile has not received much attention of late. Matters of more serious import claim the attention of the royal exile who abides there, still hoping and expectant despite the handicap of more than man's allotted span of threescore years and ten. arch who failed to hold it when he had possession.

The upturn in economic conditions has begun, Senator Joseph T. Robinson of Arkansas, majority leader, said last night on his arrival here from Washington. He is to engage in a debate tonight with Morris Hillquit, Socialist leader, on the Democratic program at the Brooklyn Academy of Music.
WASHINGTON. AFTER two weeks of the New Deal it is hardly an exaggeration to say that it is about the biggest surprise Washington ever had. The capital is in a state of exclamation.

The Spring season brings with it the annual Rainbow Ball which will be held on Friday night in the grand ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria in behalf of the Association for the Aid of Crippled Children. Always an entertainment of much interest to younger members of society, many of whom take part In the work of various committees, the event this year will offer many diversions for the subscribers.

WASHINGTON, March 18 -- The country's currency demands have been met since the banking holiday by the issuance of Federal Reserve notes, backed by at least 40 per cent gold, and national bank notes, backed by government bonds, rather than through the use of the new Federal Reserve Bank notes, according to Treasury figures today.

MOSCOW, March 17. -- There was a time when the Soviet slogan was "Asia for the Asiatics," and Joseph Stalin gave his first interview as the Communist party leader to a Japanese correspondent with the words of greeting, "I, too, am an Asiatic."

THE old four-story residence at 4 West Fifty-fourth Street, which stood almost alone when it was first occupied two generations ago, remains as a symbol of the former exclusive residential neighborhood of which it once was a part and mute evidence of the vast changes which have taken place in the mid town Fifth Avenue district during the past half a century.

SANTIAGO, Chile, March 18. -- The unexpected withdrawal by the Chilean Government of the tax of 60 pesos [$3.60] a metric ton on nitrate exports, the tax to cover the service of the international loan placed in New York and London in March, 1931, has brought the affairs of Cosach, the nitrate corporation of Chile, sharply to the fore.

LOS ANGELES, March 18. -- Except for an occasional spasm of home-run hitting with the bases empty the Chicago White Sox were foiled by Hal Schumacher and Carl Hubbell today while the Giants, in gay hitting mood, knocked out a 7-to-3 victory.

Railroad men are prepared to see their plan for the assembly of four trunk lines in the East subjected to drastic modification by the legislation which Presided Roosevelt has disclosed he will push through the present session of Congress.

A transformation of American cities, brought about by the automobile, into supercities made up of vast suburban areas tributary to cities which serve as nuclei, is described in "The Metropolitan Community," a monograph to be published tomorrow by the McGraw-Hill Book Company.

AVERT modest man is Engineer Zucker, a German, who enters the lists of the rocketeers. No romantic and perilous flights for him from the earth to Mars. Nor does he dream even of exploring the upper reaches of the stratosphere.

PITTSBURGH, March 16. -- It seems to be accepted by the principal coal producers of this district that the liberal interpretation of the Sherman anti-trust law by the United States Supreme Court in the case of Appalachian Coals, Inc., definitely puts it up to the bituminous coal industry to prove that it has the leadership and business capacity to rehabilitate itself.

WASHINGTON, March 18. -- The applause of the country, which since inauguration day has come by letter and telegraph to President Roosevelt in such volume as to make it impossible for him to make individual acknowledgements, has generously been shared by him with his assistants.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., March 18. -- A bridge party will be held on Wednesday afternoon at the Ardsley Club for the benefit of the Dobbs Ferry Hospital. Mrs. R. H. Shreve, the chairman, will be assisted by the following:

PHILADELPHIA, March 18. -- Grief-stricken over the death of his wife three months ago, Gilbert Friend, a 28-year-old railway mail clerk, took his three small children to her grave in Fernwood Cemetery in Upper Darby last night and shot them to death.

A loan exhibition of paintings by the famous Italian portrait painter Boldini will be held at the Wildenstein Galleries for three weeks beginning tomorrow. It has been arranged under the auspices of Mrs. Chester Dale, who has a noteworthy collection of paintings, for the benefit of the child welfare committee of the Bellevue Hospital Social Service.

WASHINGTON, March 18. -- Reports circulated in New York that the bankruptcy reform bill which former President Hoover signed March 4 was not the bill that Congress intended to become law prompted the explanation here today that some minor changes were made in the bill just before its enrolment.

MADRID, March 8. -- Dona Maria de Castilla," the play which Minister of Agriculture Marcelino Domingo wrote in prison in 1926, has greater historical than dramatic interest, but despite that it was a success at the Teatro Espanol.

WASHINGTON, March 18. -- Secretary Wallace of the Department of Agriculture went on the air this afternoon to explain the administration farm bill. Speaking over WJZ in the Farm and Home Hour he told how the measure on which President Roosevelt is seeking immediate action was prepared by the Department of Agriculture along lines suggested by leaders of farmers' organizations after their conference here on March 10.

PARIS, March 18. -- By means of a member's resolution the question of France's debt to the United States will be raised in the Chamber of Deputies, probably on Tuesday, and then will be referred to the finance commission. Debate in the Chamber will come later.

WE have had a number of learned articles from T. S. Eliot's admirers, articles which are a kind of exegesis at "The Waste Land" and of "Ash Wednesday," articles which explain the technique of the master. Mr. Williamson's book comes now as "the plain reader's guide to an intelligent understanding of the beauty and importance of this generation's most gifted and influential poet."

MILAN, Feb. 25, 1933. A HOUSING success was scored by Riccardo Zandonai's three-act opera buffa, "La Farsa Amorosa" (The Love Farce), en Arturo Rossato's book from "El Sombrero de Tres Picos," at its world premiere at the Royal Opera of Rome, under the composer's baton, on Feb. 22.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In a recent interview Dr. Vizetelly challenged sharply the figure which I defended in the last number of American Speech as the most reasonable total of English words namely 250,000. He declared that in his opinion our language contains far more than a million words.

The decision during the week of the United States Supreme Court, erasing Florida's chain-store tax law from the statute books of that State, was hailed yesterday as a marked setback to "oppressive" legislation against chain stores and one that will set a precedent for "more reasonable and logical grounds" for such taxation by Robert W. Lyons, executive vice president of the National Chain Store Association.

ROME. IMAGINE yourself carelessly turning the pages of a child's geography atlas and suddenly discovering that Washington was missing from the map of America. A mistake or an insult? So one need feel little wonder at the commotion in a recent Milan show when it was found that in an ingenious map of Italy, drawn by a painter and based on the relative importance of every city to art, Rome was nowhere to be seen.

ESTHER RALSTON, who appeared recently in the British-produced film, "Rome Express," may be seen at the Seventh Avenue Roxy in another British picture, called "After the Ball." She comes from a theatrical family.

The reappearance of Frederick H. Prince as a factor in railroad consolidation makes it a possibility, according to opinion in transportation circles, that he may again exercise an influence over the Pere Marquette Railway, of which he was president in 1903.

All rules since the banking holiday with respect to the limitation of insurance-policy loans and suspension of future dividends of life-insurance companies have been promulgated to preserve the integrity of insurance protection as a whole, and not because of the financial condition of individual institutions, Frederick H. Ecker, president of the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company, said yesterday, according to The Associated Press.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., March 18. -- General condemnation of present systems of examination, both in college entrance and in school and college curricula, was expressed by speakers at the closing sessions of the annual meeting of, the Harvard Teachers Association today.

NEW ORLEANS, March 18 (AP). -- E. K. Bryson's Pharatime, turning in his second consecutive victory in as many starts, today clinched the 2-year-old championship of the local racing meeting, winning the featured Duncan F. Kenner Stakes over four furlongs.

Several debutantes have joined Miss Camilla Moss in completing plans for an Easter holiday dance under the auspices of Groton and St. Marks Schools, which will be held on the night of March 31 at Essex House for the benefit of the Summer camps of the schools.

ALTHOUGH retail trade war affected by unfavorable weather early in the week, sales advanced later on, particularly as restrictions imposed by the bank holiday were lifted. Toward the close of the week it was reported that store volume was running well up to the pre-moratorium level and, in some cases where sales were being held, approaching last year's figures.

BALBOA. C. Z., March 18. -- Colonel Julian Schley, Governor of the Canal Zone, who served under General Burgess as engineer of maintenance, issued a circular in tribute to his predecessor today and ordered the flags of the Zone to be flown at half staff.

LONDON, March 8. THOSE who believe that the time has come for the English theatre to break away from the bondage of realism and to practice once again a glamourous exaggeration of life are not given much encouragement.

Answering the question, "What is an adequate navy?" Lieut. Com, Melvin F. Talbot of the United States Navy, in an article in April Current History, attacks many current views of American naval requirements and contends that an adequate navy is "the completed fleet which forms our share in the agreed apportionment of sea strength."

Public works construction over a period of ten years which, will involve the rebuilding of American cities and the creation of new and smaller industrial centres will be necessary due to the recent depression, points out Robert D. Kohn in a report to the American Institute of Architects, of which he is a past president.

To the Editor of The New York Times: "I know a bank" whose tradition goes far back of Shakespeare's time. Indeed, when, the Lord discovered that Adam and Eve were too carefree for their own good He gave them such a bank as a start in life.

One would never suspect, from the unctuous praise now being lavished upon the new President, that steps had to be taken, in the Presidential campaign last Summer, to suppress partisan political comment out of fear that Mr. Roosevelt's sensibilities would be offended.

HAVANA, March 18. -- An appeal to the United States Ambassador for immediate release or a fair trial was made today by Aristides Betancourt, American citizen, who has been held in Principe Fortress and the Isle of Pines Penitentiary for the past seven months.

MIAMI -- The interest in water racing is being kept at a high pitch at present. A third important event in this sport within a week is on the schedule for today, when boat races will be held at the Key Largo Anglers' Club for trophies presented by the Florida Year-Round Clubs.

A machine to determine whether applicants for jobs are of the neurotic or obsessional types or whether they are of the median, normal type has been in use at Hartford House, Y. M. C. A., 109 West Fifty-fourth Street, for the last week.

BREMERHAVEN . THE 5,000-ton Jiner Westfalen, which has been transformed by the Deutsche Lufthansa into a floating airport and is to be stationed in the South Atlantic half way between Bathurst, British Gambia, Africa, and Fernambuco, Brazil, has aroused much interest by its recent successful demonstration to officials of the Ministry of Transportation in the lower Weser.

This is a unique and stimulating book and one that fills a decided need. There is no history of this country for young people that this book will not supplement: adult readers, too, will find it an incentive to fresh thinking on the problems of the day.

WASHINGTON, March 18. -- Although the selection of Dr. Hans Luther as German Ambassador to the United States aroused some expressions of surprise here, the general impression at the State Department and among diplomats was one of approval.

WHENEVER the citizenry gets together in an indignant mood some one is bound to inquire why the theatre does not produce a few decent plays about normal people. Whenever the theatre produces a play of that brand the citizenry remains complacently at home.

Francis I. du Pont of New York and Wilmlngton, Del., former vice president of E.I. du Pont de Nemours and now head of the New York Stock Exchange firm of Francis I.du Pont Co., "was sued in the Supreme Court yesterday for a balance of $197,318 on a bill of $234,407 for legal services by Claudian B. Northrop, Washington attorney.

Support of President Roosevelt for a project involving the construction of a transcontinental "super-express" highway will be sought shortly by Charles F. Abbott, managing director of the American Institute of Steel Construction, Inc., he announced yesterday.

In his book with this title, Professor WHITEHBAD of Harvard likens a great idea in the background of dim consciousness "to a phantom ocean beating upon the shores of human life in successive waves of specialization." Such waves " are as dreams slowly doing their work of sapping the base of some cliff of habit."

RADIO traveling at the speed of sunlight across every State in the Union has fit into President Roosevelt's plan for rapid-fire action in the war against depression. The White House is now equipped for quick contact with the populace on a few minutes' notice.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., March 18. -- The Yale varsity fencers today defeated Harvard, 10 to 7. The swordsmen were well matched with all three weapons. The outcome gives Yale the Big Three title by virtue of a recent victory over Princeton.

Lehigh University's wrestlers again asserted their supremacy yesterday in the Columbia gymnasium, when they won the Eastern Intercollegiate Wrestling Association crown for the third successive year.

WHAT happens to broadcasting when an earthquake shakes the studios, rocks the transmitter and sways the lofty aerial masts? The staffs of KHJ, Los Angeles; KGER and KFOX at Long Beach, Cal., can answer the question from practical experience.

An event of the Spring season will be the annual theatrical production of the Lighthouse Players, an organization of sightless young women, which will be presented at their Little Theatre, 111 East Fifty-ninth Street, on the nights of April 5 and 6.

SUMTER, S. C., March 16. -- Although tobacco stocks are still unusually large, growers in the Southeastern belt, which produces the bulk of this country's leaf, are planning to increase acreage this year, according to reports from county agents who view the prospect with alarm.

Jimmy McNamara, 146 3/4, Greenwich Village welterweight, and Nick Pastore, 146, Greenpoint, battled to a draw in the feature six-round bout before 2,000 at the Ridgrewood Grove Sporting Club, Brooklyn, last night.

THIS book is a real achievement. It has clarity, authenticity, logical sequence. In addition, it is written with beauty and historical imagination. The selection of material is excellent and the author is as skillful in her omissions as in what she includes.

THE doubts about the continuance of the Philharmonic-Symphony have been resolved. The directors of the society have announced that not only will the orchestra continue next season, but that they will attempt to make it "most outstanding."
NEW HAVEN, Conn., March 18. -- Opening the Yale Rugby season with an exhibition of high quality football, the French Rugby Club of New York City today defeated the Elis, 12 to 3.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 18. -- Babe Ruth must sign a Yankee contract by March 29 or he will not be taken North when the team breaks camp, he was flatly informed today by Colonel Jacob Ruppert, owner of the club.

DALLAS, March 16. -- Its bank holiday experience proved that Texas and indeed practically all of the Eleventh Federal Reserve District is in remarkably sound financial condition. Texas proved to be in better condition than other portions of the district, which goes into Oklahoma, Louisiana and New Mexico, and Dallas, which was one of the first twelve cities in the country to resume banking:

Many pastors will preach sermons today designed to inspire "encouragement and hope" in the present crisis. Several sermons will be based on the speech President Roosevelt made over the radio last Sunday evening in announcing that banks would reopen.

AS always in her novels of China. Mrs. Miln makes a very effective. If slightly theatrical, use of her Oriental background. She writes warmly and colorfully, and her descriptions are lavish and carefully detailed. Yet the result is undeniably romantic.

The "war garden" idea of 1918 is being revived this Spring in all parts of New Jersey in response to the announcement of the State Emergency Relief Administration of a plan for establishing vegetable gardens in back yards and vacant lots.
NORTHAMPTON, Mass., March 18. -- Thirty-two girls from New York State and New Jersey were among the ninety-three seniors at Smith College who were announced today to be eligible for general honors.

It is interesting and pleasant to find this series of picture books from other countries issued at a fairly moderate price and with the text planned so that trades from 2 to 5 can use them as readers. The three volumes noted here vary in quality and value.

The chief character in this story is not a detective but a criminal lawyer named Perry Mason, who finds it necessary to do a great deal of detective work to protect the interests of his clients and of himself -- in that order. For Mason's code of professional ethics is a simple one.
RALEIGH, N. C., March 16. -- President Roosevelt's action in naming Josephus Daniels as Ambassador to Mexico was almost unanimously pleasing to North Carolinians.

PHILADELPHIA, March 18. -- Three pool records and one meet mark were broken tonight in Hutchinson Pool of the University of Pennsylvania, where the finals of the twenty-seventh annual individual championships of the Intercollegiate Swimming Association were held.

WARRENTON, Va. -- The Cobbler Hunt Club, one of the newer hunts of the county, will hold its annual trials next Saturday. They will be over its regular course near the picturesque Cobbler Mountain, on the adjoining estates of Dr, Edmund Horgan and Benjamin McCarty.
The price level of residential property in Manhattan at the end of its long boom is shown in a map just completed by tne Land Utilization Committee of the New York Building Congress.

Countess Mercati, now living in Paris, who is deeply interested in the League of Composers, has enlisted the support of many of her friends here for an entertainment of music, drama and films in behalf of the league, to take place the night of April 16 at the Town Hall.
To the Editor of The New York Times: Recently there has appeared in your columns a series of articles about the Soviet Union. The following is offered as a corrective supplement to Student's series:

The vernal equinox -- which occurs on Tuesday -- will be marked by the Spring Ball at the Pierre for the benefit of the Babies Hospital of New York. Prospective hosts and hostesses for some time have been arranging dinner parties to precede the ball, while others participating in arrangements are preparing an elaborate cabaret entertainment, enlisting stage and radio stars, to feature the supper hour.

MANILA, March 18. -- The departure of Manuel Quezon, President of the Philippine Senate, for the United States has served to crystallize public opinion on the independence plan. There is little doubt now that a large majority of Filipinos are bitterly opposed to the chief provisions of the Hawes law, although no clearly defined substitute is offered.

Miss Anne Page of Philadelphia, successfully defended the Iselin trophy as the annual invitation women's squash racquets tournament of the Junior League of New York came to a close on the courts of the clubhouse yesterday.

THERE have been innumerable reports about what is called "the new Joe Cook show." That would be the one with music, and not the three or four others without. Max Gordon has been mentioned prominently as its sponsor, and here is the latest one on that: Mr. Gordon had not read the script until last week, and when this department inquired about it he just hadn't made up his mind.

OTTAWA, March 16. -- Most closely guarded of government secrets in Canada is the annual budget statement. Once each session the Minister of Finance, now E. N. Rhodes, reviews in detail before Parliament the financial situation of the nation, moves such tariff changes as the government has decided upon and such amendments to the system of federal taxation nowadays, alas, usually upward as have been approved by the Cabinet Council.

THE next concert of the Musicians Symphony Orchestra will be given Tuesday evening at the Metropolitan Opera House. Georges Enesco will conduct and Walter Gieseking and the Hall Johnson Choir will participate in the program.

The progress made by the Roosevelt Administration last week toward balancing the national budget is described in an article published in the Feature Section of THE TIMES today. The Economy Bill is expected to result in a saving to the Government of $525,000,000.

FAIRBANKS, Alaska, Feb. 13. -- If persistence and belief in a project are material aids in bringing it to fruition, then Alaska sooner or later will have a road connecting it with the continental United States. This proposed international highway is a link in the Pan-American system.

Federal grand jury investigation to determine whether Charles E. Mitchell, who recently resigned as chairman of the board of the National City Bank, had illegally evaded an income tax payment for 1929 was projected yesterday with the return to New York of United States Attorney George Z. Medalie, who had conferred in Washington with Attorney General Cummings on the case.

HOLLYWOOD. THE crisis that threatened to close all Hollywood studios was dispelled this week when the producers and the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences, representing the creative and office employes, after a week of bitter wrangling, came to a sudden, and peaceful understanding on wage slashes and permitted halted production to be resumed.

"FEDERAL RESERVE SYSTEM" has become a household term during the past few weeks. It has been mentioned in Presidential utterances and in back-fence conversations. In a crisis which in one way or another affected every pocketbook in the nation, it was the institution to which many banks appealed for aid during the "runs" of the first days of March;

To the Editor of The New York Times: Conditions are not stopping nor delaying the devotees of contract bridge, and it seems possible that many will be interested in an extraordinary deal that occurred in a game just recently.

Beginning in the last months of 1932, correctional institutions for women and girls have been reporting gradual and in some cases sharp increases in the number of commitments, and today virtually all are over-crowded, it was reported yesterday at the opening session of the two-day conference of women superintendents of correctional institutions for women and girls at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

The New York State Brewers' Association announced yesterday that its representatives would attend the hearings on beer legislation before the Excise Commission in Albany next Thursday. At the same time the Brewers Board of Trade, through its treasurer, Julius Liebmann, president of Liebmann Breweries, Inc., of Brooklyn, urged its members to attend the hearing and extended an invitation to all other interested persons to give their views to the commission.

MANILA, Feb. 15. -- Faced with the possibility of internal dissesion and external aggression, and the certainty of economic collapse, it is small wonder that the Filipino has rung no bells in Manila upon hearing that an independence bill was passed.

A CALL is being sent out to the 47,000 graduates of the Plattsburg training camps, at which civilians were made into army officers in preparation for World War service, to become members of an organization entitled the Society of Piattsburg.

WASHINGTON. THE great money factory of the United States, the Bureau of Engraving and Printing, is working at top speed twenty-four hours a day printing the new Federal Reserve notes authorized by the emergency banking law.

WASHINGTON, March 18. -- The United States Department of State is expected to cooperate with the advisory committee of the League of Nations in exercising its good offices for a solution, of the controversy at Leticia between Peru and Colombia and to make clear soon through a State Department statement that she welcomes the effort of the League for peace in this hemisphere.

WITH constantly increased emphasis on speed in the air, it would seem that the point will soon be reached when factors of human ability to withstand highspeed travel, rather than mechanical potentialities, will have to be taken into account.

One has every sympathy with efforts to make available the old significant stories which should be a part of every child's experience, and this version is quite evidently one which the author has himself used with children.
Play in the metropolitan Class C squash racquets singles championship started yesterday at the Downtown Athletic Club. Seventeen matches were concluded in the first round and five went by default.

PARIS, March 17. -- With Hitlerism running rampant all over Germany and figuratively putting out its tongue from the other end of the Rhine bridgeheads, there has been a good deal of emotion and emotional thinking in France during the past week.

HELENA, Mont., March 18 (AP). -- A sharp protest against the seating of former Governor John E. Erickson as United States Senator from Montana to succeed the late Thomas J. Walsh is voiced in a letter written by the Federal district judge, George M. Bourquin, to the Senate and all its members and made public by him here today.

MR. PEAKE, who is lecturer in Chinese in Columbia Univercity, gathered most of the material for this book during 1928-29 in China. His study surveys the development of education in that country since 1860 as a means for the strengthening of its national consciousness.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., March 18. -- Retaining the national figure skating championship in the same arena where she first scored in 1928, Miss Maribel Vinson of Winchester, Mass., captured her sixth consecutive title tonight.

The little Church of the Most Holy Crucifix, 378 Broome Street, was much too small to hold the crowds that turned out yesterday morning for the funeral of Giuseppe Rizzo, 75 years old, beloved philanthropist, who had been for almost half a century the "Papa Joe" of all Little Italy.

The annual show-and-fashion revue of the Israel Orphan Asylum was held in Madison Square Garden last, nigh. Many prominent persons were in the vast throng, estimated at about 20,000, which viewed the array of stars of the stage, screen and radio and the fashion, revue.

WASHINGTON, March 18 -- Retail food prices in fifty-one cities, as reported to the Bureau of Labor Statistics of the Department of Labor, showed an average decrease of about 4 per cent on Feb. 15 when compared with Jan. 15, and an average decrease of about 13 3/4 per cent since Feb. 15, 1932.

To the Dramatic Editor: It would indeed be unfortunate if the present universal slump in business at our theatre box offices were to prove disastrous to "Run, Little Chillun!" I should think, if the general public were aware of the possibilities for thrills and entertainment afforded by this show, they would flock to it in sufficient numbers to make it a rival in popularity to "Design for Living."

BERLIN, March 3. WE have had war on the stage from uncounted angles, from the sentimental, the romantic, the tragic, the grotesquely comic, the militaristic, the pacifistic -- but war from the viewpoint of the crossword puzzle enthusiast is really a novelty.

The death of Abram E. Fitkin, whose decision in 1900 that he could be of more service as an efficient business man than as an inefficient preacher, brought him a fortune estimated at $250,000,000, wrote a final chapter yesterday to one of the outstanding success stories in modern American finance.

Some of the most beautiful horses in existence -- all quite lifeless though invested with certain psychic qualities of vitality and joie de vivre -- will compete for show ring honors at the Knoedler Galleries, 14 East Fifty-seventh Street, for two weeks beginning tomorrow at the International Horse Show of Art, which will tie offered for the benefit of the social service department of Memorial Hospital.

A NEW kind of City, consisting of a single line of buildings, with open country on either side, is envisaged by Edgar Chambless, head of the Roadtown Foundation, as the culmination of a plan for which engineers and architects furnished by the Emergency Work Bureau are drawing up specifications.

Prices of bonds on the Stock Exchange were irregular yesterday in quiet trading, turnover amounting to only $4,250,000. The preceding Saturday operations in the listed bond market were on Feb. 28, when heavy liquidation sent total transactions to $12,771,000.
WASHINGTON, March 18 (AP) -- The question of recognizing Russia is to be raised again soon in the Senate but may be deferred until the Roosevelt administration expresses its ideas.

Interest in gardening, particularly lawns and flowers, has increased perceptibly in recent years, and more suburban owners probably will be cultivating available plots this year than ever before, in the opinion of many horticulturists.

LONDON, March 18. -- Led by three former American university stars, who scored five first places among them, Oxford today broke a seven-year reign of Cambridge in track and field athletics to win the sixty-fifth annual meet, eight first places to three.

CHICAGO, March 18 -- The Federal Farm Board's holding's of wheat appear to be in process of liquidation, according to gossip in the trade, which estimates that in the last three days 8,000,000 bushels or more have been sold either in the pit on the Board of Trade here or to mills.

BERLIX, March 5, 1933. THE average Berlin concertgoer knows almost as much about the music of Jan Sibelius as he does about the other side of the moon. And the presumably cultivated musician is in the same boat with the average concertgoer.
