MONTREAL, March 18. -- A plan for the exportation of power to the United States is embodied in a measure which Honore Mercier, Minister of Lands and Forest, has taken before the Quebec Legislature and which has gone through first reading in the House.
PHILADELPHIA, March 18. -- Bill Carr, the Arkansas flier, lay in a hospital bed tonight -- through with collegiate track competition.

MR. WINKLER'S life of Woodrow Wilson resembles his "Morgan the Magnificent" and "Incredible Carnegie" In the liveliness of its style and its reportorial skill in describing situations and telling a story, but it adds nothing of importance to what was already familiar in the way of facts and is not, as far as proportions go, a well-rounded piece of biography.

LOS ANGELES, March 16. -- While Southern California shared the bank moratorium and currency shortage with the rest of the country, its earthquake was exclusive From the returns so far in, it is apparent that grossly exaggerated reports of the occurrences were printed throughout the country.

SHANGHAI, Feb. 25. -- George Bernard Shaw is not only a fallen idol so far as many of his former admirers in China are concerned, but has even brought upon himself a great amount of public condemnation, from foreigners and Chinese alike.

RICHMOND, Va., March 18 (AP). -- Amendment of the Muscle Shoals resolution now pending in Congress will be asked by the Commonwealth of Virginia to provide that she share with Alabama and Tennessee the proceeds from the Federal water power plant at the falls of the Tennessee River.

ROME, March 18. -- Prime Minister MacDonald of Great Britain spent what he termed "a highly satisfactory afternoon" today in his attempt to join hands with Italy to preserve European peace. After only one meeting with Premier Mussolini he believes he has already made sufficient progress to make the success of his mission highly probable if not certain.

WASHINGTON. THE first days of bewilderment, in which Washington watched the transformation of the White House and Executive offices, have passed and all who have business there are settling down to a happy appreciation that in this respect, at least, times have changed.

BERLIN, March 18. -- Reports printed in the United States that Professor Herman Zondek had been kidnapped and maltreated were denied by Frau Zondek at their home tonight. She said there was no reason to worry, her husband being on a vacation.

Field trial followers everywhere have a warm spot in their hearts for the undulating acres midway between Mount Holly and Medford, N.J., which the Friends of the Hunting Dog call home. The leading bird dog men and women of the country have gathered about the rough yet capacious fieldstone fireplace in the modest clubhouse atop the hill for many years.

STATE COLLEGE, Pa., March 18. -- Syracuse had to win only one bout tonight to clinch the Eastern intercollegiate boxing team championship, but the Orange athletes romped off with four of the eight individual titles to roll up 27 points, far ahead of Army and Western Maryland with 12 each, Penn State, with 11, Yale with 6 and M.I.T. with 4.

A survey recently completed covering about 650 loft and combination office and showroom buildings containing about 100,000,000 square feet of rentable space in the district from Fourteenth to Fortieth Street, Lexington and Ninth Avenues, disclosed an average vacancy of 18 per cent, points out Samuel Field, treasurer of the realty firm of Adams Co.

In the placid state of the markets at the week-end there were no ugly reminders of the violent dislocations through which the financial and business organism had passed in the last fortnight. Transactions in both stocks and bonds were of less than normal Saturday size.

HAVANA -- The announcement that Havana's Summer racing meet will open at Oriental Park next Saturday has awakened keen interest among local racing fans and visiting sportsmen. The usual opening date has been advanced somewhat and the meet will continue through the Summer, until Oct. 29.

Led by Miss Margaret Bannon, who accounted for fifteen of her team's points, the St. Joseph's College for Women basketball team conquered the New York University sextet, 22 to 11, for the second time this season, as both teams closed their seasons yesterday on the winner's court in Brooklyn.

MINEOLA, L.I., March 18. -- R. H. Helsel and G. E. Mole tied for the High Scratch Cup at the traps of the Nassau Trapshooting Club today. Each had a string of 50 straight targets. In the first shoot-off, they again tied with 24 out of 25 each.

LORD BADEN-POWELL says that he has lived two lives, and so he divides his autobiography into wholly separate parts, the first telling of his youth, preparation for a military career, and army service until his retirement as Lieutenant General at the early age of 50.

CHARLES CARROLL OF CARROLLTON is one of the best-remembered and least-understood or the superior group amoung the fifty-seven men who signed the Declaration of Independence. The legend, convenient for schoolroom exhortation, that he was the richest of the signera and survived all the others in an old age that might have been a model for Cicero in composing "De Senectute" has obscured his more solid claims to the reflecting attention of new generations.

A report just issued by H. F. Cellarius of Cincinnati, secretary-treasurer of the United States Building and Loan League, showing the financial status of the organizations holding membership in the league, reveals the fact that fifty-five associations have individual assets exceeding $10,000,000, white nine-one member associations have assets between $5,000,000 and $10,000,000.

Complete control of public relief, which has been supervised since the Seabury investigation by a nonpartisan committee of fifteen headed by Lawson Purdy, will pass to Tammany control tomorrow, when it is expected that Mayor O'Brien will appoint Welfare Commissioner Frank J. Taylor as "czar" of all work relief and home relief.

Paintings by Harpignies, Sargent and varidus artists of other schools will be offered at auction Thursday evening at the American Art Association Anderson Galleries, Inc. The paintings have been consigned by Joseph Milner, A. U. Suprenant and Harriet Van Boskerck of this city and other collectors and estates.

Textile High School, defending champion; Evander Childs High School and George Washington High remained in a three-way tie for the leadership honors in Division 1 of the Public Schools Athletic League fencing championship tournament by coming through with victories in three of the four engagements staged in their division at the Washington Irving High School gymnasium yesterday morning.

LONDON. THAT a three-guinea work should be the most conspicuous object in the windows of the London bookstores, and that the first edition of it, consisting of 5,000 copies, should have been exhausted before publication is certainly an unusual phenomenon.

SOME of the contagious enthusiasm and frank hero worship that John Reed was putting into his articles from Mexico nearly twenty years ago appear in this book, in which it may truly be said there is not one dull page. Reed did as much as any one to create the legend of Villa as a kind of Mexican Robin Hood.

LOUISVILLE, March 16. -- What is to be done about the State debt is a problem facing Kentucky. Candidates for the Legislature are announcing daily, and a few of them have devoted attention to this subject. That the topic will continue to press for solution may be taken as granted.

Some of the old-time salt water fishermen are talking about a jig that has been developed and which is said to have great possibilities, especially in trolling for blues, tuna, bonitas, striped sea bass and such surface strikers. The jig isn't anything new in itself.

WASHINGTON, March 18 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended on March 11 made a total of 437,813 cars, the American Railway Association announced today. This was 40,014 cars, or 8.4 per cent, below the preceding week, 137,668 cars, or 23.9 per cent, fewer than for the corresponding week last year and 295,767 cars, or 40.3 per cent, fewer than for the corresponding week two years, ago.

THE first volume of John Drinkwater's autobiography closed on his getting a job as a clerk in an Insurance office in Nottingham at twenty pounds a year. This second book begins at this point and takes him through to the age of thirty.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., March 18. -- Trenton retained the Class A high school basketball championship of the New Jersey State Interscholastic Athletic Association by defeating South Side of Newark, 31 to 17, in the Rutgers gymnasium tonight as 4,000 looked on.

BERLIN, March 18. -- After a day of speculation on the rumor that Dr. Hans Luther would go to the United States as the German Ambassador, the news of his appointment finally came from Washington today. The German Government, by failing to deny it, silently confirmed the report.

PARIS. ONE of the cleverest things the Paris couturiers have done this season is to give a romantic feeling to the easy, nonchalant fashions that constitute our actual ideal, without resorting to the help of period influence or any costume-ball effects.

NORTHPORT, L.I., March 18. -- A reduction in the village budgets for the year ending March 1, 1934. and the strictest economy all along the line are the keynote of the platforms of the candidates for the office of Mayor and Trustees at the Village elections on Tuesday.

WASHINGTON, March 18. -- The State Department announced today that it would issue a statement of American disarmament policy next week before Norman H. Davis sails on Wednesday from New York to assume his duties in Geneva as chairman of the United States delegation at the disarmament conference.

To the Editor of The New York Times : Mrs. John W. Garrett's indictment of an "international clique of profiteering (art) dealers" will attract well-deserved attention. Mrs. Garrett is more fortunate tnan a great many others in being able to tell a work of art when she sees it and she, no doubt, is in direct contact with the artists and allows them their full worth by eliminating the commission of the wicked exploiters.

Generally conceded to rank in importance with the "rule of reason" and the maple flooring and cement cases, the Appalachian Coals decision by the Supreme Court, validating the formation of a selling pool, during the week developed a variety of opinions from trade association counsels, business executives and other authorities on anti-trust legislation.

WHY does water put out fire? That water is wet is no answer at all. Theoretically water ought to be decomposed into its constituent hydrogen and oxygen. In fact this actually does happen when fires are very hot. If water is effective at all in putting out ordinary blazes it is because it cools and because it forms, a cushion of incombustible steam which smothers the flame by shutting out the oxygen of the atmosphere.

WASHINGTON. WHETHER the nation's 24,000,000 motor vehicles shall help to solve the farm problem by burning a fuel blended of gasoline and alcohol remains a live issue in "Washington. The question has a number of controversial aspects.

The sale of fifty-two steamships by the United States Shipping Board to the Lykes Brothers-Ripley Steamship Company for operation in a guaranteed service between New Orleans, the United Kingdom. European and Oriental ports is hailed by the Middle Western Foreign Trade Committee as the wisest move yet taken by the government to provide ample water transportation for shippers of the Middle West.

At the Intercollegiate Glee Club concert, which took place last night in the Town Hall, the New York University Glee Club was announced as the winner of the Metropolitan Region Intercollegiate Contest Cup for which the choruses of New York, Rutgers and Yale Universities had competed during the afternoon at the Wanamaker Auditorium.

With a cheerful smile Professor Albert Einstein, sailed yesterday for Antwerp on the Red Star liner Belgenland amid the plaudits of nearly 100 women pacifists who went to the pier to see him off. He was accompanied by Mrs. Einstein.

INSPIRED by President Roosevelt's use of radio, Congress is said to becoming more "radio-minded." In fact, observers in Washington believe there is an even chance that the question whether or not broadcasting from the Senate and House should be permitted may be settled at this session of Congress.

WASHINGTON, March 18. -- Blame for the banking and financial troubles of the country were put on the Federal Government by the Director of the Budget Lewis H. Douglas in a radio address tonight over the Columbia Broadcasting System.

In its final report before transferring direction of the share-the-work movement to the United States Chamber of Commerce in Washington the coordinating committee fostered by the banking and industrial group of the Federal Reserve Banks announced yesterday that 57,000 employers with an aggregate personnel of close to 5,000,000 reported that 1,091,282 were in jobs because of worksharing.

The setting aside of a city high school for New York's specially gifted children, so that they may receive particular attention and training in accordance with their ability was advocated yesterday by Dr. Abraham Flexner, director of the Institute of Advanced Study and noted educator.

NAtions and Isolation. Professor EINSTEIN in his New York speech on Wednesday protested against "exaggerated nationalism." It is a pity that so many people have got into the habit of saying Nationalism when they mean its exaggerations and excesses.

CHICAGO, March 17. THE week of the banking moratorium rubbed three titles off this city's playgoing catalogue. "The Bride Retires," Edna Hibbard's latest venture, gently sank into the anticipated coma at the Blackstone Theatre.
ISTANBUL, March 16. -- That the West has no monopoly on hustle is proved by the succession of recent events involving reorganization of the Turkish monopolies here.

Amendments to the existing laws governing foreclosure actions in this State are recommended by Anson Getman, assistant solicitor of the New York Title and Mortgage Company, as necessary to reduce the present heavy cost and also in the direction of simplification.

CLEARWATER. Fla.. March 18. -- His salary conference with Ruth completed. Colonel Ruppert came here to see his two championship baseball teams in an exhibition before a crowd of about 400. He saw the world's champions, the Yankees. overwhelm the Newark Bears, winners of the little world's series last year, by 10 to 1 for the fourth Yankee victory in five exhibition games.
WASHINGTON, March 18. -- Strong indications that the administration's plan for relieving agriculture will undergo major changes before it is enacted into law appeared today on Capitol Hill.

Philanthropic enterprises are to receive material assistance in consequence of the International Flower Show which will open tomorrow and continue through the week at Grand Central Palace. In addition to the tea garden, a picturesque feature for many years, there will be special booths for the sale of articles in behalf of worthy causes.
LONDON, March 17. -- Pacifism in Great Britain is showing new vitality at the very moment when Continental Europe is having one of its periodical attacks of nerves over "the next war."
The use of flowers, shrubs and trees as an aid to modern architecture is the theme of an interesting display of models, pictures and plans now at the Museum of Modern Art, 11 West Fifty-third Street.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., March 18. -- Naval Academy athletes made a clean sweep today of four events. Navy defeated Dartmouth in gymnastics to take another intercollegiate championship, the varsity fencers conquered Columbia and the indoor riflemen won a triangular match with New York University and Washington and Lee.

Snobbery, we have lately been told, has -- under one name or another -- its appropriate place in the world of youth. In what ways, and why? The following article by the rector of one of our leading private schools, St. Paul's, at Concord, N.H., gives an answer.

WASHINGTON. IT is early morning. In the Government Printing Office, not far from the Union Depot, the largest battery of typesetting machines in the world has been rattling away for hours. Now some of the most marvelous presses in the world are slapping out printed sheets faster than the eye can follow them.

Orders during the week showed a gain over the preceding week, with the increased optimism now prevalent reflected in the gain in open orders, according to the market report prepared especially for THE TIMES by McGreevey, Werring Howell, Inc.

With a downward trend in wholesale prices of fresh, fruits and vegetables noted during the week, the State Department of Agriculture and Markets received reports indicating increased production this year in the early crops of strawberries, peas and asparagus from Southern and Western States.

This season's series of the concerts for children and for young people, given by the Philharmonic-Symphony Society and conducted by Ernest Schelling, came to an end yesterday morning in Carnegie Hall. The occasion was more than the performance of an uncommonly interesting program, with explanatory remarks by Mr. Schelling.

WASHINGTON, March 18 (AP). -- Senate leaders saw little prospect today of any action to prevent former Governor John Erickson from taking his seat as Senator from Montana. As he arrived here today to take his seat Monday, word came from Helena that Judge George M. Bourquin had sent a letter to all Senators charging Senator Erickson's appointment grew out of an agreement with Lieut. Gov. Cooney.

WASHINGTON, March 18 (UP). -- A new farm plan, calling for the creation of a general banking system exclusively for the benefit of farmers, was advanced today by Senator Smith, Democrat, of South Carolina and chairman of the Senate Agriculture Committee.

THE American Republic was actually born, not in Independence Hall, Philadelphia, in July, 1776, but in a small, sloping-roofed stone farmhouse in Newburgh, on the banks of the Hudson River, in March, 1783. It was in the old Newburgh "Mansion House," built by Burger Mynders in 1725.

GENEVA, March 18. -- With the American Hemisphere represented only by Mexico, Guatemala and Panama, the Council of the League of Nations today established a precedent which would have been inconceivable here even six months ago.

AGUA CALIENTE, Mexico, March 18 (AP). -- Gallant Sir, the 4-year-old colt of the Norman W. Church string, which rules as favorite for the rich Agua Caliente Handicap, strengthened his position today by beating Old Depot, Pillow Fight and five others handily at a mile and seventy yards in 1:42 4-5.

Directors of North American Aviation, Inc., will vote on Tuesday on a plan for acquiring the assets of General Aviation Corporation. The deal provides for an exchange of treasury stock of North American Aviation for the assets of Genreral Aviation.

SHANGHAI, March 18. -- Former Premier Wang Ching-wei's return to China from Europe, where he went for his health, is causing the greatest speculation as to his intentions, which are likely to have an important effect on the political situation, at present aggravated by the Japanese conquest of Jehol.

CAMDEN, S. C. -- The bicentennial celebration of the founding of Camden, the oldest inland town in South Carolina, is being held this week. The original name of Pine Tree Hill was changed to Camden in 1768 ia honor of Lord Camden, a friend of the Colonies and a friend of an unhampered press.

ERNEST GREENWOOD cornea to the defense of the capitalistic system in this book. He considers "the great delusion" to be the belief that either general interest or individual comfort and happiness will be furthered by socialistic experiments in either our local, State or Federal affairs.

HSINKING, Manchuria, Feb. 18. -- The Manchukuo Government is doing its bit to relieve the unemployment problem among young university graduates of Japan. A considerable number of college-educated Japanese are being absorbed by the various departments of the national and provincial governments.

Backed up by an opinion from Assistant Corporation Counsel William E. C. Mayer to the effect that the pension and other funds of the Fire Department caught in the closing of the Harriman National Bank and Trust Company constituted a trust fund and could not be withheld pending solution of the bank's difficulties.

Municipal bonds, in small lots, for payment in March and future months, together with parts of three foreign issues to be retired in later months, featured the announcements last week of bonds called for payment prior to their maturity dates.

HAMILTON, Bermuda -- Easter lilies have started to blossom in the fields and gardens of Bermuda, and by the time Easter comes -- April 16 -- the entire countryside will be a great checkerboard of white fields of lilies among green patches of native cedar.

THE difference between Gilson Gardner's life of E. W. Scripps, published a year ago as "Lusty Scripps," and Negley D. Cochran's life, just issued, is the difference between a reporter's book and an editor's book. The two tend to complement each other.

An imposing array of the elder statesmen in Tammany gathered last night in the conference room at Tammany Hall, with John F. Curry, Tammany leader, presiding, and with the legislative leaders of the party also present.

DAMASCUS, Feb. 28. -- The political complications in Syria during the past few months appear to have given away to a more orderly state of affairs, but there are still no reasonable hopes of an early solution of the vexed problem of Syria's status.

Trinity School's fencing team retained the Athletic Association of Private Schools championship by triumphing over McBurney School and Collegiate School yesterday at the Salle d'Armes Vince in the annual title competition.

ROME, March 18 (AP). -- Prime Minister MacDonald and Premier Mussolini, meeting for the first time in their lives today, talked intensively about the whole European situation, including the question of disarmament. They made their beginning on the basis of Mr. MacDonald's statement, issued when he arrived at Ostia by airplane, that "peace must be organized quickly if it is to be organized at all."
WASHINGTON, March 18. -- Reports of the death today of the Duke of the Abruzzi revived in Washington memories of one of the most romantic episodes in the social history of the capital.

ON the eve of the last German election three powerful Junkers airplanes carried Chancellor Hitler, Dr. Joseph Goebbels, the fiery little Minister of Public Enlightenment and Propaganda, and a group of political associates over the narrow strip of Polish territory which divides Germany into two parts.

GOOD marks and social popularity in college are both apparently predisposing factors to a high salary later in the business world, if a study of some 800 graduates of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology is generally applicable.

The first export of gold since the declaration of an embargo by President Roosevelt on March 5 was announced yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. The gold, amounting to $8,507,500, was removed from earmark here by the Bank of Italy and shipped to Italy under a special license.

Commending the new bankruptcy law signed on March 3 by former President Hoover as highly beneficial to owners of real estate, William E. Malm, president of the National Association of Building Owners and Managers, explains that the new law is really an amendment to the prior bankruptcy law enacted by Congress on July 1, 1898.

AIKEN -- This will be another week of gala sports activity in Aiken, bringing the feature golf event of the season, the thirty-eighth annual Southern Cross Cup tournament, at the Palmetto Golf Club. The qualifying round will be played tomorrow.
Once again the American challenge will be formidable in the world's most difficult steeplechase race when the Liverpool Grand National is run next Friday over the Aintree course in England.

STOCKHOLM, March 9 (By Mail). -- Ivar Kreuger, Swedish "match king," is really dead, according to a special report by the police commission which has been untangling the affairs of Kreuger here for almost a year. Rumors that his suicide was faked are plain fantasy.

THE marked improvement in the design of household furnishings in recent years is due to a large extent, to the sympathetic cooperation of designer and manufacturer. Although artists for the most part develop their ideas in their own studios they create the final models in the factory.

WASHINGTON, March 18. -- Business activity showed a further slight decline during the week ended March 11, but was considered relatively satisfactory in volume in view of banking difficulties then prevailing, according to the weekly survey made public today by the Commerce Department.
WASHINGTON, March 18 (AP). -- Veterans administration officials decided today to await definite instructions from the White House before proceeding with veteran slashes under the economy act.

With the exception of sugar, the reaction, from the high, levels of prices reached earlier in the week continued in yesterday's commodity futures markets here. Silver, cocoa, coffee, rubber, hides and silk lost ground. Trading was on a moderate scale.

Original plays arranged by the young actors themselves will be presented this afternoon by the Children's Theatre of Greenwich House, in the auditorium of the settlement at 27 Barrow Street. The plays are "The Talisman of the Dervish Bey," a tragic drama based Tartar, and Magyar legends, and "Far Away and Long Ago," a lyric drama woven after the traditions of old-time fairy tales.

Experiments by the North German Lloyd Line in the use of spun glass as insulation in its liners Bremen and Europa have proved that the material is more effective than other forms of insulation. During the recent annual lay-up of the two ships the engineers found that the insulation of their boilers, consisting of spun glass applied in the form of mattresses covered by asbestos cloth, has remained intact.

DOROTHEA WIECK, the handsome German actress who played the part of the sympathetic teacher in "Maedchen in Uniform," will sail from Germany this week to begin her American motion-picture career at the Paramount studios in Hollywood.
NEW YORK. Mr. and Mrs. Theodore Weicker will give a reception with music Wednesday night at 1,115 Fifth Avenue.

PALM BEACH -- Although a gradual lessening of activities is noticeable, there remain several events, one in the field of sports and others of social and cultural importance, to mark the last fortnight of the month.

James Kirke Paulding of 4 East Eighty-eighth Street, Albert A. Volk, head of the house-wrecking firm which bears his name, and two women were injured yesterday afternoon when an automobile in which they were riding was in collision with the rear of a Surface Transportation Company bus in 233d Street near Kepler Avenue, the Bronx.

MIAMI, Fla., March 18. -- A new mile and a sixteenth track record was set at Tropical Park today when N. E. Stanton's Action led practically all of the way to win the featured Orange States Handicap in 1:44: 4-5. The time shaved a fifth of a second from the old mark set by Prince Tokalon.

IN the discussion of the grant to President Roosevelt of extraordinary powers to deal with the banking emergency and to reduce federal expenses, majority opinion has clearly recognized that there was no other way of handling the crisis.

President ROOSEVELT has rightly received high praise for the extraordinary vigor and resolution with which he moved to take up the tremendous tasks which were thrust upon him at the very threshold of office. Decisions which ferooked no delay he made out of hand into situations which were bad enough to paralyze an ordinary Executive he flung himself with direct courage.

LONDON . BY raising the problem of the partition of Ireland into the six counties of the North, which are still a part of the United Kingdom, and the twenty-six counties of the Free State, which enjoy dominion status.

BLUE DISTANCE" seems to be a sort of modern equivalent of the ''St. Elmo'' type of story. In the old-fashioned brand, the lovely heroine was generally an orphan who had to struggle against poverty, strictly dishonorable admirers and attacks on her religious faith.

WASHINGTON, March 18. -- Business men who are shareholders and directors in many banks throughout the country which have not yet been permitted to open as sound are volunteering large contributions to meet capital impairments and place the institutions in such condition that they may be licensed, acording to Secretary Woodin.

SHORT HILLS, N.J., March 18. -- Frederick Leland Rhodes, international authority on telephony, electrical engineer, author, composer and civic worker, who for forty years, until his retirement last year, was in the service of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company and its predecessor, the American Bell Telephone Company, died today of angina pectoris at his home in Birch Lane here after an illness of about two years.

MONTE CARLO, March 17. -- The Monacan dynastic succession rights of the 10-year-old Prince Rainier appear seriously threatened by chaims now being advanced with renewed vigor by the Pretender Count Aynard de Chabrillan, a cousin of the reigning Prince Louis of Monaco.

President Roosevelt's program of banking reform and his condemnation of banking practices which precipitated the bank moratorium were praised by financial observers yesterday at a luncheon of the League for Industrial Democracy in the Hotel Woodstock.

HUNTINGTON, L.I., March 18. -- Muskogee Frank's Ruby, a 4-year-old white and orange pointer, owned and handled by George B. Gerard of Huntington, today captured the All-Age Stake of the North Shore Game Protective Association.

MA JEETER'S girls. poor things, had a bad reputation In the countryside, though all their misfortunes came about in the most natural way in the world and seemed indeed almost unavoidable to their level-headed philosophic mother.

There has been an encouraging sale of boxes and seats for an entertainment under the auspices of the Citizens' Committee in Aid of the Stage Relief Fund which will be held on the night of March 26 on the stage of the Metropolitan Opera House.

MIAMI, Fla., March 18. -- Ray Schalk's Buffalo Bisons, playing their initial exhibition game with the Dodgers today, defeated the Carey athletes, 5 to 4, with Phil Gallivan, a former Dodger, stopping the Flatbush club in the final round.

The third gold medal awarded by the Hundred Year Association for an outstanding contribution to the civic and industrial development of the city will go to Samuel Seabury, counsel to the Hofstadter Legislative Investigating Committee, according to an announcement yesterday.

SOUTH BEND, Ind., March 18 (AP). -- The Studebaker Corporation, one of the nation's major automobile manufacturing concerns, which, in addition to Studebaker cars, builds the Pierce-Arrow and Rockne automobiles, was placed in receivership in a friendly action here late today.

TORONTO, Ont., March 18. -- A new high record for production of gold in Ontario in February has been reported for last month by the Provincial Department of Mines. The total was $3,615,354, against $3,505,198 in January and $4,135,536 in December.

ROME. NO other living man has become a historical figure so quickly as Mussolini. The dehumanization that all historical figures undergo has set in. He is already legendary, as if he had emerged from the centuries on horseback. simple pointing of his hand I got my first glimpse of the reality of supreme personal power. With one gesture he could condemn a whole section of a city. A dictator!

UNDER a decree signed by President von Hindenburg all German public buildings fly side by side, the black-whie-and-red flag of Imperial Germany and the Nazi banner with the swastika or hooked cross. By another decree the black-gold-and-red republican colors were banished from the German war flag.

Mrs. George K. Weeks heads a group of women who are completing plans for a Summer fashion show in aid of the Women's Auxiliary of the New York Infirmary for Women and Children which has been postponed from Tuesday to the afternoon of April 18.

One of the outstanding factors of the past year, due to the continued economic difficulties, is the intensive study being made by many organizations and individuals of the various problems affecting real estate, with the object of working out some satisfactory solutions.

BOSTON, March 16. -- Main may convoke a "convention" of five delegates, and only five, to pass upon the issue of prohibition repeal. Other plans are under discussion at Augusta and over the State, but this unique idea has merits which appeal to many legislators.

ON one side this novel is a study of extreme neurosis and of the transmission of brain sickness to offspring and, on the other, it is a picture of life in which men are, finally dismissed as mainly, incidental, and women are accepted as the permanent, necessary factors.

Many trades and business interests which contributed to the commercial activity of New York City twenty-eight years ago have now entirely or almost disappeared and several new industries have arisen. Some interesting facts regarding these trade changes are presented by comparing the listings in the 1933 Spring telephone Red Book, which has just been issued, with those in the first Red Book edition of 1905.

BERLIN, March 5, 1933. The opera houses are still operating under the sign of Wagner. The Staatsoper is putting the finishing touches on an elaborate revival of "Rienzi," and there is talk that the recent scandalous "Tannhauser" production will shortly be excommunicated and the old settings restored.

THE American Braille Press. 598 Madison Avenue. New York City, has recently completed its tenth year of service to the blind. During that time it has according to William Nelson Cromwell, president and founder of the organization, produced approximately 5O,OOO,OOO pages of braille literature In the form of books.

Weather permitting, the New York Women's Lacrosse Association hopes to continue the weekly practice session at Central Park today. The regular program has been interrupted recently, but the players are rather anxious to prepare for next month's games.

Two weeks from the day on which the Stock Exchange closed under the compulsion of the banking holiday, the share market fell back yesterday into its old Saturday habits. There were fractional gains in the averages at the end of the day.

Outlines of a new Constitution for India are laid down in a White Paper issued yesterday. It is the culmination of an almost continuous process of inquiry, debate, negotiation and civil turmoil, extending over a period of more than five years to the creation of the Simon Commission in the Fall of 1927.

For "Limited Ways." TANGLED traffic, automobiles capable of high speeds being compelled to inch along through a mass of slow-moving vehicles, hundreds of thousands of dollars going to waste daily from congestion and delay -- such is the situation confronting traffic experts in many cities of this country at the present moment.

PARIS, March 18 (AP). -- The presentation of the problem of the French debt to the United States in the Chamber of Deputies today caused the Nationalist newspaper La Liberte, hitherto a violent opponent of payment, to shift its camp and support the measure.

The decline in the number of traffic accidents in New York City continutd in February, the twelfth consecutive month in which both fatalities and injuries were reduced in comparison with the corresponding month of the previous year, according to figures in the March issue of the Police Department publication.

PARIS, March 16. -- Daytime bolero suits and enormously ample evening skirts constitute two conspicuous style designs seen this Spring. Semi-flexible band belts that open slightly in the manner of Arabian bracelets, in gold, silver or colored cellulose composition, finished with decorative motifs at both ends, are the latest thing in belt lines for all hours.

ALBANY, Ga., March 18 (AP). -- Horton Smith, the professional who registers from Chicago but learned his game in the Missouri Ozarks country, flashed a series of birdies today to score a 66, six under par, and take the first-round lead in the Radium Springs fifty-four-hole open golf tournament.

DR. TALMEY was stimulated to write his exposition of relativity not because he is mathematician who is dissatisfied with all past efforts to bring the finite, closed universe within the understanding of any intelligent person but because he is a man of sentiment.

LA PAZ, Bolivia, March 18. -- Another Paraguayan stronghold in the centre of the battlefront in the Gran Chac'o has been overcome by the Bolivians, according to reports from the front arriving at Fort Munoz, southern headquarters of the Bolivian Army.

PALM BEACH, Fla., March 18. -- Blue hydrangeas and yellow calla lilies were arranged against a background of tropical foliage to form a setting for the tea with which Mrs. Neill A. McMillan entertained at her villa this afternoon in compliment to her house guest, Mrs. Firmin Desloge.

IT has become the fashion to attribute all changes in the history of a people to economic causes and economic development, almost, if not quite entirely, ignoring the influence of the individual endowed with that especial type of personality which makes for leadership.

Revival of the plan for an Interstate agreement to control crude-oil production as a result of the conference of Governors of oil-producing States that has been called by Secretary Ickes of the Interior Department has aroused fresh hope among leaders of the industry.
WASHINGTON, March 18. -- Possibly a nation, dizzy with beholding wonders, does not realize that the President "passed a miracle" this week. The enactment of the economy bill was no less.

BOSTON, March 18. -- McGill University of Montreal won the first annual international indoor track meet from Boston University tonight in the West Newton Armory, 42 2-3 to 34 1-3, before almost 3,000 spectators.

IF the material collected by Mr. Wylie during his two years as professor in an American mission college had been presented in a factual narrative, the book might have had some claim on the attention of those Interested in Indian missions.

DETROIT. THE imminent return of beer has added to the spirit of optimism that prevails in this automobile metropolis at the present moment, when the economic skies are beginning to clear. The industry feels that a new market for millions of dollars' worth of motor equipment will open up within the next month, or as soon as the beverage begins to flow freely again.

An interesting alteration involving a new facade and marquise for the John Mullins Sons furniture store at 464 Rockaway Avenue, Brooklyn, has just been completed by Marvin Fine, a New York City architect, in conjunction with Horace Ginsbern.

WASHINGTON, March 18. -- The greatest danger in the great ,crisis which ravages the United States and lies in the fact that the President appears as a magician on whom one can somehow bet that he will make prosperity return and that what used to be America's greatest vice, the passion for gambling, may reappear in a new form under the man who is considered as sent by providence.

Chancellor Walcott in Wilmington, Del., approved on Friday the acquisition of all assets of the General Water Works and Electric Corporation at an auction sale on March 7 by the readjustment committee of the corporation, which paid $1,250,000 for the property.

DUBLIN, March 17. -- One of the most serious problems confronting the government here is the fast increasing unemployment in rural areas, especially in the South and West. Hundreds of young men and women who heretofore would have emigrated to the United States or crossed to England now find those outlets closed.
WASHINGTON, March 18. -- The Bureau of Navigation issued the following orders today, dated March 16:

MOST lay readers are Just now very much in need of the service this book endeavors to do for them. For in the post our financial knowledge has been even more limited than our political to conditions and matters in our own country.

With the problem of increasing the sales of electricity engaging the attention of public utility operators, the Hartford Electric Light Company has evolved a plan for leasing electric ranges to its customers which has been attended by immediate success, more than 500 ranges having been leased in the first ten days of the plan.

The appointment by President Roosevelt of two new commissioners of the United States Shipping Board and the reappointment of Commissioner Hutch I. Cone of Florida on Wednesday provided a temporary relief for shipping men who have expressed concern in recent months as to the future functions of the board.

Trading on the Cotton Exchange quieted yesterday and the market developed more resistance at about a dollar a bale above the quotations prevailing on March 3. Fluctuations were held within a normal range, and although the May at one time sold 4 points below Friday's low, the list closed unchanged to a gain of 3 points on the day.

CONTENDING that the perfect time to mate is to the first flush of youth, Mr. Wall supports his argument by contrasting the lives of three sisters yet unmarried with that of the fourth, who courageously leaps conventional barriers, accepts a humble lot and marries early the man she loves.

BARCELONA, March 3. -- Extravagant stories published in the United States picturing Majorca as Europe's new Gay White Way, as something of a new Monte Carlo surpassing the original, have put fear into the hearts of stay-at-home husbands whose wives have gone there principally because living is supposed to be inexpensive.

NYACK, N.Y., March 18. -- Contests for Mayor and trustees will feature the Spring elections Tuesday in the four principal villages of Rockland County -- Nyack, Spring Valley, Suffern and Haverstraw. West Haverstraw will also decide a contest, but in the six other villages of the county tickets have been nominated without opposition.

SUPERINTENDENTS of schools replying to an inquiry recently made by the United States Commissioner of Education, reported that three or four times as many post-graduates were in high schools today as were enrolled a few years ago.

WHEN the story of what Gilbert Seldes calls "the years of the locust" Is finally written, the march of the Bonus Expeditionary Force upon Washington In the Spring of 1932 will probably occupy as important a place as the story of Coxey's Army does In the literature of the nineties.

A striking illustration of the real difficulties under which property owners, mortgage holders and realty interests in general are laboring at the present time is furnished by the number of bills recently introduced into the Legislature which aim to provide various and very necessary means of relief to those in serious financial straits as a direct result of the great decline in real estate values.

MAGNIFICENTLY produced, with a splendid cast headed by the talented Katharine Hepburn and the efficient Colin Clive, the film transcription of Gilbert Frankau's novel "Christopher Strong," which was at the Radio City Music Hall last week, is another gratifying example of the forward strides made in motion pictures since the linking of the microphone with the camera.

Cheered to the echo by a capacity audience that paid over $5,000 net profit to a benefiting charity, the Metropolitan Opera stars gave a gala matinee yesterday as the twentieth and last of the "extra" performances annually added to their schedule for the various good causes making special appeals from this stage.

WINTER HAVEN, Fla.. March 18. -- There was a time when managing the Phillies was like going into seclusion or traveling incognito. If there was any interest at all in the occupant of that position, it was one of pity for the misfortune that had been visited upon him. But now, Burt Shotton is a marked man. The formerly futile Phillies fought their way into the first division last season.

WITHOUT any of the usual preliminary ballyhoo we are here introduced to a new mystery writer who deserves a place alongside such masters of the craft as S. S. Van Dine. R. Austin Freeman and others whose names will occur to every diligent reader of this type of fiction.

IT is a romantic story that Dr. Charles H. Herty, former preident of the American Chemical Society, has been telling associations of paper makers of late -- the old story of preconceived but wrong notions that have acquired all the force of tradition and that are usually summarized in the well-known phrase of the skeptic: "It can't be done."
MOGDISHU, Somaliland, March 18 (AP). -- The Duke of the Abruzzi, cousin, of King Victor Emmanuel and famous explorer, died today at the age of 60.

THE Flower Show comes trooping upon the public stage to answer Old Man Gloom. Last November, when the frost had put the final crimp in the chrysanthemums. Old Man Gloom said there would never be another blossom.
NEW DELHI, India, March 18. -- A storm of hostility was aroused throughout India today by the publication of the British Government's White Paper on the proposed federal Constitution.

PONTIAC dealers are letting prospective customers find out for themselves just how far they can drive on a given quantity of fuel. For the test an auxiliary one-quart glass jar is attached to a door, a rubber tube leading from the jar to the fuel pump.

MAUD DALE is so charming a truant that when she reappears one hasn't the heart to chide her for having, as it were, left art in the lurch. And as a matter of fact, Mrs. Dale never does leave art in the lurch, really, since she is always at work on projects, some of which, impressive in scope or offering peculiar difficulties, require long preparation.

AS President Roosevelt takes up the task of translating into terms of action his conception of the "new deal" there comes from the press this book in which he sets forth his convictions as to why a new deal is necessary and as to the character it must assume.

THIS book by Mary Wright Wheeler, who in a registered nurse and writes out of ample knowledge and experience, is intended for the use of any woman, wife, mother, sister, daughter, friend, companion, upon whom falls the necessity of taking care, without previous training, of the ill. the aged, the very young.

PORTLAND, Ore., March 16. -- Although the national banking holiday has occupied the centre of the stage here, as in other parts of the country, Oregon has been busy in the wings getting its own financial affairs in order and has made definite progress.

WASHINGTON, March 18. -- An unemployed Italian-American girl living in Brooklyn, who refused to sign her name to her letter addressed to President Roosevelt, has sent him a 55 gold piece and gold chain, her only article of jewelry, as her contribution to the antihoarding campaign.

Headquarters of the women's division of the Salvation Army's United Appeal will be opened tomorrow at the Plaza in a suite donated by the hotel, it was announced yesterday by Mrs. Benjamin Moore of Syosset, chairman of the division.

AN extensive literature has for some years been growing up around the theme of the isolated, backward folk of the Southern mountains, fiction, description, discussion of one sort or another. It has ranged so widely that one would have thought it has taken in all these deteriorating communities.

IF round-the-world schedules bold true. Bernard Shaw will see America first in the coining week. He will breathe the air of the country to which he owes no small part of his expansive fame and handsome fortune, but which be has hitherto consistently excluded from a visiting list embracing already the continents of Europe.

ADMITTING that Maine "is about the last place where one might reasonably expect to find romance,'' Mr. Verrill yet maintains sturdily, and apparently proves his contention, that "romance seems to be in the blood of the Maine people" and can be found "wherever one travels In Maine, whenever one delves into Maine's past."

Losses estimated at $300,000 have been reported by twenty Fifth Avenue merchants as a result of the St. Patrick's Day parade, it was announced yesterday by Captain William J. Fedrick, president of the Fifth Avenue Association. Additional losses are being reported.

A step which brings into question the effectiveness of "most-favored-nations" treaties negotiated by the United States with other countries was taken here last week by government attorneys in defending the imposition of tariffs on importations of coal from Great Britain and Germany.

HOLLYWOOD, March 18 (AP). -- Douglas Fairbanks Jr. said today that he had no intention of going to Paris to divorce his actress wife. Joan Crawford, nor does he plan to marry Mrs. Jorgen Dietz, former wife of the chemical engineer who has instituted against him a $60,000 suit charging alienation of affections and false imprisonment.

NOW that the American theatre is at last casting anxious eyes upon its laurels -- an eventuality which a familiar play character used to predict with Cassandra-like monotony -- this department cannot be remiss in casting its eyes for a few moments upon the trials and tribulations of the poor play broker, since he is having his major difficulties along with the rest of the theatrical gentry.

BERLIN, March 18. -- All Germany must celebrate the convening of the new Reichstag Tuesday, under an order from Dr. Paul Joseph Goebbels, Minister of Popular Enlightenment and Propaganda. Dr. Goebbel's call to the people begins:

CHICAGO, March 18. -- The will of Anton J. Cermak, disposing of an estate which had dwindled from 5700,000 to 8250,000 in four years, was filed for probate today by Attorney General Otto Kerner for many years personal counsel of the slain Mayor.
PARIS, March 8. -- Though diplomats gather in Geneva as the official representatives of governments, they have their own intimate meeting place in Paris at the International Diplomatic Academy.

Various phases of education, emphasizing the changes needed to meet new social conditions and the advisability of retaining existing methods because of financial restrictions, were discussed yesterday by educational leaders at a luncheon meeting of the Teachers Union of New fork at 36 West Forty-eighth Street.

Re-legalization of real beer is expected in many quarters to have far-flung beneficent effects in industry. More than a dozen different lines of activity are believed likely to benefit from the legislation, and relatively few lines expect to be hurt.

Dean Rufus D. Smith, chairman of the New York University Committee on Unemployment, reported yesterday that the university had placed more than 1,200 unemployed men and women sent by the Emergency Unemployment Relief Committee during the last three years, in congenial and worthwhile work.

YOUNG America reinforced the tides of Spring in the New York art galleries last week. The date on the calendar, the opening (tomorrow) of the annual flower show at Grand Central Palace, and the exhibition of flowers and fruit in painting at the Museum of Modern Art, are ably seconded in emphasizing the youth of the year by the outbreak of younger artists.
BOSTON, March 17. -- In four New England States bills have been introduced this year for the legalization of horse-race betting under the pari-mutuel system.

The abnormal condition of the real estate mortgage market throughout the United States is shown by the fact that in 91 per cent of the principal cities loans are seeking capital, according to the twentieth semiannual survey of the National Association of Real Estate Boards.

The new Grace Line steamship Santa Elena will sail March 31 on her maiden trip to California and the Pacific Northwest, formally ending a campaign of ship construction by the line during the last two years in which four new ships were completed at a total expenditure of about $19,000,000.

E. Richard Bagarozy, attorney, with offices at 1,775 Broadway, and two men who were arrested with him Friday night as conspirators in the robbery on Dec. 6 last of $250,000 in securities from mail being carried from the Federal Building in Chicago to the First National Bank of that city protested their innocence when they were arraigned yesterday before Francis A. O'Neill, United States Commissioner.

LISTENERS are still complaining that the announcers at the Presidential inaugural abandoned accuracy. It may be because the announcers of at least one network were ordered to "be buoyant and give a colorful picture of optimism."

Football and basketball faced campaigns during the present academic year with new rules governing their games, and now a third college sport is faced with rule changes which are more striking than was the case with football during the past season.

FOR the last three and a half years an airline which has received little prominence has been serving the traveling public between New York and Buffalo. Flying Whirlwind-powered Bellancas and Wasp-powered Fokker Universals, Martz Airline, on a three hour schedule eastbound, carrying express and passengers only, bai made a name for itself for depend ability over bad flying country.

PROBABLY never before in the history of the country have two weeks been so crowded with Executive action as were the last two; never before were so many momentous problems dealt with. Here are the outstanding ones:

LONDON, March 18. -- The House of Commons will be the scene of the next move toward an Indian federation with a three-day debate on India next week. There will be no opportunity to vote on the merits of the White Paper, but the die-hards will try their strength on the motion to establish a joint committee of both houses of Parliament to formulate an Indian constitutional bill.

WASHINGTON, March 18. -- The confusion which engulfed the House yesterday when Representative Steagall, chairman of the Banking and Currency Committee, attempted to call up for passage his amendment to the national banking act to permit State banks to obtain "circulating currency" from the Federal Reserve System, continued today when the committee, contrary to Republican requests, failed to meet for further consideration of the measure.

LONDON, March 18 (AP). -- The correspondent for Reuter's (British) news agency at Riga, Latvia, reported today that the arrests in Russia of British employes of the Metropolitan - Vickers Electrical Company was understood to be closely connected with the building of the $100,000,000 Dnieprostroi Dam, which was opened last May.

PARIS, March 18. -- Dr. Harvey Cushing, noted American surgeon, was one of five foreigners named by the University of Paris to receive the degree Doctor Honoris Causa whose selection was approved today by the Ministry of National Education.

OMAHA, March 16. -- Life in the Corn Belt seems to be just one doggoned holiday after another. When it isn't a farm holiday it is a bank holiday or an insurance holiday and then a farm holiday all over again.

THE Roosevelt administration took a long step last week in the direction of a balanced budget. On its initiative Congress adopted with amazing promptness a bill which cuts more than 5500,000,000 from the costs of the Federal Government.

LIKE "The Island of Penguins" and "In the Land of the Lion," Mr. Kearton's new book is the result of a knowledge of wild animals gained by forty years of study and photography of his subjects in their native haunts before the current of their natural lives has been disturbed by the presence of human beings.

FROM what manner of ancestors did our new President spring, what kind of blood runs in his veins, what did they send down to him in the way of intellect, character, personality, are some of the questions whose answers Alvin Page Johnson has been searching records to discover.

MINEOLA, L. I., March 18. -- "Voters in fifty-four of Nassau County's sixty-three municipalities will go to the polls Tuesday to elect candidates to govern the villages for the next twelve months. In what are known as the "millionaires' villages" most of the designated candidates are expected to be elected without opposition.
AFTER thirteen years in exile King Gambrinus, patron for many centuries past of fermented cereal beverages, is again about to show his genial countenance in the light of day in the United States.

Determined efforts by municipal bankers and institutional holders of municipal bonds to check the growing list of municipal defaults has occasioned numerous meetings in the last few days to back the bill introduced last week in Congress by Representative J. Mark Wilcox and referred to the Judiciary Committee.

EDINBURGH, Scotland, March 18. -- Scotland defeated England by the narrow margin of 3-0 today in an international rugby fixture. It was Scotland's second victory in the classic rugby series, the team having won its only other match with Wales, 11-3, early in February.

DR. CARNAP and the author of this book, Professor Hans Reichenbach, who occupies the Chair at Natural Philosophy in the University of Berlin, are leaders of a school of thought that is the direct outcome of the discoveries made by the relativists and the atomic ohysicists.

PARIS, March 7, 1933. ALL musical forms are good if one knows how to use them. The symphony in D major of Jean Rivier brings us fresh proof of the fact that this means of musical expression, which every one in 1910 thought to be dead, is as vital as ever;

SOFIA, March 17. -- The relations of Bulgaria and Yugoslavia, never friendly since the last Balkan war, have become so embittered in the last few months that they would probably be exciting the anxiety of the great powers were it not that events in Germany and elsewhere have given the great powers enough to worry about.
VIENNA, March 18 (AP). -- The machinery of Austrian politics moved another notch today toward complete synchronization with the Hitler movement in Germany.

EVERY nation has its tall tales of the folk when the folk was young, and America, which is at last appreciating what Professor Turner made plain in 1893. that the frontier line has disappeared, is now furbishing up its candidates for the role of Odysseus.

THIS volume la the outcome of a searching inquiry instituted two years ago, sponsored and financed by a group of laymen representing seven Protestant denominations, namely, Presbyterian, Dutch Reformed, United Presbyterian.

MORE evidence is accumulating to indicate that before very long the hope for a revival of legitimate activities for the ballet in this country may be consummated. Two recent announcements, one from the East and one from the West, give weight to this hope.
RALEIGH, N.C., March 18 (AP). -- Josephus Daniels became "Mr. Ambassador" today.

SUCCESS of other industries in developing radically new designs for their products, such as the streamline in automobile bodies and radiators, has developed wide discussion of sales possibilities of new designs for radio receivers.

IN "Light Again" Blair Niles treats once more of the forgotten and the lost, but this time not in a penal colony. Her book, moreover, is cast into the novel form, with which she has once or twice before experimented.

APROPOS of remarks made here last week, we slipped up over the present status of the Menuhin-Enesco performance of the Bach two-violin concerto, and were by no means alone in this. Apparently, it has been floating idly about for some time under the familiar red seal label of Victor, almost as long as it has been current in Europe -- without benefit of regular announcement.

BRUSSELS, March 6. -- Belgians are shocked to discover that mosquitos of various breeds and species, but practically all of the stingy kind, are much quicker on the up-take than mere human beings. At the close of the war central heating apparatus was installed in the busy centres of Belgian cities.

DOROTHY GRAFLY contributes to the March issue of The American Magazine of Art an essay on two German sculptors, Hugo Lederer and Georsr Kolbe. Interestingly presented and Renerously illustrated, it is announced as one of a series on contemporary European sculpture.

CHICAGO, March 16. -- With banks reopening under sunny skies, Spring has come for the new era in this tier of States bordering the western shore of Lake Michigan. Its advent for many persons is made the more joyous by the promise that they may soon be able to celebrate in a draft of 3.2 per cent beer -- or whatever the ultimately determined decimal should prove to be.

MR. SAYRE who wrrote the incredibly funny "Rackety Rax" last year, has been regarding tie raucous pageant of the American municipal follies from a point of view that combines the more entertaining features of Jimmy Durante and Lincoln Steffens.

WASHINGTON, March 18. -- President Roosevelt's first two weeks in office have been crowded with events to an extent not equaled at the national capital since the war days of 1917 and 1918. A summary of the highlights of this unusual period follows:

CHICAGO, March 18. -- The new Federal law which defines the writing of extortion letters as a felony was invoked today to send one man to prison for five years and to transfer the case against another from police to Federal jurisdiction.

SHANHAIKWAN, China, Feb. 15. -- The five-colored flag of Manchukuo flies from nearly every doorway in this historic city at the Great Wall. But Shanhaikwan is, as yet, no part of Manchukuo. Today, some six weeks after the surrender of the city to the Japanese, the future political status of Shanhaikwan remains uncertain.

MIAMI BEACH, Fla., March 18. -- The Colonel E.H.R. Green trophy for outboard motor racers went to the Southwest today as Walter Everett of Tulsa, Okla., won the fixture of the Biscayne Bay regatta with 1,089 points in two days of competition.

In reviewing the real estate situation today from the appraisal standpoint, Pell Thompson, appraiser of the firm of Pease Elliman, points out that an appraiser has a very difficult task to determine a fair market value of a piece of real estate of any kind.
WASHINGTON, March 18 (AP). -- The coal industry, ill many years from excessive competition, is about to undergo a major operation.

WASHINGTON, March 18 -- Average wholesale prices declined two per cent in February, compared with the preceding month, and were about 9 3/4 per cent below the average for the corresponding month last year, the Bureau of Labor Statistics announced today.

BERLIN, March 18. -- Dr. Hjalmar Schacht celebrated his return to the presidency of the Reichsbank by a brief radio talk tonight in which he announced Germany acknowledged her foreign commercial indebtedness in full.

WASHINGTON, March 18. -- The Treasury Department made public tonight an executive order by President Roosevelt permitting State authorities having immediate supervision of any State bank which is a member of the Federal Reserve System to appoint conservators for such institutions.

A long, angled drive by Tommy Glynn that ended a sudden-death extra period at Squadron A Armory last night put the Squadron A team into the final round of the Manhattan circuit elimination indoor polo play. That drive brought victory to the home riders over the 105th Field Artillery of the Bronx, 10 to 9.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., March 18. -- Asserting that the farmer must be rehabilitated and his earning power restored, his credit obligations validated and his position as a solvent business proprietor stabilized without great expenditure by the Federal Government, Professors Thurman W. Arnold and Wesley A. Sturges of the Yale School of Law made public today the details of a plan for farm relief.

IN one respect "Grain Race'" differs from very nearly all of the many books of recent years that have had to do with the sea and with the days of sail. For the most part -- and necessarily -- these books have come from the pens of mariners grown gray upon the sea.

WASHINGTON, March 18. -- Forecasts of the California earthquake, the national banking crisis and the death of "three nationally prominent men," with other predictions yet to be fulfilled, were included in a letter to The Los Angeles Times dated March 3.

BERLIN, March 18. -- Although with slackened momentum, the Boerse continued its upward movement today. The prevalent opinion seemed to be that this was due to public rather than professional operations. Bonds were the centre of buying interest, some rises of 4 points being recorded.

Suburban developers expect the "back-to-the-farm" movement to have a favorable effect on the demand for small homes in the outlying districts with enough land to permit vegetable gardening or truck farming to supplement the owner's income.
JEDDAH (Saudite Arabia), Feb. 22. -- King Ibn Saud, the most powerful monarch of the Arabian Peninsula, has quelled another revolt.

WEST POINT, N. Y., March 18. -- Two Army teams captured dual events today, the fencers defeating New York. University's strong team, 10 to 7, and the gymnasts scoring their sixteenth straight triumph, by overwhelming Springfield College, 39 to 15.

IN normal times the prices asked for the most coveted literary rarities are usually beyond the means of our public institutions. It must be irksome, therefore, for librarians today to find themselves offered many of these hitherto inaccessible treasures at tempting figures, only to be themselves handicapped by a diminished purchasing power.

EXPRESSING youth, seems to be the main objective of the designers of the Spring silhouette, whether they be French or American. Let us consider for a moment the new lines as we see them coming through fashion lanes.

BERLIN. WHILE biographies win form the chief subject of discussion today, the literary sensation of the moment is not a book of this genre but an individual, the youthful Franz Loeser, who was awarded first prize in the German division of the post-war-novel contest conducted by The Times, London.
LONDON, March 8. -- The keynote of British utterances, public as well as private, with regard to the present crisis of the dollar is confidence in America and the American people.

FOUR long pedestrian tunnels, offshoots of the Eighth Avenue subway, have been added to Manhattan's many underground passageways. The first enables pedestrians desiring to avoid rain or traffic to duck underground at Eighth Avenue and Forty-first Street and walk to the east side of Broadway, a distance of 600 feet, without any payment.

TWO items of news from Germany may be fittingly contrasted here. The first is the dispatch of Herbert Peyser, published in THE TIMES of last Wednesday, stating that the Hitler regime bad ousted not only politicians of opposing parties from office but had also deposed Conductor Fritz Busch of the Dresden Opera and Carl Ebert of the Berlin Civic Opera, and might eject internationally famous artists on grounds of race or nationality.
During the last few months there has been a constant demand upon loaning institutions for a reduction of mortgage interest rates.

ALBANY, March 18. -- In an address at the annual dinner of the Friendly Sons of St. Patrick tonight Governor Lehman avowed his readiness to accept further cuts in the State budget, but warned against too drastic economies for the sake of political capital.

PARIS, March 10. -- Figures recently compiled by the American Hospital at Neuilly, just outside Paris, show that the death rate there for 1932 -- 3 per cent of all cases received -- was better than that of hospitals in the United States even of the Grade A type in the year 1931.

DETROIT, March 18 (AP). -- Persons interested in formation of a new bank to supplant the First National Bank-Detroit and the Guardian National Bank of Commerce were advised tonight that a plan for organization of a $25,000,000 bank would be presented to Reconstruction Finance Corporation and Treasury officials in Washington tomorrow.

JAN WELZL, it will be remembered, is the man whose "Thirty Years In the Golden North," published not so long ago. while giving a good deal of pleasure to many, aroused also the suspicions of many. The melodramatic nature of half the episodes of the book brought down upon the author's head the charge of deliberate fabrication, or at best, of deliberate exaggeration.
With his commanding two-set lead wiped out and threatened with the loss of his national indoor tennis title, Gregory Mangin of Newark rallied to stem the tide of defeat yesterday.

DR. HARDING was born, brought up and educated in England and received her medical training at the University of London. She began her medical practice at about the time of the outbreak of the World War and continued It through all that time of stress, anxiety, suffering, frustration and anguish.

GENEVA, March 18. -- Important sections of the report adopted today by the Council of the League of Nations, acting under Article XV, Paragraph 4, of the covenant in the dispute between Colombia and Peru are now to be broadcast by the League of Nations station at Geneva.

WASHINGTON, March 18. -- That unified Federal regulation is essential to the development of a satisfactory national transportation system and that railroad consolidation to be effected, must be compelled, are among the principal conclusions reached in a study of the "American Transportation Problem" published by the Brookings Institution.
WASHINGTON, March 18. -- Final action on the Cullen beer bill is expected to follow quickly upon the reconvening of Congress Monday.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., March 18. -- Champion Benson of Crombie for the eleventh, time in his career on the bench was named best in show tonight, being awarded the highest honor in the seventeenth annual exhibition of the Providence County Kennel Club at the State Armory.

MR. STREET has written a bird guide ably designed to help the beginner. Instead of following the standard classification of birds, which is somewhat dogmatic, he has arranged his list according to bird habits: and instead of illustrating each bird as an isolated phenomenon he has fitted his birds into their proper landscapes.
WASHINGTON, March 19 (AP). -- The Federal Reserve Board wants the bank-ward rush of hoarded gold to continue for another week or more.

To the Editor of The New York Times: To read that the oldest school In this city, the Collegiate School of New York, is now celebrating the three hundredth anniversary of its founding is a bit disconcerting. There is no evidence that the school was founded in 1633.

If the author of "Masks and Faces," which opened on Saturday evening at the Liberty Theatre, was concealing anything from the audience, it's an unmitigated shame that he didn't come out with it. In that way, at least, he might have saved a persistently indifferent play from the depths into which it plunged.

Clearing up of the banking situation and the return of confidence to both the general public and business executives resulted in a sizable increase in orders for ready-to-wear last week. There was a stronger tone to wholesale prices. Piece goods orders maintained a higher level than other lines.

After the conference of the mighty minds of Tammany on Saturday, it was announced that " all "the members of the Democratic "party in the Legislature would "stand solidly behind any position "taken by Governor LEHMAN on "the so-called beer legislation."

LONDON, March 19. -- Elaborate precautions have been completed by the civil and military police for tomorrow's trial of Lieutenant Norman Baillie-Stewart of the Seaforth Highlanders, who is charged with violation of the official secrets act.

Delighted with the performance of the silvery monoplane constructed for a flight of exploration between the Ross and Weddell Seas In the South Polar region, Bernt Balchen, pilot of the Lincoln Ellsworth Transantarctic Expedition, has returned from tests in Canada under conditions approximating those in the Antarctic and will take off in a few days for the Pacific Coast by way of the Grand Canyon.

The City Superintendent of Schools devotes to the "slowprogress" pupils the first section of his annual report, released to the public today. He is wise as well as considerate to put first those who are usually the last and liable to be neglected. Scripture is invoked to give support to a policy which recognizes differences in aptitudes as stars differ from one another in glory."

David Lindsay, assistant passenger manager of the International Mercantile Marine Company, who is the agent for the White Star ine, returned yesterday from a visit to Pittsburgh, Detroit. Cleveand, Chicago and St. Louis. He said that, despite the pessimistic outlook for the shipping this Summer given out recently in Paris by the Transatlantic conference, he found that the passenger business was good.

LONDON, March., 18. -- The Bank of England continues to accumulate gold. Its purchases from the market during the week ended with Wednesday, as shown by Thursday's statement, aggregated nearly u6,500,000, making the total Influx since the last American wer-debt payment more than u46,500,000 and raising the bank's gold holdings to u167,135,000.

PRINCETON, N.J., March 19. -- Efforts of dry leaders to obtain a judgment from the Supreme Court declaring that 3.2 per cent or any other beer of "reasonable" percentage is unconstitutional will be unavailing. Professor Edwin S. Corwin of the Department of Politics of Princeton University, an authority on constitutional law, said here today.

MONTREAL. March 19. -- Further cuts in the price of newsprint, said to be imminent, would be a catastrophe from the Canadian standpoint, according to opinions obtained over the week-end from parties interested in the welfare of the industry.
NEW ORLEANS, March 19 (AP). -- T.H. Lynch's Chat Eagle turned in a stellar performance today in winning the fourth race of the Sunday welfare program at the Fair Grounds track.

SCHENECTADY, N.Y., March 19. -- The Union College alumni, faculty and undergraduates will pay tribute to 156 students who have been members of the Union varsity and freshman athletic teams during the past calendar year at the sixth annual Block U Dinner tomorrow night.

SEATTLE, March 19 (AP). -- The steel freighter Canadian Seigneur, which left Gray's Harbor, March 2, called desperately for aid today in the stormy seas off the western tip of the Aleutian Islands, while the Canadian Pacific liner Empress of Russia, was hove to in the vicinty, but unable to render assistance because of dark and stormy weather.

CHICAGO, March 19. -- Placing of the banks throughout the country on a sound basis has brought a pronounced change in ideas and actions of bankers, merchants and speculators, leading them to believe that everything is to do better and that securities and grain offer special opportunities for investment to processors and traders.

TRENTON, N.J., March 19. -- Senator Clifford R. Powell of Burlington County, floor leader of the Republican majority in the upper house, toolc up today the gauntlet thrown down by Governor A. Harry Moore in his fight to force the Legislature to reorganize the State Highway Department.

H.E. Dunn Jr., first seeded player from the Princeton Club, advanced to the third round in the Metropolitan Squash Racquets Association Class C championship tournament yesterday at the Downtown Athletic Club.

ST. LOUIS, March 19. -- The Stix Club of St. Louis won the first game of the Western final series in the national soccer competition today, defeating the Sparta eleven of Chicago by 7 to 3 before 4,000.

MIAMI, Fla., March 19. -- Behind the shut-out pitching of Walter Beck and Van Mungo and the competent efforts of Owen Carroll, the Dodgers today evened their short series with the Bisons by winning, 4 to 1.
ALBANY, N.Y., March 19. -- Democratic legislative leaders arrived here tonight prepared to draft a new beer control bill in conformity with the ideas of Governor Lehman.

The formation of a country-wide chain of citizens' councils, to work for the maintenance of essential community services during the present period of governmental economy, was advocated yesterday in a statement issued through the National Municipal League, 309 East Thirty-fourth Street, on behalf of a group of individuals andorganizations.

LONDON, March 17. -- Security markets here are still restrained by the European political situation; also by the feeling that, while the American financial crisis is being overcome, it must for some time continue to have unfavorable repercussions abroad.

Warning his congregation that the repeal of the prohibition amendment might bring liquor control back into politics, the Rev. Dr. Walter H. Rollins, superintendent of Congregational and Christian churches of New York State, declared in a sermon yesterday at the Manhattan Church, Broadway and Seventy-Sixth Street, that "we see stretched out again the grasping hand of politics to debauch our whole American system of democracy."

Joseph A. Broderick, Superintendent of Banks, announced yesterday that seven more State batiks which are not members of the Federal Reserve System, all of them upState, would be permitted to reopen for business today.

Whoever picks up a copy of the Annual Report of Commissioner MULROONEY for 1932, published today, will turn most eagerly to the statistics under three heads. They are: Crime, street accidents and public morals. Compared with the year 1931, crimes of violence decreased 2.6 per cent.

PARIS, March 19. -- Although reports of the conversations between Premier Mussolini and Prime Minister MacDonald in Rome are still too scant here to evoke official comment, it has already become obvious from the press reaction and political addresses that France sees no reason to derive satisfaction at what is going on there.
WASHINGTON, March 19 -- Three bills covering as many phases of a new and enlarged Federal program of unemployment relief will be introduced tomorrow by Senator Wagner.

PARIS, March 19. -- It is expected the French Cabinet will give official consideration tomorrow to the problem of what is to be done regarding payment of the $20,000,000 debt instalment due the United States last December and "deferred" by a vote of the Chamber of Deputies.

The annual dance and revue under the auspices of the Almoners will take place on April 17 at the Plaza for the benefit at the New York Foundling Hospital. Although the hospital is aided to some extent by the City of New York, it is largely dependent upon donations from individuals in order to maintain its ever-increasing activities.
ROME, March 19 (AP). -- An official communique issued after conferences here today between Prime Minister MacDonald and Premier Mussolini said:

Bullets ended the lives of four men in and near the city late Saturday night and yesterday and wounded one man. Early this morning a Negro woman was killed. Four of the shootings took place in or near city speakeasies. Two bodies were found in Bedford Hills, Westchester County.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In reply to R.
