Bloomfield's statement regarding my letter on cigarette taxes, I should like to say that Mr. Bloomfield is in error when he states that 60 per cent tax (being only one of the many taxes affecting this commodity) on the retail price of cigarettes does not create hardship for farmers and factory workers who raise and manufacture tobacco.

According to Sam Packer, the dean of Skytop, Pa., there won't be any lack of trout in Levitt's Brook at Skytop when the season in Pennsylvania opens next month. This famous old stream meanders down into the Brodhead and has been fished for years by New Yorkers who have come to know that trout are almost always to be had there.
A committee has been appointed by President Fred Berry of the Bronx Board of Trade to attend a meeting of the committee on local laws of the Board of Estimate tomorrow in the City Hall.

A blanket mortgage for $59,000 which is held by shell Eastern Petroleum Products, Inc., from Fred Kannen, Inc., on one parcel in Brooklyn and three in Manhattan, has been spread over the block fronting on the east side of 1st Av., from 46th to 47th St.

The granting of unusual powers to President Roosevelt in no sense vests the President with a dictatorship, unless it be one of reason, declared Senator Joseph T. Robinson of Arkansas, majority leader, in a debate with Morris Hillquit, Socialist leader, last night at the Brooklyn Academy of Music.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Governor Lehman having wisely vetoed the Alterman bill, which allowed appeals as of right to the Court of Appeals from decisions of the Appellate Division in cases of disbarment and removal of magistrates, another bill has appeared, this introduced by Mr. Sargent of Syracuse, which, although less objectionable in that it has no application to magistrates, is unconstitutional on the same grounds as the Alterman bill.

In name Smith County of Northeastern Texas has no such historical, heroic and euphonious splendor as attaches to Deaf Smith County in the Panhandle; and yet here are those, even among the outlanders, who love it. Tyler, the county seat, has a college and use to be known as " the Athens of Texas."
NEW YORK. The Spanish Ambassador to Mexico, Senor Don Julio Alvarez del Vayo, is at the St. Regis.

After eight business days in which all markets were shut down, we have now had a week in which they passed at least their preliminary judgment on the existing situation. In some regards, the verdict was much what had been expected. Recovery in the stock market, at all events, was not illogical.

Crimes of violence in New York City decreased 2.6 per cent last year as compared with the preceding year, and all major crimes decreased 17 per cent, according to the report for 1932 submitted by Police Commissioner Mulrooney to Mayor O'Brien yesterday.

LOS ANGELES, March 19. -- Two uncomfortable innings experienced by Ray Starr and Leroy Parmelee, in which the Chicago White Sox scored seven runs on nine hits, were forgotten in an avalanche of New York base hits which swept the Giants to a 13-to-8 victory today.

While the steel mills were working at 13 per cent capacity last Summer the textile industry suddenly spurted up and closed the year with a total rate of operations only 10 per cent below 1931. Is this the reason for the new textile products that astonish one at every hand? The physicist and chemist know better.
MEXICO CITY, March 19. -- Former President Plutarco Elias Calles left this morning for Ensenada, capital of Lower California, on a holiday which, it is reported, will last six months.

Superb goal tending by Jock Riddell and rugged defensive play by the entire team enabled the Bronx Hockey Club to upset the Baltimore Orioles, 3 to 0, at Madison Square Garden yesterday afternoon and thereby virtually assure the Atlantic City Sea Gulls of the national A.A.U. championship.

Sprinting on the last lap, David McErlane of the Holy Name Club won the three-mile run conducted by the Manhattan Athletic League yesterday at the Sixty-ninth Regiment Armory. Fifteen yards behind in second place was John Sullivan, a team-mate of the winner.

WASHINGTON, March 19. -- A renewal of efforts by the United Mine Workers to obtain Federal regulation of the bituminous coal industry following the Supreme Court's decision in the Appalachian Coals case was indicated today in a union statement.

MANILA, March 19. -- Senator Benigno Aquino, who has Just returned from the independence mission to Washington, attacked Senator Quezon's policies today at a public welcome luncheon. He said the Philippines suffer from "the lack of true orientation and purposeful leadership in the program of the government."

ALBANY, Ga., March 19. -- Craig Wood of Deal, N.J., who won three consecutive golf tournaments in California some weeks ago, took first place today in the fifty-four-hole Radium prings open with a total score of 209.

CHICAGO, March 19. -- Prices for Hogs at their highest point last week were $4.20 a hundredweight, while the average was $4.10. Only once in six months were they better. Demand was liberal, and packers aid 20 to 30 cents more than at the end of the previous week and 5 to 45 cents more than on March.

Thrown from his seat in a collision yesterday afternoon between two automobiles at Flatlands and Remsen Avenues, Brooklyn, William Vohs, 26 years old, of 31 Aberdeen Street, Brooklyn, was fatally injured. His head struck a fire hydrant.

To the Editor of The New York Times : "Is the policy of the nation to be dominated by a small, organized minority of mercenary ex-soldiers who have formed themselves, under professional lobbyists, into a special class to be supported by the rest of the nation?"

Bishop William T. Manning confirmed yesterday morning a class of thirtyfive adults and sixteen children, the largest class in the last ten years, at the Calvary Protestant Episcopal Church, Twentyfirst Street and Fourth Avenue. The Rev. J. Herbert Smith, assistant rector, presented the class to Bishop Manning.

It is unjust to Impugn the divine nature of the whole religious structure of Catholicismbecause a black sheep has on occasion found shelter in the body of the Church of Rome, the Rev. Dr. Fulton J. Sheen of the Catholic University, Washington, D.C., said yesterday morning in one of a course of Lenten sermons in St. Patrick's Cathedral.

WASHINGTON, March 19 (AP). -- Representative Cannon, Democrat, of Missouri, who was reported to have engaged in a sanguinary fist fight several days ago with a fellow-Missourian, Representative Romjue, today issued a statement denying a "rumor reported by a St. Louis paper that I was drinking last week."

ALBANY, March 19. -- A new drive for reorganization of the Democratic party In the up-Stateregions has been started by associates of Jamea A. Farley, national chairman, with the object of displacing at least five leaders who opposed Franklin D. Roosevelt for President.

CHICAGO, March 19. -- General improvement in banking conditions here and throughout the West, the banks in this city alone strengthening their position by $181,000,000 in deposits in less than one week, combined with the reopening of banks throughout the interior, is reflected in a better tone in business circles with a disposition to take a more optimistic view of the future.

HASTINGS-ON-HUDSON, N.Y., March 19. -- Mrs. Kenneth H. Sims, chairman of a committee of four clubwomen who operate the "Swap Shop," a non-profit barter exchange at 14 Spring Street here, announced today that an experiment yesterday with the exchange of old gold for cash had proved successful and that the gold exchange would be continued tomorrow, Tuesday and Wednesday.

SANTIAGO, Chile, March 19. -- Expressing disapproval of the Chilean Government's sudden modification of its nitrate of soda policy, particularly its removal of the fiscal guarantee backing the foreign bond issues of the monopoly now being dissolved, Horace Graham, representing Cosach, the nitrate corporation of Chile, recommended today that no changes be considered by the liquidating committee.

Food For Minors. Beer may come back as non-intoxicating. But it also seems destined to figure as the most serious menace with which youth can be brought in contact in our present civilization. The trend of the proposed State beer legislation everywhere is to prohibit its sale to minors.

In the busy week beginning today the most important event on the art world's calendar is the 108th annual exhibition of the National Academy. Friday will be varnishing day and the exhibition will open to the public on Saturday.
Although New Jersey deals furnished the bulk of real estate trading in the metropolitan arear over the week-end, the outstanding transaction involved a $1,000,000 lease in Jamaic, Queens.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In view of the outrageous conduct of Tammany Hall, it may seem, on the surface, paradoxical to say the Democratic party offers the way to reform in the coming Mayoralty election. However, brief analysis of current party trends and the fact that Tammany can hardly be considered typical of true democracy indicate that such may well be the eventual outcome.

The twentieth, annual international flower show will open at 2 P.M. today in the Grand Central Palace. Four floors of the building have been given over to the exhibition and were receiving the finishing touches yesterday to convert them into flowering gardens filled with domestic, and many foreign, species of flowers, plants and shrubs.

More than 1,500 representatives of Jewish organizations milled about the entrance to the Hotel Astor last night seeking admittance to a conference called by the American Jewish Congress to formulate plans for a nation-wide expression of indignation against the anti-Semitism of Adolf Hitler.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., March 19. -- An easterly blow carrying hail that stirred the wrath of the waters of Long Island Sound until they leaped over the breakwater off here in angry foam, confronted the Frostbite dinghy sailors who gathered today from Long Island, Connecticut and Westchester for the regatta of the Larchmont Yacht Club.

It begins to look as if European Foreign Offices were becoming "Americanized," in the sense that a change of administration brings changes in the diplomatic service. This has not been the practice on the Continent or in Great Britain. Apparently the resignation of the German Ambassador at Washington was not forced except by the inclinations of Baron TON PRITTWITZ himself.

America has rediscovered herself in the last two weeks and has learned again of the courage and resourcefulness of her people, the Rev. Dr. Ralph W. Sockman declared yesterday morning in his sermon in the Madison Avenue Methodist Church, Madison Avenue and Sixtieth Street, of which he is pastor.

Salvation is a personal thing, to be won or lost by nobody but ourselves, the Rev. Charles Connor said at the 12:15 mass yesterday in the Actors' Chapel of the Roman Catholic Church of St. Malachy, Forty-ninth Street, east of Eighth Avenue.
ALBANY, N.Y., March 19 (AP) -- The Legislature will start tomorrow night on a program which party leaders believe will clear away all their major problems by April 5.

LONDON, Monday, March 20. -- Without exact knowledge of what was arranged in Rome yesterday, British editors are distinctly cautious this morning in discussing Premier Mussolini's project for a four-power conference.

A greatly improved tone is being imparted to the steel industry by the reopening of the banks, the breaking down of the barriers to trade, deflation of government costs, rising commodity prices and freer flow of credit, currency, and checks, according to the weekly report of the magazine Steel.

Sweeping changes in the structure of the New York City government, with the legislative power for the city vested in a Common Council elected by proportional representation, are advocated in a report made public yesterday by the Republican Committee on Charter Revision, of which James Marshall is chairman.

Opening with a rush of buying following the shut-dowa during the banking holiday, most of the commodities leveled off and lost some of their gains near the end of last week. Nearly all, however, showed substantial advances over the close on March 3.

WASHINGTON. March 19. -- President Roosevelt, accompanied by his mother, Mrs. James Roosevelt, and his son James, attended morning services at St. Thomas Episcopal Church, despite the steady downpour of rain which drenched Washington throughout the day. The President spent the rest of the day quietly with members of his family at the White House.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., March 19 -- The witnesses for whom subpoenas will be requested this week by G.W. Chamlee. the Chattanooga lawyer retained by the International Labor Defense to assist Samuel Leibowitz, New York criminal lawyer in the defense of the accused Negroes are, with one exception, colored residents of Jackson County where the crime occurred.

LONDON, March 19. -- The Metropolitan-Vickers Electrical Company, four of whose engineers are under arrest in Moscow, today described as "fantastic" the alleged Soviet charge that the men had willfully damaged the giant turbines at Dnieprostroy Dam.

SOUTH BEND, Ind., March 19 (AP). -- Future plans for the Studebaker Corporation, automobile manufacturing concern, which was placed in friendly receivership yesterday, were discussed in a closed conference today by officers.

PITTSBURGH, March 19. -- The steel trade became still more sanguine last week as to the general business outlook by reason of the vigor and promptness of action in Washington, rather than because of any strikingly favorable developments in the steel market itself.

DOYLESTOWN, Pa., March 19. -- Agriculture is facing better times "with a united people back of President Roosevelt," Charles E. Fox, former District Attorney of Philadelphia, told an audience of a thousand persons today at the commencement exercises of the National Farm School.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 19. -- Colonel Jacob Ruppert's Ruthless Yankees again conquered the Boston Braves at Waterfront Park today in a game which neither the Yankee owner nor his famous holdout witnessed. The world's champions won by 3 to 2 for their third straight victory over Bill McKechnie's athletes and their fifth straight triumph in exhibition play.

Declaring that the religious teachings of patience and docility cannot indefinitely sustain the present loyalty of the working classes, Algernon D. Black, lecturer at the New York Society for Ethical Culture, urged yesterday the necessity for cooperative action by the best minds of all classes toward the building of a "self-critical and self-perfecting society."

Expressing his dissatisfaction with Controller Charles W. Berry's reports on city finances. Alderman Joseph Clark Baldwin announced yesterday that he would introduce two local bills tomorrow designed to furnish the Board of Aldermen more complete information on the city's fiscal status.

The Montreal Maroons blasted the New York Rangers' hopes of finishing in first place in the American division of the National Hockey League by defeating the blue-jerseyed six at Madison Square Garden last night. While a crowd of 7,000 persons looked on, the aggressive Canadian team won by the score of 6 to 3.

The annual design exhibit of the Apartment House Medal Committee of the New York Chapter of the American Institute of Architects opens today at the Architectural League, 115 East Fortieth Street, and will continue through Saturday. Twenty-seven prize-winning apartment houses in this city are represented.

PARIS, March 19. -- Americans arriving here from Germany are expressing more and more concern over the course of events in that country. Neither the full truth about them nor the implications arising therefrom are reaching the outside world, these Americans say, nor can the truth come out except gradually and by stealth, for excellent reasons.

Respectability is one of the deadliest sins in the "average run of Christians," that sort of respectability which urges adherence to the status quo, the Rev. Dr. Harry Emerson Fosdick asserted yesterday morning in his sermon in the Riverside Church, 122d Street and Riverside Drive.

Next Wednesday there will be a hearing at Albany on charter revision. Senator DESMOND has introduced the skeleton charter for New York proposed by Judge SEABURY, providing for departmental reorganization, preferential voting for Mayor and Controller, and a single City Council elected by proportional representation.

The shipment of Canadian grain to the port of New York for export is virtually at a standstill because of the restrictions of the Ottawa agreements act withdrawing preference from grain shipped from one part of the British Empire to another, through a foreign country.

BERLIN, March 17. -- The decrease in political disorders and the further solidifying of the Cabinet's position by its victory at the municipal elections helped in improving financial sentiment this week, and strengthened the Berlin market.

WASHINGTON, March 19. -- Opposition is developing to the administration's farm bill, with present indications that it may encounter a stiff fight in Congress by Democrats from the East and Old Guard Republicans.

WASHINGTON, March 19 (AP) -- Lieutenant James A. Willis Jr. and his two passengers, Major James A. Willis, his father, and Major John A. Parker, were killed late today when the army transport plane in which they were flying crashed near Petersburg, Va.

The final bridge party in the series given by the Alumnae Service Committee of the Smith College Club of New York will be held on Wednesday afternoon at the headquarters of the club, 34 East Fiftieth Street. The proceeds of the series will be used in aiding young women in obtaining an education at Smith.

Declaring that enactment of the Crawford-Coughlin bill, designed to end collection of fees by the clinics of hospitals supported by public contributions, would be against the interests of the many persons who use these clinics, the United Hospital Fund opposed the bill yesterday in a statement issued by Henry J. Fisher, its president.

The fact that the gift of the Juilliard Musical Foundation to the Metropolitan Opera guaranty fund, was $50,000 and no more was reiterated yesterday in a joint statement by Paul D. Cravath, chairman of the Metropolitan Opera Association, and Cornelius N. Bliss of the Metropolitan Opera and Real Estate Company.
A third mystery novel by Barnaby Ross, "The Tragedy of Z," is published today by Viking. The scene is in up-State New York, with political corruption and prison graft mixed with murder.

PALM BEACH, Fla., March 19. -- As a farewell before her departure at midnight for Chicago, where she will be a bridesmaid at the wedding of Miss Florence Smiley Carr and Egar Lewis Marston 2d, on Saturday, Miss Alice Fair McCulloch gave a dinner tonight for members of her the younger set at the home of her parents, Mr. and Mrs. David Hugh McCulloch.

The Pure Oil Company reports for the year ended Dec. 31, last, a net income of $109,316 after all charges and reserves, including minority interest, equal to 36 cents a share on the 300,000 shares of all classes of $100 par preferred stock outstanding.
A hundred members of the Society of American Magicians will attend tonight's performance of "Forsaking All Others." Fred Keating, a magician of some note, is in the cast of the play.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, March 19 (AP). -- A general shake-up occurred among the American Bowling Congress leaders today. Johnny Martino and Andy Piraino of Syracuse, N.Y., took the doubles lead from Bill Moore and Jimmy Delehanty of New York.

Spring begins officially at 8:43 o'clock tonight. The Weather Man says so, and the almanacs corroborate him, although there was nothing in yesterday's weather to bear them out. Snow, sleet, rain and near-freezing temperatures were the order of the day.

The things men do that never get into annual reports were discussed in a sermon yesterday morning by the Rev. Dr. Charles Reynolds Brown, Dean Emeritus of the Yale Divinity School, at the James Memorial Chapel of Union Theological Seminary, 122d Street and Broadway.

LONDON. March 17. -- In the view of this and other European financial markets, the Herculean task to which President Roosevelt has set his hand is progressing well. To London it was obvious enough that Congress and the American public were scared into accepting the bold measures.

A Spring fashion show and entertainment in behalf of the Hygiene and Social Service Committee off the Lenox Hill Neighborhood Association will take place on March 29 and 30 at the River Club. Ohman and Arden, pianists, will play and several stars of the screen have promised to appear.

An appeal for a "deeper spirit of humanity" in the laws regulating immigration into the United States and a direct plea to President Roosevelt to rescind the executive order limiting immigration for the benefit of German Jews who "may wish to seek a haven of refuge from political and religious persecution" were embodied in resolutions adopted yesterday at the twenty-fourth annual meeting of the Jewish.

CINCINNATI, March 19. -- The worst flood since 1913 raged tonight through the Ohio River valley all the way from West Virginia to Indiana, accompanied by seven deaths and property damage as thousands of acres of land were inundated.

The first steps toward distribution of the long-awaited Federal patronage in and around New York City may be taken this week by Democratic National Chairman James A. Farley. The general policy was determined some time ago, but no appointments were definitely decided upon.

"WASHINGTON, March 19. -- Legislatures of seventeen States have completed machinery necessary for setting up conventions to consider repeal of the Eighteenth Amendment, Jouett Shouse. president of the Association Against the Prohibition Amendment, announced today in making public the results of a nation-wide survey just finished by the association.

WASHINGTON, March 19. -- Additional regulations intended to bring about a more uniform functioning on a limited basis of banks not yet reopened under license were issued today by the Treasury Department. Simultaneously it became known that the Federal Reserve board had extended until March 27 the time in which Reserve banks must turn in their lists of gold hoarders.

AMSTERDAM. March 17. -- The general feeling in financial circle shere now is that the American bank crisis was the last serious weak spot in the world-wide business reaction, and that the energetic actions of the new Washington administration ought to Introduce improvement in the business situation everywhere.
WASHINGTON, March 19. -- The votes in the Senate and House by the delegations from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut on important roll-calls last week are given in the appended tabulation:

HELSINGFORS, Finland, March 19. -- The Russians are making determined efforts to solve the alcohol problem, says Everett Colby of New Jersey, who on the initiative of John D. Rockefeller Jr. has studied the liquor conditions in Russia for some time and is now returning home with an elaborate report.

WASHINGTON, March 19. -- The calling of a "continental congress for economic reconstruction," expected by its backers to bring 5,000 delegates to Washington from all parts of the country on May 6 and 7, was announced today by a committee on arrangements for the conference.

VIENNA, March 19: -- Sensational allegations, supported by detailed figures, of a growing concentration of Heimwehr forces in and around Vienna were made by Socialist Democrats last night in questions put to the government.

The Rev. Horace W.B. Donegan, the 31-year-old rector of Christ Protestant Episcopal Church, Baltimore, has accepted the call to the rectorship of St. James's Protestant Episcopal Church, Madison Avenue and Seventy-first Street, and will begin his work here the middle of May.

The Don Cossack Russian Male Chorus, which gave its farewell concert of the season last night in Carnegie Hall, puts on a picturesquc act. From the romantic publicity emphasis on its "men without a country" to the uniforms and military formations calculated to beglamor an audience with a sense of fallen splendors and bravery in exile, it is shrewdly and successfully staged with an eye to drama.

CINCINNATI, March 19 (AP). -- An Indianapolis real estate dealer who killed his estranged wife and dismembered her body slashed himself to death today while struggling with three policemen who had arrested him. He was later identified as Charles D. Evans.

An increase in appeals for assistance from men laid off by other organizations that had been supporting them through made work and food relief was reported yesterday by Walter D. Britt, director of the Emergency Shelter, 261 Greene Street, to Charles L. Lawrence, treasurer of the institution.

HUNTINGTON, W. Va., March 19 (AP). -- The rain-swollen Ohio River tonight routed out scores off Families in riverfront communities below Point Pleasant, W. Va., where It is joined by the Kanawha River.

PHILADELPHIA, March 19.-- The Pennsylvania Symphony Orchestra ended its season tonight with a concert in Scottish Rite Temple, which included the latest orchestra work of its conductor, Dr. Henry Hadley. The audience expressed delight over the composition "Castle Enchanted" overture, which Linton Martin, music critic of The Philadelphia Inquirer, described as "engagingly simple but spontaneous and warmly melodic," and "evidently destined for considerable popularity."

NEW HAVEN, Conn., March 19. -- Existing ideas and theories of the origin and early history of the world's highest mountains are likely to change as a result of geographical, geological and zoological data gathered by the Yale North India Expedition, which was led by Dr. Hellmut de Terra, Research Associate in Geology at the university.

Two hundred and two night students of the New York University School of Commerce, Accounts and Finance have been named to the honor roll, Professor Gerald E. Se-Boyar, chairman of the committee on scholastic standing of that division, announced yesterday.

Bernon S. Prentice of New York, chairman of the general Davis Cup Committee and the selection committee during the administration of Louis J. Carruthers, will serve in a similar capacity again in 1933.

The income of the G.E. Employes Securities Corporation for 1932 was more than $4,400,000 after all expenses, which were 15 per cent less than in 1931. Interest on bonds outstanding and other interest payments were $2,600,000. After payment of all interest and dividends earned surplus was $4,235,000 at the end of the year, against $14,159,000 on Dec. 31, 1931.

GENEVA, March 19. -- Eight thousand veterans of all battlefields of Europe, many blind, crippled and gassed, met here today in an anti-war demonstration that moved spectators to tears. Representing 8,000,000 men who were trying to kill each other fifteen years ago, and speaking for 13,000,000 comrades who had killed each other, they came "to save our children and civilization" from a danger of "a return to barbarism" they saw looming.

TOKYO, Monday, March 20 (AP). -- A Rengo [Japanese] News Agency dispatch from Sifeng Pass today said Major Gen. Heijiro Hattori's brigade of Japanese infantrymen had made a lightning attack south of the great Chinese wall and had occupied Sahochiao, nine miles southwest of the pass.

Michael Pitrik, janitor of a three-story tenement at 308 East Seventy-fifth Street, opened the door to the rain-soaked back yard at about 10 o'clock yesterday morning to get a bucket for a tenant who wanted to mop. As he turned back, he noticed that a rear window of a first-floor apartment was shattered.

MOSCOW, March 19. -- A startling picture of what the United States lost last year in Russian trade, as compared with 1931, is given in a monthly statistical bulletin issued by the Soviet Foreign Trade Commissariat.

Josef Hofmann's recital at Carnegie Hall yesterday afternoon, provided evidence anew that depressions have the least effect on the finest in art. The audience filled the available seats and included many standees, despite the miserable weather.

Increased savings and purchasing power were cited as benefits of national prohibition by Mrs. Ella A. Boole, national president of the Woman's Christian Temperance Union, in an address last night at the Congregational Church of the Pilgrims, Henry and Remsen Streets, Brooklyn.

BRIGHTWATERS, L.I., March 19. -- A unanimous vote of confidence, was extended to Dr. George L. Lawrence, New York State American Legion Commander, and the State Department by the Suffolk County Legion at the dinner dance held here last night in honor of the fourteen Past Commanders of Suffolk.

RAIFORD, Fla., March 19 (AP). -- Giuseppe Zangara, the boasting assassin who killed Mayor Anton J. Cermak of Chicago while attempting to shoot President Franklin D. Roosevelt, will toe put to death in Florida's electric chair at 9 A.M. tomorrow.

Although S.W. Straus Co., Inc., of 565 Fifth Avenue, dealers in real estate mortgage bonds, sold more than $380,000,000 of securities, it has liquid assets of only $29,000, it was disclosed yesterday. The assets were reported in a letter sent to Supreme Court Justice Charles C. Lockwood of Brooklyn by William M. Calder, former United States Senator, and Robert Moses, chairman of the State Council of Parks, in resigning as receivers of the company.

A plan for a central book exhibit here, where all new books and some old ones will be on display and which may result in a kind of book trade centre for the city, is under consideration by a committee of the National Association of Book Publishers, it was revealed yesterday.

It was at the peak of the last night's storm. The window panes rattled, gusts of wind crept into the room. Three men and two women, only survivors of the night's ordeal, leaned forward breathlessly. Their taskmaster, grim and inexorable, pointed a finger.
CHICAGO, March 19 (AP). -- Back in 1891, John R. Thompson, an Illinois farm youth, visited Chicago and decided what this country needed was a good five-cent cup of coffee.

The three hardy perennials in the spheres of college swimming, boxing and wrestling continued to dominate their sports over the past week-end with the same display of power that they had exhibited in unbeaten dual-meet seasons. Yale performed brilliantly in the inter-collegiate aquatic title meet, Syracuse captured the ring crown and Lehigh annexed premier laurels on the mat.
Governors Island and other local army centres probably will be affected by the many changes in army high commands whiche are scheduled in the near future, army officers stationed here believe.

Educators dealing with "slow-progress" children should not overemphasize manual training to the exclusion of academic subjects, Dr. William J. O'Shea, Superintendent of Schools, declared yesterday in a statement which he plans to include in his annual report.

Characterizing the present German situation as "the greatest tragedy in the history of the Jewish people during my lifetime," Rabbi Stephen S. Wise, in his sermon before the Free Synagogue Congregation at Carnegie Hall, Seventh Avenue at Fifty-seventh Street, yesterday morning, declared that "Germany must be restored to sanity and sanctity."

Protestants and Jews here will unite with Roman Catholics to celebrate the opening by Pope Pius of the Holy Door of St. Peter's at Vatican City, inaugurating the special Holy Year the Pontiff has decreed. The chief feature here will be an address by President Roosevelt, broadcast from Washington.

The loan exhibition of paintings by Boldini, arranged under the auspices of Mrs. Chester Dale and held for the benefit of the child welfare committee of the Bellevue Hospital social service, opens today at the Wildenstein Galleries, where it will remain until April 8.

WASHINGTON, March 19. -- The Treasury Department announced tonight that despite the difficulties faced because of the bank holiday the double-barreled offering of about $800,000,000 of certificates of indebtedness made to meet maturities of about $694,000,000 and for other current needs, had been largely oversubscribed, the total of cash and exchange subscriptions reaching $1,831,815,600 after all returns were tabulated.

After more than eight hours of keen competition, Lieutenant Frederick Weber of the New York Athletic Club captured the first metropolitan epee championship ever held last night at the Salle d'Armes Vince, leading the field of twentytwo fencers.

SARASOTA, Fla., March 19. -- Sitting on the terrace in front of the caravanserai in which the Boston Red Sox are quartered in this town, Edward Trowbridge Collins told the tale of how Tom Yawkey came to buy the Red Sox from Bob Quinn and how Coach Eddie Collins of the Athletics became Vice President and General Manager E.T. Collins of the Boston American League Club.

NEW ORLEANS, March 19. -- While the cotton market was closed here in the first half of last week, the improvement in the financial situation, the progress made by Congress with measures intended to balance the budget and the belief that other constructive legislation soon would follow infused optimism into trade circles and created a belief that when trading was resumed, prices would be considerably higher than when business was suspended.

WASHINGTON, March 19. -- The United States Daily, which interrupted publication on March 6, will resume publication tomorrow under the same title, but as a weekly instead of a daily, presenting a news record of legislative, executive and judicial branches of the Federal and State governments.

PARIS, March 17. -- The absence of any sharp decline In the dollar on the international exchange market, when dealings In that market were reopened on Monday, was in accordance with expectations here. The rate, however, after rising sharply at the beginning of the week, with seeming indication that the rise would continue, reactedand remained for two days below the normal gold point.

PRINCETON, N.J., March 19. -- Nineteen Princeton sports teams compiled a record of 93 victories against 50 defeats during the Winter season which has just been completed, according to statistics announced today. Eight varsity teams won 58 out of 85 contests.

CHICAGO, March 19. -- The Detroit Red Wings closed their regular National Hockey League season today with a 4-2 victory over the injury-ridden Chicago Black Hawks to assure themselves of no worse than a tie for first place in the American division.
MIAMI, Fla., March 19 (AP). -- Giuseppe Zangara avowed that his hatred for capitalists and kings led him to attempt the life of Franklin D. Roosevelt.

Because of financial and political conditions, no real progress toward unification of rapid transit lines will be made this year, it was predicted yesterday by representatives of various groups, official and otherwise, that have wrestled with the problem for more than a decade.
AGUA CALIENTE, Mexico, March 19. -- Midshipman, a dark horse in the Agua Caliente Derby, beat Bamboula, the favorite, by two lengths to take the $2,000 added 3-year-old classic today.

The City Affairs Committee addressed a letter to Mayor O'Brien yesterday urging that he appoint a new independent citizens' committee of five members, representing Democrats, Republicans, Socialist and Communists, in place of the fifteen members of the Emergency Work and Relief Administration who have resigned.

The bank loans of the Columbia Gas and Electric Corporation have been reduced to $15,500,000, with cash on hand amounting to $10,000,000, according to a statement accompanying the annual report for 1932, mailed to stockholders yesterday. At Dec. 31 last, bank loans were $19,500,000, against $43,500,000 at the end of 1931.

Publication of more informative financial reports at more frequent intervals by the national. State and local governments so that the citizens may be kept accurately informed of the state of public finance was urged last night by the New York State Society of Certified Public Accountants, meeting at the Waldorf-Astoria.

Some of the outstanding members of the Newspaper Club of New York, Inc., 507 Fifth Avenue, have resigned within the last week in protest against methods used to dispose of $15 tickets to the club's annual dinner, show and dance to be held at the Hotel Astor on April 5.
COMMERCIAL PAPER. Yesterday..3 1/2 per cent for the beat names. Friday......4 per cent for the best names. The quotations are for three-four months' paper.
The Earl and Countess of Leven and Meiville are among the passengers arriving tonight from Southampton and Cherbourg on the White Star liner Majestic. Others on the ship are:

LONDON, March 20. -- There were cheers in the House of Commons today when Captain Anthony Eden, Under-Secretary for Foreign Affairs, made the expected announcement that the British Government had halted negotiations with the Soviet Government for a new trade treaty because of the arrests of British engineers in Russia.

VIENNA, March 20. -- A portion at least of the $20,000,000 which the Austrian Government has voted for the reorganization of its other banks, somewhat on the lines of the Creditanstalt reorganization, will be taken, according to reports tonight from schillings paid to the National Bank under the transfer moratorium on account of Austria's foreign debts.

A model of the design made by the New York Chapter of the American Society of Landscape Architects for the beautification of the lower reservoir site in Central Park is a feature of the tenth annual exhibition of the chapter, open to invited guests this afternoon and to the public tomorrow at the Grand Central Art Galleries. The exhibit will continue until April 1.
RAIFORD, Fla., March 20 (AP). -- The report of the physicians who performed an autopsy on the body of Joseph Zangara after his execution here today read in part:

WASHINGTON, March 20. -- Relatively few National Guardsmen, according to the War Department, are affected by the provision of the new army appropriation act, that they must give up their National Guard pay or their Federal compensation or retirement pay.

Former Governor Alfred E. Smith, addressing the members of the Ladies Auxiliary of St. Vincent's Hospital yesterday, stressed the need for redoubled effort in private charity and gave reasons why the city, State and Federal Governments cannot assume the entire burden of relief.

Urban and Seasonal. Spring comes to the city as well as to the suburbs and the open land. It testifies to our lingering anti-urban prejudices that even when a city man hails the vernal equinox he does it in the old rural vocabulary -- robins on the lawn and crows cawing in the bare branches, and the smell of earth fresh from under its cover of snow.

While the salt-water fishermen are getting things in shape for a general attack this week-end, fresh-water anglers in this State are preparing for the opening of the trout season on April 1 -- and in mass formation, apparently. Opening day of the trout season is a bit different from any other in the year.

ALBAHY, March 20. -- The erection of a casino with theatre and concert facilities, reading and writing rooms, tea rooms and other conveniences, is one of the outstanding recommendations made by the Saratoga Springs Commission in its annual report which was handed down tonight in the Senate and Assembly.

LONDON, March 20 (AP). -- A tall, good-looking Scottish youth," a Lieutenant in the aristocratic Sea-forth Highlanders, went on trial today before a court-martial composed of his brother officers on ten charges involving the sale of military secrets.

That an iron censorship is now in force in Germany, worse than anything known since wartime, is admitted officially at Berlin. Many newspapers have been suppressed outright. Others are published only under the strictest surveillance.

An action to restrain the City of New York from ratifying an agreement with the Port Authority making the new $16,000,000 inland terminal building, Eighth Avenue and Sixteenth Street, virtually tax exempt, was started in Brooklyn yesterday.

The silver medal of the Garden Club of America was awarded to Mrs. Henry H. Rennell and Mrs. Edward M. Collie Jr. of the Fairfield (Conn.) Garden Club for their demonstration dooryard planting of a Winter garden in the competition staged by this organization in conjunction with the annual international flower show.

Dr. William Schroeder Jr., chairman of the Sanitary Commission, and Joseph P. McKay, head of the Bureau of Weights and Measures faced loss of their positions yesterday as Mayor O'Brien moved for the reorganization of both agencies.
CLEARWATER, Fla., March 20. -- The Yankees played a hilarious five-inning tie game today with Colonel Ruppert's Newark Bears.

WASHINGTON, March 20. -- As June 15 approaches, with separate debt discussions with other nations not yet begun or definitely scheduled by the administration, a plan to avert the prospects and consequences of British and French default on that date is taking definite form in the inner councils of the United States Government.

Demountable lips, demountable eyelashes, demountable noses, demountable fingernails, ear tacks, muscle oil, "artificial eye sparkle and tiny pictures and letters for fingernail decoration were the talk of the four-day convention and exhibition of the International Beauty Shop Owners, which opened yesterday at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

ALBANY, March 21. -- Irwin Steingut, minority leader, in the Assembly today offered an amendment to the Mandelbaum Senate bill proposing advancement of the date for collection of New York City taxes which indicated a change in the city administration financing policy.

WASHINGTON, March 20. -- Senator Wagner introduced three unemployment relief measures in the Senate today. Two provide for the national coordination of employment exchanges and for tax rebates as an inducement to industry to establish unemployment wage trusts.

A jury was chosen in an hour yesterday in Judge Nott's part of General Sessions to try Louis H. Willard, a Bronx business man, on a perjury indictment based on Willard's testimony last April before the Hofstadter Legislative Investigating Committee, when he attacked the official conduct of William J. Flynn, Bronx Commissioner of Public Works.

Having exhausted its enthusiasm in the four days of unrestricted trading last week, the share market gave its attention yesterday to the perfunctory business which came into the commission houses. Transactions on the Stock Exchange were light and open market values fluctuated within the bounds set by a speculative element that was mainly concerned with the preservation of profits already written up.

PALM BEACH, Fla., March 20. -- In honor of their house guests, the Duchess of Northumberland and her daughters, Lady Elizabeth Ivy Percy and Lady Diana Evelyn Percy, who arrived late today from Jamaica, Joseph E. Widener and Mr. and Mrs. Peter A.B. Widener 2d gave a dinner tonight at their residence on the Ocean Boulevard.

John Auney of 333 Fifty-fourth Street, Brooklyn, fireman on the steamer Observation, testified yesterday that it was impossible for dynamite to have caused the explosion which wrecked the steamer and killed seventy-two men last Sept. 9.
NORTHAMPTON, Mass., March 20. -- The election of thirty-four seniors and four juniors to the Smith College chapter of Phi Beta Kappa was announced today.

Blocked in their effort to raise immediate cash by advancing the date of tax collections, Mayor O'Brien and Controller Charles W. Berry conferred yesterday with representatives of the city's bankers on the possibility of new loans to meet obligations of $144,000,000 which fall due on April 26.

SPOKANE, Wash., March 20 (AP). -- Guy H. Martin, who served as United States District Judge for the Panama Canal Zone from 1924 until 1929, died after an operation at a hospital here today. He was 68 years old.

Money costs were slashed in all sections of the market, an aftermath of improved banking conditions which has permitted a freer flow of offerings. Stock Exchange call loans dropped to 3 per cent at midday, after renewing at 3 1/2. Street trades were arranged at 3@ 2 1/2 and Federal funds 3 1/4 @ 2 1/2.

ROME, March 20. -- Prime Minister MacDonald of Great Britain revealed today, before departing for Paris, that the Mussolini peace plan will not be limited to the great powers of Europe, but will include all nations of Western Europe and perhaps Russia. He said the United States would be informed of all steps.

LOS ANGELES, March 20. -- Feeling eminently satisfied with the surprising turn events have taken during the past few days. Manager Bill Terry utilized today's open date in the exhibition schedule by sending his Giant squad through a long drill that lasted from 11 o'clock in the morning until darkness closed over Wrigley Field.

An immediate investigation into the business activities of the Straus Securities Company, Inc., 60 Wall Street, dealer in securities of real estate, municipalities, public utilities, industrial companies and banks, was ordered yesterday afternoon by John J. Bennett Jr., State Attorney General.

After a hard-fought battle, Leonard S. Green of the Fraternity Club, who was unranked in the 1932 national amateur list, accounted for the outstanding victory in the opening round of the world's open squash tennis championship last night.

TOKYO, March 20. -- Before the Japanese Government's study of the disarmament plan of Prime Minister MacDonald began, the Navy Office today published its objections by informing the Japanese newspapers of the criticisms it had telegraphed to the Japanese delegation to the Geneva disarmament conference as "material for reference."

In 1931 the United States sold goods In Russia valued at $103,000,000. Last year our exports to that country amounted to only $12,500,000. This represents a loss of 88 per cent. During the same period Germany's sales to Russia declined by merely 21 per cent and England's actually increased bey 29 per cent.

CAIRO, Egypt, March 20. -- That the European centre for the manufacture of narcotics destined for the illicit trade has now shifted from Istanbul to Sofia, Bulgaria, is asserted in the fourth annual report of T.W. Russell Pasha, director general of the Narcotics Intelligence Bureau of Egypt and commandant of the Cairo police.

WASHINGTON, March 20. -- Major S. Willard Saxton, 103-year-old Civil War veteran, retired government employe and probably the oldest citizen of the District of Columbia, died yesterday at his home, 1,347 Harvard Street, N.W.

Prices for future commodity contracts moved irregularly lower in yesterday's trading here. Mostly, the declines were regarded as a further settling down of the price level to eliminate what is now considered the abnormal bulge last week.

DALLAS, March 20. -- Many prominent medical and surgical authorities of two continents were gathering in Dallas today for the opening of the congress of the Pan-American Medical Association, the first session of which will be held at Southern Methodist University tomorrow night.

Reflecting the return of currency to banks and a growing confidence throughout the country that the banking situation is rapidly getting back to normal, rates in all departments of the money market were further relaxed yesterday. At the call money post on the Stock Exchange the renewal rate at the opening was 3 1/2 per cent and at midday the 3 per cent rate was posted, and there the market remained through to the close.

The papers in the suit of Claudian B. Northrup, Washington attorney, against Francis I. du Pont for legal services will be withdrawn from the County Clerk's office today on a court order as a result of an agreement between Davis, Polk, Wardwell, Gardiner Reed, counsel for the plaintiff, and Caruthers Ewing, attorney for the defendant, it was said yesterday.

LONDON, March 20. -- A charge that he "sold his country for the sake of u50 or more" was hurled at Lieutenant Norman Baillie-Stewart, the mysterious "prisoner in the Tower of London," when his courtmartial for alleged violation of the official secrets act opened today.

CLARKSVTLLE, Tenn., March 20 (AP). -- After listening to three hours of argument. Criminal Court Judge John T. Cunningham late today granted Colonel Luke Lea and Luke Lea Jr., bail in $15,000 each, pending a hearing of the habeas corpus writ by which they are resisting removal to North Carolina.

Larry Schuk of the Lenox Hill A. A. scored two first-round knockouts in the semi-monthly amateur boxing show at the New York A.C. last night before about 500 spectators. Competing in the 165-pound class. Schuk disposed of Lawrence Fishback in 1:06 of a semi-final bout, and then went on to knock out Edward Flynn in fifty-six seconds of the final.

Sweeping changes in the United States Treasury financing calculated to eliminate the great dependence on banks entailed by an unwieldy amount of short-term debt and to enlist the support of private investors, large and small, may be adopted at once by the Roosevelt administration, according to reports in financial circles yesterday.

Shipping interests registered their opposition yesterday to the proposed incorporation of a separate organization of Hudson River pilots for the handling of ships entering and leaving the harbor to and from Albany which is proposed by bills now being considered by the judiciary committee of the State Senate and Assembly.

MUNICH, March 20. -- Preparations for an attempt on Chancellor Adolf Hitler's life by Communists were discovered this morning in time to prevent its execution, according to an announcement by Chief of Police Himmler.

WICHITA, Kan., March 20 (AP). -- The Cleveland (Tenn.) contenders advanced to the second round of the women's national A.A.U. basketball tournament by defeating the Chilocco, Okla., Indians in the first round tonight, 28 to 26.

NEWARK. N.J., March 20. -- The Studebaker Corporation and a subsidiary, the Studebaker Sales Corporation of America, were directed today by Alfred A. Stein, Vice Chancellor, to show cause on March 28 why receivers should not be appointed for them and to show cause on Wednesday why a master should not be chosen to investigate their affairs.

WASHINGTON, March 20. -- The United States plans to maintain a passive attitude for the present toward the British disarmament plan, which was submitted last week at Geneva, and the subsequent proposal of Premier Mussolini of Italy for a four-power European pact to preserve and control peace in Europe until further developments warrant some expression of views.

If Mr. PURDY'S letter had been known when the fifteen members of the Emergency Work and Relief Administration resigned, it would have quieted suspicions. It now appears that the resignation was in harmony with a recommen- dation of the body as a whole, and with the advice of the Temporary Emergency Relief Administration of the State looking toward a "further unification" of the work relief and the home relief.

Plans for its remaining schedule of four plays to be produced this season were announced yesterday by the Stage Society, which this season has inaugurated a policy of producing untitled plays, without naming their authors, before subscription audiences only.

WASHINGTON, March 20. -- With the signing by the President today of the economy bill, the second major administration proposal passed by Congress, preparations were made for the issuance of Executive orders to carry into effect the reductions authorized.

Dr. Howard J. Savage, secretary of the Carnegie Foundation for the Advancement of Teaching and author of the foundation's famous Bulletin No. 23, published in 1929, outlines five ways in which conditions may influence college athletics in an article appearing in the current issue of Education Sun of the School of Education of New York University, distributed yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 20 (AP). -- John E. Erickson of Montana today succeeded to the Senate seat held for twenty years by Thomas J. Walsh as the Elections Committee made plans for considering his right to the place.
"Far Away Horses," a comedy by Michael Birmingham and Gilbert Emery, will open this evening at the Martin Beck Theatre. Leona Hogarth and Marion Barney are included in the cast.
FORT MYERS, Fla., March 20. -- The tall, thin gentleman with the high, thin voice, Mr. Cornelius McGillicuddy, sat forward in his chair and said:

PARIS, March 20. -- What has been discussed between Prime Minister MacDonald and Premier Mussolini in Rome amounts in effect to how the basis of the European regime of which France has been the self-appointed guardian for fourteen years can best be changed.

The "depression busters" quartet, which left New York on Groundhog Day for a tour of the South to dispel gloom, announced yesterday on its return that it had "opened the banks, got beer back, and now we are going to start the wheels of industry and get the birds out of their nests in the stacks of the Mahoning Valley."

BUENOS AIRES, March 20. -- The Paraguayan War Office admitted today that the Paraguayan army was retreating from Kilometre Seven (Camp Jordan), near Fort Saavedra, where they have been stubbornly holding the Bolivians at bay since December.

PUTNEY-ON-THAMES, England, March 20. -- The Cambridge crew, practicing for the classic boat race with Oxford on April 1, today broke the record for the distance from Hammersmith to Putney Bridge, part of the boat race course.

BERLIN, March 20. -- Charging that Professor Albert Einstein had a huge quantity of arms and ammunition stored in his secluded home in Caputh, the National Socialists sent Brown Shirt men and policemen to search it today, but the nearest thing to arms they found was a bread knife.

MIAMI, Fla., March 20. -- Judge Schilling, 8-year-old gelding by Hand Grenade from Runnura, made the even-money favorite in the La Gores Purse, feature at Tropical Park today, won by a length and a half from Caerleon. Starboard Light was third in the field of nine.

SANFORD BATES is to remain head of the Prison Bureau in the Department of Justice. In announcing the reappointment of Mr. BATES, a hold-over from the Hoover Administration, Attorney General CUMMINGS commended his work in expanding Federal prisons and putting into effect new methods for the handling of prisoners.

Cumberland, Md. A new issue of $225,000 city of Cumberland (Md.) water bonds, due on March 15, 1963, was awarded yesterday to Phelps, Fenn Co. on their bid of 100.57 for the bonds as 4 1/2s. The issue will be offered today at prices to net 4.25 per cent.

Frederick J.H. Kracke, Brooklyn Republican leader, announced yesterday that he had forwarded his resignation as Federal Appraiser of the Port of New York to President Roosevelt. He promised to retain the place, he said, until his Democratic successor was named.

Chesapeake Ohio. For the fifth consecutive month the Chesapeake Ohio Railway reported an increase in net operating income in February. Gross revenues in February were within $56,610 of those in February, 1932. For the two months net income was $3,266,514, or 42 cents a share on the $25 par common stock, against $2,667,099, or 34 cents a share, in the same period last year.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, March 20. -- Harold H. Burton, former acting Mayor and former law director of Cleveland, was elected late today president of the Guardian Trust Company and chairman of a committee of six men which will direct the reorganization of the bank.

PARIS, March 20. -- Everything is being done by the French Cabinet to avoid introducing into the debt discussions any political issue. As has been indicated in recent dispatches, it is felt that the only chance of getting the Chamber to revise its decision of last December not to pay the United States is to leave it free from governmental and so political influence.

LONDON, March 20. -- In certain liberal papers, with which on many points I agree, I notice there is a vivid description of the violent destruction of all liberal ideas by the new school of Prussianism in Germany; accompanied by the curious comment that this only proves how unkind we British have been to Prussian Germany.

NEW YORK. Miss Helen Greeff will give a dinner tonight at the St. Regis for Miss Alice de Peyster and James Todd, who will be married next Monday. Mr. and Mrs. J. Randall Creel will give a dinner Thursday for Miss de Peyster and her fiance at the Central Park Casino.
PHILADELPHIA, March 20. -- Bill Carr, Olympic champion and 400meter world record holder, admitted today that his running days were over.

PHILADELPHIA, March 20. -- Warrants were issued today for the arrest of three officers of the defunct Franklin Trust Company, one of the largest banks to close in this city since the start of the depression. It had deposits of $19,664,571 when it was taken over on Oct. 5, 1931.

A change in banking regulations to permit national banks to operate branches throughout the Federal Reserve District in which the national bank is located is favored by a majority of members of the economic credit council of the National Association of Credit Men, according to a survey just completed by Henry H. Heimann, executive manager of the credit men's group.

ALBANY, March 20. -- Three bills by Assemblyman Brownell, Republican, of New York City, designed to curb election frauds in the city, were advanced to the order of final passage, in the Assembly tonight over the vigorous protest of the Democrats.

In the slowest trading of the year, bond prices declined on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday except in the foreign group, which was stronger. United States Government issues declined, the Treasury 4 1/4s of 1947-1952 and Treasury 3 3/8s of 1940-1943 showing the widest losses.

WASHINGTON, March 20. -- The Roosevelt farm relief measure, submitted to Congress Thursday, was reported favorably by the House Agriculture Committee today and will be brought up in the House tomorrow under what Republicans call one of the most drastic rules ever attempted for an important legislative bill.
The closing date for entries for the intercollegiate golf championship to be held at the Country Club of Buffalo, Williamsville, N.Y., June 26 to July 1, was announced yesterday as June 15.
LONDON, March 20. -- Admiral Sir Martyn Jerram, commander of the Second Battle Squadron of the Grand Fleet, which he led into action at Jutland, died at Alverstoke at the age of 74.

BERLIN, March 20. -- The Boerse again was bullish today. The outstanding feature was continuance of the newly developed demand for shipping stocks, all of which rose. Hamburg-American and North German Lloyd gained 3 points each, thereby bettering quotations almost 50 per cent in the last two days.

CHICAGO, March 20. -- Persistent selling of May wheat by houses that usually act for the Federal Farm Board was under way again today on the Board of Trade here and prevented any tendency of prices to advance. Wheat appeared available in amounts to suit buyers, but when the near-by future dipped below 52 cents a bushel the pressure was small.

Sales were brisk yesterday, despite the unfavorable weather, for shopping at the "Little Hat Bar," conducted by young matrons and debutantes at the Jay Thorpe establishment in West Fifty-seventh Street in the interest of the Child Adoption League, of which Mrs. Charles Dana Gibson is chairman.

After Count Leo Tolstoy died, a fugitive from his wife and home, in a railway station early one morning in November, 1910, his widow carefully scratched out of his diaries everything that he had written about her, although he had been scrupulously careful not to write harshly.

WASHINGTON, March 20. -- The Steagall amendment to the emergency banking law to enable State non-member banks and trust companies to apply for loans directly to the Federal Reserve Banks, instead of through member banks, was passed today by the House in one of its noisiest sessions.

RAIFORD, Fla., March 20. -- Joseph Zangara paid with his life in the electric chair here today for the slaying of Mayor Anton J. Cermak of Chicago, shot at Miami on Feb. 15 when the assassin made an attempt on the life of Franklin D. Roosevelt, then President-elect.

A group of veteran members of New York Typographical Union No. 6 have formed a non-political committee known as "Minute Men of No. 6," to combat the manoeuvres of Communists seeking to influence the action of union members, it was announced yesterday.

RIVERHEAD, L.I., March 20. -- Cash bequests to relatives and friends totaling about $30.000 were provided in the will of Mrs. Ethel Hunt Tyng, artist and art patron of New York and Southampton, L.I., filed for probate today. The estate was valued at more than $40.000.

MIAMI, Fla., March 20. -- Calisthenics were dispensed with as a prelude to today's short but brisk workout of the Dodgers at Miami Field, preparatory to meeting their second major league opponents, the St. Louis Browns, tomorrow.

Evidence by three well-known authorities on psychic research to prove that the "ectoplasmic fingerprints" of "Walter," declared by "Margery," Boston medium, to have been made at spiritualistic seances by her dead brother, are actually the fingerprints of a living man, is presented in a bulletin by the Boston Society for Psychic Research, edited by Dr. Walter Franklin Prince, recognized leader in the field.
With the bill for beer of 3.2 alcoholic content regarded as certain to be sent to President Roosevelt today for his signature, reports to The Associated Press from the State capitals showed:

LONDON, March 20. -- Official London was as puzzled today by Ramsay MacDonald's statements to the press this morning before leaving Rome as it was startled yesterday by news that the Britis Prime Minister had associated himself with Premier Mussolini's plan for a four-power pact.

WASHINGTON, March 20 (AP). -- Cotton production for 1932, as shown today by the Census Bureau's ginning report, was 12,703,208 running bales, counting round bales as half bales, or 12,994,430 equivalent 500-pound bales, compared with 16,628,874 and 17,095,594 for 1931 and 13,755,518 and 13,931,597 for 1930.

CINCINNATI, March 20 (AP). -- The second flood crest within a week rolled down the broad Ohio River Valley tonight, pouring yellow water into more than a score of towns and cities and over many thousand acres of lowlands in four States.

It is a duty of organized Christianity to take up the fight against anti-Semitism in Germany, the Rev. Dr. S. Parkes Cadman, former president of the Federal Council of Churches of Christ in America, told more than 600 women at the annual luncheon of the New York Chapter of Hadassah, women's Zionist Organization, at the Waldorf-Astoria yesterday.

The recital given by Robert O'Connor, pianist, last night in the Town Hall was an uneven exhibition, but it betokened an interpreter of poetic sensibility. Mr. O'Connor particularly impressed this on his listeners when he played the music of Schubert.

The Stuyvesant High School basketball team, which previously had clinched the group championship, subdued Textile, 18 -- 16, at Stuyvesant, and Seward Park vanquished Haaren, 19 -- 15, at Seward, as the teams brought their Lower Manhattan -- Richmond Division P.S. A.L. campaigns to an end yesterday.

After almost a solid hour of grueling wrestling, during which he was subjected to many punishing headlocks, Jim Browning of Verona, Mo., successfully defended his world's heavyweight championship by defeating the veteran Ed (Strangler) Lewis at Madison Square Garden last night.

With important farm legislation under discussion in Congress, foreign and domestic cotton markets and little more than mark time yesterday. Uncertainty over the bill that would levy an excise tax of several cents a pound on users of raw cotton restricted new business and held fluctuations to less than 10 points.

WASHINGTON, March 20. -- Mrs. Roosevelt, Mrs. Garner, Miss Frances Perking, Secretary of Labor, other women of administrative circles, and additional honor guests, including women distinguished in art and letters, attended tonight the annual dinner and stunt party of the Women's National Press Club, and joined in the fun at their own expense occasioned by the songs and skits in which they were satirized good-naturedly by newspaper women of the capital.

NEW ORLEANS, March 20 (AP) -- T.H. Lynch's Chat Eagle won his second race in as many afternoons in the Fair Grounds feature today, defeating J. Racklcos's Sand Boot by two lengths. Dunair, the favorite, was a tiring third. Chat Eagle scored by a half length yesterday.
To the Editor of The New York Times: In the Interest of historical accuracy the article on the bicentenary of Josiah Spode, printed in THE TIMES recently, requires some correction.
WASHINGTON, March 20. -- Income tax collections for seventeen days of March amounted to $98,176,965, which was $2,135,871 short of the figure for the same period of last year.

Four police lieutenants and seven sergeants formerly attached to the Miller Avenue precinct in Brooklyn, were placed on trial in Police Headquarters in that borough yesterday on charges that assignments, of two patrolmen were entered incorrectly in the record book of the precinct.

WHITE PLAINS, N.T., Mach 20. -- The meeting of the Westchester Board of Supervisors was opened this afternoon with a request by telephone from Governor Lehman that It go on record as favoring the issuance of certificates of indebtedness for work-relief purposes pending an improvement in the condition of the bond market.
Prizes totaling more than $3,000, awarded to artists at the 108th annual exhibition of the National Academy of Design, were announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 20. -- The navy will support the view that naval construction should be considered with other public works included in any unemployment relief program Congress may vote at this session, Secretary Swanson indicated today.

Declaring that missionaries in the foreign field were criticized "with the superiority complex of modern humanists," the Association for the Re-Emphasis of New Testament Missions, at a mass meeting last night in Calvary Baptist Church, 123 West Fifty-seventh Street, applauded a declaration adopted by the executive committee containing twelve protests against the recent report, "Rethinking Missions," of the appraisal commission of the Laymen's Foreign Mission Inquiry.

CHICAGO, March 20. -- For the second successive Summer there will be no grand opera at Ravinia, Ill. Louis Eckstein, chief sponsor and backer of the venture, explained today that the cost of the undertaking was greater than could be met at present and that there was no chance of raising a guarantee fund to meet inevitable losses. His statement follows:

BERLIN, March 20. -- It was announced tonight, on the eve of the convocation of the new Reichstag, that the Hitler government would ask it for dictatorial powers lasting until April 1, 1937, or until the replacement of the present Legislature by another.

George Z. Medalie, United States Attorney, began an examination yesterday of several volumes of records from the National City Bank and the National City Company, its securities affiliate, to determine if Charles E. Mitchell, who resigned recently as chairman of both companies, had illegally evaded payment of an income tax in 1929.

WASHINGTON, March 20. -- States and their instrumentalities possess no constitutional authority to import foreign goods duty free, the Supreme Court held today in ruling on an appeal brought by the University of Illinois.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., March 20. -- Next Winter's varsity basketball team at Harvard will be captained by Joseph Francis Ferriter, '34, of Brattleboro, Vt. He was elected today at a meeting of the varsity squad to succeed Winifield A. Huppuch of Glens Falls, N.Y.

OGDEN, Utah, March 20. -- Utah Republicans, headed toy former Senator Reed Smoot and J. Reuben Clark Jr., who resigned recently as Ambassador to Mexico, met former President Hoover here today and cheered him on his homeward way to Palo Alto, Cal.

WASHINGTON, March 20. -- Hugh R. Wilson, Minister to Switzerland, will represent the United States on the advisory committee of the League of Nations in the Leticia controversy between Peru and Colombia, exactly as he is serving with the League's other advisory committee in regard to the Far East.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., March 20. -- Earl Harold Nikkel of Joes, Col., tonight wag elected captain of the Yale basketball team for next season. His election, announced as unanimous, took place at the annual dinner.

BOSTON, March 20 (AP) -- The Post says that Professor Kenneth Ballard Murdock, 37-year-old dean of the faculty of arts and sciences at Harvard University, is the choice of the Harvard Corporation to succeed Dr. Abbott Lawrence Lowell as president.

ALBANY, March 20. -- Governor Lehman was assured by the legislative leaders of his own party today that every Democratic vote in the Senate and Assembly would be cast in support of any measure recommended by him for the control of the manufacture and sale of beer in this State.

The annual flower show, harbinger of Spring in the metropolitan area, opened yesterday in the Grand Central Palace. Long before the doors were opened to the public hundreds of horticultural enthusiasts waited in the rain for a chance to view the exhibition of thousands of Spring blooms and plants that had transformed the exhibition halls into a countryside.

WASHINGTON, March 20. -- The efforts of John Factor, or "Jake the Barber," to escape extradition to England will be reviewed by the Supreme Court April 17, according to a brief order in which the court answered Factor's petition for a writ of certiorari today.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., March 20. -- Commerce of Yonkers defeated Theodore Roosevelt High, also of Yonkers, 25 to 24, in the Class A final of the Westchester invitation interscholastic basketball tournament at the County Centre tonight.
TIENTSIN, March 20. -- The question of an early Japanese invasion of North China, which seemed a practical certainty ten days ago, is becoming more doubtful.

LONG BRANCH, N.J., March 20. -- Matt Byrnes, who witnessed the rise and decline of New Jersey horse racing and who remained a prominent turf follower for more than half a century, died at the Monmouth Memorial Hospital here last night at the age of 80.

WASHINGTON, March 20 (AP). -- Emphatic notice was given tonight by Mrs. Evalyn Walsh McLean, estranged wife of Edward B. McLean, former publisher of The Washington Post, that she would "oppose to the utmost" any attempt to sell the newspaper outside her family.

Willard K. Rice of the Harvard Club, a player of Class A rank in squash tennis, gained the quarter-final round of the Class C. championship of the Metropolitan Squash Racquets Association last night on the courts of the Downtown Athletic Club, 18 West Street.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Mr. Matsuoka is coming to Ameriica. He prefaces his visit, according to THE TIMES, with the state meat that the American people "fall for appeals to your emotions; this is what they have done regarding China."
LIMA, Peru, March 20. -- Peruvian troops halted a Colombian advance in the Leticia area Friday, according to a government dispatch published here today.

A strict boycott against German merchandise to serve as protest against Nazi anti-Semitism was urged last night by former Representative William W. Cohen at a meeting of the executive advisory committee of the Jewish War Veterans of the United States at the Hotel Knickerbocker.

In the pamphlet report of the National Dairy Products Corporation, Thomas H. McInnerney, president, announces that the company's policy of writing off depreciation was continued in 1932. Charges for repairs, maintenance and depreciation amounted to $19,403,849, he says.

Six Manhattan properties, plus an equal number in the Bronx, were bid in by plaintiffs in foreclosure actions yesterday. One Manhattan parcel scheduled for auction will be put up again later this month.

CHICAGO, March 20 (AP). -- Gregory Barnhurst, 60 years old, engineering expert on cement construction projects, died here yesterday of heart disease. He was employed by the Babcock Witaox Company here. The widow and three children survive.

BERLIN, March 20. -- The German Government regards the Mussolini-MacDonald conference as an important step toward a more just and lasting peace in Europe. The proposals of the Italian Premier, of which the German Ambassador at Rome has been informed, will be received appreciatively here, it is stated in political quarters.

With the return of beer imminent, officials of three excursion steamboat companies are making a sudden rush to obtain exclusive privileges for docking boats this Summer at Coney Island's Steeplechase Pier in the expectation that thousands of passengers will revive an Old custom of making round trips to the resort and slaking their thirst at the ships' bars the while they enjoy the sea air.

With marked promptness the State Department has accepted the invitation of the League of Nations to act with its advisory committee in the matter of the boundary dispute between Peru and Colombia. The League had already decided against the contention of Peru, and held that the strip of territory involved belongs to Colombia.

S. Howard Cohen, president of the Board of Elections, was a prosecution, witness yesterday at the start of the trial of four election inspectors before Justice McNamee and a jury in the Criminal Branch of the Supreme Court. The inspectors are charged with frauds and irregularities last election day in the polling place at 247 East Broadway, on the lower east side.

Spring arrived on schedule at 8:43 last night; but It was Spring without poesy, a dismal Spring clad in Winter raiment and no ray of sun-shine heralded its coming. Throughout most of the day a chill rain pelted the city and leaden clouds shrouded the peaks of its skyscrapers.
WASHINGTON, March 20 (AP). -- Orders by the President himself are required to make most of the reductions under the economy measure which became law today.

WASHINGTON, March 20. -- After a personal inspection of the alley dwellings of the capital where 12,000 Negroes and 1,000 whites live in company with Mrs. Archibald Hopkins, who is interested in a bill pending in Congress for several years for the improvement of housing conditions, Mrs. Roosevelt said today:

James Mitchell Hoyt, senior partner in the former Stock Exchange house of Prince Whitely, died yesterday morning at the Park Central Hotel, where he had been ill for several months with abdominal complications. Mr. Hoyt was 47 years old March 8.
WASHINGTON, March 20 (AP) -- Cash quickly for the farmer if President Roosevelt's farm relief program passes is planned by the Department of Agriculture.

WASHINGTON, March 20. -- The return of the 4 per cent beer as known before prohibition (3.2 per cent by weight) and wine of the same alcoholic content by early next month seemed assured today when the Senate by a vote of 43 to 36 adopted the conference report on the Cullen bill.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., March 20. -- Of 133 events contested by Harvard's varsity, junior varsity and freshman Winter sport teams, the Crimson emerged triumphant in eighty-seven, lost forty-four and tied twice.

While the tone of the security markets yesterday was firm, Wall Street was interested in the scattered effort to bring about a spontaneous movement in stocks. On the whole, the results were negative; it turned out in the late dealings that earlier gains were canceled.
WASHINGTON, March 20. -- The Senate vote in detail on the beer bill today was as follows:

BERN, Switzerland, March 20. -- Immediately before I left America, and shortly before the German elections, I told my anxious friends abroad that any idea of pogroms in Germany was unthinkable. President von Hindenburg's name and the solid foundations of German culture were pledges against such occurrences.

MONTGOMERY Ala., March 20. -- G.W. Chamlee, one of the attorneys retained by the International labor Defense to defend at their second trial the nine Negroes once sentenced to death for an attack upon two white girls, announced today that he had requested twenty-six subpoenas for witnesses through whom the defense hopes to establish that racial discrimination keeps Negroes off juries in Jackson and Morgan Counties.

It has been thought that there is considerable enthusiasm among the majority of Massachusetts Democrats for the proposed exportation of Mayor CURLEY. During a large part of the campaign last year his classic eloquence was given to the West, but denied to his own State, unworthy of such a boon.

It has been thought that there is considerable enthusiasm among the majority of Massachusetts Democrats for the proposed exportation of Mayor CURLEY. During a large part of the campaign last year his classic eloquence was given to the West, but denied to his own State, unworthy of such a boon.

COLUMBUS, March 20. -- It remained for a soldier, Jack Karstens, member of Co. C, U.S. Army, stationed at Fort Sheridan, Ill., to set a fair sized crowd at the Coliseum today on its collective heels when he turned in a perfect game -- 300 -- in the American Bowling Congress tournament.

Concerning the situation in Germany, the following radiogram, based on official statements and reports, coming from Maximilian Krauss, Director General of the German Railroad Information Office in Berlin, was received yesterday by Ernst Schmitz, manager of the German Tourist Information Office here:

National Cotton Week should be an important factor in contributing to general industrial revival, George A. Sloan, president of the Cottontextile Institute, said yesterday, in a statement outlining the support pledged to this year's observance of the event from May 15 to 20.

To the Editor of The New York Times: From the standpoint of the current discussion of the pending Crawford bill, which would prevent voluntary hospitals from making any charge in their out-patient clinics and confine their activities to the care of those who can afford no fee at all, the following classification of patients should be acceptable to both sides in the controversy:

Civilized opinion throughout the world finds itself contemplating with mingled bewilderment and horror the course of events in Germany today. The scenes of violence and outrage following upon HITLER'S victory are like the riot and looting after the capture of a be leaguered city.

A large supper dance, the Spring Ball, ushering in the vernal season, will be given tonight in the grand ballroom of the Pierre for the benefit of the Babies Hospital of New York. Mrs. Morton L. Schwartz is chairman of the event, which has been arranged to aid the work of the hospital, now a unit of the Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Centre, in its care for infants and small children.

The "International Horse Show of Art," which is being held for the benefit of the Social Service of Memorial Hospital -- a free nursing service for cancer patients -- opened yesterday afternoon at the Knoedler Galleries, where it will continue through April 1.

The Association of Railway Executives" will seek to formulate a policy on impending railroad legislation at a meeting in Chicago tomorrow. The views on consolidation and coordination of the administration and of banking and Investment interests here will then be presented to the group.
