With the original starting field of eight officials worn down to a wearied group of three, the latest meeting of the International League came to an end yesterday after an eight-hour session at the Hotel New Yorker with the fate of the Jersey City Baseball Club, the lone topic of discussion, at the precise point where it was at the close of the season last Fall.

The development of principles of international law to avoid double taxation as an obstacle to world trade was urged yesterday by Dr. Herbert Dorn of Munich, chairman of the fiscal subcommittee of the League of Nations, at a luncheon of welcome to its members in the Hotel Waldorf Astoria tendered by the American section of the International Chamber of Commerce, at whose invitation the subcommittee is visiting the United States.

MONTREAL, March 20 (Canadian Press). -- Bill Cook enjoys a wide lead in the race for point-scoring honors in the National Hockey League, according to the statistics issued tonight from the office of President Frank Calder.

Dudley D. Sicher, former president of the Federation for the Support of Jewish Philanthropic Societies, win advise Mayor O'Brien today whether he will serve as the third member of the new relief administration that will succeed the Emergency Work and Relief Administration, headed by Lawson Purdy, it was reported last night.

WASHINGTON, March 20. -- President Roosevelt, in conference with Congressional leaders tonight, insisted that farm relief, unemployment relief and railroad consolidation should be the chief additional legislation enacted in the present special session.
GENEVA, March 20. -- Public opinion entered the disaramament conference hall today, and only one delegate came to hear it.

A proposal by Germany to make a final $28,000,000 settlement of the claims growing out of the World War and to abolish the Mixed Claims Commission thereafter has been laid before the Secretary of the Treasury at Washington, it was learned here yesterday.

A heated exchange of words between Borough President Samuel Levy and Charles L. Fleece, an attorney, in West Side Court yesterday was halted finally when Magistrate William Klapp forbade Mr. Fleece to add any further remarks to the record.

PARIS, March 20 (AP). -- The Cabinet debated Premier Mussolini's new peace plan tonight at a three-hour session during which it was decided to defer decisions until tomorrow. At that time Prime Minister MacDonald, who is en route to Paris from Rome, will reveal full details of the proposal to Premier Daladier and Foreign Minister Paul-Boncour.

Clyde Beatty, who trains lions and tigers for circus tricks and has been sent to the hospital by them twenty times, tells some of the things that have happened to him in "The Big Cage," published today by Century. He says that in a fight between a lion and a tiger he would be inclined to bet on the lion because of certain physical advantages, such as slightly greater weight and better throat protection.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Because a gentleman who playfully describes himself as a "rube from Jersey" has the ill fortune to find himself on Seventh Avenue behind an obstinate truck-driver who will not yield him the right of way, the evil practice of unnecessarily blowing automobile horns must not be condoned.

WASHINGTON, March 20 -- Gold and gold certificates to the amount of over $400,000,000 had been returned to the Federal Reserve banks and the treasury today in the two weeks since President Roosevelt urged an end of hoarding.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., March 21. -- Eight of the nine Soottaboro Negroes were taken, from the death house cells which they have occupied for nearly two years, loaded into a prison van after dark tonight and transferred to the Jefferson County jail in Birmingham to await a second trial for their lives next week at Decatur.

In the vote on the conference report on the beer bill the Senate Democrats made a better record than the Republicans. Counting the pairs, thirty-five Democrats and twelve Republicans were for the report; twenty-one Democrats and twenty Republicans against it.

The New York Americans, playing their last game of the current National Hockey League season on their own ice, defeated the Toronto Maple Leafs at Madison Square Garden last night. A crowd of 4.000 watched the Spangled sextet turn back the snapshooting skaters from the north, 4 to 3.

Two suburban schools of college grade, the Nassau Collegiate Centre at Garden City and the Westchester Collegiate Centre at White Plains, offering free tuition to high school graduates seeking college credits, will be started today under the auspices of the College of the City of New York, the State Education Department and the State Temporary Emergency Relief Association, according to an announcement yesterday by the relief administration.

Tuesday, March 21, 1933. Continued evidence of ease in the money market was shown by lower quotations in several sections. Stock Exchange call loans were 3 per cent all day, compared with a renewal charge of 3 1/2 on Monday. Street trades were done at 2 1/2, also a shading from the previous quotation, and Federal funds 3 1/4@2 1/4.

PUTNEY-ON-THAMES, England, March 21. -- Pre-race form of the Cambridge and Oxford crews for the classic test on April 1 indicates this year's event will be a thrilling struggle. Two more practice records were eclipsed by the Oxford crew today, while Cambridge spurted as high as 39 strokes to the minute in one workout.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 21. -- Manager Gabby Street of the St. Louis Cardinals, late Sergeant "Charles Evard Street of the First Gas Regiment, Chemical Warfare Service, A.E.F., was in the clubhouse divesting himself of his store clothes and donning a baseball uniform, known technically in baseball circles as a monkey-suit. Who should come tramping in hut another former Sergeant in the A. E.F., one Hank Gowdy, now of the Boston Braves.
Mayor John P. O'Brien and Aldermanic President Joseph V. McKee vied with each other yesterday in fostering measures designed to cut the cost of city government and increase its efficiency.

BERLIN, March 21. -- Chancellor Adolf Hitter, in his address at the Garrison Church in Potsdam today, dwelt on the alternations of rise and, decline that had marked German history and ascribed the declines to the same recurrent cause -- internal fissure.

CHICAGO, March 21. -- Little or no evidence of selling of wheat futures by the Federal Farm Board appeared today, but even the let-up in that pressure failed to help the market. Offerings increased on all minor upturns and prices dropped as much as 1 cent a bushel from the top.

WASHINGTON, March 21 (AP). -- To get the funds for his proposed "Civilian Conservation Corps," President Roosevelt looked tonight to his Director of the Budget. Lewis Douglas, who is preparing the plan to carve out more than $400,000,000 in savings from government salaries and veterans' compensations which was authorized in the economy act.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 21. -- The Yankees needed a ninth-inning rally to win from the Braves at Waterfront Park today, 8 -- 6, for the fourth straight conquest of the Boston team and the sixth triumph of the world champions' exhibition schedule.

PENNSBURG, Pa., March 21 (AP). -- Three deputy sheriffs seeking to sell out a farmer for debts were seized today by a crowd estimated to number 300 to 500, mauled and held virtual prisoners for nearly an hour. One of the deputies attempted to hold the crowd back by firing his pistol into the air.

An appropriate celebration of the new season took place last night in the main ballroom of the Pierre, where several hundred persons attended the Spring ball in behalf of the Babies Hospital of New York.

Five witnesses before Judge Nott and a jury in General Sessions yesterday identified Louis H. Willard, Bronx real estate dealer, as the man they had known in Rochester, N.Y., as A. Guy Hirsch, who practiced as an attorney in 1906.
Lorenz Strack gave to Albert L. Brink a mortgage for $22,500 to be paid April 15, 1934, at 6 per cent, on 325 W. 175th St.

The three-year reign of the Crescent Athletic-Hamilton Club as champion of the Eastern Athletic Club Basketball League was ended last night by the Montclair Athletic Club when the New Jersey quintet turned back the Brooklyn five, 27 -- 18, in the play-off game for the title on the Seventh Regiment Armory court.

The declared purpose of the new farm bill is to restore "parity" between prices of farm commodities and those of non-agricultural products. Things the farmer sells have depreciated more in value during the depression than those he buys.

WASHINGTON, March 21. -- Amendment of the Constitution to abolish the electoral college and provide for the popular election of Presidents is provided in a joint resolution introduced today by Senator Norris.
BERLIN, March 21. -- The new Reichstag was consecrated in the Garrison Church in Potsdam today and with this ceremony the dustbin received the remnants of the Weimar democracy.
WASHINGTON, March 21. -- The Bureau of Navigation issued the following orders today, dated March 18:

Dudley D. Sicher, former president of the Federation for the Support of Jewish Philanthropic Societies, advised Mayor O'Brien yesterday that owing to the pressure of his duties in other communal organizations he would be unable to accept appointment as the third member of the new relief board to succeed the Emergency Work and Relief Administration, headed by Lawson Purdy.

DALLAS, Texas, March 21. -- Emphasizing the "danger" that legislative bodies, prodded by the necessity for economy, will limit public health, work, Surgeon General Hugh S. Cumming of the United States Public Health Service told the Pan-American Medical Congress tonight that this would be false economy in its ultimate effects on the people.

MIAMI, Fla., March 21. -- An eighth-inning rally, with Charley Sheerin, youthful rookie outfielder, and Jimmy Jordan, Jersey City recruit, in the heavy batting roles, brought the Dodgers from behind to win their opening engagement with the St. Louis Browns, 5 -- 4, today.

A further reduction of $1,500,000 in the two-year 6 per cent secured notes of the Brooklyn-Manhattan Transit Corporation has been authorized by the board of directors and will become effective on April 10, leaving outstanding $10,250,000 of the issue of $13,500,000 sold to bankers in July, 1932.

NEWARK, N.J., March 21. -- Officials at Newark Airport revealed today that a flight they considered of great importance because of its bearing on air transport operation had been completed yesterday under weather conditions that held all scheduled planes on the ground.

Spring celebrated its first full day in New Tork yesterday by pelting the city's millions with rain and chilling them with bitter northwest winds that blew at eighteen or twenty miles an hour. The new season will mend its manners somewhat today, giving the city fair skies for the first time since last Friday, according to the Weather Bureau.
Manhattan real estate trading centered on the west side yesterday. Deals there indicated a demand for housing properties.

WASHINGTON, March 21. -- Modifications of two agreements between the United States Lines Operations, Inc., the Cunard Steamship Company, Ltd., and the White Star Line, one covering the establishment and maintenance of uniform rates on shipments of specie, bullion, bonds and platinum from Southampton to New York, the other covering rates on general cargo between the same ports, were approved by the Shipping Board today.

While securities were showing the eroding effects of renewed liquidation and speculative selling, the dollar advanced so sharply yesterday in the foreign exchange market as to make it evident that an exposed short position was being covered in some confusion.
VIENNA, March 21. -- The Reichspost and the Weltblatt, Vienna Catholio newspapers, continued today charges of Nazi excesses in Germany, begun last week by the Arbeiter-Zeitung.

WASHINGTON, March 21. -- The conference report on the Cullen beer bill was finally adopted by the House today, but because the Senate recessed before Vice President Garner could sign the enrolled copy of the measure the country will have to wait one day longer than expected for 3.2 per cent beer and wine.

The Controllers Institute of America announced yesterday that it had appointed a committee to cooperate with the New York Stock Exchang in the promulgation of rules to govern the accounting practice of corporations.

Sergel Rachmaninoff. playing alone in competition with 200 men who gave one of his own major works a mile down Broadway, made his sixth appearance of the local season last evening at Carnegie Hall. The Russian pianist and composer was again welcomed by an audience of the faithful with enthusiasm, if less of tumult and crowd.
An application by bondholders for the appointment of a receiver for all the S.W. Straus Co., Inc., mortgaged properties now in default was filed yesterday in the Supreme Court.

Ditlevsen Co., representing the import house of Ditlevsen Cia. of Buenos Aires, Argentina, has leased the fifth-floor space in the Evening Post Building, 75 West Street, in expectation of increased exports from this country this year. The lessee has been in smaller quarters at 17 Battery Place.

Weakness in the shares of public utility companies, obviously resulting from Governor Lehman's special message to the State Legislature, influenced the general market unfavorably on the Stock Exchange yesterday. Sharp declines occurred in many parts of the market, notably in the utility group.

An indictment charging forgery in the third degree in ordering a false entry in the books of the National City Company, an affiliate of the National City Bank, was returned by the New York County grand jury yesterday against Horace C. Sylvester Jr., a vice president of the company.

AKRON, Ohio, March 21. -- William G. State, consulting engineer for the Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company, died today at his home here from a complication of ailments, He had been ill for three months.

Christian leaders, acting under the initiative of the Greater New York Interfaith Committee, joined yesterday in the protest movement against persecutions of Jews in Germany, while Jewish organizations continued their efforts to make their own protests heard and bring about the intercession of the United States Government.

Noticing that the driver of a car under suspicion was dressed in the uniform of a city policeman, Patrolmen Frederick G. Ganss and Charles P. Small of the Queens Village radio motor patrol were almost persuaded last night that neither he nor two youths with him in an automobile outside Ruddman's Pharmacy, at Jamaica Avenue and 190th Street, were the robbers they were seeking.

PARIS, March 21. -- In view of the fact that the United States has a new President, and because of the American financial crisis, France should pay the December instalment of the war debt, and pay at once.

HARRISBURG, Pa., March 21. -- Reconsidering the Sunday sports bill, which was defeated by a close vote last week, the State Senate today passed the measure with amendments sponsored by Senator McClure of Delaware County providing for State-wide and local referenda to determine the people's will on the question of legalizing baseball and football games on Sunday afternoons.

Cardinal Hayes returned yesterday on the Munson liner Pan America after a restful vacation in the Bahamas. He paid tribute to President Roosevelt, whose pronouncements of the last two weeks he heard by radio during his vacation.

PARIS, March 21. -- In the person of Premier Edouard Daladier an Foreign Minister Joseph Paul-Boncour France gave a sympathetic ea today to the "views" -- they are no yet supposed to be proposals -- that their British colleagues, Prime Minister Ramsay MacDonald and Sir John Simon, Foreign Secretary brought back from Rome.

ALBANY, March 21. -- Although the exact form of legislation for the control and regulation of the manufacture and sale of beer in this State is still unsettled, Assembly-man Dunkel today brought out the beer bill sponsored by the State commission for alcoholic beverage control legislation which hears his name and put it through a course of drastic amendments.

ALBANY, March 21. -- Governor Lehman in a letter today to William J. Schieffelin, chairman of the Citizens Union, reiterated his interest in charter changes to render the government of New York City more efficient and less costly to the taxpayers.
Paderewski's program will be devoted entirely to Chopin at his concert tonight at the Westchester County Centre in White Plains.

MIAMI, Fla., March 21. -- Mrs. Janet Allen Walker, weeping as she testified, told a master-in-chancery hearing her divorce suit today that James J. Walker, former Mayor of New York, deserted her in 1928 and has refused to return to her.

Three armed men held up the Innovation Luggage Shop at 20 East Forty-sixth Street yesterday afternoon. They took $167.65 from the cash register, robbed three customers of $167 more and after binding them and three employes with picture wire shut them up in a rear room.

Six more State witnesses were questioned yesterday al the trial of Hyman Margolin, Lawrence Buckner, Benjamin Wallach and Benjamin Leventhal, election inspectors indicted for fraud. The defendants, who comprised the board of inspectors in the Fourth Election District of the Fourth Assembly District, are the first of ninety-two to be tried on State charges.
Dwellings comprised the bulk of yesterday's reported turnover in the New Jersey realty market.

In his message to Congress yesterday the President spoke, as if it were a well-known thing, of "our recovery program." He aims specifically to reduce unemployment. For that purpose he makes various recommendations, promising later to produce a "broad public works program."

WASHINGTON, March 21. -- After a long debate, in which the measure was sharply criticized by both Republican and Democratic opponents, the House voted today, 184 to 102, to consider President Roosevelt's farm relief bill under drastic procedure prohibiting amendments and forcing a vote after four hours' discussion, thus assuring the passage tomorrow of the administration's proposal.

Elections were held yesterday in 115 villages in six counties in the metropolitan area, including twenty-one in Westchester, fifty-four in Nassau, seventeen in Suffolk, eleven in Rockland, nine in Orange and three in Putnam counties.

DETROIT, March 21. -- With support being rushed to the Detroit Institute of Arts officials, who are being severely criticized for the Rivera frescoes, the city's argument over whether the murals will be allowed to remain probably will be decided within the next few days.
The committee in charge of the Holy Hour, which will launch the Holy Year decreed by the Pope, issued the following statement from its Hotel Biltmore headquarters last night:

WASHINGTON, March 21. -- Loans of $8,000,000 for slum clearance and construction of model apartments to be known as Knickerbocker Village on the lower east side of New York City and $5,050,000 for the development of Jones Beach Park on Long Island were approved today by the Reconstruction Finance Corporation.

OTTAWA, March 21. -- The Canadian Government proposes to increase income and excise taxes, Edgar N. Rhodes, Minister of Finance, said today as he laid before the House of Commons the annual budget program.
Boxes for the concert to be given on Sunday night in the ballroom of the Plaza, in aid of the Musicians Emergency Fund, have been taken by the following:

ANNAPOLIS, Md., March 21 (AP). -- They're dusting off a niche in Navy's hall of athletic fame for William R. (Killer) Kane of California, track, football, baseball and wrestling star, who leaves the academy for the high seas this year.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Discussing the alcoholic content legally permissible in beverages under the Eighteenth Amendment, G. E. Richter asks THE TIMES if it has not "overlooked the fact that Congress did not 'define,' but merely incorporated a definition" of intoxicating content -- one-half of 1 per cent-in the enforcement act.

WASHINGTON, March 21 (AP). -- Scarcely a moment was devoted in the House today to analyzing provisions of the Roosevelt plan for increasing farm buying power. But in a continuous procession, member after member arose to tell why he was voting for or against the measure.
Miss Helen Greeff gave a dinner last night in the Seaglade of the St. Regis for Miss Alice Townsend de Peyster and James Todd, whose marriage will take place next Monday. The other guests were:

PRINCETON, N.J., March 21 (AP). -- Old wooden tables still bearing the carved initials of Princeton men who gathered around them in the late 1800s, and old-fashioned pewter steins that figured in toasts to many a Tiger victory in sports, began to emerge from their storage places in historic Nassau Inn today.

WASHINGTON, March 21. -- Dave Hennen Morris, New York lawyer and influential Roosevelt supporter, who has heretofore been mentioned for appointment as Ambassador to Germany, will probably be chosen for Ambassador to Belgium, according to indications given in administration circles today.

GENEVA, March 21. -- Officers of the disarmament conference decdied today that at Thursday's meeting called to discuss the British draft convention the delegates would discuss instead demands coming from several sides for adjournment of the conference for four or five weeks over Easter.

Acknowledgment for a great opportunity opened to women will be made this month to the modest printer and journalist, CHRISTOPHER LATHAM SHOLES. He did not realize, when in March sixty years ago he began the manufacture of the first "writing machine," that his invention would put millions of his fellow-countrywomen into business, but he had an inkling of what was coming.

James L. Kilpatrick was elected president of the New York Telephone Company by the board of directors yesterday, following the annual meeting of stockholders, and James S. McCulloh, former president, was appointed chairman of the board.

Increased confidence in economic conditions is indicated by advancing sales figures in department stores, H.I. Kleinhaus, manager of the controllers congress of the National Retail Drygoods Association, declared in an address last night at a dinner of the Credit Bureau of Greater New York, Inc., at the Plaza.

Except for coffee, the market for which was stimulated by the prices obtained by the Federal Farm Board at the auction of its allotment for March, commodities traded on local exchanges yesterday declined again. Business continued in fair volume.

Nothing could more strikingly illustrate the two-fold good that the Musicians' Symphony Orchestra is performing for music than the quality of its last two concerts, which not only provided work for otherwise unemployed instrumentalists, but permitted the public of the average pocketbook to hear artists of the first rank at prices within its reach.

The Edison Electric Illuminating Company of Boston reports for 1932 electric operating revenues of $30,578,498, compared with $30,815,429 in 1931, and expenses of $12,448,034, against $12,788,132. Uncollectible revenue was $171,823, against $128,150, and taxes were $4,882,543, compared with $4,585,730.

WASHINGTON, March 21. -- President Roosevelt laid before Congress today the outlines of an unemployment relief plan, including the recruiting of 250,000 unemployed, direct grants to States for relief work and a "broad public works labor-creating program." Perkins and Senators Wagner, Costigan and La Follette. It is expected that these stipulations will be increased during study of the bill in the Senate committee.

PALO ALTO, Cal., March 21. -- Herbert Hoover returned home today. Free of the burden of the world's greatest office, he stepped from the train at Oakland into the early California morning, and the years seemed to slip from his shoulders.

WASHINGTON, March 21. -- The Reconstruction Finance Corporation and the General Motors Company joined today in the establishment of a new national bank in Detroit, as a result of which, accordins to expectations, at least 40 per cent of the deposits now tied up in the First National and the Guardian National Banks of that city will be made available.

TORONTO, March 21. -- Glen Cunningham, the sensational mile from the University of Kansas abandoned his specialty tonight to win the two-mile event at the Canadian indoor track and field championships in 9:39.6.

MINEOLA, L.I., March 21. -- Surprising upsets marked the annual village elections in Nassau County here tonight, when the concerted efforts of the various economic parties failed to return a single candidate to office. In virtually every instance the incumbent was returned to office where he sought re-election.

WASHINGTON, March 21. -- A bill, which is virtually the old Steagall measure, permitting State non-member banks to borrow from Federal Reserve banks was approved by the Senate Banking and Currency Committee this afternoon. It will be introduced in the Senate tomorrow without Mr. Steagall's name upon it as the second move in what appears to be a contest between the House and Senate Banking Committees.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., March 21. -- Several hundred Radcliffe and Harvard students attended the 125th anniversary concert of the Pierian Sodality of Harvard, oldest college musical organization in the country, in Paine Hall, Harvard, tonight. The sodality was assisted by the Radcliffe Choral Society.

Charles L. Kohler, Director of the j Budget since Jan. 1, 1926, and Tammany leader of the lower half of the Tenth Assembly District, announced yesterday that he had applied for retirement, giving poor health and a desire to devote his time to his family as his reasons.

A move to alter competitive conditions in the automobile tire industry, which the manufacturers themselves describe as chaotic, and to simplify the market was made yesterday by the B.F. Goodrich Company and a few hours later by the United States Rubber Company.
PARIS, March 21. -- Opinion is divided in French Parliamentary and even governmental circles as to the advisability of holding any debate yet on the question of the debt to the United States.

Upsets in Nyack, where an independent village ticket defeated the Republican machine on an economy measure, and in Suffern, where a record vote was cast to put into office Democratic trustees and a police judge, the first Democratic victory in years, marked the balloting in the village elections in Rockland County today.

Charles K. Mitchell, former chairman of the National City Bank, was arrested at 9 o'clock last night at his home, 934 Fifth Avenue, charged with willfully evading payment of an income tax of $657,152.40 for 1929.

Joseph V. McKee, president of the Board of Aldermen, called upon Mayor O'Brien yesterday for prompt action to bring resumption of the transit unification conferences of the Board of Estimate and the Transit Commission that were broken off last September.

PARIS, March 21. -- The Minister of Commerce opened negotiations today with the American Chamber of Commerce with a view to putting Into effect the new law authorizing a tax on import licenses, and in so doing gave American business circles in Paris considerable shock.
PARIS, March 21 (AP). -- Colors are the main problem in this Spring's wardrobes. New colors have made their debut on the style scene and new ways of combining them are seen.

WASHINGTON, March 21. -- Application of sound banking principles to all future loans to cooperative marketing associations from the new Farm Credit Administration, successor to the Farm Board, was promised today by Henry Morgenthau Jr., who, at the same time placed total losses of the board's original $500,000,000 revolving fund at $360,000,000.

Curtis High School's basketball team defeated Townsend Harris Hall High, 28 to 14, yesterday in the Curtis gymnasium in the final Lower Manhattan-Richmond division P.S.A.L. game of the season. The game was originally scheduled for Monday, but was postponed.

Rumblings were heard here yesterday of the storm of controversy in Detroit which threatens to destroy the recently completed mural paintings by Diego Rivera -- paintings which Rivera, widely regarded as one of the world's greatest living artists, himself considers his masterpiece.

If Nick Blaire, manager of the Paradise restaurant and cabaret at 1,919 Broadway, had not elected to be tried in Special Sessions and thus avoid a hearing in the Tombs Court yesterday on a charge that he misleadingly advertised there was no cover charge in the place, it was evident that Magistrate Overton Harris would have dismissed the case.

Mayor O'Brien's new advisory board on city planning, named to replace the former City Planning Department, held its first meeting in City Hall yesterday under the chairmanship of George McAneny, president of the Regional Plan Association of New York.
ALBANY, March 21. -- By unanimous vote the Assembly Taxation Committee defeated the Moffat bill repealing State censorship of motion pictures today.

"Man Hunters of Scotland Yard." published today by Doubleday, Doran, is Artfrur Fowler Neil's account of some of the things that happened to him during forty years as a British, police officer. Mr. Neil was formerly superintendent of the Criminal Identification Department, New Scotland Yard, and a member of the original "Big Four" of Scotland Yard.
NEW YORK. Mr. and Mrs. Donald Carr have returned from Augusta, Ga., and are at Sunnyridge, their country place in Mount Kisco.
WASHINGTON, March 21. -- The War Department issued the following orders today, dted March 18:

WASHINGTON, March 21. -- Widespread apprehension over the plight of Jews in Germany under the Hitler government resulted today In instructions from the State Department to the United States Embassy in Berlin to make a complete report of the situation.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In THE TIMES Magazine James Truslow Adams says that the "American system," which is based on our traditional individualism, "has meant an enormous advance in opportunities for development and happiness for the ordinary men everywhere."

PINEHURST, N.C., March 21. -- With a card of 39, 39 -- 78, Miss Maureen Orcutt of Englewood, N. J., the defending titleholder, captured the qualifying medal in the thirty-first annual North and South women's golf championship over the No. 3 course today.

LONDON, March 21. -- Two British Cabinet meetings have been called for tomorrow. The regular session will be held in the forenoon and a special meeting late In the day to greet Prime Minister MacDonald when he arrives to tell his government colleagues the detailed results of his discussions at Geneva, Rome and Paris.

To the Editor at The Nein York Times: As one whose whole mind has revolted against the notion of magical prosperity which is involved in the dogmas of economic protectionism, a system which has nourished erroneous ideas of success in business and has produced immoral results in the minds and hopes of the people, I have read with keen satisfaction your not infrequent attacks on Republican tariff policy.

The tangled affairs of the Jersey City baseball club, the subject of numerous International League meetings since the close of last season, finally were settled yesterday when the league decided to have Sam Colacurcio continue to operate the club as president.

While Eastern brewery interests were rushing plans yesterday for investing more than $22,533,000 in new plants, additions and alterations, including $13,798,000 in New York City, and $2,500,000 for a complete brewery in the national Capitol, the New York State Brewers Association, in session at its headquarters, 50 Union Square, disavowed any intention of trying to control the retail distribution of beer through any such thing as a chain resembling the old saloon.
CINCINNATI, March 21 (AP). -- The Ohio River and its tributaries continued their assault upon cities in Ohio, Kentucky and Indiana tonight as the murky torrent approached the Mississippi.

Charles E. Mitchell, former chairman of the National City Bank, attracted nation-wide attention and the subsequent scrutiny of the authorities by his testimony to the Senate Banking Committee in Washington on Feb. 21, that in 1929 he sold to a member of his family 18,000 shares of National City Bank stock, the resulting loss of nearly $2,800,000 enabling him to avoid paying a Federal income tax for 1929.

The dollar scored yesterday its broadest advance over other currencies since trading was resumed after the banking holiday. The trend was indicated abroad before the opening of the foreign exchange market here, and it continued with increased momentum throughout the day.

The administration of President MACHADO in Cuba has been weighed in the balance by RUSSELL PORTER in an article in the April Current History. No more impartial review of political conditions has been made. Mr. PORTER does justice to the achievements of the President in his first term.

CHICAGO, March 21. -- Directors of the American Railway Association and operators of freight car equipment will meet here tomorrow morning to discuss mileage allowances made by the railroads on private equipment.

Arms and the Man. The mere fact that a Nazi search of Professor EINSTEIN'S country home near Berlin failed to disclose the huge store of arms and ammunition believed to be concealed on the premises does not end the matter.
"Raw Meat," a play by Myla Jo Closser and Holmer Little, will be presented this evening at the Provincetown Playhouse.

MIAMI, Fla., March 21. -- J.V. Stewart's Singing Heart, 5 to 1 in the U.S.S. Akron Purse, featured event at Tropical Park today, dealt a blow to the form players when she won by three lengths from Golden Fate, the 1-2 favorite. The officers of the Akron were guests of President Frank J. Bruen and viewed the races from the clubhouse.

WASHINGTON, March 21. -- Elimination of the "secret service" activities within the Labor Department built up and headed by Murray Garsson under the last administration, complete reorganization of the employment service, and a combination of the practical with the academic in the future handling of statistics, are the main points in the "new deal" mapped by Miss Frances Perkins, Secretary of Labor, and disclosed at her first general press conference this morning.

"What we need are some nice warm days," writes Captain Mel Eldred from Peconic Bay, "and then we will have good fishing. I had a party of eight out this week on the Lady Helen -- eight old-timers who know their fishing -- and while the catch of flounders wasn't anything to bray about, for bulk, I must say the individual fish were mighty fine.

Mrs. Augusta H. Harriman, wife of Joseph W. Harriman, founder of the Harriman National Bank and Trust Company, who was arrested last week when the bank was closed, filed a petition in bankruptcy in Federal court yesterday.

Interest was divided yesterday at the International Flower Show between the awards -- offered for the first time by the Italian Government and the prizes given by the Horticultural Society of New York and other organizations under whose auspices the twentieth annual exhibit is being held at the Grand Central Palace.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, March 21 (AP). -- Ohio, West Virginia and New Jersey bowlers, rolling in the minor events of the American Bowling Congress today, failed to dislodge any of the leaders.

Prospect of an early move on the part of the Roosevelt administration to undertake a nation-wide drive to interest private investors in placing their funds in new refunding issues of United States Government obligations occasioned considerable speculation in financial circles here yesterday as to which one of the many forms the new flotation might take.

PARIS, March 21. -- Owing, it asserted, to covering and to sales of the pound sterling, the dollar rose sharply today in the exchange market, almost touching the gold export point from France to the United States. The final quotation was at the day's high of 25.52 francs, but at the evening session of the Bourse in unofficial trading the dollar fell off slightly, being quoted at 25.49 1/2.

WASHINGTON, March 21. -- Rabbi Stephen S. Wise and Bernard S. Deutsch of the American Jewish Congress appeared before the Immigration Committee of the House of Representatives today to urge revocation of the executive order of Sept. 8, 1930, for a stricter curb on immigration.

Counsel for the St. Louis-San Francisco Railway having found that the recent amendment to the bankruptcy law is applicable to the company's readjustment plan, a meeting of the readjustment managers will be called next week to put the plan into effect through a further application to the Interstate Commerce Commission.
OTTAWA, March 21 (Canadian Press). -- Highlights of the budget announcements by E.N. Rhodes, Minister of Finance, follow:

When the Irish become the Irish-Americans their lyric fervor becomes ear-splitting din. Or at any rate, so you would gather from "Far Away Horses," a comedy by Michael Birmingham and Gilbert Emery, which was shouted from the stage of the Martin Beck last evening.

BUFFALO. March 21. -- A credit balance of $100,000 due the Stude-baker Corporation of America from the Pierce-Arrow Motor Car Company was attached today by Sheriff Frank J. Offerman under a Supreme Court order in a $1,448,000 civil action begun against the Studebaker Corporation by Albert J. Carey of Brooklyn.

PATCHOGUE, L.I., March 21. -- Elections were held today in seventeen incorporated villages of Suffolk County. In most of the communities there were no contests, although there were several instances of spirited elections.

The International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation reports for 1932 a consolidated net loss of $3,981,171 after all charges and provision for depreciation but before losses amounting to $2,157,665 on foreign exchange in converting earnings of foreign subsidiaries into United States dollars.

It was discovered yesterday that James G. Harbord, retired Major General and former commander of the army's Service of Supply in France, severed his connection more than a month ago with the campaign of the National Economy League for the reduction of veteran expenditures as a result of the counter-attack of veteran organizations for the reduction of the retired pay of army and navy officers.
ALBANY, March 21. -- Governor Lehman sent a special message to the Legislature today urging enactment of a series of bills to provide for stricter regulation of public utilities.

The bond market turned weak in all departments yesterday as trading on the Stock Exchange rose to $10,189,000, compared with $7,672,000 on Monday. The volume of United States Government issues was $3,388,000, with declines sharp in several issues, particularly in Treasury 3 3/8s, 3 3/4s, 4s and 4 1/4s.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., March 21. -- With all but one of the twenty-one villages which held elections in Westchester heard from it appeared that the Democrats made slightly more gains than the Republicans.

LOS ANGELES, March 21. -- By way of taking a final trial spin for their three-game test with the Pirates which opens here tomorrow, the Giants took a farewell fling against the Hollywood Stars today, but with negative results. The Stars upset Manager Terry and his colleagues, 6 to 4.
CAMDEN, S.C., March 21. -- In spite of the chilly blasts that swept the show ring, a large gallery was present this afternoon to usher in the first day of the twenty-third annual Camden Horse Show.

Michael Arlen changed his writing style and took a new kind of subject matter when he wrote "Man's Mortality," published here today by Doubleday, Doran following an enthusiastic reception from English reviewers and backed by the recommendation of the English Book Society.

OSSINING, N.Y., March 21. -- Bernard K. Marcus, former president of the Bank of United States, and Saul Singer, who was vice president, entered Sing Sing Prison at 5 o'clock tonight to serve sentences of from three to six years for misapplication of funds.
WASHINGTON, March 21. -- The text of President Roosevelt's message to Congress today on unemployment relief was as follows:

Samuel J. Foley was appointed District Attorney of Bronx County yesterday by Governor Lehman to fill the post left vacant by his former chief, Charles B. McLaughlin, who was sworn in as a justice of the Supreme Court last week.
WASHINGTON, March 21. -- The text of the Robinson-Wagner unemployment relief bill introduced in the Senate today to carry out the recommendations of President Roosevelt, was as follows:
CLEVELAND, March. 21. -- George H. Schwartz died yesterday after a long illness at his home in Lakewood, Ohio. He was 73 years old.

LONDON, March 21. -- Behind locked doors the court-martial of Lieutenant Norman Baillie-Stewart of the Seaforth Highlanders continued today, with nine witnesses called to testify as to his alleged dealings with German agents.

Dates for three senior high school track and field meets were set by members of the High Schools Games Committee of the P.S.A.L. during their March meeting yesterday at the Hotel Astor. They voted to hold the annual senior high outdoor novice meet on May 13 and the annual senior high outdoor championships on June 10, both at the General George W. Wingate Athletic Field in Brooklyn.

Mr. ROOSEVELT when Governor made more effective regulation of public utilities in this State a popular issue. Governor LEHMAN is following in his footsteps. In his annual message he called for closer scrutiny of the relation between holding companies and operating companies and made a number of suggestions for improving the regulatory process.

Disturbing European news, a sharp rise in dollar exchange and uncertainty over the effects of the proposed farm legislation caused heavy selling pressure yesterday on the Cotton Exchange. After an early loss of 10 points on foreign selling, trading quieted for several hours, only to increase considerably before the close.

The New York Towboat Exchange demanded assurance yesterday of the continued movement of seagoing tugs in waters adjacent to the harbor when Colonel E.D. Ardery of the Army engineers summoned navigation interests to a hearing on proposed new regulations for drawbridges in Newark Bay, the Hackensack and Passaic Rivers and their navigable tributaries.

The State completed its case yesterday against Alexander J. Forsyth, part owner of the steamer Observation who is on trial before Bronx County Judge Barrett on a charge of manslaughter resulting from the explosion which wrecked the steamer and killed seventy-two men Sept. 9.

Declaring that children should be made "music-conscious" at an early age, Miss Marion Flagg, music instructor at the Horace Mann School of Teachers College, Columbia University, in a study on "Creative Music," made public yesterday, asserts that every home should be a "miniature grand opera" with all conversations between children and their parents taking place in a sing-song, chanting manner.

In addition to the grand awards received by the entries from the various garden clubs in the open competition of the flower show, the following awards were given to the groups exhibited under the auspices of the Garden Club of America, the Federated Garden Clubs of New York State and the Federated Garden Clubs of New Jersey:

Dickinson W. Richards Jr., Assistant Professor of Medicine in the Columbia University School of Medicine, has received the Walter Belknap James Fellowship for 1933-34, it was announced yesterday by Dr. Frank D. Fackenthal, secretary of the university.
considerations."

William J. Hall of the Crescent Athletic-Hamilton Club, the only amateur playing last night in the world's open squash tennis championship, made a determined bid to advance through the initial round, but bowed finally in a five-game match at the Fraternity Club.

The Musical Art Quartet, consisting of Sascha Jacobsen, Paul Bernard, Louis Kaufman and Marie Roemaet-Rosanoff, presented its final concert of the season at the Town Hall last night. The first half of the program included Brahm's Quartet in C minor, Opus 51, No. 1, and Beethoven's Quartet in G, Opus 18. No. 2.

ALBANY, March 21. -- A drive for final adjournment of the Legislature in two weeks was begun today by the Democratic leaders, although it was admitted that three weeks might be nearer the period required to wind up the affairs of the 1933 session.
LONDON, March 21. -- The stock markets continued strong today, particularly South African gold mines, on a rise in the price of gold.

We have not yet the exact text of the proposals which MUSSOLINI made to Prime Minister MACDONALD for guaranteeing the peace of Europe for at least ten years. The British statesman spoke in high praise of the plan which he brought hack with him to Paris on his way home.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., March 21. -- A call for a "Combined people's support" of "a wise and courageous leadership" of the government in Washington was issued here tonight by Rear Admiral Richard E. Byrd, national chairman of the National Economy League.

WASHINGTON, March 21. -- The vital legislation confronting the administration, farm relief, unemployment, railroad consolidation and permanent banking reforms, and the attitude of the government toward war debts consumed the attention of the Cabinet today.

Albert Halstead, who retired as American Consul General at London on Sept. 30 after serving the government for twenty-six years in important consular posts abroad, was critically injured last night when he was struck by a taxicab while crossing Sixth Avenue at Fifty-fourth Street.

HAMILTON, N.Y., March 21. -- Michigan's crack swimmers broke one national intercollegiate and two pool records tonight when the National Collegiate A.A. champions held an exhibition meet with the Colgate team. They stopped over at Hamilton en route to the N.C.A.A. championships at Yale later in the week.

GOSHEN, N.Y., March 21. -- Five villages in Orange County were the scenes of spirited contests in their village elections here today, Maybrook, Otisville, Monroe, Harriman and Goshen. The remainder of the elected officials in other villages were unopposed.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Now that the director of the Gibson committee work bureau has publicly criticized the home relief, perhaps a voice from those that have to seek relief might be heard.
ALBANY, March 21. -- Democratic legislators announced today their purpose to rush the budget and tax bills through the Senate before the end of the current week.

City officials were urged yesterday by Miss Catharine S. Leverich, president of the girls' branch of the Public Schools Athletic League, to provide at least as good after-school recreational facilities for girls as for boys. Presenting her report at the twenty-seventh annual meeting of the branch at 315 Lexington Avenue, Miss Leverich said recreational economies had been made at the expense of the girls.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., March 21. -- Seven of the eleven commercial banks in Westchester County which opened after the bank holiday for limited business have had conservators named to take charge of their assets, one of the eleven, the Huguenot Trust Company of New Rochelle, has reopened for normal business, and three were still operating on the limited basis of the past week with no change of status.

NEW ORLEANS, March 21 (AP). -- F.P. Letellier's Marie Jean, a consistent daughter of Wise Counsellor, dashed over a mile distance in 1:41 today to defeat two Kentucky Derby eligibles, E.R. Bradley's Bobsled and C.V. Whitney's Cresta Run.

Mrs. Alexander Hamilton was hostess at a luncheon yesterday at the Savoy-Plaza in the interest of the "society circus" to be given on April 25 at the Waldorf-Astoria for the benefit of the Boy Scout Foundation of Greater New York. Beatrice Lillie.

BOSTON, March 21. -- The Boston Bruins, thanks to a pair of Alex Smith's savage left-handed thrusts, gained the American group championship of the National Hockey League for the fifth time in six years by vanquishing the speedy New York Rangers, 3 -- 2, tonight before a capacity crowd of 16,500 at the Boston Garden.

LONDON, March 21. -- With the Grand National Steeplechase at Aintree only three days away, the big Irish jumper Gregalach and Miss Dorothy Paget's Golden Miller today remained joint favorites for the classic at odds of 9 to 1, with the American-owned horses rank outsiders.

More than 50,000 subway passengers were delayed about an hour at the rush period last evening when the I.R.T. system between Atlantic Avenue and the two Brooklyn terminals of the line was tied up in both directions by a breakdown in the power substation.

The Federation of Yeshivahs and Talmud Torahs, including twelve Jewish parochial institutions and seventy-five Hebrew schools in New York City, announced yesterday that it had leased a three-story building at 65 Pitt Street and had undertaken the manufacture of between 500,000 and 750,000 pounds of matzoths for the Passover holidays.

The Erie Railroad contributed 51,771,776 in the form of proceeds from the freight surcharges that took effect on Jan. 2, 1932, to the Railroad Credit Corporation, but borrowed $2,530,000 from that organization, it is shown in the report for 1932 by C.E. Denney, president, and C.L. Bradley, chairman.

Uncompromising orders to support every measure on the Roosevelt administration's legislative program have been sent to the members of the House of Representatives from Manhattan and Brooklyn by Tammany, Hall and the McCooey organization, it was learned yesterday.

DETKOIT, March 21 (AP). -- "A heartless hoax," "the greatest work of a modern artist," "pure Communist propaganda," "a stunning interpretation of industrial life" -- such are the comments of Detroiters viewing the murals of Diego Rivera, whose vivid, flaming colors depict his conception of the city's industrial history on the garden court walls of the Detroit Institute of Arts.
PALM BEACH, I a., March 21. -- Mrs. Seward Webb gave a dinner tonight at Mirador. Her sister, Mrs. Hamilton McK. Twombly, has returned to New York.

MOSCOW, March 21. -- As a result of the arrest of thirty-five Russian and six British engineers on charges of sabotage, Moscow representatives of the International General Electric Company, on instructions from their home office in Schenectady, N.Y., have asked the Soviet Government to make clear whether responsibility for defects in machinery installed in Russian plants by foreign companies is to be placed upon the installing company or upon its employes.

Ed (Strangler) Lewis, 240, Kentucky, former world's champion, and Joe Malcewicz, 202, Utica, N. Y., wrestled to a draw in the feature finish match before 3,500 persons at the New York Coliseum last night. The bout was halted after 26 minutes by the Athletic Commission curfew law.

WASHINGTON, March 21. -- Great interest was aroused in official and embassy circles by the publication this morning of the plan being discussed in important administration councils to promote Executive and Congressional accord on war-debt settlements and new economic and trade agreements.
COMMERCIAL PAPER. Yesterday -- 3 1/2 per cent for the best names. Monday -- 3 1/2 per cent for the best names.

HARRISBURG, Pa., March 22. -- The possibility of a fight over beer in the Legislature appeared today when Governor Pinchot announced that he was studying two bills on this subject now pending in the House and that he expected to have something to say on the subject within a few days.

MIAMI, Fla., March 22 (AP). -- Dissolution by divorce of the marriage of Janet Alien Walker and James J. Walker, former Mayor of New York City, was recommended to Circuit Court here today by T.J. Dowdell, Master in Chancery. Yesterday the master heard testimony of Mrs. Walker and other witnesses in the suit she filed.

HAMILTON, Ont., March 22 (AP). -- Ralph Metcalfe, Marquette University's Negro sprint flash, equaled the world's indoor record for the 60-yard dash he set this Winter by running the distance in 0:6.1 in the Ninety-First Higlhanders' meet tonight.

YATUNG, India, March 22. -- The Mount Everest climbing expedition, its membership completed at Kalimpong, where Lieutenants Thompson and Smythe-Windham of the Royal Corps of Signals joined us, reached Yatung today.

PARIS, March 22. -- Efforts are being made to nullify the bargaining value at the forthcoming World Economic Conference of the trade restrictions put down by many countries in the last year or more, it became known today. This is being done -- and so far without much success -- by the experts all over the world who are continuing preparations for the parley.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., March 22. -- Attorney General Thomas E. Knight Jr. announced today that he will leave tomorrow for Decatur to discuss with Sheriff Davis of Morgan County the advisability of providing military protection, for the Scottsboro Negroes who will go on trial for their lives there Monday.

The electric power index for the week ended March 18 showed a small decline of 0.2 points to 60.8, slightly below the low record of the week before, when the index stood at 61.0. The index for the corresponding week last year was 72.9. The seasonally adjusted daily average was 197,000,000 kilowatt-hours, as against 197,300,000 kilowatt-hours in the preceding week and 220,400,000 in the corresponding week last year.

ALBANY, March 22. -- Following a public hearing this afternoon on measures introduced to further revision of the New York City charter and reforms in county governments within the city, the Assembly Cities Committee held an executive meeting this evening and voted to report favorably tomorrow four of the county reform bills and the Hofstadter committee charter bill sponsored by Assemblyman Moffat of New York City.

There are no idle hands around the headquarters of the Lindenhurst Boatmen's Association these days. The captains are getting ready for a record year and consequently are as busy as bees. All the captains gathered yesterday at Barnacle Bill's to dine at the expense of Charlie Bauer because Captain Charlie has just commissioned a new boat. Seagull II, and is very proud of her.

Listing of new common stocks or four corporations with par values ranging from $1 to $10 a share has been approved by the Stock Exchange upon notice of issuance of the new shares, which are exchangeable share for share for the old no par stocks.+

The bill providing for a year's moratorium on foreclosures of home mortgages for non-payment of principal, introduced in the State Senate by Senator Joseph D. Nunan Jr. of Queens and passed by that body last Monday, is a "step in the right direction," but does not go far enough in affording the wide relief now needed, in the opinion of the Long Island Real Estate Board.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., March 22. -- The first exhibit of the work of undergraduates at Harvard ever given by the Harvard Society for Contemporary Art opened today for a large and enthusiastic stream of visitors in the society's galleries at Harvard Square.

The Downtown Gallery has opened a group exhibition containing work in several mediums by nearly forty American artists. It will continue until April 8. Oil paintings fill two of the larger rooms and there is an array of prints in the entrance gallery.

"Any President of the United States," George Herman (Babe) Ruth and President Roosevelt as an individual won the first three places, in the order named, in a poll taken last week among 1,171 men who earn nothing to select the men throughout the world most deserving of salaries of $80,000 a year or more, the Salvation Army United Appeal announced yesterday.

Alfred E. Smith took the witness stand for the government yesterday at the trial of Otto E. Goebel and eight others accused of mail fraud in the sale of stock of the National Diversified Corporation, whose officers are alleged to have promoted a "clean motion-picture" movement among Roman Catholic clergymen and laymen which netted $3,000,000.

Joseph V. McKee received 54,185 votes for Mayor in Manhattan at the last election, the recanvass by the Board of Elections showed yesterday. On election night, the returns for the borough credited him with 26,634 votes, and the official canvass, two weeks later, gave him 46,087.

United States Government bonds rallied briskly yesterday, featuring an otherwise irregularly lower bond market on the Stock Exchange. Federal issues closed with net gains of 2-32 to 29-32 point. The heaviest gainers were the Treasury 4s, 3 3/4s and 4 1/4s in the order named.

At last those two eminent Democratic leaders, Mr. McCOOEY and Mr. CURRY, have been forced to appear as bosses. This course must be distressing to them. They previously had avoided the exertion of pressure on the independent and unterrified Kings County and Manhattan Representatives when the Economy Bill was voted on.

The volume of bankers' acceptances outstanding declined $3,578,411 in February to $703,825,889 at the close of that month, according to the survey of the American Acceptance Council published yesterday. The latest figure represents a net decline of $5,903,000 since the close of last year.

William P. Kenney, president of the Great Northern Railway, announced yesterday that holders of more than 75 per cent of the company's 4 1/2 per cent first and refunding bonds had assented to an extension of the St. Paul, Minneapolis Manitoba consolidated bonds that will mature July 1.

The murals recently completed by Diego Rivera in the Detroit Institute of Arts will not be whitewashed without provoking indignation among artists here, it appeared yesterday from comments by persons well known in the art field. Although varied points of view were expressed by individual artists and officers of organizations, the burden was in opposition to the group in Detroit that is agitating for removal or whitewashing of the murals.
UTICA, N.Y., March 22. -- Bankruptcy petitions filed here today Included:

Eastern District High School's team gained undisputed possession of first place in Division 2 of the city P.S.A.L. championship fencing competition by defeating James Madison, runner-up for the crown last season, 5 to 4, yesterday at Townsend Harris Hall High School.

In all the theatrical capitals of the world the same desperate situation, exists. Various wizards try their spells to turn people from the cinemas, the radio and their own firesides toward the box office. ANDRE DE FOUQUIERES, an old favorite of the Paris stage, has recently been telling managers how to do it.

LONDON, March 22. -- Neville Chamberlain, described in the House of Commons tonight by a Labor member as "the gloomiest Chancellor of the Exchequer England ever had," immediately undertook to disprove the charge by saying that the world situation was likely to improve in the next few months.

WARSAW, March 22. -- A close alliance of Poland and the Little Entente is advocated here as a reply to the Mussolini-MacDonald agreement in Rome, which is interpreted here as an attempt to revive the pre-war European concert of powers without Russia or Austria-Hungary.

CHICAGO, March 22. -- Barney Ross, a product of Chicago's ghetto, conquered Billy Petrolle, the Fargo Express, in a blistering ten-round battle in the Chicago Stadium tonight and established himself as challenger for the world's lightweight championship held by Tony Canzoneri.
Ten Manhattan and Bronx properties were bought in by plaintiffs at foreclosure auctions yesterday. The results follow:

ALBANY, March 22. -- Governor Lehman and the Democratic legislative leaders conferred tonight on proposals for new and additional taxes to balance the budget. The Governor found the leaders favorable toward a 2 per cent retail sales tax, but not completely committed to it.

Salaries and wages of officers and employes of the Public Service Corporation of New Jersey and its subsidiaries will be reduced about 10 per cent on April 1. Dividends on the common stock, payable after the same date, will be reduced by 12 1/2 per cent.

WASHINGTON, March 22 (AP). -- In the House debate on the farm relief bill today Representative Lemke, Republican, of North Dakota voiced an opinion, apparently shared by many farm representatives when in explaining his support of the bill, he said:

WASHINGTON, March 22. -- The State Department's announcement today that Congressional authority and specification would soon be sought by the President before proceeding to negotiate new commercial agreements, confirms the report that what Europe calls "pig-in-a-poke" treaty-making with the United States is to be ended by Mr. Roosevelt if he can manage it.

WASHINGTON, March 22. -- Internal revenue collections for the first eight months of the fiscal year 1933 amounted to $921,957,521.84, a decrease of $81,732,552.33 as compared with the corresponding period ending in 1932, the Internal Revenue Bureau announced today.

WASHINGTON, March 22 (AP). -- Edward B. Dunford, attorney for the Anti-Saloon League of America, said today that "an attack upon the (beer) law will certainly be made when the requisite circumstances arise."
MILWAUKEE, March 22 (AP). -- This pre-prohibition brewing centre bubbled over with activity today.

WASHINGTON, March 22. -- Mrs. Roosevelt went for a horseback ride this morning, accompanied by Mrs. Henry Morgenthau Jr.; had luncheon with Mrs. Thomas J. Walsh, widow of the late Senator Walsh, and this afternoon attended the concert given in Constitution Hall by Ignace Jan Paderewski, who has been a guest at the White House.

Mayor CONGLETON of Newark, announcing that he will fee a candidate for re-election on May 9, admits that his Administration is under fire, but he stands upon his record, giving notice that he does not want the support of any voter who has found it unsatisfactory.

Jack Haskell, dance director, who in August, 1930, accused Arthur Hammerstein and a chorus man of punching him on the jaw at a theatre rehearsal, was beaten and robbed by two men last night in his apartment at the New Weston Hotel, 34 East Fiftieth Street, four hours before he was to have sailed for Europe on the Hamburg-America liner New York.

MIAMI, March 22. -- The direction of Cuban rebel activities, once led by General Mario G. Menocal, former President, who is now resident here, will pass to a new junta being completed here tonight, members of the exile colony said.

WASHINGTON, March 22. -- The beer bill was signed today by President Roosevelt and lawful 8.2 per cent brew, after thirteen years of proscription, will be sold in States variously estimated at fourteen to twenty-three when the act becomes operative at 12:01 A.M. on April 7. not show the number for beer violations.

BERLIN, March 22. -- The United States Embassy made plain today that it had not protested to the German Foreign Office against anti-Semitic attacks, but had merely received instructions from the State Department to place special emphasis in its regular reports to Washington upon the matter of persecutions of Jews in Germany.

Although Wall Street was at pains yesterday to emphasize the improved "technical position" of the share market, prices continued to fall on the Stock Exchange. The market opened fractionally lower, in dull dealings, then drifted downward further.

Policemen and ambulance surgeons worked in vain for five hours yesterday to save the life of Edward O'Hara, 60-year-old laborer, who was buried beneath twentyfive tons of sand in a hopper at the city asphalt plant at Ninetieth Street and York Avenue.

Two Canadian trains which are now the fastest in the world for their respective distances, are to be pooled on a slower schedule, it was announced yesterday by the Canadian National Railways. The change will be a part of the first move in a program for reducing excess service approved by the Canadian Parliament.

A bill before the Canadian Parliament proposes to confer certain dictatorial powers upon Prime Minister BENNETT. But they are to be valid and he is to exercise them only when Parliament is not sitting. In this respect the proposal might seem to be copied from a Mexican precedent.

Except for a partial recovery in United States Government bonds, there was no interruption yesterday of the downward movement in securities. Stocks and bonds of almost all descriptions declined further, but less emphatically than on the day before.

More than 1,000 members of Adolf Hitler's Swastika organization who immigrated to this country in recent years, have organized themselves into an American division of the Nationalsozialistische Deutsche Arbeiterpartei, according to Paul Manger, chief of the New York office of these overseas Nazis, at 309 East Ninety-second Street.

Rightly or wrongly, the celebration of the 300th anniversary of the founding of New York City's oldest school went through according to schedule yesterday afternoon in the school's chapel, at West End Avenue and Seventy-seventh Street.

One of the novel events arranged in behalf of philanthropic groups is the Dutch Treat County Fair and dance which will take place tonight at Teutonia Hall, 144 East Sixteenth Street, for the benefit of Riis House. Divertissements will be given during the evening by the Don Hall Trio, radio entertainers; Carlo Restivo, accordianist, and the Lindy Hop Team.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I have read with interest your recent editorials on the proposed farm relief situation. What you say is true. But there is one consideration that you and many urban people often overlook.

WASHINGTON, March 22. -- Effects to amend further the State bank aid bill frustrated a plan to drive the measure through the Senale today, and at nightfall completion of the bill had to be deferred until tomorrow.

After a fiery four-hour session the executive committee of the Kings County American Legion, representing fifty-seven Legion posts, adopted a resolution early today pledging its support to President Roosevelt in his economy measures regardless of what sacrifices to veterans and Legionaires such action might entail.

The discontinuance or marked downward revision of 150 industrial pension plans affecting more than a million workers -- nearly a third of the entire movement -- raises the question whether from a purely economic viewpoint the pension experiment has been justified, according to the study, "Industrial Pensions in the United States and Canada," just published by Industrial Relations Counselors, Inc.

The protest against the persecution of Jews in Germany under the regime of Adolf Hitler continued to gain country-wide momentum yesterday as Christain leaders and churches joined Jewish organizations in the effort to stop by moral pressure the acts of oppression reported from Germany.

Charging that the city's faulty purchasing methods waste $14,000 a day, the City Affairs Committee in a letter to Mayor O'Brien yesterday pressed for immediate action on the creation of a central purchasing agency to do all the city's buying.

CHICAGO, March 22. -- Receipts of hogs here today were larger than yesterday and prices dropped 5 to 10 cents a hundredweight below yesterday's final quotations. The top was down 20 cents at $4.15, while the day's average was off 15 cents at $3.95.

CHICAGO, March 22. -- Fifty-two claims totaling $22,275,727 have been allowed in the Probate Court against the estate of Julius Rosenwald, philanthropist and capitalist, who died Jan. 6, 1932. The Assistant Probate Judge, Oscar S. Caplan, allowed forty-one claims today.

A new loan of $15,000,000 was obtained by New York City late yesterday afternoon from a citywide group of banks, all but four of which are members of the New York Clearing House Association. The proceeds will be used for work and home relief and will take care of the city's financing program until late next month.

On a block front for which an offer of more than $5,000,000 was refused by Klein Jackson, operators and builders, at the peak of the real estate boom, a structure of artistic design adaptable in part for a high-class restaurant and beer garden, is about to replace a wellknown landmark.
WASHINGTON, March 22. -- following was the House vote today on the farm relief bill:

SAN FRANCISCO, March 22. -- A potential market about double that of the pre-prohibition days finds Pacific Coast brewers faced with the necessity of making heavy plant expenditures to serve the expected demand for legalized beer.

The following editorial, expressing a German-American viewpoint of the conditions in Germany under the Hitler regime, is printed this morning in the New Yorker Staats-Zeitung, of which Bernard F. Ridder is president and publisher:

A Communist movement by about thirty pupils of the James Monroe High School, 172d Street and Boynton Avenue the Bronx, led yesterday to the suspension of two girls by the school principal, Dr. Henry E. Hein, and to a student demonstration after school hours, which was broken up by the police.

The authors of "Raw Meat," having had some experience with the public prints, apparently just grew tired of the chant of the jungle. They therefore decided to drop Hero, the circus lion, into the gentle fields of Connecticut and then let a couple of explorers capture him.

While the steel business is still feeling the effects of the recent banking crisis, the demand for pig iron and scrap has shown a sharp increase, according to the weekly review of The Iron Age. Operations in the last week were at the rate of 14 per cent of ingot capacity, taking the country as a whole, representing a slight contraction compared with the week before.

PINEHURST, N.C., March 22. -- Two perennial rivals, Miss Maureen Orcutt of Englewood, N.J., and Mrs. Opal S. Hill of Kansas City, Mo., shared the spotlight as the match play in the thirty-first annual North and South golf tournament for women got under way today over the No. 3 course.

The dollar made further moderate gains yesterday in the foreign exchange market, but did not duplicate its uprush of the previous day. In the early hours of trading some of the European exchanges recovered sharply, but only marks and francs were able to hold their gains.

WASHINGTON, March 22. -- Formal authorization of two loans for large self-liquidating projects in New York, amounting to $5,050,000 for a causeway to Jones Beach, L.I., and $3,400,000 for the Catskill Bridge across the Hudson, was voted today by the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, following a conference of directors at the Treasury with Secretary Woodin.

When the Greenwich Savings Bank sold to the Contract Realty Corp., Benjamin winter, president, the twelve-story Hotel Hermitage at 592-9B 7th Av., adjoining the southwest corner of 42d St., the buyer gave the bank a mortgage for $42.750. The indicated consideration was $47,000 above the mortgage for $432,250 held by the bank.

PARIS, March 22. -- Premier Daladier and Foreign Minister Paul-Boncour today outlined before the Senate Foreign Affairs Commission the French policy with regard both to the proposed four-power entente and to the British arms limitation proposals in a manner which showed the present government has definitely chosen to follow the path of international cooperation along those lines with such prudence as opinion at home and events in Germany demand.
WASHINGTON, March 22. -- The administration farm relief bill, which seems likely to be rewritten in large part in the Senate, was passed by the House this afternoon by a vote of 315 to 98.

PALM BEACH, Fla., March 22. -- Malmaison, the residence of James H.R. Cromwell on the estate of Mr. and Mrs. Edward T. Stotesbury, was the setting tonight for a buffet supper and dance with which Mr. Cromwell entertained in compliment to Mr. and Mrs. Paul Whiteman, who are at the Everglades Club.

Alexander J. Forsyth, master of the steamer Observation, took the stand in his own defense yesterday in his trial before Bronx County Judge Barrett for manslaughter as a result of the explosion which wrecked the steamer and killed seventy-two workmen on Sept. 9.

PARIS, March 22. -- Baron Heari de Rothschild signed today documents donating to the French National Library his collection of autographs, which is the most important private collection relating to French history in existence.

Word has been received from England which strengthens the probability of the appearance in American polo this Summer of the Maharajah of Jaipur's team from India. The British word is to the effect that the Indian team has already shipped thirty-six ponies to England, where the players will arrive early in April, and that the Maharajah and his companions plan to play throughout the full London season.

The Legislature will be asked to enact laws to prevent companies dealing in guaranteed real estate mortgages from assuming liabilities greater than they can meet, it was announced yesterday at the office of George S. Van Schaick, Superintendent of Insurance.

The General Education Board appropriated $10,816,146 for the support of education in the fiscal year ended June 30, 1932, it was disclosed in the board's annual report, made public yesterday. The board was founded in 1902 by John D. Rockefeller.

CHICAGO, March 22. -- Liquidation was on in wheat today on the Board of Trade here, with operators and others who bought on the recent advance active in disposing of their holdings. Prices never went as high as at the finish on Tuesday and with stop-loss orders uncovered, the close was at the bottorn at net losses of 1 to 1 3/8 cents a bushel, the May showing the most strength.
PURNEA, India, March 22. -- The airplanes with the bulk of the members of the Mount Everest flight expedition arrived here this afternoon from Delhi.

Norman H. Davis, Special Ambassador of the United States on Disarmament and Work Economics, sailed last night on the steamship Manhattan of the United States Lines for London to confer with leading British officials before going to Geneva to assume his duties as chairman of the General Disarmament Conference.

The tri-color of the Federated Garden Clubs of New York State, awarded each day in conjunction with the annual flower show, was awarded yesterday to Mrs. John W. Force of the Allyns Creek Gardens Club of Rochester, N.Y., for her special arrangement for a Spanish table dinner.

Biology fired the enthusiasm of James Hopkins, 15-year-old third term student at Manual Training High School, Brooklyn. James, ever since his first lecture early in February, has been telling the five older boys with whom he whiles away after-dusk hours at Ninth Street and Fourth Avenue, about the wonders of the science.

In issuing the annual report of the General Foods Corporation for 1932, showing a net profit of $10,343,882, or $1.97 a share on the 5,251,501 shares of no-par value common stock outstanding at the end of the year, C.M. Chester, president, announced that the company had purchased all capital stock of the Sanka Coffee Corporation.

An order of Supreme Court Justice Glennon denying alimony yesterday for Mrs. Ethel Rosner in a suit for divorce against Morris Rosner, underworld agent for Colonel Lindbergh in the hunt for his kidnapped son.

The British destroyer Westminster has returned to port after having burned oil successfully during an experimental voyage -- not ordinary fuel oil, but oil made by British chemists from British coal. Now, it is said, the Admiralty has contracted for a twelve months' supply.

To the Editor of The New York Times: It is to be hoped that the splendid accomplishments of the new administration at Washington will not be marred by the adoption of the farm relief measures which are proposed by Secretary Wallace. ExSenator James A. Reed of Missouri is right in advocating abolition of the entire Department of Agriculture.

In consequence of the recent reorganization of the city's Relief Administration, a certain confusion has arisen in the public mind. Some have thought that it meant merging of the work of the Emergency Unemployment Relief Committee with that under control of Commissioner TAYLOR.

LYNCHBURG, Va., March 22 (AP). -- Dr. Fernando Wood Martin, formerly vice president of Randolph-Macon Woman's College and for thirty-six years head of its department of chemistry, died here today at the age of 69. He retired in 1929 as emeritus professor.

TOKYO, Thursday, March 23. -- Rumors that the National Cabinet was preparing to resign received special force yesterday from a long conference between Premier Saito and Viscount Takahashi, the Finance Minister.

Prices for commodities in local markets continued yesterday their downward trend in much lighter trading. For the most part the decline was the result of lack of buying interest. Cash prices, except in the case of cotton, were lower.

WASHINGTON, March 22. --Senator Borah today threw the weight of his influence behind the arms embargo resolution, alreday passed by the Senate, which is pending before the House Foreign Affairs Committee.

Magistrate Thomas F. Casey, in Brooklyn Homicide Court, set bail at $10,000 yesterday for Anthony Malandro, 17 years old, of 377 Atlantic Avenue, Brooklyn, charged with murdering his father, because the boy had gone to the defense of his mother.

The presence of Mrs. James Roosevelt, mother of the President, at the International Flower Show in the Grand Central Palace yesterday added to the interest of the judges and members of the committee in the awards for rose displays for private and commercial growers made during the day.

Wealth in times like the present is a stewardship, Myron C. Taylor, chairman of the board pf the United States Steel Corporation, told "business leaders yesterday at a luncheon at the Salvation Army at Gold Dust Lodge, 40 Corlears Street.

UTICA, N.Y., March 22 (AP). -- Valentine Bialas denied today that he or the others facing suspension had broken training. "We did the most conscientious training of our careers on this trip," he said.

Surface traffic on Broadway was tied up for three and a half hours, dozens of Broadway cellars were flooded and tons of water poured into the B.M.T. subway station at Broadway and Eighth Street, a block from the Wanamaker store, last night while firemen fought a stubborn blaze in the basement and sub-basement of a building which runs from 306 Mercer Street through to 747 Broadway.

Even before March 4, Mr. ROOSEVELT made it clear that one of the early acts of his Administration would be to abolish the Federal '' stabilization corporations " which have failed so signally since 1930 to stabilize the price of wheat and cotton.

ALBANY, March 22. -- With the Senate slated to approve the Wald mandatory minimum wage bill, affecting women and minors, Professor Felix Frankfurter of Harvard University issued a warning here today against any attempt to include men in such legislation on the ground that it would then be held unconstitutional.

The League of Human Rights, a newly formed organization headed by Dr. Frederick B. Robinson, president of the College of the City of New York, met last night at the Hotel Commodore and announced that it would seek a full report on the charges of persecution of Jews in Germany.
Gilbert Haven Durston of 39-46 Forty-sixth Street, Long Island City, died yesterday in the MidTown Hospital of complications following influenza after a week's illness.
