AINTREE, England, March 22. -- Though lightly regarded by the experts as well as the bookmakers, the traditional success of outsiders in the Grand National Steeplechase reacted today to the favor of Mrs. T.H. Somerville's Trouble Maker. The 10-year-old jumper is the only American homebred due to compete in the ninety-fourth running of the famous race on Friday.

Mayor O'Brien yesterday invited all classes of security holders of the B.M.T. and Interborough to organize committees with which he could immediately begin direct negotiations for early unification of rapid transit lines on a five-cent fare basis.

The eviction of three tenants from an apartment house at 219 Herzl Street, in the Brownsville district of Brooklyn, yesterday, caused a clash between sympathizers and police resulting in the arrest of twenty-three persons. Police were stationed on the roofs of near-by houses to prevent a recurrence of assaults from the air, a practice peculiar to that neighborhood during former disturbances, when bottles and other missies were hurled at the arresting officers.

WASHINGTON, March 22. -- Ambassador von Prittwitz and Gaffron of Germany called at the State Department today to advise that law and order would be maintained in Germany, and that fifteen Sturm Abteilung, or Storm Detachment, men who took part in the recent outrages against Jews had been dismissed and punished.

PHILADELPHIA, March 22. -- "Stay away from saloons" was the advice given today by Judge Joseph Buffington, dean of Federal judges as senior member of the Federal Circuit Court of Appeals, to sixty men and women who had just been accepted as naturalized citizens.
To the Editor of The New York Times: THE TIMES article "Making Paper From Pines" interested me, as I spent several years in the Southern yellow-pine belt.

WASHINGTON, March 22. -- President Roosevelt explained his unemployment relief measure to members of the Senate and House Labor and Education committees tonight and won their approval to his proposal, which aims to give employment to 250,000 men recruited in a civilian conservation corps for work in national forests.

Holders of bonds of the city of Asheville and Buncombe County, N.C., who have deposited their holdings with the protective committee will receive today their pro rata share of the $437,867 that is to be disbursed. Payment will be made through the Chase National Bank, depository for the committee, and will represent the fourth distribution in thirteen months.

PARIS, March 22. -- Such, private information as has trickled through to Paris from Germany in the last two days has brought no assertions of fresh racial persecutions there, and it is hoped again that such restraint as Chancellor Hitler is still able to impose on his followers is operating more efficaciously.

How the Chesapeake Ohio Railway was able to maintain its dividend in 1932 alone among the major lines is disclosed In the annual report of J.J. Bernet, president. The statement shows that although revenue tonnage decreased by 16.6 per cent to 52,344,542 in the year, the revenue for each mile of freight train movement was increased 6.3 per cent to $10.323 and revenue tonnage for each train-mile by 7.3 per cent to 1,745 tons.

WASHINGTON, March 22. -- Appeals for a French national subscription to erect a monument in Paris to the memory of Aristide Briand have been received here. The national subscription, the circular said, has the official support of the French Government, and the President of France is acting as president of the committee of patrons.

WASHINGTON, March 22 (AP). -- Announcement that Brazil would accept the League of Nations' invitation to participate in the work of an advisory committee handling the Leticia dispute between Colombia and Peru was received in a cablegram to the Colombian Legation today from Rio de Janeiro.

Federal legislation forbidding the employment of any person in Industry more than thirty hours a week during the existing emergency was advocated by the board of managers of the Silk Association of America, Inc., at its annual meeting yesterday at the association's headquarters. Enactment of Federal emergency legislation permitting economic planning "through, concerted action and cooperation in production and distribution" was also urged in another resolution adopted by the board.

Alderman Francis D. McGarey, who represents the Wiliamsburg District of Brooklyn, was appointed yesterday as counsel to the Board of Transportation, after a year's deadlock between John H. Delaney, chairman of the Board of Transportation, and John H. McCooey, Brooklyn Democratic leader.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 22. -- Three men in a boat. Reading from left to right, they are Sam Breadon, Branch Rickey and Gabby Street. They are worrying about the Cardinal in field for 1933. "We have the greatest pitching staff you ever saw!" says Owner Sam Breadon.

WASHINGTON, March 22. -- Mrs. Nellie Tayloe Ross, vice chairman of the Democratic National Committee and a former Governor of Wyoming, is slated to be made United States Treasurer and Mrs. Ruth Bryan Owen is thought likely to get a position in the State Department.

WASHINGTON, March 22 (AP). -- Robert Worth Bingham of Kentucky, President Roosevelt's choice for the major American diplomatic assignment, Ambassador to Great Britain, was confirmed today by the Senate within a few hours after his nomination had been approved by the Committee on Foreign Relations.

The five-story, eightsen-family tenement house at 1,193 First Ayenue has been sold for an estate through Howard LeC. Roome, Inc., to a client of Ecker Ecker, lawyers. The purchaser will remodel the house, which fronts 25 feet on the avenue between Sixty-fourth and Sixty-fifth Streets.

DALLAS, Texas, March 22. -- Air travel on an international scale has brought the problem of mosquito "stowaways" in planes spreading yellow and dengue fever in South American countries to the United States, Dr. T.H.D. Griffits, of the Public Health Service, told the Pan-American Medical Congress today.
COMMERCIAL PAPER. Yesterday ..3 per cent for the best names. Tuesday ...3 1/2 per cent for the best names. The quotations are for three-four months' paper.

A team of New York boxers enjoyed considerable success in the interstate amateur bouts which featured the program at Madison Square Garden last night. Appearing against combinations of picked battlers from Massachusetts, Virginia, Pennsylvania and Rhode Island, the local warriors emerged triumphant in eleven out of fifteen bouts.

PARIS, March 22. -- Rene Richard's proposal to authorize the government to pay the debt instalment due the United States last December was deferred by the Chamber of Deputies when it came before the Foreign Affairs Commission this afternoon.

Hundreds of readers read thousands of books and sent in 5,000,000 quotations on which to build the Oxford English Dictionary. The work of preparation started in 1857; the first volume was published at the Clarendon Press, Oxford, in 1888; the final volume came out in 1928.

CAMDEN, S.C., March 22. -- Our Friend, bay gelding, owned and ridden by Miss Page Lewis of Toledo, Ohio, and Westport, Conn., captured the hunter championship at the twenty-third annual Camden horse show today. Scamper Joe, owned by Miss Edith Wills of Greenwich, Conn., took the reserve prize.

ALBANY, March 22. -- With 3.2 per cent beer legalized by President Roosevelt's signature, Governor Lehman and legislative leaders speeded their program today to bring about controlled sale of the foaming beverage in New York State by 12:01 A.M. April 7.

The Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company, one of the "big four" in the tire industry, announced yesterday that it was discontinuing its third and fourth-line tires and would henceforth concentrate on its first and second-line output. Its step is in line with the policy announced by the B.F. Goodrich Company and the United States Rubber Company on Tuesday.
LOS ANGELES, March 22. -- Putting on a performance of wide variety, the Giants upset the highly touted Pirates today in the opening clash of a three-game series, winning by 6 to 5.

Fire Commissioner John J. Dorman, who urged Secretary of the Treasury Woodin in Washington yesterday to order the release of $668,915 Fire Department relief funds tied up in the Harriman National Bank and Trust Company, on the ground that they are trust accounts, telephoned his New York office after the interview that he felt extremely hopeful of success.

GENEVA, March 22. -- Members of the Leticia advisory committee of the League of Nations decided at a private meeting today to consult the various governments as to whether they were prepared to accept the principle of an arms embargo against Peru if Peru opposed by military force the execution of the Council's recommendations of March 18 for withdrawal from territory seized by Colombia.

Hardly Skin Deep. If a delegation of nudists could be persuaded to attend the annual conventlon of International Beauty Shop Owners the results might be interesting. A nudist is a person who believes in going back to nature to the extent of taking off all his clothes.

After a discussion of the crisis in public relief yesterday, the Coordinating Committee on Unemployment of the Welfare Council issued a statement approving the proposals for centralizing control of all public relief under a committee of five, but declared that the members of the committee must be able and informed citizens who will administer the law "in accordance with the best standards of social work."
"Sweepings," the RKO Radio film version of the novel by Lester Cohen, with Lionel Barrymore in the leading role, will open at the Radio City Music Hall this morning.

Lief Nordlie, professional at the Sleepy Hollow Country Club, advanced to the semi-final round of the world's open squash tennis championship last night at the Fraternity Club by eliminating the only remaining amateur in the tourney. Leonard Green, in a four-game match.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, March 22 (AP). -- Dr. Fonsa A. Lambert, widely known as an authority on football rules, died early today in a hospital here of wounds suffered when he was shot by his son, Samuel, 17, during a family quarrel yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 22 (AP). -- Senator Johnson of California laid before the Senate today a sheaf of legislation calling for rigid regulation and full publicity for all foreign loans underwritten in the United States.
ALBANY, March 22. -- Republican and Democratic leaders of the Legislature reached an agreement today to cut 58,799,627 from Governor Lehman's $216,000,000 budget.

Siam's new Minister to the United States, Prince Damras Damrong Devakula, cousin of the King, arrived yesterday with his wife, Princess Aradipya, and their three children, two girls and a boy, on the North German Lloyd liner Europa.

WASHINGTON, March 22 -- When the farm bill comes up in the Senate for discussion it will be coupled with demands for currency inflation on the part of those Senators who demanded an expanded but controlled currency in the last session.

Three men said to have used the name Hirsch became the focal point of interest in Judge Nott's part of General Sessions Court yesterday as the trial of Louis H. Willard, Bronx real estate dealer, on charges of perjury growing out of his testimony against William J. Flynn, Public Works Commissioner of the Bronx, before the Hofstadter committee, continued.

CHICAGO, March 22. -- Leading railroad presidents, members of the board of directors of the American Railway Association, met with operators of private car lines here today to discuss a proposal of the railroads to reduce by one-fourth cent the mileage allowance given to operators of such equipment.

Harry F. Wolf of the New York L.C., who equaled the record of Nillmore Hyde of the Harvard Club his year in winning the national amateur squash tennis championship for the fourth time, heads the ranking list of the National Squash Tennis Association for the fourth successive year.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Many of your readers are undoubtedly familiar with the recent announcement of the Public Library, limiting each borrower to two books. Economy evidently conceived this ruling, but certainly not common sense, and at that it is false economy.

Work on two new incinerators, one in upper Manhattan and the other in the Bronx, was started officially yesterday with ground-breaking ceremonies conducted by Mayor O'Brien and a number of city officials, including Dr. William Schroeder Jr., chairman of the Sanitary Commission; Sheriff Joseph T. Higgins, Christie R. Bohnsack, director of Municipal Station WNYC, and others.
WASHINGTON, March 32. -- The Bureau of Navigation Issued the following orders today:
BERLIN, March 22. -- The opening session of the recently elected Prussian Diet today passed off just as quickly and quietly as yesterday's initial meeting of the Reichstag.

Mary Menk's debut recital last night in the Town Hall opened with the Bach-Siloti Fantasia in C minor, followed by the Bach-Siloti organ prelude in G minor and Mozart's variations in A major. It continued with Beethoven's sonata Op. 13.

MIAMI, Fla., March 22. -- Mrs. A. Carfano's General A., three times a winner and three times second at Hialeah Park, scored his first victory of the Tropical Park meeting today when he charged forward from last place in a field of six to triumph by a head.

HACKENSACK, N.J., March 22. -- Dr. Walter Rautenstrauch Jr., 27 years old, son of Dr. Walter Rautenstrauch, a Columbia University professor, formerly identified with Howard Scott in the technocracy movement, has been named defendant in a $50,000 breach of promise suit instituted by Miss Victoria Sutphen, 27 years old, of Jersey City, it became known here today.

Municipal Court Justice Thomas E. Murray, who has been on the bench for more than forty years, issued an order yesterday calling on David J. Rosen, an attorney, with offices at 1,767 Broadway, to show cause on Tuesday why he should not be punished for contempt.

BERLIN, March 22. -- After yesterday's holiday the Boerse opened buoyant today, a considerable number of the more active shares registering substantial advances over Monday. In later trading, however, prices sagged, the decline being attributed to realizing by professional traders.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The Topic of The Times "Italy's Power Balance," while most reasonably dismissing any dictatorial boasting of Mr. MacDonald's visit to Rome, ends with the remark that the head of the present Italian regime "merely follows in the footsteps of his democratic-parliamentary predecessors in practicing sa- cred egoism."

The proposed development of the Chrystie-Forsyth Street area through the erection of model tenements would neither solve the slum problem nor contribute toward the proper re-creation of the lower east side unless the project were heavily subsidized by the city, George McAneny, president of the Regional Plan Association and chairman of the Advisory Board on City Planning of the Board of Estimate, declared yesterday.

BERLIN, March 22 (AP). -- The only check now restraining the Nazis from overrunning everybody appears to be the determination of Vice Chancellor Franz von Papen not to let a Hitlerite have the coveted post of Prussian Premier.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., March 22. -- The chemical elements in nine meteors which never touched the earth were announced today at Harvard Astronomical Observatory.

A resale of a Jersey City cornel flat for the fourth time since last June was included in the New Jersey realty conveyances reported yesterday. The building, a four-story, sixteen-family brick structure at 34 Orient Avenue, northwest corner of Rose Avenue, was bought from John P. Zemboski by Rose Aberbach of the Bronx.
Lease of space to new tenants in mid-Manhattan business buildings were reported in large numbers yesterday.
The case of the United States Government against Charles E. Mitchell, former chairman of the National City Bank, on the charge of incoms-tax evasion was presented to the Federal grand jury yesterday.

INDIANAPOLIS, March 22 (AP). -- Southwestern Indiana's river cities awaited the flood crests on the Ohio and Wabash today, although from Weather Bureau predictions it appeared that the flood would pass with the inundation only of lowlands.
NEW YORK. Mr. and Mrs. James R. Sheffield have returned from South Carolina to 45 East Sixty-seventh Street.
The opening date for "Ann Adams, Spinster," at the Sutton Theatre, has been set back to Saturday night. The opening had been scheduled for this evening.

Unusual police arrangements, as the result of a telephone call from the State Department in Washington, were being planned last night for the protection of Yosuke Matsuoka. chief Japanese delegate at recent League of Nations meetings on the Manchurian conflict, who is to arrive here tomorrow morning aboard the Leviathan.

WASHINGTON, March 22. -- Three resolutions to authorize the State Department to protest formally to Germany against attacks on United States citizens of Jewish origin resident in Germany were introduced today in the House.

The Pennroad Corporation, the investment company formed by the Pennsylvania Railroad to further its plans for railway consolidation, reported yesterday a net income of $793,897 in 1932, against $4,495,046 in 1931. No dividends were paid in 1932 and, consequently, the full year's income was added to surplus, bringing that account to $9,060,111.

ALBANY, March 22. -- Chances for the enactment of Governor Lehman's eight-point program for closer regulation of public utilities appeared bright tonight, with supporters, of the Governor confident that the Legislature would approve the major part of the recommendations.

The Studebaker Corporation, which was placed in receivership several days ago, reported yesterday for 1932 a net loss of $8,279,805, in contrast with a net profit for 1931 of $859,805. The report for last year excludes the operations of the White Motor Company which was acquired Oct. 18, 1932.

BOSTON, March 22. -- Arguing that there could be no satisfactory "new deal" in the nation until a solution of unemployment was worked out, Edward A. Filene suggested tonight that, as a practical test of the thirty-hour week, the government establish a $500,000,000 fund to back employers in trying it out.

The Rev. Dr. George M. Ellsbree, 57 years old, former pastor of the Chelsea Presbyterian Church, Chelsea Avenue near Atlantic Avenue, Atlantic City. N.J., was found dead yesterday in a furnished room at 123 East Fifteenth Street, the cord of a bathrobe knotted about his throat.

The report of the Pan American Petroleum and Transport Company from May 1, 1932, the effective date of the sale of its foreign properties, to Dec, 31 last, as shown in its application to list its new $5 par shares on the New York Stock Exchange, details a net loss of 527,756 after all charges and reserves.
After having lost all grains made last week, prices on the Cotton Exchange steadied yesterday and closed at net advances of 2 to 8 points.

While merchants are strongly opposed to a State retail sales tax, they believe that if such a levy is to be enacted it should take the "less harmful" form of a mandatory stamp tax, Grover Whalen, general manager of John Wanamaker, said yesterday on behalf of the retailers' committee on the sales tax, of which he is chairman.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 22. -- In a ten-minute conference at the home of Babe Ruth today, the famous home-run slugger and Colonel Jacob Ruppert, owner of the Yankees, reached an agreement in the much-discussed salary dispute. The Babe consented to sign a oneyear contract for $52,000.
Mayor O'Brien's statement outlining his plan for transit negotiations follows:

PEARY LODGE, Thule, Greenland, March 10 (By Wireless to Copenhagen). -- The first Winter visitor to Peary Lodge was Abel Danielsen, a Greenlander, who served with the Danish explorers Professor Peter Freuchen, Dr. Lauge Koch and Professor Knud Rasmussen.

PALM BEACH, Fla., March 23. -- Inaugurating a series of entertainments to be held at intervals this Spring and Summer, the Sun and Surf Club tonight gave a supper dance on the new floor on the stone terrace facing the ocean. A large number of members and guests were present.

Representatives of security holders' groups of the Interborough, the B.M.T. and the Manhattan elevated lines responded yesterday to Mayor O'Brien's Invitation to discuss transit unification with an alacrity that Indicated that they were not unprepared for his invitation.

Plans to defeat the passage of the Dickstein bill, which would ban the employment of foreign players unless they are of "distinguished merit or ability," will be discussed this afternoon at a meeting of the board of governors of the League of New York Theatres.

WASHINGTON, March 23. -- A bill to control the marketing of securities so that the interests of the investing public will be carefully guarded is being prepared by experts of the administration in consultation with Congressional leaders and probably will be ready for the consideration ou President Roosevelt early next week.

Robert A. Fairbairn, one of the best-known members of the Jockey Club, was elected yesterday to be the seventh steward of the organization, which is the governing body of the turf sport in this State. Mr. Fairbairn's election fills the vacancy caused by the death of the late F.K. Sturgis, one of the original members of the Jockey Club, which was formed in 1894.

ELIZABETH, N.J., March 23. -- Two men were killed, two others were seriously injured and six others were slightly burned when the tower of a crude oil still at the Bayway refinery of the Standard Oil Company blew off this morning and showered the vicinity of the still with blazing oil.

WASHINGTON, March 23. -- Discontinuance of the proceeding instituted upon the complaint of the Dollar Steamship Line, under Section 20-2 of the merchant marine act of 1920 to determine a question of membership discrimination against that line by the Japan, China and Straits Bombay Conference, was ordered today by the Shipping Board.

German Developments. BERLIN -- The Reichstag passed by a vote of 441 to 94 yesterday the enabling act that permits the Cabinet to make laws without consulting that body and without action by the President. The prerogatives of the President, including dismissal of the Chancellor, were preserved.

LONDON, March 23. -- Prime Minister MacDonald told Parliament today of his mission with Sir John Simon, the Foreign Secretary, to Geneva to save the disarmament conference and to Rome to reconstruct the political situation in Europe by revision of treaties as an indispensable preliminary to peace.

CHICAGO, March 23. -- Raymond W. Stevens, ex-president of the defunct Illinois Life Insurance Company, shot himself this afternoon at his country home, The Meadows, in Highland Park. He died half an hour later on the operating table in the Highland Park Hospital.

PHILADELPHIA, March 23. -- Youth had its day in the court tennis championship today as the youngest quartet of players to gain the semi-finals of the national amateur tournament in many years came through the second round of competition at the Racquet Club.

The Committee of Twenty on Street and Outdoor Cleanliness, of which Dr. Bernard Sachs is chairman, met yesterday afternoon at the New York Academy of Medicine to confer with Jere F. Ryan, Commissioner of Markets, regarding ways to improve conditions in the city's open-air markets.

WASHINGTON, March 23. -- A program for lightening the farm mortgage burden which would involve from $1,000,000,000 to $2.000,000,000 of refinancing by the government, according to some estimates, was approved today by President Roosevelt at a conference with Democratic Congressional leaders.

A sentence of from two to four years in Sing Sing was imposed yesterday by Judge Corrigan in General Sessions on Michael Favaloro, 27 years old, of 227 East 100th Street, who, in the early morning of July 26, 1931, while intoxicated, drove his taxicab into the East River at Twenty-third Street, drowning four of its seven passengers.

A plan for segregating in a new company certain assets of North American Aviation, Inc., after which the latter company will acquire substantially all assets of General Aviation Corporation in exchange for North American stock, was approved yesterday by the directors of the two companies.

McKee District Votes. A map of Manhattan showing the distribution of civic virtue and arithmetical ability by Assembly Districts, on the basis of the corrected McKee vote, would reveal surprising results.

WASHINGTON, March 23. -- Interested observers of the trend of the Hitler policy are, of course, more numerous in Washington than anywhere else in the United States, since they include the personnel of all embassies and legations, some members of Congress, a group in the State Department and several administration, officials.

Mayor O'Brien announced last night the appointment of the five members of the newly formed Unemployment and Home Relief Executive Committee which will succeed the Emergency Work and Relief Administration, whose fifteen members have resigned.

An appeal to civic and welfare organizations to oppose certain bills now before the State Legislature to amend the multiple dwelling law was issued yesterday by the Multiple Dwelling Law Committee, of which Lawson Furdy is chairman and Harold Riegelman counsel.

While rejecting the idea of nationalist separatism, Albert Einstein, in a message yesterday to the American Palestine Campaign called upon all Jews to stand together in this hour of their trial. Professor Einstein's message was sent from the Belgenland, on which he is bound for Antwerp, and is to be read at the dinner on March 29 at the Hotel Astor in honor of Nathan Straus Jr.

MILAN, March 23 (AP). -- All the forces of the Fascist revolution are "intact and formidable," said Premier Mussolini today in a message to Fascisti who massed here to observe the fourteenth anniversary of the founding of the movement.

DETROIT, March 23 (AP) -- John Thomas Smith, spokesman for Alfred P. Sloan Jr., announced that James McAvoy, chief of the General Motors Corporation legal staff, has been named acting president of the new national bank. The institution temporarily will be operated by directors chosen from the corporation's organization, Mr. Smith said.

Fifteen Manhattan and Bronx properties were acquired by plain tiffs at foreclosure auctions yesterday. Most of the liquidated properties were apartment houses and dwellings. The plaintiffs bid in the properties to protect their liens.

Forty writers and publishers met yesterday afternoon at the home of Fannie Hurst, 27 West Sixty-seventh Street, to consider means of compelling the State Senate to hold a public hearing on the "bad book" bill, sponsored, by the National Council on Freedom from Censorship.
BAY SHORE, L.I., March 23. -- George Cox, a native of Brooklyn, is dead at his home in Argyle Park, Babylon, where he had been ill for several months with heart disease. His age was 76.

WASHINGTON, March 23. -- The Association of Railway Executives has notified the Interstate Commerce Commission that there will be no further pooling of revenues from the emergency freight rate surcharges, as was suggested by the commission in a decision on March 13 authorizing continued collection of the higher rates until Sept. 30.
WASHINGTON, March 23. -- Nathan R. Margold of New York City was appointed today solicitor for the Department of the Interior.

Crowds of flower-lovers are still thronging Grand Central Palace, forgetting in the pleasure of the gorgeous exhibits that March can still produce snow and frost. All the lovely old standbys are there -- great red roses, delicate trembling acacias, hosts of the azalea family in full flower, and the perfect symbol of Spring, the bulbs.

To the Editor of The New York Times: President Roosevelt's plan for putting gangs of unemployed to work in the national forests is objectionable in many ways, and one objection is that the plan would mean the ruination of the beauty of the forests.

PHILADELPHIA, March 23. -- A plea to the nation's leaders to solve domestic problems and set our own national house in order as "the road to freedom from world wars and to prosperity" was made tonight by Dr. Wallace B. Donham, dean of the Harvard Graduate School of Business Administration, speaking at the University of Pennsylvania's fourth Wharton Alumni Institute of Business.
A sweeping recovery in the strength of the Federal Reserve System and its member banks was revealed in the report for the week ended Wednesday, published last night.
ALBANY, March 23. -- The Wald bill, creating a mandatory system of minimum wages for women and minors in industry, was passed by the Senate today by a vote of 37 to 13, after an hour of sharp debate.
WASHINGTON, March 23. -- The Bureau of Navigation issued the following orders today, dated March 21:

BUENOS AIRES, March 23. -- The Bolivian forces in the Chaco have begun an attack on Fort Gondra, twenty miles north of Fort Nanawa, which the Paraguayans call Fort Ayala. This is an important move in the plan of General Hans Kundt to surround and isolate Nanawa, which is Paraguay's strongest position in the Chaco.

HAVANA, March 23. -- The military censors confiscated today 115 copies of the April issue of the American, magazine. Current History, because of an article on the Cuban situation written by Russell B. Porter.

MIAMI, Fla., March 23. -- The Sir Greysteel filly, Boscobel, which carries the colors of J.E. Smallman, was an easy winner of the Tamiami Purse, feature at Tropical Park today. Over a fast track and with the feather of 100 pounds in the saddle Boscobel, 3 to 1 shot, scored by four lengths over Starboard Light.

CHICAGO, March 83. -- The perfect beer is the 3.2 per cent brew that America is about to consume, according to Dr. Max Henius, who for fifty years has devoted himself to analysis and synthesis of the foam-collared beverage.

WASHINGTON, March 23. -- By a vote of 180 to 53 this afternoon the House passed the Palmisano bill legalizing the sale of 3.2 per cent beer in the District of Columbia when the national act becomes operative on April 7.

New York trust companies, savings banks and other financial institutions which are large holders of guaranteed mortgages are preparing to cooperate fully with the mortgage guarantee companies as soon as permissive legislation, now before the Senate committee on banks in Albany, has been adopted by the State Legislature.

Scarcely a day passes without record of some Post of the American Legion voting to stand by the President, in revising the pensions and allowances of veterans. In many cases this represents a reversal of previous action, seemingly official.

When a word is not a word and why is the perplexing problem that the Municipal Court, assisted by a battery of dictionaries and three Columbia University professors, is attempting to decide, President Justice Edgar J. Lauer revealed yesterday.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The newspaper reports about representations being made by our government on behalf of the unhappy German Jewish victims of Nazi barbarism raise some important questions.

Stockholders of Stone Webster, Inc., voted yesterday to reduce the board of directors from twenty-two to fourteen. Those elected were Henry G. Bradlee, W. Cameron Forbes, Joseph P. Grace, George O. Muhlfeld, Thomas N. Perkins, Herbert L. Pratt, Russell Robb, Charles A. Stone, Whitney Stone, Eliot Wadsworth, Walter B. Walker, Edwin S. Webster, Edwin S. Webster Jr. and Albert H. Wiggin.

Corporation bonds rallied yesterday in fairly active trading on the Stock Exchange under the leadership of the rails, while foreign loans and United States Government bonds finished irregularly lower. Total transactions in bonds in the listed market amounted to $10,973,000, compared with $10,310,000 on the previous day.

PALO ALTO, March 23. -- With a loaded .38-calibre pistol in his pocket, William Compogiani, 55 years old, a Burlingame theatre janitor, odd-job man and former wrestler, went to visit former President Hoover at his home on the Stanford Campus yesterday.

Action by the City of New York to bring about the intercession of the United States Government in behalf of German Jews was foreshadowed yesterday when Alderman James F. Kiernan made public a resolution he will introduce to this effect when the board meets next Tuesday.

An established ring engaged in compensation insurance frauds has grown up in Brooklyn, where it is aided by a staff of "reputable" cestors and lawyers, according to Jerome G. Locke, deputy commissioner of the United States Employes Compensation Commission.

WASHINGTON, March 23. -- If present measures taken by the administration do not materially relieve unemployment and bring money into circulation, there will be new demands in Congress for inflation, it was admitted today even by Senators who have been among the strongest upholders of "sound money."

Mayor O'Brien named yesterday a committee of fifteen, headed by Peter Grimm, chairman of the Citizens' Budget Commission, to survey the city's needs for additional water from the Delaware River watershed, a project involving $272,000,000.

ATLANTIC HIGHLANDS, N.J., March 23. -- Al Lillien, one of the reputed leaders of a rum ring that operated in this section, was shot to death today in the old Hammerstein homestead here, which was used as a base of operations.

In 1931 the people of New York State, by an overwhelming vote, approved an amendment to the Constitution calling for large-scale reforestation of marginal lands now put to no productive use. In order to insure steady and orderly progress in carrying out the Reforestation Commission's program, there was incorporated in the amendment itself a definite schedule of annual appropriations, from $1,000,000 up, to be expended over a period of eleven years.

Among the many extraordinary phenomena of the present economic situation the recent piling up of gold in the Bank of England has not heen the least remarkable. Four months ago, when the British Government paid the Decemher instalment on the war debt and the Bank's gold holdings were drawn upon for that purpose, their total decrease in a week was u19,600,000.

NEWARK, N.J., March 23. -- With the semi-monthly municipal payroll of $400,000 overdue one week, the city was advised today by Newark bankers who have been aiding the Commission in its finances that they had been unable to sell any new Newark bond issues.

LONDON, March 23. -- The Metro-politan-Vickers Electrical Company announced today that it had received a message from the Soviet Ambassador to London, I.M. Maisky, intimating that the public prosecutor in Moscow was ready to admit to bail W.H. Thornton, John Cushny and a fitter named Gregory.

BERLIN, March 23. -- Reports of agitation in the United States on behalf of German Jews is hotly resented in the National Socialist newspapers, which regard it as unjustifiable interference with German affairs and propaganda calculated to arouse hostility toward Germany and the new regime.
WASHINGTON, March 23. -- The text of the State banking aid bill, which is an amendment to the emergency banking act, is as follows:

Contrary to the general impression that bootleg beer is of a stronger alcoholic content than that to be allowed when beer becomes legal on April 7, Amos W. W. Woodcock, prohibition director, who came here from Washington yesterday, said that most of the bootleg breweries in the country have been making 3.2 per cent beer right along.

CHARLESTON, S.C., March 23. -- Archie Hambrick, Zanesville, Ohio, today led a field of seventy in the first round of the Charleston open golf tournament. He had an 18-hole score of 66, five under the Wappoo course par.

Supporting his charges that the perjury prosecution of Louis H. Willard had been inspired by William J. Flynn, Public Works Commissioner of the Bronx, for revenge, Irving Ben Cooper, Willard's counsel, elicited yesterday from a reluctant State witness the story of a party where five of the witnesses met Flynn at dinner.

WASHINGTON, March 23. -- Technicians engaged here in investigating the possibilities of a change in American tariff policy have decided that the "most-favored-nation" and reciprocity systems can be reconciled, inquiry today brought out.

CHICAGO, March 23 (AP). -- Favorites, many of them representing high schools of less than 200 students, reached the second round of the National Catholic School basketball championship, no unsets being recorded in the eleven games decided today.

BERLIN, March 23 (AP). -- Informed quarters report the dispute over the Premiership of Prussia as the first serious break between Adolf Hitler's Nazis and their government associates, the Nationalists.

MIAMI, Fla., March 23 (AP). -- Gilford Clobridge, 33, formerly of Staten Island, N.Y., was arrested here today and charged with sending Colonel Charles A. Lindbergh at Hopewell, N.J., an extortion letter demanding $50,000.

DETROIT, Mich., March 23. -- Capitalized at $25,000,000, equally provided by General Motors and the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, a new bank will open for business here tomorrow morning, in the banking offices now occupied by the First National Bank-Detroit.

WASHINGTON, March 23. -- Appointment as circuit judge in the Eighth district was formally offered by President Roosevelt today to Arthur F. Mullen, National Committeeman from Nebraska, who had figured as a possibility for Attorney General.

LONDON, March 23 (By Wireless). -- Captain Hermann Wilhelm Goering, who holds four posts in the present German Government, is rapidly becoming the real power in the Cabinet and Chancellor Hitler is merely the window-dressing, according to well-informed people in Berlin, who only whisper this in private places where the acoustics is not very good.

Some apples by Robert Brackman, in his one-man show at the Macbeth Gallery, ought, for purposes of comparison and demonstration, to be carried across the street and into Durand-Ruel's, where the Monet exhibition, previously discussed, is current.

Thomas Patrick Morris, whose claim to the $35,000,000 fortune of Ella Von E. Wendel as the son of her brother, John Gottlieb Wendel, was thrown out as fraudulent by Surrogate Foley, with the result that Morris was indicted with others for second-degree forgery, testified yesterday that he had a "secret agreement" with Samuel Untermyer and Arthur Garfield flays in connection with his claim.

PEIPING, March 23 (AP). -- Chinese resistance against Japanese invaders in Manchuria and Jehol will continue "until the Chinese flag again flies therein," General Ho Ying-ching, the War Minister and new military overlord of North China, said today.

Sixteen prizes for sculptures and porcelains exhibited at the International Horse Show of Art in the Knoedler Galleries, 14 East Fifty-seventh Street, were awarded yesterday afternoon, when four classes of the exhibits were judge'd by Maud Earl and M. Parish-Watson

CHICAGO, March 23. -- Discussion of a plan to name a railroad dictator with full power to end "wasteful practices" took place at a meeting here today of leading rail executives of the country. The idea is said to be part of the program of President Roosevelt to strengthen the financial position of the railroads.

At the Gridiron Club dinners in Washington the fifty newspaper correspondents who are the club's members hold to the rule, "ladies always present and reporters never present." Now, for the first time, what a President of the United States said at eight of these dinners is to be published.

Alexander Forsyth, 24 years old, master of the steamer Observation, of West New Brighton, S.I., was absolved last evening of any criminal blame in connection with the explosion that wrecked the steamer last Sept. 9 on the East River, killing seventy-two men and injuring many others.
Egon Petri will give a piano recital at the Greenwich House Music School tonight.

About $200 was realized in the exchange of old gold articles for cash and $10 for silver items at the barter party held last night under the auspices of the American Woman's Association at its clubhouse, 353 West Fifty-seventh Street.

The Missouri Pacific Railroad will take action under the recent amendment to the bankruptcy act in advance of completion of a readjustment proposal, according to plans discussed yesterday. This move would be made in order to meet near-by financial obligations.

Charles E. Mitchell, former chairman of the National City Bank, retained Max D. Steuer, noted trial lawyer, yesterday to defend him against the charge of evading payment of his 1929 Federal income tax.

Andrew Ponzi gained slightly on James Caras in their pocket billiard match at Jack Doyle's Academy yesterday, but continued to trail in total points, 1,000 to 892. Ponzi won the afternoon block, 172 to 125, in eighteen innings, but lost at night, 135 to 92, in ten innings.
BERLIN, March 23. -- Following are the most important sections of the address of Chancellor Adolf Hitler at today's session of the Reichstag:

LOS ANGELES, March 23. -- Eleanor Boardman, motion-picture actress, filed a petition in superior court here today amending her complaint for separate maintenance, filed several months ago, to one seeking a divorce from King Vidor, motion-picture director.

GENEVA, March 23. -- With even its fathers not daring to support it publicly, the Italo-British plan for the immediate recess of the disarmament conference for a month, to allow the four great powers to discuss secretly the Mussolini pact, perished this morning.
AINTREE, England, March 23 (AP). -- Post time for the ninety-third renewal of the Grand National Steeplechase tomorrow is 3 P.M. (10 A.M. Eastern Standard Time).

WASHINGTON, March 23. -- Dr. James M. Doran, Commissioner of Industrial Alcohol, declared today that he saw no reason why America should not have a five-cent glass of beer when the legalized brew is available on the morning of April 7.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., March 23. -- Because of superior conditions in the Payne Whitney gymnasium swimming pool, several records are likely to be shattered in the tenth annual National Collegiate Athletic Association championship meet tomorrow and Saturday.
WARSAW, March 23 (Jewish Telegraphic Agency) -- Twenty-five new attacks are charged in an official complaint lodged by the Polish Ambassador with the German Ministry of Foreign Affairs.
LONDON, March 23 (AP) -- A detailed account of his affair with a German woman, "fair and about 22," was told by Lieutenant Balllie-Stewart today.

A reduction of 10 per cent in the pay and working time of all salaried employes of the United States Steel Corporation, beginning on April 1, was announced yesterday. Wage earners in the company's plants will not be affected. Several other steel companies adopted the plan of time off without pay for "white-collar" workers last year.

WASHINGTON, March 23. -- Hearings on the Dickstein resolution authorizing the State Department to facilitate immigration passports from Germany will be opened next Wednesday morning, Chairman Dickstein of the immigration committee announced this afternoon, and leading Jews, Catholics and Protestants will be called to testify.

WASHINGTON, March 23. -- Mrs. Roosevelt's last day in the capital on the eve of her impending visit to New York was crowded with special engagements, including a White House luncheon, a symphony concert in the afternoon and a reception given tonight in her honor by the District of Columbia League of American Penwoment.

When Captain John Houston Craige of the United States Marines first visited Haiti in 1912 he was "a young man in search of revolutions," accompanied by a large man named Hennessey, "a gunrunner by trade." They stood together at the ship's rail looking at Port au Prince and Hennessey called the town "Black Bagdad."
LONDON, March 23. -- Catholic priests and prelates here are deeply stirred by the almost daily reports of attacks on Jews in Germany, although no official statements for the church have been made.
Andrew W. Mellon, retiring Ambassador to London, will return today on the United States liner Leviathan, accompanied by his daughter, Mrs. David K.E. Bruce.
WASHINGTON, March 23. -- The White House is to have a swimming pool soon, but the money will not come from the Treasury.

Holders of the preferred stocks of the Central Public Service Corporation have been notified that the time limit for depositing the stocks for shares in the Central Public Utility Corporation, under the exchange agreement of Aug. 15, 1932, has been extended from April 1 to June 5.

WASHINGTON, D.C., March 23. -- Prosecutions In connection with the affairs of the Harriman National Bank and Trust Company of New York were delayed for several months by United States Attorney George Z. Medalie on instructions from Washington, Attorney General Cummings disclosed today.

ROME, March 23. -- "What we wanted in that distant Spring of 1919 is today Italian reality and will tomorrow be European reality," said Premier Mussolini today in a message addressed to the Italian nation on the fourteenth anniversary of the founding of fascism, which was celebrated with great solemnity throughout Italy.
Leo Collins, Block Hall professional, and Thomas Iannicelli of the Essex Club survived their semi-final matches in the world's open squash tennis tournament at the Fraternity Club last night.

In his first public address since assuming the presidency of the American Museum of Natural History, F. Trubee Davison, former Assistant Secretary of War for Aviation, emphasized yesterday the reluctance with which he is curtailing museum activities, especially in view of ever-increasing educational demands upon the institution.
WASHINGTON. March 23. -- The War Department issued the following orders today:

Louis Propp, 42 years old, wealthy electrical engineer and a director of the Noma Electric Corporation of 524 Broadway, was Instantly frilled yesterday noon when he fell or jumped from the bedroom of his apartment on the ninth floor of 590 West End Avenue and landed in the rear courtyard of the building.

WOODBURY, Conn., March. 23. -- Leaders in the Protestant Episcopal Church will gather here Saturday at the Glebe House to celebrate the 150th anniversary of the election to the episcopate of the Right Rev. Samuel Seabury, the first Bishop of that communion in the United States.

A bill now before the General Assembly in Connecticut is attracting a great deal of attention among fishermen of the Nutmeg State. The bill is to have a hearing shortly with the State Fish and Game Commission, of which Thomas H. Beck is chairman, heading the opposition.
LONDON, MarcL 23. -- Negotiations between the Cunard and White Star lines, which Neville Chamberlain made known yesterday, may result in a closer working agreement if not actual amalgamation.

Gloucester, famed fishing port out on the jaw of Cape Ann, will be the distance objective of the New York Yacht Club cruise. The rendezvous will be on Aug. 9 at New London, Conn., instead of at Glen Cove, the club's Long Island station.

It now seems probable that the Legislature at Albany will vote a sales tax in order to raise the money needed to extinguish the State deficit. The various bills are still under revision. Governor LEHMAN proposed a rate of three-quarters of 1 per cent, but it is now stated that the leaders of both parties favor a tax perhaps graduated up to 2 per cent.

It was Arturo Toscanini who in due course drew from the shelves Mendelssohn's "Reformation" symphony and by the insight and beauty of his interpretation placed the work securely in the Philharmonic-Symphony repertory.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., March 23. -- With twenty-seven knockouts to his credit in thirty-one bouts, Joe Moran of Niagara Falls and 155-pound member of the Syracuse University squad, has hung up his gloves for good.

The "American Home" achievement medal was awarded yesterday by the Federated Garden Clubs of New York to Mrs. George Shor of the Garden Club of Dobbs Ferry for her unusual terrarium, a planting of small native mosses and ferns in a large glass bubble.

GEORGE MCANENY, SAMUEL UNTERMYER, JOHN DELANEY, Mayor WALKER, WILLIAM G. FULLEN and a number of other distinguished citizens of this town, representing various official and unofficial bodies, have all tried their hands at transit unification.

Ferdinand Pecora, special counsel for the Senate Committee on Banking and Currency in the recent hearings at Washington, announced yesterday that he would begin an investigation of the affairs of the Harriman National Bank and Trust Company, as requested by the committee.

OYSTER BAY COVE, L.I., March 23. -- The story of how Henry T. Dollard, a real estate dealer, and twenty of his friends stole the village election in ten frantic minutes last Tuesday evening from the group of wealthy residents who incorporated the area in 1931 and had run it ever since was being told here today.

CHICAGO, March 23. -- Sentiment in the wheat trade changed materially overnight. General buying, which developed today at the opening of the Board of Trade, disclosed a heavily oversold condition incident to a five-day straight decline in prices, and opening sales were as much as 2 cents a bushel above yesterday's final quotations.
SAN FRANCISCO, March 23 (AP). -- George Bernard Shaw, Irish dramatist, arrived in San Francisco tonight on the round-the-world liner Empress of Britain for his first visit to America.
SEATTLE, March 23 (AP). -- Bishop Antonin Fokrovsky, aged prelate of Alaska, attributes to "a conscious act of God" his escape from a storm and shipwreck in which thirteen men died.

One of the most curious fruits of Mr. ROOSEVELT'S policy of prompt and courageous action, creating hope and even confidence, is the sudden conversion of Mr. NEVILLE CHAMBERLAIN. The Chancellor of the Exchequer has long been seeing England and the rest of the world blacker than Erebus.

LONDON, March 23. -- Lieutenant Norman Baillie-Stewart, the 24-year-old "prisoner in the Tower," went on the witness stand in his own court-martial today and strongly denied he had seold military secrets to German agents.

DECATUR, Ala., March 23. -- The question of whether to ask National Guard protection for the trial of the Negroes accused of attacking two white girls when it opens here Monday remained undecided today.

WEST PALM BEACH, Fla., March 23. -- Continuing to suffer from a famine of base hits, the Dodgers were shut out, 4 to 0, in their return engagement with the Browns today, Lloyd Brown and Bump Hadley blanking the Carey athletes.
WASHINGTON, March 23 (AP). -- The Roosevelt farm-relief bill was referred by the Senate today to the Agriculture Committee.

The market price of the stocks in the portfolio of the General Education Board, founded by John D. Rockefeller in 1902, has increased $2,479,936, or roughly 10 per cent, since June 30, 1932. Their total value on June 30 last was $25,542,528, while as of March 22 their aggregate market value was $28,022,464.

A downtown Manhattan deal was announced yesterday by Robert F. Bonsall, broker, who sold two corner properties to Rich McLean, Inc., of 9 Park Place, manufacturers of parts of typesetting machinery. The properties were bought from James Moss and consist of 2-4-6-8 Ferry Street, south-east corner of Gold Street, and the six-story building on the opposite corner, at 83 Gold Street, north-west corner of Spruce Street.
TOKYO, March 23. -- "Japan has a dummy hand this time," said an official in summing up the War Office's attitude toward the British disarmament plan.

After the resources of two hospitals, a jeweler, a druggist and an emergency crew from the gas company had been exhausted in a two-day effort to remove a lock washer from the finger of a 3-year-old Negro baby, Joseph Cunningham, an ambulance driver at Bellevue, finally relieved the child's excruciating pain last night, breaking the washer with a pair of pliers.

Mayor O'Brien announced yesterday that he had ordered a bill drafted that would consolidate the Children's Court and the Family Court into ane Court of Domestic Relations, and said the measure would be introduced in the Legislature soon.
NEW YORK. Mrs. Bartow S. Weeks will give a dinner tomorrow at the Park Lane.

PINEHURST, N.C., March 23. -- The big four of women's golf in the South this Winter, Miss Maureen Orcutt, Miss Edith Quier, Miss Bernice Wall and Mrs. Opal S. Hill, moved into the semi-final round of the thirty-first annual women's North and South championship today.

The Millinery Quality Guild, Inc., an organization of twelve manufacturing concerns, formed last August for the alleged purpose of maintaining prices on reproductions of French hats for women, was named a defendant yesterday in an antitrust suit filed by George Z. Medalie, United States Attorney.

RIO DE JANEIRO, March 23. -- Doubt is now expressed that the government will decree amnesty for exiles of the Sao Paulo, inasmuch as there are no criminal charges against them, and it is argued that amnesty is unnecessary.

BERLIN, March 23. -- The Reichstag quickly completed today the work for which it had been elected and had been called together by adopting in three readings the government's enabling act which gives to the Cabinet authority to make laws by decree for four years if it is not meanwhile displaced.

BERLIN, March 23. -- The Boerse opened weak today, declines of 2 to 4 points being frequent, but in the course of the day the market recovered. The closing was irregular, but final prices generally were not much above or below yesterday's. The bond market was dominated by realizing sales and the recent upward movement was stopped, although no market weakness developed.

The Annalist's February farm-price index of crops shows a decline to 49 (August, 1909, to July, 1914 -- 100), from 51 in January and 60 a year ago. In the four years since February, 1929, when it stood at 136, it has fallen 64 per cent.

The New York Rangers, engaging in their last game of the regular National Hockey League season, defeated the Canadiens of Montreal at Madison Square Garden last night, 4 to 2. A crowd of 3,000 persons, the smallest gathering of the local season, witnessed the contest, which had no bearing on either team's standing.

GENEVA, March 23. -- The interest Germany is now openly showing in the fate of Japan's mandate exceeds that with which Geneva awaits the passage dealing with the mandate in the Japanese note announcing her withdrawal from the league, which is expected here about Monday.

Maxie Rosenbloom and Bob God win, rival claimants of the world's light - heavyweight championship will clash at Madison Square Garden in a fifteen-round bout tonight in an endeavor to settle beyond doubt the leadership of the division. The battle will be the third championship struggle at the Garden in three weeks and is expected to attract a large crowd.

HAVANA, March 23. -- The proposed extension to Jan. 1, 1934, of the 700,000-ton sugar pool scheduled to terminate on July 1 and an additional proposal to include in the pool sugar of the present crop have brought forth a storm of protest from small producers.
BERLIN, March 23 (AP). -- Captain Hermann Wilhelm Goering, Nazi Speaker of the Reichstag, declared during its session today that "Germany never has been more peaceful."

LOS ANGELES, March 23. -- Manager Bill Terry blasted two home runs out of Wrigley Field and otherwise so inspired his Giants that they found no trouble in flattening the Pirates for the second successive afternoon.

"When beer returns on April 7, after its theoretical absence of thirteen years, it may be welcomed officially into esthetic circles by the Society of Independent Artists. It may be that on the opening night of the annual independent exhibition on April 7, some sort of paraphernalia for serving beer may be tucked artistically among the paintings and sculptures.

GLENS FALLS, N.Y., March 23. -- In the opening game of the Eastern States basketball tournament tonight, Fordham Preparatory School, Catholic High Schools Athletic Association champion of New York, emerged victorious over Roman Catholic High, Philadelphia Catholic League titleholder, 23 to 19.

DALLAS, Texas, March 23. -- More is to be expected from the working out of closer cooperation between the republics of North and South America at the coming conference at Montevideo, General J.G. Harbord told the Pan-American Medical Congress today, than from, all the disarmament conferences which have occupied the State Department and diplomats since the armament conference in Washington.
"Enchantment" is the title selected for the new comedy by Laurette Taylor in which she will appear under the management of Harry Moses on April 17. The play will go into rehearsal today.

Ten more associate members of the National Academy of Design were elected last night at a meeting of the academy held in the Fine Arts Society Building, 215 West Fifty-seventh Street, where the 108th annual exhibition of the academy will be opened privately this afternoon with a reception and to the public tomorrow.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., March 23. -- Awards of twenty-five of the more important fellowships and scholarships at Harvard University, representing about $34,000, were announced tonight, the list including eight fellowships in the Harvard Medical School, sixteen fellowships and scholarships in the Harvard Law School and one fellowship in the Graduate School of Arts and Sciences.
LONDON, March 23 (AP). -- The weekly statement of the Bank of England shows the following changes in pounds sterling:

A suit to prevent enforcement in this State of the Federal Hawes-Cooper act on sale of prison made goods and the State law passed about a month ago prohibiting sale of convict-made goods has been brought in Albany County against Attorney General John J. Bennett Jr., it was announced here yesterday by Mortimer Fishel, attorney for the plaintiff.
ALBANY, March 23. -- The Desmond-Moffat bill for the election of charter revision commissions became the focal point today of a struggle over charter changes for New York City.

LOUISVILLE, March 23 (AP). -- Flood preparations were rushed along the lower reaches of the Ohio River today, while on the upper stretches, where the swollen stream has been on a rampage for several days, rehabilitation work got under way.

An application for listing of the outstanding stock of the General American Tank Car Corporation under the new name General American Transportation Corporation has been made to the New York Stock Exchange.

PARIS, March 23. -- A syndicate or American radio importers here today had its members cable to their home offices requesting that immediate complaints be made at Washington against the French proposal to place a heavy import license tax on all radios.

PARIS, March 17 (A.P., by Mail). -- The suit holds the centre of the fashion stage when the smart set gathers for luncheon these days. First Spring costumes appearing at the Ritz and La Cremaillere are made around the smart tailleur, accented by bright scarves and hats.

Bloomingdale's has added more than 800 persons to its staff in the last week in anticipation of the increased business expected during its sixty-first anniversary sale, which begins tomorrow, it was announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 23. -- Details of the $5,050,000 self-liquidating loan to the Jones Beach State Park Authority through the purchase of a like amount of its bonds at 4 1/2 per cent were announced today by the Reconstruction Finance Corporation.
The Outlook on Beer. Beer delay beyond April 7 faced in New York due to difficulties in effecting State control at Albany.

ALBANY, March 23. -- Governor Lehman took issue today with portions of the proposed $8,799,000 budget reduction program agreed upon by the Democratic and Republican leaders. As a result the Democratic fiscal experts began refraining their schedule in an attempt to bring it into accord with the Governor's ideas.

The New York County grand jury, which since Jan. 13 has been investigating election frauds, handed up indictments yesterday against nine more persons to Judge Freschi in General Sessions. The grand jurors also voted similar indictments against about twenty others, which will be handed up to Judge Freschi next week, when these have been handed up a total of 121 will have been indicted in the county inquiry.
COMMERCIAL PAPER. Yesterday -- 3 per cent for the best names. Wednesday -- 3 per cent for the best names. The quotations are for three-four months' paper.
A gain of $5,985,000 was reflected in the Federal Reserve Bank's report of transactions affecting the monetary gold stocks of the country for the week ended on Wednesday, which was issued yesterday.
SALT LAKE CITY, Utah, March 23. -- The State of Utah, by a law enacted by the Legislature and just signed by Governor Henry H. Blood, places itself in the position of certain teetotalers.

Passage of the farm bill by the House of Representatives led yesterday to an advance on the Cotton Exchange. Prices having lost all of last week's improvement and a stronger technical position having developed below 6 1/4 cents a pound for the May delivery, an increase in buying brought about gains of 6 to 9 points on the day.

WASHINGTON, March 23. -- Secretary of Labor Perkins, making her debut before a Congressional committee today, defended in terse language President Roosevelt's plan to enlist 250,000 unemployed in a conservation corps to work on reforestation and similar projects.

City, regional, State and national planning has pained in importance since President Roosevelt and others have broached various public works programs as a partial remedy for unemployment, Shelby M. Harrison, general director of the Russell Sage Foundation, declared last night in an address at the English-Speaking Union, 19 West Forty-fourth Street.

DUBLIN, March 23. -- All Free State Government employes receiving more than u300 (about $1,000) a year will suffer pay cuts under the emergency economy bill introduced in the Dail Eireann tonight by Sean MacEntee, Minister of Finance.

ALBANY, Friday, March 24. -- Governor Lehman and the Democratic and Republican leaders of the Legislature, after a conference which came to a close just before 2 o'clock this morning, failed to reach an agreement on legislation for control and regulation of the prospective traffic in beer, which will be inaugurated as a result of the new statute enacted by Congress legalizing 3.2 brew.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Because I live so far away I always receive THE NEW YORK TIMES four days after New Yorkers have read theirs; and sometimes, even when it does come, circumstances make it necessary for me to put off looking at it immediately.

WASHINGTON, March 23. -- Although the Senate will not meet until Monday, an extraordinary unanimous consent agreement made just before a recess this evening enables the Chamber to continue business tomorrow and Saturday.

AINTREE, England, March 23. -- A last-minute rush of money from an unknown source has, as last year, hoisted the American-owned jumper Heartbreak Hill to the position of favorite for tomorrow's classic Grand National Steeplechase.
NEW ORLEANS, March 23 (AP). -- Corning from behind in a great stretch duel, Jimmy Sutro today outgamed War Plane to win by a neck the mile featured handicap at the Fair Grounds.

WASHINGTON, March 23. -- Emergency printing of currency to supply the needs of the nation's banks has been halted, a sufficient quantity now being available throughout the country to meet requirements, it was announced today at the Treasury Department.

The hurried call of the Jewish War Veterans to "our former comrades in arms to make common cause with us in a protest parade" was answered yesterday by 700 members of their own organization, 400 of the American Legion, 200 of the National War Veterans, 100 of the Veterans of Foreign Wars and 100 of the Seventy-seventh Division, supplemented by 500 marchers representing religious, civic and fraternal organizations of the metropolitan district.

An upward movement in securities and commodities developed yesterday, with, accompanying improvement in sentiment. The share market had a backslide in the afternoon which erased part of the gains, but bonds, which were not uniformly strong at any time, managed to close near the best levels of the day, showing scattered advances that ran to 2 and 3 points or more in favored groups.

For a time yesterday it appeared that the share market was about to recapture some of the speculative enthusiasm which was shown after the reopening of the security exchanges last week. The movement lost its force later in the day, however, and trading returned to the slow, measured tread of the previous three days.
LONDON, March 23 (AP) -- Europe's small nations need have no fear of Premier Mussolini's four-power plan, Prime Minister MacDonald told Parliament today.
MONTREAL, March 23 (AP). -- Just a farewell gesture before they put away their hockey equipment, the New York Americans ran through the Montreal Maroons for a 6-3 victory tonight.

WASHINGTON, March 23. -- The bill permitting State banks and trust companies not members of the Federal Reserve System to borrow directly from the Reserve Banks was approved by both houses of Congress late today and the presiding officers were authorized to sign the act and send it to President Roosevelt at once.

WASHINGTON, March 23. -- The daily average volume of Federal Reserve Bank credit outstanding during the week ending March 22 as reported by the Federal Reserve Banks was $3,108,000,000, a decrease of $528,000,000 compared with the preceding week and an increase of $1,512,000,000 compared with the corresponding week in 1932.

Boston, Mass. No bids were reported received yesterday by the city of Boston for its issue of $1,000,000 of notes, dated March 24 and due on Oct. 5. The city treasurer announced that up to Wednesday the city had collected 78.198 per cent of its 1932 tax levy and 96.873 per cent of its 1931 levy.

The carnation and other longstemmed varieties of Spring blooms held the attention of the judges yesterday at the International Flower Show, while the large number of visitors continued to view the more pretentious exhibits in the main exhibition hall of the Grand Central Palace.

Former Governor Philip La Follette of Wisconsin, here for a few days at the Hotel Roosevelt to finish owriting a series of articles on his recent European "study tour," was insistent yesterday that he would return to private life and the practice of law in his home town, Madison, Wis.

The following pictures will have New York premieres this morning: "Private Jones," with Lee Tracy and Gloria Stuart, at the RKO Roxy; "A Lady's Profession," with Alison Skipworth and Roland Young, at the Rialto; "Pick Up," with Sylvia Sidney and George Raft, at the Paramount; "Daring, Daughters," with Marian Marsh and Kenneth Thomson, at the Seventh Avenue Roxy.
ALBANY, March 24. -- Governor Lehman predicted today that an agreement would be reached early next week on the entire problem of the budget and the tax program.

A complete readjustment of religious guidance to, fit modern youth for an entirely different kind of world from that faced by their elders was seen as necessary by the Women's Committee for Religious Education of Children at its sixth annual luncheon yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 24.-- The long chain of events that terminated in the arrest of J.W. Harriman on charges of violations of the national banking act was outlined today by F.G. Awalt, Acting Controller of the Currency.

When contrasted with the feeling of anxiety which so persistently characterized the reports on trade conditions a few weeks ago, the transformation effected by the initiative, courage and wisdom of the new administration has been little short of miraculous, according to the weekly trade review by Dun Bradstreet, Inc.

WASHINGTON, March 24 (AP). -- Representative Dingell of Michigan said tonight that Secretary Woodin had assured him the operation of the newly created National Bank of Detroit would be handled in the best interests of the creditors of the two Institutions it displaced.
WASHINGTON, March 24. -- The Democratic steering committee of the House, whose responsibility it will be to keep the Democratic membership in line on major legislative proposals, was created today.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I was very much interested several days ago in a press dispatch printed in THE TIMES concerning the recent stand of University of Glasgow students, who, following the example of the Oxford Union, voted not to take up arms for King and country.
WASHINGTON, March 24. -- The Administration farm relief program was defended and attacked before the Senate Agricultural Committee this afternoon, when the first public hearing was held.
"Twentieth Century." the Hecht-MacArthur comedv, will reopen to-night at the Broadhurst Theatre. It closed ten days ago because of the disagreements between the managers and the stage-hands.

WASHINGTON, March 24. -- Anna Eleanor Dall, granddaughter of President Roosevelt, will celebrate her sixth birthday at the White House tomorrow, assisted by her, brother, Curtis Roosevelt Dall, 3, and fifteen guests ranging from 1 to 6 years old.

BETHLEHEM, Pa., March 24. -- Wrestlers from Indiana University gained five semi-final places as the result of the opening tests today in the National Collegiate A.A. championships and so showed the way to their rivals from thirty-one other institutions.

The purchase by the Dallas (Texas) Museum of Fine Arts of a portrait by Anthony van Dyck was announced yesterday by the Newhouse Galleries, 578 Madison Avenue. The subject of the portrait is considered to be Diana Cecil, daughter of William, second Earl of Salisbury, who was married to Henry de Vere, tenth Earl of Oxford.

DALLAS, Texas, March 24. -- The possibility of microbes being carried to the earth from other planets and even from stars of other solar systems was suggested today by Dr. Fred Valles of Tucson, Ariz., to the Tropical Medicine Section of the Congress of the Pan-American Medical Association.

As was the case last week, the new financing this week consisted of only two municipal issues of securities, and the total was only $525.000. compared with $1,050,000 last week. The fact that many corporation issues which had made sharp advances immediately after the general reopening of sound banks throughout the country subsequently lost the major portions of these gains, reduced the prospects for new financing of this character.

ALBANY, Saturday, March 25. -- Governor Lehman's bill for establishing State control and regulation for the manufacture and sale of 3.2 beer was introduced in the Senate at nine minutes of midnight last night.

ALBANY, March 24. -- Governor Lehman invited the leaders of the Legislature today to consult with him on a State policy on the recommendation of War Department engineers for the expenditure by the Federal Government of $27,500,000 for deepening the Barge Canal from Lake Ontario to the Hudson.

Mortgagees acting as plaintiffs in foreclosure proceedings bid in a dozen Manhattan and Bronx properties at auction sales yesterday. Multi-family structures dominated the list of defaulted holdings. Auctioning of a west side property was postponed.

Representatives of the Board of Taxes and Assessments with such documents, books and other data as were used in the deciding upon a taxable valuation to be placed upon two Flushing apartments, are to appear in Special Term, Supreme Court, in Queens on April 17.

These orders were Issued yesterday: Trial Results. Lieutenant John E. Stafford. H. and L. 46. Charge 1: Conduct prejudicial to the interest or welfare of the department: guilty: sentence suspended. Charge 2: Disrespect to superior officer (two specifications) -- Specification 1, guilty, reprimanded; specification 2, guilty, reprimanded.

Accused of demanding $20,000 from her employer under threat of kidnapping the two children she had been employed to care for Mrs. Marion Lasko. 39. a nursemaid in the home of Louis Marx, toy manufacturer, of 211 Central Park West, was held in $10,000 bail on a charge of blackmail yesterday in West Side Court.

PATCHOGUE, L.I., March 24. -- Two stakes were completed and a start made on a third today in the opening session of the eleventh annual Spring field trials of the Brookhaven Game Protective Association held over the covers on Strongs Neck.

The final day of competition at the International Flower Show, which opened in the Grand Central Palace last Monday, was divided yesterday between the exhibits of sweet peas and table decorations for private growers and the classes in large roses for commercial growers.

BALTIMORE, March 24. -- A suit to fix the legal rights of Mrs. Libby Holman Reynolds and Zachary Smith Reynolds 2d, widow and son of Smith Reynolds, to shares in the Reynolds tobacco millions was filed in Circuit Court today by the Safe Deposit and Trust Company.
ITHACA, N.Y., March 24. -- The pioneer spirit, rugged Americanism and intensified nationalism were described today by Edward A. Filene, Boston merchant, as "worthless in a machine civilization.
In "Land of Promise," published today by Macaulay, Edmond Flag tells of what Jewish emigrants to Palestine will find there.
COMMERCIAL, PAPER. Yesterday -- 3 per cent for the best names. Thursday -- 3 per cent for the best names. The quotations are for three-four months' paper.

AMARILL0, Texas, March 24. -- A gigantic meteor lighted the skies with awesome brilliance in five Southwestern States before dawn today and, with a thunderous rumble that rattled doors and windows, apparently disintegrated on Its earthward plunge.

BERLIN, March 24. -- Reports in the foreign press of atrocities suffered by German Jews at the hands of the Nazis were branded as "pure inventions" in a statement issued today by the Central Union of Germans Citizens of the Jewish Faith. The statement follows:

WASHINGTON, March 24. -- The Reconstruction Finance Corporation is being flooded with applications from officials of bank throughout the country which need laid, seeking what will be done to help in organizing new banking institutions under the "Detroit plan," by which the R.F.C. will put up half the capital for new institutions by purchase of preferred stock which carries voting power.

BERLIN, March 24. -- The Boerse opened bullish today, some stocks gaining as much as 7 points. A subsequent recession wiped out a good deal of the gains, yet the majority of the active list closed higher than yesterday, a few making substantial improvement.

The customary calls in the first quarter of the year for statements of condition of national banks and State banks and trust companies are expected to be omitted. In the case of the national banks, the Controller of the Currency is expected to skip the call as he did last year, only three calls a year being required under the law.
A mysterious explosion, which could be heard for blocks, leveled a two-family house at 648 East Forty-eighth Street, in the East Flatbush section of Brooklyn, shortly after 10 o'clock last night.

HUNTSVILLE, Ala., March 24. -- Victoria Price, who alleges that she and Ruby Bates were assaulted by a dozen Negroes on a freight train near Scottsboro two years ago, told her story again here today and expressed the hope that the men she accuses will die in the electric chair.

LONDON, March 24. -- The American victory for Mrs. F. Ambrose Clark's horse, Kellsboro Jack, in the Grand National Steeplechase at Aintree this afternoon brought two first prizes of u30,000 [about $102,000 at the current rate] in the Irish sweepstakes to New Yorkers.

Championship series races of the Atlantic class of sloops will consist of three contests in the future, two over a triangular course, and one to windward and leeward, and each to be not more than ten miles nor less than eight miles.
NEW YORK. Mr. and Mrs. F. Bartholomay Jelke will give a reception on Thursday afternoon at 1,160 Park Avenue.

WASHINGTON. March 24. -- Friendly representations were made to the Chilean Government today by Ambassador Culbertson on instruction of Secretary Hull in regard to termination of the export fee of 60 pesos a ton on nitrate and resumption of the old export tax.

Maxie Rosenbloom definitely established himself as the undisputed light heavyweight champion of the world by stopping Bob Godwin of Florida in the fourth round of a scheduled fifteen-round battle at Madison Square Garden last night.

Fifteen hundred men and women prominent in politics, social welfare work and organized labor gathered in the ballroom of the Hotel Commodore last night to pay tribute to Miss Frances Perkins, former New York State Industrial Commissioner and the new Secretary of Labor in the Roosevelt Cabinet.

AINTREE, England, March 24. -- Kellsboro Jack, 25-to-1 outsider owned by an American, Mrs. F. Ambrose Clark of New York, won the Grand National Steeplechase today by three lengths in the record time of 9:28.

The money market was quiet and featureless. On a minimum of business quotations were at a standstill in all departments. Stock Exchange call loans remained at 3 per cent, outside money at 2 1/2 and Federal checks 3@3 1/4. Time money, commercial paper and acceptances were dull.

Mayor O'BRIEN has carried out his promise to reorganize the Department of Sanitation. In terms of flesh and blood, the main incident of the new dispensation, provided in the bill approved by the Board of Estimate yesterday, is the elimination of Dr. SCHROEDER.
To the Editor of The New York Times: The controversy about the Rivera decorations in the Detroit Institute of Arts and the proposed obliteration of them is after all a matter of opinion.

With a line of standees encircling New York's opera house before its last performance this season, a box-office return of at least $10,000 and all the parterre boxes privately sold by Lucrezia Bori of the Committee for Saving Metropolitan Opera, the swiftly departing stars last evening sang Verdi's "Aida" on the stage where Giulio Gatti-Casazza began with the same work his first season here twenty-five years ago.

PHILADELPHIA, March 24. -- James H. Van Alen of New York passed another milestone in his climb to the forefront of American court tennis today when, for the first time, he gained the final round of the national championship at the Racquet Club.

Officially the "Shamrocks" were the winners last night of the Hudson Guild singing contest, but technically the honors went to the "Railroad Gang" and by popular acclaim the "Lindberghs" "walked away with it" by giving an Eleventh Avenue conception of a Negro camp meeting.

William J. Flynn, Public Works Commissioner of the Bronx, took the witness stand before Judge Nott and a jury in General Sessions yesterday to declare that he had taken a personal interest in preparing the perjury case against Louis H. Willard, Bronx real estate dealer.

New York City has a larger stake in charter revision than in any other measure now before the Legislature. The issue is no longer whether this or that plan is to prevail, but whether the city is entitled to have a new charter if it wants one.
