Mr. Roosevelt Will Have His Swim. The United States Government could well have afforded to provide Mr. ROOSEVELT with a swimming-pool for his exercise, but, as it has turned out, one can almost be grateful for the obstacles that arose.

Two measures of importance to the railways were favorably reported yesterday by a committee of the House of Representatives. The first would put the formation of holding companies under the supervision of the Interstate Commerce Commission and require its approval before a single interest could obtain control or management of two or more carriers.

Over the protest of Aldermanic President Joseph V. McKee and H. Warren Hubbard, Public Works Commissioner for Manhattan, the Board of Estimate voted a two weeks' delay yesterday in authorizing the extension of the west side express highway between Thirtyeighth and Forty-sixth Street.

WASHINGTON, March 24 (AP). -- Secretary of the Treasury Woodin said today that an announcement on the embargo which prohibits the export of gold was in the making and -would probably be issued tomorrow.

Though beer will flow from the nation's breweries with the sanction of the law on April 7, its manufacture in the home, even if it does not exceed the allowed alcoholic content of 3.2 per cent, will still be illegal, in the opinion of Federal Attorney Medalie's prohibition division.

PARIS, March 24. -- While praising Prime Minister MacDonald for his effort to save the disarmament conference from collapse, former Premier Herriot urges, first, a careful study of the British plan and then adoption of a watchful waiting policy. An article by the former Premier appearing in tomorrow's Lyons Democrate says:

The pamphlet report of the Pacific Lighting Corporation for 1932 says that operating expenses were $1,157,484 Tinder those of 1931 as a result of economies and a reduction in gas purchases on account of decreased industrial sales. The reduction partly offset a decline of $1,770,793 from the gross revenues of 1931, exclusive of impounded collections in either year, G.O.G. Miller, president, says in his report.

PARIS, March 24. -- Prime Minister MacDonald's open admission in the British House of Commons yesterday that the best method of revision of the treaties of peace so as to secure peace was that which had been discussed in Rome and here, and which would be the purpose of the four-power agreement proposed by Premier Mussolini, has been greeted with great resentment in the French press.

CHARLESTON, S.C., March 24. -- Walter Hagen, the veteran of the golfing fraternity, marched to the front tonight as the field of seventy pros and amateurs reached the half-way-mark in the first annual Charleston open tournament.

WASHINGTON, March 24. -- Beer was the theme song for the first nation-wide broadcast of a Senatorial hearing of one and one-half hours this afternoon. It was a spirited, old-fashioned debate on prohibition.

AINTREE, England, March 24 (AP). -- Kellsboro Jack, 7 years old, a bay golding and Irish bred, is the third American-owned horse to win the classic Grand National Steeplechase in nearly a century of racing history. The honors went to Stephen Sanford's famous Sergeant Murphy in 1923 and to A. Charles Schwartz's Jack Horner in 1926.

The Rev. Dr. William Carter, pastor of the Throop Avenue Presbyterian Church at Macon Street, Brooklyn, will announce his resignation at the annual roll call service of the congregation at the morning service tomorrow. The resignation will take effect Oct. 1, when Dr. Carter retires after completing eighteen years of service in the Throop Avenue church.

LONDON, March 24. -- For five hours today Lieutenant Norman Baillie-Stewart of the Seaforth Highlanders faced a torrent of questions from the court-martial prosecutor, never ceasing stoutly to maintain that it was "absurd and ridiculous" to suggest that the money received from a German girl whom he described as Maria Louise was in payment for secret military information.

Prices on the Cotton Exchange improved further yesterday, closing 2 to 4 points higher than on Thursday. Although weakness in securities and grains in the morning caused a temporary recession, firmless developed after wheat rallied in the afternoon and cotton reached its best figures in the final dealings.

LONDON, March 24. -- The Jewish boycott movement against reported anti-Semitic persecution in Germany gained momentum in London today as placards bearing the words "Boycott German Goods" appeared in windows and stores in the high-class shopping district of the West End, while automobiles similarly billed slowly paraded the streets.

It is expected that the 134th session of the New York annual Conference of the Methodist Episcopal Church, which will be held here beginning Thursday and continuing through Monday, April 3, will go down in the history of local Methodism as a memorable one because for the first time laymen may vote with the ministers in the annual conference.

GENEVA, March 24. -- The final article of the British draft convention dealing with the suppression of the military clauses of the Versailles, St. Germain, Trianon and Neuilly' treaties led Turkey to demand today that the same principle of equality be applied also to the Lausanne treaty by suppressing the demilitarized zone around the Dardanelles and Bosporus Straits.

Mayor O'Brien's announcement that he would enter into direct negotiations with the holders of transit securities in an effort to bring about early unification has intensified recent reports that the city's financial difficulties were soon to be made the basis of a demand for a ten-cent fare, whether unification is achieved or not.

In the Maine county named after General HENRY KNOX the town of St. George occupies an amphibious position. It is a peninsula surrounded on three sides by the Atlantic. Its situation and its instinct prompt it to go down upon the sea in motor boats.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 24. -- Babe Ruth formally signed his $52,000 contract for the 1933 playing season this morning and them demonstrated this afternoon why he still is the highest-paid player in baseball.

Warning that there were steps on foot to raise the fares on all subway lines in the city to 10 cents, Joseph V. McKee, President of the Board of Aldermen, in an address last night at the Temple Gates of Israel Synagogue, 560 West 185th Street, attacked the economy measures of the city and criticized in particular the substitution of fifty-year bonds for four-year bonds to finance the city-owned subway.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., March 24. -- Accusing the Democrats of "stealing a quarter of a million votes" in 1932 by opening machines and changing totals in New York, W. Kingsland Macy, Republican State chairman, told the newly formed Republican Club of Dutchess County tonight that his organization will make a vigorous campaign next Fall to end dishonesty at the polls.

CAMDEN, S.C., March 24. -- More than 25,000 spectators are expected to be present for the annual Carolina Cup meeting at the Springdale Course tomorrow, with a field of fifteen named overnight for the chief event, the Carolina Cup Steeplechase.

Ferdinand Pecora, special counsel to the Senate Committee on Banking and Currency, conferred with United States Attorney George Z. Medalie yesterday on the affairs of the Harriman National Bank andTrust Company.

Bond prices were irregularly lower yesterday in quiet trading on the Stock Exchange. German bonds of all descriptions were particularly weak, with losses ranging up to more than 6 points and establishing new lows for the year for a number of issues.

American flag steamships now transport one-third of the foreign commerce of the nation and collect $200,000,000 annually in freight revenues as against $300,000,000 paid to foreign ship lines serving American ports, according to R.J. Baker, secretary of the American Steamship Owners Association.

By deciding that the words "who" and "whom" may refer not only to a human being but to a corporation, the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court upheld yesterday a decision of Surrogate James A. Foley and saved $616,750 to twentyone charitable and religious institutions by a construction of the will of Mrs. Hannah M. Lydig.

Convinced that newspapers offer a more effective medium for advertising than the radio, executives of the Frigidaire Corporation, subsidiary of General Motors Corporation, revealed yesterday that two-thirds of its advertising appropriation for 1933 would be allotted to daily publications and that no funds would be spent on broadcasting.

BERLIN, March. 24. -- Reports in the United States that the German Government will demand revision of private foreign debts evidently are based on Chancellor Hitler's statement to the Reichstag yesterday that the most important question before the World Economic Conference would be Germany's private long-term and short-term debts abroad.

With a breathless escort limping at her heels, Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt made another whirlwind visit yesterday to New York. She arrived at the Newark Airport shortly after 3 P.M. after a flight from Washington in which the plane was flown so high to avoid bumpy air conditions that ice formed on the wings.

MIAMI, Fla., March 24. -- This training centre, not used by a major league club until this year since the Cincinnati Reds were here more than a dozen years ago, will be the scene of the Dodgers' Spring conditioning for the next five years, according to present information.

Yosuke Matsuoka, who led the Japanese delegation's walkout from the League of Nations a month ago in protest against its censure of his country's Manchurian policy, arrived in New York on his way home yesterday to the accompaniment of boos and jeers from Chinese, Communists and Chinese sympathizers massed in the street outside Pier 59 and "banzais" and waving flags of the Rising Sun from a group of his own countrymen.
VIENNA, March 24. -- Vienna will be without newspapers tomorrow morning.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 24. -- Bill Dickey of the Yankees was perched atop a big black trunk in the clubhouse of the Braves at Waterfront Park. From another section of the clubhouse there came a rich, rolling voice singing in a good thick brogue:

CHICAGO, March 24. -- The wheat market on the Board of Trade showed more resistance to pressure today after an early break that carried prices off about 1 cent a bushel. A good class of buying developed later and despite selling of the May which was attributed to the Federal Farm Board the market more than recovered the early losses and closed at the top with net gains of 1/4% to 1/2% cent.

In the Queens Supreme Court, Special Term, at Jamaica yesterday Justice James C. Cropsey handed down a decision directing Morris Okoshken, attorney, of Jamaica, as referee in foreclosure, to sell the Kew Gardens Terrace apartments located in Kew Gardens under foreclosure proceedings on April 13.

George Spitz, national high jump champion and world's record holder, jumped 6 feet 8 inches In an exhibition in the Seventh Regiment Armory last night which was the feature of the regiment's eightysecond track and field games.

Bernard (Mike) Kelly of Indianapolis, chief assistant to Al Mamaux in managing the Newark Bears last year, yesterday was named manager of the Jersey City Baseball Club of the International League for this season by Sam Colacurcio, president of the club.

LOS ANGELES, March 24. -- A belief that the present era of scientific achievement would lead to a great spiritual accomplishment by mankind was expressed yesterday by Dr. John H. Finley, associate editor of THE NEW YORK TIMES, in a speech at the local observance of the charter day celebration of the University of California.

WASHINGTON, March 24. -- President Roosevelt expects to end the first fiscal year of his administration with a balanced budget and perhaps a slight surplus, so far as ordinary expenditures are concerned. This feat will be accomplished by "capitalizing" extraordinary and emergency expenditures and financing them over a long period of time through bond issues, instead of charging them against normal income as at present.

PINEHURST. N.C., March 24. -- Miss Maureen Orcutt amazed Pinehurst's galleries today by matching men's par for the twelve holes she needed to eliminate Miss Edith Quier of Reading, Pa., in the semifinal round of the thirty-first annual women's North and South golf, championship. The score was 7 and 6.

PHILADELPHIA, March 24 (AP). -- Warning the defendants that he would be "relentless" with future violators, Judge George A. Welsh, within a few minutes today, practically cleared the blotter in Federal District Court of petty prohibition cases.

For more than forty minutes late yesterday afternoon, Mrs. Samuel Russo shrieked in the corridors of the Criminal Courts Building her denunciation of a Jury that had just found the slayer of her husband guilty of manslaughter in the first degree.

WASHINGTON. March 24. -- The State Department will ask wheat surplus producing countries, such as Canada. Australia and Argentina, whether they will agree to a discussion at the impending World Economic Conference of a program for international control of wheat production.

Governor LEHMAN some time ago announced his determination to keep politics out of the beer bill. The draft of his measure submitted to the Legislature yesterday appears to do this, so far as it is humanly possible. It provides for a State regulatory board of five persons, to be appointed by the Governor with the advice and consent of the Senate.

Mrs. Ethelbert Nevin will be the guest of John McCormack at his concert at Carnegie Hall tomorrow night. He will sing at her request her late husband's "Little Boy Blue." Mr. McCormack is the owner of the original manuscript of the poem, written by Eugene Field.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., March 24. -- As a promising augury for even more brilliant performances in tomorrow's finals, pool records were eclipsed in five of seven events today as the tenth annual National Collegiate A.A. swimming championships stepped off to a brisk start in the magnificent Yale University pool.

WASHINGTON, March 24. -- The United States is not entering at this juncture the controversy as to the status of the South Pacific islands mandathed to Japan after that country withdraws from the League of Nations. The State Department is watching the situation but is making no special study of it, and, it was said today, does not have the matter actively under consideration.

LOS ANGELES, March 24. -- The Giants bade farewell to the Pacific Coast today with a rousing ninth-inning triumph over the Pittsburgh Pirates, 6 to 5, making a clean sweep of their three-game series with their National League rivals.

WASHINGTON, March 24. -- William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, today criticized President Roosevelt's reforestation plan to enlist 250,000 men in a conservation corps as "smacking of fascism, Hilterism and in some respects of sovietism," and objected to its proposed "regimentation of labor."

FORT MUNOZ, Bolivia, March 24. -- Since the Paraguayan defeats at Fort Alihuata and Camp Jordan the Chaco region has entered a period, of comparative calm, although some military action continues. What is going to happen in the near future has not been revealed here, although military men display great confidence while maintaining extreme reserve.

WASHINGTON, March 24. -- Delay by the administration in appointing Assistant Secretaries for Air for the War, Navy and Commerce Departments has caused expressions of doubt here that any of the positions will be filled.

PALM BEACH, Fla., March 24. -- Mr. and Mrs. J. Gordon Douglas gave a dinner tonight at the Beach Club, having as their guests Mr. and Mrs. Peter A.B. Widener 2d, Joseph E. Widener, Mr. and Mrs. Franklin L. Hutton, Mrs. James P. Donahue, Mrs. John Gaston, Mrs. Lucius Pond Ardway, Mr. and Mrs. Maurice Fatio and Major Pryce Harrison.

WASHINGTON, March 24. -- Japanese purchases of foreign goods are expected to be small, pending stabilization of yen exchange, the Department of Commerce said today in its weekly review of business conditions abroad.

Combination of the local passenger and freight department offices of the Union Pacific Railroad at 521 Fifth Avenue, northeast corner of Forty-third Street, was announced yesterday by William A. White Sons, brokers, in arranging a lease of space on the fourth floor.

The municipal bond market remained in the doldrums this week not only in so far as new financing was concerned but also from the standpoint of trading in blocks of old issues. The general level of municipal bond prices is somewhat below that of a week ago, on the average, since what little trading has been done has been in the nature of a buyers' market.

Cardinal Hayes will attend and offer the invocation at the "Holy Hour" to be held by Protestants, Jews and Roman Catholics, Sunday morning, April 2, in the Music Hall of Radio City, which will be a civic, patriotic and religious recognition of the ideals as recently laid down by Pope Pius XI and as expressed by President Roosevelt in his inaugural address.

WASHINGTON, March 24. -- Appointment of a "Federal coordinator of railroads" with broad powers to effect economies in operation of the lines has developed as the keystone in President Roosevelt's prospective legislative structure for dealing with the railroad emergency.

ALBANY, March 24. -- A new tax rate for stock transfers in the State was asked today by Governor Lehman in a special message to the Legislature, and a bill embodying his proposals was introduced immediately by Assemblyman Hamerman, Democrat, of New York.

ATLANTIC HIGHLANDS, N.J., March 24. -- A pair of pallbearer's gloves and an upturned king of spades offered the only clues tonight to the murder of Alexander (Al) Lillien, the 36-year-old "master mind" of the New Jersey coast rum-runners.

Despite maximum efforts by charitable organizations and churches, the unemployment relief problem has grown to the point where the city must provide at least partial support for almost one-tenth of its residents, and the number dependent upon it is rapidly increasing, Mayor John P. O'Brien said last night in an address before the Men's Club of the All Souls Universalist Church, Ocean and Ditmas Avenues, Brooklyn.

WASHINGTON, March 24. -- Discussions looking to a revision of the British war debt were begun formally by the administration today through a conversation of more than an hour among Secretary of State Hull, Assistant Secretary of State Moley and Sir Ronald Lindsay, British Ambassador.

Swedish intellectuals have a new grievance. Learned Swedes are writing letters to the newspapers. The issue is pressing and vital. By immemorial habit and tradition it is taboo to address a person other than a bootblack, servant or messenger directly.

The New York University girls' swimming team repulsed the Brooklyn College mermaids, 29 to 24, in the London Terrace seventyfive-foot pool last night. The triumph was the forty-third in forty-four meets for N.Y.U. since 1925 and the third in four starts this season.

HEADRICK, Okla., March 24 (AP). -- W.C. Ernest, a State bank examiner, was shot to death here today when he turned from a telephone after asking State Bank Commissioner W.J. Barnett at Oklahoma City to take over the Citizens State Bank.
Housing properties composed the bulk of the New Jersey realty turnover reported yesterday.

Billboards are not a world-shaking issue, but nevertheless they manage to stir up a lively debate at State capitals every year at this season. Last week a large delegation of roadside beauty advocates journeyed up to Hartford to plead for a bill which, would give Connecticut more effective control over this rural nuisance.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 24. -- Taking sharp sallies at interviewers, George Bernard Shaw, Irish dramatist, took off by airplane today for San Simeon, 200 miles south of here, to be the guest of William Randolph Hearst.

Protest against the discriminatior against Jews under the Hitler regime in Germany was expressed yesterday in an official statement adopted by the executive committee of the Federal Council of Churches of Christ in America, speaking for twenty-two Protestant denominations with a total membership of 22,000,000.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In your issue of March 20 there is published a letter from Dr. William H. Kilpatrick of Teachers College in which it is asserted that there is no evidence that Collegiate School, which was at the time engaged in the celebration of the three hundredth anniversary of its founding, was, in fact, founded in 1633, and that the evidence points to 1638 as the proper date.

OTTAWA, March 24 (Canadian Press). -- The operating deficit of the Canadian National (West Indies) steamships for 1932 was 283,715. according to the report tabled in the House of Commons today by R.J. Manion, Minister of Railways and Canals. This was $446,568 less than in the preceding year.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Having a country place about thirty-five miles from my home at White Plains, I am seriously considering becoming a farmer. I understand that if I do this the government will tax the city people for their food so that I may live in the style to which my predecessor, who owned the place some twenty years or more ago, was accustomed.

The Board of Estimate approved yesterday by a l0-to-6 vote an amendment to the city's zoning regulations which will enable owners of private garages in residence districts to rent out to neighbors space for not more than one pleasure car each.

When Charles O'Connor bought from Susan Iva Thomasson the five-story dwelling at 318 Lexington Av. he gave back a purchase money mortgage for $6,500, due in three years, at 6 per cent, and subject to a first mortgage for $I2,000.

After Thursday's moderate recovery on the Stock Exchange the share market fell back into a narrow groove yesterday and struggled laboriously but vainly to find a course which it could follow. The net result was insignificant. The composite index of fifty stocks showed an average gain of 9 cents; in the other classifications the net advance was of about equal scope.

SEATTLE, Wash., March 24 (AP) -- The American Mail liner President Madison capsized at her pier here tonight while 140 workmen and members of her crew were aboard. Five men, three of whom later escaped, were trapped in her rapidly filling hold.

The relationship between the New York Telephone Company and the publishers of Donnelley's Red Book is the object of an investigation ordered by the Public Service Commission and directed particularly at including on regular bills for telephone service the charge for advertisements in the Red Book.

The downward trend in prices on local commodity exchanges continued yesterday, although for the most part losses were small. The trading volume continued to dry up and was in several cases the smallest since the reopening of the exchanges. In the cash markets grains advanced.

Signs of increased activity in the theatrical producing field became apparent yesterday when it was learned that four plays will be placed in rehearsal next week. The quartet of forthcoming productions are "9 Pine Street," "Just Out," "Unto the Third" and "Hilda Gassidy."

Poland wants and needs peace more than any other nation in Europe, but stands ready to defend herself to the last against any attempts to "repeat the crime committed against her in 1793, when, under the leadership of Prussia, she was partitioned by Prussia, Austria and Russia," Ignace Jan Paderewski, the pianist and first Premier of the new Poland, said here yesterday in an interview.

Paul Abolila, 36 years old, who lives with his wife and four children at 2,540 Cambrelling Avenue, the Bronx, was arrested yesterday in the office of Harold W. Hastings, Assistant District Attorney, in the Criminal Courts Building Annex on charges of extortion and coercion.

Michael Arlen, whose new book, "Man's Mortality." is a tale somewhat after the H.G. Wells's manner of fast action in 1987, is explaining that he made enough money out of such popular successes as "The Green Hat" and "These Charming People" to be able to write now as he likes.

The newspapers of the country have underemphasized rather than overemphasized the depression, Frank Parker Stockbridge, editor of The American Press, said yesterday during a symposium on the question held at the Columbia School of Journalism under the auspices of Sigma Delta Chi, national journalistic fraternity.

PHILADELPHIA, March 24. -- Lowering of tariff barriers and acceptance of the idea of the interdependence of nations constitute necessary steps toward true economic recovery for this country, according to Dr. Ernest Minor Patterson, Professor of Economics, at the University of Pennsylvania, who spoke today before the Wharton Alumni Institute of Business at the university.

Pullman, Inc., the holding organization for the Pullman Company, the Pullman Car and Manufacturing Company and allied industries, wrote down property and other assets $23,445,015 in 1932. Together with a net loss of $3,834,724 on the year's operations, the payment of $11,460,540 dividends from surplus, and other deductions, this reduced its surplus from $112,565,684 to $74,765,122, or by $37,800,562.

PURNEA, India, March 24. -- On the flight from England to India the three Moth airplanes which brought out members of the Mount Everest Flight Expedition were never separated throughout the nineteen days for more than a few hours. On the whole, the flight was an enjoyable adventure, yet the expedition may have fewer difficulties before it than it has already met and overcome.
The voters who went to the polls on Nov. 8, armed with pencils and determination, succeeded in recording 262,649 votes for Joseph V. McKee for Mayor, the Board of Elections announced yesterday.

Awards for mass arrangements of flowers and silhouettes, featured the competition in the classes of the Garden Club of America in their competition at the flower show yesterday, while still life displays were prominent in the program conducted by the federated garden clubs of New York and New Jersey, in the divisions reserved for them.

Andrew W. Mellon, retiring United States Ambassador to Great Britain, arrived yesterday on his seventy-eighth birthday on the Leviathan of the United States Lines. He seemed in excellent health and carried his years lightly. He said be had no plans in particular and would concern himself with business"only when I feel like it."
PITTSBURGH, March 24. -- Carnegie Institute decided this week to revolt against the advice of Andrew Carnegie.

Because of the recent reduction in prices of admission, leading motion-picture companies are refusing to supply the old Roxy Theatre, Fiftieth Street and Seventh Avenue, with films, it was charged yesterday in a complaint to State Attorney General John J. Bennett Jr. Mr. Bennett ordered an investigation to determine if the State antimonopoly act had been violated.
WASHINGTON, March 24 (AP). -- Intended by its drafters to be plain in intent, the new beer bill nevertheless is presenting as many problems as a jigsaw puzzle to those charged with its enforcement.

DETROIT, March 24. -- Detroit. with the assistance of the General Motors Corporation and the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, opened a new bank, capitalized at $25,000,000, today, the first bank to be established under the Roosevelt emergency act plan.

The boat captains of Lindenhurst and Babylon are to hold a mass meeting at Barnacle Bill's, the headquarters of the Lindenhurst Boatmen's Association, on Monday night to consider a revision in the prices charged to passengers. A meeting held on Thursday night failed to bring definite action, and a second session has been called in an effort to adjust the situation.

The Board of Estimate branch of the Municipal Assembly passed yesterday Mayor O'Brien's local bill reducing the administrative heads of the Sanitation Department from three men to one, forecasting the elimination of Dr. William Schroeder Jr. and Leonard C. L. Smith as members of the Sanitary Commission.

BERLIN, March 24 (AP) -- An effort to have the Holy See prevail upon German Catholic Bishops to change their allegedly hostile attitude toward the Nazis was seen by political circles in the dinner the Italian Ambassador, Vittorio Cerruti, arranged tonight honoring Mgr. Cesare Orsenigo, Papal Nuncio, and Captain Hermann Wilhelm Goering.

Varnishing day at the National Academy of Design comes twice a year. One of these traditional rites was solemnized yesterday and the Spring exhibition opens to the public today. It will remain until April 18.

LOUISVILLE, March 24 (AP) -- Fear of heavy flood damage along the western reaches of the Ohio River and on the Mississippi River was abated somewhat today as the Ohio's rise declined and the Weather Bureau at Washington said the Mississippi would not reach flood stage at Memphis, Tenn., and Helena, Ark.

Archbishop Edward Mooney, Apostolic Delegate to India, sails today on the Italian motor ship Augustus. Others sailing for Mediterranean ports include Mr. and Mrs. W.C. Goodale, Mr. and Mrs. W.T. Crocker and Mrs. H.W. Chappell.

WASHINGTON, March 24 (AP). -- As formidable efforts to change the administration's farm relief bill, interrupting the smooth flow of Roosevelt measures through Congress, came into the open today in the Senate Agricultural Committee, the President himself watched intently the progress on the measure.

Considering the remarkable progress that has been, made in repairing the banking position, as disclosed in the weekly statement of the Federal Reserve System late on Thursday, the action of the security markets yesterday was disappointing. Stocks gave little evidence of interest.

DANVILLE, Ky., March 24 (AP) -- A student strike at Centre College came to an abrupt end this afternoon when President Charles J. Turck appeared unexpectedly at a campus gathering of some 250 male students and issued an ultimatum to the strikers.

KANSAS CITY, March 24 (AP). -- The flash of a brilliant meteor across the Texas-New Mexico skies this morning was described today by Bill Coyle, air mail pilot, of the Transcontinental Western Air, Inc., as it appeared to him from What he termed "a ringside seat 9.500 feet above the earth."

It is often said that the British Government is superior to ours in one respect. Members of the British Cabinet are expected to be in the House of Commons, at question time, to give various kinds of information and to explain and defend Government policies.

WASHINGTON, March 24. -- A resolution urging recognition of Russia by the United States was submitted to the White House and the State Department today by representatives of "the American Women's Committee for Recognition of Soviet Russia."

RENO, Nev., March 24. -- Gifford Pinchot 2d, nephew of the Governor of Pennsylvania and son of Amos Pinchot and Mrs. Minturn Pinchot of New York, who came to Reno in September with the announced intention of seeking a divorce, left Eeno last night for the East.

Plans for a six-month relief program will be submitted to Mayor O'Brien on Monday by the newly appointed City Work and Relief Administration, it was announced last night by Welfare Commissioner Frank J. Taylor, chairman of the committee.

Work stopped earlier than usual yesterday afternoon In the Adult Classes in Art Education operated by the State relief fund in the East Side Continuation School Building, 214 East Forty-third Street, and the students displayed their work so visitors might see what is being accomplished in the instruction of the unemployed in art.

The Chase National Bank will sell at public auction on next Friday the collateral securing a $6,000,000 promissory note, of which $5,485,051 remains unpaid, of the Seaboard Public Service Company, which is in bankruptcy. The company was a subsidiary of the bankrupt National Public Service Corporation, controlled in turn by the National Electric Power Company, Eastern holding organization of the Insull-controlled Middle West Utilities Company.

The Chase National Bank will sell at public auction on next Friday the collateral securing a $6,000,000 promissory note, of which $5,485,051 remains unpaid, of the Seaboard Public Service Company, which is in bankruptcy. The company was a subsidiary of the bankrupt National Public Service Corporation, controlled in turn by the National Electric Power Company, Eastern holding organization of the Insull-controlled Middle West Utilities Company.
ROME, March 24 (AP) -- Premier Mussolini today received the homage of a huge Fascist army congregated in Rome to commemorate the fourteenth anniversary of the formation of their party.

The Reading, the Detroit, Toledo Ironton and the New York, Ontario Western railroads reported yesterday increased net operating incomes in February, but the Pennsylvania continued to show a decrease under this heading, while the Southern Pacific operated at a deficit of $1,226,346 in the month.

About $20,000,000 will be spent in the New York metropolitan area in the next four months for new breweries and for remodeling and altering old ones, it was estimated yesterday by L. Seth Schnitman, chief statistician of the F.W. Dodge Corporation, a building trades service-reporting organization.

GLENS FALLS, N.Y., March 24. -- Fordham Prep, Catholic High Schools Athletic Association champion of New York, lost in the semifinals of the Eastern States basketball tournament tonight to Waterford High, Eastern New York State champion.

ALBANY, Saturday, March 25. -- The entire State of New York, more than three-quarters of which was dry prior to prohibition, will be wet for 3.2 per cent beer under Governor Lehman's bill for the control and regulation of the manufacture and sale of the beverage when it is passed and approved by the Governor and Federal legalization of the beer has become effective April 7.
Charles E. Mitchell, former chairman of the National City Bank, was indicted by a Federal grand jury about noon yesterday on the charge of evading $573,312.81 income taxes for 1929.
GENEVA, March 24. -- There is no likelihood that the League of Nations powers will accept Japan's view that she holds the mandated Pacific islands by secret agreement with the Allies during the war.

Mrs. F. Ambrose Clark, whose Kellsboro Jack won the Grand National yesterday, for more than twenty years has been one of the outstanding figures in steeplechasing in this country. Her husband is president of the United Hunts Racing Association and has been identified with the sport through the field for thirty years or more.

MIAMI, Fla., March 24. -- Von Sion, the Carlaris colt which races for F.A. Forden, made it two in a row at Tropical Park when he annexed the featured Flagler purse in easy fashion today. The even-money favorite, Von Sion sped along in front to win by a length and a half from Liqueur, which saved the place by a nose from Golden Fate.

To the Editor of The New York Times: BEVERLY HILLS, Cal., March 24. -- Bernard Shaw, you let me come to your home in London, to talk to you for a long time. I always said I never met a man I didn't like. You would all like Shaw if you met him -- that is, everybody that is fair and honest with themselves.

MIAMI, Fla., March 24. -- Von Sion, the Carlaris colt which races for F.A. Forden, made it two in a row at Tropical Park when he annexed the featured Flagler purse in easy fashion today. The even-money favorite, Von Sion sped along in front to win by a length and a half from Liqueur, which saved the place by a nose from Golden Fate.

To the Editor of The New York Times: BEVERLY HILLS, Cal., March 24. -- Bernard Shaw, you let me come to your home in London, to talk to you for a long time. I always said I never met a man I didn't like. You would all like Shaw if you met him -- that is, everybody that is fair and honest with themselves.
CHICAGO, March 25. -- Increased activities are being manifest at the Century of Progress Exposition

PARIS, March 23. -- The season's smartest bride will wear Vionnet's crepe satin tie-on apron dress with the voil attached to Roboux's Russian diadem head dress set so low that it covers both eyebrows.

BOUND BROOK, N.J., March 25. -- Five persons were cut or bruised when a Public Service Coordinated Transport trolley car left the track in the Lincoln section of Middlesex Borough about a mile east of here at 9:05 o'clock tonight and overturned on the sidewalk of Harris Avenue, after plunging clear across that thoroughfare.

DODGE CITY, Kan., March 23. -- The Southwest, with the recuperative power that has enabled it to surmount droughts, grasshoppers and depressed markets, is more than ever convinced that informed and coordinated agriculture points the way out.

THIS is a day of dictatorship," declared Senator Steiwer when the "economy" bill made its debut in the Senate. "Italy is under a dictatorship; Russia is under a dictatorship; Germany is under a dictatorship, and those who are here pressing this legislation are seeking to put the United States of America under a dictatorship!"

Five notable collections of art treasures will be opened to the public during April under the sponsorship of the Adopt a Family Committee of the Unemployment Relief Fund. Three of these are in the private residences of prominent New York, art collectors, which will be opened to the public for one day only in each case.

WASHINGTON, March 25. -- Reports are being received by the State Department from the United States Embassy and the consulates in Germany concerning the character and extent of the anti-Semitic activities, but they are incomplete as yet and until final reports have been received that are accurate beyond question the department is planning to make no announcement.

Tammany has made no progress in efforts to learn what patronage it is to receive from the Federal administration, it was learned yesterday following a visit to this city of James A. Farley, Democratic national chairman and Postmaster General.

PARIS. WE have heard a lot, during the past few years, of proletarian literature. I must say that I believe very little in such classification. I recognize good books and mediocre books; but 1 have a hard time making distinctions, unless it is by subject-matter, between bourgeois literature and proletarian literature.

United States Senator Robert F. Wagner, in speaking yesterday of the necessity for interest rate revision said "one of the consequences of the long and deep decline in prices is the unavoidable necessity of reducing the fixed charges of business enterprises."

Ministers of virtually every faith will devote all or part of a sermon today to a discussion of the treatment of Jews in Germany, and they will pray that Germany may be made "to see the light of justice and humanity." Some will urge, it is expected, that the United States Government take some action in the matter.

ALBANY, March 25 (AP). -- Passage of Governor Lehman's State beer control bill by Tuesday, so that New York may have a legal bulwark against "wildcat" traffic in beer untill it can get its control machinery functioning, was the plan of Democratic leaders in the Legislature tonight.

Arthur M. Levy, manager of the Littman's women's clothing store at Broadway and Thirty-ninth Street, and a nephew of the owner, reported to the police last night that he and another employe were held up by two men, robbed of the receipts of two Littman's stores at Forty-second Street and Fifth Avenue and kidnapped and taken to Twenty-fifth Street and Second Avenue.

PHOENIX, Ariz., March 25. -- Before a gathering of about 8,000, the largest crowd of the current exhibition season and one which included such celebrities as Governor Ben Moeur. Baseball Commissioner K.M. Landis, President John A. Heydler of the National League and Gene Tunney, former heavyweight champion, the Giants went on display today and defeated a team of all-stars representing the Phoenix Commercial League.

LONDON. JOHN HENRY NEWMAN wrote the most famous of his hymns, "Lead, Kindly Light," while becalmed on a cargo-boat in the Mediterranean. Last Summer Colonel T.F. Tweed, hitherto known only as a skillful party organizer in the interests of Lloyd George, also found himself in a Mediterranean cargo-boat with ample time on his bands.

PARIS, March 25. -- Conflicting rumors agitated the Paris Bourse today as the government officially closed subscriptions to the first slice of the new consolidation loan devised to cover budgetary deficits of 10,000,000,000 francs in the last three years.
College baseball in the Metropolitan district got away to a frigid start yesterday at Baker Field when Manhattan scored three runs in the seventh inning to defeat Columbia 5 -- 3.

THERE is something to be said both for and against the type of fictionized biography which E. Barrington, since her romantic version of the life of Byron in "Glorious Apollo," has rendered popular. When the events of a subject's life are only slightly distorted, so that the false is difficult to distinguish from the true, there is reasonable ground for objecting to the method.
THE first of a series of five consecutive Sunday afternoon Beethoven programs will be given this afternoon by the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra at Carnegie Hall.

A survey indicated that more than 15,600 of the approximately 19,296 banking institutions in the country were open again yesterday, some still restricted, The Associated Press announced. Of the 6,891 institutions that are members of the Federal Reserve System, 5,328 were doing business.

A steady increase in the occupancy of the various apartment houses in Westchester County under the management of the Reliance Property Management is reported by Mark H. Flaherty, vice president of the company.

PEIPING, March 2. -- China's ancient walled capital has now been linked with the commercial metropolis of Shanghai by a thrice-a-week air service, belonging to the government and utilizing American pilots.

Dismissal of all complaints involving only the sale or possession of beer will be recommended here after by the Federal prosecuting authorities in the Eastern District of New York, it was announced yesterday by Frederick J. Peper, assistant United States Attorney in charge of prosecuting prohibition violations.

The people of the United States have lost "a cool billion dollars" as a result of the collection by the Treasury of the $93,000,000 payment on Great Britain's debt last December, members of the National Republican Club were told yesterday by Dr. Bernhard Ostrolenk, economist.

THE news that Rollins College, at Winter Park, Fla., is to embark this year on the plan for determining student tuition charges by the actual cost of instruction illustrates, I believe, an important trend in education. To the admirable argument given by President Hamilton Holt in his article on the plan on this page recently it may be useful to add the experience of Bennington College under a similar arrangement.

WASHINGTON, March 25 (AP). -- After a six-hour conference at the Treasury Department, Police Commissioner James K. Watkins of Detroit and six companions who have been protesting the formation of the new banking set-up in the Michigan City tonight ended their discussions, but announced they would be resumed on Monday.
WASHINGTON, March 25 (AP). -- President Roosevelt again discussed his railroad legislative program today with Congressional leaders and railway experts.

CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., March 23. -- Nowhere in Virginia perhaps is interest -- legal and illegal -- in the present status of the liquor situation so marked as in Central Piedmont, and there is ample reason for it. That district, actually and sentimentally, is the wettest portion of the State.

WASHINGTON, March 25. -- The influence of chemistry in linking industry and providing new outlets for farm products, new processes for producing gold and other metals, and its general effect on improvement in living conditions, will be discussed here next week at the annual meeting of the American Chemical Society.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., March 25. -- All phases of theatrical lighting, from the simplest settings to the complicated lighting of a special dance number, will be demonstrated before a group of professional designers, architects, engineers, and members of the Yale Drama Department as an invited audience on Monday and Tuesday at the Yale theatre.

AFTER having operated the Colon Opera of Buenos Aires at an actual deficit of 958,744 pesos (worth about 25 cents each) last year, the municipal commission in charge of the famous lyric theatre will have to get along with a subsidy of only 800,000 pesos in the 1933 season, according to a decision by the Board of Aldermen on Feb. 23 reported in Argentine papers.
SAN FRANCISCO, March 25 (AP). -- A chronology of the Mooney case follows:

PARIS, March 15. -- The approach of mid-Lent merely emphasizes the calm of an unusually quiet Winter season. The Opera, for the Monday and Friday subscription nights, continues to gather a distinguished crowd, and much brilliant dress is to be seen.

W.S. VAN DYKE and the first unit of the Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer polar expedition, which has been in the Arctic for several months filming "Eskimo," are now on the way back to California. The party is due at the studio base within the next two weeks.

BETHLEHEM, Pa., March 25. -- The little band of wrestlers from Oklahoma A. and M. who made the long overland trip from Stillwater by auto to compete in the National Collegiate A.A. championship meet captured three titles tonight to divide the honors of the sixth annual title tourney with Iowa State, which also annexed three championships.

WASHINGTON, March 25. -- Whether the United States will enter debt negotiations with France after Andre Lefebvre de Laboulaye arrives on April 12, if France has not paid her deferred Dec. 15 instalment of $19,000,000 by that time, is a question that is expected to be determined by President Roosevelt in the next few days.

MONTREAL, March 25. -- The Detroit Red Wings scored a brilliant National Hockey League play-off victory tonight, conquering the Montreal Maroons, 2 -- 0, in the first game of a home-and-home series, total goals to count, between the second-place teams.

A portrait of Mrs. Winifred Edgerton Merrill, the first woman to receive a degree from Columbia University, will be presented to the university at a ceremony at Columbia on March 31. Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of the university, will accept the painting and Dean Virginia Gildersleeve of Barnard College will make the presentation speech.

William Jay Schieffelin, chairman of the Citizens Union, replied yesterday to Governor Lehman's letter, in which the Governor expressed sympathy with legislation to amend the city home rule law to permit the voters of cities to Initiate charter changes.

Fred G. Clark of Cleveland, commander-in-chief of the Crusaders, anti-prohibition organization, in a telegram made public yesterday at the organization's local headquarters, 100 East Forty-second Street, called upon dry leaders of the nation to cooperate in a movement to preserve temperance and forestall the return of the old-fashioned saloon.

FOR many readers who are by no means superannuated it may need something of an effort to realize that a story dated from 1897 to the early years of the present century in properly labeled as a historical novel. Yet that period is now as effectively of the past as the age of the Pharaohs.

Immediate launching of a campaign by Japan to promote the use of silk in this country is being urged by American silk manufacturers. A petition is now being circulated by the Silk Association of America and has already been signed by leading silk interests, asking Japan to encourage increased use of silk by weavers here and to develop keener appreciation of the qualities of silk by the purchasing public.

The directors of Dividend Shares, an open-end investment trust sponsored by Calvin Bullock, its president, have proposed adding to the portfolio six common stocks and increasing capitalization from 20,000,000 shares of 25 cents par value each to 50,000,000 shares of the same par value.

MOST of the squatter villages that sprang up last year in the waste places of New York City have somehow come through the Winter. A score still lift their stovepipe chimneys to the sky, defying the cold; a few have vanished.

THE difficulties between England and Soviet Russia over the recent arrest of six British subjects working in Russia have raised the questions: What does the Soviet consider its sovereign rights in regard to aliens? And what is the legal status of aliens in Russia?
LONDON, March 25. -- A proposal to declare a nation-wide boycott on German goods has caused a, split in the Jewish Board of Deputies, which represents Britain's 300,000 Jews.

An exhibition illustrating the history of the plot of ground facing Broadway between Twenty-third and Twenty-fourth Streets has been arranged in the arcade of the Fifth Avenue Building, 200 Fifth Avenue, which occupies the site. Rare prints and costumes and other articles lent by the Museum ot the City of New York and private collectors throw light on the history of this plot of ground and the vicinity from the carry days of the city.

WASHINGTON, March 25. -- A campaign to stimulate State Legislatures to ratify the child labor amendment to the Constitution was recommended today to all State Federations of Labor and city central bodies by William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor.

The listed bond market was much steadier in tone yesterday than on Friday. Reich loans were again a centre of attention, and while many German corporation and municipal issues lost a point or more for the day, the government 7s recovered 7/8 point and the 5 1/2 s held unchanged.
LONDON. IN the last few days Europe's attention has been absorbd by two events which throw into sharp relief the essential problem of Europe's future.

PATCHOGUE, L.I., March 25. -- With ninety dogs having competed in four stakes, the Brookhaven Game Protective Association completed its eleventh Spring field trials tonight at Strongs Neck with the awarding of trophies in the Open All-Age Stake, feature of the two-day card.

In the sixteen years that he has been in prison Tom Mooney's case has become one of the most famous in the jurisprudence of the United States. It has been called "the American Dreyfus case," and the prisoner has been described as "a symbol of the class war."

EVERT once in so often a story comes alone, slight in texture. simply written, which at once achieves a popular success. This, it seems, is the history of this slim volume by Sigrid Boo, a young Norwegian girl whose "Servants' Entrance" has captured the imagination not only of Scandinavian countries but others where the book has been translated.

Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt spent another busy day here yesterday. She opened the International Flower Show in St. Louis by pressing a telegraph key in a ballroom at the Commodore while leaders of horticultural organizations looked on.

OMAHA, March 23. -- This section of the farm front is inclined to accept the Roosevelt relief plan on trial, reserving the right to turn hostile just as soon as its flaws, if any, may appear. The disposition is to go along with the President in what is regarded as a rather dubious experiment and hope for the best.

ALBANY, March 25. -- Senator Dunnigan, Democratic Senate chief, announced today that he would soon offer a resolution providing for creation of a joint legislative economy investigating committee to aid next year's Legislature in reducing the cost of the State government.

The advantages in many cases of the individual power plant for generating steam and electricity were explained to the members of the management division of the Real Estate Board of New York at their dinner meeting last week by Laurence Ernest Habben.

Booked far above their capacity, brewers of New York City disclosed yesterday that they would be compelled to allocate or ration beer when it is legal for them to fill the rush of orders that has nearly swamped them. Some brewers admit the possibility of a beer shortage.

Eastern District High School's fencing team, which previously had been the only unbeaten combination in the competition, met with a sur- prising 5-3 defeat at the hands of the Erasmus Hall representatives yesterday at Washington Irving High School in one of the matches contested in Division 2 of the City P.S.A.L. championship tournament.

WASHINGTON, Marsh 23. -- On Monday, March 6, the managing editor of the Paris Soir called me by telephone in Berlin and said: "Go, go to America without the loss of an hour. Fantastic things are going on there."

The American Council of Learned Societies has made awards aggregating $64,000 to fifty-seven scholars for research in the humanities, its committee on fellowships and grants announced yesterday. The awards comprised sixteen fellowships providing $1,800 a year and traveling expenses and forty-one grants in aid of research ranging from $100 to $1,000.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 25. -- With startling unexpectedness Judge Louis H. Ward of the Superior Court today granted to Thomas J. Mooney a trial on the remaining and untried indictment against him for complicity in the Preparedness Day bomb outrage.

WASHINGTON, March 25. -- A revision of the unemployment relief bill was undertaken today by the Senate Committee on Education and Labor in an effort to change it from an "employment" bill to a "relief" bill without changing its essential features.

PINEHURST, N.C., March 25. -- For the third year in succession, Miss Maureen Orcutt of Englewood, N.J., won the North and South women's golf championship today when she defeated Miss Bernice Wall of Oshkosh, Wis., 5 and 4, mainly through the effectiveness of her slender putter.

Louis Crawford Clark, a partner in the New York Stock Exchange firm of Clark, Dodge Co., of 61 Wall Street, who died on March 10 last, left his estate of undetermined Value to his widow and three children, by a former marriage, it was learned yesterday when his will was offered for probate in Surrogates' Court.

WASHINGTON March 25. -- Business activity was somewhat depressed during the week ended March 18, but some improvement was reported toward its close, according to the survey of domestic conditions made public today by the Commerce Department.

MILAN, Feb. 28, 1933. ONE of the three outstanding successes of the past two years in the field of Italian operatic novelties is, with little question, Igino Robbiani's three-act "Romanticismo," book by Arturo Rossato, which had its premiere recently at the Teatro della Fenice of Venice, where it scored a remarkable triumph.
DECATUR, Ala., March 25. -- Attorney General Thomas E. Knight ordered a Statewide search today for Ruby Bates, missing witness in Alabama's cause celebre, the Scottsboro case, involving nine Negroes.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Having resided in Manchuria for several years as American Consul General and subsequently as adviser to the war lord Chang Tso-lin, I desire to contribute the following information in connection with your comment relating to the Chinese practice of throwing out dead children or throwing living babies out to die.

PALM BEACH, Fla., March 25. -- Mr. and Mrs. Peter A.B. Widener 2d and Joseph E. Wldener were dinner hosts tonight at II Palmetto for the Duke of Sutherland, Mr. and Mrs. Archibald Barklie, Mrs. Spalding Jenkins, Mrs. Edward Roberts, Colonel and Mrs. Barclay M. Warburton and Mr. and Mrs. John C. King.

Army "chow," prepared by army cooks in nine motorized field kitchens of the Sixteenth United States Infantry, will be the fare of 4,000 persons who will attend the dinner on the night of April 3 at the 107th (old Seventh) Regiment Armory, Park Avenue and Sixty-sixth Street, Which will start the Salvation Army.
With the approach of the Easter holidays in college and school calendars, several entertainments have been arranged for the students who will be in town during that period.

THE American intervention in Haiti, which began in 1915 and is not entirely ended, has been responsible for several books by American authors. Two of them are literature -- "The Magic Island." by W.B. Seabrook, and "Black Haiti," by Blair Niles.

BERLIN, March 25 (AP). -- Captain Hermann Wilhelm Goering, Minister without portfolio, today redeemed his pledge to permit foreign correspondents to see and talk to prominent arrested Communists and other members of the Left, in order that they might satisfy themselves that the prisoners were neither dead nor injured.

ABOUT one family of every thirty in this country has an oil burner. Most oil burners are of the so-called pressure type. As the name implies, the oil is atomized on the perfume-spraying principle, whereupon it is ignited. This process of atomization is ar- companied by a wearing away of the nozzle.

PHILADELPHIA, March 25. -- On the same court in which Jay Gould defeated G.F. Covey of Crabbet Park, London, the world's champion, almost twenty years ago, James H. Van Alen brought the two-year reign of William C. Wright to an end today and restored the national amateur court tennis crown to New York for the first time since 1929.

In The Saturday Evening Post for March 25, Mr. EVERETT SANDERS prints a few letters which he received from ex-President COOLIDGE at different dates in 1932. They are of little consequence except as showing Mr. COOLIDGE'S desire to aid the Republican party in last year's campaign in all ways within his power.

THE law which changes the manufacture and sale of beverages containing 3.2 per cent of alcohol by weight from a criminal act into a legitimate business enterprise makes the retail distribution of beer once more a recognized factor in politics.

HOWEVER March came in, the lion and the lamb are both occupying gallery space as the month goes out. From the old master of Impressionism to the newest abstractionist, the exhibitions continue undiminished in number and enthusiasm.

EXPEDIENTS designed to remedy the existing mortgage situation today must recognize the necessity of providing for the keystone of the whole situation -- the small home owner, the mortgagor. Consider Frank T. Smith, the owner of a small home, one of hundreds of thousands.
A Federal Trade System which would aim to organize industry on a national basis is described by Samuel S. Fels, Philadelphia soap manufacturer, in the current issue of The Survey Graphic.

GENEVA, March 25. -- While Italy paid a glowing tribute to Prime Minister MacDonald of Great Britain and supported his disarmament treaty less cautiously than the others, the Little Entente voiced today opposition to Premier Mussolini's plan and warned against treaty revision talk.

LONDON. THE British Government's longawaited scheme for a federal Constitution for India has been laid before Parliament. It is the fruit of prolonged discussions in three round-table confer- ences, of a long series of studies and reports of extensive experi- ence in governing this vast Oriental empire.

THE Philharmonic-Symphony Society's newly formed junior auxiliary is an organization rich in promise for the future. For more than a generation past New York's educational concerts for children and young people have furnished examples widely copied by orchestras in this country and even in Europe.

G.C. Schwalb and C. Scbad tie for the high scratch cup at the Jamaica Bay traps of the Berge Beach Gun Club yesterday. Each finished the regular shoot by breaking forty-eight out of fifty targets In the shoot-off, Schwalb scored 24 -- 23.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I wonder if your readers will be able to suffer a few words of sympathy from an unimportant British voice, a New Zealand voice, incidentally, yet not, I believe, an unrepresentative voice. We are sorry for you, sincerely sorry, and not less so because of our manifold troubles which have left us in the peaceful, if not happy, condition when nothing more can possibly hurt us.

THE Dancers Club, after a brave effort to keep its troubles to itself, has finally been forced to admit that it is facing the possibility of having to close its doors and much against its will is asking for public support in order to prevent this catastrophe.

Judging by the large subscription that has been received for the performances of the annual production of the Lighthouse Players on the nights of April 5 and 6 at the Lighthouse Little Theatre, 111 East Fifty-ninth Street, the funds for carrying on the work of that organization will be augmented appreciably.
PRINCETON, N.J., March 25. -- Scoring all its points before Princeton could tally, the New York Rugby Club defeated the Tiger fifteen, 7 -- 5, today in Princeton's first game of the season.
CHARLESTON, S.C., March 23. -- This city of Yankee tourists, azaleas, Winter gardens and flowering spaces has something else that few other cities now have -- fire department horses.

MORE than one hundred years after his most exuberant lyric period had passed. Wordsworth still holds for the student of poetry an attraction commensurate with his exalted rank among English poets. This attraction, however, has often proved to be for commentators a temptation into devious ways.

Under the patronage of many prominent women of society, there will be a showing of the latest Spring costumes and accessories, in behalf of the hygiene and social service committee of the Lenox Hill Neighborhood Association, on Wednesday and Thursday at the River Club.
GLENS FALLS, N.Y., March 25. -- Union Hill High of Union City, N.J., champion of Hudson County, won the Eastern States tournament tonight, defeating the Waterford, N.Y., High quintet, by 30 to 22.

VARNISHING on Friday and opening to the public yesterday, the National Academy of Design once more decorates the current exhibition calendar. The Spring showing will be discussed here next Sunday. Meanwhile, Claude Monet, who is helping the House of Durand-Ruel celebrate its 130th anniversary, serves to remind us that the last word concerning impressionism can never be spoken.

Donie Bush, manager of the Cincinnati Reds, thinks that the base on balls is demoralizing to a team. He has his squad in Winter quarters at Tampa, Fla., and recently gave a talk to the rookie pitchers. Bush stressed control and more control, and went on to say that a base on balls is more demoralizing to a team than a base hit.

An American foreign policy in the Far East based on "utility" rather than on "morality," and a more consistent adherence to whatever policy this country might adopt in its relations with Japan, were suggested yesterday by George E. Sokolsky, writer on Far Eastern affairs, at a luncheon of the Foreign Policy Association in the Hotel Astor.

CHARLESTON, S.C. -- The season of Charleston's famous gardens is now reaching its peak. The azaleas of Magnolia Gardens are at the crest of their beauty both in color and profusion, and Middleton Place Gardens are in full bloom, although the height there is considered to come a week later than Magnolia.

One hundred and four years ago a letter from a boating member of St. John's College, Cambridge University, to an oarsman of Christ Church at Oxford resulted in the birth of the oldest intercollegiate sporting event in the world. On Saturday, over the historic 4 miles 374 yards of the Thames course, the oarsmen of Oxford and Cambridge will meet for the eighty-fifth time in the series of boat races started in 1829.

Predicting that common sales agencies of the type validated by the United States Supreme Court decision in the Appalachian Coals case will be set up shortly in other natural resource industries, such as lumber, copper and oil, George A. Renard, secretary-treasurer of the National Association of Purchasing Agents, said yesterday that buying executives will welcome the opportunity of cooperating with any supplier group which seeks to eliminate trade abuses.

IT is about time that Helen Hayes, who has either suffered or breathed her last in five pictures, had an opportunity to contribute her histrionic talent to a cheery story. In her first film, "The Sin of Madelon Claudet," she passed away after enduring all possible sorrow, including a term in prison for a crime of which she was guiltless.
WASHINGTON, March 25. -- The Bureau of Navigation issued the following orders today, dated March 23:

BENEFITS to the tire-buying public, to the dealer and to the manufacturer are expected to result from the price reductions announced last week by major tire producers and their decision to confine their activities to only two lines of products.

THERE have been axioms about the genesis of palywrights, and many legends. sone of them, as they say, have been born to the third act, and some have been newspaper men first. Ocassionaly, it is quite difficult to follow what can be called The Growth of An Idea, to see, in short, just where the plot started.
The facts and foibles of American life were outlined yesterday, at length and with emphasis and vigor, by Senator Huey Long, Louisiana's "Kingfish," in an interview at the Hotel New Yorker.

WHEN the San Capador sailed from San Pedro (Los Angeles's port) her passenger list included the reporter-novelist Steve Bramley and a quartet of San Francisco society folk: Mr. and Mrs. Jay Holmans and their guests, the polo player Gregory March with his fiancee Elise (still undecided whether to marry Gregory or become the second Mrs. Holmans.

One thing that Chancellor HITLER has anew demonstrated during the past week is the existence of a collective moral sentiment of the modern world. He seemed quite unaware of what he was doing in this respect. His words and acts were in praise of the new might and glory of the German Reich, which he thought of as uncontrolled and dominant.

THE approaching trial of Judge Harold Louderback of California on impeachment charges is the eleventh of its kind in American history. Eight judges, a Senator, a President and a Secretary of War in times past have been accused by the House of Representatives of "high crimes and misdemeanors."

SOUTH BEND, Ind., March 25 (AP). -- John McCormack, lyric tenor, will be the 1933 recipient of the Laetare medal of the University of Notre Dame. Proclamation of the award comes by custom on the fourth Sunday of the Lenten season, called Laetare Sunday.

BERLIN, March 24. -- By the time this is being read the new Germany will have a new flag. It will be the black-white-red of Bismarck's Germany with the swastika -- the hooked cross -- of the National Socialists superimposed on the white.

DES MOINES, Iowa. AN experiment in using the public schools as forums for adults in which current political and economic problems can be freely discussed is now beginning in Des Moines. This project, which is to run for five years, is administered by the local Board of Education and is financed by a grant of $120,000 from the Carnegie Corporation through the American Association for Adult Education.

LITTLE or nothing, to be sure, is done about it, but the school and college examination system has begun to vie with our economic system as a target of attack. East and West in the past fortnight the mud has been flying.
WASHINGTON, March 25 (AP). -- Any change in present plans for constructing public buildings throughout the United States must be made by President Roosevelt.

The name of Carl Gray, president of the Union Pacific Railroad, was mentioned prominently yesterday for the position of Federal moderator for railroads, which is contemplated in President Roosevelt's legislative program for the carriers. Mr. Gray's name was put forward not only because he stands high among the managements but particularly because he is understood to hold the confidence of Mr. Roosevelt.
WASHINGTON, March 25. -- Colonel George B. McClellan, former Mayor of New York City and a member of Congress for five terms, is in Emergency Hospital with a broken leg suffered in a fall.

A program of Chinese music was given last night at Roerich Hall under the auspices of the Chinese Roerich Association. The program included contemporary work songs of Chinese coolies in action, folk-song's, lyrics, a condensed version of the Chinese opera, "Cho Fang Tsao," and instrumental music.
NEW YORK. Charles E.P. McCann and Miss Haiena McCann have left Palm Beach and are in Aiken, S.C., before returning to 4 East Eightieth Street.

SAN FRANCISCO, Cal., March 25. -- Fourteen persons were killed, one man was injured and three houses were destroyed by fire when a transport plane crashed into a private residence at 1,281 144th Avenue, between San Leandro and Hayward, tonight.

This week brings the concluding events of the Spring field trial season on Long Island and it will be a busy period for the enthusiasts who take delight in following the work of pointers and setters in competition, with two meetings scheduled.

Revival of bright colored fieldflower prints after two seasons of white-pattern prints is the direct result of consumer demand, Tobe, fashion and merchandise counselor to retail stores, says in a report prepared especially for THE TIMES. Women all over the country asked for colorful prints that were soft and flattering, Tobe asserts.

Business was aided last week by a gathering movement toward the conversion of hoarded or other cash into goods. This development has been nationwide in scope, and has proceeded despite the simultaneous restoration of deposits in reopened banks.

To the Editor of The New York Times: There is an expression in legal parlance that "hard ke bad law." This I have found to be true in many instances, but recently I have read a reported case (157 N. Y., 541) which came squarely to the question of applying an adopted and well-known rule of law to the facts in hand.

TRAILING not clouds of glory but simply his dog, Jimmie, on the end of a leash, Gilbert Miller, world traveler and modest wearer of the title, once bestowed, of "the most civilized producer in America," leaped from the baggage car of the Twentieth Century Limited arriving in Grand Central Terminal the other morning and thus returned to New York from a six weeks' "term" in Hollywood.

CINCINNATI, March 25 (AP). -- Daniel Willard, president of the Baltimore Ohio Railroad, said today that an increase of from 10 to 15 per cent in their business would make everything "all right," for the railroads again.

PARIS. IT is amusing to watch the progress of certain textiles. They are like travelers who start out on a trip round the world; some of them make the whole journey, while others stop off en route and settle down to finish their life far from their point of departure.

To the Editor of The New York Times: When the Congress ratified the repeal resolution containing the provision for conventions in the several States, it was through. It has no more power of any kind of dictation or advice than had the Continental Congress in 1787, and that Congress had none.

THE impresarios of the Metropolitan Opera, who a little more than a year ago reluctantly yielded to the overtures of the broadcasters to install microphones in the shadow of the Golden Horseshoe, now look to the radio to assist in rescuing the opera and keep it going, according to Lucrezia Bori, the noted soprano, who is chairman of a fund-raising committee representing the artists, the producing organization and the boxholders at the Opera House.

WASHINGTON, March 25. -- Congress must trust the President to exercise "sound discretion" in dealing with the farm problem by means of the relief bill now pending, Secretary Wallace told the Senate Agriculture Committee today, in urging that the measure be passed, intact.

BALTIMORE, March 25. --The Smith Reynolds fortune, estimated up to $19,000,000, may be distributed by the Baltimore Circuit Court, on the petition of the Safe Deposit and Trust Company, as trustees for the estate.

MIAMI. -- Two big events for lovers of flowers will mark this week. The third annual International Tropical Flower Show at Miami Beach will open on Wednesday and continue until Sunday, and the annual convention of the National Council of Garden Club Federations will also open on Wednesday and continue through Saturday.
To the Editor of The New York Times: The six bases for a fight on beer which have been mapped by the Anti-Saloon League are, from the legal point of view, merely frivolous.
INDIANAPOLIS, March 25. -- Rain and quickly melting snow throughout Indiana today caused some fear of additional flood damage along the lower courses of the Ohio and Wabash Rivers.

WASHINGTON, March 25. -- An inevitable slackening of the administration's headlong pace became as tangible as the dome of the Capitol this week. It is not precisely a case of "Oxus, forgetting the bright speed he had in his high mountain-cradle in Pamere," for the river was old when it began to move in a slow, broad channel, and the administration is still very new.

RING LARDNER has missed a trick. Time was when the Brooklyn National League baseball club was known as the Daffiness Boys. A genial fat man by the name Uncle Wilbert Robinson managed the team in a lackadaisical fat man's way, but with surprising results, for all that.
ATLANTA, Ga., March 25 (AP). -- Beer may wash the borders of Dixie, but so far only one State has defected definitely from the dry tradition of the Solid South.

As a result of the increased importance of the International scrapiron trade since the start of the year, a scrap export organization will be formed shortly under the Webb-Pomerene law, Benjamin Sehwartz, director general of the Institute of Scrap Iron and Steel, said here yesterday.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., March 23. -- Arkansas has avoided default upon its $146,000,000 high-way obligation by an exchange of outstanding bonds for new bonds, bearing 3 per cent interest. This action was taken by the General Assembly because revenue from highway taxes would have been insufficient to meet interest and maturity requirements.

CAMP DIX. N.J., March 25. -- As a target for attacking planes, Camp Dix was under a rain of aerial bombs for several hours, today, when aviators from Mitchel Field opened their war practice manoeuvres, which will continue until April 10.
A composite portrait of 8,266 City College freshmen was drawn yesterday by Professor Arthur Frank Payne, personnel director, on the basis of four years of psychological testing.

PROFESSOR MILLER is a sociologist who has traveled extensively and "engaged in happy controversy" with a graduate class at Ohio State University. "I also owe more than can be measured," he says, "to numerous lecture audiences on whom I have tried out my ideas."
WASHINGTON, March 25. -- President Roosevelt is finding it an uphill task to recruit an advisory committee on the subject of war debts.

The decline in first-class travel across the Atlantic has been keenly felt by the stewards on the big liners. Although the staffs have been considerably reduced, there are still hardly enough passengers to go round for the saloon waiters, bedroom stewards and stewardesses.

CANADA'S new rule to limit advertising on the radio to a minimum of 5 per cent of each program after April 1 may have an influence on several broadcasts from the United States which are also handled by the stations in the Dominion.
To the Editor of The New York Times: In a letter from Albert H. Roberts to THE TIMES the following statement appears: "With the passing of March 4 as inauguration date," c.

At the end of a three-day examination of witnesses, State Attorney General John J. Bennett Jr. announced yesterday that he would not take any action against the Straus Securities Company, 60 Wall Street, against which the charge was made that it was in substance the S.W. Straus Co., Inc., of 565 Fifth Avenue, which had moved to the Wall Street address and continued in business after it consented to a receivership.

Attracting large crowds throughout the day, the twentieth International Flower Show closed last night at the Grand Central Palace. Officials estimated that the number of admissions on the closing day approached the total for Wednesday, when an all-time record of 29,960 was set.

Z.G. Simmons Jr. led a field of thirty gunners at the Travers Island traps of the New York A.C. yesterday, taking the high scratch cup by breaking 98 out of 100 targets. The second cup went to C. W. Phellis, who had 97. The scores were excellent considering the handicap of a high wind.

PALM BEACH. -- In line with the tendency of the majority of regular Winter visitors to linger for an unusually late season, hotels are setting their closing dates well into April and May, and clubs and smart rendezvous are following their lead.

TOKYO, March 9. -- The idea that the Japanese Army is running the government and dictating national policy was refuted in an interview given to THE NEW YORK TIMES today by Viscount Kikujiro Ishii, who is sailing for the United States about the end of March.

PARIS, March 10. JEAN GIRAUDOUX'S new play, "Intermezzo," has been called a fairy story, but if it is one it is written for very grown-up children. Moreover, they would have to be French grown-up children, interested less in persons than in humanity, less in happenings than in speculations, less in character than in intellect.

High tribute was paid to Richard Wagner in the Soviet Union last month on the occasion of the fiftieth anniversary of his death, not only as a musical genius but also as a one-time revolutionist and friend of Mikhail Bakunin.
ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 25. -- Babe Ruth wasn't hitting today. Yankee bats generally were stilled, and the net result was a victory for the Boston Braves at Waterfront Park, 4 -- 2.

WASHINGTON, March 25 (AP). -- Indications of willingness to co-operate with the Crusaders in seeking "solution of the liquor problem" were given today by the Methodist Board of Temperance, Prohibition and Public Morals and the Anti-Saloon League.

CHICAGO, March 25. -- Persistent commission-house and local buying, based partly on talk of inflation and the strong cash situation that recently developed, more than offset today everything of a bearish influence in the wheat market on the Board of Trade and carried the May future up 2 cents a bushel after an early break.

Development of Westchester County's park system, an enterprise which was started in 1922, has tended to increase realty values since that time, and during the past three years of economic stress has helped to stabilize conditions in many sections, real estate men believe.

DERIVED from the very fast heavy bomber which has stepped up the speed of this class of fighting aircraft practically to that of pursuit planes for the Air Cprps, the first of the new twin-engined passenger transports, sixty of which are to play the nation-wide routes of United Air Lines, has taken the air.
PROVIDENCE, March 25. -- The town, of Exeter, R.I., with a present population of 1,314, borrowed $9,150 in 1861, still owes the money, and has paid interest of more than $25,000 for the privilege.

ISTANBUL. THE once great Kingdom of Pontus, which owed its rise in power nearly 2,000 years ago to its very isolation, is becoming accessible to the outside world. Railroads have displaced some of the ancient caravan trails, and improved highways have opened up this rich wheat belt and made travel relatively easy and pleasant.
