The New York Rangers and the Canadiens of Montreal will swing into action tonight at Madison Square Garden, where they will clash in the first game of the third place play-off round of the series to determine the world's professional hockey championship.

THAT the erection of artificial barriers -- of regulation, legislation or taxation -- cannot be permitted to stay the tide of progress in air transport is the opinion of transport operators after further study of the report of the National Transportation Committee.

WASHINGTON, March 25 (AP). -- Secretary Wallace, making his first appearance at a public Congressional committee hearing, impressed the Senate group today with his straightforward statements and ready answers to a rapid fire of questions.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 23. -- But still a ruby kindles in the California vine, and it isn't a three-point-two ruby, either. What the California grape growers want to know is who put it into Senator McAdoo's head to tack a 3.2 per cent wine clause on the beer bill.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, March 25 (AP). -- Scoring games of 463, 352 and 470, Lou Marone and Ralph Thomas of Pittsburgh took second place in the doubles division of the American Bowling Congress today with a total of 1,285. Marone scored games of 209, 188 and 247 while his partner tallied 254, 164 and 223.

AIKEN. -- The Aiken season will reach a climax during the week with the seventeenth annual Horse Show, which opens on Wednesday afternoon at 3 o'clock. There will be the open jumping class for the afternoon and, after an off-day Thursday, the show will be resumed at 10:30 on Friday morning.

SUMTER, S.C., March 23. -- A sales tax is a burning issue in the Carolinas as the Legislatures of the two States continue to work weeks overtime in an effort to keep the public schools, the institutions of higher learning and other State departments and agencies on something more than starvation wages without recourse to some new form of taxation.
I HAVE a very strong opinion that every university on the face of the earth ought to be leveled to the ground and its foundations sowed with salt.

TORONTO, Ont., March 25. -- Mining men from all parts of the Dominion will meet here under the auspices of the Canadian Institute of Mining and Metallurgy on April 4, 5 and 6, to discuss the developments in the industry. The program calls for some forty addresses by authorities on various phases of mining.

MINEOLA, L.I., March 25. -- Keen competition featured the weekly shoot over the traps of the Nassau Trapshooting Club today. In the singles, G.E. Mole and W.F. Ke cham tied for the High Scratch Cup Each had 49 out of 50 targets. In the first shoot-off they again tie with 24 targets each.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 25. -- G. Herman Ruth, starting on a season that will round out twenty years of service in the major leagues, was sitting in the dugout pounding a ball into his glove. Did he remember the day when he first joined the select circle?

Real estate interest in and around Greenwich, Conn., is showing many evidences of improvement. Reports from the various brokers indicate that more sales and leases have been closed in Greenwich since the first of the year than were consummated during the entire Fall and Winter season.

ATLANTA, March 23. -- The principal gloom which has rested on Georgians was dissipated when the Legislature, unwept and unsung, stopped its filibustering long enough to accomplish its most applauded and most worthwhile feat -- adjournment.

NO more important contribution to reform of judicial procedure has been made than by this book published by the Legal Research Institute of the University of Michigan. Mr. Ragland's work is of technical interest to lawyers, but is of greater importance to the public and especially to those interested in improving the administration of justice.

AN ordinary map shows the general contours of countries and lesser divisions, cities and villages, roads and streams, lakes and the like. It is good enough for the broad purposes of the geographer but not good enough for the property owner (State, country, city or private person), the engineer, the architect and the general staff of an army.
CHARLESTON, S.C., March 25. -- Walter Hagen, the veteran shotmaker from Detroit, won the $2,500 Charleston open golf tournament and its $700 first money today with a 72-hole score of 282.
The government hopes to bring Charles E. Mitchell, former chairman of the National City Bank, to trail in about three weeks, it was indicated at the Federal Building yesterday.

SOME years ago Alfred L. Loomis, who spends three days a week in Wall Street as the executive of an important bank and the other days in his laboratory in Tuxedo Park, N.Y., reached the conclusion that the physicists had not been paying attention enough to sound.

There has been an encouraging subscription for the lecture, "New Odysseys for Old" by Byron D. MacDonald on Wednesday night at the Biltmore, for the benefit of the American Colony Charities Association. Motion pictures of modern scenes and customs in ancient countries will be shown in conjunction with the lecture.

IS there a psychological suggestion in the title of this little book, that if you buy it you will be providing yourself with a package of an elusive possession that everybody wants? Is Dr. Goodspeed practicing upon possible readers a subtle form of that salesmanship about which he writes in one of these essays?

THE frank young president of student government gazed at me in amazement. "Why, there's all the difference in the world!" she cried. "You go to any intercollegiate convention and the co-eds don't raise their voices. They wait for the men in their delegations to speak.

PARIS, March 24. -- Those who sit on the sidelines watching Europe's great statesmen trying to work out the jig-saw puzzle of peace have, during the last week, been filled with apprehension that the pieces were getting more hopelessly mixed up than ever.

PARIS, March 25 (AP). -- Surprise was expressed at the Foreign Office tonight at a statement by Secretary of State Hull at Washington that he could not say whether war debt discussions would be held by the United States with nations which have defaulted.

In order to raise funds for carrying on the work of the 1,075 Madison Avenue Soup Kitchen, members of the Junior Branch of the New York Women's League for Animals will repeat their performance of Shakespeare's "Merchant of Venice" on the night of April 5 at the headquarters of the MacDowell Club, 166 East Seventy-third Street.

A collection of Americana, comprising prints, marine paintings, furniture, silver and glass, together with English decorative porcelains and table services from the estate of the late Charles Hitchcock Tyler of Boston, will be offered at auction at the American Art Association Anderson Galleries, Inc., on Thursday, Friday and Saturday afternoons.

WASHINGTON, March 25. -- The apparent slowing up of the Roosevelt rehabilitation program in the Senate is occasioning considerable comment, if not criticism, in the House, where some of the majority spokesmen are frankly fearful that the teamwork which has marked legislation in the special session thus far may be disrupted and the administration may lose prestige through undue delay in the enactment of its farm bill and other relief measures.

Charles A. Oberwager, former magistrate, who in the early days of the World War was counsel for Lieut. Col. Franz von Papen, German Vice Chancellor, made public last night a cable message he had sent to the Vice Chancellor urging the lifting of German restrictions on American newspaper correspondents.

SOUTHERN PINES, N.C. -- With many activities on the calendar for the remaining days of March, the colony here will turn from a varied program of sports to witness the Pinehurst Horse Show on Thursday and Friday. Southern Pines entries will include horses owned by Mrs. Magruder Dent of Greenwich, Conn.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., March 25. -- Cleaving the waters of the Yale pool with a powerful and rhythmic stroke, Donald Horn of Northwestern swam to a new world's record in the 200-yard breast stroke tonight to furnish one of the outstanding achievements of the tenth annual National Collegiate A.A. championships.

DETROIT. THERE is a certain quality about Henry Ford which thrusts him from time to time into the centre of public interest, whether or not he desires it. Aloof and engrossed in his factories along the River Rouge, his personality nevertheless overhangs this metropolis.

MOSCOW, March 25. -- Allan Monkhouse, chief of the Metropolitan-Vickers Electrical Company's staff in Russia, was instructed today to offer "reasonable bail" for his arrested colleagues on condition that the nine Russians of the company's staff as well as the four Englishmen be released.
PARIS, March 25. -- The struggle of the French Foreign Legion to subdue recalcitrant tribesmen in Morocco is officially called "pacification," but the casualty lists are those of a good-sized war.

RETAIL trade in areas not unduly affected by banking difficulties made a fair showing for the week. Locally, sales picked up briskly after the first few days of unfavorable weather and held this improvement to the close.

No announcement has been made so far at the offices of the Cunard and White Star lines in this city as to the cancellation of sailings as suggested by Neville Chamberlain, Chancellor of the Exchequer, recently in London to curtail the heavy cost of operation.

PARIS, March 16. -- If the new American Ambassador to France, Jesse I. Straus, happens to be a connoisseur of wines, he may experience difficulty in finding room for his private stock in the already overcrowded cellar at the embassy residence.

STOCKHOLM, March 13. -- While the wheels of Swedish law for nearly a year, in proceedings more gigantic than any ever before known to the courts of this city, have slowly been grinding out sentences and imposing fines on directors and others identified with the Kreuger Toll case, new appraisals of Ivar Kreuger the man come occasionally to light.

ALBANY, March 25. -- Democrats in the Legislature plan an effort, when Governor Lehman's beer control bill comes up for debate next week, to insure that the beverage be really available as the "poor workingman's drink." They fear that the prohibition on sale of the beverage over a bar will militate against that end.

SAN JUAN, P.R., March 22. -- No change of national administration in recent years has found Puerto Rico as little concerned as at present with the question of who its new Governor is to be. The reason for this so far as can be determined is that here there is no active demand for a change.

Preparations are now being made for the annual Butterfly Ball, a fixture of the Spring season, which is to take place on Friday of Easter week -- April 21 -- at the RitzCarlton. As in past years, the net proceeds will be devoted to the maintenance of the House of Rest, a hospital at Sprain Ridge, near Yonkers, for the treatment of pulmonary tuberculosis.

For more than a quarter of an hour yesterday 10-year-old Fred O'Donnell of 942 Willow Avenue, Hoboken, speechless from fright, clung to a jagged rock with his feet braced upon a narrow ledge halfway down the perpendicular side of King's Bluff, a 200-foot cliff at Weehawken, before he was rescued by firemen.

YALE debaters on the eastern edge of the American Continent recently contested with Cambridge students who faced a microphone in London. They talked about the cancellation of war debts. A bundle of the listeners' comments forwarded by the British Broadcasting Corporation gives American broadcasters an insight into England's radio mail, and incidentally an idea of what some of the public over there think about the war obligations.

At the meeting of the executive committee of the National Association of Amateur Oarsmen, held last night in the New York Athletic Club, it was decided to award this year's national regatta to Chicago. It will be held at the World's Fair, tentative dates being Aug. 4 and 5.

Continuation of banking difficulties in several parts of the country is reflected in THE NEW YORK TIMES weekly business index for the week ended March 18. While the drop was not as sharp as in the previous week, a further easing of all series except car loadings brought the combined index to a low point of 47.9 from 48.4 for the preceding week.

Governor Lehman's proposal to change the State stock transfer tax so as to impose a flat rate of 3 cents a share on all shares selling at less than $20, would check the present trend toward stocks with a par value ranging from $1 to $10 a share, brokers believe.

Sharp differences of opinion concerning the best type of legislation for checking the spread of "supermarkets" split the grocery industry into two camps last week. In one group is the American Wholesale Grocers Association, sponsoring a bill for introduction, into Legislatures of all States.

THIS 1932 volume of the American Year Book follows the general plan of its predecessors, which long ago proved their necessity as reference books for the desk or shelf of professional men and women of every sort and for general readers who want their information about current affairs to be definite and accurate.

HSINKING, Manchuria, Feb. 25. -- Irritated at the pronounced anti-Manchukuo attitude of certain of the smaller European powers, Manchukuo Government officials are casting about for some means of retaliation. The authorities are particularly incensed at the stand taken by Czechoslovakia in the deliberations of the League of Nations and there have been strong hints from government circles that something drastic will be done about it.

JAPAN has presented a novel spectacle in the last eighteen months. While larger military powers have kept their guns inactive, she has conquered Manchuria. While they have been fully occupied with the depression, she has been enjoying the semblance of a "little boom."

WASHINGTON. THE new President sits at the big glass-topped desk in the beautiful oval room which has walled in a succession of Presidents. He sits remarkably at ease. Energy is the note he strikes on the ear of the country, but at close range this ease in office is even more impressive.

PARIS. THOUGH in "Profits et Pertes de l'Art Contemporain -- Vers un Nouvel Humanism." Waldemar George seems too eager to prove the point that classic antiquity always has been and always must be at the heart of European art if it is to have a heart, his book nevertheless makes excellent reading and is full of salient expression.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 23. -- State job holders, right up to the members of the Governor's Cabinet, are in a ferment over the probability that there will be a shake-up preparatory to the launching of the campaign for a second term for Governor Rolph.

BASLE, March 24. -- Leon Fraser, who will become president of the World Bank in May, is now on the liner Rex going to the United States for a fortnight's visit. He declined to speak of his plans before sailing except to say he was mixing business with pleasure.

PREPARED in order to meet an increasing and insistent demand for such a publication in the English language, this first attempt to produce a year book of the League; its organization and finanspeaking countries is evidence of the deeply rooted importance of that institution to the modern world and of the world's recognition of its permanent character.

Asserting that he had just talked with several persons reported killed by the Hitlerites, Miles Bouton, correspondent in Germany of The Baltimore Sun, denied last night in an address rebroadcast from Berlin over National Broadcasting Company networks that there had been any atrocities against the Jews in Germany.

Bridge parties in conjunction with luncheons and fashion shows will be held in the near future for the benefit of various philanthropic enterprises. A card party in behalf of Everybody's Thrift Shop will be held on the afternoon of April 20 in the Regency Room of the Carlyle.

In the carefully prepared statement for the American public which Mr. MATSUOKA issued on landing in New York, the Japanese delegate made a plea for looking at the "realities" in Manchuria. Over against these he set certain "fictions." Among them he named the assumption of the Nine-Power treaty that there was such a thing as "the territorial integrity of China."

Exploration is still thought of as a phase of adventure rather than of science. Yet it must rank in importance with the work that the physicists and chemists are doing in tearing bits of matter apart in order to discover of what the earth and the stars are made. It is science at its empirical best.
ITHACA, N.Y., March 25. -- Cornell defeated Syracuse and Colgate in Central New York's first triangular indoor track meet tonight, scoring 68 points to 30 1/2 for the Orange and 8 1/2 for the Maroon.

THE problems of a father who, through shyness, has allowed himself to become too separated from his children and his household, are depicted in this book, and the solution offered, if it may be called a solution, is a distinctly gloomy one, since it implies that nothing but a series of the most crushing disasters falling on the heads of his children will bring them even the fraction of an inch nearer to him.

IN connection with proposals for the blending of alcohol with gasoline for use in motor cars, the Standard Oil Company of New Jersey has analyzed the suitability of such fuel blend and has come to the conclusion that the benefits of an alcohol-gasoline mixture on engine performance are far overbalanced by the disadvantages.

NEW ORLEANS, March 25. -- One of the closest finishes in the history of the Louisiana Derby occurred today at the Fair Grounds when Col. Hatfield won by a neck from Spicson which Rained the place by a head from Gyro. The victory was worth $4,750 to the winner and was scored over a muddy track at the expense of several well fancied Kentucky Derby eligibles.

Plans for the approaching transit unification negotiations with holders of B.M.T. and Interborough securities were discussed by Mayor O'Brien yesterday at a three-hour conference with John H. Delaney, chairman of the Board of Transportation, and "William G. Fullen, chairman of the Transit Commission.

CAIRO, March 3. -- Quite by acci- dent an archaeological discovery was made early last Summer in Upper Egypt which has just now, after further investigation, resulted in the identification of a diorite quarry of the Old and Middle Kingdoms of ancient Egypt -- lost 3,500 years -- the location of which had been hitherto unknown to Egyptologists and geologists, although diligently sought in recent times.

ZOE AKINS, who disappeared into those azure hazes of the West some time ago, is coming back again. Her association with some motion-picture people named Paramount ceased, as a matter of fact, just before the recent unpleasantness.

The fact that the town of Stamford, Conn., has just fixed its tax rate at 15 mills, the lowest town rate since 1925, and the prospects for a lower city tax rate, to be fixed in April, lend encouragement to real estate men and property owners of that district.

Although the banking community is prepared to accept a rigid revision of the banking laws and to conform to more detailed and rigorous supervision of banking affairs than ever before, there is one proposal that bankers here still vigorously oppose -- any plan for guaranteeing bank deposits.

Transportation agencies other than the railroads are endangered by legislative policies which have been built up during the period when the railroads predominated as a means of transporting passengers and freight on long-distance routes, according to Roger D. Lapham, president of the American-Hawaiian Steamship Line.

TUNGKLIAO, Manchuria, Feb. 27. -- Comparative peace has settled down on this frontier city amid the sandy wastes of western Manchuria. Tungliao is slowly coming back after a year which was made horrible by repeated bandit attacks, bombing raids, unspeakable murders, devastating floods and death-dealing plagues.

WASHINGTON, March 25 (AP). -- The possibility of more revenue from the beer and wine legislation than had been estimated was held out today by Dr. James M. Doran, Industrial Alcohol Commissioner, who said he would announce next week regulations permitting the use of wine to flavor non-alcoholic drinks.

To the Editor of The New York Times: THE TIMES recent editorial, "Spring in the Mind," found quick response among your readers. We are glad that city folk are aroused to such fine expression by things deeply cherished in the country.

THE story of Henry M. Leipziger's life makes an eloquent commentary on tne world's forgetfulness of those who have served it well. New York City ought to remember long and gratefully the splendid and unselfish service he gave her people.

AT the League of Composers concert to be given Sunday evening April 16 in the Town Hall, the sound-film "Adna" (Alone) will be given its first American presentation. The picture deals with the adventures of a young girl from Moscow who essays to teach the Soviet doctrines to the inhabitants of the village of Altai, a remote Siberian hamlet, its population the fierce Mongol descendants of the tribes of Jenghis Khan.

CHICAGO, March 25. -- Four primary lines along which business recovery may be promoted by international cooperation were discussed today by Dr. Harold G. Moulton, president of the Brookings Institution of Washington, at a joint session of the Chicago Council on Foreign Relations and the English-Speaking Union.

NUMEROUS works new to America and some scheduled for their first performance anywhere will be given at the sixth Coolidge festival to be held in Washington April 23, 24 and 25. The festival will introduce the Adolf Busch String Quartet to America.

WITH the sales of radio receivers shrinking from 4,438,000 outfits sold in 1929 to 2,620,000 in 1932, immediate steps must be taken to save the industry from the doldrums, O.H. Caldwell, former Federal Radio Commissioner, recently declared at a meeting of manufacturers, merchandisers and designers.

Archie O. Dawson of the Young Republican Club, speaking yesterday at a symposium on the fusion movement for the coming mayoralty election, declared that it was up to Joseph V. McKee to say now whether he would lead the anti-Tammany fight this Fall.

MOSCOW, March 24. -- The writer is constantly getting letters from America asking how the Russians live. They might just as well ask, Why? For life in the present period of Socialist construction is so uncomfortable and fantastic that one wonders -- and wonders.

Under the auspices of the Fair-field County Planning Association, Connecticut, a parkway, park and high-way program has been prepared with the object of providing road and other community improvements which will add to comforts and conveniences of the entire county.

THE general all-around understudy record for the current season is probably held by Arthur Chatterton, the "on-call man" of " Dinner at Eight," which is playing at the Music Box. Mr. Chatterton has already acceptably played three of the important roles in the Kaufman-Ferber opus on a few hours' notice and is under-studying no less than nine other performers in the cast.

Regretting that lack of funds will compel the early dismissal of 2,950 women employed by the Emergency Work and Relief Bureau, Miss Ollie A. Randall, women's director of the organization, declared yesterday that those who have dependents will have extreme difficulty in obtaining permanent jobs.

Evidence dealing with thirteen charges of making false enteries on the books of the Harriman National Bank and Trust Company will be presented to the Federal grand jury this week when it begins consideration of the case of Joseph W. Harriman, former chairman of the board of that bank.

THIS is the same Michael Arlen who wrote tales of Mayfair and the playboys of the New York plutocracy, but no one would ever believe it from the new novel. Gone are the charming mannerisms, the graceful twists and turns of phrase and character.

LONDON, March 24. -- It is very much the fashion now in England among statesmen, industrialists, bankers and ordinary mortals of all shades of political and economic opinion to praise President Roosevelt.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va. -- The Spring colony here is looking forward with interest to the forthcoming playing of the 1933 Davis Cup team in the eleventh annual Mason and Dixon lawn tennis tournament, to be held on the clay courts of the Greenbrier Club the week of April 17, following the North and South tournament at Pinehurst.

WASHINGTON, March 25. -- Application by the Long Island State Park Commission for bridges to be constructed across High Flat Drain, Fundy Channel, Sloop Channel, Reynolds Channel, Long Creek and Swift Creek (State Boat Channel) in Hempstead Bay received the approval today of the War Department.

That the world is a community is a truth that has been brought home with no little force to the German Government in the past week. Not only Herr Hitler and the other two Nazi members of the Berlin Cabinet, but the eight non-Nazi members as well profess chagrined surprise that evidences of anti-Semitism in Germany were followed by such wide condemnation from so many quarters.

By any standard of comparison, yesterday's share market was a dull and uneventful affair. Transactions fell about 200,000 below the total of the previous Saturday, which made the market the slowest in more than a month. Stocks fluctuated nervously at the opening, with no definite trend discernible; they pointed downward at the end of the first half hour, then rallied slightly before the close.

ON with your Spring coat, Madame! Winter has gone and Easter is just three weeks off. It is time to be planning how you will look for the great parade. Can you imagine anything better than to array yourself in any one of the coats displayed on this page?

LILY PONS singing Gershwin melodies is one of radio's highlights this week. There will be plenty of symphonic music from Sunday to Saturday, with the following orchestras in the line-up to the microphone: the New York Philharmonic, two concerts by the Philadelphia Symphony, the Manhattan Symnhony, the Boston Symphony and the Baltimore Symphony.

PINEHURST, N.C. -- The Pinehurst season, now in full swing, enters its most active week of the year, the week which includes such fixtures as the North and South open golf tournament, the Kennel Club's Bench Show, the Horse Show, the Pinehurst vs. All-South golf match and the start of the North and South amateur.

MIAMI, Fla., March 25. -- The Dodgers were held to four hits today and despite fine pitching by Owen Carroll and Ray Lucas, the Carey athletes lost to the Cardinals, 2 to 1, in their sixth major league engagement of the training season.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., March 25. -- Leaders of science, almost every phase of which has benefited by his genius, will gather at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology Wednesday to pay tribute to Professor Elihu Thomson on the occasion of his eightieth birthday.

Another Winter Gone. The coming of Spring these last few years has been more than usually welcome because it has marked the end of another Winter of distress. We have behind us the fourth Winter of the depression, the third Winter of unemployment.

ALBANY, March 25. -- A marked coolness among up-State Republican Assemblymen toward the Desmond-Moffat bill for election of charter revision commissions was revealed today, but it was believed that they might be compelled to pass the measure in the lower house if Governor Lehman came actively to its support.

UNORTHODOX architectural details so often found both in new apartments and re-conditioned houses may, if skillfully handled, form a real contribution to the final effect, whether period or contemporary in mood. In a home where some rooms are furnished with traditional furniture and others in the modern manner, such backgrounds may even contribute to decorative unity.
"No county in the United States offers more residential advantages than Westchester," said Joseph P. Day yesterday, discussing its development and future prospects.

NEWS, and good news, conies from Wilmington, Del. It is there that in the home of the late Samuel Bancroft Jr. a fine collection of English preRaphaelite paintings has hung for many years and it may be said that there only has the extraordinary little band of pre-Raphaelites been fully and fairly represented in this country.

The Calvert Associates celebrated the 299th anniversary of the founding of Maryland and the establishment of religious liberty in this country by attending a special mass and a Te Deum in St. Patrick's Cathedral yesterday morning at 9 o'clock.

SEATTLE, March 25 (AP). -- Supported only by her upper works, which are draped over a dock, the American Mail liner President Madison lay on her side in forty feet of water here tonight because "somebody made a mistake."

Supreme Court Justice Edward J. Glennon granted yesterday the application of George S. Van Schaick, Superintendent of Insurance, for an order permitting him to take possession of the Globe and Rutgers Fire Insurance Company of 111 William Street for the purpose of rehabilitation.

The lure of sunken treasure has beckoned to several Long Island shipping men, who, under the leadership of Alan C. Robertson of Rockville Centre, will attempt to recover the reputed $10,000,000 cargo of the Braak, a British sloop of war.

In today's NEW YORK TIMES Book Review Mr. WILLIAM M. WHERRY of the New York bar summarizes with clearness and accuracy the essentials of Mr. GEORGE RAGLAND'S "Discovery Before Trial." The written pleadings of the common law were a wholly insufficient basis of preparation for trial.

THE publishing house of Alfred A. Knopf has signed a contract for the publication of a series of novels by Jules Romains, to be issued under the general title of "Men of Good Will." Two novels in this series have already appeared in France -- "The Sixth of October" and "Quinette's Crime."

PHILADELPHIA, March 25. -- A double mystery confronted police today after the finding of a woman's body, with two empty shells and a loaded one nearby, on the grounds of the Cedarbrook Country Club about midnight. After many hours of investigation they had made no apparent progress toward determining the identity either of the slayer or the victim.

The active season of the Junior League Players will be brought to a close this week with the presentation of their third production of the season, "Mr. Dooley Jr.," performances of which will be given on Friday afternoon and Saturday morning and afternoon in the Great Hall of the league clubhouse at 221 East Seventy-first Street.

BERLIN, March 25. -- Herman Wilhelm Goering, Minister of the Interior of Prussia, delivered an impassioned argument today before representatives of the foreign press against what he contended was a drive against the national rising in Germany, fomented by Socialist Jews in foreign countries and feeding on fabricated stories of atrocities.

Mortgage money is needed to foster activity in the realty and construction fields in Westchester County, particularly for small homes, realty interests pointed out yesterday. Although there is ample housing in some classes, they reported, in the small house field a number of prospective builders have been held back because of inability to arrange necessary financing.
BERLIN, March 25. -- It became manifest today that the Hitler-Papen government was rallying a strong body of home opinion against the charges abroad of atrocities in this country.

Old-fashioned ways of diagnosing ailments found a defender yesterday in Dr. Gervase C. Flick of Boston, who spoke at the opening of the thirteenth annual convention of the Eastern Osteopathic Association at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

While golf purses have been reduced in most cases during the past Winter campaign, the United States Golf Association has decided to maintain the customary $5,000 stake for the national open championship.

NEW HAVEN, March 25. -- The discovery of an ancient Jewish synagogue at Dura-Europos, Palestine, the walls of which are covered with frescoes and the ceilings with painted tiles, was reported to President Angell today by Professor Clark Hopkins of Yale University.

When Roosevelt Hall of the American Museum of Natural History is completed, two bronze statuettes, one of a bison and the other of a grizzly bear, will adorn the niches on each side of the main entrance of the building. The hall, which will be dedicated as a memorial to the late Theodore Roosevelt, is rapidly nearing completion.

Four alarms were turned in early yesterday for a fire that swept six stores and a bowling alley in a two-story brick building, 100 feet long, on the southwest corner of Third Avenue and Fifty-first Street, Brooklyn. Two double-family brick houses at 270 and 272 Fifty-first Street were scorched by the flames and the tenants driven to the street.

THOSE fortunate readers of poetry who happened upon Horace Gregory's "Chelsea Rooming House" will lose no time in securing a copy of "No Retreat." For it is manifest (and this new book, slight in quantity as it is, is further emphasis of it) that in Mr. Gregory the somewhat bilious and purposeless field of contemporary American poetry possesses a newcomer of undoubted strength and distinguished talent.

The much discussed advent of Spring in the metropolitan area remained a matter of conjecture yesterday when a cold drizzle of rain and snow, sweeping eastward from the Middle West and the Alleghenies, ended a day of crisp breezes and bright sunshine.

BATTLE scenes, special effects and other militant details at the MGM plant required nearly three carloads of high explosive in the past few months, in addition to thousands of rounds of ammunition. Much of this military ordnance went into the making of "Hell Below," which deals with submarine warfare.
DETROIT, March 25. -- The National Bank of Detroit was opened for its second day of business today and yesterday's deposits of about $12,000,000 were swelled to a total of about $13,000,000.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., March 25. -- The Naval Academy fencers, in their last dual match of the season today, defeated the University of Pennsylvania, 12 to 5. The midshipmen have won from all their college apponents to qualify as a favorite in the finals of the Intercollegiate Fencing Association, which will take place in Philadelphia next Friday and Saturday.

THIS is the third of the Drury Lane mysteries. Perhaps it is the last, for the author has introduced a new character who may possibly take the place of the veteran Shakespearean actor who figured so prominently in "The Tragedy of X" and "The Tragedy of Y."

BOSTON, March 24. LIKE the crocuses, the theatre in Boston is pushing up through the snow proper to a New England Spring. Absurd as it may seam in New York, the two months from mid-March to mid-May are often the height of the season hereabout, because that same New York is sending Eastward the plays and players of which it has tired.

THE title of this latest book by the eminent German physicist is inaccurate and misleading. What the reader actually has before him is an attempt by one of the keenest and moat thoughtful of contemporary scientists to define the nature and limitations of science, as illustrated by his own specialty, and to clarify some of the more insistent philosophic issues centring around the newer concepts of probability and causation.

AN Atlantic island peopled by stiff-necked Yankee fishermen who in their proud isolation refer to the mainland as America; a harbor teeming with mongrel fishing craft; a spread of beach and a pile of cliffs facing the bleak sweep of northeastern ocean; the light frame houses of the natives, built low against the wind.

IT is reassuring to find that the lure of foreign sets, the number of which simplifies the task of the program makers considerably, has not entirely engrossed the Victor Company, and that though we have not had a domestically recorded album since the "St. Matthew's Passion," the studios have not entirely been given up to supplying the demand for current popular hits.

THERE was a day when North Oshkosh-maple and Louis XVI maple went together in motion-picture sets and the incongruity made no difference to any one. But this is an enlightened age for Hollywood and the sets are expertly matched, from, wallpaper to minor decorative gadgets.
The trout-fishing season in New York State will open next Saturday. It is a day toward which the fresh-water anglers have been looking with longing eyes for many weeks.

BANISHED beer will be back with us again -- legal beerjust about the time that preVolstead New Yorkers used to encounter a harbinger of Spring more dependable even than the swelling of the buds upon the trees that sun lined streets not a few of which are now bare-walled canyons.

The James Monroe High School basketball team of the Bronx and the Thomas Jefferson High quintet of Brooklyn yesterday won the interdivisional semi-finals in the city P.S.A.L. senior high school championship competition and will meet next Saturday in the final at the 245th Coast Defense Armory in Brooklyn.

IT been for some years now that rumors of Mabel Dodge Luhan's memoirs have percolated various literary circles; and now in "Intimate Memories Background," we have the first volume of them. Mrs. Luhan's life has been unique in that being an American born in the genteel social setting of the '80s and '90s she has had the courage and intelligence to lead an individual, and what used to be called emancipated, existence.

LONDON, March 25 (AP). -- Aston Villa crept within three points of Arsenal, leader in the first division of the English Soccer League, today by winning from Everton, 2 -- 1, while the gunners were dropping a 2-to-1 decision to Newcastle United, and Sheffield Wednesday, the second-place team, was losing to Portsmouth, 3 to 0.

AS AN example of the pyramiding of pensions -- now halted by the emergency economy act -- students of veterans' legislation cite the outlays made as a result of the Spanish-American War of 1898, the Philippine insurrection of 1899-1902 and the Boxer Rebellion of 1900.

IN the days when radium was the wonder of the world, it was decided that only the heavy elements could change spontaneously and emit energy as they did so. That lead should be slightly radioactive was to be expected, for that metal was the end product of uranium's activity.

PROFESSOR READ admits in his preface that geologists and mineralogists restrict the term mineral to "a homogeneous substance of definite composition found ready-made in nature and not directly a product of the life or decay of an organism."

One of the most remarkable features of the present situation with reference to Germany is that the people in Germany have evidently had no idea of what the outside world thinks is going on in Germany, while the outside world has gained an impression of current German events which contrasts deeply with the picture viewed by the German people.

PEIPING, Feb. 27. -- The condemnation leveled against the university students of Peiping and Tientsin, who are charged with cowardice, continues unabated. The agitation had its inception when, just after fighting broke out at Shanhaikwan, hundreds of students refused to take their midwinter examinations, and insisted that because of "the emergency" they be permitted to depart for their homes at once.

Bonds called last week for redemption in March and future months, prior to their dates of maturity, were few in number and consisted mainly of parts of industrial, municipal and foreign loans. The total for March is now $28,347,000, compared with $59,979,000 in February, and $11,110,000 in March, 1932, in corresponding weeks.
SAN JUAN, Puerto Rico. FROM seas which pirates sailed for two centuries in search of Spanish gold the yacht Caroline recently returned to Washington with new treasure found in the ocean's depths.

RYE, N.Y., March 25. -- Miss Eleanor Mathews, daughter of Steward Bates Mathews of this village, who will be married on April 8 to James Comly Maples of Port Chester, was guest of honor this afternoon at a tea given by the prospective bridegroom's mother, Mrs. Frederick Maples.

Abroad the striking event which followed announcement of our new emergency banking statute, less than two weeks ago, has been the firmness of dollar exchange on the international market, with its continued quotation above the normal point of exchange, as contrasted with the down-plunge of the pound sterling after Sept. 21, 1931.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, March 25 (AP). -- A suit against stockholders of the Union Trust Company of Cleveland tentatively seeking $22,850,000 Judgment -- the total capitalization of the institution -- was filed today by a depositor under the double liability provision of the State Constitution.

WINNIPEG, Man., March 25 (Canadian Press) . -- Adding the weight of his influence to discussions cenring around the transfer of the Winnipeg Grain Exchange and its trading facilities to Fort William or Port Arthur, Ont., Sidney T. Smith, president of the exchange council, approved such a move today.

STEWART EDWARD WHITE continues in this novel his account of the extraordinary adventures of Andy Burnett, the trapper and mountain man whose earlier exploits were narrated in "The Long Rifle." After the tragic conclusion of his life among the Blackfeet, Andy Burnett, armed with his long Boone gun. pushes westward alone.

WASHINGTON, March 25 (AP). -- Daniel C. Roper, who as Secretary of Commerce has been one of the key men in working out President Roosevelt's ideas of economy through reorganization, promised tonight that the program would be announced soon.

While the preliminary discussion has been based largely upon inferences drawn from the Washington dispatches and from the platform pledge of the Democratic party, Wall Street is resigned to the prospect of broad regulative legislation for the protection of investors.

OUR handling of pupils of both the gifted and the slow types are being considered anew. On the one hand, Dr. Abraham Flexner has just reiterated his suggestion, first made some years ago when he was a member of the Board of Education, that a separate high school be established in New York City for gifted pupils.

The Misses Henrietta and Eleanora Skinner, twin daughters of Mr. and Mrs. R. Dana Skinner, are among a group of young women who are aiding in the plans for a tea dance for the benefit of the Visiting Nurse Service of the Henry Street Settlement to be held next Saturday at the Savoy-Plaza.

THE adjective that best seems to fit the short stories of Kay Boyle is one we are accustomed to apply to people: soft-spoken. "Soft-spoken" carries many connotations with it, all of them appropriate here: one thinks of women, perhaps of ladies, of cultivation and aristocracy, and of an "atmosphere."

SCORTCHING down such tracks as the stage of the Broadhurst Theatre permits, " 20th Century," the Hecht-MacArthur fracas, which has been steaming on the platform of that edifice since late in December, was violently derailed a week ago last Tuesday when it thundered into what seemed, at first blush, an occult obstruction.

Unless the present rate of growth of total production, which reached its maximum in 1911 and has been decreasing ever since, reverses its trend, the debt structure under which industry is staggering cannot be rebuilt, Bassett Jones, engineer and a member of the group at Columbia University engaged on the quantitative survey of production, told THE TIMES yesterday.

In the brief session yesterday, on the commodity exchanges, the prices of most staples continued to work slightly lower. Trading, however, was light, reflecting the absence of any large speculative element. Sugar, coffee, rubber, silver, silk and cocoa were lower, while hides were moderately improved, due largely to short covering.

LONDON, March 4. THE week has been remarkable for the production of one uncommonly good play, "The Lake," written by Dorothy Massingham in conjunction with Murray MacDonald, and for a first-class theatrical controversy.

VIENNA, March 12. -- Interesting details concerning the projected production of Goethe's "Faust" in the famous open-air riding school at Salzburg in the course of this Summer's festivals have been given by Professor Klemens Holzmeister, the rector of the Vienna Fine Arts Academy, who is supervising the stage arrangements.

Protests against anti-Semitism in Germany, as manifested since the rise to power of Adolph Hitler, found expression here yesterday in sermons at Jewish services, in further plans for the protest meetingto be held tomorrow night in Madison Square Garden and in resolutions and statements by various organizations.

The $18,600 in cash that the police seized from Arthur (Dutch Schultz) Flegenheimer, Bronx beer runner, when the latter was arrested in June of 1931, belonged in reality to some one else, and therefore the government of the United States, which filed a lien against the amount for Schultz's unpaid income tax, cannot hold the City of New York liable for surrendering this sum, Arthur J.W. Hilly, Corporation Counsel, reasoned yesterday.

THIS "first book on one of America's most distinguished artists, a definitive biography," turns out to be a work worth our having waited for. In its general excellence, the thoroughness with which its material has been digested and the attractiveness with which this is laid be- fore the reader, the study amply repays the long and painstaking labor that went into it.

In a letter addressed to Richard Whitney, president of the New York Stock Exchange, William C. Durant, automobile manufacturer and former stock market operator, urges that the short interest on the Exchange be required to cover its commitments immediately.

Officials of leading investment trusts are greatly relieved by the feeling that prospects of wide currency inflation have disappeared. Because of the manner in which the administration has apparently averted such a development and because of the success attending the balancing of the budget, these men believe the general trend of business for the future will be gradually but definitely upward.

WASHINGTON, March 25. -- In the three weeks of its strenuous life, the Roosevelt administration has dealt realistically with all its problems save one. That is the next war-debt payday of June 15. Thus far the real beliefs of the President and his advisers on that subject have been shrouded in ambiguity.

SAMUEL GOLDWYN has moved his headquarters to London for a busy week or two. The producer sailed Wednesday to supervise the presentation of "The Kid From Spain" at the Adelphi and to arrange trade showings of "The Masquerader," the new Colman film.

WHEREVER German Nazis Rather the militant strains of the "Horst Wessel Lied" are heard. It is their campaign song, their battle cry, now their hymn of triumph, too. It takes its curious name from its composer, Horst Weasel, a Nazi follower who was killed by Communists in 1930.

AT a time when all values are changing it is no easy matter to determine what a particular book is worth. (This remark may be taken in its non-commercial sense, but for the purposes of the present discussion its more literal, limited meaning is intended.)

BOSTON, March 23. -- Last November Governor Ely, in anticipation of the repeal of the Eighteenth Amendment, appointed a committee to draft legislation for the coming of the new era, "in order that Massachusetts might show her colors as a Commonwealth devoted to law and order, sobriety and temperance," and to furnish other States with a model on which they might base their own laws.

Provision for drastic changes in the methods now employed in the marketing of new securities will be contained in a bill which is expected to be introduced in Congress this week as a result of intensive study and research by experts of the administration and Congressional leaders.

"Do you believe there will be as much interest in tournament golf this year as in other seasons?" Mrs. Anthony Bassler, tournament chairman of the Women's Westchester and Fairfield Golf Association, was asked a few days ago.

VIENNA, March 25. -- The strike of Vienna typesetters against the order of the Dollfuss Cabinet for censorship of the Arbeiter Zeitung and Kleine Blatt, Socialist newspapers, was ended this afternoon. The success of the government and Hitlerite newspapers in obtaining strikebreakers made continuance of the struggle useless.

MADRID, March 15. -- Some Spaniard once remarked jokingly that every third man in Spain is a policeman. As a matter of fact, Spain has one of the largest and most efficient secret police forces in Europe, built up by Prime de Rivera, and maintained and strengthened by his successors.

THE news that 600 of Uganda's wild elephants have been officially "condemned to death" raised a burning question among the pioneer farmers and planters of Kenya Colony, Tanganyika Territory, and that queer "Quadruple Kingdom" which his Highness, the Kabaka of Uganda, rules from a modest palace in Mengo on $7,500 a year.

ROSTOV-ON-DON, Russia, March 25 (AP). -- A report from North Caucasian areas today told of the refusal of a group of collective farmers to work in the fields because of complaints of no food and their summary punishment as ''saboteurs."

HOLLYWOOD. TRANQUILLITY reigned this week as studios forgot their pay slashes and other troubles and resumed production activities. Fox, shut down for a week, again began shooting. Thirty companies, a high number, were working on all lots.

To the Dramatic Editor: Frederic Palmer declared that if any one were to blame for the crisis in the theatre today, the finger should be pointed at " a small group of men who have probably been dragged away from a party or club to report upon an opening: they arrive feeling very disconslate, and it is quite concievable that they sound the death-knell of a play before even entering the theatre."

SUMMIT, N.J., March 25. -- Robert S. Holt, for many years a member of Holt Co. of New York, wholesale flour merchants, died last night at his home in New Providence, near here, after a week's illness of pneumonia.

BERLIN, March 25. -- The Boerse opened irregular today, but after early hesitancy an upward movement began, carrying many stocks to higher levels. The biggest gain was in Bavarian, motors which closed 15 1/4 points above yesterday. The stock market finished strong.

JEFFERY AMHERST'S was one of those ironical lives which just fall of being great successes. He ought to rank in men's memories with Robert Clive, the conqueror of India, and he ought to outrank his own subordinate.

The substitution of a Board of Directors of the United States in the place of Congress, the division of the country into nine regional States instead of forty-eight and a new Constitution to be framed on social guarantees instead of individual rights are among the reforms necessary for a genuine "new deal" for the American people, according to William Kay Wallace, historian and constitutional authority.

Leading citizens of New York of the Protestant, Jewish and Roman Catholic faiths are members of the honorary committee for the Holy Hour to be held in Radio City Music Hall next Sunday morning, April 2. The service will mark the opening that day of the Holy Door at Vatican City to usher in the special Holy Year.

THE difference between, the micro-vivarium and the usual projection, of a lantern slide of a cell or spore is the difference between a zoo and a collection of stuffed animals. For the microvivarium is alive. By its means the simple, lower forms, seen only by the fortunate possessor of a microscope, become the admiration of the multitude.

MEN have lifted ambitious eyes again to the highest mountain on earth and set their hearts upon the hope of reaching its top. Twice have men dared to grapple with Mount Everest, and twice, after unimagineble struggle with the deathdealing giant, they have been beaten back.

STARTING out on a jig-saw journey which will take him 15,000 miles through every State capital, Stu Hawley, director of the Texaco national road reports, left Washington, D.C., last Tuesday, headed first for Florida. The main idea of the trip is to collect firsthand information about routes all over the country, to be passed on to the motoring legions which will soon begin rolling along the highways.

The old law of the pressure of the population on the food supply has its modern counterpart at Washington in the pressure of the politicians on the supply of jobs. "Positions Net Under the Civil Service," published by the Government Printing Office in January, has been a best seller ever since.

BOSTON, March 23. -- The surviving bartenders of Boston are getting ready to revive their union. There were 2,000 of them fourteen years ago. There are some hundreds of them today. During the officially dry era they have languished in relative obscurity as a branch of the Hotel and Restaurant Employes Union, Local 34.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., March 25 (AP). -- The elimination of two low board dives in future swimming competitions of the National Collegiate Athletic Association was voted today by the Rules Committee.

WHENEVER the United States experiences a mild Winter, an extraordinarily hot Summer or severe wintry blasts some persons of an imaginative turn of mind blame radio for the "changing weather." Dr. Alfred N. Goldsmith asserts such ideas are fantastic.

BUFFALO, March 23. -- In this city as elsewhere the main topic of public interest during the last three weeks has been the course of the new Federal administration. The psychological response of the public to the series of measures which have established the character of the Roosevelt regime has been enthusiastic.

MAX MILLER is the same young newspaper man of Southern California whose first book. "I Cover the Waterfront," won much praise from critics a year or so ago. Distinctive and striking and brimming with many charms and graces of thought and expression though it was, this new one registers a marked advance.

The psychological response of the public to the series of measures which have established the character of the Roosevelt regime has been enthusiastic.

The American Palestine Campaign, fund-raising organization of the Jewish Agency for Palestine, will launch its 1933 national drive for funds for reconstruction activities in Palestine on Wednesday night at a dinner at the Hotel Astor in honor of Nathan Straus Jr., one of the national chairmen.

THE depression is making an important contribution to numismatics in providing those who collect coins with new kinds of currency, or substitutes for currency. In the past year or two there have appeared many types of emergency money, principally of paper, of various denominations and from widely separated localities.

FOR more than forty years the Child Study Association has been an ever-present help to bewildered and despairing parents. By the thousand they have taken their problems to it and asked what they should do about this that and the other difficulty: about food, conduct, training, play sex, discipline and every other matter that ever troubled a parent.

THIS first novel has some effective, even brilliant, scenes. It has originality in language, especially in the projection of moods. But, when it is over, one is puzzled about what it all means. The book doesn't bang on any peg. Perhaps as a psychological study of John B. Sanford, the law clerk, who is the chief character, it has meaning -- but the rest is only pyrotechnics.

WHEN 18-year-old Althea Turtill, after several years at school in Oklahoma, returned to her widower father's ranch in Sonora she received two severe shocks: Will Turtill, she found, had degenerated into a worthless sot who was letting his 40,000 acres and the mine workings go to wrack and ruin: moreover, he had married Teresa, his Mexican housekeeper, a woman quite devoid of moral sense.

The Judiciary Committee of the Senate will hold a public hearing at Albany Wednesday, March 29, on the mortgage moratorium bill, prepared and sponsored by the Real Estate Board of New York, and other proposed laws of the same character.

DUBLIN, March 24. -- Both the Fianna Fail and Cosgrave party organizations are already busily preparing for another electoral battle which is due to take place in June. This time the major parties will fight to gain control of the local administrations in counties, cities and boroughs.

LOUISVILLE, March 23. -- Legalized beer will put 5,000 more persons on the payrolls in Kentucky within the next fortnight, add $150,000 a week to salaries and wages, and spread considerable collateral employment as well as financial benefits to farmers and tradesmen, according to conservative estimates of those in touch with the situation.

ABOUT this time of year expect this column to show unmistakable signs of enthusiasm. So it was last year when Spring was in the bud. So it was once or twice before. On all of those occasions the theatre seemed in immediate retrospect to be sufficiently lively to encourage a man to think well of its and to think hopefully of its future.

CHICAGO, March 23. -- In this region of the United States, and particularly in that section of it which counts Milwaukee as its metropolitan centre, April 7, 1933, seems likely to join April 6, 1917, as the most memorable dates in recent American history.

ONE lays down Mr. Hill's book with a feeling of exasperation which may or may not be a tribute to it. To begin with, the author has succeeded only in raising a question, not in answering it. A good deal of the book reads like a social primer, composed out of the works of Van Wyck Brooks, Lewis Mumford, James Truslow Adams, Charles A. Beard, Constance Rourke.
AGUA CALIENTE, Mexico, March 25 (AP). -- Gallant Sir, Agua Caliente Handicap favorite, today won easily over Waylayer and five others at a mile and a furlong. The time was 1:51 over a fast track.

MIAMI, Fla., March 25. -- Carrying the feather of ninety-eight pounds, Broadway Lights, owned by Thomas McCarthy, galloped to a new mile and an eighth track record at Tropical Park today to win the featured John McEntee Memorial Handicap.
WARM SPRINGS, Ga., March 25. -- Georgia has moved to honor permanently her adopted son, President Franklin D. Roosevelt.

It is doubtful whether recognition of Soviet Russia by the United States would be an asset to this country in its policy toward Japan, according to M. Malewsky-Malevitch, author of "Russia -- U.S.S. R." and a former Colonel in the Russian Army under the Czar, in an interview at the Hotel Gotham.

In Englewood's ten apartment houses, which comprise 500 apartment units, there are available for Spring occupancy about 125 apartments, or about 25 per cent of the city's capacity, according to a survey just made public by the Housing Committee of the Englewood Chamber of Commerce.

ON first thought, the story of fighting grasshoppers, army worms and plant-lice might not seem heroic or thrilling. However, it will be wise to take second thought on the matter. For no medieval knight ever couched lance against a more formidable foe and no policeman ever captured a gunman more menacing to society.

Low costs of labor and materials in the building industry and the prospect of rising prices under President Roosevelt's program have prompted the Haring Blumenthal Realty Corporation, owners and developers of six Westchester residential properties at Rye, Mount Kisco, Crestwood and New Rochelle, to proceed with improvement and construction work in these developments.

Practically no important revision of buying procedure has developed due to the recent talk of inflation, merchandise executives here disclosed yesterday. Price trends in major commodities since the banking crisis, it was said, have led retailers virtually to discard the possibility that higher prices are likely to be in evidence before the Fall season.

The reduction in dividends of four associated or affiliated companies of the Bell System so far this year is the direct result of a decline in earnings which made it necessary for a majority of the companies in the group to call upon their surpluses last year to meet their full dividend requirements.

THIS attractively made book of small quarto size catalogues, describes and Interprets the exhibition of American folk art made last year by the Museum of Modem Art in New York City, thus diving permanent form to the important collection it brought together and making it part of the art history of the country.
NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., March 25. -- The aged, the young and the ill were suffering from lack of water tonight on Clifford Island, a few hundred feet from the New Rochelle shore line.

A more intensive use of the railroads, rather than additions thereto, appears a likely policy for the railroads in the view of F.E. Williamson, president of the New York Central Railroad, as expressed in a recent address to the Railway Engineering Association.

MEXICO CITY, March 21. -- From the termination of the period of office of President Abelardo L. Rodriguez, no Mexican Chief Executive can be re-elected, is the decision -- which will cause a change in the Mexican Constitution -- adopted at a special session of Congress, which voted unanimously to that effect last night.
BERLIN, March 25. -- Five of the twelve Governors of Prussian provinces were dismissed today and new men, most of them prominent National Socialists, were appointed to take their places.

ASSISTING Lee Tracy at the RKO Roxy this week in "Private Jones" is Gloria Stuart, who came up out of nowhere in a great hurry not long ago. Born at Santa Monica, less than twenty miles from Hollywood, she was educated at the University of California in Berkeley, and after being graduated appeared in amateur theatricals at the Theatre of the Golden Bow.

CLEVELAND, March 23. -- With all its sixty-odd movie theatres dark and disconsolate, this Athens of the Western reserve was turned this week into a field for wage and working conditions warfare between theatre owners and theatrical labor unions, the outcome of which is expected to have a national effect.
Rafaelo Diaz, Max Rosen and Clarence Adler appeared last evening at the Community Club, 550 West 110th Street, in aid of the Mental Hygiene Clinic.

BROOKLINE, Mass., March 25. -- Mrs. Arthur H. Hill of Newton, Mass., the former Mianne Palfrey, has been seeded first in the women's national indoor tennis tournament, which starts at the Longwood Cricket Club Monday. Mrs. Hill, 1930 champion, will oppose Mrs. Paul Sanborn of Boston in a second-round match.

ARTHUR WEIGALL was for many years Inspector General of Antiquities under the Egyptian Government, and during his residence there he had the amusing experiences with animals of which he tells in this entertaining little book.

MORE than half a million Jews dwelling in Germany are affected, directly and indirectly, by Adolf Hitler's vigorous anti-Semitio campaign. In 1925, when the last census was taken, 564,379 Jews were living in the Reich; and it is estimated that the Jewish population has grown by only a few thousand since.
MADRID, March 24. -- Claude G. Bowers, the next Ambassador from the United States to Spain, will face a difficult task.
The Long Island Historical Society, Pierrepont and Clinton Streets, Brooklyn, has placed on exhibition a collection of local maps presented to the society by Mrs. Edwin P. Clark of Brooklyn.

WASHINGTON, March 25. -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended on March 18 made a total of 449,712 cars, the American Railway Association announced today. This was 11,899 cars, or 2.7 per cent, more than in the preceding week, but 135,047 cars, or 23.1 per cent, fewer than for the corresponding week last year and 291,541 cars, or 39.3 per cent, fewer than for the corresponding week two years ago.

An ocean liner in a fog is not a cheerful place at best, and a murderer at large on board does not lighten the gloom to any appreciable extent. The first victim of the killer is Alonzo Holt, an elderly American millionaire, who is taking the trip on the advice of his physician.

SETTING out to compose a mystery tale extraordinary, which will completely disregard the familiar formulae of the thriller, Mr. Curie succeeds admirably in creating the requisite atmosphere of gripping menace and suspense. But in other equally important elemeats he fails disastrously to maintain a corresponding level of craftsmanship.

CAMDEN, S.C., March 25. -- Pink Tipped, an aged chestnut mare owned by Richard K. Mellon of Pittsburgh, sprang a genuine surprise at the Springdale course today by taking the third renewal of the Carolina Cup, beating Mrs. W. Austin Wadsworth's popular favorite, Hotspur II, in a thrilling finish.
Sales of $15,139 yesterday brought to $48,909,50 the total of the threeday sale of English antiques of Richard W. Lehne, Inc., at the Raines Auction Rooms, 3 East Fifty-third Street.
BERLIN, March 25 (AP). -- The Reichsbank's statement as of March 23 shows the following changes in reichsmarks:

The Merchants Association and other civic organizations have decided to oppose a series of bills introduced in the Legislature by two Tammany Senators, John J. McNaboe and Thomas F. Burchill, designed to prevent the Irving Trust Company from continuing as receiver and trustee in bankruptcy proceedings, it became known yesterday.

AINSWORTH MORGAN has chosen as background for this book of physical and spiritual adventure one of the few regions on this planet that have not, as yet, been exploited with meticulous completeness by novelists.

What the Federal Home Loan Bank System did to relieve the financial stringency in many parts of the country during the cessation of banking facilities is explained by Ward B. Whitlock, president of the United States Building and Loan League, who states that the Home Bank System proved its worth by supplying building and loan associations with funds to meet the temporary emergency.

The annual New York concert of the Harvard Glee Club will take place on April 8 in the Town Hall. The occasion will mark the seventyfifth anniversary of the club, which was organized in 1858. Members of the club will be assisted on the program by eleven performers of the Boston Symphony Orchestra, who will present an anniversary program under the direction of Dr. Archibald T. Davison.

THE benefits of coordinating under one responsible authority the various road-building agencies of the State are stressed by Colonel Frederick Stuart Greene, Superintendent of the New York State Department of Public Works, in his annual report to the Legislature, which now comes to hand.

An auction of jewelry brought $125,162.50 yesterday at the American Art Association Anderson Galleries,. Inc. Included in the sale were precious stones consigned by the estates of the late Charles Hitchcock Tyler, Mrs. William F. Sheehan, Miriam D. Thropp and Laura A. Palmer.

A Communist delegation admitted to the office of the German Consulate yesterday morning to present a resolution against Hitlerism apparently was so astounded at being received that the members became abusive and were finally ejected.

THE present is not only a period of great seriousness for the German Republic but it is also a time of peril for German scholarship and science. Many of the distinguished professors at the universities, while they stoutly proclaim there has been no decline in the accomplishments of German scholars, are anxious about the future.

In a wildly exciting game which had the crowd on its feet through nearly all of the last period, the New York Athletic Club indoor polo team last night defeated Squadron. A to win the Manhattan circuit championship and qualify for the Eastern championships in Class C.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., March 25. -- "No. 23" of a long and notable series of models depicting the progress of mankind in ethnological and archaeological periods Has been added to the collection of the Peabody Museum of Harvard University.

MOUNTAIN climbing in India is not only a supreme test of endurance but a race. The objective must be reached before the onset of the Summer monsoon with its torrential rains. So in discussing the plans of the Mount Everest Climbing Expedition, J.M. Scott, the expedition's secretary, recently said their chances of success rested primarily on "time and weather."

SAN FRANCISCO, March 25 (AP). -- Tom Mooney gained a new opportunity today, after sixteen years of imprisonment, to go into court and prove himself not guilty of complicity in the bombing of the Preparedness Day parade in which ten persons were killed and forty injured in 1916.

John Q. Tilson, former Republican majority leader in the House of Representatives, declared yesterday that the best way Republicans can help their party "is to back up, as far as we can, the Roosevelt administration."
PARIS, March. 16. -- Beautification of postoffices, giving each an architecture characteristic of the province in which it is located, is the policy of the French Ministry of Posts.

Deprived of any outside stimulus, the security markets conformed yesterday to teh conventional Saturday pattern. They were dull and aimless, lacking in conviction and too timid to move out of a narrow area. The net results were unfavorable in stocks, negative in bonds.
NASHVILLE, Ga., March 23. -- In Carter Melvin, a Georgia Negro now serving a term at the State highway camp near this little town in South Georgia, there seems to be the making of a financier.

NEW YORK CITY'S charter, long criticized because of its huge size, presents a remarkable contrast to the royal English charters granted to the city in early days. These were usually concise documents, but with the years the charters grew, until the ponderous documents of 1897 resulted.

In the debate last week in Congress on the Administration's new farm bill little attention was given to international aspects of the problem of putting American agriculture on a profitable basis. The purpose of the measure adopted by the House is to restore "parity" between prices of farm commodities and those of non-agricultural products.

COMPREHENSIVE and complete in its survey, up to the limit of its pages, is this "General History of Nursing," although its author, an English trained nurse, laments in her preface the difficulty of compressing "so vast a subject" into a single volume.

CORRESPONDENTS with questions to ask often propound provocative matters. In the last week a conductor has asked how, after years of looking for this great opportunity, he may expect to get before the public.

LIFE and its problems were a simple matter to Nod Grace. All one needed to do, he believed, was to make a plan and carry it through. He had had a plan for preparatory school, another for Harvard, and, as soon as he graduated, he would have another.

WASHINGTON, March 25. -- New York received its third relief loan from the Reconstruction Finance Corporation today when approval was announced of an advance of $6,600,000 for meeting April relief requirements in sixty-seven of 115 welfare districts of the State, embracing forty of the sixty-two counties.

BOSTON, March 25. -- After 14 minutes 14 seconds of "sudden death" overtime, Marty Barry broke a long deadlock and gave the Boston Bruins a 2-1 victory over the Toronto Maple Leafs before 15,000 tonight in the opening game of the first-place play-off for the National Hockey League championship.
WASHINGTON, March 25. -- Movements of vessels follow. All dates are March 24, unless otherwise specified:
LESS than five years ago Anthony H.G. Fokker, in a talk before a group of men interested in transportation, said:

The East had a rather lean day in the National Collegiate A.A. swimming and wrestling championships on Saturday. The West made a clean sweep of the eight mat titles and captured five of the nine aquatic crowns. The Eastern wrestling hopes fell in droves and the Eastern swimming stars could not quite keep pace with the talented mermen from the Central and Pacific Coast portions of the United States.

"It is easy," writes Governor-General ROOSEVELT in his report on the Philippine Islands for the year 1932-33, "to be an executive "or a legislator when revenues "are mounting, government ac"tivities expanding, salaries rising "and employment increasing."

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., March 26. -- A mass meeting calling for fairness at the second trial of seven Negroes in the Scottsboro case was held here today, and a resolution adopted urging change of venue from Decatur to Birmingham.

After having studied for several weeks the report of Earl M. Steer, examiner for the Interstate Commerce Commission, which recommended the abolition of free lighterage of freight in the port of New York, counsel for the various New York organizations opposing the change have applied to the commission for permission to submit additional evidence.

Headlining local art events of the week, the Whitney Museum will open to the public on Wednesday an exhibition of paintings by nineteenth-century American masters, an exchange loan from the Addison Gallery, Andover. The Museum of Modern Art on the same day will open four exhibitions -- Drawings by sculptors, the Lizzie P. Bliss Collection, paintings from the museum's permanent collection and the results of the typography contest arranged by the museum's architecture department.

John Hazedel Levis's recital and discussion of Chinese music, which took place last night at the Little Theatre, under the auspices of the China Society of America, had the rare merit of making interesting a subject remote and abstruse to most of his audience.

WASHINGTON, March 26. -- That next ice age, if one is coming, when glaciers may come grinding down from the North again to overwhelm America, is still a long way off, if Uncle Sam's weather charts are any indication.
ALBANY, March 26. -- The State budget will total about $211,000,000 under an agreement reached by Democrats and Republicans, it was disclosed today.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., March 26. -- As its concluding performance of the season the New Haven Symphony Orchestra today gave in Woolsey Hall, Yale University, the first presentation of "1929 -- A Satire," composed by David Stanley Smith, dean of the Yale School of Music and conductor of the orchestra.

LONDON, March 24. -- In the week ended on Wednesday, covered by Thursday's weekly statement, the Bank of England hought u3,229,685 more gold. This made u49,838,221 thus acquired since the beginning of the year and brought the Bank's total gold holdings to u170,374,908.

BERLIN, March 26. -- In the Gave du Nord in Paris last night just before the Blue Train pulled out for Brelin a company of French poilus with full marching equipment occupied a large part of the big waiting room.

The Union Carbide and Carbon Corporation reports for 1932 a net income of $8,781,426 after all charges and reserves for depreciation and depletion, equal to 97 cents a share on the 9,000,743 shares of capital stock outstanding. This compares with $18,029,522 or $2 a share on the same number of shares in 1931.

A ten-point platform upon which all voters opposed to Tammany might unite in a fusion campaign in next Fall's city election was suggested yesterday by a special committee on party rehabilitation, made public by James Marshall, chairman of the Republican advisory committee of New York County.

Students of the Columbia University School of Engineering, replying to a questionnaire issued by the 1933 Columbia Engineer, yearbook of the school, overwhelmingly expressed their readiness to bear arms in defense of the United States, rejected war as an instrument of national policy, favored capitalism and denied that the "world is going to hell."

DECATUR, Ala., March 26. -- The fight to save the lives of seven Negroes once condemned to death for alleged assault upon two white girls will open tomorrow in the Morgan County Court with an attack upon the jury system of Alabama.
Protests against political and religious persecution and discrimination in Germany were made yesterday by the American League for Human Rights and the Church Peace Union.

The officers and staff of five departments of the General Assembly of the Presbyterian Church, with headquarters in the Witherspoon Building, Philadelphia, have taken a new 10 per cent cut in their salaries, the Rev. Dr. Lewis Seymour Mudge, stated clerk and former Moderator of that body, revealed in an interview here yesterday.
FILLERES GYOERS, a musical comedy in Hungarian, with Joseph Sziklai, Magda Kun, Sandor Rado and Rozsi Csikos; a Sugar Film production; directed by Bela Gaal. At the Seventy-second Street Playhouse.

PRAGUE, March 26. -- The highest importance is attached here to the forthcoming visit of the Polish Foreign Minister, Colonel Joseph Beck, to Prague and Belgrade as heralding a close rapprochement first between Poland and Czechoslovakia and, second, between Poland and the whole Little Entente.

EL PASO, Texas, March 26. -- Baseball aeems to tie thriving in this section of the country with much more virility than on the coast. This was indicated again when a crowd of 5,000 packed the stands of Dudley Field today to see the Giants engage another array of local all-stars.

Services commemorating the 200th anniversary of the birth of Joseph Priestley, discoverer of oxygen and one of the two founders of the Unitarian Church, were conducted yesterday at All Souls' Unitarian Church, Lexington Avenue and Eightieth Street.

The downward tendency in commodity prices continued throughout most of last week with the result | that nearly all the grain following the resumption of trading after the banking holiday now has been wiped out. Trading activity declined further last week with speculators in most instances showing indifference pending a more definite outlook as to general business.

Rapid transit unification negotiations with the holders of Interborough and B.M.T. securities should be conducted by the entire Board of Estimate, with $370,000,000 as the "outside" price to be paid by the city for acquisition of company properties, Samuel Untermyer, former special counsel for the Transit Commission, declared yesterday.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I have perused with interest THE TIMES editorial "Trade With Russia," in which the statement is made that "it is highly doubtful, therefore, whether the sale of American goods to Russia would be greatly increased solely by the act of recognition."

New York's better speakeasies know him as "Major Wells, late of his Majesty's Highland Regiment, the Black Watch." He is of medium height, well-knit, trim and erect. He has a military mustache, an air of authority, and he is quiet, well-spoken and well dressed.

Frank L. Polk, Under-Secretary of State during President Wilson's administration, urged yesterday the prompt organization of citizens' councils for constructive economy in municipalities and counties throughout the country, in time for active cooperation in working out new budgets for those units whose fiscal years end July 1.

The growth of crime in the United States is due to absence of religious training in youth, the Rev. Jones I.J. Corrigan, S.J., Professor of Sociology at Boston College, declared yesterday afternoon in an address at the Spring conference at Fordham University.
