Two men and a woman, accused by the police of being implicated In the sale of dry goods and clothing stolen from the Craft Shop for the Blind at 306 Livingston Street, Brooklyn, were arraigned yesterday before Magistrate Steers in Flatbush Court and held in $1,000 bail each for a hearing on Friday.

Dispatches from Geneva frequently speak of the Little Entente as if it were a distinct nation. Almost it is. By treaties, by trade arrangements, by a unified foreign policy, by fixed meetings of their respective Foreign Ministers, Czechoslovakia, Yugoslavia and Rumania have really constituted themselves as a separate European Power.

WASHINGTON, March 26. -- The Home Loan Bank System's total of outstanding loans and the prospects for future business were chronicled here yesterday by former Representative Stevenson of South Carolina, the new chairman of the board.

WASHINGTON, March 26. -- The joint resolution now pending in Congress to give President Roosevelt power to prohibit the exportation of arms and munitions to other countries where such exportations might "encourage the employment of force in the course of a dispute or conflict between nations'' was criticized today by Representative George H. Tinkham, Republican, of Massachusetts, as a hostile move against Japan.

James G. Lern of 112 West 122d Street has seen many strange sights during his strolls along Central Park West hut one he encountered at midnight last night was the eeriest of all. Seated on a park bench near Seventieth Street, he saw a skeleton, complete except for head and arms.
CHICAGO, March 26 (AP). -- Amid much controversy, the sales tax is the chief means which State Legislatures are enacting or trying to enact to obtain much-needed new revenue.

Despite certain constructive changes made in some industrial pension plans in recent years, the movement on the whole in 1932 was "definitely in a much more precarious condition than three years earlier," according to an investigation just completed by Industrial Relations Counselors, Inc., 165 Broadway.
MUNICH, March 25. -- Mob violence has ended, at least temporarily, in Germany. But legal oppression goes on.

Some of President ROOSEVELT'S advisers apparently believe that it is possible to increase the Government's expenditures greatly and still balance the national budget by a sort of painless arithmetic. The method would be to set up a new system of Treasury bookkeeping which would exclude from calculations of each year's balance funds needed for debt retirement, for public works and for "extraor"dinary and emergency expendi"tures."

A questionnaire to determine the current economic status of 503 persons of moderate incomes who undertook, in 1928, to purchase their own homes in Sunnyside Gardens, Long Island City, was completed yesterday by A. Anton Friedrich, Assistant Professor of Economics at New York University, and T.G. Herendeen, statistician, as follows:

The importance of good speech was stressed yesterday by Dr. William J. O'Shea, Superintendent of Schools, in a paper on "Oral English," the second of a series being made public by him in advance of the publication of his thirty-fourth annual report.

PHILADELPHIA, March 26. -- Bells, which play an important part in Wagner's "Parsifal," will be heard in a new and electrically controlled form when the Philadelphia Orchestra, with the aid of soloists and a chorus of 350 voices, presents the "Parsifal" music in its entirety in concert form next weekend, Leopold Stokowski, the conductor and musical director, announced today.

BERLIN, March 26. -- Foreign Minister Constantin von Neurath, ordinarily the Hitler Cabinet's silent man who seldom receives journalists, broke his silence today to throw the entire weight of his internationally known personality against what he considers "the deliberate, sudden rebirth of the vilification campaign conducted during the World War against the German Government."

CHATTANOOGA, Term., March 26. -- Sharp warning to veterans' organizations against "Treasury raiding" and against threats of reprisal is given in a statement by Silas Williams, national commander of the American Veterans' Association.

Andre Lefebvre de Laboulaye, newly appointed French Ambassador to the United States, made his first address to the American people yesterday in an international radio talk from Paris, rebroadcast here over a network of the National Broadcasting Company.

Clean Sweep Wanted. It is pleasant to read that an inefficient SanStation Department has been sanitated out of existence by the Board of Estimate. But it would be still pleasanter to know that the change has come out of real discontent with inefficiency and not because Mr. CURRY desires to sanitate his own political trenches by ousting a follower of the late Mayor.

Mark Twain, who did most of his writing in bed, decided that he could make a great fortune out of travel books if he could get some one else to do the traveling. It was in 1870, "The Innocents Abroad" was tremendously popular and the Kimberly diamond fields in South Africa had recently been discovered.

MUNOZ, Bolivia, March 26. -- Nature rather than the Paraguayan Army was the enemy Bolivia had to overcome first in the undeclared Chaco war. Away from Bolivia it is difficult to realize the tremendous efforts required to mobilize thousands of men in Bolivia's cities, 10,000 feet above sea level in the Andes, and transport them a thousand miles through the wilderness described as "Green Hell."
Further housing transactions marked the New Jersey realty activity reported over the week-end.

Three proofs of the existence of God were offered yesterday morning by the Rev. Dr. F.L. Fagley in his sermon at the Manhattan Congregational Church, Broadway between Seventy-sixth and Seventy-seventh Streets.

As was natural for a period is which the effect of a dramatically sudden change in our own banking and currency position would have to find response in the markets, the past fortnight and particularly the past week have been crowded with highly interesting events.

MOSCOW, March 26. -- Allan Monkhouse, chief of the Metropolitan-Vickers Eletrical Company's staff in Russia, who was summoned at 8:30 o'clock last night for further examination by Soviet authorities, did not, as was previously reported, go to Lubianka Prison but to the Office of Public Prosecutor Vishinsky.

LONDON, March 26. -- The Jewish Board of Deputies, representing 300,000 Jews in Britain, passed a unanimous resolution today demanding that Germany accord equal "freedom and justice" to Jewish and non-Jewish citizens.

The appreciation of the fine arts in America, as indicated by attendance at nineteen principal art museums, has grown rapidly in recent years except in Boston and Philadelphia, the oldest cultural centres of the country, where the fine arts have lost ground, according to the latest published monograph in the series of studies undertaken by the Hoover Research Committee on Social Trends.

PITTSBURGH, March 26. -- Last week the steel trade reported no further decrease in mill operations, production of ingots being estimated at 13 per cent of capacity, the same as in the previous week, which had been the fifth successive week to show a decrease.

WASHINGTON, March 26. -- Reporting progress in the movement to bring about the ratification of repeal of the Eighteenth Amendment, Jouett Shouse, president of the Association Against the Prohibition Amendment, made public today a survey showing that eighteen States had passed legislation set ting up conventions and that similar action, was pending in nineteen others.

Condemnation of the persecution of the Jews in Germany by the Hitler government and the Nazi legions was voiced yesterday in many pulpits throughout the city, in churches and synagogues alike. Many of the clergy who discussed the situation urged that the United States relax its immigration restrictions to permit entry to Jewish refugees from Germany.

One of the reasons for the presentation of the Beethoven cycle, which the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, under Arturo Toscanini, began yesterday afternoon at Carnegie Hall, may have been that these Sunday concerts needed some particular inducement to attract the public in greater numbers.

SHANGHAI, March 26. -- Declaring that the Japanese are campaigning for the subjugation of China and that their actions are a formidable indication of preparations for an eventual war with the United States, Eugene Chen, former Foreign Minister of China, in a statement today urged the Chinese to make representations to the government and people of the United States.

The committee on legislation of the New York County Lawyers Association made public yesterday reports on ten bills pending in the Legislature, approving two and disapproving eight. The reports were made by individual members of the committee, and then approved by that body.

DAGENHAM, England, March 26 (AP). -- M.J. Tanner, organizing delegate of the Amalgamated Engineering Union, was the principal speaker at the meeting at which the British Ford workers decided to strike.

WASHINGTON, March 26. -- A declaration by Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt that scientific training in home economics was a sound foundation for efficient home-making, and that such training was the best if not the only means by which maximum results could be achieved, was made public in a statement today.

Wickedness of the Speaker as "czar" is good old Progressive-Democratic doctrine. Speaker RAINEY is only a moderator, so to speak. He, with the majority leader, the chairman of the House Democratic caucus and the Democratic whip, are ex officio members of a steering committee of which the other fifteen are chosen by the Democratic Representatives of their States or zones.

Samuel Untermyer, New York lawyer, is returning today on the Panama Pacific liner Virginia, after spending the Winter in California. Others coming on the ship from the West Coast ports via Colon and Cuba include: John R. Hearst, son of William Randolph Hearst, publisher, and his bride, who was Miss Gretchen Wilson, and Richard, Charles and Margaret Ledebur, children of Count and Countess Ledebur.

Dr. Dexter Fellows, who spells it Fellowes in even years, paid his annual visit to THE TIMES office yesterday. Reporters and editors rushed to the windows to see the warm Spring sun, the budding grass and the chirping robins generally heralded by the call.

J.H. Wantling, G.C. Walsh and T.H. Lawrence tied for the High Scratch Cup at the Travers Island traps of the New York Athletic Club yesterday. Each finished the regular shoot with a card of 96 out of 100 targets. In the shoot-off Wantling prevailed, breaking 25 straight targets.
LONDON, March 26. -- The Times throws the whole weight of its authority behind the policy of treaty revision in Europe by peaceful means but with the least possible delay.

Two prisoners, in-and-out residents of State and city penitentiaries for the last ten years, took French leave of the penitentiary on Welfare Island Saturday afternoon and still were missing last night despite the belief of prison officials that "they are only playing truant."

AGUA CALIENTE, Mexico, March 26. -- A trim little filly, Risky Miss, owned by T.C. Worden, won the Agua Caliente Futurity today, leading a select field of 2-year-olds. She has scored five straight victories, with no defeats, since she began running in January.

ALBANY, March 26. -- Up-State school teachers are contributing to tax reduction from two to ten times more than they would have been compelled to pay had the graded percentage reductions, made mandatory for New York City at the special session of the Legislature, been made State-wide, according to Arvie Eldred.

Gimbel Brothers, Inc., and subsidiaries, operators of three department stores in New York and one each in Philadelphia, Pittsburgh and Milwaukee, reports for the year ended on Jan. 31, last, a net loss of $4,459,059, compared with a net loss of $1,763,253 in the previous twelve months.

The date of the first public hearing on the new building code is expected to be announced tomorrow when the Board of Aldermen meets, according to Alien E. Beals in the current Dow Service Daily Building Reports. Early consideration of the measure was forecast last week when the code was advanced on the calendar of the board.

PARIS, March 26. -- In a few important words and phrases in an address on the need for international accord, Foreign Minister Joseph Paul-Boncour at a dinner of Lea Amities Internationales this evening indicated what would be the French Government policy on the four-power entente suggested by Premier Mussolini, on the British disarmament plan, on the World Economic Conference and on the war debts.
LONDON, March 26. -- The annual report of the Cunard Steamship Company, Ltd., published tonight, shows how badly the Cunard Line needs an agreement enabling it to make drastic operating economies.

A German Government suddenly caring what the world thinks of it is something of a novelty. For what it signifies, it is to be welcomed. No longer does the old Prussian spirit think it a badge of distinction to be criticized and disliked by other nations, which thereby confess their jealousy and envy of the only great race on earth.

WARREN, Ohio, March 26 (AP). -- Within thirty hours after an "amnesty" period expired, 15-year-old Peter Meyers Jr. was returned unharmed to his father early today, supposedly by the men who, armed with revolvers and submachine guns, snatched him from his home at Masury eight days ago.

TOKYO, Monday, March 27. -- The Privy Council unanimously approved today a communication to the League of Nations announcing Japan's formal resignation from the League. The document will be cabled to Geneva this afternoon.

The popularity of John McCormack, who gave last night his second Carnegie Hall recital of the season, has gone hand in hand with his conscience and zeal as an artist. His program contained material of particular interest to the informed music lover as well as the casual concert goer, in the instances of "Gioite al conto mio" by Peri, the Florentine and pioneer of opera, and the choral melody from Bach's "Christ Lag in Todesbanden."

Picturesque country gardens In Westchester will be opened to the public again this Spring in behalf of charity under the auspices of a committee of prominent Westchester women headed by Mrs. George Arents Jr. The beneficiaries are to be the Westchester County Children's Association and the WestChester Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Children.

PARIS, March 24. -- The strength of the dollar has caused no surprise here, where there would be no astonishment if It rose to even higher levels, Inasmuch as short covering is thought to have not yet ended.

WILKIE COLLINS makes a character in "The Moonstone" say that "we believe in romance only when we read it in the newspaper." A bit of cosmic romance got into newspapers last week. A flaming visitor from parts unknown appeared shortly before dawn on Friday and was seen by air pilots, farmers, station agents and others in Texas, Oklahoma, Arizona, New Mexico and Colorado.

Thirty-eight fellowships awarded to scholars, artists, musicians and writers by the John Simon Guggenheim Memorial Foundation for 1933-34 were announced yesterday by Henry Alien Moe, its secretary. Twenty-nine of the fellowships have been granted to residents of the United States and nine to scholars from Argentine, Chile, Cuba, Mexico and Puerto Rico.
PALM BEACH, Fla., March 27. -- In honor of Mrs. Julius Walsh, Mr and Mrs. Frank Vernon Skiff gave a dinner tonight at the Everglade Club. Their guests were:

WASHINGTON, March 26 (AP). -- President Roosevelt's sudden move today to consolidate agricultural credit agencies came as a preliminary to a program for refinancing the debt burdened holders of farm mortgages which will be submitted to Congress this week, probably to be followed shortly by a program for reviving the National Transportation System.

To the Editor of The New York Times: We all applaud President Roosevelt's recent request to Congress for permission to save $500,000,000 by discontinuing unjustified payments to veterans, and reducing wages, because we know it will help to balance our budget, restore our credit, improve business and eventually reduce our taxes.

CHICAGO, March 26. -- Sentiment in the grain trade has turned strongly to the constructive side and last week ended with prices at about their highest level for that period. Talk of inflation in commodities is spreading, and in the last few days a majority of operators, who had been slightly optimistic, have become emphatically so and now are outspoken in their expressions of opinion regarding the future.

A rapprochement between Poland and the Little Entente has been forecast since Premier Mussolini, after his talks with Prime Minister MacDonald in Rome, announced his plan for a four-power pact among Italy, Great Britain, France and Germany to keep the peace in Europe.

PANAMA CITY, March 26. -- The weather has been in alliance with Peru so far in holding the Upper Amazon settlement of Leticia against reoccupation by Colombian forces. The waters of the Amazon and Putumayo have been getting so low that ships are unable to reach Leticia and now, unless early action is taken, the rainy season may make airplane operations practically impossible.

MONTREAL, March 26 (Canadian Press). -- Following quickly upon an anonymous warning that incendiarism was intended, fire burst forth in St. Jacques Roman Catholic Church today while services were being conducted. In a few hours one of Montreal's finest and most historic churches was in ruins.

The sudden demand for merchandise appearing in the wholesale markets last week found manufacturers unable to supply immediate deliveries on desirable goods. Stocks of wearing apparel and accessories were light and quickly exhausted. The large number of buyers in the market exceeded those expected.

A statute that would authorize the parole of any convict after he had served one year in a State prison was recommended to the Legislature yesterday by the Commission to Investigate Prison Administration and Construction, of which Sam A. Lewisohn is chairman.

PARIS, March 24. -- Imports by France in February totaled 2,655,000,000 francs in value, an increase of 256,000,000 francs, while exports were 1,541,000,000 francs, a decrease of 238,000,000 francs, according to foreign trade figures issued today.

CHICAGO, March 26. -- Betterment in tanking conditions was reflected last week in generally improved business, and although there was no rust of buying there were indications that the manufacture and consumption of all kinds of merchandise would continue at about the recent rate.

About 1,250,000 individuals in New York State received home and work relief in February at a cost of $10,603,278 from State, Federal and local sources, it was revealed yesterday in a report by Harry L. Hopkins, chairman of the State Temporary Emergency Relief Administration.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, March 26 (AP). -- Chicago bowlers and one doubles team from Detroit caused six changes among the doubles and all-events leaders in the American bowling congress tournament today.

BERLIN, March 26. -- After a week of Roman holidays the waves of the national revolution have subsided. As modern revolutions go, this Teutonic upheaval was about as lacking in bloodshed as the average Latin-American upset. But the comparison must end there.

BUENOS AIRES, March 26. -- Absence of European interest in Argentine wheat, the depressing effect of the heavy tonnage afloat and the continued unexpected strength of the dollar combined to depress Argentine grain markets, although they were calm throughout last week.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., March 26. -- There was rejoicing today among the twenty-eight families on Clifford Island, formerly known as "Goat Island," in Long Island Sound off New Rochelle, when the water supply, which had been shut off since Thursday for non-payment of services, was once more turned on.

When they celebrate the eightieth birthday of ELIHU THOMSON this week electrical engineers will honor one of the eminent pioneers of their profession and at the same time take stock of their achievements during his lifetime. BELL and EDISON were still obscure young men when, as a 23-year-old professor, he was teaching chemistry and mechanics in Philadelphia and astonishing large gatherings with electrical experiments in the Franklin Institute.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 26. -- On the heels of Superior Judgs Ward's action of yesterday in granting a new trial to Tom Mooney on the indictment against him for the preparedness day bombing which the State never dismissed, the next step was awaited today from Attorney General U.S. Webb of California, whom Judge Ward requested to appoint a prosecutor for the case, which would come to trial April 26.

WASHINGTON, March 26 (AP). -- F.G. Await, Acting Controller of the Currency, issued tonight a statement defending the action of L.K. Roberts, chief national bank examiner in New York, for withholding "temporarily" the original of a report showing "irregularities" in the affairs of the Harriman National Bank and Trust Company in New York.

The need for a "planned system." io correct the abuses brought about by the "unrestricted play of economic forces" was agreed upon yesterday by speakers for capital, labor, socialism and the Catholic faith in symposia sponsored by the Newman Clubs at Columbia University.

WASHINGTON, March 26. -- Mistreatment of Jews In Germany has virtually ceased, according to Secretary of State Hull, who conveyed this information today in telegrams to Dr. Cyrus Adler of Philadelphia and Rabbi Stephen S. Wise of New York, who came to Washington last week to protest against German treatment of Jews.

The Pawtucket soccer team won its way into the Eastern final of the National Challenge Cup competition by defeating the German Hungarians of Brooklyn by 5-0 in a semi-final game at Starlight Park yesterday before 1,000.

More adequate provision for the unemployed and needy and abolition of "the present cruel and unnecessary inequalities in men's opportunity to obtain and enjoy the earth's material blessings" are urged by 160 prominent clergymen and laymen representing the Catholic, Protestant and Jewish faiths, in a manifesto issued yesterday under the auspices of the National Conference of Jews and Christians.

Subjecting Goalie Benny Haynes to a withering barrage of drives, the Atlantic City Sea Gulls completed the successful defense of their national A.A.U. hockey championship at Madison Square Garden yesterday by finishing the double-round robin undefeated as they turned back the Baltimore Orioles, 8 to 3, in the tournament finale.

WASHINGTON, March 26. -- The Langmuir Award for chemical research has been conferred this year on Dr. Frank Harold Spedding of the University of California, it was announced today by Professor Arthur B. Lamb of Harvard University, president of the American Chemical Society, which is meeting in Washington this week.

WASHINGTON, March 26. -- President Roosevelt moved today to consolidate and reorganize all agricultural credit agencies of the Federal Government and to abolish the Federal Farm Board. He announced that he would send to Congress tomorrow an executive order to effect these changes.

More than 250,000 Jews in this city and 1,000,000 throughout the country will join in protest meetings today against the persecutions and discriminations practiced against Jews by the Hitler Government in Germany, while hundreds of thousands of Jews, in response to a call from their religious leaders, will spend the day in fasting and prayer that the persecutions may cease.

WASHINGTON, March 26. -- Actual advances made by the Reconstruction Finance Corporation from Feb. 2, 1932, the date the corporation went into action, until March 21 totaled $2,083,750,079. A statement made by the corporation today showed that repayments over the same period totaled $407,368,772, leaving $1,676,381,307 in loans outstanding.

Miss Pescha Kagan, a native of Pittsburgh, making her debut as pianist at the Town Hall this evening, will be greeted by a delegation from her home city, including officials of the Pittsburgh Symphony Orchestra.

The Weyhe Gallery is holding a novel and very effective exhibition concerned with "ninety-nine ways of drawing a nude." It should prove of particular value to students, but may be enthusiastically recommended as well to the general art-loving public.

MIAMI, Fla., March 26. -- The weather dealt its first severe blow to the Dodgers today. With the Cardinals as their opponents and the prospect of a record attendance because of no competition from racing at Tropical Park, the game had to be canceled when rain began falling before 1:30 and persisted until nearly 4 o'clock.

Scores of automobile accidents occurred, during yesterday's rain and snow in and around New York. Vehicles proceeded at a reduced pace, but despite the carefulness of drivers there were many ambulance calls.

WASHINGTON, March 26. -- Doubt that the negotiation of reciprocal tariff agreements will provide sufficient impetus to a revival of world trade to meet the present crisis and permit debtor nations to meet their obligations to the United States was expressed today in a report on "Tariff Issues Confronting the New Administration," prepared by Maxwell S. Stewart of the research staff of the Foreign Policy Association.

One of the largest benefit performances -- well, say The Largest -- of all time went on last night and early today at the Metropolitan Opera House. It was the contribution of the Citizens Committee aiding the Stage Relief Fund, and the participants went through the alphabetical list.

The multiple dwelling law committee's recent appeal to civic organizations to oppose certain bills now before the State Legislature to amend the multiple dwelling law was the subject of a sharp attack in a statement issued yesterday by the Real Estate Board of New York, Inc., through John H. Hallock, head of the realty group's committee on old law tenements.

PARIS, March 26. -- Secret negotiations nave been going on in the last few months between French and Japanese officials regarding a possible solution of French claims in the Chinese Eastern Railway in Manchuria, it became known today.

NEW ORLEANS, La., March 26. -- The activity that Immediately followed the reopening of the cotton contract market here on March 16, with an advance in prices of about 55 a bale, gradually fell off last week and the greater portion of the advance was lost.

CHRISTCHURCH, New Zealand, Monday, March 27 (Canadian Press). -- A violent dust storm swept this city late today and caused abandonment of the test cricket match between England and New Zealand. New Zealand had scored 35 without the loss of a wicket in the second innings.

The legal size for trout in New York State remains at six inches. The bill introduced at Albany, sponsored by the Division of Fish and Game of the Conservation Department to increase the size to seven inches, failed of passage. The hope of the department was that by raising the size to seven inches the propagation of the fish would be assisted and eventually the anglers would profit by having larger trout to battle.

The church is "in for criticism and condemnation" and because of its defeats it is constantly being made a subject for "front-page news," the Rev. Dr. Will H. Houghton, pastor of the Calvary Baptist Church, 123 West Fifty-seventh Street, declared in his sermon yesterday morning.

"The Party's Over," a comedy written and produced by Daniel Kusell, will have its premiere this evening at the Vanderbilt Theatre. Included in the cast are Katherine and Ross Alexander, Peggy Conklin and Harvey Stephens.

CHICAGO, March 26. -- Prices of hogs here now are almost the highest of the year, the top at the close of the market on Friday being $4.25 a hundredweight, with an average at $4, against $3.90 three weeks ago and $4.10 a year ago. The week's average of $4.05 was the highest since last September, being 10 cents better than the previous week and only 25 cents less than a year ago.

NEW HAVEN, March 26. -- Professor Irving Fisher's index number of commodity prices, based on 100 as the average for 1926, is 56.6, which compares with 56.1 a week ago, 55 three weeks ago (markets closed two weeks ago) and 55.1 four weeks ago.

LONDON, March 24. -- In offering on a weekly tender system the new 2 1/2 per cent conversion loan stock, the proceeds of which are intended to repay a considerable portion of the floating debt, the government is breaking new ground and exploiting to the largest extent the extraordinary monetary ease created by the influx of gold and the extreme trade depression.

WASHINGTON, March 26. -- The second of the administration's relief bills, providing for a $500,000,000 fund for relief to the States, will be introduced in the Senate tomorrow by Senator Wagner jointly with Senators Costigan and La Follette.

A leadership in which all the people of the nation can have confidence, such as was displayed by President Roosevelt, is essential in such a crisis as recently arose in banking, Aldermanic President McKee told members of the Order of Seville at their annual communion breakfast at the Hotel Astor yesterday.

Taking advantage of every opening offered them and refusing to allow their rivals' passing game to function until late in the battle, the New York Rangers gained a commanding edge over the Canadiens of Montreal in the third-place playoff for the world's hockey championship by defeating the Flying Frenchmen at Madison Square Garden last night, 5 to 2.

ALBANY, March 26. -- While "economy pressure" in the Legislature has held up proposals to improve hours and working conditions for employes in State hospitals and asylums, hope was expressed today by Frank Teague, secretary of the Press Association for Humanity's Sake, that Governor Lehman by executive order would extend the eight-hour system to such employes, if the Legislature failed to act.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 26. -- A four-run rally in the eighth inning gave the Boston Braves a victory over the Tankees, 4 to 3, today in the closing game of their exhibition series at Waterfront Park, providing the third Boston triumph, against six for the McCarthymen.

NEW DELHI, India, March 26 (AP). -- The Moslem Conference executive board tonight adopted a resolution expressing profound dissatisfaction with the British Government's White Paper proposals for self-government in India.

ISTANBUL, March 26. -- The first report of the British draft disarmament convention that reached Turkey aroused some misgivings in government circles, it being felt that the absence of any mention of the Turkish army in Prime Minister MacDonald's proposals indicated an intention to regard Turkey as an Asiatic State.

FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., March 26. -- Christian Channing Gross, 37, soldier, author and colorful figure of the American Diplomatic service, was killed here today in an automobile accident which also took the lives of his two small children, and his mother, Mrs. Natali Gross of Chicago.

CHICAGO, March 26 (AP). -- A ten-year Indiana campaign to land the national Catholic high schools basketball championship ended tonight as Cathedral of Indianapolis scored a crushing 31-to-10 victory over St. Rita, Chicago, in the tournament final.

OAKLAND, Cal., March 26 (AP). -- Rainstorms, causing poor visibility, were blamed today by Varney Speed Lines officials for the crash of their transport plane which took thirteen lives, injured one person and reduced two dwellings to smoking ruins near here last night.
WASHINGTON, March 26. -- The votes in the Senate and House by the delegations from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut on important roll-calls last week are given in the appended tabulation:

In issuing the pamphlet report of the General Motors Corporation for 1932, Alfred P. Sloan, president, said yesterday that the automotive industry, at the conclusion of its period of readjustment, would not only maintain its position as the world's leading industry, but that its rate of recovery would be accelerated by the obsolescence of automobiles in recent years.

PHILADELPHIA, March 26. -- Completing a first hand survey to determine just who are the unemployed, the Pennsylvania Employment Commission announced today that the average present-day jobless worker is 36 years old, married, white, native born, physically fit, with a good previous record at his calling.
The new musical comedy which was presented at the Second Avenue Theatre over the week-end is called "The Jewish Melody."

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., March 26. -- The Clark brothers, Allan and Ted, shared most of the honors In the dinghy regatta held by Long Island sailors today at the Knickerbocker Yacht Club on Manhasset Bay.
Richard E. Whittlesey, 15 years old, accidentally killed his brother, George N. Whittlesey Jr., 19, while exhibiting a new rifle yesterday in their home at 66 Willow Street, Brooklyn.

The Associated Dry Goods Corporation reports for its fiscal year ended Jan. 31, 1933, a consolidated net loss, after all charges, interest and earnings applicable to the minority interest, of $1,939,914. This contrasts with a net income of $563,734 or $4.09 a share on the 136,764 shares of $100 par 6 per cent cumulative first preferred stock in the preceding fiscal year.

Hart Crane's poems are published by Liveright today, edited and supplied with an introduction by Waldo Frank. The book, which is titled "The Collected Poems of Hart Crane," contains, in addition to "The Bridge" and "White Buildings," forty-four of Crane's unpublished verses.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Would the Breltbart bill for reducing by law the interest on mortgages, as I understand it, add to the burdens and perplexities of many house owners, to say nothing of its effects on investors and on dealers in mortgages?

WASHINGTON, March 26. -- The Philippine Government, reducing expenses, converted a large threatened deficit into a surplus in 1932, and will have a balanced budget in 1933, according to the annual report of Colonel Theodore Roosevelt as Governor General to the Secretary of War, made public here today.

By defeating his fellow Olympian, Norman C. Armitage, in the fence-off, Miguel A. de Capriles, national three-weapon and junior national saber champion, added the metropolitan saber title to his list yesterday at the Salle d'Armes Vince.

WASHINGTON, March 26 (AP). -- Declaring they constituted a majority of the Texas Railroad Commission and that their decision would stand, C.L. Terrell and E.O. Thompson announced here today that the proposed two-hour test flow from 10,000 East Texas oil wells would be delayed from Monday until Thursday and that there would be a complete shut-down thereafter, until a check-up on the test had been made.

The proposed financing of a lower east side housing development with funds of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation is protested in a letter addressed to the Federal body and made public here yesterday by Frederick A. Wyckoff, president of the Wood, Dolson Company, real estate brokers.
Although a note of confidence persists in the steel industry, production of steel ingots last week declined a point to 14 per cent of capacity, according to the magazine Steel.
NEW ORLEANS, March 26 (AP). -- M.B. Cohen's Cherry Time, a 6-1 outsider in the betting, won the feature event of today's final racing program at the Fair Grounds track.

In a cold drizzle from the northeast and with, a splash over gunwales, the sailing dinghies of the Frostbite Tacht Club put forth on Pelham Bay yesterday for the regatta of the City Island Yacht Club.

A new social order was predicted by the Right Rev. William Hall Moreland, Bishop of Sacramento, guest preacher at the St. James Protestant Episcopal Church, Madison Avenue and Seventy-first Street, yesterday morning.

Samuel S. Koenig, veteran chairman of the New York County Republican Committee, whose leadership is under attack from several quarters, repelled a new assault last night when his supporters thwarted an attempt to put the Republican advisory committee on record against his continuance in the leadership.

Mr. JAMES MARSHALL'S Republican Advisory Committee, publisher of many tracts on good government as seen through Republican eyes, has now put out a "ten-point platform" on which all anti-Tammany forces in the city are invited to stand.

Charles Hayden, Arthur H. Bunker and Herbert B. Swope were designated yesterday by the directors of the B.M.T. as a committee to participate in the unification negotiations which Mayor O'Brlen plans to conduct with various classes of security holders of the B.M.T. and the Interborough.
ALBANY, March 27 -- Amid prolonged cheering the Assembly tonight adopted a resolution fixing April 7 as the date for adjournment of the legislative session.

It is needless to question the Sincerity of the regret expressed by the Japanese Government in withdrawing from, the League of Nations. Japan's association with the League has been to her a ground for patriotic pride. It placed her on a level with the greatest European nations.

WASHINGTON, March 27 -- President Roosevelt took the first step today in his governmental reorganization program with an executive order abolishing the Federal Farm Board, whose stabilization operations are estimated to have cost the government $360,000,000.

PURNEAH, India, March 27 -- The Mount Everest Flight Expedition's Houston-Westland and Westland-Wallace airplanes and their engines have now been thoroughly examined and adjusted in preparation for the big hop over the world's highest peak and will be ready for full trials after slight alterations of the equipment in the observers' cockpits.

LONDON, March 27 (AP) -- The courtmartial trying Lieutenant Baillie-Stewart on charges that he sold his country's military secrets, was informed by the Judge Advocate today that the young officer had no treacherous intent when he left England for Germany last Summer.

WASHINGTON, March 27 -- The age-old pastime of stuffing the Congressional Record with unspoken speeches, poetry, editorials which have no bearing on legislation, ancient statistics and other non-legislative material was aired in the House today.

GENEVA, March 27 (AP) -- The convention for the limitation of manufacture of narcotic drugs, the most far-reaching effort the world has seen to curb the traffic in opium products, is in imminent danger of being lost through the failure of European manufacturing States and Japan to ratify their signatures to it.

More than 35,000 men and women who came from the five boroughs and near-by communities to attend the protest meeting at Madison Square Garden last night were unable to gain admittance, according to police estimates.

BRUNSWICK, Germany, March 27 -- By order of Dietrich Klagges, National Socialist Interior Minister of the State of Brunswick, all the auxiliary police drawn from the ranks of the Stahlhelm [the Nationalist Steel Helmets] have been disarmed.

DETROIT, March 27 -- Federaland State investigations of the First National Bank-Detroit and the Guardian National Bank of Commerce were started in Detroit today, following a radio address by the Rev. Charles E. Coughlin yesterday, in which general charges of mismanagement against officers and directors of the two banks were made.

MIAMI, Fla., March 27 -- Silvio Coucci scored a triple at Tropical Park today, one of his winners being Mrs. W.M. Moore's Romac, 121-to-1 shot, which scored by a nose and returned $244.30 for $2, the longest price of the meeting. On the opening day Comstockery won and returned $228.10, the previous high price.

Awards were announced yesterday in the classes comprising bronze entries in the international horse show of art which is being held at the Knoedler Galleries for the benefit of the Social Service of Memorial Hospital. Mrs. Harry S. Duran is chairman of the horse show and Miss Gertrude Hill is chairman of the general committee.

After waiting more than six weeks beyond the usual time for making public the playing dates for the year in the hope that the Pennsylvania Legislature would act favorably on a Sunday opening bill, the National League finally announced the schedule for 1933 yesterday.

A decision which may result in the abrogation of the "basic agreement" now existing between the Actors' Equity Association and the obsolescent Managers' Protective Association is expected from an arbitration which will be held tomorrow between representatives of those two organizations.

Banking houses here which have marketed $84,000,000 of State of Arkansas highway bonds since 1927, the bonds being a first lien on the State's gasoline and motor vehicle taxes, charged yesterday that if Governor J.M. Futrell signed the highway bond refunding bill tomorrow, these bonds would automatically become secondary liens.

Vulgarity no longer pays at motion-picture box-offices and the industry during 1932 recognized this improvement in the public's taste by producing pictures that were socially important as well as entertaining, Will H. Hays said yesterday in his annual report to the Motion-Picture Producers and Distributors of America, of which he is president.

After something of an absence, as they reckon those thing's, Daniel Kusell returned last night to the mysteries of Broadway. He came back to toss to the stage of the Vanderbilt Theatre those varied whims of "The Party's Over." Apparently they had been his bland reflections in absentia, or, perhaps, Connecticut, and they suggested, on the whole, that he should not disappear again.
WASHINGTON, March 27 (AP) -- President Roosevelt went to work on the coal problem today.

BROOKLINE, Mass., March 27 -- Five of the eight quarter-final brackets in the women's national indoor tennis championships were filled after the first day's play on the Longwood covered courts today. Not an upset was recorded.

WASHINGTON, March 27 -- Conversations were resumed today between Secretary Hull and Sir Ronald Lindsay, the British Ambassador, under circumstances that indicated London had deferred to the wishes of Washington and was prepared to explore economic questions on the basis of the agenda for the World Economic Conference.

CHICAGO, March 27 -- Bullish enthusiasm in wheat on the Board of Trade was dampened somewhat today by the failure of Liverpool to respond to Saturday's upturn in the market here, but at the same time there was persistent buying by commission houses in small lots.

"This Joe Smith," said a writer in a New York newspaper of Sept. 4,1843, "must be set down as an extraordinary character, a prophethero, as Carlyle might call him. He is one of the great men of this age, and in future history will rank with those who, in one way or another, have stamped their impress strongly on society."

WASHINGTON, March 27 -- A further pay cut for Federal employes, effective April 1, loomed tonight after the Labor Department presented to the Budget Bureau a survey showing that the cost of living over the country had fallen 23 per cent since 1928.

Extensive alterations in the acoustical equipment in Madison Square Garden will be made before the final Musicians' Emergency Aid concert next Monday evening, Walter Damrosch announced yesterday. A special sounding board with a roof which will completely cover the orchestra of 175 musicians will be constructed.

Both the Whitney Museum of Art and the Museum of Modern Art are opening exhibitions this week. At the Whitney a, private view of the loan collection of nineteenth century American paintings from the Addison Gallery in Andover was held yesterday afternoon and beginning today the public may visit this show, which remains until April 27.

WASHINGTON, March 27 -- The effect of chemistry on human affairs is becoming so great that it is felt even in international politics, producing new industries and enlarging the world's supply of gold at a time when it is most needed, chemists said here today at the opening of the annual meeting of the American Chemical Society.

PINEHURST, N.C., March 27 -- Dabbler O'Dingle of Pinegrade, international champion Sealyam terrier owned by Mr. and Mrs. F.C. Brown of Armonk, N.Y., won his fourth best-in-show award in this country today at the exhibition of the Pinehurst Kennel Club.

Hitlerism with its anti-Semetic propaganda and persecution of Jews must be dragged out into the open and given the same treatment "we gave the Ku Klux Klan," former Governor Smith told a cheering audience of more than 20,000 Jews assembled in Madison Square Garden last night to protest against Hitler's treatment of the Jews in Germany.
COMMERCIAL PAPER. Yesterday -- 3% for the best names. Friday -- 3% for the test names. The quotations are for three-four months' paper.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 27 -- The Yankees closed their Southern schedule of games against National League teams with a rollicking victory over the Cincinnati Reds today, 16 to 3. The Yankees started with the line-up that is expected to appear in the opening league battle.

The New York County Committee of the American Legion, representing ninety-three posts and 7,156 World War veterans, unanimously adopted at its meeting last at the Hotel Pennsylvania a resolution endorsing State Commander George W. Lawrence's statement last week backing President Roosevelt's economy program.

BRUNSWICK, Germany, March 27 (AP) -- A ban on the Steel Helmet war veterans' organization throughout the State of Brunswick was issued tonight by Dietrich Klagges, Nazi Minister of the Interior, following a raid on the Steel Helmeters' guardhouse during which 1,350 persons were arrested.

GENEVA, March 27 -- The disarmament conference unanimously agreed tonight to accept the British draft treaty as a basis for discussion and to take a holiday until April 25, when the conference will begin examination of the first part of the convention providing for a universal consultative and nonneutrality agreement.

Growth of population in this country is steadily creating a deficiency of housing for normal living conditions that should result ultimately in a greatly increased demand for residential construction, Clarence M. Woolley, chairman of the board of the American Radiator Standard Sanitary Corporation declared in the company's report for 1932.

Dividend uncertainties were again uppermost yesterday in Wall Street's immediate market considerations. Speculative interests, where they could muster enough courage, continued cautiously to put out "short lines" in those issues which are figuring prominently in the dividend discussion.

MOSCOW, March 27 -- Spring sowing has now been in progress nearly a fortnight in the North Caucasus and South Ukraine -- where 93 and 73 per cent of the tractors of the two regions, respectively, have been repaired, but nothing is said about the horses and oxen that must do three-quarters of the whole job -- and reports have begun to give a fairly clear picture of the work.

DECATUR, March 27 -- An orderly court room crowd saw nine Negroes, accused of a crime which the South regards as more heinous than murder, brought into court here today to stand trial for their lives and listened apathetically as their lawyers tried to prove that Negroes are excluded from jury duty as effectively as though the law drew a color line.

At the New Jersey Historical Congress at Atlantic City on Saturday the claim of New Jersey to Staten Island was aired again. WILLIAM H. RICHARDSON of the Jersey City Board of Education declared that the land of the Aquehongas was held illegally by the State of New York, as he could prove by old documents and by maps published from 1638 to 1828.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., March 27 -- Both the varsity and freshman rowing squads at Harvard were cut to three crews for today's outdoor practice.

LONDON, March 27 -- A dramatic final plea was made today, ending the taking of evidence in the court martial of Lieutenant Norman Baillie-Stewart for the alleged sale of secret military information to German agents.

Trading volume on local commodity exchanges continued to dwindle yesterday, as prices moved in a narrow range with lower tendencies. The markets, in the absence of any news of general importance, were largely influenced by special conditions affecting them individually.

KILGORE, Texas, March 27 (AP) -- Wide opening of Sinclair Oil Company wells for a two-hour test under a disputed order of the Texas Railroad Commission, conservation agency, added to confusion in the gigantic East Texas oil field today. Complaints were issued against the producers.

BERLIN, March 27 -- Konstantin yon Neurath, German Foreign Minister, today made public a cable he had sent to Cardinal O'Connell of Boston "in view of reports that members of the American Catholic clergy are participating in protests against alleged pogroms," in which he said:

In an eight-page presentment handed up to Judge John J. Freschi In General Sessions yesterday, the New York County grand jury, which since Jan. 13 has been investigating frauds in the last election, recommended drastic changes in the election laws on the methods of conducting polling.

CHICAGO, March 27 -- General Robert E. Wood, president of Sears, Roebuck Co., told stock-holders at their annual meeting in New York today the company had obtained a modification in the terms of its mortgage repurchasing agreement with the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company.

PERTH, West Australia, March 27 -- Joseph A. Lyons, Prime 'Minister of West Australia, started a State-wide campaign tonight to persuade citizens of West Australia to vote against secession from the Commonwealth in a forthcoming referendum.

WASHINGTON, March 27 (AP) -- Senate Democratic leaders moved to enlarge the extra session program today to include action on the St. Lawrence waterway treaty and the proposal for American adherence to the World Court, but stipulated that neither should interfere with the administration's emergency measures.

Mrs. Helen Malcolm McLaughlin, prominent in New York and Philadelphia society and widow of Frank McLaughlin, newspaper publisher, died on Sunday at the Post Graduate Hospital ufter an operation for appendicitis.

ALBANY, March 27 -- W. Kingsland Macy, Republican State chairman, told the Republican women of Albany County today that Tammany was responsible for at least 250,000 illegal votes cast at the last election and he Warned that the Wigwam was attempting to extend its influence in up-State counties.

WEST PALM BEACH, Fla., March 27 -- Continuing their losing streak, Max Carey's weak-hitting Dodgers went down before the Browns today, 3 to 1, collecting only four safe blows off the combined deliveries of Bump Hadley and John Henry Knott.

With officials of the Liquidation Bureau of the State Insurance Department working on the plan for rehabilitation of the Globe and Rutgers Fire Insurance Company, negotiations were being carried on yesterday to raise capital to complete the severance of affiliated companies so that they may not be affected by its condition.
The speech of Rabbi Wise last night at Madison Square Garden follows:
Following is the text of the address of Senator Robert F. Wagner in Madison Square Garden last night:

WASHINGTON, March 27 -- More effective limitation and control of oil production was demanded with practical unanimity at the preliminary meetings held today by the representatives of the Governors and producers of thirteen States, who met here at the call of Secretary Ickes, issued at the suggestion of President Roosevelt.
Mayor O'Brien's speech at the protest meeting at Madison Square Garden last night follows:

The Western Union Telegraph Company reports for 1932 a net loss of $842,595 after charges, taxes, interest and reserves for depreciation. This contrasts with a net income of $5,974,499 or $5.72 a share on the 1,045,280 capital shares of $100 par value in 1931.

NICE, France, March 27 -- The English Duke of Leeds married Irma Amelie de Malkhazouny, a former ballet dancer, today in the American Church here because the rector of the Cathedral of the Holy Trinity refused to make an exception to the Anglican Church's rule against remarrying divorced persons.

Funeral services for Max Sarnoff, prominent hat manufacturer and head of the large chain of Sarnoff-Irving stores, whose death yesterday morning in Jacksonville, Fla., was reported in a late edition of THE NEW YORK TIMES yesterday, will be held at 11:30 A. M. tomorrow in the funeral chapel at 597 Lexington Avenue.

"The Werewolf of Paris," a book that has caused some pre-publication stir, is brought out today by Farrar Rinehart. It is a tale told with some humor and considerable horror of some extraordinary events in Paris about sixty years ago. The author, Guy Endore, is also the author of "Casanova: His Known and Unknown Life," "The Man From Limbo" and "The Sword of God: Jeanne D'Arc."

WASHINGTON, March 27 -- The policy of the Roosevelt administration will be one of immediate action whenever banking irregularities are revealed, and nothing will be withheld from the public, Secretary Woodin said today when asked to comment upon the delay of several months that followed the discovery of irregularities in the Harriman National Bank and Trust Company of New York.

To the Editor of The New York Times: As secretary of the Company of Amateur Brewers, a society of some 500 gentlemen domestic brewers, I wish to lodge a protest against an interpretation of the legal status of home brew as defined in an article in THE TIMES today.

Sociologists and antiquarians will bear with pleasure that Boston is true to tradition. It is not the return of beer, but the return of ale, to which she looks forward. The comprehensive term "beer" covers both.

The liquidation of $11,695.54 owed to the General Electric Company by the Radio Corporation of America for merchandise on Nov. 21, 1932, the date of the consent decree entered in the United States District Court for Delaware terminating the financial relationship between the two companies and also between the Westinghouse Electric and Manufacturing Company and the Radio Corporation, is outlined in the annual report of General Electric Company, issued today.
PALM BEACH, Fla., March 27 -- Mr. and Mrs. Henry Seligman were dinner hosts tonight at Casa Mia, their villa. Those present were:

SHANGHAI, March 27 -- General Chiang, who returned to Nanking from North China Sunday, was conferring today with Former Premier Wang Ching-wei and other government officials in an attempt to settie internal political affairs, upset by Mr. Wang's refusal to cooperate with General Chiang, who is believed to be aiming at a positive dictatorship.

The Spring of the year is when the fly fisherman and the bait fisherman have their greatest arguments. The old-timers generally admit that the bait devotee is likely to emerge with the greatest honors on opening day and for a while thereafter.

Plans for the first general reunion of former American and Canadian Rhodes scholars at Swarthmore College, Swarthmore, Pa., from June 4 to 6, were discussed last night at the annual meeting of the Association of American Rhodes Scholars at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

BOGOTA, Colombia, March 27 -- The announced capture yesterday of the Peruvian outpost of Guepi, on the Putumayo River, fifty miles above the important Colombian base of Caucaya, is believed here to be the beginning of a military drive to clear the Putumayo and Napo valleys for a Colombian attack via the Amazon River on both Iquitos, Peru, and Leticta, the Colombian town seized by Peruvians last September.

RIVERHEAD, L.I., March 27 -- A mortgage for $150,000 on the oceanfront home in Southampton of Charles E. Mitchell, former chairman of the National City Bank, given to Henry S. Morgan of New York to secure a debt for that amount was filed in the office of the Suffolk County Clerk here five days ago, it was learned today.

PHILADELPHIA, March 27 -- Mayor Charles H. Kline of Pittsburgh was ousted from office today under an order issued here by Judge Thomas D. Finletter, before whom Kline was tried and convicted in the Butler County court on charges of malfeasance in connection with city contracts.

MIAMI, Fla., March 27 -- A final decree of divorce for Mrs. Janet Alien Walker of Miami Beach against James J. Walker, former Mayor of New York, now living in France, was signed by Judge Worth W. Trammell in Circuit Court today.

Following the announcement last week that three large tire companies would eliminate two of the four lines of tires of their own brands and establish prices 10 per cent above those of the mail-order houses, Harvey S. Firestone, chairman of the Firestone Tire and Rubber Company, the remaining member of the "big four," in a message to stockholders indicates his disapproval of the move.

A petition asking the judges of the United States District Court to abrogate the rules by which the Irving Trust Company has been made receiver in virtually all bankruptcy cases was filed yesterday by the Federal Bar Association of New York, New jersey and Connecticut with the judges of the court.
WASHINGTON, March 27 -- The Bureau of Navigation issued the following orders today, dated March 24:

In an effort to lighten the financial burdens of its customers and at the same time to win back the thousands of former riders who are now using other forms of transportation or are not traveling at all, the Long Island Railroad will place on trial for three months, beginning May 1, a new series of reduced-rate round trip and communication tickets.

The disappearance of Elsie Kross, 17 years old, of 162 East 102d Street, and of her first cousin, Susan Gulick, 16, of 1,764 Third Avenue, both of whom had told their mothers they were going to look for work when they left their homes more than a week ago, was reported yesterday to the police.

PARIS, March 27 -- In a signed statement given to a delegation from the International League Against Anti-Semitism who met him at Havre on his arrival from New York, Professor Albert Einstein declared that the acts of oppression against Jews in Germany had aroused all countries devoted to liberty.

Miss Peseta Kagan, who made her New York debut at the Town Hall last night, is a young pianist of considerable talent. Her playing revealed a number of marked assets -- simplicity and directness of style, clarity of execution, an agreeable tone and the sensitivity of an unquestionably musical nature.

SAN ANTONIO, Texas, March 27 -- Returning to the scene of their former triumphs, the Giants arrived in the land of the Alamo today to be greeted by what the local Chamber of Commerce at once put down as something strikingly unusual and almost without precedent.

ALBANY, March 27 -- Addressing a mass meeting at the Capitol Theatre here tonight in protest against the Hitler government's stand on Jews, Governor Lehman appeald to the German nation to restore complete religious equality. Speaking as a Jew whose forbears for many generations lived in Germany, the Governor insisted that most of the citizens of that country were opposed to discrimination against the Jews of the nation.

WASHINGTON, March 27 -- A Senate resolution asking that the Department of Justice investigate allegations made recently in civil suits by David A. Olson, in which he charged government officials with failure to collect large amounts of taxes due from foreign steamship and other companies, was introduced today by Senator Wheeler.

The call to "constructive economy" made by Mr. FRANK L. POLK should be heard in every community. No purely national action can achieve such a readjustment as will assure continuance of those local agencies and services which are at the very heart of our American life.
The play-offs for the world's hockey championship will continue tonight, with three games listed on three different fronts.

Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt returned to her residence in East Sixty-fifth Street yesterday after spending Sunday at Hyde Park. She had promised to be back at 4:30 in the afternoon and was two minutes late.

Former Crown Prince Frederich Wilhelm of Germany, in a cablegram made public here yesterday afternoon, likened the reports of German cruelty to Jews under the Hitler regime to the anti-German propaganda carried on in America before the United States entered the World War.

Tosuke Matsuoka, former chief Japanese delegate to the League of Nations. who arrived here last Friday on his way to Tokyo from Geneva, discussed Far Eastern affairs yesterday and last night at private gatherings. Mr. Matsuoka is a member of Parliament and an authority on Manchuria, and was a member of the Japanese delegation at the Paris peace conference.

BERLIN, March 27 -- The National Socialist party announced tonight that it would conduct a counter-boycott against Jewish business concerns in Germany if Jews in the United States and England continued their boycott and atrocity propaganda.

LONDON, March 27 -- Although no definite appointment is yet on the Downing Street calendar, it is a foregone conclusion that Norman H. Davis, chairman of the United States disarmament delegation, who is due at Plymouth Wednesday, will see Prime Minister MacDonald before going to the Continent.

Returns to date for February fail to show the gains in net operating income which the railroads registered in January and December. For the twelve months ended on Jan. 31, comparisons were bettered by the fact that the figures in that period reflected a 10 per cent reduction in wages which was not in effect in the preceding like period.

President ROOSEVELT first exercised yesterday the broad powers Congress gave him to reorganize the Federal Government. He chose an appropriate point at which to Start in his effort to eliminate duplicating agencies" and "overlapping authority.

WASHINGTON, March 27 -- The drys feel "a little dazed by the confusion of the beer bill," Mrs. Henry W. Peabody of Boston, chairman of the Woman's National Committee for Law Enforcement, said yesterday. The law does not, she contends, bar the return of the saloon.

Representatives of the Catholic and Protestant faiths joined Jewish residents of communities throughout the suburban area last night at meetings held coincident with the gathering in Madison Square Garden, to protest the anti-Semitic campaign of the Nazi Government in Germany.

A decided Improvement in the Columbia varsity crew was evident yesterday in the five-mile workout on the Harlem River. After taking the wash of the junior varsity shell in every racing start this season, the big eight left the second crew half a length astern yesterday In the final of three starts.

CHICAGO, March 27 -- Chicago Jews packed the Auditorium Theatre tonight and thousands unable to get in stood on Wabash Avenue and Congress Street listening through amplifiers as speakers denounced the German Government for its treatment of Jews.

Several leases of midtown commercial space and several store rentals were included in the business space contracts reported by brokers yesterday. Leases of a store on Fulton Street, Brooklyn, and of retail space in the Bronx also were announced.

Telegrams from Governors of several States and from members of the United States Senate and House of Representatives condemning German persecution of the Jews and expressing sympathy with the aims of the gatherings were received last night at the mass meeting in Madison Square Garden.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Exportation of Mayor Curley? Or should the word have been "exploitation" in your recent editorial, "Three Hills or Seven?" Massachusetts friends of Boston's able Mayor appreciate the significance attached to him nationally, as evidenced by such a discussion of his future career in THE TIMES.

PHILADELPHIA, March 27 -- A reduction in the capital stock of the General Asphalt Company from $36,100,000 to $4,100,000 was proposed to stockholders today in a notice of the annual meeting on April 26, sent out with the 1932 report.
Bishop Manning's address last night at the protest meeting follows:

WASHINGTON, March 27 (AP) -- The deadline for the return of hoarded gold having expired at the close of business today, the Federal Reserve Banks tonight had a store of the precious metal worth $503,000,000 as a result.

Business in the money market in the new week was resumed without any variation in rates or turnover from those which has characterized trading in the preceding week. Stock Exchange call loans continued at 3 per cent, outside trades at 2% and Federal funds ranged 1 1/2 to 3.

WASHINGTON, March 27 -- Production and distribution of goods showed some increases after banking operations were resumed in the middle of March, the Federal Reserve Board stated today in its monthly review. Business conditions in the last part of February and the first half of March were largely influenced by the crisis in banking, culminating in the proclamation on March 6 of a national banking holiday by the President.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., March 27 -- Although the Yale varsity football eleven was unable to take a long trip last Fall, the recently organized rugby team will start tomorrow on an international journey for two and possibly three games in Bermuda with the British Army and Navy Club teams.

WASHINGTON, March 27 -- The appointment of a Collector of the Port of New York is impending, according to information obtained in administration circles today. It is understood that an offer has been made to a prominent party worker representing the anti-Tammany forces of New York.
ALEBANY, March 27 -- Two new programs designed to check abuses In the real estate field in New York City were brought here tonight by returning legislators.

MIAMI, Fla., March 27 (AP) -- A five-point legislative program to be presented to the American Legion at its next convention, calling for reversal of the Legion's action last year in seeking immediate cash payment of the bonus, was made public today by Colonel Henry Lindsley, first national commander of the body.

Expansion of the work program of the newly appointed City Emergency Work and Relief Administration in order to put 76,000 men on work relief in April was announced yesterday by Mayor O'Brien after the committee had met at City Hall.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I am in hearty sympathy with your correspondent Mabel L. Walker as to the proposed sales tax. At the rate suggested it could hardly fail to drive business out of the State and conflict in other ways with public interest.

With the more controversial features of the Administration's legislative program now before a Congress in which rebellious spirits are daily becoming bolder, the security markets displayed yesterday more than their usual caution. Stocks were subjected to gentle selling pressure, but in trading that involved only a half-million shares.
LONDON, March 27 -- Sir Percival Perry, the chairman of the British Ford Company, drove away from the great factory at Dagenham tonight hardly knowing, he said, what the strike was all about.

The case against Louis H. Willard, Bronx real estate dealer, charged with perjury growing Out of his testimony against William J. Flynn, Public Works Commissioner of the Bronx, will be given to a jury in General Sessions Court by Judge Nott today.

DOC GAUTREAU, the midget manager of the Montreal baseball team, was encountered on a recent trek through Florida, and Doc was bubbling over with hockey facts and fancies. As his name indicates, the former Holy Cross baseball star is of French-Canadian ancestry. He lives in Montreal through the Winter and he speaks the language.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, March 27 (AP) -- Several new names were placed among the leaders in the American Bowling Congress tourney as a result of high scoring today.

BEDMINSTER, N.J., March 27 -- Arthur Russell Jones, 46 years old, a New Tork stock broker, was found dead early today in the wreckage of his automobile that had crashed Into a tree on the Post-Bliss Road between Bernards-ville and Mendham.

A charge that court records in Tennessee had been tampered with, preventing five residents of that State from proving their claim that they are related to the late Ella V. Von E. Wendel and therefore entitled to share in her $35,000,000 estate, was made by their counsel, George A. Washington, during the examination of Robert E. Landis, a genealogist, of Nashville, before Surrogate James A. Foley yesterday.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., March 27 -- Reversing its position of last week, when special legislation had been requested at Albany to permit the raising of money for work relief by the sale of temporary certificates instead of bonds, the Westchester County Board of Supervisors authorized today the sale of $500,000 bonds for work relief in the county.

To the Editor of The New York Times: James Hopkins, 15 years old, has been declared a juvenile delinquent. His case is stated in THE TIMES of March 23 and briefly is as follows: James became go fired with the new world which his course in biology was revealing to him that he just had to tell the gang.

Thwarted yesterday afternoon in her attempt to commit suicide by hurling herself from the northbound platform of the Forty-second Street-Sixth Avenue elevated station in the path of an approaching train, Sylvia Schwartz, 12 years old, of 620 East 178th Street, the Bronx, was arrested on a charge of juvenile delinquency and placed in the custody of the Children's Society.

PEIPING, March 27 -- The United States Minister, Nelson T. Johnson, has decided to protest directly to the Japanese Charge d'Affaires against the Japanese aerial bombing of American Methodist mission property at Taotowying, a few miles east of Peiping.

LONDON, March 27 -- In an atmosphere of suppressed excitement, the House of Commons today began the Important three-day debate on the Government's proposed Constitution for India. The whole range of British policy in India since 1919 will be discussed, although a vote will be taken solely on the proposals to establish a committee of both houses of Parliament to consider the Government's recent White Paper.

Trapped by flames in their apartment on the fourth floor of the five-story building at 911 Longwood Avenue, the Bronx, a widow and her four children were all painfully burned about the hands and face early this morning before firemen carried them down extension ladders to the street.

The texts of the communication from Count Yasaya Uchida, Japan's Foreign Minister, announcing to the League of Nations Tokyo's decision to withdraw, and of the Japanese Emperor's rescript concerning the decision, as given out by the Consulate General here last evening, were as follows:

Officers at the New York General Depot Army Base in Brooklyn have discovered that a strict application of the "buy American" clause in the Treasury-Postoffice bill passed by the last Congress will make impossible the purchase of a large number, possibly a majority, of magazines and newspapers for use in army stations.

No One Understands Them. The Hitler regime is amazed and pained to find itself so greatly misunderstood. Here, for instance, is one Herr HAEFSTANGL, chief Nazi press agent, who says that the German people in the last fourteen years "crumbled morally, financially and politically" because of Jewish influence in the life of the nation.
WASHINGTON, March 27 -- Silver legislation hereafter will be studied by a special Senate subcommittee named today by Chairman Fletcher of the Banking and Currency Committee.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., March 27 -- Delayed a week by inclement weather, Spring football practice at Harvard opened today with sixty-four candidates participating in a ninety-minute drill on Soldiers Field.
WASHINGTON, March 27 -- Movements of vassels follow. All dates March 25, unless otherwise specified:

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., March 27 -- Dress rehearsal tonight closed the long period of preparation by the Hasty Pudding Institute of 1770 of Harvard for its seventy-third consecutive musical comedy production which will open for a five-show run tomorrow night.
SAN FRANCISCO, March 27 (AP) -- Tom Mooney today dared his former prosecutors again to prove him guilty and if possible hang him.

WASHINGTON, March 27 -- Favorable committee reports were made both in the Senate and the House today on the revised bill to provide jobs for 250,000 Idle in reforestation and similar projects, and in addition, the Costigan-Wagner-La Follette measure for $500,000,000 direct relief to States was reintroduced in the Senate.
NEW YORK. The Duchess of Northumberland will arrive at the Savoy-Plaza today from Palm Beach.

BOSTON, March 27 -- William Smith, born in slavery "somewhere in Virginia," celebrated his eighty-third birthday today and also his fifty-eighth year of, continuous service as a waiter in Boston, first at Young's Hotel and now at the Parker House, by doffing the waiter's garb and becoming the guest of the Parker House for the day.

A substantial improvement in the cash position of Best Co. is revealed in the annual pamphlet report for the fiscal year ended on Jan. 31. Current assets, including $1,078,629 of cash, amounted to $3,444,339, while current liabilities were $602,720.

Stabilization of the price situation in the Canadian newsprint industry, due in a measure to the elimination of high-cost producers and the dwindling of supplies of wood pulp, is seen by Neil C. Head, vice president of the International Paper Company, who returned here yesterday from New Brunswick, Canada, where he had been inspecting company properties.
The text of the speech of Alfred E. Smith at Madison Square Garden last night follows:

Collectors of autographed books and dealers in rare volumes were pleased when the Public Library announced a few years ago that it was establishing a collection of forged "association books." Even the most experienced collectors are occasionally deceived by a clever imposture.

Surprised by an assailant who stole up from behind and dashed acid in his face. Adelbert Letscher, 29 years old, an unemployed electrical worker, of 64 Washington Street, Hoboken, N.J., was painfully burned as he was walking along Sixth Avenue near Twenty-third Street yesterday afternoon.

ALBANY, Tuesday, March 28 -- Power to authorize the drinking of beer at bars would be vested in the control board, ultimately to be chosen under Governor Lehman's bill, through amendments to that measure, sent to the Legislature early this morning by the Executive himself and introduced by Senator Dunnigan and Assemblyman Steingut, the Democratic leaders, in their respective houses.

TIENTSIN. March 27 -- "Incidents like the occasional Japanese airplane bombings of Chinese positions south of the Great Wall and the recent capture of the village of Shahochiao, nine miles south of the Jehol boundary by Japanese troops are likely to recur somewhat frequently as long as the Chinese continue sporadically attacking the Japanese forces," declared an official spokesman for Lieut. Gen. Kotaro Nakamura, commander of the Japanese forces in North China.

TRENTON, N.J., March 27 -- State control of breweries and wholesale dealers, with municipal licensing of retailers of 3.2 beer, is expected to be recommended to the Legislature by the commission of twelve named to devise a policy for regulation and taxation of alcoholic beverages.

Bernard H. Ridder, editor of The New Yorker Staats-Zietung, last night gave out the text of the speech he bad intended to deliver at the meeting at Madison Square Garden. He said that this speech had been rejected by the commitee in charge, who asked him to deliver one prepared by them.

TOKYO, March 27 -- Count Yasuya Uchida, the Foreign Minister, notified the League of Nations today of Japan's decision to withdraw because of "irreconcilable" differences with the League over Manchuria.

AMSTERDAM, N.Y., March 27 -- Dr. Theron Akin, who attracted State-wide attention by his spectacular campaign for Congress in 1910, when he defeated the late Cyrus Durey of Green Lake, died at his home here last night from a stroke of paralysis suffered yesterday.

Strength in foreign loans featured an otherwise irregularly lower bond market on the Stock Exchange yesterday. Advances and declines in German bonds were about at a stand-off, although the Government 7s and 5 1/2s finished fractionally lower on the day.
Fourteen Manhattan properties and one Bronx parcel were auctioned yesterday as a result of fore-closure proceedings. The realty was taken over by the stated plaintiff in most of the cases.

TRENTON, N.J., March 27 -- Under suspension of rules the New Jersey Assembly rushed through an emergency measure tonight declaring a moratorium on mortgage foreclosures for home owners of the State. The vote was 56 to 1, wtih Elmer King, Republican of Morris County, casting the only negative vote.

WASHINGTON, March 27. -- The Senate Agriculture Committee took action today to make speed on the farm relief measure. It decided that it would complete the testimony, if possible. by tomorrow night and report the bill to the floor for action before the week-end.

A study of the performance of the stabilizing system of the Italian, liner Conte di Savoia during the first six months of its operation indicates the success of the system, according to engineers of the Royal Italian Navy and the Sperry Gyroscope Company, which furnished the equipment.

WASHINGTON, March 27 -- The Department of Justice has declined to agree to a plan under which Owen D. Young, official of the Radio Corporation of America and the General Electric Company, would be permitted to remain as a member of the boards of both corporations, Attorney General Cummings revealed today.

WASHINGTON, March 27 (AP) -- Congressional Democrats have been working with the President and his advisers for months on his plan to consolidate the farm loan agencies and were prepared to block any effort which might be made to prevent it from going into effect.
Dwelling conveyances comprised the larger part of the New Jersey realty transfers reported yesterday.
After displaying comparative steadiness for several hours yesterday, prices on the Cotton Exchange grave way with other markets and ended at losses of 18 to 21 points.

Meeting in closed session at the Racquet and Tennis Club last night, the Davis Cup committee of the United States Lawn Tennis Association chose the personnel of the selection committee, which will pick the 1933 team, and arranged definitely for the first round tie with Mexico to be played in Mexico City.

While some of the large restaurant chains in New York City announced yesterday that they would serve beer with meals when it becomes legal, others announced they would not serve alcoholic beverages or that they were undecided as to what they would do until the legislative situation cleared.

PATCHOGUE, N.Y., March 27 -- With Frederick C. Metz of Queens Village, who was vice president of, the Bank of New York and Trust Company, from 1914 to 1929, as its president, the new Patchogue Citizens Bank and Trust Company, was opened on an unrestricted business basis at noon today.

Sidney Z. Mitchell, who has been identified with electric light and power companies for nearly fifty years, has resigned from all offices and directorates that he holds in the Electric Bond and Share Company, its subsidiaries and affiliates and other organizations, on account of ill health.
