SAN FRANCISCO, March 27 -- Steps to clear the way for trial April 26 of Tom Mooney on an unused murder indictment, growing out of the 1916 San Francisco preparedness day bombing, went forward today.

The Canadian Pacific Railway set aside a $4,000,000 reserve from surplus in 1932 to meet losses in respect to lines in the United States controlled through stock ownership, the annual report discloses. The Minneapolis, St. Paul Sault Sainte Marie Railway, which is in receivership, is one of the properties in this country controlled by the Canadian road.

WASHINGTON, March 27. -- Anestimate that the farm indebtednes of the United States was $12.000,000,000 and a program for permanent adjustment of that burden were laid before the House of Representatives today by Secretary Wallace.

Rallying after being buffeted by a series of flying tackles. Jim Browning of Missouri, recognized in New York State as world's heavyweight wrestling champion successfully defended his title before a crowd of 4,000 in the Seventy-first Regiment Armory last night.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., March 27 -- "If the right to live interferes with profits, profits must necessarily give way to that right," said former Representative La Guardia tonight in an address at Yale University under the auspices of the Public Committee of Labor Legislation.

WASHINGTON, March 27 -- Action to obtain relief from a deficiency income tax assessment of $7,400, with a request for a refund of $2,600, has been filed with the Board of Tax Appeals by George Z. Medalie of New York City, United States Attorney.

DURHAM, N.C., March 27 -- Threatened by a mob of Negroes after he had opened his dance program in a big tobacco warehouse soon after midnight, Cab Calloway and his Cotton Club musicians ended their engagement today with the Negro post of the American Legion.

Supreme Court Justice Daniel V. McNamee of Hudson, N.Y., who is sitting by special assignment in the election fraud cases here in the criminal branch of the Supreme Court, took an action without precedent, so far as veteran court attaches could recall, at the trial of four election inspectors last night.

PHILADELPHIA, March 27 -- Glenn S. (Pop) Warner, Temple's new head football coach, was greeted by fifty-six candidates at the start of Spring training today. Twenty-two veterans and thirty-four newcomers from last year's freshman ranks turned out in uniforms and went through a two-hour drill.

For two hours yesterday afternoon business was suspended in the Brownsville section of Brooklvn while about 10.000 persons participated in a parade protesting the treatment of Jews in Germany. After the march, which attracted other thousands who lined the streets there was a mass meeting at Public School 84.

With four fencers qualifying for the women's national foils championship which will be held on April 12, Miss Muriel Guggolz, the metropolitan titleholder, failed to survive the preliminary test that was held at the Fencers Club last night.

John F. James, prominent Brooklyn real estate operator, died yesterday of a complication of diseases at the residence of his son, Harold R. James, in Red Bank, N.J. He was president of the real estate, firm of John F. James Sons, which was founded by his father in 1858.

William J. Duffy, manager of Primo Carnera, and former proprietor of Duffy's Tavern on Forty-fourth Street between Broadway and Sixth Avenue, was indicted yesterday by a Federal grand jury for failure to report a net Income of $34,170.50 for the year 1930.

The Firestone Tire and Rubber Company announced yesterday that it had lowered its prices to a level which would permit its dealers to meet not only the prices of standard-brand tires of other manufacturers but also the prices of special-brand tires sold by mail-order houses and others.

TRENTON, N.J., March 28. -- The joint commission of legislators and private citizens created to formulate a State policy for distribution and sale of 3.2 beer voted today to recommend enactment of a law to govern the traffic until such time as a permanent program is adopted.

About 100 passengers on two oneman trolley cars were badly shaken up, and twenty-five of them suffered shock, contusions and abrasions last night in a rear-end collision in the tunnel approach to the Manhattan side of the Williamsburg Bridge.

Frank Ward, world's open squash tennis champion since 1926, successfully defended his crown last night and demonstrated once again that there is no player on the courts who can stand up against his killing speed and incomparable racquet work.

BRUSSELS, March 28. -- Fifteen persons were killed when the British Imperial Airways liner City of Liverpool crashed in flames near Dixmude this afternoon. The victims, who comprised all on board, were the pilot, assistant pilot, radio operator and twelve passengers.

BOSTON, March 28. -- The Boston Maine, reporting today for 1932, its 100th year of service, announced that while revenues had declined $12,697,224 from those of 1931, 16.34 per cent of its gross revenues of $45,087,753 had been saved for net railway operating income, compared with 17.12 per cent in 1931, when the gross revenues were nearly $13,000,000 greater.
Harry M. Durning of the Bronx has been selected Collector of the Port of New York to succeed Philip Elting, Republican, according to a report received last night from Washington.
WASHINGTON, March 28. -- President Roosevelt's reforestation meas- ure, which is counted upon to put at least 250,000 idle men to work, was passed by the Senate today without a record vote.
Three gangs of crooks invaded midtown Manhattan yesterday and three daylight hold-ups netted more than $7,000 in cash, checks and furs.

The Fencers Club trio retained the national epee team championship last night by turning back the New York A.C. representatives at the Saltus Fencing Club headquarters in the Twenty-third Street Y.M.C.A.

A reduction of inventories and an increase in net working capital are shown in the report of Abraham Straus, Inc., for year ended on Jan. 31. The company continued to operate at a profit through the year.

Mr. KOENIG'S friends on the New York County Advisory Committee got a moratorium for him by a none too muscular majority, which might have been turned into a minority if there hadn't been ten vacancies which he had prudently filled.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., March 28 (AP). -- Governor J.M. Futrell today signed the Ellis highway bond refunding bill, despite protests from bondholders and the threat of the Attorney General of Pennsylvania to institute suit against the State of Arkansas.

WASHINGTON, March 28. -- President Roosevelt will send a message to Congress tomorrow recommending Federal regulation of the sale of new securities. It will be accompanied by a bill described in some administration quarters as "a national blue-sky law," which will require the fullest publicity regarding offerings of securities to the public.

Edith Evans, seen here this season in "Evensong," and Cedric Hardwicke will have the leading roles in Gilbert Miller's London production of "The Late Christopher Bean," which Mr. Miller will soon go abroad to prepare.

Representatives of Interborough and B.M.T. security holders will meet Mayor O'Brien at City Hall at 1:30 o'clock this afternoon for a preliminary discussion of negotiations for rapid transit unification. Mayor O'Brien sent invitations yesterday not only to the spokesmen for various committees of stock and bond holders, but also to several individual owners of company securities.

The immediate enactment of a compulsory unemployment insurance law for the wage earners of New York State by the present Legislature was urged yesterday upon Governor Lehman in a petition signed by more than 700 individuals and members of civic, labor and welfare organizations.
Hitler and Communists. Did Communism in Germany make HITLER inevitable, or did HITLER make the rapid growth of German Communism in the last three years inevitable?

LONDON, March 28 (AP). -- The charges that Lieutenant Baillie-Stewart sold military secrets have centred around L90 ($311) which he received in letters from Berlin. His defense was that this money was in payment for his love-making and that it came from a young German woman known to him only as "Marie Louise."

The directors of the Hahn Department Stores, Inc., have recommended to stockholders a reduction in common stock capital from $9,869,373 to $1.357,489 by reducing the stated value of the shares from $7.26 to $1 a share. This move would increase the surplus account to $10,962,823.

An order by Supreme Court Justice Richard P. Lydon awarding $10,286 to Mrs. Stella Crater as temporary administratrix of the estate of her husband, former Supreme Court Justice Joseph Force Crater, who disappeared on Aug. 6, 1930, was disclosed yesterday.
ALBANY, March 28. -- The battle over charter revision for New York City and the rest of the cities of the State approached its final phase today in both houses of the Legislature.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., March 28. -- With little debate, the Legislature today overrode the veto of Governor Miller on the Mullins bill for a prohibition, repeal convention within an hour after he had returned it with a message expressing his belief that the measure was unconstitutional, undemocratic and untimely.
ANTWERP, March 28. -- Professor and Mrs. Albert Einstein arrived at Antwerp aboard the liner Belgenland this afternoon. Mayor Camille Huysmans went aboard to welcome them.

The story of how President Roosevelt decided upon and wrote his historic message to Congress calling for beer legislation, which came as a surprise to House leaders and which followed closely the prohibition plank in the 1932 Democratic platform, was told yesterday by his friend, former Supreme.

Eugene Ormandy was guest conductor of the Philadelphia Orchestra last night in Carnegie Hall. The novelty of the occasion was the symphonic poem, "The Prairie," by Leo Sowerby. The music was inspired by the poem of Carl Sandburg.

WASHINGTON, March 28. -- After a year's delay, the Engineers' Ad- visory Board of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation has come to terms with the Port of New York Authority on the latter's application for a $75,000,000 loan to construct a midtown tunnel under the Hudson River from Thirty-eighth Street in New York City to Weehawken, N.J.

PARIS, March 28. -- The progress of the Washington oil conference is watched here with interest by the delegates to the international oil meeting, which is negotiating for a renewal of the accord for a limitation on production which expires at the end of the month.

Informal discussions which may prove to be of great importance have been begun in Washington by representatives of the British and American Governments. The subject under consideration is the whole question of "the world economic situation."

The evolution of living quarters from the cave of prehistoric days to the modern penthouse and the problems of slum clearance today, are depicted in an exhibition of housing and city planning arranged at the New School for Social Research, 66 West Twelfth Street, under the auspices of the Public Housing Conference.

WASHINGTON, March 28 (AP). -- The army and the navy paused in their customary tasks today to debate the topic of whether posts, ships and stations will be permitted to have beer on April 7, when it becomes legal for the nation at large.

BOSTON, March. 28. -- The Toronto Maple Leafs poked home a sudden-death goal in the overtime to defeat the Boston Bruins tonight, 1 -- 0, and deadlock the National Hockey League's championship playoff at one game each. The Bruins won the opener in overtime, 2 -- 1.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 28. -- The Yankees took a free-hitting ball game from the Newark Bears at Waterfront Park today, 10 to 8, and gave Colonel Jacob Ruppert's farm club two ball players in return.

A statement of the Department of Commerce on the source or destination by countries of the gold imported or exported during February shows that the month's total gold imports of $30,381,313 came from thirty-three different countries, while gold exports, aggregating $21,520,552, went to ten.

"Tide-over" jobs for 1,000 men and women whose courage in the face of adversity won the admiration of Mrs. August Belmont and her committee will be sought in an intensive effort that will begin on April 17 and end on April 29, it was announced yesterday at the Women's Division of the Emergency Unemployment Relief committee.
LIMA, Peru, March 28. -- The entire population of 1,000 in the village of Tantaday is now believed to have been wiped out by the landslide which buried it at 1 o'clock Sunday morning.

Disregarding the major economies which are possible through elimination of unnecessary "frills" in distribution, and through the perfection of a more scientific sales technique, manufacturers have concentrated on the easier but less profitable practice of slashing wages and reducing sales staffs.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, March 28 (AP). -- Ohio bowlers gained another high spot in the American Bowling Congress today when Eddie Collins and Alex Graham, Dover, Ohio, connected with a torrid 1,304 series to vault into second place in the doubles division.

Supplementing their petition to the Interstate Commerce Commission for further consideration of shipping conditions in the port of New York before a final decision is issued in the action of New Jersey interests to eliminate free lighterage of freight in the port, counsel for the New York interests filed with the commission yesterday a summary of shipping developments of the last two years.

In his foreword in the annual report of the Police Department, Commissioner MULROONEY speaks a good word for the Crime Prevention Bureau. "Although the full "effects of its work cannot yet " be known," he said, "the bureau's "report for 1932 shows that the "value of having a unit in the "department devoted to the pre"vention of delinquency is already "being demonstrated."

VIENNA, March 28. -- Mobs of National Socialists terrorized the Inner City from 6 until after 10 o'clock tonight, continually shouting "Germans awake!" "Judea perish!" and "We want elections!" covering all the streets with hundreds of thousands of paper swastikas and placarding Jewish shop fronts with anti-Semitic labels.

OTTAWA, March 28 (Canadian Press) -- The question whether foreign boats should be permitted to carry grain from a Canadian port to a United States port, tranship it to another foreign vessel, and proceed to a Canadian port is involved in the shipping bill now before the Senate Committee.
BEAUMONT, Texas, March 28. -- After a delayed start of twenty-four hours, the Giants and Tigers launched their ten-game exhibition series today, with Detroit taking the opening contest, 7 to 5.

COLOGNE, Germany, March 28. -- Cardinal Schulte, the Archbishop of Cologne, acting in behalf of the German Bishops of the Fulda Bishops' Conference, today formally revoked the ban placed by the Catholic Church on the National Socialist movement two years ago.

HAVANA, March 28. -- The two-year mortgage moratorium recommended by President Machado was unanimously approved by the Senate in an all-night session which terminated at 4 o'clock this morning. Although many amendments were introduced, little change was made in the text of the measures presented by the Chief Executive.

Denial that "the slightest acts of terror" had been committed in Germany against Jews was made in a cablegram from executives of the Hamburg-American Line received yesterday by the Board of Trade for German-American Commerce and made public by Herman A. Metz, president of the board, from his office at 230 Fifth Avenue.

PARIS, March 28. -- The isolation of element 61, originally discovered by X-ray spectroscopy in 1926 by Professor B.S. Hopkins of the University of Illinois, and named by him Illinium, was announced here today by Professor G. Urbain in a paper read before the Academy ot Sciences at the Sorbonne.

BERLIN, March 28. -- The terms of a sweeping boycott against the Jews of Germany, which is to be nationally minded Germany's answer to demonstrations in the United States, Great Britain and elsewhere against anti-Semitism were announced tonight at the headquarters of the National Socialist party in Munich.
WASHINGTON, March 28. -- The War Department issued the following orders today:
WASHINGTON, March 28. -- The government's $800,000,000 public building program has been temporarily held up, but no reason was assigned for the delay by Secretary Woodin in making the announcement.

PRINCETON, N.J., March 28. -- The 1933 Princeton football team will meet Rutgers in Palmer Stadium Nov. 25, it was announced today by Thurston J. Davies, acting chairman of the board of athletic control of Princeton University. The game will mark the thirty-first contest between the oldest intercollegiate rivals, which last clashed in 1915.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., March 28. -- Announcement of the award of 175 athletic insignia and nine charms to members of Yale Winter sports teams was made tonight by the board of control of the Yale Athletic Association. The list included seventeen major letters, sixteen to members of the hockey team, and the other to Nicholas Del Genio of Brooklyn, boxing captain, who won an intercollegiate championship.

BROOKLINE, Mass., March 28. -- Miss Dorrance Chase of Dorchester, Mass., seeded second; Mrs. Robert Morris of Boston, seeded fourth, and Miss Helen Germaine of New York City, public parks champion, won the three remaining places in the quarter-final bracket of the women's national indoor tennis tournament today.

DETROIT, March 28. -- The Detroit Red Wings defeated the Montreal Maroons in the final game of the second place play-off round tonight by 3 to 2, and advanced to the semi-finals of the world's championship hockey play. Detroit won the opening game by 2 to 0, and the series on total goals, 5 to 2.

Protests against the passage of the $211,000,000 State budget have deluged the offices of the New York State Economic Council in the Chrysler Building as the result of a ten-day survey conducted by the organization, it was announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 28. -- A proposal for Federal control of oil production was put before the Secretary of the Interior today by a dominant group of spokesmen for Governors of the petroleum-producing States, the major companies and some independents.

HUNTINGTON, N.Y., March 28. -- Representatives of six field trial clubs contested today over the Farmingdale course of the Long Island Field Trial Association for the Interclub All-Age Brace Stake, the trophy which was carried up-State by the Verbank Hunting and Fishing Club of Verbank, N.Y.

From HITLER down, we are getting bitter German complaints about "propaganda" and monstrous "slanders" circulating in French and British and American newspapers. A favorite German comparison today is with the stories of alleged "atrocities" in Belgium at the onset of the war in 1914.

To secure an issue of $547,500 of ten-year sinking fund mortgage bonds, payable Aug. 1, 1942, Park Avenue and 91st Street, Inc., David Miller, president, gave a trust mortgage for $520,000, the amount already issued, to the Continental Bank Trust Co. of New York on the fifteen-story apartment building at the southeast corner of Park Av. and 91st St.

Bad weather simply does not exist, in the opinion of Dr. James H. Scarr, meteorologist of the United States Weather Bureau here. It is nothing more than a superstition created by people who do not like rainy days. A morning grouch occasioned by an overcast sky is an indication that some one misunderstands "the greatest physical influence in the world," according to Dr. Scarr.

King George of England may have another opportunity to acquire the 1-cent magenta British Guiana stamp which he lost in 1922 when his agent was outbid by the late Arthur Hind of Utica. Mr. Hind's collection, valued at from $1,500,000 to $2,000,000, will be sold by Charles J. Phillips of this city and William C. Kennett Jr. of Hazelwood, Ohio, after the will is probated at Utica April 24.

Daily average gross crude oil production in the United States last week was 2,249,650 barrels, compared with 2,126,450 in the preceding week, an increase of 123,200 barrels, according to the American Petroleum Institute. Increases of 107,050 and 32,350 barrels, respectively, in the average daily outputs of Oklahoma and East Texas and a decline of 40,100 barrels in that of California were the most important changes.

The first fifty-seven railroads to report for February showed a net operating income of about $7,958,000, against $17,513,000 in February, 1932, a decline of 54.5 per cent, and against $22,914,000 in February, 1931, a drop of 65.2 per cent. In January their net was $10,249,000, against $9,170,000 in January, 1932, an increase of 11.7 per cent.

WASHINGTON, March 28. -- The interest of other governments in the economic discussions between the United States and Great Britain looking to understandings that would contribute to the success of the proposed World Economic Conference was reflected today in calls made by two foreign envoys on Secretary Hull.

Recovery was the rule in financial and commodity markets yesterday. Strength in the agricultural staples, notably wheat, was communicated to the Stock Exchange, where share prices pointed sharply upward in the afternoon. Modest gains occurred in United States Government securities.

DOWN with these deceitful poets who sing the joys of the blithe vernal season! In this melancholy region there is no rejoicing that "in green underwood and cover, blossom by blossom the Spring begins." Woe, woe, unutterable woe! Travis Jackson of the Giants has confessed that his legs feel weak under him. That ruins not only the budding Spring, but spreads a pall over the coming Summer at the Polo Grounds.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The TIMES editorial "Too Much Third Person," reflecting the grievance of Swedish intellectuals and the comments of the Stockholm correspondent of The London Times, brings back the reaction I had when I started to become initiated into the intricacies of the English language.
The New York Telephone Company has instituted a policy of seeking "voluntary resignations" among more than 20,000 employes comprising its operating force, it was learned yesterday.

All available detectives in Brooklyn, more than 200 of them, joined last night in a search for the slayer of 6-year-old Barbara Wiles, who was attacked and strangled yesterday morning in the cellar of her home at 161 Himrod Street while her father, a jobless shipping clerk, was at the Wilson Avenue police station only two blocks away, drawing his weekly ration of coal.

CHICAGO, March 28. -- The Central and Southwest Utilities Company and subsidiaries, a part of the Middle West Utilities System, reported for 1932 a net income of $1,364,339, subject to the adequacy of the provision for depreciation. In 1931 net income was $3,288,000.

WASHINGTON, March 28. -- Conservators in charge of unlicensed national banks and supervisory officials in charge of unlicensed State member banks received broader authority to permit limited activities under the terms of a regulation issued today by Secretary Woodin of the Treasury Department.

BERLIN, March 28. -- After an almost unprecedented upward movement in recent weeks, which brought the turnover on some days to the high record of 1927, a downward movement, heralded by yesterday's relative inaction, began on a large scale in the stock market today.
After reaching the lowest prices since the exchanges reopened after the banking holiday, cotton prices recovered a quarter cent sharply yesterday and ended 10 to 13 points higher than on Monday.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W.Va., March 28. -- Mr. and Mrs. Henry Waters Taft of New York, with members of their family and intimate friends, celebrated their golden wedding anniversary at the Greenbrier today. Mr. Taft is a brother of the late William Howard Taft.

The Metropolitan Life Insurance Company, as plaintiff, bought in the thirteen-story Hotel Cumberland, at the southwest corner of Broadway and Fifty-fourth Street, on a bid of $400,000 at a foreclosure sale yesterday. The property was offered by Joseph P. Day in the Vesey Street Exchange as a result of an action brought by the life insurance company against the Construction Realty Company and others.

BERLIN, March 28. -- At the time when the government of national regeneration was assembling in the Garrison Church at Potsdam to perform the solemn opening of the newly elected Reichstag, the world press was flooded with monstrous atrocity propaganda, which assumed the direst dimensions in American newspapers.

Without a single dissenting vote, the Board of Aldermen adopted a resolution yesterday petitioning the United States Government to make "vigorous and proper representation" to the German Government against the persecution of Jews by the Hitler regime.

Japan has not completed any plans for the conquest of China, "as some of our Chinese friends would have us believe," much less plans for the conquest of the world, Yosuke Matsuoka, former chief Japanese delegate to the League of Nations, declared last night in a dinner address at the Hotel Astor.

To the Editor of The New York Times: A great deal has been published during the past few weeks about the political situation in Cuba. I feel that more should be written about the economic situation, so that public opinion can be formed on all phases of the Cubans' plight.

Two markets that have not declined, but on the contrary have grown by leaps and bounds despite the depression, were disclosed yesterday by the American Museum of Natural History -- the markets for eggs, not chicken or ducks' eggs, but frogs' and salamanders'.

BERLIN, March 28 (AP). -- The ban on the Stahlhelm or Steel Helmet [war veterans] organization in the State of Brunswick, declared yesterday when National Socialist leaders there charged it was attempting counter-revolution, will be rescinded April 1.

Five members of the illustrious O'Keeffe family have now been definitely accounted for in the art world. With Georgia O'Keeffe's work every one, of course, is familiar. Georgia has two sisters, one of whom, Mrs. Catherine Klenert, exhibited recently at the Delphic Studios.

CHICAGO, March 28. -- Houses with Eastern connections bought heavily of wheat futures on the Board of Trade in the last hour of trading today, and with a flood of bullish crop reports from the Southwest and North Pacific Coast points, prices advanced more than 2 cents a bushel from the early low and to a new high mark since March 18.

Commodities traded on local exchanges reversed their recent trend quickly yesterday and moved for good gains. All staples took part in the rally, regardless of special developments in the individual markets. The trading volume did not pick up to any great extent.

NEW YORK. The final Colony Dance of the season will take place tonight at the Ritz-Carlton. Mrs. DeLancey Kane Jay heads the committee, which includes also Mrs. Gordon Auchincloss, Mrs. George Whitney, Mrs. Frederick H. Osborn, Mrs. Beverley Bogert, Mrs. Francis S. Clark and Mrs. Robert Low Bacon.

Ira S. Robbins, chairman of the housing committee of the United Neighborhood Houses, 70 Fifth Ave- nue, sent a letter yesterday to legislative leaders in Albany expressing the opposition of his committee to some of the proposed amendments to the multiple dwelling law which are now pending.

WASHINGTON, March 28. -- Once Upon a time a man said that insects might some day control the earth. American chemists who have been finding new ways to kill them do not go quite so far as that, but Dr. Harry F. Deitz, entomologist, told the American Chemical Society today that only 40 per cent of pests are controlled by chemical means.

MIAMI, Fla., March 28. -- The Keeneland Stud's Don Romiro scored his second victory of the Florida season when he led from start to finish of the featured Miami Herald purse at Tropical Park today. Next to the outsider in a field of seven, Don Romiro returned 29 to 1.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., March 28. -- Asserting that certified milk is "a luxury we can well do without," Dr. Matthias Nicoll Jr., county health commissioner, explained a proposed county-wide regulation requiring that all milk be pasteurized, at a hearing here today before the county board of health.

There is a concerted effort at Albany to break down housing standards in New York City. A dozen bills have been introduced which would have that effect in greater or less degree. Senator O'BRIEN'S bill authorizes the use of fire-retarding material without the standard test, renders less effective the regulations for artificial lighting of public halls and stairs at night, and repeals the prohibition of vertical fire-escapes.

Formation of a municipal bridge authority modeled after the Port Authority to complete the Triborough Bridge through issuance of bridge authority bonds was under consideration by Mayor O'Brien yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 28. -- By next Saturday, four weeks to the day after he assumed the Presidency, Franklin D. Roosevelt hopes to have made public many of the regulations through which he will administer the vast powers granted to him in the economy act and officially to foreshadow a saving in government costs of nearly $900,000,000 a year.
The holders of 25,800 shares of 7 per cent cumulative preferred stock of Burns Brothers, coal sales company, will have control of the company at the annual meeting in Jersey City on April 13.

The Salvation Army will formally open its united appeal at a large military dinner and mass meeting now being arranged for next Monday night at the Seventh Regiment Armory, Park Avenue and Sixty-seventh Street. Mrs. Benjamin Moore has organized an executive committee to direct the women's division in the course of the drive.

CHICAGO, March 28. -- Jesse L. Livermore, Chicago and New York stock market and grain speculator, and Mrs. A. Warren Noble, concert singer, of Omaha, announced here today that they were married last Thursday in Geneva, Ill. Mrs. Livermore is 38 years old and her husband 55.

ALBANY, March 28. -- After a day marked by a succession of bewildering developments in which the legislative machinery was at a standstill so far as the Governor's beer control bill was concerned, that measure was reported tonight by the excise committee in the Senate and advanced to third reading by unanimous consent.
ROME, March 28 (AP). -- The police have in custody a man who, they announced today, had confessed that he intended to assassinate Premier Mussolini yesterday.

PHILADELPHIA, March 28. -- The Babe Didriksons and Helen Wills Moodys notwithstanding, women never will equal the sports achievements of men, says Miss Diana Fishwick, 22-year-old former women's British golf champion.
MUNOZ, Bolivia, March 28. -- Military activities in the Chaco yesterday are said here to have consisted mainly of a bombardment by Air Squadron No. 6 of the Paraguayan Airport at Isla Poi.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Your report of my remarks at the symposium held yesterday at the Pulitzer School of Journalism on the question, "Have the newspapers overemphasized the depression?" give an impression precisely opposite to the facts.

WASHINGTON, March 28. -- Hearings on the administration's emergency farm-relief bill were completed today by the Senate Agriculture Committee and 10 o'clock tomorrow morning was set for the members to meet in executive session to begin their final consideration.

There has come to light a letter, written by GROVER CLEVELAND just after the Congressional elections of November, 1890, that is peculiarly pertinent at this moment. It was addressed to that gallant soldier, General FRANCIS CHANNING BARLOW, who was shot through the body and left for dead on the field at Gettysburg, but was succored by the Confederate General GORDON, given water and put in a place of safety.

Mrs. John H. Finley gave a buffet luncheon yesterday at her home, 1 Lexington Avenue, for Mrs. James Stewart Cushman, who returned recently from Geneva, Switzerland, where she attended the meetings of the executive committee of the World's Council of the Young Women's Christian Association.

MEXICO CITY, March 28. -- Several windows of the United States Embassy were broken last Friday by Communists as a demonstration against the appointment of Josephus Daniels as Ambassador. The attack was officially reported to the Mexican Foreign Office, but was not disclosed until today.

Mrs. Rosalia Gurnee Blauvelt, identified by birth and marriage with two old Rockland County families, died at St. Luke's Hospital early yesterday from the effects of a broken hip suffered in a fall. The accident occurred on Wednesday at her Winter home at 401 West End Avenue.

Mrs. William K. Vanderbilt is returning today from Southern France on the North German Lloyd liner Bremen. Also on board from the Channel ports are Lady Furnss, Sir William Letts, Albert H. Wiggin, former chairman of the Chase National Bank and Mr. and Mrs. Marshall Field 3d.

MUNICH, March 28. -- The National Socialist party's proclamation of a boycott against Jewish stores and business establishments -- "tolerated but not supported by the government" -- in retaliation for demonstrations of protest in the United States, Great Britain and elsewhere against persecution of the Jews in Germany, was issued from the Brown House here tonight.

DECATUR, Ala., March 28. -- Circuit Judge James E. Horton denied a motion today to quash the indictments against nine Negroes, accused of attacking two while girls nears Scottsboro two years ago, and immediately the defense turned its guns upon the administration of the jury law in this county where the defendants are to be tried.

An old typewriter, introduced in court as a mute witness, and the testimony of a writing expert that a document used in support of the plaintiff's case could have been typed only on this machine, were instrumental in bringing about a judgment yesterday in favor of the International Germanic Trust Company in a suit brought against it by Florindo S. Polo.
WASHINGTON, March 28. -- The Bureau of Navigation issued the following orders today, dated March 25:

SAN FRANCISCO, March 28. -- Prosecution of Thomas J. Mooney on an old murder indictment for the Preparedness Day bombing was thrust back into the hands of District Attorney Matthew Brady today by Attorney General U.S. Webb of California.

BRADENTON, Fla., March 28. -- With Dazzy Vance, Brooklyn pitching ace for so many years, viewing his former team-mates as a member of the opposition, the Dodgers opened their invasion of the West Florida Coast today by losing to the Cardinals for the second time, the score being 7 to 4.

Cosmo Hamilton, brother of Sir Philip Gibbs and A. Hamilton Gibbs, and a friend of many of the leading English and American writers, gives twenty-nine brief sketches of his friends and relatives in "People Worth Talking About," published yesterday by Robert McBride.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., March 28. -- Through the purchase of 85,966 shares of American Turf Association stock now held by the receiver for the National Bank of Kentucky, the management of the turf association was an apparent winner tonight in a proxy fight for control.

Plans for the most important art exhibition ever held in this country, to comprise works of art said to be valued at about $75,000,000, were disclosed yesterday by Dr. Robert B. Harshe, director of the Art Institute of Chicago, in an address broadcast over WJZ.

Numerous business leases, particularly in the midtown section of Manhattan, were reported yesterday. Among the tenants to change quarters is the Heating and Piping Contractors National Association, which has leased from May 1 space on the fourteenth floor of the seventy-story RCA Building in Rockefeller Center.

Moderate gains in United States Government bonds, slightly higher prices, on the average, in leading foreign loans, and irregularly lower quotations on domestic corporation issues characterized dealings in bonds on the Stock Exchange yesterday.

After an all-night debate the jury in the first of the State trials growing out of election frauds reported to Justice McNamee in the criminal branch of the Supreme Court shortly before noon yesterday its inability to agree on a verdict and was discharged.

TORONTO, Ont., March 28 (Canadian Press). -- The International Nickel Company of Canada, Ltd., has been successful in marketing its copper in Europe since the duty of 4 cents a pound imposed in June, 1932, barred its output from the United States, Robert C. Stanley, president, told the shareholders at the annual meeting here today.

The world's champion New York Yankees will play host to the Boston Red Sox, tail-enders in 1932, when the American League season opens on April 12, according to the official schedule released today. It had been known previously that the Yanks would begin their campaign at the Stadium, but their opponents had not been named.

Pending decision as to reopening of the Globe and Rutgers Fire Insurance Company, now in the control of the State Insurance Department, policy holders were warned yesterday by George S. Van Schaick, Superintendent of Insurance, to protect themselves by taking out insurance in other companies, subject to cancellation in the event that the Globe and Rutgers company resumes business.

Thayer Hobson, president of William Morrow Co., has just returned from London with a number of manuscripts. Among them are Esme Wingfield-Stratford's "The Victorian Aftermath" and Eric Fitch Daglish's "Book of Dogs." There are also novels by James Hilton and R.A.J. Walling, and a book for children by Honore Morrow.

"Go out and spread the word among your playmates that the best friend any youngster can have is the cop on the beat," Police Commissioner Mulrooney told seven boys and girls to whom he presented the first membership cards in the Junior Police Athletic League yesterday.

Up-State Democratic county leaders, who fear they may be in danger of being displaced in a reorganization movement directed by Postmaster General James A. Farley, State and national chairman, have appealed to former Governor Alfred E. Smith for support, it was ascertained yesterday.

In trading that brought the turn over for the week thus far on the Stock Exchange to about 1,200,000 shares, which would have been a fair half-day's business in the stirring days of 1928 or 1929, the share market was able yesterday to break away from the moderately reactionary influences which have governed it recently.

HAVANA, March 28. -- Five students of Pinar Del Rio were brought to Havana this morning under a military escort and lodged in Principe Fortress at the disposition of the military authorities. It is alleged the youths were caught yesterday placing bombs under petroleum tanks of the Standard Oil Company in that city.

Arthur H. Schwartz, Assistant United States Attorney, spent part of yesterday at the offices of the Harriman National Bank and Trust Company, which has been placed under a conservator, working with accountants and representatives of the Department of Justice on the books of the institution.

Patrick Kearney, 39-year-old playwright, best known for his dramatization of Theodore Dreiser's novel, "An American Tragedy," and a play, "A Man's Man," ended his life yesterday by inhaling gas in a furnished room at 348 East Fiftieth Street, where he had lived intermittently for ten years.

Republicans opposed to the continuance of Samuel S. Koenig as chairman of the New York County Republican Committee conferred again yesterday with regard to the possibility of making an extensive promary fight for the election of anti-Koenig county committee members.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, March 28 (AP). -- Led by Mrs. Dorothy Campbell Hurd of Philadelphia, a team of women golfers today won the Gooderham and Worts competition over the Belmont Manor course, defeating two men's teams.
The examination of Anders Jordahl, American agent of Ivar Kreuger, was resumed yesterday in the bankruptcy inquiry into the American affairs of the Kreuger Toll Company.

ALBANY, March 28. -- Governor Lehman in a special message today urged the Legislature to enact a bill to permit municipalities to operate public utility plants and sell electricity to their residents.

PARIS, March 28. -- By failing to pay the $19,000,000 debt instalment due the United States last December France has already lost $160,000,000 in trade, General Emile-Adolphe Taufflieb, who recently returned from America, told a gathering of representatives of commerce, industry and politics here today.
ALBANY, March 28. -- Repeal of the surtax on all motor trucks was assured today under the terms of an agreement between Democratic and Republican legislators and Governor Lehman.

PALM BEACH, Fla., March 28. -- Quaint costumes of former years were displayed tonight by members of the younger set appearing in the Palm Beach fashion pageant at the Everglades Club in conjunction with a revue and supper dance. Miss Bonnie May Murray was director:

Buyers' Arrivals Increased. The number of buyers registered in town during the week ended yesterday showed a slight increase over the figures for the preceding week and for the same period a year ago, according to the lists published in THE TIMES.

PARIS, March 28. -- After a heated skirmish this morning the government managed to get the Chamber of Deputies to adopt, 369 to 212, a resolution postponing debate on France's foreign policy which Henry Franklin-Bouillon and other opponents sought to bring up.

HARRISBURG, Pa., March 28 (AP). -- Attorney General William A. Schnader last week telegraphed Governor J.M. Futrell of Arkansas that suit would be brought if the present 4 1/4 per cent issue of bonds is refunded by a 3 per cent issue.
ALBANY, March 28. -- Repeal of the surtax on all motor trucks was assured today under the terms of an agreement between Democratic and Republican legislators and Governor Lehman.

MONTREAL, March 28. -- The New York Rangers survived the third-place play-off round for the world's hockey championship by holding the Montreal Canadiens to a 3-to-3 tie at the Forum tonight before a capacity crowd of 12,500.

NEWARK, N.J., March 28. -- Gerald Ronan of Philadelphia, an attorney, was the principal witness here today when the trial before Federal Judge Guy L. Fake was resumed in the accounting suit of Oil Shares, Inc., an investment corporation, against the Commercial Trust Company of New Jersey of Jersey City; Montefiore G. Kahn, former vice president of the corporation, and Joseph Herzberg and Thomas H. Watson of New York.

WASHINGTON, March 28. -- American Consuls abroad were notified by the State Department tonight that invoices may be issued for shipments of beer to the United States which do not arrive prior to April 7, the effective date of the beer law.

This afternoon and evening seven prominent women's organizations of Greater New York are to hear discussions by prominent speakers of the economic and international questions which are now pressing upon all civilized nations. The aim is to help create an intelligent public opinion in these matters.

On the application of Benjamin Schellenberg, a stockholder of Brookline, Mass., Federal Judge Alfred C. Coxe signed an order yesterday requiring the Fox Film Corporation, four of its directors and the Chase Securities Corporation to show cause next Friday why an equity receiver should not be appointed for the Fox concern.

WASHINGTON, March 28. -- More than a dozen witnesses appeared today before the House Immigration Committee, some to argue for passage of the Dickstein resolution, which would give citizenship to the children of women who married foreigners on an equal basis with those of American husbands who marry women from other countries and others to argue against what they termed "lowering the gates" to a flood of immigrants.

Louis H. Willard, Bronx real estate dealer, was acquitted yesterday by a jury in General Sessions Court of the charge of perjury made against him following his testimony against William J. Flynn, Public Works Commissioner of the Bronx, before the Hofstadter legislative committee a year ago.

LONDON, March 28. -- The court-martial, after deliberating two and one-half hours today, found Lieutenant Norman Baillie-Stewart of the Seaforth Highlanders, the "Tower prisoner," not guilty on three alternative charges of attempting to collect, to obtain and to communicate military secrets.

CULVER CITY, Cal., March 28 (AP). -- Still not noticeably impressed by his recent "discovery" of America, a continent about which he at odd times has expressed some dubiety, George Bernard Shaw, seeing the world, came to Southern California today and had a look at the movies.

Murray J. Posner, whose loan of $50,000 from Helen Kane, baby-song singer, has been a subject of long court litigation, and Jack Eisen, his partner in the defunct Bond Dress Company, were indicted yesterday by a Federal grand jury in connection with the failure of their firm on Aug. 12, 1930.

Amendments relating chiefly to definitions of and designed to include 3.2 per cent wine in the Lehman beer bill were drawn by the New York State Commission on Alcoholic Beverage Control Legislation, at an all-day session in the Hotel Park Lane yesterday in accordance with instructions issued Monday by the Governor.

CHICAGO, March 28. -- The writing down of patents and other intangible assets from $38,029,841 to $1 was the outstanding action reported in the annual statement of the Bendix Aviation Corporation for 1932, which was submitted to stockholders today by Vincent Bendix, president.
LONDON, March 28. -- Rebels among the government supporters had an exciting time in the House of Commons today during the second day's debate on the proposed Indian constitutional reforms.

WASHINGTON, March 28. -- Secretary Roper announced today after a Cabinet meeting that he would submit to the President on Saturday a detailed report giving the results of his investigation of several plans for reviving the railroad industry.

A drop in time money rates, all maturities, to 2 @ 2 1/2 per cent from 2 1/2 on Monday, featured. This is the lowest for period funds since the resumption of trading after the bank holiday. However, no business was reported, demand being light although the offering side was good.

MANILA, March 28. -- The strongly nationalistic newspaper. The Philippines Herald, opened today a campaign editorially for appointment of John L. Holliday, Acting Governor General, to that post permanently.

At a stormy session of the Board of Estimate's committee of the whole yesterday two objectors to the city's relief procedure were ejected before the committee voted out for approval an appropriation of $5,000,000 to carry on work and home relief for April.

WASHINGTON, March 29 (AP) -- The government today agreed to lay down dollar for dollar with Cleveland citizens in opening a new national bank there to take the place of the Union Trust, the city's second largest bank.

WASHINGTON, March 29 -- Following a long-drawn-out debate, in the course of which a score of amendments were defeated in a roar of "noes," the House late this afternoon passed the Roosevelt bill for unemployment relief through reforestation in practically the form it passed the Senate.

The governing committee of the New York Stock Exchange has authorized the removal from the Exchange's list at the close of business today of the Willys-Overland Company's $5 par value common stock and 7 per cent cumulative $100 par value preferred stock and the Paramount Publix Corporation's $10 par value common stock.

HOUSTON, Texas, March 29 -- The Giants were still on the receiving end as their series with the Tigers swung into the second game today, the Detroiters again winning, 7 to 4. This gave Bucky Harris's men their second straight triumph and Manager Bill Terry a touch of the Memphis blues.

MOUNT HOLLY, N.J., March 29 -- The Burlington County grand jury was charged today by Justice Joseph L. Bodine of the New Jersey Supreme Court with the task of inquiring into the evidence in the deaths nearly four years ago of Horace Roberts Jr. and Ruth Mowdray Wilson of Moorestown to determine "whether there have been any infractions of the criminal law, and if so, who the offenders are."

An investigation of the activities of Paul Manger, who asserts that he is the leader of a Hitler organization in New York City, to determine whether he has violated any statutes of the United States was promised yesterday by United States Attorney Howard W. Ameii.

The report of the receivers of the Consolidation Coal Company for 1932 shows a consolidated net loss of $1,105,919 after all charges, including reserves for depreciation and depletion and also including $677,445 as profit on bonds redeemed.

To the Editor of The New York Times: As a result of the present economic situation many college and professional school graduates find themselves unable to obtain employment. This is especially true of recent graduates, some of whom have never succeeded in obtaining employment since their graduation several years ago.

WASHINGTON, March 29 -- Bank suspensions in February, not including those resulting from action of the civil authorities in declaring "holidays," were reported by the Federal Reserve Board today as 148, with deposits of $72,870,000, as compared with 241 with deposits of $135,020,000 in January, and 121 with deposits of $57,266,000 in February, 1932.

NANKING, March 29 -- Following a conference this morning between General Chiang Kai-shek, Wang Ching-woi, T.V. Soong and other government and Kuomintang (Nationalist party) leaders, it was officially announced that Mr. Wang would resume the presidency of the Executive Council, which Mr. Soong had been holding during Mr. Wang's absence in Europe.

Real estate improvements of various descriptions were sold at foreclosure auctions yesterday. Thirteen properties in Manhattan and the Bronx were offered at auctioneers stands, including a nine-story store and office building, a factory, four garages and several dwellings and tenement houses.

Four of the thirteen depositors in the Harriman National Bank and Trust Company whose accounts were discovered, when the bank was closed, to have been charged an aggregate of $1,600,000 were brought before the Federal grand jury yesterday to testify that they had not authorized these charges and had learned of them only after the arrest of Joseph W. Harriman, former chairman of the bank.

Plans for the Holy Hour ceremony at Radio City Music Hall next Sunday, with which the Roman Catholic Holy Year will be opened in New York, were carried forward yesterday by the inaugural committee. Special emphasis was placed on the message to be broadcast by Pope Pius from the Vatican on Saturday.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, March 29 (AP) -- Ralph Marshall of Richmond, Ind., was responsible for two changes today in the minor events of the American Bowling Congress tourney.

Countess Alexandra Tolstoy's book about her father, "The Tragedy of Tolstoy," which was published here ten days ago by the Yale University Press, was a defense of his memory written in answer to the third volume of her mother's diary.

WASHINGTON, March 29 -- Testifying today before the House Immigration Committee in opposition to the Dickstein resolution seeking to revoke an executive order issued in 1930 to curtail immigration, Wilbur J. Carr, Assistant Secretary of State, denied that passage of the resolution would have any bearing on the present German situation as it affects Jews.

NEWCHWANG, Manchuria, March 29 (AP) -- In one of the most daring raids in recent history, Chinese buccaneers kidnapped four British officers today from the British merchantman Nanehang while the vessel was waiting for the high tide at the Newchwang bar.

Having triumphed in the third-place play-off round of the world's hockey championship competition, the New York Rangers tonight will begin a two-game total-goal series at Madison Square Garden with the Detroit Red Wings, winners of the second-place play-off round, to determine the opponent for the victors in the first-place play-off round now in progress between the Boston Bruins and the Toronto Maple Leafs.

WASHINGTON, March 29 -- A bill to set up a Federal "super-mortgage bank" to deal with all governmental farm financing was introduced in the Senate today by Senator McAdoo, the first measure touching the farm-mortgage situation laid before that body at this session.
Mayor O'Brien's statement to the representatives of B.M.T. and I.R.T. security holders, explaining the procedure and principles to be applied at the transit unification conferences, follows:

WASHINGTON, March 29 -- Representative McSwain of South Carolina, chairman of the Military Affairs Committee, today proposed three separate measures to create an adequate and economical machine for national defense, with aviation as one of the major elements.

The Mercantile Bank and Trust Company of 526 Eighth Avenue, one of the two commercial banks in Manhattan that did not reopen after the bank holiday, has applied for withdrawal from the Federal Reserve System. The application was made several days ago and is likely to be approved soon.

With Elbridge Gerry setting the pace with twelve goals and his team-mates, Jimmy Mills and Bobby Gerry, giving able aid, Aknusti galloped over the new Los Nanduces team by a score of 18 to 3 1/2 at Squadron C Armory last night.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 29 -- Showing no inclination to try Thomas J. Mooney on an old indictment charging murder in connection with the Preparedness Day bombing of 1916, District Attorney Brady maintained his non-committal attitude today.

With more than twenty candidates for the post of Budget Director under consideration, Mayor O'Brien said last night that he expected to fill the position by tomorrow and admitted that Maurice A. Stephenson was a possible choice.

Police Commissioner Mulrooney urged the strong support of the Salvation Army in its forthcoming drive for funds last night in a radio address over Station WEAF, asserting that the organization was one of the best crime deterrents in the city.

CHICAGO, March 29 -- Heavy Eastern buying orders for wheat futures, coming after the market had had a break of about 3/4 cent a bushel from yesterday's closing prices, quickly absorbed the surplus in the pit on the Board of Trade today and the advance did not stop until prices were up around 1 1/2 cents from the low.

Opposition to the bill now before the Senate which would extend for another year the legal occupancy of cellar apartments was expressed yesterday by the Committee on Public Health Relations of the New York Academy of Medicine in a resolution sent to both houses of the State Legislature.

NEW YORK. Mr.and Mrs. Fierre Cartier will give a reception for the French Ambassador and Mme. Paul Claudel and for the Belgian Ambassador and Mme. Paul May, on the afternoon of April 7 at their home, 15 East Ninety-sixth Street.

The Port Authority publishes today its annual report. The latest addition to its facilities is the Inland Freight Terminal on Manhattan, opened last October. The offificial historian speaks modestly of the railroads as having opened "their" terminal, though he concedes that the Port Authority has been "active in promoting its use."

PINEHURST, N. C., March 29 -- With a record-breaking score of 277 for seventy-two holes, Joe Kirkwood, veteran Philadelphia trickshot expert, won the thirty-first annual North and South open golf championship today, beating Macdonald Smith's mark of 281, which had stood for eight years.

Ralph Krakower, 48 years old, the jeweler who was arrested in Miami recently as an alleged accomplice of Harry Sitamore, master gem thief, killed himself yesterday in his apartment at 1,815 Riverside Drive by taking poison.

In spite of the desirability of developing voluntary industrial pension plans for humanitarian reasons, further expansion of the movement in the United States is definitely limited, according to Industrial Relations Counselors, Inc., 165 Broadway, whose three-year study of the pension problem has just been completed.

The ideas which President Roosevelt is incorporating day by day in his program are his own and not the products of the experts with whom he has surrounded himself, it was disclosed yesterday by Professor Adolph A. Berle Jr. of Columbia University, one of Mr. Roosevelt's advisers during the campaign and a member of his "academic cabinet."

To the Editor of The New York Times: The news dispatches from Albany state that a retail sales tax is certain to be passed within the next fortnight; the only remaining question, we are told, is whether the rate will be 1 or 2 per cent.

The New York Association, for Improving the Condition of the Poor spent $2,471,000 for all its activities in 1932, the largest amount ever spent in any one of its ninety years of service to the community, Cornelius N. Bliss, president, declared in a letter to contributors, enclosed with the annual report and made public yesterday.
PHILADELPHIA, March 29 -- "We have a special contract for the production of everything George Bernard Shaw ever wrote, with the exception of his latest play, 'Too True to Be Good.'

The Public Service Commission ruled yesterday that it would have power over the labor policies of the Brooklyn Edison Company or any other utility in the event that it could establish that such policies affected the service given by the company or the rates charged by it.

The creditor-trustees of Brentano's, the world's largest retail book outlet, who have been in control of the concern for three years on behalf of publisher-creditors, lave withdrawn their trusteeship, it was learned yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 29 -- The Reconstruction Finance Corporation today reached an agreement with representatives of mortgage loan companies and surety companies under which it will embark upon a large scale program for refinancing bonds of the mortgage loan companies in about thirty-six States where the securities have been guaranteed by surety companies.

Entries at the International Horse Show of Art were judged solely "as horse flesh" yesterday afternoon by J. Macy Willets, secretary and treasurer of the American Horse Show Association. The show, which is being held for the benefit of the social service of Memorial Hospital, a free nursing service for cancer patients, will continue through Saturday at the Knoedler Galleries, 14 East Fifty-seventh Street.

DETROIT, March 29 (AP) -- Detroit's two largest banking groups, holding companies for the inoperative First National Bank-Detroit and the Guardian National Bank of Commerce, faced new difficulties tonight as charges of "fraud, deceit and trickery" were made against them by the receiver for an out-State bank.

MIAMI, Fla., March 29 -- J.C. Milam's Flyat, a 3-year-old gelding by the Kentucky Derby winner, Flying Ebony, annexed the featured race at Tropical Park today and made it two in a row at the meeting. Flyat scored over Dodiodo by the unusual margin of seven lengths.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., March 29 -- Establishment of the Elihu Thomson Professorship of Electrical Engineering at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology was announced tonight by President Compton as the most fitting way in which the institute could honor its former acting president and life member of the corporation.

A renewed fight against the sale of beer and the repeal of the Eighteenth Amendment was urged yesterday in addresses at the second annual luncheon of the Kings County Woman's Christian Temperance Union, held after a morning conference at the Towers, Brooklyn.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In view of the attacks which are being made from many quarters on the missionary enterprise, we ought in all fairness to remember that the missionary enterprise, in the last analysis, is not an abstraction or an organization.
With five national collegiate champions among the entries, the national A.A.U. swimming championships will get under way today at the New York A.C. pool.
The outline of President Roosevelt's proposed law to supervise the traffic in investment securities evoked a mixed and, for the most part, apathetic reaction in Wall Street.
CHICAGO, March 29 -- Chicago's amateur Golden Gloves boxers tonight defeated New York's fistio representatives in the intercity series staged by The New York Daily News and The Chicago Tribune.

WASHINGTON, March 29 -- Secretary Woodin invited tenders today for a new offering of Treasury bills amounting to about $100,000,000. They will be ninety-one-day bills, sold on a discount basis to the highest bidders. Tenders will be received at the Federal Reserve Banks or their branches up to 2 P.M., Eastern Standard Time, Monday, April 3.

Lord BRYCE in one of his travel essays said that nowhere on the European Continent" does an Eng"lishman feel himself more at "home than in Hungary." Even a few weeks of residence there allowed one to enter into the spirit of the national adage, which in translation from the Latin ran:

LONDON, March 29. -- Norman H. Davis arrived in London tonight and has an appointment with Prime Minister MacDonald at 10 Downing Street tomorrow forenoon. But, before his first session with" the Prime Minister, President Roosevelt's ambassador to Europe in feneral will have a talk with Hugh S. Gibson, United States Ambassador to Belgium, who arrived this afternoon from Brussels to inform Mr. Davis of the latest developments in the European situation.

Buying of a concentrated character was active again yesterday on the Cotton Exchange. One block of 10,000 bales of October contracts advanced quotations above 6 3/4 cents a pound before the rise was halted. An improvement of a quarter cent in two days attracted selling from the South and spot houses did more hedging than for some time.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., March 29 (AP). --- Steps to increase passenger revenues of the New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad Company to offset a falling off in income were outlined by its president, J.J. Pelley, in his annual statement, given out tonight.

The United Aircraft and Transport Corporation reported yesterday a net profit for 1932 of $1,687,663 after having set up a special reserve of $400,000 for contingencies. The net profit was equivalent, after preferred dividends, to 53 cents a share on the average number of shares of common stock outstanding during the year.

Governor LEHMAN'S address before the joint session of the Legislature yesterday is of concern to every one who desires the repeal of the Eighteenth Amendment. Is the Legislature of New York by its course on the beer bill to justify the hopes and accusations of the Drys?

By studying his private collection of school textbooks, which, according to the British "Who's Who," is the largest in the world, George A. Plimpton, head of the English educational publishing house of Ginn Co., has made estimates of what Shakespeare must have been taught during his brief schooling.

Every one knows that many have had to call on the charitable organizations this year for the first time, but the extent and quality of the alteration are brought put with remarkable force. The New York Association for Improving the Condition of the Poor finds that three out of four families applying for relief during the fiscal year of the report have never asked for help before.
One Liberating Machine. The late CHRISTOPHER L. SHOLES did much more for the emancipation of women than did IBSEN, who made Nora walk out of the doll's house and slam the door after her.

WASHINGTON, March 29 -- Under the administration railroad consolidation program, which may be sent to Congress in the latter part of next week, there will be a chief coordinator and regional coordinators to effect railway operating economies and eliminate waste.

A transfer tax report on the estate of Frederick H. Bedford, former official of the Standard Oil Company of New Jersey, who was a resident of Westport, Conn., filed in Surrogate's Court in Brooklyn yesterday, listed a gross estate of $1,355,430 and a net estate of $1,096,370, but did not include real estate outside of New York State.

DUBLIN, Thursday, March 30. -- Extraordinary scenes were witnessed in Dublin last night when crowds of young men attacked Connolly Hall, headquarters of the Communists, and, after a fight, set the building ablaze.

BERLIN, March 29 -- Despite Chancellor Hitler's statement at today's Cabinet meeting that the difficulty between the Nazis and the Stahlhelm in Brunswick might be regarded as settled, reports from different parts of Germany make clear that the trouble is not confined to Brunswick and that the organization of war veterans is suspect over a wider area.
ALBANY, March 29 -- Opposition by two New York City Democrats caused the defeat today in the Senate of a bill backed by Mayor O'Brien as part of his economy campaign for the city.

WASHINGTON, March 29 -- President Roosevelt's plan for Federal supervision of investment securities moving in interstate commerce went to Congress today, and quickly began there its legislative course.

ALBANY, March 29 -- The solvency and practices of companies guaranteeing mortgages were bitterly assailed in the Senate today as the upper House passed a series of measures designed to relieve stress on these organizations.

German bonds of all descriptions were weak yesterday on the Stock Exchange, more than half of the two-score of such, issues dealt in for the day reaching new low marks for the year. Losses ranged from small fractions to more than 5 points.

Bishop Charles Wesley Burnes of the Boston area of the Methodist Episcopal Church organized the sixty-eighth annual East German Conference of that denomination last evening in the Second German Methodist Episcopal Church.

The rags-to-power pictures of Andrew Jackson that give Horatio Alger touches to the school history books are missing from "Andrew Jackson, the Border Captain," by Marquis James, just published by Bobbs-Merrill. The "seventh President was a thin orphan but not a hungry one.

Last season the Julien Levy Gallery introduced here the work of Eugene Berman, a young Russian artist associated with one of the more significant of the modern groups in Paris. That exhibition featured Mr. Berman's drawings, although a few oils, already in private or museum collections, were included.

THE score in the Stanley Cup series so far is two out and three to go. The fair city of Montreal is in mourning over the forced exits of the Canadians and the Maroons on the same melancholy evening, and Canada is now forced to count on Toronto to keep the Stanley Cup from spending the coming Summer in United States territory.
BERLIN, March 29 -- The boycott against Jewish stores that the National Socialist party set for Saturday morning is already on.

WASHINGTON, March 29 -- Congress has full constitutional power to do away with State banking systems and compel the establishment of a unified system under Federal control, according to an opinion of Walter Wyatt, chief counsel for the Federal Reserve Board, which the board made public today in its monthly bulletin.

BROOKLINE, Mass., March 29 -- Miss Dorrance Chase of Dorchester, Mass., and Mrs. Benjamin E. Cole 2d of North Andover, Mass., seeded second and third respectively, entered the semi-final round of the women's national indoor tennis championship on the Longwood covered courts, Chestnut Hill, today with straight-set victories.

PRINCETON, N.J., March 29 -- Samuel Seabury, speaking today before 500 students and faculty members of Princeton University, criticized the governments of large American cities, with specific reference to New York.

Revival of the war-time United States Housing Corporation, and passage of the State bill to set up municipal housing authorities, were urged in resolutions adopted last night at a dinner of the Public Housing Conference at the New School for Social Research, 66 West Twelfth Street.

PARIS, March 29 -- Japan's withdrawal from the League of Nations is a source of keen regret in France. This is obvious from press comment as well as from conversations in the corridors of the Chamber of Deputies and elsewhere today by those observers who have been following the course of Franco-Japanese relations.

"Unto the Third," a new play by James Gilchrist, has been placed in rehearsal, with Mr. Gilchrist producing and directing. It is scheduled for a Broadway opening on Wednesday evening, April 19, at a theatre yet to be announced.

WASHINGTON, March 29 -- The text of President Roosevelt's special message to Congress today, recommending the enactment of a law for Federal supervision of interstate traffic in investment securities, was as follows:

ALBANY, March 29 -- A proposal for a new bond issue, totaling perhaps as much as $50,000,000. for unemployment relief in the State, was considered today by Governor Lehman, leaders of the Legislature and members of the temporary emergency relief administration.
WASHINGTON, March 29 -- The Bureau of Navigation issued the following orders today, dated March 27:

R.H. Macy Co., Inc., report for the fiscal year ended on Jan. 28, a consolidated net income of $3,287,151 after taxes, depreciation and reserves, equal to $2.20 a share on the 1,509,556 shares of common stock outstanding at that time, less 12,143 shares owned by the corporation.

WASHINGTON, March 29 -- Employment increased 1.6 per cent in manufacturing industries during February and payroll totals in these industries were 1.7 per cent higher than for the preceding month, Secretary Perkins reported today.

With only a week left before the Federal beer law becomes effective, brewers, bottle makers, hotel and restaurant keepers, and those in many allied trades continued yesterday the rush to prepare for slaking the fourteen-year thirst for legal beer.

Thomas H. Beck, chairman of the Connecticut Fish and Game Commission, yesterday announced that the woman warden who is to preside over the exclusive women's trout fishing stream which the State has leased on a stretch of the Branford River would be selected on Saturday.

The percentage of locomotives in disrepair rose, to a record high level on March 1, according to the American Railway Association. There were 10,290 engines requiring classified repairs, or 20 per cent of the number on line on that date, compared with 10.014, or 19.4 per cent, on Feb. 1.

Eight recommendations for inclusion in any retail sales tax law, one of them making it a misdemeanor for a merchant not to pass the tax along to the consumer, were forwarded to Governor Lehman yesterday by a committee of merchants, of which Grover A. Whalen was chairman.

One passenger who arrived here yesterday on the North German Lloyd liner Bremen told about Nazi mistreatment of Jews in Germany. He was Edward Dahlberg. American Jewish author, who said he himself had been the victim of a Nazi attack.
Resale of a Union City flat acquired in foreclosure earlier this year featured the New Jersey realty transactions reported yesterday.

With President Roosevelt pressing upon Congress the first of a series of regulatory measures designed to reduce the hazards of security investment, the stock and bond markets pursued yesterday an unsteady course in slow and colorless trading.

Marie Patterson, 15-year-old high school student, who had been missing from her home at 500 Eleventh Street, Brooklyn, since Sunday night, was found shortly after 3 o'clock this morning at Fourth Avenue and Ninth Street, a few blocks from her home.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., March 29 -- Thousands of gallons of milk were dumped into ditches today by independent producers in a milk war against the Dairymen's League Cooperative Association. More than 1,000 farmers in this region are enlisted in the strike.

The first hearing in the arbitration case between the Actors' Equity Association and the Managers' Protective Association, by which the former group is endeavoring to break the ten-year "basic agreement" with the latter organization, was held yesterday afternoon in the offices of the American Arbitration Association.

A suit in behalf of the Chinese Government was filed in the Supreme Court yesterday against the Russo-Asiatic Bank for $3,344,902 on the ground that the government had this sum on deposit in branches of the bank when it was closed by the Soviet Government on Sept. 25, 1926.

Michael Filosa, who is under conviction of manslaughter for slashing his step-brother three years ago, testified against his mother, Mrs. Anna De Hall, and she again accused him of the crime yesterday at her trial on a charge of second-degree murder for the same crime.

Mayor O'Brien's direct negotiations with the security holders of the B.M.T. and Interborough systems for unification of rapid transit lines began yesterday with a preliminary conference at City Hall. More than a score of spokesmen for various classes of company stocks and bonds and individual owners of substantial blocks of securities were present.
WASHINGTON, March 29 -- The Copeland bill to remove restrictions on liquor prescriptions was approved so rapidly by the Senate today that the members were left gasping.
COMMERCIAL PAPER. Yesterday -- 3 per cent for the best names. Tuesday -- 3 per cent for the best names. The quotations are for three-four months' paper.

Miss Janet Lifson, 14 -- year-old member of the Women's Swimming Association, who holds the metropolitan senior diving championship, was defeated by Miss Madeline Karson of the Dragon Club in the ten-foot fancy dive at the open swimming meet held at the Central T.M.C.A. in Brooklyn last night.

BOGOTA, March 29. -- That the Peruvians' abandonment of Guepi when it was attacked by Colombian troops a few days ago may have been a strategic retreat to trap the Colombians at Pantoja, where it says the Peruvians are strongly intrenched, is a theory advanced by El Tiempo today.

Costumes for town and country, ranging from evening clothes to bathing suits and from afternoon attire to bridal gowns, were displayed yesterday afternoon in a parade of thirty manikins at a Spring fashion show for the benefit of the Hygiene and Social Service Committee of the Lenox Hill Neighborhood Association at the River Club, 435 East Fifty-second Street.

PALM BEACH, Fla., March 29 -- In the patio of Louwana, her home on the Ocean Boulevard, Mrs. Gurnee Munn entertained tonight with a dinner and dance for her daughter, Miss Fernanda Munn, who will leave Saturday to resume her studies at Miss Hewitt's School in New York, and her son, Gurnee Jr., who will return to Promfret School in Hartford, Conn.
The Franklin Savings Bank has agreed with the Kay Forest Realty Co. that the mortgage for $36,000 on 709 W. 170th St. be extended to Feb. 28, 1936, at 5 per cent.

LONDON, March 29. -- The British Government's proposal for a joint select committee of Parliament to frame proposals for constitutional reforms in India was accepted by the House of Commons tonight after the Labor party's amendment calling for the release of political prisoners as a necessary prelude had been defeated by a vote of 475 to 43.

Plans for raising additional capital so that the Globe and Rutgers Fire Insurance Company may continue to operate are being considered by the newly appointed reorganization, committee. These plans are reported to provide for additional help from the Reconstruction Finance Corporation.

Controller Berry issued yesterday his annual comparison of the city budgets for the current and preceding years, showing how the 1933 budget represented a reduction of $112,938,325.81 from the 1932 total.

The closing of the South African commercial office in New York City in no way indicates a change of policy, on the part of the government of the Union of South Africa toward trade relations with the United-States, and the fostering of these relations will, on the contrary, be prosecuted with ever-increasing vigor, Eric H. Louw.
John Vitale of the Maris Stella Council, K. of C., New York State champion, stopped Moe Fisher of the Holy Name Club in the first round of the 147-pound class final at the Downtown A.C. last night.
WASHINGTON, March 29 -- Following is the text of the bitl submitted to Congress today by President Roosevelt for Federal supervision of the sale of securities:
WASHINGTON, March 29 (AP) -- The recommendations of the President for strict regulation of securities sales were enthusiastically received on Capitol Hill by Republicans as well as Democrats.

When 3,000 members of the American Chemical Society meet in Washington we expect revelations. Despite collegiate courses in science, we never fail to gasp at the announcements made, especially those that deal with synthetic chemistry.

FORT MYERS, Fla., March 29 -- Connie Mack and the Dodgers had a good time today. The citizens of Fort Myers presented the dean of all managers with a traveling bag and Connie's Athletics presented the ball game to Max Carey's athletes.

PHILADELPHIA, March 29 -- Outspoken criticism of junion high-school courses, particularly in economics and social subjects, was voiced at the annual schoolmen's week on the University of Pennsylvania campus today by Dr. Herbert B. Bruner of Teachers College, Columbia University, who said such courses "in the main suggest little, if anything, of value regarding fundamental economic and social problems."

The German Nationalists are forcing the world to see something more than a "Jewish question" in the Reich. By their methods and manifestos they are taking the matter out of the realm of narrow race hatred and making it appear one of humanity and civilization itself.

The United States again led the civilized nations of the world in 1932 in the number of homicides, according to Dr. Frederick B. Hoffman, statistician, whose survey on the subject is published in The Spectator, an insurance periodical.

Operations of the Port of New York Authority were carried on in 1932 at a profit despite the business depression, according to the twelfth annual report of the commissioners, submitted yesterday to Governor; Lehman of New York and Governor Moore of New Jersey.

For more than twenty years England has had laws similar in purpose to the one recommended yesterday by President ROOSEVELT. The Companies Act of 1908 requires the filing of relevant information when new securities are offered to the public.

BERLIN, March 29 -- Yesterday's downward reaction continued to dominate early trading on the Boerse today, numerous issues opening fractionally to 2 points or more lower. Later a recovery set in and the general market steadied, but the counter-movement was irregular, so that at the closing some issues remained below yesterday's finals, some approximated them and a few even surpassed them.
WASHINGTON, March 29 -- President Roosevelt expects France to pay her deferred debt instalment of $19,000,000 that was due on Dec. 15, 1932, within a reasonable time.

WASHINGTON, March 29 -- When the Senate takes up the Wagner relief bill tomorrow, it may appear incongruous to some observers of the administration's course that it should be proposing? spending half a billion in the very week the President is promulgating regulations to save almost a billion in the annual costs of government.
