With the object of ascertaining the complete truth about the situation in Germany as it bears on the treatment of Jews and other phases of alleged religious discrimination, the American Committee on Religious Rights and Minorities, consisting of prominent Protestant, Catholic and Jewish clergymen, voted unanimously yesterday to send a commission to Germany.

While the unsteady market on the Stock Exchange yesterday was generally ascribed, and correctly so, no doubt, to the submission by the administration of a Federal securities bill, commission houses insisted that their customers were exhibiting no great amount of interest anyway.

Prices were mixed yesterday in local commodity markets. Raw sugar, futures, silver and silk futures closed with moderate gains, while coffee, cocoa, rubber and hides reacted from the gains of the preceding day. In the cash markets, prices were higher for grains.

PURNEA, India, March 29 -- The trial flights today of the two airplanes, the first since the Mount Everest flight expedition's arrival, satisfied both pilots that the aircraft and engines are fit for the great attempt to fly over the world's highest peak when the weather is suitable.

ALBANY, March 29 -- Governor Lehman, making a dramatic appearance at a joint session of the Senate and Assembly at noon today, delivered a special message in which he urged enactment of his beer-control bill as free from the taint of politics and the old abuses which marked the liquor traffic in preprohibtion days and, as he emphasized, led to the enactment of the Eighteenth Amendment and the Volstead law.
VICHY, France, March 29 -- An appeal for a suspension of judgment with regard to events in Germany was made by United States Ambassador Frederic M. Sackect in an interview here today.

Operations in the steel industry have risen this week to an average of 15 per cent of the country's ingot capacity, according to the weekly review of The Iron Age. This compares with the 14 per cent rate last week. The expansion does not reflect any "broad improvement in business, but rather is due to special circumstances."

Murray J. Posner, dress manufacturer, who was indicted last Tuesday under the Federal bankruptcy statutes, testified yesterday before Federal Judge Francis G. Caffey that it had been the custom of the Bond Dress Company, of which he was a partner, to burn its books every year after the company's income tax return had been filed.

Dispossess cases in this city during the first two months of 1933 totaled 54,399, an increase of 7927 over the same two months last year, according to figures obtained from President Justice Lauer of the municipal court from Matthew M. Levy, chief counsel of the Bronx Tenants Emergency League.

HUNTINGTON, L.I., March 29 -- After two days of running, with one hour heats for each brace, the judges today awarded the Long Island field trial championship to Rosedale Bob, a lemon and white pointer dog, owned and handled by Samuel Faile of White Plains, N.Y.

AGUA CALIENTE, Mexico, March 29 (AP) -- Pillow Fight, the New Zealand Invader, became a very doubtful starter in the $25,000 Agua Caliente Handicap next Sunday after he had finished fifth today in a preparatory race at a mile and a sixteenth.

New York State obtained yesterday a loan $25,000,000 at an annual interest rate of 3 per cent from banks here. The loan is to run until June 27. It is strictly a banking transaction and will not involve a public sale of securities. It was made to enable the State to pay to New York City part of the balance due the latter from the State school fund.

Murray J. Posner, dress manufacturer, who was indicted last Tuesday under the Federal bankruptcy statutes, testified yesterday before Federal Judge Francis G. Caffey that it had been the custom of the Bond Dress Company, of which he was a partner, to burn its books every year after the company's income tax return had been filed.

Dispossess cases in this city during the first two months of 1933 totaled 54,399, an increase of 7927 over the same two months last year, according to figures obtained from President Justice Lauer of the municipal court from Matthew M. Levy, chief counsel of the Bronx Tenants Emergency League.

Sing Sing prison will contribute the paintings of one of its inmates to the annual exhibition of the Society of Independent Artists, which, will open, next week in Grand Central Palace. In sending these paintings, Sing Sing will be following the example set by Clinton prison at Dannemora in submitting to the exhibition the art work of three of its inmates.

Leasing of space in mid-Manhattan business buildings continues to play an important part in real estate trading. An outstanding transaction announced yesterday was the leasing of the store, basement and mezzanine in 3 West Forty-seventh Street, near Fifth Avenue, to the Consolidated Ticket Offices, now on Forty-second Street, near Sixth Avenue.

WASHINGTON, March 29 -- The Senate Foreign Relations Committee today postponed consideration of a report to the Senate on the World Court protocol for one week, leaving the fate of the protocol at this special session of Congress extremely doubtful.
WASHINGTON, March 29 -- President Roosevelt sent to Congress a special message recommending legislation for Federal supervision of traffic in investment securities in interstate commerce.

Vladimir Horowitz was distinctly in the vein for his piano recital at Carnegie Hall last night. He devoted himself, moreover, to substantial compositions. The result was an evening of finished and often exciting interpretations. And the audience, which was larger than it had been at Mr. Horowitz's first recital of the season, proved by its size and enthusiasm that good music is no handicap.

LOS ANGELES, March 29 -- Chicago's chances of retaining the National League pennant received a severe blow today when Hazen (Kiki) Cuyler, one of the finest out-fielders in the senior circuit, suffered a fracture of his right leg while attempting to steal second base in an exhibition game with Hollywood.

The selection of a jury for the trial of four election inspectors for violations of the State Election law was completed yesterday before Supreme Court Justice Daniel V. McNamee. An adjournment was then taken until today, owing to the indisposition of Assistant District Attorney James G. Wallace.

BERLIN, March 29 -- On the ground that "we are having trouble with America just now" the American composer, Werner Janssen, who was engaged to conduct a concert of the Berlin Philharmonic Orchestra on April 9, was informed by Lorenz Hoerber, head of the directorate of the orchestra, that he could not play Rubin Goldmark's "Gettysburg" tone poem which Mr. Janssen had planned to offer for the first time in Berlin.

WASHINGTON, March 29 -- A bill authorizing the Secretary of War to clear as much of Governors Island as is necessary to provide a suitable landing field for passenger and mail planes, and appropriating $300,000 for that purpose, was introduced in the House today by Representative Peyser of New York.

DECATUR, Ala., March 29 -- A petition asking Circuit Judge James E. Horton to quash the venire from which a jury is to be drawn to try Haywood Patterson, one of nine Negroes accused of an attack on two white girls, was drawn up today by Samuel Leibowitz, chief of defense counsel.

Count Laszlo Szechenyi, retiring Hungarian Minister to the United States, will sail for Europe tonight on the North German Lloyd liner Bremen. Countess Szechenyi, who is the former Gladys Vanderbilt, daughter of the late Cornelius Vanderbilt, will remain in New York for a time at the home of her mother, at 1 East Sixty-seventh Street, before joining her husband at London.

MANAGUA, Nicaragua, March 29 (AP) -- Two Americans who were lost Sunday after leaving Managua over a new air route to Northeastern Nicaragua were sighted canoeing down a river about 200 miles from here today by army and civilian fliers.

Reports yesterday that Fiorello H. La Guardia, who ran for Mayor on the Republican ticket In 1929, was considering announcing his candidacy again this year added another possible barrier to the proposed fusion movement this Fall.
ALBANY, March 29 (AP) -- Following is the text of Governor Lehman's personal plea to the Legislature today to approve his beer control plan:

Donald G. Geddes of Clark, Dodge Co. was the largest stockholder of the Western Union Telegraph Company at the close of 1932, with 12,600 shares registered in his name. Mr. Geddes is a director of the Western Union, the Chemical Bank and Trust Company and the Celanese Corporation and a trustee of the Consolidated Gas Company of New York and a director of most of its subsidiaries.

NEWARK, N.J., March 29 -- The City Commission took the first step today to comply with the conditions laid down by bankers yesterday as prerequisites for a loan of $3,000,000 on tax notes, which the city requires to meet current needs in the immediate future.
ALBANY, March 29 -- Some of the highlights of Governor Lehman's speech, to the Legislature today were:

The wide gap between the vast regions of the Gobi Desert and the well-known circus tent was bridged yesterday by Roy Chapman Andrews, explorer of the waste lands of the Far East, with his induction into the Dexter Fellows tent of the Circus Saints and Sinners Club pf America, an organization composed chiefly of "circus fans."

The New York Stock Exchange issued yesterday to its members a circular containing new rules concerning reports of transactions in foreign exchange which are required by the Federal Reserve Bank as well as by the Exchange.

WASHINGTON, March 29 -- Dr. Irving Langmuir, winner of the Nobel Prize in chemistry, who is here for the meeting of the American Chemical Society, turned economist today long enough to discuss a plan he has for spreading employment, bringing back prosperity and then maintaining it by a method similar to the farm leasing plan now before Congress.

CINCINNATI, March 29 -- City Council clerks droned tonight through the reading of ordinance after ordinance, intended to replace those of the last six years, which have apparently been invalidated by the Ohio Supreme Court.

MOSCOW, March 29 -- A sharp increase in Anglo-Soviet tension was revealed today in a Tasg (Soviet) News Agency account of a rebuff administered to Sir Esmond Ovey, British Ambassador to Moscow, by Foreign Commissar Litvinoff yesterday afternoon. The communique says:

The New York State branch of the National Economy League, which, has concentrated until now on reducing the Federal budget will confine its activities hereafter to reducing State and local budget within New York State.

VIENNA, March 29 -- Five thousand National Socialists again tried to block traffic in the streets tonight, but the police, responding to criticism that they had been too mild in their repressive measures last night, used more energetic methods and the demonstration was effectively quelled an hour after it had been started.

Nathan Straus Jr. was the guest of honor at a dinner at the Hotel Astor last night opening the 1933 drive of the American Palestine Campaign, fund-raising branch of the Jewish Agency, which directs world-wide endeavor for the reconstruction of a Jewish national homeland.

As the after-theatre rush hour crowds were at their height in the I.R.T. Times Square subway station last night, a short, well-dressed man, about 35 years old, threw those near him in the passageway between the shuttle and the Broadway line into wild confusion by drawing a pistol and flourishing it wildly.

TORONTO, March 30. -- Robust Eddie Shore, the gentleman farmer from Alberta, drove the Boston Bruins to a 2-1 sudden-death overtime victory over the Toronto Maple Leafs tonight in the third game of the National Hockey League firstplace play-offs before a crowd of 14,000.

Berkeley Williams Jr. is having another one-man show at the Montross Gallery. He exhibited there, on his own, in April, 1932, and has participated, besides, in group afiairs. The present collection of fifteen oils illustrates in a more or less unmistakable way several phases of this ingratiating and progressing talent.

ALBANY, March 30. -- The Senate Judiciary Committee gave several hours tonight to a hearing on the bill recently introduced by Senator H.L. O'Brien of Brooklyn, empowering Supreme Court justices on application to defer the execution of certain foreclosure judgments.

ALBANY, March 30 -- With no assurance that the amendment would be acceptable to Governor Lehman, the Senate, controlled by the Democrats, this evening passed his beer bill after first eliminating the provision requiring the Chief Executive to consult the State Bar Association, the Chamber of Commerce, the State Medical Society and the State Federation of Labor with regard to his appointees to four of the five places on the board of control.
ALBANY, March 30. -- Governor Lehman signed today the Kernan bill postponing until April 10 the 65 per cent surtax on trucks and buses. The law was to have become effective Saturday.

The combined statement of the twelve Reserve Banks issued yesterday brought out fresh evidence of the continued improvement in the banking situation. Gold holdings showed another large increase, on top of that recorded last week, with the present stock approximately $553,000,000, above the low established three weeks ago.

BROOKLINE, Mass., March 30. -- Miss Helen Germaine, the unseeded New Yorker, gained the semi-final round of the women's national indoor tennis championship when she eliminated the fourth-seeded Mrs. Robert H. Morris of Boston, 4 -- 6, 6 -- 0, 6 -- 4, in a third-round upset at the Longwood covered courts today.

GALVESTON, Texas, March 30. -- The Juvenile combination of Hank Leiber and Homer Peel, which may be regarded of only secondary importance later in the year, nevertheless contrived to do today what heretofore a number of Manager Bill Terry's very best regulars have tried in vain, to accomplish.

WASHINGTON, March 30 -- By a standing vote of 153 to 59 this afternoon the House passed the Copeland-Celler medicinal liquor bill, which amends the medicinal clauses in the Volstead act to permit physicians to prescribe as much alcoholic liquor as the physician believes necessary in each individual case.
WASHINGTON, March 30 (AP). -- Senate approval of President Roosevelt's farm-relief bill was forecast today even by opponents of the measure.

Stocks continued to mark time yesterday as Wall Street sought to appraise the recent development relating to the proposed regulation of security transactions. Business on the Stock Exchange was only slightly heavier than on the day before.

The estate of Marcus Daly, son of the pioneer Montana copper man and brother-in-law of James W. Gerard, was appraised yesterday at $7,733,060 gross and $6,845,895 net by Deputy Tax Commissioner Stephenson. Mr. Daly, who died on Nov. 10, 1930, of a heart attack while he was hunting ducks in Virginia, owned securities which were worth $6,059,063 at the time of his death but which have depreciated greatly since that time.

Leon Fraser, who will be the president of the Bank for International Settlements for the next three years, succeeding Gates W. McGarrah, said yesterday on his arrival on the Italian liner Rex that the four days preceding the banking holiday in the United States had been a troublous time for the international banking institution.
Price changes were irregular in trading on the Cotton Exchange yesterday and final quotations were 1 to 7 points higher for the day.

CHICAGO, March 30. -- Ernest J. Stevens opened a fight today to regain control of the Illinois Life Insurance Company, the collapse of which led to the indictment of himself, his father and his brother on charges of embezzlement.

Seven of thirteen Manhattan and Bronx properties put at foreclosure auctions yesterday were bought in by banks. Most of the defaulted holdings were small housing properties, the banks and other successful bidders at the sales being the plaintiffs in the foreclosure proceedings.

Rose Livingston, who for the last twenty-nine years has conducted a single-handed campaign against white slavery in this city, submitted her 1932 report yesterday to the small group that collects the $600 fund which maintains her and her work each year.
FRANKFURT-AM-MAIN, Germany, March 30. -- The National Socialist threat to declare a nationwide boycott against the Jews comes home to citizens in this city chiefly as a question of bread and butter.

At last Congress has given up the practice of medicine and ceased to prescribe prescriptions. The passage by the Senate Wednesday and the House yesterday of the Celler-Copeland bill ends one of the most arbitrary, irritating and preposterous by-products of prohibition.

WASHINGTON, March 30 (AP). -- Senator Bulkley, Democrat of Ohio, today told Representative Sweeney, another Ohio Democrat, who is seeking a Senate investigation of Cleveland banks, that the Senate Stock Market Investigating Committee might reach into his State in the course of its inquiry into large New York banking interests.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., March 30. -- State troopers swung their heavy riot clubs and one even drew a gun today to get that portion of the city's milk supply for tomorrow furnished by the Dairymen's League Cooperative Association safely through crowds of picketing farmers fighting the league over the price of milk.

"Music in the Air," the Jerome Kern-Oscar Hammerstein 2d operetta which closed at the Alvin Theatre during the "bank holiday," will reopen this evening at the Fortyfourth Street Theatre. The original cast, with the exception of Katherine Carrington, remains intact.

No official publication has been made of the terms of the proposal which MUSSOLINI laid before Prime Minister MACDONALD at Rome. But enough has leaked out, or got into the realm of diplomatic gossip, to alarm the Little Entente.
PINEHURST, N.C., March 30. -- Under perfect weather conditions, the two-day horse show of the Pinehurst Jockey Club got under way today, with women riders taking a majority of the prizes.

WASHINGTON, March 30. -- Rep- resentatives of the Governors of oil-producing States in the three-day conference called by Secretary Ickes reiterated today their endorsement of the program agreed upon yesterday with Mr. Ickes and the representatives of the oil industry.
Federal Hall, which together with a deficit of $76,000 is about all that remains in Manhattan of the George Washington bicentennial celebration, is to be removed at last from Bryant Park.

ROME, March 30. -- Vincenzo Azzolini, governor of the Bank of Italy, informed the shareholders at the annual meeting today that he expected negotiations would start soon for revision of Italy's war debt to the United States. He stressed that Italy's capacity to pay is much different than it was when the original debt settlement was made.

Curtailment of missionary activities and reduction of salaries of the clergy of the Methodist Episcopal Church in the New York area was reported as necessary to the continuation of the church's program at the annual meeting, which opened yesterday at the Metropolitan Temple, Seventh Avenue and Thirteenth Street.

WASHINGTON, March 30. -- Approval of the first housing loan application filed with the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, involving an advance of up to $8,075,000 to Fred F. French Operators, Inc., for replacing Manhattan's "lung block" with a model housing development to be known as Knickerbocker Village on the lower east side, was announced by the corporation today.

CHICAGO, March 30. -- Washington Porter 2d, former diplomat, must return to his mother, Mrs. Frances Lee Porter, 72 years old, nearly $1,000,000 worth of stocks and real estate which, she charged, he tricked her into signing over to him.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I have read your editorial on governmental bookkeeping entitled "Painless Arithmetic." I have at various times during the past noticed other writings on this same subject in the press, but all appeared to me to confuse the issue and overlook the fundamentals involved.

CHICAGO, March 30. -- Uncertainty whether the wheat market would be affected by the liquidation of loans made by the Federal Farm Board on commodities caused bulls today to go slowly on the buying side of the market on the Board of Trade.

WASHINGTON, March 30. -- Brewers' preparations for 3.2 per cent beer are pouring millions of dollars into many industries, according to a survey issued by the Department of Commerce today. Orders have been placed or are contemplated for passenger cars, trucks, bottles, barrels, glasses, rubber goods, cereals, malt and various other articles.

The Dance Centre last night gave a special performance of the third bill of its season at the BarbizonPlaza, which is scheduled to have its regular premiere tomorrow evening. The program consists of the much - postponed "Dream Phobias," suggested by John Vassos's book of somewhat similar title, with music by A. Lehman Engel, and Debussy's "Afternoon of a Faun."

PALM BEACH, Fla., March 30. -- Concluding its activities for the season, the Everglades Club, which will be officially closed after luncheon tomorrow, gave a costume dinner and barn dance tonight in the orange gardens, transformed to resemble a rock garden.

A series of paintings and drawings of Vatican City, believed to be the most comprehensive pictorial portrayal ever undertaken of the Palace of the Popes, is to be shown here publicly next week for the first time. Vernon Howe Bailey, the first American artist authorized to make such a series of pictures of the Papal Palace, returned from Rome recently after working nearly a year on the project.

A close union of up-State an down-State Republicans this Fall to insure continued party control of the State Assembly and, in the city, to aid the fight for a fusion Mayor was urged last night by W. Kingsland Macy, Republican State Chairman, at a dinner of the New York Young Republican Club in the National Republican Club, 54 West Fortieth Street.

LONDON, March 30. -- The Marquess of Reading evoked sympathetic cheers in the House of Lords tonight when, with deep feeling, he appealed to the government to convey to Germany the sentiment of the British people on the discriminaton being applied against Jews on purely racial grounds.

The hope that President Roosevelt's "new deal," with its emphasis on justice, brotherhood and respect for the rights of others, would be broadened beyond domestic problems, to embrace all phases of Pan-American life, was expressed yesterday by Josephus Daniels, newly appointed Ambassador to Mexico.

CHICAGO, March 30. -- Anton J. Cermak, Chicago's Mayor, shot down by the would-be assassin of Franklin D. Roosevelt at Miami, died of ulcerative colitis and the bullet wound inflicted by Joseph Zangara was only a contributory factor, Dr. Karl A. Meyer, the Mayor's physician, said today.

Sales of department stores, chain stores and wholesale firms in the New York Federal Reserve District continued in February to run substantially below those in the corre- sponding month last year, according to the monthly review of credit and business of the Federal Reserve Agent at New York.

BERLIN, March 30 -- There is every indication that the economic madness known as the concerted Jewish boycott, scheduled for Saturday morning, on the Jewish Sabbath, by the National Socialist organization that has framed it, will go into operation at that time, despite its certain effect upon the German as well as the Jewish populace.

BERLIN, March 30. -- The obscurity overhanging the clash between the Nazis and the Stahlhelm organization of war veterans was thickened rather than lightened by a manifesto to the Stahlhelm issued today by Franz Seldte, head of the organization and Labor Minister in the Hitler government.

WASHINGTON, March 30. -- Slight modification of the administration farm-relief bill was agreed to by President Roosevelt in a conference late today with Senators Robinson and Harrison and Secretary Wallace.

Some one has taken pains to discover what books those who fill the main room of the New York Public Library choose for reading. The inquiry covered only a mid-afternoon hour of a Winter's day, in the midst of the depression, and for that reason the list was doubtless somewhat more sober than in normal times and at other seasons.
Leaders in Killing. Our world leadership in homicide remained unchallenged among civilized nations in 1932, according to the annual report by Dr. FREDERICK B. HOFFMAN.

SHREVEPORT, La., March 30 (AP). -- An electrical storm that blew into Louisiana late today from Texas killed six persons and injured an undetermined number in four Louisiana parishes it swept through in an arc of destruction.

WASHINGTON, March 30. -- Urging passage of the McSwain bill to consolidate the War and Navy Departments in a Department of National Defense, former Brig. Gen. William Mitchell, who commanded the American Expeditionary Force aviation section, declared today before the House Military Affairs Committee that the United States had no air force.

Announcement was made by the Indoor Polo Association yesterday of the plans and schedule of the Eastern championships, the intercollegiate and interscholastic tournaments in New York City and of the tentative schedule for the national championship finals in Chicago.

Mayor O'Brien made public last night the memorandum on transit unification, given to him by the Transit Commission, and scrutiny of the document revealed that, despite official denials to the contrary, a price of $420,499,000 for the Interborough and B.M.T. systems had apparently been proposed by the commission as a basis for negotiation.

PARIS, March 30. -- Because of partial interruption of work late yesterday as a protest against salary cuts, the 21,000 employes of the Citroen automobile factory in Paris, the largest in France, found lockout notices posted when they reported for work today.

Price movements on local commodity exchanges were irregular again yesterday, with trading in most cases somewhat limited. Raw sugar futures were an exception, being strong and active. Coffee was also higher, while rubber showed gains in borne positions.

The continuation of support for public and private education as the "one clear way ahead" for colleges, universities and schools, was urged last night by Dr. Thomas S. Gates, president of the University of Pennsylvania, at a dinner in his honor at the University of Pennsylvania Club, 35 East Fiftieth Street.

WASHINGTON, March 30. -- An agreement between member lines of the United States Intercoastal Conference and concurring agreements of the Calmar Steamship Corporation and the Shepard Steamship Company, providing an extension to May 31 of intercoastal conference agreement No. 188 were approved today by the Shipping Board.

Harry Ebbets, hard hitting Freeport light-heavyweight, and Adolph Heuser of Germany will furnish the action in the main bout of ten rounds at Madison Square Garden tonight. The bout is a return meeting between the pair, Heuser having taken the decision in the first fight, after a torrid eight-round struggle.

One of the exhilarating things about the young is the insouciance with which they tackle large orders. The debut recital of Gerald Tracy last night in the Town Hall opened with the formidable Bach-Busoni Chaconne and proceeded to Brahms's early sonata in F minor -- a work which Brahms, also in the fine fervor of youth, packed to the brim with technical difficulties and gave more ideas than he provided space to develop.

PARIS, March 30. -- Good relations between France and the United States at present are of capital importance in the maintenance of the world balance and world peace, said Andre Lefebvre de Laboulaye, newly appointed Ambassador to Washington, addressing the American Club in Paris today.

PHILADELPHIA, March 30. -- A probability that not only may the mass of an atom be transformed into energy, but, inversely, that the kinetic energy of motion may be turned back into mass -- in other words, that matter may be created out of energy-was advanced before the Franklin Institute tonight by Dr. Kenneth T. Bainbridge.

F.H. Prince, former president of the Pere Marquette Railway, is to submit to President Roosevelt tomorrow the plan for railroad consolidation that he has devised. It provides for merging the railroads into seven systems, of which two each would be in the East and Southeast and three in the West.

Willingness to cooperate with the administration in its series of financial reforms, and admissions that the basic measures so far announced at Washington are necessary, were voiced here yesterday by bankers, investment dealers and others connected with security transactions.

LONDON, March 30 -- The British Government has requested Sir Esmond Ovey, Ambassador to the Soviet Union, to return from Moscow immediately for a consultation on the situation growing out of the arrests of the Metropolitan-Vickers Electrical Company's engineers. Sir Esmond is not "recalled," in the usual diplomatic sense of that word.

The New York Forestry Association, which celebrated this year the twenty-first anniversary of its organization, notes with satisfaction that the President is "forestryminded." For this New York State rightfully claims part of the credit. Long before he became Governor Mr. ROOSEVELT practiced various kinds of forestry on his home estate.

Chicago, Ill. The city of Chicago plans to pay off tomorrow $6,615,000 of its warrants issued in anticipation of 1931 taxes, which are in process of collection. The warrants include those of general corporate, bond and interest fund, public library, and municipal tuberculosis sanitarium.

WASHINGTON, March 30. -- Opposition to vital portions of the railroad rehabilitation program, which is contemplated by President Roosevelt, developed on three fronts today as railway labor executives, representatives of national farm organizations and the National Highway Users Conference made known their position.

BELGRADE, March 30. -- "The Little Entente is firmly resolved to maintin by all possible means all the territories it won," said Foreign Minister Jeftitch in the Yugoslav Senate today during discussion of Premier Mussolini's four-power peace plan.

Jack Pleva and Harry Schwartz, election inspectors in the Fourth Assembly District, who were convisted March 1 in the first trial held here since 1870 for violation of the Federal election laws, received a sentence of a year and a day each yesterday when they were brought before Judge John C. Knox.

MIAMI, Fla., March 30. -- Cornelius V. Whitney's Banderlog made it two in a row at the current meeting when he captured the featured test at Tropical Park today in time which set a new mile and a sixteenth track record. The gelded son of Chicle and Flyleaf was clocked in 1:44 2-5, lowering by two-fifths of a second the mark set by Action.

FORT MYERS, Pla., March 30. -- Connie Mack's two young outfielders, Bob Johnson and Loll Finney, gave the Dodgers a farewell party today that was pleasing to their veteran manager, but highly unsatisfactory to Max Carey.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, March 30 (AP).v -- Only twenty-five teams participated in the American Bowling Congress tourney tonight and the five-man event leaders remained undisturbed.
Mary Pickford, film actress, returned from Europe yesterday on the liner Rex enthusiastic about her plans to film "Alice in Wonderland," and "Peter-Pan," or any other similar play.

American Machine Foundry Company and subsidiaries -- For 1932: Net profit after expenses, interest, depreciation and other charges, $1,117,658, equal to $1.12 a share on 1,000,000 no-par common shares, compared with $1,838,529, or $1.84 a share in preceding year.

Two members of the famous Spence family of swimmers gained additional aquatic honors last night when Walter and Wallace each captured a championship race in the National A.A.U. title meet which opened at the New York A.C.

WASHINGTON, March 30. -- A regulation permitting unlicensed member banks to perform normal fiduciary functions, under certain conditions, and another to permit withdrawals from State member banks of deposits which were secured by collateral, were issued today by Secretary Woodin of the Treasurry Department.

DETROIT, March 30. -- A bomb lowered into the basement of the Rev. Father Charles E. Coughlin'a home exploded early today directly under the first-floor bedroom in which the radio speaker was sleeping. He was shaken but uninjured.

Before the assembled heads of city, county and borough departments Mayor O'Brien reiterated yesterday his determination to effect further economy in city government during the year, and demanded quarterly reports beginning today from his subordinates showing in detail the savings they have made.

In the second year of an experiment which started informally with the borrowed materials of Harlem River oarsmen, Manhattan College's rowing squad steps out next week with its own equipment, with plans for races this year and hopes of competing at Poughkeepsie some day in the future.

Major L.B. Roberts, director of the City Commission "Work Bureau for a year, has resigned and will leave tomorrow when the newly appointed City Work and Relief Administration officially takes office, it was revealed yesterday.
Despite recent snow, trout streams in this State are in good shape for the opening of the season tomorrow, according to the latest reports from a dozen or more observers in as many sections.

Numerous leases of space for business occupancy were reported in Manhattan yesterday. This type of trading again formed the bulk of real estate activity in the borough and was featured by the renting of stores to merchants who cater to the retail trade.

Bank clearings throughout the country continued to keep within close range of the amounts for last year, according to the weekly compilation by Dun Bradstreet, Inc. The total for the week ended on Wednesday was $3,704,839,000, or a drop of 6.7 per cent from last year.
NEW YORK. The Duchess of Northumberland, who had planned to sail on the Bremen last night, has postponed her departure, and is at the Savoy-Plaza until she leaves for England.
Brentano's, Inc., the world's largest retail book chain, was thrown into receivership yesterday, but every effort will be made to keep the business alive.

B.B. Davis Jr., president of the United States Rubber Company, announced yesterday a formal offer to holders of the company's three-year 6 per cent secured notes which will mature on June 1. The offer contemplates payment of 30 per cent in cash and 70 per cent in new three-year 6 per cent notes.

WASHINGTON, March 30 -- The Senate Banking and Currency Committee decided today to ask the Senate to broaden the authority of its stock market inquiry when committee counsel reported that J.P. Morgan Co. was hesitating to agree to its requests for information because of "the use which might be made of it."

WASHINGTON, March 30. -- The $500,000,000 unemployment relief bill, incorporating the second phase of the administration's relief program and setting a precedent in authorizing direct Federal grants to States, was passed by the Senate today by a vote of 55 to 17.

WASHINGTON, March 30. -- Beginning a drive to make the new Farm Credit Administration "sales conscious," Henry Morgenthau Jr., its chairman, today announced the appointment of H.E. Babcock of Ithaca, N.Y., to assist him in obtaining markets for large stocks of agricultural commodities taken by the Farm Board as collateral security for loans of $157,236,323 to cooperative marketing associations.

WASHINGTON, March 30. -- The Black bill providing for a five-day thirty-hour week in industry, but amended to limit its effect to two years as an emergency relief measure, unexpectedly went on the Senate calendar today backed by a large majority of the Judiciary Committee.
WASHINGTON, March 30. -- The only grand division to which exports from the United States increased last month as compared with a year ago was South America.

WASHINGTON, March 30. -- A further loan of $7,000,000 from the Reconstruction Finance Corporation to the New York Central Railroad Company was approved today by the Interstate Commerce Commission for meeting a like amount of debenture bonds maturing May 1 of the Boston Albany Railroad, a Central subsidiary.

WASHINGTON, March 30. -- The daily average volume of Federal Reserve Bank credit outstanding during the week ended March 29, as reported by the Federal Reserve Banks, was $2,787,000,000, a decrease of $321,000,000 compared with the preceding week and an increase of $188,000,000 compared with the corresponding week in 1932.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., March 30. -- Daniel Curtin of 34 Grove Street was released from a charge of driving without a license by City Judge Francis Doherty today after Mr. and Mrs. George Connors, owners of the automobile, had testified that Curtin, who was arrested yesterday, had taken the wheel after trying unsuccessfully to stop the machine from rolling down a hill with an elderly woman passenger and severely cutting himself.

Despite the depression, Columbia College students have spent more than $10,000 on social affairs of the college during this academic year. This is shown by a survey conducted by The Columbia Spectator, student daily newspaper, the results of which were made public yesterday.

De Wolf Hopper, with a career of fifty-four years on the stage, was 75 years old yesterday. Deluged with congratulatory messages and shaking hands with well-wishers and brother actors, he declared in an interview at the Lambs Club that this unusual attention paid to his birthday made him realize for the first time that he was getting old.

WASHINGTON, March 30. -- The anti-Semitic economic boycott in Germany was the subject of a conference at the State Department this afternoon between Under-Secretary Phillips and Rabbi Stephen S. Wise, honorary president; Bernard S. Deutsch, president of the American Jewish Congress, and Max Rhoade, Washington legal representative.

The profit and loss surplus of the Norfolk Western Railway was reduced in 1932, the total on Dec. 31 standing at $151,023,716, against $151,857,456 a year previously. The decrease resulted from sundry adjustments, the company having earned its dividend disbursements in 1932 by a safe margin.
LONDON, March 30 (AP). -- The weekly statement of the Bank of England shows the following changes in pounds sterling:

To Stage Clearances in May. Advices received in the market here to date indicate a very large number of retailers will defer their post-Easter clearances. Consumer buying of Spring apparel has de- veloped so late that there has been quite general agreement expressed by the stores that it would be un- wise to stage clearances immediately after Easter.

BOSTON, March 30. -- Arthur Bliss Seymour, widely known botanist, who for the last forty-seven years was with Harvard University Herbarium, died yesterday at his home in Belmont after an illness of two months. His age was 74.

WASHINGTON, March 30 (AP). -- Legislation permitting distressed municipalities to obtain a composition of their debts was approved before the House Judiciary Committee only as a two-year emergency measure by Charles G. Taylor Jr., vice president of the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company.
WASHINGTON, March 30. -- The War Department Issued the following orders today: McCleave, Brig. Gen. R., to retirement.

Plans that have been advanced in Washington looking to regulation of the security business exerted a restraining influence yesterday upon the course of the markets. Stocks and bonds were depressed moderately and the volume of business on the Stock Exchange was reduced again to an extremely small basis.

WASHINGTON, March 30 (AP). -- Advances in prices of all groups of agricultural commodities, except dairy and poultry products, raised the index of the general level of prices paid farmers 1 point during the month ended March 15.

NEWARK, N.J., Friday, March 31. -- The threatened strike of the Public Service Corporation's bus and trolley crews, numbering more than 4,000 workers, throughout New Jersey was averted when it was announced here early this morning that the operators had voted to accept a 10 per cent wage reduction and rejected proposals to strike in protest.

Dr. Cyrus Adler, chairman of the American Jewish Committee, made public a cablegram last night received by him from Oscar Wassermann, director of the Deutsche Bank in Berlin, warning that the threatened economic boycott of the Jews by the Nazis would be carried out if foreign protest meetings or boycotts of German goods should be promoted by Jews or with Jewish assistance.

Almost the entire fourth floor of the Heckscher Foundation for Children, at Fifth Avenue and 104th Street, has been converted into dormitories, recreation rooms and a dining room for homeless women, it became known yesterday. The shelter was made possible by the combined philanthropy of August Heckscher and William J. Wollman, the broker.

Commander P.F. Roach of the United States Coast Guard, said at the customs house yesterday that Atlantic Coast vessels of the Coast Guard had completed one of the most exhaustive searches it had ever conducted. A dozen cutters and patrol boats have been on the lookout since the middle of March for the 75-foot fishing schooner Mary, of New Bedford.

PURNEA, India, March 30. -- High winds prevented serious flying today, for the planes of the Mount Everest flight expedition. The wind strength, which, was 74 miles an hour at 3,300 feet altitude at dawn, rose to 100 miles an hour in the afternoon.

DECATUR, Ala., March 30. -- Samuel Leibowitz, chief counsel for the Negroes whose conviction two years ago at Scottsboro for an attack on two white girls was reversed by the United States Supreme Court, won the right today to inspect the secret roll from which jurymen are chosen in Morgan County.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The community is to be congratulated upon the jury's verdict, in one ballot, of "not guilty" in District Attorney Crain's prosecution, at the behest of the Bronx Public Works Commissioner, of a private citizen who had dared testify in the city investigation and tell the truth about a city official.

LONDON, March 30. -- It is a reasonable assumption that the World Economic Conference will begin in the second half of May. This new note of reality in place of vague reasons for delay is the first fruit of the consultations between Norman H. Davis, President Roosevelt's diplomatic representative, and Prime Minister MacDonald which began today.
To the Editor of The New York Times: I read with interest Mr. Machen's letter of alarm with regard to President Roosevelt's so-called reforestation plan.
CHICAGO, March 30 -- The big Winter campaign of American golf was over today with Craig Wood, the blond shotmaker from Deal, N. J., in possession of major honors.

Developments which might have a far-reaching effect on the industry are expected to result from the four-day conference of oil executives and the Governors or representatives of the oil producing States with Secretary Ickea of the Interior Department, according to the views of most of the oil company executives who returned from Washington yesterday.

MARSEILLES, France, March 30. -- In the midst of plaudits for his feat in leading an automobile party in an 8,000-mile circuit of French Sahara, J. Rogers Mathieu died suddenly here today. He was stricken at a reception given in his honor on his return to France following his journey.

NORFOLK, Va., March 30 (AP). -- Federal Judge Luther B. Way handed down today an opinion sustaining the Federal Power Commission's control over hydroelectric plants on non-navigable streams under certain conditions and dismissed the injunction bill of the Appalachian Electric Power Company to restrain the commission from interfering with its project on New River in Montgomery County.

VIENNA, March 30 (AP). -- The government announced today that the foreign credtiors' agreement with the Austrian Government covering the obligations of the Credit-anstalt, signed Jan. 10, was impossible of fulfillment.

After his last regularly scheduled recital at the Brooklyn Academy last evening, Ignace Jan Paderewski made the announcement that he will close his present American tour by giving his services for a benefit of the Musicians Symphony Orchestra at the Metropolitan Opera House on Monday evening, April 10.

Clifford Ryan, 21 years old, speakeasy owner and twice convicted automobile thief, and Thomas Venetucci, 19, were found guilty of first-degree murder by a jury before Judge Corrigan in General Sessions last night. They were tried as participants in the shooting of Paul Cassullo, 46, in the attempted hold-up of the victim's grocery at 551 West Fifty-ninth Street last Dec. 8.
To the Editor of The New York Times: It is much easier to write about what should be done than to do it. Your editorial in regard to the multiple-dwelling law and my situation are examples.

The New York Rangers advanced one step nearer the play-off for the Stanley Cup by defeating the fastskating Detroit Red Wings at Madison Square Garden last night. Showing their characteristic vigilance on the attack and battering their rivals' defense consistently, the blue-jerseyed stick wielders triumphed, 2 to 0.

MIAMI, Fla., March 30. -- The wedding of Mme. Virginia C. Willys De Aguirre, daughter of John North Willys, automobile manufacturer and former Ambassador to Poland, to Jose de Landa of Paris took place this morning at Miami Beach.

WASHINGTON, March 30 --Although, the date for the opening of the World Economic Conference remains unsettled and uncertain, the preparation for it is progressing earnestly, and in these labors there have been several important developments recently.

BERLIN, March 30. -- As a result of Dr. Hugo Eckener's recent trip to Batavia, Dutch Java, to investigate climatic conditions for dirigible service between Europe and the East Indies, negotiations have been resumed for establishing a dirigible service between Europe and North America.

LONDON, March 30. -- The text of Premier Mussolini's proposed four-power pact, obtained today from a trustworthy source, reveals six brief articles, entitled, "A Political Pact of Understanding and Cooperation Among the Four Western European Powers."
WASHINGTON, March 30. -- The Bureau of Navigation issued the following orders today, dated March 28:

The Roosevelt administration has taken a path that will restore economic health and happiness in the United States, former Governor Alfred E. Smith declared in an article in the issue of The New Outlook, of which he is editor, published today.

Samuel Seabury received last night the gold medal of the Hundred Year Association, awarded to the person "who has done most for the civic and industrial development of the city," in recognition of his work as counsel to the Hofstadter legislative committee.

PINEHURST, N.C., March 30 -- The annual team golf match between Pinehurst and All-South, which acts as the curtain-raiser to the thirty-third annual North and South amateur golf tournament, starting tomorrow, was won today, for the thirteenth successive year by Pinehurst, 16 1/2 to 13 1/2.

The Hamburg - American liner Hamburg will arrive today. Among her passengers is Dr. Walter S. McClellan, medical director of the Saratoga Springs Commission, who has been abroad since last Fall doing research work at the Kerckhoff Institute for Study of Affections of the Heart at Bad Nauheim.

BUENOS AIRES, March 30 -- The Uruguayan political situation, which has been tense for several weeks, reached a crisis today when President Gabriel Terra was forced to abandon Government House, moving the executive office and Ministry of the Interior to the central barracks of the Montevideo Fire Department.

WASHINGTON, March 30. -- Thousands of Americans were losers without a chance to win in a drawing based upon the Cuban National Sweepstakes, run on Sunday. March 12, in Havana, despite a fraud order issued against it on Dec. 3 by the Postoffice Department.

The membership of J. Henry Townsend in the New York Stock Exchange has been posted for transfer to Peter du Bois Eckler for a nominal consideration. If elected to membership, Mr. Eckler will become a partner in Theodore Price Co. Mr. Townsend will remain as senior general partner in Townsend, Graff Co., of which James E. Sauter is the floor partner.

DETROIT, March 30 (AP). -- Controversy raged anew over affairs of the Detroit Institute of Arts tonight with the publication of charges by Edgardo Simone, Italian sculptor, that eighteen of the most famous canvases and sculptures in the institute's permanent Italian collection were "wrongly attributed or outright fakes."
PARIS, March 30 (AP). -- The weekly statement of the Bank of France shows the following changes in francs:

WASHINGTON, March 30. -- As part of his effort to save $900,000,000 in the next fiscal year, President Roosevelt has decided to restrict rivers and barbers appropriations as far as possible to self-liquidating projects. His policy was defined today to a delegation representing the National Rivers and Harbors Congress, and members of the House Rivers and Harbors Committee.

PHILADELPHIA, March 30. -- Representatives from twelve Eastern colleges are entered in the annual Intercollegiate Fencing Association championship tournament which opens at the Penn A.C. tomorrow morning and comes to a close with the finals on Saturday night.

Mr. Toscanini, conducting the concert of the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra last night in Carnegie Hall, afforded his audience a momentous experience. It was nothing less than the performance of the first and the last symphonies written by Mozart.

Described by the police as an escaped convict and a burglar who started his career in his early teens, Andrew Rogers, 20 years old, was captured and slightly wounded by a policeman in the rear yard of the Fourth Unitarian Church, Beverly Road and East Nineteenth Street, Brooklyn, after about 100 families, in the neighborhood had chased him over backyard fences for nearly three-quarters of a block.

The New York State Banking Board, of which Joseph A. Broderick, State Banking Super- intendent, is chairman, has memorialized Congress in favor of compulsory membership of all banks and trust companies in this State in the Federal Reserve System, it was learned yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 30 -- Automobile production throughout the United States in February totaled 106,814 units, compared with 130,114 for the preceding month and 117,418 for the corresponding month last year, according to figures made public today by the Commerce Department.

Restrictive legislation for beer control will defeat its own end by making repeal of the Eighteenth Amendment impossible, Dr. Max Henius, president of the Wahl-Henius Institute of Chicago, said yesterday in an interview at the Commodore.

Many persons in Park Avenue, between Thirty-fourth and Fortieth Streets, were startled shortly before 8 o'clock last evening when three shots rang out. Brakes screeched on moving automobiles, resulting in a minor traffic snarl, and a scurry for cover among pedestrians resulted.

TRENTON, N.J., March 30. -- With the question of return of the saloon still open, the State commission charged with formulation of a policy for sale of beer in New Jersey on and after April 7 will hold a public hearing at the Capitol tomorrow.

With "tide-over jobs" already provided for 213 heads of families the campaign of the Adopt-a-Family Committee, headed by Mrs. August Belmont, opened yesterday in behalf of 1,000 men and women with a luncheon meeting of workers at the Cosmopolitan Club, 129 East Sixty-fifth Street.

BOGOTA, Colombia, March 30. -- Colombia's moratorium on foreign debts, by which funds for interest on national bonds sold abroad are made available for use in the war with Peru, which is still undeclared, probably will be applicable to $1,206,000 annual interest on $15,750,000 outstanding foreign bonds of the Agricultural Mortgage Bank and $3,680,000 annual interest on the equivalent of $62,826,000 in national government foreign bonds.

Former Mayor James J. Walker is seriously ill and has been advised to take a long cure in a European spa, according to his brother, Dr. William H. Walker, who returned on the liner Rex yesterday after a visit with his brother in Cannes.

MOSCOW, March 30. -- In the middle of the diplomatic duel between Great Britain and the Soviet Union over the accused British engineers there appears from a British source a big scare story in the American press about famine in the Soviet Union, with "thousands already dead and millions menaced by death from starvation."

Former Mayor James J. Walker is seriously ill and has been advised to take a long cure in a European spa, according to his brother, Dr. William H. Walker, who returned on the liner Rex yesterday after a visit with his brother in Cannes.

MOSCOW, March 30. -- In the middle of the diplomatic duel between Great Britain and the Soviet Union over the accused British engineers there appears from a British source a big scare story in the American press about famine in the Soviet Union, with "thousands already dead and millions menaced by death from starvation."

BERLIN, March 30. -- It becomes evident that the downward trend on the Boerse, which has now been lasting several days, is more than a mere month-end movement for technical reasons, and is rather a reaction of some moment which was due after the long, rapid rise in securities.

The real truth about the war debts is that they are as dead as Fenian bonds or Confederate securities, Frank H. Simonds says in "The A B C of War Debts," published by Harpers today. But as American public and political opinion has not caught up with this reality, the one thing left for the Roosevelt administration to do is to persuade Congress to agree to a moratorium in June.

No better news has come out of City Hall in a long time than Mayor O'BRIEN'S announcement that the city is preparing to push forward to completion the work on the Triborough Bridge. This is a public improvement which meets every test.
WASHINGTON, March 30 (AP). -- George Otis Smith, chairman of the Federal Power Commission, today described as "a major victory in the public interest" the decision of Judge Way.

The current program at the Radio City Music Hall sways from the sublime to the mundane, for the principal stage attraction is John Murray Anderson's impressive visualization of Oscar Wilde's poetic tale, "The Young King," and the screen feature bears the suggestive title of "The Keyhole."
Two deals with New York principals featured the New Jersey realty trading reported yesterday. Small dwellings comprised the bulk of the turnover.

Graduates of the city's public schools in February totaled 52,303, an increase ot 879 over February, 1932, according to complete figures announced yesterday by Dr. William J. O'Shea, Superintendent of Schools, and, except in one course, the girls again made a better showing than the boys.

WASHINGTON, March 30.-- An order curtailing the number of flying hours demanded of naval aviation officers as their requirement to qualify for flier's pay, was issued by Secretary Swanson under date of March 17, it was revealed today.

A program for the restoration of confidence as the prerequisite of business recovery was outlined last night by Prof. E.W. Kemmerer of Princeton, who served the Dawes commission as expert in 1925 and also has acted as financial adviser of several nations.

Money market was quiet and steady throughout. The full supply of funds available in the outside market on call loans brought a rate of 2 per cent, with Federal checks down to a low of 1/2. The official quotation on the Exchange remained at 3. Time money, commercial paper and acceptance markets were dull.

WHEN the stewards summarily called off the Poughkeepsie regatta for 1933 there was a sorrowful feeling in this corner that the overlords of a fine amateur sport had run up the white flag too soon. Evidently the husky youngsters who ride the sliding seats in school and college shells felt the same way about it. They are bending their backs to the oars and making fine headway against the tide of depression.

WASHINGTON, March 30 -- Leaders in Senate and House laid plans today for speedy action on President Roosevelt's securities control bill, predicting that it would be on its way to the statute books by the latter part of next week.

The Wagner relief bill, approved yesterday by the Senate, authorizes direct grants by the Federal Government to the States amounting to $500,000,000. This is just about the sum which the President hopes to save by means of the economy act, permitting him to reduce Federal salaries and to discontinue payment of pensions to ex-soldiers on account of disabilities not connected with war service.

The American Society of Composers, Authors and Publishers held its annual dinner in the ballroom of the Ritz-Carlton last night. A business meeting preceded the dinner, with Gene Buck, president of the society, presiding. A spirit of reunion was apparent among the 300 members attending, though there was no music.

German bonds of all classifications were subjected to heavy pressure again yesterday on the Stock Exchange and about thirty of the forty-odd issues touched new low marks for the year. Their losses ranged from fractions to 7 points.

WHEN the stewards summarily called off the Poughkeepsie regatta for 1933 there was a sorrowful feeling in this corner that the overlords of a fine amateur sport had run up the white flag too soon. Evidently the husky youngsters who ride the sliding seats in school and college shells felt the same way about it. They are bending their backs to the oars and making fine headway against the tide of depression.

WASHINGTON, March 30 -- Leaders in Senate and House laid plans today for speedy action on President Roosevelt's securities control bill, predicting that it would be on its way to the statute books by the latter part of next week.

The Wagner relief bill, approved yesterday by the Senate, authorizes direct grants by the Federal Government to the States amounting to $500,000,000. This is just about the sum which the President hopes to save by means of the economy act, permitting him to reduce Federal salaries and to discontinue payment of pensions to ex-soldiers on account of disabilities not connected with war service.

The American Society of Composers, Authors and Publishers held its annual dinner in the ballroom of the Ritz-Carlton last night. A business meeting preceded the dinner, with Gene Buck, president of the society, presiding. A spirit of reunion was apparent among the 300 members attending, though there was no music.
WASHINGTON, March 30. -- With beer seven days away, Prohibition Director Woodcock started today the preparation of regulations to govern activities of the prohibition bureau under the new conditions.

Franklin D. Rooseevlt Jr., the President's son, and Thomas H. Choate, representing respectivey the Groton and St. Mark's Schools, were chairmen of a holiday dance given last night at Essex House in the interests of the Summer camps maintained by the two institutions.

WASHINGTON, April 1 (Science Service). -- Discovery of a germ or micro-organism that can cause cancer was announced by the United States Public Health Service's National Institute of Health here today.

PINEHURST, N.C., March 31. -- Mountain Star, a sorrel gelding owned and ridden by Miss Elizabeth Adams of Sedgefield, N.C., was judged the champion three-gaited saddle horse of the two-day Pinehurst Horse Show, which was concluded today.

Judge Martin T. Manton of the United States Circuit Court of Appeals signed an order yesterday directing the Paramount Public Corporation to show cause next Monday why six of its bondholders, Who had filed suits against Paramount in Supreme Court, should not be permitted to file a petition for a writ of prohibition against the continuance of the receivership created in Federal Court by Federal Judge William Bondy.

WASHINGTON, March 31. -- Labor leaders of the United States, headed by William Green of the American Federation of Labor, at a conference today swung into agreement with Secretary Perkins on steps to provide employment and relief.

Further reductions of dividend payments, especially those of bank and insurance companies, featured the announcements made in March. Total declarations, embracing all classes of shares, made by 1,002 corporations were $197,702,862, compared with payments totaling $311,741;233 voted by 1,462 corporations in March, 1932.

Details of the model housing development on the lower east side to be financed with the $8,075,000 loan made on Thursday by the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, were revealed yesterday by Fred F. French, president of the Fred F. French Operators, Inc., who obtained the loan.

Stock trading on the New York Stock Exchange last month was slightly heavier than in February, with only eighteen days of trading, because of the bank holidays. The heaviest day's trading amounted to 3,301,185 shares, on March 16, and the smallest to 501,490, on March 27.

The Transit Commission's "Memorandum on Development of a "Plan for the Readjustment and "Unification of Rapid Transit Railroads and Related Power Properties in the City of New York" reviews the advantages that would flow from its consummation.

The nomination of JOHN W. TROY, the Juneau editor, to be Governor of Alaska is a fit selection if loyalty to the interests of the Territory is the criterion. Not only has he made a study of every district of Alaska, but he has kept the Democratic organization going when its light was almost out.

NEWARK, N.J., March 31. -- James L. Kinney, Department of Commerce pilot, climbed into the cockpit of a plane this morning at the Metropolitan Airport here, pulled a hood over his head and fastened it. Then, unable to see anything of the outside world, he took off, using instruments and radio guides alone, flew in a circle about the field and landed.

The Right Rev. George Craig Stewart, Protestant Episcopal Bishop of Chicago, speaking in that city in a Lenten sermon broadcast yesterday by the Columbia network in this country and Canada, and heard here over Station WABC, called upon the German people "to assure the world that persecution of the Jews has ceased."
LEAVENWORTH, Kan., March 31. -- Lynn Barlow and A.H. Noris, two ex-convicts, were arrested by Federal officials this afternoon on a charge of shooting to commit murder at the Federal penitentiary.
NEW YORK. Mrs. Samuel T. Gilford will give a dinner tonight at the St. Regis for her niece, Miss Gertrude Groes-beck Riker.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., March 31. -- Iona School of New Rochelle retained the interscholastic championship in the third annual Westchester County indoor track and field title meet held at the County Centre tonight. A crowd of 1,500 spectators saw the Iona representatives tally 23 points to take the scholastic honors for the second straight season.

WASHINGTON, March 31. -- Wheat is not included in the list of commodities accepted by the Federal Farm Board as collateral for its loans of about $157,000,000 and that commodity will have no part in the program of the Farm Credit Administration for liquidating such loans, Henry Morgenthau Jr. announced today.

Revision of the election rules of the Columbia University Chapter of Phi Beta Kappa, national honorary fraternity, to eliminate "undue advantage" to students whose "friends" are present during an election meeting was announced yesterday by The Columbia Spectator, student daily newspaper, following a general meeting of the Columbia chapter.

The desirability of changing the State relief law to provide that public officials charged with the responsibility of granting home relief may make cash payments or payments in kind is being considered by Governor Lehman as a result of action taken by the Welfare Council's Coordinating Committee on Unemployment and made public yesterday.

BERLIN, March 31. -- According to information reaching Berlin, the recent executions of thirty-five high officials in various Soviet agricultural commissariats by the Ogpu [political police] involves a story of espionage that rivals the exploits of the famous Eugene Azeff, who for many years lived a double life as a trusted leader of a desperate group of revolutionaries and as a spy for the Czarist police.

New financing here in March was virtually at a standstill. Because of the uncertainty surrounding the banking situation during the month and with business activity at a low level, little interest was manifested in new offerings. Only eight bond issues, totaling $3,000,000 and one stock issue, amounting to $1,239,000, were marketed in March.
ALBANY, March 31. -- Stirred to action by violence in the milk strike of farmers near Rochester, the Senate tonight passed the Pitcher bill establishing a board to fix the price of milk.

Commonwealth of Massachusetts. The Commonwealth of Massachusetts awarded yesterday a new issue of $2,000,000 of notes, due on April 2, 1934, to the First National Bank of Boston and the National Shawmut Bank. Each bank submitted a bid for the issue on a 3.22 per cent basis, and each received an allotment of half of the notes.

DETROIT, March 31 (AP). -- Affairs of Michigan's two largest financial holding companies, principal stock-holders in two of the state's big national banks, both inoperative, tonight were in the hands of temporary receivers.

The New York Rangers entrained last night from the Grand Central station, bound for Detroit, where they will meet the Detroit Red Wings tomorrow night in the final game of their "two-game home and home series for the right to meet the winner of the Toronto Maple Leaf-Boston Bruin clashes for the Stanley Cup and the world's professional hockey championship.

With the exception of sugar and rubber, commodity futures' prices were lower in trading on loan exchanges here yesterday. Sugar continued its strong rally on the basis of hopes for aid from Washington, while rubber recovered partly from the recent low levels. Cash grains advanced.

ST. LOUIS, March 31. -- The Missouri Pacific Railroad filed with Federal Judge Faris today a petition in bankruptcy, stating that it owed $40,589,330, due tomorrow and within thirty days, and was without funds to pay the obligations.
The following dispatch from a special correspondent in Germany was published in The Manchester Guardian in England on Thursday. It is printed in THE NEW YORK TIMES by permission of The Baltimore Sun:

WASHINGTON, March 31. -- President Roosevelt designated May 1 as Child Health Day in a proclamation today in which he urged all agencies, private and public, to consider the needs of children in their communities.

A demand that the city be made a party to the Interborough receivership now pending in the Federal courts was made yesterday by counsel for the receivers at a conference held in the chambers of Judge Martin T. Manton of the Circuit Court of Appeals.

LONDON, March 31. -- The British financial year ended tonight with a real deficit of u8,605,000 ($29,558,000 at the current rate). The results of Chancellor Neville Chamberlain's first budget, however, are held to be far from discouraging, since it reveals far greater power of resistance on the part of Britain to the economic blizzard than once had seemed probable.

Further relaxation in money with small amounts of 60-90 day funds offered and traded at 2 per cent compared with 2 1/2 previously featured. The longer dates remained unchanged, but interest In these maturities was small. Outside trading on call loans dropped to 1 3/4 per cent from 2, while the Stock Exchange quotation held at 3 per cent.

C. Howard Marfield has resigned the presidency of the Continental Bank and Trust Company, it was announced last night. Mr. Marfield's resignation will take effect May 1, after which, according to the announcement, he intends "to engage in reorganization work and later enter the investment banking field."

A decline of 0.7 point carried the Annalist Weekly Index of Wholesale Commodity Prices to 82.1 on Tuesday from 82.8 (revised) the week previous and 82.8 on Thursday, March 16, the first day complete quotations were available after the banks reopened.

The Chase National Bank bought at auction yesterday afternoon, for $4,002,540, the collateral securing a defaulted $5,485,051 note of the Sea-board Public Service Corporation held by the bank. It now owns all the common shares of the Virginia Public Service Company and two-thirds of the common shares of the Eastern Shore Public Service Company, together with other securities.

WASHINGTON, March 31. -- President Roosevelt today nominated Daniel W. MacCormack to be Commissioner General of Immigration and former Governor Harry Hines Woodring of Kansas to be Assistant Secretary of War.

BERLIN, March 31. -- The National Socialist case for the anti-Jewish boycott, as compounded for the edification of the German people, is contained in a huge poster displayed by the central committee in all the streets of Berlin today.

The bill submitted to Congress on Wednesday by President Roosevelt for Federal supervision of the sale of securities has been generally misunderstood, if one may judge by the comments in the press. The bill is of such a technical nature that apparently most of the commentators have not had an opportunity to carefully analyze it.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Every bank that weather's this panic and is approved by Federal authorities is safe for the dollar, even that of the widow and orphan. For the first time in the history of the United States we have an opportunity, through President Roosevelt, to get a sound banking system.
VIENNA, March 31. -- The Socialist Schutzbund, a uniformed protective organization, was dissolved throughout Austria today by order of Chancellor Dollfuss.

To the Editor of The New York Times: THE TIMES article "Assembly Advances Three City Election Bills" has brought back some recollections of my own experience as an election inspector when I served on boards in the early days of my law practice for about seven years.

A new battle against prohibition repeal, the saloon and for the protection of the youth who have "never seen open saloons with the drunkards reeling from their swinging doors" was begun yesterday at the 134th session of the New York Annual Conference of the Methodist Episcopal Church.

This is the day that all species of the trout family go on the defensive in New York State. From now on for several months the trout will be prey to hundreds of thousands of anglers, residents of the State and visitors. New York's trout streams are noted far and wide and annually there is a big influx of fly fishermen who love to whip the streams in all sections of the State.

CHICAGO, March 31. -- General buying of wheat futures in small lots was under way today on the Board of Trade here, and despite aggressive selling credited to the Federal Farm Board and to houses with Eastern connections the close was at net gains of 5/8 to 3/4 cent a bushel after prices at one time had been advanced 1 1/4 cents above yesterday's finish.

LONDON, Saturday, April 1 (Canadian Press). -- Financial editors of several leading daily newspapers here maintained today that the action of Stock Exchange traders yesterday in suspending dealings in Canadian securities was justified because of uncertainties surrounding the proposed Canadian tax on dividends of bonds held outside the Dominion.

The profit and loss surplus of the New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad was $14,011,017 on Dec. 31, against $17,718,094 a year previously. The reduction resulted from a net loss of $393,047 suffered in 1932, against a net income of $9,179,869 earned in 1931, the payment of $858,142 in preferred dividends and other causes.

Unable to agree on a verdict after deliberating seven and a half hours, a jury before Federal Judge Henry W. Goddard, which had listened since last Friday to evidence at the trial of Morris Bier, a watcher at the polls on election day, for alleged perjury, was discharged last night.

A comprehensive program of relief for Jews in Germany will be worked out at a conference called for tomorrow afternoon by the Joint Distribution Committee at Temple Emanu-El, Fifth Avenue and Sixty-fifth Street. Prominent Jewish leaders and representatives of Jewish organizations will attend the conference.

The application for the appointment of an equity receiver for the Fox Film Corporation by Benjamin Sohellenger, a stockholder of Brookline, Mass., was withdrawn yesterday by his attorney, Martin C. Ansorge. when the matter came up for a hearing on a show-cause order before Federal Judge John C. Knox.

PUTNEY-ON-THAMES, England, March 31. -- The Oxford and Cambridge crews will race for the eighty-fifth time over the historic Putney-Mortlake course tomorrow in a contest that will decide whether Cambridge can beat all previous records by winning for the tenth year in succession.

WASHINGTON, March 31. -- President Roosevelt moved today to harmonize difficulties incurred in the Senate Agriculture Committee, relative to the passage of the farm relief legislation now pending, and worked out an agreement which is expected to result in the passage of the measure within the next week or ten days.

ALBANY, March, 31. -- Governor Lehman's $212,071,341 executive budget, the lowest in ten years, was passed today by both houses of the Legislature, approximately two months after it was submitted to the lawmakers.

DALLAS, Texas, March 31 (AP). -- Tornadoes in widely separated communities of four Southern States yesterday and early today left in their devastating wake at least forty-eight dead, scores injured and property damage running into hundreds of thousands of dollars.

Columbia University received yesterday afternoon a portrait of Mrs. Winifred Edgerton Merrill, the first woman to receive a degree from Columbia University, that of Doctor of Philosophy cum laude in 1886, at a ceremony in Philosophy Hall.

A gentle-mannered, white-haired little man sat at the banquet board at the Princeton Club last night, flanked by educators and trustees and looking into the faces of some hundred and fifty Nassau alumni who had gathered to do him honor.

Plans were completed last night for the beginning here of Holy Year with a service tomorrow morning at 10:30 o'clock in Radio City Music Hall under the auspices of a committee including representatives of the Roman Catholic, Protestant and Jewish faiths.

LA PAZ, Bolivia, March 31. -- The text of the plan drawn up at Mendoza, Argentina, by the Argentine and Chilean Foreign Ministers for peace between Bolivia and Paraguay was published here today, as was the Bolivian reply dated Feb. 28.

Starting a movement that is expected to be followed by other important banks, the National City Bank announced yesterday a policy of complete and prompt information to stockholders on all major developments affecting the institution and at the same time disclosed that $30,000,000 had been transferred from surplus account to reserves to make provision for slow and doubtful assets.

While Marie Antoinette was being prepared for the guillotine, according to an old story, she accidentally stepped on the executioner's foot and politely excused herself with a "Pardon, Monsieur." This tale, together with many similar ones that have appeared in most biographies of the French Queen, is dismissed by Stefan Zweig, latest biographer, as "too good to be true."

See Late Spurt in Accessories. No marked increase in consumer buying of accessories for Easter has yet developed, owing to the desire of many customers to purchase these items after they have bought their coats and dresses, it was reported here yesterday.

The third and fourth floors of l,263-65 Lexington Av. were sublet for occupancy as a dwelling and furnished rooms by the Pilrose Holding Co., Inc., to Emma Cichy for three years from March 1, 1933, at rentals of $2,280 for the first year, $2,400 for the second year and 2,520 for the third year. A prior lease has been terminated.

WASHINGTON, March 31 (AP). -- Lacking only the pen-scratch of the President's signature to promulgate it, an Executive order designed to save annually some $400,000,000 in veterans expenditures rested tonight at the White House.

ALBANY, March 31. -- A special message calling for amendments to the State banking law to enable State banks and trust companies to take full advantage of Federal assistance was sent to the Legislature today by Governor Lehman.

The Louis K. Liggett Company, which operates a chain of 450 retail drug stores in thirty-five States and has its principal offices at 41 East Forty-second Street, filed a petition in bankruptcy yesterday through W.E. Watt, its vice president.

CHICAGO, March 31. -- Reports of earnings issued today by four operating units of the Middle West Utilities System reflect the changes in financial policy effected by the receivership management. In somecases the operating revenues held up fairly well, but the necessity for additional depreciation reserves, appropriations for investment losses coupled with the general economic situation resulted in material curtailment in net income.

On the application of Dorothy Weissman Nisinoff, an owner of $130 worth of capital stock of the Irving Trust Company, Federal Judge John C. Knox signed an order yesterday requiring the trust company to show cause on April 11 why it should not he enjoined from acting as receiver in virtually all bankruptcy cases in this district.

The American Lutheran Publicity Bureau, the headquarters of which are at 1,819 Broadway, has appointed a committee to be known as the Lutheran anniversary committee to outline a program for the celebration in November of the 450th anniversary of the birth of Martin Luther.

WASHINGTON, March 31. -- President Roosevelt will be asked next week to approve an extensive naval construction program designed to bring the fleets up to the approximate strength fixed for the United States by the Treaty of London.

Because the array of counsel, clerks, stenographers and bondholders reminded him of a "mass meeting," Supreme Court Justice Philip J. MeCook would not accede yesterday to a request of owners of bonds of S.W. Straus Co., Inc., that he hold in his chambers the hearing on a motion of Samuel L. Chess, attorney, 17 John Street.

PHILADELPHIA, Saturday, April 1. -- In one of the most surprising developments in the forty-year history of the Intercollegiate Fencing Association, New York University exceeded the fondest hopes of its followers early this morning by winning three of the four team championships in the opening session of the tournament in the Penn A.C. gymnasium.

HAVANA, March 31. -- A two-year mortgage moratorium measure and another authorizing President Machado to declare foreign-debt moratoriums were passed by the House of Representatives at an all-night session that terminated at 7 o'clock this morning.

BERLIN, March 31. -- The Boerse continued to decline today, especially stocks which were extremely weak again, with a negligibly few exceptions. All the favorite stocks which usually show large turnovers fell 2 to 3 per cent and more. Bonds also were weak, although some Reich issues, including the Hilferding Loan, advanced.
