PINEHURST, N.C., March 31. -- George T. Dunlap Jr., Walker Cup star, played the championship No. 2 course today in 33, 32-65, six under par, to break the amateur course record and lead a field of 111 players at the half-way mark in the thirty-six hole qualifying round of the North and South amateur golf championship.

The neat little structure taking shape on the Times Square traffic island at Forty-third Street that has piqued the curiosity of thousands of passers-by is the latest thing in police booths, Police Commissioner Mulrooney revealed yesterday.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., March 31. -- Although Federal authorities have investigated banking conditions here, the Citizens' Protective League, a taxpayers' organization, has petitioned President Roosevelt for a special inquiry. About $25,000,000 is held In closed and restricted institutions here and this has caused a strained financial situation.

Reaching out to add a distant strategic link to its widespread system of 26.000 miles of air-lines, Pan American Airways has acquired a substantial interest in the national air transport system of China, entering into a partnership with the national government.

The new Grace liner Santa Elena sailed on her maiden voyage to the West Coast yesterday afternoon after a ceremony at which Mayor O'Brien paid tribute to the enterprise and foresight of the company's founder and the spirit of present officials in following out their building program under adverse economic conditions.

One man was killed and two others, one of whom is a police lieutenant, were critically wounded last night in pistol battles which resulted from an attempted hold-up of a drug store in Ozone Park, Queens, and the burglary of a house in Rockville Centre, L.I. The dead man, a robber killed in the drug store shooting, was unidentified.

William McClellan was elected yesterday president of the Potomac Electric Power Company to succeed William F. Ham, who was elected chairman of the board of directors. Mr. McClellan also was elected a director of the company. Identical changes were made in the Braddock Light and Power Company, a subsidiary.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., March 31. -- Rain today forced a cancellation of the exhibition game between the Yankees and the Birmingham Barons, the first break in the training campaign of the Ruppert forces since the start on March 1.

WASHINGTON, March 31. -- President Roosevelt completed the changes from the prohibition regime, pending ratification of the repeal amendment, by signing today the bill removing virtually all restrictions from the prescription of liquor by physicians.

VATICAN CITY, March 31. -- Vatican prelates and workmen made their final preparations today for the Pope's inauguration of the Holy Year tomorrow and the opening of the Holy Door of St. Peter's. This will commemorate the 1,900th anniversary of the passion, death and resurrection of Christ.

WASHINGTON, March 31. -- Continued government aid for maintaining railroad credit and the preservation of "healthy competition among the different systems" were laid down as fundamental to any plan for dealing with the railroad situation in a statement by the board of directors of the United States Chamber of Commerce today on the eve of President Roosevelt's conference with groups interested in his emergency program for railroad rehabilitation.
WASHINGTON, March 31. -- Real estate foreclosure proceedings in 1932 showed an increase of 274.9 per cent over 1926, the Federal Home Loan Bank Board reported today after an exhaustive survey.

LONDON, March 31. -- Discussions between Norman H. Davis and Prime Minister MacDonald concerning plans for the early convening of the World Economic Conference progressed so satisfactorily today that Sir John Simon, as chairman of the conference organizing committee, was authorized to call a meeting of that committee April 10.

Autograph collecting has a place among the hobbies of President Franklin D. Roosevelt, it appears from a letter by him acquired recently by Thomas F. Madigan, autograph dealer, of 2 East Fifty-fourth Street. As such he is one of the few Presidents who have practiced this form of collecting, although various others have collected books, according to Mr. Madigan.

WASHINGTON, March 31. -- First hearings on President Roosevelt's Federal securities measure went swiftly forward today in House and Senate committees, developing some difference of opinion and bringing out testimony that of $50,000,000,000 in securities floated in this country in the last thirteen years half had proved either "worthless or undesirable."

WITH a packed house at the Garden looking for excitement in the hockey play-off, the Detroit Red Wings went to sleep on their skates and remained sleeping through the evening, except when the rude Rangers came clattering around the net to wake them up. The way the first episode in this feud was conducted, it's too bad that the second episode will be put on in Detroit.

The usual seasonal expansion in trade is being augmented by the progressive measures of the new administration, the force of which gives promise of carrying the movement beyond the objective set for this period, according to the weekly trade review of Dun Bradstreet, Inc.

Rear Admiral Richard E. Byrd, chairman of the National Economy League, said yesterday that the league would continue its work more vigorously than ever, now that its first great objective has been achieved in the passage of President Roosevelt's economy bill at Washington.

The Board of Estimate voted $5,000,000 yesterday for home and work relief in April and decided to hold a special executive session next week to consider asking further aid from the State and from Congress. With the $2,000,000 expected from the State and Federal Governments, the public relief roll in New York City will be $7,000,000 this month.

WASHINGTON, March 31. -- A self-liquidating loan of $2,800,000 to the Niagara Frontier Bridge Commission was authorized today by the Reconstruction Finance Corporation for the construction of two toll bridges over the east branch of the Niagara River on a proposed highway from Niagara Falls to Buffalo.
WASHINGTON, March 31. -- The Bureau of Navigation issued the following orders today, dated March 29:

Mayor O'Brien, informed last night of the declaration of Republican leaders in the State Legislature that control over the distribution of 3.2 beer rested with municipalities, said he would bend every effort consistent with the State's policy to provide the beer for New Yorkers on April 7, the date of national legalization.

PUTNEY-ON-THAMES, England, March 31 (Canadian Press). -- The usually quiet scene along the historic Thames will be gone tomorrow. Thousands will line the banks, the more fortunate being on trains which will run along the river at a level with the boats.
Prices on the Cotton Exchange fluctuated irregularly yesterday within a range of 15 points and ended 3 to 6 points lower than on Thursday.

Chancellor Adolf Hitler informed the United German Societies of New York through, a spokesman yesterday that "German Jews will be treated like all other nationals in accordance with their attitude to the national government."

"The Kingfish," by Webster Smith, is a book about Huey P. Long which all Louisiana book sellers, according to the publishers, Putnams, refused to stock. Published today, it traces, with many anecdotes, Senator Long's fast rise from self-confident farm boy to complete political power in Louisiana, the State he now serves as United States Senator.

The executive committee of the Republican Mayoralty committee appointed by W. Kingsland Macy State chairman, to arrange for a fusion ticket at next Fall's city election, met yesterday at Republican State headquarters and decided that it was too early to consider candidates or even to appoint a sub-committee to consider them.

The Appellate Division upheld yesterday the dismissal by Surrogate Foley of a contest of the will of George L. Duval of 300 Park Avenue, who left more than $1,000,000 and gave $387,500 to the Catholic University, the Catholic College of the Immaculate Conception, the Cenacle of St. Regis, the Convent of Presentation, in Ireland; Seton Hospital, the Home for the Aged of the Little Sisters of the Poor and three Roman Catholic institutions in Chile.
ALBANY, March 31. -- With the Legislature deadlocked in the fight over beer regulation, Governor Lehman decided tonight to take the issue of his control bill directly to the people of the State.

NEODESHA, Kan., March 31 (AP). -- Tragedy flew with a group of young Canadian athletes through bright Kansas skies today and ended in quick death and injury their sporting invasion of the United States.

Bidders representing banks continue to play important parts at foreclosure auctions. Fifteen Manhattan and Bronx parcels were offered at forced sales yesterday and ten of these were bought in for banking institutions. Most of the defaulted realty consisted of tenement houses.

TRENTON, N.J., March 31. -- Unless there is an unexpected change in plans, the State Commission on Control of Alcoholic Beverages will have ready Monday night for immediate enactment by the Legislature a bill to regulate the taxing, distribution and sale of 3.2 beer and wine from April 7 to May 15.

Suspension of exports of gold after March 4. following a loss of $158,818,500 through earmarking for foreign account, halted the steady drain on the supplies here which had started abruptly in February. Shipments were made under special licenses after the nation's banks were reopened, but the net loss for last month was kept smaller than that which had occurred in February.

Charles W. Gould, lawyer and trustee of the Metropolitan Museum of Art, who died March 18, 1931, at Santa Barbara, Cal., left an estate appraised yesterday at $1,790,376 gross and $1,595,956 net. Of the gross estate $1,645,401 was in securities.

Further weakness in the share market was attributed yesterday to the acute unsettlement in German bonds. This explanation was not altogether convincing, but it served the purpose of those who must assign a reason for any special movement.

The Bush Terminal Company, operating steamship piers, warehouses and terminals on the South Brooklyn waterfront, was made defendant yesterday in an equity suit brought by the Perth Amboy Dry Dock Company in Federal court in Brooklyn.

Miss Rosa Ponselle, soprano of the Metropolitan Opera Company, will sail on the Rex of the Italian Line this afternoon to sing for the first time in Italy. Tullio Serafin, conductor of the Metropolitan, also will depart on the Rex. Others on board, bound for Gibraltar, Nice and Genoa, are: Homer Saint-Gaudiens, sculptor; Pierre de Salis, Miss Moly Picon, actress; Mrs. Cooper Hewett, A.D. Sebastiani and Lieutenant Guglielmo Durantini of the Royal Italian Navy.

WOODMERE, L.I., March 31. -- Jumping from the roof of the Woodmere High School on Broadway here, Harold Lehman, 17-year-old high school sophomore, committed suicide today. He was found lying in an alleyway beside the two-story building at 12:30 P.M. and he died ot his injuries three hours later at St. Joseph's Hospital at Far Rockaway.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., March 31. -- Their battle won for action by the Legislature on the Pitcher bill, rebellious farmers in the Rochester area this afternoon called a halt until Monday in their war against the Dairymen's League which virtually has cut the league off from its normal sources of supply in Monroe and near-by counties for the last three days.

BERLIN, March 31. -- After a final day of preparation in which popular excitement was stirred up to a glowing climax, the great concerted anti-Jewish boycott that, beginning tomorrow morning, was to show the world what National Socialist Germany could do to a minority in defiance of world opinion has been modified to a daylong demonstration.

WASHINGTON, March 31 (AP). -- A long-pending suit over the right of radio station WNJ of Newark to continue broadcasting was ended today with a formal order from the Radio Commission ordering the station off the air.

Diametrically opposed viewpoints of judge and jailer regarding effective crime control were presented yesterday by Warden Lewis E. Lawes of Sing Sing prison and Judge Joseph E. Corrigan of the Court of General Sessions. Addressing a luncheon of the Advertising Club, Warden Lawes urged expansion of preventive agencies, while Judge Corrigan stressed the correctional function of prisons.
COLUMBUS, March 31 (AP). -- Phil Werner of the Elks No. 102 team of Altoona, Pa., landed among the leaders in the American Bowling Congress tournament today.

DECATUR, Ala., March 31. -- From a venire composed exclusively of white men, a jury was chosen in Morgan County Court House this afternoon for the retrial of Haywood Patterson, one of the nine Negro defendants in the Scottsboro case, after the defense lost its long, hard fight against exclusion of Negroes from the jury rolls.

Is the German capacity for blundering absolutely unlimited? Yesterday's half-hearted and wrong-headed modification of the universal boycott orders, proudly issued by the Nazis, is a perfect model of how not to do it. The very heading of the official proclamation: "Respite Granted the Foreign Atrocity Propaganda," fairly makes the intellect reel.

AIKEN, S.C., March 31. -- Dark Herod, a bay gelding owned by Thomas Hitchcock, won the hunter championship as the seventeenth annual Aiken horse show came to a close today. Another Hitchcock entry, Morning Mist, the chestnut gelding which triumphed last year, was awarded the reserve ribbon.

The Treasury Department's full monthly report of the stock, of a kinds of money In the United States as of March 1 shows the following principal changes in February, Gold earmarked for foreign banks is deducted; gold released from earmark is added:

Down on the east side there is a slum which old-timers will recall as "Lung Block." ERNEST POOLE gave it that name when he was living at the University Settlement, in the days when tenement-house reform was still young and hopeful.

On behalf of American investors of $100,000,000 in Ivar Krauger's bankrupt International Match Corporation, a retainer of $2,000 was authorized here yesterday by Oscar W. Ehrhorn, referee, for two lawyers in Germany who will try to obtain for the American bankrupt a share in $1,000,000 annual profits of the German match monopoly which are about to be distributed.

Again PADEREWSKI shows himself premier among our foreign friends. Once more he offers his genius in behalf of his fellow-musicians who find themselves without occupation in these trying days. At the conclusion of his tour, as announced yesterday, he is to give his services for a benefit of the Musicians Symphony Orchestra at the Metropolitan Opera House on Monday evening, April 10.

After the arrest here late yesterday of six men who had planned, according to the police, to put into circulation $500,000 in counterfeit notes, all bearing a close resemblance to the new Chase National Bank issue, an alarm was broadcast to authorities in New England for the arrest of an alleged contact man known as Louis the Boot-legger.

At the annual meeting of the Yacht Racing Association of Long Island Sound, held in the Yale Club, Forty-fourth Street and Vanderbilt Avenue, last night, a full season's program of dates for the coming Summer was adopted.

WASHINGTON, March 31. -- An order to terminate the long-standing representation of the Union Pacific Railroad on the board of the New York Central, in which it holds 200,000 shares of stock, is expected soon from the Interstate Commerce Commission pursuant to a recommendation adverse to the interlocking directorate made by Oliver E. Sweet, head of the commission's bureau of finance.

WASHINGTON, March 31. -- A sample copy of an advertisement of securities such as would be required under President Roosevelt's Federal securities act, was presented to the House Interstate and Foreign Commerce Committee today by Huston Thompson, one of the authors of the measure.

BERLIN, March 31. -- Dr. Otto Wagener, one of Chancellor Hitler's most intimate advisers, said in an interview today that the anti-Jewish boycott would be called off the minute leading German Jews disassociated themselves from the so-called Eastern and migratory Jews and as soon as foreign governments compelled their Jews to cease anti-German propaganda.

Meeting at a forum of the New York City Federation of Women's Clubs for analysis of the economic problems involved in current legislative proposals, 250 women yesterday heard pleas for a minimum wage law for women to correct sweat-shop conditions, and for unemployment insurance as a means of doing as much for labor as is now done for inanimate machinery.

An attack on tendencies toward a "wide-open" Sunday marked yesterday's sessions of the annual East German Conference of the Methodist Episcopal Church, at the Second German Methodist Episcopal Church, 445 West Forty-third Street.

The Kansas City, Fort Scott Memphis Railway, a subsidiary of the St. Louis-San Francisco Railway, is to default in the payment of interest due today on its refunding 4 per cent bonds of 1936. This action is expected to hasten deposits of these securities under the Frisco's reorganization plan, which provides for payment of interest on the bonds at the present rate.

Writing about Edward Laning in the current issue of Creative Art, James W. Lane remarks: "Fortunately, he came under Kenneth Hayes Miller at the Art Students League." The adverb would seem to call for some dissecting. One may heartily agree that any student is fortunate in having so learned and accomplished a teacher; a teacher who, pedagogic duties aside, is such an excellent artist.

FORT WORTH, Texas, March 31. -- Combining excellent pitching along with some fine swatting, the Giants continued their astonishing form reversal against the Tigers today by recording their second straight triumph over the American Leaguers.

MUNICH, March 31. -- Without warning, the boycott of Jewish shops, scheduled to start tomorrow, began at midday today in Munich. In all parts of the city detachments of Nazi storm troopers, armed with rifles and pistols, were marched through the streets and posted as sentries at the doors of shops owned by Jews, where they remained until closing time.

BERLIN, March 31. -- Large crowds gathered this morning in front of the two chief court houses here and demanded the removal of all Jewish judges and attorneys. Among those who were forced to leave was Dr. Kurt Soelling, president of the Court of Appeal.

An appeal to teachers and other employes of the Board of Education to contribute $100,000 of their April salaries was made yesterday by Dr. William J. O'Shea, superintendent of schools, in a circular which calls attention to the aid given the school relief committee by the city work and relief committee and by the Red Cross.

Adolph Heuser, hard-hitting German light-heavyweight, registered his second victory over Harry Ebbets by defeating the Freeport battler in the feature bout of ten rounds at Madison Square Garden last night.

Despite the absence of a budget appropriation this year for park concerts, Mayor O'Brien said last night that he would make every effort to continue the band music that has been heard each Summer in twenty city parks.
BROOKLINE, Mass., March 31 -- Two former champions were eliminated in the semi-final round of the women's national indoor tennis championships on the Longwood covered courts, Chestnut Hill, today.

NEWARK, N.J., March 31. -- To meet the demands of bankers for further economies in government before a $3,000,000 loan will be granted to the city, William J. Egan, Director of Public Safety, ordered the dismissal today of 101 policemen and 100 firemen.

WASHINGTON, March 31. -- Extension of the stock market inquiry by the Senate to include a sweeping investigation of banking is provided in a resolution introduced for the Banking and Currency Committee today by its chairman, Senator Fletcher.

The Eastern Gas and Fuel Associates had total assets of $225,577,960 at the close of 1932, giving effect to subsequent acquisition of the controlling interest in the outstanding capital stock of the Koppers Coal Company by a subsidiary, the Koppers Coal and Transportation Company, according to the pamphlet report mailed today to stockholders.

WASHINGTON, March 31. -- Major A.V. Dalrymple of California was appointed today by Attorney General Cummings to succeed Colonel Amos W.W. Woodcock, whose resignation as director of the Bureau of Prohibition was announced.
WASHINGTON, March 31. -- Coming banking prosecutions in New York were discussed with Attorney General Cummings today by George Z. Medalie, United States Attorney, and Assistant Attorney Dewey.

BERLIN, March 31 (AP). -- Dr. Paul Joseph Goebbels, the Minister of Popular Enlightenment and Propaganda, preceded his reading of the government boycott manifesto to apacked National Socialist meeting here today by a declaration of Naziantipathy toward the Jews.

The problems of employment facing the younger generation and the housing conditions of the lower east side were among the phases of social welfare work that impressed a group of college students who completed yesterday a three-day tour of social institutions in various parts of the city.
To the Editor of The New York Times: A recent editorial of yours advocated a pleasant innovation -- the installation of outdoor bookstalls in Bryant Park.

One of the most tangled situations in the annals of the Kings County Court was settled yesterday with the conviction of Mrs. Anna De Hall on a charge of first-degree manslaughter for stabbing her 14-year-old son, Salvatore, three years ago.

Seven officials of the M. Berardini State Bank at 34 Mulberry Street, which was closed by the State Banking Department on Oct. 31, 1931, were indicted yesterday by the New York County grand jury on two charges of misapplying the bank's funds.

PALM BEACH, Fla., March 31. -- In compliment to Mr. and Mrs. Pierre Lorillard of Tuxedo Park who are at the Breakers, Mrs. Henry Morgan Tilford entertained tonight with a dinner at the Beach Club. The guests included:

George Fissler, 26-year-old New Yorker who learned to swim as a youngster in the city's indoor pools, and Leonard Spence, the country's leading breast stroke star, shared the individual honors in the second day of national A.A. U. championship competition at the New York A.C. last night.

PARIS, March 31. -- At the same hour tomorrow when the official German anti-Jewish boycott is scheduled to become effective, Jews and sympathizers in France will proclaim a boycott on German goods if plans announced tonight are carried out.

Princeton and Harvard, West Point and the Pennsylvania Military College start pursuit tonight of the first national championship to be decided in indoor polo this season -- the intercollegiate. At Squadron A Armory in Manhattan, Princeton and Harvard meet in a first-round match in the tournament, the winner to face Tale Thursday night.

PHILADELPHIA, March 31. -- With the aid of several soloists, a large chorus of men and boys and several electrical innovations, the Philadelphia Orchestra, with Leopold Stokowski conducting, presented the entire first act of Wagner's "Parsifal" in concert form before an audience that filled to capacity the Academy of Music this afternoon.

GENEVA, March 31. -- The hint in the House of Commons yesterday that Britain had been considering bringing German anti-Semitism before the League of Nations Council aroused interest here, but so far has not been, followed by any British move.

The Pioneer Air Transport Operators, an association with headquarters in Washington, and made up of executives of the air transport lines holding government malt contracts, has been dissolved by consent, it was revealed here yesterday.

Dealings in bonds on the New York Stock Exchange in March amounted to a par value of $192,056,200 divided as follows: Corporations, $89,882,000; United States Government, $54,288,700; foreign, $47,885,500. The month's total was $39,483,500 less than in the previous month, and $60,627,000 less than in March, 1932.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I am not anti-Semitic, I am not of German blood. I believed in the ideals and ideologies of 1917-18. It pains me greatly that THE NEW YORK TIMES should print an editorial today against Germany called "A Moral Tribunal," reinforcing "the spontaneous emotions of enlightened men and women," which have swept our land in the last few days.

Large income taxpayers, more than any other group, availed themselves of the sixteen-day extension of the time limit for filing returns and making tax payments, according to William Duggan, Collector of Internal Revenue for the First New York District, who announced that a rush of big taxpayers had been noted at the Custom House yesterday, the last day of the time extension.

A precipitate decline in German bonds, which reflected the growing anxiety of investors who are weighing the possible economic consequences of the threatened trade boycott in Germany, was the incident of overshadowing interest in the markets yesterday.

Frederick Debes, for forty-four years a clerk in the registry division of the City Hall Postoffice, retired yesterday. During his years of service, most of which were spent at the bank delivery window, great sums passed through his hands.

Mayor O'Brien has approved the plans for a $30,000,000 recreation centre In Marine Park, Brooklyn, submitted by Charles Downing Lay, landscape architect, to the Mayor's office more than a year ago during the Walker administration, it became known yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 31. -- The reforestation bill, third of the administration's major proposals, was signed by President Roosevelt today. Preparations were immediately hastened by the various departments to put it into effect and give work to 250,000 men.

BUENOS AIRES, March 31. -- President Gabriel Terra of Uruguay dissolved the Uruguayan Congress and National Administrative Council, assumed dictatorial powers and appointed a junta of eight notable civilians to assist him in administrative functions until such time as the Constitutional Assembly which he plans to call reforms the Constitution and sets up a new administration.
Even amid the cheering rays of The Baltimore Sun, Mr. FRANK KENT looks darkly at the Senate:
Women's Vote in Spain. All existing doubts about the stability of the Spanish Republic may now be dismissed. The Spanish politicians are watching the women's vote.

A "beer orgy" that may last five or ten years and defeat the wet program for prohibition repeal was forecast yesterday afternoon by Miss Helen H.G. Estelle, corresponding secretary of the New York State W.C.T.U., in an address at the Central Queens Young Men's Christian Association, Parsons Boulevard and Ninetieth Avenue, Jamaica, Queens.

Wide fluctuation in rates for all classes of loans and financial paper, reminiscent of movements in 1929, featured the money market last month. The irregularity was attributed to rapid changes in the banking system, which was under heavy pressure of withdrawals of deposits by the public.

WASHINGTON, March 31. -- Despite a number of hints from Paris official quarters that France would prefer Washington as the meeting-place of the World Economic Conference, and although there is some British sentiment of the same kind, the meeting will be held in London, as scheduled, unless Prime Minister MacDonald joins the procession.

WASHINGTON, March 31. -- Declaring that the original five-year air corps program for 1,800 fighting airplanes now in its seventh year has not been completed, Major Gen. Benjamin D. Foulois. Chief of the Army Air Corps, told the House Military Affairs Committee today that in his judgment the program would provide just half the planes needed to put the Army aviation service in the position this country should occupy among first-class powers.

MIAMI, Fla., March 31. -- The mile track record was lowered at Tropical Park today when the Man of War gelding, Sea Fox, bearing the colors of J.F. Somerville, led from start to finish to win the featured offering in 1:37 1-5.

The trial of four election inspectors of the Fifth Election District of the Fourth Assembly District on fraud charges before Supreme Court Justice Daniel V. McNamee of Hudson began yesterday, but was delayed until a new juror was chosen to replace Joseph Hirsch, a clothier, of 614 West 157th Street, who recalled' that he had had real estate dealings with an uncle of Nathan Silver, one of the defendants.
WASHINGTON, March 31. -- Reorganizations had permitted 265 national banks to obtain licenses for 100 per cent operation up to the close of business March 25, Secretary Woodin announced today.

PARIS, March 31. -- Opposition in France to the four-power European "directorate" proposed by Premier Mussolini of Italy has been stiffening in the French press during the past few days. The government is bombarded with demands to come out flatly against the plan.

A resolution to investigate coal freight rates generally was adopted yesterday at a meeting of the Presidents' Traffic Conference in the Pennsylvania Station. The committee was formed as part of the rail-roads' move to reduce competitive wastes. It aims to reduce destructive rate-cutting.

Praise of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation for its approval of the loan for the Knicker-bocker Village project and for its previous aid to two other New York State projects was expressed in statements issued yesterday by former Governor Smith, Robert Moses, Darwin R. James and Peter Grimm.

BERLIN, April 1. -- It was reported in diplomatic circles today that Baron Constantin von Neurath, the Foreign Minister, resigned last night because he was opposed to the launching of the Nazi's anti-Jewish boycott, fearing bad effects on international relations.

Carrying out recommendaitons adopted last December by the International Radio and Telegraph Conference in Madrid, the cable and radio companies serving the United States discontinued yesterday their week-end letter service to foreign countries.

RECENT instances of official action or initiative and events in two hemispheres illustrate the urgency and importance at this moment of the problem, of controlling the traffic in munitions. What are the main issues involved in this question?

Three generations of President Roosevelt's family are working for the success of the Children's Easter Fair to be held during the week of April 10 at Saks-Fifth Avenue, the proceeds from which will be devoted to the babies' wards of the New York Post-Graduate Hospital.

Credit association and other opponents of the move on the part of legal groups to oust the Irving Trust Company as receiver in bankruptcy cases are preparing to shift their fight to Washington, following Senator Copeland's introduction during the week of the New York State Legislature's resolution which memoralized Congress to enact legislation discontinuing the Irving Trust monopoly of receivership cases.

A suit against Mrs. Ruth Sheppard of 1,021 Park Avenue, for dancing lessons and for being escorted to tea dances, dances and balls, was disclosed in the Supreme Court yesterday, when Mrs. Sheppard applied for particulars from Alex V. Thompson, who charged that $6,700 was due him and that leges that between April, 1930, and only $1,200 had been paid.
PARIS, March 23. -- For the first time in the history of the Paris Horse Show, women entrants have this year been permitted to ride astride, and are being greeted with applause when they do.
MIAMI, Fla., April 1. -- The Keeneland Stud's Don Romiro set a new six-furlong track record as the Florida racing season came to an end today with a benefit card at Tropical Park.

Belief that the action of the Colombian Government last week in decreeing a moratorium on the external debt payments constitutes the first step in a movement to scale down Colombian foreign loans was expressed yesterday by the Independent Bondholders Committee of the Departments and Municipalities of Colombia, which is headed by Robert L. Owen, former Senator from Oklahoma.
CHICAGO, April 1 (AP). -- A charge that two vast railroad systems had broken, faith with their union employes was made today and promptly denied by the railroads involved.

WASHINGTON, April 1. -- Financial aid for insurance companies through purchase of their preferred stock by the Reconstruction Finance Corporation is provided in a bill which the Senate Banking and Currency Committee voted today to report favorably on Monday.

A great many rounds of golf have been contemplated during these last few Spring-like days. Those who devote yearly a share of their recreation to participation in golf tourneys may assure themselves that within a few weeks the tournament season will be in full swing.

A plan has been presented to security holders and other creditors of the National Electric Power Company and three subsidiaries, all bankrupt, providing for the grouping under a new company of utility properties which had gross revenues of nearly $12,000,000 in 1932.

Goshen, N.Y., where the famous Hambletonian will be trotted during the Grand Circuit meeting, Aug. 14 to 18, inclusive, has taken on renewed activity during the past few weeks. There were quite a few trotters and pacers stabled there during the Winter, but the Southern, strings have begun to arrive.

AUCKLAND, New Zealand, April 1. -- England today declared in its first innings of the second test cricket match against New Zealand with a score of 548 runs for seven wickets, after Wally Hammond, Gloucestershire slugger, had hit up 336 not out to establish a new batting record for test matches.

IN any large collection of paintings, such as those to be shown presently for the benefit of the adopt-a-family committee, there are always a number that draw the interest aside from the central theme into by-paths of more intimate pleasure.

Men in reduced circumstances, compelled to make sacrifices of all kinds, cling with the tenacity of despair to their social status until the very last minute, according to the experience of the staff of Hartford House, Y.M.C.A., 109 West Fifty-fourth Street, which announced yesterday that a few vacancies were available on credit to young men, 20 to 40 years old, of good educational background and business experience.

A kerosene price war has started in China between the Soviet and the international oil companies operating there. The cause, it is said, is underselling by Russians in their attempt to gain a larger share in one of the biggest kerosene markets of the world.

JAPAN'S announcement that she intends to withdraw from the League is the second notice of the kind before that body. Mexico served notice last December, and her withdrawal will become effective after two years unless she rescinds her action.

With the new administration addressing itself determinedly to the regulation of Wall Street, the financial focus shifted back to Washington last weels. The developments there were witched apprehensively. The securities bill which has been introduced in both houses of Congress goes further than was expected.

BERLIN, April 1. -- The National Socialists' one-day boycott of the Jews was observed throughout Germany today and whatever its economic results, "was orderly almost everywhere. In Berlin, where foreigners had the best opportunity of observing its operations, it was entirely so.

Immediate action by the city to become a party to the Interborough receivership proceedings was demanded, yesterday by Samuel Untermyer, former special counsel to the Transit Commission, in a letter to the Board of Estimate. The city's "persistent and unreasonable" refusal to contest the receivership, Mr. Uutermeyer declared, will not only jeopardize the five-cent fare on Interborough elevated lines, but will saddle upon the city some $2,000,000 of charges in connection with the receivership.

IT was natural that the economy crisis should have loomed large in the proceedings of the Amercan Chemical Society, which met last week in Washington Rightly or wrongly, chemistry was extolled as a driving force in work recovery.

In the successful effort made in Washington to reform the Federal pension system the National Economy League played an important part. Its searching analyses of the costs of veterans' relief and its demonstration of the fact that more than $400,000,000 a year has been spent on account of non-service-connected cases helped to shape the public opinion which President ROOSEVELT mobilized so effectively.
PUTNEY-ON-THAMES, England April 1. -- Cambridge University's eight made rowing history today by winning the annual crew race on the Thames from Oxford for the tenth successive year.

WASHINGTON, April 1. -- President Roosevelt gave himself two hours off today to watch the hardriding cavalry troopers at Fort Myer, Va., go through their paces, and a gray-haired top sergeant will never forget it.

HOT SPRINGS, Va. -- Two major sporting events, the third annual Old Dominion women's golf championship and the annual Spring tennis tournament, will vie for the attention of the colony during the week of April 24.

LONDON, March 24. -- In these years of the world crisis we have witnessed so many financial and economic troubles that we can consider ourselves hardened. Still the swift collapse in London of German moral values is staggering. Hitler and his followers, in the space of a few days, have achieved this incredible result by their attack on the morality and culture of their own country.

WILMINGTON, Del., March 30. -- The 1933 session of the General Assembly of Delaware has gone progressive in a manner unparalleled since Civil War days, and the new laws being placed on the statute books, initiated largely by a Democratic House, promise to be the most radical in the State's long history.

A tentative bill to enact emergency legislation granting industry relief from the restrictions of the anti-trust law has been prepared by the committee on commerce of the American Bar Association and will be presented for general discussion at the annual meeting of the committee, to be held at the New York State Chamber of Commerce Building on April 12, it was learned here yesterday.

With the retirement last week of Rear Admiral Frederic R. Harris as general chairman of the Professional Engineers' Committee on Unemployment, a statement was made available for the first fifteen months of the organization's existence, showing that the total relief afforded for that period was about $1,177,000.

Hubert Scott-Paine, challenger for the Harmsworth Trophy, is to try out his new boat, Miss Britain III, on Lake Garda, Italy, where the international motor boat racing is to be held again this year. The boat is being built at Hythe.

WASHINGTON, April 1 (AP). -- A White House conference brought an agreement today on legislation for development of the Tennessee Valley, including restoration of the Muscle Shoals power and nitrate plant.

BERLIN, April 1. -- Professor Albert Einstein's bank balance of 5,000 marks (about $1,200) and 25,000 marks (about $6,000) in securities belonging to him were seized by the Nazi Government today "to prevent their use for treasonable purposes. "

RICHMOND, March 30. -- Failure of T.R. Hocutt, Negro waiter in a Durham hotel, to obtain a mandamus compelling the University of North Carolina to admit him to its pharmacy course, merely postpones a final show-down in the courts on the question whether Negroes are entitled to enter institutions of higher learning in the Tar Heel State.

BERLN. IT is a moment of great jay for tie critic when he discovers a talent of extraordinary breadth and depth. Such a happy moment comes to me today as I introduce to American readers the hitherto quite unknown author.

WHAT are the effects of mixing alcohol with gasoline in an automobile engine? How does the blend affect horsepower, carburetor action and motor knock? Headed by Beekman Pool of the Harvard Club, national and metropolitan champion, who succeeds his brother, J. Lawrence Pool, as the top man, five new members appear in the ranking first ten of the Metropolitan Squash Racquets Association.

Some Method of adjustment is urgently needed, points out Lewis H. Pounds, president of the Long Island Chamber of Commerce, whereby the home buyer may be able to meet his mortgage obligations. Financial help for these problems, he adds, is particularly needed by many small home buyers on Long Island.

Radio stations carried to American listeners yesterday the voice of Pope Pius XI as he delivered a brief invocation in the Vatican at Rome on the occasion of the illumination of a great cross on Mount Senario, near Florence, signifying the beginning of the Holy Year.

Troops, planes and anti-aircraft equipment from army posts in ten States will begin to assemble in the vicinity of Fort Knox, near Louisville, Ky., this week to rehearse for another act in the long drama of the plane versus the gun.

MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, April 1 (AP). -- Nearly every Opposition leader was under arrest or had sought asylum in foreign legations today as President Terra's day-old dictatorship became more nearly absolute.

Some of the country's finest collections of art treasures are being made available in the interests of charity, with the result that during this month and next several notable exhibitions will be held in aid of Mrs. August Belmont's adopt-afamily committee, an important phase of unemployment relief.

BERLIN, April 1. -- Prices soared at today's session of the Boerse and the greater part of the sharp losses recorded early in the week were made up in the course of a few hours. The upward movement received particular momentum from the scarcity of securities available for those who were anxious to rebuy what they had sold for fear of repercussions from the boycott of Jews.

NOVELTY and diversity are the keynotes in broadcasting this week. Celebrations of the return of legalized beer in Chicago, Milwaukee and St. Louis will go on the air. There will be a transoceanic debate between Columbia University and Oxford.

WASHINGTON, April 1 (AP) -- Communications from John C. Hull, director of the securities division of the Massachusetts Department of Public Utilities, and Waldo S. Kendall, prominent Boston broker, urging government action regarding unlisted departments of Stock Exchanges have been presented to the Senate by Senator Walsh of Massachusetts.

In the Brown House of Munich, Hitler's former headquarters, the portrait of II Duce decorates the desk of the Nazi chieftain The brown shirt of the Hitlerites is a pale imitation of Mussolini's black shirt.

Pressure against German, bonds was relaxed yesterday and the sharp losses of the day before were erased, with a small margin to spare. Stocks marked time, speculative impulses having been suppressed to a large extent as a result of the steps that have been taken in Washington looking to Federal supervision of the security business.

AIDE choice of symphonic music is offered to concertgoers during the current week. The PhilharmonicSymphony this afternoon presents the second of its series of all-Beethoven programs; tomorrow evening the Musicians Emergency Aid, under the direction of Walter Damrosch, will be heard at the Madison Square Garden, with Fritz Kreisler and Sergei Rachmaninoff as soloists.

BERLIN, March 31. -- By a stroke of the pen the Hitler government has given definitive shape to the Reich's Economic Council, which in the republic's fourteen years of existence had never emerged beyond "provisional" organization and recently had fallen into such desuetude that most German citizens had forgotten its existence, although it was originally conceived as an "economic parliament" of all but conjoint dignity with the Reichstag.

The banking system of the country is facing revolutionary changes in its structure, practices and philosophy as a result of the crisis through which it passed last month. Although the full extent of the banking reform cannot be estimated until the program of legislation formulated by the administration in Washington has been disclosed, there are already ample signs of a "new deal' in the banking world.

MR. PITTS SANBORN, the music critic who in 1929 gave us "Prima Donna,'' a distinguished novel of the operatic world, now finds his theme in high society -- specifically that of the richer Knickerbocker aristocracy. The central figure in this tale of Manhattan blue-bloods is Robert Fleming, a blond giant from the West, erstwhile right tackle of Elkhorn College's varsity.

Under the auspices of the United Youth Committee Against Fascism, 500 persons marched yesterday to the German Consulate, 17 Battery Place. The meeting, originally heralded as "a demonstration against German Fascism," was chiefly devoted to the exploitation of the Mooney and Scottsboro cases, the distribution of petitions demanding the immediate recognition of Soviet Russia and the collection of funds.

DUBLIN, April 1. -- Scotland today won the undisputed international rugby championship for 1933, defeating Ireland, 8 to 6, in the final game. The Scots piled up a lead of 4 to 3 at half-time and had to rally to gain the advantage in the last period.
MEMPHIS, Tenn., April 1. -- The Yankees failed to hit today and as a result they dropped the first of their two-game exhibition series to Memphis by 5 to 4.

To the Editor of The New York Times: With the spirit of nationalism rampant throughout the entire world and the disarmament conference apparently foredoomed to an unhappy end, one cannot help ask: What is the reason for this mad desire on the part of each nation to arm itself to the teeth and glare defiantly across its borders at its neighbors?
In at least seventeen States and parts of two other States 3.2 per cent beer may be sold on Friday.

The provision in the 8 per cent sales tax recently enacted in Illinois, making it mandatory for retailers to pass the levy on to consumers, will be cited by the local retailers' committee, headed by Grover Whalen, general manager of John Wanamaker, when it goes to Albany this week to present its arguments at the hearing on sales tax legislation.

WASHINGTON, April 1. -- The partners in J.P. Morgan Co. have been notified to hold themselves ready to appear as witnesses in the stock market inquiry being conducted by the Senate Banking and Currency Committee.

DENVILLE, N.J., April 1. -- The streets of this township in the North Jersey lake resort area will be dark tomorrow night because of a refusal of township officials to renew a contract with the New Jersey Power and Light Company, without a sharp reduction in rates.

PADEREWSKI will give his services for the benefit of the Musicians Symphony Orchestra of 200 unemployed musicians when he appears in the double role of soloist and composer at a concert of the orchestra on Monday evening, April 10, at the Metropolitan Opera House.

To the Dramatic Editor: Are you quite fair to "the citizenry"? You must know that the public is going to see Alfred Lunt, Lynn Fontanne and Noel Coward, and not "Design for Living." But do you know that many people are not going because they are afraid something will be spoiled for them? Many of us have wanted to see the Lunts in anything they did, but this time we find that we are afraid.

BURLINGTON, Vt., March 30. -- Vermonters have set their financial house in order and are prepared for the worst while hoping for the best. The Vermont Legislature which adjourned last Saturday after a session lasting eleven weeks and three days, cut the State budget to $14,071,281, a reduction of approximately 25 per cent.

AS the time draws near for the legalization of beer, new life is being breathed into industries dormant since proprohibition days, and many lines of business drooping under the depression are hoping soon to get the red ink out of their ledgers.

PINEHURST, N.C., April 1. -- George T. Dunlap Jr., Walker Cup star, scored 35, 37 -- 72 today for a thirty-six-hole total of 137, which gave him a thirteen-stroke lead on the field and enabled him to win the qualifying medal in the thirty-third annual North and South amateur golf championship.

At a time of great economic depression like the present, when our Chief Executive is giving us a vigorous leadership in the formulation of constructive plans for economic recovery, it is the patriotic duty of all classes of citizens to support the President.

FRANCHOT TONE, who makes his talking picture debut in "Gabriel Over the White House" at the Capitol this week, is a graduate of Cornell University, where he was a member of Phi Beta Kappa, honorary scholastic fraternity.

PARIS. -- Mid-Lent, although the popular celebration of the day has only reminders of its oldtime gayety, is still a time for entertaining. On Mi-Careme night the fashions of the last century were passed in review at the Bagdad Restaurant in the Faubourg St. Honore to the amusement of the guests.

The collection of paintings formed "by the late Burton Mansfield of New Haven, Conn., consisting largely of works by nineteenthcentury American painters, will be sold at auction on Friday evening at the American Art AssociationAnderson Galleries, Inc.

More than 250 Barnard College students, representing the sophomore and freshman classes, will engage in the thirtieth annual Greek festival of the Pythian Games, a traditional contest in athletic events, lyric and music writing, costume designing and, dancing, to be presented in the college gymnasium on Saturday afternoon, at 3 o'clock.

THIS is a British book, written by British men and women on aspects of British life doling the half century it covers. But it has for American readers much interest and considerable consequence, since the question that is implicit in every one, and is some- times brought prominently into the foreground, is that query which is everywhere so much mooted nowadays, is the world better or worse for its modern scientific and mechanical developments?

MADRID. EVENTS in Spain are rapidly moving toward some sort of a climax. There may be an explosion soon, unless the present government is able to reconcile the disintegrating force of the Left and the Right.
A request that the State put no "further burdens" upon industry through social or labor legislation was made to Albany yesterday by twenty-two industrial leaders.

SIXTEEN courses in radio broadcasting and program building are being offered in colleges and universities of the United States, according to replies to an inquiry by the Federal Office of Education. More than fifty other institutions of higher learning, which do not offer formal courses in this field, report that they provide some instruction in broadcasting in connection with other courses or to voluntary groups in the university.

Six new ministers were admitted to full membership on the approval of the New York Conference of the Methodist Episcopal Church at the third day's session of the annual meeting of that body, held yesterday in the Metropolitan Temple, Seventh Avenue and Thirteenth Street.

Substantial progress has been made in the last two weeks toward the resumption of normal insurance business after the general shut-down during the banking holiday. Already the Commissioner of Insurance for Connecticut has expressed the opinion that it will not be long before the lifting in general of the emergency ban against the withdrawal of cash surrender values and the granting of policy loans from life insurance companies.

Hans Priwin, member of the executive committee of the Association of German National Jews, appealed last night in a transatlantic radio talk from Berlin broadcast here by National Broadcasting Company stations, for a cessatior of anti-German sentiment in this country.

SPRING car care this year has a dual aspect. Its more important phase is that which relates to preserving human life by restoring the car to a higher standard of safety. The other is the traditional one of bringing the ear to an efficiency level that will make its operation more enjoyable and less expensive.
LONDON, April 1. -- The London Times publishes what it describes as "a fully authenticated case of political violence in Germany."

MOSCOW, April 1. -- Foreign dipplomatic circles here seem to believe the Anglo-Soviet tension is greater than appears on the surface. It is being currently reported that the British Ambassador will not return to Moscow and that the "British Embassy is already packing up for departure," which is not true.

While foreign traders here last week were hailing the "dawn of a new era in this country's tariff history," protectionist groups, including the American Tariff League, prepared to demand an opportunity to be heard by Congress when that body considers any legislation delegating wide powers to President Roosevelt in the negotiation of reciprocity tariff agreements with other nations.

HARTFORD, March 30. -- To what degree the State shall constitute itself the guarantor of the municipalities it has chartered, to support their poor and alleviate the burdens of their taxpayers, is developing into one of the major problems of the Connecticut General Assembly.

DIEGO RIVERA is again the centre of a raging controversy. and his new job at the RCA Building in the Rockefeller Center is likely to provoke another. For the story of his life and the story of his work is a gory of controversies, in which ike Bernard Shaw, he accumulates on alps and glory, and, as with Shaw time skewers his dragons and blurs the issue.

WASHINGTON, April 1 (AP). -- Leaders of both the opposing factions of oil producers and their representatives tonight claimed a victory at the administration-sponsored oil conference which assembled here this week.

WASHINGTON, April 1. -- The administration's farm relief bill will be reported to the Senate Monday in substantially the form in which it was sent to Congress, except for the elimination of cattle and sheep from its provisions

Extensive private label lines of grocery products are promoted by 40.2 per cent of the representative voluntary chain grocery organizations throughout the country, according to data compiled by the American Institute of Food Distribution in its study, "The Voluntary Chains -- an Adjustment in Relationships and Methods," reports on which are being sent out this week.

A unique experiment in the rearing and distribution of pheasants has been undertaken by the Wisconsin Fish and Game Commission. The commission has decided to attempt to raise for game purposes the dark pheasant.

PARIS. THE French capital has been offered many new French pictures in recent months, without counting the foreign ones, and in addition there are three film houses of comparatively recent vintage that the American visitor to Paris might well include in even a hasty itinerary.

While business on the Stock Exchange yesterday was more active than on the previous Saturday, speculative impulses were so feeble that fluctuations were held within the narrowest range of the week. The composite index of averages showed a net decline of 6 cents.

ROME, April 1. -- High up on Mount Senario, which proudly rears its head between Florence and Bologna, an enormous illuminated cross stands brightly tonight, casting its light over half a dozen provinces on both sides of the Apennines from the Tyrrhenian Sea to the Adriatic Sea.

Complete severance of the financial connection between Loew's, Inc., and the Fox Film Corporation was foreshadowed yesterday when the Film Securities Corporation, formed by Fox to hold a 45.15 per cent interest in Loew's, failed to make complete payment of $20,000,000 of notes then due.

A preliminary report on the findings of the national survey of the education of teachers, conducted by the United States Commissioner of Education under a $200,000 Congressional appropriation, will be offered at the eighth annual Spring conference of the Eastern States Association of Professional Schools for Teachers.

TRENTON, N.J., April 1. -- Twelve advisory masters were appointed today by Chancellor Campbell to handle all matrimonial cases. The Chancellor's action removes proceedings of this nature from the jurisdiction of vice chancellors, who heretofore have referred such cases to either advisory or special masters.

WASHINGTON, April 1. -- Warnings by Governor Lehman and others that abuses in legalizing beer may delay or prevent repeal of the Eighteenth Amendment will help the days to stop the repeal movement, according to Dr. F. Scott McBride, general superintendent of the Anti-Saloon League. He congratulated Governor Lehman and others of the same attitude on their "cooperation."

TOKYO, April 1. -- The foreign office dispatched today to the principal Japanese embassies abroad a statement of the reasons which, in the government's view, entitle Japan to retain possession of her mandated South Sea Islands in perpetuity regardless of secession from the League of Nations.

IMMORAL, unmoral, amoral, Lucky Baldwin was all at them, in numerous, varied and picturesque ways. So, at least, C.B. Giasscock portrays him in this first biography ever published of the man who was the most vivid and spectacular personality of all that amazing brood of multimillionaires that California produced during her heyday sixty years ago.

Offices of Collectors of Internal Revenue in New York City were nearly swamped yesterday by the largest volume of income-tax mail this year. While most of the collectors' offices were able to dispose of the bulk of tax mail by 1 o'clock, the closing hour, William Duggan, collector in the Second New York District, had no such luck.

GLASGOW, April 1. -- Scotland decided international soccer honors in favor of Wales today by scoring a 2-1 victory over England in the final game of the series. Wales won from Scotland and Ireland, and was held to scoreless tie by England to compile a near-perfect record with five points.

CHICAGO, April 1. -- In company with Mississippi and Indiana, Illinois is now experimenting with the sales tax. It went into effect today, and the once despised penny, already enhanced in value by recent stringency and low prices, reached a new height of importance.

AND so, too, do they look to the prospective reader as he turns the pages of Mr. Chase's book and gazes at the faces of the dozens of friends whom he has drawn for its illustration. So interesting are they that they are sure to lure him on to read the swarming procession of little anecdotes about them which marches through all the pages not filled with pictures.

Extensive changes In Instruction in American architectural schools are suggested by George Herbert Gray of New Haven, Conn., director of the New England division of the American Institute of Architects, "as a means of enabling building design to keep pace with scientific advances."

PRESUMABLY the editor of The London Mercury spends a lot of his time with literary folk and is only too intimately acquainted with their vanities and foibles. At any rate, this is the world which he satirizes in "Outside Eden." a collection of short stories.

STOCKHOLM. SOME of the new American and English books figure in the current Swedish critical surveys. "Ann Vickers," according to Frederick Book, one of the "eighteen" who make the Nobel Prize awards in literature for the Swedish Academy, does not surpass the Inimitable "Babbitt" but ranks as one of the best novels Sinclair Lewis has written.

The Salvation Army s united appeal for $1,100,000 for the support of emergency relief and institutional aid activities here will be inaugurated tomorrow night at a military dinner and mass meeting symbolizing the Army's "ceaseless war on hunger and distress," at the 107th Regiment Armory, Park Avenue and Sixty-sixth Street.

WASHINGTON, April 1. -- Nineteen enlisted men of the Marine Corps whose feats of valor during their recent Nicaraguan service won for them the commendation of the Navy Department will be decorated by the Nicaraguan Govvernment next Tuesday at the Marine Barracks at Quantico.

WASHINGTON, APRIL 1. -- The United States Government will await the presentation of the official statement of the Japanese Government concerning its right to retain its mandate in perpetuity before expressing any view on the Japanese position.

There will be no curtailment of the local racing season if the Legislature grants relief to the New York racing associations, George H. Buli, president of the Saratoga Association, said yesterday in sounding a note of optimism for the turf in 1933.

Returns to date indicate that net operating income for the Class 1 railroads in February declined 23.8 per cent from January and 54.1 per cent from February, 1932. Indicated gross revenue for February was down 5.4 per cent from January and 19.8 per cent from February, 1932.

PHILADELPHIA, April 1 (AP). -- Under rain-laden clouds and with a small attendance, the Athletics today won the first of five games for the city championship from the Phillies, 6 to 3. The Mackmen went out in front in the opening inning and were never headed.

SECOND in horror only to the vampire is the werewolf. The two are in fact closely akin, and where belief in the one is prevalent, fear of the other usually exists also. Very prevalent is that fear, for there are few nations in whose folklore some trace cannot be found of the fearsome creature who, man or woman by day, becomes at night a ravening beast, thirsting for human blood.

WASHINGTON, April 1. -- Democrats and that large heterogeneous political group which is enthusiastically following the President's program are pointing to Governor Lehman's troubles with the New York Legislature as another object lesson against party division between the Executive and law-making branches of an American government.

With measures now pending in the Legislature at Albany for relief of the racing associations in this State so that they may conduct meetings without losses, it is interesting to note that almost fifty years ago a petition was sent to the lawmakers with the same general purpose in view and signed by twenty-eight of the best known men in the United States at that time.

In the United States Law Review, Presiding Justice FINCH of the Appellate Division of the New York Supreme Court writes of Mr. ROOSEVELT as the twenty-third lawyer-President. Twenty-three of the thirty-two Presidents have been lawyers. He counts WASHINGTON, JACKSON, HARRISON, TAYLOR and GRANT as soldier-Presidents, but JACKSON was a lawyer and a judge as well as a soldier.

TUESDAY will mark the beginning of art's participation in the adopt-a-f amily campaign, conducted by a special committee of the Unemployment Relief Fund. On and for that day alone the residence of Lord Duveen of Milbank will be opened to the public.

BANANA BOTTOM' is of a different order from Claude McKay's other books. Some of the stories in "Gingertown," it is true, are also laid in Jamaica. But the more hard-boiled, sophisticated tales of Afro-American life, such as "Home to Harlem," are the ones best known.

DOBBS FERRY, N.Y., April 1. -- The Thursday Club gave an entertainment tonight, which included a cinema showing and fashion show at the Embassy Theatre, here, followed by a dance and entertainment at the Ardsley Club.

THE WHITE HOUSE, WASHINGTON, April 1. -- Before I came to the White House I confess that I was not a little worried at the prospect of how a house which was partly public and partly private on such a large scale as the White House could be run in order to provide for a family real peace and quiet and home life and still give the public all the rights which they should have.

MR. RICKARD is an eminent mining engineer who has won success also as editor and author, for he has written several other books on both mining and general subjects and through a good many years he served as editor for one or another of the important mining journals of this country and England.

DIFFERENT from ordinary puzzles and likely to have a very general appeal, this new piece of ingenuity by the authors of "The Baffle Books'' combines the elements of intellectual interest afforded by both puzzles and detective stories.
ALBANY, April 1. -- The lotus flower, famed in song and story, was the subject of a forty-five-minute debate in the Senate late this April afternoon.
Retirement of bonds in March before their dates of maturity made the smallest total for a month this year. The sum was $28,347,000, against $59,979,000 in February and $11,110,000 in March, 1932.

THE entrance of Pan America Airways into the International air picture in the Far East has been expected for some time. Germany is now engaged in her second attempt to pioneer an airway across Russia to China. Her Eurasia line over the high mountains northeast of Turkestan, shortening the time of travel between Berlin or Hamburg and the trade centres of China, is still in the making.

WASHINGTON. SINGES June 30, 1930, the end of the last fiscal year during which the Treasury Department had surplus of revenues over expenditures, the gross public debt of the United States has increased by slightly more than $5,000,000,000; on March 31 it was about $21,360,000,000.

George Z. Medalie, United States Attorney, began an unofficial investigation yesterday into the source of a mimeographed letter addressed to all Jews of the New York County Lawyers Association urging them to combat Hitlerism by electing only Jews as officers of the association next May.

THE parents of Daniel Kusell -- of the Vanderbilt (Theatre) Kusells and "The Party's Over". -- were divided in their, hopes as to his future career. His father thought he would make a respectable, and probably a very good, attorney.

MOSCOW. IT is a matter of course that the complete reorganization of all the conditions of life in the Soviet Union upon a Socialist basis did not stop at the door of the museums. The new regime in "classless" Russia, entirely devoted to the Idea of educating the masses, saw at once in the important heritage of museums from former epochs a great unused opportunity for methodical mass instruction.

HAVE you ever heard a palmist say: "I look at hands before I look at a face, they are more revealing"? Well this Spring and Summer we shall be following the palmist's lead by di recting our gaze to the hands; it will not be possible to escape them; they will bristle with character.
Gunners of the New York A.C. scored over Perm A.C. representatives in the second and last leg of the annual interclub shoot at Travers Island yesterday.

IT was not Andrew Jackson's lot to be one of those historic figures whose virtues it is a sort of sacrilege to doubt. He is, nevertheless, one of the two or three most interesting of our Presidents -- as Mr. James says, "only the names of Washington and Lincoln appear more often on the printed page."

LOS ANGELES, March 30 -- Reopening of the Mooney case by Judge Ward of San Francisco was received with only passing interest here. As a matter of fact, Mooney and his 17-year-old effort to get out of jail are more of a cause celebre in other parts of the country than they are in California.

The 127th annual meeting of the Medical Society of the State of New York will be held at the WaldorfAstorla tomorrow, Tuesday and Wednesday, with an expected attendance of 3,500 physicians from every county In the State.

THIS novel -- or rather this series of tales loosely compounded into a novel -- represents Margaret Widdemer in one of her most romantic moods. This, as her numerous readers will realize, is saying a good deal. For Miss Widdemer, since she wrote "The RoseGarden Husband" some years ago, has been a recognized mistress of light and popular romance.

MUNICH, April 1. -- Munich was a blaze of bunting today, flown everywhere -- on a hint that it would have been unwise to disregard -- to celebrate the one-day boycott of the Jews, which passed off without serious incident.
AIKEN. -- The coming week, despite the fact that the Aiken season reached its climax last Friday with the seventeenth annual horse show, will be well filled with sports activities.

DETROIT, April 1 (AP). -- Because eighty-seven, of Michigan's 100 State Representative districts voted last November for elimination of the State's bone dry constitutional provision, opponents of prohibition are predicting a decisive pronouncement in Monday's election in favor of repeal of the Eighteenth Amendment.
MORRISTOWN, N.J., April 1. -- Mrs. James Fitz Randolph, who was prominent in church and philanthropic work, died at her Madison Avenue home here this afternoon, after an invalidism of many years.

SHOULD a modern, successful business woman support a perfectly healthy, but permanently unproductive mate simply because they love each other? This is the marriage problem posed in this brightly written, somewhat trivial and shallow story.

PALM BEACH. -- The lazy Spring has set in and the Palm Beach colonists are engaged mostly in impromptu parties. For the most part they pass the days on the beach, where under vivid umbrellas bridge games and luncheons are held, or on the water, where many go on daily fishing expeditions to the Gulf Stream or on more prolonged trips among the keys.

MADRID, March 31. -- Spain's position on arms, as outlined by Foreign Minister Luis Zulueta, that any European disarmament proposal must be carried either to the League of Nations or the disarmament conference, where Spain is represented, for discussion and settlement, coincides with the position taken by Czechoslovakia's Foreign Minister, Edouard Benes, the Little Entente's spokesman, and shows a new spirit has grown up among the small nations since the war.

AMONG the lost causes rank idealism as one of the highest. The idealist is a lonely figure in the modern world. To judge by his fortune in the plays of this season, be is the one who gets slapped. Being a practicing idealist himself, Arthur Hopkins gave the young Hamlet of "Conquest" a Pyrrhic victory.

THERE is a subtle Oriental hormone in M. Cohen's blood which separates him from us by leagues and centuries. It will be difficult for the Western mind, which is still subconsciously dominated by inherited Greek notions of form and unity, to comprehend this strange, Byzantine composite, this magnificent, disordered work.
Nineteenth fellowships, including four renewals, were awarded by the Social Science Research Council for study in the United States and Europe during 1933-34, it was announced yesterday.

More scientific distribution of expense, yielding accurate data on the cost of doing business departmentally, was a major factor in the net profit showing for 1932 of quite a number of leading stores, according to analysis made during the week in retail quarters.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., March 30. -- The State is interested no less than Monroe County taxpayers as Rochester smooths the edges of a plan to unite the widely divergent city and county relief activities as a sort of laboratory experiment to wipe out welfare racketeering, unnecessary expense and the tinge of politics in a single decisive swoop.

MANUFACTURING a storm at sea, one that would have the appearance of a tropical hurricane, on an artificial lake at a motion picture studio, was one of the production difficulties that came up during the filming of the new Richard Barthelmess picture "Central Airport," which will arrive at the Strand Thursday night.

LONDON. A BY-PRODUCT of the present crisis is the rise of a popular demand for a class of publication that normally would appeal to only a comparatively small number of readers. A few years ago it would have been incredible that such books as Professor Laski's "Democracy in Crisis" and the new edition of Sir Arthur Sailer's "Recovery" could appear in the list of the best sellers of the week.

Among the bills before the Legislature providing for amendments to the real property law is one which would increase the responsibility of real estate brokers for the acts of their salesmen. This has been sponsored by the New York State Association of Heal Estate Boards.

PROFESSIONAL drys are not alone in regretting the imminent passing of the prohibition era. There are also those to whom prohibition has been of great material advantage a great group actuated by the ambition to retain power and to continue practically unmolested in the enjoyment of huge incomes.

PARIS. APARADOXICAL fact of modern chic is that informal evening dresses are apt to be much more decollete than formal ones. This is, by the way, the most distinctive sartorial sign of our epoch, which has decreed the twenty-four-hour sports day and prolonged the sunburn vogue Into the moonlight -- real or artificial.

THERE is no better illustration of the situation making a personality than the career of Marie Antoinette, Archduchess of Austria and Queen of France. She was evolved by a monstrous period and steeled in the fire of revolution.

DR. WALTER DAMROSCH will begin a series of Spring symphony concerts on April 11 at 10 P.M. over a, nation-wide network associated with WEAF, the New York outlet. Each program of one hour will be confined to the works of two noted composers.

BUENOS AIRES, April 1. -- Highly censored dispatches from Montevideo, Uruguay, coatinue to insist that President Gabriel Terra has the support of the armed forces of Uruguay and also of the police, and that his intervention in all public offices gives him control of the capital at least.

PROFESSOR FAIRCHILD'S "Profits or Prosperity?" posits a question which is likely to puzzle many. For is not prosperity dependent upon the opportunity to make profits vouchsafed to the investor of capital who hires labor to produce commodities for wages, thus creating purchasing power which increases prices and helps all forms of business share in the rewards of industry and trade?

The 238th session of the New York Yearly Meeting of the Religious Society of Friends opened yesterday at the Friends Meeting House, 221 East Fifteenth Street. The characteristics and effect of "vital religion" were discussed by S. Archibald Smith, principal of the Friends' Academy, Locust Valley, L.I., at the afternoon meeting for ministry and counsel.

GENEVA, March 31. -- It would be hard to exaggerate the satisfaction, to say nothing of the interest, with which, the return of Norman H. Davis to Europe as President Roosevelt's diplomatic representative was marked in this international nerve centre.

PARIS, April 1. -- Ambassador Henry de Jouvenel, returning from Rome today, "brought his government the latest fun account by Premier Mussolini of the four-power peace proposal made by the Italian statesman to Prime Minister MacDonald of Great Britain.
