Two of the leading scholastic basketball records compiled in this vicinity during the recently concluded campaign were registered by a pair of Yonkers quintets, namely, the Yonkers High School of Commerce five and the Yonkers High School squad.

PHILADELPHIA, April 1. -- Captain Jose R. de Capriles of the New York University team won the individual epee championship of the Intercollegiate Fencing Association at the Penn A.C. tonight to give the Violet swordsmen their fourth title, N.Y.U. captured three team crowns yesterday.

With retail trade maintaining its recent slight improvement, the volume of mail orders during the week continued heavy, according to the market report prepared especially for THE TIMES by Kirby, Block Fischer. The number of orders received indicated that there has been no change in the policy of maintaining low stocks, the buying office said.
PRAGUE, March 17. -- The Mayor of Teschen has taught the bureaucrats of Prague a lesson in the matter of their usual insistence on all applications being supported by documents.

THIS second novel by Mateel Howe Farnham succeeds in holding the reader's respect by its splendid depiction of character and locale. The author tells the story of Bella Price and her illegitimate son, Hugh, both of them members of a fine old family of Missouri, and throughout her telling she retains the integrity of manner and background of her people.

Maurica A. Stephenson, Deputy State Tax Commissioner heading the New York office, was appointed Budget Director for the city yesterday by Mayor O'Brien. He succeeds Charles L. Kohler, who retired because of poor health.

IT must have been a very stimulating experience to have lisened a year or so ago to Dr. Millikan delivering these McNair lectures to an eager audience at the University of North Carolina. For he has a robustness and forthrightness that carry conviction.

PINEHURST, N.C -- The professionals held the spotlight last week in the North and South open golf championship, and now the remaining weeks of the Pinehurst season will be devoted to amateur sport and accompanying social activities.

Hope that Hamilton Street, one block long, which extends diagonally across the two-block east-side tract on which the Fred F. French Operators, Inc., plan to erect a model housing development with the $8,073,000 lent by the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, can be purchased from the city for one dollar, the exact sum it cost the city in 1819, was expressed yesterday by the builders.

HOLLYWOOD. ONE of the town's oldest institutions, dormant for the past year, is to spring into life this week with the reopening of the Fox Hollywood studios. Once the home lot of Theda Bara, Gladys Brockwell, William Farnum, Milton Sills and Betty Blythe, stars of the cinema's more garish era, it rose to its greatest heights with "Cleopatra," "Queen of Sheba" and similar offerings which brought the word "colossal" into the vocabulary of every native.
ALBANY, N.Y., April 1. -- Governor Lehman and the legislative leaders failed tonight to reach an agreement on the program for new and additional taxation needed to balance the budget.

A GROUP of distinguished psychologists, neurologists and educators recently attended a meeting of the Advisory Council of the Normal Child, Development Clinic in New York and watched the antics of two identical twins eleven months old-that is, twins produced from a single cell.

STATION WLW's new $400,00 broadcasting plant, which will give Cincinnati the most powerful ethereal voice in the Unite States, is under construction an rapid progress is reported. The huge porcelain insulator which will serve as the base or cradle of the 831-foot vertical radiator antenn has been installed. The site of the 500,000-watt transmitter is Masor Ohio, near WLW's present 50,000 watt outfit.

Textile, George Washington and Evander Childs High Schools continued in a triple tie for the leadership in Division 1 by scoring triumphs, while James Madison and Abraham Lincoln High Schools, also victorious, remained in a deadlock for the Division 2 honors as the regular schedule in the city Public Schools Athletic League fencing championship tournament was brought to a close at the Washington Irving High School gymnasium yesterday morning.

The Federal bill to regulate the sale of securities that has been introduced in Congress for President Roosevelt is a step in the international movement toward more stringent regulation of corporations that apparently was set in motion in 1929 by the British companies act.

A BARTER plan, sacrifices on the part of the teachers and volunteer services on the part of the pupils are combining to keep open the School of Organic Education at Kairhope, Ala., Mrs. Marietta Johnson's pioneer progressive education school, which she has run heretofore mostly on gifts and little or no tuition.
PRINCETON, N.J., April 1. -- Bill Buffum's field goal in the last two minutes of play gave Princeton a 12-8 decision over the French Rugby Club of New York in a closely played game today.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, April 1 (AP). -- Joe Raaker of Cincinnati took the lead in the singles division of the American Bowling Congress today when he put together three games for an impressive total of 705 pins. Raaker replaces R. Knade of Chicago.
DETROIT, April 1. -- Officials of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation and General Motors Corporation met late today and effected a permanent organization of the new National Bank of Detroit.

CHICAGO, April 1. -- Wheat traders showed today little fear of what was regarded as Federal Farm Board selling of futures on the Board of Trade, and, while the board was credited with having sold actively, the offerings were absorbed readily by commission houses and local professionals.

Mr. Graves'a concise and illuminating book bears unmistakable marks of the duality of the author's attitude toward his subject. On the one hand he is the expert business tabulator and interpreter of statistical graphs relating to all phases of economic activity.

HAMILTON, Bermuda. -- The ninth series of the annual yacht races between the Bermuda One Design and the Long Island Sound Interclub classes takes place here this week and opens the season for Atlantic Coast yachtsmen.

THE SCHOOL FOR HUSbands," the Arthur Guiterman-Lawrence Langner adaptation in rhyme of Moliere, probably will be set back to the Fall some time. The Guild originally planned to produce it in the Summer, but there have been difficulties in casting.

WHEN will we have a real American opera? The old question is revived by two events of the season now closing. The first of these was the very successful production by the Metropolitan Opera Association, of Louis Gruenberg's setting of Eugene O'Neill's subject, "Emperor Jones."

The relative advantages and disadvantages of having one's money Invested in a piece of ground, bought when the market is at lowebb, will be weighed by investors, as compared with the disadvantages of hoarding it, points out Peter Forrest, counsel for the Twentythird Street Association.

TOKYO, March 9. -- A picture of Japan's economic position shows paradoxical contrasts. Textile exports are expanding in every market of Asia except China, and in spite of the Chinese boycott the value of Japan's exports in 1932 showed an increase of 23 per cent over 1931, and was only one-half of 1 per cent below 1930.

Frank Hulswit of Grand Rapids, Mich., a resident at the Hotel Astor for twenty years, was critically injured early this morning when he fell from a window of his fifth-floor apartment at the hotel to the top of a two-story extension on the west side.

WILMINGTON, Del., Apri 1 (AP). -- Christopher L. Ward Jr. of Wilmington and William J. Wardall of New York today were appointed receivers for the Associated Telephone Utilities Company of New York, which has subsidiary companies supplying telephone service in twenty-five States.

BOSTON, March 30. -- The towns of New England, some 1,500 in number, ranging in population from a few score to many thousands of persons, and in property valuations from a few thousands of dollars to many millions, now once more have provided the world with their annual demonstration of pure democracy.
VIRGINIA BEACH, Va., April 1 (AP). -- Winds blew and rain fell today, but failed to affect the golf of Paul Runyan, wiry little professional from White Plains, N.Y.

"In this book," says the author in his preface, "is a variety of writings that tell of the cowboy's riggings, the cowboy today, and why the high heels, the big hat and such like, along with experiences in narrow escapes that's all in the day's riding.

WHEN fiction enters the realm of the occult, it is required to satisfy a single test -- the test of objective reality, not as fact, but as fiction. Not proof of the thesis, not even its plausibility, is required. Suppose the author proposes to engage his ingenuities in presenting a dual personality, as did Stevenson with his "Dr. Jekyll and Mr. Hyde."

Bainbridge Colby, former Secretary of State, speaking last night at the annual dinner of the Bronx Real Estate Board, hailed Aldermanic President Joseph V. McKee as the next Mayor of New York City. Mr. McKee was toastmaster at the dinner, held at the Hotel Biltmore.

While many people will not find it possible to support every doctrine of the allocution proclaiming the Holy Year (which was yesterday ushered in by the opening of the Holy Door with pomp and penance), there will be a general joining in the hope that it will be "a year of spiritual exaltation" not only for "the whole Christian world" but for "all mankind."

SOUTHERN PINES, N.C. -- The season at Southern Pines is now nearing its height, and each day brings an influx of Northern visitors who are daily joining in a round of golf or riding the scenic bridle trail of Weymouth Heights.

In celebration of its thirty-fifth anniversary, the Charles F. Noyes Company has issued a booklet descriptive of the growth and accomplishments of the firm during the past thirty-five years. The Noyes concern was established in 1898 and now manages nearly four hundred buildings in New York City and employs about two thousand persons in its various departments.

WHILE public school salaries in half the States of the Union are, for certain grades of teachers, actually higher today than In 1929, those for the country as a whole have now dropped below the 1929 level, in some cases as much as 42.5 per cent.

WASHINGTON, April 1. -- Men prominent in various activities have written to President Roosevelt urging that he retain in office George H. Carter, Public Printer. The prominence of the writers has brought the Government Printing Office into the limelight.

THIS is a picture, done in high lights and deep shadows, of one of the "years of the locust," 1932. Its author, Edwin C. Hill, has long been known for his news stories in The New York Sun, and more recently for his sprightly radio commentary.

WARSAW, March 31. -- Encouraged by the access to power of the anti-Semitic Nazis in Germany, the Polish Nationalists are again endeavoring to stir up anti-Jewish feeling here in an effort to damage the government and win back their middle class and peasant following.

AS if drawing breath for a renewed burst of activity with the coining of April, the season slumped a bit last week. Some of the arrivals, however, made up to a considerable extent in interest for any numerical lack. The Museum of Modern Art staged several shows at once and the Whitney Museum opened to the public a loan collection from the Addison Gallery.

DETROIT, March 31. -- The explosion of a bomb in the basement of the residence of the Rev. Charles E. Coughlin of the Shrine of the Little Flower during the early hours of Thursday morning has thrown into higher light one of the most spectacular phases of Detroit's troubled financial situation.

Igor Markevitch's "Rebus," which the Boston Symphony Orchestra under Koussevitzky will play for the first time anywhere at Carnegie Hall Thursday evening, Is the work of one of the most gifted of the younger Russian composers. Markevitch resides in Paris.
AGUA CALIENTE, Mexico, April 1 (AP). -- In a racing drama here tomorrow, known as the Agua Caliente Handicap, any one of eight in the field of nine thoroughbreds entered may emerge a hero.

COLLECTORS are experiencing some difficulty in determining which is the first edition of President Franklin D Roosevelt's "Looking Forward." The John Day Company states that the original order for the first printing was for 5,000 copies.

THIS is a novel of modern marriage with the emphasis placed in equal measure on the physiological aspects of maternity and the psychological mutations of young parents. The first part of the narrative describes with unsparing realism a young wife's experience of pregnancy and childbirth, while the rest of the story deals with the ensuing changed relationship between husband and wife.

PHILADELPHIA, March 30. -- Loud dissension over who is going to control the flow of beer in Pennsylvania and how has not succeeded in giving a back seat at the present session of the General Assembly to a program of social legislation which is unifying the liberal forces of the Commonwealth and threatening to have widespread political consequences.

EASTER buying started in the stores last week and enabled them to hold the gains which have been made since the banking holiday. Locally, the bad weather held down volume, but there were several days of brisk sales on apparel and millinery.

MIAMI, Fla., April 1. -- A five-hit assault on George Blaeholder in the third inning today netted the Dodgers four runs and a 4-to-3 victory over the St. Louis Browns in the Carey clan's farewell to Miami until next Spring. The triumph evened the series with Killefer's men, with games still to be played in Jacksonville tomorrow and Monday.

Young women, headed by Miss Louise Bushnell, are taking an active interest in the concert in behalf of the Musicians' Emergency Fund which will be held tomorrow night at the Madison Square Garden. The artists will be Sergel Rachmaninoff and Fritz Kreisler, who have donated their services.

An amendment to wipe out a troublesome mistake in the zoning provisions enacted in 1916 is about to be enacted by the Board of Estimate and the Board of Aldermen, constituting the Municipal Assembly, states Edward M. Bassett, counsel to the zoning committee.

The New York Superintendent of Schools in his annual report gives especial attention to the importance of good speech in our daily life. As an educational objective it deserves a first place. GOETHE gave it this place when he said that "if language were " not incontestably the highest gift "that we possess, music would be."

Brisk recoveries in the various classification of German bonds featured dealings in an otherwise irregular foreign and domestic bond market on the Stock Exchange yesterday. The recoveries in the main body of German issues range small fractions to 8 points.

WASHINGTON, April 1. -- Cuts affecting almost all of the 1,400,000 pensioners on government rolls and estimated by the Veterans Bureau to save at least $400,000,000 a year will be put into effect July 1 under an executive order signed today by President Roosevelt.

To the Editor of The New York Times: THE TIMES reported some weeks ago a statement by Captain Richard St. Barbe-Baker before the New York Bird and Tree Club that seven-eighths of the timber in the United States has been exhausted.

GENEVA, April 1. -- For the first time in five years the gates of the grounds of the palace of the League of Nations were closed today. The shutters on the windows were closed, even to the fifth floor, to keep them from being broken, and a heavy guard patrolled the palace all afternoon.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., April 1. -- Samuel R. Bell, 60 years old, president of the Larchmont National Bank and Trust Company and prominent in financial and civic affairs of this village, shot and killed himself in the basement of the bank building at about 7:30 o'clock this morning, a few minutes after he had arrived for the day's work.

Dogs of any pointing breed are eligible in the four stakes of the Spring field trials of the English Setter Club of America, to be decided on the grounds of the Friends of the Hunting Dog near Medford, N.J., starting tomorrow and continuing through the week.

To the Dramatic Editor: There was a thrill in that inspired line in the announcement of the then approaching Actors Fund Benefit: "A Benefit for the Benefit of Actors Who Have Played Benefits for the Benefit of Others!" It recalled one of the most unusual and successful of all benefits given in the American theatre, because it was a single-star attraction, it attracted nation-wide attention and realized a prodigious sum in a moderate-sized theatre.

Competing in their home armor the old Thirteenth Regiment quaters in Brooklyn, representatives the 245th Coast Artillery capture the team laurels with 44 points the annual Military Athletic League indoor track championships last night.

One of the most unusual farmschool experiments in the history of modern educational methods will begin April 15, when a selected group of students from Teachers College of Columbia University will take possession of an 1,800-acre tract near Springdale, N.C., where they will continue their present studies and develop the farm on a no-profit basis.

TORONTO, Ont., April 1. -- Harvey Jackson and Charlie Sands, a rookie, shot the Toronto Maple Leafs into a tie with the Boston Bruins tonight as the Leafs won the fourth game of the National League first-place series, 5 -- 3.

Miss Mary A. Benjamin heads the young women in charge of the sale of seats for a repetition performance of Shakespeare's "The Merchant of Venice" by members of the junior branch of the New York Women's League for Animals on Wednesday night at the headquarters of the MacDowell Club, 166 East Seventy-third Street, in behalf of the 1,075 Madison Avenue Soup Kitchen.

Dexter Fellows called at newspaper offices yesterday afternoon and said it would be a good idea for the papers to print something about the circus. He was even willing to tell them what to print. Chewing the gutta-percha cigar and mopping his brow with the cellophane handkerchief which, together with his reputation for veracity.

THIS new volume by Edith Wharton consists of one story running to something less than half the pages of the book, and four shorter stories. To say that all exhibit in a uniformly high degree the many excellences which have given Mrs. Wharton her high rank among American and English novelists and practitioners of the short story would be to give the book considerably less than its due.

TORONTO, Ont., April 3. -- Increases in the value of Manitoba's output of gold, silver and zinc in 1932 are features of an advance report issued for that Province. Physical production of copper increased in the year, although its total value was considerably reduced by the sharp drop in price.

Transportation methods have developed and changed so radically in recent years that plans for the construction of a new Hudson River bridge at Fifty-seventh Street have been outmoded and the central plan for the development of the port's facilities no longer has a place for such a structure, according to engineers of the Port of New York Authority.

TO the Editor of The New York Times: In THE NEW YORK TIMES of March 22, 1983, is a note from London regarding 60,000 Assyrian refugees living in Iraq since 1918, to whom Persia now promises "sanctuary" within its borders.
HAVANA. -- Although Havana's Winter season is supposed to end on March 31, the opening week of April finds but little letup in social and sports activities here.

WASHINGTON, April 1 (AP). -- The wheat futures holdings of the Grain Stabilization Corporation, which at one time amounted to as much as 257,000,000 bushels, had been reduced to 11,911,000 bushels at the close of the markets yesterday.

THE primary purpose of Walter Wilson in this volume is to show how idyllic are the conditions under which labor works in Soviet Russia as compared with its slavery to capitalism in the United States. His "main purpose," he says, is "to consider the forms of direct forced labor in the United States and in the colonies directly or indirectly under its domination," and he does devote to this purpose almost three-fourths of his space.

MIAMI. -- Social events in connection with the Florida State Hotel Association's annual convention taking place here next Wednesday, Thursday and Friday, will be inaugurated with a frolic on Wednesday night in the gardens of the Honey Plaza Hotel when the 300 delegates, their wives and friends will assemble for a buffet supper in the palm bowl of the gardens, this to be followed by a floor entertainment and dancing.

The economic situation in Germany has improved since August, 1932, in spite of the political disturbances there, according to the National Industrial Conference Board in a survey, which shows that the decline in business activity has stopped, production and trade have either begun to increase or to move horizontally after years of decline and the financial crisis has been overcome.

"HUMANS don't belong up here." This was the thought that came to Apollo Soucek, navy pilot, six or eight miles above the city of Washington, while he was climbing toward a new world's record for height.

WASHINGTON . OUT of the West a few weeks ago came a tall, lanternjawed man, in whom burned the fires of idealism. What he believed he believed with all his heart. His eyes shone with the fervor of one who would not be put aside with platitudes.

GUIDO PANNAIN is an Italian critic whose name has not yet reached these shores resoundingly. He has studied modern music closely, and here presents studies of twelve modern composers, all living except Ferruccio Busoni.

OMAHA, March 30. -- A little more than a fortnight has elapsed since the late Senator Robert B. Howell was buried here, leaving an unexpired balance of two years of his term to foe filled by appointment of the Governor. Within that time there has developed a lively, not to say acute, interest in his successor and in the awkward, political situation which his selection involves.

WILHELMSHAFEN, Germany, April 1. -- Germany's second "pocket battleship," which is to replace the old cruiser Lothringen, was launched today in the presence of General Werner von Blomberg, Minister of Defense, and high, naval and military officers.

Declaring that statements concerning the number of wandering youths have been greatly exaggerated, Otis W. Caldwell and Julius B. Maller of the Institute of School Experimentation, Teachers College, Columbia University, in a survey made public yesterday said that the number of wandering boys and girls, 20 years or younger, was probably less than 40,000 or less than one-fifth of so-called "conservative" estimates of 200,000.

THE jovial round-faced mater-familias looked down the lunch table of college seniors in bewilderment. "I can't believe it," she said. "Why, when I graduated twenty-five years ago and we were all asked the same question about our ideal life after college, there was only one of us who admitted -- haltingly -- that she hoped to be a wife and mother.

Demanding that the New York Clearing House Association guarantee the deposits of the closed Harriman National Bank 100 cents on the dollar and thus permit the reopening of the institution, Jacqnes Braunstein, chairman of a depositors committee of the Harriman, made a statement last night charging unwarranted delay because of factional disputes within the clearing house membership in the matter.

The extent of foreclosures and forced sales of properties in West-Chester County has been exaggerated in many instances, and the number of such properties constitutes only a small percentage of realty holdings in the county, says Blakeman Quintard Meyer, president of the Wappanoca Realty Company of Rye.
The trout fishing season opened in New York State yesterday, but it could not be called an auspicious inaugural. Rain, fog and other conditions combined to spoil the day for the fresh water angler.

WASHINGTON. EARNINGS of nearly 1,000,000 persons are affected by the 15 per cent pay-cut order is sued by President Roosevelt under the new economy act and put into effect yesterday. This number includes civilian and military employes of the government.

MERLE COLBY'S rather lively specialty is orchestrating history. He may lack something as a novelist of character, but he does the orchestrating very well indeed. "History made painless" might very well be his motto. Into his first novel, "All Ye People," he poured all the incidents and information available about the westward trek of the years presided over by James Madison.

The complexity of the economic structure of the modern world seems to have made the minds of men impervious to basic truisms which are as old as Aristotle and are as efficacious now as they were then, in maintaining and preserving the peaceful well-being of society and in regulating and controlling the intricate mechanism of business.

DETROIT. APRIL is being regarded here as the key to the future, even if it may fail to achieve its old distinction of being the big production month of the year. Most observers here are convinced that sales during the next three weeks will indicate quite positively whether or not the turn has come.

Amateur boxers of New York proved decisively better than those from other cities when they won twelve of fifteen bouts in an intercity tournament at Madison Square Garden last night. Two matches were taken by Clevelanders and one by a Philadelphian.

LONDON, March 11. COMPARED with art at its best, life is a ragged and imperfect thing that fails again and again to round off its best stories or to give them a significant shape, but now and then life contributes a flawless anecdote.

PRESIDENT ROOSEVELT'S executive order of last week cutting the salaries of Federal employes 15 per cent was based on figures showing that the cost of living in the nation has declined by more than that percentage since the first half of the year 1928.
To the Editor of The New York Times: The objections which Professor Shorey makes 16 the point of view set forth in my recent letter on the classics are not, I think, of overwhelming cogency.

WEST POINT, N.Y., April 1. -- Army opened its lacrosse season with a one-sided victory over City College of New York today, 13 to 1. The game was slowed by the poor condition of the field, a downpour of rain continuing throughout.

LONDON, April 2. -- Viscount Chelmsford, former Viceroy of India, died suddenly here today of a heart attack after listening to a radio broadcast of the OxfordCambridge boat race. He was warden of All Souls College, Oxford. His age was 64.
DUBLIN, March 31. -- All things considered, the government of Eamon de Valera, nearing the close of the financial year, finds itself in a better financial position, than most observers expected.

The annual cumulative volume of The New York Times Index, which, since its inception, has served as a master key to the news of the year, was released for publication yesterday. The volume, covering the countless items of news published in the final edition of THE NEW YORK TIMES, daily and Sunday, from Jan. 1 to Dec. 31, 1932, is 2,733 pages in length.
PARIS, March 23. -- Application of the quota system to foreign musicians in Paris and surrounding districts is provided in a decree just issued by the French Ministry of Labor.

BERLIN, April 1. -- The Hitler Government has promulgated a law under the enabling act which, if not formally, at least for practical purposes revises the fundamental Federal structure of the Reich, bringing it considerably closer to the form of a unitary state.

VATICAN CITY, April 1 (AP). -- Pope Plus XI blessed the whole world today upon inaugurating the holy year by opening the holy door of St. Peter's with a golden hammer before a throng of 55,000 persons.

THE telephone rang in the subscription department of the Theatre Guild. It rings perhaps 100 times a day. This time it was a lady who wanted to know the location of her subscription seats for the evening performance of "Both Your Houses," the organization's newest play, at the Royale Theatre.

As the result of a study of existing mortgage difficulties, the Long Island division of the Home Mortgage Advisory Board has recommended to the Home Mortgage Advisory Board that a plan be considered by which qualifying home mortgages might be taken over by a government writ as collateral for a Federal bond issue.

WHEN Mary Pickford arrives in Hollywood this week, she will set about organizing her 1933 production schedule for United Artists. Most interesting of the projects she is considering are color productions of "Peter Pan" and "Alice in Wonderland."
Preliminary plans have been announced for an Opera Ball to be held on April 28 at the Metropolitan Opera House.

AFTER viewing their clever work in "A Lady's Profession," the picture which was at the Rialto, it will probably be the hope of many spectators that Roland Young and Alison Skip-worth will soon be teamed in another film.

A rally in silver futures and a halting of the rapid rise in sugar prices were the features of yesterday's trading on local commodity Exchanges. The trading volume, as usual on the short day, was small. Cash markets were featured by a continuation of the advances in grains.

Vincent Lanusio, 70 years old, of 322 Atlantic Avenue, Brooklyn, was run down and fatally injured about 5:30 o'clock yesterday afternoon as he was crossing Atlantic Avenue at Boerum Place, Brooklyn. He died in the Holy Family Hospital three hours later.

BERLIN, April 1 (AP). -- Baron von Neurath's move to resign as Foreign Minister was understood to have resulted in part from belief that the Nazi appointment of Alfred Rosenberg to the foreign political division of the party was the first drastic step toward later seizure of the Foreign Office.

The Borough of Manhattan faces a future of steadily rising land values due to its increasing importance as the world's business and financial centre, and trade needs are due to bring further expansion of the business districts, with a consequent usurping of some areas still residential in character, in the opinion of Joseph P. Day, real estate auctioneer and broker.

TALK of a Scottish renaissance of literature would be very idle indeed but for the occasional achievement of books like "Sunset Song." Although it is a regional novel primarily, coming from the heart of agricultural Scotland and exactly abiding by its Scotch quality, it may be read with delight the world over.

PETERBOROUGH, N.H., March 31. -- The 100th anniversary of the first free public library in the United States to be supported by taxation is to be observed this Spring and Summer by the people of this town, where on April 9, 1833, the Peterborough Town Library, by vote, was declared "free" to every citizen.

WASHINGTON, April 1. -- Although urging a maximum fortyhour week for every employed person during the present emergency, a special committee of the Chamber of Commerce of the United States coupled the recommendation with a warning against establishing temporary expedients which might become permanent.

The junior high school, as "the Jeystone of the educational system," and the need in the present unsettled social order to maintain and improve its standards, were discussed at length yesterday before 1900 teachers at the third annual city-wide conference on junior high schools under the auspices of the Junior High School Principals' 'Association in the Hotel Astor.

Only 8 per cent of the tonnage of the American merchant marine is twenty-five or more years old, according to a study of world shipping prepared by the Baltic and International Maritime Conference. Holland with a percentage of 5 and Great Britain with 7 per cent are the only nations with a larger proportion of new tonnage.

There is still wide discussion of the success of President ROOSEVELT'S leadership thus far. Washington correspondents have offered a new explanation for it. The President is strong, because Congress is weak. Mr. ROOSEVELT has no difficulty in leading, because there are no bold and able and influential leaders in either house of Congress to withstand him, or to propose measures of their own superior to those which he recommends.

There has been of late a marked renewal of interest in child labor. With millions of adult men and women out of work, it was inevitable that the competing labor of children, always a social factor, should again become an economic problem calling for attention. President HOOVER'S child health conference in 1930 grave renewed impetus to the campaign to prevent exploitation of children in industry.

TOPEKA, Kan., March 30. -- Topeka is in turmoil. It has been for weeks, but the chaos has been only relatively noticeable because the Legislature has been in session and there have been other things to think about. Now that State issues have been settled, the voters of the State capital are going to the polls next Tuesday to assert their inalienable rights in a local but crucial matter.

As a fitting climax to their unusual performances this week, the Spence brothers, Walter, Leonard and Wallace, combined their efforts last night to carry off the 300-yard medley title event that brought the National A.A.U. swimming championships to a close at the New York A.C. pool.

AFTER passing through thirteen, years of a bone-dry regime Finland completes next Wednesday the first year of its new wet regime. It is a regime which was hurriedly adopted under the Impact of an overwhelmingly wet decision in a country-wide referendum.

SIMON MARKS, like so many Jews in fiction, had risen from lowly beginnings to great wealth. When the new bridge was erected, he saw chances of further increasing his wealth; at the "undeveloped '' end of the bridge he built model tenements for city workers.

As they left church, JOHNSON and BOSWELL discussed BERKELEY'S theory that matter exists only in the mind. When BOSWELL remarked that it was impossible to refute the doctrine the Doctor kicked a stone. "I refute it thus." Practical men will applaud. A modern physicist would say that the Doctor had proved nothing but his own inability to understand what BERKELEY was driving at.
LACROSSE, Va., April 1 (AP). -- Police were engaged in an intensive search, tonight for the slayers of four reputedly wealthy bachelors found shot at their farmhouse near here early today.

FORT MUNOZ, Gran Chaco, April 1. -- After several quiet days fighting has been resumed in the vicinity of Fort Gondra, to which the Paraguayans retired from Camp Jordan after the "hundred days battle."

Followers or the three leading faiths in the country will gather in Radio City Music Hall at 10:30 this morning for a distinctively religious meeting, under the auspices of an honorary committee composed of prominent members of these faiths to be addressed by a leader of each -- a Roman Catholic, a Jew and a Protestant.

AGUA CALIENTE, Mexico, April 1. -- L. Cunningham's Moronge, a 5-year-old son of Morvich, turned in a mild surprise by winning in the mile and seventy yards of the sixth race today. Frank D. was second and On the Job third, while Diodoro, the favorite, finished out of the money. The winner covered the distance in 1:46 to pay $12.80.

With the championship events of the Yacht Racing Association of Long Island Sound assigned to the various clubs for the coming Summer, and the Larchmont and American Yacht Clubs' own programs arranged, those organizations again will lead all others in scheduled contests.

NEVER does the end of a theatrical season draw nigh but some impertinent fellow away in the back of the room suddenly hops to his feet and inquires, with something of a grimace, "How have things been on the road?" Within the past few years a satanic expression has been creeping into those grimaces, and the invariable reply of the wags sitting well up toward the front has been, with a knowing wink, "What road?"

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., April 1. -- As the result of separate acts by the State, the Legislature and Chattanooga banks, Hamilton County has come close this week to a suspension of many governmental functions.

The first definite step toward reorganization of the Democratic party in the State outside of New York City was taken yesterday by Postmaster General James A. Farley in an announcement that Philip N. Krug, Nassau County leader, would not he recognized in the distribution of Federal patronage.

As a result of the cooperative work between the managing agents of apartment houses in the city, a system of credit information has been perfected with the Idea of protecting landlords against tenants who have broken their leases. Through the exchange of its information the managing agents are refusing to rent to an applicant whose record shows that he has broken his lease in a formerly occupied house.

MR. EWING'S timely and valuable book is of special consequence because of the practical nature of his approach to his theme. He holds no brief for his subject nor for any one of the various types of insurance against unemployment.

In consideration, of further economies and the expansion of the present program for increasing municipal revenues the banks will supply the city with funds to meet the $144,000,000 of short-term debt maturing on April 26, it was indicated yesterday.

Miss Clare L. De Ceu, an assistant superintendent of the Navy Nurse Corps at its headquarters in Washington, D.C., and from 1903 to 1908 superintendent of the Children's Hospital in Buffalo, N.Y., died Friday night in the Naval Hospital, Brooklyn, after a long illness.

WASHINGTON, April 1 (AP) -- Veteran organizations, which, for weeks have been following the newpension plan's creation, unofficially estimated that 29,000 veterans of the World War who have been receiving non-service connected allowances for total and permanent disability would be reduced to the $20 allowance.

PROFESSOR JOAD certifies that he is a pacifist, internationalist, socialist, highbrow, "intellectual." These distinctions are not rare. Even the last two, perhaps essentially one, would make fat figures in a census.

DYNAMIC to the Japanese attitude toward Manchuria are "Gosenzo-sama." the spirits of Honorable Ancestors. Honorable Ancestors are accountable not only for the amazing mettle of the Japanese, nation, but also for the equally amazing deference of the individual Japanese.

IN an address before the Tropical Medicine Section of the Congress of the Pan-American Medical Association Dr. Fred Valles endeavored to revive the theory of panspermy once advocated by Svante Arrhenius. According to the panspermic doctrine bacteria are propelled through space by the pressure of light with the possibility of eventually landing on a planet on which they may thrive.

TANJONG RHU, MALAYA. WHICH would you rather do -- fight a twenty-five-foot python coiled around your body or lie passively on a cot with your eyes closed while an equally active python crawled about your tent? Probably you'd rather-feed an elephant peanuts at the zoo-but that wouldn't add much excitement to the adventure picture, "Man Eater," which Clyde E. Elliott has been making for the Fox company in the jungles of Malaya.

ARCHAEOLOGY and history togather have made it possible now to draw an astonishingly life-like picture of the ancient Mexican, the Aztec. who was the forebear of a big proportion of the Mexicans of today. J. Eric Thompson is well qualified to make the picture, for he has charge of the department of Central and South American Archaeology of the Field Musenm, Chicago.

All was quiet yesterday along the waterfront of Riker's Island. The pigs grunted contentedly; the wild dogs slumbered undisturbed on the garbage dump; the inmates of the prison farm colony whistled as they fed the hogs or plowed the fertile fields.

DALLAS, March 30. -- The utter and helpless confusion in which the oil Industry of Texas finds itself today, principally because of the uncertain status of things in the East Texas field, has united it on one thing, at least -- that jurisdiction over oil and gas must be taken from the Railroad Commission.

The refusal of the Interstate Commerce Commission to permit continuance of the interlocking of directorates between the New York Central and the Union Pacific, which had existed for about a quarter of a century, was accepted in railroad circles yesterday as the final notice that L.F. Loree would not be able to fulfill his ambition to serve on the Eastern trunk line's board.

The average lender of home mortgage money in the United States is less wealthy than the man whose home he is financing, points out the United States Building and Loan League. The average type of home borrower, it is stated, has at least $1,500 for a down payment or his property, while the man who loans the money has an average investment of only $742.

PARIS, March 31. -- After last week's rapid events there has been a kind of lull in international politics, at least so far as the public is concerned. Every foreign ministry and every embassy, however, have been humming with activity.

Political pressure will not influence the Board of Higher Education in its selection of a successor to Dr. James M. Kieran, whose resignation as president of Hunter College will become effective at the close of the academic year, Mark Eisner, chairman of the board, said yesterday in reply to letters from civic and educational groups urging choice of a new executive on the basis of scholarly and administrative qualifications alone.

The Army Day parade next Saturday, in which regular army and other units will participate, has been routed through upper Fifth Avenue, at the request of the Fifth Avenue Association. The association has long opposed parades through the Fifth Avenue business section as temporarily detrimental to business interests.

LONDON, March 31. -- Norman H. Davis's activities in London this week have been hailed by the British Government as the first step of the new Washington administration toward bringing the United States back to active and effective participation in international affairs.

DECATUR, Ala., April 1. -- Remote from the discussions of the fellow-citizens of Morgan Count regarding last week's assault upon its jury system, the twelve jurors who will begin hearing evidence against Haywood Patterson, one of the nine Scottsboro Negroes, at his second trial next Monday, amused themselves today with jigsaw puzzles and playing cards.

By way of breaking the ice -- which they have been forced to do almost literally on occasions in the past -- for the new season of rowing, the varsity 150-pound crews of Harvard will open the year of racing Wednesday on the beautiful stretch of the Housatonic below Kent School, rowing the schoolboys two races over the Henley distance.

WHATEVER doubts may exist in the minds of others as to who originated the tank, this book clearly proves that General Swinton harbors no doubts at all. He alone and single-handed did it! To this end he presents an impressively documented case.

Passion for Tinkering. Americans are always being chastised for their excessive devotion to machines, whereas their real fault is excessive faith in machinery. The Eighteenth Amendment was a piece of machinery for making men good.

LONDON, April 1. -- Norman H. Davis, United States representative in preparations for the World Economic Conference and delegate to the disarmament conference, had an hour's talk with Stanley Baldwin, Lord President of the Council, today, after which he received a call from Tsuneo Matsudaira, Japanese Ambassador to London.

AIR express transported by planes bearing the insignia of the United States amounted to more than 1,600,000 pounds in 1932, a growth of about 800,000 pounds over the year before. Only four years ago less than 300,000 pounds of goods were moved by air in this country.

The Army Day parade next Saturday, in which regular army and other units will participate, has been routed through upper Fifth Avenue, at the request of the Fifth Avenue Association. The association has long opposed parades through the Fifth Avenue business section as temporarily detrimental to business interests.

LONDON, March 31. -- Norman H. Davis's activities in London this week have been hailed by the British Government as the first step of the new Washington administration toward bringing the United States back to active and effective participation in international affairs.

DECATUR, Ala., April 1. -- Remote from the discussions of the fellow-citizens of Morgan Count regarding last week's assault upon its jury system, the twelve jurors who will begin hearing evidence against Haywood Patterson, one of the nine Scottsboro Negroes, at his second trial next Monday, amused themselves today with jigsaw puzzles and playing cards.

By way of breaking the ice -- which they have been forced to do almost literally on occasions in the past -- for the new season of rowing, the varsity 150-pound crews of Harvard will open the year of racing Wednesday on the beautiful stretch of the Housatonic below Kent School, rowing the schoolboys two races over the Henley distance.

WHATEVER doubts may exist in the minds of others as to who originated the tank, this book clearly proves that General Swinton harbors no doubts at all. He alone and single-handed did it! To this end he presents an impressively documented case.

Passion for Tinkering. Americans are always being chastised for their excessive devotion to machines, whereas their real fault is excessive faith in machinery. The Eighteenth Amendment was a piece of machinery for making men good.

LONDON, April 1. -- Norman H. Davis, United States representative in preparations for the World Economic Conference and delegate to the disarmament conference, had an hour's talk with Stanley Baldwin, Lord President of the Council, today, after which he received a call from Tsuneo Matsudaira, Japanese Ambassador to London.

IF THE old adage that the grass always looks greener on the other side of the fence applies in broadcasting. American listeners often complain about the conduct of broadcasting in this country and point to the English non-commercial system as the ideal method.
PARIS, March 30. -- Marquisette evening hats made in one piece with pleated brims bring Charlotte Corday coiffures up to date.

Professor Jean Capart, famous Egyptologist and director of the Museum du Cinquantenaire of Brussels, Belgium, will arrive on the Red Star liner Westerland tomorrow. He will spend two months in this country as advisory curator of the Egyptian department of the Brooklyn Museum.

OVER the Imposing headquarters of the Nazis, a palatial house in the sedate Briennerstrasse in Munich, there has flown for several years an enormous flag bearing a swastika sign, while above the doorway was the injunction: "Germany, awake!"

BERLIN, April 1 (AP). -- Dr. Paul Joseph Goebbels, Minister of Propaganda, made it clear to a vast cheering throng in the Lustgarten this afternoon that it would be a simple thing to make repressive measures against all Jews effective again.

CHICAGO, March 31. -- President Roosevelt's program for reforestation and other public works to mitigate the evils of involuntary Idleness has stimulated advocates of similar plans in Illinois and its neighboring States of Wisconsin and Indiana.

NATCHEZ, Miss. -- From tomorrow until April 10 hospitable Southerners in this quaint old Mississippi city will throw open the doors of twenty-two ante-bellum mansions so that visitors may view the treasures contained therein.
PALM BEACH, Fla., April 1. -- Mr. and Mrs. Chester Milton Williams entertained with a dinner at their residence tonight. Their guests were:
WASHINGTON, April 1. -- The Bureau of Navigation issued the following orders today, dated March 30:

WASHINGTON, April 1. -- Setting up of a Federal coordinator of railroads with broad powers to enforce economies in railroad operation with a view to eventual consolidation of all companies into not more than seven regional systems appeared likely tonight to be adopted as the emergency rehabilitation program of President Roosevelt, following his conference with various groups interested in the general railroad situation.

Five women, were in the line-up yesterday morning at Police Headquarters, three accused of hold-ups and two of violating the Sullivan law. Detectives said they could not remember so large a number of women ever having appeared there in a single day before.

Eleven musicians of world fame, headed by Arturo Toscanini, cabled to Chancellor Hitler of Germany yesterday in protest against the persecution of their colleagues in that country for political or religious reasons. Mr. Toscanini's name headed the list of signers at his own request.

In April no one speaks of the climate as having changed. More than a hundred years ago it was the same April that is so temperamental today. A diary kept on Long Island in 1818 has such entries as "very fine and warm," "rain all day," "drying wind and miserably cold," "cold and raw," "just " the weather to give one the blue "devils,' " "frost and ice in the morn"ing.

FOURTEEN years ago the Harvard Glee Club announced to the world that it preferred to sing Brahms instead of barber-shop ballads; Palestrina in place of flat-car songs, and Bach before "The Bull Frog on the Bank." The world would not believe its eyes, and said so.

WASHINGTON, April 1. -- There was an upward trend in a number of indexes of production and distribution for the week ended March 25, but progress from the low level of the preceding week was slow and without uniformity, according to the weekly survey of domestic business made public today by the Commerce Department.
Prices on the Cotton Exchange advanced 10 to 11 points yesterday as a direct result of efforts to hasten the passage of the farm bill in substantially the form urged by the administration.

BOYS and girls of widely different tastes and ages unite in a liking for animal stories. It is a satisfaction to be able to put into their hands a book such as this. It has charm, accuracy and humor and is so well written that adults as well as children can take pleasure in reading it.

WASHINGTON, April 1. -- Representatives of investment houses whose stock and bond flotations in the last few years have run into the billions told the House Interstate and Foreign Commerce Committee today that legitimate business had nothing to fear from President Roosevelt's plan for Federal supervision of interstate securities.

ALBANY, April 1. -- Plans to check further withdrawal of water from underground sources of supply in Kings, Queens, Nassau and Suffolk Counties have been begun by the introduction in the Legislature of bills by Senator Twomey of Brooklyn, and Assemblyman Maurice A. Fitzgerald of Queens, to require approval of the Water Power and Control Commission before new wells are sunk.

Several hundred members of the younger set representative of leading colleges and preparatory schools throughout the East, as well as debutantes of this season and former years, thronged the roof garden of the Waldorf-Astoria last night for the first in a series of interschool and college dances.

Although activity in skyscraper construction and new office building and apartment projects remains at a low ebb in Manhattan and the Bronx, several interesting building operations are under way for special uses.

A NEW radio set Introduced by the General Electric Company has a visual control that enables the operator to regulate the high and low notes independently of each other, thereby tuning to please the ear with the aid of the eye.

CHICAGO, March 31. THE air of this forlorn mid-Western Rialto seethes with rumors, reports, promises and proclamations about shows that will come or may come to Chicago for the period of the Century of Progress Exposition.

The capital readjustment for which, the Missouri Pacific Railroad took action in the courts on Friday means that the burden of supporting the Alleghany Corporation, top company in the Van Sweringen Holding Company structure, will for some time rest chiefly on the Chesapeake Ohio Railway.
PRAGUE, March 31. -- The Forthcoming visit of Colonel Beck, the Foreign Minister of Poland, to two of the three Little Entente capitals promises to prove an event of first-class importance to Europe.

ROME, March 31. -- Probably Premier Mussolini himself, even allowing for the optimism natural in the originator of a new idea, never imagined that his four-power project for European peace would be acceded by all nations with shouts of joy.
NEW YORK Mr. and Mrs. Adolf Pavenstedt have returned to 10 East Sixty-fourth Street after a visit with relatives in France.

BROOKLINE, Mass., April 1. -- Bringing to a close the sensational winning streak of Miss Helen Germaine of New York City, Miss Dorrance Chase of Dorchester, Mass., a recent graduate of Simmons College, won the women's national indoor tennis championship as she turned back Miss Germaine, 6 -- 3, 6 -- 2, on the Longwood covered courts today.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., April 1. -- The 85-foot schooner Antonia, sailed and owned by Harkness Edwards of Pittsburgh, was five miles off Egmont Key in the Gulf of Mexico late today, leading the eleven sailing yachts in the fourth annual St. Petersburg-Havana yacht race.

ALBANY, April 1. -- The Democratic-controlled Senate and Republican-controlled Assembly remained deadlocked tonight over beer control legislation, following a conference between Governor Lehman and the legislative leaders at which a new effort was made by the Governor to harmonize their divergent views.
ISTANBUL, March 31. -- The British disarmament plan submitted at Geneva by Prime Minister MacDonald was received in Turkey and Greece with mixed feelings.

WASHINGTON, April 1. -- Immediately on being sworn into office at the Justice Department today, Major A.V. Dalrymple of California plunged into his new task of Director of the Bureau of Prohibition, convinced that the legalization of 3.2 per cent beer and wine would simplify the enforcement problem.

WASHINGTON, April 1. -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended on March 25 make a total of 475,850 cars, the American Railway Association announced today. This was 26,138 cars, or 5.8 per cent, more than for the preceding week, but 85,268 cars, or 15.2 per cent, fewer than, for the corresponding week last year and 263.030 cars, or 35.6 per cent, fewer than for the corresponding week two years ago.

OUT of the schoolroom in the past century the dunce cap has disappeared. Perhaps in the next generation its one-time wearer may almost have vanished as well. Toward such a consummation point experiments of the past three years in the Detroit public schools with the glandular treatment of retarded children.

IF the Filtpinos accept the independence granted them recently by Congress, the United States will lose its last claim to royalty. For the only hereditary monarch under the Stars and Stripes is Hadji Mohammed Jamalul Kiram II, the Sultan of Sulu, whose royal realm comprises some two thousand palm islands and coral atolls in the southernmost Philippines.

WASHINGTON, April 1. -- The President, at the end of his first month in office, remains the most interesting and the most popular person in Washington. This capital is usually a poor sounding-board of national opinion, but apparently Mr. Roosevelt has retained the interest and the approval of the United States in the degree revealed at the seat of government.

WASHINGTON, April 1.-- Eight hundred women from all parts of the country will meet here this week to plan a drive in every State for ratification of the repeal of the Eighteenth Amendment, and to evolve a "temperance" standard in the development of State liquor control laws.

RUMORS that the dismissal of Fritz Busch from the directorship of the Dresden Opera would change the plans for the Dresden premiere of Strauss's "Arabella" and transfer the first performance to Vienna are denied in a recent article in the Vienna Neue Freie Presse.
To the Editor of The New York Times: President Roosevelt has at least reduced unemployment among constitutional lawyers.

GARDENING is older than history, therefore the author of "The Story of the Garden" has had to draw upon mythology and archaeology for her opening chapter. But the race had scarcely invented the pen and the chisel before fact material for such a book became abundant.

James C. Van Siclen of Jamaica, former Supreme Court Justice, and C. Walter Randall of Garden City, former president of the Nassau County Bar Association, were appointed receivers in equity for the Bush Terminal Company by Federal Judge Robert A. Inch in Brooklyn yesterday under a joint bond of $100,000.

BROOKLINE, Mass., April 1. -- Bringing to a close the sensational winning streak of Miss Helen Germaine of New York City, Miss Dorrance Chase of Dorchester, Mass., a recent graduate of Simmons College, won the women's national indoor tennis championship as she turned back Miss Germaine, 6 -- 3, 6 -- 2, on the Longwood covered courts today.
JACKSONVILLE, Fla., April 2. -- For the second time this Spring rain spoiled a Sunday contest today for the Dodgers, but not before they had played five innings and part of the sixth with the Browns.

WASHINGTON, April 2. -- A glgantic flotation of government bonds to refinance the mortgage indebtedness of the farmers will be proposed by President Roosevelt in a special message which he will transmit to Congress tomorrow. The bonds will carry an interest rate of 4 per cent, and between $2,000,000,000 and $3,000,000,000 will be required, it is estimated.

BERLIN, April 2. -- It is virtually certain tonight that the boycott of the Jews, a sample of which was served up yesterday throughout Germany, will not be resumed Wednesday, the day conditionally set for its continuance. The opposition of sober Germans outside the National Socialist ranks who realize what it has meant for Germany in the outside world is too strong.

More than 6,000 members of the New York Police Department Holy Name Society attended St. Pattrick's Cathedral yesterday at a mass celebrated by Cardinal Hayes, and afterward heard Mayor O'Brien and Commissioner Mulrooney speak at a breakfast at the Hotel Astor.

The political, social and economic Institutions of the world will never he reformed unless man himself is reformed first, the Rev. Bede Jarrett of the Dominican Priory of Oxford, England, asserted in one of his course of Lenten sermons yesterday morning in the Roman Catholic Church of Our Lady of Lourdes.

DETROIT, April 2. -- One more obstacle was hurdled tonight by the New York Rangers in their quest for the Stanley Cup. Facing a sturdy and courageous Detroit team, the Rangers won their second straight game of the home-and-home series and earned the right to meet the winner of the Toronto Maple Leaf-Boston Bruin series in the final round of the play-offs for the world's professional hockey championship.

The Boston Red Sox players, who were tossed about in their threecar section of the train derailed near Dover yesterday morning, were not so mentally upset that they could not beat the Jersey City Skeeters, 12 to 0, at Jersey City in the afternoon.

MONTREAL, April 2 (Canadian Press). -- A fire believed to be incendiary was discovered and put out early today in St. James Basilica the cathedral of the Roman Catholic diocese of Montreal, just one week after the burning of St. Jacques la Mineur Church. In the interim another edifice, St. Eduard's was threatened with destruction.

WARREN, Ohio, April 2 (AP). -- The mellow glow of lamplight and candlelight shone tonight from the windows of nearly 200 homes in the countryside near here, where residents have cut off their electric light switches in a protest against light rates as too high.

CINCINNATI, April 2. -- Before many years have passed governmental agencies, municipal, State or Federal, will have taken over the major part of hospital work, old age and child care and family relief which until now have been sustained by private philanthropy, Paul Felix Warburg, vice president of the Bank of Manhattan Company, New York, predicted at the annual meeting of the United Jewish Social Agencies here tonight.

STANFORD UNIVERSITY, April 2. -- A resolution pledging a refusal "to be conscripted into any war service whatsoever" was adopted at a meeting here last night by the Inter-Collegiate Conference, a student group representing seven San Francisco Bay region universities and colleges.

Frank T. Hulswit, public utilities financier who was widely known for the "come-back" he achieved by operations of great size after the stock market slump of 1926 had shorn him of about $10,000,000, the presidency of the $575,000,000 United Light and Power Company and of his dominant position in the utilities field, died yesterday morning in Bellevue Hospital.
BERLIN, April 2. -- While National Socialist organs hail the outcome of yesterday's boycott of the Jews, the Frankfurter Zeltung deplores it as "an act of undoubted injustice."

The new United States liner Washington returned to the yard of the New York Shipbuilding Company at Camden, N.J., yesterday afternoon, after passing her builders' tests off the Delaware Capes. In a series of manoeuvres Saturday and yesterday, the ship was found ready for her official sea trials on April 24-25, which will precede her entry to the transatlantic service in May, according to observers who were aboard.
ALBANY, April 2. -- Following is the text of Senator George R. Fearon's radio address tonight:
Beneath the sweeping arches of Radio City Music Hall, 6,000 persons -- Catholics, Protestants and Jews -- united yesterday morning in a ceremony of rededication to old spiritual ideals.

Appearing before the House Military Affairs Committee on Friday last, General FOULOIS, Chief of the Army Air Corps, urged a thorough study of national defense by Congress. He had been summoned to testify about the needs of the Army Air Corps, which after seven years is short of serviceable combat planes provided for in the five-year program of 1927.

ALBANY, April 2. (AP). -- Governor Lehman tonight made public a letter to Frank H. Baird of Buffalo, in which the Governor approved a proposal to change the Buffalo and Fort Erie Bridge Company from a private corporation into a public agency similar to the Albany and New York City Port Authorities.

While the Marshall Chess Club, defending titleholder in the Metropolitan Chess League, defeated the Hungarian Workers, 6-2, in the ninth round of the annual competition at the Marshall rooms yesterday, a strong team representing the Manhattan Chess Club trailed against Empire City when play was stopped with six games decided.
PARIS, April 2 (AP). -- The Mussolini four-power peace plan was said in official quarters tonight to be gaining ground as it was undergoing modification.

NEW HAVEN, April 2. -- Professor Irving Fisher's index number of commodity prices, based on 100 as the average for 1926, is 56.4, which compares with 56.6 a week ago, 56.1 two weeks ago and 55 four weeks ago. The markets were closed three weeks ago.

WINNIPEG, April 2 (Canadian Press). -- Ray Robinson, a former Canadian National locomotive fireman of Edmonton, said by the police to have confessed complicity in the kidnapping of Haskell Bohn, 20-year-old eon of G.C. Bohn, a refrigerator manufacturer at St. Paul, Minn., last June, was brought here today by Koyal Canadian Mounted Police.

Former Governor Alfred E. Smith, championing the cause of Governor Lehman in the fight for non-political control of beer, issued a formal statement yesterday in which he said that the Governor would "receive the support and cooperation of thinking people throughout the State."

Government toy lobbies representing intelligent minorities should replace the existing system at Washington, according to Robert D. Kohn, president of the New York Ethical Culture Society, who spoke yesterday morning in the Meeting House, Central Park West and Sixty-fourth Street.

WASHINGTON, April 2. -- James M. Cox, Democratic nominee for President in 1920 and former Governor of Ohio, may be one of the American delegates to the World Economic Conference, according to reports current here today.

WASHINGTON, April 2 (AP). -- Veterans' Administration officials tonight had written the word "economy" over a wide field of their activities in conformation with President Roosevelt's decree for an annual saving of $400,000,000 in veterans' benefits.

Arturo Toscanini directed a performance of the "Eroica" at the second concert of the Philharmonic Symphony Orchestra's Beethoven cycle at Carnegie Hall yesterday afternoon that Beethoven would have known best how to value. For, from what we know of the limitations of individual and ensemble of his day, the composer could not have heard a realization of his creation that was the peer of this one except in his imagination.

It is a very fortunate thing for New York University that Miguel A. de Capriles is a curious young man. Back in his sophomore year in 1926 the total fencing knowledge of the present national three-weapon champion amounted to zero.

John J. Dunnigan, Democratic leader in the Senate, assailed Republican legislative leaders on their handling of beer legislation yesterday afternoon in a speech made over radio station WOR. The part of his speech dealing with beer control was as follows:

The versatile Vladimir Rosing, tenor, who has been before the public as a remarkably dramatic exponent of Russian songs, as director of the former American Opera Company and as co-director of the Cooperative Theatre, gave a song recital last night In Steinway Hall, assisted by Harriet Kells, soprano.

PINEHURST, N.C., April 2. -- George T. Dunlap Jr. of Garden City, L.I., the medalist and tournament favorite, will meet R.A. Jones Jr. of Larchmont, N.Y., tomorrow as match play opens in the thirty-third annual United North and South amateur golf championship.

"An Inexpensive Church" was the topic of the sermon by the Rev. Dr. Harry Emerson Fosdick yesterday morning in the Riverside Church, Riverside Drive and 122d Street. Judged by the per capita cost of those served by it, he said, the Riverside Church is one of the least expensive churches in the country.

A proposal to use the city's unemployed to landscape the neglected site of the former lower reservoir in Central Park to restore thirty-four acres to public use was addressed to Park Commissioner Herrick in a letter made public yesterday by Nathan Straus Jr., as president of the Park Association of New York City.
The Rev. Ignatius W. Cox, Professor of Ethics at Fordham University, condemned anti-Semitism yesterday in his sermon at the Church of St. Ignathis Loyola, Park Avenue and Elghty-fourh Street.

In quest of further volcanological, archaeological and geological knowledge a seventh expedition will be made to Alaska next month by the Rev. Bernard J. Hubbard, a Jesuit, known as "the glacier priest," he revealed yesterday after a lecture at Town Hall on his Alaskan explorations.

"Come, take, learn and find" are Christ's four words of invitation to man, a summons to man's will which if heeded will open the doors to a higher, richer, and fuller life, the Rev. Dr. Charles R. Brown, Dean Emeritus of the Tale Divinity School, declared in his sermon yesterday morning at the Collegiate Reformed Church of St. Nicholas, Fifth Avenue at Forty-eighth Street.

Earnings of the Eastman Kodak Company from Dec. 26, 1931, to Dec. 31, 1932, amounted to $6,058.748 after United States and foreign income taxes and after depreciation on the usual basis. This compares with $13,408,785 in the year ended on Dec. 26, 1931.

Robert Fulton Cutting, financier, patron of music, churchman and philanthropist, was felicitated yesterday morning at St. George's Protestant Episcopal Church, Stuyvesant Square and East Sixteenth Street, because last Monday he had completed fifty years as a vestryman of that parish.

At its concert at the Freaeh Institute last night the League of Composers presented works written, according to the program, for its tenth anniversary. The concert opened with Chavez's quartet for oboe, clarinet, trumpet and bassoon.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Mr. Lowry in his communication anent the Willard case should have stated that he was formerly associate counsel to the joint legislative committee. While his official connection, with the inquiry does not and should not disqualify him from making any pertinent observations, it bears nevertheless upon the degree of objectivity or lack of dispassionate interest with which he approaches a discussion of the subject.

A protest against tax exemption for New York City housing in which, the maximum rental per room monthly exceeds $8 or $9 has been, filed with Mayor O'Brien and the other members of the Board of Estimate by the First Avenue Association.

AGUA CALLENTE, Mexico, April 2. -- Untouched by the whip, Gallant Sir, powerful 4-year-old colt owned by Norman W. Church, won the $25,000 added Agua Caliente Handicap from a small field today in track record time.

MILWAUKEE, April 2 (AP). -- A victory for Wisconsin anti-prohibitionists in Tuesday's referendum on repeal of the Eighteenth Amendment was conceded today by the Rev. Warren Jones, State Superintendent of the Anti-Saloon League.

After Edward Estlin Cummings had finished "Eimi," brought out today by Covici, Friede, he wanted it published with no name at all. The publishers thought that it should have some sort of title and "Eimi" was agreed on. It is a novel, written in ultra-modern style and with so many type changes that S.A. Jacobs, the designer, set most of the type himself.

Pan American Airways Corporation reports for 1932 a consolidated net profit after all charges and reserves, of $698,527, equal to $1.36 a share on the 512,581 shares of capital stock outstanding. This compares with a net profit of $105,452, or 21 cents a share in 1931.

ELIZABETH, N.J., April 2. -- Charles Wilson Crane, president of C.W. Crane Co., lighterage concern with offices at 17 Battery Place, New York, died a few minutes before midnight last night at his home here, 108 Stiles Street. Mr. Crane was 80 years old and had been ill almost a year.

Mr. ROOSEVELT'S Executive order cutting down nearly a million and a half pensions, and thereby reducing the Government outlay by $400,000,000, has been made so familiar by anticipation that its immense significance may partly escape the public mind.

BERLIN, March 31. -- The anti-Jewish outbreak, simultaneous with the opening of hostilities between the Hitlerites and their supposed Stahlhelm allies, has been a disastrous blow to confidence. The Boerse reacted on Tuesday, and Thursday saw the collapse of highpriced stocks, which lost from 20 to 30 points.

The Fere Marquette Railway earned $591,233 from the emergency freight surcharges in 1932 and transferred this sum to the Railroad Credit Corporation, but it borrowed $1,000,000 from the corporation, according to the annual report.

PORT WASHINGTON. L.I., April 2. -- There wag a gathering of crack skippers from all along Long Island Sound at the Knickerbocker Yacht Club's dinghy regatta today. Twenty-five craft, made up of fifteen Class A and ten Class B boats, were in the competition, which turned out to be one of the best days of racing the Frostbite Yacht Club sailors have had.

The Viscose Company will put into effect today price reductions averaging 10 cents a pound on its viscose process yarns. The 10-cent cuts apply to all denier from 50 to 150, inclusive, while 9-cent revisions are made on the 200-denier numbers and a 5-cut reduction on the 300-denier styles.

Do people who habitually remember and quote poetry ever honor in that way the poets they have read since they were young? They see or hear something that brings a tag of verse from their school days to mind. They read "Hamlet" again and are amazed to find it made up entirely of quotations.

BERLIN, April 1. -- The Berlin Boerse on Friday recorded the severest decline since 1931. Stocks began the week with advances In certain favorites, but the general tendency was toward lower prices. Thereafter, with the exception of Wednesday, headlong selling by professionals and the public was induced partly by the disorders in Brunswick, but mainly as a result of the boycott on Jews.

Three men, accused by the police of implication in the "radiogram racket" by which scores of prominent men are said to have been swindled of sums aggregating several hundred thousand dollars in the last eight years, were rounded up here Saturday and locked up yesterday in police headquarters charged with attempted grand larceny.

If we regard the League of Nations simply as a machine that should function automatically, war is inevitable, the Rev. Dr. Charles Alexander Richmond, president emeritus of Union College, Schenectady, said in a sermon yesterday at the Park Avenue Presbyterian Church, at Eighty-fifth Street.

HARTFORD, Conn., April 2. -- Beer will flow freely only under Federal regulations in Connecticut Friday and for some time thereafter, because Connecticut's State enforcement law at present follows Federal practice and the long, complicated liquor control bill, which includes beer regulations to be proclaimed by the Governor, cannot get through the Legislature this week.
NEWARK, N.J., April 2. -- The Phillies regained winning form today with an impressive 3-to-0 shutout victory over the Newark Bears, International and minor league champions of 1932.
Will They Walk? So many things can be said in favor of the big slum-clearing project on lower east side that one may venture to be skeptical on a minor point.

The only surviving copy of a book published in Edinburgh, Scotland, in 1571, left the United States recently and now has returned to the city of its origin, after an absence, so far as can be learned, of more than 350 years.

TRENTON, N.J., April 2. -- With the Legislature scheduled to act tomorrow night on a bill giving the municipalities of New Jersey practically unlimited authority to issue retail licenses for the sale of 3.2 beer, Senate President Emerson L. Richards of Atlantic City warned tonight in a statement that misuse of this power would lead to State control.

Robert Moses, chairman of the Emergency Public Works Commission, in a statement issued yesterday criticized Frederick L. Cranford, who resigned from the commission Saturday, for his advocacy of "vague projects" not related to the work assigned to the commission by Governor Lehman.

Steel ingot production last week was lifted 1 1/2 points to 15 1/2 per cent of capacity, with greater gains in finishing mill operations than indicated by this rate, the magazine Steel says in its weekly review. The magazine expects a moderate upturn in operations in April, influenced by seasonal requirements, expansion in beer production and distribution and increased demand from the automotive industry.

Germany is carrying on her ordinary pursuits in orderly fashion, notwithstanding the "wild reports" on conditions in the country, Dr. Friedrich Bergius, scientist and Nobel Prize winner, said yesterday in an international radio broadcast from Berlin, received in the United States through stations of the National Broadcasting Company.

Margaret Barker, whose last appearance on Broadway was in the Group Theatre's presentation of "Success Story," has been signed for the ingenue role in "Hilda Cassidy." Others recently added to the cast are George Greenberg, Frieda Altman, Charles Moyer, Harry Hanlon, Max Beck and Joseph Olney.

PHILADELPHIA, April 2. -- The combined net income of the United Gas Improvement Company for 1932 was $35,384,300 after deduction of depreciation charges, taxes, subsidiary interest and dividends and minority interest, the annual report shows. After payment of dividends on preferred stock this is qual to $1.36 a share on the common stock outstanding, comparing with a combined net income in 1931 of $37,722,774, or 51.46 a share.

The mildest day so far this Spring turned all New York outdoors yesterday. With the thermometer touching 64 thousands of families used automobiles, buses and subway or elevated trains to head for the near-by coast resorts, while thousands of others paid their first visit to the city parks since Autumn.

VATICAN CITY, April 2 (AP). -- Pope Pius today had one of the busiest days of his career in the first day of the Holy Tear in receiving thousands, including school children and a number of high prelates. He did not take his usual Sunday drive through the Vatican garden.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In your editorial on the Triborough Bridge you say that "if, as is now proposed, the other East River crossings are to revert to tolls, there is every reason to believe that it will be genuinely self-supporting."

COLUMBUS, Ohio, April 2 (AP). -- Flaig's Opticians of Covington, Ky., scoring games of 1,023, 968 and 1,030, rolled into the five-man lead in the American Bowling Congress tourney tonight with a total of 3,021. New leaders were also established in two other events.

MOUNT HOLLY, N.J., April 2. -- Three fraternity brothers of Bradway 'Brown, Philadelphia printing house executive who was slain at his home at Palmyra on Jan. 16, have been apprehensive lest they too be killed for some unrevealed reason, it was disclosed here today by Prosecutor Howard Eastwood of Burlington County.

One of the interesting events in behalf of charitable enterprises this week is the entertainment for the benefit of the Manhattanville Nursery Association which will take place this afternoon on board the 'Queen of Bermuda through the courtesy of the Furness Line.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., April 2. -- The Giants tried to annoy the Tigers with a home run today, but the Detroiters replied with a broad side of three that accounted for seven runs, and so it came to pass that Memphis Bill Terry's men took another inelegant thrashing.

DOVER, Del., April 2. -- Racing northward on the southbound track in order to skirt a slow freight, the Cavalier, the Pennsylvania's crack Norfolk-to-New York express, early this morning struck an open switch at Wyoming, five miles south of here, and jumped the rails, killing two trainmen and causing painful injuries to seven passengers.
To the Editor of The New York Times: Within the last few days two cases came to my attention showing how necessary it is to immediately liberalize our tax-collection system.

After recovering most of their losses of February in five trading days of March, stocks again turned reactionary on March 17, following two days of active trading after the Stock Exchange reopened and three days prior to its closing. They drifted downward throughout the remainder of the month in exceptionally light trading and held only a small part of their gains.
Mr. Matsuoka, in a radio address in Chicago last night over a network of the National Broadcasting Company, said in part:

The fresh water fishermen have been occupying the centre of the stage in recent days, aided by the advent of the trout season in New York State. But the salt water clan has not been entirely removed from the scene. The Great South Bay boat captains reported large crowds over the week-end and good catches.
