It is possible that Major DALRYMPLE of California, sworn in on Saturday as chief of the Federal prohibition service, will be the last occupant of that disappointing office. Eighteen States have definitely set a date for a popular vote on repeal, and similar legislation is pending in nineteen others.

BUENOS AIRES, April 2. -- Statistics for the first quarter do not indicate any change for the better in Argentina's economic situation. Exports continue low compared with previous years, with prices in general lower than the cost of production.

A nation-wide campaign for funds to aid the 600,000 Jews of Germany suffering from political persecution and economic discrimination was launched by the American Joint Distribution Committee at a conference yesterday afternoon. The relief will be conducted on a wide basis and as a humanitarian enterprise devoid of any political character.
PARIS, April 2. -- Germany has become a country of suspicion and fear, a well-known American who has just returned from there declares.

LONDON, March 31. -- The Bank of England continues to accumulate gold, although at a less spectacular rate than heretofore. For the week to date the return of gold brings the total holdings to within u4,000,000 of the high record of u176,500,000 established on Sept. 12, 1928.
ALBANY, April 2. -- Following is the text of Governor Lehman's radio address tonight:

With the new administration's legislative program entering what may be described as the regulatory phase, admiration for the constructive achievements already on the statute books is obscured to some extent, so far as financial interests are concerned, by anxiety at the possibility that a punitive spirit may develop where the purpose should be, both as a matter of public policy and of simple prudence in a troubled period, to apply preventive and corrective measures.

A new science, named psychological geography, which aims to chart the emotional currents, cross-currents and under-currents of human relationships in a community, was introduced here yesterday at the scientific exhibit of the Medical Society of the State of New York, which opens its 127th annual meeting here today at the Waldorf-Astoria.

MOSCOW, April 2 (AP). -- Allan Monkhouse, Moscow director for the Metropolltan-Vickers Electric Company, and a subordinate, Charles Nordwall, have been formally charged with military as well as economic espionage, fostering of "wrecking activities," and bribery.

Former Representative F.H. La Guardia, Republican-fusion candidate for Mayor in 1929, announced yesterday that he would support Aldermanic President Joseph V. McKee for Mayor if the latter would run on an anti-Tammany fusion platform pledging the removal of all unfit and incompetent office-holders and the rehabilitation of the city's finances and governmental morale.

The banking crisis of last month reflected primarily the accumulative effects of the extraordinary decline in business volume during the last four years and the accompanying drastic decline in prices of commodities, securities and properties of all kinds, says the current monthly review of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York in a detailed account of the course of the disturbance.

TORONTO, Ont., April 3. -- With Joe Primeau making a quick recovery from an infected leg which has kept him in the hospital for the past three days, the Maple Leafs expect to be at full strength tomorrow night when they face the Boston Bruins in the fifth and final game of the National Hockey League championship series.

In a telegram to President Roosevelt last night, given out to The Associated Press, R.C. Holmes, president of the Texas company, said the operation of a "lawless element" threatened to "complete the destruction of the oil industry here and abroad and put the last murderous knife thrusts Into the banking situation."

WASHINGTON, April 2. -- Proposed legislation dealing with the railroad situation will be transmitted to Congress this week if the committee of officials headed by Secretary Roper is able to whip it into shape within that time for the President's approval.

ALBANY, April 3 (AP). -- The Assembly is scheduled to determine tomorrow night the fate of the Pitcher milk-control bill, which provides for price-fixing by the State as an emergency measure to restore order to the disrupted milk industry.

PITTSBURGH, April 2. -- Production if steel ingots last week was estimated at about 13 per cent of capacity, the same as In the two Weeks preceding. There had been five successive weekly declines from the high of the year, about 22 per cent in the week ended on Feb. 11, just before proclamation of the banking holiday in Michigan.

For sixty year Colonel James Churchward has been trying to and and put down on paper conclusive proof that all mankind and aH civilization were cradled on the lost continent of Mu, now deep beneath the surface of the Pacific Ocean.

Excepting raw sugar and wool tops, prices for future contracts in local commodity markets worked into lower ground last week. The trading volume was mostly small outside of the sugar turnover. In the cash markets grain prices followed the contract grades to higher levels.
WASHINGTON, April 2. -- High tariff policies of the Eastern two-thirds of Australia are the accredited cause of the threatened Western secession from the Commonwealth.

BUENOS AIRES, April 2. -- Reports of plans for an armed revolt against the dictatorship of President Gabriel Terra reached Buenos Aires from several Uruguayan sources today, including letters smuggled through the censorship and from Argentine towns along the Uruguay River.

Vigorous endorsement of proposed unemployment insurance legislation by a group of business men who believe such legislation is necessary at this time, even though the law were not effective until business conditions improved substantially, was made public yesterday by the American Association for Labor Legislation, 131 East Twenty-third Street.
DETROIT, April 2. -- Michigan voters will cast an estimated 900,000 ballots tomorrow, and be the first in the nation to render a verdict on retention of the Eighteenth Amendment.

Japan is trying to throw off the odium that has come upon, her, because of her activities in Manchuria, by shifting the blame to China, it was asserted last night in an address broadcast from Station WOR by Dr. Y.Y. Tsu, former Professor of Sociology at St. John's University, Shanghai, and now visiting lecturer from Shanghai University to the General Seminary in New York.

WASHINGTON, April 2 (AP). -- Regulations covering the recruiting of 250,000 men for the nation's biggest forest conservation project will place States on a quota basis under which maximum limits will be set for the number of men each can supply.

CHARLESTON, S.C., April 2. -- Brig. Gen. Golden L'Hommedieu Ruggles, who retired in 1930 as Assistant Chief of Ordnance, United States Army, died this morning of heart disease at his Winter residence here. He was 64 years old.

Modern psychology should not be accepted too seriously by the present generation, Professor Frank D. Whalen of Hunter College told 150 members of the Evening Chapter of the Junior Newman Club, an organization composed of Roman Catholic students of New York's evening high schools, at its annual communion breakfast yesterday at Riggs's restaurant, 43 West Thirty-third Street.

Trade union pension systems in the United States, virtually all of which have been operated independently of employers, on the whole are in so precarious a condition that "they cannot much longer be maintained on existing financial foundations," according to a report just published by Industrial Relations Counselors, Inc., 165 Broadway.

Reversing Saturday's result at Pawtucket and outclassing their rivals in decisive fashion, the New York Americans won by 4 to 1 yesterday and eliminated the Pawtucket Rangers from the National Challenge Cup competition of the United States Football Association.

Behind the one-hit pitching of Bob Wetland and Paul Andrews the Boston, Red Sox registered an easy 12-to-0 victory over Jersey City as Manager Mike Kelly and his men made their 1933 debut at West Side Park, Jersey City, yesterday. Dale Alexander hit a home run with one on base in the sixth inning.

Mail and telegraphic orders were heavy in the wholesale market last week and immediate delivery or desirable merchandise was almost impossible to obtain. Manufacturers have no stock and were unprepared for the continuous demand.

NEW ORLEANS, La., April 2. -- While trading in the cotton market during last week was marked by Spurts of activity business in general was professional and participation by the public unimportant. The general financial situation and events in Congress have tended to restrict speculative activity.

EGG HARBOR CITY, N.J., April 2. -- Three persons were killed and five were injured, two of them critically, in a head-on collision of two cars on the Egg Harbor-Mays Landing highway during a drizzling rain about a mile and a half south of here at 11 o'clock tonight.

Disapproval of two pending proposals to set up a State sales tax was expressed yesterday by the Committee on State Legislation of the Association of the Bar of the City of New York, in a report on proposed legislation on taxation and other subjects.

PURNEA, India, April 2. -- Wind conditions here this morning were sufficiently improved for the main flight over Mount Everest to be contemplated, and the whole Houston Everest Expedition assembled at the airdrome at 7 o'clock to await the result of the reconnaissance.
ALBANY, N.Y., April 2 (AP). -- Two school boys were killed and two injured early today when their automobile struck a tree in Madison Avenue, a principal thoroughfare.

Dean Milo H. Gates, in his sermon at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine yesterday, declared that a return to normal economic conditions must be based upon character -- that is, that business men must be men of character.
ALBANY, April 2. -- Prospects for passage in the Legislature's "home-stretch" of a bill creating a system of unemployment insurance seemed brighter today.
PALM BEACH, Fla., April 2. -- In honor of Mrs. Woodrow Wilson, widow of the war President, Mr. and Mrs. Harold Fitz Gerald gave a luncheon today at Wave Crest Cottage.

WASHINGTON, April 2. -- First actual "pictures" of how fast and how hard the ground shivered during the California earthquake of March 10 -- the first time in history that an earthquake has "drawn a picture" of itself -- were made public today by the Coast and Geodetic Survey.

WASHINGTON, April 2. -- Conversations looking to reciprocal trade agreements between the United States and the Irish Free State have been begun with officials here by Senator Joseph Connolly, Minister of Lands and Fisheries of the Free State Government.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., April 2. Messages late today from the Coast Guard cutter Tuscarora, which is convoying the fleet of eleven yachts in the fourth annual St. Petersburg-Havana sailing race, said the schooner Haligonian, owned by Houston Wall of Tampa, and the schooner Antonia, owned by Harkness Edwards of Pittsburgh, had distanced the rest of the fleet.

CHICAGO, April 2. -- Developments today indicated that an allnight celebration of the return of legal beer probably will go on as originally planned, despite the proposal of the Chicago Hotel Association yesterday that the breweries deliver no beer before 7 A.M. Friday.

Excellent scores prevailed at the Travers Island traps of the New York Athletic Club yesterday. The High Scratch Cup was taken by T. H. Lawrence, who broke 99 out of 100 targets. He had a straight run of 97.

BANGKOK, Siam, April 2 (AP). -- The first change in the Siamese Government since its conversion in last year's coup d'etat from one of the world's few remaining absolute monarchies to a democracy was effected peacefully and without bloodshed today.

The selected New York Gaelic football team made a brilliant showing in opening the season at Innisfail Park yesterday, defeating the Tailteann team, which toured Ireland last Summer, 8 to 5. A crowd of 3,000 attended.

Three American records were broken in the handicap weight-lifting meet held under the auspices of the German-American A.C. at its clubhouse yesterday. William Good of the York (Pa.) Oil Burner A.C., competing in the heavyweight class, broke the two-hand snatch mark with a lift of 231, one pound more than the old record.

DECATUR, Ala., April 2. -- The jury which will begin hearing evidence tomorrow in the Scottsboro case prepared for the task ahead today by attending the services at St. John's Episcopal Church in a body.

THIS is slightly out of season, but several football matters have come up that require attention without delay. Some days ago there was a formal notice that Holy Cross had called the doctor to remedy its football ills, the said doctor being Dr. Edward Anderson, who, in addition to being a specialist on ears, noses and throats, is also a specialist in shifting backs, weaving ends and reverses to the short side.

The Salvation An y's 1933 united appeal for $1,110,000 with which to continue its relief activities in New York City will open with a military dinner and mass meeting at the Seventh Regiment Armory, Sixty-seventh Street and Lexington Avenue, this evening, in which regular army, National Guard and Boy Scout units will join.

Last Friday the State Senate passed a bill succinctly described in the Albany dispatches as "providing for the release of first offenders sentenced prior to March 18. "1932, for first degree robbery or "burglary, after serving ten years "of their sentence."
VIRGINIA BEACH, Va., April 2. -- Paul Runyan, diminutive professional from White Plains, N.Y., today won the cavalier open golf tournament with a margin of four strokes over the rest of the field.
NEW YORK. Sir Harold and Lady Boulton will arrive next week on the Santa Paula from a world cruise and will be at the St. Regis until they sail, later this month, for their home in England.

The annual exhibition of the Allied Artists of America will open privately today and to the public tomorrow at the Brooklyn Museum. It contains less than 300 items as against nearly 400 at last year's show. The previous exhibition was held at the Fine Arts Building, where the Spring exhibition of the National Academy is now in progress.

Representatives of veterans' organizations were generally reticent yesterday about the details of the $400,000,000 cut in veterans' compensation announced by President Roosevelt Saturday. Most of the representatives of the American Legion who were reached declined to comment without further study of the provisions, or on the ground that their opinions would not be representative of the organization.

MARTINEZ, Cal., April 2 (AP). -- The body of a young Filipino woman, who authorities here said was burled alive by members of a secret society, was exhumed today from a grave on Jersey Island in the San Joaquin River forty miles from here.

CHICAGO, April 2. -- Business Is steadily gaining in virtually all lines. Although the improvement from week to week is not large, the undertone suggests a more confident feeling. With increased consumption and Improved banking facilities, the outlook is better than in many months.

MEMPHIS, Tenn., April 2. -- The Yankees resumed their winning ways today before the largest crowd to see them perform thus far this year. With some 8,500 fans looking on at Russwood Park, the world's champions defeated the Memphis Chicks, 6 to 0, for their first shutout triumph of the year.

Mayor O'Brien's plan to achieve transit unification by dealing directly with the security holders of the Interborough and B.M.T. behind closed doors was assailed yesterday by former Mayor John F. Hylan, under whom Mr. O'Brien served as Corporation Counsel.

PARIS, April 2. -- With the official Italian and British interpretations and the objections of the Little Entente before it, the French Cabinet will draft tomorrow a statement of its position on the proposal of Premier Mussolini of Italy for a four-power European peace pact.

From the Congressional Record of March 29 it appears that Mr. COPELAND'S bill relating to the prescribing of medicinal liquor "was ordered to be engrossed for "a third reading, read a third time "and passed." With such Tacitean brevity is a great reversal of Senatorial opinion or a docile submission to public opinion registered.

Dr. Clarence True Wilson, secretary of the Methodist Board of Temperance, Prohibition and Public Morals, and Fred A. Victor superintendent of the State Anti-Saloon League, joined last night in a denunciation of beer before more than 300 persons in the Eighteenth Street Methodist Episcopal Church, 305 West Eighteenth Street.

To the Editor of The New York Times: It is good news -- in these days when economic dogma and tenet are excellent journalistic fodder -- that J.M. Keynes has been converted to the establishment of a world "trade dollar."

Shipping interests acting through the Maritime Association of the Port of New York announced yesterday their opposition to legislation which would restrict the placing of workmen's compensation insurance in New York State exclusively with the State fund.

Under direction of Presiding Justice Edgar J. Lauer, the Municipal Courts of the city will begin today a drive to bring up to date their calendar, which are eight months behind, with 8,000 cases awaiting trial.
CHICAGO, April 2 (AP). -- Tax reduction was the battle cry today in several State Legislatures and apparently taxpayers can look forward to reductions of at least $100,000,000.

PARIS, March 31. -- During the week London continued the acquisition of gold, taking an even larger amount than was indicated as having left the Bank of France, as some gold arrived from elsewhere. Since Dec. 2 the Bank of France has lost 2,736,000,000 francs in gold.

American Jewry is just beginning to realize that the foundation of Jewish life in this country lies in a sound system of Jewish education. Dr. Bernard Revel, president of Yeshiva College, declared last night at a dinner commemorating the thirty-third anniversary of the founding of the Rabbi Jacob Joseph School, 165 Henry Street, at the Hotel Astor.

CHICAGO, April 2. -- Hog-raisers of the West are confident and are slow to sell hogs below $4 in the Chicago market and curtail their marketing movements on all breaks. The trade in general, however, is said to be unable to take more than light to moderate supplies and runs of about 10,000 hogs daily would easily satisfy the demand.

Jim Browning, regarded by the New York State Athletic Commission as the world's heavyweight wrestling champion, successfully defended his title against Nick Lutze. California, at the Seventy-first Regiment Armory last night before a crowd of 3,000 persons.

An amendment to the minimum basic agreement now existing between the Dramatists' Guild of America and the theatrical managers and producers, whereby the fees to be paid to the arbiter for the sale of all motion picture rights to legitimate productions shall not exceed $20,000 in one year, has been prepared by a committee representing the Guild and a group of managers affiliated with the League of New York Theatres.

BUENOS AIRES, April 3. -- After several months of study of Argentina's financial, economic and banking situation, Sir Otto Niemeyer, vice governor of the Bank of England, in a 12,000-word report, recommends the abolition of the Gold Conversion Office as obsolete and inadequate to meet Argentina's currency and credit problems.

WASHINGTON, April 3. -- Divorce of security affiliates from banks under the Federal Reserve System within one year is now proposed by Senator Glass, with President Roosevelt reported to be standing behind this proposal and other reforms to be presented by the Virginia Senator in a measure soon to be put before Congress.

LONDON., April 3. -- Norman H. Davis, President Roosevelt's diplomatic representative, is leaving tomorrow for Paris, having finished his first series of conversations concerning the World Economic Conference with members of the British Government.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., April 3. -- Aside from a dash of rain which washed out the exhibition game between the Yankees and the Nashville Volunteers and the fact that the seems unable to say definitely who will play shortstop when the championship season opens, nine days hence, Joe McCarthy, boss of the world's champions, appeared to have no serious worries today.

LONDON, April 3. -- Love letters from Prime Carnera were read in King's Bench Court today before Miss Emella Tersini, a waitress in a restaurant in the Soho quarter of London, received an award of u4,200 [$14,400] damages against the boxer for breach of promise.

The New York Public Service Commission, after an investigation begun on its own motion, has made a report stating that properties did not cost the Associated Gas and Electric System more than $2,275,000 when bought from outsiders were placed on the books of the New York State Electric and Gas Corporation at $6,500,000.

WARSAW, April 3. -- A protest against the burning of an effigy of Chancellor Hitler in the market-place of Kattowice was made today by the German Consul General to the Governor of Polish Upper Silesia. The effigy was burned Sunday by Polish students, who also destroyed German newspapers and magazines seized from shops.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., April 3. -- Defending the first championship won by any Yale baseball team since 1899, the current Eli nine faces the Eastern Intercollegiate League campaign somewhat better prepared than the team which led Columbia for the Hutchinson cup a year ago.

Passenger ships of the United States Lines operating between Hamburg and New York will abandon the practice of taking on passengers from tenders at Cowes Roadstead, off Southampton, on their westbound trips, effective with the sailing of the Manhattan today from Hamburg.

BERLIN, Arpil 3 -- The Olympic Games, scheduled to be held in Berlin in 1936, were drawn into the Nazis's anti-Semitic campaign when the Nazi press opened fire on Dr. Theodor Lewald, chairman of the Reich committee on physical training and a member of the international Olympic committee.
Small housing properties comprised the bulk of the New Jersey realty turnover reported yesterday, though another brewery deal also was included in the transactions.

WASHINGTON. April 3. -- Declaring that the United States has given substantial evidence of a return of confidence in its financial institutions, Secretary Woodin in a radio address tonight called for a further return of hoarded money to the banks.
The opening of "The Secret Among Four" has been indefinitely delayed. The play, the work of John D. Haggart, had been rehearsing under the management of Kenneth Nash.

CHICAGO, April 3 (AP). -- The University of Chicago's "new deal" in football started today when, for the first time in forty-two years, a new head coach, Clark Shaughnessy, took charge of the university's gridiron forces.
WASHINGTON, Tuesday, April 4 (AP). -- Following is a list, telphoned by the Naval Air station at Lake-hurst, N.J., to the Navy Department early today, of those aboard the airship Akron last night:

COLUMBUS, April 3 (AP). -- A new doubles record for the American Bowling Congress was established today when Gil Zunker and Frank Benkovic of Milwaukee turned in a total of 1,415, thirty-five pins better than the former record.

WASHINGTON, April 3. -- Claude G. Bowers, editorial writer and author of political books, was appointed Ambassador to Spain today by President Roosevelt, who also sent to the Senate the nomination of Sumner Welles of Maryland to be Assistant Secretary of State.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Why not settle the subway fare problem once and for all by charging 5 cents on local trains and 10 cents on express trains? This would involve no serious difficulties, merely the building of longitudinal fences on the express platforms, separating local from express traffic, and having turnstiles through which one entering the express enclosures would deposit an extra nickel.

LONDON, April 3. -- An appeal for the relaxation of immigration restrictions to enable German Jewish refugees to enter Palestine was made in the House of Commons by a number of independent Laborites, but Sir Philip Cunliffe-Lister, Secretary for the Colonies, found many difficulties in the way.

The New York Rangers, happy over having survived two strenuous rounds of post-season play in the fight for the world's professional hockey championship, arrived in New York last night confident that they will carry through to win the Stanley Cup.

NEWARK, N.J., April 3. -- The belief that John di Giacomo, 55 years old, of 135 Seventh Avenue, had cast a "spell" that had brought misfortune to the home of friends with whom he had broken, led to the fatal shooting of di Giacomo at the corner of Sheffield Street and Seventh Avenue today, according to a statement made to the police by Michael Marino, 63, of 53 High Street.
James Truslow Adams, American historian and author, is returning from Europe today on the Cunarder Aquitania. Others arriving in the ship from the Channel ports are:

That the railroads, despite their difficulties, will remain the basis of transportation in this country is predicted by W. W. Atterbury, president of the Pennsylvania Railroad, in his report for 1932. He asserted, however, that methods of regulation should be changed and that the carriers should be permitted to earn in good times surpluses to tide them over adverse periods.

WASHINGTON, April 3 -- Robert Fechner of Massachusetts was appointed by President Roosevelt today to be Director of Unemployment under the unemployment reforestation act. He will begin his duties within the next few days, and the administration expects to have 25,000 men working in the forest camps within a fortnight.

Plans for shifting men from home relief to work relief were completed yesterday by the New City Home and Relief Commission, and by the end of this month, according to Welfare Commissioner Frank J. Taylor, it is hoped to have 75,000 men in relief jobs.

For years one of the major educational problems in this city was to provide full-time instruction for every pupil in the elementary schools. Gradually the seating capacity has been gaining upon the school census and today the City Superintendent of Schools reports that in Manhattan Borough the number of pupils on full time in the day elementary schools at the end of 1932 was 100 per cent of the total registration.
OYSTER BAY COVE, L. I., April 3. -- This village, which was incorporated by a group of wealthy residents in 1931, was without a government tonight.

PARIS, April 3. -- Definite limits to the scope and method of any revision of post World War treaties by the four big powers will be fixed by the French Government in a memorandum that has been prepared, and will be approved Wednesday for submission to Britain and Italy.

Max Cooperman of 106 Norfolk Street, Republican watcher in the Fifth Election District of the Fourth Assembly District at the last election, was the chief witness yesterday before Supreme Court Justice McNamee and a jury in the trial of Nathan Silver, Irving Markel, Fred Friedman and Louis Coolick for returning intentionally a false count of the vote in that district.

ALBANY, Tuesday, April 4. -- After a stormy debate of more than three hours, the Assembly at 1:45 o'clock this morning passed the Republican beer-control bill sponsored by Assemblyman Harry F. Dunkel by a bare majority vote of 76 to 73.

BALBOA, C. Z., April 3. -- George Bernard Shaw, the playwright, who arrived here on board the liner Empress of Britain today, told reporters he was not looking forward to his visit in New York, nor to anything else except dinner.

Mayor O'Brien announced yesterday that in the event the Legislature failed to enact beer-control legislation before Friday he would ask the Board of Aldermen to enact a form of license to provide revenue for the city from the sale of the 3.2 per cent beverage.

Mayor John P. O'Brien polled 51.4 per cent of the votes cast for Mayor at the last election, the lowest percentage of the vote cast for a Tammany candidate in years, the recapitulation of the recount showed yesterday, when it was made public by the Board of Elections.

WASHINGTON, April 3. -- President Roosevelt sent to Congress today a far-reaching plan for refinancing farm mortgages in a way to make the indebtedness conform more nearly to present commodity prices and carrying a $2,000,000,000 Federal Land Bank bond issue with which to start it off.

Minneapolis, Minn. Offering will be made today of a new issue of $1,020,000 city of Minneapolis (Minn.) public relief and park bonds by a syndicate comprising Lehman Brothers, Phelps, Fenn Co., F. S. Moseley Co., and Foster Co., Inc.

The New York Investors, Inc., of which the Prudence Company, the Allied Owners Corporation and the Realty Associates Securities Corporation are subsidiaries, agreed yesterday at its annual meeting at 162 Remsen Street, Brooklyn, to extend its guarantee of the bonds of the Realty Associates Securities Corporation.

Fluctuations of prices on the Cotton Exchange yesterday were the smallest in some time and the list closed with losses of 2 to 4 points. A sharp advance in wheat steadied cotton, holding the July within a four-point range and stimulating professional short covering.

Nineteen professors of the faculty of political science of Columbia University have reiterated their stand, taken in a manifesto issued in 1926, that a complete revision of war debts was necessary to world stability and economic recovery, according to a survey made public yesterday by The Columbia Spectator, student daily newspaper.
WASHINGTON, April 3 -- President Roosevelt's message to Congress urging enactment of legislation to aid in the refinancing of farm mortgages read as follows:
Eight realty parcels offered at auction yesterday in foreclosure proceedings were bid in by the repective plaintiffs. Three of the properties were in Manhattan and five in the Bronx, as follows:

BERLIN, April 3 -- Jewish business establishments were gradually recovering today from the blow of Saturday's boycott. Some of the most prominent shops, department stores and restaurants reported business from one-half to three-quarters normal.

James J. Farnsworth, 67 years old, widely known railroad advertising representative and former railroad official, died yesterday at his home, 43 Vine Street, Reading, Mass., according' to word received by friends here. He had been in ill health for two months.

While the opening of the drive to clear up the Municipal Court calendars brought an estimated total of 4,000 persons to the Municipal Court Building at 30 West Thirty-fifth Street yesterday and resulted in more than tripling the daily average of cases disposed of there, another experiment in clearing the calendars by inducing the parties in dispute to submit to arbitration was started in the Second District Court in the Bronx.

of New York adopted last night the report of a special committee characterizing as an "extremely disappointing and empty document" the majority report made last year by the Wilbur Committee on the Cost of Medical Care, which urged the socialization of medicine.

The chief pilot of the Houston-Everest expedition is the Marquess of Douglas and Clydesdale, a squadron leader in the auxiliary air force and a well-known amateur boxer. He is 29 and is the eldest son of the Duke of Hamilton and Brandon, head of one of the most illustrious families in Great Britain.

WASHINGTON, April 3 -- Whether beer would be sold in the Capitol remained a question tonight even after conferees reached an agreement on the District of Columbia beer bill, which is supposed to settle the controversy between the Senate and House on this important point.

To the Editor of The New York Times: THE TIMES comments on the homicide record in different sections of the country will, I hope, prove valuable in provoking thought among the younger generation to whom we must look for improved conditions of every character.

"Cat-ears," disguised by its hyphen, had its brief moment in the legal sun yesterday in the Municipal Court. In the slow march of judicial progress down the long columns of disputed words constituting the evidence in New York's one and only word suit, "cat-ears" stood out all by itself.

Only in 1917, when, war conditions accounted for the large number of cases, have clients applied in greater numbers for the help of the Legal Aid Society than in 1932. Its report for that year, just published, reveals a winning struggle against heavy odds to secure justice for the poor.
BERLIN, April 3 (AP). -- Julius Streicher, head of the central anti-Jewish boycott committee at Munich, today issued the the following statement:

In a series of changes preliminary to the unification next Fall of the Bell Telephone Laboratories and the research department of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, H. P. Charlesworth, assistant vice president of A. T. and T., has become assistant chief engineer and E. H. Colpitts, also assistant vice president of A. T. and T., has become vice president of the Bell Telephone Laboratories.

WASHINGTON, April 3. -- Devaluation of the gold content of the dollar and the establishment of a system whereby this content will fluctuate in value along with commodities is proposed in a bill introduced today by Senator Connally.

In preparation for negotiations by the railways with organized labor, to start about June 15, Eastern railroads are circularizing large employer of labor in New York State to determine the extent of wage reductions in recent years. The bureau of information, which is in charge of the work, is the clearing house for labor matters for rail-roads in this region.

WASHINGTON, April 3. -- Senator McNary today blocked for one, and possibly two days adoption of a resolution designed to cover objections by J. P. Morgan Co. to questions put to them in the stock market investigation.

Stock Exchange call money declined to 2 per cent in the last hour after opening and renewing at 2 1/2. The day's minimum was 1 per cent under Friday's final and the lowest since March 2. Outside trades went at 1 1/2 and Federal checks 1/2@3/4. Four months' money was offered at 2 per cent, bringing it in line with earlier maturities and a drop of 1/2 from previous offering.

DECATUR, Ala., April 3. -- Victoria Price, whose testimony two years ago at Scottsboro led Jackson County juries to condemn eight of nine Negro defendants to death, repeated her charges today before Judge James E. Horton and a jury in the Morgan County Court House at the first of the retrials ordered by the United States Supreme Court.

Nunzio Pontorno, unattached, knocked out Pete Qualles of the Trinity Club in the first round to carry off the honors in the heavy-weight class of the amateur boxing tournament staged last night before 1,000 persons at the New York A.C.

The annual report of the Board of Elections, as compiled, by Edward J. McGowan, chief clerk, showed yesterday that the Democratic enrolment in the city had reached the mark of 1,652,140, as compared with 449,166 enrolled in the Republican party.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., April 3. -- Sharp reductions in salaries and numerous changes in personnel marked the organization meetings of newly elected village boards in Westchester County. Democratic boards took control in Elmsford and North Pelham, while the Republicans returned to power in Tarrytown.

The 1933 appointments in the New York Conference of the Methodist Episcopal Church were announced by Bishop Francis J. McConnell at the close of yesterday's session. The list Includes both reappointments and new posts and covers the New York, Kingston, Newburgh and Poughkeepsie districts and the special appointments for the year.

CHICAGO, April 3. -- New high levels on the current upturn in wheat were established today on the Board of Trade, the May selling within a fraction of the outside figure of March 17, and with that exception at the best price since last October.

WASHINGTON, April 3. -- When beer again becomes a legal beverage in Washington, it will be provided at the White House for any one who wants it, the personal views and tastes of the first lady to the contrary notwithstanding.

In considering the plan for refinancing farm mortgages which President ROOSEVELT proposed to Congress yesterday, it is useful first to note the nature of the problem. Of the 6,300,000 farms in the United States nearly 60 per cent are wholly free of mortgage.

BERLIN, April 3. -- Saturday's firmness was carried over to the opening of today's session of the Boerse, a number of stock issues scoring additional gains. I. G. Farben was the object of special interest, in expectation, it was believed, of a 7 per cent dividend declaration at the impending general meeting.

The limitation on policy loans and cash surrender values under which life insurance companies in this State have been operating for the last three weeks was again modified yesterday by George S. Van Schaick, Superintendent of Insurance.

WASHINGTON, April 3 -- Establishment of a Federal coordinator of railroads as the keystone of the Roosevelt program, was endorsed today by Howard Cullman, Commissioner of the Port of New York Authority, following a conference with President Roosevelt at the White House.

Final tabulation of the five-day poll on war conducted on the Morningside Heights campus by The Columbia Spectator, student daily newspaper, showed that, with a total of 920 students voting, 52 per cent would bear arms only in case of an invasion, while 50 per cent would be willing to "suffer imprisonment for the sake of their convictions."

WASHINGTON, April 3. -- The House Rules Committee today agreed in executive session to" report out tomorrow President Roosevelt's arms embargo bill. Chairman McReynolds of the Foreign Affairs Committee is prepared to call it up in the House on Wednesday.

The fifth and last of the extraordinary series of concerts that Walter Damrosch has arranged and conducted for the benefit of the Musician's Emergency Fund took place last night in Madison Square Garden, with Dr. Damrosch conducting and with Fritz Kreisler and Sergei Rachmaninoff as soloists.

Negotiations by O. P. and M. J. Van Sweringen of Cleveland, who control the United States Trucking Corporation, to acquire the National Carloading Corporation, a freight-forwarding agency, from an affiliate of the Pennsylvania Railroad were disclosed yesterday in the announcement that W. G. Bernet, chairman of the trucking company, had been elected president of the forwarding company.

WASHINGTON, April 3 -- Democratic House leaders, concerned over what possible "organized minorities" might do in the days to come, moved today to restore a rule which they liberalized on taking control of the House in the Seventy-second Congress.
WASHINGTON, April 3. - The Bureau of Navigation issued the following orders today, dated March 31:

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., April 3 (AP). -- The schooner Haligonian, commanded by Houston Wall of Tampa, was apparently far in the lead in the fourth annual St. Petersburg-Havana yacht race, according to fragmentary messages picked up from the Coast Guard cutter Tuscarora, convoying the fleet of eleven racing yachts from this city to the Cuban capital.

WASHINGTON, April 3. -- Under a special rule limiting debate to forty minutes, the House of Representatives today by a vote of 299 to 29 passed one of the most drastic proposals ever brought forward in peace time to impose penalties for the publication, sale, mutilation, falsification, obliteration of destruction of any official record, document, book, map, or other paper on matters prepared in an official code.
LONDON, April 3. -- The new account on the Stock Exchange opened cheerfully today, with the market generally firm British funds were easier after a firm opening, while German bonds improved.

TRENTON, N.J., April 3. -- With sale on Sundays prohibited and sales on weekdays restricted to the hours between 7 o'clock in the morning and 12 midnight, a bill providing temporary regulations for the sale of 3.2 beer in New Jersey was introduced in the Legislature tonight by Assemblyman Muir of Union County.

The relationship between the Missouri Pacific Railroad and the Alleghany Corporation, which controls it, has been affected by a change made in the issue of notes by the Terminal Shares, Inc. The last named organization controls terminal properties which have been under acquisition by the Missouri Pacific through annual payments of $1,600,000.

WASHINGTON, April 3. -- With the full support and cooperation of the Department of Justice, United States Attorney George Z. Medalie will remain in his post in New York City until the prosecutions of Charles E. Mitchell, former chairman of the board of the National City Bank, and Joseph W. Harriman, former chairman of the board of the Harriman National Bank and Trust Company, are completed, Attorney General Cummings announced today.

To the Editor of THe New York Times: I think I am in a position, as a Mexican versed in the political history of my country, to correct a misapprehension produced by the wide publicity given to recent protests by certain subversive elements in Mexico against the reception of Ambassador Josephus Daniels based on the fact that as Secretary of the Navy he ordered the American fleet to Vera Cruz in 1914.

Trapped at sea in a violent thunderstorm, the U.S.S. Akron, largest and finest dirigible airship in the world, crashed off the Barnegat Lightship at 12:30 o'clock this morning with seventy-seven officers and men aboard. Among them was Rear Admiral William A. Moffett, Chief of the Bureau of Aeronautics.

PHILADELPHIA, April 3 (AP). -- With extra base hits rattling off their bats almost as frequently as singles, the Phillies today defeated the Athletics, 9 to 6, to square the city series at one -- all before a crowd of 6,000.

Awards were made to sixty-eight members of four City College Winter sports teams at a meeting of the athletic association, according to an announcement yesterday by Professor Walter Williamson, faculty director of athletics. Members of the basketball, boxing, wrestling and freshman swimming units were rewarded.

Breadstuffs commanded higher prices yesterday, but with only mild repercussions in the share market. The sharp advance in grain prices, while it coincided with the presentation to Congress of President Roosevelt's special message asking for farm mortgage relief, resulted mainly from the news that the Farm Board had closed out the bulk of its commitments in wheat futures and from the fresh indications of crop deterioration which appeared over the weekend.

MOUNT HOLLY, N. J., April 3. -- Radio Matilda, a white and orange pointer bitch, owned and handled by E. A. Lantermann of Morristown, N. J., today won the Gustave Pabst blue ribbon trophy as the annual fields trials of the English Setter Club of America got under way.

WASHINGTON, April 3 (AP). -- The Reconstruction Corporation today voted 83,725,000 of emergency relief, funds for use in Cook County (Chicago) and forty-four down-State counties in Illinois for the first fifteen days in April.

MONTREAL, April 3 (Canadian Press). -- Art treasures valued at $100,000 were destroyed by an early morning fire in the home of the late Sir William Van Home today. The damage was estimated by fire underwriters. The Van Home collection in its entirety has been valued at $1.250,000.
RENO, Nev., April 3 (AP). -- Herbert Hoover was back in California tonight after an outing in Nevada which was enlivened by a tiff with a camera man at Virginia City.

The Curtiss-Wright Corporation reported yesterday for 1932 a net loss of $596,574 after depreciation, interest, inventory adjustments and other charges, compared with a net loss of $4,126,080 in 1931.

An address by Albert Ottinger former Republican candidate for Governor, at the Women's National Republican Club yesterday, in which the speaker was critical of his party's national record and policies and amenable toward a Democratic candidate for Mayor provoked disapproval among the club members and caused the president of the club to repudiate such views.
NEW YORK. Mrs. Minturn Pinchot and her son, Gifford Pinchot 2d, are at the Savoy-Plaza to stay until they sail for Europe next month.

BUCHAREST, April 3. -- Colonel Pomponiu, Advocate General of the Rumanian Army, went to Prague today to accept an offer of the Skoda Munition Works to allow the correspondence of its arrested Bucharest representative to be deciphered in the presence of a representative of the Rumanian Government.

BERLIN, April 3 (AP). -- The Reichsbank, in its report for 1932, made public tonight, declared a 12 per cent dividend, the same as in 1931. It showed a net profit of 40,000,000 marks (currently about $9,600,000). Of this sum 4,000,000 marks will go into the reserve fund, 18,000,000 marks will be devoted to dividend payments, and the remainder, an equal amount, will be turned over to the Reich's Government.

The science of lighter-than-air aeronautics has been spotted with disasters in the seventy-odd years of its development in rigid airships since Count Zeppelin first flew his semi-rigid balloon in 1859.

A collision of an automobile and a De Kalb Avenue trolley at De Kalb and Nostrand Avenues, Brooklyn, last night, cost Louis Massa, driver of the automobile, his life, and resulted in injuries to six other persons who were riding in his car.

Mr. LEWIS W. DOUGLAS, the new Director of the Budget at Washington, has a short article in the April number of Review of Reviews and World's Work on "Economy in Federal Government." It is, in effect, a sketch of the frame-work within which he has to wield the knife of retrenchment.

Milton C. Stark, Harvard, '33, the defending titleholder, and Peter M. Day, Dartmouth, '35, were the winners yesterday as play started in the annual tournament for the individual championship of the H.Y.P.D. College Chess League at the Marshall Chess Club.

WASHINGTON, April 3. -- President Roosevelt sent a special message to Congress, accompanied by a bill, urging legislation to aid in refinancing farm mortgages; wrote to the Governors of seventeen oil States urging them to take action appropriate to meet the emergency in the oil industry and prepared to ask Congress for authority to start reciprocal tariff agreements to break through trade barriers.

William B. Joyce, chairman of the National Surety Company, issued yesterday a statement designed, he said, to clear up misunderstandings as to the agreement reached between the surety companies and the Reconstruction Finance Corporation relative to the mortgages that the companies had guaranteed before the discontinuance of such business at the end of 1928.

Bond prices worked moderately lower yesterday in quiet trading on the Stock Exchange. United States Government bonds were weak early in the day before the text of President Roosevelt's message to Congress on farm-debt aid was published.

WASHINGTON, April 3. -- Acting upon reports submitted by Secretary Ickes, President Roosevelt asked the Governors of oil-producing States today to cooperate with each other in curtailing the production of oil and in closing all flush pools.

WASHINGTON, April 3. -- Despite the increase in rates written into the revenue act of 1932, income tax collections for March showed a decline, as a result of the option given taxpayers to postpone filing returns from March 15 to March 31. This option was granted because of the position in which many taxpayers were placed by the banking holiday.
JACKSONVILLE, Fla., April 3. -- Rain today deprived the Dodgers of a chance for an even break in their exhibition series with the Browns.

WASHINGTON, April 3 (AP). -- Delving deeply into President Roosevelt's Executive order decreeing $400,000,000 annual savings in veterans' benefits to determine its full effect upon thousands of beneficiaries, the Veterans' Administration is completing detailed instructions to carry the plan forward.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The interested minority which wants political advantage and special benefits from the beer bill is the tail. The silent majority which wants a beer bill free from politics and conceived fairly and impersonally is the dog.
To the Editor of The New York Times: The letter published in THE TIMES under the heading "Cuba's Plight" is only a lean picture of the realities of Cuba's present conditions.
HAVANA, April 3. -- Sentences of death assessed by a court martial on four civilians, but later modified, have been thrown out by the Supreme Court of Cuba, it was learned today.

IN April of 1928 Governor Alfred E. Smith was marshaling his forces for a Presidential campaign, Mr. "Cash and Carry" Pyle's famous Bunion Derby was limping through Texas, Gene Tunney was smiling broadly at the prospect of demolishing Honest Tummas Heeney in a bout for the world's heavy-weight championship and the roving Rangers of hockey were in a wild scramble for the Stanley Cup.

WASHINGTON, April 3. -- The Wagner-Costigan-La Follette $500,000,000 relief bill, which passed the Senate Friday, met opposition in the House today when Representative Snell made a point of order against it on the ground that it was a revenue measure and thus should have originated in the House.

CHICOPEE FALLS, Mass., April 8 (AP) -- Real estate, buildings and other property of the Fisk Rubber Company, in receivership since 1929, were sold at auction here this afternoon to Orrin G. Wood of Boston, representing the so-called Fisk reorganization committee, for $3,30,000.

TORONTO, Tuesday, April 4 -- The Toronto Maple Leafs won the longest hockey game in the history of the sport early this morning, defeating the Boston Bruins by 1-0 after l Hour, 44 minutes and 46 seconds of overtime.

A high protein reducing diet permitting the patient to eat as much as he or she may desire was described yesterday at the twenty-seventh annual meeting of the Women's Medical Society of New York State at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria by Dr. Josephine Hemenway Kenyon of New York.
CONCORD, N. C., April 3 (AP). -- Court action to determine what claim baby Anne Cannon Reynolds has to the R. J. Reynolds tobacco millions was started here today.

Mayor O'Brien held a two-hour conference on transit unification yesterday, with spokesmen for a committee representing the holders of the 5 per cent mortgage bonds and 7 per cent notes of the Interborough. Assisting him were John H. Delaney, chairman of the Board of Transportation, and William G. Fullen, chairman of the Transit Commission.

MUNICH April 3. -- All Jewish stores were open here as usual this morning and eager crowds of German purchasers proved that only the Nazi storm troops and not a spontaneous feeling had kept them away.
DETROIT, (Tuesday) April 4 (AP). -- The repeal outpouring seemed destined to equal, proportionately, the margin by which Michigan's own bone dry amendment was eliminated last November.

CANNES, France, April 3. -- James J. Walker, former Mayor of New York, and Betty Compton, the actress, got complete information at City Hall today about the regulations that must be observed by people who are married under the French law.

Events are bearing out the varied reports that the German Government has been given furiously to think about the consequences of its recent course. Something, some influence, some power, has intervened to slow down the orgiastic Nazi program.

CONCORD, N. H., April 3 (AP). -- A bill legalizing betting on horse races in New Hampshire automatically became law today upon the failure of Governor John G. Winant either to sign or veto the measure. The bill was introduced primarily to permit the Rockingham Park race track at Salem to operate a pari-mutuel system, but it also permits the operation of betting machines at State fairs.

The Akron, which, was named by Mrs. Hoover and made its first flight as an official part of the United States Navy on Aug. 8, 1931, is the largest airship in the world. Twice as large as the Los Angeles and one-third again as large as the Graf Zeppelin, it is a smooth-riding and powerful craft.

A challenge to the American people to advance to victory in our second great war of of the twentieth century -- the war against hunger and want, unemployment and business paralysis, and most of all, fear -- was flung out last night by Secretary of War George H. Dern, Evangeline Booth and other speakers at the launching of a drive for $1,110,000 for the support of the Salvation Army's relief activities in New York City.

WASHINGTON, April 3 (AP). -- Framers of the administration bill to regulate the sale of securities conceded today that some of its provisions would work unintentional hardships and changes immediately were proposed to apply it only to new issues or parts of old issues not yet offered for sale.

PURNEA, India, April 3. -- Mount Everest, the world's loftiest peak, has been conquered. Today the two planes of the Houston Expedition flashed over its white summit, which reaches more than 29,000 feet into the sky and had hitherto resisted every assault by man.

Plans have been completed by Miss Ethel Cleveland Lenssen and John Findlay Allen for their marriage, which will take place on the afternoon of April 29 in St. James's Episcopal Church, Madison Avenue and Seventy-first Street. The Rev. Dr. George P. T. Sargent, rector of St. Bartholomew's Church, a cousin of Mr. Allen, will perform the ceremony, assisted by the Rev. Sidney Cooke, assistant rector of St. James's Church.

MEMPHIS, Tenn., April 3. -- Undiscouraged by rain, which made the field wet and treacherous, Memphis Bill Terry gave his hometown folks a look at the 1933 edition of his New York Giants today in a walk-away victory over the Memphis Chicks, 10 to 2.

Maill Orders Continue Heavy. Mail orders for apparel and accessories continued to reach this market in heavy volume yesterday, reflecting the active retail trade at the close of last week. The call for coats, dresses and suits was particularly good and producers here will be hard put to it to make delivery in accord with retailers' wishes.

The thirty-fifth anniversary celebration, of Madison House, 226 Madison Street, on the lower east side, was inaugurated last night when members of the mothers' and fathers' clubs, ranging in age from 30 to 60, appeared in a dramatic sketch retracing the history of the house.

ALBANY, April 3. -- Both, houses of the Legislature began determined efforts tonight to bring about final adjournment by Friday, despite the view of Governor Lehman that many important problems still require more consideration than can be afforded them during the days intervening.
DETROIT, Tuesday, April 4. -- An overwhelming trend for repeal of the Eighteenth Amendment was shown yesterday as Michigan held a referendum to determine the Stafe's attitude on ratification.

MINEOLA, L. I., April 3. -- A program of economy on which the campaigns of the recent villages had been based was reflected tonight in salary cuts ordered at the organization meetings of boards of trustees in this and other villages of Nassau County.
To the Editor of The New York Times: Referring to Topics of The Times of March 26, and the subject of the increase in the number of students at the German universities:

TRENTON, N.J., April 3 -- The designation of thirty-two Democrats was announced here tonight as candidates for election at the primaries May 16, as delegates at large to the State convention for action on repeal of national prohibition. These candidates have the endorsement of the Democratic State Committee and will be pledged to ratification of repeal.
WASHINGTON, April 3. -- Loans of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation during February increased sharply as many banks, sought cash with which to meet the demands at depositors.

ALBANY, April 3. -- Governor Lehman sent a special message to the Legislature tonight urging enactment of legislation creating a triborough bridge authority to construct the proposed triborough toll bridge as a self-liquidating project.

BERLIN, April 3. -- The wonderful news that the Nazi propaganda machine has brought the great United States to its knees and forced it to behave was duly forth-coming tonight and was proclaimed in the heaviest type with the strongest adjectives throughout the thoroughly controlled press.

Ivan the Terrible, first Czar of Muscovy, is still held in some honor in Soviet Russia because he killed so many aristocrats, Stephen Graham says in his biography, "Ivan the Terrible," published today by the Yale University Press. Another Czar still honored there is Peter the Great.

Speculative Interest was limited yesterday and business on the Stock Exchange did not exceed the average for the previous week, which was small indeed. The market was under the same restraining influence that governed the course of trading last week.

Prices for commodities on local exchanges moved irregularly yesterday but in a narrow range. Many of the staples showed gains in some contracts and losses in others. Sugar continued its advance, while silver was lower. Trading was conducted on a limited scale.

PALM BEACH, Fla., April 3. -- Mrs. Fritz B. Talbot, who is visiting Mr. and Mrs. Nathan D. Bill, was luncheon hostess this afternoon at the Beach Club, where Mr. and Mrs. John C. King, John L. Clawson and William Clarke Geer entertained small groups.

PHILADELPHIA, April 3.-Net income of the Philadelphia Electric Company for last year available for dividends and surplus totaled $22,029,157, compared with $21,978,224 for 1931, said the company's consolidated earning statement, issued today.

Several local banks and trust companies issued yesterday statements of their condition as of March 31, although no calls for reports have been issued by the national or State banking authorities. The reports showed a general decline in deposits and in total resources, compared with the figures for Dec. 31, reflecting in part the effects of the recent bank crisis and in part purely seasonal factors.

The question of whether the trout season, in this State should be Inaugurated on the first Saturday in April or at some other date, say two weeks later, long has been discussed among sportsmen and the officials of the Conservation Department.

WASHINGTON, April 3. -- In submitting his message to Congress today on farm mortgage refinancing legislation, President Roosevelt took another step to redeem his pre-election pledges by declaring that he would ask for authority to initiate "practical reciprocal tariff agreements."

With 97.36 per cent of the pupils in the city's elementary schools on full time at the end of the school year on June 30, 1932, the number of pupils on short-time schedules, 2.64 per cent, was the lowest in the history of the city, according to the annual report of Dr. William J. O'Shea, Superintendent of Schools, an instalment of which was made public yesterday.

Decision, was reserved at the close of the second hearing yesterday in the arbitration case between the Actors Equity Association and the Managers Protective Association. Each group again contended the other had breached the ten-year "basic agreement," which will expire May 12, 1934.
WASHINGTON, April 3 -- The text of the administration's bill to aid in the refinancing of farm mortgages:

Julius R. Schmeltzer, senior member of Sehmeltzer, Clifford Co., over-the-counter brokers, shot and killed himself yesterday in his twenty-third-floor offices at 1 Wall Street. In a note left to associates Mr. Schmeltzer said "there is no future here in the Street."

WASHINGTON, April 3 -- President Roosevelt's emergency program for rehabilitating the railroad industry will make no provision for regrouping or wholesale consolidation of existing lines, it was disclosed today by an official engaged in drafting the, plan after the concluding conference of various interested groups with the committee headed by Secretary Roper.

Mike Meola, rookie right-hander, and Henry Johnson kept four hits well scattered as the Boston Red Sox made a clean sweep of the two-game exhibition series with Jersey City at West Side Park, Jersey City, yesterday by blanking the home team again, 6 to 0.

WASHINGTON, April 3. -- Former Representative Ruth Bryan Owen is to be the next Minister to Denmark, and the first woman ever named by an American President to represent this country at a foreign Court.

Idealist Keeps Ideals ! In Siam a royalist stroke has brought about the fall of the popular regime, consisting of a band of "young idealists" headed by LUAN PRADIT. The Bangkok report says that the chances of a counter-attempt by him are considered slight, because he is "a patriot interested only in restoring the prosperity of the farmers, developing health education and similar matters."

Discrimination against physicians "based on race or creed" was condemned in a resolution adopted yesterday by the House of Delegates of the Medical Society of the State of New York on the first day of the 127th annual meeting of the society at the Waldorf-Astoria.

Anthony Carfano, 35 years old, known in Brooklyn as Little Augie Pisano, was arrested as a fugitive from justice yesterday at Fifth Avenue and Union Street, Brooklyn, at the request of Police Captain Harry Jenkins of Union City, N. J.

PURNEA, India, April 3. -- Immediately after we left the ground I began my routine duties. At the start of all high-altitude flights, a number of vital checks must be made, and to avoid omitting any I made a list amounting to forty-six separate jobs.

PARIS, April 3. -- The German tug-boat Seefalke, putting into Brest this afternoon with the Norwegian freighter Borgfred, which had been salvaged after grounding last Friday, was seized by the French authorities on the demand of the French Maritime Union.

WASHINGTO, April 3. -- The new French Ambassador, Andre Lefevre de Laboulaye, and the new German Ambassador, Dr. Hans Luther, will arrive in Washington at about the same time. M. de Laboulaye is expected on April 12, according to French Embassy officials, and the German Embassy is expecting Dr. Luther on April 14.

PINEHURST, N.C., April 3. -- Richard A. Jones Jr. of the Westchester Hills Golf Club, White Plains, N.Y., came within a shade of scoring the biggest golf upset of the Pinehurst season when he carried George T. Dunlap Jr. to the nineteenth hole before losing to the Walker Cup star in the first round of the North and South amateur journey today.

KENT, Conn., April 3. -- The two varsity lightweight crews from Harvard that arrived at Kent School yesterday for the races on Wednesday were on the river for a pair of workouts today. The Harvard crews are coached by Fred Sullivan, former varsity coxswain.

In the presence of a crowd of obviously sympathetic spectators, Magistrate Thomas F. Casey in Brooklyn Homicide Court dismissed yesterday a charge of murder against Anthony Malandro, 17-year-old high school student, of 377 Atlantic Avenue, Brooklyn.

ALBANY, April 3. -- Despite the depression, the State's credit has been raised to the highest point in its history, Morris S. Tremaine, State Controller, said today in his annual report to the Legislature.

As the tide turned to run out of the Harlem River yesterday afternoon, three shells and two training barges were launched from an old riverboat, repainted a brilliant green, and with a gray ex-navy motor boat following them, the little Manhattan College flotilla staged the first outdoor workout of the year.

Strange sounds have come recently from the four-story brown-stone building with the broken windows and the "For Sale" sign outside at 3 East Sixty-sixth Street, where Ulysses S. Grant lived after retiring from the Presidency.

PURNEA, India, April 3. -- The flight over Mount Everest today was carried out with no more fuss than if it had been an ordinary service night at home in England, and it was completed in exactly three hours.

President ROOSEVELT and Congress have succeeded in eliminating the most glaring abuses in World War veteran pensions and privileges. A good deal of mopping up remains to be done, however, especially in the sphere of special favors and direct payments to veterans who claim that they are suffering from some minor disability when in fact it has not interfered with the performance of their ordinary professional duties or their ability to earn a livelihood.

The seventh annual Associated Press pennant poll, with a batting average of 500 to its credit since 1927, pointed yesterday to the New York Yankees and Pittsburgh Pirates as the probable winners of the 1933 major league baseball races.

LONDON, April 3. -- An enabling act by which Parliament would give to the government new power to put an embargo on any or all imports from Russia will be presented in the House of Commons tomorrow, and the government hopes to have the measure rushed through all stages by Wednesday night, when it would go to the House of Lords for equally hurried action.
WASHINGTON, April 3. -- Movements of vessels follow, all dates are April 1 unless otherwise specified:

Replying to the proposal by Nathan Straus Jr., president of the Park Association of New York City, that the city's unemployed be used to landscape the thirty-four-acre site of the abandoned lower reservoir in Central Park, Walter R. Herrick, Commissioner of Parks of Manhattan, wrote Mr. Straus yesterday that funds were not available to carry out such a proposal.

"The Propaganda Menace," published today by Century, is the result of several years of study by Frederick E. Lumley, Professor of Sociology at Ohio State University. He attempts to illustrate the workings of propaganda in business, politics, international affairs, religion and education, and shows the various techniques most common in its various forms.

President Roosevelt's recommendations to the Governors of the oil-producing States, if carried out, would be of material aid to the oil industry, C.B. Ames, president of the American Petroleum Institute, said yesterday. He also expressed the opinion that the Governors would cooperate with the national administration in efforts to stabilize the industry.

A move to cut salaries, with the heaviest reductions in the higher brackets, is in progress among the leading life insurance companies of the city. The companies have made provision, however, against reducing small earnings.

Most markets were under restraint yesterday as pending legislation in Washington was exposed to further critical study. Stocks continued to reflect a confusion of opinion and there were few emphatic price movements. Commodities were steady and firm as a rule.

The new English fiction field is largely under the control of "log-rolling cliques," and the quality of English fiction writing in declining, James Truslow Adams, American historian, who spends much of his time in England, said yesterday.

Prices in the local commodity markets were generally steady yesterday. Sugar advanced smartly, but reacted, while silver and coffee closed with gains. Trading volumes were slightly larger than on Monday. In the cash markets most prices continued to move higher.

Young women of society will act as ushers at the performance of three one-act plays to be given tonight and tomorrow night by members of the Lighthouse Players at their Little Theatre, 111 East Fifty-ninth Street. They are the Misses Katharine Hoppin Salvage, Joan Ball, Cassandra Lee Arnold, Harriet Whelan, Virginia Harrison, Esther Kneeland, Virginia Waller and Frances Cookman.

Spokesmen of shipping and civic groups debated the value of a breakwater off the southern shore of Staten Island as against the dredging of the upper bay to a depth of forty feet as a means of increasing anchorage space in the harbor, at a hearing before Colonel G.R. Lukesh, engineer for the First Army District, yesterday at the Army Building, 39 Whitehall Street.

For a time the share market was mildly stimulated yesterday by the strength shown in silver, sugar and a few other commodities. The later reaction in these commodities, however, deprived the market of even this supporting influence. After the flurry in the forenoon, Wall Street took little interest in the proceedings on the Stock Exchange.

Parts of Mr. S.E. MORISON'S forthcoming "History of Harvard "College in the Seventeenth Century," reprinted in The Harvard Graduates' Magazine for March, deal with NATHANIEL EATON, first head professor or schoolmaster rof Harvard, curiously disreputable predecessor of a distinguished line of Presidents.

ALBANY, April 4. -- An effort will be made tomorrow at a conference between the Senate Banks Committee and Governor Lehman, to reach a decision on legislation to establish a central State savings bank system for the State.

Almost a year after his indictment for income tax evasion, James J. McCormick, Deputy City Clerk in charge of the Marriage License Bureau, went-on trial yesterday before Federal Judge John C. Knox and a jury, who were told by Thomas E. Dewey, Chief Assistant United States Attorney, that the defendant had received so many tips from bridegrooms that he had deposited his money in thirty-four separate banks.

With $270,000 of the $300,000 needed to insure continuance of the Metropolitan Opera next year already pledged, plans for a fourteen-week season to open Dec. 25 or 26 are now being formulated, it was learned last night. The signing of contracts and definite decisions on repertoire will not be made until the entire sum has been raised, however.

BERLIN, April 4. -- A new Nazi Protestant movement, styling itself German Christians, which has for its aim "the elimination of parliamentarism from the churches and their reorganization in conformity with the national resurgence," concluded the first convention this evening by the adoption of the following canon:
MOUNT HOLLY, N.J., April 4. -- The severe storm which swept this section disrupted the schedule of the English Setter Club of America, and no dogs were sent into the covers at Medford today.

QUEBEC, Que., April 4 (Canadian Press). -- Finding that essential allegations contained in the action had not been proved. Judge A. Stein in Superior Court today dismissed with costs the suit brought by Price Brothers Co., Ltd., against the Newsprint Institute of Canada for $787,162, which the plaintiff claimed under an agreement entered into on Nov. 29, 1928.

Westchester County, N.Y. A banking group comprising Lehman Brothers, R.W. Pressprich Co. and the Manufacturers and Traders Trust Company of Buffalo obtained yesterday the award of a new issue of $500,000 Westchester County unemployment work relief bonds, due serially on April 1, 1934 to 1943.

WASHINGTON, April 4. -- The silver question will be discussed tomorrow evening by Secretary Woodin and a Congressional group headed by Senator Pittman at a private dinner to be given by the Secretary. It is expected that about fifteen will attend, and Mr. Woodin will obtain for the administration the views of the silver bloc in Congress.

Buyers' Total Shows Gain. Registration of buyers in the market during the week ended yesterday showed an increase over the figures for the preceding week, but remained slightly under the number listed in the same period last year, according to the lists published in THE TIMES.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., April 4. -- Professor George E. Little of Rutgers University announced today the definite program of a four-day coaching clinic which will be held in the Rutgers gymnasium April 14. 15, 17 and 18 under the direction of the department of physical education.

Henrietta Schumann, making what was said to be her formal debut here in a piano recital at the Barbizon-Plaza last evening, was greeted by an audience apparently including many persons aware of her well advanced career up-State and elsewhere since she arrived here once before, in 1924.

BERLIN, April 4. -- The anti-Semitic boycott will not be resumed tomorrow, the government announced today, but the National Socialist party reserved the right to start the movement again if the "atrocity campaign" were revived abroad.

Trading on the Cotton Exchange continued yesterday to be restricted pending the outcome of farm-relief legislation, but selling pressure was absent and prices rose 5 to 6 points, the best quotations of the day being made in the final dealings.

LAKEHURST, N.J., April 4. -- The wives of the officers and enlisted men on the Akron, summoned from their beds early this morning to receive the news of thee tragic end of the airship and the loss of their loved ones, were bearing up heroically tonight under a strain that would have required the steel nerves of the navy's men themselves.

The New York State Athletic Commission, at its meeting yesterday, allotted to Jack Dempsey and Tim Mara. associated in promoting boxing bouts at the Yankee Stadium and , the Polo Grounds, Wednesday nights throughout the Summer season to conduct their shows.

WASHINGTON, April 4 (AP). -- The Forest Service plans to have 200 men at work within ten days planting trees in the Allegheny National Forest in Northwestern Pennsylvania under President Roosevelt's reforestation program.

In response to a warning from Dr. Morton Gottschall, the Acting Dean of City College, that a proposed undergraduate peace poll would be "extremely impolitic" as furnishing ammunition for "very strong groups actively opposed to the college," The Campus, the student newspaper, announced yesterday that it would abandon the project.
WASHINGTON, April 4. -- The official list of those who were aboard the Akron, their home addresses and next of kin were given out by the Navy Department today as follows:

PURNEA, India, April 4 (By Wireless). -- It was a long climb up and out of the mist, and I could do nothing apart from my routine duties as observer and cinematographer on the plane piloted by Lieutenant D.F. McIntyre for more than an hour, as we roared toward the summit of Mount Everest yesterday.

All of twenty-three properties in Manhattan and the Bronx offered at foreclosure auctions yesterday were bought in by plaintiffs who brought about the foreclosures because of defaults. Most of the forced sales involved dwellings and tenement houses.

PINEHURST, N.C., April 4. -- The son of a Japanese Prince, playing in his first amateur tourney, caused the initial upset in the thirty-third annual North and South amateur golf championship today, when Fumitaka Konoye, Lawrenceville Prep's No. 1 man, defeated Jack Ryerson of Coopers-town, N.Y., former Yale star, 1 up.

Details of the proposed deal under which North American Aviation, Inc., would acquire substantially all the assets of General Aviation Corporation, after certain assets and subsidiaries of North American had been segregated into a separate company, were outlined yesterday in a letter sent to stock-holders of North American.

LONDON, April 4. -- Examination of the theory that Dr. Albert Voss, one of the victims of the disaster to the air liner City of Liverpool, had fired the machine in mid-air either to commit suicide or in hope of escaping and making the world believe he was dead brought forth astounding suggestions in the coroner's court at Salford today.

Lieut. Commander Herbert V. Wiley of the United States Navy, the only officer who survived the wreck of the Akron, stood half-way down a flight of stairs in the Brooklyn Naval Hospital yesterday afternoon and in calm, clear phrases told of the last hours of the world's greatest airship.

Lieut. Col. Alfred Fellows Masury of the Army Reserve Corps, one of the guest passengers on the Akron, was vice president, chief engineer and director of the Mack International Motor Truck Corporation, 25 Broadway. He made the flight, according to John Sloan, his secretary, at the invitation of Rear Admiral William A. Moffett.

Fritz Kreisler issued a statement yesterday deploring the pressure being brought "by some artists in American" on Arturo Toscanini not to conduct the Wagerian Festival at Bayreuth next Summer as a protest against the dismissal of certain musicians in Germany from the opera and concert halls for racial and political reasons.

Supporting Nathan Straus Jr., president of the Park Association of New York City, in his movement to restore the thirty-two-acre site of the abandoned lower reservoir in Central Park, landscape architects warned yesterday that incalculable harm was being done to the parks by workers from the ranks of the unemployed who have been set to cleaning up the parks under what they call incompetent supervision.

ALBANY, April 4. -- With the threat of an extraordinary session confronting the tired and disgusted lawmakers if a State beer-control bill acceptable to Governor Lehman has not been passed prior to final adjournment, set for Friday, the Democratic and Republican legislative chiefs made their way to the executive chamber this evening for another conference with the Chief Executive.
Veterans of many years of naval service and representatives of many branches of naval activity were among the men dead or missing from the dirigible Akron.

Tuesday, April 4, 1933. Return of month-end distribution of dividend and interest payments, putting banks into funds, brought about easier rates in all sections of the money market. Stock Exchange call loans were done at 2 per cent, the lowest for standing loans since March 1; outside money was loaned at 1 1/2, and Federal checks 1/2@1.
NEW YORK. Mrs. James C. Ayer of the Pierre will sail Saturday on the Conte di Savoia to pass several months in France and England. She will be joined later by members of her family.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., April 4. -- Led by the gray-haired, distinguished-looking Kentucky Colonel, Earle Combs, who, single-handed, propelled no fewer than five runs across the plate, the Yankees trampeled the Nashville Volunteers today, 13 to 0.

WASHINGTON, April 4 (AP). -- A remodeled bill to reform the national banking laws began to takes hape today in a Senate banking subcommittee with a tentative provision for a deposit-insurance fund for Federal Reserve member banks. The measure was being drafted by the subcommittee, headed by Senator Glass, on the basis of the bill he sponsored in the Senate last session to curb the use of Federal Reserve credit for speculative purposes.

The National Orchestral Association, under the direction of Leon Barzin, continued its commendable practice of presenting solid and at the same time provocative programs at its concert at Carnegie Hall yesterday afternoon. The first half was devoted to Rimsky-Korsakoff's "Russian Easter" overture, distinctly in season, and Mozart's Concerto in E flat for two pianos, with Rosina and Josef Lhevinne as soloists.

BEACH HAVEN, N.J., April 4. -- Fighting landward in the teeth of a forty-five-mile off-shore wind after a dangerous but fruitless search at sea for survivors of the wrecked dirigible Akron, the navy non-rigid blimp J-3 plunged into the ocean here at 1:45 P.M. today, 300 feet off Long Beach bar.

Martin C. Start of Harvard, defending titleholder and favorite for first honors, yesterday defeated Edgar T. McCormick, Princeton captain, to gain a commanding lead in the annual tournament for the individual championship of the H.Y.P.D. College Chess League in progress at the Marshall Chess Club.
