BERLIN, April 4. -- Dr. Hugo Eckener, commander of the Graf Zeppelin, was deeply concerned over the fate of the airship Akron when he attended this afternoon a meeting of the German section of the All People's Association, of which he is chairman.

All the available forces of the navy and of the oast Guard and individuals who put out in their boats from New Jersey beaches to the scene of the Akron disaster ended their day of searching last night on a sea at last calmed of its ferocious wind.
WASHINGTON, April 4. -- Competition between committees in both House and Senate over precedence in sponsoring the administration's farm mortgage relief bill overshadowed the bill itself today.
RICHMOND, Va., April 4. -- Bill McKechnie's Braves and Max Carey's Dodgers paused here long enough today for the Hub athletes to win, 7 to 6. That rarity of base-ball, a triple play, marked the game.

Net income of the Niagara Hudson Power Corporation and subsidiaries in 1932 amounted to $9,378,343, equal to $1.07 a share earned on 8,735,780 common shares, comparing with $13,409,865, or $1.53 a share earned on the same capital basis in 1931.

WASHINGTON, April 4. -- A courage and faith that drew admiring comment from a President's wife today sustained Mrs. William A. Moffett. whose husband, Rear Admiral Moffett, went down on the wrecked dirizible Akron with seventy-two officers and enlisted men.
PALM BEACH, Fla., April 4. -- Mayor and Mrs. John Shepard Jr. entertained at Casa Del Pastor, their home, with a dinner followed by contract this evening. Their guests included:
WASHINGTON. April 4. -- The following is a record of dispatches received at the Navy Department during the day regarding the Akron disaster from various sources:

WASHINGTON, April 4. -- Authority to modify the present license of Press Wireless, Inc., so as to extend its service to certain points in foreign countries, notably between New York and Amsterdam, was asked of the Federal Radio Commission today.

PARIS, April 4. -- With the announcement today that Robert Kane, former European director of the Paramount Company, was now connected with Fox Films, it became apparent that the latter company was in position to dominate the production of talking pictures on the Continent.

As K.K. Kawakami, Washington correspondent for a Tokyo newspaper, explains the present situation in Manchukuo, Japan is trying to "carry the white man's burden, and the white man, long accustomed to think the burden exclusively his own, is reluctant to commit it to the young shoulders of Japan, yellow, and an upstart at that."

Sam Stein of Newark threw Mike Mazurki, former Manhattan College football player, in the feature finish wrestling exhibition at the New York Coliseum last night. Using a series of flying tackles, Stein gained the fall in 24:43. A crowd of 7,000 attended.

OTTAWA, April 4 (Canadian Press). -- Canada's new shipping bill would prohibit grain being carried from the Canadian head of the lake ports to Buffalo in United States vessels and reshipped from there to world markets by way of a Canadian port, the Senate Shipping Committee was told today by representatives of two Canadian ship lines.

PURNEA, India, April 4 (by Wireless). -- The successful flight over Mount Everest was followed today by a flight by both Houston machines over Mount Kanchenjunga, only less successful photographically because a later start was made and clouds had begun to form over the mountains.

Mite boxes have been mailed to all communicants of Grace Protestant Episcopal Church, Tenth Street and Broadway, to be filled for the endowment fund of the parish, according to the report of the rector, the Rev. Dr. W. Russell Bowie, published yesterday as a preface to the sixty-fifth annual year book of the parish.

The American Medical Association as an organization will protect individualism in medicine and will resist socialization of medicine from any source. Dr. Edward H. Cary of Dallas, Texas, president of the association, declared yesterday at the 127th annual meeting of the Medical Society of the State of New York at the Waldorf-Astoria.

Hugh Alessandroni, Fencers Club ace, was among the qualifiers for the semi-finals of the national foils championship competitition last night when he swept past all of his opponents in the preliminary round at the New York Athletic Club.
WASHINGTON, April 4. -- The Bureau of Navigation issued the following orders today, dated April 1:

A combined restaurant and beer garden, replica of a popular Viennese cabaret, is planned for the corner store at 1,854 Second Avenue by John Schmeisel, Yorkvilla restaurateur, who has leased the space from Pauline Pollak. The lease, for a long term, is at a rental considerably above that quoted last month, according to Sidney L. Warsawer, the broker.

The listed bond market displayed a fair degree of steadiness yesterday in quiet trading. As a rule, the active issues of all classifications showed only minor net changes for the day on the Stock Exchange, although the more infrequently traded issues developed fairly wide swings.
PURNEA, India, April 4 (By Wireless) -- Now and then in our flight over Mount Everest yesterday it seemed we never would clear some of the stupendous peaks that rose sheer into our view.

WASHINGTON, April 4. -- Chairman Vinson of the House Naval Affairs Committee discussed the navy's construction program with President Roosevelt today and told newspaper men afterward that the President appeared impressed with the possibilities as an unemployment relief measure.

Last November's vote was by far the largest ever cast in a Mayoralty election. More than two million men and women went to the polls, most of them no doubt attracted by the contest over the Presidency. Tammany's forecast was as accurate as usual so far as its own voting strength, was concerned.

To appreciate the full significance of Michigan's overwhelming vote for repeal of the Eighteenth Amendment it is necessary to look back to the time when that State first adopted prohibition. This was in 1916, one year before the question was put to a test in Congress.
WASHINGTON. April 4. -- The War Department issued the following orders today:

WASHINGTON, April 4 (AP). -- Arthur H. Dean of New York, who said he represented a "number of investors," criticized the administration's securities bill before the Senate Banking Committee today as "a hopeless confusion of ill-as-sorted provisions lifted bodily out of the English marketing act and certain blue sky laws.

Pursuant to the plans of the Chase National Bank to cut adrift the Chase Harris Forbes Corporation and its parent, the Chase Securities Corporation, announced on March 8 by Winthrop W. Aldrich, chairman of the governing board of the bank, a definite move to accomplish the divorcement is expected to be made today, following the regular weekly meeting of directors.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 4 (AP). -- The Pacific Coast Baseball League observed its thirty-first annual opening today in four California cities, and a total of more than 32,000 fans took advantage of new reduced prices to attend inagural games.

The Brooklyn Real Estate Board telegraphed the Reconstruction Finance Corporation yesterday protesting against the granting of a loan for $75,000,000 for construction of the proposed Thirty-eighth Street-Weehawken tunnel. The telegram was as follows:

WASHINGTON, April 4. -- A plan to coordinate terminal facilities at the Port of New York as part of the administration's program for railroad coordination was outlined today by Howard Cullman, Commissioner of the Port of New York Authority, to Secretary Roper, who heads the President's committee on railroad legislation.
BIRMINGHAM, Ala., April 4. -- Leroy Parmelee pitched in midseason form today as he shut out the Birmingham Barons, 7 to 0, in the Giants' one and only appearance here.

Several suits for the reduction of assessments on the Walter J. Salmon realty holdings in mid-Manhattan were filed in the Supreme Court yesterday. Justice McCook signed orders directing the Board of Taxes and Assessments to submit all the proceedings in the cases to the court.

ALBANY. April 4. -- In a move to protect thousands of small investors in guaranteed mortgage certificates, Governor Lehman sent a special message to the Legislature today urging the creation of a quasi-public corporation to coordinate efforts of holders of the certificates, which have greatly shrunk in value, to obtain the best possible settlement.

TRENTON, N.J., April 4. -- A bill for control of the handling of beer from Friday until May 25, when the State Beverage Commission is expected to be ready with a permanent code was passed late tonight by both houses of the New Jersey Legislature.

The Railroad Credit Corporation had made or authorized loans of $62,314,518 to railroads on March 31, according to the monthly report filed with the Interstate Commerce Commission. Of this amount, $56,322,706 had been lent, $1,246,312 had been repaid and $4,745,000 had been authorized, but not lent.

MUNICH, April 4. -- Alfred Rosenberg, Chancellor Adolf Hitler's "private Foreign Minister," declared in an interview today that one of the purposes of the newly created foreign policy section of the National Socialist party, of which he is the head, would be "to carry the realization to the German people that foreign politics is not a matter for a small caste, but the concern of the entire nation."

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., April 4. -- An injury to Captain Malcolm Bancroft forced several changes in the three varsity crews at Harvard during the second day of the double workout program on the Charles River today.

Testimony at the trial of Irving Markel, Louis Coolick, Fred Friedman and Nathan Silver, election inspectors in the Fifth district of the Fourth Assembly District, on charges of intentionally returning a false count at the recent election, was completed yesterday before Supreme Court Justice Daniel V. McNamee and a jury in the County Court House.

Hundreds of candidates for employment under the reforestation act have applied at the Army Information Bureau and to the army recruiting service as well as to State and Federal employment offices in New York City, but they have been turned away with the statement that no information has been available from Washington as to their induction into the new jobs, it was revealed yesterday.
WASHINGTON, April 4. -- Steps were taken by Senate leaders today to remove from, the House bill designed to forbid the publication of government secrets any implied threat to free speech.

To the Editor of The New York Times: American press comments on Colombian economic matters show that the bondholders' associations have gone too far in meddling with private affairs of my country. In fairness to American investors and Colombian taxpayers, realities should be considered.

SHANGHAI, April 4. -- While out-wardly harmonious calm prevails in Nanking, plentiful reports are sifting into Shanghai that indicate the greatest tension in government circles and actual conspiracy in some quarters to oust General Chiang Kai-shek, national commander-in-chief, because the events of the last three weeks confirm the conviction that he does not intend to take any active steps against the Japanese along the Great Wall.

BERLIN, April 4. -- Dr. Alfred Hugenberg, Nationalist party chief and Reich. Minister of Food and Economics, swung into line today with the Nazi anti-Jewish campaign within the official world. He decreed that all governmental syndicates connected with his Ministry be "purged" of "all Jewish and Marxist elements."

Seventy-three officers and men, including Rear Admiral William A. Moffett, chief of the navy's Bureau of Aeronautics, were lost in the wreck of the navy dirigible Akron during a storm early yesterday in the Atlantic Ocean off the New Jersey coast -- the worst airship disaster in history.

The flight of the two planes of the Houston expedition over Mount Everest was much more than a triumph over altitude and climatic rigors. The adventurers were flying into an atmospheric region that had never been penetrated. The peak of Everest was often to be seen as the centre of whirling snows driven by winds at the rate, it was believed, of more than one hundred miles an hour.

Because of the reluctance of the city administration to obligate itself under present conditions to purchase more lands for park purposes, the plans for Marine Park in Brooklyn, prepared by Charles Downing Lay, landscape architect, may have to be revised, it was learned yesterday.
BERLIN, April 4. -- Great anxiety over the continued shrinkage last year of the Reichsbank's foreign exchange reserve is expressed in the bank's annual report, published today.

Mrs. Owen in Denmark. When WILLIAM JENNINGS BRYAN'S daughter arrives in Copenhagen as America's Envoy Extraordinary and Minister Plenipotentiary it will be the second time that a woman has held such high diplomatic office, and on both occasions it will have been in a Scandinavian country.

TOKYO, April 4. -- Rumors of impending Cabinet change were revived today by reports that Kore-kiyo Takahashi, Finance Minister, was determined to resign because he is too old to continue in office. He is 88 years old. He told newspaper reporters today that he wished to retire if a successor could be found, but added that the resignation need not involve the fall of the Cabinet.

Stockholders of the Goldman Sachs Trading Corporation have been called to vote on April 17 on termination of its contract with Goldman, Sachs Co. for management of its operations, on changing its name to Pacific Eastern Corporation, and on the turning of its management over to the Atlas Corporation.

Mayor O'Brien will confer this morning with spokesmen for the holders of Interborough stock and voting trust certificates, to discuss rapid transit unification. He has already held one conference with representatives of the 5 per cent mortgage bondholders and the holders of the company's 7 per cent notes.

The officer standing at his post coolly giving orders, although the heavens open and death stares him in the face, is uppermost in the laconic account that Lieut. Commander WlLEY gives of the Akron's struggle with elemental forces. Between the lines something of the most appalling tragedy in the history of aeronautics can be read.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, April 4 (AP). -- The Eckerd Drugs of Erie, Pa., scoring games of 911, 1,006 and 989 tonight, led the twenty-one fiveman teams participating in the American Bowling Congress tournament. Their total of 2,906 gave them tenth place in the team standing.

CHICAGO, April 4 (AP). -- Angelo Trulio of New York, defending titleholder, and his chief rival, Sam Atcheson of Memphis, Tenn., won easy victories tonight in the second round of the national amateur handball championship singles at the Lake Shore Athletic Club.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., Wednesday, April 5. -- Following Monday's example of Michigan, sentiment for repeal of the Eighteenth Amendment was sweeping Wisconsin as returns were being tabulated early today showing a rejection of prohibition in yesterday's referendum by a margin of about four to one.

KENT, Conn., April 4. -- The Kent School first and second crews and the Harvard varsity lightweight eights participated in workouts today on the Housatonic in final preparation for their races tomorrow that will mark the opening of the 1933 rowing season.
LONDON, April 4. -- The Akron disaster overshadowed all other news here today, eliciting expressions of sympathy on all sides.

Loans on securities to member firms decreased $48,995,475 in March, it was announced yesterday by the New York Stock Exchange. The total at the close of March was $310,961,581, compared with $359,957,056 at the end of February. In the four weeks ended on March 29 brokers' loans as reported by the Federal Reserve Bank declined $47,000,000, or from $418,000,000 on March 1 to $371,000,000 on March 29.

"His own Is dear to every man," but the dearer the greater the agony for those who can find no way to care for their own. There are 120,000 families utterly dependent upon the relief which the city gives them in their homes -- besides the more than normal numbers cared for by private agencies.

The Rev. Edward H. Emett, dismissed pastor of the Manhattan Congregational Church, Broadway and Seventy-sixth Street, was accused yesterday, in a suit filed by the church in Supreme Court, of having misappropriated church funds between April 1, 1928, and last Feb. 14.

WASHINGTON, April 4. -- A project to assemble an international committee of the major foreign powers in Washington this Spring to prepare, through discussions, for the World Monetary and Economic Conference has been taken abroad by Norman H. Davis, special Ambassador in Europe for President Roosevelt.
LONDON, April 4. -- Sir John Simon, Foreign Secretary, today introduced in the House of Commons the promised bill empowering the government to declare an embargo on Russian trade.

WASHINGTON, April 4 (AP). -- Democratic leaders tonight predicted that the Senate would pass in modified form tomorrow the Black bill to apply a shorter work week in industry, after debate had developed sentiment that the thirty-hour-week measure was too drastic.

Mrs. Alfred Jacobsen gave a farewell luncheon yesterday at the Plaza for Mrs. Olive Pearson of London and her daughter, Miss Anne Pearson, who, with Mr. Pearson, will sail for England today on the Aquitania. The other guests were Mrs. John Lovejoy, Mrs. Allmond Blow, Mrs. John C. King, Mrs. Herbert Carr, Mrs. Allmond Blow Jr. and Miss Irene Rich.

WASHINGTON, April 4. -- Temporary permits for the production of wine of 3.2 per cent alcoholic content will be granted to winemakers now holding permits to operate a bonded winery, James H. Doran, Commissioner of Industrial Alcohol, announced today.

BERLIN, April 4. -- A new Nazi Protestant movement, styling itself German Christians, which has for its aim "the elimination of parliamentarism from the churches and their reorganization In conformity with the national resurgence," concluded its first convention this evening by the adoption of the following canon:

Those who saw HENRY IRVING play Don Quixote will remember the way in which, after being battered and disarmed, he struggled to his feet with a hoarse cry of "Victory!" This is irresistibly recalled by the claims of the Hitlerites that foreign nations have been cowed by the threat of making the boycott in Germany even more ferocious.

PARIS, April 4. -- Negotiations successfully conducted through the intercession of the American Chamber of Commerce here today gave evidence of the eagerness of influential French business interests to establish Franco-American trade relations on a reciprocal basis when Ambassador Jesse Isidor Straus reaches Paris.
INEZ, Ky., April 4 (AP). -- Nine men and women were indicted here today and ordered to trial Thursday morning as a result of the "human sacrifice" slaying last February of an aged mountain woman.

Some of the details of the forthcoming Antarctic expedition this Summer under the leadership of Lincoln Ellsworth were revealed yesterday by Sir Hubert Wilkins at a luncheon at the Western Universities Club.

TRENTON, N.J., April 4. -- Republican State Chairman E. Bertram Mott made public today the names of thirty men and women who will be candidates at the May 16 primaries for election as delegates-at-large to the State convention for ratification of the repeal of national prohibition.

WASHINGTON, April 4. -- Unemployment increased in February, according to an estimate based on government figures, and reports from trade unions showed a further increase in March, William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, declared today.

ALBANY, April 4. -- The bill creating a board of milk control with broad regulating and price-fixing powers was passed in the Assembly today after a vigorous attempt to amend it in several hours of spirited debate.

Taking a militant stand against the Republican sponsorship of State legislation aimed at revision of the Greater New York charter, Mayor O'Brien caused the introduction of a bill yesterday providing for a local referendum on the question of whether or not a new charter should be drafted by a commission to be appointed by the Mayor.
ALBANY, April 4. -- Governor Lehman was ready today to take the initiative to compel a decision in the Legislature on charter revision for New York City.

The daily average gross production of crude oil in the United States last week was 2,239,750 barrels, compared with 2,249,650 barrels in the preceding week, a decrease of 9,900 barrels, the American Petroleum Institute reported yesterday.

William Adger Moffett, Chief of the Bureau of Aeronautics, United States Navy, lost with the Akron, would have been retired for age next Autumn with the rank of Rear Admiral. Wherever flying men congregated, whenever "the Admiral" was mentioned it was instantly known that Admiral Moffett was meant.

MUNICH, April 4. -- The writer has just visited Dachau, the site of the concentration camp for those who have incurred the displeasure of the present rulers of Germany but have committed no offense for which they could be tried. Dachau is a market town a half hour from Munich.

A rush to procure fishing licenses in Connecticut was reported yesterday at the State Fish and Game Commission's headquarters in Hartford. It is expected that when the trout season opens in that State a week from Saturday the number of licensed anglers will about equal that of last year.

Slavic music, principally Russian, made the program of the concert given last night by the Musicians Symphony Orchestra in the Metropolitan Opera House, under the leadership of Vladimir Golschmann, the young and brilliantly gifted conductor of the St. Louis Symphony Orchestra.

More than 18,000 persons, the largest crowd ever to attend a hockey game here, saw the New York Rangers defeat the Toronto Maple Leafs in the first battle of the five-game series for the Stanley Cup, emblematic of the world's professional hockey championship, in Madison Square Garden last night.

The money market relaxed further yesterday, reflecting the progressive reduction of the stringency created by the recent bank crisis. Bill dealers cut open-market discounts on bankers' acceptances one-quarter of 1 per cent, carrying short-term bills down to 1 7/8 per cent bid, 1 3/4 per cent offered, or exactly half the rates quoted between March 13 and 16, when the credit stringency reached its peak.

WASHINGTON, April 4 (AP). -- Fortified with all the Senate's constitutional power, the Senate Banking Committee was ready tonight to resume its investigation of that colossus of finance, J.P. Morgan Co., and other private bankers.

Delegates attending the twentieth annual convention of the National Foreign Trade Council at Pittsburgh, April 26 to 28 inclusive, will analyze the administration's plan for negotiating reciprocal tariff agreements with foreign nations, consider credit policies in export trade, study the question of branch plants abroad and discuss trade prospects in Latin-America and in the Pacific trading area, E.P. Thomas, president of the council, announced yesterday.

Americans gave about $60,666,000 to educational institutions in 1932, of which the women's colleges received only $2,000,000, according to an analysis made by the alumnae committee of seven colleges. The heads of Barnard, Bryn Mawr, Mount Holyoke, Radcliffe, Smith, Vassar and Wellesley Colleges met at the Cosmopolitan Club here last night to discuss the future of higher education for women in this country.
BASLE, Switzerland, April 4. -- Following is the balance statement of the Bank for International Settlements giving its condition as of March 31. Figures are in Swiss gold francs at par, 19.3 cents.

DECATUR, Ala., April 4. -- The State of Alabama closed today its second attempt to send Haywood Patterson to the electric chair for a criminal attack on Mrs. Victoria Price two years ago and the defense immediately began its effort to prove her "a perjurer."

To the Editor of The New York Times: A woman who wished to help came to our Adopt-a-Family Committee and asked, "Have you a family with a boy named David which needs help? I have always wanted a boy David." We had a David, and a need and a desire to serve were thereby brought together.

Distribution of 6,525 special packages of Passover food to needy Jewish families will begin this morning from twenty-two relief stations of the Emergency Unemployment Relief Committee, under a plan instituted by Harvey D. Gibson, chairman.
The opening of "Her Tin Soldier," which was scheduled for this evening at the Playhouse, has been postponed until tomorrow evening at the same theatre.

The possibility of a student strike at Columbia College was indicated yesterday afternoon when, following the publication of the 1933-34 catalogue of the college, students found that the university had not renewed the yearly contract of Donald Henderson, instructor in economics and one of the leaders of the Columbia Social Problems Club.

An investigation into the listing practices of the New York Curb Exchange was ordered yesterday by State Attorney General John J. Bennett Jr. He announced that Howard C. Sykes, president of the Curb Exchange, would appear at 11 o'clock this morning at the State Bureau of Securities offices, 80 Centre Street, for examination.
BERLIN, April 4. -- All foreigners, including Americans, who find themselves in Germany will henceforth be unable to leave it without a police permit.

WASHINGTON, April 4. -- The House Committee on Naval Affairs will meet tomorrow and order a complete investigation of the loss of the Akron. Representative Vinson of Georgia, chairman of the committee, was in frequent communication with the Navy Department during the day.

A special meeting of the Board of Aldermen has been called at the request of Mayor O'Brien so that the board may be ready to enact an ordinance regulating the sale of beer and permitting the city to collect revenue on and after Friday in the event that the Legislature does not adopt a beer control measure before then.

WASHINGTON, April 4. -- To the unadmitted decision of the administration, that, before the special session of Congress adjourns, it must seek power to defer war-debt payments on June 15, and to the President's public request for authority to make reciprocal trade agreements issued yesterday has been added another point in the Roosevelt foreign policy.

WASHINGTON, April 4. -- Rear Admiral Moffett considered the United States Navy dirigible Akron far superior to any dirigible built up to this time, the "safest dirigible ever built anywhere" and "something we could all be proud of."

The Museum of Modern Art, 11 West Fifty-third Street, will open an exhibition today in which are contrasted the styles of 1900 and the present. To give the display an effective setting, the museum has altered extensively two rooms on the third floor, virtually, building new rooms inside the old.

WASHINGTON, April 4. -- The ad-ministration's railroad program, which calls for a chief coordinator and regional coordinators, will be infinal shape next weeK and be sent to Congress, according to Secretary Roper, who has headed a committee making the survey for the President.

Samuel Rosoff, president of the Manhattan Ash and Garbage Removal Company, appeared yesterday before the Board of Estimate, sitting in committee of the whole, to press his organization's bid for the contract of disposing of Brooklyn refuse, on which it has made the low bid.

Are the Democratic boys to be blamed for boiling over? Again and again they hear about the New Deal. What does that mean except firing Republicans from office and putting in deserving Democrats? The Administration is more than a month old, yet most of the "rascals" who ought to be turned out are still at ease.

The Chicago North Western Railway has received deposits of about 87.5 per cent of its $6,555,000 of 5 per cent debentures under a plan to meet their maturity on May 1 through payments of one-half in cash and one-half with 5 per cent general mortgage notes.

Dolly Haas, the impish little actress already popular with patrons of the German-language film houses here, has the time of her life in "Ein Madel der Strasse" ("A Girl of the Street"), a cemedy romance in German that came to the little Tobis Theatre yesterday.

WASHINGTON, April 5. -- President and Mrs. Roosevelt went to the theatre tonight, taking with them to see "When Ladies Meet" the members of their family and friends who are their guests at the White House. It was President Roosevelt's first appearance in a Washington theatre since his inauguration, and the arrival of the Presidential party was greeted with applause from the audience.

DECATUR, April 5. -- A dramatic pronouncement from the bench interrupted the trial of Haywood Patterson today as he and five other Negroes testified before Judge James E. Horton that Victoria Price swore falsely that they attacked her on a freight train near Scottsboro two years ago.

To the Editor of The New York Times: It is startling and mournful that at the time when we have been claiming to lead the nations at Geneva in the effort to cut down armaments a great body of politicians, including Secretary Swanson of the Navy Department and Congressman Vinson, chairman of the House Naval Committee, should be petitioning for an appropriation of $230,000,000 to enlarge our navy.

Workmen are busy placing the finishing touches on the seventy-story RCA Building, main unit in Rockefeller Center, and the first tenants will move into this structure about May 1, the developers announced yesterday.
ALBANY, April 5. -- Governor Lehman's Agriculture Commission recommended to him today approval of the Pitcher bill to regulate the milk industry and fix prices.

PARIS, April 5. -- An abrupt stop has been put by German authorities to the flight of Jews across the frontier into neighboring countries. Police authorization is now needed by those leaving the country and this authorization, it is said, is being refused to Jewish citizens.
PHILADELPHIA, April 5 (AP). -- The Philadelphia Athletics hopped into a 2-to-1 lead in the city series today by defeating the Phillles, 9 to 3.

While the plan of the New York Clearing House Association for going to the aid of its closed member, the Harriman National Bank and Trust Company, was being submitted yesterday for approval of the authorities in Washington, indications piled up that the twenty member banks of the association were still far from agreement on the question of helping out the Harriman, and particularly on the plan finally evolved by the clearing-house committee for doing so.

BERLIN, April 5. -- The first stage of the attempt to bring foreign cor- respondents in Berlin under the domination of National-Socialized Germany was halted today when the correspondents refused to be dominated. The Foreign Press As- sociation, by an overwhelming vote, refused to accept the resignation of its president, Edgar Ansel Mowrer of The Chicago Daily News.

Renewing his plea to the city to landscape the site of the old lower reservoir in Central Park, Nathan Straus Jr., president of the Park Association of New York City, asserted yesterday that fill for the landscaping could be obtained at a cost "very close to zero" and that a "sincere attempt" by the Park Department would find enough trucks for the work.

Miss Marion Rumsey Cartier and Pierre Claudel, whose religious marriage ceremony will take place Saturday morning in the Church of St. Jean Baptiste, according to French law, will first be married in a civil ceremony. The latter will take place tomorrow afternoon at the French Consulate, and Count Charles de Fontnouvelle, the French Consul General in his capacity of "officer d'etat civil," will perform the ceremony.

Nathan Straus Jr., president of the Park Association of New York City, Inc., said yesterday he had heard that the plans for Marine Park in Brooklyn prepared by Charles Downing Lay, landscape architect, were not feasible from an engineering standpoint.

To the Editor of The New York Times: One frequently hears the comment that the recent arrest of several British engineers by the Soviet Government and the difficulty the British Government has experienced in trying to secure fair treatment for them by the Soviet authorities is an argument against recognition of the Soviet Government by the United States.

The three survivors of the navy airship Akron, which crashed off the New Jersey coast during a storm early Tuesday, flew to Washington yesterday afternoon to make official reports to the Navy Department. They are Lieut. Commander Herhert V. Wiley, executive officer and second in command of the Akron; Moody E. Erwin, aviation metalsmith, second class, and Richard E. Deal, boatswain's mate, second class.

BASLE, Switzerland, April 5. -- The American bank holiday and gold suspension early in March appear to be reflected in the March statement, published yesterday, of the Bank for International Settlements, which showed a decline of 108,000,000 Swiss francs in its funds during the month. This leaves funds totaling 938,721,668 Swiss francs, the first time in months it has been below a billion.

The mental and physical health of the destitute unemployed in New York State is deteriorating to an alarming extent, with more than twice as much illness among them as among the general population, Dr. Thomas Parran Jr., New York State Commissioner of Health, told a radio audience yesterday over Station WOR.

The "commercial imbecilities" of authors, the gambling hazards of publishing and the general difficulties of making money by writing are discussed by George Bernard Shaw in a letter-foreword to G.H. Thring's "The Marketing of Literary Property," just published in England and now made available here by Frederic Melcher.

COQ-SUR-MER, Belgium, April 5 (AP). -- Professor Albert Einstein said today that his two daughters had fled from Germany. The younger, the wife of a Russian, left Germany for France, and the elder, whose husband is a German, went to Scheveningen, Holland, after having left Berlin secretly.

In January, 1931, the Department of Commerce reported that miniature golf had become a $125,000,000 industry. Within a few months its magnates folded their imitation greens and quietly disappeared into the limbo of forgotten fads.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., April 5. -- Ben Chapman, tha Alabama Arrow, took his turn today at leading the Yankees in their grand offensive manoeuvres and by his deeds paved the way for a 9-to-0 triumph over the Louisville Colonels. It marked the third successive shut-out victory for the world's champions.

KENT, Conn., April 5. -- Riding the crest of a flooded river that made for fast conditions, the first crew of Kent School finished a perfect day of rowing for the school boys by defeating the Harvard 150-pound varsity today.

The Society of Illustrators opened their annual exhibition last night in the galleries of the National Arts Club, 15 Gramercy Park. Today the show will be opened to the public and the pictures will remain on view until April 22, when they will be taken on a tour of the country.
WASHINGTON, April 5. -- At last Franklin D. Roosevelt and Ramsay MacDonald are to meet and try to repair the broken world together.

Beer at Albany has held the front page, but there are a million farmers and farm laborers and their wives and children in this State more interested just now in milk. The price the farmer is getting for his milk has dropped lower and lower, until it is today far below the cost of production.

PRINCETON, N.J., April 5. -- The spirit of optimism in Princeton athletics, rekindled by the success of Fritz Crisler in his first year as football coach here, was given expression in other fields of Tiger sporting endeavor today.

Walter R. Herrick, Manhattan Park Commissioner, resigned yesterday from the post he received in 1927 as a personal appointment from formor Mayor Walker and was succeeded within two hours by John E. Sheehy, Tammany leader of the Fifteenth Assembly District and close friend of John F. Curry.

DENVER, April 5. -- Up until today there had been some question as to whether Secretary Woodin actually received a pair of asbestos breeches as a gift, but doubt has been swept aside by G.M. Fiechtner, a Denver Democrat, who is responsible for the following story:
ANNAPOLIS, Md., April 5. -- The University of Richmond, playing a faultless game in the field and hitting Clute and Davis hard, won from the Naval Academy today, 14 to 5.

Information as to the turnover of listed and unlisted securities on the New York Curb Exchange for the three years ending 1931 was asked of Howard C. Sykes, president of the Exchange, when he appeared for questioning yesterday in the offices of the State Bureau of Securities.

The Executive order issued by the President yesterday amplifies and particularizes his earlier warnings against hoarding. On March 6, taking advantage of a wartime statute which had not been repealed, he forbade the hoarding "of gold or silver coin or bullion or currency," under penalty of $10,000 fine or ten years' imprisonment or both.

PARIS, April 5. -- The Cabinet this afternoon completed the first draft of the memorandum which will set forth the French views as to what the Mussolini four-power peace pact ought to contain. One more revi- sion, after consultation with foreign emissaries, will be required before the text is given out.

Heavy feet tramped up the stairs to Dr. Joseph I. Herman's dental office on the second floor at 152 Second Avenue at 11:30 A.M. yesterday. The dentist heard the feet in the hall and presently a knock at the door.

A "daring" hold-up by a girl who "confessed" to robbing an employe of the Knickerbocker Ice Company of $500 at pistol point last Summer was revealed yesterday as a hoax in which the victim played a prearranged part, according to District Attorney Geoghan of Brooklyn.

Reports that Prime Minister MACDONALD would seek an early conference with President ROOSEVELT at Washington were borne out by a White House statement yesterday. It merely said that Mr. ROOSEVELT had for some time cherished the hope that the Prime Minister would come here, and now is strongly of the mind that a visit to Washington by Mr. MACDONALD ''would be helpful."

WASHINGTON, April 5 (AP). -- Machinery for action on repeal of the Eighteenth Amendment now has been created in twenty-five States, some with dates for elections and constitutional conventions not yet set. Legislation is pending in thirteen others, and a bill is before Governor Pinchot of Pennsylvania for his signature.

ALBANY, April 5. -- The deadlock on beer-control legislation held firm today, but the Buckley bill, imposing a tax of $1 a barrel on 3.2 per cent beer, passed both Senate and Assembly and goes to Governor Lehman, who will approve it.
WASHINGTON, April 5. -- The text of President Roosevelt's executive order on gold "hoarding issued today was as follows:

BERLIN, April 5. -- The Foreign Press Association, representing about 135 correspondents from more than twenty nations, may be dissolved by the German Government because the Cabinet regards a book written by its president as offensive.

Last night's concert of the Philharmonic Symphony Orchestra under Arturo Toscanini, with Jascha Heifitz as soloist, took place in Carnegie Hall before an audience that packed the available standing room and filled every seat; an audience that gave the conductor prolonged and tumultuous welcome as he appeared, and repeatedly displayed its enthusiasm as the evening advanced.
WASHINGTON, April 5. -- The War Department issued the following orders today: Ramses, Lt. Col. N.F., Ordnance Department, to Washington, D.C.

BERLIN, April 5. -- Thirty-nine million German Lutherans, comprising virtually the entire Protestant Church in Germany, learned today from the newspapers that their church was on the way to become an annex of the Nazi government and of an "awakened Germany."

The Westchester County Golf Association's season will open on May 17, according to the schedule released yesterday by Leonard Martin of Apawamis, former metropolitan amateur champion, who is now serving as chairman of the tournament committee.

PARIS, April 5. -- Three different conceptions as to how the nations should proceed in a concerted effort to conquer the world depression are developing in the conversations of Norman H. Davis, President Roosevelt's special Ambassador, with European statesmen, which continued today.
Stimulated by improvements in other speculative markets, prices on the Cotton Exchange advanced yesterday to the best figures of the last two weeks and closed with gains of 3 to 6 points.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., April 5. -- The Giants, pausing here today on their journey north, scored a victory over the Chattanooga Lookouts, champions of the Southern Association, 6 -- 2. The losers' errors contributed to the Giants' triumph.

Philip H. Bevier, chief engineer of the National Fireproofing Corporation, who was a descendant of a French Huguenot family which settled in Ulster and Orange Counties in the seventeenth century and traced its ancestry from Gauthier de Beyvier, French nobleman and crusader in 1120, died yesterday at his home, 162 Eighth Avenue, Brooklyn, as the result of a heart attack suffered there Tuesday night.
SAN FRANCISCO, April 5 (AP). -- Plenty of beer for breakfast but not one drop for midnight revelry was

WASHINGTON, April 5. -- The American Federation of Labor in its monthly survey of business, made public today, endorsed some of the reconstruction steps taken by the Roosevelt administration, but opposed the forestation program, declared the farm relief plan proposed what amounted to a sales tax on food and clothing and asserted that the $400,000,000 cut from veterans' aid was "bound to have serious deflationary effects."
ALBANY, April 5. -- Governor Lehman sent a special message to the Legislature today, urging the immediate passage of unemployment reserve legislation.

Owing to his appointment as Ambassador to France, Jesse Isidor Straus resigned yesterday as president and as a member of the board of directors of R.H. Macy Co., Inc., at a special meeting held in the executive offices of the corporation.

Sale at auction yesterday of 20,000 shares of its capital stock will have no effect for some time on the management of the Shenandoah Life Insurance Company because the stock cannot be delivered until 1938 under the terms of a contract with the company according to representatives of the Julius H. Barnes interests yesterday.

A net profit of $22,732,772 is reported for the year ended Feb. 25, 1933, by the Great Atlantic and Pacific Tea Company of America, after charges, depreciation and Federal taxes. This is equivalent after dividend requirements on the 7 per cent preferred stock to $10.02 a share earned on 2,086,748 no-par common shares, comparing with $29,792,974, or $13.40 a share, earned in the preceding fiscal year.

Several promotions and salary increases for members of the Brooklyn District Attorney's staff were announced yesterday by District Attorney William F.X. Geoghan of Brooklyn. The changes resulted from the vacancy caused by the death last year of Nicholas Selvaggi, an Assistant District Attorney.

LONDON, April 5. -- An enabling act giving the British Government power to impose an embargo on all Russian trade with this country in reprisal for the arrests of British engineers in Russia passed its second reading in the House of Commons tonight by a vote of 347 to 48.

With railway securities selling at lower prices, financial interest was centred yesterday upon the individual status of companies which conceivably may find it necessary, or convenient, to follow the example of the Missouri Pacific in seeking relief from debt under the provisions of the emergency amendment to the United States bankruptcy act.
VILLANOVA, Pa., April 5. -- Villanova opened its baseball campaign today with a 3-to-0 conquest of Lehigh.

The dip in business caused by the recent bank holiday is illustrated by the blast furnace production figures for March, which show a falling off of 11.7 per cent in the daily pig iron output last month as compared with February. According to The Iron Age, the March total was 542,011 gross tons, against 554,330 in February, while the daily average last month was 17,484 tons, compared with 19,798 tons in February.

Aside from the late decline yesterday in railway securities, which had an unsettling effect upon the market generally, the incident of most interest so far as Wall Street was concerned was the uniformly higher range of prices for commodities.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, April 5 (AP). -- Earl Hewitt of Erie, Pa., rolled into the singles lead of the American Bowling Congress today when he turned in games of 207, 259 and 258 for a total of 724, two pins higher than the score of Rudy Riepel of Milwaukee, who was dropped to second position.
ALBANY, April 5. -- The New York Telephone Company was ordered by the Public Service Commission today to reduce its charge from 25 cents to 15 cents a month for hand-set or "French-type" telephones.

LONDON, April 5. -- Convincing evidence developed today that last night's report to THE NEW YORK TIMES that Prime Minister MacDonald was going to Washington next week had been correct. Official announcement of the trip now awaits only receipt of a definite invitation from President Roosevelt to supplement the tacit understanding with Washington that the Prime Minister would be most welcome.

LONDON, April 5. -- Early resumption of the work on the giant Cunarder 534, now lying unfinished at Clydebank, was indicated today by Sir Percy Bates, chairman, at the Cunard Steamship Company's annual meeting at Liverpool. Neither the hull nor the machinery had suffered by the suspension of work, he said.

HAVANA, Cuba, April 5. -- The Haligonian, 45-foot schooner, sailed by her owner, Houston Wall of Tampa, Fla., crossed the finish line at Morro Castle, Havana Harbor, at 6:58 A.M. today to win the fourth annual St. Petersburg-to-Havana race and the President Machado Cup.

Latest College Fad. Idealist youth is not always indifferent to the impact of the bread-and-butter argument. At City College a proposed newspaper poll on peace and war, after the now famous Oxford neither-king-nor-country vote, has been abandoned.

Sixty young men of this season's Fordham College Glee Club opened their club's tenth anniversary concert at the Town Hall last evening with the traditional "greeting song" -- "We Meet Again Tonight, Boys" -- sung from behind closed curtains with a blend of clear voices in singularly transparent harmony that prompted the first of many outbursts of applause.

George Leask, New York banker and philanthropist, who died last Sunday in his eighty-fourth year, left many large cash and contingent bequests to charitable institutions, relatives, friends and employes, it was disclosed yesterday when his will was offered for probate in Surrogate's Court.
WASHINGTON, April 5. -- The Bureau of Navigation issued the following orders today, dated April 3:

MOUNT HOLLY, N.J., April 5. -- Seventeen brace were run today in the members' all-age stake at the annual Spring field trials of the English Setter Club of America in progress in the covers at Medford. The test is scheduled to end tomorrow.

PALM BEACH, Fla., April 5. -- Several members of the college set were guests tonight at the dinner given by Miss Anne Askew Davies, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Oscar G. Davies, at Patio Margery. Those present included Miss Lorraine Eddy, Miss Erna Hurlburt, Miss Althea Tevander, Miss Betty and Miss Patricia Mitchell, John Jacob Astor 3d, Robert Wilson Evans, Philip Banker, Minford Wolcott Bond, Francis Biedler, Kimball Chalmers and Mason Tucker.

WASHINGTON, April 5 (AP). -- A sweeping revision of the administration's securities regulation bill was in store tonight as the House Interstate Commerce Committee, completing hearings on the measure, called an executive session for tomorrow to redraft the legislation.

Play will resume tonight in Squadron A Armory, Ninety-fourth Street and Madison Avenue, in the national and Eastern indoor polo champioships. Two of the oldest rivals of college sport, Yale and Harvard, will meet in the semifinal of the national intercollegiate championships.

Despite protests from more than 100 minority stockholders, the system for allotting stock to officers of the American Tobacco Company was ratified and directors were reelected at the annual meeting yesterday at 75 Montgomery Street, Jersey City.

Public and private relief agencies in New York City spent the unprecedented total of $9,540,000 during February, according to an analysis of such expenditures made public yesterday by the Welfare Council. February expenditures compared with a total of $8,000,000 during January and $1,000,000 a month during 1929 and 1930.

PINEHURST, N.C., April 5. -- Last week in the first qualifying round of the North and South amateur golf championship, George T. Dunlap Jr., Walker Cup star, set a new amateur record of 65 for the No. 2 course, and today in a quarter-final round match against Dick Wilson, former Georgetown golfer, he clipped another stroke from his record, tying Joe Turnesa's course mark.

WASHINGTON, April 5. -- Any suggestion of new taxes to amortize extra-budgetary expenditures that might have been a part of President Roosevelt's general program when he entered the White House has practically been abandoned, Congressional circles disclosed today.

ALBANY, April 5. -- Governor Lehman demanded charter revision for New York City and other cities of the State in a special message to the Legislature today. Specifically, he called for the enactment of the Desmond-Moffat bill to permit election of charter revision commissions.

IN their quiet way the Boston Red Sox have been in town for several days. It isn't a pennant-winning club as it stands, but Manager Marty McManus is jubilant over the way it stood the first real test of the season. It came through a train wreck intact.

Enlarged demand by the automobile and brewing industries has lifted the level of steel operations this week to 16 1/2 per cent of the country's ingot capacity, according to The Iron Age. This compares with 15 per cent last week.

An irregularly higher price movement prevailed in the local commodity futures markets yesterday. Sugar and silver resumed their advances, while hides also showed gains. Others moved in a narrow range, with losses in some contracts and gains in others, except in the case of cocoa, which continued its descent into record low ground, and hides, which advanced.

At midnight tonight it will become legal here to buy, transport, sell and drink beer of normal alcoholic content, but New York will see few if any public celebrations of the end of the fourteen-year drought.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, April 5. -- Bermuda yachtsmen found today's light to moderate breezes just to their liking and made a clean sweep of the first team race against the representatives of the Long Island Sound interclub fleet.
The chief points of the regulations drawn up by the city yesterday for the manufacture and sale of 3.2 per cent beer and wines until State control legislation is enacted, effective tomorrow, follow:

ALBANY, April 5. -- Representatives of public utilities in the State voiced strong opposition today to a bill recommended by Governor Lehman and sought by the Power Authority as part of its St. Lawrence development program permitting municipalities to own, operate and purchase any public utility service either inside or outside their territorial limits.

WASHINGTON, April 5. -- The second day's hearing before the Federal Radio Commission on the applications submitted by Press Wireless, Inc., for modification of licenses to include additional points of communication was consumed mostly in cross-examination of J.B. Pierson, president of the company.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., April 5. -- St. John's lacrosse team defeated Harvard today by 4 to 3, but was forced to the limit by the Crimson which, largely through its great defense, threatened the supremacy of one of Maryland's "Big Four" in the stick game.

WASHINGTON, April 5. -- Despite declines of 23 per cent in volume and 33 per cent in the value of shipments to foreign countries, the United States retained its position as the world's leading export nation in 1932, according to a detailed analysis of this country's trade made public today by the Commerce Department.

WASHINGTON, April 5. -- The administration's dual program for agriculture relief, involving in one bill a broad plan for enhancing farm commodity values and in another the refinancing of farm mortgages, was laid before the Senate today in two committee reports.

ALBANY, April 5. -- Reasons why many corporations had failed to file their annual reports with the Public Service Commission on March 1, as required by law, were given today at a hearing conducted by Chairman Milo R. Maltbie. There were 158 companies cited on March 21 to appear and show cause.

PHILADELPHIA, April 5. -- Penn opened its baseball season with an easy 16-to-3 victory over Haverford on Franklin Field today. Coach Walter Cariss tried out nineteen Red and Blue players, Captain Martens at first base being the only one to go the entire nine innings.

CHICAGO, April 5 (AP). -- The added money value of the American Derby, to be decided at Washington Park in June, was slashed in half tonight, from $50,000 to $25,000. C.W. Hay, general manager of the Washington Park Jockey Club, also announced that other stakes would be reduced in keeping with general business conditions.

Colonel Jay Boots, who has been abroad on a government mission, is due today on the North German Lloyd liner Europa. He will be accompanied by Miss Louise Boots. Others arriving on the ship from Bremen via Southampton and Cherbourg are:

The circus slipped into town yesterday, hid itself during the afternoon in the Harlem yards of the New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad and proceeded last night under its own power and as quietly as possible to Madison Square Garden.

With the addition of "Strange Gods," arriving at the Ritz Theatre on Saturday night, April 15, three openings are scheduled for Broadway playhouses next week. Jessica Ball is the author of "Strange Gods," the action of which takes place in the Florida swamplands.

WASHINGTON, April 5 (AP). -- Washington hit Seibold, Boston starting pitcher, hard today and got enough added runs because of Brown's wildness to gain an easy 7-to-3 victory in an exhibition game with the National League team.

WARSAW, April 5. -- The revised French version of the Mussolini plan is as strongly criticized in Poland as the original proposal. Poland cannot understand the pur- pose of the proposed pact, accord- ing to the pro-government newspaper Kurjer Poranny, and, together with the Little Entente na- tions, must withhold approval.

WASHINGTON, April 5. -- Labor's opposition to the administration's proposed railroad legislation was presented to the President today by A.F. Whitney, chairman of the Railway Labor Executives' Association; George M. Harrison, vice president, and Donald Richberg, general counsel, who declared that the elimination of small railroads and the proposed coordination would throw thousands of men out of work.

BERLIN, April 5. -- The Reichsbank will pay back in a few days its foreign discount credit of $70,000,000. Equal parts of this will go to the Federal Reserve Bank in New York, the Bank of England, the Bank of France and the Bank for International Settlements.

Declaring themselves opposed to the "rampant economic nationalism and individualism which threaten to sweep the world into another war," twenty-one members of the faculty of Columbia University, in a statement issued yesterday by the Columbia Socialist Club, listed an eight-point program which, if followed, would act as "the first steps toward the establishment of permanent peace."
The Jersey City International League baseball club overwhelmed the Manhattan College nine by a 10-to-4 score in an exhibition game at West Side Park, Jersey City, yesterday.

BERLIN, April 5. -- Stocks advanced slightly at today's session of the Boerse. Most of the buying orders were still due to the fact that the boycott of Jewish stores would not be renewed today. I.G. Farben and the Reichsbank each benefited by this trend.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I note the denial of the starvation of those in Ukraine, North Caucasus and Lower Volga regions by your correspondent Walter Duranty, in this morning's issue of THE TIMES.

The New York Chapter of the American Institute of Architects awarded its Medal of Honor for 1932 last night to Louis Ayres, member of the firm that designed the Rockefeller Hospital here and the Department of Commerce Building in "Washington, and presented to Julian Clarence Levi, chairman of the Architects' Emergency Relief Committee, a citation for outstanding service in relief work among architects.

Henry F. Gerguson, who promised last January, when he pleaded guilty to perjury and violation of the immigration law, to give up the name "Prince Michael Romanoff" and to cause no more trouble to immigration authorities, was sentenced yesterday to serve ninety days in the Federal House of Detention.
WASHINGTON, April 5. -- A building program to bring the navy up to the London naval-treaty strength will be submitted to the House Naval Affairs Committee within the next ten days.

A temporary beer bill passed Tuesday night by the New Jersey Legislature to regulate the sale of the 3.2 beverage until permanent legislation has been drawn by the State Beverage Commission was signed yesterday by Governor A. Harry Moore at the home of Dr. Harvey N. Davis, president of Stevens Institute of Technology, at Castle Point, Hoboken.

Midtown Manhattan, where there are numerous high-class shops and art stores, furnished an important transaction yesterday in the sale of the six-story Georgian-style dwelling at 19 and 21 East Fifty-fourth Street.

COPENHAGEN, April 5. -- The verdict announced this morning by the World Court in the East Greenland dispute is a clear victory for Denmark, as the court declares Norway's occupation and declaration of July 10, 1931, and all measures connected with it are illegal.

Two huge mutual investment trusts, to be operated on a plane with such institutions as savings banks, are being organized by Frank A. Vanderlip, former president of the National City Bank. One of these will have a portfolio of bonds and the other will be limited to stocks.

Although the Girls Service League is not a relief agency, it has adapted itself to the most difficult conditions it has ever had to meet and given shelter, food, clothing, medical care and money to thousands of girls during 1932. Its annual report shows an increase of 76 per cent over 1931 in the number of applicants for help.

WASHINGTON, April 5. -- Aroused by implications that he had at- tempted to muzzle the press through the bill for protection of public documents, Secretary Hull denied this indignantly to newspaper correspondents today.

George Washington High annexed the Division 1 championship, while James Madison High carried off the Division 2 crown as a result of fence-offs for the respective sectional honors in the city Public Schools Athletic League tournament staged in the Washington Irving High gymnasium yesterday.

The proposal to rezone the Grand Concourse, in the Bronx, from 161st Street to East 201st Street, from a residential to a business district has aroused considerable discussion among property owners in the vicinity, and there is every prospect of a very lively fight when the matter comes up before the Board of Estimate next week.

CHICAGO, April 5 (AP). -- Favorites, including Angelo Trulio of the New York A.C., the defending titleholder, entered the quarterfinals of the national amateur handball singles championship at the Lake Shore Athletic Club tonight.

VIENNA, April 5. -- Max Reinhardt, now at his beautiful castle, Leopoldskron, near Salzburg, discussed today the report that he had been ousted from the artistic management of the Deutsches Theater in Berlin by the National Socialist Minister of Education, Art and Science, in Prussia.

WASHINGTON, April 5. -- Twenty-five thousand men from sixteen cities, who have been selected by the Labor Department from enrolment lists of public welfare associations, will be sent into reforestation work camps within a fortnight, Robert Fechner, director of the emergency conservation work, announced today.

As was the case in the annual team tournament of the H.Y.P.D. College Chess League during the Christmas holidays, when Harvard led the field, the Crimson again was triumphant yesterday as a result of play in the fifth and final round of the individual championship concluded at the Marshall Chess Club.

WASHINGTON, April 5. -- An Executive order to force gold coin and gold certificates out of hoarding was issued today by President Roosevelt, acting under the emergency banking act, which imposes a heavy penalty on those who do not exchange their gold for other currency.

WASHINGTON, April 5. -- The Senate debate on the Black maximum work-week bill was enlivened today by a proposal to make the measure provide for a thirty-six-hour week with a limit of eight hours daily, instead of the six-hour day, five-day week now specified.
NEW YORK. The French Ambassador and Mme. Paul Claudel will arrive today from Washington and will be at the Waldorf-Astoria.

While a "new element of great strength has entered national affairs in President Roosevelt's readiness to initiate and assume responsibility for constructive action," five "next steps" in a program of monetary adjustment intended to restore the price level are necessary, according to the Committee for the Nation, representing 300 industrial leaders, which made public its program yesterday.

TEGUCIGALPA, Honduras, April 5 (AP). -- Fire destroyed fourteen blocks today in the commercial centre of the town of Tela, the chief fruit port on the Northern Honduran coast, causing an estimated loss of more than $1,000,000.

BERLIN, April 5. -- The new regulation providing that "all persons" must have a police permit to leave Germany, after having been applied yesterday to all foreigners, is off again today so far as the foreigners are concerned. It is unlikely to be reimposed, for there are certain legal obstacles.
NEWARK, N.J., April 5. -- Newark dropped another exhibition, game today, losing an exciting battle to the Boston Red Sox, 7 to 6.

WASHINGTON, April 5. -- Acting on the aviation maxim that the best tonic for a flier who has crashed is to take the air again as soon as possible, the three survivors of the Akron crew flew from New York to Washington today and spent the afternoon in making detailed verbal reports to Admiral William V.

James J. McCormick, Deputy City Clerk in charge of the Marriage License Bureau, kept the drawer of his desk open to the view of brides and bridegrooms, so that they could see that others had given him gratuities, and when a bridegroom failed to leave a tip, McCormick called him a cheap skate, it was testified yesterday before Federal Judge John C. Knox and a jury.

Exceptional Blouse Call Noted, Interest in blouses continues notably keen and the large volume of business being done in these garments ranks them as one of the major accessories of the season. The call for organdy blouses, particularly in the popular price range, has been very strong.

Definite plans of the Chase National Bank interests to terminate "promptly" the affairs of its security affiliates, the Chase Securities Corporation and the Chase Harris Forbes Corporation, in order to make the bank a strictly commercial banking institution, were announced yesterday by Winthrop W. Aldrich, head of the bank, after a meeting of the board of directors.
WASHINGTON, April 5. -- Sale of beer in the national capital on Friday was assured today as President Roosevelt signed the TydingsPalmisano bill swiftly and with but little ceremony.

The claim of $112,000,000 filed here last October by Ivar Kreuger's Swedish Match Company against the assets of his bankrupt International Match Corporation was amended yesterday to $50,000,000. The original claim was intended to protect the eventual rights of the Swedish organization in general.

A shut-down of all copper mines in the United States for six months in an effort to restore the price of the metal to a profitable basis is considered imminent in the trade, where informal discussions along these lines have been taking place for more than a year.

The art of fly fishing is so delicate a one that devotees of the sport never have been able to agree on the precise technique which should be followed, nor upon the equipment to be used. As a result the topic of fly casting has never ceased to be controversial.
PRINCETON, N.J., April 5. -- Princeton's baseball nine opened its season on University Field today with a 5 -- 4 victory over Panzer College of East Orange.

WASHINGTON, April 5. -- Norman H. Davis denied in a telegram to the State Department today reports that he had negotiated on intergovernmental debts during his recent conversations in London as special Ambassador.
The American Jewish Congress renewed yesterday its protest against the continued repression of Jews in Germany and called upon Americans of all faiths to join in the efforts to end persecution.

F. Trubee Davison, president of the American Museum of Natural History, and George McAneny, president of the Regional Plan Association, discussed with Mayor O'Brien at City Hall yesterday plans for the creation of a Planetarium Authority.

While President Roosevelt's statement on the oil industry was "a very satisfactory reaction to the industry's request," R.C. Holmes, president of the Texas Corporation, said yesterday he personally felt some disappointment that the President had not asked for some authority that would "enable the States and the Federal Government to work more closely together, in the most effective way, to accomplish some real conservation of petroleum."

More than 15,000 Communists and sympathizers assembled in Madison Square Garden last night at a meeting organized by the Communist party with the support of some liberals to protest against the regime of Adolf Hitler.

CHICAGO, April 5. -- Students in a number of south side and west side high schools today dropped their books and went on strike in protest at the delay in the payment of teachers' salaries. Principals estimated that 14,200 pupils had joined the strike.

To the Editor of The New York Times: THE NEW YORK TIMES published a communication with reference to the problem of remodeling a house under present conditions. R.S.A., who signed the communication, complained that he had buildings which he felt should be remodeled before being rented, but had not the necessary money to undertake this work.

PURNEA, India, April 5. -- Air Commodore P.F.M. Fellowes's slight misadventure Tuesday now proves to have been due largely to trouble with his oxygen mask while flying over Mount Kanchenjunga. A similar difficulty seems to have been encountered by Flight Lieutenant D.F. McIntyre and Flying Officer Ellison.

HELSINGFORS, Finland, April 5. -- On the occasion of the first anniversary today of the repeal of the prohibition law here prominent citizens declared that the change had proved a distinct success, although rum-running had not been fully suppressed.

TRENTON, N.J., April 5. -- J.H. Thayer Martin, State Tax Commissioner, appointed today former Assemblyman George W. Grimm Jr. of East Orange, as State beverage license agent to administer the new beer law.
The Columbia rowing squad took to the placid stretches of the Hudson River yesterday for a sevenmile workout, continuing the intensiveness that has marked the daily sessions this week.

MOSCOW, April 5. -- In the excite- ment over the Spring sowing campaign and the reports of an increasing food shortage, a fact that has been almost overlooked is that the production of coal, pig iron, steel, oil, automobiles, tractors, automotive parts, locomotives and machine tools has increased by 20 to 35 per cent during recent months.

To conform with decreases in traffic, the Atchison, Topeka Santa Fe Railway eliminated 150,000 train-miles in 1932, according to the report for the year issued by W.B. Storey, president. This made a total reduction of 5,550,000 train-miles on an annual basis in the last three years.

The reorganization plan for the Empire Public Service Corporation and subsidiary and affiliated companies has been formally abandoned, Edward C. Delafield, chairman of the reorganization committee, announced yesterday. Depositors of securities under the plan may withdraw, without charge, securities of the character and to the amount represented by the certificates of deposit issued by the City Bank Farmers Trust Company as depository.

WASHINGTON, April 5 (AP). -- A challenge to the nations of America to measure their civilization by their economic ideals and accomplishments was laid down today by Secretary Hull in his first meeting as chairman of the governing board of the Pan American Union.

Although they will not see action until Saturday, when they meet the Toronto Maple Leafs in the second game of the Stanley Cup series, the New York Rangers departed for Toronto last night. The entire squad, in addition to Manager Lester Patrick and Trainer Harry Westerby, entrained at the Grand Central.

In an address before the American Economic Committee for Palestine at a meeting at the Fraternity Clubs last night, Israel B. Brodie, president of the committee, called upon the government of Palestine to let down immediately the existing immigration restrictions to meet the grave emergency now affecting Jews in Germany as a result of the persecutions by the Hitler government.

Whether crickets in an apartment are "a plague of insects" or "harmless" creatures whose chirping is "enjoyable" is a question that Municipal Court Justice Nicholas M. Pette must decide before ruling whether Fernham Fox, a tuba player, must pay three months' rent to the Benhar Holding Company.

WASHINGTON, April 5. -- An eventual saving of 1,203,000,000 to the government in hospital and domiciliary facilities for veterans will be one result of the economy law, General Frank T. Hines, Administrator of Veterans Affairs, reported today to President Roosevelt.
The Baron de Hirsch Fund made a loan of $15,000, payable three years hence, at 5 1/2 per cent to the Elliac Corp., August Caille, president, on the five-story building at 753 Madison Av.

ALBANY, April 5. -- After a long conference tonight the Senate Democrats framed an $85,000,000 new taxation program to balance the State budget, which included a retail sales levy of 1 per cent and a levy of 1 per cent on gross incomes. The latter would be an extra tax on incomes, payable next year.

BALTIMORE, Md., April 5. -- Thirteen hits and six bases on balls were of no avail against the Orioles today and the Dodgers lost to the International Leaguers, 9 to 7. The Orioles made one hit for each run they recorded.

WASHINGTON, April 5 (AP). -- The Reconstruction Corporation today agreed to lend to the Guardian Trust Company of Cleveland about $9,000,000 for liquidating purposes, contingent upon the merger of the Guardian and the Union Trust Company into a new national bank, uniting the second and third largest of the city's banks, with deposits aggregating about $200,000,000.

The preliminary annual report of the Associated Gas and Electric Corporation for 1932 shows a balance of $18,062,122 available for Federal income taxes, interest on convertible obligations now converted into stock, optional reserves, dividends and surplus.

PURNEA, India, April 6 -- The meteorological forecast of the end of the lull in the weather has been justified and the second Everest flight is impossible for the present. The west wind went howling across the plains today at forty-five miles an hour. The velocity at high altitudes was unobtainable because the dust reduced visibility to 1,000 yards.

Three New Yorkers arrested by Postoffice Inspectors here March 17 in connection with a $500,000 Chicago mail robbery obtained an adjournment of one week in their fight against removal proceedings yesterday. Their attorney argued before United States Commissioner Garrett Cotter that the indictment returned against them contains a misjoinder.

Sweeping revision of the present pre-service and in-service education of teachers was recommended last night by Professors Ned H. Dearborn and Edward S. Evenden in reports based on the preliminary findings of the national survey of the education of teachers, now being conducted by the United States Commissioner of Education under a $200,000 Congressional appropriation.

WASHINGTON, April 6 (AP) -- Farm relief, one of the basic points in President Roosevelt's recovery program, today became the Senate's pending business, with debate to start tomorrow and leaders hopeful of passage within a week.

BERLIN, April 6 -- For the first time since he became Chancellor, Adolf Hitler issued a pronouncement on the Jewish question today and this pronouncement was an endorsement of the anti-Semitic drive in Germany, together with a declaration that the United States had no business to protest because of its own racial discrimination through an immigration embargo.

With 3.2 per cent beer legal in nineteen States and the District of Columbia after 12:01 o'clock this morning for the first time since the enactment of prohibition legislation, a new era in the nation's social life was greeted joyfully in many cities.

The Common Council of Detroit, Mich., voted yesterday to cut the rate of interest on the city's outstanding debt to 3 per cent from the present rates of 4 1/2 to 6 per cent and to eliminate appropriations of $18,552,063 from the 19331934 budget for payments of principal on funded debt and bank loans, according to word received here.

The management of the Central West Public Service Company has prepared a plan of adjustment and refunding in an effort to prevent any need for the institution of foreclosure proceeding's by holders of its first lien collateral bonds and has invited all holders of its securities to join in the move by depositing their securities.

Mr. DAVISON, president of the American Museum of Natural History, will not imitate Hercules in shifting the load of the heavens to the shoulders of Atlas. He does not propose to make the city bear the burden of supporting the planetarium, a model of the whole heavens, which he hopes may be built in the space just north of the museum.

A sharp drop was recorded in bank clearings for the country in the week ended on Wednesday, compared with the same week last year, and the increase for the week over the preceding week was only about one-third of the gain at the same time last year.

The second performance of three one-act plays by the Lighthouse Players, totally blind young actresses of the New York Association for the Blind, was given last night before an appreciative audience in the little theatre of the Lighthouse at 111 East Fifty-ninth Street.

BERLIN, April 6 -- The executive committee of the Federation of German Industries, after its directors had tendered their resignations, held a meeting today, which was presided over by Krupp von Bohlen, the chairman, and unanimously adopted the following resolution:

A soaring market in sugar, a sharp rebound from recent low levels in cocoa and higher prices for almost all other futures contracts characterized the movements on the local commodity exchanges yesterday. In all cases there was a substantial improvement in the volume of trading.
WASHINGTON, April 6 -- The War Department issued the following orders today:

In a decision yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Schmuck in a suit to foreclose a $700,000 mortgage on the Hotel Elysee, 56-60 East Fifty-fourth Street, the court for the first time passed on the plans for the reorganization of the property in ruling on the demand for the sale of the premises.

A gang of seven men described as the strong-arm squad of a group which has been attempting to gain a monopoly over the poultry business in this city were captured early yesterday as they were wrecking the S.,S. B. Live Poultry Corporation, 2,962 Park Avenue, the Bronx.
Under a broadened buying movement from both trade and commission-house quarters, prices on the Cotton Exchange moved upward again yesterday and ended with gains of 9 to 10 points.

MOSCOW, April 6 -- The first two weeks of Spring sowing have given such good results that the newspaper Pravda, in an editorial, utters what is almost a cry of triumph. At any rate, the words are a strong appreciation and they contrast sharply with recent pessimism.

WASHINGTON, April 6 -- During cross-examination today at a bearing before the Federal Radio Commission on the application of Press Wireless, Inc., to expand its services, W.A. Winterbottom, vice president and general manager of R.C.A. Communications, Inc., admitted that employes of his company had intercepted and made a complete record of all transmissions of radio station WJP from Oct. 4 to Nov. 16.

Out of the mists there crept on the Playhouse last evening a sad little saga of the Roxy usher. Maligned and uniformed by life -- and without gratuity into the bargain -- he could but suffer further on the stage. For when the curtain of "Her Tin Soldier" finally descended on an elder world, it did seem that the state of the theatre had not advanced.
LONDON, April 6 (AP) -- The weekly statement of the Bank of England shows the following changes, in pounds sterling:

WASHINGTON, April 6 -- No legislation looking to an increased coinage of silver money Is likely at this session of Congress, Speaker Rainey indicated today. The Speaker said, while he favored silver legislation of some kind, the fact that the silver question is included in the agenda of the Economic Conference makes action by Congress at this time unnecessary.

New York was wet when beer became legal at midnight last night, but only with the rain. The new 3.2 per cent beer was not available until 6 o'clock this morning. midnight to patrons, guests and reporters was "the real stuff," but the hotel manager, when asked whence the stuff had come merely shrugged his shoulders and refused any direct answer.

Thursday, April 6, 1938. Topping the action of other sections of the money market where there had been downward revisions in quotations as a result of the accumulation of funds seeking placement, the Reserve Bank announced after the close of business a cut of 1/2 in the rediscount rate to 3 per cent.
Rain did not deter the Columbia crew yesterday from going through a six-mile workout on the Harlem River in preparation for its race with Navy here three weeks from tomorrow.
PARIS, April 6 (AP). -- The weekly statement of the Bank of France shows the following changes in francs:

WASHINGTON, April 6 -- The conclusion that the main structure of the Akron broke in the air as a result of the terrific stress of divergent air currents in the centre of the low pressure area on Monday night was drawn by high ranking navy officers today after reading Lieut. Commander H.V. Wiley's extended report to Secretary Swanson.
