The executive committee of the Westchester County Advisory Committee for Probation, at its first annual meeting yesterday at the Hotel Biltmore, agreed upon a general program for sponsoring probation as an improved social measure. The program, which will be submitted to the advisory committee for adoption, includes the following activities:

ALBANY, April 6 -- Your editorial this morning "The Milk Bill" acknowledges the emergency, but I feel does not give adequate analysis to that which is proposed to help correct conditions. It is true, as the editorial sets forth, that the dairy farmers of the State are in a deplorable situation.
ASHEVILLE, N.C., April 6 -- Staging an exciting ninth-inning rally today, the Giants scored a victory over the Detroit Tigers, 4 to 3, while some 3,500 fans thrilled to the uprising.

WASHINGTON, April 6 -- Former Representative Butler B Hare of South Carolina, who went out of office on March 4, was mentioned today as the possible appointee as Governor General of the Philippines. At the same time it was indicated that Attorney General Cummings, originally intended for the insular office, would be retained in his present post.

HAVANA, April 6 -- Captain Oscar Pau, military supervisor of Guanabacoa, across the bay from Havana, was shot and gravely wounded tonight by unknown assailants. At the Camp Columbia military hospital he was reported to be dying.
WASHINGTON, April 6 -- The Bureau of Navigation issued the following orders today, dated April 4:
TORONTO, Ont., April 6 (Canadian Press) -- The Financial Post publishes a dispatch from its Montreal correspondent which saya in part:

LOUISVILLE, Ky., April 6 -- Babe Ruth, suffering from a sore throat, remained in his hotel room today, but this did not prevent the Yankees from driving on to more signal accomplishments. Among other things, they survived a biting gale and a drizzling rain, and for the second successive afternoon flattened the Louisville Colonels, 10 to 6.

Yesterday the Assembly defeated the Moffat bill, which proposed to give to the voters of this and other cities the right to decide in a referendum whether they wish to start the process of revising a charter. Is it out of courtesy to a friendly power, an occasional associate and ally, that a Republican-controlled branch of the Legislature smashes a measure brought in by a Republican and approved by various civic organizations here?
PALM BEACH, Fla., April 6 -- C. Percival Dietsch gave a tea at his villa today, presenting for the first view the portrait bust in bas relief of the late Addison Mizner, which he recently completed.

The committee for holders of dollar bonds of Colombia, which is headed by Richard Washburn Child and which previously had confined its activities to Colombian departmental and municipal bonds in default, circularized holders of the Colombian Government's bonds yesterday, asking for deposits of these securities and of the government-guaranteed mortgage bank issues.

Mayor O'Brien, speaking yesterday at a meeting of the Chamber of Commerce of the State of New York, at 65 Liberty Street, pledged the continued soundness of the city's credit, and promised that he would continue his economy policy.

ALBANY, April 6 -- The long fight for enactment of a minimum wage system for women, and children in industry appeared to have been won tonight as the all-powerful Assembly rules committee reported favorably on the Eberhard bill to create a mandatory law.

Arturo Toscanini, general musical director of the PhilharmonicSymphony Orchestra, will return next season for his ninth consecutive season with the orchestra, and will conduct the second part of the season. Bruno Walter, who comes back for his third successive season, will be here for the first part of the 1933-34 season, and Hans Lange, the assistant conductor of the orchestra, will conduct in the time intervening between Mr. Walter and Mr. Toscanini's visit.

The New York Stock Exchange has received applications for listing five common-stock issues With par value from $1 to $25 a share. Each new issue is to be exchanged for shares of higher par value or of no-par value now listed. The applications cover the following stocks:

WASHINGTON, April 6 -- Legislative proposals to give the President authority to make reciprocal tariff agreements with foreign nations were discussed today by President Roosevelt and Secretary Hull. A measure is expected to be ready for submission to Congress next week, and a determined effort will be made by the administration to obtain immediate action.

PARIS, April 6 -- Young-plan bonds took another sharp decline on the Paris Bourse today, dropping from 525 francs to 477. In French circles this weakness was attributed to the Reichsbank's decision to repay in advance its foreign rediscount credit from central banks, which In some quarters is regarded as equivalent to lowering the cover of the mark.

These orders were issued yesterday: Death Announced. Fireman 1st grade Francis J. McGurty of Engine 40, died April 5. Funeral will take place from his late residence, 1,360 Ogden Av., Bronx, at 9:30 A.M., Saturday, April 8. Interment at Calvary Cemetery.

PINEHURST, N.C., April 6 -- M. Pierpont Warner of Yale was shorn of his North and South amateur golf championship today when he lost, 2 and 1, to George T. Dunlap Jr., Walker Cup star, in the semifinal round of the thirty-third annual tourney.

Nathan Silver, chairman of the election board of the Fifth Election District of the Fourth Assembly District, was convicted, and Fred Friedman, Irving Markel and Louis Koolick, three other inspectors, were acquitted on charges of willfully making false returns at the last election by the jury before Supreme Court Justice Daniel V. McNamee of Hudson, N.Y., which had heard the case for five days.

THE champion hitter of the big leagues is with the Red Sox and the name is not Dale Alexander. It's Hughey Duffy. Ty Cobb led the American League in hitting a dozen times and Rogers Hornsby led the National League seven times. G.H. Ruth is recognized as a fair hitter, though he never specialized in aiming at an average. He was more interested in aiming at the fences.
BERLIN, April 6 -- Adolf Hitler, having made himself political dictator of Germany, today became dictator of German big business as well.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Twenty years ago I went to Germany to study rigid-airship construction and operation. Since then, through the columns of THE NEW YORK TIMES, I have followed with keen interest the progress and development of Zeppelin-type airships.

WASHINGTON, April 6 -- The Senate Foreign Relations Committee today prepared to revise the bill to penalize unauthorized publication of government information which was passed by the House Monday, making less severe the House bill restrictions, but retaining some Federal control.

The full history of the Morgan war-time plan for coordinating the allied purchases of war material, which went into effect in 1915, is told by Thomas W. Lamont in his first instalment of "The Biography of Henry P. Davison," published in the current issue of Collier's Weekly.

The aggregate market value of stocks listed on the New York Stock Exchange on April 1 was $19,914,893,399, compared with $19,700,985,961 on March 1, an increase of 5213,907,438, according to the monthly report issued yesterday. The number of stock issues decreased from 1,228 to 1,221, while shares listed declined from 1,296.231,953 to 1,292,601,719. The average price of listed shares was $15.41, compared with $15.20.

TORONTO, April 6 -- Lester Patrick led his redoubtable New York Rangers into town today for the resumption of the Stanley Cup series here Saturday night. A few hours after their arrival the Rangers went through a light workout at Maple Leaf Gardens.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, April 6 -- Again favored by light westerly winds Bermuda yachts today repeated yesterday's performance of taking the first four places in the second team race of the series between Bermuda one-design craft and the Long Island Sound interclub yachts.
To the Editor of The New York Times: May we clarify and correct the report of our detention in Decatur printed in THE TIMES of April 2?

An application for the liquidation of the Globe and Rutgers Fire Insurance Company was made to the Supreme Court yesterday by George S. Van Schaick, State Insurance Superintendent, bringing to the close attempts to rehabilitate the concern.
George S. Collins, executive secretary in the Mayor's office, resigned his $6,890 post yesterday and almost immediately became secretary of the Police Department at an annual salary of $7,340.
COMMERCIAL PAPER. Yesterday -- 2 3/4 to 3 per cent for the best names. Wednesday -- 2 3/4 to 3 per cent for the best names. The quotations are for three-four months' paper.
ALBANY, April 6 (AP) -- Elmer F. Andrews of New York City was nominated by Governor Lehman today to succeed Miss Frances Perkins, now Secretary of Labor, as State Industrial Commissioner.

The so-called "Pratt bill" suspending mandatory laws or ordinances that require an expenditure by local communities, has in modified form, though without change in principle, again made its appearance in the Legislature. There have already been made certain modifications in mandatory acts resulting in the temporary reduction of teachers' salaries and giving local boards authority to make such temporary retrenchments as are approved by the State Education Department.

It was the legal advice of Joseph A. Gavagan, Representative from the Twenty-second Assembly District, supported by the opinions of two other attorneys, that caused James J. McCormick, Deputy City Clerks in charge of the Marriage License Bureau, to assume that he owed the government no income tax on fees he had received at the Municipal Building from bridegrooms, McCormick testified yesterday at his trial for income tax fraud.

BERLIN, April 6 --The Boerse, especially the stock market, was remarkably active today. An upward movement of some moment was caused by reports of a further | rise in the production of coal, iron and steel in the Rhineland industrial district.

British South Africa Company -- Year ended Sept. 30: Net income after expenses, loss from sale of securities, interest, Khodesian income tax and other charges and including u194,117 Income from investments and operation, u172,900, equal to 2.63 per cent on u6,570,376 lOa capital stock of 153 par value, against u262,151, or 3.99 per cent on the capital stock, in the preceding fiscal year.

A statement advising the public to deal directly with the official motor vehicle bureaus, rather than with unofficial agencies which impose a service charge for obtaining registration plates and licenses, was made yesterday by Charles A. Harnett, commissioner of motor vehicles.

WASHINGTON, April 6 -- State and Federal forestry experts gathered at a conference called by Secretary Wallace today to formulate a plan of reforestation of State lands to be applied throughout the country by Robert Fechner, director of emergency conservation work under the administration's program for putting 250,000 men on jobs in the forests.

CHICAGO, April 6 -- New high levels for the season for cash grains and futures were established today on the Board of Trade in one of the biggest bull markets in several years. Pit brokers n ported that the volume of trading was the largest since wheat advanced 30 cents a bushel in thirty days In October and November, 1931.

Despite the fact that this is the time of year when the sportsman's attention chiefly is centred on fishing, either in fresh or salt water, it also is the period when wild water fowl, which have wintered in this locality and places still further south, begin to show signs of moving.

ALBANY, April 6 -- A 1 per cent tax on retail sales, a 1 per cent tax on gross incomes, a bill lowering the exemptions on the State personal income tax, and a fourth measure increasing the inheritance tax to the Federal level were passed today by the Senate as it moved swiftly toward balancing the State's budget.

Mayor O'Brien presided yesterday over the second of the series of conferences scheduled between city officials and security holders of the B.M.T., Interborough and Manhattan elevated lines, on transit unification. The meeting was with representatives of holders of $10,000,000 of Interborough 6 per cent unsecured notes, now in default.

On the eve of the return of legal beer, thousands of men and women stormed the offices of the Department of Health in all five boroughs yesterday afternoon and last night for permits to sell beer or wine, chiefly beer. At midnight, when the offices closed, a total of 9,138 permits had been issued.
PRINCETON, N.J., April 6. -- Prlnceton's baseball nine conquered C.C.N.Y., 6 to 2, today in a game shortened to five innings by rain. Wilson and Glazebrook held the Lavender to three safeties.

The United Light and Power Company has reduced its bank loans from $1,250,000 at the end of 1932 to $550,000, William Chamberlain, president, announced yesterday. He added that he hoped that the remainder would be paid by mid-year.

Failure of the Hitlerites' efforts to control the Lutheran Church in Germany was predicted yesterday by the Rev. Dr. Frederick H. Knubel, president of the United Lutheran Church in America. He minimized the importance of the new society called "German Christians" and said that while he would not deny that its members were Christians, a number of its aims were "ridiculous" and "not Christian."

WASHINGTON, April 6 -- Del Bissonette's rocky trail to a come-back, which he has followed courageously since fighting his way back to life in a New York hospital last Summer, was made into a broader, smoother highway today by the action of Vice President Joe Gilleaudeau and Manager Max Carey of the Dodgers.

ROCHESTER, April 6. -- Plans for setting up Rochester's street railway and bus lines in a new company largely owned and managed here were revealed today by Rochester bondholders. The lines are now. a part of the New York State Railways receivership.

Knocks for Everybody. Among the speakers at the anti-Hitler meeting held by the Communists in Madison Square Garden the other night was the secretary and active head of the American Civil Liberties Union.

ALBANY, April 6 -- The Desmond-Moffat bill on which advocates of charter revision, for New York City had been building their hopes was killed today in the Assembly when the measure failed to get the 76 votes necessary. The vote was 72 for to 71 against.
Four New York A.C. fencers were among the six who qualified last night for the semi-finals of the national epee championships in the preliminary tests held at the N.Y.A.C.

WASHINGTON, April 6 -- The texts of President Roosevelt's invitation to Prime Minister MacDonald of Great Britain to confer with him here on economic and disarmament questions, and of the acceptance by the Prime Minister, were made public tonight by the State Department. The invitation was as follows:
C0HICAGO, Friday, April 7 -- Chicago accorded a hearty but decorous welcome this morning to legalized 3.2 per cent beer.

For at least ten years the deteriorating effects of unemployment on health and morale have been recognized in England. We are beginning to note similar conditions here. In the address of Dr. PARRAN, State Commissioner of Health, he gives a timely warning against relief without work.

Praising volunteer social workers as largely responsible for a great part of the task of caring for the unemployed and for some of the greatest social reforms in the State, and urging the State minimum wage bill as one of the important measures for which they have labored, former Governor Alfred E. Smith pleaded yesterday for continuance of private charitable work, without which, he said, New York City could not get along.
WAKE FOREST, N.C., April 6 -- Wake Forest College swamped the University of Delaware in an eight-Inning baseball game today, 23 to-7. The contest was curtailed because of the heavy scoring.

The Board of Aldermen adopted unanimously yesterday a resolution chiding bankers who received "fabulous compensation" from their banks and advising them to practice the economies they preached in demanding salary reductions for city employes.

MEDFORD, N.J., April 6 -- Well handled by her owner, Raymond Hoagland Jr. of the Rumson Farm Kennels, the white, lemon and ticked pointer bitch, Rumson Farm Madge, today was awarded first honors in the members' all-age stake at the annual Springfield trials of the English Setter Club of America in the covers at Medford.
The following table shows the ten most active stocks traded on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday; also the new highs and lows for the last three days:

BERLIN, April 6 -- In justification of the removal of Jews from medical, legal, artistic and scientific positions in Germany, Chancellor Hitler pointed today to the exclusion of the yellow race by the United States.

Still wearing Warden Lewis E. Lawes's brown felt hat and overcoat, which he appropriated a week ago when he escaped from Sing Sing, Harry S. Kagel Jr., 21 years old, one of a robber trio known as the "Three Musketeers," was recaptured here last night.
Several small flats and a plot for improvement, in addition to the usual quota of dwellings, comprised the New Jersey realty turnover reported yesterday.

Contracts for residential construction closed during March In the Metropolitan area showed a decline, while those closed in thirty-seven States east of the Rockies showed an increase of about 35 per cent, according to figures compiled by L S. Schintman, chief statistician of Dodge Building Reports.
Harvard's varsity polo team rode into the final round of the inter-collegiate championship at Squadron A Armory last night, victor over Yale by the margin of a single goal, 13% to 12%.

New Jersey had fifty-nine minutes of legal beer, beginning at 12:01 o'clock this morning, and when the regular curfew law shut off the supply at 1 A.M. a good time apparently had been had by all. The Jersey beer taps were allowed to open again at 5 o'clock this morning.
WASHINGTON, April 6 -- A step to reduce working hours in industry was voted today by the Senate. The Black thirty-hour-week bill, carried by 53 to 30, now goes to the House.

The economic factors in the prevention of tuberculosis were stressed yesterday by speakers at the annual joint meeting and conference of the New York Tuberculosis and Health Association in the Hotel McAlpin, which brought together several hundred medical directors and staff workers of the clinical and sanitarium divisions of this organization.

Lincoln Ellsworth, leader of the Ellsworth Transantarctic Expedition, and Sir Hubert and Lady Wakins were guests of honor yesterday afternoon of Mr. and Mrs. Harry A. Bruno at a bon voyage party at their residence, 400 East Fifty-seventh Street.

DECATUR, Ala., April 6 -- Making a dramatic reappearance in the Scottsboro case today, Ruby Bates, previously missing State's witness, repudiated all her testimony given at the first trial two years ago and swore that Victoria Price had "framed" the Negro youths condemned to die at that trial for an alleged criminal attack on the two women while they were "hoboing" on a freight train.

BERLIN, April 6 -- The German Minister to Warsaw has been instructed by the government to make a formal protest to the Polish authorities against terrorism in Upper Silesia where, according to reports received at the Foreign Office, German minorities have been subjected to violence for several days.

LONDON, April 6 -- Prime Minister MacDonald received President Roosevelt's invitation to visit the United States tonight and accepted with the full approval of the Cabinet. He will sail, as THE NEW YORK TIMES indicated, aboard the Berengaria a week from Saturday and is due in New York on April 21.
WASHINGTON, April 6 -- Following is the text of Lieut. Commander Wiley's report on the crash of the Akron:

A budget of $11,660,055.21 for the fiscal year beginning July 1, 1933, a decrease of $1,238,422.25 from the current budget, has been adopted by the board of trustees of Columbia University, it was announced yesterday by Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of the university.

The Police Department announced yesterday 232 official citations of members who in recent months have displayed exceptional merit in the line of duty. Patrolman George L. Gerhard of the West Sixty-eighth Street station, who while on radio car patrol duty Dec. 14 was killed in the apprehension of two gunmen, headed the list.

The sport of horse racing throughout the United States as well as the breeding industry, which involve investments of scores of millions of dollars, are threatened by the impending curtailment of the New York racing season, according to statements from Colonel M.J. Winn, president of the American Turf Association, and E.J. Hughes, Secretary of State of Illinois, both of whom arrived in New York yesterday.

Several plans have, been proposed at Albany for pooling bank assets. One of these, embodied in the McCall bill, provides for a central "Reserve Savings Bank." All savings banks in the State would be required to join this central institution, in which the large city banks would be heavily outvoted.

LONDON, April 6 -- The bill to prohibit Russian imports was forged into a weapon considered likely to be more effective in protecting the life and liberty of the arrested British engineers when Walter Runciman, President of the Board of Trade, declared in the House of Commons this afternoon that the powers granted to the government would not be employed to enforce a favorable trade agreement with Russia.

PARIS, April 6 -- Although no official invitation has yet been received by the French Premier to visit Washington at the same time as Prime Minister MacDonald, informal conversations of Norman H. Davis, President Roosevelt's special Ambassador, with French statesmen here have made clear that it is Mr. Roosevelt's intention to make the meeting a gathering of British, French and American experts perhaps with other countries represented.

BUENOS AIRES, April 6 -- The Mendoza plan for peace between Bolivia and Paraguay was made public today simultaneously in Buenos Alres, Rio de Janeiro and Santiago, Chile. The replies of Bolivia and Paraguay also were published.

The Chase National Bank yesterday issued a report of its condition as of March 31 showing deposits of $1,306,745,347, against $1,466,038,619 on Dec. 31 last and $1,328,737,000 on March 31, 1932. Total resources of the bank amount currently to $1,777,727,031. against $1,856,290,382 at the end of last year.
Twelve Manhattan and Bronx properties were taken over by the plaintiffs at foreclosure auctions yesterday. Six of the defaulted parcels went to banks.

PARIS, April 6 -- Premier Daladier received the biggest majority since, be took office when he obtained the backing of 430 votes against 107 tonight in support of his declaration of foreign policy. It was more than a party vote and marked a notable evolution of French opinion on how the peace and disarmament problems must be approached.

BERLIN, April 6 (AP) -- The religion of Germany under Hitler rule, as defined today by the Protestant Nazi "German Christian movement," would oust the Old Testament and would erect in its stead the sagas and fairy tales of Germany and the leading personalities from German spiritual, philosophical and artistic life.

The New York Central and twenty-five other railroads have joined the "renovize movement" to stimulate buying and employment, it was disclosed yesterday in a letter sent to executives of the system by F. E. Williamson, president of the New York Central.

THE TRAGEDY OF THE AGES, a Passion play In three acts and eleven scenes, by the Rev. Joseph M. Congedo, with Incidental music by B. Gagliano. Staged by Giuseppe Sterni; produced by the Classic Players. At the Mecca Auditorium, 135 West Fifty-fifth Street.
HAVANA, April 6 -- The official announcement of the results in the St. Petersburg-Havana race, made today, follows:

ALBANY, April 6 -- With final adjournment of the Legislature or a legislative recess imminent, no progress had been made today toward harmonizing conflicting opinions on beer-control legislation. Governor Lehman was still standing firm on his own bill as the measure best calculated to achieve his purpose of keeping the beer traffic free from political influences.

COLUMBUS, April 6 (AP). -- A.J. Held's Funeral Directors of Columbus swept into second place in the five-man event of the American Bowling Congress tourney tonight with a total of 3,018. They rolled games of 937, 1,015 and 1,066.

Describing the merchant marine as a "line of defense" in both the economic and defense aspects of world affairs, Rear Admiral Hutch I. Cone, chairman of the United States Shipping Board, declared yesterday that the return of the United States to its pre-war status at sea would be "disastrous" to the nation's economic well-being.

Although the introduction of the ten-second rule in basketball a year ago brought forth some criticism from court coaches the board of directors of the National Association of Basketball Coaches yesterday went on record in executive session at the Hotel McAlpin as being unanimously in favor of the new code.

The Boston Symphony Orchestra, Serge Koussevitzky conductor, opened its concert last night in Carnegie Hall with the first American performance of the ballet music of Igor Markevitch, "Rebus." Markevitch is a young Parisianized Russian.

Peter J. McGuinness, Democratic boss in Greenpoint, is 100 per cent for the re-election of Mayor O'Brien, and that is why he will not attend a dinner at the Hotel Astor on May 11 when the Sons of Knickerbocker will honor Joseph V. McKee, the Aldermanic President and possible opponent of Mayor O'Brien.

WASHINGTON, April 6 -- The daily average volume of Federal Reserve Bank credit outstanding during the week ended April 5, as reported by the Federal Reserve Banks, was $2,587,000,000, a decrease of $200,000,000 compared with the preceding week and an increase of $987,000,000 compared with the corresponding week in 1932.

WASHINGTON, April 6 (AP). -- Production of crude petroleum in the United States in February was reported today by the Bureau of Mines to have totaled 61,029,000 barrels, a daily average of 2,108,000. This was 116,000 barrels more than the dally average for January and 25,000 more than the average for February, 1932.

The 7,500 single men who will be recruited for the new Civilian Conservation Corps will be accepted as volunteers from the families of the 120,000 men who are receiving aid from the Home Relief Bureau of the Department of Public Welfare, according to an announcement made yesterday afternoon by Harry L. Hopkins, chairman of the State Temporary Emergency Relief Administration.

Despite the tremendous headway man has made against the power of the sea, science probably never will make a ship totally steady in bad weather, in the opinion of Preston Bassett, chief engineer of the Sperry Gyroscope Company, who returned yesterday from, an observation voyage on the Italian liner Conte di Savoia.
WASHINGTON, April 6 -- Departmental cuts and reorganizations now being worked out by President Roosevelt were revealed today to be much more drastic than were planned at first.

As a result of sharp declines on Wednesday in stock and bond Issues of the Chicago North Western Railway Company, the committee on business conduct of the Stock Exchange began yesterday an investigation into all transactions in these issues.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., April 6 -- Brilliant fielding plays by Johnny Dugan and Preston Woodlock, who played their first game In a Yale varsity uniform, featured Yale's opening contest of the season today when the Elis defeated Springfield College, 8 to 4.

Yorkville, the colony centring around Eighty-sixth Street on the upper east side, to which German-Americans brought the traditions of beer when they moved there from the lower east side half a century ago, greeted the legalization of 3.2 brew with what seemed to be apathy to those familiar with its jovial inhabitants.

Plans for reclaiming the thirty-two-acre site of the abandoned lower reservoir in Central Park will be discussed today at a luncheon of the executive committee of the Park Association of New York City when John E. Sheehy, newly appointed Commissioner of Parks of Manhattan, will be made an ex-officio member of the association.

Parks were one of the few bright spots in the record of the Walker Administration. With the collaboration of Controller BERBY, the borough Park Commissioners and interested private organizations, a program of development and expansion was formulated whose gradual realization brought joy to the hearts of all who love parks, for the means of refreshment and release they are capable of affording to millions of city dwellers.

NEW HAVEN. Conn., April 6-- Yale will establish next Fall a new system of Intramural sports; will discontinue class teams, and will form a distinct intramural athletic council, according to a statement made today la The Tale Daily News by Malcolm Farmer, chairman of athletics at the university.

A plan for assembling regional coordinating committees to carry out the Washington administration's ideas for reducing competitive railroad costs was under discussion in railroad circles yesterday. The legislation originally planned had called for a Federal moderator working with three regional moderators, one each for the East, Southeast and West.

Doggedly but futilely, the navy continued its search for the Akron dead yesterday. Hour after hour the fleet of searching ships and planes swept through mist and rain across a great area of the sea off the New Jersey Coast. At the saddened town of Lakehurst, final preparations were made for the convening on Monday of the naval court of inquiry that will investigate the destruction of the world's greatest airship.

The effects of the bank holiday on the steel industry during the first half of last month were shown in the monthly steel ingot production figures of the American Iron and Steel Institute issued yesterday. The output for March receded approximately to the level of last December, averaging 15.08 per cent of capacity, against 20.41 per cent in February and 24.04 in March, 1932.
To the Editor of the New York Times: Dr. Henry van Dyke's tulips may not bloom in Union Square; the groundhog still may slumber, but Spring has come to Riverside Park.

WASHINGTON, April 6 -- Plans for wholesale dismissal of minor officials and employes of the Department of Justice were announced by Attorney General Cummings today as part of a far-reaching economy drive.

Joseph W. Harriman was indicted by a Federal grand jury yesterday on charges that he made false entries totaling $1,713,225 in the accounts of fourteen depositors at the Harriman National Bank during 1931 and 1932, while he was president.

With the financial and commodity markets responding to a fresh optimism, interest was centred yesterday upon the accompanying indications of moderate expansion in business and of continued recovery in the banking position. Aside from the encouraging record of progress revealed in the Federal Reserve statement late in the day, there was accumulating evidence of enlarged industrial operations and of increased activity in the distributive trades.

WASHINGTON, April 6 (AP). -- A Federal ban on loans to governments in default to America or its citizens was recommended to the Senate today by its Judiciary Committee in a report on the Johnson bill. Meanwhile, the administration's securities bill forged ahead in Congressional committees.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I read with Interest the letter of George Foster Peabody referring to the editorial in THE TIMES which states that the high homicide rate in the South is probably due not so much to "the presence of large Negro populations but rather the standard of law and order to which a particular community may reconcile itself."

Joyously greeted as a harbinger, of good times, beer flowed legally yesterday in the home communities of about 70,000,000 Americans for the first time since its banishment thirteen years ago. Only one complaint wag widely heard as millions sought to sample the new brew, and that was that the supply in many places was not equal to the demand.

A story of how a 13-year-old Brooklyn high school girl with an appetite for mystery stories allegedly attempted to extort $10,000 from a well-to-do physician on the threat of kidnapping his 11-year-old daughter was related yesterday in the Brooklyn Children's Court when Elaine Petry, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. August Petry of 5,510 Sixth Avenue.

The news of the passage of the "Wallace betting and tax bill by the Assembly at Albany was received with delight in racing circles yesterday. The presidents of three of the New York racing associations gave high praise to the Albany lawmakers, while Algernon Daingerfield, an official of the Jockey Club, said:
COMMERCIAL PAPER. yesterday ......2 3/4 to 3% for the beat names Thursday ......2 3/4 to 3% for the best names The quotations are for three-four months' paper.

With the fanfare of initiation varying from the blare of brass bands and the jubilant parades of students to the quiet and business-like demeanor of the stout brewery truckman hoisting a case on his shoulder for a march up the drive of a private residence, the new era of beer was ushered in in communities within 100 miles of Broadway yesterday.

MINNEAPOLIS, Minn., April 7 -- Commenting on a Canadian report that the Minneapolis, St. Paul Sault Ste. Marie Railroad, of which he is president, was looking toward reorganization under the amended bankruptcy act, C.T. Jaffray said tonight:

BERLIN, April 7. -- A sweeping constitutional reorganization of Germany that creates Chancellor Adolf Hitler's promised "third Reich" and converts the country from a federation of States into one centralized State completely in the hands of Herr Hitler was decided upon at a Cabinet session today.

WASHINGTON, April 7 (AP) -- A move to reconsider the thirty-hour work week bill because imported products were excluded from its drastic terms was made in the Senate today simultaneously with the introduction of another measure by Senator Black to establish a six-hour day for the railroads.
BOSTON, April 7 (AP) -- The Commercial Bulletin will say tomorrow:

Effects Will Be Immediate. Beer having become available to the American people on the morning of Friday, April 7, it would be kind of the experts if they waited at least until Monday morning, April 10, before pointing out the profound effects of the return of beer on the entire national situation.

WASHINGTON, April 7 -- A joint Congressional investigation into the causes of the Akron disaster probably will take the place of the present House Naval Affairs Committee inquiry, because of a feeling among members of Congress that those having nothing to do with military affairs should conduct it in order to avoid any possibility of an appearance of "whitewashing" some aspects of construction and Operation.

A clash between Mayor O'Brien and John J. Halleran, Queens Public Works Commissioner who was sitting for Borough President Harvey, marked the Board of Estimate's discussion yesterday of the claim of the Long Island Railroad for $183.40 for furnishing passenger transportation for some of the employes of Mr. Harvey's office in January and February, 1932.
Plaintiffs bought in ten Manhattan and Bronx properties at foreclosure auctions yesterday. The results follow:

CHICAGO, April 7 -- Heavy profit-taking in grains disclosed early today an overbought condition on the Board of Trade and gave corn a substantial setback from which it did not fully recover. Nothing in the news started the selling, but the recent sharp bulge gave good profits to many operators, and they did not resist the temptation to take them.

Tom Wright, captain-elect of the Columbia University swimming team for next year, won the 500 yard metropolitan A.A.U. junior free style championship swim, feature event of the meet held last night In the Columbia University pool.
Naval officers were reported last night as believing it probable that the wreck of the airship Akron had been found.

WASHINGTON, April 7. -- Declaring that the law of supply and demand has failed, so far as farm prices were concerned, Senator Robinson of Arkansas, the Democratic floor leader, today opened the fight in the Senate for enactment of the agricultural relief program of the administration.

WASHINGTON, April 7 -- Indicative of the necessity for international action to bring about a freer flow of commodities among nations, the Department of Commerce, in a report made public today, showed that world trade in both exports and imports during 1932 declined to $26,160,000,000, a reduction of 34 per cent in value and 25 per cent in volume below the preceding year.

WASHINGTON, April 7 -- A broad range of economic discussions with foreign governments here in the next few weeks was assured today when the State Department, on behalf of President Roosevelt, invited seven other governments to send delegations here.
The Connecticut Board of Fisheries and Game yesterday announced a complete list of State-leased trout streams. It is a compilation which the anglers will welcome.

The New York Telephone Company has owned and published Donnelley's Red Book, ths classified directory of business telephone subscribers, since March 11, 1931, it was disclosed yesterday at a hearing before the Public Service Commission to determine the relationship between the telephone company and the Reuben H. Donnelley Corporation.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Regarding the statement by the Port Authority that the Fifty-seventh Street bridge over the Hudson is no longer needed, it should be pointed out that this is in contradiction of the actual situation.
MEDFORD, N.J., April 7. -- A powerful pointer, Mote Baird, won the open junior all-age stake today in the annual Springfield trials of the English Setter Club of America.

Several large blocks of stock of the Consolidated Gas Company of New York were accumulated in 1932, according to a list of persons or corporations owning 1 per cent or more of the shares at the end of the year, but the changes were small compared with the total shares outstanding.

TOKYO, April 7 -- By appending to the resignation of Matsukichi Koyama, the Minister of Justice, which was tendered to the Emperor yesterday, a recommendation that it be not accepted, on which the Emperor acted, Premier Viscount Makoto Saito has aroused a furor among politicians which threatens to weaken instead of strengthening his Cabinet.
"Hummin' Sam," a Negro musical comedy, will open this evening at the New Yorker Theatre. Gertrude (Baby) Cox is its star and Allan K. Foster its producer.

After advancing again yesterday until the list had reached more than $2 a bale above recent low levels, prices on the Cotton Exchange lost the improvement and closed 1 to 3 points lower than on Thursday. For a time a large quantity of contracts changed hands under the continuation of a broader commission-house interest and active price-fixing by consumers.
With the March report of the Manhattan Bureau of Buildings showing alteration plans far ahead of new building, more work of the former type of improvement will result from deals announced yesterday.

LONDON, April 7 -- John Galsworthy's will, made public today, revealed that he left an estate valued at u88,587 [about $303,300 at current exchange]. Probate was granted to his widow, Rudolf Sauter, a nephew, and Sir Walter Halsey, solicitor.

PARIS, April 7 -- The French Government received, late this afternoon President Roosevelt's invitation to have a representative attend advance discussions on the World Economic Conference. which are to be held in Washington soon.

The Baron de Hirsch Fund has agreed with the Elliac Corporation that a mortgage for $15,000 recently given by the latter on 753 Madison Av. be consolidated with a prior mortgage to form one first lien of $30,000 thereon, and extended to April 3, 1938, at 5 1/2 per cent.
WASHINGTON, April 7 -- The War Department issued the following orders today:
BERLIN, April 7 -- The visit to Berlin tomorrow of Norman H. Davis, "United States Ambassador at Large," as he is considered here, is awaited by German Government circles with great Interest.

LONG BEACH, L.I., April 7. -- Mayor Frank Frankel and the Long Beach City Council were notified today by the protective committee for holders of notes of the city that the committee intended to sue for payment of demand notes totaling $554,853.

WASHINGTON, April 7 -- Further important domestic legislation will be laid before Congress in the next ten days by President Roosevelt so he may be free to devote himself to international questions such as the economic conference and intergovernmental debts.

WASHINGTON, April 7. -- Senators Robinson, Connally and Borah were appointed today by Chairman Pittman of the Foreign Relations Committee to study the "censorship" bill passed by the House, and submit recommendations. Senator Robinson announced that the whole measure would be rewritten, possibly tomorrow, and reported for action of the full committee and the Senate early next week.
To the Editor of The New York Times: In these days of lightning-like legislation by Congress to meet the emergency little heed is paid to constitutional limitations.

Jake, a four-and-one-half-foot black snake, awakened yesterday noon and found himself in strange surroundings. Where he had been the night before is a mystery, but there he was, in a refuse can, placed by the Department of Sanitation at the southwest corner of Broadway and Thirty-sixth Street.

It used to be the theory, and it was the theory of the makers of the Constitution, that the Senate would be more conservative than the House, a check upon hasty and imprudent legislation. On Thursday the Senate passed by 53 to 30 the Black bill to prevent interstate commerce in commodities produced in factories whose employes work more than thirty hours a week.

Reflecting easier rates on money in the open market following the cut in the rediscount rate of the Federal Reserve Bank here from 3 1/2 to 3 per cent, the listed bond market moved generally higher yesterday. United States Government bonds showed good strength, and leading foreign loans, with the notable exception of the German issues, averaged considerably higher.
To the Editor of The New York Times: George Foster Peabody, writing to THE TIMES, undertakes to explain a certain matter down South. I might as well undertake to explain something about Peiping.

MOSCOW, April 7. -- The trial of the accused Metropolitan-Vickers Electrical Company's engineers will begin, next Wednesday, with M. Ulrich, who has presided in other famous cases, as the president of the court. The locale has not yet been determined.
Legal beer came back to New York yesterday after an absence of thirteen years, and enjoyed an immedite and widespread popularity throughout the city.

The approximate status of the municipal bond market is reflected in the following list of representative high-grade State, city and county bonds, legal for savings banks in this State, now offered by dealers:

PALM BEACH, Fla., April 7 -- In compliment to Mrs. Arthur MacArthur of Washington, who is their house guest, Mr. and Mrs. Edward T. Stotesbury entertained tonight with a dinner at Elmirasol. Mr. and Mrs. Stotesbury plan to remain until late this month before returning to Philadelphia.

The Consolidated Oil Corporation reports for the eleven months ended on Dec. 31 last a consolidated net Income of $1,601,039 after all charges and reserves, equal, after preferred dividend requirements, to about 4 cents a share on the 14,218,835 common shares of no par value.

Joseph Castaldo, the so-called artichoke king, who is serving a sentence in a Federal penitentiary for violating the income-tax law, was indicted yesterday by a Federal grand jury, with five others, on charges of violating the Sherman anti-trust law.
NEW YORK. Mrs. Le Grand C. Cramer is giving a dinner tonight at the Barclay for her granddaughter, Miss Joan Wilmerding Cramer, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Wilmerding Cramer.

PHILADELPHIA, April 7 -- Had this country and the League of Nations, when the Chino-Japanese troubles began, "been willing to force China to agree to direct conversations" with Japan, an era of goodwill beneficial to both Far Eastern countries might well have begun, according to William R. Castle Jr., Under-Secretary of State in the Hoover administration.

The movement to restore the thirty-two-acre site of the lower reservoir in Central Park, launched by the Park Association of New York City under the leadership of its president, Nathan Straus Jr., received fresh impetus yesterday when Frank. J. Taylor, Commissioner of the Department of Public Welfare, pledged his cooperation at a luncheon of the association's executive committee.
HAMILTON, Bermuda, April 7 -- Bermuda's one-design yachts defeated the Long Island Sound Interclub fleet for the third consecutive time today and clinched the international series by a wide margin.

BERLIN, April 7. -- Chancellor Adolf Hitler's already dictatorial political powers over Germany were vastly increased tonight when the Cabinet approved a law drastically curtailing the functions of the State Diets.

ALBANY, April 7. -- In a surprising move today the Assembly threw Governor Lehman's $212,000,000 budget completely out of balance, defeating a bill to continue the 1-cent additional gasoline tax voted last year, from which about $15,000,000 in revenue was expected this year.

Steaming through the Mediterranean Sea on their way to celebrate Easter at Rome, a band of American pilgrims aboard the Italian liner Rex observed the Holy Year yesterday with a program of music and talks, which were flashed by short radio waves back to listeners in the United States, nearly 4,000 miles away.

WASHINGTON, April 7 (AP) -- The administration's securities control bill was subjected to further attack before the Senate Banking Committee today while a House Interstate Commerce subcommittee began revising the measure to meet many objections.
PRINCETON, N.J., April 7 -- Three Frinceton pitchers allowed twelve hits today as the Tiger nine bowed to the Philadelphia Nationals, 10 to 1, on University Field.

A $2 a day wage reduction, from $13.20 to $11.20, for journeymen electricians was voted last night by Local 3 of the International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers at a meeting in the Central Opera House, 205 East Sixty-seventh Street, attended by 4,000 members.

STUTTGART, Germany, April 7 -- The victory of the National Socialist revolution in Germany has resulted in wholesale arrests of the Nazis' political opponents. The number of political prisoners in Germany today is a closely guarded government secret, but it is generally agreed it must run well into the thousands.
New York greeted the return of legal beer yesterday with an effer-vescent spirit that left brewers and retailers alike wondering how much of it was genuine enthusiasm and how much passing curiosity.

It is not only the United States Treasury that is disappointed in the flow of revenue, far below even the revised estimates which it made at the end of the last year. The British Exchequer has discovered that there is such a thing as progressive exhaustion of the tax-payers.

Figure skating featured the annual carnival and competition of the Junior Skating Club, held yesterday afternoon on the roof rink of Madison Square Garden. The youngsters not only engaged in their contests but there were a number of exhibitions, and the space around the ice was well filled by spectators.

A profit-taking reaction, following the wide advances on Thursday, resulted in losses yesterday in several of the commodities traded on local exchanges. Sugar, coffee, cocoa and silver lost some of their gains of the preceding day. Ruber, hides and silk, on the other hand, continued to advance.

PERTH, Australia, April 7. -- The people of Western Australia will vote tomorrow on whether they favor secession from the Australian Commonwealth or whether they favor a convention of representatives of the Australian States to revise the Commonwealth Constitution.

The entire entertaining suite of the Ambassador will be given over tonight to the Blue and White Supper Dance, which has been arranged under the auspices of the Prosperity Club for the benefit of a charity. The Louis XV ballroom. Italian garden and main dining room will be used for general dancing and a special program of entertainment.
WASHINGTON. April 7 -- The Bureau of Navigation issued the following orders today, dated April 5

MONTREAL, Que., April 7 (Canadian Press) -- The protective committee for holders of collateral trust bonds of the Beauharnois Power Corporation has approved the socalled Montreal Power plan of reorganization of the corporation and recommends its adoption at a meeting to be held here on May 3.

A plea was made yesterday to Federal Judge Frank J. Coleman that it might endanger the life of Joseph W. Harriman to bring him into court for arraignment on the indictment of the previous day, charging him with false entries totaling $1,713,225 in the accounts of fourteen depositors at the Harriman National Bank during 1931 and 1932, while he was president.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Mr. Cravath's decision as noted in his letter to THE TIMES is a most surprising one. He takes the position that we should officially recognize the Soviet Government so that we could better protect the American citizens who are now residing in Russia.

With about a dozen new rules changes offered for consideration, the National Association of Basketball Coaches continued its three-day meeting at the Hotel McAlpin yesterday. It is believed that few of the suggestions will be approved in the final session this morning.

LONDON, April 7 (AP) -- President Roosevelt's initiative in arranging eeonomic discussions with representatives of the other powers in Washington was received favorably here in authoritative quarters.

Only a slight Increase in the volume of new municipal financing is scheduled for award next week. Twenty-eight communities throughout the country seek bids on bonds and notes in the amount of $5,058,085. Some of these issues are "repeats" inasmuch as they have been offered before without attracting bids.

There have been many prescriptions of the kind of currency inflation which the country and the times are alleged to need. Some say it must be "controlled inflation," or "regulated," going just as far as is safe but no further. All of these theories imply that there is a great demand for an addition to the money in circulation.

LONDON, April 7. --Sir Austen Chamberlain issued a stern warning to the German Government in a speech tonight at Birmingham, where he was re-elected president of the Conservative Association. The former Foreign Secretary of Britain said progress toward peace in Europe had been lost and the Continent was "more full of fear and more acutely sensitive to imminent danger than a year or two ago."

NEWARK, N.J., April 7 -- Federal Judge Guy L. Fake today exonerated the Commercial Trust Company of New Jersey of Jersey City of the charge of participating in an alleged conspiracy as a result of which Oil Shares, Inc., asserts it was looted of $500,000.

WASHINGTON, April 7. -- Selection of fifty-three army posts and depots from which the commanding officers will choose conditioning camps for the 25,000 forestry workers was announced today by Robert Fechner, director of emergency conservation work.

DECATUR, Ala., April 7. -- The issue of Alabama against New York City and the clothes, manners and customs of its people was brought up here today before Judge James E. Horton and the jury which is trying Haywood Patterson, a Negro, for his life.

PARIS, April 7 -- The International Oil Conference, which opened simultaneously with the Washington oil discussions, closed here today without making any important alterations in the industry's situation.

Miss Olivia S. Bird gave a dinner last night at her home, 127 East Sixty-fourth Street, for Miss Marjorie Schuyler and Eugene Van Ness, whose marriage will take place April 18. Miss Bird later took her guests to the Seaglade of the St. Regis for supper and dancing.

COLUMBUS, Ohio. April 7 (AP). -- Scoring games of 938, 1,036 and 1,019, the Congressman auf der Heide five from West New York, N.J., gained third place in the team division of the American bowling congress tonight with a total of 2,993.

PRAGUE, April 7. --Fresh frontier violations by German Nazis were reported today in the Socialist press, which says that on Wednesday night a German Communist named Martin was kidnapped from the village of Kreibitz, near the German frontier, where he had been staying for several weeks.

An undergraduate interpretation of what happens when members of college faculties dabble in student politics was revealed to more than 1,000 persons last night, when the City College Dramatic Society presented "Here Comes the Bribe," a musical farce, as its semi-annual varsity show at the college's Twenty-third Street building.
WASHINGTON, April 7 -- An investigation into the motion picture industry was approved today by the House Committee on Rules in voting to report favorably the Sirovich resolution.

A highly symbolic and 3.2 per cent alcoholic case of beer was delivered yesterday afternoon to former Governor Alfred E. Smith on the doorstep of the Empire State Building. The first case of the new beer to be received by Mr. Smith, it was definitely a tribute to his political "wetness."

One thousand Boy Scouts will participate in the eighth annual celebration of National Parents' Day, which will be observed with ceremonies on the Mall in Central Park Sunday afternoon, May 14, Uncle Robert, organizer of the event and children's radio broadcaster, said yesterday.

"The largest part" of what was left of the Democratic campaign fund in the Twenty-second Assembly District went to James J. McCormick, Deputy City Clerk in charge of the Marriage License Bureau, McCormick testified yesterday at his trial before Federal Judge John C. Knox and a jury for income tax fraud.

A total of forty-three thorough-breds remain eligible for the sixty-fifth running of the historic Belmont Stakes for 3-year-olds, which will be renewed during the latter part of the coming Spring meeting at Belmont Park, according to an announcement yesterday by Racing Secretary Victor Schaumburg.

Recipients of old age relief who obtained monthly allotments from the city and State fraudulently have turned back approximately $200,000 in the last year, according to Deputy Attorney General Charles A. Schneider, who conferred yesterday with city and State officials on measures intended to speed the drive against impostors.

The twelfth annual series of Holy Week noon lenten services will be conducted by the Greater New York Federation, of Churches, beginning Monday and continuing daily through Good Friday in the Palace Theatre, Broadway and Forty-seventh Street.

The untiring Director of the Budget, Mr. DOUGLAS, is planning further economies at Washington. He has made it clear that the Administration does not intend to stand on the large reduction it has already made in the outlay for veterans' relief.

Net operating income of 149 Class I railroads decreased 54.5 per cent in February compared with February, 1932, according to the Bureau of Railway Economics. This was in contrast to January, when net operating income increased 18.6 per cent over that of a year before.
BERLIN, April 7. -- When the law courts resume activities with a pure Teutonic personnel there is a certain amount of new business already assured the judges and lawyers in the way of divorce cases.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., April 7. -- Angered by the blocking of the Pitcher milk control bill in the State Senate, several hundred independent milk producers of the Rochester area tonight ended their truce in a milk war which halted just a week ago today, when the Pitcher measure was started through the Legislature.

LONDON, April 7 -- A plan to recapture Great Britain's lost iron and steel export trade has been issued by the Import Duties Advisory Committee. The proposal is "to build up comprehensive national machinery for the iron and steel industry within which the advantages of both combined action and individual enterprise may be secured."

The need for "new blood" in the teaching profession and obstacles which have prevented appointments and made the demand for new teachers almost non-existent were brought to the attention of delegates to the eighth annual Spring conference of the Eastern States Association of Professional Schools for Teachers, in the Hotel Pennsylvania, yesterday.

BERLIN, April 7. -- Some wonderment has been aroused here by a passage in Chancellor Hitler's speech last night to provincial editors in which he compared "the immense discipline and unexampled control" of the victorious National Socialist revolution not only with the record of previous political upsets in Germany since the war but with the tribulations of the Nazis themselves during their ten-years' struggle for power.

PURCHASE, N.Y., April 7. -- Mr. and Mrs. George W. Cole of Stamford, Conn., came off with the chief honors of the opening day's competition in the three-day meeting of the Southern New York Field Trial Club, which got under way in a sweeping rainstorm this morning.

Visible evidence of continuing improvement in business furnished the background for further recovery yesterday in the security markets. In bonds, the substantial gains were held until the close, but stocks turned mildly reactionary in the afternoon, losing their early gains.

The first champion of Indoor polo for 1933 will be crowned tonight at Squadron A Armory, Ninety-fourth Street and Madison Avenue, when Harvard and the United States Military Academy meet in the final of the intercollegiate championship.

ALBANY, April 7 -- Governor Lehman today made another unsuccessful attempt to bring the Republicans in the Legislature in line for a beer-control measure that he consistently could accept. The deadlock still holds.

Some branches of business went to new high levels for the year as the Spring expansion spread widely in the last week, according to Dun Bradstreet, Inc. The commercial agency reports indications that the expansion is more than seasonal and notes also multiplying evidences of definite confidence in the restorative powers and competence of the new administration.

ALBANY, April 7. -- Governor Lehman is bringing pressure to bear on the fiscal leaders of the Legislature to restore to the budget $18,300 which was cut from the appropriation for the State Division of Housing. This evening it was stated at the Executive Chamber that he had received assurance that the amount provided in his original budget, $32,680, would be awarded to the Housing Board.
METUCHEN, N.J., April 7 -- The Rutgers University golf team vanquished New York University, 3 1/2 to 2 1/2, today at the Metuchen Country Club.

Assurances were given yesterday in political Circles that the repeal slate of convention delegates to be voted upon at the special election on May 23 will include names of nationally prominent Democrats and Republicans.

The Ringling Brothers-Barnum Bailey circus, which is celebrating its golden jubilee, will open at 2 P. M. today in Madison Square Garden. The circus went through a midnight rehearsal last night before a picked audience of newspaper men, while Dexter Fellows cracked a ringmaster's whip from the sidelines.

Declaring that the methods of the Auto Travel Bureau, Inc., of 11 West Forty-second Street, in arranging for private car owners to carry passengers on a "share-expense" basis, constituted "a quasiattempt to evade the law," Magistrate Michael A. Ford found two officials of that corporation guilty of a violation of the motor vehicle law at a hearing yesterday in Jefferson Market Court.
ALBANY, April 7 -- The Republican-controlled Assembly reversed itself today and passed the Desmond-Moffat bill for election of charter revision commissions.

The great doors of St. Patrick's Cathedral swung open yesterday morning for a varied company of mourners, come to pay homage to those lost aboard the Akron. There were friends and relatives, sailors and marines, the commanding officers of the navy and the army in this area, and Mayor O'Brien and other officials representing the City of New York.

WASHINGTON, April 7. -- President Roosevelt has turned his face definitely against inflation of the currency, remonetization of silver or any form of fiat money and will seek instead to reinflate commodity values by a vast public works program designed to revive business, it was reliably understood, today.

A new intercoastal service which calls for weekly sailings from New York and San Francisco, with calls at the Canal Zone, Havana and Kingston, will be started by the United Fruit Company, succeeding the fortnightly service now in effect, it was announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, April 7. -- Any reductions in the Army Air Corps budget estimates which would prevent accomplishment of the five year expansion program, still incomplete in its seventh year, were made by the Army General Staff, Representative Collins of Mississippi, chairman of the subcommittee in charge of War Department appropriations, today told the House Military Affairs Committee.

The basal forms of personal religion that form a wide and ancient basis for such comparatively new movements as Buchmanism are studied in "The Living God," just published by the Oxford University Press. The book was written by the lats Nathan Soderfalom, Archbishop of Upsala, in Sweden.

Although the net results in the share market were disappointing, Wall Street continued yesterday to manifest its new spirit of hopefulness. Brokers reported that while their customers were cautious they were becoming "increasingly bullish."
The speakeasy and beer racketeering, fattened by thirteen years of making, running and selling illicit beer, were emerging yesterday as partly or completely legitimate businesses.

President Roosevelt may perhaps justly consider himself the hero of the seventeenth annual exhibition of the Society of Independent Artists, which was opened last night on the fourth floor of Grand Central Palace.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Jacob Fisher in a letter to THE TIMES says that social workers do not regard the enactment of the reforestation bill as an unmixed blessing, giving as reasons the further depression of the wage level and the fact that families of men recruited can hardly be maintained on a $30 monthly wage.
A quick resale of a former brewery parcel was included in the New Jersey realty transactions reported yesterday.

BERLIN, April 7. -- Dr. Philip Heineken, president of the Norddeutscher Lloyd and chairman of its executive board, today joined the ranks of those, including Dr. Ludwig Kastl, recently president of the Federation of German Industries, who will not be "coordinated" with the new Germany.

Buses plied back and forth last night between the Army Building at 39 Whitehall Street and Fort Slocum, near New Rochelle, transporting a steady flow of recruits for the Civilian Conservation Corps, who were among the first of the 7,500 young single men from New York who will work on reforestation projects for $30 a month.

Informed yesterday by Controller Charles W. Berry that the Board of Education's funds would show a probable deficit of $4,500,000 this year, partly as a result of the reduced State aid for local schools, the Board of Estimate referred the matter to its Committee of the Whole with the possibility that the shortage may be met through new sources of revenue.

PINEHURST, N.C., April 7 -- Continuing the sub-par golf which he has maintained all week, George T. Dunlap Jr., Walker Cup star, won his second North and South amateur golf championship today when he overcame Jack Toomer of Jacksonville, the champion of Florida, in the final of the thirty-third annual tourney.

WASHINGTON, April 7 -- The River and Harbor Board of Army Engineers was urged by Brooklyn, Coney Island and New York City interests at a hearing today to reconsider its adverse decision on improving Coney Island Creek at present. The project calls for nearly doubling the depth of the creek by providing a 12-foot channel.

NORFOLK, Va., April 7 -- The Giants celebrated the final game of their exhibition tour with a spirited batting onslaught which buried the Detroit Tigers under a 17-7 defeat today. Tonight Memphis Bill Terry's boys are heading for New York and the Polo Grounds for their two closing interleague clashes with Detroit.

OKLAHOMA CITY, Okla., April 7 (AP) -- Several days postponement of the oil States conference at Amarillo, Texas, was announced tonight by Colonel Cicero I. Murray, personal representative of Governor William H. Murray, who had called the meeting for Sunday.
Hiram Percy Maxim, whose inventions have silenced rifles, engines and hospital rooms, ranges in speculation to Mars and beyond in "Life's Place in the Cosmos," just published by Appleton.

LITTLE FALLS, N.J., April 7 -- More than half a century ago Professor George Ziegler and his German bands were known in the beer gardens of Long Island, Coney Island, Fort George and other centres of amusement. On Jan. 17 thirteen years ago he retired from business.

Lee Shubert regained control yesterday of his theatres and other theatrical properties which went into receivership last year. The Select Theatres Corporation, of which he is president, bought them at the auction sale in the County Court House for $400,000, the minimum sum allowed under the terms of the sale.

The International Utilities Corporation, sponsored by Percy M. Chandler, was revealed yesterday as the leader of the opposition to the management of the Phoenix Securities Corporation, formerly the Prince Whitely Trading Corporation, and as the company that in the past attempted to effect a merger with Phoenix.

Celebrating the sixteenth anniversary of the entry of the United States into the World War, 18,000 veterans and members of patriotic and civic societies will march down Fifth Avenue from Ninetieth Street ginning at 2:30 o'clock in the annual Army Day parade.

TORONTO, April 7. -- Fit and ready after a three-day lay-off, the New York Rangers and Toronto Maple Leafs will resume the series for the Stanley Cup, emblematic of world professional hockey supremacy, tomorrow night.

PURNEA, India, April 7 -- The Houston Mount Everest pilots found flying impossible today owing to strong winds. The day was marred by a serious accident to S.N. Gupta, the meteorological officer here, and two assistants.

ALBANY, April 7 -- A bill to permit open betting at the New York race tracks, backed by The Jockey Club, was passed in the Assembly today by 117 votes to 17. Tonight a drive was on in the Senate to win enough votes to insure passage in the upper house.

An oil painting by the noted American artist, Winslow Homer, called "The Fisher Girl," brought $11,000 last night at the American Art Association-Anderson Galleries, Inc., in the auction of the art collection of the late Burton Mansfield of New Haven, Conn.

General PERSHING sounded the right note when he said of the celebration of Army Day this year that, while it is the annual custom to select April 6, the anniversary of the entrance of the United States into the World War, to honor the land service, "today the "army fights shoulder to shoulder "with all our people in the battle "which is being successfully waged "against the forces of economic "depression."

Miguel de Capriles of the University Fencers Club, former N.Y. U. star, qualified for the semi-final round of the national saber championship in the elimination tests held last night at the New York A. C.

TEHERAN, Persia, April 7. -- The semi-official newspaper Iran, announces today that Persia has completed arrangements for a number of fifteen-year monopoly agreements with the Persian-American Trading Corporation of New York.

Yale's baseball team will open the defense of its Eastern Intercollegiate championship today at 3:15 P.M., when it opposes Columbia at Baker Field in the first game of the league campaign. The Lions were runner-up to the Eli nine last season and league officials forecast a close encounter this afternoon, Today's contest will be part of a charity sports program.

BERLIN, April 7 -- Whatever may the effect on the Reichsbank's policy of the shrinkage of Germany's export surplus and the consequent depletion of the nation's gold reserves, Germany must stand by her commercial foreign debt to preserve confidence abroad, which she will need in her future trade relations, Dr. Hjalmar Schacht, president of the Reichsbank, told leading German bankers at today's meeting of the Reichsbank's shareholders.

Officials of the Globe and Rutgers Fire Insurance Company announced yesterday they would oppose the appointment of a liquidator, requested in a petition filed in the Supreme Court by George S. Van Schaick, State Superintendent of Insurance, which is to come up for argument on next Tuesday morning before Justice Edward J. Glennon.

CHICAGO, April 7 -- The possibility of an early lifting of the ban on life insurance company policy loans and cash-surrender privileges was still remote tonight after insurance commissioners of more than thirty States held an executive session here.

The pamphlet report of the Nevada Consolidated Copper Company for 1932 shows that on Dec. 31 current assets were $12,267,728 and current liabilities, $1,624,355, compared with $19.388,114 and $4,951,169, respectively, at the close of the preceding year.

BALTIMORE, April 7. -- Clinton O. Richardson, 68 years old, former chairman of the board of the closed Park Bank, who has been on trial this week on charges of conspiracy to defraud, was found dying today in his office with a bullet wound in his head.
LONDON, April 7 -- Among the fellow-passengers of Prime Minister MacDonald on the liner Berengaria bound for the United States next week will be Sir Walter Layton, the editor of The Economist.
WASHINGTON, April 7 -- Italian industrial activities have increased since April 1, the Department of Commerce said today in its weekly review of business economic conditions abroad.

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., April 7 -- Playing under frigid atmospheric conditions, the Yankees, with Babe Ruth doing part-time duty, brought their exhibition road tour to a close today by defeating St. Paul, 6 to 3.

Corporations with bonds listed on the New York Stock Exchange have been requested by the Exchange to instruct their trustees or fiscal agents to forward information promptly concerning the issues. This will not relieve the companies of any specific agreements made with the Exchange to give prompt notice of changes in bond collateral, but will merely provide a routine for obtaining items of information about the bonds.

WASHINGTON, April 7 -- The pitching of Alvin Crowder, backed up by the sensational fielding of Fred Schulte and Heine Manush in the outfield, proved too much for the Dodgers today, and they went down to their fourth straight defeat, 4 to 1, at the hands of the Senators.

Unless some home-bred professional golfer other than the nine players already named for the American Ryder Cup team wins the United States open championship in June, the team leaving here on June 14 for England will consist only of the men selected, according, to George R. Jacobus, president of the P.G.A.

WASHINGTON, April 7 -- The administration's banking reform bill, including a bank depositors' insurance fund corporation with resources of about $2,000,000,000, is Virtually ready for introduction in both houses of Congress and will probably be pressed for action within a week or ten days.

Jack Dempsey, former heavyweight champion, speaking at a luncheon held in his honor yesterday noon at the Faculty Club of Columbia University, told the members of the Columbia faculty that if he had to live his life over he would prefer being a boxer to a college professor, because "you can't make a race horse out of a mule."
PHILADELPHIA, April 8 -- Eddie Loughlin pitched Harvard to a 3-1 victory over Pennsylvania on Franklin Field today before a crowd of 1,500 chilled fans.

Only nine freight ships have been built for the American merchant marine in the last ten years, as compared with 913 built for the British fleet, according to the National Council of American Shipbuilders. The United States in this field of marine construction is rated in last place among the five leading maritime nations of this world despite the fact that most of the merchant ships of American registry are freighters.

LONDON, April 8 (AP) -- Arsenal kept ahead of the field in the first division of the English Football League today by conquering Middlesbrough, 4 -- 3, while Huddersfield Town defeated Sheffield Wednesday, the runner-up, 4 -- 0.

THORLIEF COALBITER was the only one of Ragnar Hairybreeks's sons who did not love fighting. His father, the most famous of all Vikings, and his brothers harried far and wide. This is the saga, of Thorlief Coalbiter's sons, of their childhood in Orkney, of their voyages, and of their last heroic voyage to Northumbria, where Ivar the Boneless dwelt.

Of more than ordinary interest was the announcement that Harvard intends to join the Eastern Intercollegiate Baseball League this year. The step marks a radical departure from established policy on the part of Harvard, and behind that change lies the policy of a possible further shift in sentiment at Cambridge.

Some of the esthetic and the inquisitive who made the annual pilgrimage yesterday to the fourth floor of Grand Central Palace, where the seventeenth annual exhibition of the Society of Independent Artists is being held, to search for the latest trends in art, discovered apprehensively what they term less trends than symptoms.

A further sharp rise to 52.4 is shown in THE NEW YORK TIMES weekly business index for the week ended April 1, representing a gain of 2 points over the figure of 50.4 for the previous week. The index now stands slightly above the low point of 52.2 during the two weeks ended Aug. 20 last year.

The Stock Exchange has been informed of a decision of the Supreme Court of the United States in accordance with which certain securities and cash held by a broker for the account of a foreigner cannot be released in the event of the death of the foreign owner until the Federal estate tax has been paid or provision for its payment has been made.
ITHACA, April 8 -- Forty-four fellowships and scholarships in the Graduate School of Cornell University, valued at $18,200, were announced today by Dr. Floyd K. Richtmyer, dean.

Although I am convinced there is renewed interest and confidence in our national game of baseball throughout the country, it would be foolhardy for me to attempt any predictions as to what the forthcoming season will develop, especially for the clubs in the National League.

ANY one interested in children's books of the past must have been conscious of the light these little volumes of long ago throw upon the life and manners of the day when they were written. This book, however, is the first attempt to show systematically and thoroughly how children's books mirror the thought, tastes and fashions of their generation.
MOSCOW, April 7 -- Passports remain the chief topic of the people of Moscow -- far transcending in interest all international affairs.

While presenting a picture of reduced sales volume and missing profits, the reports of representative department store organizations for 1932 contrasted favorably with the annual statements of leading industrial units for last year, according to comment in retail circles during the week.

MINEOLA, L.I., April 8 -- Lynn Hunt captured the second registered shoot of the year over the traps of the Nassau Trapshooting Club today, breaking 96 out of 100 targets. Thirty-four gunners competed.

SERGE KOUSSEVITZKY has made public in Boston his plans for the Brahms festival which the Boston Symphony Orchestra will give in that city from April 26 to 30 in commemoration of the centenary of the composer's birth. Of six concerts, five will be in Symphony Hall, Boston, and one, on April 27, in Sanders Theatre, Harvard University.

THE nation's forests again demonstrate their capacity to help meet a national emergency. In the past they have repeatedly contributed to the solution of important national economic problems. Following the Civil War rapid development of the great inland prairie empire was made possible by the vast supply of cheap timber available for the construction of cities, railroads and farmsteads.

SECURITTES have come to play a major role in our economy. More than half the wealth in the United States is represented by securities -- stocks, bonds, warrants, debentures, notes, mortgages -- a vast array of pieces of paper which indicate that their holders have a prospect of receiving money in the future based on some sort of contractual agreement.

LONDON. NOEL COWARD'S "Cavalcade" and J.B. Priestley's "The Good Companions" are running neck and neck for premier honors in London just now. Winfield Sheehan, who bought the film rights of the former for the Fox organization, has deserved well both of his own country and of this.

IT would be difficult not to agree with Stephen Graham that "it is strange that Ivan the Terrible has, up to now, escaped the attention of the English biographer." History, indeed, has on its records few figures as picturesque, tragical, psychologically complicated and luring as this man "one of the greatest and yet cruelest of the Czars of Russia."

BERLIN, April 8 -- Norman H. Davis arrived today in Berlin in his new role of diplomatic explorer of important international questions in which the United States is interested and has put in a busy twelve hours here with every indication of regarding them as well spent.

THE Automobile Club of New York, which for years has advocated the placing of markers in the metropolitan area to guide motorists through the maze of Manhattan streets to through routes surrounding the city, is conducting a survey to determine where signs are most needed.

To the Editor of The New York Times: THE TIMES editorial "The Crisis in Science" at a single cast presents two propositions of basic importance. First, it points out that the universe is a place of "overwhelming" order and, second, it shows that the thoughts of those who seek to interpret the laws of that order are, because of multiplicity and complication of viewpoint, in a condition bordering on chaos.
WASHINGTON, April 8 (AP) -- First recruits in the Roosevelt reforestation-employment program assembled today in army camps throughout the East.

CAN a snail learn? Does it profit by experience? Can it be made to change its ways? Is it adaptable? Or does it work by instinct alone? According to the poet, on a Spring morning the snail is to be found on the top twig of the thornbush.

PARIS, March 30 -- The Champs Elysees, once reserved exclusively for fashionable residences, has become the busiest street in Paris.
