Not only is the wide avenue trav- ersed by more motor vehicles than any other of the Parisian thorough fares, but pedestrian traffic on a fine day is more dense than on the downtown boulevards or in the Place de l'Opera.

DODGE CITY, Kan., April 6 -- Legalized beer will start a rough-and-tumble wet and dry fight in Kansas with the odds in favor of the advocates of prohibition. In spite of the claims of wets, there has been no marked lapse of the Kansas stand on prohibition.

To the Music Editor: Among current developments in the musical life of this city there is one of general interest, I think, that has hardly received the attention it deserves. I refer to the generous facilities afforded by Mrs. Newton Monk of 155 West Twelfth Street for the rental of phonograph records belonging to her remarkable collection.

The Fordham University football team concluded its Spring practice yesterday, and the chief impression left was that probably no similar period of training at the institution in recent years has been marked with such significance.

IT is Mr. Aron's purpose in this book to discover the essentials of successful living and human happiness and to show how simple and easy would be the process of realizing them if mankind would honestly and earnestly make the attempt.

BEFORE the war there was a wild animal paradise in Russia which had been created on his Ukrainian estate, Ascania Nova, by F.E. Falz-Fein. Here mammals and birds from all parts of Europe, Asia, Africa and Australia, roamed, burrowed and flew about in perfect liberty.

THE American novel usually falls into one of the two broad categories. Either it is a "sociological" novel, such as Sinclair Lewis writes, or it is an "art" novel, such as Kay Boyle writes. The sociological novel came out of the period of the quest for social justice which died, temporarily, with the World War.

HERE is a swift-moving, intelligent and seasoned glimpse of Germany's conflict and confusion immediately following the memorable post-war events at Versailles. From January, 1919, until January, 1926, the author, a British officer, resided in Berlin's famous Adlon Hotel as a member of the Interallied Commission of Control, charged with disarming Germany and carrying out various military terms of the Versailles Treaty.

DRAWINGS by Adolf Dehn make up a very attractive show at the Macbeth Galleries. Pairs of portraits of husband and wife, on glass, wood, canvas, ivory, , dating through the last 150 years, are being shown at the bookshop of Harry Stone, 24 East Fifty-eighth Street.
LONDON, March 31 -- The disaster that has overtaken democracy in Germany should have the effect of contributing to a Liberal revival in Great Britain.

THE contemporary style of decorative art is now old enough to excite interest in its beginnings. Several books on its history have recently been published and at the Museum of Modern Art, 11 West Fifty-third Street, a retrospective exhibition, the first of its kind, has just been opened.

CHICAGO, April 8 -- A uniform set of regulations, providing for a continuation of the present limitations on life insurance policy loans and cash surrender payments, was unanimously adopted here today by the National Association of Life Insurance Commissioners, meeting in executive session at the Palmer House.

IT is a long time since The Rosenbach Company has issued a list of its literary treasures accompanied by prices. To most collectors this famous institution has always been regarded with a little awe, as being something too immaculate and refined to descend to the vulgar level of mentioning money.

BOSTON, April 6 -- Since the first week in January, New England has had four Democratic Governors. The Governor of Connecticut, Wilbur L. Cross, and the Governor of Massachusetts, Joseph B. Ely, are now well known to the nation, having entered on their second terms.

CHARACTERS who have lived and tasted of fame for many a year between the covers on books are now made to wins their way and act their roles on the radio. They remain as unseen characters, phantom forms that speak from the skies to capture the imagination of an invisible audience.

With its membership ratio completely altered, the Joint Rules Committee will continue to legislate for basketball for another year at least, it was announced yesterday by L.W. St. John of Ohio State, the chairman.

THE Musicians Symphony Orchestra will present a special concert tomorrow evening at the Metropolitan Opera House, with Paderewski appearing in the double role of soloist and composer. This concert, conducted by Ernest Schelling, is not one of the regular subscription series.
BARCELONA, April 7 -- The Police Department of Barcelona has become a storm centre because of the imminent transfer of police powers from the central government to the autonomous Catalan Generalidad.

Sportsmen who follow with keen delight the competitions of pointers and setters in the field will return to New Jersey covers this week for the annual Spring trials of the Jockey Hollow Field Trial Club on its grounds at Basking Ridge, some seven miles beyond Morristown and only about twenty-five miles by motor from New York.

WHEN the story or our times is written by some objective critic of the future he will undoubtedly devote a chapter to the extraordinary misapplication of what now passes for science in anthropology and ethnology in explaining the official persecutions organized by the Nazis.

The moderator for the railroads to be provided by pending national legislation should save the railroads $100,000,000 annually through elimination of duplicated facilities and services, according to John F. Harris, a director of the Southern Pacific Company and of the New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad.

One of the most firmly established facts about hockey, which has pained an unusually strong hold on the New York sports public, is that practically all of the players in both divisions of the National Hockey League are Canadians.

Gerald Campbell, British Consul General, and Robert R. Appleby, president of the British Chamber of Commerce in the United States, will be among the speakers at the craftsmanship award on the British Empire Building, to be held on Tuesday morning under the auspices of the New York Building Congress.

WINSTON-SALEM, N.C., April 6 -- The Moravians in Salem and the Southern Moravian province, which includes this entire county, are preparing for the sunrise service on Easter Sunday which attracts approximately 50,000 persons to this city each year.

BERLIN, April 8 -- The political upheaval in Germany has brought to a complete standstill the business of American, moving-picture concerns in this country both as to production and distribution, and the same is true of the entire German movie industry.

Laborers are being given preference over internationally famous artists in relief activities, to the ultimate harm of industry as well as art, Walter Russell, painter and sculptor and president of the Society of Arts and Sciences, said yesterday in an interview at the organization's headquarters at the Hotel Pierre.

PARIS MOST recent of the artistic movements of Paris is "Les Artistes Musicalistes," launched at the Renaissance Gallery; it furnishes its visitors with a chic catalogue bound in tin-foil; M. Harriot, president d'honneur of the society, was present at the vernissage.

PARIS, April 8 -- Acceptance by former Premier Edouard Herriot of the mission to represent the French Government at the Washington conversations of world economies was regarded in Paris today as virtually certain, although no definite reply to the invitation from Premier Daladier will be given until M. Herriot returns from Lyon Tuesday.

The Brooklyn Museum has placed on exhibition a collection of tribal relics, ornaments, utensils and household articles which Desmond Holdridge brought back from the lesser-known regions of the Amazon River in South America. Several months ago Mr. Holdridge led a museum expedition to Brazil, where he unearthed many relics dating from a pre-Columbian period.

In a renewed drive to wipe out race track gambling in the White Light district, the police raided two cigar stores and a so-called club in the midtown area late yesterday afternoon, arresting ninety-one persons, six of whom were charged with keeping and maintaining places for gambling purposes.

Harry A. Ahern, widely known newspaper advertising executive, who was advertising manager of The New York Evening Post from 1912 to 1918, died on Friday night of heart disease in his apartment in the Hotel Pierrepont, 55 Pierrepont Street, Brooklyn, at the age of 53.

The first formal vote for ratification of the Twenty-first Amendment, repealing the Eighteenth, will be cast tomorrow. The scene will be Lansing, where the constitutional convention elected last week in Michigan will meet with a repealist majority of 99 to 1. The second vote will be cast on April 25 in Wisconsin, which instructed all fifteen of the delegates to its convention to favor the new amendment.

Gar Wood has decided to await the outcome of the trials of Miss Britain III, Hubert Scott-Paine's Harmsworth Trophy challenger, before making any plans for defense of the prize. The international competition is not scheduled until Labor Day, at Detroit.

A GAIN the Whitney Museum of American Art has demonstrated its sensitive awareness of the sort of service a museum may advantageously perform by inviting into its galleries a restrospective exhibition of work by Guggenheim fellows.

Sales to consumers of cars of the General Motors Corporation last month totaled 47,436, against 42,280 in February and 48,717 in March, 1932, it was announced yesterday. The gain from February's business was made in spite of the bank holiday early last month.

Although other commodity markets were somewhat reactionary yesterday under week-end profit-taking following sharp advances, prices on the Cotton Exchange steadied and ended unchanged to 3 points net higher on the day.

OWENSBORO, Ky., April 8 (AP) -- Clifton Wood Bransford, former president of the Owensboro Banking Company and widely known in the flour milling industry throughout the South, died today at his home here. He was 75 years old and served as president of the American Millers Association in 1919-20.

BALTIMORE, April 8 -- Maryland's cross-country racing season opened today on the Worthington Valley estate of J.W.Y. Martin with the running of the Junior Cross-Country Steeplechase and the Neophyte Handicap.
WARSAW, April 8 -- The fourth list of Polish Jews resident in Germany who have been victims of Nazi persecutions has been submitted by the Polish Envoy to the German Foreign Office.

PURCHASE, N.Y., April 8 -- Tuckahoe Eve, a 6-year-old white and liver setter owned by Jack Disbrow of Scarsdale, today triumphed in the close-cover stake which featured the second day of the annual three-day meet of the Southern New York Field Trial Club.
WASHINGTON, April 8 -- Unofficlal estimates at the Treasury today indicated that the internal revenue from beer was likely to exceed expectations.

Improvement in both credit and collection conditions is noted for the first three months of this year in the regular quarterly survey completed yesterday by the foreign credit interchange bureau of the National Association of Credit Men. The marked downward trend in credit conditions, noted in the last quarter of 1932, has been checked, the report continues, and improvements are now evident in thirteen countries.
COPENHAGEN, Denmark, April 8 -- Since the election victory of the Nazis in Germany an extremely strong campaign has been conducted on both sides of the Danish-German border at Slesvig.

IT must be remembered that after 1890 the popularity of Shakespeare and the old comedies declined and the modern drama began to emerge. So the question naturally arises: How was this modern drama greeted by the critics?

LONDON, March 17 ALLAN MONKHOUSE is among the most practiced and experienced of English dramatists, but I am not aware that any play of his has enjoyed a popular success commensurate with his accomplishment.

PHILADELPHIA, April 8 (AP) -- The Phillies defeated the Athletics, 3 to 0, today to even the count at two-all in the games for the city baseball title. The contest was the last scheduled in the series.

The Eastern Class D indoor polo title was won by the Brooklyn Riding and Driving Club at Squadron C Armory last night, the 110th Field Artillery of Baltimore falling before a whirlwind attack, 6 to 2. The game was played on the flat and proved far faster than the usual games in this bracket.

LONDON THE woman who, as some assert, "made" George Bernard Shaw will be with him when he arrives in New York on the final lap of his round-the-world cruise. That woman is G. B.S.'s wife and constant companion for the last thirty years -- Charlotte Frances Shaw.

SIOUX FALLS, S.D., April 8 (AP) -- The Associated Press was absolved of charges of monopoly, discrimination and unfair competition in findings of fact and conclusions of law filed in Federal District Court today as a result of its suit to prevent a local radio station from using its news dispatches without authorization.

JACOPONE (or Jacomo) daTodi, the brilliant Italian lawyer who, in the latter part of the thirteenth century, joined the Franciscan Order and became celebrated for his asceticism and his religious verse, was the subject of innumerable legends crystallized, 150 years afterward, in the "Vita" which, for long, was believed to be strictly true but which later scholarship has shown to be largely apocryphal.

Explaining some of the features of the reduced railroad fares on the Long Island Railroad, going into effect on May 1, George Le Boutillier, vice president of the road, said that the management hopes to accomplish two important things. The first is that, in recognition of the economic situation, the company is desirous of assisting in lightening the financial burdens of patrons, especially part-time workers.

LOS ANGELES, April 7 ATTENDED by almost as many ermine coats and autograph hunters as the gala premiere of a movie, "Dinner at Eight," the outstanding event of the local theatrical season, revealed itself to an eager audience Monday night at the Belasco under the careful aegis of the Messrs. Belasco and Curran.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, April 6 -- Milk control legislation, socialistic in character, has been introduced in the Ohio General Assembly and may be enacted when the Legislature reconvenes in May.

WASHINGTON A STUDENT of economics, Cordell Hull comes to the office of Secretary of State at a time when, in his own words, "the world is in a state of bitter economic war" and when negotiations in the interests of world peace must, for some time to come, be based on economic questions.

Faulty distribution of expenses by departments is not a reason for the loss of volume by department stores to the chains of specialty shops, Sidney R. Baer, vice president and treasurer of Stix, Baer Fuller Company, writes in a communication to the business news editor of THE TIMES, commenting on an article which appeared on this page last Sunday.

EDWARD J. DENT'S biography of Ferruccio Busoni* is an extremely interesting document. Perhaps it is more significant as a revelation of the complexities of a great mind but a thwarted man than it is important to the history of music.

With security markets registering the confidence which recent developments in domestic business and finance have inspired, the broader perspective began yesterday to take in the prospect of international cooperation toward solution of the serious economic problems with which the forthcoming conferences will be concerned.

THIS admirably realistic, simple and just presentment and discussion of the war debts owed to the United States by our associates of the World War ought to be most helpful for American readers who want to understand this thorny question.
CHICAGO, April 8 (AP) -- Sam Atcheson of Memphis, Tenn., is the new national amateur handball singles champion.

WASHINGTON, April 8 -- John D. Rockefeller Jr. today petitioned the Board of Tax Appeals to reverse a ruling by the Internal Revenue Bureau that his income-tax return for 1930 shows a deficiency of $828,708.88. He contended that the government erred in revising income-tax regulations subsequent to the filing of his return and thereby increased his liability.

Sergei Koussevitzky and the Boston Symphony Orchestra gave their final New York concert of the season yesterday afternoon in Carnegie Hall. The Albert Roussel suite in F major opened this concert. It is a vigorous and clean-cut piece of writing.

PEIPING, April 8 (AP) -- Unconfirmed Rengo (Japanese) News Agency reports said today that Manchukuoan troops, which had been advancing southward from the Great Wall of China, occupied today the important Chinese seaport of Chinwangtao, ten miles south-west of Shanhaikwan, in Hopei Province.

THE prosperity that lies "around the corner" in this optimistic novel of middle-class America passing through the depression is not of the one-time booming order. It is what awaits a return to conscience and the practice of the old sound American virtues.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., April 8 -- A plan seeking to solve the housing problems of two-thirds of the population of the United States is taking form at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology.

PITTSBURGH, April 6 -- By virtue of his office as President of the City Council, John S. Herron automatically became Acting Mayor of Pittsburgh March 31 on the ousting of Mayor Charles H. Kline, convicted of malfeasance in office in connection with irregularities in the purchase of municipal supplies.

THE reader who is not drawn to this book by its title is probably so impervious to any appeal which poetry may make that to read anything about Miss Drew's little work would be merely to waste time. However, "Discovering Poetry!" Instantly comes to mind Keats's immortal.

BETHLEHEM, Pa., April 8 -- With the reporting of committees to a plenary session on the Manchurian problem, world unemployment and an arms-control treaty, the Model League of Nations Assembly of the Middle Atlantic colleges adjourned today at Lehigh University to meet next year at Bucknell.

WASHINGTON, April 8 -- The broad lines of forthcoming administration relief legislative measures were discussed today by Senator Wagner as he left the White House after a conference with President Roosevelt. He indicated that the Roosevelt proposals on home mortgage relief, public works, liberalization of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation activities and the Wagner Federal employment exchange plan, vetoed by President Hoover, will be presented to Congress soon.

C. HENRY GORDON, who plays a gangster in "Gabriel Over the "White House" at the Capitol, was engaged in Secret Service work for the government during the World War. His ability as a linguist helped him greatly in this work.

WITH beer coming back to us, an outlaw restored to civil rights, curiosity is dispersed as to the effect of the return to beer and the problem of dealing with beer. It may be useful therefore to see what went on when beer was a familiar creature.

MEN have been murdered -- quite a good many of them. Though always startling, murder is far from unusual, either in fact or in fiction. But not many men find themselves in the curious, not to say fantastic, position of being busily engaged in hunting their own murderers.
LONDON, April 8 -- The German Government has banned The Manchester Guardian from Germany until further notice.

WASHINGTON, April 8 -- "We must use our credit to destroy unemployment, or unemployment will surely destroy our credit," Edward A. Filene, Boston merchant and president of the Credit National Extension Bureau, declared tonight in a radio address.

PROFESSOR LYMAN of Union Theological Seminary has written a great book. It is important because, like other books now appearing, it is typical of a certain trend of thought. In Dr. Lyman we see the working of the modernist mind in its best and its latest mood.

Increased building activity in Queens, particularly in the private residential field, is forecast by the Queensboro Chamber of Commerce as the result of the extension of the county's highway system, including feeder roads, and the new municipal subway, nearing completion.

Young women are aiding in arrangements for the Summer fashion show and entertainment which will be held on the afternoon of April 18 at the Plaza. They are Miss Florence Weicker, Mrs. Goodhue Livingston Jr., Miss Virginia Cowles, Miss Adele S. Kelley, Mrs. Julian Street Jr. and Miss Mary Haskell.

Improvement in realty conditions has become noticeable in Brooklyn during the past two weeks and there are indications that a gradual grain will be made in the amount of leasing and selling during the Spring and Summer, according to George S. Horton, president of the Brooklyn Real Estate Board.

The Castello brothers, Hugo and James, sons of J. Martinez Castello, New York University's fencing coach, shared the spotlight as George Washington High School regained the city P.S.A.L. fencing team title by defeating the James Madison High foilsmen, 5 to 3, at Washington Irving High School yesterday.
Their muscles exercised and kneaded to a proper point of flexibility, the highly trained athletes of the sixteen major league ball clubs are about to launch another championship campaign.

FOUR new home designs, two of Colonial type and two of the English cottage type, have been prepared for Sears, Roebuck Co. They all have the same basic floor plan of four rooms and bath and will be erected, announces E.P. Dibbs, the New York general manager, at a price not exceeding $2,500 anywhere east of the Mississippi River and north of the Ohio River.
SAINT-GERMAIN-EN-LAYE, April 1 -- This picturesque suburb of Paris, once the habitation of kings, will celebrate the centenary of "pommes soufflees" in 1937, it is announced.

Although no definite understanding has been entered into relative to a complete shut-down of the remaining producing copper mines in this country, the consensus in the trade is that in the next few days one or two of the most important units will cease operations and that the others will fall into line rapidly, since ail are operating at a loss.

EIGHT hitherto unpublished speeches by former President Hoover are included in a new volume entitled "Hoover After Dinner," edited by Mr. Hoover's secretary, Theodore G. Joslin, and scheduled for publication this month by Charles Scribner's Sons.

BERLIN, April 8 -- The principle that Germany shall be governed and administered only by Aryans, and the definition that any person having one Jewish grandparent is a Jew, were formally established in German law today.

MANY thousands of Americans have seen Clyde Beatty in action. That remarkable performance of his, in which he steps into a thirty-two-foot arena with as many as forty lions and tigers and puts them through their paces, is one which commands and deserves all the superlatives which circus ballyhoo can muster.

The body of Lieut. Col. Alfred F. Masury, who was a guest aboard the dirigible Akron when it was wrecked at sea last Tuesday, was brought to Brooklyn Navy Yard at 4:30 P.M. yesterday by the Coast Guard cutter Galatea. After having been sighted by the tanker John D. Archbold in the forenoon, the body was picked up by the Galatea seventeen miles off Barnegat Light.

CLEVELAND, April 8 (AP) -- The daring hold-up of the Monterey Hotel in Asbury Park, N.J., a year and a half ago was definitely linked by police today with the murder of 26-year-old Chester Davies in Cleveland last night.

BERLIN, Md., April 8 -- The Rev. Dr. Littleton P. Bowen, Presbyterian minister, lawyer and historian, died here today of ailments incident to advanced age. He would have been 100 years old on June 5. He is said to have been the oldest surviving former student of Princeton Theological Seminary.

BERLIN, April 8 -- The fight for power between the National Socialists and the Nationalists, which has been going on behind the formidable facade of the Cabinet of "national revolution," is ending in complete victory for the Nazis.

WITH the acquisition of the Columbia Interests by Grigsby-Grunow, it was only to be expected that all manner of unfounded and distressing tales would be tossed into circulation. Many of these have reached us through the mail from interested collectors who seek confirmation of the worst or wish to register a protest against what they understood to involve the discon- tinuance of one of the most impor- tant sources of records in this country.

FROM its graceful dedication to the closing pages of festivity at a Mayoral dinner in an English village where, as the au-. thor ingenuously remarked, "This account * * * was left unfinished because we enjoyed ourselves too much at Holkham to have time for writing," la Rochefoucauld's lit- tle book of memoirs stands as a monument to the triumph of style over matter.

DWIGHT LISTER, after Sand-burst and the war, has given up several years to traveling with his invalid mother, and at her death finds himself without money or training and faced with the ne- cessity of earning his own living. Old General Lister, his uncle, thereupon introduces him to Claudette Davini, proprietor of a large department store, which she has inherited from her uncle, and which is a London institution.
CHICAGO, April 8 (AP) -- Dedicated to removal of any communistic influences from schools and churches, completion of the Organization of the Paul Reveres was announced today.

THE fear that a huge volume of Soviet wheat may be dumped on an already surfeited world wheat market and further demoralize prices and markets has haunted grain dealers for half a decade. Some years ago the Amtorg Trading Corporation, either as a flier in the market or to cover a sale for future delivery, sold five million bushels short.

WASHINGTON, April 8 -- The choice of an Ambassador to Germany is being deferred by President Roosevelt. It is generally understood, though not officially admitted, that he desires to see how the Hitler regime functions for a while longer before sending a new envoy.
Within a few days the Women's Swimming Association team that will compete in the national indoor championships at the Buffalo Athletic Club on April 19 to 22 will be selected.

BOSTON, April 7 IN Boston, as elsewhere, the stage world is oftener looking forward to next season than dwelling upon the end of the present theatre year. It is openly said, for example, that the American Theatre Society has had enough and to spare of subscription series in a dozen cities with no plays to fill them:

The French proverb "Les femmes "peuvent tout, parcequ'elles gouver"nent les personnes qui gouvernent "tout" suggests that there is more reason for educating women than men, since in the end men are governed by women. The greatest specific progress made in higher education during the last half century has been in the education of women.

SANDWICHED in between advertisements for run-away slaves and West Indian rum, there appeared in ye olde New York Gazette of Jan. 7, 1750, at announcement that, "by his Excellency's permission," there would be given in "The Theatre in Nassau Street" a performance of "The Beggar's Opera," written by one John Gay of London and presented by the Murray and Kean Company of actors lately arrived from England by way of the West Indies and Philadelphia.

An adverse decision of the United States Supreme Court some years ago discouraged advocates of minimum wage legislation in this country. Massachusetts made shift with an "advisory" law, but the movement lost momentum when the court spoke. Recently the depression caused a renewal of agitation for minimum standards of some kind which would prevent wages, at least in the case of women and minors, from spiraling down to zero.

THE return of beer is already having its effect on pretzel baking. One plant in St. Joseph, Mo., is reported to have added sixty-eight employes and to be turning out 4,000,000 pretzels daily. In near-by Pennsylvania, where the largest pretzel bakeries in the world are located, the factories have been keyed up to high speed since early in March.

FRANKLY admitting that he is "in no sense an economist," Lee Sherman Chadwick approaches the problem of unemployment and its causative connection with the depression from the viewpoint of a business man who has had long experience, has observed

WASHINGTON, April 8 -- Invitations were extended by the State Department today on behalf of President Roosevelt to Mexico and Canada to send personal representatives here for discussions preliminary to the World Economic Conference, making eleven nations so invited and completing the list of those with whom it is desired to enter into conversations through their government heads or other high representatives.

The Eastern turf season, later by approximately two weeks than in recent years, will get under way on Saturday at Havre de Grace, the course of the Harford Agricultural and Breeders' Association in Maryland. It is a new departure for the Maryland racing to begin so late, and also for Havre de Grace to open the season.

THE publication of what continues to be the most important English list of books on typography was completed in 1886. "A Bibliography of Printing" occupied Messrs. Bigmore and Wyman for ten years, and their three volumes were issued to 250 subscribers, in 1880, 1884 and 1886 respectively.

SOME of the best big-game hunting in the world is to be found in Indo-China. Its jungles, inaccessible except to well-organized and adequately equipped expeditions, swarm with an abundant and varied fauna, including the elephant, rhinoceros, buffalo, wild boar, tiger, leopard, panther and bear.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I have an uncle who suffered a severe breakdown about three and a half years ago. Some of us were afraid he would die, but he managed to survive the shock and for a while showed signs of recovery.

A CALL to every society that performs music, from the symphony orchestra to the smallest local club, has been launched by the League of Composers, exhorting these organizations to commission works by American composers for next year.

Male and female emotional stability were tested and contrasted yesterday at Hartford House Y.M. C.A., 109 West Fifty-fourth Street, and it was concluded that women in business or in the professions bring to their jobs a slightly higher emotional drive or concentration than men and fail to touch the extremes of neurotic or "obsessional" tendencies displayed by men.

Conditions for the Riverside Yacht Club's annual 50-mile race from Riverside, Conn., to and around Stratford Shoal, off Bridgeport, and return, have been announced. The event will be another overnight affair, the start being scheduled for 10:30 P.M. on July 15.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The latest Federal Census of Religious Bodies reports 213 denominations, of which 155 are grouped in twenty-three families and fifty-eight are listed as separate denominations. For example, among the "families" are reported 18 kinds of Baptists, 17 brands of Mennonites, 19 groups of Methodists and 9 divisions of Presbyterians.

Postmaster General James A. Farley, who is chairman of the Democratic State Committee as well as of the Democratic National Committee, tried yesterday to get in touch with W. Kingsland Macy, Republican State chairman, in an attempt to get a "gentlemen's agreement" for the selection of a repeal slate of convention delegates to be voted upon at the special election on May 23.

TODAY the people of the United States are examining, and examining critically, the business and political practices of the '20s, submitting them to spectrum analysis, and are finding weaknesses in our standards, weaknesses in business organization and weakness in our ethical concepts.

OSCAR JELLINEK'S rugged, colorful talent is inspired directly by his earth-loving Moravian peasants. He sees them as a part of the land and measures their worth by their labor, as they themselves value the year by its fruitfulness.

Aided by a 22-second handicap, Miss Elsie Ferril of the Dragon Club turned in a good performance in winning the 200-yard free style race in the last of the indoor handicap swimming meets held under the Women's Swimming Association's auspices at the W.S.A. Clubhouse last night.

Antonio Scotti, Italian baritone of the Metropolitan Opera for thirty-two years, who recently retired, sailed yesterday for his native land in the Italian liner Conte di Savoia. A large number of friends were at the pier to see him off after filling his cabin with flowers.

In his latest volume of essays, "All I Survey," Mr. GILBERT CHESTERTON, that stout medieval monarch, speaks disparagingly of the readers of modernist poets as a "new race of pedants." They are but a clique of persons "who "understand something and do not "wish it to be understood; do not wish "it to be understandable."
VIENNA, April 7 -- The interplay of many forces, national and international, has brought the Austrian situation to what appears to be a state of relative calm.

DR. LILLIEN J. MARTIN is herself high and glowing proof that there should be no cobwebs to be swept, that almost every one could and should live fully and fruitfully and happily until death, even death by old age, intervenes.

TOKYO, March 25 -- Japan's devaluation boom shows no signs of flagging; orders are pouring in and goods pouring out. Foreign trade in January and February was 50 per cent better than in the corresponding period of last year, exports rising fully 50 per cent and imports 45 per cent.
The army had its day yesterday, and to the roll of drums and the wail of fifes that day was ushered into history.

SOME persons hold that Spring begins with the vernal equinox. Some say "Spring is here!" when the first robin appears. To others the best harbingers of Spring are the first violets. But 20,000,000 Americans -- who can't be wrong -- know that Spring and circus bills are synchronized.
DARJEELING, India, March 5 (By Mail) -- It has been well said that the first three rules of Himalayan mountaineering are "reconnoitre, reconnoitre and, again, reconnoitre."

DECATUR, Ala., April 8 -- Warned by Judge James E. Horton to banish bigotry and prejudice from their minds, the members of a Morgan County jury tonight held in their hands the power of life and death over Haywood Patterson, a Negro accused of a crime which has stirred fires long thought dead.

ALBANY, April 8 -- The Legislature passed two measures today designed to help holders of guaranteed mortgage certificates. One, proposed by Governor Lehman last week, sets up machinery for the creation of corporations, under the supervision of the State Superintendent of Insurance, which may bring about, without any great cost to certificate holders, the consolidation of their interests.

LONDON, March 18, 1933 THERE have been countless concerts of chamber music in the last few weeks. The Lener Quartet gave six at the Queen's Hall; the Busch Quartet gave seven at the Wigmore Hall in conjunction with the pianist Rudolf Serkin.
A.L. Burns and Tracy H. Lewis tied for the High Scratch Cup at the Travers Island traps of the New York A.C. yesterday. Each finished the regular shoot with a card of 97 out of 100 targets.

AT the Twentieth International Flower Show, which was recently held in New York, Westinghouse engineers showed what they have been doing in forcing plants electrically. With their electrical method cabbages are ready for transplanting in twenty-one days.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The President's securities bill has been criticized in THE TIMES by Eustace Seligman. His criticisms raise such fundamental issues and reflect such a typically conservative philosophy as to challenge the attention of those interested in a better ordered financial structure.

The series of benefits being presented by the Women's Division of the architects' emergency committee for the relief of unemployed and destitute architects and draftsmen will have a notable addition with the opening this afternoon of an exhibition of recent sculpture by Paul Manship.

ST. LOUIS, April 8 (AP) -- The Browns outhit the Cardinals today and won the first game of their two-game city series, 7 to 3. The Browns reached Carleton and Walker for a total of twelve hits, six of which were for two bases. A crowd of 4,500 saw the contest.

More than 10,000 of the faithful welcomed the Dodgers home at Ebbets Field yesterday and saw them lose the opening battle with the Yankees, 5 to 3, despite well-nigh perfect pitching performances by Watson Clark and Joe Shaute.

ALBANY, April 8 -- The Democratic-controlled Senate gave the death blow tonight to the Desmond-Moffat bill to permit the election of charter-revision commissions, earnestly sought by advocates of charter reform in New York City.

The Harvard Glee Club, Dr. Archibald Davison conductor, now celebrating its seventy-fifth anniversary year, gave its annual New York concert last night in the Town Hall. The concert was admirably representative of the standards of glee club programs and performances which Dr. Davison has established.

THE theme of "In God's Land" is not new and not difficult: Nexo has chosen to contrast the old wholesome ways of Danish farmers with the modern spirit of unrest, of trying to make money fast, to climb up in the world, to be modern and clever and businesslike.

MR. JOHNSON'S novel covers a period of thirty years. When the story opens, to 1902, Rogersville was a smail, sleepy North Carolina town. It consisted of two unpaved streets, a tiny group of shops and offices and a green, tree-shaded court house square.

Late Heroic Age. To read of the death of General CUSTER'S widow is to be once more reminded how very near this country stands to its epic past. Less than sixty years ago the Indian tribes of the Far West were still a problem, if not exactly a menace.

MANY an industrial magnate may hang his head in shame over a piece of educational news emanating from Greenwich Village. The Little Red Schoolhouse, which set out in the gray days of last September to perform a supposedly impossible financial feat, is performing it.

Two New Utrecht High School teams are among the seven city P.S.A.L. senior high school Spring sports squads which will defend titles during the remaining twelve weeks of the 1932-33 school year. Teams of Abraham Lincoln High, Textile, Manual Training, Curtis and Jamaica will also endeavor to prolong championship reigns in some of the various competitions that will hold the attention of New York City's public high school sports fans during the next three months.

The vote favoring secession of Western Australia from the Commonwealth crystallizes the recent sentiment for separatism throughout the State, the largest in Australia, with an undeveloped area about the size of Western Europe and a population of a half a million people.
The alarming increase in the number of real estate foreclosures during the past few weeks has moved the realty interests at the city to find some method of checking them.

Combing the deliveries of two pitchers for nine hits, four of them doubles, City College opened its home varsity baseball season at the Lewisohn Stadium yesterday by beating Panzer College, 10 -- 5. The game was limited by mutual agreement to eight innings.

The Ringling Brothers-Barnum Bailey Circus, which is as much an American institution as Congress and generally can be depended upon to afford more amusement, began its fiftieth season here yesterday with a matinee performance before 8,000 persona in Madison Square Garden.

PEEKSKILL, N.Y., April 8 -- Following the action taken by Cornelius A. Pugsley and Chester D. Pugsley, president and vice president, respectively, of the Westchester County National Bank and Trust Company, sixteen other stockholders of that institution, closed since March 3, have voluntarily surrendered their common stock for the benefit of depositors, it was announced today by the depositors' committee.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., April 8 (AP) -- Police Chief Byram said today the killing of Chester Davies in Cleveland might result in the apprehension of several members of the gang which held up the Monterey Hotel here in 1931.

OAKLAND, Cal., April 8 -- Washington's Huskies swept to three thrilling victories over the California Bears on the wind-tossed Oakland Estuary today in the annual renewal of the crew regatta established thirty years ago.

BERLIN, April 8 -- The Boerse was extremely quiet today, with slowly declining stock prices, owing apparently to the week-end and the approaching Easter holiday, which caused realizations. The new law on tax exemption of newly bought automobiles stimulated Daimler, but the movement failed to spread to other stocks.

ATHENS, March 19 -- King Fuad of Egypt has conceived an arrangement with European railroads which will make it possible for travelers to go from Paris to Cairo in the same train without a change, according to an interview with him by the representative of Elephtheron Vima, the big Athenian daily newspaper.

IT is not easy to predict the course or result of social drifts. There are certain well-established facts, however, upon which such prophecies may be safely based. It is almost sure to happen that, after a great successful effort has been made for some moral reform, a reaction sets in which at times seems to threaten the achievement in toto.

DETROIT -- Twelve days in which to run over certain cities of the Middle South and the Middle West and to end up finally in Chicago and Detroit is obviously not much time. But if these dozen days be fully employed in seeing and listening one may gather certain impressions to which a foreign observer is possibly more sensitive than an American.

EVERY one knows that peppers and tomatoes go well together in a salad, but it may be news that they agree, too, when one is grafted on the other. The latter fact has recently been demonstrated by experts of the Brooklyn Botanic Garden.
The massive John R. Townsend Cup, symbolic of the intercollegiate indoor polo championship, is on its way to the Harvard trophy room for the second time since it has been at stake.

BUENOS AIRES, April 7 -- The details, made public here and in Rio de Janeiro and Santiago, Chile, yesterday of the Chaco peace plan drafted at Mendoza, Argentina, by the Argentine and Chilean Foreign Ministers, reveal an elaborate formula for ending the war and settling the dispute between Bolivia and Paraguay.

CHICAGO, April 8 -- Not in several years have so many American League club presidents and managers been so insistent that they have first division clubs -- teams that will be contenders for the pennant.

The relationship between civic reform and improved educational standards was stressed yesterday by speakers who addressed the members of the Teachers Union Auxiliary at a luncheon at 36 West Forty-eighth Street.

A telegram asking the removal from office of Wade Wright, Circuit Solicitor of Morgan County, Ala., was sent to the Governor of Alabama yesterday by five New York lawyers. Mr. Wright, in an address to the jury at the trial of Haywood Patterson at Decatur Friday, characterized the defense as linked "with Jew money from New York."

BEHIND the curtain of broadcasting, with its jazz bands and opera, politics and sermons, there are unscheduled dramas and tragedies. The broadcast listener, within his restricted confines from 200 to 550 meters as wave lengths are measured, may lose sight of the fact that entertainment is not all that flows in the useful arteries of radio.

ASHEVILLE, N.C. -- The Asheville Kennel Club Dog Show, to be held here on Friday and Saturday, and the Tryon Horse Show, to be held at Tryon on Thursday, will be two of the major events to be held in this section during the Spring season.

THE new George Arliss picture, "Voltaire," which was completed last week at the Warner studios in California, will be presented simultaneously in New York, London and Paris, the date to be announced shortly. Assisting Mr. Arliss in this historical re-creation of the life of the great Frenchman will be Doris Kenyon, Margaret Lindsay, Theodore Newton and Reginald Owen.

WARRENTON, Va. -- Plans are now being made for the eleventh annual race meeting of the Virginia Gold Cup Association, which will be held on May 6. This race has steadily grown in interest and popularity and is now recognized as one of the major sporting events of the country.

With $200,000 urgently needed from New York City as the immediate requirement for relief work among Jewish populations of Central and Eastern Europe. Dudley D. Sicher, city chairman of the appeal of the American-Jewish Joint Distribution Committee, made a special plea yesterday for the support of this work.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., April 8 -- A slate of officers offered by the nominating committee of the Westchester County Teachers Association at the annual convention here today was voted down on the floor and a new slate elected, by a vote of about 2 to 1.

Passage of the Black thirty-hour work-week bill by the Senate during the week brought out a variety of opinions as to the merit of the legislation from business men and trade association executives here. In many quarters it had been considered so radical and so hopeless of enactment that executives had given very little attention to it, assuming that the act would not progress any further than the Senate.

WASHINGTON, April 8 (AP) -- Jesse Jones, a director of the Reconstruction Corporation, announced tonight that he hoped for an early distribution of 30 per cent of the deposits of the First National Bank and the Guardian National Bank in Detroit, now being merged into the National Bank of Detroit, in addition to the 10 per cent distribution already made.

READERS of "Mad Puppetstown," the novel by M.J. Farrell which preceded this one, will recognize with pleasure the same Irish countryside so richly and vividly described therein. To be sure, the scene is not now Puppetstown, but Pullinstown.

ART SHIRES checked out some twelve hours before Hank Leiber and Schoolboy Rowe checked in, leaving the color content of this area at about the same level. The Great Shires turned his back on the Boston Braves and Messrs. Leiber and Rowe arrived with the Giants and the Detroit Tigers.

PINEHURST, N.C. -- With the conclusion of the North and South amateur golf tournament, just held here, golf is to be succeeded by tennis as the leading sports activity here. Save for the mid-April tournament late this month, and several Silver Foils events, golf will pass from the tournament spot-light.

Immense, lurid posters are now proclaiming to prospective subscribers the myriad attractions of Cobina Wright's Circus Ball to be presented in the grand ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria on April 25 for the benefit of the Boy Scout Foundation, of which President Roosevelt is executive head.

Acquisition of control in the Missouri-Kansas-Texas Railway by New York Investors, Inc., was indicated yesterday in advices from St. Louis, which said that William M. Greve, president of the New York company, together with Matthew S. Sloan, former president of the New York Edison Company, had been elected directors of the railroad.

THE world's first marine timekeeper, invented in 1735, was recenetly started again after having lain idle since 1767 in the Royal Observatory in London and found to be as good as when it went to sea two centuries ago. It was constructed by John Harrison.

FOR several years past interest in the preservation of American folklore, and especially preservation of ballads -- variants of border ballads and indigenous songs -- has been keen throughout the colleges of the United States, with the burden of publication, since the results would not be such as to make a wide commercial appeal, falling generally upon the university presses.

THIS is not the book M. Fleg intended to write when he made his journey to Palestine. He went there because he wanted to write a life of Jesus and before beginning it wanted to follow the footsteps of Jesus through all his goings and comings, study his backgrounds, envision him and his works in the very scenes in which he lived.
VIENNA, March 24 -- The Social Democratic municipality does not extend its approval of Parliamentary debating methods to the animal world, as it proved by its sparrow war.

PARIS, April 6 -- "Excelsior" is still the motto of the new Summer hat collections, with crowns or trims doubling the headline height. Maria Guy's turbans built up into Spanish comb crests are sensational.

WASHINGTON, April 8 (AP) -- Under an income tax decision today by the Board of Tax Appeals, deduction from net incomes of millions of dollars in charitable contributions would be allowed, the immediate beneficiaries of the ruling including John J. Raskob, former chairman of the Democratic National Committee, and Pierre S du Pont, Industrialist.

SOUTHERN PINES, N.C. -- With a full calendar of events scheduled for the remaining days of April, the colony here will turn from an active week of social events to witness the fifteenth annual united North and South Tennis tournaments at the Pinehurst Country Club, which opens tomorrow.

PALM BEACH -- Daily programs have become entirely a matter of the moment's fancy and are running the gamut from bathing, golf and tennis to impromptu affairs at villas or the two rendezvous remaining open, Patio Margery and L'Aiglon.

The Public Service Commission announced yesterday that it had approved the report of W.T. Wilkinson, examiner, recommending denial of the amended petition of the Staten Island Edison Corporation to issue $5,761,000 in thirty-year mortgage bonds and to apply the proceeds to payment at maturity on June 14 next, of refunding and improvement 6 per cent bonds, dated June 15 last.

ST. LOUIS, April 6 -- The return of beer means more than a social drink to St. Louis and contiguous territory. It marks the return of an important industry, which has already, after a thirteen-year drought, acted as a vital stimulant to business other than that immediately engaged in the manufacture of potent brew.

When the German Republic was set up and the Weimar Constitution adopted, Americans felt that Germans were really paying us the compliment of imitation. Not that our forms of government were bodily taken over. The Germans had old traditions with which they could not at once part, and allowance was made for that.

PARIS IN designing their new sports clothes Paris creators have seemingly sworn to cheat Satan of that mischief which, we are told, he still finds for idle hands to do; for what with rows of really functioning buttons and all the rope and other lacings that the couturiers are using lavishly, it looks like a busy Summer.
In its present internal conflict over the case of the Harriman National Bank and Trust Company the New York Clearing House Association is facing a crucial test, in the opinion of many bankers.

Each Spring Devon, leads the way for the outdoor horse show season and this year the annual Devon Horse Show and County Fair will be held from May 24 to 30, inclusive, except on Sunday, May 28. Prize lists for the exhibition, which is for the benefit of the endowment fund of the Byrn Mawr Hospital, have been sent to exhibitors, and entries will close on Wednesday, April 26.

THE series of round-table discussions of the dance sponsored by Sara Mildred Strauss have instituted in an unexpected manner an activity which, it is to be hoped, will become a regular feature of the local dance program.

CHICAGO, April 8 -- Heavy profit-taking developed today in the grain markets on the Board of Trade. A forecast for rain in the West and Southwest, evening up for over the week-end, and the fact that the government crop report will be issued after the close of the market on Monday, increased the pressure on wheat.

PERTH, Western Australia, April 8 (Canadian Press) -- The State of Western Australia today voted to secede from the Australian Commonwealth. Incomplete returns from the State-wide referendum indicated a majority for those in favor of breaking away from the five other States.

Small lots of municipal bonds and tax warrants, parts of two foreign issues and one domestic industrial issue featured last week's announcements of loans to be paid in April before maturity. Notices of redemptions for future months made the smallest total for a week in many months and comprised, with one exception, foreign bonds.

ROME, April 7 -- The Italian air force has just celebrated the tenth anniversary of its founding. Four thousand pilots, not counting those who form part of the reserve, paraded the streets of Rome and were reviewed by King Victor Emmanuel and Premier Mussolini.

Winning three of the five events, swimmers representing the community centre of Public School 70, Bronx, won the team championship for the third consecutive year and for the fifth time in six seasons in the annual League of Neighborhood School Centres title meet, held last night at the C.C.N.Y. pool.

WASHINGTON, April 8 -- A moderate extension of the upward trend in business activity occurred during the week ended April 1, according to the weekly survey of domestic business conditions made public today by the Commerce Department.

UNDER the expansive presidency of Lord Burnham there has been inaugurated a new kind of comradeship. Its aim is to promote a fraternity between places in the United States and Great Britain, like Reading, Pa., and Reading, Berkshire, which happen to be namesakes.

PRESIDENT ROOSEVELT and George Bernard Shaw, Secretary of State Hull, Secretary of Commerce Roper, Claude G. Bowers, the new Ambassador to Spain, are on the radio speakers' list this week. There will be Lenten music from Oberammergau, greetings from Anton Lang, who plays Christus; Holy Week oratorios and opening baseball games, all crisscrossed through space on numerous wave lengths.
BETHLEHEM, Pa., April 8 -- Coming from behind in the final three innings, Lehigh launched the home baseball season on Taylor Field today by defeating Swarthmore, 6 to 5.

A sharp single by Mike Rubinsky with the bases full in the eighth and the score tied at 2-all enabled St. John's College to open its season with a 4-to-2 victory over the Savage School nine at Carey Field yesterday.

LONDON, March 30 -- The New Statesman, formerly, The Spectator, and The Week End Review, formerly The Saturday Review, were debarred last week from circulation in Germany for six months by a ruling of the Prussian Commissary of the Interior because both had ex- pressed skepticism as to the Communist origin of the Reichstag fire.

About twenty passengers in a southbound Broadway surface car were thrown into confusion just after 8 o'clock last night when an explosion beneath the car at Broadway and Ninetieth Street shattered two of its windows and drove a nine-inch steel plate from the flooring into the roof of the car.

President Roosevelt's action Friday in inviting France, Italy, Germany and other nations to send representatives to Washington for discussions of world problems was interpreted by foreign traders here yesterday as the first step in a definite program for obtaining trading advantages for the United States at the coming World Economic Conference in London.

Realty owners and brokers in the Jackson Heights section of the borough of Queens are anticipating an increasing activity in the district because of the approaching opening this Summer of a new link in the municipal subway system.

HOW strongly entrenched are the Hitler forces? What is the opposition and what are its possibilities of making itself felt? These are the questions which the world is asking while anxiously awaiting the outcome of events in Germany.

HASSOLDT DAVIS was a lad half way through Harvard when four years ago he decided he would quit college, go out and see the world and do some writing. After a while he landed in Tahiti, stayed there a considerable time, lived in Papeete, clambered about in the unfrequented parts of the island, and then moved on to Australia, Fiji, and the Celebes Islands.

America's annual bill for recreation just before the depression set in was, conservatively, $10,165,857,000, according to a monograph to be published tomorrow by the McGraw-Hill Book Company under the auspices of the Research Committee on Social Trends appointed by President Hoover.

A NEW story of romantic adventure by the author of "The Four Feathers" and "No Other Tiger," "The Sapphire" carries the readers from London to Burma, with its seas of green jungle, its pagodas and its exotic beliefs.

WASHINGTON, April 8 -- Democratic leaders in Congress may not know it yet, but the President has not abandoned the plan to amortize by special taxation some of the huge expenditures contemplated by the government to relieve unemployment, increase purchasing power and reduce personal debts on the farms and in the cities.

A new chapter will be added to the history of the famous Metropolitan Opera House on the night of April 28, when the Opera Ball will be given there in the interests of the campaign to raise about $30,000 outstanding of the $300,000 needed for the continuation of Metropolitan Opera in New York next season.

THE administration's plan to support moves in the forthcoming World Monetary and Economic Conference for a system of regulating the production and export of wheat draws attention to the critical wheat situation during the past few years.

Prices for crude rubber futures continued their recovery in the short trading session yesterday, and cocoa was higher, while other staples moved in a narrow range with lower-price tendencies. Trading volumes were about average for a Saturday.

IN "Special Delivery" Branch Cabell has written the book which legions of authors, editors, actors, statesmen and critics have longed to write, have vaguely planned to write and will now rejoice to see written. One hopes the book will be read by those for whom its lessons are primarily intended, although others will find the barbed wit and general jocularity of "Special Delivery" a powder magazine of entertainment and amusement in continuous explosion.

WASHINGTON RUTH BRYAN OWEN'S appointment as Minister to Denmark is expected to give impetus to the movement of women into the American Foreign Service. Mrs. Owen will be the first woman to represent the United States at a foreign court as chief of mission.
PHILADELPHIA, April 8 -- Astonishment was expressed by Helen Keller when she was informed George Bernard Shaw had denied saying to her that "all Americans are blind, deaf and dumb."

Exploitation of immigrants and alien visitors by taxi drivers and hotel runners was reported to Police Commissioner Mulrooney yesterday by Edward Cord, Commissioner of Immigration at Ellis Island. Mr. Corsi's report, made after two months of investigation, was sent also to the Collector of the Port and to the secretary of the Transatlantic Shipping Conference.

BERLIN, April 7 -- German domination of the management of all fields of artistic endeavor, but with the German latchstring hanging out for all foreign artists -- even free-lance Jewish performers -- will be the official attitude of the new national government, according to Hans Hinkel, who has been assigned to "special duties" in the Prussian Ministry of Culture.

CHICAGO, April 6 -- A practical solution of the unemployment problem for a major portion of the 800,000 persons on relief in Cook County has been offered here in a program of land colonization on acreage located within thirty miles of Chicago's Loop.

With the anticipated opening during the Summer of the Queens extension of the Eighth Avenue subway to Broadway, Jackson Heights, renewed activity in realty and business is expected to develop throughout the area served by this transportation route.
NEW YORK. Mrs. Philip Sawyer of 10 Park Avenue will sail Wednesday on the Empress of Britain. Her afternoon musicale today will be her last of a series.

THERE is a great deal in this small volume on friendship by Abel Bonnard, one of the forty immortals of the French Academy, which is reminiscent of Anatole France; more, perhaps, of one of the latter's characters, Sylvestre Bonnard, the gentle scholar.

To the Editor of The New York Times: A considerable part of the article by Professor E.W. Kemmerer in THE TIMES of last Sunday is unintentionally confusing and misleading. I refer to his description and discussion of the assessments which are to be imposed upon the processors of certain farm products in the pending farm relief bill as "taxes" or "a tax."

Basing his estimates upon the number of apartments and residences built in the Bronx from 1915 to the close of 1932 and the population increase during the same period. Robert E. Simon concludes that no actual surplus of residential space exists at present in that borough.

A compilation of the earnings of leading industrial companies whose shares are listed on the New York Stock Exchange shows that the tobacco and food groups have been the most consistent money makers in the depression years.

SPINNERS of utopia via collectivism fall naturally into two categories. One kind is aggressive, defiant, rough-riding, eager for the immediate destruction of the present social order. The other is gentle, persuasive, more vocal about the boons to humanity.

IF we are ever to find out how matter is constituted we must break up the atom. This means that it must be blasted open. Now an atom consists of a highly complicated nucleus of protons and electrons, around which from one to ninety-two negative electrons are grouped.

THE chameleon on plaid and the Stephen Leacock general who mounted his horse and rode off in all directions are the only symbols that come to mind to convey the problem of the gallery-goer during the last week. So far as the New York art world was concerned, the proverbial April showers brought with them not May flowers, but an immediate inundation, of tidal-wave proportions, in the number of local gallery exhibitions.

Advising subscribers that, as a result of drastic changes which it is making in its basis of rating insurance companies, no reliance should be placed on last year's ratings, the Alfred M. Best Company is preparing to make its new schedule available this week, with casualty-surety and fire-marine companies appraised on the basis of the market value of their investment portfolios instead of on the valuations allowed by the National Convention of Insurance Commissioners.

A dance to aid charity, heralded for several weeks as "different" and "amusingly novel," took place last night in the entertaining suite of the Ambassador. Entitled the Blue and White Supper Dance, it combined these colors in an attractive decorative scheme and presented many features of entertainment for the several hundred guests, mostly younger members of society.
ALBANY, Sunday, April 9 -- Acting in accordance with a special message from Governor Lehman, the Legislature gave final approval early today to a $60,000,000 bond issue for unemployment relief.

WORCESTER, Mass., April 8 -- Waldo Lincoln, of a distinguished ancestry which includes two Governors of Massachusetts and three United States Senators, died after a brief illness at his home here yesterday in his eighty-fourth year. The funeral will be held at the First Unitarian Church tomorrow afternoon at 3.

Steady improvement in retail trade in advance of the Easter holiday appears in most sections of the country to have gone somewhat beyond seasonal expectations, while the return of beer has stimulated commerce in a general way. Additional constructive indications are the firmer tendencies noted in all the commodities and higher prices reported for raw materials not traded in on exchanges.

MY impressions of America are altogether reassuring. When the bank holiday broke like a clap of thunder the American kept his smile. He was right. Since that time I have called upon President Roosevelt, to whom I carried the homage of a valued friendship begun in Paris during the World War.

Figures on fluctuations in the short interest on the New York Stock Exchange since Feb. 27, made public yesterday, showed that while short commitments had decreased 310,320 shares in the five days of trading preceding the closing of the Exchange on March 4, they had increased 120,974 shares from the reopening of the Exchange on March 15 until last Monday.

TWO young Russian musicians, Nathan Perleman, pianist, and Herz Tsomik, cellist, recently gave two concerts in the Industrial town of Kuznetskstroi, Western Siberia. They played Chopin, Liszt and Bach. Their audiences, workers, Red Army soldiers and students, packed the hall of the local trade school -- 500 for the first concert, 1,000 for the second.

OTTAWA, April 6 -- Federal concern with provincial finance is something new in this country -- an unpleasant development of extraordinary conditions. The Provinces are masters of their own exchequers, raise money as they see fit in a wide field of taxation, spend it as suits them and obligate their future within their own judgment and their ability to sell bonds.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va. -- The colony here for Palm Sunday and Easter has grown largely during the last few days, and many golfers have gathered for the annual Mason and Dixie golf tournament, which will open tomorrow and continue through the week.

Period furniture and furnishings from the private collections of H. G. Gore of Hendham, N.J., and Mrs. Emily Roberts Coxe of this city and from other sources will be offered at auction next Friday and Saturday afternoons at the American Art Association Anderson Galleries, Inc.

Current events will serve as the inspiration, for several innovations now being planned for the Butterfly Ball, one of the largest entertainments of each Spring in New York, which is to take place on April 21 at the Ritz-Carlton for the benefit of the House of Rest.

LEXINGTON, Ky., April 8 -- Upholding a tradition that the first day of Lexington racing is "longshot day," Ridge Wise, owned by the Ridgeview Stable, captured the Ben Ali Handicap, a $1,000 purse that featured the inaugural program today, and paid $71.10 for $2 to win in the mutuels.

Suddenly admitting that he was an escaped murderer who had been the object of an international search for the last thirteen years, a middle-aged Brooklyn man who had been living a quiet, respectable life here for more than a decade with his second wife created a sensation yesterday during a habeas Corpus proceeding before Supreme Court Justice Charles C. Lockwood in Brooklyn.

Findings of a comparative study of British and American methods of handling unemployment run directly counter to the fear expressed by employers in this country that unemployment insurance "would tend to lessen the interest of the worker in getting other work," according to a survey by the Unemployment Division of the National Federation of Settlements, made public yesterday.

DETROIT THOSE Spring sales or offensives which are traditional in the automotive industry have not been canceled for the year 1933. They merely are being held in abeyance. Present indications, however, are that this state of affairs is destined for an early termination.

IN his preface to this account of Mormonism and its founder, Mr. Evans states that he has "tried to give a scientific treatment of Joseph Smith -- that is, to present the available facts, without smothering these facts in opinion," modestly adding: "This, I believe, has never been done before."

WASHINGTON, April 8 -- A wholesale revision of the administration securities control measure has been drafted by the Senate Banking Committee under which the power of the government to block stock and bond sales would be curtailed sharply.
The celebration of Passover, commemorating the release of the Jews from bondage in Egypt, will begin at sunset tomorrow and continue until nightfall on Monday, April 17.
NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., April 8 -- A double by Walter Wiggins with two out in the ninth inning gave Rutgers a 7-to-6 victory over Princeton today in the Scarlet's opening baseball game of the season.

LONDON OF all boring books, books about music are almost, and books about musicians are quite, the worst." When he opened his weekly literary article in The Observer with this gesture of contempt, Basil de Selincourt was obviously inviting some one to tread on the tail of his coat.

John I. Campbell, chief clerk of District 1 of the Railway Mail Service, will complete tomorrow forty-five years of service with the organization. But, as Mr. Campbell, who is now 66, explained yesterday at his home, 43-13 Elbertson Street, Elmhurst, Queens, there will be no celebration in his office at the General Postoffice, Manhattan, "because times are too hard and I wouldn't want to have any of the men waste money on me."

NEW HAVEN, Conn., April 8 -- With one month remaining before the start of the rowing season, Yale has a fleet of twenty-five varsity and class crews. They include nineteen at Derby on the Housatonic course, where they are quartered at the Robert J. Cook boathouse; and six in New Haven Harbor at the George A. Adee boathouse.

Several attempts by Communists to break up a Socialist demonstration in Union Square against fascism and war yesterday afternoon were frustrated by the police, who forcibly ejected the Communists from the vicinity of the meeting. The meeting was under the auspices of the Young People's Socialist League, Young Circle League, Young Poale Zion Alliance and the League for Industrial Democracy.

WHEN the far-famed Light Brigade charged half a league onward into the Valley of Death it performed that fatal manoeuvre, according to the poet, because somebody had blundered. But when the Messrs. Lew Brown and Ray Henderson knocked their two heads together one afternoon last Fall and decided to produce a musical show they did it with a vague idea of what they were about.

WE used to razz the fellows who went to the guinea-pig college," a campus leader at the University of Wisconsin told me recently, referring to the experimental college under Professor Alexander Melklejohn which closed last June.

A brief but successful attack in the eighth inning gave the Columbia baseball team a 1-0 victory over Yale yesterday at Baker Field in the opening encounter of the Eastern Intercollegiate League season.

ALTHOUGH Clyde Beatty's collection of lions and tigers was the nominal menace, it took a black leopard to throw a scare into the Universal company that helped the animal trainer to produce "The Big Cage," which opens at the RKO Roxy on Friday.

WASHINGTON, April 8 -- The House "censorship bill," with its drastic penalties for publication of official secrets, was rewritten today by a Senate Foreign Relations subcommittee to penalize only Federal employes who make private use of official code messages.

"Blue Jeans," a melodrama popular in the '90s, was revived last night by the Junior Society of Congregation Emanu-El for the benefit of its scholarship fund, in the temple community house, 1 East Sixty-fifth Street. Fifty young men and women of Emanu-El were in the cast and on the various committees.
DUBLIN, April 7 -- The future of the Free State's Senate is now very much in the balance. The Republicans have always urged, if not its abolition, at least its reduction and reconstitution.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., April 6 -- It took a pleasant-faced, mild-mannered, white-haired doctor to break the thirty-three-year hold of the Republican party on Lake Placid village politics. The reign came to an end when Dr. George C. Owens, former associate surgeon at St. Mary's Hospital in Brooklyn, was chosen Mayor recently by a margin of 92 votes over the Republican candidate for re-election, Martin T. Ryan.

METEOROLOGISTS cherish an anecdote recorded in the official journal of the weather station maintained many years ago on the lofty summit of Pike's Peak. One day, before the railroad facilitated access to the spot, a woman came up with a guide.

MOSCOW, April 8 -- Soviet newspapers devote most of their front pages today to the proposed British import restrictions on Soviet goods, using such headlines as "Threats of British Imperialists," and editorials captioned "They Do Not Frighten Us."

The week disclosed no let-up in orders for pre-Easter promotions, according to the market report prepared especially for THE TIMES by McGreevey, Werring Howell, Inc. Mail and telegraph orders were heavier, with reorders in practically every department showing a substantial increase in quantity over initial purchases.

DALLAS, Texas, April 7 -- Business in the district has shown a moderate but steady growth since the lifting of the bank holiday. Wholesalers report an increase in orders from retailers in preparation for the pre-Easter trade, and retailers report that the expected buying rush for Easter Week has already started.

HARTFORD, Conn., April 8 -- Rising more than an inch an hour, the Connecticut River had reached a freshet height of eighteen feet tonight and a supplementary flood warning by the Weather Bureau confirmed the indications that the river had started its annual dan- gerous Spring rampage.

CHICAGO, April 6 -- Whatever may be the aftermath of beer's renaissance in Chicago, the approach of the date on which the legitimacy was to be restored to the outlaw did not lack its comedy for neutral observers. As between beer's apologists and its opponents, the latter, in so far as they enjoyed a sense of humor, had the better end of the joke.

DURING those long years through which the walls of Troy resisted the utmost efforts of the Grecian host, King Priam drew to himself many more or less heroic allies. And of them all none was braver, none more redoubtable in combat than the band of Amazons, headed by their famous Queen, Penthesilea.

PHILADELPHIA, April 8 -- Assertions that Japan was "legally wrong" in her dealings in Manchuria but that the modern basis of world pease was the "theory of national sterility and immobility" and that Japan "simply happened" to be the first nation to prove the "economic fallacy" of this view were made before the American Academy of Political and Social Science today by Professor Frank R. Eldridge of New York University.
The plan to hold an open tennis tournament in the United States this year has been abandoned.

THE opening last Friday of the legal spigot which allows beer of not more then 3.2 per cent of alcohol by weight to flow freely in all States desiring it, came to the wet majority of a thirsty nation as the first relaxation in a prohibition law which has been in effect for more than thirteen years.

Anglers of both salt water and fresh water schools have been exceedingly busy the past week, judging from reports, and while the trout fishermen have been halted somewhat by high water and streams that were pretty muddy and full of feed, the salt water fishermen have had better conditions.

ANOTHER political prisoner has recently walked up and down the grass court of London Tower, where, during many centuries, men and women charged with being enemies of the King or the State have awaited execution or reprieve.

Speculation as to whether Secretary Woodin of the Treasury Department plans to announce by next Saturday the calling of the $6,268,000,000 of Fourth Liberty 4 1/4 per cent bonds for payment on Oct. 15, in whole or in part, if at all, formed the principal topic of conversation in government bond circles last week.

Competition is so keen that only apartments which are spick and span are being rented, Ernest L. Hall, vice president of Realty Associates Management, told the property owners and building managers who were present at the Brooklyn Real Estate Board's lecture meeting in the Brooklyn Edison Building last week.

Writing in The London Spectator, Mr. VERNON BARTLETT points to the fact that there exist just now many "defeatists" of peace. The word gained its currency in wartime. Great numbers of people, especially in England, despaired of winning the war against Germany.

GENEVA THIS lovely town in Switzerland, where Calvin and Beza founded one of the first modern academies, and where the genius of Rousseau discovered new pedagogic principles, seems to be predestined for educational developments.

WITH the touch of ironic fate inherent in great drama, there were spread on the front page of THE NEW YORK TIMES on Tuesday morning two contrasting narratives of aeronautics. One recorded the successful attempt of the British Houston Mount Everest Expedition to fly over the world's highest peak.

WE are informed that Carl Liddle, who spent a year or more among the head-hunting Sbuara Indians of the remote "Oriente" jungle in Ecuador, has put the account of his adventures into fictional form "for fear that no one would believe it if it had been presented as a straight narrative."

COLUMBUS, Ohio, April 8 (AP) -- American Bowling Congress leaders held their places during today's bombardment in the minor events of the national pin classic, now drawing near a close. The five-man event will end tomorrow night and the minor events late Monday.
PARIS, April 2 (AP by Mail) -- Flowers, feathers and fur lend a note of formal elegance to the frocks designed for the parties following Easter.

The Museum of the American Indian Heye Foundation, 155th Street and Broadway, has placed on exhibition an unusual collection of items picturing the Pueblo Indian culture of New Mexico and Arizona. The Indians of the different groups represented are noted for their elaborate rites and ceremonies, which play a large part in their daily lives.
SHERIDAN, Wyo., April 8 -- Wyoming lost a titled ranchman today and England gained an Earl.

BERLIN, April 8 -- Adolf Hitler talked to his Storm Troopers this evening, not as German Chancellor but as their supreme commander. Thousands of them were gathered before him in the Berlin Sport-palast, but the entire "brown army" -- 500,000 men, the National Socialists say -- was mustered in barracks throughout the Reich to listen to its leader's words, which were broadcast.

While the demand for beer continued so strong yesterday that the brewers could not meet it fully, statisticians estimated that it had added $10,000,000 to Federal, State and local revenues on Friday alone. It was figured that the Federal government had collected $7,500,000 from 1,500,000 barrels in twenty-one States and the District of Columbia.

BERLIN, April 8 -- Mystery today shrouded the death of Erik Jan Hanussen, one of Europe's best known clairvoyants, who years ago predicted the rise of Hitler to power. His bullet-riddled body was found yesterday in the woods near Baireuth, forty-five miles south of here, thirteen days after he had abruptly terminated an engagement at a Berlin vaudeville house "on account of a nervous collapse."

WASHINGTON, April 8 -- A joint Congressional investigation into the Akron disaster was assured today when Chairman Vinson of the House Naval Affairs Committee withdrew his opposition and agreed that a thorough and unbiased inquiry was necessary.

FOR a number of years the fashion parade along the Boardwalk at Atlantic City on Easter Sunday has drawn thousands of motorists from New York and other near-by cities. For many car owners that will be the first trip of the season.
