To the Editor of The New York Times: It will take a good deal more than Dr. Edward H. Gary's denunciation of "Fordized" medicine to settle the question of the socialization of medicine which was raised by the report of the Wilbur Committee on the Costs of Medical Care.

ONE of the most important improvements to be undertaken this year on the south shore of Long Island is the Meadowbrook Causeway, which will run from Meadowbrook State Park Immediately east of the village of Freeport and extend southerly across the bay to the west end of Jones Beach State Park.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 6 -- Perhaps because they were centring their enthusiasm on April 7, with its return of beer to the thirsty multitudes, the people of California evinced no unusual enthusiasm over the decision by which the State Supreme Court this week opens the way for the fullest conservation of water in the interest of the entire public.

SAVANNAH, April 6 -- Thomas Gamble, the former Philadelphia newspaper reporter who for the past two months has been Mayor of Savannah, has caused a sensation by declaring that all forms of gambling must cease and calling upon the Superintendent of Police to see that his orders are carried out.

Young matrons and debutantes of this and recent seasons are interested in the success of the children's Easter fair in behalf of the babies' wards of the New York Post-Graduate Hospital, which will be held throughout this week at Saks-Fifth Avenue.

The New York University baseball team opened its season yesterday with an impressive 10-to-4 victory over the Alumni at Ohio Field. The winners confined all their scoring to two innings, the fifth and sixth.

CHICAGO, April 8 (AP) -- Al Simmons smashed a home run into the left field stands of Comiskey Park in the fourth inning today to give the White Sox a 1-to-0 victory over the Cubs, champions of the National League.
WASHINGTON, April 8 -- The War Department issued the following orders today:

Both the Columbia University Council for Research in the Social Sciences and Dr. ELIZABETH F. BAKER of Barnard College are to be congratulated on the publication of "Displacement of Men by Machines," the one for having made possible and the other for having conducted the first detailed study of technical progress in its relation to unemployment.

EASTER business jumped to very satisfactory proportions in the stores last week. Locally sales were reported to have run ahead of a year ago in quite a few instances, and reports from other centres free from banking tie-ups were similarly encouraging.
WASHINGTON, April 8 -- The Bureau of Navigation issued the following orders today, dated April 6:

It is a serious mistake for parents to hide undelivered deeds in desks or safe deposit boxes with the idea of conveying property to their children after death, pointed out Albert Hutton, an attorney, at the Brooklyn Real Estate Board's lecture meeting in the Brooklyn Edison Building last week.

PARIS, April 7 -- All eyes in Europe have been turned toward Washington ever since President Roosevelt's inauguration, and it would seem as if many footsteps were to be turned there soon also. Prime Minister Ramsay MacDonald of Britain has accepted an invitation to spend the Easter vacation from Parliament there.

There is every reason to believe that this year's Grand Circuit meeting at the Goshen Mile Track at Goshen, N.Y., will be one of the best ever held over the famous track. The program for the racing, Monday, Aug. 14, to Friday, Aug. 18, inclusive, has been announced, with the noted Hambletonian listed for Wednesday, Aug. 16.

WITH the motoring season about to open, the question of service will gain interest for car owners and dealers alike. Writing in The Automotive Daily News, E.M. Lubeck of Dealers Service Bureau offers some lively and pertinent comment, from which the following is extracted:

A German speaker and an Italian speaker at yesterday's discussion luncheon of the Foreign Policy Association at the Hotel Astor urged a fair and sympathetic withholding of judgment on Chancellor Hitler, and agreed that his power was not dangerous to the peace of Europe.

WASHINGTON, April 8 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended on April 1 make a total of 494,588 cars, the American Railway Association announced today. This was an increase of 18,738 cars, or 3.9 per cent, over the preceding week, but a reduction of 50,373 cars, or 9.2 per cent, under the corresponding week last year, and 233,264 cars, or 32 per cent, fewer than for the corresponding week two years ago.

HOT SPRINGS, Va. -- Glorious weather and the attractiveness of the Alleghanies are bringing many colonists here for the riding, golfing and other outdoor pursuits which are much a part of this resort at this season. Several of the beautiful estates at Virginia Hot Springs are to be reopened shortly.

ALTHOUGH it is too early as yet to ascribe an exact cause for the greatest disaster in the history of aeronautics, the loss at sea off the New Jersey shore of the U.S.S. Akron early on Tuesday morning with a death list of seventy-three, this culmination of the recurrent catastrophes which have beset rigid airships both here and abroad in recent years makes desirable a review of lighter-than-air history and development.

TORONTO, Ont., April 8 -- Celebration of the fiftieth anniversary of the discovery of the nickel deposits at Sudbury, from which Canada has built a world industry, was formally begun on Thursday with a speech by Robert C. Stanley, president of the International Nickel Company of Canada, Ltd., at the thirty-fourth annual dinner of the Canadian Institute of Mining and Metallurgy.

WASHINGTON, April 8 -- A ten-point program for the improvement of agriculture was offered today by the agriculture policy committee of the Chamber of Commerce of the United States and will be submitted to the chamber's annual meeting early in May.

Members of the younger set who are interested in the work of the Prosperity Shop, a permanent thrift shop at 1,279 Third Avenue, which is maintained for the assistance of various charitable organizations in the city, have arranged a unique party in behalf of the shop.

BERLIN, April 7 -- Final steps for the racial "purification" of the legal profession in Germany have been announced by the Nazi commissar in charge of the Anwaltskammer -- the general bar association -- in a communique that is worth quoting. It follows:

BERLIN, April 8 -- In the German newspapers today Frau Winifred Wagner, widow of the composer's son, emphatically repeats her denial yesterday of reports current in musical circles here that Arturo Toscanini will not conduct the performance of "Die' Meistersinger" and "Parsifal" at the forthcoming festival in Baireuth.

THE repeal forces of the country are certainly off to a good start. Michigan and "Wisconsin have declared in no uncertain terms on behalf of repeal, and the psychological effect of the overwhelming votes in those two States is sure to be felt throughout the nation.

There is every reason to believe that this year's Grand Circuit meeting at the Goshen Mile Track at Goshen, N.Y., will be one of the best ever held over the famous track. The program for the racing, Monday, Aug. 14, to Friday, Aug. 18, inclusive, has been announced, with the noted Hambletonian listed for Wednesday, Aug. 16.

WITH the motoring season about to open, the question of service will gain interest for car owners and dealers alike. Writing in The Automotive Daily News, E.M. Lubeck of Dealers Service Bureau offers some lively and pertinent comment, from which the following is extracted:
More than 250 members of the freshman and sophomore classes of Barnard College participated yesterday afternoon in the thirtieth annual Greek games pageant, held in the college gymnasium.

ROME, April 8 (AP) -- Pilgrims from all parts of the world have assembled here for the most extraordinary Holy Week ceremonies held by the Roman Catholic Church in more than six decades. They will begin tomorrow, on Palm Sunday, which commemorates Christ's triumphant entry into Jerusalem nineteen hundred years ago.

WASHINGTON, April 8 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended on April 1 make a total of 494,588 cars, the American Railway Association announced today. This was an increase of 18,738 cars, or 3.9 per cent, over the preceding week, but a reduction of 50,373 cars, or 9.2 per cent, under the corresponding week last year, and 233,264 cars, or 32 per cent, fewer than for the corresponding week two years ago.

HOT SPRINGS, Va. -- Glorious weather and the attractiveness of the Alleghanies are bringing many colonists here for the riding, golfing and other outdoor pursuits which are much a part of this resort at this season. Several of the beautiful estates at Virginia Hot Springs are to be reopened shortly.

ALTHOUGH it is too early as yet to ascribe an exact cause for the greatest disaster in the history of aeronautics, the loss at sea off the New Jersey shore of the U.S.S. Akron early on Tuesday morning with a death list of seventy-three, this culmination of the recurrent catastrophes which have beset rigid airships both here and abroad in recent years makes desirable a review of lighter-than-air history and development.

TORONTO, Ont., April 8 -- Celebration of the fiftieth anniversary of the discovery of the nickel deposits at Sudbury, from which Canada has built a world industry, was formally begun on Thursday with a speech by Robert C. Stanley, president of the International Nickel Company of Canada, Ltd., at the thirty-fourth annual dinner of the Canadian Institute of Mining and Metallurgy.

WASHINGTON, April 8 -- A ten-point program for the improvement of agriculture was offered today by the agriculture policy committee of the Chamber of Commerce of the United States and will be submitted to the chamber's annual meeting early in May.

Members of the younger set who are interested in the work of the Prosperity Shop, a permanent thrift shop at 1,279 Third Avenue, which is maintained for the assistance of various charitable organizations in the city, have arranged a unique party in behalf of the shop.

BERLIN, April 7 -- Final steps for the racial "purification" of the legal profession in Germany have been announced by the Nazi commissar in charge of the Anwaltskammer -- the general bar association -- in a communique that is worth quoting. It follows:

BERLIN, April 8 -- In the German newspapers today Frau Winifred Wagner, widow of the composer's son, emphatically repeats her denial yesterday of reports current in musical circles here that Arturo Toscanini will not conduct the performance of "Die' Meistersinger" and "Parsifal" at the forthcoming festival in Baireuth.

ALBANY, April 8 -- The Senate and Assembly tonight were preparing to pass on Monday an entirely new beer-control bill following a a compromise reached today at a conference among Governor Lehman and the Democratic and Republican leaders of the Legislature.

Reduction of State and city payrolls in proportion to the decline in the cost of living was urged by the Merchants Association yesterday in a statement giving its program for the betterment of business.

ITHACA, N.Y., April 8 -- The Cornell crews have taken advantage of the Spring recess to practice needed distance rowing. More than fifty oarsmen have remained through the recess and the crews have been out on the lake twice daily.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., April 8 -- Fifty-nine awards of the gold "R" for satisfactory participation in non-athletic extracurricular activities were made to members of the two upper classes of Rutgers University, it was announced today.
TORONTO, April 8 -- The New York Rangers need only one more victory to take the Stanley Cup back to New York.

IN the convention which framed the Constitution of the United States George Mason of Virginia declared that it would be as unnatural to allow the people to choose a Chief Magistrate as it would be "to refer a trial of colors to a blind man." He reached this conclusion because "the extent of the country renders it impossible that the people can have the requisite capacity to judge of the respective pretensions of the candidates."

GENEVA, April 7 -- Recent developments in Germany are having both good and bad effects on the prospects and progress of the three big interlocking disguised wars in the Far East and South America. The net effects are deemed bad.
NEWARK, N.J., April 8 -- The first strike of brewery employes since beer became legal caused a complete shutdown of the Gottfried Krueger Brewery Company here tonight.

AN analysis of audience reaction to Captain Henry's Show Boat reveals that 85 per cent of the mail is written by women. Children comprise the majority of the remaining 15 per cent, with men constituting less than 3 per cent of the letter writers.

ALBANY THE controversy over beer on Capitol Hill has once more focused attention upon Governor Herbert Lehman. The fact that arrayed against the political forces of the State was a business man who disregarded ancient political precedents has added interest to the fight.
Back from the sunshine of the Southland the Giants came yesterday to the frigid atmosphere of the Polo Grounds to win a rather erratic game from the Detroit Tigers, 5 to 4, in eleven innings.
WASHINGTON, April 8 -- Both houses of Congress stood in recess today.
WEST POINT, N.Y., April 8 -- With representatives of ten colleges competing, Navy gymnasts won five of the seven individual championships at the Eastern Intercollegiate Gymnastic League meet today.

ALBANY, Sunday, April 9 -- At an early hour this morning the Legislature recessed until Monday, when final adjournment will be in order following the passage of the compromise State beer control bill.

THE April issue of The London Studio is a special "Birthday Number," celebrating "forty years of progress in the arts of modern civilization." This magazine was launched in 1893. A wide range is covered. Sir William Rothenstein discusses "Forty Years Evolution in the Fine Arts"; C.R. Ashbee, "Forty Years of British Architecture," and Carlyle Burrows, "The Rise of American Art."

A new Benjamin Franklin letter, written in 1784 from Passy, France, which has been lost for 149 years, has been discovered by Milton Halsey Thomas, curator of Columbiana at Columbia University, it was announced at the university yesterday.

WASHINGTON, April 8 -- Beer came back this week, and the President mentioned it gleefully on several occasions. Seven days before Der Bier-Tag he called to newspaper men departing from his Friday press conference to remember what was coming. This week he made another expectant reference to the innocent delights in store for the parched American palate after this Thursday night.

LONDON IN these times of overwrought nationalism, when many States have inflicted a great deal of damage upon international commerce and thereby upon their own peoples whom they were striving to protect, there is in Europe at least one trade that has continued to flourish -- that of national propaganda.

THE late James Arthur of New Rochelle, N.Y., left $36,500 to the American Museum of Natural History, the income of which sum was to be expended for the study and investigation of the human brain and for the founding of a series of annual lectures on the evolution of the brain.

The transatlantic conference steamship lines have formed a pool with Thomas Cook Son and the American Express Company for an advertising campaign throughout the country to induce Americans to take advantage of the low steamship fares to Europe and also the reduced rates for railroad travel and hotel accommodations on the Continent and in Great Britain.
Despite the fact that general construction work continues at a low ebb on Long Island, as in nearly all parts of the metropolitan area, considerable activity is to be found in the small home field.

BOSTON, April 8 (AP) -- The Red Sox gave Ivy Andrews and Bob Kline some timely hitting today, and the American Leaguers defeated the Braves, 7 -- 0, in the opening game of the annual intercity series at Fenway Park.

TRENTON, N.J., April 8 -- New Jersey's temporary beer law, hastily adopted toy the Legislature on Tuesday to make sale or new brew possible yesterday in conformity with Federal authorization, probably will be amended when the Senate and Assembly reconvenes on Monday.

HOW much does it actually cost a student to live in New York? The New York School of Social Work has recently made a study of the question with the cooperation of a number of its students living under varying conditions during the last year, and with the help of other organizations.

ATLANTA, April 6 -- If good old King Canute were in the land of the living, he would find himself as helpless to stop the beer wave which is engulfing Dixie as he was to prevent the billows of the sea from flooding the sands at his feet. But the spirit of the misled monarch of the misty past may be "putting over a fast one" on the Empire State of the South.

CURLES NECK, Va., April 8 (AP) -- Jumping Jack carried the colors of Mrs. Francis P. Garvan of Sewickley, Pa., to victory today in the Deep Run Hunt Cup, feature of the annual meet at Curles Neck, to win by four lengths.

ALONG the items discussed in Washington during the last month in the tremendous effort the administration is making to cut governmental expenditures is the elimination of the under-secretaries for aviation in the Army and Navy Departments and the placing of these important branches directly under the control of the department chiefs.

PARIS, April 8 -- The restoration of political stability is advanced as of primary importance in the draft report adopted here by the Inter- national Chamber of Commerce, to be submitted to the chamber's general congress in Vienna and at the world economic conference as a memorandum for the program of economic and monetary reconstruction.

Mrs. Sylvia Branfon, an unemployment relief investigator, of 270 South Third Street, Brooklyn, pleaded not guilty in Pennsylvania Avenue court, in Brooklyn, yesterday to a charge of having taken $5 for getting a part-time job for an unemployed man.

South Ferry and the vicinity of the Army Building at 39 Whitehall Street were a festive scene yesterday as hundreds of single young men, volunteers in the Civilian Conservation Corps, and their relatives bade each other farewell for six months, the recruiting period during which the men are to be paid $30 a month for work on conservation projects.

A NEW firm is about to set forth on those chartless seas of theatrical life. Its component parts -- and there is a suave expression for you -- are Alfred E. Aarons and Thomas Mitchell. The first of these, taken alphabetically only, is the former general manager for the late A.L. Erlanger and an occasional producer.

Sustained rallies in German loans marked yesterday's otherwise generally prosaic market for bonds on the Stock Exchange. The Reich issues responded to the reassuring statement given by Dr. Hjalmar Schacht, head of the Reichsbank, in the matter of continued payments on Germany's commercial debt, with the inference that the bonded debt would, perforce, be safegaurded.

ALBANY, N.Y., April 8 -- With violence growing among the striking milk farmers of the State, the Senate passed by a vote of 45 to 4, the Pitcher price-fixing milk control bill just before midnight after rejecting amendments offered by Senator Hendel of Queens regarding cream selling in New York City.

WITH such a variety of midget radios at their command the merchandisers are planning an aggressive Summer campaign. Usually the radio industry considers its season closed on St. Patrich's Day, after which comes a lull while new models are prepared for the market.

The Public School 189 swimmers of Manhattan and Public School 77 of Brooklyn, compiling 11 points each, deadlocked for the seventh and eighth year championship, while Public School 89 of Manhattan annexed the fifth and sixth year title with 9 markers at the annual city elementary Public Schools Athletic League meet in the City College pool yesterday morning.

BOOKS of reference can be as dry as the most alkaline of dust. While this volume, the fifteenth in the series of year books, is a complete book of reference in that it contains all the statistics of the year 1932 in the field of aeronautics, it escapes entirely the blighting touch of aridity.
WASHINGTON, April 8 -- A substitute for the administration's farm relief bill, framed by a Republican committee headed by Senator Carey, will be introduced on Monday by the member from Wyoming.

PHOENIX, Ariz., April 6 -- Arizona is angry. In fact, not before in its history has the Baby State been so deeply irritated. The objects of its wrath are the Legislature, recently adjourned, and Governor B.B. Moeur, elected last November by the largest majority ever given a Governor in Arizona.

THE world community has its first international vigilance committee in action. It is the advisory committee set up by resolution of the special Assembly of the League on Feb. 24 and meeting since March 15 with the nonvoting participation of a representative of the United States.

Several important corporations have arranged within recent months to hold their annual meetings in more accessible locations than in past years, so that stockholders will be able to attend in person if they desire to meet the officers of the company and obtain first-hand information on points affecting the business.

Almost a millennium ago ERIC the Red, sailing westward from Iceland in search of a land which had been sighted a little time before by another Norwegian, reached the east coast of Greenland, sailed past its southernmost point and then northward along the west coast, where he built his home and his primitive fortress at the northern threshold of the New World.

THIS story of French peasants begins and ends in a striking manner. It opens in the Coindet's tidy kitchen, with Aurelie, quite dead, banging by a stout cord to a hook in the middle of the room where the lamp was generally suspended.

Performances of Gilbert and Sullivan's operettas, "The Yeomen of the Guard" and "H.M.S. Pinafore," will be given in the near future for the benefit of charitable enterprises. The former will be offered by members of the Bluehill Troupe, a group of amateur players devoted to the production of Gilbert and Sullivan operettas, on the nights of May 4 and 5 at the Heckscher Theatre in behalf of the Stuyvesant Square Hospital.

Exchange of checks at 168 clearing houses throughout the country for March aggregated $16,449,678,492. This was a decline of 10.5 per cent from the preceding month, and the smallest amount in a score of years. Compared with March, 1932, there was a shrinkage of 32.8 per cent.

MIAMI -- Presenting a climax to the notable events that have featured the closing days of the season in the Miami area, Pan-American Day will be observed April 17. It will be on a much larger and more comprehensive scale than heretofore attempted since the observance of the day was established by Presidential proclamation in 1930.

PALM BEACH, Fla., April 9.--At the Beach House on the estate of Il Palmetto, where they have passed the season, Mr. and Mrs. Peter A. B. Widener 2d gave a buffet supper tonight.

Confidence that the Hiltler-led Nazis would fail in their reported effort to gain control of the German Lutheran Church was expressed yesterday morning by the Rev. Dr. Norman Vincent Peal...
WASHINGTON, D. C., April 9 (AP).--The disturbance that was central Saturday night over Eastern Colorado has advanced eastward to Missouri, with a trough extending southwestward to the Mexican...
BERLIN, April 7.--At midweek there was a sharp increase in the demand for money and later day loans were made at rates of 4... to 5... per cent.
PARIS, April 9.--Former Premier Edouard Herriot today accepted an official invitation transmitted to him by telephone by Foreign Minister Joseph Paul-Boncour to represent France at the White House...

WASHINGTON, April 9.--A second "bonus army" invading this city May 12, veterans flanked by thousands of Communists, loafers and tramps is threatened.

The Broadway opening of "The 3-Penny Opera," which was scheduled for this evening at the Empire Theatre, has been postponed until Thursday at the same house to permit the rehearsal of much dialogue omitted...
CHICAGO, April 9.--Prices for hogs moved erratically last week and ended with a decline of 25 cents a hundredweight from the previous week. The general average of $3.65 was the lowest since...
Private funeral services for Herbert Nathan Straus, vice president of R. H. Macy Co. and president of L. Bamberger Co. of Newark, who died on Thursday, were held yesterday morning at his home...

Passover, the period of feasting commerorating the release of the Jews from bondage in Egypt, will begin at sundown tonight and continue until Tuesday, April 18.

Three men, seized in a police raid early in the morning on a six-room apartment at 277 Park Avenue, near Forty-eighth Street, were held yesterday in $200 bail each by Magistrate Renaud in Yorkville Court...
The following were the best sellers, nationally, for the week ended Saturday:
A pair of elderly and quite unmannerly horses are major characters in "Tschiffely's Ride," pub-lished today by Simon Schueter. A. H. Tachiffely, who wrote the book, started out with these horses...
A report on State beer legislation, containing a warning that the proposed State board of control probably would be declared unconstitutional, was made public yesterday by the committee on State...
A sustained first-half attack enabled Leitrim to defeat Mayo, 10 to 7, in a Gaelic football game at Innisfail Park yesterday before a crowd of 4,000.
The persecution of the Jews in Germany is a reversion to savagery or to the Dark Ages, John Haynes Holmes told the congregation of the Community Church yesterday morning in the Town Hall, 128...

ALBANY, April 9.--The first quarter of 1933 showed a decrease of 373 new stock corporations from the number for the same period in 1932, according to the report of Secretary of State Edward...
A new technique for the early discovery and treatment of lateral curvature of the spine resulting from infantile paralysis was announced yesterday by the Information Bureau of the United Hospital...

An attack on the campaign for compulsory social insurance, with specific reference to the pending compulsory unemployment Insurance and minimum wage measures in this State, was voiced at the school of politics of the Women's National Republican Club yesterday by Merwin K. Hart, president of the New York State Economic Council.

ALBANY, April 10 -- Police Commissioner Edward P. Mulrooney of New York City will head the new State Alcoholic Beverages Control Board. Governor Lehman, following the passage of his beer control bill in the Senate and Assembly late today, announced that he had asked Commissioner Mulrooney to accept the position, that Mr. Mulrooney had accepted, and that he would be formally appointed as soon as the bill had received the Governor's signature and become law.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., April 10 -- The committee on the regulation of athletic sports at Harvard today discussed a proposal to have the Crimson join the Eastern Intercollegiate Baseball League. Following the meeting, William J. Bingham, chairman and athletic director, said an announcement of Harvard's decision would be made tomorrow morning.

The naming of a peninsula far up in the northwest of Alaska and east of Bering Strait in honor of the late LEONARD D. BALDWIN because he had been so prominent in aiding the Government to establish a reindeer industry has been announced by the Geographic Board.

PARIS, April 10 -- The French Council of Ministers approved today the texts of the memorandum and pact in reply to the Italian and British proposals for a four-power agreement. They have been telegraphed to Ambassadors de Jouvenel in Rome and Fleuriau in London, but will not be published any more than were the original Italian proposition or the British version.

The plan for prompt payment In full of depositors of the closed Harriman National Bank and Trust Company, announced late Sunday night by Secretary of the Treasury Woodin, is based on the belief that the bank has a valid claim for assistance against the New York Clearing House Association, it was indicated yesterday.

WASHINGTON, April 10 -- Mrs. Roosevelt endorsed today the position taken by Miss Frances Perkins, Secretary of Labor, on the question of employment of married women, and further declared that it would be a "very bad and very foolish thing" to set up as a standard for retention or dismissal either the marital status of an employe or the number of other members of the family on a government payroll.

DESENZANO, Lake Garda, Italy, April 10 -- After two years of unremitting effort, in which several pilots have lost their lives, Italy broke today the world's speed record for seaplanes, hitherto held for Britain by Lieutenant George H. Stainforth, when a seaplane flashed three times in both directions over a measured course of three kilometers here at an average speed of 423.7 miles an hour.

Babe Ruth, suffering from a slight cold and still nursing a sore throat which has been aggravating him for more than a week, remained confined in his West Eighty-eighth Street apartment yesterday, but nevertheless expressed confidence that he would be in the Yankee line-up when the world's champions open the season at the Stadium against the Red Sox tomorrow.

Unfilled orders of the United States Steel Corporation were 1,841,002 tons on March 31, compared with 1,854,200 on Feb. 28, a decrease of 13,198 tons, it was announced yesterday. Although the total was a new low record, the decrease was much smaller than Wall Street had expected and the figures were regarded as highly encouraging.

Prices rallied briskly yesterday in all departments of the bond market on the Stock Exchange. Traders took cognizance of the generally favorable news over the week-end, notably the plans to resuscitate world trade, the program of public works to aid the unemployed instead of through out-and-out relief funds, and, sentimentally, at least, the assurances in connection with one weak link in New York City's banking situation.
BERLIN, April 10 -- The Reichsbank statement as of April 7 shows the following changes in reichsmarks:

WASHINGTON, April 10 -- President Roosevelt in a special message urged Congress to provide for development of the Tennessee River basin and Muscle Shoals and held a night conference on the railroad situation.

BOSTON, April 10 -- Captain Eugene E. O'Donnell, president of the Eastern Steamship Lines, who had been in a critical condition in the Cardinal O'Connell House of St. Elizabeth's Hospital, Brighton, since undergoing an operation for appendicitis on Thursday, died tonight of peritonitis.

A Federal court jury of eleven men who began deliberating at 3:20 P.M. yesterday on the question of whether James J. McCormick, Deputy Clrk in charge of the Marriage License Bureau, who received $69,000 in tips from bridegrooms in 1929 and 1930, was guilty of income tax fraud, returned a sealed verdict at 10:30 o'clock last night.

The recent recount of the votes cast in the Bronx last November was characterized as a "mere fishing expedition" yesterday by the January term of the Bronx grand jury, which asserted in a presentment that its own investigation had proved to have been unjustified.

PRINCETON, N.J., April 10 -- A three-run rally in the ninth inning enabled Vermont to conquer the Princeton nine, 6 to 4, on University Field today. Palmer drove home two runs with a double to right-centre and counted later on an infield error to settle the issue.

WASHINGTON, April 10 -- As a result of the government's intensive (campaign, $460,766,892 in gold and gold certificates were returned to the Treasury and Federal Reserve Banks during March, according to figures issued today.
ALBANY, April 10 -- Outstanding provisions of the new beer-control bill, as passed by the Legislature here today, are as follows:

SHANGHAI, April 10 -- Increasing evidence that Japan plans a natural move for consolidating the strategic safety of Manchuria and Jehol and for cutting Russian access to the Gulf of Po by ultimately controlling the Peiping-Suiyuan Railway is emphasized in foreign advices from Kalgan declaring Japanese and Manchukuoan agents have been busy for months in conversation with ten Mongol tribes, trying to arrange for Chahar Province to join Jehol.

WASHINGTON, April 10 (AP) -- Among the dozen other cases decided, the court granted a review to Richard Reid Rogers, a stock-holder in the American Tobacco Company, to test the validity of a by-law adopted by the stockholders of the company in 1912 under which 10 per cent of the net profits over about $8,000,000 were made payable to the president and each of the five vice presidents.

The Continental Oil Company reports for 1932 a consolidated net loss of $1,444,133 after all charges and reserves, including a writedown in inventories of $1,553,223 in order to put values at market or lower. Net income from operations, after excluding $9,739 applicable to minority interests was $109,089.

PARIS, April 10 -- Former Premier Edouard Harriot's role at the White House talks in Washington will be that of "an observer and an informant." He will go without official investiture as a Minister of State.
WASHINGTON, April 10 (AP) -- Senator Norris'a measure is to follow closely the general outline of the legislation he has sponsored for several years.
NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., April 10 -- The "army" of 1,791 workmen who reported to Fort Slocum last night for work under President Roosevelt's reforestation plan dwindled by 257 today.

WASHINGTON, April 10 -- The Supreme Court, returning today from a two-week recess, handed down a decision that Bishop James Cannon Jr. and Miss Ada L. Burroughs, his secretary, could not resort to a legal technicality in their fight against the indictment accusing them of conspiracy to violate the Federal Corrupt Practices Act.

Hitler is like a Hawalian surf board rider, cleverly keeping his place on the crest of a rising wave of nationalism, the Rev. Everett R. Clinchy, director of the National Conference of Jews and Christians and author of "The Strange Case of Mr. Hitler," said yesterday at a luncheon of Advertising Men's Post 209 of the American Legion at the Western Universities Club, 500 Fifth Avenue.

GANGTOK, Sikkim, India, April 10 (By Runner From Kampa Dzong) -- The Mt. Everest climbing expedition arrived at Kampa Dzong on March 29, thus completing more than the exposed half of the march to Everest. We crossed the Tibetan frontier by the Natu Pass, more than 14,000 feet high.

Justice Edward R. Koch of the City Court in the Bronx was notified by telephone yesterday by Governor Lehman that he had been appointed a justice of the Supreme Court to succeed the late Justice Peter A. Hatting, who died Feb. 28.

In a stirring appeal, quite without precedent in professional baseball, John A. Heydler, president of the National League, yesterday addressed a statement to all the players in his circuit warning them that the championship season ahead may see the popularity of baseball put to the acid test and urging upon all to bend every effort to retain the public's interest in the game.

BUENOS AIRES, April 10 -- Well-Informed sources report new coolness between the ABC-Peru group and the Commission of Neutrals in Washington and express frank pessimism as to the settlement of the Chaco conflict between Bolivia and Paraguay through ABC-Peru mediation, although hope is held for an armistice by Good Friday.

LANSING, Mich., April 10 -- Carrying out the mandate of the votes which elected them a week ago, the hundred delegates of the Michigan Constitutional Convention by a vote of 99 to 1 put their State on record today as the first in the Union to ratify repeal of the Eighteenth Amendment.

TORONTO, April 10 -- The Toronto Maple Leafs are prepared to wage a desperate battle in an endeavor to prevent the New York Rangers from relieving them of the Stanley Cup and the world's professional hockey championship.

WASHINGTON, April 10 -- William Gorham Rice, Civil Service Commissioner of New York, is slated for appointment as Minister to Holland, and Breckenridge Long of Missouri, a former Assistant Secretary of State, will be Ambassador to Rome.
Two housing parcels in Hoboken were included in the New Jersey realty turnover reported yesterday.

Supreme Court Justice McCook heard argument and reserved decision yesterday on the application by several hundred owners of real estate mortgage bonds sold by S. W. Straus Co., for the appointment of a receiver for all the defaulted Straus properties, on the ground that the interest of the bondholders will not be protected otherwise.

Moscow Locks Stable. The Third International authorities at Moscow have called upon the German working class to rise against the Hitler Government. In preparation the German Communists are advised to form a united front with the Socialists.

LONDON, April 10 -- Posters urging a boycott of German goods because of the Nazi persecution of Jews, which were removed yesterday at the request of the local police, were returned to the windows of Jewish shops in London's East End today.

Details of a conference held on last Wednesday by George S. Van Schaick, Superintendent of Insurance, with officials of the Globe and Rutgers Fire Insurance Company and members of the organization committee of that concern were made known yesterday when Supreme Court Justice Glennon refused to vacate an order signed on last Thursday directing the reinsurance of certain Globe and Rutgers risks.

MOSCOW, April 10 -- The Soviet Government continues to maintain the reserve about foreign affairs that has characterized its policy ever since the Japanese invaded Manchuria. This does not mean that foreign events are not reported in the Soviet press, but simply that editorial comment or the expression of views by an official spokesman is virtually non-existent.
BOSTON, April 10 -- The Boston Red Sox beat the Boston College Eagles, 9 -- 2, today in their final practice game before the opening in New York against the Yankees on Wednesday.

In the most active market since March 15 leading stocks gained 1 to 4 points yesterday as encouraging news was received in Wall Street from many fields. Commodities also rose sharply under the leadership of wheat.
Tributes were paid yesterday by his contemporaries to the life-work of Dr. Henry van Dyke.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., April 10 -- The body of Rear Admiral William A. Moffett, chief of the Navy Bureau of Aeronautics, was recovered from the sea today by the Coast Guard boat Daphne, which found it floating off Beach Haven, N.J., about ten miles from the scene of, the destruction of the dirigible Akron last Tuesday morning.

BERLIN, April 10 -- The first public protest from any part of Germany against the bitter suffering which has been inflicted wholesale upon certain classes of public servants and professional men who have not deserved it was heard today.

The air breathed by New York City dwellers in March was cleaner than during any other month since May, 1932, it was said yesterday by David R. Morris, meteorologist at the Federal Weather Bureau Observatory in Central Park. Flying dirt, smoke and soot averaged but nine-tenths of a ton to the cubicmile.

Jim McGloskey, rookie right-hander, held New York University to six hits and became the first pitcher to go the route for Jersey City this Spring as the International Leagruers defeated the collegians, 9 to 1, in an exhibition game at West Side Park, Jersey City, yesterday.

"Children's Books of Yesterday" is the title of an exhibition which will open in the main exhibition room of the Public Library this morning. There will be about 500 books, manuscripts, drawings, -woodcuts, prints, cards and games on show, some of them more than 400 years old.

MINEOLA, L.I., April 10 -- A committee to study a proposal for the revival of the Vanderbilt Cup automobile road races, the last of which was held in Nassau County twenty-three years ago, was appointed today by the county Board of Supervisors, James L. Dowsey, Republican leader of North Hempstead, who presented the proposal, suggested the races as a means of obtaining funds for unemployment relief.

An old trail that had led government agents on long journeys to many countries came to an end last night when a deputy United States marshal arrested Jacob Krietz, alias Kasvier Augustus Szpokas, when the Dollar liner President Adams anchored at the Quarantine station off Rosebank, S.I.

LAKEHURST, April 10 -- A dark, rain-filled control car, open windows through which the winds that buffeted the Akron tore at men's uniforms, the darkness shattered by constant and vivid flashes of lightning, men standing calmly at their posts or peering into the night-all the repressed tragedy of the last hour of the great airship was unfolded today before the naval court of inquiry by gray-haired Lieut. Commander Herbert V. Wiley.

Money market continued easy at the opening of business in the new week. Stock Exchange call money was 1 1/2 per cent, the lowest for standing loans since early in March. Street trades were done at 1, and Federal funds, 1/8. Five-six months' money dropped to 1@1 1/4 per cent., a decline of 1/4; earlier maturities were offered at 1, but demand was light.

After a heated discussion, the Presbytery of New York, at its annual Spring meeting yesterday in the Parish House of the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church, at Fiftyfifth Street, adopted unanimously a resolution criticizing the verdict in the Scottsboro case at Decatur, Ala., on Sunday, which reconvicted Haywood Patterson of an attack on two white girls.
WHITE SULPHUR. SPRINGS, W.Va., April 10 (AP) -- John B. Ryerson of Cooperstown, N.Y., posted a 72 to lead the qualifying field in the annual Mason and Dixon golf tournament by seven strokes today.

The Strollers, an organization with a roster replete with distinguished names, which was formed forty-seven years ago and was noted for its amateur theatrical performances, has been dissolved. However, the luxurious quarters the club has had for a number of years on the fourth floor of the Hotel Delmonico, Park Avenue and Fifty-ninth Street, will not be vacant long because the New York Club, the second oldest in the city, will move in without delay.
CINCINNATI, April 10 (AP) -- The process of getting that extra "shot" of energy for split-second action in emergencies was described to the American Physiological Society today.

Passover, which commemorates the emancipation of the Jews from Egyptian slavery, was ushered in at sundown last night and will continue until a week from tomorrow. The celebration began last night with the seder, the Passover feast in homes and institutions.
WEST POINT, N.Y., April 10 -- The New York Yankees paid their annual visit to West Point today and exacted their annual tribute from the Army nine, defeating the Cadets, 9 -- 0.

Alfred Mond, who once promised that he would work ruthlessly to build up a fortune of $70,000,000 with which to bring the Jews back to Palestine and who was one of the world's great Zionist leaders although his children had been brought up as Christians, is pictured against a thorough background of family inheritance in Hector Bolitho's "Alfred Mond, First Lord Melchett," just published by Appleton.

LEXINGTON, Ky., April 10 -- J. C. Milam's Kentucky Derby candidate, Captain Red, led home a field of five over the short six furlongs of the Futurity course to win the Providence Farm Purse, feature today at Lexington. C.W. Moore's Scream, beaten a half length, was second, three lengths ahead of the third-place Nyack.

Employment in New York State factories declined 3.6 per cent in March, due primarily to the banking holiday, it was announced yesterday by Industrial Commissioner Elmer F. Andrews. The normal seasonal rise in March is 1 per cent.
TOKYO, Tuesday, April 11 (AP) -- The War Office announced Japanese forces had completed the occupation of Lengkow, a Great Wall pass north of Keinchangying, at 7 A.M. today.

The United States Shipping Board will not take back the liner Leviathan at this time, it was indicated yesterday. The ship will sail from New York April 25 for a round-trip voyage to Plymouth, Cherbourg and Bremen, according to an announcement by P.V.G. Mitchell, vice president of the Roosevelt Steamship Company, general agent of the United States Lines.

WASHINGTON, April 10 -- The authority of the Interstate Commerce Commission is paramount in requiring the Long Island Railroad to operate over the tracks of, and share in, the facilities of the Pennsylvania Tunnel and Terminal Railroad Company, the Supreme Court held today in an opinion adverse to the Transit Commission and New York State.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The apocalyptic reference in your editorial of April 7 must have impressed many. May I remind any of your readers who have not yet devoted much attention to biblical prophecy that "the end of the world" means in this connection the end of the Age, of this period, and not the destruction of the planet or even the end of the world's history?

LONDON, April 10 -- There was a keen debate in the House of Commons today when criticism of the proposed joint select committee on Indian constitutional reform was strongly urged and strongly rebutted. Finally the government won the day and the following sixteen members of the House of Commons were appointed:

LONDON, April 10 -- Prime Minister MacDonald was asked in the House of Commons today if he intended to discuss in his forthcoming talks with President Roosevelt Great Britain's return to the gold standard, and if he would give assurance before going to the United States that the wishes of Parliament would be ascertained before any action, was taken in that matter.

A final report was issued yesterday by the Laura Spelman Rockefeller Memorial, founded by John D. Rockefeller in memory of his wife, which was active from 1922 until 1929, when it was consolidated with the Rockefeller Foundation.

The flounder fishermen who have been working the waters of Great South Bay report that they never have seen better fish of this species than can be taken light now. Big runs are in the bay and the flounders now are heading for deeper water, working into the ship channels and into the areas where there is sand bottom.

BOSTON, April 10 -- Edward Cabot Storrow, partner in the cotton brokerage firm of Charles Storrow Co., and a well-known sportsman, died yesterday at the Peter Bent Brigham Hospital, after a long illness.

General buoyancy prevailed in the local commodity markets yesterday, as prices for all staples went to higher levels in relatively quiet trading. Silver was very strong, while rubber and cocoa also closed with good gains. Sugar, coffee, silk and hides all finished higher.

The New York Curb Exchange announced yesterday that it had "removed from dealings" Continental Shares, Inc., preferred stock, Series B, with a par value of $100, and convertible preferred stock with a par value of $100, and Mississippi Valley Utilities Investment.
Closing their exhibition season at Ebbets Field yesterday, Max Carey's Dodgers romped through eleven hilarious innings against the Athletics, finally winning, 7 to 6, to the delight of 4,000 fans.

WASHINGTON, April 10 -- The United States should enter negotiations on world economics with "clean hands" and admitted recognition of the "self-evident condition resulting from our impossible tariff situation," Secretary of Commerce Roper said tonight in a radio address over the National Broadcasting Company's system and Station WOR of Newark.

Homer S. Cummings, Attorney General of the United States, paid a formal call yesterday afternoon upon Federal Attorney George Z. Medalie at the Federal Building and expressed full confidence in Mr. Medalie and indicated clearly that the local prosecutor, even though he is a Republican, can hold his position as long as he wishes and can proceed with a free hand.

Prices on the Cotton Exchange recovered yesterday to the high levels made last week and ended 3 to 5 points higher than on Saturday. Strength in other markets and more optimism in trade and financial circles stimulated buying on all recessions.
You can never make a country great and splendid if within it you oppress and exploit part of the people.

The Legislature of 1933 had to deal with an emergency. The long-continued depression brought evils in its train many of which could not be cured without legislation, however impracticable it might prove to cure them by legislation alone.

NEWARK, N.J., April 10 -- The distinction of being the first city in New Jersey to fill its quota of enlistments in the Citizens' Conservation Corps was accorded to Newark today in a telegram from the United States Department of Labor. Under the auspices of the State Emergency Relief Administration the quota of 500 men from this city was filled this morning and the last detachments sent to Fort Hancock and Camp Dix.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, April 10 -- Finish was written to the thirty-third annual American Bowling Congress tournament tonight as the last squads of doubles and singles out-of-town pinsters failed in their efforts to topple the leaders on the wind-up card.

George Bernard Shaw, who boasted for years that he never would visit America, will arrive in New York this morning and spend twenty-six hours here. The Empress of Britain, on which Mr. and Mrs. Shaw are making a world cruise, is expected to dock at Pier 61, at the foot of West Twenty-first Street, at 10 A.M. and sail again for England tomorrow noon.

A fashion show in which debutantes of Westchester acted as models opened yesterday a benefit sale at Arnold Constable's for the Children's Village at Dobbs Ferry, which will be continued today with Mrs. Curtis B. Dall, daughter of President Roosevelt, "taking a turn" as saleswoman and manager this afternoon.

A dozen leaders in progressive education, meeting last night at the New School for Social Research, 66 West Twelfth Street, expressed the general view that progressive schools needed more guidance for the children, more discipline, more attention to developing consideration for others, more emphasis on the relation to society, and especially a closer relationship between the school and the parents.

The New York Central Railroad has become the largest taxpayer among railroads, F.E. Williamson, president, said yesterday. He gave the company's tax total for 1932 as $30,083,642, the burden of which he said was a handicap.

The verdict in the Scottsboro case was condemned sharply here yesterday as "worthy of Hitler," "lynch justice," "blind, racial prejudice," "vicious" and as an obstacle in the way of interracial understanding, while plans were being made for two mass meetings to protest against the outcome of the Alabama trial.

Ignace Jan Paderewski, with the princely generosity which is one of his characteristics, gave his services as soloist last night in the Metropolitan Opera House in order to aid the members of the Musicians Symphony Orchestra of unemployed players.

Mr. ROOSEVELT'S message to Congress yesterday shows that his zeal for the development of the Tennessee Valley has not abated. The United States has put $150,000,000 into Muscle Shoals. This "national investment" must not be suffered to remain idle.

Pre-Easter Volume Subsides. A fair volume of quick delivery orders from near-by stores was received in the market here yesterday, following the excellent retail activity Saturday. For the most part, however, retailers are centring their attention on moving current stocks of ready-to-wear during the next few days.

As a result of the refusal by the State Senate yesterday to pass the Crawford-Wallace bill to legalize betting, racing in New York State will be curtailed during the coming season, it was stated yesterday by William "Wood-ward, chairman of the stewards of the Jockey Club.

Continued recovery on the Stock Exchange yesterday indicated that there had been no impairment of confidence over the week-end. The most recent developments in business and industry were distinctly favorable, even to the extent that improvement has been carried beyond seasonal expectations.

WASHINGTON, April 10 -- Development of the Tennessee Valley, with completion of the Muscle Shoals power project a small but vital part, was urged upon Congress today by President Roosevelt in a Special message.

WASHINGTON, April 10 -- A $2,200,000,000 home mortgage relief bill, which is said to embody the administration's views, has been worked out by a Senate Banking and Currency subcommittee and will probably be introduced tomorrow or Wednesday.
WASHINGTON, April 10 -- The Bureau of Navigation issued the following orders today, dated April 7:

PARIS, April 10 (AP) -- A comprehensive propaganda organization, aimed at making France known in her "true ligrht," has been proposed by Deputy Adrien Dariac in a report on the foreign affairs budget.

WASHINGTON, April 10 -- Federal employes who develop inventions need not assign the patents to the United States nor grant the government exclusive rights unless specifically assigned to work out the inventions concerned, the Supreme Court ruled today in the suit of the government against the Dubilier Condenser Corporation.

WASHINGTON, April 10 -- Only emergency railroad legislation, intended to effect economies, will be attempted by the administration in the special session of Congress, it was virtually agreed tonight at a White House conference.

What is described by Dr. Francis Carter Wood, director of the Institute of Cancer Research, Columbia University, as "an extremely hopeful discovery" in cancer research, giving practical assurance to millions the world over that cancer is not hereditary, is reported today in the current issue of the American Journal of Cancer, of which Dr. Wood is the editor.

President ROOSEVELT'S curt dismissal of the suggestion that we might solve our troubles by "printing money" was hardly needed as evidence that the danger of inflation and depreciation of the currency -- if such danger ever actually existed -- is now definitely past.

BERLIN, April 10 -- The Boerse was listless today and quotations were irregular, fluctuating under chance influences. In the course of the day stocks tended to sag generally, but the volume of offerings was small and losses were held within moderate limits.

Plans for the organization of a tambourine brigade of 5,000 men and women to aid in raising funds in the Salvation Army United Appeal were announced yesterday by Miss Gertrude Robinson-Smith, chairman of the appeal's popular donation committee, with headquarters at the Plaza Hotel.

The Museum of Modern Art will open privately today and to the public tomorrow an exhibition of the work of young architects of the Middle West. The show comprises plans, models and photographs of single dwellings as well as housing projects, all designed in the so-called international style.
PALM BEACH, Fla., April 10 -- at Casa del Pastor, her home here, Mrs. John Shepard Jr. was hostess today to several guests for luncheon.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., April 10 -- American universities should strive to produce a new and better informed type of business leader, Dean Wallace B. Donham of the Harvard School of Business, said tonight in an address which marked the opening of a celebration of the twenty-fifth anniversary of the school.
To the Editor of The New York Times: It is evident from the letter of Dr. William O. Douglas, Professor of the Law of Corporation Finance of Yale University, published in THE TIMES of April 9, that

BASKING RIDGE, N.J., April 10 -- Coming through a stirring competition and improving as he went. The Coming Storm won a notable victory today for Udo M. Fleischmann of New York City in the open all-age stake, principal event of the annual Spring field trials of the Jockey Hollow Field Club, which opened today.

IT was Sunday afternoon at the Polo Grounds and the lone occupant of the Giant dugout was a fellow as big and as brown as a Kadiak bear. It was Pancho Snyder, who caught for McGraw's championship teams of 1921-24 and is now a coach under Manager Bill Terry.

Improved conditions in Manhattan's real estate market were reflected yesterday in the purchase for close to $1,000,000 of the south-west corner of Sixth Avenue and Forty-seventh Street by Benjamin Winter, one of the very few operators active a couple of years ago who are still in the field.
NEW YORK. Mr. and Mrs. Charles E. Merrill of the Carlyle have gone to Tucson, Ariz. Shortly after returning to New York they will go to Southampton.

The winners of seven bronze medals and six honorable mentions in the twelfth annual exhibition of the Art Directors Club, which will be opened today at the Art Centre, 65 East Fifty-sixth Street, were announced yesterday by Joseph B. Platt, chairman of the exhibition committee.

President Roosevelt was praised as a "chief worthy of America" by Paul Claudel, retiring French Ambassador, at a dinner given in his honor last night at the Ritz-Carlton by Franco-American organizations here.

ABOARD THE EMPRESS OF BRITAIN, April 10 -- Pacing the deck and clutching a manuscript, George Bernard Shaw today discussed acting after a brilliant performance in a talking movietone directed by himself.
CHICAGO, April 10 -- A schism in the ranks of the Federal Reserve System loomed tonight over the allotment of new issues of United States Government short-term securities.
But now farewell. I am going a long way

Four children, unaccompanied, arrived on the Scandinavian-American liner United States yesterday to rejoin their father, Jacob Larsen of 758 Forty-eighth Street, Brooklyn. They have been away from the United States for two years and spoke little English on their return.

CHICAGO, April 10 -- Sharply higher wheat prices are expected by the trade tomorrow at the opening of the Board of Trade because of the sensationally bullish construction placed on the government estimate on the Winter crop, issued today after the close of the markets.
Fordham University's baseball team renewed relations with the New York Giants yesterday after almost a decade and lost to the National Leaguers, 7 to 0, at Fordham Field.

BASLE, Switzerland, April 10 -- All doubt whether the United States is still on the gold standard ended officially today as far as the world's chief central banks are concerned. Their governors and other members of the World Bank Board, at their monthly meeting this morning, authorized the Bank for International Settlements to resume dealing in dollars normally as in other gold currencies.

Faithful to the tradition that the show must go on, the circus continued in Madison Square Garden yesterday. There were indications that the strain of the hectic opening week-end and of a golden jubilee celebration besides, had been severe.

WASHINGTON, April 10 -- President Roosevelt and a considerable section of official Washington are preparing to "bench" grave governmental problems for a couple of hours Wednesday while the American League pennant chase gets under way here.

A peaceful meeting of Negroes at Union Square yesterday, called to protest the verdict in the Scottsboro case, developed into a running fight along Broad-way for miles with policemen thrown to the ground and trampled and Negroes becoming acquainted with scores of nightsticks before it was over.

PITTSBURGH, April 10 -- Malachi (Max) Leslie died late last night after a long illness. Known as Pittsburgh's "maker of Mayors, he had taken part in a score or more bitter political feuds in forty-six years of public life.

MADRID, April 10 -- Professor Albert Einstein [who refuses to return to his home in Germany because of anti-Semitism] has accepted the chair of Research Professor of Science at Madrid University, it was officially announced today by the Minister of Public Instruction, Fernando de Los Rios.

ROME, April 10 -- Hard upon the heels of Vice Chancellor von Papen, who arrived in Rome from Berlin yesterday and was received by Premier Mussolini today. Chancellor Hitler's right-hand man, Captain Hermann Goering, arrived by airplane from Munich early this afternoon.

BERLIN, April 10 -- A law promulgated by the government today establishes the framework of uniform nation-wide regulations defining the status of Jewish lawyers in Germany between now and October. It carries the presumption that more generous counsels may prevail over the sweeping exclusion spirit of recent enactments by subordinate authorities, all of which are annulled by this new Federal gesture.
Fifty-nine awards have been made to members of three varsity teams at City College, according to an announcement yesterday by Professor "Walter Williamson, director of athletics.

ALBANY, April 10 -- The 156th session of the Legislature adjourned sine die at 4:32 o'clock this afternoon after a day that began with exciting conflict between the two houses, but ended with the fatigued members greeting the final gavel in tame fashion.

Josephine Travado, 15 years old, died early this morning from severe burns and from smoke she inhaled when fire swept the four-story tenement house in which she lived at 346 Third Avenue. Three others, the girl's mother and father and a fireman summoned to assist in the rescue of twenty trapped tenants, were injured.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Since 1929, when prices began to fall so fast, I have often recalled the interesting evening, about 1926, when it was all predicted at a little dinner party in Villanova, Pa., by the well-known English author and Member of Parliament who has since become Sir Norman Angell.

A luncheon in behalf of the women's division of the Federation for the Support of Jewish Philanthropic Societies, of which Mrs. Sidney C. Borg is chairman, will be given on April 19 at the Commodore. After the luncheon the annual meeting and election of officers will take place, to be followed by a symposium on "Social Service in a Changing World."

WASHINGTON, April 10 -- After having extended to eleven its original list of four or live nations to be invited to the "Washington conversations," beginning April 21, the administration finds itsell pressed, for various reasons, to increase the group to a dozen or more.

WASHINGTON, April 10 -- Following is the text of the message which President Roosevelt sent to Congress today recommending that provision be made for the further development of the Tennessee River basin and Muscle Shoals:

WASHINGTON, April 10 -- Authority to borrow an additional $1,500,000 from the Reconstruction Finance Corporation for meeting fixed interest obligations due May 1 was sought by the Erie Railroad Company today in an application filed with the Interstate Commerce Commission.

WASHINGTON, April 10 -- Representative Byrns, Democratic leader in the House, announced today that from now on until the end of the special session it will proceed at top speed to complete the enactment of the Roosevelt national rehabilitation program.
WASHINGTON, April 10 -- A Winter wheat crop of about 334,087,000 bushels, the lowest since 1904, was predicted by the Department of Agriculture today on the basis of April 1 conditions.

The Intercollegiate Disarmament Council, with headquarters at 14 East Forty-first Street, announced yesterday that it had begun a national poll to determine how the students in 730 colleges throughout the country feel about the question of participating in war.

Edward P. Mulrooney, named head of the State Alcoholic Beverage Control Board by Governor Lehman, will resign today as Police Commissioner. Mayor O'Brien, according to the best information obtainable last night, has not yet decided on his successor.
To the Editor of The New York Times: George Bernard Shaw is making his first visit to this country. However, he already knows all about us -- he says. As witness:
LONDON, April 10 -- The British Government issued, a second White Paper tonight concerning the case of the accused British engineers in Russia.

CHICAGO, April 10 -- Demand for hogs today was not aggressive and prices were steady to 10 cents a hundred weight lower than on Saturday, the level being the lowest since March 2 and 25 to 35 cents under the figures of a week ago. Packers reported the call for fresh pork as slow.

All markets found encouragement yesterday in the expanding volume of domestic business and in the energetic efforts that are being directed from Washington looking to the reduction of unemployment and to the rebuilding of foreign commerce.

ALBANY, April 10 -- Ignoring urgent messages from Governor Lehman in the closing moments of the session, the Legislature today scrapped two items in the public utility regulation program which were sought by the Chief Executive of the State.

WASHINGTON, April 10 -- Demands for currency inflation in connection with farm relief legislation came from two distinct sources today as a reluctant Senate plodded through debate on the proposed bill.

Registration licenses of 1932 for buses and trucks in this State, extended several times while the Legislature debated repeal of the 65 per cent surtax on these vehicles, will expire at midnight tonight, officials of the Bureau of Motor Vehicles announced yesterday.

As citizens of New Jersey swung into the first week of their return to beer-drinking traditions, several sharp discords were sounded over the problems of the manufacture, distribution and sale of the beverage. With the first brewery strike of the new era continuing in Newark, officials at the Hudson River border for several hours faced a problem resulting from the refusal of New Tork brewers to pay State taxes in New Jersey.

The preferred stockholders' committee of the International Combustion Engineering Corporation voted unanimously yesterday to oppose the plan for reorganizing the company involving the sale of its properties to International Combustion, Inc., it was announced by E.M. Bacon, secretary.

New York Central. The New York Central hag reported a net loss of $2,150,348 in February, one of the largest recent deficits to be reported by the road and one which came after a period of improved returns. Net loss for January and February was $3,875,810, against a net loss of $1,712,427 in the same period last year. Reports of that rad and its subsidiaries follow:

Alexis Kleinmeier, detective, who for twenty-eight years was a member of the police force, died on Sunday at the home of a daughter, Mrs. Alice Grant, at 122 Stewart Street, Floral Park, L.I. He had been ill for many months and was in his fifty-sixth year.

Cutting in half the interest rates announced for member banks just before the banking holiday, the New York Clearing House Association issued yesterday a new schedule for demand and time deposits. In the course of the day, also, call money on the New York Stock Exchange dropped to the lowest rate since early in March.
PINEHURST, N.C., April 10 -- The drive for berths on this year's United States Davis Cup team was inaugurated today with the start of the fifteenth, annual North and South tennis championship.

The need for men of principle and conviction, with courage, ability and vision, in journalism and in the ministry was emphasized yesterday by Bishop William T. Manning at the annual exercises commemorating the birthday of Joseph Pulitzer, founder of the School of Journalism of Columbia University, held in the journalism building on the campus.

ALBANY, April 10 --The Republican-controlled Assembly in its closing moments killed a bill sought by Mayor O'Brien to provide for a central purchasing bureau for New York City as the Democrats in the Senate sounded the death-knell of the Desmond-Moffat bill to permit election of charter revision commissions.

KANSAS CITY, April 10 (AP) -- Conrad H. Mann, civic leader here, whose sentence in the Eagle lottery conspiracy case was affirmed in New York by the Circuit Court of Appeals today, said he would appeal to the United States Supreme Court. He declined to comment further.

While the brewers of the city struggled to supply the unprecedented demand for beer and the Department of Health issued 4,475 additional beer permits bringing the total up to 21,060, representing $301,215 in revenue. Mayor O'Brien conferred yesterday with Arthur J. W. Hilly, Corporation Counsel, and was informed that the regulatory measures of the Department of Health were in conflict with the new State beer-control bill.
WASHINGTON, April 10 -- Representatives are going to have their 3.2 per cent beer within easy reach, but matters of economy may keep it out of the House cloakrooms.

Dr. Charles O. Paullin of Washington and Dr. John Kirtland Wright of New York, author and editor, respectively, of the "Atlas of the Historical Geography of the United States," have won the Loubat prize of $1,000, presented every five years for the "best work printed and published in the English language on the history, geography, ethnology, philology or numismatics of North America."

Joseph W. Harriman, so ill apparently that he had to be taken to the Federal Building in a private ambulance and rolled into a court room in a wheel chair, pleaded not guilty yesterday to an, indictment charging him with responsibility for false entries totaling $1,713,225 in the books of the closed Harriman National Bank and Trust Company.

GENEVA, April 10 -- In striking contrast to the distrust and uneasiness aroused here by Premier Mussolini's efforts to hold a four-power meeting in Rome, President Roosevelt's invitation to the same four powers to meet in Washington has aroused more confidence in international circles here than any move in a long time.

WASHINGTON, April 10 -- Drastic regulation of short selling on Stock Exchanges is proposed in a bill introduced by Senator Borah today as a prelude to a measure which he said will cover the entire field of trading in securities.

W. Kingsland Macy, chairman of the Republican State Committee, at a meeting of the Republican Committee of One Hundred in the Savoy-Plaza yesterday, reviewed some of the problems facing his party in the State and city. He reiterated his warning that Tammany methods would become prevalent up-State unless the party was vigilant.

ALBANY, N.Y., April 11 (AP). -- With the deadline on income tax payments only four days away, the Income Tax Bureau today prepared to handle the rush of the last minute filing, of which there are many thousands.

Restrictions on loans on insurance policies and their surrender for cash, under which the life insurance companies in this State have been operating for the last month, were again, modified yesterday by George S. Van Schaick, State Superintendent of Insurance.

Edward P. Mulrooney brought thirty-seven years of service in the Police Department to a close yesterday when he handed his resignation as commissioner to Mayor O'Brien. He expects to assume his new duties today as head of the State Beer and Wine Control Board, to which he has been appointed by Governor Herbert H. Lehman.

WASHINGTON, April 11 (AP). -- President Roosevelt and Robert Fechner, director of his emergency conservation program, today approved sites for fifty camps, all in national forests, where the first 10,000 men of the Conservation Corps will be put to work.

Patient effort, great mechanical skill and courage of the highest order were rewarded when the Italian air force, in the person of FRANCESCO AGELLO, wrested the world's record for speed in the air from Great Britain by sending a Machi seaplane over the measured three-kilometer course at Lake Garda six times for an average speed of 423.7 miles an hour.

THE starting pitcher at the Yankee Stadium this afternoon (weather permitting) will be Mayor John P. O'Brien, who will take a short wind-up and toss one to another deserving Democrat, Bill Dickey from the hard-biscuit region of Arkansas. After that Mayor O'Brien will sit down in the box and Don Vernon Gomez, the courtly Castilian left-hander, will take over the task of subjugating the visiting firemen from Boston.

WASHINGTON, April 11. -- A reduction of the postage rate on local "drop letters" from 3 to 2 cents appeared to be an immediate prospect on the eve of a meeting of the Ways and Means Committee to decide on what tax legislation should be submitted to the present special session of Congress.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., April 11. -- The Southern Association was off on its thirty-third campaign today under threatening skies, following a constant overnight rain which kept the attendance far below the level of other seasons.
To the Editor of The New York Times: THE TIMES on March 21 published the following:

PINEHURST, N.C., April 11. -- A 19-year-old Duke University freshman, Charles Harris of Palm Beach, Fla., brought about the first upset in the North and South tennis championship today "when he defeated Berkeley Bell of New York, eighth seeded player, in the third round, 3 -- 6, 9 -- 7, 6 -- 4.
WASHINGTON, April 11. -- Tempestuous debate of two hours' duration marked consideration of the administration's farm relief bill in the Senate today and the emergency farm mortgage bill in the House.

The International Hydro-Electric System reports for 1932 total revenue and other income amounting to $63,640,767, after net loss on exchange and including profit on bonds and other securities redeemed, comparing with $57,576,396 in 1931.

While a jury in General Sessions shortly after 6 o'clock last night was deliberating in an adjoining room a first-degree murder charge against Thomas Fitzgerald and John Groghan, each 19 years old, accused of killing a grocer in a hold-up on Dec. 8, both defendants unexpectedly offered guilty pleas to second-degree murder, which, promptly were accepted by Judge Corrigan.
George Bernard Shaw asked the captain of the Empress of Britain to protect him from the press on his arrival in New York yesterday, and the captain took him seriously.

ALBANY, April 11. -- Governor Lehman will sign the alcoholic beverage control bill tomorrow and former Police Commissioner Mulrooney of New York City, who will head the Alcoholic Beverage Control Board, os expected to witness the signing.

The first week of the Salvation Army's campaign to raise $1,110,000 to carry on its emergency relief and institutional aid activities has resulted in the raising of $126,1710.44 in gifts and pledges, it was announced yesterday at a report luncheon held in the Bankers Club.
BERLIN, April 11. -- Chancellor Hitler today appointed Captain Hermann Wilhelm Goering as Prussian Premier.

Sentiment in market circles appeared to have undergone no alteration yesterday as a result of the mild reaction which overtook the stock list. There was no aggressive selling, and for most of the afternoon the market simply drifted aimlessly, the profit-taking having been absorbed in the late forenoon.

Corporations applying to the New York Stock Exchange for the listing of new securities that have been sold to investors must disclose the net proceeds of the sale under a rule adopted by the committee on stock list.

WASHINGTON, April 11. -- Jesse H. Jones of Texas is slated for chairman of the board of directors of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation when the President fills the three Republican vacancies existing on the board, probably next week.

CHICAGO, April 11. -- With the worst reports of damage to the Winter wheat crop fully confirmed by the government's April estimate, there was a rush of buying of futures today on the Board of Trade which assumed huge proportions at the opening and again at the close.
One hundred and twenty-two insignia have been awarded to Columbia University students, it was announced yesterday by Robert F. Moore, assistant director of athletics.

Debutantes headed by Miss Barbara Leslie who are active in the arrangements for the Happy Days supper dance in behalf of the scholarship fund of the Floating University, to be held April 21 at Sherry's, are meeting this afternoon there to complete plans for the forthcoming benefit.

The Irving Trust Company, as trustee in bankruptcy for the International Match Corporation, was authorized yesterday by Oscar W. Ehrhorn, Federal referee, to make payment of $40,181 to Price, Waterhouse Co., accountants in the bankruptcy proceedings involving all the Kreuger Toll companies.

Tuesday, April 11, 1933. Fresh cuts in money costs continued in some sections of the money market. Sixty-day money was offered and done at 3/4 of 1 per cent, a new low for the post-bank holiday, while three to six months were traded at 1, a fractional shading from previous quotations.

Work on filling in the lower reservoir site in Central Park will begin this morning and is expected to be finished within thirty days. Mayor O'Brien said last night after a conference at City Hall with representatives of the Park Association and several department heads.
The text of George Bernard Shaw's speech at the Metropolitan Opera House last night follows: Mr. Chairman, Ladies and Gentlemen:

A contract for the construction of the main building of a group of four that will comprise the new American Students Social Centre in Paris, France, has been awarded to Hegeman-Harris Company Inc., according to advices from John W. Harris, treasurer of the firm, who arrived in Paris recently in connection with the company's work in erecting the new American Embassy Building now nearing completion in that city.

SEATTLE, Wash., April 11 (AP). -- A proposal to cut twenty-five years off the idle time of Pacific Northwest forests by using fir trees as soon as they are 15 years old to make white newsprint paper was made today by Professor H.K. Benson of the University of Washington.

WASHINGTON, April 11. -- The administration is studying the advisability of removing first and second-class postmasters from the requirements of examinations, Postmaster General Farley said today, following a discussion of this and patronage matters with the President.

WASHINGTON, April 11 (AP). -- Killed in a seven-story drop from a window of his hotel suite, the pajama-clad body of Paul B. King, 38-year-old son of Senator William H. King of Utah, was found tonight on the paved area-way outside the building.

Eleven important measures on Mr. ROOSEVELT'S program of legislation for the special session have still to he enacted. This list doesn't include the thirty-hour-week bill passed by the Senate on its own motion and enthusiasm. The foundling seems to be shut out from the White House, and Speaker RAINEY will have none of it.

BERLIN, April 11. -- While Hitler Government is playing its best diplomatic cards in Rome to win the tolerance if not the actual cooperation of some quarters in Europe, thus offsetting the outspoken hostility to its program and methods expressed by the nations still enjoying political freedom in full measure, certain indications of a more chastened spirit are observable here.

A white silk badge bearing the seal of the Soviet Government of Russia, with the statement that its bearer was thoroughly trustworthy, was offered as evidence yesterday to Garret W. Cotter, United States Commissioner to refute the contention of Jacob Kreitz, who was arrested here Monday as a principal in a passport fraud, that he was an American citizen.
