A trustee in bankruptcy for Brentano's, Inc., the world's largest retail book outlet, probably will be elected in about ten days, according to a statement just issued by the creditors' protective committee, of which Frank C. Dodd of Dodd, Mead, is chairman.

WASHINGTON, April 11 (AP). -- It was the understanding in Congressional circles after the conference today of President Roosevelt, Secretary Woodin and Senator Glass that the Chief Executive desired the all-inclusive banking reform measure be split into parts and enacted as a series of measures.

With the brewers swamped by orders and the Health Department working overtime to meet the rust of applicants for beer permits, New York City was quenching its thirst with a variety of brands of beer having an average alcoholic content of 2.7 by weight and 3.4 per cent by volume, according to the first report of the Bureau of Industrial Alcohol of the Treasury Department.

WASHINGTON, April 11. -- President Roosevelt intends to be fully armed for his discussions with foreign statesmen on economic questions preparatory to the world conference and to permit no obstacles in the foreign or domestic field to prevent the success of his conversations.

WASHINGTON, April 11. -- Reports that a decision had been made to reduce drastically the armed services of the country in the move for governmental economy were received in army and navy circles today with consternation.

Josef Hofmann's second New York recital of the season, which took place at the Town Hall last night, closed the series of five concerts for the benefit of that institution's endowment fund. He began with Saint-Saens's arrangement of music from Gluck's "Alceste" and Beethoven's Sonata, Opus 101.

BERLIN, April 11. -- Daniel Prenn, Germany's tennis hope, may not play on this year's Davis Cup team. There seems to be a double reason for barring the German ace -- he is a naturalized German of Polish birth and he is a Jew.
Nationally organized Negro defense of the nine Negroes involved in the Scottsboro case is being planned by New York leaders of the race.

The Association of the Bar of the City of New York put itself on record last night in a series of resolutions in favor of the major part of Samuel Seabury's recommendations for reforming the inferior court system of the city.

BASKING RIDGE, N.J., April 11. -- Two stakes were completed today in the annual Spring field trials of the Jockey Hollow Field Trial Club, the winner of the subscription junior all-age stake being the white and liver pointer dog. Floating Power, owned by Dr. William H. Wallingford of Princeton, W. Va., and handled by Robert D. Bevan.

The skyscraper era is closing and the tall buildings of today may be curiosities in the future, according to William Orr Ludlow, chairman of the committee in industrial relations of the American Institute of Architects.

A devil-fish, a three-ton whale shark, dozens of penguins and numerous rare specimens of tropical fish were some of the captures recorded on the log of Vincent Astor's yacht, Nourmahal, after President Roosevelt had debarked last February at Miami.
BERLIN, April 11. -- The Prussian Academy of Sciences has received the following letter from Professor Albert Einstein, dated Ostend, April 5:

PHILADELPHIA, April 11. -- At a meeting marked by caustic criticism of the present management, W.W Atterbury, president of the Pennsylvania Railroad, told stockholders today that better service and cheaper fares for the public, with larger profits for the railroads, might result from a modification of the Sherman and Clayton acts through legislative plans placed before President Roosevelt.

LEXINGTON, Ky., April 11. -- Five Kentucky Derby eligibles went to the post in the featured Strollers Purse at Lexington today and the winner turned up in the Calumtt Farm's Warren Jr., 17-to-1 shot, and next to the outsider in the field of six.

The Standard Oil Company of California reports for 1932 a net Income of $14,014,992 after all charges and taxes, including reserves for depreciation, depletion and amortization, equal to $1.07 a share on the 13,102,900 shares of capital stock outstanding.
ALBANY, April 11. -- The new Milk Control Board announced today that it was prepared within three days to put into effect the first of its orders affecting milk prices in the State.

WASHINGTON, April 11. -- When a successor to Rear Admiral William A. Moffett is selected, he will be an officer who has had "experience in flying personally and also has shown executive ability in administering a great and expensive aviation department," Secretary Swanson told newspaper men today.

LONDON, April 11. -- A bill empowering the government to prohibit the importation of Russian goods passed all stages in the House of Lords tonight, thus endorsing the action of the House of Commons in its effort to obtain a fair trial tomorrow for the British engineers accused of sabotage in Russia.

The Sound Interclubs again will start the yacht racing on Long Island Sound. Several of them are being fitted out, in addition to the four that were taken to Bermuda, and their season's program is being arranged, it was learned yesterday.

COPENHAGEN, April 11. -- Continuing today his Articles in the newspaper Politiken, "Georg Bernhard, former editor of the Vossiche Zeitung, who fled here from Germany recently, paints out the protected position of all Jews in Germany of foreign nationality, and continues:

The Republicans at Albany redeemed themselves handsomely when the Moffat charter bill came up a second time in the Assembly, voting in sufficient numbers to assure the passage of the measure in that House.

Erasmus Hall, Manual Training and Samuel J. Tilden High scored victories in the Brooklyn division yesterday, while John Adams High and Flushing triumphed in Queens division contests in the annual city P. S. A. L. senior high school championship competition.

WASHINGTON, April 11. -- The Shipping Board approved today an agreement for the operation of a joint steamship service between the Dutch East Indies and Atlantic Coast ports under the trade name of the Java-New York Line.

The values of restraint as opposed to liberty are set forth in "Ethical Systems and Legal Ideals -- An Essay on the Foundations of Legal Criticism," written by Felix S. Cohen, a New York lawyer who is the son of Professor Morris R. Cohen of City College.
RIGA, Latvia, April 11. -- The trial of six British engineers and their Russian co-workers will open in the Trade Union House in Moscow tomorrow.

The Tenement House Committee of the Charity Organization Society, sponsor for the original tenement house law, and other civic organizations will ask Governor Lehman for a hearing on a bill creating a new Board of Buildings with extensive powers, which passed the Assembly during the closing hours of the legislative sesson.

The construction of merchant shipping in the ten leading nations of the world, exclusive of Russia, decreased to a new low point for fifty years during the first three months of 1933, but several developments indicated an improvement in the general situation, according to the quarterly report of LJoyd's Register of Shipping, published yesterday.
BERLIN, April 11. -- A plea to avoid excesses was issued today by Dr. Alfred Hugenberg, Minister of Economics of Agriculture and leader of the Nationalist party.

In the opinion of counsel for all twenty banks of the New York Clearing House Association, the Harriman National Bank and Trust Company has no legal claim on them for assistance and no such claim could be enforced against the association itself, it was revealed yesterday.
LONDON, April 11 (AP). -- An improvement in British exports for March was announced today.

BERLIN, April 11. -- Dr. Paul Joseph Goebbels, Minister of Propaganda, in a letter published here states that the way to unhampered activity may be opened to all true artists who are constructive and creative. The letter was addressed to Wilhelm Furtwaengler, conductor of the Berlin Philharmonic Orchestra, who in a letter to the Minister called for complete freedom for the artistic work of such Jewish artists as Bruno Walter, Otto Klemperer and Max Reinhardt.

Commandeering by the government of idle plants, mines and farms, to be operated by the unemployed under a national self-sustaining, self-help program was proposed last night before the New York Chapter of the Society of Industrial Engineers, at a meeting in the Engineering Societies Building.

Parents can outfit the "depression baby" for 57.70 by careful shopping, students of the children's clothing class of the home economics and home-making department of the New York University School of Education announced yesterday.

The Kate Depew Strang Clinic for Cancer and Allied Diseases, the gift of her two daughters in memory of a sister of Chauncey M. Depew, was formally opened yesterday afternoon, in the presence of a notable gathering of physicians and laymen, as a regular department of the New York Infirmary for Women and Children, 321 East Fifteenth Street.

The addresses and club affiliations of more than 10,000 club women are listed in the twenty-sixth edition of Club Women of New York, which was ready for distribution yesterday. Bound in red silk with old trimming's and containing about 300 pages, the publication is endorsed by the New York City Federation of Women's Clubs.

CINCINNATI, April 11. -- Carbon monoxide poisoning has become a "new menace to the nation," Dr. Erma Smith of Iowa State told members of the American Psysiological Society, which, with the Federation of American Societies of Experimental Biology, held the second session of its convention here today.

PHILADELPHIA, April 11. -- A petition for a receiver in equity for the Baldwin Locomotive Works to force it to pay $12,000,000 of three-year 5 1/2 per cent gold notes which matured on March 1 last was filed today in federal District Court here by Bainbridge Colby, on behalf of Patrick J. McNaney of New York, who holds $19,000 of the notes.

Amid a display of pomp and ceremony designed to suit the occasion the New York Yankees, who crowned themselves world's champions by the simple expedient of crowning the Cubs in four straight games last Fall, will unveil the 1933 championship campaign of the American League at the Stadium this afternoon before a gathering expected to total about 50,000.

WASHINGTON, April 11 (AP) -- Production of this year's Winter wheat crop, announced yesterday by the Department of Agriculture to be indicated as 334,087,000 bushels, the smallest crop since 1904, and compared with 462,151,000 bushels last year, was announced today by important producing States as follows:

A farewell reception and tea in honor of Paul Claudel, retiring Ambassador of France, and Mme. Claudel was held yesterday afternoon at the Museum of French Art, French Institute in the United States, 22 East Sixtieth Street.

ROME, April 11. -- Dr. Engeibert Dollfuss, Austrian Chancellor, sped by airplane from Vienna to Rome today, presumably to join, the German-Italian parleys begun yesterday by Vice Chancellor Papen and Premier Mussolini. The Chancellor is expected to see Premier Mussolini tomorrow.

The 10,000-ton treaty cruiser New Orleans, which has been under construction at the Brooklyn Navy Yard for the last two years, will be launched at 10 o'clock this morning at the navy yard with colorful ceremonies. Miss Cora Stanton Jahncke, daughter of former Assistant Secretary of the Navy Ernest Lee Jahncke, will be sponsor of the ship.

TRENTON, N.J., April 11 (AP). -- The question of the Bethlehem Steel Corporation's bonus system for officials, which was the basis of a court action two years ago, was revived today in an action filed in Chancery Court to compel Charles M. Schwab, chairman of the board; Eugene G. Grace, president, and other officers to repay allegedly excessive amounts received between 1917 and 1930.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., April 11. -- Contradiction of testimony by Westchester park officials and the admission of William F. Mallette, general manager of Playland, that he received a "split" of one-eighth of the income from vending machines placed in the park during the Summer of 1928, marked the testimony today before the committee of the Board of Supervisors hearing charges against the Playland administration made by John Macri of Port Chester, former concessionaire.

George Bernard Shaw told an audience which filled the Metropoliant Opera House last night that it is up to the United States to provide leadership to save civilization from the ruin which previous civilizations have met in the history of the human race.

Sir Hubert Wilkins, the explorer, and Lady Wilkins are among the 400 passengers sailing today for Cherbourg and Southampton on the Canadian Pacific liner Empress of Britain, which is making the last leg of her round the world cruise.

The American Bar Association was urged to support calendar reform at a public hearing conducted by its commerce committee yesterday afternoon at the Chamber of Commerce of the State of New York, 65 Liberty Street. Miss Elisabeth Achelis, president of the World Calendar Association, urged adoption of a revised twelve-month calendar, while M.N. Stiles, American secretary for the International Fixed Calendar League, advocated a thirteen-month calendar.

ALBANY, April 11. -- While the Legislature ignored or opposed all measures providing for revision of the New York City charter growing out of the Hofstadter investigation, not a few bills of immediate benefit to the city were put through at the legislative session which ended yesterday.

After hearing an appeal yesterday from counsel for the Globe and Rutgers Fire Insurance Company for time to carry out plans for its rehabilitation, and assertions in behalf of George S. Van Schaick, Superintendent of Insurance, that the company is admittedly insolvent and that there is a difference of $12,260,000 between the company's assets and liabilities, Supreme Court Justice Alfred Frankenthaler reserved decision.

Within an hour after Federal Judge John C. Knox had opened a sealed verdict, in which James J. McCormick, Tammany leader of the Twenty-second Assembly District, had been found guilty late Monday night of having failed to file income tax returns for 1929 and 1930, Michael J. Cruise, City Clerk, announced yesterday that McCormick had resigned as his deputy in charge of the Marriage License Bureau.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., April 11. --John B. Ryerson of Cooperstown, N.Y., twice winner of the Mason and Dixon golf tournament and qualifying medalist this year, led the way into the second round of match play in the tourney today with a 2-up victory over Robert E. Barbour of Paterson, N.J. Ryerson had a medal score of 73 to Barbour's 75.

PALM BEACH, Fla., April 11. -- His villa on the Lake Trail was the setting for a luncheon with which Edward Lowber Welsh entertained today, having Mr. and Mrs. John North Willys, Colonel and Mrs. Clarence S. Wadsworth, Mr. and Mrs. A. Kinnaird Tod, Mr. and Mrs. George Luke Mesker, Mrs. Irving Hall Chase, Mrs. John Edwin Dietz, Mrs. Morton C. Nichols, Mrs. George H. Nicolai and Colonel Robert Glendinning.

Further pooling of passenger trains in the Northwest is contemplated, Charles Donnelly, president of the Northern Pacific, said yesterday at the annual meeting of the company. He believes that in general there is still more passenger-train movement than traffic justifies, but he doubts the feasibility of widespread pooling.

WITH JAPANESE TROOPS AT LENG PASS FRONT, April 11. -- All Jehol roads leading to Leng Pass were congested today as the Japanese troops poured southward to press the campaign against the Chinese, who held the pass until yesterday.

State of Oklahoma. The State of Oklahoma, which has only a small amount of bonded debt, plans to fund its unwieldy amount of short-term obligations, running close to $13,000,000, by means of a refunding operation, bankers here were advised yesterday.

WASHINGTON, April 11. -- Accused of favoritism in appointments of receivers and other conduct unbecoming his high office, Harold Louderback, Federal judge for the Northern California district, today faced the Senate in the first steps of his impeachment trial, which will be held May 15.

TORONTO, April 11. -- The Toronto Maple Leafs snapped the streak of the New York Rangers tonight by winning the third game of the Stanley Cup series for the world's professional hockey championship after a bitterly contested struggle.

PHILADELPHIA, April 11. -- Assertions that passage by Congress of the Black bill, providing for a thirty-hour work week, would create "bootleggers of industry" and I bring "disaster," especially without "compensatory tariff legislation," were made here today at a protest meeting attended by more than 100 leading business men and manufacturers.

Mayor O'Brien held yesterday his first transit unification conference with representatives of the holders, of bonds and stocks of the Manhattan Railway Company, owner of the elevated lines operated by the Interborough under a 999-year lease.

WASHINGTON, April 11. -- President Roosevelt was reported today to be opposed, but not irrevocably, to bank deposit insurance as provided in the revised Glass banking bill. His position was so reported in Senatorial circles after a twenty-minute conference with Senator Glass and Secretary Woodin at the White House.
NEW YORK. Brig. Gen. and Mrs. Cornelius Vanderbilt are leaving tomorrow for Hot Springs, Va., to pass the Easter holiday.

In the Army and Navy Journal Major Gen. FUQUA, Chief of Infantry, asks the question whether the infantry may eventually be displaced by a mechanized arm. He is of the opinion that the use of motor vehicles and tanks will not relieve them of the duty of delivering the final assault to determine victory.

The broadened demand for contracts continued yesterday on the Cotton Exchange, sending all 1933 crop deliveries above the 7-cent level and adding 10 to 11 points to prices for the day. Both trade and commission house sources were buyers, houses with mill connections fixing prices on more raw material than for some time.

"For Services Rendered." a new play by W. Somerset Maugham, will have its American premiere this evening at the Boolh Theatre under the management of Sam H. Harris, Fay Baintc, Elizabeth Risden, Henry Daniell and Walter Kingsford will be included in the cast.

While 2,200 men, women and children were viewing a performance at the Strand Theatre, Forty-seventh Street and Broadway, yesterday afternoon, fire started in the building at 1,585 Broadway, part of which houses the theatre, causing the death of one man and damage estimated at $30,000.

The Minnie Untermyer Memorial Theatre, the gift of Samuel Untermyer in memory of his wife, will be dedicated tomorrow on the eastern slope of Mount Scopus, as part of the Hebrew University in Jerusalem. It is regarded as the finest classic open-air theatre constructed in Palestine since the days of the Roman Empire.

Daily average gross crude oil production in the United States last week was 2,221,350 barrels, compared with 2,239,750 in the previous week, a drop of 18,400 barrels, the American Petroleum Institute announced yesterday. Declines of 20,850 barrels daily in Oklahoma and of 7,150 in the Texas Panhandle and an increase of 7,750 in Bast Texas were the most important changes.

WASHINGTON, April 11. -- At the Treasury today it was stated that there was no foundation for intimations attributed to bankers in Chicago that the Federal Reserve Banks were cooperating with houses specializing in short-term government securities to manipulate the prices at which the securities were marketed.

With the advance in stocks halted by realizing sales for the account of impatient speculators, interest centred yesterday in the major agricultural staples, particularly wheat, which engaged in a broad advance in response to the unexpectly low estimate placed by the government upon the Winter crop.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., April 11. -- Reversing its policy of the recent past, Harvard today announced that it had joined the Eastern Intercollegiate Baseball League and the Intercollegiate Wrestling League.

Terming the limitation of hours of labor useless as a way to restore prosperity, J.H. Rand Jr., president of Remington, Rand, Inc., urged last night in a speech at the Town Hall Institute of Economics a "two-year moratorium on anti-price-fixing laws," reflation by raising the price of gold, and adoption of a concerted plan by employers for re-employment of 3,000,000 men.
Streams in Connecticut and New Jersey are now in good condition, according to official reports received yesterday from Hartford and Trenton, respectively.

Good rallies in silver, rubber and silk were the outstanding developments in the local commodity markets yesterday. Other staples were also for the most part higher, although profit-taking reduced the gains in some cases. The volume of trading was larger.
The search for the Akron dead was handicapped yesterday by a strong east wind, which forced the smaller Coast Guard ships to shelter, and by poor visibility.

NEWARK, N.J., April 11. -- Although there was no improvement in earnings of the Bethlehem Steel Corporation in the first quarter of this year, operations last week showed a definite upturn, Eugene G. Grace, president of the company, declared today at the annual meeting.

NEW DELHI, India, April 11. -- The government of India announced today it had given Japan six months' notice of termination of the "most favored nation" clause of the trade convention of 1905. This is a protective measure to offset dumping of goods, the legislative assembly was told today by Sir Joseph Bhore, commerce member of the Viceroy's executive council.

TRENTON, N.J., April 11. -- In a report to the Interstate Commerce Commission, the Public Utility Commission of New Jersey approved today the unification of the Pennsylvania and Reading Railroad facilities in South Jersey. The proposed merger includes the West Jersey and Seashore Railroad, controlled by the Pennsylvania, and Atlantic City Railroad, a branch of the Reading.

Plans to coordinate operations at the ports of New York, Philadelphia and Baltimore in accordance with the principles followed in legislation pending in Washington were discussed yesterday at a meeting of railroad presidents in the Pennsylvania Station.

The slate of 150 anti-repeal candidates for the State ratification convention was virtually completed yesterday at an all-day meeting at the headquarters of the Woman's Christian Temperance Union, 156 Fifth Avenue. No names of candidates were given out, as the dry leaders said acceptances had not yet been received from all, but the list is expected to be complete by Friday.
WASHINGTON, April 11 (AP). -- Andre Lefebvre de Laboulaye, new French Ambassador to the United States, arrived in the capital tonight from New York, accompanied by his wife and two daughters.

CHICAGO, April 11. -- Embittered farmers in the Northwest were pictured today as preparing to join in a food strike early in May if legislation pending in Congress is unsuccessful in increasing farm prices by that time.

Following the announcement on Monday by the Clearing House Committee of a reduction in interest rates on deposits from 1 per cent to one-half of 1 per cent, effective tomorrow, there was a further general relaxation of the money market yesterday.

WASHINGTON, April 11. -- The cost of the forty-eight State Governments in 1931 was $2,508,743,486, the Census Bureau announced today. Revenue receipts were $2,324,522,179, and the net indebtedness at the end of the year was $1,976,844,129.

CLARKSVILLE, Tenn., April 11 (AP). -- The writ of habeas corpus obtained by Colonel Luke Lea and his son, Luke Lea Jr., on March 14, was quashed today by Judge John T. Cunningham in the Criminal Court.

The Government's forecast of Winter wheat production, published yesterday, was below all private estimates. The crop is placed at 334,000,000 bushels. This is a drop of nearly 30 per cent from last year's yield and of nearly 60 per cent from that of 1931.
To the Editor of The New York Times: Your correspondent E.C.D. Villaverde is aghast at the endless dole possibilities of the pending farm bill, though its life in limited to a definite trial period.

TRENTON, N.J., April 11. -- By a vote of 13 to 2, the Senate confirmed tonight the appointment of Wilfred H. Jayne of Ocean County for a full term as a Circuit Court judge and thereby ended a dispute that began before the general election last November.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., April 11. -- The Yale University Athletic Association today made a marked departure in granting insignia by announcing that the major "Y" had been awarded to members of the basketball and swimming teams, winners of intercollegiate titles during the past season.

WASHINGTON, April 11. -- A bond issue in small denominations for popular sale to accomplish partial refunding of the Fourth Liberty loan appeared possible today, with only four days left for Secretary Woodin to decide whether the loan will be called in whole or in part Oct. 15.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., April 11. -- In the first encounter in baseball history between the New York Yankees and Yale, the major leaguers had their final tune-up for the American League campaign by blanking the Eli nine, 6 to 0, today. A crowd of 5,000 shivered through the game and was rewarded by watching Charley Devens pitch a brilliant no-hit game against the collegians.

WASHINGTON, April 11 (AP). -- Closely coordinated regulation of the nation's transportation system on land, sea and in the air is to be sought by the Roossvelt administration as a key to many of the economic difficulties of the carriers.

The enforcement of fair practices in all forms of advertising in order to retain public confidence and avoid governmental censorship was advocated yesterday at a luncheon in the Advertising Club at 23 Park Avenue.

WASHINGTON, April 11 (AP). -- President Roosevelt informed Senator Robinson of Arkansas, the party leader, tonight that he would submit his proposal for refinancing of home mortgages to Congress Thursday. Senator Robinson is prepared to introduce the legislation, which he has helped work out with banking experts in Congress and in the executive departments.

The purple and gold of Rimsky-Korsakoff's orchestration, as it is manifested in the chanting, shimmering music of the overture, "The Russian Easter," opened the program of the Philadelphia Orchestra, Leopold Stokowski conductor, last night in Carnegie Half.

Heavy hitting behind the airtight pitching of Joe Nekola, sophomore right-hander, enabled the Manhattan baseball team to overwhelm the University of Vermont, 13 -- 3, at the Mosholu Park diamond yesterday.

LONDON, April 11. -- The Cabinet will hold two more meetings before Prime Minister MacDonald sails on Saturday for the United States. These sessions will be chiefly concerned with his mission in Washington.

We have become accustomed to expect good counsel from President. HOPKINS of Dartmouth whenever he speaks. He did not disappoint in his address at the celebration of the twenty-fifth anniversary of the founding of the Harvard School of Business.

LAKEHURST, N.J., April 11. -- Lieut. Commander Herbert V. Wiley testified here today before the naval court of inquiry into the Akron disaster that he now believed the great airship's structure had not broken in the air, but had been smashed when she hit the ocean in a storm off Barnegat, N.J., a week ago.

Humanity is at the crossroads, with one way leading to madness and the other to redemption, declared Rabbi Jonah B. Wise in his Passover sermon at the Central Synagogue, Lexington Avenue and Fifty-fifth Street, when he urged the Jewish people to he brave and have faith in the face of the persecution unleashed against them in Germany under the regime of Adolf Hitler.

BERKELEY, Cal., April 11. -- Officials of the University of California announced today that the coldest man-made temperature yet attained, 459.1 below zero Fahrenheit, had been reached by experiments at the university. This achievement of Professor W.F. Giauque, assisted by C.F. Nelson, a mechanician, and D.P. MacDougall, research assistant, was accomplished by use of a magnetic cycle process which Professor Giauque developed.
WASHINGTON, April 11. -- Behind closed doors tomorrow, the Lea bill to legalize wine of 10 per cent alcoholic content by weight will stand trial before the Ways and Means Committee.

WASHINGTON, April 11 (AP). -- Federal legislation for a modified thirty-hour working week in industry appeared likely tonight as Frances Perkins, Secretary of Labor, endorsed the principle of the Senate bill.

Large Drop in Buyers Here. A large drop in the number of buyers visiting this market took place during the week ended yesterday, according to the lists published in THE TIMES. For the past week 596 buyers were listed as against 739 in the previous week and 814 in the same period last year.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., April 11. -- Cap'n Harry Stubbs and his tugboat crew, two landlubber deputy sheriffs and a high tide got the last two rebel houseboat squatters off the town beach here today, but left Dave Dows, the county's millionaire sheriff, with something new to worry about.

Pan-American Day was celebrated here yesterday by the Fan-American Society, with speeches by prominent representatives of this and other American countries and a program of pageantry and song participated in by students from the city's high schools.
A drastic curtailment in the Spring racing program for Belmont Park was announced yesterday by Joseph E. Widener, president of the Westchester Racing Association, which operates the track.

George Engles as their concert manager, was honored yesterday by a group of distinguished musicians, led by Paderewski and Walter Damrosch, with a reception at the home of Mr. Damrosch, 133 East Eightieth Street. The function marked the fifth anniversary of the formation of the NBC Artists Service, of which Mr. Engles is director.
WASHINGTON, April 11. -- The War Department released the folowing orders today.

The International League's Golden Jubilee year will get under way today with two games being contested. The Baltimore Orioles will face the Toronto Maple Leafs at Baltimore and the Albany Senators will oppose the Rochester Red Wings at Albany.

WASHINGTON, April 11. -- That Eugene Meyer tendered his resignation as a member and governor of the Federal Reserve Board to President Roosevelt about ten days ago and that it had been accepted with the understanding that he would remain in office until his successor was chosen became known here tonight.

Regulation of the manufacture and sale of beer is important, but administration of the police in Greater New York seems much more so. Yet no one will question Commissioner MULROONEY'S motives in accepting the chairmanship of the State Excise Board pressed upon him by the Governor.

PARIS, April 11. -- In order to permit three-cornered conversation at the White House among President Roosevelt, Prime Minister MacDonald and Edouard Herriot, it has been arranged that the French envoy shall leave next Monday on the Ile de France, her sailing date having been advanced two days.

SHANGHAI, Wednesday, April 12. -- Continuously hopeful of foreign assistance from any quarter in their conflict with Japan, Chinese official circles are now eagerly watching the precarious situation developing between Manchukuo and Soviet Russia over Manchukuo's charges that Russia has been detaining enormous quantities of Chinese Eastern Railway rolling stock.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., April 11 (AP). -- As a further measure of economy, it was explained, notice was given at the general offices of the New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad Company here today, but effective May 1, that all executives, officials and members of the supervisory forces will be required to take two days off a month without pay.
WASHINGTON, April 11. -- The Bureau of Navigation Issued the following orders today, dated April 8:

NEWARK, N.J., April 11. -- Newark defeated the Rutgers nine today in the Bears' final exhibition. The score was 16 to 1. Johnny Murphy and Chandler worked on the mound for the Bears and allowed only three hits.

TRENTON, N.J., April 11. -- The question whether Pearl S. Buck, novelist, whose writings on Chinese life have attracted wide attention, shall be removed as a missionary of the Presbyterian Church has been brought before the Presbyterian Board of Foreign Missions, it was revealed today.

The four European gold-standard exchanges rose in dollar valuation yesterday, while the pound sterling and exchanges in the sterling group were uniformly soft. Francs advanced 3/8 point to 3.94 3/8 cents, the best price reached since the banking holiday and close to the normal gold export point.
Routine Along Broadway. Down, a side street off Times Square a 12-foot elephant, escorted by a 3-foot donkey and an ordinary 5-foot 7-inch circus attendant, approaches sedately.
To the Editor of The New York Times: There is a vital stipulation in the foreign debt agreements which has not been made clear to the American people.

The State Temporary Emergency Relief Administration will contribute $4,450,300 to New York City for unemployment relief in April, or $500,000 more than the funds allotted for March, it was announced yesterday by Harry L. Hopkins, chairman of the relief organization.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., April 11. -- Appointment of the first five men of the new society of fellows at Harvard University was announced tonight by President Lowell.

Plans whereby the women consumers of millions of dollars' worth of garments made in the industrial States might know whether the clothes they buy are made under conditions assuring the workers a fair and minimum wage were discussed yesterday at a meeting called by the Women's Trade Union League at 99 Park Avenue.

For the first time since he became virtual dictator of Germany, Chancellor Adolf Hitler reached out across the ocean yesterday and dismissed a German official who has refused to embrace the new political dispensation in Germany. The victim was Dr. Paul Schwarz, who for four years has been the German Consul in this city.

The Beaver Brook building, in which there was a dormitory, the dining room and administration quarters of the Ethel Walker School for Girls in the Weatogue section of Simsbury, was destroyed this afternoon by fire.

Play will continue tonight at Squadron A Armory, Ninety-fourth Street and Madison Avenue, in the indoor polo championships, with a start to be made in the last remaining national championship which New York will hold this season, the interscholastic.

WASHINGTON, April 11. -- President Roosevelt's plan for development of the Tennessee Valley through the operation of the huge facilities of Muscle Shoals and improvement of the Tennessee River was introduced in the Senate and House today.
HOLLYWOOD, Cal., April 12 (AP) -- Six motion-picture studios have announced resumption of full salary payments to players and two others are expected to take similar action at once.

Two jurors, who had served in separate cases in Federal court and had been members of rival political clubs in the Twenty-second Assembly District, had hearings yesterday before separate judges on motions to have them punished for contempt of court.

F.W. Charske, chairman of the executive committee of the Union Pacific System, was elected a director of the Western Union Telegraph Company at the annual meeting of stockholders yesterday to succeed Charles B. Seeger, who resigned.

ROME, April 12 -- Vice Chancellor Franz von Papen of Germany and Captain Hermann Wilhelm Goering, Reich Minister Without Portfolio and Prussian Premier, were received in private audiences by Pope Pius this morning, but although both the German Ministers declared themselves most satisfied with the reception accorded them by the Vatican, it is understood their mission to it has been a failure.

WASHINGTON, April 12 -- The Ways and Means Committee decided informally today to submit to the House a two-item tax bill, carirying a reduction of local postage from three to two cents and continuation of the one-cent Federal gasoline levy for one year.

WASHINGTON, April 12 -- The path of banking legislation was to some degree cleared today when Congressional leaders declared that President Roosevelt had taken no position for or against features of the Glass bill, but was reserving decision until he had studied the subject carefully.

PHILADELPHIA, April 12 -- The demand for the dismissal of Mrs. Pearl S. Buck as a missionary by the Presbyterian Board of Foreign Missions was only one of six specific charges made against the board in a brief he has filed with the Presbytery of New Brunswick, N.J., it was revealed tonight by the Rev.Dr.J. Gresham Machen, a professor in the Westminster Presbyterian Theological Seminary here.

PRINCETON, N.J., April 12 -- As a result of an investigation by Princeton University authorities of a party held at the Campus Club in celebration of Spring vacations Prince Prasob Mom Chow Sukhvasti of Siam, a nephew of Queen Rambai Barni and a member of the club, has teen withdrawn from the university, where he was a student in the sophomore class, it became known here today.

Thus far patronage at Washington has flowed only over the spillways. Soon the floodgates are to be opened. The faithful have received that assurance from the lips of Mr. FARLEY himself, the man in charge of the dam, who reveals that the Administration is "studying the advisability " of easing the flew by removing the requirement that first and second class postmasters shall be appointed only after examination.

Joseph M. Price, chairman of the independent fusion committee, formed soon after the last election, yesterday invited former Governor Charles s. Whitman of the Republican Mayoralty committee and Maurice P. Davidson of the City party to take the first step toward selecting a fusion slate to run against Tammany's candidate this Fall.

Helen Kane, the singer, was ordered yesterday by Federal Judge Francis C. Caffey to surrender $40,000, plus interest of $6,400 to the Irving Trust Company, as trustee in bankruptcy for the Bond Dress Company, which paid the principal sum to her on Aug. 4, 1930.

LONDON, April 12 -- Amid thunderous cheering in the House of Commons tonight. Walter Runciman, President of the Board of Trade, announced that an agreement had been reached with the German Government which should greatly assist the British coal export trade.

German, bonds on the Stock Exchange weakened perceptibly yesterday as a result of the overnight news of the heightening of political tension within the Reich. A number of the German issues lost 1 to 3 points, including the Government 7s, which were down 3 points, and the 5 1/2s, off 2 7/8 points for the day.

To the Editor of The New York. Times: I have read from time to time in THE NEW YORK TIMES that in the adjustment of pensions to disabled World War veterans the service-connected cases must not be made to suffer an injustice.

Yesterday the 10,000-ton cruiser New Orleans left the ways at the navy yard in Brooklyn. A month ago the San Francisco was floated at Mare Island, California. The phrase "pocket battleship " sometimes applied to these ships came into fashion after the Germans surprised the world by turning out the 10,000-ton battle cruiser Deutschland.

TOKYO, April 12 -- Viscount Ishii has consented to serve as Japan's delegate to the economic conversations in Washington. His formal appointment awaits the Cabinet's confirmation, which is expected tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, April 12 -- Because of its facilities to handle such work, the army was directed by President Roosevelt today to take over the control of forest unemployment camps. This was a duty assigned first to the Agriculture Department, to whom the forest workers were to have been turned over after the army had organized them.

CINCINNATI, April 12 -- Researches on a wide variety of subjects were described today before the Federation of American Societies for Experimental Biology as the scientists' convention met in closing sessions.

WASHINGTON, April 12 -- The Norris bill for development of Muscle Shoals was reported out unanimously today by the Senate Agriculture Committee after a twelve-minute executive session. Meanwhile the House Military Affairs Committee continued its hearings on an identical measure.

WARSAW, April 12 -- For the fourth, time in the past fortnight the German Minister, Hans-Adolf von Moltke, called at the Polish Foreign Office today and asked that the anti-German boycott be stopped. He was received by Colonel Joseph Beck, the Foreign Minister, and was assured the government would take all necessary measures to prevent further demonstrations and rioting.

ALBANY, April 12 -- The alcoholic beverage control bill was signed by Governor Lehman at 1:35 P.M. today. Four hours later the Governor handed former Police Commissioner Edward P. Mulrooney his commission as head of the Alcoholic Beverage Control Board, ereated through the measure.

To celebrate its sixty-first birthday, the New York Press Club will present an all-star frolic at the Majestic Theatre on Sunday evening, April 23. Outstanding figures of the opera, concert, vaudeville, radio and legitimate stage have accepted invitations to take part.

WASHINGTON, April 12 -- After less than six weeks in office, the Roosevelt administration is apparently attaining its economy goal, a reduction of $1,000,000,000 in Federal expenditures for the coming fiscal year. Figures obtained, here today indicate that a total of $1,020,000,000 of the appropriations voted at the last session of Congress will not be spent because of the sweeping economic measures effected or projected by President Roosevelt and his aides.

MEXICO CITY, April 12 -- Mrs. Zelia Nuttall, noted archaeologist, died at her home near here tonight of a heart attack. She had been one of the most interesting figures in Mexican life for a generation.
BERLIN, April 12 -- The most important news in Germany is still that of racial restriction. There is no escaping it.

LONDON, April 12 (AP) -- The British Foreign Office, issuing tonight its summary of today's session of the Moscow trial, noted that W.H.MacDonald, who pleaded guilty, had been interrogated out of his order in the list of the accused.
ALBANY, April 12 -- Kenneth F. Fee was appointed director of the new State Milk Price-Fixing Board by Governor Lehman today.

PHILADELPHIA, April 12 -- After two years of laboratory research and experimenting in which Dr. Leopold Stokowski, conductor of the Philadelphia Symphony Orchestra, played the part of musical counselor, the Bell Telephone Laboratories demonstrated the ceno-orchestra today before several hundred musicians, scientists and critics of New York, Philadelphia and Washington in the Academy of Music here.

Although attention was directed again to the acceleration of industrial operations, the security markets were unresponslye yesterday. Stocks, bonds and commodities settled back moderately, with wheat losing about half of Its advance of the previous day.

CHICAGO, April 12 -- Operations of the Chicago North Western Railway in 1932 resulted in a net deficit of $11,216,820, compared With a net deficit of $6,034,124 in 1931. according to the annual pamphlet report to stockholders, made public today.

WASHINGTON, April 12 -- A plea for peace in the Western Hemisphere and observance of "the policy of the good neighbor" was made by President Roosevelt today in an address before the governing board of the Pan American Union at a special session in celebration of Pan-American Day at the Union Building.

The sincerity of Mayor O'Brien and his official associates in the transit unification conferences with spokesmen for holders of B.M.T. and Interborough securities was questioned last night by former Mayor John F. Hylan in an address at the Paramount Democratic Club, Inc., 123 East 169th Street, the Bronx.

LAKEHURST, N.J., April 12 -- The fragility of the Akron, which sailed so surely and serenely over the sea and country and frequently encountered storms, was shown unmistakably today at the naval court of inquiry into her destruction. Things were constantly being spliced and repaired aboard her -- longitudinal girders, frames, transverse girders and wires that broke or were strained, some by accident, some by stress and some just by being stepped upon.
WASHINGTON, April 12 -- The War Department is so top-heavy that it will collapse at the outbreak of the next war, according to Major Gen. Johnson. Hagood, commanding the Seventh Corps Area.

MUNICH, April 12 -- Baroness Marie von Washington, the last of her name, was found dead this morning in her home near here of a stroke of apoplexy. She was 89 years old. The Baroness was the former Countess von Butler-Clonebough von Haimhausen and was the widow of Baron Karl von Washington, Royal Bavarian Chamberlain and Lieutenant Colonel, who died in 1897.

WASHINGTON, April 12 -- Increased by large revenues from beer, miscellaneous internal revenue receipts for the 1933 fiscal year will more than offset losses on Income taxes, according to figures compiled at the Treasury Department today.

The St. Louis-San Francisco Railway has obtained the consent of a sufficient proportion of all classes of its bondholders to permit action for reorganization under the new bankruptcy law, E.N. Brown, chairman of the readjustment committee, said yesterday.
WASHINGTON, April 12 -- The War Department issued the following orders today:
ST. PAUL, April 12 -- Governor Olson threatened today to declare martial law and confiscate private wealth unless relief measures he sponsors were enacted by the Legislature.

The gap of 3,000 feet remaining between the transmission lines of the New York. Edison System and the new electric lines of the Niagara Hudson Power System will be filled within thirty days as a result of action taken late on Tuesday night by the Yonkers City Council.

INEZ, Ky., April 12 (AP). -- Three relatives of Mrs. Lucinda Mills, 67-year-old mountain woman who was slain following a weird religious ceremony' Feb. 8 near Tomahawki, Ky., were convicted of her murder 'today by a Jury which acquitted two others In the same case.

In its annual report for 1932 the Massachusetts Judicial Council repeats a recommendation, first vainly made In 1928, that waiver of jury trial be made a condition of protection by insurance in motortort cases. The lawyers In Legislatures are notoriously tender to the pockets of their profession, and to adopt proposals to reform the administration of justice they an as slow as cold molasses.

Bidders acting for banks were active at foreclosure auction sales yesterday. Fifteen Manhattan and Bronx properties were put up by auctioneers. Except for one withdrawal, all the holdings were struck down to ihe plaintiffs, who acted to conserve their liens.

The danger that nationalistic feeling in the protection of home markets, as expressed through the "Buy American" campaign, might spread locally in this country in the form of "Buy State" movements was pointed out yesterday by Robert L. O'Brien, chairman of the United States Tariff Commission, in an address before the New York Board of Trade at the Commodore.

WASHINGTON, April 12 (AP). -- Senate administration supporters prepared today for a fight against the proposal to guarantee the farmer his production costs after Secretary Wallace let it be known that he wants it left out of the all-embracing measure designed to cure agriculture's financial ills.

Resignation of EUGENE MEYER as Governor of the Federal Reserve May have been partly caused by Overstrain. His recent simultaneous conducting of Reserve Board policies and the work of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation involved exhausting personal responsibilities.

AUGUSTA, Ga., April 12 -- Establishment of a central bank by the Federal Government, with the twelve Federal Reserve Banks as branches and with State chartered commercial and mutual savings banks admitted into the Federal Reserve System, was recommended here today at the close of the Spring meeting of the executive council of the American Bankers Association.
WASHINGTON, April 12 -- President Roosevelt is seeking a successor to Eugene Meyer as Governor of the Federal Reserve Board, but has not reached a decision, according to an official statement.
WASHINGTON, April 12 -- President Roosevelt and 23,999 other fans saw the Washington Senators vanquish the Philadelphia Athletics today. 4 -- 1. in an auspicious opening of the 1933 haseball season.

Predicting that the adoption of legislation making the parole of criminals more lenient would nullify the deterrent effect of punishment, Judge Joseph E. Corrigan of General Sessions yesterday urged the abolition of the Division of Parole and the indeterminate sentence.

DETROIT, April 12 (AP) -- A costly outfield error, an intentional pass and three singles in the thirteenth inning gave Cleveland three runs to break up a sparkling pitchers' duel between Tommy Bridges of the Tigers and Clint Brown of the Indians today.

In Spite of Commissioners. To get anything done in Central Park it may soon be a rule that one must begin by getting a new Park Commissioner. Not so long ago the people of New York were asked to believe that the trees in Central Park were doomed.
"The 3-Penny Opera," an English version of the German musical production based on John Gay's "Beggar's Opera," will open this evening at the Empire Theatre.
NEW YORK. Count Guy de Pomereu of Paris is at the Waldorf-Astoria.

Buffalo, N.Y., The city of Buffalo has scheduled for award on April 20 a new issue of 4,000.000 of relief bonds due on May 1, 1943. It will be one of the largest single pieces of new municipal financing thus far this year. Bidders will be permitted to name the rate of interest at not to exceed 6 per cent.

Details of the plan for paying depositors of the Harriroan National Bank and Trust Company in full are expected to be announced today by the Manufacturers Trust Company, which is to liquidate the closed institution. Representatives of the Manufacturers Trust returned from Washington, where they conferred with Acting Controller of the Currency F.G. Await, and went into consultation with Henry E. Cooper, conservator of the Harrirnan Bank.

A deluge of rain greeted the elaborately prepared inaugural ceremonies that were to have ushered in New York's major league championship baseball season at the Yankee Stadium yesterday and as a consequence the program now finds itself scheduled for today.

The Rev. John A. Wade, rector of St. John's Episcopal Church and senior Protestant chaplain of the Police Department, who died on March 23, left an estate of less than $5,000, according to the petition for probate filed with his will, drawn in 1925, in Surrogate's Court yesterday.

WASHINGTON, April 12 -- Mrs. Ruth Bryan Owen will have the honor of being the first woman to represent the United States Government abroad in the capacity of a Minister. Her nomination to be Envoy Extraordinary and Minister Plenipotentiary to Denmark and Iceland was sent to the Senate today by President Roosevelt, and later confirmed by that chamber without even the customary formality of reference to a committee.

WASHINGTON, April 12 -- A step in the administration's program for reorganization of railroad capital structures as a condition to further loans from the Reconstruction Finance Corporation was taken today with the naming of Professor A.A. Berle of Columbia University as special assistant on railroad matters to the corporation's board of directors.

The depression is having one good effect, anyhow, it is revealed in the annual report of the New York Public Library for 1932, which was submitted to the trustees yesterday afternoon. The depression has stimulated the public's search for knowledge.

Mrs. Jennie Patterson, mother of Haywood Patterson, Negro youth recently convicted in Decatur, Ala., at his second trial for an alleged attack upon two white women, came to New York yesterday to aid the International Labor Defense in its fund-raising campaign to carry on the defense of Patterson and the eight other Negroes with whom he is jointly accused.
ST. LOUIS, April 12 (AP) -- Durham and Heving allowed the St. Louis Browns only four hits and the Chicago White Sox won the opening game of the season today, 4 to 2.
PALM BEACH, Fla., April 12 -- Mr. and Mrs. John North Willys, who will leave late this week for New York, gave a small dinner tonight at Villa Florencia.

The Baltimore Ohio Railroad plans for New York City the most Important change in terminal operation which the company has undertaken in conformity with the policy of railroad economy favored by the Washington administration, Daniel Willard, president, disclosed yesterday.

Because of existing business conditions the terms of the lease to Bonwit Teller Co. by the 721 Fifth Avenue Corporation, a subsidiary of the Arnold Constable Corporation, have been, changed and the management of Bonwit Teller Co. has been vested with the second mortgagee, it was revealed in an application for listing of stock made yesterday by Arnold Constable Co. to the New York Stock Exchange.

VIENNA, April 12 -- With conversations under way in Rome to link Austria, Germany and Italy closer together, Austrian Socialists dealt Anschluss -- union with Germany -- a severe blow today by withdrawing from the movement as a protest against Hitlerism in Germany.

Operations in the steel industry had a sharper expansion this week than in any similar period in the year to date, according to the weekly review of The Iron Age. This publication estimates the producing rate at 191 1/2 per cent of ingot capacity, compared with 16 1/2 per cent in the week before.

Forty-two games, to be contested on a home-and-home basis, comprise the schedule of the seven clubs affiliated with the Metropolitan and New Jersey Cricket Association in their annual championship competition beginning next month. The clubs include the Brooklyn, Crescent Athletic-Hamilton, Flatbush, Staten Island, Union County, Veteran St. George and Westchester County.
WASHINGTON, April 12 -- The Bureau of Navigation issued the following orders today, dated April 10:

The Transit Commission ordered yesterday an indefinite suspension of the certificate of necessity and convenience under which the Tompkins Bus Corporation operates its fleet of about 100 buses on eleven routes in Staten Island. The action was taken because of the company's persistent failure to comply with the commission's orders and regulations regarding service, insurance, accounting practices and upkeep of equipment.

The Pacific Gas and Electric Company reports for 1932 a net profit of $21,154,575 after charges, taxes and depreciation, before subsidiary preferred dividends. This is equal after subsidiary and company preferred dividends to $2.10 a share earned on 6,250,861 average number of common shares outstanding during the year, and to $2.09 a share on 6,271,885 shares outstanding at the end of the year.

WASHINGTON, April 12 -- The nation's gratitude has been expressed by President Roosevelt in a letter to Carl Dalldorf, captain of the German tanker Phoebus, which picked up the three survivors of the Akron disaster.

CHICAGO, April 12 -- Lonnie Warneke baffled the St. Louis Cardinals with a great four-hit pitching performance today to send, the Cubs off on their National League pennant campaign with a shut-out victory, 3 to 0. Ha struck out six men.

Except in the case of rubber, the local commodity markets were reactionary yesterday. Profit-taking, combined with the absence of any important general news or the stimulus of rallies in the outside markets, sent prices lower and, for the most part, trading volumes were in a turnover of 3,550,000 ounces.

To the Editor of The New York Times: May one of those whose people did not come over on the May-flower but were already here to greet it with gifts of venison and maize and what not, until it was quite clear that the guests were not after refreshments so much as they were after the entire estate, write you a letter?

Counsel for cities and towns in Westchester County asked the Public Service Commission yesterday to order an immediate reduction of 25 per cent in the commutation rates charged by the New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad in their area.
BALTIMORE, April 12 (AP) -- The Baltimore Orioles rallied for five runs in the seventh inning and defeated Toronto, 12 to 7, in the International League opener before 4,000 today.

WASHINGTON, April 12 -- Cynical observations to the effect that some foreign envoys are coming to Washington this month in the expectant mood of hungry children invited to a Christmas feast do not alter the fact that for the first time since Woodrow Wilson returned from Paris a President of the United States has been offered and has accepted the leadership of the world.

Gregory Polonski, a former teacher of philosophy at the Universities of Petrograd and Leipzig, who had given lectures on Cartesian philosophy at New York University in the last few years, died of heart disease yesterday in Mount Sinai Hospital after a week's illness.
The 10,000-ton cruiser New Orleans -- one of the most powerful of her class, had a sailor's christening yesterday at the Brooklyn Navy Yard.

Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of Columbia University, is bringing suit against the closed Harriman Bank and Trust Company to recover some $200,000 in securities, it became known yesterday when Supreme Court Justice Lockwood, in Brooklyn, signed an order making Henry E. Cooper, conservator of the bank, a defendant in the action.

WASHINGTON, April 12 -- President Roosevelt today sent a telegram to the Governors of thirteen industrial States calling attention to the new minimum-wage act of New York State and expressing the hope that other States will adopt similar laws "for the protection of the public interest."

Sales of tickets at reduced rates sent suburban passenger revenues of the Delaware, Lackawanna Western Railroad in 1932 above those of 1931, according to the annual report of J.M. Davis, president. Although commuter rates were raised at the beginning of 1932, Mr. Davis attributed the increase in suburban-traffic revenue to the encouragement of travel in off-peak periods with, low tariffs.

An appeal to the United States to help Japan "keep peace in Asia," instead of hindering her "by what he insisted was misunderstanding of Japan's activities, was made last night by Yusoke Matsuoka, chief of japan's delegation to the League of Nations, in a farewell address in San Francisco on the eve of his sailing for home.
The Davis Cup forces of the United States, now largely concentrated at Pinehurst, N.C., will be joined by their commanding officers at White Sulphur Springs, W. Va., next week.

MOSCOW, April 12 -- The trial of the accused engineers, both British and Russian, of the Metropolitan-Vickers Electrical Company began with a sensation this afternoon when W.H. MacDonald, one of the six Britons accused, pleaded guilty to charges of espionage, wrecking, bribery and conspiracy.
MEXICO CITY, Mex., April 12 -- Querido Moheno, unquestionably Mexico's leading criminal lawyer for the last thirty years, died today at the age of 60, after a heart attack.

To the Editor of The New York Times : The celebration of "Pan-American Day," April 14, seems a most appropriate occasion to dwell upon certain fundamental principles on which the Pan-American ideal is founded.

Whether the State shall compel a mother to subject her 2-year-old baby to an operation, which physicians admit may be fatal will be decided soon by the Appellate Division in Brooklyn, it was revealed yesterday.

Vigorous action will be taken by New York Interests to maintain State control of trucks handling foreign commerce to and from piers in the port district, it was indicated yesterday during a discussion of proposed Federal motor truck legislation at the monthly meeting of the Shippers Conference of Greater New York.
The bright white light of publicity that shines down upon the White House more persistently than the sun was at first described with some amusement by Herbert Hoover, early in his term as President.

The storm that swept up from Virginia yesterday, its northern-most border touching on the St. Lawrence watershed and its centre moving out to sea east of New York, was virtually ended for this area by 9 o'clock last night.

CHENGTEH (Jehol City), April 12 -- Thousands of persons crowded the roofs here today as the dull rumbling of terrific cannonading rolled in on a favorable wind from the distant Great Wall, where the Japanese were pressing their general attack.

A somewhat reactionary tone developed yesterday in trading on the Cotton Exchange in sympathy with other markets, but prices steadied after a twelve-point setback and a late recovery left the list only 4 to 6 points lower than on Tuesday.
CINCINNATI, April 12 (AP) -- The Pirates chalked up one victory on their way to a possible National League pennant today, defeating the Reds, 4 to 1. in the season's opening game in Cincinnati.

BERLIN, April 12. -- Although the volume of transactions remained restricted, yesterday's upward tendency reasserted itself today in a more marked way on the Boerse. The centres of interest were I.G. Farbenindustrie, which netted a gain of 3 7/8 points; steels and colliery stocks. The day's high levels were not maintained throughout the session, but the average closing price was above that of yesterday.

To Wall Street the slow and hesitant reaction on the Stock Exchange yesterday seemed to represent the familiar corrective readjustment after an advance. Operators for the rise consoled themselves with the thought that needed repairs to the "technical position" were being made.

The note of general regret in the cordial farewells to Ambassador VON PRITTWITZ is a sign that his work as representative of Germany in this country has been duly appreciated here. It was a somewhat trying position to which he fell heir when he went to Washington.

CHICAGO, April 12 -- Heavy profit-taking in wheat developed again today on the Board of Trade and, while sensational crop comments came from the Winter wheat belt and the seeding of Spring wheat is delayed, there was not the free buying so much in evidence yesterday.

GENEVA, April 12 -- The League of Nations convention limiting the manufacture of narcotics, signed in Geneva in 1931, now is assured of going into force. The convention requires for its enforcement the depositing here of twenty-Five ratifications, including four by manufacturing States, by tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, April 12 -- Speaking for the administration, Miss Frances Perkins, Secretary of Labor, told the House Committee on Labor today that President Roosevelt sympathized with the purposes and principle of the thirty-hour work week," but that the bills now before the committee must be amended in important particulars if the President was to sign such a measure.

The advertising review committee which was formed by the Association of National Advertisers, Inc., and the American Association of Advertising Agencies to make effective and to interpret its code of practices considered unfair or tending to discredit advertising made public its plan of operation yesterday.

Commercial failures last month were fewer than in any other March in the last eight years and the liabilities involved were smaller than in that month for several years past, according to the monthly analysis of defaults made by Dun Bradstreet, Inc. They say In their report:
WASHINGTON, April 12 -- To retire an issue of $75,032,000 in Treasury bills April 19, Secretary Woodin today invited tenders for a new block of 75,000,000 in ninety-one-day bills. The circular read:
Great South Bay's yachting schedule for the coming Summer was announced yesterday as a result of a gathering of the various club representatives at the Crescent Athletic-Hamilton Club in Brooklyn.

Governor Wilbur L. Cross of Connecticut yesterday signed a bill by which the trout season in the Nutmeg State will be extended this year and thereafter by fourteen days. Instead of the season closing on July 1, as heretofore, anglers now will be able to whip the streams for trout up to and including July 14.

Mayor O'Brien announced last night that after considering the arguments for the use of the old Fort Schuyler army reservation at Throgs Neck as a city park or as a shore base for the New York Merchant Marine Academy he believed that the tract should be devoted to park use.

The recent rebound in steel operations probably represents the beginning of a gradual improvement in business, Tom N. Girdler, chairman and president of the Republic Steel Company, declared yesterday at the annual meeting of stockholders in Jersey City.

Dr. Richard Willstaetter of Munich, Nobel Prize winner in 1915 for his outstanding contributions in organic chemistry, has been selected to receive the Willard Gibbs Medal for 1933, one of the highest American honors in chemistry, it was announced here yesterday by the American Chemical Society.

Sweeping past all three of her opponents in the final after having lost only one bout in the semi-final round, Miss Dorothy Locke of the Salle d'Armes Vince retained the women's national foils championship before an enthusiastic gallery at the Fencers Club last night.

To the Editor or The New York Times: Ten years ago Mr. and Mrs. Holt took five little children of Mrs. Holt's brother to bring up, the brother and his wife having died very suddenly. All through the years they worked and struggled to keep a home for these children, and now both have broken down and are in the hospital.

The Maritime Association of the Port of New York protested yesterday to President Roosevelt and the Senate against the proposed treaty with Canada for the canalization of the St. Lawrence waterway. Resolutions adopted by the association said no economic demand for the waterway existed and that government finances were In no condition to warrant the expenditure.

Good Friday will be widely observed in this city tomorrow. Almost as many denominational churches will hold special services as will the Roman Catholic and Protestant Episcopal houses of worship. In a score or more of churches one of the special Good Friday oratorios will be sung in the late afternoon or evening.

Through an order granted yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Lydon directing an immediate trial of suits by Banking Superintendent Broderick against stockholders of the Bank of United States to recover an assessment of $25 a share, it was said that the liquidation of the bank and final payments to the 400,000 depositors and other creditors of the bank would be hastened nearly a year.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The New York Clearing House Association orders a reduction of the rate of Interest to be paid by its members on deposits, with which no fault can be found by depositors who understand the money market. But a provision of the proposed Glass banking bill does better still in eliminating entirely interest on balances in commercial banks except under special circumstances.

BERLIN, April 12 -- Systematic search by the police of passengers baggage deposited at Prussian railway cloakrooms has yielded a rich harvest of treasonable material, it was said in an official report issued tonight.

WASHINGTON, April 12 -- Women prohibitionists met here today at the call of Mrs. Henry W. Peabody, chairman of the Women's National Committee for Law Enforcement, to pledge continued defense of the Eighteenth Amendment.

With Billy Nicholls, last year's Pennsylvania Military College cajtain, running wild at back in the last period, the Commonwealth Polo Club of Boston came from behind at Squadron A Armory last night to upset the Allenhurst Polo Club of New Jersey and win the Eastern championship in Class B.

TORONTO, April 12 -- Inspired by their showing of last night when they beat the New York Bangers In the third game of the Stanley Cup play-off for the world's hockey championship, the Maple Leafs are a new team today.
George Bernard Shaw departed for London yesterday on the Empress of Britain, uncertain of the result of his American mission.

WASHINGTON, April 12 -- The administration has sought to appease dissatisfaction among the Little Entente and other powers at not being invited to send representatives here for discussions with President Roosevelt on economic subjects preliminary to the World Monetary and Economic Conference in London by formally inviting all of them to discussions through their chiefs of mission in Washington.

An application by bondholders of the Paramount Publix Corporation for the appointment of a receiver for the Film Producing Corporation, on the ground that Paramount transferred to the producing corporation title to many of its most valuable films in violation of the rights of the bondholders, was denied yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Valente.

Bernt Balchen, polar flier, smiled and waved at the several hundred Norwegian-Americans who braved the cold rain yesterday morning to see him off for Norway aboard the Stavangerfjord on the first stage of his latest adventure, the Ellsworth Antarctic Expedition.

The Bank of England, a year and a half after its suspension of gold payments and three months after its gold reserve had fallen to the lowest figure since 1920, now reports gold holdings larger that at any time in its history. This remarkable change has taken place in almost immediate sequence to the fall of the pound sterling to i the lowest international gold value in more than a century.

The Bank of England, a year and a half after its suspension of gold payments and three months after its gold reserve had fallen to the lowest figure since 1920, now reports gold holdings larger that at any time in its history. This remarkable change has taken place in almost immediate sequence to the fall of the pound sterling to i the lowest international gold value in more than a century.

CALLED on account of rain. The outdoor baseball ceremonies were postponed and the indoor fanning bees were resumed. The ball players sat around and discussed one thing and another touching on and appertaining to the diamond pastime. They like to talk shop.
A general retrenchment move by racing associations in New York was indicated yesterday following a meeting of turf officials.

LONDON, April 12 -- British newspapers generally have received the Moscow indictment with incredulity, the charges being regarded as the more mysterious, since they do not lack precision. The Daily Telegraph says W.H. MacDonald's plea of guilty gravely compromises the position of the other five Britons and manifestly aggravates their peril. That paper adds:

When Alice Marie Kennerly sold to Gladys Edwards the dwelling at 230 W. 139th St. the former took back a purchase money mortgage for $1,835 to be paid off S100 quarterly, at 4 1/3 per cent, and subject to a first mortgage for 57,000 at 6 per cent.

For the first time in the memory of veteran police officials, New York's Police Department was left without an active head at noon yesterday when former Police Commissioner Edward P. Mulrooney left the Centre Street headquarters without being able to welcome his successsor.
ALBANY, April 12 (AP) -- There are two minimum wage bills before Governor Lehman, who has not, however, signed either of them. He will, it is certain, sign one and perhaps both.

In a court room guarded by a dozen patrolmen and several detectives, two members of Local 3, International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers, were held yesterday for the grand jury by Magistrate Dreyer in Yorkville Court on charges of felonious assault growing out of a shooting in the union offices, 130 East Twenty-fifth Street, in which two members were wounded.

Metropolitan stay-at-home golfers who have been hearing so much this last Winter about the enlarged golf cup, advocated by Gene Sarazen, will have an opportunity to try it out tomorrow, weather permitting.

WASHINGTON, April 12 -- Senator Borah strongly urged recognition of Russia in a Senate speech today, after Senator Robinson of Indiana raised the question for the first time this session with a denunciation of what he called the subversive acts of the Communist forces.

WHITE PLAINS, N.T., April 12 -- An agreement between the Westchester County Park Commission and Frank W. Darling, director of Flayland, which had not been made public previously, under which Darling had received commissions on amusement park equipment costing about $1,000,000, was disclosed at the Playland inquiry here today.

At the request of the board of directors of the Mercantile Bank and Trust Company, whose main office is at 526 Eighth Avenue, the institution was taken over for liquidation yesterday by State Superintendent of Banks Joseph A. Broderick.

ELIZABETH, N.J., April 12. -- Two men were shot dead late this afternoon in an elaborate suite occupying most of the eighth floor of the Elizabeth Carteret Hotel here. The slayers escaped unseen. The suite, according to the police, was the headquarters for the principal local bootleg ring.
A soft-spoken Southerner sat at his desk in a fourteenth-floor office of the Whitehall Building yesterday and casually pushed a folded note on thin cream paper across the broad blotter.
MOSCOW, April 12 (AP) -- W.H. MacDonald, one of the six British engineers who went on trial today on charges of sabotage, bribery and espionage, made a double admission of guilt.

PINEHURST, N.C., April 12 -- George M. Lott Jr. of Chicago former Davis Cup star, passed an active day on the courts of the Pinehurst Country Club today winning three singles matches and one doubles contest with John Van Ryn as his partner, to catch up with the rest of the field in the North and South championship.

Two alternative bills to supplement the existing anti-trust laws and permit industry to engage In a certain measure of cooperative action were discussed all day yesterday at a hearing of the committee on commerce of the American Bar Association at the New York State Chamber of Commerce Building.

With the assistance of Ed Wynn, Harry Hershfield and other stars of the theatre, Thrift House, a new venture in raising funds for relief work and other philanthropic activities, will be opened today at 9 West Fifty-seventh Street. Organized by a group of volunteers under Mrs. Julius Ochs Adler, the house will sell new and old articles, all of which will be contributed.
Several deals by financial institutions were included in the New Jersey realty transactions reported yesterday.

The Sheldrake branch of the Mamaroneck Valley trunk sewer line is due to be In operation about July 15. providing additional drainage facilities for sections of Scarsdale, New Rochelle and Mamaroneck. according to James Berg, secretary of the Westchester County Sanitary Commission.

Somerset Maugham, whose ways have gone more often along the unrighteous paths of impolite comedy, has -- in his most recent play -- bowed to the serious drama. He has done go in "For Services Rendered," which was put forward at the Booth Theatre last night by Sam H. Harris.

LEXINGTON, Ky., April 12 -- Samuel Furst's Bright Bubble, making the second start of her career, showed the way in the featured Ashland Purse today at Lexington. Next Call, a Greentree Stable racer, trailed by five lengths to finish in second place, while S. S. Combs's Nituma was third, three lengths further back.

WASHINGTON, April 13. -- A supplemental North Cape cruise agreement of the Transatlantic Passenger Conference specifying minimum fares on cruises to ports of the North and Baltic Seas, Russia and Iceland was approved by the Shipping Board today.

Newlyweds have a right to live their own lives without interference from each other's relatives, even if the latter happen to include great-grandchildren, Magistrate Aurelio ruled in Essex Market Court yesterday in reconciling Joseph Lessner, 86 years old, and his bride of four weeks, Anna, 76.

WASHINGTON, April 13. -- A vast public works building program and speedy enactment of the thirty-hour week bill to reduce unemployment and stimulate industry was urged upon President Roosevelt today by representatives of organized labor.

ALBANY, April 13. -- Governor Lehman decided today to approve the Wald bill providing for a mandatory minimum wage system for women and minors in industry, but he is undetermined as to his action on the Desmond bill, which is permissive, includes male workers and would be in force only during the present emergency.

Easter Monday egg rolling will not be confined to the White House lawn this year. A half dozen youngsters were out in the meadow in Central Park yesterday, practicing for a local egg-rolling contest, and it is understood there will be a contest on the Prospect Park meadows in Brooklyn.

The Wait Was Too Long. BERNARD SHAW has sailed away, depressed at the thought that he "bungled" his Metropolitan Opera House speech. If this was truly the case, it was not because of lack of preparation.

CHICAGO, April 13. -- Further talk of currency inflation, based on utterances by members of Congress in Washington, enlivened the wheat market today. The early part of the session on the Board of Trade was listless, with prices dropping about 1/2 cent a bushel on scattered selling.

BABYLON, L.I., April 13. -- The award of contracts totaling $1,039,822 for two of the three projects in the further development of Jones Beach was announced today by the Jones Beach State Parkway Authority at the headquarters of the Long Island State Park Commission in Belmont State Park near here.
Twelve Manhattan and Bronx properties were bought in by plaintiffs at foreclosure auctions yesterday. There was one withdrawal and an adjournment. The results follow:

In accordance with its policy of preventing corners in listed issues, the New York Stock Exchange is using a form of agreement under which holders of large blocks of certain stocks agree to make the shares available for lending, or to sell them if asked to do so by the committee on stock list.

WASHINGTON, April 13. -- For the first time since the convening of the extra session of Congress, the Republicans in the House of Representatives showed signs today of presenting an almost solid front in opposition to a measure urged by President Roosevelt, when the arms-embargo resolution came up for debate.

The usual eight weeks' season of concerts by the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra will be presented at the Lewisohn Stadium of the College of the City of New York this Summer, it was announced yesterday by Mrs. Charles S. Guggenheimer, chairman of the Stadium Concerts, Inc.

Unemployment relief by the city should be provided not so much through spending $7,000,000 a month, as the municipality does at present, but rather through the expenditure of this and other moneys on work which could be created through the advancement of "necessary" public improvements, according to Aldermanic President Joseph V. McKee.

WASHINGTON, April 13. -- The daily average volume of Federal Reserve Bank credit outstanding during the week ending April 12, as reported by the Federal Reserve Banks, was $2,555,000,000, a decrease of $32,000,000 compared with the preceding week and an increase of $926,000,000 compared with the corresponding week in 1932.
