The Tenement House Committee of the Charity Organization Society has asked Governor LEHMAN for a public hearing on the McCall bill setting up a new system of building inspection in this city. Other civic bodies are disposed to look askance at the measure, which was introduced in the Legislature just before the close of the session and rushed through both houses without a hearing.

The city will ask the United States Supreme Court on Monday for permission to file a brief, as a friend of the court, in the legal proceedings pending before that body in the Interborough-Manhattan Railway receivership case.
Clarence C. Pell, national amateur racquets champion, won his opening match in the first class, handicap court tennis tournament of the Racquet and Tennis Club yesterday.

ST. PAUL, Minn., April 13. -- Reiterating his threat to declare martial law in Minnesota and confiscate wealth to prevent "human misery," Governor Floyd B. Olson today made a new plea to the Legislature to permit use of the State's cash and credit to "take care of its own."

ALBANY, April 13. -- A minimum price of 18 cents a quart for bottled Grade A milk delivered to homes in New York City and 10 cents for Grade B, effective Monday, was ordered today by the new State Milk Control Board following a hearing.

Golden Gate Bridge District. Bankers were advised here yesterday that the California Supreme Court has upheld the legality of the sale on Aug. 31 last of an issue of $6,000,000 Golden Gate Bridge and Highway District 4 3/4 per cent bonds to a California banking group on a 5.26 per cent basis.

Four States in the East, within whose borders are some of the most noted trout streams in the country, will inaugurate the season tomorrow. These States are New Jersey, Connecticut, Pennsylvania and Massachusetts.

WASHINGTON, April 13. -- The State Department announced today that David P. Johnson, American Collector of Customs, at Port au Prince, bad confessed, that he had been guilty of defrauding the Haitian customs and accepting bribes from Zrike Brothers, Syrian-American importers and merchants, of Port au Prince.

Louis Conti of the Lenox Hill A. A., holder of national A.A.U. 126-pound wrestling championship, won the metropolitan A.A.U. crown last night when he threw Arthur Bartels, defending titleholder, competing unattached, in the final at the Twenty-third Street Y.M.C.A.
WASHINGTON, Appril 13. -- The Bureau of Navigation issued the following orders today, dated April 11:

Home owners' equities of $6,000,000,000 will be wiped out if the administration's home mortgage bill becomes law, J. Charles Laue, executive secretary of the Consolidated Home Owners Mortgage Committee, declared in a statement yesterday.

To the Editor of The New York Times: We are living in an age of advanced civilization, reaping the benefits of scientific discovery. Human beings have already learned to utilize the sciences in order to satisfy their physical needs. But they have failed to recognize and to understand the other side of human nature -- the spiritual element.

In the start of his book, "Our Stone-Pelted Planet," just published by Houghton Mifflln, H.H. Nininger summarizes the astronomical picture of the physical importance of the earth in the universe as known now.

After holding within a narrow range in the morning trading yesterday, prices on the Cottony Exchange advanced sharply a dollar a bale under the heaviest trading in some time. Stimulated by a large rise in sterling, a general buying wave carried May contracts above 6 3/4 cents, which was $3 a bale above recent low levels.

Debate in the Senate on the farm bill has prompted several members to renew the argument that only currency Inflation can "save" American agriculture. Farmers are suffering from abnormally low prices. Inflation, it is said, would raise them and so lighten the burden of mortgages contracted on a higher level of values.

WASHINGTON, April 13. -- Modification of the anti-trust laws to permit wage and price agreements among members of individual industries was recommended to President Roosevelt today by Governor Joseph B. Ely of Massachusetts.

WASHINGTON, April 13. -- The President's request to Congress for the broadest possible authority to negotiate international trade agreements, similar in character to the "dictatorial" powers he has used in meeting the domestic emergency, will be sent to the Capitol in the next few days.
WASHINGTON, April 13 (AP). -- Earl Whitehill celebrated his advent in a Washington uniform with an 11-to-4 victory over the Athletics today, making it two in a row for the Senators.
SIMSBURY, Conn., April 13. -- Fire which the police believe was of incendiary origin tonight destroyed the second large building of the Ethel Walker School for Girls to burn within three days.
PARIS, April 13 (AP). -- The weekly statement of the Bank of France shows the following changes in francs:

Thrift House, which opened yesterday morning at 9 West Fifty-seventh Street for the sale of contributed merchandise of all sorts for philanthropic purposes, had such a rush of customers that the aid of the police was required to handle the crowd.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Controverting the article of Professor Kemmerer in THE TIMES, in which he condemned the provisions of the farm bill as contravening "most of the fundamental canons of justice in taxation," the Rev. John A. Ryan defends the measure on the ground that it is not its aim to levy a tax but to fix prices.

SHANGHAI, Friday, April 14. -- The Japanese forces in North China continued to advance today. Piter stiff fighting, capturing villages south of the Great Wall passes of Leno in the centre, and Kupei, in the west.

Twenty members of the Authors' League have just been elected directors of the Authors' League Fund. They are Ruth Aley, Bruce Barton, Irvin S. Cobb, Marc Connelly, Homer Croy, James Forbes, John Golden, Rita S. Halle, Harry Hansen, Julian Mason, Mrs. William Brown Meloney, Arthur McKeogh, Geoffrey Parsons, William MacLeod Raine, Arthur Richman, Arthur Somers Roche, Sigmund Romberg, Booth Tarkington, A.E. Thomas and Louis Wiley.

Proposals for giving the President complete legislative power with only a "limited veto" by Congress, for prolongation of the existing "dictatorship, American style," and for reforming the banking system by taking the profit out of commercial banking, were heard yesterday by 100 political scientists from twenty-seven colleges and universities, meeting at Washington Square College, New York University, at the first regional conference of the northeastern group of the American Political Association.

Evidence of the demand for good residential properties in Manhattan is found in an announcement by Douglas Gibbons Co., who report that they have just sold the modern four-story American basement house at 128 East Seventy-first Street for Neilson Edwards of the Chase Bank Harris Forbes Company.

Stirred to a frenzy by the eloquence of Samuel S. Leibowitz, who promised he would not give up his legal battle in defense of the nine Negroes in the Scottsboro case even if he had to "sell his house and home," a congregation of more than 4,000 persons hailed the lawyer as "our leader" and "a new Moses" yesterday afternoon at a meeting in the Salem Methodist Episcopal Church, 129th Street and Seventh Avenue.

WASHINGTON, April 13. -- Ira Nelson Morris of Chicago, who was Minister to Sweden in the Wilson administration, is slated to be Ambassador to Turkey. His appointment, together with several other selections for foreign posts, will be sent to the Senate by President Roosevelt next week.

CHICAGO, April 13. -- Edward J. Kelly, president of the South Park board and chief engineer of the sanitary district, was elected by the City Council today to be Mayor of Chicago until April, 1935, completing the unexpired term of the late Anton J. Cermak.

A remarkable correlation between the variation in the amount of the total heat radiated by the sun and booms and depressions in business was demonstrated with charts last night before the Science Forum of the New York Electrical Society at the Engineering Societies Building, 29 West Thirty-ninth Street.

G.B. Carpenter of Darien, Conn., and Mills P. Baker of the Garden City Casino gained the final in the first annual metropolitan Badminton championship at the 212th Anti-Aircraft Armory yesterday. Carpenter eliminated Donald C. Vaughan Jr. of the Garden City Casino, 15-8, 15-3, and Baker halted K.J. Ridgeway, also of Garden City, 15-6, 15-11, in the semifinals.

The trial in Federal court of five election officials of the Fourth Assembly District, on a charge of intimidating voters at the polls and failure to count votes properly last November, developed yesterday into an attack by defense counsel upon Paul Blanshard, executive secretary of the City Affairs Committee.

One of the broadest general advances in recent months, exceeded in scope this year only by the move after the reopening of the banks, took place in the local commodity exchanges yesterday. Rubber futures were the leaders, while sugar and silver also made strong rallies, and all others closed with gains on the day.

The dollar fell to the lowest level in years in the foreign exchange market yesterday. Through a combination of simultaneous foreign raiding, domestic fears of inflation and apparent misunderstanding among the big banks and the Federal Reserve and Treasury authorities, sterling was rushed up 6 1/8 cents to $3.47 1/2, the franc rose 4 1/4 points to 3.99 cents, the highest price since 1926, and all other foreign currencies soared.

An appeal to Secretary of State Hull and Frances Ferkins, Secretary of Labor, to ease immigration restrictions against political refugees, was urged yesterday at a conference on international and racial problems under the auspices of the social education committee of the United Neighborhood Houses in Greenwich House, 27 Barrow Street.

TORONTO, April 13. -- The world's hockey championship returned to the United States tonight. The New York Rangers, meeting the rugged Toronto Maple Leafs, in the fourth game of the Stanley Cup series, defeated the defending champions in a torrid struggle that went 7 minutes and 34 seconds overtime by the score of 1 to 0.

ALBANY, April 13. -- Edward P. Mulrooney, former Police Commissioner of New York City, making his bow as chairman of the State Alcoholic Beverage Control Board, pledged the board in a radio address this evening to a policy free from political influences.

WASHINGTON, April 13. -- Imported beer will not have to pay an internal revenue tax, but will still be liable to the import tax, it was decided at the Treasury late this afternoon as a result of protests which importers have been making over an anticipated obligation to pay both levies.

A watchman was missing, fifteen firemen were overcome or injured and the interior of a two-story packing plant was destroyed early this morning by a four-alarm fire in the Bronx. The building, at 631 Brook Avenue, was the Bronx and Westchester plant of Morris Co., one of a line of such buildings in which the week-end supplies of Morris Co., Swift Co. and Armour Co. are stored.

WASHINGTON, April 13. -- France's attitude should present no obstacle to any low-tariff movement which might develop at the World Economic Conference, it was indicated today by Andre Lefebvre de Laboulaye, new French Ambassador, at his first press conference since his arrival.

WASHINGTON, April 13 (AP). -- Cotton consumed in March was reported by the Census Bureau today at 494,167 bales of lint and 50,082 bales of linters, compared with 441,663 of lint and 46,470 of linters in February this year, and 488,907 of lint and 55,388 of linters in March last year.

BOSTON, April 13. -- Eight deaths and untold property damage on land and sea marked a wild April blizzard which raged across New England today. It buried the six States under a soggy snowfall ranging from 5 inches to 3 feet and hurled huge waves on a flood tide against a 300-mile waterfront.

A hard-hitting New York University nine repulsed Lehigh, 12 to 2, at Ohio Field yesterday. The Violet batters made thirteen hits and took advantage of seven Lehigh errors to capture the long-drawn-out contest, which required more than two hours to play.
BOSTON, April 13. -- Heman Merrick Burr, retired Boston lawyer, who graduated from Harvard in 1877, died today at his home here. He had been ill for only a week. His age was 76.

MOSCOW, April 13. -- The screen that has hidden the real basis and purpose of the trial of the Metropolitan-Vickers Electrical Company engineers was brusquely torn away this evening when Prosecutor Andrey Y. Vishinsky read a deposition that L.C. Thornton, a British subject, made on March 13 during the preliminary inquiry.

DETROIT, April 13. -- A committee of officials of this city will be in New York on Monday morning to lay before a large group of bondholders a refunding program by which Mayor Frank Murphy and the Council hope to get a low tax rate for the current year and to avoid increasing the city's financial tangle.

ALBANY, April 13 (AP). -- Milk producers and dealers joined hands at the hearing to demand the minimum prices established by the board as a stop-gap order to end price wars pending the fixing of permanent minimum prices for individual localities.

PHILADELPHIA, April 13. -- The Francis Wayland Ayer Cup for typographical superiority was awarded to THE NEW YORK TIMES today in the third exhibition of newspaper typography, in which 1,386 dailies were entered.

Nearly two generations of New Yorkers benefited by the dramatic criticism of the late J. RANKEN TOWSE. They knew that uncommon intelligence and a sturdy character were behind all that he wrote about the contemporary theatre.
WASHINGTON, April 13. -- Prompt passage of legislation to relieve mortgage-burdened owners of small homes was urged by President Roosevelt today in a special message to Congress.

DETROIT, April 13 (AP). -- Fred Marberry, late of the Senators, pitching his first game for Detroit, held Cleveland to six hits and one run in the first eight innings today, then weakened and the Indians won their second consecutive game from the Tigers, 7 to 4.

LAKEHURST, N.J., April 13. -- The navy dirigible Akron could have escaped the storm which wrecked her on April 3 if she had held her course to the west, a course which she abandoned at midnight when she again started out to sea and was enveloped in thunderstorms, it was brought out here today before the naval court of inquiry.

Alone of the lines serving New York, the Pennsylvania and Long Island Railroads will begin storedoor service in the metropolitan area on May 1. The other railroads, which, with the Pennsylvania and Long Island, have been postponing the service for six months, withdrew their proposed tariffs from the Trunk Line Association.

Ratification of the League of Nations convention on narcotics by a sufficient number of States to make it binding upon all the signatories comes as a happy surprise. Until six weeks ago only nine countries out of the necessary twenty-five had ratified this treaty of 1931 (the Drug Limitation Treaty) and only two of the required four manufacturing countries: the United States and Turkey.

LONDON, April 13. -- Prime Minister MacDonald told Parliament today his chief objective in going to America was so "Great Britain and the United States may act closer together, not in alliance but in a spirit, that a new relationship may be established between the two countries of the most cordial and cooperative kind."

Again the Treasury's receipts from income taxes have made a disappointing showing. When the rates in all brackets were sharply advanced by the revenue act of 1932 it was hoped by Congress that the yield would be increased accordingly.

WASHINGTON, April 13. -- A plan to mobilize private industry under the government for expansion in the production of articles and materials in normal demand, this expansion to be coeval with the administration's public works activities, is being developed by the President's closest advisers, and they hope to persuade him to attempt it.
LONDON, April 13 (AP). -- The weekly statement of the Bank of England shows the following changes in pounds sterling:

THE head coach of football at West Point has a military background as well as a military foreground. "His father's sword he has girded on," in the words of the old song, but he has no wild harp slung behind him. Lieutenant Garrison Holt Davidson, Corps of Engineers, is not musical. He is emphatic about that.

The principal improvement in bonds on the Stock Exchange yesterday occurred in domestic corporation issues, with the rails, industrials and utilities averaging higher in the order named. United States Government bonds were irregularly higher, and foreign loans irregularly lower with German loans leading the decline.

Dr. Hans Luther, former president of the Reichsbank and recently appointed German Ambassador to the United States, will arrive today on the North German Lloyd liner Bremen. Others on the Bremen include Mr. and Mrs. F. Ambrose Clark, whose horse won the Grand National at Aintree; Max Schmeling, German heavyweight champion; John M. Morehead, United States Minister to Sweden; Cardinal J.M. Rodriue Sweden; Cardinal J.M. Rodrique Nelson Doubleday, publisher, and the following:

PARIS, April 13. -- France's "effective expenditure for military defense" has been reduced from almost 9,000,000,000 francs [$352,620,000] in 1932 to only slightly over 6,000,000,000 francs [$235,080,000] this year. Premier Daladier made this declaration in the Chamber of Deputies today in seeking to prove that this budgetary economy was an indication of France's good faith in disarmament.
WASHINGTON, April 13. -- The War Department issued the following orders today:

Dissolutions of three Stock Exchange firms, Wilcox, Drake Co., R.V. Hiscoe Co. and T.F. Scholl Co., were announced yesterday. The last named firm was dissolved on Monday, and action in the two others will be effective officially tomorrow.

Thursday, April 13, 1933. Stock Exchange call money was 1 per cent all day. This was the first time the flat rate of 1 prevailed since Feb. 28. Outside money was done at 3/4. Time money and acceptances were quiet and unchanged. Choice name commercial paper was quoted at 2 1/2 per cent.

WASHINGTON, April 13. -- Under the guidance of Henry Morgenthau Jr., head of the Farm Board, representatives of farmer-owned cooperative marketing associations and private traders have agreed on a plan for more orderly marketing of wool.

PINEHURST, N.C., April 13. -- Frank Shields of New York, the second seeded player, was eliminated from the North and South tennis championship today, when Bryan Grant of Atlanta, the former national clay-court champion, won a five-set quarter-final round match, 6 -- 4, 6 -- 4, 1 -- 6, 5 -- 7, 6 -- 3.

WASHINGTON, April 13 (AP). -- If you happened to own a $10,000 home and had against it an $8,000 mortgage which you could not carry, you could go about benefiting by the $2,000,000,000 home mortgage bill in this way:

A violent movement in foreign exchange, which placed the dollar at a serious disadvantage temporarily in its relation to other currencies, tended yesterday to obscure the action of the security and commodity markets. The fluctuations were the widest in many years.

While Mr. and Mrs. John Vasko barricaded their Westchester home against physicians and newspaper men yesterday, the Appellate Division in Brooklyn received final briefs on the legal question as to whether the State should permit physicians to operate on two-year-old Helen Vasko against her parents' wishes.

Mario Castelnuovo-Tedesco's Second violin concerto was played for the first time anywhere by Jascha Heifetz at the concerts of last night and Wednesday afternoon of the Philharmonic - Symphony Orchestra, Arturo Toscanini, conductor, in Carnegie Hall.

Holders of preferred shares of Burns Brothers obtained increased representation on the board through the election of three directors, Harry E. Byram, Allison Dodd and Mason B. Starring, at the annual meeting of stockholders in Jersey City yesterday.

WASHINGTON, April 13. -- While no official comment could be obtained tonight, it was understood that no concern was felt here because of the fall in the exchange value of the dollar today in its relationship to some of the foreign currencies.

WASHINGTON, April 13 (AP). -- The Interstate Commerce Commission today denied an application of the City of New York and six business organizations in that city for further hearing in the New York Harbor lighterage case.

LEXINGTON, Ky., April 13. -- J. C. Milam's Captain Red won his third consecutive victory and his second of the week when he romped home four lengths in front of C.W. Moore's Scream in the featured Leyland Hotel Purse at Lexington today. R.L. Baker's Peggy Lehmann was third.

The Minnie Untermyer Memorial Theatre formally became part of the Hebrew University In Palestine yesterday. Simultaneously, at a luncheon in his honor here, Samuel Untermyer, the donor, said the regime of Adolf Hitler had cast a pal over the dedication.
WASHINGTON, April 13 (AP). -- The petition filed with the Senate making charges against Senator Long read as follows:

BOSTON, April 13 (AP). -- The Boston Cubs put on such a sustained drive that they defeated the firstplace Philadelphia Arrows, 4 -- 2, to even the Canadian-American Hockey League's championship play-off at two games each before 8,000 at the Boston Garden tonight.

College yachtsmen will have an opportunity to compete for a special trophy in the ocean race to be held by the Gibson Island Yacht Squadron starting on June 24, it was announced yesterday by the race committee.

WASHINGTON, April 13. -- Unanimous agreement to go ahead with the Glass banking reform bill, including the establishment of a $2,000,000,000 fund to insure bank deposits, was reached today by the Senate banking subcommittee in charge of the measure.

A schedule of 150 racing days for the season of 1933 was announced yesterday by the stewards of the Jockey Club, governing body of the turf in this State, accompanied by the statement that every material economy would be practiced and that all of the associations would pull together to carry on in the face of difficult conditions.

There bounded over the ancient and honorable stage of the Empire Theatre last evening as nice a collection of rascals as it could ever boast. They appeared for and in "The 3-Penny Opera," and on behalf of the restoration to a beer-complacent city of -- the restoration drama.
CHICAGO, April 13 (AP). -- Southpaw Bill Hallahan's pitching, plus Jimmy Collins's hitting, gave the Cardinals a 3-to-1 victory over the champion Cubs today and evened the series.

NEWARK, N.J., April 13. -- After the City Commission had adopted a resolution cutting $1,500,000 from the budget for municipal and school purposes for this year, arrangements were completed for the sale of $1,750,000 in temporary bonds of the city, and it was announced that the city payroll, due on April 1, would be paid Saturday.

LONDON, April 13. -- Sir John Simon, Foreign Secretary, declared categorically in the House of Commons today that none of the British engineers now on trial in Moscow had ever been directly or indirectly connected with the British Intelligence Service, had never received money from it or been promised any money, had never been asked to furnish Information and never had furnished any.

PRINCETON, N.J., April 13. -- The resignation, because of continued ill health, of Professor Augustus Trowbridge as dean of the graduate school of Princeton University was accepted today "with regret" by the board of trustees at their Spring meeting here.

WASHINGTON, April 13. -- Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt was thrown into a mud puddle in Potomac Park early today when her horse slipped. She was uninjured and remounted to continue her morning ride in mud-spattered costume.

LONDON, April 13. -- A sudden flurry in the dollar, which aroused some excitement but greater speculation, regarding its cause, occurred tonight in London after the official markets had closed. When Throgmorton Street finally was cleared, dollars unofficially were on offer at the rate of $3.44 3/4 to $3.45 for the pound sterling, and there were no takers.

BERLIN, April 13. -- The government is losing no time in applying the recently decreed law barring persons of Jewish extraction and Marxists from the civil service. The first action was taken today by Education Minister Rust of Prussia, who ordered enforced leaves of absence for sixteen university professors, of whom thirteen are of Jewish extraction.
VATICAN CITY, April 13 (AP). -- Priests poured wine and water on the central altar, stone of St. Peter's this evening to commemorate Christ's passion 1,900 years ago.

Nothing could be more logical than the Nazi student campaign for purging German literature and the German language of Jewish elements. If adult Hitlerite leaders have discovered that the authors of the Old Testament are a pernicious element in the German national life, the college boys are hardly to be blamed for cpming to the same decision about modern Jewish writers.

NEWARK, N.J., April 13.-- The fastest multi-engined transport plane designed for regular service reached Newark Airport this morning. It had flown, from Chicago to this field, in a journey broken at Cleveland, in 4 hours 35 minutes without the aid of tail winds.

ROME, April 13. -- Statements made today by Vice Chancellor Franz von Papen of Germany and Captain Hermann Wilhelm Goering, Reich Minister Without Portfolio, indicated that as a result of their conversations with Premier Mussolini Italy and Germany would henceforth work in harmony toward the same objective and would stand side by side on most if not all international questions.

The annual display of Spring flowers conducted by the Department of Parks at the conservatories in Central Park, along Fifth Avenue, between, 104th and 106th Streets, was opened yesterday by Deputy Commissioner John M. Hart, assisted by other members of the staff.

A flower-blanketed urn containing the ashes of Lieut. Col. Alfred F. Masury, who perished in the Akron disaster, was committed to the deep with the solemn ceremonies of sea burial from the rolling deck of the Coast Guard cutter Champlain five miles off the Ambrose Light at noon yesterday.

MANILA, April 13. -- Emillo Aguinaldo, former rebel leader, plans to make his first speeches on the Hawes independence act in a campaign Saturday and Sunday in the province of Bulacan, in which was the capital of the short-lived Filipino republic.

A sharp advance of 1.5 points carried The Annalist weekly index of wholesale commodity prices up to 83.3 on Tuesday, from 81.8 (revised) the week before, leaving it at the highest level since Jan. 10, when it stood at 83.9. The rise was due chiefly to the upturn of 5 cents in wheat.

NANKING, April 13. -- The Communist situation in Kiangsi Province today was worse than it ever had been before and more inimical to the government's existence than at any time in the past, according to a Nanking official spokesman this morning.

A will and two codicils of Herbert Nathan Straus, vice president of R.H. Macy Co. and president of L. Bamberger Co. of Newark, filed yesterday in the Surrogates' Court, disclosed that a total gift of $1,250,000 left to his widow, Therese Kuhn Straus, was reduced to $300,000, while charitable gifts aggregating about $1,000,000 were revoked.

RENO, Nev., April 13. -- Divorce proceedings against Colonel Henry H. Rogers will be started here about May 15, it became known today with the identification here of his wife, who came here April 1. The suit will charge extreme cruelty, it is understood.

All markets -- those which deal in commodities as well as those on which securities are traded -- will be closed today in observance of Good Friday. However, business will not be suspended entirely in Wall Street. The banks will be open as usual. Several commodity exchanges will remain closed until Monday.

NEW YORK. Mrs. Enrico Giobbi della Bitta of Rome, the former Miss Mary Stanley, arrived on the Saturnia and is at the New Weston before going to Baltimore. Her husband and son, now in Rome, will join her here in June.

MOSCOW, April 13 (AP). -- For five hours tonight L.C. Thornton, one of six British engineers on trial, sat in the witness stand of a packed court room and denied, item by item, a confession which, he said, had been wrung from him by the Soviet secret police.

WASHINGTON, April 13. -- Administration leaders sustained the first setback in the Roosevelt legislative program today when the Senate voted, 47 to 41, to incorporate in the agriculture relief bill an authorization for the Secretary of Agriculture to fix agricultural prices on a "cost-of-production" basis.

Easter flowers will be cheaper this year than they have been on any previous Easter in the last two decades, a Fifth Avenue florist announced yesterday. The air mail, winging natural blossoms from the fertile West Coast and making fast deliveries from Canada and the South, is held responsible for the drop.

WASHINGTON, April 13. -- Power distribution directly by the government through the proposed Muscle Shoals plant drew sharp criticism today from representatives of leading power interests, who testified before the House Military Affairs Committee that construction of transmission lines to distant points would be a waste of government money.

Off to a delayed start, major league baseball nevertheless moved swiftly into its stride at the Stadium yesterday as the Yankees triumphantly launched the 1933 championship season of the American League in New York.

BERLIN, April 13. -- On the eve of a four-day holiday stocks on the Boerse exhibited a firm tone today. I.G. Farbenindustrie was a centre of interest, rising 1 3/4 points above yesterday's closing quotation.

WASHINGTON, April 13. -- Open warfare on the liquor traffic, including a "buy dry" campaign against grocers and others who sell beer, was urged today at the conference of women prohibitionists called by Mrs. Henry W. Feabody, founder and chairman of the Women's National Committee for Law Enforcement, which, opened here yesterday.

Railroad officials moved promptly yesterday to answer the sweeping investigation into rates launched this week by the Interstate Commerce Commission. The material to be provided in response to the commission's questionnaire is expected to be used by the Federal moderator of railroads contemplated in pending legislation at Washington.

PLAM BEACH, Fla., April 13. -- Mrs. William Woods Plankinton entertained twenty guests with a dinner followed by contract tonight at Casa de los Ensuenos, her lakefront villa. With Miss Elise Plankinton, her daughter, she will return to New York late this month to pass a short time before sailing for Paris for the Summer.

WASHINGTON, April 13 (AP). -- The administration's $2,000,000,000 farm mortgage refinancing bill as passed today by the House authorizes the Federal Land Banks to issue $2,000,000,000 on farm-loan bonds, at a maximum interest rate of 4 per cent.

LONDON, April 13. -- Lieutenant Norman Baillie-Stewart of the Sea-forth Highlanders, known as "the Officer in the Tower," who was recently tried by court-martial under the official secrets act has been sentenced to dishonorable dismissal from the army and to five years' penal servitude, the War Office announced today.

Various modifications in the minimum basic agreement between theatrical producers and the Dramatists Guild, which will not expire until 1936, were discussed yesterday afternoon at a lengthy meeting of the producers in the offices of the League of New York Theatres.

The Utah Copper Company controlled by the Kennecott Copper Corporation, reports for 1932 a consolidated net loss of $2,469,704, after operating expenses, depreciation and adjustments for the price of the metal, the last amounting to $1,150,627.

WASHINGTON, April 13 (AP). -- The administration's $2,000,000,000 farm mortgage refinancing bill as passed today by the House authorizes the Federal Land Banks to issue $2,000,000,000 on farm-loan bonds, at a maximum interest rate of 4 per cent.

WASHINGTON, April 13. -- Proposals for legislation to give to the President authority to reduce or Increase postal rates during the period for which the 3-cent rate was enacted will be sent to Congress soon, Postmaster General Farley announced today.

LONDON, April 18 (AP). -- Prime Minister MacDonald told Parliament today that "American policy always has been to avoid any European entanglement, and I never would try to persuade America to do otherwise than to carry out that historic policy."

JERUSALEM, April 13. -- Viscount and Viscountess Allenby and Sir Arthur Grenfell Wauchope, the High Commissioner for Palestine, were among those who attended the dedication ceremony for the new Graeco-Roman stage of the Minnie Untermyer open air theatre at the Hebrew University this afternoon.

Clearings of checks at banks in twenty-one of the leading financial and business centres of the country declined again sharply last week, according to the compilation by Dun Bradstreet, Inc. The gap between this year's and last year's weekly totals is approaching the proportions reported before the banking holiday.

The quotations are for three-four months paper. * * * Dry Goods Orders Expanded. Dry goods wholesalers operated a little more freely toward the end of this week, although they continued to confine orders to current needs, they reported yesterday.
WASHINGTON, April 13. -- The text of the bill submitted by President Roosevelt to Congress today to set up machinery for refinancing home mortgages follows:

LONDON, April 13. -- Sir Austen Chamberlain, former Foreign Minister, stirred applause on both sides of the House of Commons tonight in a speech criticizing Prime Minister Ramsay MacDonald and Foreign Minister Sir John Simon for even thinking of revision of the peace treaties at this time.
Resale of a Jersey City apartment house by a bank was included in the New Jersey realty transactions reported yesterday.
WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W.Va., April 13. -- Larz Anderson, former American Ambassador to Japan, arrived at the Greenbrier tonight from Washington to pass Easter.

ST. LOUIS, April 13 (AP). -- The White Sox won a slugging match from the Browns, 11 to 7, in eleven innings today. The Sox amassed twenty hits, including a home run by Fonseca, as against fourteen hits for St. Louis. Jack Knott, making his big league debut on the mound for the Browns, allowed eleven hits in seven innings.

Charles E. Mitchell, who resigned as chairman of the National City Bank two months ago after making admissions to a Senatorial investigating committee, was indicted yesterday for the second time on the charge of evading payment of his income tax.

Mayor O'Brien announced last night a list of fourteen police officials, army officers and civilians who had been recommended to him for the vacancy in the Police Commissionership and said he needed more time in which to decide on the successor to former Commissioner Edward P. Mulrooney.
Pearl S. Buck, novelist and missionary, says in a magazine article that Jesus Christ is "not often truly believed in even by those who profess to be His followers.
Ernest Cossart, whose last appearance here was in G.B. Shaw's "Too True to Be Good," has been engaged for the Theatre Guild's forthcoming production of "The Mask and the Face."

Application for the listing of voting trust certificates for 1,949,111 shares of $1 par value common stock of the Sperry Corporation, formed through the segregation of certain properties of North American Aviation, Inc., has been made to the New York Stock Exchange.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., April 13. -- Yale athletic authorities tonight stated that they had not received a formal invitation for the Yale crew to participate in the proposed international eight-oared regatta on the Olympic marine stadium course at Long Beach on July 8.

The Morris and Evander Childs High School baseball teams triumphed in seven-inning games played yesterday in the Bronx. Morris registered its third victory in as many contests by defeating Colby Academy, 5 to 4, at Sterling Oval.

Borough President Samuel Levy of Manhattan took issue last night with Mayor O'Brien on the creation of an executive budget for the city. With Mayor O'Brien on record as favoring the proposal, the Manhattan Borough President emphatically opposed the recommendation and urged that the Board of Estimate keep its budget-making powers.

The Brooklyn Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals was investigating yesterday the complaint of Mrs. W.F. Sillock Jr. of 66 Kenilworth Place, Brooklyn, that some one had cut the tongue of her 2-year-old Maltese cat, Cap, injuring the animal so seriously it had to be killed.

Dr. William H. Walker, brother of the former Mayor, and four other physicians were exonerated yesterday of fraud and deceit by the medical grievance committee of the State Education Department. The committee ruled adversely on the petition of the city affairs committee that their licenses be revoked.

It is scarcely to be wondered at that Pan-American Day this year is not marked by the exuberance, whether real or merely conventional, of other days. President ROOSEVELT, speaking at the ceremonies in Washington, frankly referred to the fact that there are existing armed conflicts between "four of our sister republics."

WASHINGTON, April 13. -- Judge John Barton Payne, chairman of the American Red Cross and of the League of Red Cross Societies, has received a message from the German Red Cross declaring that published reports of atrocities there under the rule of the National Socialist party were "in no way in accordance with, facts."

With Tammany already divided into two factions, one supporting John F. Curry, the leader, and the other, a minority group, pledged to Edward J. Ahearn, a third faction, led by James J. Hines, leader of the Eleventh Assembly District, is in process of formation, it became known yesterday.

WASHINGTON, April 13. -- Charging Senator Long with personal dishonesty, corruption, immorality, with controlling the State Legislature, making elections a farce, with racketeering and bribery, former Governor John M. Parker and other Louisiana citizens petitioned the Senate today to investigate these accusations and eject the Senator if they are found true.

For five weeks the power of prayer has been invoked to save small homes in Queens Village menaced by the depression by the members of the Roman Catholic Church of Our Lady of Lourdes, 220th Street and Ninety-third Avenue. A constant novena has been held under the leadership of the Rev. Bernard J. Reilly, rector of the church.

At the request of Secretary of Commerce Roper for suggestions for improving railroad terminal conditions in New York, the Port of New York Authority has submitted proposals by which facilities would be pooled or consolidated to effect an annual saving estimated at $7,500,000.

PARIS, April 14 -- The French press collectively rejoices today over the harsh words spoken against Germany In the British House of Commons yesterday. No pronouncements that have come out of London In many months have aroused such a sense of relief and satisfaction as the verbal drubbing tha Hitlerites received at the hands of Sir Austen Chamberlain, Sir Herbert Samuel, Colonel Wedgwood Benn, Winston Churchill and even Sir John Simon, the Foreign Secretary.

MOSCOW, April 14 -- A Russian witness charged tonight that L.C. Tnornton, British engineer, organized a plot which, in case of war, would have paralyzed the large Moscow electric station serving the Kremlin, important factories and powerful wireless stations.

LONDON, April 14 -- The instructlons that Dr. Leopold von Hoesch, the German Ambassador, received from the Berlin government today to protest immediately and energetically against speeches made during the debate in the House of Commons yesterday are held here to be "absurd."

WASHINGTON, April 14 -- Democratic Senate leaders, faced with the necessity of voting on several inflation plans before reaching final decision on the agricultural relief bill, hoped tonight that this phase of debate might be concluded tomorrow.

The American Telephone and Telegraph Company reports net income of $32.055,227 for the first quarter of 1933, equal to $1.72 a share on the average number of shares outstanding in the period, comparing with $38,879,531, or $2.08 a share, in the first quarter of 1932.

Over the protest of spokesmen of the Administration the Senate has added the so-called Simpson plan to the new farm bill. It authorizes the Secretary of Agriculture "to proclaim from time to time" prices for farm products equivalent to the cost of producing that part of the crop which goes into the domestic market.

BOSTON, April 14 -- Fighting doggedly for twenty-four hours in a raging sea, within sight of the dangerous tip of Cape Cod, the crew of the Coast Guard cutter Ossipee today rescued twenty-eight men on the disabled coastal freighter Malang.

CHICAGO, April 14 -- City officials tonight decided on a big drive to sell 1932 education tax warrants to the public so as to pay the school teachers. The campaign is to be conducted as was the sale of the Liberty loans with everybody in the city and suburbs being canvassed.
Something' of the lost "glory that was Greece" lives in Manhattan today In, a marble statuette rivaling in Interest any other piece of Pentelic marble that has ever come to America.

SOUTH RIVER, N.J., April 14 -- Crazed by acute alcoholism for which he had been treated for six months at the State Hospital for the Insane, Joseph Kensek, 50 years old, a former miner in Pennsylvania, shot and killed his wife and two children in their home here early this morning and then ended his own life by swallowing poison and leaping from a second-story window.

The appointment of former President Hoover as a good-will envoy to Germany "to save Germany from the catastrophic blunders" of the Nazi Government's anti-Jewish policy is suggested to President Roosevelt by David A. Brown, publisher, in the current issue of The American Hebrew and Jewish Tribune, appearing today.

Behind the brilliant pitching of Howard (Ace) Elliott the Buffalo Bisons shut out Jersey City, 7 to 0, in the International League inaugural at West Side Park. Jersey City, yesterday before 8,000 persons. Mayor Frank Hague tossed the first ball.
The city continued without an active head of its Police Department yesterday, while political differences over the choice of a successor to Edward P. Mulrooney were being ironed out.

An orderly meeting of Communists listened last night in Union Square to speakers for the International Labor Defense plead for unity among white persons and Negroes to fight for the release of the "Scottsboro boys."

WASHINGTON, April 14 (AP) -- Calling upon the President and Congress to "revoke" the 3.2 per cent beer bill, the Woman's National Committee for Law Enforcement tonight adjourned Its three-day convention here under the leadership of Mrs. Henry W. Peabody.
Churches throughout the city were crowded yesterday for Good Friday services marking the 1,900th observance of the death of Christ.

HAVRE DE GRACE, Md., April 14 -- With eight Kentucky Derby eligibles, including the highly regarded Ladysman, nominated for the Bayview Purse and another strong field entered in the featured $2,500-added Harford Handicap, the inaugural of Maryland's 100-day racing season, will get under way tomorrow.

Charles E. Mitchell, former chairman of the National City Bank, pleaded not guilty before Federal Judge Frank J. Coleman yesterday to an indictment charging him with evading payment of $156,791.09 income tax on his $760,389.90 income in 1930.

PHILADELPHIA, April 14. -- Topped by the perfect hitting of Johnny Frederick the Dodger bats spoke with complete authority today for fifteen hits as Brooklyn scored its second victory in a row over the Phillies. The score was 7 to 1.

WASHINGTON, April 14 (AP) -- More than 2,000 panacea plans which have poured in upon Secretary Frances Perkins from citizens eager to help the nation were "roughly classified" by her today into six types, as follows:

Among the passengers on the Hamburg-American liner New York, which arrived yesterday from Hamburg and channel ports, was Major Gen. Friedrich von Boetticher, the first military attache assigned to the German Embassy in Washington since the World War.

CLEVELAND, April 14 (AP). -- Formation of a central marketing agency to handle the output of coal mines in the West Virginia Panhandle and Ohio, with the exception of the Hocking district, was approved today. Its sponsors hope to launch the plan next week.

To the Editor of The New York Times: It has been called to my attention during the last few days that the agencies in the city have encountered no small difficulty in filling their quota of recruits for the conservation corps. It was also reported in THE NEW YORK TIMES that 257 men had dropped out after arriving at Fort Slocum.

HAVANA, April 14 -- With bombs exploding here and there at intervals of fifteen minutes to half an hour, Havana last night and today seemed like a city bombarded by an enemy fleet. All authorities agreed that twenty-six bombs had exploded in the city or suburbs, oppositionists said the number was forty-three and some sources put the figure as high as seventy-two.

Juries make law, and before long a great many law-book statements of legal doctrine must be revised to keep up with juries, Judge Joseph N. Ulman, of the Supreme Bench of Baltimore, says in "A Judge Takes the Stand," published today by Alfred Knopf.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., April 14 -- The varsity and junior varsity crews of Princeton and the Naval Academy held their final drills today in preparation for their races tomorrow.
LOS ANGELES, Saturday, April 15 -- The Los Angeles Times this morning prints a dispatch from Kyle D. Palmer, its Washington correspondent, which in part reads:

Two hold-up men, one of whom described himself as a former honor man and football player at Brooklyn College, were arrested yesterday after a two-block chase in which 200 pedestrians took part and charged with stealing $803 and jewelry from four men in an apartment at 341 West Forty-fifth Street.
WASHINGTON, April 14 (AP). -- Shutting out the Senators for eight innings, Bob Grove today led the Philadelphia Athletics to a 5-to-1 victory, their first of the season.

The dry forces of the State, under the leadership of the Woman's Christian Temperance Union and the Anti-Saloon League, completed yesterday their slate of antl-repeal candidates for convention delegates to be voted for at the special election on May 23.
WASHINGTON, April 14. -- The Treasury will not call the $6,268,095,250 Fourth Liberty Loan, President Roosevelt announced today.

Member lines of the United States intercoastal steamship conference were summoned yesterday to a meeting to be held Tuesday at conference headquarters, 44 Whitehall Street, to consider the problems created by the passage of the Copeland bill at the recent session of Congress.

WASHINGTON, April 14 -- Routine work at the Navy Department was practically at a standstill today while fifty bureau chiefs and administrative officers conferred with Assistant Secretary Roosevelt on economy plans. While Secretary Swanson said that no order had come from President Roosevelt as yet concerning the amount of expense reduction expected of the navy, it was evident that such an order was looked for soon.

WASHINGTON, April 14 -- With the Republicans, aided by some Democrats, standing solidly in opposition to the resolution granting arms embargo authority to President Roosevelt, the House staged an old-time partisan debate today.

WASHINGTON, April 14 -- Mayor James M. Curley of Boston, nominated to be Ambassador to Poland, declined the appointment today and informed President Roosevelt that sentiment in Boston demanded that he remain at his post there. After calling on the President, Mayor Curley made the following statement:

HAVANA, April 14 -- Two youths believed to be the brothers Abilio and Ramiro Valdes Daussa were deliberately shot down by government agents today, following their arrest after a night of terroristic bombing. One was killed at once and the other fatally injured.

MIAMI, Fla., April 14 -- General Mario G. Menocal, speaking as leader of the opposition to President Machado of Cuba, emphatically denied tonight responsibility for the bombing outbreak in Havana and deplored terroristic activities in a statement issued from his residence here.

Despite pleas for clemency by the prosecutor and police officials, Federal Judge Clarence G. Galston in Brooklyn yesterday ruled that Ernest Schoening, rum runner and central figure in a kidnapping, must serve a two-year sentence for bribing coast guardsmen.

George Jean Nathan offers in "Since Ibsen." published today by Alfred A. Knopf, a "statistical historical digest of the elements that have gone to constitute the world's popular threatre since the time of Ibsen." It is a collection of situations and lines in the theatre of which Mr. Nathan is tired.

ST. PAUL, April 14. -- Governor Olsen replied today to a charge made in the State Senate yesterday by Senator A.J. Rockne of Zumbrota, conservative leader, that the Governor was "playing politics" with relief measures.

PALM BEACH, Fla., April 14. -- Casa Alejandro, her villa in Vita Serena, was the setting for a dinner at which Mrs. George Alexander McKinlock entertained tonight and at which Jackson Hines sang. Mrs. McKinlock is remaining until May 1 before joining Mr. McKinlock, who left recently for Chicago.

PHILADELPHIA, April 14 -- The Rev. Dr. J. Gresham 'Machen, Professor of New Testament at West-minster Theological Seminary, today denounced as "misleading" a printed quotation of the Rev. Dr. Charles R. Erdman of Princeton, president of the Presbyterian Board of Foreign Missions, and reiterated that his own anti-modernist attack was directed against the board itself, with Pearl S. Buck, the novelist, an incidental factor.
The expanding force of an upward seasonal trend has contributed constructively to the broader forward movement in almost all branches of trade, Dun Bradstreet. Inc., say in their weekly trade review.

The pamphlet report of the Western Pacific Railroad Company for 1932 shows current assets of $5,291,323 and current liabilities of $3,640,067 as of Dec. 31, compared with $5,295,690 and $2,822,644, respectively, at the close of 1931. Long-term debt increased from $57,019,100 at the close of 1931 to $61,522,969 at the end of 1932.

Norman Henderson, founder of the banking firm of Henderson Co., who died Jan. 10, 1932, left an estate appraised yesterday at $1,300,875 gross and $1,215,507 net, of which $995,087 was in securities. Only $46,992 of the estate was taxable in New York because he was a resident of New Jersey.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., April 14 -- An imported maiden, heretofore only lightly regarded in the list of Kentucky Derby eligibles, won his way into the group of "dark horses" for the classic to be run May 6 by turning in a first-class workout today at Churchill Downs.

SAN JUAN, P.R., April 14 -- Saying Puerto Rico desired to become a State and be admitted to the Union. Rafael Martinez Nadal, the President of the Senate and of the Republican party, introduced today a concurrent resolution asking congress to call a constitutional convention as an essential step toward statehood.
CINCINNATI, April 14 (AP) -- Dr. Jermaine G. Porter, astronomer, an authority on stellar motion, died of heart disease here today at the age of 81.

BERLIN, April 14 -- The criticism of political developments in Germany that was heard yesterday in the British House of Commons has provided a great disappointment to German political opinion and it is felt all the more acutely as the National Socialist leaders have always been inclined to regard the Nordie Anglo-Saxon as a natural ally of the third Reich.

The dollar sagged again in the limited foreign exchange transactions here yesterday, while the status of gold for shipment abroad remained in doubt and apparently will not become definite until early next week because of the three and four day banking and business holidays in the principal, European centres.
NEW YORK. Mr. and Mrs. John A. Griswold and John A. Griswold Jr. have returned from the South and will be at the Pierre until they return to their home at 29 Rue de Constantine, Paris.

Savings banks in New York State had 15,256 more depositors on April 1 than on Jan. 1, according to the report of the Savings Bank Association of the State of New York for the first quarter of this year, which was issued yesterday. The 5,761,073 depositors had on April 1 total deposits of $5,208,374,227, a reduction of 1.8 per cent, or $94,241,045, since the beginning of the year.

The futility of scheduling new municipal bond issues for award so long as the market for such securities remains at almost a standstill was demonstrated this week, when bankers here passed up virtually the entire calendar of scheduled issues.

LEXINGTON, Ky., April 14 -- Dixiana's Constant Wife romped home an easy winner at Lexington today as a race for 2-year-old fillies held the feature position on the program. The Calumet Farm's Hug Again was second and Candle Fly third.

William Busk, 35 years old, a stock salesman, jumped from a fifth-floor extension of the St. George Hotel in Brooklyn early yesterday and was killed. Just before crawling out of his hotel-room window and crossing the extension roof he had slashed his throat with a broken tumbler.

WASHINGTON, April 14 (AP) -- Federal Reserve Board officials were called into consultation today by the Senate Banking subcommittee drafting permanent banking legislation, but at the conclusion of another long executive session Senator Glass, the chairman, said no conclusion had been reached.

The Northeastern Group of the American Political Science Association, closing its two-day session yesterday at Washington. Square College of New York University, was told that, with New York City's finances in worsa condition than ever, the city faced a possible $250,000,000 deficit this year that bankers were displacing political bosses as rulers of the country's large cities, and that the Roosevelt administration had done "practically nothing" so far to end the depression.

Explaining that his action had nothing to do with Gene Sarazen's recent criticism of the Professional Golfers' Association for its failure to include Billy Burke, 1931 open champion, on this year's Ryder Cup team, George R. Jacobus, president of the P.G.A., yesterday gave out the tabulation of votes in the poll from which the selections were made.
"Strange Gods," a play by Jessica Ball, will open tonight at the Ritz Theatre. The cast includes Vera Allen, John B. Litel, Ralph Theadore and Mary Horne, and Priestly Morrison is the director.
To the Editor of The New York Times: The movement on foot in Washington in respect to the underwriting and selling of securities is having a very sobering effect on the financial community.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In regard to your editorial "A Nut for Lawyers to Crack," I, in common with all general practitioners and the public in general, agree with the statements which indicate that the civil calendars of the various courts in this State are far in arrears, and that a good deal of such congestion is caused by demands for juries in automobile accident cases.

To the Editor of The New York Times: May I express a brief defense of the people of Kansas in reference to the prohibition question? It will be found upon investigation that our people are quite as sophisticated and as well informed as those of other States, but that because of no opportunity to throw off this tyranny we are still under control of the Anti-Saloon League.

AMHERST, Mass., April 14 -- The Amherst College athletic budget for 1933-34, as It has been adopted by President King and the advisory committee on sports, effects a reduction of over $6,000 in expenditures.
John Vasko, of Hastings-on-Hudson, who refused to permit an operation on his baby In an attempt to save her life, yielded a point yesterday by placing the responsibility in the hands of "the law."

TOKYO, April 14 -- Tokyo's first experience with anti-Semitic agitation came today when 2,500 persons heard a fierce anti-Jewish address by a retired General and received leaflets containing a song which exhorted them to "punish Jewish people, break the General Electric and defeat the Mazda lamp."

Fine linens and other textiles including embroidery and peasant type homespuns, examples of wood carving ranging from crucifixes to playing card cases, hand-painted ceramics, carved ivories and other novelties, all the products of Swiss home industry, will be shown to the public, beginning Monday, at the James McCutcheon Co. store, Forty-ninth Street and Fifth Avenue.

With the security and commodity Exchanges closed on account of Good Friday, interest was centred again yesterday in the foreign exchange market, which regained its composure after the unaccountable advance of European currencies against the dollar on the day before.

Federal Judge William Clark of New Jersey, foe of the Eighteenth Amendment, acted yesterday for an investigation of the issuance of Federal permits to three New Jersey breweries, at least one of which, he said, is alleged to have concerned the two racketeers murdered in Elizabeth on Wednesday.
The quotations are for three-four months' paper.

Business will be resumed on almost a normal basis in Wall Street this morning after having been sharply curtailed yesterday in observance of Good Friday. The security exchanges and most of the commodity exchanges will reopen. A few of the commodity exchanges will remain closed until Monday.

BERLIN, April 14 -- Criticism of Germany yesterday in the British House of Commons so aroused the ire of the Reich Government that Dr. Leopold von Hoesch, the German Ambassador, was ordered today to protest to Great Britain.

WASHINGTON, April 14 -- Passage of a Muscle Shoals bill with Federal construction of transmission lines provided would make worthless $400,000,000 of securities of six Southern utilities companies, W.L. Willkie, president of the Commonwealth and Southern Corporation, declared today before the House Military Affairs Committee.

WILDWOOD, N.J., April 14. -- Jerry Marr of the Torresdale Country Club, Philadelphia, blazed his way on the back nine with a subpar 34 to card a 74 and carry off the medal in the annual Eastern States Easter golf tournament at the Wildwood Country Club today.
SYRACUSE, April 14 -- Edward Schoeneck, appointed to the beer control board, has been leader in Republican politics for the past twenty-five years.

LOS ANGELES, April 14 -- Legal test of waiver agreements signed by several hundred film workers accepting a 50 per cent salary cut for a period of eight weeks or less loomed today as the result of the refusal of Warner Brothers-First National Studio to accept a decision of the emergency board of the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences.

WASHINGTON, April 14 -- Steps to coordinate all governmental forces of the nation with a remobilization of private Industry in an early attack on unemployment and wage deflation were mapped today in a conference at the White House.

The Rev. Dr. E. Stanley Jones, author and Methodist Episcopal Missionary in India, will preach at the Easter Dawn service tomorrow from 7 to 8 o'clock at the plaza, of Columbia University, 116th Street, west of Broadway, under the auspices of the Greater New York Federation of Churches.

Sir PERCY SYKES wrote only a few years ago that few countries are "by nature" more isolated than Persia. It was difficult to enter from the Persian Gulf. PIERRE LOTI, in his "Vers Isfahan," said of the road from Bushire by way of Shiraz that, while it was in effect a road, it was in reality an "escalier unimaginable."

WASHINGTON, April 14 (AP) -- The Senate agreed today to finish work on the provisions of the farm relief bill seeking to raise farm incomes to the 1909-14 level before taking up the mortgage sections. An amendment by Senator Robinson of Arkansas was adopted to change the date for making the proposed processing tax effective.
WASHINGTON, April 14 -- The war Department issued the following orders today:

VERBANK, N.Y., April 14 -- Running a meritorious race, Bend Down Sister, white and lemon pointer bitch, owned and handled by William H. Hand of East Hampton, L.I., gained her ninth field trial victory when she won the open junior all-age stage as the annual Spring trials of the Orange County Field Trial Club got under way today.

ALBANY, April 14. -- Seventeen bills, including two by Assemblyman Reidy, Bronx Democrat, relating to real estate brokers, were signed by Governor Lehman today, bringing to 197 the number he has approved.

WASHINGTON, April 14 -- Praise of President Roosevelt's action in inviting foreign nations to send representatives to confer with him in preparation for the coming World Economic Conference is contained in the formal French acceptance which was transmitted by the Embassy today.

A mass meeting in honor of Rose Pastor Stokes, militant radical leader, was held last night in Webster Hall, 119 East Eleventh Street. The meeting, attended by about 500 Communists and labor representatives, was intended primarily to raise funds for medical treatment for the divorced wife of J.G. Phelps Stokes.

WASHINGTON, April 14 -- A joint resolution to define the status of New York State's power rights under the St. Lawrence waterways treaty is being drafted by Democratic leaders at the suggestion of President Roosevelt.
BINCETON, N.J., April 14 -- Bob McNamara held Frinceton to lour hits as N.Y.U. blanked the Tigers, 4 to 0, on University Field today. He fanned nine hatters and did not issue a pass.

BUENOS AIRES, April 14 -- The United States-subsidized Pan American and Pan American-Grace Airways and the French-subsidized Aeropostale Air Line will be the objects of attack by Argentina at the Universal Postal Union's preparatory conference in Ottawa in May.

High water is likely to greet anglers who fare forth for the opening of the trout season in Connecticut today. Chief Game Warden A.J. Williamson reported last night that heavy rains and a fall of snow in the northern part of the State had sent the larger rivers raging.

Charlie Ruffing, star righthander of the Yankees, put on virtually a one-man show at the Stadium yesterday as the world's champions reeled off their second successive triumph of the recently inaugurated championship campaign by again defeating the Red Sox.
TORONTO, April 14. -- The New York Rangers disbanded today, departing for their homes in Canada and the United States. They left the Stanley Cup, however, in Toronto.

Americans must be sensible of the compliment paid them by the German Government in designating HANS LUTHER as Ambassador to the United States. His distinction and achievements are well known. Never technically a diplomat, he has had to undertake many tasks for his country which required him to be diplomatic.

DETROIT, Mich., April 14 -- Mayor Frank Murphy and a refunding committee will leave for New York Sunday evening with the hope that an agreement with Eastern bankers and insurance executives will be reached that will permit a workable refinancing program for $47,000,000 for municipal obligations due in 1933-34 and about $3,500,000 due in the balance of the current fiscal year.

NEWARK, N.J., April 14. -- A home-run smash into the left field bleachers by Jim Moore with Jack Saltzgaver on base enabled Newark to defeat the Montreal Royals in the opening game of the International League season here today, 2 to 1.

Governor LEHMAN'S selection of former Police Commissioner MULROONEY as chairman of the Alcoholic Beverage Control Commission was received with unanimous approval, tempered in this town with regret that an official so experienced, able and upright must be transferred to Albany.

WASHINGTON, April 14 (AP) -- Secretary Perkins of the Department of Labor today announced the membership of the advisory committee she asked the American Statistical Association to appoint for studying the statistical system of her department.

PRAGUE, April 14 -- Joseph Drechsler, a Czech woodcarver, who has lived for twenty years in Schmiedeberg, Germany, was found in a grave condition today in a field just across the border in Czechoslovakia, having been the victim, according to the newspaper Sozialdemokrat, of an assault by German Nazis.

ROME, April 14 (AP) -- With altars uncovered and tabernacles bare, all Rome's 400 churches today observed the solemn ceremonies commemo-rating the crucifixion of Christ nineteen bunderd years ago. Cardinal Pacelli, Papal Secretary of State, presided over Good Friday services in St. Peter's.

PINEHURST, N.C., April 14 -- Clifford Sutler of New Orleans, the nation's third ranking star, and George M. Lott Jr. of Chicago, rated eleventh, will meet tomorrow afternoon in the final round of the fifteenth annual North and South tennis tournament.

Surveys of the banking situation throughout the nation last night showed that far more than threequarters of the Federal Reserve member banks and well over half of the State banks are open and doing business on an unrestricted basis.

WASHINGTON, April 14 -- Senator Long was busy this afternoon drawing up an amendment to the Senate rules aimed at tho presentation of petitions such as the one received yesterday in which citizens of Louisiana denounced his personal and official conduct and urged his ejection from the Senate.
BOSTON, April 14 (AP) -- The Commercial Bulletin will say tomorrow:

Maung Suri, who grins and says "Yes, please," with the disturbing frequency of a phonograph caught in a rut, reluctantly left the balloon-tossing game in Madison Square Garden yesterday afternoon and summoned the giraffe-necked ladies.

WASHINGTON, April 14 (AP) -- A bill to prohibit railroads and pipe lines from carrying in interstate commerce oil produced in violation of State laws or regulations was introduced today by Representative Marland, Democrat, of Oklahoma.

BOSTON, April 14 -- Mrs. Catherine M. Logan of South Boston, widow of General Lawrence J. Logan and mother of General Edward L. Logan, died early today at her Summer home in Cohasset at the age of 81.

A conference of Jewish organizations and societies to renew the protest against the persecutions of Jews in Germany and the mobilization of "vigorous resistance'' to the anti-Semitic policies and actions of the Nazi government was called yesterday for Wednesday evening, April 19, by the American Jewish Congress.

Taxation and trucks and the proposed blending of grain alcohol with gasoline as a motor fuel are among the topics to be discussed at the midyear sessions of the American Petroleum Institute In Tuisa, Okla., on May 17, 18 and 19, it was announced yesterday.

HOT SPRINGS, Va., April 14. -- General and Mrs. Cornelius Vanderbilt arrived here this morning and after a carriage drive through the Warm Springs valley they were entertained with a tea by the Belgian Ambassador and Mme. May.

WASHINGTON, April 14 --There was a slight improvement in the French business situation in March, but it "was merely seasonal, the Department of Commerce said today In its weekly review of business-economic conditions abroad.

HARTFORD, Conn., April 14 -- While State police were investigating the incendiary fires which have cost the Ethel Walker School for Girls in Simsbury $400,000, Dr.E. Terry Smith, husband of Ethel Walker Smith, founder of the school, announced today that it would be removed temporarily to Fisher's Island in Long Island Sound off New London.
HAVANA, April 14 (AP) -- Police gunfire killed two young Cubans today and brought to seven the number of victims in the latest resurgence, of political terrorism in the last ten days.

Alanson B. Houghton, former United States Ambassador to Great Britain, will sail tonight for the Channel ports on the Bremen of the North German Lloyd Line. Others sailing are H.B. Lees-Smith, English economist; Count Carlos Sforza, Henry Rogers Winthrop, Mr. and Mrs. Harold Nicholson, Sir Hugh and Lady Smiley, Sir Hubert and Lady Wilkins, J.D. Elder, General R.E. Wood and Mrs. Grafton Payne.

LONDON, Saturday, April 15. -- William H. MacDonald, one of the British engineers on trial in Moscow, did withdraw his plea of guilty, but later recanted after he had been removed, and then returned to the court room, according to the British official version, and this has aroused more indignant comment than any other incident at the trial.

Early in April an exhibition was opened in the South Kensington Science Museum to commemorate the centenary of the death of RICHARD TREVITHICK, who in 1804 put in operation the first locomotive near Merthyr Tydvil, Wales. It pulled five wagons containing ten tons of iron and seventy men for a distance of nine and a half miles.

CHICAGO, April 14 -- The French people today see American leadership in international affairs being resumed, according to Pierre de Lanux, director of the Paris office of the League of Nations, who spoke today before the Chicago Council on Foreign Relations at the Palmer House.

Flowers in the Parks. The city's own flower shows are open to the public. It is now for the Federal Government to say whether it will help to make the occasion a success by providing the right kind of weather.

Ten thousand Jews have fled from Hitlerite terrorism in Germany, according to reports received by the Hebrew Sheltering and Immigrant Aid Society of America (known as HIAS) from Dr. James Bernstein, its European commissioner, and from affiliated organizations in Paris and Poland.

A necklace of ninety-one graduated pearls with a reputed value of about $100,000 was lost on "Wednesday afternoon during a shopping tour in the Fifth. Avenue district by Mrs. Eugene A. Noble of 1 Beekman Place, it became known yesterday.

While the report of the medical grievance committee of the State Department of Education clears Dr. WILLIAM H. WALKER and his associates of fraud, it condemns the system under which these famous fee-splitters were able to do such a lucrative business.
WASHINGTON, April 14 -- The Bureau of Navigation issued the following orders today, dated April 12:

Flowers in the Parks. The city's own flower shows are open to the public. It is now for the Federal Government to say whether it will help to make the occasion a success by providing the right kind of weather.

Ten thousand Jews have fled from Hitlerite terrorism in Germany, according to reports received by the Hebrew Sheltering and Immigrant Aid Society of America (known as HIAS) from Dr. James Bernstein, its European commissioner, and from affiliated organizations in Paris and Poland.

A necklace of ninety-one graduated pearls with a reputed value of about $100,000 was lost on "Wednesday afternoon during a shopping tour in the Fifth. Avenue district by Mrs. Eugene A. Noble of 1 Beekman Place, it became known yesterday.

While the report of the medical grievance committee of the State Department of Education clears Dr. WILLIAM H. WALKER and his associates of fraud, it condemns the system under which these famous fee-splitters were able to do such a lucrative business.
WASHINGTON, April 14 -- The Bureau of Navigation issued the following orders today, dated April 12:

Appearing in fine physical condition, Max Schmeling, former world's heavyweight boxing champion, arrived yesterday on board the North German Lloyd liner Bremen to begin preparations for his fifteen-round bout with Max Baer at the Yankee Stadium on June 8.

Several objections to the securities bill now before Congress were registered in a telegram sent yesterday by the Merchants Association of New York to Senator Duncan U. Fletcher, chairman of the Senate Committee on Banking and Currency, and Representative Sam Rayburn, chairman of the House Committee on Interstate and Foreign Commerce.

Frankie Cinque, 134 1/2, 102 Engineers, retained his New York State National Guard lightweight championship when he outpointed Al Ciullo, 132, 106th Infantry, in a twelve-round bout before 2,000 persons at the 106th Infantry Armory, Brooklyn, last night.
WASHINGTON, April 14. -- Only emergency legislation will be recommended in President Roosevelt's message to Congress on the railroads, which is expected to be delivered next week.

ALBANY, April 14 -- The State Liquor Control Board was completed today by Governor Lehman with the appointment of four members to serve under the chairmanship of Edward P. Mulrooney, who immediately called a meeting of the new body here Monday.

President Roosevelt's plan to establish a Home Owners' Loan Corporation under the Federal Home Loan Bank Board, with a capital of $2,000,000,000 to refinance home mortgages threatened with. foreclosure, was hailed yesterday by real estate Interests as a step in the right direction.

ALBANY, April 14 -- An order fixing the minimum prices for milk and cream in New Tork City, WestChester, Suffolk and Nassau Counties, effective Monday morning, was issued today by the State Milk Board. At the same time the board issued a separate order fixing minimum prices in up-State municipalities of more than 1,000 population.

The recent announcement of a full schedule of dates for the five New York tracks completes one of the longest racing calendars in recent years. Meetings also are contemplated at four Ohio tracks but probably will not start until July 7, when the new Ohio pari-mutuel racing law becomes effective.

Dr. Hans Luther, former German Chancellor and former president of the Reichsbank, arrived here yesterday to assume his new duties as Ambassador to the United States. He avoided an interview with newspaper men, explaining afterward that diplomatic etiquette forbade envoys to speak of political questions before presenting their credentials to the head of the State.

New Yorkers drank more than 65,000 barrels of beer manufactured In the city during the first week of legal 3.2 per cent brew, according to a survey made public yesterday by the United States Brewers Association, of which Colonel Jacob Ruppert is president.
A wide variety of real estate in Manhattan passed to new control in mild trading yesterday. Deals included a dwelling, several tenement houses, a hotel and a loft building.

This week will mark the opening of the Spring horse show season and activity in the show rings of the East, indoors and out, will continue with hardly a break until mid-November, when the national in the Garden will close the schedule for the year.

PALO ALTO, Cal. RAY LYMAN WILBUR is back at Leland Stanford University as active president after a four-year leave of absence to serve as Secretary of the Interior. Herbert Hoover, trustee since 1912 and alumnus of Stanford, is also bagk on the campus serving the board which manages the university's affairs.

Inasmuch as the United States Treasury will not redeem any part of the $6,268,095,250 Fourth Liberty Loan 4 1/4s on Oct. 15 next, the Savings Banks Association of the State of New York in its weekly bulletin yesterday suggested that the refunding of the short-term obligations of the Treasury should be made as they mature, with the refunding maturities distributed over a period covering the dates of the long-term bonds outstanding.

World attention is now focused on the drive to put the Nazi program into effect in Germany. In the following article, the platform of the Nazis, virtually unchanged since it was first put forth, is analysed under three main heads, showing the three chief objectives of the Hitler government.

ST. PAUL, Minn., April 15 (AP). -- Enactment of a measure providing $1,000,000 to care for disabled veterans in "Minnesota was urged today by Governor Floyd B. Olson in a special message to the Legislature.

A FOGGY dew hung over the ancient city of Dublin as I made my way along O'Connell Street; and through the veil shone, with a certain anachronistic effect, the lights of a moving picture theatre offering "Five Star Final."

CLEVELAND, April 15 -- The thirty-hour work week, government ownership of the railroads and the curbing of high incomes by taxation were among measures advocated by "William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, at a luncheon given here today by the City Club.

Investigation by State authorities into the listing practices of the New York Curb Exchange, begun in private two weeks ago, is to take the form of public hearings as the result of an order issued yesterday by Attorney General John J. Bennett Jr.

Miss Eleanor Hepburn Fisk, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Pliny Fisk of 128 East Sixtieth Street, announced yesterday that her marriage to Hugh Fraser Noall, an English actor had been "indefinitely postponed."

BUFFALO, April 13 -- A struggle which Illustrates the tendency of a public office to assume something of the character of a vested interest terminated with Governor Lehman's signature of a bill putting the office of Sheriff in this county on a salary basis.

WASHINGTON, April 15 -- President Roosevelt will make the only address at the dinner of the Chamber of Commerce of the United States, which will be held here on May 4 in connection with the annual meeting of the organization. The guest list made public today included members of the Cabinet, with the exception of Secretaries Hull and Perkins; Speaker Rainey, Senator Robinson and Representative Byrns.

SOUTHAMPTN, Eng., April 15 (AP). -- In a brief interview before sailing from here today. Prime Minister MacDonald declared, "I am not going to bring back any documents or agreements, but President Roosevelt and I are going to strive with mutual determination to help forward the work of the world economic conference."

Trout fishermen were happy yesterday along an extensive area which reached through Massachusetts, Connecticut, New York State, New Jersey and Pennsylvania. For in all except the Empire State the day marked the opening of the trout season.

MADISON, Wis., April 13 -- President Franklin D. Roosevelt's plan for putting men to work on conservation projects as a relief measure has a working model in Wisconsin, where 12,790 men with more than 40,000 dependents were employed last year under the direction of the Conservation Commission.

Seymour Alexander of the Trinity Club made an auspicious start in the defense of his handball title yesterday when he defeated Thomas Clancy of the Greenport Y.M.C. A. in the opening round of the national A.A.U. one-wall soft-ball championship at the Crescent Athletic-Hamilton Club.

VERBANK, N.Y., April 15 -- Four Winds Bess, a lemon-and-white pointer bitch, owned by Miss Mabel Dumbell of Buchannon, Conn., and handled by George Cranglee, carried off the honors in the open puppy stake today in the annual Spring trials of the Orange County Field Trial Club.

Graduates of Barnard College in New York are looking forward to the tea in aid of the student loan fund of their alma mater to be held on April 26 at the home of Mrs. "Ogden Reid, 15 East Eighty-fourth Street, at which Alice Duer Miller will read from her novel, "Forsaking All Others."
