INDIANAPOLIS, April 15 (AP). -- Governor McNutt, beginning to wield the new broom placed in his hands by the Indiana Legislature in the form of reorganization powers, has already swept from the capital some of the State's 160 boards and commissions and has grouped those remaining under eight major departments.
WEST POINT, N.Y., April 15 -- Army's baseball team won handily today, shutting out Haverford College, 6 to 0.
PHILADELPHIA, April 15 (AP) -- The Boston Cubs tonight captured the Canadian - American Hockey League championship by defeating the Philadelphia Arrows, 4 to 3.

Young women of society, headed by Miss Beatrice Stewart, will act as models in the budget fashion show to be held on Thursday afternoon at the Waldorf-Astoria, under the auspices of the Fifteenth Assembly District of the New York League of Women Voters.

TORONTO, Ont., April 15 -- Pioneer Gold Mines of British Columbia, Ltd., reports for March bullion production to the value of $165,000, which, after deductions, left a net operating profit of $115,000. The mill averaged 298 tons a day, which approximates the rated capacity.

MIAMI, Fla., April 15 (AP) -- A masked man stumbled up the steps of a Miami home last midnight to thrust the body of a slain son into a mother's arms, and a few hours later was arrested in Fort Lauderdale, where he told of a ride over three States after a hold-up, with the body in the rear of a stolen automobile.

LONDON. ROBERT GRAVES showed his courage -- if that is the right word -- when he wrote "Good-bye to All That." He has now eclipsed himself in producing, under the title "The Real David Copperfield" (Barker), not only an abridgment but a modernization of Dickens's favorite novel.

DR. PHYLLIS ACKERMAN has undertaken the gracious task of enchanting common mortals with toe perennial charm of tapestry. Through all eras, she surveys whatever is known of the comfortable craft in all stages of development, and her horizon is comprehensive.

BERLIN, April 14 -- It's no longer safe to jest here over one's drink or over the telephone. A case in point is that of Paul Otto, stage and screen actor, who has asked the newspapers to publish the following statement:

WASHINGTON, April 15 -- Andre Lefebrve de Laboulaye presented his credentials as Ambassador of France to President Roosevelt at the White House this afternoon. He referred to Franco-American relations as "of capital interest" under the circumstances through which the world is passing.

THERE was once a disgruntled, a pessimistic and an extremely broke young man who wrote a piece entitled "Why I Am Leaving the Theatre." He sold it for $75, to his complete and utter amazement. It was full of fury and adjectives, and was a bitter and scalding excoriation of the so-called "commercial theatre," which he had decided to leave flat on its back.

Former Governor Alfred E. Smith was picked yesterday for chairman of the New York State convention to ratify repeal of the Eighteenth Amendment, if, as expected, the repeal candidates for convention delegates are successful at the special election on May 23.

WILDWOOD, N.J., April 15 -- After a day of match play marked by first-round upsets, two seashore golfers and two inland players grained the semi-finals of the annual Eastern States Easter tournament of the Wildwood Golf Club today.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., April 15 -- Dr. Charles H. Parkhurst, veteran foe of Tammany, who forty years ago led the "forces of decency" against the corrupt influences which then held New York in their power, will celebrate his ninety-first birthday, on Monday, at his residence, 108 South Surrey Place, Ventnor.

Nearly five acres of daffodils, or narcissi, are entering the height of their season of bloom at the New York Botanical Garden, where 500,000 buds are expected to open before the month is out. The narcissi are in the southern part of the Botanical Garden, in the area east of Southern Boulevard and Fordham.

PINEHURST, N.C., April 15 -- Clifford Sutter of New Orleans, the nation's third ranking player, practically assured himself of a place on the United States Davis Cup team today when he defeated George M. Lott Jr. of Chicago, ranked eleventh, in the final round of the fifteenth annual North and South tennis tournament.
MacDonald to Washington today has been intensified since his visit four years ago by delay in applying solutions, manifestly overdue, to world problems.

RAMSAY MacDONALD, Prime Minister of Great Britain, will arrive in the United States this week to discuss with President Roosevelt an international effort to promote recovery. He will be followed by spokesmen of other nations.

ALBANY, April 15 -- The minimum prices fixed by the State Milk Control Board for New York City and vicinity apply equally to the small retailer and the large distributer, the board in a statement today said:

BALTIMORE, April 15 -- Safely negotiating the seventeen post and rail fences on the three-mile course, Jumping Jack, owned by Mrs. Francis P. Garvan of New York, won the twenty-fifth annual running of My Lady's Mano point-to-point by two lengths to day.
ISTANBUL, April 13 -- General Sherill, the third United States Ambassador to Turkey in six years, having resigned as a result of the change in administrations, left Istanbul this evening.

In the expectation that Governor Lehman will sign the bill imposing a State retail sales tax of 1 per cent, retail executives during the week began to take steps to shape a uniform method of handling the tax among the department stores here.

HOLLYWOOD. A MUCH - TALKED - OF new company headed by Sam Katz, formerly of Paramount-Publix, came into the limelight with the news that the Four Marx Brothers are to make pictures for Mr. Katz's Producing Artists, Inc., the first of which will probably be "Of Thee I Sing."

BALTIMORE, April 15 (AP) -- Royle's single in the tenth with the bases filled, enabled Baltimore to defeat Toronto, 5 to 4, in the final game of the series today. It made five straight for the Orioles.

A home without evergreens is like a garden without flowers. In Winter the beauty of evergreens is thoroughly appreciated. One method of making a little money go a long way is to plant baby evergreens and let them grow in beauty and value.

Judging by the large subscription for the Summer fashion show and entertainment for the benefit of the New York Infirmary for Women and Children to be held on Tuesday afternoon at the Plaza, the funds for caring for the ill and needy at the infirmary will be considerably augmented.

THROUGH all the changing fashions in fiction of the past fifty years this type of novel for the feminine public has remained tie same. Dressed with a modern smartness which still somehow recalls the scenes of high life invented by the Victorian lady novelists, it is the same story of the meek wife who stands tearful and helpless under the sting of a loved husband's scorn.

FORT KNOX, Ky., April 15 -- Twenty-one artillerymen from Fort Totten, N.Y., moved into quarters here today, forming the advance guard of a troop concentration which in the next month will bring here thousands of infantry, artillery and cavalry soldiers and 113 fighting airplanes for one of the largest peacetime war games the army ever staged.

BERLIN, April 15 -- Holy Week brought the first lull in the terrific speed with which the government machinery has been functioning ever since Jan. 30, when Adolf Hitler's Nazis and the Nationalists joined hands in the Cabinet of national concentration.

Pitched on its nose in an attempted landing at a small flying field just off Cross Bay Boulevard near Goose Creek, Queens, a small cabin plane cracked to splinters yesterday afternoon, seriously injuring the pilot and terrifying a passenger who, after his first flight, was pulled from the wreckage with only a few minor bruises and lacerations.

THERE is at least one Sunday in the year in America when the music of the church bells drowns out the calliope appeals of the golf course, the flesh and the devil. There is one day when pews are sure to be filled and the ushers have to put chairs in the aisles.

Although recruiting was believed to have slowed down because of the observance of Passover and because of the approaching celebration of Easter, another quota in the army's enrolment of young men for the Citizens Conservation Camps was completed yesterday at 1:35 P.M., when the last of 1,000 recruits were sent to Fort Hancock.

HAMBURG, April 15 -- The citizens of Hamburg, being urbane and tolerant, are sending flowers to their Jewish friends and fellow-residents these days as tokens of their sympathy and continued esteem, and in part also as a mute protest against the new era of intolerance and oppression decreed by the triumphant Nazis in the name of national liberation.

THE title implies that Chesterton. unlike Caesar has accepted a kingly crown. He has long since possessed himself of kingly attributes. Every day, as he commends his girth am soul to the god of Distributism, he emulates Canute, crying "Recede recede" to the tides of modernity. Not only has he hastened to command but as Ko-Ko. his own Lord High Executioner, he has lopped off a good many heads, first and last.
MELBOURNE, April 14 -- No one was perturbed by the fact that the people of Western Australia voted two to one in favor of secession from the Commonwealth.

CHICAGO, April 15 -- More than 20,000 teachers, pupils and parents of pupils marched through the downtown district today in a colorful demonstration for payment of eight months' back salaries to the teachers.

BERLIN, April 15 -- The wave of "coordination" that has forced State and municipal governments, banks, industry and agriculture into line with the National Socialist regime has now struck firm resistance.

WASHINGTON, April 15 (AP). -- A real old-style White House Easter egg-rolling is in store for Washington boys and girls Monday, with a warm welcome assured them by Mrs. Roosevelt and her grandchildren.

IF the Zane Grey public is so misled by the title as to purchase "Forest Fire," it will be sorely disappointed. The familiar ingredients are, to be sure, all there. The scene is laid in the wild forest reserves of Montana; it is peopled by robust he-men; it is laid waste by a conflagration of major dimensions.

SENATOR LONG is not only the Kingfish of Louisiana but the most spectacular of all the long procession of spellbinders who nave gesticulated and ranted themselves into the National Capitol, and so it is highly edifying to have this story of his stormy and thus far highly successful career.

NEW YORK. Mr. and Mrs. Charles H. Thieriot and their daughter, Miss Lucile Thieriot, accompanied by Miss Anne Meyer, have returned from Europe and are at 1,175 Park Avenue until they leave for Cedar Hill, Oyster Bay, for the Summer.

The statistical position of the petroleum industry continues good, but prices remain poor, an abnormal situation artificially created, according to William J. Kemnitzer, petroleum technologist, based on data of the United States Bureau of Mines.

Old law tenement owners probably will be given another year in which to make certain alterations required under the multiple dwelling law through the passage in the State Legislature of a further amendment to the housing regulations, points out the legislative committee of the Brooklyn Real Estate Board in a review of some of the measures affecting realty which came before the last session of the Legislature.

THE material of this story is intrinsically rich in the potentialities for travesty. Though the author fruitfully develops the humorous vein, he occasionally shades it with more sober factors which are completely appropriate ish the book's design.

LONDON, April 15 -- The German Charge d'Affaires, Count von Bernstorff, acting on instructions from Berlin, called at the Foreign Office today to deliver his government's protest on Thursday's debate in the House of Commons, when Sir Austen Chamberlain, former Foreign Secretary, bitterly attacked the Hitler regime.
CHICAGO, April 15 -- As a dream of five years nears realization, workers on the Temple of Science at the Century of Progress grounds are becoming increasingly proud of their achievement.

IN 1904 the Franklin Institute awarded to Dr. Schuyler S. Wheeler its John Scott Gold Medal for his invention of an electric fan, reduced to practice in 1886. It occurred to Wheeler that by turning upside down the type of motor made to run sewing machines a little wind propeller could be hitched on -- and there was the fan motor!

WASHINGTON, April 15 (AP) -- The leniency which Attorney General Cummings suggested had been shown recently toward violators, engaged in the beer traffic, of the prohibition laws was made evident in the March report of the prohibition bureau.

THE world, and more particularly the United States, is today facing a new era in transportation. By this is meant an era in which the existing systems and practices will be basically modified, and radically so.

THE task of turning the too often marbleized figures of antiquity back into flesh and blood is one at which Mr. Weigall is particularly adept. But with the exception of his justly celebrated biography of the Seventh Cleopatra. he has done no other to equal his portrait of the young man who aspired to conquer and rule the whole world, Alexander the Great.

By far the largest number of trophies and awards ever made in the annual motor boat race down the Hudson River from Albany will be distributed in that event this year, which will be run on May 14. The prize list was announced yesterday by Charles Alexander Jr., secretary of the Middle Atlantic Outboard Association, which holds the contest.

Rental difficulties and high taxation costs were discussed by Harry A. Taylor of the Frank H. Taylor Sons, realty firm of East Orange, N.J., before the Apartment House Group of the Management Division, Real Estate Board of New York, last week.

Rallying to overcome a three-run lead gained by the visitors, City College's baseball team scored four runs in the third inning and three in the fourth at Lewisohn Stadium yesterday to conquer Springfield College of Springfield, Mass., 7 to 5.
HOT SPRINGS, Va., April 15 -- Society leaders from all parts of the country are at the Homestead for tomorrow's Easter fashion promenade, the high spot of the Virginia Hot Springs season.

MOSCOW, April 15 -- Allan Monkhouse, chief of the MetropolitanVickers Electrical Company's staff, in Russia, startled the court in the trial of the British and Russian engineers this morning when he charged that the accusations against the British defendants were a frame-up.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., April 15 -- Mrs. Thomas Davidson Van Dusen will entertain with a tea on Tuesday in Honor of Miss Eleanor Brice Kimball, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harry Grant Kimball of Bronxville, whose marriage to her son, William Taigh Van Dusen, will take place on May 6.
AMHERST, Mass., April 15 -- The Amherst College track team triumphed over Swarthmore by a score of 76-50 in its first outdoor meet of the season at Pratt Field today.

The relations of the intercoastal steamship lines and the railroads, which were emphasized at recent hearings on legislation designed to give the government greater control of the ship lines, and in statements before the national transportation committee, have received added attention in the last week because of speculation as to the transportation consolidation plan being considered by President Roosevelt and his advisers.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I read with interest the editorial in THE NEW YORK TIMES about "tears in the eyes of Norway" when a recent decision of the Court of International Justice took Greenland from her and its appeal to Denmark to cherish the memory of Eric in Greenland, "which he was the first of the sons of the Old World to set foot upon."

The decision of the Columbia University authorities not to hold the Columbia interscholastic track and field meet this Spring not only deprives the metropolitan district of one of the biggest scholastic events of the outdoor campaign, but also postpones for several weeks the start of the major schoolboy track and field competitions in New York City.

An Interesting decision which, it is said, may pave the way toward Simplifying the customary troublesome methods of realty bond holding reorganizations was recently made by Supreme Court Justice Lockwood in Brooklyn who granted to Mortimer Lanzit, president of the Lefcourt Realty Corporation, permission to submit to the Justice a plan for reorganizing the mortgage bond status on 1,412 Broadway, corner of Thirty-ninth Street, a Lefcourt-controlled building in the midtown garment area.
SAN FRANCISCO, April 15 (AP). -- Worshipers by the scores of thousands will rise ahead of the sun tomorrow, and climb their chosen hills for Easter observances at dawn.
Two ex-Princeton golfers and an alumnus of Georgetown head the honor roll of the Metropolitan Golf Association, for 1933.
LEXINGTON, Ky., April 15 -- Six eligibles for the Kentucky Derby paraded to the post at the historic Kentucky association track today, but none of them succeeded in winning.

MEMPHIS, Tenn., April 13 -- Assurance from government engineers that the levees of the lower valley can stand fifty feet on the Memphis gauge, a stage 3% feet higher than the record, has not only given the people behind the levees a feeling of security seldom known in high-water times, but has proved to many the wisdom of the flood-control act of 1928.

A band of 600 pieces, made up of the massed musical units of seventeen principal high schools of New York City, will furnish a musical program as the piece de resistance of the ceremonies on the Central Park Mall in observance of National Parents' Day on Sunday, May 14.

RICHMOND, April 13 -- Surrounded by an ocean of beer, legally dry Virginia has been wondering how the tide is to be kept back without the enlistment of a brand new army of prohibition raiders. The answer apparently is that it won't be.

SIMPLICITY verging on austerity is dominant in many of the new silverware designs. These draw their inspiration from Colonial days, "when patterns with unadorned surfaces appeared MODE with more ornate forms. Though the new silver is made to meet current needs, its possession of the old manner is a boon to the housekeeper who must, harmonize her silverware with antique as well as contemporary types of furnishings

With the proposed model housing development by the Fred F. French Company of the so-called "lung block" on the lower east side bounded by Catharine, Market, Cherry and Monroe Streets, many of the thoroughfares in that old and historic section are destined to become better known to the residents of Manhattan Island.

HAVRE DE GRACE, Md., April 15 -- W.R. Coe's 1932 juvenile champion, Ladysman, won his first start of the year as the Eastern racing season got under way before 15,000 spectators at the Havre de Grace track today. The big Coe 3-year-old led S.W. Labrot's Rush Hour home by half a length in the six furlongs of the Bayview Purse, with W.N. Adrians's Crap Shooter a distant third.
GLOUCESTER, Mass., April 15 -- New England fishermen, who say they are facing economic disaster, will sail next week for Washington to ask the President to save the industry.

CHICAGO, April 15 -- Wheat forged ahead today into new ground on the current movement on the nearby futures and to a new high mark for the season on the September on the Board of Trade. The trade is taking inflation talk seriously, and commission houses in general reported an expansion in outside buying sufficient to absorb all profit taking" early and to hold prices above the finish of Thursday.

STRING has burst upon us. Just as we were in the grip of a gray vogue in the early Autumn, so now we are facing a season of popularity for those natural tones that come under the general heading of "string."

The proposal that Congress enact a law requiring that all gasoline sold in the United States as motor fuel be blended with 10 per cent by volume of alcohol made from agricultural products grown within the Continental United States is opposed by oil companies on the grounds that it would give the motorist a fuel inferior to that which is obtained solely from crude oil and that the prices would be higher.

BUENOS AIRES, April 15 (AP) -- Federal supervision of professional soccer games in Buenos Aires to prevent disorders such as occurred last Sunday when spectators hurled missiles and fired shots at the players and even attempted to burn one stadium, will be imposed for the balance of the season, the government announced today.

PALM BEACH, Fla., April 15 -- Mr. and Mrs. Wiley R. Reynolds entertained tonight with a dinner at their residence, where they will remain until late April before groins to their Summer home in Jackson, Mich.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., April 15 -- Prints and maps covering 200 years of New Haven's history and including two notable collections lent by Canon Anson Fhelps Stokes and Francis P. Garvan have been placed on display in the Yale University library until June 10.

The Spring field trial season is rapidly drawing to a close and the next fortnight will witness the last of the meetings that are accessible from New York. Notwithstanding prevailing conditions devotees of the sport have voted that the competitions during the recent weeks have reached an unusually high plane, not only in the number of entries in the various stakes but in the quality of the dogs and their performances.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., April 15 -- Although Penn State got only two bits oft Davenport, it profited by misplays, and defeated the Naval Academy nine today, 4 to 2. Parks limited the Navy to six scattered hits.

A number of books and mngazine articles have appeared from time to time relating to the water garden and its position in the garden proper. In this book the plants contained in the pool and their culture are the main points for discussion. The author is the leader of research into water-plants for the Guild of German Horticulturists.

William L. Calver and Reginald Pelham Bolton of the field exploration committee of the New York Historical Society, 170 Central Park West, have returned from a tour of Inspection of historic sites in Virginia, which they visited as representatives of the society.

White members of student organizations were held to blame for discrimination against Negro students in a talk by Donald Henderson, economics instructor at Columbia University, at the opening session yesterday of a three-day student conference on Negro student problems, initiated by the National Students' League, in the McMillin Theatre at Columbia.

The Happy Days supper dance, in aid of the scholarship fund of the Floating University, will take place on Friday night at Sherry's. The Gold Room of the restaurant will be transformed into a semblance of a Bavarian beer garden for the occasion. Mrs. Willis Gemmill Mitchell and Mrs. Harold E. Talbott are responsible for arrangements.

Although they were caught unprepared by the quiet passage in the early part of last week of the bills in the State Senate which would eliminate trust companies and banks as receivers in bankruptcy cases, opponents of the move are ready for a strong fight at the hearings to be called by Governor Lehman.

WASHINGTON, April 15 -- Criticism of the principles of the pending Muscle Shoals legislation as "uneconomical' was voiced today in a Chamber of Commerce statement, as the House Military Affairs Committee completed its hearings on the McSwain bill.

FROM the legendary days of Antaeus man has renewed his strength by contact with the earth, and so the author of "Cure It With a Garden" suggests a return to the primal source of vigor for a healing of some of life's ills.

An important real estate decision, fixing the rights of the landlord in the event that the tenant goes into bankruptcy, was announced yesterday by the Appellate Term of the Supreme Court in a suit brought by the estate of Ella V. von E. Wendel against the United Stores Realty Corporation, the 560 Seventh Avenue Corporation and others, in which previously unsettled questions were determined.

FERRUCCIO BUSONI was known in this country almost entirely as a pianist of extraordinary power -- using that term in a physical as well as a figurative sense -- and as an arranger of other men's works, especially Bach's for the pianoforte.

Proposed changes in the tariff policy of this country appear likely to overshadow even the International credit and exchange situation in deliberations of delegates attending the annual convention of the National Foreign Trade Council in Pittsburgh next week.

Debutantes of this and recent seasons will act as jockeys in the "horse racing" event, a feature of the "Bundle-ing Party" in aid of the Prosperity Shop to be held on Wednesday afternoon at Cammeyer's, 677 Fifth Avenue. Patterned on the Chemin de Fer of French casinos, there will be four races, three horses to be entered in each, and the fourth race to consist of the victor in the first three.

After trailing for seven innings Jersey City launched a five-run rally in the eighth at West Side Park, Jersey City, yesterday to topple the Buffalo Bisons, 8 to 5, and even the abbreviated two-game series at one victory apiece.

MIDDLEBURG, Va., April 15 -- Ostend, from the stables of Mrs. F.M. Gould of New York, with William Streett riding, won the Middleburg Hunt Cup race, four mile across country, in the thirteenth annual Middleburg Hunt race meeting at the Glenwood race course on the D.C. Sands estate today.

CHICAGO, April 15 -- Tommy Armour, the celebrated Scottish star of the fairways, tonight stepped into the dispute raging about the exclusion of Billy Burke from the 1933 Ryder Cup team with a stinging rebuke of the Professional Golfers Association and a proposal that no American be permitted to compete more than twice in the international team matches against England.

CHICAGO, April 15 -- A tenth-inning flurry of extra base hits at the expense of relief pitcher Burleigh Grimes gave the Pittsburgh Pirates a 6-to-4 victory over the Cubs in their series opener today.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., April 15 -- A Princeton eight with the courage and strength to answer as game a last-minute challenge as any crew has ever been called on to face started the season with victory for Old Nassau today.

EASTER is the theme of special broadcasts which will be relayed from many studios and churches today. Throughout the next seven days international broadcasting will bring voices from the Holy Land and from other distant points on the globe.

An interesting alteration job to old building's which presents a striking object lesson of the income possibilities in modernizing more or less worn-out structures is being made by the architect Emery Roth at the northeast corner of Third Avenue and Fifty-eighth Street.

DETROIT, April 15 (AP) -- Lynwood (Schoolboy) Rowe, rookie pitcher from Beaumont, Texas, hurled Detroit to its first victory of the season today when he shut out the Chicago White Sox, 3 to 0, and allowed them only six hits.

The creation of a public directorate, an innovation in the control of public utilities by which persons of no connection with the corporation would serve on the board of directors with the same powers as other directors, was announced yesterday by the Fifth Avenue Coach Company and the New York Railways Corporation, operators of the Green Line surface cars.

Spain postponed from Good Friday to yesterday her celebration of the second anniversary of the republic. It is proper enough to describe any drastic political overturn as a revolution, but the event of two years ago commemorated by the Spanish people yesterday was almost unique in the history of revolutions.

MILAN, March 26, 1933. PROBABLY the largest audience that ever listened to a premiere at this historic house heard Igino Robbiani's four-act lyric tragedy, "Guido del Popolo," broadcast from La Scala last night -- the second rovelty of the season.

With European currencies advancing sharply against the dollar again, the comparative firmness of the share market and the irregularity in bonds made little impression yesterday. The foreign exchanges were in confusion as a result of the uncertainty that still surrounds the United States Treasury Department's attitude with respect to gold exports, which have been becoming increasingly profitable, on paper.

PARIS, April 7 -- French physicians, following the well-known practice at Vichy, are prescribing more and more the moderate drinking of wine instead of milk for patients suffering from gastric or intestinal troubles. So important has this tendency become that the dairy farmers have recently launched a campaign to urge the public to drink more milk.

Sylvan L. Hanauer, assistant secretary of the General Realty and Utilities Corporation, speaking before the apartment house group of the management division, Real Estate Board of New York, last Thursday stressed the necessity of keeping up to date with modern improvements and apartment conveniences.

A hapless bass tuba player was informed yesterday, to the tune of $135 back rent, that the cricket is a "romantic" and "intellectual little fellow" and "an indefatigable musician" and that his nightly concerts inside an apartment house are not sufficient reason, legally at any rate, for the tenant to break his lease and move away from the din.

CHICAGO, April 14. ALTHOUGH Holy Week on the religious calendar, this period might also be called Old Home Theatrical Week, for it has brought return engagements of "Of Thee I Sing" and "Counsellor-at-Law."
