Sickness Is unusually prevalent among the more than 300,000 families on the public relief rolls in the State, the State Temporary Emergency Relief Administration reported yesterday on the basis of a study made at its request by the State Department of Health.

IN a study of particularly timely importance the Guggenheim Airship Institute at Akron, Ohio, is endeavoring to learn how to forecast wind gusts whose unexpected appearance constitute one of the major airship dangers. Both wind velocity and direction instruments, now being used at the institute, record their findings, according to Science Service, by means of photoelectric cells.

WASHINGTON, April 15 -- The majority leadership in the Senate prepared today to take drastic steps to end a stalemate of a week's duration, while that body ambled at an easy pace through another day's debate.
PARIS, April 15 -- The debate in the House of Commons on the German Government's policies is regarded here as strengthening France's hand in the disarmament and other international negotiations.
MONTREAL, April 15 -- The sensitive muzzle of a "booze hound" snooped out a cache of alcohol today that liquor police "were unable to find.

Advocates or a change in the antitrust laws to permit greater cooperation among industries were thrown into confusion during the week by reports from Washington that President Roosevelt. contemplated a broad-scale mobilization of industry, similar to that of wartime.

For the eighth consecutive year, an N.Y.U. baseball team triumphed over Manhattan yesterday. In a battle which required nearly three hours to play, the Violet won by 7 -- 4 at Ohio Field. It was N.Y.U.'s fourth consecutive intercollegiate victory and its third in as many days.

Aknusti, the indoor polo trio made up of Elbridge T. Gerry, Robert L. Gerry Jr. and James Mills, last night rode to the Eastern open championship by defeating Los Nanduces, 8 to 7. The final, played in Squadron A Armory, was one of the fastest contests of the Winter season.

The first week of 3.2 per cent beer, despite unfilled orders at the breweries, poured millions of dollars into the coffers of the government and enhanced the nation's commerce, according to a survey by The Associated Press.

MINEOLA, L.I., April 15 -- P.E. Gardner and S.W. Isaac tied for the High Scratch Cup at the traps of the Nassau Trapsbooting Club today. Each had a card of 47 out of 50 targets. In the shoot-off Gardner won by breaking 25 straight.

ST. PAUL, April 13 -- The Minnesota Legislature has made an heroic attempt to lighten the load of two important classes of taxpayers, the automobile owner and the owner of real estate. In the case of the former, success is already achieved by an average reduction of 42 per cent in motor vehicle license fees.

LUCILLE LESUEUR, better known to her admirers as Joan Crawford, is to be seen at the Capitol this week in "Today We Live." She was born in San Antonio, Texas, and was educated at a school in Kansas City. Although her father was a theatre man, the family opposed her stage ambitions, which she began to reveal at an early age.

ALBANY, April 15 -- Governor Lehman has not yet signed the bill imposing an emergency tax of 1 per cent on "gross" personal incomes, but meanwhile a Republican drive has been started to bring about repeal of the law early in the 1934 Legislature.

PHILADELPHIA, April 15 -- A fly ball from the bat of Hal Lee that just eluded a desperate dive by Johnny Frederick gave the Phillies a 2-to-1 ninth-inning triumph and 7,500 fans their first thrill of victory today.

The New York Rugby Club registered its third successive victory of the season by defeating the French Rugby Club at Innisfail Park yesterday. After a closely-fought first half, which ended with the New York fifteen leading by 5-4, the victors resumed with a sturdy attack to triumph, 15-7.

IT now looks as if the North American Radio Conference to be held in Mexico City will not take place much before May 15 or June 1, if then. The postponement has been caused by the delay of the Mexican Government in issuing the formal invitations.

SINCE "The Street of the Sandalmakers" is a historical novel, criticism is compelled to depart from some of its usual courses. By eschewing the present and the known, and barking back to a past which, at first hand, can be as little known to reader as to author, the novelist places the reader in a disadvantageous position.

An increased demand is appearing, announces the Professional Engineers Committtee on Unemployment, for trained engineers of the managing executive type, to take charge of the skyscraper and apartment house properties in the metropolitan area.
James S. Bolan, the city's new Police Commissioner, made a reputation as an efficient police officer during his thirty-seven years on the force.

In the glittering ranks of Government publications our never enough to be esteemed contemporary. The Reclamation Era, still keeps its place of honor. The April number of the twenty-fourth volume has been sent us by the Department of the Interior, Bureau of Reclamation.
HAMBURG, April 14 -- Hamburg is Germany's window toward the outside world.

FROM fifty to seventy million people inhabiting an area as large as France live under the Chinese Soviet Government which was organized on Nov. 7, 1931. Dominating important provinces north and south of the Yangtse River, the Chinese Soviets defy the Nanking authorities.

LONG BEACH, Cal., April 15 -- The University of Washington's powerful crews swept the lagoon today as its varsity eight climaxed an afternoon of smooth rowing with a smashing victory over the University of California and the University of California at Los Angeles.
WASHINGTON, April 15 (AP) -- Alexander's homer in the seventh spoiled a Monte Weaver shut-out today, with Washington defeating Boston, 2 to 1.

Mrs. Warren C. Van Slyke gave a farewell dinner last night on the terrace of the Central Park Casino for Mrs. Lupton Hoge, who will sail on Tuesday for Europe. The guests were seated at a crescent-shaped table, which was decorated with azaleas and white heather.

BERLIN. AMONG the many books that this year has brought us, two stand out by reason of the unusualness of their themes. They are meant for the thoughtful reader. The first of them -- by far the more profound, a volume filled with deep religious yearning -- is "Das Licht der Welt," by Walther Eidlitz (Zsolnay. Berlin).

WASHINGTON, April 15 (AP) -- The bill creating a foreign securities board to pass on all foreign loans floated in this, country was favorably reported to the Senate Judiciary committee today by a subcommittee headed by Senator McCarran, Democrat of Nevada.

Graduates and undergraduates of New England colleges are to be introduced to dinghy sailing on Saturday and next Sunday at the regatta to be held on the Charles River, Boston. Long Island Sound, Narragansett Bay and Massachusetts Bay boat-owners are going to take their craft there for the two-day racing.

LAKEHURST, N.J., April 15 (AP) -- Officially terminating its investigation of the loss of the Blimp J-3, a naval court of inquiry adjourned today until Tuesday, when it will resume its inquiry into the destruction of the dirigible Akron with sessions at the Washington Navy Yard.

Congress is now debating President Roosevelt's plan for the utilization of the Muscle Shoals power sources and the development of the Tennessee Valley area. The following article reveals the possibilities opened up by the proposed, development and shows its relation to national planning.

THREE new national monuments established since the first of the year bring the total of these historic and scenic parks to seventy-nine. The spectacular gorge which the Gunnison River has cut through the black granite of Colorado, creating the Black Canyon:
BERLIN. RETURNING, after a rather long absence, to the centre of the German art world, one is somewhat surprised at first at the apparent internationalism prevailing in the field of the plastic arts.

FLORENCE, Ariz., April 15 (AP). -- Hysterical outbursts, laughter and tears came from Winnie Ruth Judd today as her sanity hearing began, with a little more than five days left before the time set for her hanging.
GALVESTON, Texas. AFTER loading cotton and resin at Houston until Saturday midnight the Cingalese Prince crept cautiously down the ship channel to Galveston, where she arrived on Sunday afternoon.

THE blending of Guy de Maupassant's persistent theme of "Eoule de Suif" with Henning Berger's drama, "The Deluge." and the use of a bomb, instead of Prussians or a flood, for a menace, might result in something like "Infernal Machine," the picture which was at the Seventh Avenue Roxy last week.

Plans of Frank A. Vanderlip to construct two large investment trusts along mutual lines, with the idea of placing the trust business on a plane with such institutional organizations as mutual savings banks and life insurance companies, have caused a good deal of discussion in the financial community since they were made public ten days ago.

The Colombian Government is considering plans whereby holders of American dollar bonds of departments and municipalities of Colombia which are secured by specifically pledged revenues will be enabled to exchange their present holdings, if they so desire, for new government full - faith - and - credit bonds which are not secured by revenues, according to private advices received yesterday in financial circles here.

Eugene Wettstein of the Swiss Turn Verein won two Metropolitan Association A.A.U. young men's gymnastic championships in the meet held last night at the Turn Verein Vorwaerts, Brooklyn. The meet was open to boys under 21 years of age.

With the arrest yesterday of a man who described himself as John C. Lambert, 33 years old, of Haverhill, Mass., on a New York Central train, the police believed they had captured one of a band of imaginative "con" men who have been duping well-to-do residents of New York State in recent months by an old confidence game modernized with contemporary frills and furbelows.

MICKEY MOUSE, Jimmy Durante and Jack Pearl will be the stars of a comedy to be produced by Metro - Goldwyn - Mayer. Arrangements for the appearance of the celebrated cartoon hero were made with his creator, Walt Disney, last week, and plans for production are now "proceeding under the supervision of David O. Selznick, who thought up the odd collaboration in the first place.

While the proposed power development of the Tennessee River is regarded as unnecessary and unsound by public utility companies operating in that territory, they are prepared to cooperate with the government in furthering its plans. In expressing their willingness to participate in this enterprise, however, they do not conceal their alarm as to what may happen to their businesses and securities if the proposal to build transmission lines at government expense is carried out.

To the Editor of The New York Times: There is always some dissatisfaction with the status and study of foreign languages in our high schools and colleges. Occasionally some editor will write that more attention should be paid to English and less time wasted on a modern foreign language that the average student will never use afterward.

Colonel Charles A. Lindbergh expects to leave Newark Airport early this week, probably on Tuesday or Wednesday, on an extended inspection flight over the lines of Transcontinental Western Air. Mrs. Lindbergh will accompany him, it was said last night.

THE arrival from Richmond Hill, L.I., of one of those all too infrequent lists representing a digest of the research in foreign catalogues, undertaken to such excellent purpose by the International Records Agency, sets one thinking.

FROM the title alone one might reasonably conclude that Dr. Turck's last book (he died in November, while the work was going through the press) would be of interest only to specialists in biology. Nothing could be further from the truth. If Dr. Turck's forty years of exacting experimental work is validated by further investigations, which now seems probable, a very important chapter will have been added to the history of biological and medical science.

HIGH protectionism in the eastern two-thirds of Australia has caused the other third, West Australia, to vote for secession from the Commonwealth. The defeated alternative in the past week's referendum was a constitutional revision which would correct the handicaps of West Australia's fruit growers, farmers, cattle raisers and gold miners.

FRAULEIN VON BERNBURG, the gravely sympathetic school teacher of "Maedchen in Uniform," has arrived in America to make pictures for Paramount. In real life she is Dorothea Wieck, 25 years old, wife of a German journalist, and the possessor of none of the austerity that her American admirers associate with the performance that made her famous.

ONCK more automobile road racing has become a topic of active interest among devotees of the sport. The possibility of its revival, at least for a single event, took definite shape with the proposal initiated last Monday at a meeting of the Nassau County Board of Supervisors.

THE approach to age 50 is terrifying. You've been warned that now your about to lost your hair, your initiative or perhaps even your interest in the interesting sex. You awake mornings, timidly look in the mirror and find that not a hair is missing.

AS recently as January of last year, Diana Wynward was an English actress who, theaatrical reports had it, was coming over to America soon to appear in Benn W. Levy's play, "The Devil Passes." She had never appeared in a motion picture.

WHEN Drs. T.J. Glover and J.L. Engle of the National Institute of Health suggest that cancer may be caused by a germ, specialists in that disease maintain a skeptical silence. The Glover-Engle news is not news at all.
EVENTS at the United States Military Academy at West Point, of interest to the thousands of motorists who visit the post each year, have been scheduled as follows:

VIENNA, April 15 -- An appeal to Austrians to be "objective" regarding what is going on in Germany and not to mix themselves in her domestic affairs was made by Vice Chancellor Winkler today. "It must be remembered," he added, "that German tourist traffic to Austria is an important factor in correcting Austria's unfavorable trade balance with Germany."

MEXICO CITY, April 15 (AP). -- Josephus Daniels, the new American Ambassador, against whose appointment there have been protests because he was Secretary of the Navy at the time of the Vera Cruz operation, was heavily guarded when he arrived here today, and there was no untoward incident.

ON one side of Lubyanka Square In Moscow stands a six-story building which, before the revolution, housed the home office of a life insurance company. Today it is the central office of the Ogpu, the Soviet Secret Political Police.

THE scientific event of last week was the meeting in Cincinnati, Ohio, of the Federation of American Societies for Experimental Biology, which ineluded physiologists and anatomists as well as biologists. Although the Cincinnati meeting had little to offer that had not already appeared in print, it served the useful purpose of summarizing current biological thought and indicating the trend of research.

AN extremely pert, independent young heiress named Lynn is the heroine of this romance. Camping in the Canadian woods with her fiance, her brother, and a party of friends, Lynn, in disobedience of warning to stay close to their base, deliberately wanders alone into the wilderness, becomes hopelessly lost for several days, and is saved from starvation by providentially stumbling upon a cabin occupied by a mysterious stranger.

Finally aroused to action by the hostile appearance of the Athletics -- though there seems to be nothing very awe-inspiring about the once all-conquering Mackmen -- Babe Ruth swung heavily on the ball at the Stadium yesterday and with damaging results.

CHICAGO, April 15 -- Members of the committee of the State House of Representatives investigating receiverships and foreclosures were told today that Claudius H. Huston, former chairman of the Republican National Committee, had received $25,000 and $1,000 a month for ten months as adviser to Peabody Co. In the reorganization of the Pettibone Mulliken Company, railway supplies, which is now in receivership.

WASHINGTON, April 15 (AP). -- The tide of oratory in the Senate today postponed until next week the first test vote on currency inflation to aid the farmer, after Democratic leaders had been thwarted in an effort to stem the flow of debate on the Roosevelt-sponsored agricultured relief program.

There is In this country one class of people who should have every protection that so-called class legislation can give, and that class Is the savings depositors in national banks and trust companies, according to George A. MacDonald, former president of the Chicopee National Bank of Springfield, Mass.

AT least once in his lifetime every airplane pilot has been told that aviation is a fair-weather game. He has heard that while flights may be carried out with complete safety, the airplane will never equal surface transportation for consistency of operation and reliability of schedules.

WHEN Doro was only a baby her gay and beautiful mamma, Lady Alix, ran away from the man she was about to marry, Stefan Perez, the internationally known portrait painter, leaving Doro with her very bored and very British grandfather, a retired General with no remote interest in small girls.

BOSTON, April 13 -- Nothing very spectacular marked the advent of 3.2 per cent beer. What many observers looked for, what many drys hoped for and what many wets feared did not happen. Many were exhilarated but few were intoxicated.

To the Music Editor: As a subscriber to the New York concerts of the Philadelphia Orchestra, of which Leopold Stokowski is the leading conductor, I wish to express my protest against the policy which in late seasons has forced us to listen to other conductors than Stokowski, who have not his sovereign gifts as an interpreter.

WASHINGTON, April 15 (AP). -- The cooperation of all the eleven great nations invited was pledged tonight to the far-reaching program of Washington parleys on world economic recovery which President Roosevelt will hold in the coming weeks.

SALISBURY, Md., April 15 -- John Sidney Rambrldge, who as Mayor of Salisbury, Wiltshire, England, traveled more than 3,000 miles last Summer to participate in the observance of the 200th anniversary of this city's founding, was chosen today to receive the 1932 Salisbury Award, an honor bestowed annually on the person who has been the city's greatest benefactor during the year.

While opposition to the Black shorter work week bill crystallized during the week and executives became more articulate in picking flaws in legislation, many of them agreed yesterday that the measure would pass in some form or other. Textile and paper Industry executives joined in protesting against the act, and brought out some arguments, hinging mainly around the scarcity of personnel that would ensue in event of passage of the act.

WILMINGTON, April 13 -- Widespread criticism of the new State House completed in Dover last Fall has raised an issue among Delaware architects that favoritism and discrimination have been practiced in selecting designs and awarding contracts for the State's public buildings, notably the schools.

PHOENIX, Ariz., April 13 -- President Roosevelt's pension cut hits Arizona harder than any other section of the country. It is estimated that ex-service men and their families comprise one-fifth of the entire white population of the State.

With the aid of figures published last week by the Treasury, it is now possible to obtain a more complete view of the movement of money during March, a month which witnessed both the peak of the banking crisis and the subsequent progress toward recovery of confidence.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., April 15 -- A new life can be breathed into the Department of Justice, "just as it can be breathed into that living organism which is sometimes aloofly described as the national machinery of government," Attorney General Cummings said tonight at a dinner given in his honor by Democratic leaders of Connecticut.

A BOOT two and a half centuries ago a French merchant by the name of Legendre addressed the French Minister Colbert on the plight of business which was then going through a period of acute depression. When asked: "What is to be done to help you?"

"Assessed valuations have no place as evidence In the trial of condemnation cases, and the law which was enacted to permit their use should be repealed," declared Bruce R. Duncan, attorney, addressing the members of the Brooklyn Real Estate Board at its weekly meeting.

MR. MUIR proves himself in this little book on the present world ailment and its causes a sage physician of keen and wise diagnostic powers. Until recently he was Professor of Modern History in the Universities of Liverpool and Manchester, and therefore a special knowledge of the causative backgrounds of present conditions has gone into his diagnosis.

The First National Bank, which for nearly a year has been housed in temporary quarters at 52 Wall Street, will return tomorrow to its old site on the northeast corner of Broadway and Wall Street. It will occupy a new building, massive in design and constructed of polished granite, which supersedes the brownstone structure that had been for more than fifty years a landmark of the financial district.

At the mouth of the Severn, England, the waters rise and fall 47 feet at the equinoxes. Even the Spring tides have a range of 40 feet and the neap of 22. Why not build a dam to hold back the water and pay it out gradually through turbines which would be coupled with dynamos to generate electric energy? Moon and sun would turn the wheels of British factories.
WASHINGTON, April 15 -- The War Department issued the following orders today:
PARIS. THERE has been so much talk of the embroidery revival of late that it may be interesting to consider just to what extent it has taken in Paris fashions.

A STRONGLY marked public reaction against the policy of showing two feature pictures on the same program is shown in a national survey recently completed by the Hal Roach studios in conjunction with the Hays organization and the Women's Better Picture Movement.

PHILADELPHIA, April 15 -- Permits for three Northern New Jersey breweries now under fire in connection with the Hassel-Greenberg killings at Elizabeth were issued at the specific order of the Bureau of Industrial Alcohol in "Washington, following a conference in the office of Commissioner James M. Doran, it was learned today.

The principle of the caisson, the engineering device which has made possible many of the huge structures of the present day, was utilized by the Egyptians nearly 4,000 years ago, the Metropolitan Museum of Art discloses in the report, just issued, of the work of its Egyptian Expedition for 1931-1932.

IN the April issue of The American Magazine of Art Stephen J. Schramm tells us -- the account based upon his own experiences -- how one may collect art on a small income. It Is a very interesting tale and will perhaps tempt others to start upon a great and fascinating adventure.

THE second birthday of the Spanish Republic fell on April 14. Much has happened during these two years, and much more will happen, for the revolutionary period is not yet at an end. But from what I have seen during a tour through Spain, from north to south, from east to west, I am led to believe that the republic, notwithstanding the forces arrayed against it, is attaining a lusty growth.
NEWARK, N.J., April 15 -- Foe the second time in as many days the Newark Bears today defeated the Montreal Royals by a score of 2 to 1.1

PARIS, April 14 -- With a dozen best smokers from his collection of 600 pipes packed somewhat pellmell among his shoes and old-fashioned nightgowns, former Premier Edouard Herriot is preparing to start for Washington and one more effort to help bring the world back to common sense.
BERLIN, April 15 -- Thursday's debate in the British House of Commons on German policy is still the subject of irate editorial comment here.

ALTHOUGH the name of Maria Jane Jewsbury was not unknown a hundred years ago, it will probably surprise most readers today to be told that she was a writer of rare vivacious wit, who wrote in a style and with a charm that make her not unworthy to be mentioned in the same breath with Hazlitt and Lamb.

THE wealth of Information in this book about the South and its development in relation to natural environment is little short of extraordinary, and one wonders at the industry which assembled it. A less ambitious writer would have been content to take only one part of this diverse region for so detailed a study, but Dr. Vance's closely packed thesis invades every area from Virginia tidewater to the Florida tropics and the Texas oil fields.
To the Editor of The New York Times: Why did President Roosevelt invite Ramsay MacDonald to visit him at the White House and why is the British Premier going?

THERE is always a glamour about the circus for boys and girls and for some of their elders as well. There was even more, perhaps, in the days when the circus folk traveled across the country in caravans and wagons, when the performing horses were led or ridden, when the elephants could be seen drawing the animal cages or helping to manoeuvre the big vans into place when the day's journey ended.

If Thursday's debate in the House of Commons really gave the German Hitlerites the shock they pretend to have felt, there may lie therein the possibility of eventual modifications in the Nazi program of government.

SEEKING to acquaint the public with the methods and significance of important activities carried on by the Department of Agriculture, the Extension Service of the department has for some time prepared for distribution films for exhibition by clubs, colleges, churches, grange organizations and other agencies.

Since the first of April, President Roosevelt has sent to Congress two special messages accompanied by proposed bills that are of vital interest to the real estate world. These are the proposed emergency farm mortgage act. which went to Congress on April 3, and the home loan act, submitted last Thursday.

WASHINGTON, April 15 -- All is not harmony in the Democratic ranks in the House of Representatives and a situation which Representative Byrns of Tennessee, the majority floor leader, described today as "bad" is facing the administration's lieutenants.

Deputy Chief Inspector James S. Bolan, backed by Tammany Leader John F. Curry, was appointed Police Commissioner yesterday by Mayor O'Brien to fill the vacancy created when Edward P. Mulrooney resigned to become chairman of the State Alcoholic Beverage Control Board.

This is cherry blossom time in Washington. Around the Tided Basin, and later along Hains Point Drive, the blossoms will accompany Easter and delight thousands of visitors who flock to the national capital at this season. Indeed, the trees have become almost as much a part of Washington and its life as the Monument, or the White House, or the doings of Congress.

THE Rembrandts at Knoedler's, a loan exhibition, the fourth in the series for the Adopt-a-Family Committee, will be shown to the public tomorrow and from then on through the month. They present a brave and grave appearance, illustrating as a group the serious side of the Dutch temperament of which Rembrandt is a consistent exponent.

MR. MILLS, British Vice Consul at Tsernigrad, capital of the fledgling Balkan republic of Vuchinia, describes the brighter side of life viewed by diplomatic and consular officials of the younger set. His own amorous escapades bulk largely in the story.

Transactions on the Stock Exchange yesterday were the heaviest for the last day of a week in almost two months. The volume was more than twice as great as on the previous Saturday. Fluctuations were narrow, except for a few issues in which there was pronounced weakness.

THIS gentle romance of our Southwestern border country, we are informed on the jacket, is the work of a member of a Catholic sisterhood whose duty has been teaching in an impoverished parish school near the Mexican border. Her church has permitted the publication of her novel, while asking that her "name in religion" be withheld.

VIENNA, April 15 -- What can happen in Austria to an American who incurs the displeasure of political notabilities is indicated in the case of Julian Freedman of New York, founder and director of the Salzburg Orchestral Academy for Overseas Students.

The first of the expected lamentations from supporters of winning crews over the loss of the Poughkeepsie regatta is at hand. It is a letter from a former Washington oarsman, and it expresses what is probably the opinion of a, good number of Washingtonians.

WALLKILL, N.Y., April 15 -- Renold Rock, 29 years old, a burglar, who had been a model inmate of Auburn prison for six years, escaped late this afternoon from the State Medium Security Prison here, in the sight of at least one of the inmates.

WASHINGTON, April 15 -- Allocation to New York State of all the hydroelectric power available to the United States under the St. Lawrence waterway treaty, in exchange for $89,000,000 paid by the State as its share in construction costs, was proposed in a joint resolution introduced today by Senator Pittman, chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee.

MOSCOW, April 14 -- The trial of the British and Russian employes of the British Metropolitan-Vickers Electrical Company is the most interesting of the many big trials held in the Union of Socialist Soviet Republics because it throws into the sharpest relief the contrast between the ideas and methods of justice under the Western capitalist and Soviet Socialist systems.
The author of the following article is Professor of Sociology at the University of Chicago and was research director of the President's Research Committee on Social Trends, which recently reported.

CHICAGO, April 15 -- Jerome Factor, the 19-year-old son of John (Jake the Barber) Factor, who is fighting extradition to England on a $7,000,000 fraud charge, was kidnapped near his home at 1,215 Lunt Avenue. Wednesday night and is being held for $100,000 ransom.

COLONEL AHERN'S authoritative book, eloquent with facts and conviction, comes at the timeliest of moments. For now, with the new national administration launching a practical policy of afforestation and President Roosevelt's keen and long-time interest in the subject attracting attention, it seems possible that at last public opinion may be roused to real appreciation of the disgracefully unintelligent attitude toward our threatened forest bankruptcy that the nation as a whole has stubbornly taken and kept.

ON a certain day in early March 1536, four Spanish slave-hunters, riding near the River Sinaloa in Western Mexico, were startled to see "a white man and a black, vastly bearded, wearing only girdles, but clothed in a kind of majesty." burst suddenly from the chaparral beside the trail.

On the eve of sailing for Europe on the liner Bremen last night. Count Carlo Sforza, former Foreign Minister of Italy, deplored what he termed the "saber-rattling" of Adolf Hitler and Benito Mussolini, but added that neither of them really wanted war.

ARTHUR J. BECKHARD, who is producing or staging practically everything these mad days, plans to revive "Another Language." This event will take place April 25, and there will be what they call "virtually the original cast."

FOURTEEN THOUSAND high school pupils went on strike in Chicago the other day This was not merely an at tack of Spring fever. It was the dramatic way these boys and girls took to show their disapproval of an intolerable situation which has developed in the schools of that great city over a period of more than four years.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., April 15 -- The appointment of Professor Earl Reed Silvers as editor of The Rutgers Alumni Monthly was announced today. Professor Silvers will take over the editorship with the May issue of the publication, succeeding Arthur C. Busch, who will continue as business manager.

The New York Press Club, now in the sixty-first year of its organized history, will hold its annual frolic next Sunday night at the Majestic Theatre. Members of the club are making a determined effort to ward off a threatened receivership of its property, in which it has an equity of $125,000 with a first mortgage of $113,000, reduced from $130,000, remaining.

ROME, April 15 (AP) -- The International Institute of Agriculture, in its semiannual survey, predicts that wheat stocks will experience "a very appreciable increase" this season. On Aug. 1, 1932, exportable stocks were 565,000,000 bushels, says the institute, and it forecasts a rise to 650,000,000 by Aug. 1 next.

The eight representatives who are carrying the hopes of the Women's Swimming Association in the national indoor championships which start on Wednesday at the Buffalo Athletic Club, Buffalo, N.Y., are already at the scene of the meet to complete several days of preliminary trials.

WASHINGTON, April 15 -- With the accompanying accusation that Senator Long is "a demagogue and traitor," Francis Williams, chairman of the Jackson Democratic Club of New Orleans, has sent to Vice President Garner half a dozen petitions from about 250 New Orleans citizens asking a Senate investigation into the "moral unfitness" of the Louisiana "Kingfish" as a member of the Senate.

Sap's a-runnin'! That means concenntrated activity throughout the "sugar bush" of Northeastern United States and neighboring Canadian provinces, says a bulletin from the Washington (D.C.) headquarters of the National Geographic Society.

A few Congressmen are showing signs of restiveness under the shower of proposals and bills which President ROOSEVELT has been pouring upon them. Perhaps more than one of them, feels a bit like the stamp-tax agent when GLADSTONE was at the Exchequer. "I must resign," said the man, "my head won't stand it.

WASHINGTON, April 15 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended on April 8 amounted to 487,296 cars, the American Railway Association announced today. This was 7,292 cars, or 1.5 per cent, fewer than In the preceding week and 58,327 cars, or 10.7 per cent, fewer than In the corresponding week a year ago.

Consumption of crude rubber by manufacturers in the United States during March decreased 16.6 per cent compared with February, according to the Rubber Manufacturers' Association. The total for March was 18,047 long tons, against 21,638 long tons in February and 27,828 long tons in March, 1932.

One of the more notable perennials of Spring entertainments -- the Butterfly Ball -- will be given on Friday night in the main ballroom suite of the Ritz-Carlton for the benefit of the House of Rest at Sprain Ridge, near Yonkers.

WILSON COLLISON has turned from his usual farcical vein, in this story, to the more serious task of creating a novel of marital unrest. The author takes the case of two mismated couples, in which the husbands are brothers, who, under the exigencies of the depression, are forced to see their mistake sooner than is usual.

NOT for a long time has a first novel as completely satisfactory as this one come off the press. Wilson Wright -- it is difficult not to call him Senor Wright, so deeply does he convince the reader of the integrity of his understanding of the Cubans he writes about -- has produced a book that distinguishes him as an American novelist of importance.

A reduction in rentals is announced in the Phipps Garden Apartments at Fiftieth Street and Thirty-ninth Avenue in the Sunnyside section of Long Island City. This reduction is in line, explains Phipps Homes, Inc., the owning concern, with its policy of operating residential buildings on a limitedreturn investment basis.

THE chief item of news in automobile circles last week was the question of passenger car prices. Many factory executives are said to be convinced that prices are too low in proportion to the size of the existing market. They were set in anticipation of a sales volume slightly in excess of that of 1932.

BETHLEHEM, Pa., April 15 -- Athletic awards to fifty-nine members of Lehigh University's varsity and freshman Winter sports teams have been announced. Of this number a total of thirty-three letters went to the varsity basketball, swimming and wrestling teams.

WASHINGTON, April 15 -- The Port of New York Authority, the New York State Chamber of Commerce and the Eastern railroads joined forces in briefs filed today with the Interstate Commerce Commission denouncing a proposed report to the commission by Examiner Earl M. Steer sustaining a Complaint by New Jersey and the city of Boston and recommending abolition of free lighterage at the Port of New York.

Calling attention to the fact that the results of the recent legislative session at Albany were practically negligible in respect to the enactment of measures affording real relief to the serious tax and mortgage questions confronting property owners, the New York State Association of Real Estate Boards states that more than fifty different bills pertaining to mortgage foreclosures were introduced.

RICHMOND, April 15 -- Mrs. J. B. Bowman of Richmond, president of the National Federation of Business . and Professional Women's Clubs, said today that presidents of seventeen large railroads had replied to a circular letter that they did not and would not discriminate against women employes in their systems.

MODERN college youth, we are often told, is cynical and materialistic. Yet a personality test recently given to Wellesley freshmen and seniors disclosed that both groups were of a predominantly religious type of mind.

A proposal that the administration, which now is surveying the possibilities of planned production as one way of stimulating better economic conditions, might well consider the problem of distribution from the same angle, was advanced yesterday by "Ward Melville, president of the Melville Shoe Corporation.

In commemoration of the 158th anniversary of the Battle of Lexington, which occurred on April 19, 1775, the New York Historical Society, 170 Central Park West, has placed on exhibition a rare collection of original manuscripts, letters, broadsides, newspapers, prints and engravings.

PARIS, April 13 -- The whole gamut of grays is having a triumph, particularly at the Longchamps horse show. Vivid contrasting puff-sleeved boleros lend a variety to the grandstands. Geranium-red with brown, and black laquered satin with white are two notable combinations.

Dr. Sydney Hancroft Mitchell, who is Professor of Librarianship at the University of California, has written several previous volumes and many magazine articles relating to gardens. He was also chosen by the American Library Association to write the course on gardening for its series, "Reading With a Purpose."

CHICAGO, April 15 -- On this, the eve of the first anniversary of the collapse of the Insull Utilities System, a canvass of the records of the manifold Insull companies now in receivership or bankruptcy shows that about $405,300 has been paid in fees to receivers and their lawyers to date.
Albert Kahn, head of the architectural and engineering firm bearing his name, asks the pertinent question, Why so many and varying building codes?

An Increase in cash and a decrease in notes payable are shown in the statement of the International Paper and Power Company and subsidiaries for the year ended on Dec. 31, last. Cash increased from $7,634,264 to $9,487,058. There was a consolidated net loss of $8,757,728 after depreciation, interest, amortization, taxes, subsidiary preferred dividends, minority interest and other charges.

Resumption of trading in the listed bond market yesterday following the holiday on Friday brought an irregularly lower movement of prices. Foreign loans were lower, with German issues distinctly weak. United States Government bonds, however, pointed higher, led by the fourth Liberty 4 1/2s, as a result of the decision not to redeem this issue in October.

The handicraft of boys from all over the United States, and examples of their abilities in almost every line of endeavor, will be shown at the Grand Central Palace from April 27 to May 6 at a vocational exposition under the auspices of the Boys Clubs of America.

MODELS of a new line of de luxe Plymouth six-cylinder cars wers put on display by Dodge, De Soto and Chrysler dealers yesteroay. The new car, a companion to the Plymouth six, is built on wheelbase of 112 inches and has a 70-horsepower engine.

The discovery of gold in the Kakamega district of Kenya Colony, just above the Equator, soon brought the Government geologist, Sir ALBERT KITSON, to the scene. With the publication of his report there was a rush of prospectors, many of them farmers, who had been selling their crops at a loss.

Oil paintings, etchings, drawings and lithographs from the estate of Newman E. Montross, art dealer, will be offered at auction next Thursday evening at the American Art Association-Anderson Galleries, Inc., by order of the Bankers Trust Company, executor for the estate.
After seeing Fordham get off to a rousing 4 -- 0 lead in the first inning, the Columbia baseball team overcame the Maroon, 6 -- 5, yesterday before 1,500 persons at Baker Field.

Almost every one of the 120,000 families receiving city home relief is in need of clothing, it was pointed out yesterday in an appeal addressed to New Yorkers by the Welfare Council to send the suits, coats, frocks and shoes replaced by their Easter outfits to the destitute persons in the city in desperate need of wearing apparel.

THE League of Composers, which is constantly stirring' up the already turbulent waters of musical modernism, makes its annual major contribution to the musical life of this city performing Arnold Schonberg's "Pierrot Lunaire" as a stage production, under the baton of Leopold Stokowski, this evening in Town Hall.

Postmaster General James A. Farley, Democratic State and National Chairman, made another move yesterday in his reorganization of the party up-State to put it into line with the Roosevelt administration by deciding to recognize Jacob L. Hicks of Highland Falls as Democratic leader of Orange County in place of Thomas J. Conmy of Middletown.

MOSCOW, April 15 (AP). -- Allan Monkhouse, highest ranking of the six British engineers on trial for spying and sabotage, provided a double sensation in court today by charging that the case was a frame-up and then failing to follow through with a detailed explanation of his accusation.

In keeping with the conditions of the time, scientists are endeavoring to take the uncertainty out of farming by producing cabbages ready for transplanting in twenty-one days, lettuce which breaks ground in three days, and geraniums, which take but half as long to root with practically no loss of "slips."

Easter, the most sacred festival in the Christian calendar, will be celebrated by churches of all faiths today with music, sermons, pageants, dedication or memorials, early and late communion services, and with virtually all who have health attending church.

ENTERTAINMENT likes and dislikes of the radio audience are believed to be much the same from coast to coast. This fact stands out in the majority of surveys whether they are conducted by telephone, house-to-house canvass, or by written questionnaire.
GENEVA, April 14 -- Two departures from Geneva draw attention to some elements in the League of Nations situation in relation to the Far East which rarely reach the public eye.

BERLIN, April 1. REVOLUTIONS may be going on every side (as they are at the moment here) and the whole nation may be having its face "lifted" politically (they call it the government of the national "Erhebung") but, despite everything, there is one kind of entertainment that will draw people into the theatre.

Brooklyn Polytechnic Institute Evening Session gained permanent possession of the Metropolitan championship rifle trophy by winning a third straight leg in the fourth annual match conducted by St. John's College at the 106th Infantry Armory in Brooklyn yesterday.

F.O. Williams won the high-overall cup in the third registered shoot of the season over the Travers Island traps of the New York Athletic Club yesterday. He triumphed by returning a card of 98 targets.

GREENWICH, Conn., April 15 -- Miss Cecelia Whittelsey on her mount Findale, won the cup and blue ribbon in the class for juniors, 14 to 18 years inclusive, at the first annual Greenwich Junior hunter trials, held over the Chickahominy hunter trial course today.

ROME, April 15 (AP). -- Rome's church bells at noon today rang out the end of Lent. Tomorrow will see the return of one of the church's most important annual events, after sixty three years of abandonment, when Pope Pius says Easter Mass in St. Peter's and blesses the populace outside from the Basilica's balcony.

ST. CHARLES, Mo., April 15 (AP) -- George Saling, 23 years old, famous Olympic hurdler of the University of Iowa, died here today of injuries received when, his automobile crashed into a stalled truck last midnight.

KETTLE" is a novel of uneven merit and uneven interest. What we first of all seek in fiction it hasn't got. It falls really to enlarge our knowledge of life or our understanding of people. But this serious defect, which immediately delimits the significance of the book, doesn't prevent it from Giving us something else of value.

VIENNA, April 15 -- For having incurred the displeasure of political notabilities Julian Freedman of New York, founder and director of the Salzburg Orchestral Academy for overseas students, after having been forced to resign his position, is now, with the assistance of the United States Consulate and legation in Vienna fighting a deportation order.

WASHINGTON, April 15 (AP) -- Commissioner Doran of the Bureau of Industrial Alcohol, today ordered a "sweeping investigation" into reports that New Jersey brewery permits had fallen into the hands of racketeers.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, April 15 -- The Bermuda floral season and the Easter season coincide, and the host of American visitors which arrived during the week are enjoying the rich semitropical coloring of the Spring blooms. As an appropriate token of friendship between the governments, the Governor of Bermuda, Sir Thomas Astley Cubitt, this week sent a large bouquet of Bermuda Easter lilies to the White House addressed to Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt.

We are midway in the fourth year of the depression, according to Lawrence B. Cummings, vice president of Douglas L. Elliman Co. The bewilderment, the regret for the paper profits of 1929 that we never realized, the resentment, are all behind us.

IN this delightful volume of reminiscences Grant Richards, author and publisher, covers the early part at his career, to the time when, at the age of 24, he established his own publishing business. It was a career which, even at that early period, had brought him in touch with most of the important figures in the world of literature and art at the moment when the Victorian age was giving way to the Edwardian.

RIO DE JANEIRO, April 4 -- Providing railway communication from the hinterland of Brazil to the outside world is the purpose of the new administration of the State of Sao Paulo. A shorter route to the seaboard for Bolivia and Paraguay and access to a railway for the southern part of the Brazilian State of Matto Grosso will be the result of the move now being contemplated when it is completed.
PARIS, April 15 -- Fernand Rabier, former Vice President of the Senate, who presided at the joint meeting of Parliament which elected Albert Lebrun President of France, died at his Paris home today.
PARIS, April 15 -- A meeting that is bound to have an important effect on the internal politics of France begins tomorrow, when the extraordinary congress of the Socialist party opens at Avignon.

WASHINGTON, April 15 -- Further improvement in general business conditions was indicated in the weekly survey of domestic business for the week ended on last Saturday. The upward reaction from the level of mid-March has been accompanied by an expanding seasonal demand in numerous lines.

Advent of the new 3.2 beer has brought a permanent increase of 12 per cent in the annual dollar volume of the average retail grocery store, in the opinion of executives of large corporate and voluntary chains and of local wholesale grocery houses.
BERLIN, April 14 -- The inertia of the human mind is Chancellor Hitler's chief bugaboo.

An entertainment will be given in conjunction with a supper dance and card party on April 26 on board the Ile de France under the auspices of the Ladies Benevolent Society of St. Vincent de Paul. The artists will be Mrs. Clarence H. Mackay, Misa Cornelia Otls Skinner and Marcel Grandjany.

Directing attention to the fact that the recent retail store survey in White Plains shared the same amount of vacancies in March as was revealed in the March survey one year ago, L.O. Rostenberg, chairman of the business property division and president of the Rostenberg Realty Company, says that the results of the present survey seem to indicate that the "bottom" of the economic depression has been reached.

WASHINGTON, April 13 -- A graphic description of the task which the World Economic Conference will have to face has been prepared by H.O. Chalkley, British economist and commercial counselor of the British Embassy here.

"SON OF EARTH" is a pleasant, artless, sentimentally conceived novel of Iowa farm life. It is the story of Tolf Luvversen, who broke away from his shiftless immigrant family and aspired to become like his American neighbors.

Professor James's timely work is an earnest, competent and well-reasoned presentation of the case for Inflation, abounding in factual material and cogent argument. It gains in effectiveness with repeated reading. The Inflation advocated by the author is a controlled one, looking beyond the immediate future toward a goal predicated upon a consideration of the benefits of the nation as a whole.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In THE NEW YORK TIMES of April 2 there appeared an article by Professor Edwin W. Kemmerer under the title of "Finds Farm Relief Wrong in Principle." May I point put some of the more important inconsistencies of Professor Kemmerer's criticism of the government's policy of agricultural relief?

AN air-power steering control, by means of which a heavy truck or bus may be steered with even greater ease than a light passenger car, was demonstrated last week by officials of the BendixWestinghouse Automotive Air Brake Company of Pittsburgh, Pa., which developed the mechanism.

UNDER the title "A 16,000 Metri," Piccard publishes in Italy an account of his two balloon ascents of 1931 and 1932 into the stratosphere. Although an authorized translation from the German original, it is thoroughly Italian because of a preface by General Balbo, a lively description by the novelist Orio Vergani of the descent last year at Desenzano, and a characteristically fervid letter from Gabriel d'Annunzio.

THE El Paso Bar Association at El Paso,Texas, has gone on record as condemning the broadcasting of court trials.The action was taken alter Judge W.D. Howe permitted KTSM at El Paso to install a microphone in his court room during a murder trial.

HAVANA, April 15 -- Leaders of the opposition to the Machado administration charged today that six students bad been killed by the police yesterday in reprisals for Thursday night's bombings. But only the bodies of the two Valdez Daussa brothers, who were killed in the Vedado residential district yesterday afternoon, have been received at the municipal morgue.

THE final week of concerts by the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra this season will bring two first performances on Thursday evening and Friday afternoon. Arturo Toscanini will conduct Adolfo Betti's revision of Francesco Geminiani's Concerto Grosso in C minor, Op. 2, No. 2, and Martucci's Symphony No. 1 in D minor.
WASHINGTON, April 15 -- James C. Biggs of Raleight, N.C., was nominated by President Roosevelt today to be Solicitor General and John Collier of California to be Commissioner of Indian Affairs.

NEARLY 1,000 new radio operators have been added to the roster of amateurs in the New York district during the past year, according to Arthur Batcheller, inspector in charge of the Federal Radio Commission's field operations office in the old Subtreasury Building.

COLUMBUS, Ga., April 13 -- Fort Benning, the military post adjacent to Columbus, has erected a monument, not to a general or a colonel, nor even a buck private, but to the memory of Calculator -- a dog. The inscription reads: "Calculator -- He Made Better Dogs of Us All."

VIENNA, April 1, 1933. THE Vienna Festival this year will be held from May 28 to June 18. As usual, the chief attraction will be various gala performances in the Vienna State Opera House. In commemoration of the fiftieth, anniversary of the death of Richard Wagner the State Opera is doing eleven Wagner operas, "From Rienzi to Parsifal."

GANGTOK, Sikkim, India, April 15 (By runner from Kampa Dzong), -- In all expeditions to the greater mountain, ranges of the world, the problem of transport demands the closest study and preparation. Failure Is the almost certain result of a weak line in the lines of communication.

Arrangements are nearing completion for a two weeks' exhibition of children's portraits to be held at the Reinhardt Galleries beginning on May 1. The beneficiary will be the Children's Welfare Federation, which serves as a clearing house for 259 associations concerned with the health of children in the city.

BERLIN, April 15 -- German-Polish relations have not been helped this week by the unveiling of a monument to "Germanism" in a forest about 100 yards from the Polish frontier, near the German town of Schneidemuehl. The monument is a figure of a woman gazing toward the former German territories of Posen and West Prussia, and beneath it is this inscription:

The Alleghany Corporation, the $200,000,000 railroad holding company controlled by the Van Sweringen interests of Cleveland, showed a $170,000,000 market loss on its investments in 1932, according to the annual report by C.P. Van Sweringen, president.
WILDERNESS WALLS" is an extraordinary, even a baffling, novel. Its slender action is laid against a rough and unadorned background:
Wide interest has been aroused in realty and mortgage circles by the proposal to create a Federal Home Owners Land Corporation to assist small home owners in refinancing their mortgages.

OMAHA, April 13 -- The spectacle of caravans of dollars headed for Minnesota, Wisconsin, Illinois, Missouri and Colorado to be spent for beer has galvanized the Legislatures of two dry farm States into action. The dormant beer bills of Iowa and Nebraska were aroused, almost simultaneously from their quiet slumber in committee to take foremost rank among the subjects which must be acted upon before adjournment.

While the Easter holidays have necessitated a moratorium on the activities of Manhattan's Spring sports teams, the athletic convention which John F. (Chick) Meehan will conduct on the Jasper campus this week will occupy the beads of the various sports departments.

LONDON, March 31. THE fate of "This Inconstancy," a play by Roland Pertwee and John Hastings Turner which has appeared at Wyndham's Theatre under all the fashionable auspices, will be watched with more than common interest, for it is, in a special sense, a pointer to the monument of public taste.
SYRACUSE, N.Y., April 15 -- Block letter awards were made to 134 men and outstanding athletes of last season were awarded various trophies at the annual Syracuse Block S dinner.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., April 15 -- By batting Art Boisseau from the box in the third inning, after pounding him lustily in the second, Yale today defeated Dartmouth, 6 to 3, in an Eastern Intercollegiate League game on Yale Field before 1,500 spectators.

WASHINGTON, April 15 -- Measures which would give to Congress authority to control rents, and to the President power to consolidate government agencies in any way he desired in time of war, were introduced in the Senate today by Senators Vandenberg, Robinson of Arkansas and Reed, representing the War Policies Commission.
Holy Saturday was celebrated yesterday in the ritualistic churches in preparation for Easter today, marking the 1900th anniversary of the ressurection of Jesus Christ.

THE school of sociologists that takes especial delight in pointing out that the race is more important than any individual in it and that however necessary great men may be to the advance of the race they are nevertheless the creatures of environment would make much of Professor W.F. Giauque's achievement of a new low-temperature record.

MODERN art is fundamentally just the same as the art we survey through the binoculars of historical perspective. But at the time it always seems so "different." People are ever, and justifiably, seeking more light on the baffling phenomenon of the art of their own time.

WALLINGFORD, Conn., April 15 -- Racing over the waters of Community Lake today, the crews of the Choate School opened their season by scoring a sweep in the dual regatta with Princeton's freshman fours.

THE NEW YORK TIMES weekly business index continued to advance for the week ended April 8, a rise of nearly 1 point bringing the figure to 52.8. The revised index for the previous week was 51.9 and the figures for the corresponding week of last year 59.9.

Pointing out that amendments which would cover present weaknesses in the Federal pure food and drugs law nave been advocated for several years by the Associated Grocery Manufacturers of America, Inc., Charles Wesley Dunn, general counsel for the grocery producers, yesterday wrote R.G. Tugwell, Assistant Secretary of Agriculture, and volunteered the grocery Industry's help in strengthening the food provisions of the law.

MEXICO CITY, April 15 -- Aboard the special car placed at his disposal by the Mexican Government, Josephus Daniels, the new United States Ambassador, accompanied by Mrs. Daniels, arrived this morning just before 11 o'clock.
LONDON, April 9 -- The American press, we hear, describes Prime Minister MacDonald's visit as being of a "deadly serious" nature.

LONDON, April 14 -- With Premier MacDonald on the high seas bound for America and Parliament adjourned for a twelve-day Easter recess. Britain is having a lull in which to take stock of foreign affairs that have been most bewildering for the last month.

The dedication of the new home of the Jerusalem Young Men's Christian Association on Tuesday will culminate a week's celebration in which more than 1,000 members, comprising twenty-six nationalities, will have participated, according to an announcement yesterday at the headquarters of the international committee of the organization at 347 Madison Avenue.

Federal, State and local action to assist real estate recovery is taking two main paths-legislation to improve the mortgage situation and to provide more equitable State and local taxation -- points out the National Association of Real Estate Boards.

TIME was, and that not so long ago, when the Spring performance of the English Folk Dance Society, whose seventh annual festival will take place on Saturday afternoon of next week at the Seventh Regiment Armory, constituted the season's sole activity of a public nature in the folk dance field.

Decline and Fall? We may now be witnessing as some people believe, the decline and fall of the American Republic. But in one respect at least the symptoms do not correspond to the original Decline and Fall.

Members of the Women's Division of the Federation for the Support of Jewish Philanthropic Societies, of which Mrs. Sidney C. Borg is chairman, will give a luncheon on Wednesday at the Commodore, after which the annual meeting will be held.

BUFFALO, April 13 -- The return of beer may not have aroused more interest in Buffalo than in most other places, but there are some bits of special local color in the event. This locality was one of the earliest brewing centres west of the Atlantic coast and in the pre-prohibition days brewing became one of its principal industries.

NEW HAVEN, April 15 -- The national, social, political and economic life of China is being directly influenced by fetishes, ghost fears, charms, spirits and auguries, according to Professor Edwin D. Harvey of Dartmouth College, who has returned after spending twenty years in that country, where he was Professor of Sociology at Yale-in-China.

DUBLIN, April 14 -- The week just closing has been a difficult one for the de Valera administration. Following the conclusion of the settlement of the ten-week railway dispute over the Northern system, the Free State became the centre of the rail strife as the result of a sudden unofficial strike declared by the Dublin workers.

PALMA, Majorca, April 14 -- Here is one of the strangest ports in the world, a haven of fugitives from the depression. Here Americans of every walk of life, fleeing realities, have reached a last refuge on a paradise island and many of them have found that, not peace nor solace, but anguish awaits those who run away.

DECATUR, Ala. ONE HUNDRED AND THIRTEEN years ago, on Jan. 13 last, President Monroe ordered his Surveyor General to lay out a town to be named in honor of Stephen Decatur, the distinguished naval commander dear to the 100 per cent American for his words:
PRINCETON, N.J., April 15 -- Princeton beat Cornell, 5-4, in a lacrosse game today. Ed Schwab scored thrice for Nassau. The Tiger freshman lacrosse team lost, 4 -- 2, to Poly Prep.

WATERVILLE, Me., April 15 -- A united appeal from the fifteen fraternities and sororities of Colby College for a reduction of the expenses of their national organizations was revealed today by President Franklin W. Johnson.

Twenty-five election-day workers, including Samuel Kantor, Democratic captain of the Seventeenth Assembly District, of which Alderman William Solomon is the leader, are fugitives from justice, George Z. Medalie, United States Attorney, announced yesterday.

LOOKING back on it all on the burden of tragedy that Hollywood forced her to bear in such recent films as "The Son-Daughter," "A Farewell to Arms" and "The White Sister," Helen Hayes decided that she felt just a trifle wilted.

PARIS, April 15 (AP). -- The United States dollar in the course of unofficial trading this afternoon showed improvement, recovering from 25 francs, which was quoted by banks at noon, to 25.16 to 25.20 francs. The last official closing was 25.35 francs on Thursday.

ANNAPOLIS. Md., April 15 -- The University of North Carolina, showing great strength in the field events, vanquished Navy in a track meet today, 77 to 49. The midshipmen gained an even break in the eight track events, but scored only one first and a tie for first in six field events.

COMMANDER KING - HALL'S brisk, skirmish with fiction takes the reader to Bunga-Bunga, an island in the South Seas that has too much American night life to be a good British possession. Its notoriety worries the Colonial Office sufficiently to send out Sir Montagu Thumpeter as Governor to clean the place up.

Garden interest in America at the present time centres largely in the rock garden and the cultivation of alpine plants. This book, therefore, bringing an account of the many beautiful alpines found in our Western mountains, is particularly welcome.

ARTISTICALLY and meteorologically the season continues true to form. The Spring tide of exhibitions flooding the galleries shows as yet no sign of ebbing toward the neap tide, which midsummer, in defiance of the calendar, brings.

IN 1932 the main event in the English auction rooms was the sale of the first part of the A. Chester Beatty collection of Western manuscripts at Sotheby's. Early In June thirty-three manuscripts dating from the eighth to the sixteenth century were bartered for the sum of L26,500.

Announcement that several hundred public schools will be kept open during the Easter holidays in order that luncheons may continue to be served to the needy children under the auspices of the School Relief Committee brings to notice a charity made possible by the teachers, whose devotion to the children of this city is second only to that of their parents.

CHICAGO, April 13 -- Five Governors, meeting in Chicago the other night, faced the possibility of a general strike of dairy farmers early in May. They represented Illinois, Wisconsin, Indiana, Michigan and Iowa.

PRINCETON, N.J., April 15 -- Princeton beat Cornell, 5-4, in a lacrosse game today. Ed Schwab scored thrice for Nassau. The Tiger freshman lacrosse team lost, 4 -- 2, to Poly Prep.

WATERVILLE, Me., April 15 -- A united appeal from the fifteen fraternities and sororities of Colby College for a reduction of the expenses of their national organizations was revealed today by President Franklin W. Johnson.

The gardener who wishes out-of-door bloom in December will stray from the beaten track and set out some of the more uncommon plants, according to Montague Free, horticulturist at the Brooklyn Botanic Garden.

PARIS, April 8 -- Figures showing the foreign tourist decline in France, compiled from visas delivered by French consulates and by a checkup through the entries at ports and frontier stations, have just been issued here. They cover, according to each nationality of tourists, the four years of 1929, 1930, 1931 and 1932, as follows:

A PROGAM or music, drama and films will be presented by the League of Composers at Town Hall this evening. "Pierrot Lunaire," a melodrama by Arnold Schonberg, will be given its New York stage premiere under the direction of Leopold Stokowski.

DALLAS, April 13 -- The present session of the Legislature still has much to do before it can be said to have paid for itself in accomplishment, but already there is talk of a special session to save the schools. These may be the end days of the depression, but to Texas educators they feel like the whip end.

JERUSALEM, April 15 (AP) -- A colorful scene of religious fervor took place from noon onward here today when with pomp and splendor the Greek Orthodox community celebrated the ceremony of holy fire, the most spectacular of Eastertide observances.

LOUISVILLE, April 13 -- After sixteen years of Republican rule, broken only by a few months when the Democrats held office following a contest which unseated their rivals five years ago, Louisville Democrats, greatly encouraged by their success in carrying city and county last Fall under the Roosevelt banner, have high hope of regaining control.

CHICAGO, April 15 -- Chicago at last has been aroused to take serious note of the plight of its unpaid school teachers. Three movements are under way to discharge an eight months' obligation totaling nearly $30,000,000. A citizen mass meeting last Friday night organized itself into a drive for the sale of school board tax warrants.

A compilation of the balance sheets of twenty-seven representative industrial companies shows that inventories declined 27 per cent in the three years from Dec. 31, 1929, to Dec. 31, 1932, which in the same period the cash, demand loans and holdings of government securities increased 4.2 per cent.

NEW YORK STATE will not issue road maps this year. Colonel Frederick Stuart Greene, Superintendent of Public Works, in a communication to THE TIMES announcing discontinuance of the highway detour maps, at least for the present motoring season, declared that his department had been forced to take this step "for the very good reason that we have not money enough to spend for this purpose."

ISTANBUL, March 30 -- The speech which Jemal Husni Bey, the Turkish delegate to the disarmament conference, made at Geneva a few days ago has caused a fluttering in the dove-cotes of many European Chancelleries.

DETROIT, Mich., April 15 -- At two meetings with the city's creditors, to be held in New York on Monday, Mayor Frank Murphy and other officials will propose that Detroit refund approximately $50,000,000 of bonds and notes that are about to fall due.

The long-necked ladies from Burma made their debut yesterday at the circus. They marched around the mammoth ring along with the elephants, clowns, trapeze artists and musicians, apparently bored with the whole proceedings. From their seats on platforms in the basement of Madison Square Garden they surveyed the curious throngs with indifference.

WHEN Chapelle, a vagabond remittance man of good English family, in the course of his world wanderings came to Bai, chief island of the Tama group in the British West Indies, his 10-year-old daughter, Faire, accompanied him.

Miss Mary M. Hare, spinster daughter of the late J. Montgomery Hare, who was prominent in the fire insurance business, was found dead in bed yesterday morning in her apartment at 1,220 Park Avenue. She had been a semi-invalid for some years. Her maid found the body.

BERLIN, April 1, 1933. IN what manner and to what dedegree is the so-called "national revolution" likely to alter the face of German musical life? Prophecy was never so futile as at this moment, yet barring sudden shifts and developments, there is cause to believe that the change will be far-reaching.

AGORA has a new statue in commemoration of the most sweeping changes affecting the women of any country during this generation. It is a statue of a Turkish woman without the veil and the flowing charshaf that have been worn in the towns for the last two or three centuries.

VILLANOVA, Pa., April 15 -- John (Huck) Finn of Jersey City, with a single in the pinch, enabled Villanova to defeat Lafayette, 4 to 3, in a fourteen-inning game today. Finn batted for Murphy after Link Lenzi, sophomore catcher, bad singled and stolen second.

Isaac Wyman Drummond, former chairman of the 'board of directors of the Devoe Raynolds Company, paint manufacturers, with which he was associated for more than half a century, died yesterday at his home, 436 West Twenty-second Street, at the age of 77.

A drop in the number of arrests for drunkenness in New York City and other cities of the metropolitan district since the return of beer was reported yesterday by police and other officials, who quoted supporting statistics. The police records of New York City show the daily average of arrests of all kinds for intoxication has dropped from 15.3 to 13.5 since the legalization of 3.2 brew.

One of the historic buildings in Bergen County, N.J., the old stone mill on the banks of a charming rural lake in the Saddle River district, has been renovated into an attractive home and was opened for exhibition yesterday. The mill occupies part of a twenty-acre tract under development by Warren and Edwin D. Allabough of Ridgewood, N.J.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., April 15 -- Augustus Farnsworth Meehan of this city died in a Cincinnati hospital today at the age of 61, after a long illness. He was an outstanding industrialist of this locality.

PIERRE, S.D., April 13 -- Surrounded on three aides by legally "wet" neighbors, "bone dry" South Dakota finds itself in the position of a bootlegger's paradise as the sale of 3.2 per cent beer begins. To the east Minnesota, to the west Wyoming and Montana, and to the north North Dakota are wet, and the need for border patrols seems imperative.

Brock Pemberton, theatrical producer, outlined yesterday in some details injuries which he said the spoken drama was suffering at the hands of practically all those who work in this field, including the dramatist, actor, stagehand, theatrical teamster, critic, and even the manager, and concluded by asserting that the drama, having survived these, "must be immortal."

THE English publishing firm of Sheed Ward has opened offices at 63 Fifth Avenue. New York City. This firm was founded in 1926 by F.J. Sheed. an Australian of Irish blood, and his wife. Maisie Ward, a daughter of Newman's biographer.
Broadway, probably the best known thoroughfare in the world, is slated for Spring housecleaning, according to the Broadway Association, which guards its welfare and progress jealously.
Speakers condemned the policies of Adolf Hitler and German fascism, at a mass meeting yesterday afternoon in the north side of Union Square.

PRINCETON, N.J., April 15 -- The Princeton varsity baseball nine scored an 8-to-1 victory over Lehigh today. It was the Tiger team's third triumph of the season and was featured by the smart pitching of Gosnell, who scattered seven hits nicely.

PARIS. IT is always a pleasure to discover an unknown. Let me pass along this pleasure. I had never before heard of the name of Roger Vercel. but I have just finished reading a novel of his which I like very much.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., April 15 -- An important link in the chain of 250 seismograph stations in all parts of the world, entering the preparatory stage for the physical examination of the core of the earth in a geological "five-year plan," is completed with the opening of the Harvard station near here.

The thoughtful gardener has a definite purpose in view when he plants his roses. While roses can be made to serve a great variety of purposes, the principal ones are to produce pleasing mass effects and to provide roses for cutting. The properly planned cutting garden will provide a profusion of roses from June until frosty weather.

MUKDEN, Manchuria, April 15 -- While the Japanese are conducting their campaign against the Chinese at the Great Wall a serious siuation has arisen in the district west and southwest of Mukden. It is illustrated by the kidnapping of Dr. Niels Nielson, the American missionary, for whom a reward of $100,000 is demanded by his outlaw captors.

Fantasy that has seldom been equaled in an entertainment in New York is being planned for the Metropolitan Opera House on the night of April 28, when the Opera Ball will be given to aid the "saving fund" for the continuation of the Metropolitan's opera season next Winter.

WASHINGTON, April 15 -- The account of the correspondent of THE NEW YORK TIMES of the killing of two students by Havana police shocked officials here but led to no move looking toward intervention in Cuba.

FIVE notable Alaskans, four men and one woman, interesting, each one, by reason of personality and achievement, tell more or less of their life stories in this book through the medium of Barrett Willoughby's capable pen. The author, who in private life is Mrs. Florance Prosser, is herself a native Alaskan and feels keenly the lure of that vast, strange land.

HASTINGS-ON-HUDSON. N.Y., April 15 -- Helen Vasko, 2 years old, and her family disappeared during the night from the residence at 21 Ridge Street. Medical experts say if one of Helen's eyes is not removed she will die and the Children's Court of Westchester County has ordered the operation against the wishes of the parents.

LOS ANGELES, April 15 (AP). -- A desire for solitude as well as to make the beat of a lack of money was disclosed today by Gwyn Enerson, 19, a Norwegian student of psychology and philosophy, who has lived more than two months beneath a bridge near the University of California at Los Angeles.

MILWAUKEE. RESTORATION after thirteen arid years to its former status as the "Munich of America" has brought about a refreshing metamorphosis in Milwaukee. There are smiles everywhere among the more than 600,000 inhabitants of this quiet, orderly German-American community made famous in pre-Volstead days by the brewers' product.
VIENNA, April 14 -- The repercussions of German Hitlerism among the 12,000,000 Germans who live outside Germany in Southeast Europe grow louder from day to day.

ABOARD THE S.S. BERENGARIA, April 15 -- Prime Minister MacDonald was on his way tonight to Washington for his economic talks with President Roosevelt. Just before the Berengaria left Southampton this morning he received messages from Mr. Roosevelt and King George wishing him bon voyage.

ALTHOUGH weather conditions reduced volume on several days, the final week of Easter shopping produced very satisfactory results. Yesterday a week ago turned in the test day's business since Christmas. Sales last week ran 10 to 15 per cent ahead of the earns week last year, though of course the holiday was earlier in 1932.

A king at once, democratic and almost legendary is Albert of Belgium. A keen student of world affairs, who has traveled extensively and observed much, he gives, in the interview that follows, his impressions of America and her future, and of the course which events may take in Europe.

The charity song recital to be given by John McCormack on Tuesday night in Carnegie Hall has attracted many subscribers who are much interested in the beneficiary -- the Catholic Boya Clubs of the Archdiocese of New York. Mr. McCormack will be assisted on the program by Miss Lucrezia Bori of the Metropolitan Opera and Henri Deering, pianist.

PURSUIT aviation in the Army Air Corps is undergoing another change. The advent of bombers with nearly double the speed of the bombing planes that were standard two or three years ago has placed the emphasis on speed as never before.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The correspondence from Moscow on "Russia's Museum Plans" printed in THE NEW YORK TIMES states "that the museum directors do not wait for the masses to come to them, hut send out traveling exhibitions to carry the light of art culture even to the remotest villages of the U.S.S.R."

Having launched upon a vigorous "reform-from-within" policy, the New York Stock Exchange may succeed in forestalling any drastic regulatory action by Congress. It Is not admitted that the Innovations recently introduced are in any way a concession to the clamor for a Federal curb upon security exchanges, but at least the agitation for government supervision appears to be losing force now that farreaching changes have been ordered.

For the year 1931 thirty-three variety chains operating 2,565 stores had aggregate net sales of $415,370,484 and obtained an average gross margin of 31.89 per cent of net sales and incurred average total expense, of 30.65 per cent, according to the study published today by the Bureau of Business Research of the Harvard Graduate School of Business Administration on "Expenses and Profits of Variety Chains in 1931 Compared with 1929."

Leading by 2 1/2 - 1/2, with five games adjourned after four hours of intensive play in the eleventh round at the rooms of the Marshall Chess Club yesterday, the champion Marshalls loom as likely victors in their annual Metropolitan League match with the Manhattan Chess Club.

Mayor O'Brien's transit unification conferences have struck a snag because of the inability of the committees representing holders of Interborough and Manhattan securities to speak for a controlling interest in the matter of the price at which they would be willing to sell their holdings to the city.

Calvin B. Hoover of Duke University is in Germany gathering material for a book to be called "Germany Enters the Third Reich." He will try to describe the position of capitalism when Hitler came into power and will tell the sequence of events from the fall of Bruening's Cabinet through the first weeks of Hitler control.

Leaving argument to unbelievers, the Right Rev. William T.
