Manning, Bishop of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of New York, spoke yesterday morning on "The Message of Easter" at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine. More than 2,000 persons were turned away, and the parts of the cathedral that are completed, the seven chapels, the Crossing and the Ablatory, were crowded with 3,500 others.

To the Editor of The New YorK Times: The letter of Thaddeus Merriman on "Relativity" adds one more engineer to the protestants against the point of view and state of mind necessary for the unquestioned acceptance of the Einstein theories. May the number continue to increase.

PARIS, April 16 -- The statement of the Bank of France for April 13 shows that the gold reserve totaled 80,412,000,000 francs, or 3,000,000 more than at the end of the previous week. The Bank of England continues to convert into gold its balances in the Bank of France, but during the week ended on April 13 it withdrew an amount slightly less than that acquired by the latter bank.

Another season of opera at the Metropolitan is now considered so sure, it was revealed yesterday, that Giulio Gatti-Casazza, general manager, has fixed the length of the next season as fourteen weeks, and the opening date as the day after Christmas.

Riding on the crest of Lou Gehrig's third home run of the young campaign, the Yankees successfully staved off some belated and desiperate efforts on the part of the Athletics at the Stadium yesterday to record their second straight victory over the somewhat bewildered Mackmen.

PEIPING, Monday, April 17 (AP) -- Chinese troops evacuated Changli and the entire Chinese army was withdrawing today to the south bank of the Lwan River, its retreat harried by constant bombing of Japanese fliers.

The proposed creation of a new steamship line to operate between Philadelphia and Liverpool, sponsored by the Baltimore Ohio, Pennsylvania and Reading railroads, and the International Mercantile Marine Company, is criticized as an unwarranted intrusion of railroads into a competitive field, in a statement by Hans J. Isbrandtsen, president of the Isbrandtsen-Moller Co., Inc., operator of ship lines to Gulf, Pacific Coast and Far Eastern ports.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I have before me a dozen copies of Yankee Notions, a monthly magazine printed in 1853, and fashioned after Punch. It was published by T.W. Strong at 98 Nassau Street. On the cover of each issue is a cartoon of Uncle Jonathan -- a tall, gaunt figure, the prototype of Uncle Sam.

VERBANK, N.T., April 16 -- A notable field trial victory was scored today by the entrants of Mr. and Mrs. George W. Cole of Bridgewater, Conn., when their young pointer bitches, Tobermory Dot and Arcady Farm Capture, captured first and second prizes, respectively, in the open all-age stake.

WASHINGTON, April 16 -- Robert Lincoln O'Brien, chairman of the United States Tariff Commission, today disputed statements made "by Garet Garrett in a Saturday Evening Post article that Great Britain and other countries, which were off the gold standard, had been enabled through their depreciated currncies to flood the United States market with cheap goods, thereby destroying American industry.

Two tunnel contracts totaling $4,000,000 for work on the Colorado River aqueduct in California held heavy engineering awards for the week ended April 10 above last month's average, The Engineering News-Record reports. Contracts for the week totaled $13,046,000, against a $12,919,000 weekly average in March.
A stirring second-half rally gave the Offaly hurling team a 15-to-11 victory over Tipperary at Innisfail Park yesterday before a crowd of 3,000.

A home run by Mills, centre fielder, with the bases filled, won for the Rochester Red Wings over Jersey City at West Side Park, Jersey City, yesterday. The final score was 7 to 3. When Mills made his drive in the fourth inning the home team was leading, 3 to 2.

SAN JUAN, P.R., April 16 -- Commemorating the first anniversary of the death of Manuel Rafael Suarez Diaz, killed in a riot here when Puerto Rican Nationalists protested against the adoption of the one-star flag as official for the island, Pedro Albizu Campos, president of the Nationalist party, today led several hundred Cadets of the Republic and Daughters of Liberty in a procession to the cathedral, where a requiem mass was celebrated.

Large Increases in government revenues and a decrease in drunkenness and disorder marked the first full week in which the sale of 3.2 beer was legal, according to reports from a dozen cities to THE NEW YORK TIMES.

PARIS, April 16 -- Financial circles here continue to follow sympathetically the actions of the American Government, hoping the result will be re-establishment of the confidence that is an essential condition for improvement of the economic situation.

The vast majority of mankind believes in and hones for immortality of the soul, the Rev. Dr. Ralph W. Sockman, pastor of the Madison Avenue Methodist Church, at Sixtieth Street, declared yesterday in his Easter sermon.
Small housing properties formed the bulk of real estate conveyed in New Jersey over the week-end.

A sequel to "Of Thee I Sing" -- showing President John. P. Wintergreen in his second term of office -- was announced yesterday by Sam H. "Harris. The same authors, George S. Kaufman, Morrie Ryskind, and George and Ira Gershwin, will be responsible for the second show, and the main parts in its cast will be filled by the same actors of "Of Thee I Sing."

WASHINGTON, April 16 -- President and Mrs. Roosevelt attended Easter services at the "Washington Cathedral this morning. Mrs. Roosevelt and a number of friends journeyed in the rain to Arlington, where early morning services were held in the amphitheatre.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., April 16 -- The Harvard Athletic Association tonight announced the award of 209 insignia to members of the nineteen Winter sports teams.

PARIS, April 16 -- "I am going to Washington on a mission of peace, ready to consecrate all my strength and all my good-will toward its success," said former Premier Herriot tonight at a dinner in Havre on the eve of his departure for conferences with President Roosevelt and, he hopes, with Prime Minister MacDonald.

To the Editor of The New York Times: It was my privilege early in the week to hear the former Premier of France, Edouard Herriot, speak at a large meeting at Marseilles. His subject was "The United States of America and Franco-American Relations."

LOUISVILLE, Ky., April 16 -- Announcement by Colonel E. R. Bradley that he had chosen Boilermaker and Broker's Tip to carry his colors in the Kentucky Derby, enabled turf followers to obtain a more definite line today on the prospects of Western candidates for the $50,000 added stake at Churchill Downs on May 6.

To the Editor of The New York Times : In the matter of the "first free public library in the United States" at Peterborough, N.H., the 100th anniversary of which is described in THE TIMES, a spirit of pride in my own beloved New Jersey prompts me to submit a list of public libraries in that State, all of them free and all antedating the one in New Hampshire.
CINCINNATI, April 16 (AP) -- The Reds today humbled their old foemen the St. Louis Cardinals, winning their first game of the season, 7 to 0.

CHICAGO, April 16 -- A surprising expansion in most lines of business has developed in the last few weeks, the greatest progress being made last week, and expectations are of further improvement, although some lines may not hold their full gains.

Fed on boiled leather and sick with fevers, Henry Morgan's men marched on Panama City, won a battle and sacked the Spanish town They did this under the flimsy legitimacy of an old war between England and Spain that had ended officially months before.

WHEN the Roosevelt Expedition went paddling along the River of Doubt in the wilds of South America some years ago the voyagers came into occasional and unpleasant contact with a ferocious fish called the piranha. It is a small fish with, large teeth and a mean disposition. It attacks humans with great gusto and malice prepense.

Dr. William N. Guthrie will attempt to recover control of the vestry of St. Mark's-in-the-Bouwerie at the annual parish meeting to be held tomorrow between 10 and 11 o'clock, after morning services in the church, it was learned yesterday.

For the second time in two weeks Jim Browning, world's wrestling champion, will defend his crown against Nick Lutze tonight at the Seventy-first Regiment Armory. They Trill meet in the feature finish match. Another scheduled finish match will bring together Sam Cordovano and Dr. Fred Meyers.

Christianity is threatened at its very foundation by those Christians who deny Christ's resurrection, the Rev. Joseph A. McCaffrey, Police Department chaplain, declared yesterday at the 12:15 P.M. mass at the Holy Cross Roman Catholic Church, where he is pastor.

MOSCOW, April 16 -- Audrey Y. Vishinsky, prosecutor in the trial of the British and Russian employes of the British Metropolitan-Vickers Electrical Company, began his speech for the prosecution at 7:30 o'clock this evening. His speech is scheduled to last seven hours and will not be concluded until tomorrow.

LONDON, April 16 -- The Daily Mail says the Cunard Line plans to cut Atlantic travel rates and has notified members of the North Atlantic Conference it cannot longer adhere to the agreement regarding first-class fares. The newspaper asserts some ships are offering accommodation in the cabin class approximating first-class amenities at second-class rates and suggests a break away from the conference is likely, with a subsequent rate-cutting war.

BERLIN, April 14 -- The Institute for the Study of Trade Fluctuations sees signs of a gradual increase in consumption, particularly in that of clothing and food products. The stock of finished textiles has shrunk heavily, while the stock of textile materials is 13 per cent greater than in 1928, whereas in 1931 it was 23 per cent smaller than in 1928.

TETERBORO, N.J., April 16 -- David Hughes won the low net prize in the final of a series of fifteen Snowbird tournaments today over the Meadow Golf and Country Club course. A score of 90-25-65 enabled him to register his eighth triumph of the series and as' a result gain the prize offered for the greatest number of low net victories.

The active retail trade on the Saturday preceding Palm Sunday necessitated a large volume of reorders last week and apparel producers faced a problem in attempting to make spot deliveries. As a result both the wholesale and retail trades may emerge from the Easter rush with sparse stocks Manufacturers and stores started to prepare for post-Easter promotions and a number of buyers are expected in the market this week to cover such requirements.

The annual "Be Kind to Animals" week will be observed, starting today, throughout the United States by more than 500 humane societies under the guidance of the American Humane Association, a national federation of 500 anti-cruelty organizations, it was announced yesterday at the headquarters of the American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals, 50 Madison Avenue.

MANILA, April 16 -- The possibility of further divisions over the Hawes-Cutting act granting Philippine independence was indicated today by the reaction of Senator Sergio Osmena and Manuel Quezon, president of the Philippine Senate. Senator Elpidio Quirino, acting majority leader, said in a statement that Senores Osmena and Quezon did not dare to overlook the whole public in taking a stand on the question.

New high levels for the year to ate were reached by many comaodities in the short trading week nded Thursday night. With the exeption of raw silk, none of the ocal commodities was traded on ither Friday or Saturday. The allies in commodities were part of general rally in all staples and a securities, believed to have been aused to a large extent by the weakness of the dollar in foreign exchangc markets.

DUBLIN, April 16 -- The annual Easter week national commemoration, organized by the Irish Republican Army, was held in many centres of the Free State today, attended by large numbers in Dublin, Cork, Limerick, Galway and Sligo, where the principal parades were held.

Determination to carry on the fight for the nine Negro defendants in the Scottsboro case, was voiced last night at a protest meeting in Arcadia Hall, Halsey Street, Brooklyn, at which Mayor John P. O'Brien, John H. McCooey, Democratic leader of Kings County, and Samuel Leibowitz, attorney for the defense, were the principal speakers.

Congress shows signs of being tired of acting like a good child. It is apparently irked by its own exemplary conduct for a month past. Partisanship has been largely eliminated; superfluous debate has been cut out; bill after bill has been passed with unprecedented speed and almost by unanimous consent.

The property of the former North Castle Golf and Country Club at Armonk, Westchester County, has been purchased by a New York syndicate to be developed and renamed as the Westchester Embassy Golf and Country Club. A well equipped clubhouse is on the property.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., April 16 -- Resolutions urging that the remaining Scottsboro retrials be held In Birmingham only after the State Supreme Court has acted on an appeal in the case of Heywood Patterson, recently re-convicted, were adopted at a mass meeting here today under auspices of the Citizens Scottsboro Aid Committee.

Easter draws us irresistibly to church, seeking the answer to the perennial questions of where we came from, who we are and whither we are going, the Rev. Frederic S. Fleming said yesterday in his sermon at Trinity Church, Broadway and Wall Street.

The gold medal given annually by Chi Omega, national woman's fraternity, to an American woman who has made an outstanding contribution to the culture of the world, will be awarded tonight to Miss Cecilia Beaux, noted American artist. Announcement of the selection of Miss Beaux was made by Laura Gardin Fraser, sculptor and member of the jury, which included Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt.

Overcast skies, fog and heavy morning mists cut down the attendance at outdoor Easter sunrise services yesterday in suburban communities surrounding New York City. Twenty thousand persons left their homes at 4:30 o'clock, or even earlier, to attend three of the larger services in New Jersey, but double that number had been expected in the event of favorable weather.

GENEVA, N.Y., April 16 (AP) -- Mourned for eighteen years as one of the many who lost their lives in the sinking of the Lusitania off the Irish coast on May 7, 1915, Miss Mary Thompson, 39, is today at the home of a sister, Mrs. Terence Mooney of Philadelphia.
BOSTON, April 16 (AP) -- The Braves' baseball opening, postponed four times, today gave John Berly an opportunity to hold the Boston club to two hits as the Phillies shut them out, 2 to 0.

Book Larnin' took unto herself another bridegroom on Saturday night, and showed herself to be a maiden quite without respect. For It was the "Strange Gods" of larnin' that did for Jason Williams, and toward the end almost cost him his life.

CHICAGO, April 16 -- Spring lambs for the Easter trade were in demand last week and offerings were well absorbed. The Greek demand was good, and buyers for that interest paid $9 a hundredweight at the close of the week. The rush has ended, however, and an easing in prices would not surprise the trade.

A plan for combating fire hazards by the inspection of lumber to be used in dwellings in this city is being worked out by the lumber trade here in conjunction with officials of the Fire Department. The proposed inspection service will supplement that of the building bureaus in the various boroughs and is intended to anticipate resumption of building on a large scale here.

CHAPEL HILL, April 16 (AP) -- Representatives of municipal, county, State and national governments will hold joint conferences on legislation, when the North Carolina Institute of Government meets in June; Director Albert Coates announced today.

The kind of event which has too long been lacking in the musical life of this city took place last night in Town Hall. This was a gala concert for the benefit of its composers' fund by the League of Composers.

MOSCOW, April 16 (AP) -- Allan Monkhouse was depicted by Prosecutor Vishinsky tonight as trying "to represent that -we are attacking the aieiropolitan-Vickers Company." The prosecutor said there was no charge against the British concern "as a company," and added that "Monkhouse is here as a man accused of a crime and not as a representative of Metropolitan-Vickers."

PITTSBURGH, April 16 -- Demand or steel has increased sharply in ha last two weeks, and the increase has been reflected promptly by leavier mill operations. Production of steel ingots last week is estimated at fully 18 per cent, against 15 to 16 per cent in the preceding week.

HAMBURG, April 16 -- Ostensibly public opinion in Hamburg, as throughout the rest of Germany, has been "coordinated" into uniformity with the official Nazi doctrine, at used to be said that when two Germans met three political opinions were represented.

As the result of a nationwide competition the Art Students League of New York has selected ten art students from various parts of the country who will receive free tuition at the league's school beginning next Fall. Scholarships will be awarded to six men and four women, whose names, ages, places of residence, and previous art training are:

DERBY, England, April 16 -- Defying its chiefs, the Independent Labor party conference today decided, 83 to 79, to make direct approaches to the Communist International at Moscow. Thus the development of another split among the rank and file of the party makes it increasingly likely that a crisis will be reached, tomorrow, when the extreme Left will endeavor to commit the delegates to a new constitution based on the idea of a "workers' dictatorship."

NEW ORLEANS, April 16 -- Approach of the Easter holidays and delay in the disposition of the farm-relief measure in the United States Senate, restrained trading in the cotton contract market here last week. Nevertheless the continued liquidation of the May option in advance of the first notice day and the customary evening up of commitments for over the holidays led to fair activity late in the week.

Frightened by a false fire alarm, the audience of a motion-picture house In Yonkers stampeded late yesterday afternoon. Six children, all between the ages of 5 and 13, were treated for lacerations, cuts, bruises and other minor injuries.

WASHINGTON, April 16 -- Representative Hamilton Fish Jr. of New York will speak in the House of Representatives tomorow, if an opportunity offers, on conditions in Cuba and urge the State Department to use its influence to bring about a restoration of law and order and a peaceful election in that island.

BERLIN, April 16 -- It is now demanded that the thirteen Jewish and three "Marxist" university professors who were ousted last Friday should be forbidden to leave the country and take positions abroad. This demand is occasioned by the report that Professor Albert Einstein has accepted a chair at the College de France.

The Chicago, Milwaukee, St. Paul Pacific Railroad earned $1,702,897 from the emergency surcharges in 1932. In accordance with the surcharge plan, these were transferred to the Railroad Credit Corporation, which extended a loan of $2,000,000 to the company, which was used to meet part of the interest payments due on Aug. 1 last.

Making up for the days of idleness caused by the repeated postponements of their initial championship same, Memphis Bill Terry's Giants yesterday battled desperately with Max Carey's Dodgers at Ebbets Field for fourteen innings and then achieved only a 1 -- 1 tie.

Edward (Big Ed) Horstman 35 years old, a South Carolina liquor smuggler, dropped seven stories to his death at 5 o'clock yesterday morning in an attempt to escape from his eighth-floor room in the Hotel Montel at 35 West Sixtyfourth Street while detectives with a warrant were pounding at the door.

The Zionist Organization of America took the first step yesterday designed to start a series of international negotiations through Great Britain and the League of Nations, and with the help of the United States Government, aiming at settlement in Palestine of as large a number of Jewish refugees as the country can absorb.

One of the largest leases of commercial space in several months was announced yesterday by Rocketfeller Center, Inc. The contract, signed with the Westinghouse Electric and Manufacturing Company; involves three entire floors and part of another floor in the seventy-story RCA Building, central unit in the Rockefeller midtown development.

PHILADELPHIA, April 16 -- Slightly less than $500,000 has been collected by the Federal Government in the Eastern Pennsylvania District for licenses to brewers and retailers and in excise stamps for beer.

WASHINGTON, April 16 -- A petition calling upon President Roosevelt to make sharp military and naval reductions and to use his power to secure agreements for universal disarmament is being circulated by the Women's International League for Peace and Freedom.

NEWARK, N.J., April 16 -- The Toronto Maple Leafs won their first game of the season today and did it on one hit. The score was 2 to 1, and Charlie Devens, Harvard pitching sensation last year who was making his debut with the Newark Bears, was the unusual loser.

A sale of useful articles in behalf of the Finch School Day Nursery will be held on Wednesday afternoon and night at the headquarters of the nursery, 338 East Sixty-ninth Street. Tea and supper will be served. The proceeds will be used in maintaining the nursery, which is supported largely by the Finch School.

With every available seat in the nave, ambulatories and the long south gallery filled, the Rev. Dr. Roelif H. Brooks, rector of St. Thomas Protestant Episcopal Church, Fifth Avenue and Fifty-third Street, yesterday morning dedicated a clerestory window midway down the church and a rose window at the astern end of the nave.
WASHINGTON, April 16 -- The votes in the Senate and House by the delegations from New York, New Jersey, and Connecticut on important roll-calls last week are given in the appended tabulation:

The recurrent forward spurts of last week in the financial and industrial markets reflected quite evidently experimental tests applied by speculators. Wall Street being what it is, the tentative demonstrations aroused the imaginative faculty.

On two sides of the country Interesting and important things happened in the ancient sport of rowing over the past week-end. While Princeton and the Naval Academy were inaugurating the Eastern season successfully, Washington's crews on the West Coast were putting the finishing touches to one of the most remarkable comebacks in the modern history of the sport.

Cardinal Hayes celebrated pontifical Easter mass in St. Patrick's Cathedral yesterday morning and afterward imparted the papal benediction upon a kneeling throng that filled the edifice. Admission was by ticket until 11 A.M., when the mass began.

ABOARD THE S.S. BERENGARIA, at Sea, April 16 - Another day of glorious sunshine and blue sky gave Prime Minister MacDonald a chance to store up energy for his strenuous visit in Washington. He attended Eastern morning services in the ship's chapel and then rested quietly when not attending to official messages, which are arriving continuously.

Mayor O'Brien outlined last night the fight of his administration to maintain adequate relief for the city's needy. Speaking at the Broadway Temple, 174th Street and Broadway, he said conditions that were serious when he took office were "more serious now" and that meeting them constituted the one great financial problem of the city.

BERLIN, April 14 -- While the week's business reports have been uniformly favorable, anxiety has increased in consequence of the visibly radical character taken by the Nazi economic policy. It appears that Chancellor Hitler, being unable to formulate his long-promised program for the creation of work, seeks to soothe his impatient adherents with petty doses of anticapitalism.
Easter was celebrated yesterday in New York City and throughout the world with a solemnity unknown since the World War.

PARIS, April 16 -- Commenting on the prospect of a combination of Germany, Italy and Hungary as a result of the recent Rome conversations between German and Italians leaders, the French press places hopes in the Washington conversations as a counteracting force.
A revival of the Gilbert and Sullivan operetta, "The Mikado," will be presented this evening by Milton Aborn at the St. James Theatre.

WASHINGTON, April 16 -- The administration will consult members of Congress in making appointments of postmasters, Postmaster General Farley, chairman of the Democratic National Committee, said today in announcing that civil service examinations of candidates would be maintained and Republican postmasters continued until the end of their terms if they were giving efficient service.

Telegrams commending Mayor O'Brien for his support of two park projects -- the adding of Fort Schuyler to the park system of the Bronx and the landscaping of the lower reservoir in Central Park -- were made public yesterday by the Park Association of New York City.

ALBANY, April 16 -- Many Republican, lawmakers, representing normally dry territory up-State, who contended for the home rule principle when Governor Lehman's Beer Control bill was before the Legislature, left here at the end of the session fearful that the wetand-dry issue would complicate the Assembly elections in November.

Bucky, who started life nineteen years ago as Bucephalus, wandered yesterday in green pasture off Linden Boulevard at Stanley Avenue in Brooklyn. He munched succulent Spring shoots, stared enviously at soaring birds and tried a caracole, with only indifferent success.
ST. LOUIS, April 16 (AP) -- Cleveland captured its third straight game of the season by winning, 7 to 1, today from the St. Louis Browns, who met their third consecutive defeat.

aSea Gate, at the west end of Coney Island, which for thirty-five years has had its own police force has been unguarded for twenty-four hours. The sixteen private patrolmen, with their lieutenant and sergeant, received their leave of absence, it was revealed yesterday, as a result of a taxpayers' revolt in this little community.
Nearly 3,000 persons congregated before the library of Columbia University at 7 A.M. yesterday to participate in Easter dawn services, held under the auspices of the New York Federation of Churches.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., April 16 -- Professor Irving Fisher's index number of commodity prices, based on 100 as the average for 1926, is 56.8, which compares with 56.2 a week ago, 56.4 two weeks ago, 56.6 three weeks ago and 56.1 four weeks ago. The average of 57.4 in the first week in January was the highest of the year to date.
Breaking 99 out of 100 targets, J.H. Wantling won the season's final regular shoot of the New York Athletic Club at the latter's Travers Island traps yesterday. He had a run of 92 straight.

WASHINGTON, April 16 (AP) -- In a ceremony of candle-lighting on a cross, Daughters of the American Revolution today memorialized their dead -- 2,379 members deceased since last they met here a year ago.
Transactions announced over the week-end indicated a good demand for improved real estate in Manhattan.

A fire that attracted thousands of spectators and lighted up the lower bay and the Narrows for miles last night destroyed the old boat house of the Crescent Athletic Club at the foot of Eighty-fourth Street and Shore Road, Brooklyn. The building, a roomy, three-story frame structure, had been vacant and neglected for two years, the club having moved its boating activities to Huntington, L.I.

BERLIN, April 16 -- The Stahlhelm or League of German War Veterans, the sole organization left in Germany still not bearing the National Socialist label, is about to throw up the sponge and come in under the Nazi swastika.
LONDON, April 16 -- The security and commodity markets here generally are showing a very encouraging trend, firmness in the latter being largely responsible for the rising tendency in the former.

ALBANY, April 16 (AP). -- A survey of manufacturing industries in the fifty-three counties of the State north of Westchester and Rockland completed by the Department of Labor showed that about 336,000 factory workers and 39,000 office wage earners were employed in 8.900 plants, Commissioner Elmer F. Andrews stated today.

While the fresh water anglers were busy on Saturday ushering in a number of trout seasons in the East, the salt water fishermen became more active than ever, especially along Long Island's shores. The New Jersey salt water men report that the flounders haven't begun to run very fast excepting above the Highlands Bridge, and that the flat fellows are more or less scarce.

WASHINGTON, April 16 -- Statistics showing that youths remain the most persistent law violators were made public today by the Department of Justice and revealed that 40 per cent of the crime records examined by the department's Bureau of Investigation pertained to persons less than 25 years of age.

Former Deputy City Cleric J.J. McCormick has resigned as Democratic leader of the Twenty-second Assembly District, it became known yesterday. A meeting of the members of the Democratic committee for the district will be held Wednesday, when an attempt will be made to elect his successor.

To children tapping their feet to a march, to young people happily dancing an evening away, to every one who whistles a tune or hums the chorus of a popular song, music is anything but mathematical. Its essential mathematics is recognized by all composers, consciously or otherwise, and some of them show a gift for another kind of arithmetic in a pamphlet just published by the American Society of Composers, Authors and Publishers.

On the eve of the first meeting of the Presbyterian Board of Foreign Missions since the controversy arose over the theological position of Mrs. Pearl S. Buck, missionary and author, the Rev. Dr. Charles F. Erdman, president, at his home in Princeton, N.J., made clear last night that the board had not yet contemplated any action about the matter.
Two art exhibitions will be held this week for the benefit of the adopt-a-family committee of the Emergency Unemployment Relief Committee.

A Federal agency to protect holders of defaulted real estate securities in the period of liquidation and readjustment was proposed by Samuel Seabury, former counsel to the Hofstadter legislative committee, In his decision made public yesterday as arbiter in a case involving defaulted realty bonds.

Viewing the warnings of municipal bankers to municipal officials throughout the country to reduce budgets to conform with decreasing revenues as revealing a transfer of power to the financier, "William C. Beyer, director of the bureau of municipal research of Philadelphia, writing in the current publication of the National Municipal League under the title, "Financial Dictators Replace Political Boss," lists New York. Chicago, Philadelphia and Detroit as foremost in financial dictation.

VATICAN CITY, April 16 -- Resuming an old custom that had fallen into disuse in the last sixtythree years, since the Popes lost their temporal power, Pius XI, after celebrating pontifical high mass in St. Peter's this morning. Imparted the solemn benediction "urbi et orbi" -- to the city [Rome] and to the world from the outer balcony of the basilica in a sunlit and colorful ritual.

When the University of Oxford thought that EUCLID was the sum and substance of higher mathematics and still looked upon bathing as a heathen custom, Moorish scientists were both bathing and laying the foundation of modern culture.

HUNTINGTON, L.I., April 16 -- L.D. Wara won a leg on the President's Cup at the traps of the Crescent Athletic-Hamilton Club today. He took the shoot by returning a card of 40-8-48. A Doubles Cup went to T. Kilpatrick.

The basis of human belief in immortality lies in the true meaning of Easter, the Rev. Dr. Harry Emerson Fosdick, the pastor, declared in his Easter sermon yesterday morning in Riverside Church, Riverside Drive and 122d Street.

The fourth concert of the Beethoven cycle by the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra under Arturo Toscanini brought another, group of outstanding performances at Carnegie Hall yesterday afternoon. The works played were the "Coriolanus" overture, the triple concerto and the Seventh Symphony.
FORT MUNOZ, Gran Chaco, April 16 -- A break in the main defense line of the Paraguayan southern army is reported in advices from the front tonight.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., April 16 -- Winding up its cold-weather dinghy racing today, the Larchrmont Yacht Club held a regatta which was a cross between a frostbite program and a gentle Spring one. An east-northeast breeze, with alternate showers and clearings, made the weather chilly.

BOSTON, April 16 -- The future of the brewery industry is linked with the welfare of society in general, according to Colonel Jacob Ruppert, president of the United States Brewers Association, expressing his views in a signed statement in The Boston Herald.

NEW YORK. Mr. and Mrs. Ethelbert I. Low and Miss Gertrude Low will give a dinner on Friday in the Seaglade of the St. Regis for Miss Augusta H. L. Du Val and Alfred J. Yardley, whose marriage will take place on April 29.

BARCELONA, Spain, April 16 -- A counter-revolution is brewing in the tiny feudal State of Andorra, in the Pyrenees, where sixty youthful Andorrans last week successfully conducted a revolution in one hour, changing the order of things of several centuries' duration.
Phidias in Replica. Up at the Metropolitan Museum of Art the authorities are happy over their newly acquired marble copy, in reduced size, of the "Amazon," a famous lost bronze by PHIDIAS.

If the Mayor was to put any uniformed policeman at the head of the Police Department, his selection of Deputy Chief Inspector JAMES S. BOLAN was as good as any he could have made, Inspector BOLAN has a good police record. His reputation for upholding the sternest discipline in the force has been long established.

WASHINGTON, April 16 -- Demands for currency inflation tonight complicated the Congress sional stalemate against which Democratic leaders plan to open an intensive fight tomorrow. The inflationists, more audible in the Senate than in the House, intend to press their attack in the Senate tomorrow.
READING, Pa., April 16 -- "Hitlerism" was sharply denounced by the national executive committee of the Young Socialist Movement in America today as a two-day session closed.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The thirty-hour-week bill is the first official recognition of the existence of a permanent unemployment problem. It is generally believed that even a return of economic normalcy will find us with millions of workers not needed for the smooth operation of adequate production facilities.

PEIPING, Monday, April 17 -- Following the retreat of the Chinese army from the upper end of the triangle between the Great Wall and the Lwan River, Japanese and Manchukuoan troops have made their way rapidly along the seacoast, capturing Chinwangtao, important seaport south of Shanhaikwan, late Saturday and Peitaiho, famous Summer resort, yesterday.

Several noteworthy country estates in Long Island will be opened to the public during May, June and September in a continuation of the annual series of garden visits arranged for the benefit of the Wayside Home for Girls in Valley Stream.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W.Va., April 16 -- Forsythia, peach blossoms, early honeysuckle and bridal wreath, jonquils, tulips, pansies and narcissi in full bloom provided a colorful background today for the Spring costumes in the colony.

JERUSALEM, April 16 -- A bright clear dawn ushered in Easter Sunday today, and with the dawn many Anglicans arose to attend a picturesque service at the Garden Tomb, also known as Gordon's Calvary. Found by the British General Charles Gordon, who died later at the siege of Khartoum, the tomb is at the foot of the Hill of the Skull, the reputed place of Calvary.
READING, Pa., April 16 -- "Hitlerism" was sharply denounced by the national executive committee of the Young Socialist Movement in America today as a two-day session closed.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The thirty-hour-week bill is the first official recognition of the existence of a permanent unemployment problem. It is generally believed that even a return of economic normalcy will find us with millions of workers not needed for the smooth operation of adequate production facilities.

Mayor CURLEY'S decision not to accept the Ambassadorship to Poland rests upon the higher obligation which he owes to the citizens of Boston in the present condition of its affairs and "the demand or public and press " that he stick to his job at home.

Having offered relief to the farmer whose mortgage rides by his side like an evil spirit, President ROOSEVELT has now turned to the home owner in villages, towns and cities whose plight is not less pitiable, even though, his voice does not always carry far.

WASHINGTON, April 16 -- Asserting that " 'The Prince' is still the handbook of a certain class of public men who believe that success is the test of right and wrong," Dr. James Brown Scott, president of the American Institute on International Law, attacked a "double standard of morality" in the conduct of world affairs in his annual report made today to the trustees of the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace.

ALBANY, N.Y., April 16 (AP) -- Albany scored seven runs in the first inning today and beat Montreal, 7 to 1, for the home team's first victory. Frank Ragland held the Royals to four hits. Whitman, Albany outfielder, was hit in the head by a pitched ball in the first inning, and had to retire, but will be able to play tomorrow.

HUNTINGTON, L.I., April 16 -- Chicken thieves who have been raiding Huntington hen houses for the last few weeks and who have made away with hundreds of chickens and hens are no respecters of persons, for early this morning they made another successful raid, this time on the Cold Spring Harbor estate of Norman Thomas, candidate for President of the United States on the Socialist ticket last Fall.

CHICAGO, April 16 (AP) -- John (Jake the Barber) Factor tonight was reported to have appealed to the craft and power of the underworld to assist him in efforts to obtain the return of his kidnapped son, Jerome, aged 17.

Reference is not intended to new clothes which, may have taken the place of old yesterday, but to garments that may become new in a further use. The Welfare Council, after a survey, reports that it would take $27,000,000 to clothe the 900,000 members of those families of the unemployed "who have "bought no new clothing of any "sort in the last two or three "years."
A proposal that the Federal Government spend $700,000,000 a month in a comprehensive plan for business revival was made yesterday by James Harvey Rogers. Sterling Professor of Economics at Yale.
Criticism of Congress for the silence of its members concerning anti-Semitism in Germany was voiced yesterday by Samuel Untermyer In a radio address assailing Hitlerism.

A situation described as a "mortgage strike" to bring to the attention of mortgage holders the necessity for reduction in monthly payments in conformity with largely reduced incomes, has developed at Sunnyside Gardens, a home owning community in Long Island City, Queens, consisting of 563 one, two, and three-family houses, spokesmen for the community revealed yesterday.

DECATUR, Ala., April 16 (AP) -- A new move to transfer the Scottsboro case from North Alabama appeared certain tonight as attorneys, witnesses and veniremen gathered for the trial of Charlie Weems, second of nine Negroes to face retrial.

ST. LOUIS, April 16 -- Willie McLean's spectacular goal in the second minute of play in the final half enabled the Stix, Baer Fuller eleven to score a 1-0 victory today over the New York Americans in the opening contest of the three-game series for the soccer championship of the United States.

SHANGHAI, Monday, April 17 -- After the Japanese-Manchukuoan capture of Chingwantao and Peitaiho, where many Americans and other foreigners have homes, Japanese sailors landed at Peitaiho from destroyers and repaired the railway line between the two points.

Several card parties in behalf of charitable organizations have been arranged for the coming week. Mrs. Harold Ruckman Mixsell and Miss Mary K. Choate head a, group of women who have planned a bridge and backgammon party to be held on Wednesday afternoon at the Plaza for the benefit of Everybody's Thrift Shop.

For the inflationists in the Senate one argument in favor of deliberate currency depreciation is the supposed advantage of such a policy in foreign commerce. Thus Mr. LONG, lamenting "the pitiful spectacle we are witnessing," asserted that the cheap-money countries "have taken our foreign trade" away from us and "shut down our own plants" by selling their goods in the United States at lower prices than we can meet.

Mrs. Charles King Morrison and many of her friends who are interested in the Opportunity Shop, maintained to aid philanthropic organizations in the city, are making a special appeal this week for donations of articles of all kinds suitable for resale later at the shop.

Milton Aborn opened the Spring -- or the Gilbert and Sullivan -- season last evening at the St. James Theatre. He did so with a pleasing revival of "The Mikado," complete with encores, curtain calls and a short speech by the impresario. Judging from the first audience's definite reactions thereto, the epic of Nanki-Poo has just completed a preliminary and half century tour in preparation for New York.

Power given to supervisory officials to extend needed protection in emergencies assures the public that financial independence through life insurance is not only possible but also la surrounded by every conceivable precaution and safeguard, George S. Van Schaick, State Superintendent of Insurance, said yesterday in a nation-wide radio address.

An intensive fortnight's effort to provide "tide-over" jobs for at least 1,000 men and women who are unable to find work and lack resources will be started at a meeting at 1 P.M. today at the Junior League Club, 221 East Seventy-first Street, it was announced yesterday by Mrs. August Eelmont, chairman.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., April 17. -- A prediction that our present civilization, "the business man's paradise," will disintegrate was made by the Rev. Dr. Reinhold Niebuhr of Union Theological Seminary at the opening session of the Yale Divinity School's twenty-fourth, annual convocation today.

A vigorous rally in raw sugar futures was the outstanding feature of yesterday's trading in local commodity markets. Silver prices also advanced and hide futures were irregularly higher, while other markets were lower. Trading was in large volume in the sugar and silver markets and fair in the others.
To the Editor of The New York Times: A man is on the sea today, coming from England to talk with our President. He is James Ramsay MacDonald, Prime Minister of Great Britain.

PARIS, April 17 -- The extraordinary congress of the Socialist party which ended its two-day meeting at Avignon late tonight brought bad news to the present government, for it made it evident that any consistent collaboration with the Radical Socialists or any Socialist participation in the government was impossible.

Former Mayor John F. Hylan, now justice of the Children's Court, re-entered the political arena last night as the champion of the downtrodden and protagonist of the five-cent fare with an announcement that he would be a candidate for Mayor at the election in November.
Transfer or cancellation of the Olympio Games, scheduled for Berlin in 1936, loomed yesterday as a result of the anti-Semitic attitude of the Hitler government.

While the New York City League of Women Voters protested yesterday to Mayor O'Brien against the filling of unnecessary exempt positions in the city service, Philip A. Hines, brother of James J. Hines, Tammany leader of the Eleventh Assembly District in Manhattan, was appointed Deputy City Clerk in charge of the Marriage License Bureau at a salary of $7,340.

WASHINGTON, April 17 -- New York City, with a $309,186,421 stake in the subway system, officially designated itself today as an interested party in the suit before the Supreme Court over the receiverships of the Manhattan Railway Company (elevated) and Interborough Rapid Transit Company.

WASHINGTON, April 17 -- The Wheeler amendment to the farm relief bill to remonetize silver on the old Bryan formula of 16 to 1 was defeated in the Senate today, 43 to 33. Despite the fact that inflation was beaten for the time being, those in favor of it showed surprising strength and a shift of six votes would have carried the measure.
Rochester, N.Y. The city of Rochester, N.Y., formally advised bankers here yesterday it plans to open bids at 1 P.M. tomorrow on a new issue of $3,750,000 of notes.

TUCSON, Ariz., April 17 (AP) -- Police Chief Dyer said tonight that the Tucson police had recovered $63,000 in negotiable securities stolen from the Chase National Bank of New York in a robbery about eighteen months ago and had arrested one man who they believed was implicated in the robbery.

ALBANY, April 17 -- The Law Preservation party, through former Judge Harvey S. Remington of Rochester, head of the party, today began proceedings in the Supreme Court to enjoin Secretary of State Flynn from accepting and filing petitions on behalf of candidates for seats in the prohibition repeal convention on June 27.

In an office bedecked with flowers from well-wishers, James S. Bolan spent his first full day as Police Commissioner yesterday. He announced a small handful of departmental shifts occasioned by his elevation.

A new mortgage organization to be known as the Mortgagee Management Corporation is being formed and will soon be incorporated with the object of giving advice and other assistance to holders of mortgage certificates guaranteed by various title and mortgage companies.

WASHINGTON, April 17. -- Plans for balancing the budget of the Postoffice Department by making a further saving of $72,000,000 in its expenditures during the fiscal year of 1934, beginning July 1 next, were discussed by Postmaster General Farley tonight in a radio talk over the National Broadcasting network and WOR.

Every one of the fifty-seven varieties of proposals to inflate, or debase, the currency is expected to get a hearing in Congress this week. Speaker RAINEY discerns a widespread, sentiment for inflation, and observes that if it were only " crystalized " it would compel the House to pass a bill embodying it.

The Kenuecott Copper Corporation reports for 1932 a net loss of $7,102,198 after depreciation, taxes, minority interest and a write-down of $l,576,963 for metal inventories at mines and fabricating plants to market prices at Dec. 31 last, but before depletion.

WASHINGTON, April 17. -- The Reconstruction Finance Corporation, after nearly a year's consideration, will vote before the end of the week its final approval of the $75,000,000 loan to the Port of New York Authority for construction of the mid-town vehicular tunnel from Thirty-eighth Street, Manhattan, under the Hudson River to Weehawken, it was learned from an important administration source today.

MONTREAL, Que., April 17 -- It is virtually certain that Canadian newsprint companies will meet the discount of $5 a ton announced today by the International Paper Company, according to opinions expressed here tonight. On previous occasions the general disposition has been to "follow the lead of International," largest unit in the industry through its subsidiary, Canadian International Paper Company.

MOSCOW, April 17 -- L.M. Karakhan, Assistant Commissar for Foreign Affairs, has sent a note to Tamekichi Ota, Japanese Ambassador to Moscow, protesting that the rights and interests of the Soviet Union along the Chinese Eastern Railway in Manchuria had been Jeopardized by recent events.

EASTON, Pa., April 17 -- Dr. George Balch Nevin, one of the most prominent composers of sacred music in the country, a cousin of the late Ethelbert Nevin, noted composer, died of paralysis today at his home. He was 74 years old on March 15.

HAMBURG, April 17. -- The "cold pogrom" of economic strangulation enforced by the Nazis against German Jews has had repercussions far beyond Germany's borders. According to reports reaching Hamburg, the German example has revived the Jewish problem in countries to the south and east of Germany.

ALBANY, April 17 -- Edward P. Mulrooney, chairman of the State Liquor Control Board, served notice on illicit brewing concerns today that the possession of a Federal permit would not protect them against adverse action by the board when they sought licenses to continue operations in this State.

ABOARD THE S.S. BERENGARIA, at Sea, April 17 -- Although weather conditions were not so good today, Prime Minister MacDonald was early astir and before 8 o'clock was in the ship's gymnasium. He tossed a medicine ball with Sir Walter Layton, used the punching bag and cycled vigorously.

Extending widely its interests and influence, the Atlas Corporation assumed yesterday control and management of the Goldman Sachs Trading Corporation which at the same time changed its name to the Pacific Eastern Corporation. The actions were taken at a meeting of stockholders of Goldman Sachs Trading in Wilmington, Del.

The Delaware Hudson Company had a market price loss of $20,589,000 on its investments on March 16, the report for 1932, issued yesterday, shows. This includes a $2,650,000 market loss on its investment of 10 per cent in the control of the New York Central Railroad.

The Board of Estimate will be asked on Friday to authorize the use of $145,000 already available for the continuance of Summer sessions in City College, Hunter College and Brooklyn College, it was disclosed last night by Mark Eisner of the Board of Higher Education.

FLORENCE, Ariz., April 17 -- Shrieking and clawing at her jailers, Mrs. Winnie Ruth Judd was led from the court room here today after a violent outburst during the insanity hearing which, her counsel hope, may result in commutation of her sentence to be hanged at dawn on Friday.

One reason that Russian soldiers sometimes stood unarmed, as they did in the marshes of Tannenburg, trying to fight off the efficient German advance with clubs instead of bullets, was the campaign of sabotage carried on here in Manhattan under the direction of Captain Franz von Rintelen, according to his book "The Dark Invader," published today by Macmillan.

The city will make no price offer to holders of securities of the B. M.T., Interborough and Manhattan Railway Company, Mayor O'Brien declared yesterday. Its policy would be, he said, to obtain from them, if possible, definite figures for their holdings.

Mrs. Gertrude Nason Carver, 39 years old, a writer and poet, of 2 Beekman Place and Bryn Mawr, Pa., died on Sunday of an overdose of medicine that had been prescribed for a chronic ailment, it was learned yesterday.

A slight but fiery-tempered young woman who had been worrying the police for three weeks was captured yesterday afternoon with two alleged accomplices, a woman and a man, after she had attempted to hold up the butcher shop of Thomas and Henry McMahon at 147 Willis Avenue, the Bronx.

BALTIMORE, April 17 (AP) -- The opinion that Hitler's anti-Jewish campaign, may bring a shift of the 1936 Olympic Games from Germany was expressed by Avery Brundage, president of the American Olympic Committee, in a letter received here today.

Three member lines of the North Atlantic steamship conference announced yesterday that they had filed notice of their withdrawal from membership, and action by other lines was expected unless the conference moved to avert a serious break in its ranks.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W.Va., April 17 -- Rain-soaked courts today threatened to postpone the opening of the Mason and Dixon tennis championships, but the sun came out in time to let six of the eight seeded players lead the advance into the second and third rounds of the singles competition.

Harvey Penick, German-American A.C. entry, defeated Harold Holcombe, captain of the Yale freshman fencing team, 5-2, in the fence-off, to capture the Dr. James B. Clemens Medal last night at the New York Athletic Club. Twenty-five competed In the twenty-fifth annual novice foils event.
Members of the Almoners gave their annual revue and supper dance last night In the main ball-room of the Plaza in aid of the New York Foundling Hospital. Among those who took part in the revue were:

The belief that business conditions in the United States were improving was expressed yesterday by Myron C. Taylor, chairman of the board of the United States Steel Corporation, at the annual meeting of the company's stockholders in Hoboken.

CHICAGO, April 17 -- Heavy profit-taking based on a sharp recession in sterling and other exchanges and easiness in stocks carried wheat prices off today around 1 1/2 cents a bushel from Saturday's finish in the early trading on the Board of Trade.
ALBANY, April 17. -- The State Milk Control Board refused to be stampeded today by dairy farmers' threats of another milk strike unless the board fixed the minimum prices for producers.

WASHINGTON, April 17 (AP). -- Opposite sides in the controversy over free lighterage in the Port of New York were presented in briefs filed with the Interstate Commerce Commission today by the Port of New York Authority and the New Jersey Traffic Advisory Committee.

Although the more important European centres extended their observance of Easter through yesterday, the routine transactions in foreign exchanges and the colorless dealings in securities were sufficient, nevertheless, to mark a general course for the markets.
Precise Thinking Indicated. "I don't like this word 'inflation,'" said Representative STEAGALL last week. "I much prefer the word 'expansion.' "

In its twenty-third annual report covering 1932, made public last night, the Cities Service Company shows consolidated net earnings of $60,951,583, compared with $63,106,882 in 1931 and with $84,862.958 in 1930. The earnings in 1930 were the highest in the company's history.

WASHINGTON, April 17. -- A batch of appointments, the first to reach the job hunters in the States, including postmasters, collectors of internal revenue and marshals, will be sent to the Senate this week, the White House announced today.

The estate of Lewis Cass Ledyard, lawyer, who was counsel to the late J.P. Morgan and the Stock Exchange, was appraised yesterday by Deputy State Tax Commissioner Manikoff at $10,820,456 gross and $10,326,401 net, of which $9,621,402 was in securities, chiefly in bonds. Mr. Ledyard died Jan. 27, 1932.

Dr. Carlos de la Torre, former professor at the University of Havana, has been elected president of a new Cuban revolutionary junta with headquarters in New York for the overthrow of the government of President Machado of Cuba, it was announced yesterday.

On the payment of $2,500 in cash, all right, title and interest in the Barbizon-Plaza Hotel was transferred yesterday by order of Bankruptcy Referee Harold P. Coffin from the Park Sixth Avenue Corporation, which built it in 1929, to a newly organized corporation under the title of One Hundred and One West Fifty-eighth Street Corporation, which is the address of the hotel.

In a fighting dry speech at a "home-preservation luncheon" of the New York County W.C.T.U. at the Hotel Paris yesterday, Mrs. D. Leigh Colvin, State president of the organization, ridiculed the "non-political" character of the State Alcoholic Beverage Control Board.

Eitaro Shimada, honorable secretary-treasurer of the Nara Goldfish Importing Company, Inc., which adorns the drear Canarsie flats at the foot of East 106th Street, explained in detail? yesterday how he caught two fish pilferers at midnight Sunday.

As holders of the major portion of $144,000,000 of short-term obligations of New York City which will mature a week from tomorrow, member banks of the New York Clearing House Association are expected to begin today a series of meetings to determine what course they will pursue in the matter.

To the Editor of The New York Times : What comment upon Mrs. Peabody's threat that if the Eighteenth Amendment is repealed the "wimmin" of these United States will bring it back could be more apt than the immortal remark of Samuel Johnson:

Officials of the New York Curb Exchange, through counsel, notified State Attorney General John J. Bennett Jr. yesterday that they would not appear at public hearings or produce records he ordered in the inquiry into the listing practices of the Exchange unless they were subpoenaed.

Money market was quiet, little actual business being reported in any section. Quotations for all classes of accommodation carried over into the new week unchanged from those which prevailed last week. Stock Exchange call loans remained at 1 per cent, outside funds at 3/4 and Federals 1/8.
COMMERCIAL PAPER. Yesterday ...2 1/4 per cent for the best names Friday ......2 1/2 per cent for the best names The quotations are for three-four months' paper.

DETROIT, April 17 -- The boys who are fighting for jobs with the Detroit Tigers covered themselves with glory today, one of them, Ervin Fox, hitting a home run in the tenth inning to score two men ahead of him and give the Tigers an 8-to-5 victory over the Chicago White Sox.

The County Trust Company, "Al Smith's bank," has become a member of the Federal Reserve System, has written off all its losses and charged down all securities in its portfolio to current market prices, it was announced yesterday.

PEEPING, April 17 -- Japanese and Manchukuo troops advanced rapdily southward along the Pelping-Mukden Railway in North China today after having captured the port of Chinwangtao, near which the United States Fifteenth Infantry has its Summer camp.

ST. LOUIS, April 17 (AP) -- The St. Louis Browns bunched five hits off Hudlin and Hildebrand in the sixth inning for four runs and won the second game of the series from the Cleveland Indians today, 4 to 3.

WASHINGTON, April 17 -- The House adopted the administration arms embargo resolution today, 253 to 109, without debate, discussion of the controversial measure having been concluded Saturday. The final roll-call was preceded by a motion by Representative Fish of New York to recommit, which was defeated, 247 to 113.

Although Mrs. Pearl S. Buck will confer within the next few days with representatives of the Presbyterian Board of Foreign Missions on the question of her doctrinal views, no action by the board toward her removal as a missionary in China was foreseen yesterday by the Presbyterian officials.

LONDON, April 17 (AP). -- Newcastle United today made victory secure for Arsenal in the first division of the English Soccer League by defeating Aston Villa, 3-1. The Villans, previous to today's game, were the only team with a chance of overtaking the league leaders.

Praised by Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt, William Sloane Coffin, Cass Gilbert and other persons prominent in the cultural life of the nation, Miss Cecilia Beaux, noted American artist, received last night the national achievement award of Chi Omega, a gold medal presented annually to an American woman who has made an outstanding contribution to the culture of the world.

MOSCOW, April 17 -- Prosecutor Andrey Y. Vishinsky ended his six-and-a-half-hour speech today in the trial of the British and Russian employes of the Metropolitan-Vickers Electrical Company with a burst of hot invective, the chief victim of which was L.C. Thornton, one of the accused Britons, whom the prosecutor called "a coward and a traitor" to his face.

Lawrence M. Marks, president of the Bond Club of New York, announced yesterday the appointment of committees for the annual field day of the club at the Sleepy Hollow Country Club on May 26. Reginald G. Coombe heads the executive committee, which includes three vice chairmen: Jonas C. Anderson, in charge of indoor sports and entertainment; Herbert F. Boynton, outdoor sports, including golfing and racing, and Irving D. Fish, publications and attendance.
WASHINGTON, April 17 -- In the same House restaurant where real beer was last sold thirty years ago thirsty Congressmen, their guests and secretaries today downed 720 bottles of the new 3.2 beverage.
LONDON, Tuesday, April 18. -- The British Foreign Office late last night transmitted the following message from Leslie C. Thornton, who is on trial in Moscow, to his wife:

A taxpayer's action to prevent Park Commissioner John J. O'Rourke of Richmond from issuing permits to campers to occupy practically the entire waterfront of "Wolf's Pond Park, on Princess Bay, Staten Island, and to compel him to bring about the removal of about ninety shacks and cottages on the beach, has been started in the Supreme Court in Kings County by Thomas Venditto of 279 Nelson Avenue, Great Kills, S.I.

TOKYO, Tuesday, April 18 -- Rapid progress on the most important strategical and commercial railroad laid in Eastern Asia since Russia built the Transsiberian is revealed in an announcement that the 108-mile railroad between Tunhwa, and the Tumen River will be formally opened on Thursday and opened to traffic in August.

WASHINGTON, April 17 (AP). -- Over 600 of Senator Long's Louisiana adherents joined in a battle of petitions today and asked the Senate to disregard charges of corruption brought by another faction in the State seeking to unseat the selfstyled "Kingflsh."
Roberta Beatty has replaced Zamah Cunningham in the cast of "Nine Pine Street," which is scheduled to open at either the Plymouth or the Longacre Theatre on the evening of April 27.

Mayor Frank Murphy of Detroit, who has been named Governor General of the Philippines, headed a delegation of officials of that city who conferred here yesterday with bankers and important holders of the city's bonds in an effort to formulate a definite plan for refunding burdensome debt maturities that would be agreeable to the city's creditors and within the city's capacity to pay.

The Young Women's Christian Association's income from its activities during 1932 was $250,000 less than in the previous year, according to a report by Miss Margaret Webster, general secretary, made yesterday at its annual meeting at 135 East Fifty-second Street.

That "life is meaningless unless one can see" was the conclusion yesterday of an aged man and middle-aged woman whose sight was recently restored to them after years of blindness. They met yesterday for the first time, conversed for hours and made an appointment to view a theatrical performance together.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., April 17 -- When Wesley Fesler, the former Ohio State three-sport star, takes over his new duties as Harvard's basketball coach, in the late Fall, he will be confronted with the task of preparing the Crimson for its stiffest schedule in years.

The volume of acceptances of banks in operation at the end of March was $671,117,491, according to the monthly survey of the American Acceptance Council. This was $32,708,398 less than were outstanding at the end of February and $240,173,223 less than on March 31, 1932.

Pondering how to relieve human distress leaves little time for plans for kindness to animals, but the American Humane Association cannot afford to drop its work even in these times. In urging the observance of this week in behalf of our dumb friends it points out that the depression has also had its effects on them.
Handicaps for the motor-boat race down the Hudson River from Albany were decided upon last night at a meeting in the Columbia Yacht Club, foot of West Eighty-sixth Street.

Reports regarding the Administration's intentions in the matter of patronage are now succeeded by official utterance, at least so far as the postmasters are concerned. "No incumbent whose term has not yet expired and who has been rendering loyal and efficient service to the Government need have the slightest fear of removal," states the Postmaster General.

WASHINGTON, April 17. -- With administration legislation lagging in committees or delayed by prolonged debate in the Senate, the House, in passing today the arms-embargo bill, disposed of the only major matter awaiting action on the floor and then adjourned after passing five minor bills.

The D.M.B. Holding Company, Catherine McGowan, president, sold the two-story brick bowling alley building at 545-49 16th St., adjoining the southwest corner of Madison St., West New York, to the Colony Holding Corp. of 437 16th St., West New York. Assessed at $23,700, the realty was taken over subject to two mortgages totaling $66,865.

WASHINGTON, April 17 -- Any thing that former Premier Edouard Herriot of France has to say in an effort to lay the groundwork for a lump sum settlement of war debts will receive sincere consideration by the Roosevelt administration From what was said in authoritative circles today, however, the President intends to adhere to his policy that other economic questions should not be subordinated to the debt problem.

BERLIN, April 17 -- The Hitler-Papen government will act on urgent domestic and foreign matters this week. Chancellor Hitler, on his return from Bavaria tomorrow, will convoke a series of important Cabinet sessions at which economic reforms and social relief measures will be promulgated.

Paul Claudel, retiring French Ambassador to the United States, is to sail for Havre tonight on the French liner Paris, accompanied by Mme. Claudel and their daughter, Reine Claudel. Enrique Gil, Argentine Ambassador, also is to sail on the Paris for England on a special mission.

Charles H. Lockwood, for many years a compositor for THE NEW YORK TIMES, died Sunday in St. Petersburg, Fla., after a long illness. Mr. Lockwood resided at 216-17 Forty-third Avenue, Bayside, Queens, and for some years had made his Winter home in St. Petersburg.

WASHINGTON, April 17 -- Opponents of the St. Lawrence Waterway Treaty, now pending on the Senate calendar, began a new attack today through a determined effort to open a study of the possible harm from the proposed waterway to the commerce of the United States.

DECATUR, Ala., April 17 -- Judge James E. Horton sentenced one of the nine Scottsboro Negroes to death today in accordance with the finding of a jury which found him guilty of attacking a white girl two years ago and postponed the trial of his eight co-defendants indefinitely.
To the Editor of The New York Times: From one of my friends in New York I received today a clipping from THE NEW YORK TIMES of March 29 reporting the Franco-American meeting held here on March 28.

PARIS, April 17 -- Without undue optimism, and in fact with a studied effort to discourage exaggerated hopes for concrete accomplishments, former Premier Edouard Herriot sailed from Havre on the Ile de France today on his mission to the United States.

Eighteen, properties on the auction block yesterday were bid in by plaintiffs in the respective foreclosure actions. Seven of the parcels are in Manhattan and eleven in the Bronx. A scheduled sale of the Hotel Victoria was postponed to May 25.

New financing of $26,000,000 for the Edison Electric Illuminating Company of Boston will be done formally today by a banking group headed by the First of Boston Corporation, which will offer $16,000,000 of three-year 5 per cent notes and $10,000,000 of non-interest-bearing seven-month notes.

HAVRE DE GRACE, Md., April 17. -- Neverfade, Mrs. F. Ambrose Clark's 5-year-old horse, made a triumphant return to the races after a layoff of nearly two years when he scored by two lengths over an odds-on favorite, P.M. Burch's Tambour, in the featured West-minster Purse at the Havre de Grace track today.
George McAneny, former chairman of the Transit Commission, is slated for appointment by Mayor O'Brien as Sanitation Commissioner, it was learned last night on excellent authority.

With the approval of members of an election board in the Fourth Assembly District, Miss Sadie Keller of 32 Columbia Street, Manhattan, voted twice last November at a polling place in Public School 110, Broome and Cannon Streets, she testified yesterday at the trial before Federal Judge John C. Knox and a jury of a Tammany district captain and four members of the election board.

The former Ziegfeld Theatre at Fifty-fourth Street and Sixth Avenue will reopen Friday as a motion-picture house of the Loew circuit. Friends and associates of the late Mr. Ziegfeld, the chorus girls he glorified, the stagehands he worked with, and the stars he made will assemble at the theatre at noon Friday to participate in a tribute to the memory of the producer.
WASHINGTON, April 17 -- The Senate roll-call on the Wheeler 16-to-1 silver amendment to the farm relief bill follows:

Reports in yesterday's TIMES from a dozen cities showed that our engaging young friend, Three-Point-Two, was justifying expectations, both as a temperance drink and a revenue-maker. Working twenty-four hours a day, the breweries can't turn out enough to keep up with the demand.

WASHINGTON, April 17 -- Patriotic education for citizenship to restore equilibrium in the nation upset by the economic depression was urged upon the Daughters of the American Revolution today by Mrs. William Russell Magna, President General.

Dr. and Mrs. Victor W. Logan were hosts yesterday afternoon at their home, 1 Beekman Place, at the annual meeting and reception of the Bible and Fruit Mission of the Public Hospitals of New York, of which Dr. Logan is treasurer and his wife a member of the board of trustees.

WASHINGTON, April 17. -- An outstanding reason for the refusal of the Senate today to adopt Senator Wheeler's 16-to-1 silver amendment, a direct inflationary proposal, was an authoritative whisper in the cloakrooms that the President will seek to make with Great Britain, France, Germany, Italy and Japan an international currency agreement on the basis of bimetallism.

While Federal authorities took steps yesterday looking to the revocation of licenses issued recently to five brewerits in Northern New Jersey to manufacture 3.2 per cent beer the authorities of Elizabeth, N.J., continued their investigation of the murder of Max Greenberg, former gangster, and Max Hassel, beer racketeer, which resulted in the brewery inquiry.

Funeral services for Daniel Fillmore Lewis, former president of the Brooklyn City Railroad, were held yesterday afternoon at the Greenwood Cemetery Chapel, Brooklyn, with the Rev. Dr. E. Louis Walz, a nephew, who is pastor of the First Presbyterian Church, City Park Branch, Brooklyn, officiating.

WASHINGTON, April 17. -- The Senate today for the second time approved the thirty-hour work week bill as it stands, thereby definitely placing responsibility for fate of the legislation in the hands of the House and of the administration.

American Judaism suffers from an overabundance of "big temples," Dr. Julian Morgenstern, president of the Hebrew Union College, Cincinnati, said last night in endorsing the ideals of the Little Temple experimental group which was started last Fall.

WASHINGTON, April 17 -- "Smoothing out" of the Muscle Shoals measure was begun by the House Military Affairs Committee today, with the intention of reporting out the bill tomorrow night and calling it up for action in the House by Wednesday.

The controversy that has troubled the parishioners of St. Mark's-in-the-Bouwerie for many months was traced yesterday by the Rev. Dr. William Norman Guthrie, the rector, to an interest in property and money rather than in the salvation of the soul.

DETROIT, April 17. -- Depositors in the two closed national banks will receive 30 per cent of their deposits next Monday. Probably no further payments will be released until Nov. 30, according to C.O. Thomas, conservator of the First National Bank-Detroit.

RED BANK, N.J., April 17. -- Newton D. Alling was appointed today receiver of the Broad Street National Bank. He has heen its conservator. His appointment as receiver means that the bank will no longer be able to receive deposits in trust accounts, as it has been doing since the bank holiday.
Midtown office and garment space constituted the featured items in Manhattan's commercial leasing activity as reported by brokers yesterday.

NEW YORK. Princess Henry XXXIII of Reuss is expected tomorrow on the Olympic and will go to her home at 740 Park Avenue. With her is the Countessa Martini Crotti of Rome, a daughter of the Marchesa Sommi Picenardi, now at the Savoy-Plaza.
To the Editor of The New York Times: If W.C. Lyman will read the debt-funding agreements several of the points made in his letter to THE TIMES will be cleared up.

WASHINGTON, April 17 (AP). -- The Supreme Court cleared the way today for a court test on charges of price fixing by the Aluminum Company of America, giant enterprise of the Mellon family of Pittsburgh, by rejecting the company's appeal from a lower court order to produce information from its own records.

WILMINGTON, Del., April 17 (AP) -- Appointments of receivers for the South American Railways Company and the Public Utility Holding Corporation of America are asked in two bills of complaint filed in Chancery Court here by Joseph Greene of New York City.

WASHINGTON, April 17 -- A reduction of $144,000,000 in the War Department budget for the next fiscal year is the goal set by President Roosevelt in his economic program. This was revealed by Secretary Dern today after a brief conference with the President.

MOSCOW, April 17 (AP). -- A "five-year plan of sabotage" by six British electrical engineers on trial for bribery, sabotage, and espionage, was charged tonight by the counsel for three of their Russian co-de-fendants.

" Ultimate Statehood for Puerto Rico" was a declaration of the Democratic National Convention. Congress has so many domestic problems to deal with, including economic conditions in that island, that early attention to the resolution of President NADAL of the Puerto Rican Senate asking Congress to call a constitutional convention as an essential step toward Statehood is not to be expected.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., April 17 Forty oarsmen of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, under Coach Bill Haines, arrived today and will remain for the week as the gruests of the midshipmen, while preparing for the racing on Saturday. Varsity, junior varsity, freshman and 150-pound events will be held with the Naval Academy, all over the Henley distance.

For the benefit of the Adopt-a-Family Committee of the Emergency Unemployment Relief Fund a loan exhibition of paintings by Rembrandt was opened yesterday at the Knoedler Galleries, 14 East Fifty-seventh Street, to continue through April 29.

John H. McCooey will head the Brooklyn Democratic organization's slate of candidates for delegates to the State Repeal Convention, it was agreed yesterday at a meeting of the Kings County executive committee.

The tagging of trout is not a new idea. It has been tried with varying success by a number of States. From the information gained through the reports made by anglers who have landed the tagged fish, conservation departments have been able to do valuable checking on their restocking programs.
WASHINGTON, April 17. -- The Bureau of Navigation issued the following orders, dated April 14:
WASHINGTON, April 17 -- The Boston Red Sox won their first game of the season, 4 to 2, today, although, reserve pitchers were forced to rush in to quell a Washington uprising before the game ended.

Two apes recently born on the Rock of Gibraltar increased the number of those sacred guardians, listed as members of the garrison, to ten. In the colony's estimates a grant of money is provided for their subsistence. Captain D.A. SMITH, officer in charge of apes, has a staff of one non-commissioned officer.

CHICAGO, April 17 (AP). -- Possibility that members of the Capone gang, assisting in the search for kidnapped Jerome Factor, 19, had obtained a "lead," was indicated here tonight as police apprehended six of them inspecting "rogues' gallery" photographs of three men suspected of membership in a Northern Illinois-Iowa extortion ring.
WASHINGTON, April 17 -- The War Department Issued the following orders today:
LEXINGTON, Ky., April 17 (AP). -- Rain was the order again today at Lexington and attendance and mutuel play were reduced to a minimum.

Tom Chester of the Salem-Crescent A.C. and Charles M. Greene of the Politan A.C. qualified to represent the metropolitan district in the national A.A.U. boxing championship tournament to be conducted at Boston next week as the result of their victories at the New York Athletic Club last night.

MEXICO CITY, April 17. -- Critics of Josephus Daniels changed their protests to compliments as the new Ambassador from the United States called on Foreign Minister Jose Manuel Puig Casauranc today. Because of objections to him Mr. Daniels had been heavily guarded since entering the country.

Booksellers sell about twice as many books of fiction as they put into their rental libraries. This statement is reiterated by the Baker Taylor Company, based on a new survey of what happened to 13,991 copies of fifty representative book titles bought by forty-eight stores.

MANILA, April 17 -- Senator Benigno Acquino madea fiery plea today at Hoilo for acceptance of the Hawes law for the independence of the Philippines, and Senator Quirino, acting majority floor leader, broadcast an address in reply, assailing the Hawes law, chiefly the naval base provisions, alleging that under its terms the United States might also reserve commercial districts.

The names of George W. Davison, chairman of the board of the Central Hanover Bank and Trust Company, and Thomas J. Watson, president of the International Business Machines Corporation, were submitted yesterday to member banks of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York as nominees for election to the board of the bank to succeed, respectively, Albert H. Wiggin and William H. Woodin who have resigned.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The logic which, in many letters written on the subject of socialized medicine toy laymen, uses arguments based on monetary statistics to prove how the practice of medicine should be conducted, is a spurious logic, but it is such a familiar method of reasoning in other fields of public interest today that to the unthinking reader it is often convincing.

VIENNA, April 17. -- "It is now certain that Austria has also a friend in the south who will always stand as helpfully by her side," Dr. Engelbert Dollfuss, Austrian Chancellor, said today on his return by airplane from his visit to Pope Plus and Premier Mussolini in Rome.

WASHINGTON, April 17-- Easter Monday was celebrated in traditional fashion at the White House today, with 47,100 children rolling eggs on the slopes of the south grounds. Indoors, Anna, Eleanor and Curtis Dall, grandchildren of the President and Mrs. Roosevelt, entertained this afternoon.
