Plans of a campaign for further drastic reductions in governmental expenditures in New York to reduce the tax burden were approved yesterday by business and professional leaders at a luncheon given at the Bankers Club by George W. Wickersham, chairman of the board of the New York State Economic Council.

A temporary reduction of $5 a ton in the price of newsprint, effective April 1, was announced yesterday by the International Paper Company. The new price is $40 a ton delivered f.o.b., New York, thus making it less than $35 a ton at the mill.

Drawing their illustrations from the present economic and political situation, Seventh Day Passover sermons delivered yesterday in some of the city's synagogues emphasized the thought that economic as well as moral justice should be the concern of religious leaders.

WASHINGTON, April 17 -- Protests against a proposed loan of $2,100,000 to the American Mortgage Company of El Paso, Texas, for financing the construction of a 200-mile natural gas pipe line by the El Paso Natural Gas Company have been filed with the Reconstruction Finance Corporation by Southwestern railroads and independent petroleum producing companies.

HAVANA, April 17 -- Because of the rigid military censorship and the absence of any authentic news in Havana newspapers concerning activities of the authorities or the Opposition elements, there have been many rumors of the killing of students by police and of street battles and bomb explosions, none of which could be confirmed.

With speculators marking time, largely because of the uncertainties which surround the foreign exchange market, the trading pace on the Stock Exchange slackened yesterday. Outwardly Wall Street seemed to be most interested in the status of our currency in relation to the gold-standard currencies of Europe, but at the same time a weather eye was kept open in the direction of Washington, where vague "inflationary" projects are reported to be taking form.

WASHINGTON, April 17. -- A Senate subcommittee headed by Senator Glass forged ahead today on bank deposit "insurance" legislation, unmindful of whether the administration favors or opposes the proposal at this time.

Dr. Ashley Horace Thorndike, Professor of English at Columbia University and one of the world's foremost Shakespearean scholars, collapsed at Madison Avenue and Forty-first Street last night while on his way home from a dinner in the Fraternity Clubs Building two blocks away.

In January two years ago Professor ASHLEY THORNDIKE made the memorial address at the commemoration service for those who during their lifetime "advanced the honor of Columbia University." He will himself hereafter be numbered in that illustrious company.

LONDON, April 18. -- There was the usual post-holiday lull on the Stock Exchange today, the attendance being small and business restricted. British funds were dull. German loans had a sharp setback as a result of continued weakness in reichsmark exchange.
ST. LOUIS, April 18. -- Four men from Augusta, Ark., were killed when the airplane in which they were flying here crashed and burned near Valmeyer, Ill., this forenoon.

WASHINGTON, April 18. -- Wholesale commodity prices increased seven-tenths of 1 per cent in March, as compared with, the preceding month, but were 8.75 per cent below the corresponding month last year, the Bureau of Labor Statistics announced today.

Jules I. Bogan, who is managing editor of The New York Journal of Commerce, and Marcus Nadler, Professor of Finance at New York University, are the authors of "The Banking Crisis: The End of an Epoch," which will be published on Friday by Dodd, Mead.

George Jean Nathan, who has just published in "Since Ibsen" a collection of scenes and speeches that he considers he has seen and heard too often in the theatre, discussed the theatre and his thirty years of writing about it in an interview yesterday.

Tuesday, April 18, 1833. All departments of the money market were quiet and at a standstill so far as rate changes were concerned. Business was on a small scale, and chiefly of a routine character. Stock Exchange call loans remained at 1 per cent, with the usual concessions in outside money prevailing.

SHANGHAI, Wednesday, April 19. -- The probabilities of extension of the Japanese invasion of North China into the Peiping-Tientsin area were sharply accelerated Tuesday afternoon when three Japanese airplanes heavily bombed the walled town of Tungchow, only ten miles east of Peiping, incidentally endangering the lives of 200 American children of high school age from all parts of China who attend a private school there.

Mayor O'Brien held a transit unification conference yesterday with a committee representing about 45 per cent of the outstanding 4 per cent consolidated mortgage bonds of the Manhattan Railway Company. The committee was headed by Van S. Merle-Smith.

Following is the statistical comparison of the Labor Bureau's general average of wholesale prices in the United States for March. The calculation is based on 784 commodities since the end of 1931 and 550 for earlier dates. Comparisons with months prior to 1931 are presumably affected by this change.

Against a silver garden setting, a Summer fashion show was staged yesterday afternoon in the ballroom of the Hotel Plaza for the benefit of the Woman's Auxiliary of the New York Infirmary for Women and Children, one of the few remaining hospitals in the neighborhood of Stuyvesant Square.

MOSCOW, April 18 (AP). -- Just before the court retired today to consider its verdict in the Metropolitan-Vickers sabotage case, William L. MacDonald reiterated his guilt, the other British prisoners stoutly affirmed their innocence and the Russian defendants abjectly threw themselves on the mercy of the court after admitting all the charges.

WASHINGTON, April 18. -- The Akron was sound and well constructed of good material, Commander Ralph D. Weyerbackar, who had charge of the design and construction of the airship, told the naval court of inquiry when it resumed its hearings in the navy yard here today.

Mr. ROOSEVELT saw the necessity of doing something to slow down the inflation mania in Congress. At his request, or demand, the various amendments to the farm bill proposing to meddle with the currency in one way or another have been withdrawn.
Nick Carter's Publishers. Few publishing firms can aspire to the double claim on posterity which has fallen to the lot of Street Smith, specialists in "pulp" literature.
To the Editor of The New York Times: Much has been written about the control features of the State beer law and little attention has been paid to other provisions of that act.

New York's Police Department will not interfere with the operation of "wildcat" breweries here unless action is requested either by the State Alcoholic Beverage Control Board or Federal authorities, Police Commissioner James S. Bolan said yesterday at his noon press conference.

SCRANTON, Pa., April 18. -- Changes in railroad rate-making and accounting practices required by the law or the Interstate Commerce Commission were recommended by L.F. Loree, president of the Delaware Hudson Company, in an address before the Chamber of Commerce tonight.

The Musicians Symphony Orchestra, conducted by Sandor Harmati and assisted by Harold Bauer and Albert Spalding, played last night in the Metropolitan Opera House. The concert, all things taken into consideration, was perhaps the most brilliant that this orchestra has given this season.

To establish the basis for an economic revival of the building industry, a twelve-point inquiry has been suggested by Orion H. Cheney, former New York State Superintendent of Banking and former vice president of the Irving Trust Company, who directed a national survey of the publishing industry two years ago.

On the eve of their departure for Chicago, where they are entered in the national open indoor polo championship, Winston Guest's Optimists played a practice match at Squadron A Armory last night, turning back, a pick-up team by the score of 11 1/2 to 9 1/2.
WASHINGTON, April 18. -- The Bureau of Navigation issued the following orders today, dated April 15:

Cheered by unexpected strength of the group in Congress in favor of silver, futures for this commodity rallied vigorously yesterday on the National Metal Exchange. Silk also was strong, while all other commodities except sugar and coffee in local markets closed with gains on the day.
WASHINGTON, April 18. -- Following are the index numbers by groups and subgroups, compared to previous figures:

RICHMOND, Va., April 18. -- Cyrus Hall McCormick, inventor of the reaping machine, was added to Virginia's Hall of Fame here this afternoon when a-marble bust was unveiled in the old hall of the House of Delegates in the presence of descendants of the inventor and a large group of Virginians and visitors from New York and elsewhere.
WASHINGTON, April 18. -- The War De- partment released the following orders today:

BOSTON, April 18 (AP). -- Dr. Owen Copp, who died of a heart attack while attending a fair at Seville, Spain, was a specialist in the care of insane. He was born in Salem, N.H., in 1858 and was a graduate of Dartmouth, class of '81 and Harvard Medical School, class of '84.

Two days before Mr. MACDONALD left England for the United States to discuss with President ROOSEVELT methods of reviving international commerce, it was announced that his Government had concluded a new trade agreement with Germany.

BUFFALO, April 18 (AP). -- More than thirty of the leading women swimming stars of the United States and Canada made final preparations today to compete for nine National A.A.U. senior titles in the pool of the Buffalo Athletic Club, starting tomorrow night.

The selection of a successor to Dr. James M. Kieran, president of Hunter College, who will retire at the end of August, will be made by the Board of Higher Education at its next regular monthly meeting, either on May 15 or May 22, Max Eisner, chairman of the board, disclosed yesterday.
PARIS, April 18. -- Talk of inflation in the United States was blamed by French newspapers and bankers today for the weakness of the dollar on the Bourse.

Professor FRANCK of Gottingen University, a World War veteran as well as a distinguished scientist, resigned yesterday in protest against the plans and decrees of the Hitler Government. They demanded from Germans of Jewish descent, he declared, "that our "children shall grow up conscious "of never being allowed to show "their worth as Germans."

In a letter to The London Times Mr. H.G. WELLS relates with perfect good humor the trouble and expense to which he and his publishers were put to disprove the curious charges made by a Canadian lady that "The Outline of History" was plagiarized from a still unpublished work of hers.

ALBANY, April 18. -- After representatives of independent milk dealers in New York City had protested today that they would be driven out of business under the present minimum price schedules, the State Milk Control Board decided to ask Attorney General Bennett for a ruling on the price charged by stores for milk purchased from the big distributers and the unadvertised dealers.

WASHINGTON, April 18. -- Measures aimed at improving economic conditions in Cuba by raising the price of sugar received intensive consideration from the administration today at separate conferences held by Oscar B. Cintas, the Cuban Ambassador, first with President Roosevelt, and then with Sumner Welles, Assistant Secretary of State, who has taken over supervision of Latin-American affairs in the State Department.

Activities of the New York Curb Exchange in unlisted securities were described yesterday at the first public hearing in the inquiry being made by Attorney General Bennett. The hearing was in the State Office Building.

Indications that the Metropolitan Opera would go "over the top" in subscriptions for next season, exceeding the number this year, were seen yesterday at the box office, which reported a "wonderful response" to the request for renewals.

BERLIN, April 18. -- The defeat of the Wheeler amendment to the farm relief bill to remonetize silver at 16 to 1 in yesterday's session of the United States Senate caused a recovery of the dollar, which was today only one decimal point below the usual mark exchange rate, but at the same time again aroused discussion in the German press as to what is going to happen to the dollar.
"The Comic Artist," a new comedy by Susan Glaspell and Norman Matson, will have its postponed premiere this evening at the Morosco Theatre.

WASHINGTON, April 18. -- After a day of moves and counter-moves during which inflation was discussed at many conferences, it was understood that the President will make a statement tomorrow that no more gold will be exported for the present.

WASHINGTON, April 18 (AP). -- Important limitations today were written into President Roosevelt's program for developing the Tennessee Valley as the House Military Committee slowly plodded through a new plan for disposing of its old trouble-maker, Muscle Shoals.

HAVRE DE GRACE, Md., April 18. -- Mrs. J.H. Whitney's Kentucky Derby eligible Poppyman won the Calvert Purse, feature at Havre de Grace, today before one of the largest early week crowd in several years.

All the member lines of the United States Intercoastal Steamship Conference were represented yesterday when the Spring meeting convened at the conference offices, 44 Whitehall Street. Several committees were appointed to prepare reports and the meeting will be reconvened this afternoon to hear them.

The Newark Bears staged a heavy-hitting attack and defeated Toronto, 7 to 2, before 2,500 spectators at Newark yesterday. The Bears collected twelve blows, including George Selkirk's homer which scored Cooke ahead of him in the eighth inning.

Immediate construction of the Triborough Bridge and the East River tunnel connecting Manhattan and Brooklyn was urged yesterday in two measures introduced in the Board of Aldermen with the object of lessening unemployment. Alderman Edward W. Curley of the Bronx sponsored the bridge measure, while Alderman Patrick J. McCann supported the tunnel.

After being mysteriously absent since last October, one of the precious manuscripts of the Pierpont Morgan Library has returned, none the worse for its wandering's. The prodigal is part of the autograph manuscript of the first volume of Sir Walter Scott's "Guy Mannering," which disappeared last October while on loan exhibition at Columbia University and for which an international search has been made.

Louis S. Cates, president of the Phelps Dodge Corporation, told stockholders yesterday that "the present policy of the company is to produce as much copper as it can sell through its fabricating subsidiaries and to its regular customers."

A "steering committee" of bankers to deal with New York City's financial situation, particularly the $144,000,000 maturities due a week from today, was appointed yesterday at the meeting of representatives of clearing house banks and leading investment bankers.

LONDON, April 18. -- A warning that the World Economic Conference must succeed, at whatever sacrifice by any of the participating nations, and a plea that it be the first of a series of such conferences are contained in the annual report of the Liverpool Chamber of Commerce, published today.

MOSCOW, Wednesday, April 19. -- One sentence of three years' imprisonment, another of two years' imprisonment and an order for the expulsion of three men from Soviet Russia was the judgment of the court early today on five of the six British electrical engineers who have been on trial here on charges of espionage and sabotage.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., April 18. -- A large gallery on the lawns of the Casino watched the opening round of the women's singles matches in the Mason and Dixon tennis tournament this morning. Mrs. John Van Ryn defeated Mrs. Barger Wallach; Miss Florence Le Boutillier won over Mrs. Louis Reinhardt; Miss Barbara Stoddard defeated Miss Natica Nast, and Miss Helen Meany, Miss Celeste Richards.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., April 18. -- John Wanamaker ran his Gold Cup speed boat Louisa through a test on Manhasset Bay this afternoon, and the boat attained a speed of approximately 58 miles an hour. The run was preparatory to taking the Louisa abroad for the international racing in Italy.

Paul Claudel, who has just retired as French Ambassador to the United States, boarded the French liner Paris late last night on his way to his new post at Brussels. Because the Paris was delayed by fog yesterday on her return from a Bermuda cruise and did not dock until 6 P.M., it was expected that her sailing would be delayed until 4 or 5 A.M.

The listed bond market developed a much firmer tone yesterday, con- trasting sharply with the weaknesses in nearly all sections of the list on Monday. Trading was appreciably heavier in both foreign and domestic bonds. United States Government bonds showed considerable irregularity in view of the prospect of new long-term government financing soon and the discussions concerning inflation.

CHICAGO, April 18 (AP). -- Lonnie Warneke today hurled the Cubs to a 3-to-1 victory over Pittsburgh. It was the Cubs' second triumph of the season, both of which, incidentally, were pitched by Warneke. Also it was the first setback for the Pirates.

Fifteen additional players are given a national ranking, while three who were previously listed are stricken from the lists in the final report of the ranking committee of the United States Lawn Tennis Association, which was made public yesterday.
NEW YORK. Mrs. James Lees Laidlaw will give a dinner on April 27 at the Colony Club for Pierre de Lanux, chief of the League of Nations bureau in Paris.

WASHINGTON, April 18 (AP). -- Federal prohibition of interstate shipments of oil unlawfully produced, a plan regarded by President Roosevelt as "well considered," was supported by railroads and the oil industry before the House Interstate Commerce Committee today.

LONDON, Wednesday, April 19. -- The first reaction to the sentencing of two British engineers in Moscow for espionage and sabotage came from the government, within half an hour of receipt of the news in London, in a form leaving little doubt that the government intends to apply an immediate embargo on Russian goods.

Princess Henry Reuss and Countess Martini are due today from the Channel ports on the White Star liner Olympic. Others arriving on the steamship include Percy J. Phybus, Member of the English Parliament; Arthur C. Hardy, Speaker of the Senate at Ottawa; Captain Paul Kimberley, Mr. and Mrs. Charles M. Connfelt, Mr. and Mrs. H.T. King, Mrs. E.M. Robinson and Seaman Watson, boxer.

At the conclusion, yesterday of the second day's meeting between officials of the city of Detroit and bankers here in the offices of the Bankers Trust Company, some members of the former group, which, is headed by Controller C. E. Rightor, indicated that a tentative agreement or understanding had been reached whereby the city's 1933-34 tax levy would be set at $53,600,000.

SPRINGFIELD, Mo., April 18. -- Mrs. Kate Kentling, 97-years old, who had witnessed the writing of some of the most colorful pages in history when she had served as lady-in-waiting to the "mad Empress" Carlotta, died at her home here early today.

President Roosevelt would never have received from Congress the sweeping powers granted in the economy bill had it not been for the grave emergency in the nation's economic life, Arthur Krock, chief Washington correspondent of THE NEW YORK TIMES, declared last night in a discussion of "Parties and Pressure Groups" with Dr. E. Pendleton Herring of Harvard University, broadcast over a nation-wide National Broadcasting Company network.
In sympathy with the advances in stocks and grains, prices on the Cotton Exchange recovered yesterday all of Monday's losses and closed at net gains of 13 to 16 points.

The dense fog that came down over the harbor late Monday night with the rain lightened yesterday morning from Sandy Hook to the Battery and the North and East Rivers cleared off entirely in the afternoon, but it hung over the Ambrose Channel until 3 P.M.

SCHENECTADY, N.Y., April 18. -- Charles Francis Adams, Secretary of the Navy in President Hoover's Cabinet, was elected today a director of the General Electric Company at the annual meeting of stockholders here. The other directors were re-elected.

The floating supply of common stock of the United States Steel Corporation on March 31, 1933, as indicated by stock brokers' names, was 1,398,856 shares, or 16 per cent of the total issue of 8,703,252 shares, it was announced yesterday. This represents an increase of 74,878 shares since Dec. 31, 1932, when the floating supply was 1,323,978 shares or 15.21 per cent of the total issue.

WASHINGTON, April 18. -- Proposed drastic cuts in army and navy appropriations and personnel were protested as false economy in a resolution proposed at a meeting this afternoon called by the committee on national defense of the Daughters of the American Revolution, here in convention.

Characterizing the postponement of the remaining trials in the Scottsboro case as "undoubtedly a blessing to both sides," Samuel S. Leibowitz, chief counsel for the Negro defendants, informed Judge James E. Horton of Decatur, Ala., in a letter yesterday that he may utilize the opportunity offered by the postponement to bring the case before the United States Supreme Court on the issue of race discrimination.

To the Editor of The New York Times: There have been recent attacks upon the general principle of parole and probation, particularly by certain members of the judiciary. If not stated it is implied that those who believe in this principle are "sentimentalists," "theorists" and "lacking in a sense of the realities."

LEXINGTON, Ky., April 18 (AP). -- Ridgeview Farm Stable's Ridgewise, winner of the Ben Ali Handicap on opening day, repeated that smashing performance to score his second victory of the meeting in the Shandon Farm Purse, an allowance affair which headlined today's otherwise mediocre card.

The Federal Bar Association of New York, New Jersey and Connecticut made public yesterday a resolution adopted at a meeting of the association at the Hotel Commodore extending "deepest fraternal sympathy to fellow lawyers persecuted in Germany" because of their Jewish faith and condemning the persecutions and economic destruction to which Jewish lawyers are being subjected under the Hitler regime as a return to barbarism.

The United States is committed to a policy of increasing price levels but lacks a monetary policy to effect this increase, Dr. Lionel D. Edie, economist and former Professor of Finance at the University of Chicago, told members of the New York Financial Advertisers Association at a luncheon at the Commodore yesterday.

WASHINGTON, April 18 (AP). -- A seventh-inning drive today gave Boston a 6-to-4 victory over Washington and the second Red Sox triumph of the season. The defeat sent Washington from third to fourth place in the league standing.

WASHINGTON, April 18 (AP). -- Agreed upon a widely ramifying banking reform bill, embodying a $2,000,000,000 proviso for insuring Federal Reserve member bank deposits, the Senate banking subcommittee made known tonight that it would withhold final action until the administration speaks.
George McAneny, independent Democrat and former chairman of the Transit Commission, was appointed by Mayor O'Brien yesterday to head the reorganized Sanitation Department.

Ending many weeks of argument and dispute, the committee of the whole of the Board of Estimate reported out favorably yesterday a resolution to accept the low bid of the Manhattan Ash and Garbage Removal Company, of which Samuel R. Rosoff is president, for the disposal of Brooklyn's refuse for the next five years.

A unanimous decision upholding the State's right to order a dangerous operation on 2-year-old Helen Vasko, over the protests of her parents, was handed down yesterday by the Appellate Division in Brooklyn.

CHICAGO, April 18. -- Archie Brown, suspected by the "underworld detective bureau" of being one of the kidnappers of Jerome Factor, 19, son of John (Jake the Barber) Factor, was identified today by Mrs. Leon Marcus, mother of Jerome Factor, as a man she had seen lurking in front of her home just before the kidnapping.

QUEBEC, April 18. -- Fears of a newsprint price war, which would send prices tumbling under their already low levels and which might force more newsprint concerns into bankruptcy, were expressed here today by representatives of the Canadian industry as a result of the International Paper Company's discount of $5 a ton.

BOSTON, April 18. -- Two additional deaths, the closing of a score of factories, the abandoning of several hundred homes and the disrupting of highway and rail transportation in Northern areas were reported tonight as New England rivers, already far above ordinary flood stage, continued to boll beyond control.

Celebrating the tenth anniversary of the official opening of the Stadium in a manner that could not have been more fitting had it been designed, the Yankees again upset the Athletics yesterday to record their third straight triumph over the Mackmen and their fifth in a row since the opening of the season.

The Phoenix Cereal Beverage Company, operating the Phoenix Brewery at Twenty-fifth Street and Tenth Avenue until it was padlocked under the Volstead act, withdrew its motion in the Federal District Court yesterday for an order vacating the padlock decree.

A noticeable improvement in the business of the United States Rubber Company occurred in the first two weeks of April, William de Krafft, chairman of the finance committee, said yesterday at the annual meeting of stockholders.

Belief that important legislative plans are in the making, with strong administration sponsorship, existed in Wall Street yesterday as the advance was resumed on the Stock Exchange. The possibility of interesting developments at the approaching conferences which President Roosevelt will hold with representatives of foreign governments also figured in the speculative calculations.

WASHINGTON, April 18 (AP). -- Called together by the American Legion, representatives of patriotic, labor and fraternal organizations joined tonight in a mass meeting designed to arouse public sentiment against recognition of Soviet Russia.

Jim Browning of Missouri, recognized in New York State as world's heavyweight wrestling champion, successfully defended his title in the feature finish exhibition at the New York Coliseum last night. A crowd of 9,000 saw Browning pin Sammy Stein of Newark with a body scissors in 40:27.

No city would reduce its police force to a total of officers and men too weak to patrol the streets, control traffic and protect life and property. The same principle of practical expenditure should be applied to the maintenance of the army.

Gifts and pledges of $186,303.76 for the support of Salvation Army relief activities, from more than 6,000 individuals and including more than $16,000 in unsolicited donations, were reported yesterday at the second united appeal report luncheon at the Bankers Club.

The first of several suits against the Harriman National Bank and Trust Company and its indicted former chairman, Joseph W. Harriman, to recover money paid for stock in the bank, alleging misrepresentations by Mr. Harriman and other officers, began yesterday before Supreme Court Justice Shientag.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., April 18 (AP). -- Seven of the eight quarter-final brackets in the men's singles division of the thirteenth annual Mason and Dixon tennis tournament were filled today without a break in the list of seeded players.
WASHINGTON, April 18 (AP). -- Newton D. Baker appeared for John Factor before the Supreme Court today to plead that orders for Factor's extradition to England be set aside.

WASHINGTON, April 18. -- United States exports moved seasonally upward during March to $108,000,000, compared with $101,530,000 in February, and imports reached $95,000,000, as against $83,750,000 for the preceding month, according to preliminary figures made public today by the Commerce Department.

WASHINGTON, April 18 (AP). -- Henry Morgenthau Jr., tonight neared the first goal he set for himself when he became Farm Board chairman March 6, to get the Hoover-created board out of "the farm commodity stabilization business."

TOKYO, Wednesday, April 19. -- Japan's dispute with Russia over the Chinese Eastern Railway is a local one, to be settled by officials on the spot, according to the answer being drafted here to Moscow's demand that its rights be protected.

The largest run of flounders that has been seen this Spring now is furnishing Peconic Bay fishermen with fine sport, according to reports from New Suffolk. The boat captains say that while this big run was late in arriving it is making up for the delay by abundance and size.
JOEY SEWELL was talking about hitters in a soft, Southern drawl.

The Rev. Dr. William Norman Guthrie took complete charge of the annual parish meeting of St. Mark's-in-the-Bouwerie yesterday, and, through firm exercise of the authority vested in him by the ancient charter of the church to deeide who should vote and who should not, he got rid of the vestry which three weeks ago asked Bishop Manning to get rid of him.

In full view of hundreds of shoppers, three hold-up men whisked two messengers, on their way to a bank to cash a payroll check amounting to $12,954.43, into a sedan in crowded Union Square yesterday afternoon, forced one of the messengers to enter the bank and cash the check and then drove them to the lower east side and abandoned them in a tenement.

ABOARD THE S.S. BERENGARIA, Bound for New York, April 18. -- Prime Minister MacDonald's days on shipboard are divided into certain clear-cut categories. He rises early, in accordance with his habit of taking a walk in St. James's Park before 8 A.M. when he is in London.

YOUNGSTOWN, Ohio, April 18. -- Iron and steel companies in this district are operating this week at the highest level since May, 1932, managers announced today. The average is 22 per cent of capacity. Rolling mill schedules are somewhat ahead of steel ingot output, indicating that steel production will rise in the next few weeks.

To the Editor of The New York Times: "The Face on the Barroom Floor" has found a mysterious equal, for it was never one whit more intriguing than the face which startlingly appeared on Seventy-second Street last Saturday evening. Pedestrians passing between Broadway and West End Avenue stopped to gaze in wonder at this portrait on the south sidewalk.

BERLIN, April 18. -- Professor James Franck, eminent German physicist and Nobel Prize winner in 1925, resigned today his professorship in Gottingen University in protest against the anti-Semitic animus of the Hitler government.

OTTAWA, Ont., April 18 (Canadian Press). -- Canada ended the last fiscal year with an export trade balance of $67,693,483. Domestic exports for the twelve months ended on March 31 totaled $473,907,455, against imports of $406,213,972. At the end of the preceding year the Dominion had an import balance of $2,148,580.

Charles M. Schwab, chairman of the board of the Bethlehem Steel Corporation, expressed the view yesterday that the depression has "reached bottom" and that business may now look forward to gradual improvement.

BERLIN, April 18. -- Reopening after the four-day Easter holiday, the Boerse found itself today almost without orders from the public. Trading thus was left to professional speculation, which was apathetic, and prices sagged generally.

CHICAGO, April 18. -- Continued talk of inflation of the currency, an advance in sterling exchange to the highest level since early last August and a flood of reports of damage to the wheat crop west of the Missouri River swelled to large proportions the volume of today's wheat trading on the Board of Trade.

WASHINGTON, April 18. -- Confident of the President's general approval of the plan to mobilize private industry under the government for expansion under strict hour and wage regulation in the production of articles and materials in normal demand, as a companion measure to the impending public works unemployment relief program, some of his closest executive advisers have prepared a draft of the proposed legislation.

WASHINGTON, April 18 (AP). -- The War Department's plan for making the $144,000,000 cut in next year's operating expenses demanded by President Roosevelt was placed directly before the Chief Executive late today.

Paul Brunet, a radio singer of 65 West Fifty-eighth Street, who was employed last November as a Republican watcher in a polling place at Cannon and Broome Streets, saw repeaters voting, and when he asked where they had come from, Max Markowitz, Democratic chairman of the local election board, said they had been recruited from "rum row," Brunet testified yesterday.

FORT MUNOZ, April 18. -- Paraguayan troops, apparently from Fort Arce, have been attacking Fort Alihuata since Sunday night, seemingly determined to recapture it at all costs, according to information received today.

FLORENCE, Ariz., April 18. -- Mrs. Winnie Ruth Judd won another week of life today when the Arizona Pardons Board advanced to April 28 the date for her execution so that a decision as to her sanity may be made.

WASHINGTON, April 18. -- The dispute over the receiverships for the Interborough Rapid Transit Company and the Manhattan Railway Company was brought before the Supreme Court this afternoon, when attorneys argued over the right of Circuit Judge Martin T. Manton to designate himself to sit as a circuit judge and name the receivers.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., April 18. -- Three times sentenced to death for murder, Russell McWilliams of Rockford, Ill., 18 years old, today escaped the electric chair and was condemned to prison for ninety-nine years. His life was spared by Governor Horner.

WASHINGTON, April 18. -- Aroused by developments in the New Jersey brewery-permit controversy, arising from charges that licenses have fallen into the hands of racketeers, Attorney General Cummings today began a personal investigation of the situation.

Aldermanic President McKee took the initiative yesterday in pressing for rate reductions on electricity, gas and telephone service in this city and thus manoeuvred Tammany out of the initial credit for launching a drive that seems likely to become one of the chief issues in the Fall Mayoralty campaign.

Grappling hooks of naval tugs caught in a twisted duralumin girder of the wrecked airship Akron yesterday morning, and before sun down divers working in about 100 feet of water had sent to the surface large sections of the control car and part of the jumbled framework of the hull.
LONDON, April 18 (AP). -- Football matches played in the British Isles today resulted as follows:

JERUSALEM, April 18. -- The solemn chimes of the finest carillon in the Near East, playing sacred hymns and secular airs, initiated the ceremonies of dedication today of the magnificent new Y.M.C.A. Building here.

Daily average gross crude oil production in the United States last week was 1,934,000 barrels, compared with 2,221,350 during the preceding week, a decrease of 287,350 barrels, according to the American Petroleum Institute. A decline of 70,800 barrels in the daily average at Oklahoma City and one of 228,450 barrels in East Texas, reflecting shut-down orders in both areas, accounted for the large drop.

Aldermanic President McKee took the initiative yesterday in pressing for rate reductions on electricity, gas and telephone service in this city and thus manoeuvred Tammany out of the initial credit for launching a drive that seems likely to become one of the chief issues in the Fall Mayoralty campaign.

Grappling hooks of naval tugs caught in a twisted duralumin girder of the wrecked airship Akron yesterday morning, and before sun down divers working in about 100 feet of water had sent to the surface large sections of the control car and part of the jumbled framework of the hull.
LONDON, April 18 (AP). -- Football matches played in the British Isles today resulted as follows:

JERUSALEM, April 18. -- The solemn chimes of the finest carillon in the Near East, playing sacred hymns and secular airs, initiated the ceremonies of dedication today of the magnificent new Y.M.C.A. Building here.

Daily average gross crude oil production in the United States last week was 1,934,000 barrels, compared with 2,221,350 during the preceding week, a decrease of 287,350 barrels, according to the American Petroleum Institute. A decline of 70,800 barrels in the daily average at Oklahoma City and one of 228,450 barrels in East Texas, reflecting shut-down orders in both areas, accounted for the large drop.
LIVERPOOL, April 18 (AP). -- Shipping circles foresee an Atlantic steamship rate war unless the Cunard Line is able to settle its differences with other companies over cabin class fare.

While there has been no indication thus far that the administration in Washington is giving countenance to any of the radical proposals looking to some form of inflation, the advance yesterday in the share and commodity markets was commonly ascribed to such influences.

RICHMOND, Va., April 18. -- Annual meetings of stockholders of the Chesapeake Ohio Railway Company and the Atlantic Coast Line Railroad Company were held here today. The sessions were harmonious and all directors of both companies were re-elected.

The fiftieth anniversary of the incorporation of the International Committee of the Young Men's Christian Associations of the United States and Canada and the dedication yesterday of the new home of celebrated here yesterday at a luncheon at the Hotel Biltmore.

John McCormack, Lucrezia Bori and Henri Deering, pianist, were the artists at a concert last night for the benefit of the Catholic Boys' Clubs of New York. The concert, held under the patronage of Cardinal Hayes, was arranged to help wipe out a deficit and to insure the uninterrupted continuation of the activities of the clubs.

To the Editor of The New York Times: May I direct attention to the fact that the proposed Federal mortgage relief bill will fail to bring assistance or relief for a great number of home owners in the City of New York and its immediate environs?
Ogden L. Mills has been elected a director of the Mergenthaler Linotype Company.

WASHINGTON, April 18. -- A grant of large powers to the Secretary of Labor to control industrial production, regulate the hours of labor of workmen and prescribe fair wages is proposed for the administration in a tentative draft of legislation sent to the House Labor Committee by Secretary Perkins.

With "tide-over" jobs provided for 456 heads of families and unmarried women through the efforts of the Adopt-a-Family Committee, an intensive effort will be made in the next ten days to "adopt" 544 additional families, it was announced yesterday at a luncheon of women volunteer workers of Manhattan, the Bronx and Queens, held at the Junior League Club, 221 East Seventy-first Street.

CHICAGO, April 18. -- First in the Chicago area to avail itself of the new Federal bankruptcy law, the Chicago Eastern Illinois Railroad today filed a petition in United States District Court here seeking relief under Section 77, Chapter 8, of the act's provisions.

An ultra-high-speed motion-picture timing camera that can take up to 3,000 pictures per second, enabling man to see what hitherto has belonged to the realm of the invisible, was demonstrated yesterday by Electrical Research Products, Inc., at its projection room, 250 West Fifty-seventh Street.

A nation-wide decline in births in the decade from 1921 to 1931 is indicated by figures presented by statisticians of the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company for twenty-six States and the District of Columbia. Only those twenty-six States and the District were members of the United States Registration Area in 1921, making their statistics available for comparison.

BERLIN, April 18. -- Reports in German newspapers today touching on the warning issued by Avery Brundage, chairman of the American Olympic Committee, that Berlin faced the loss of the games in 1936 because of the anti-Semitic attitude of the Hitler government, produced a mixture of shock and incredulity in the office of the Olympic organizing committee.

More than 100 faculty members of colleges and universities throughout the country attended the 145th meeting of the American Oriental Society yesterday at the Casa Italiana of Columbia University, Amsterdam Avenue and 117th Street.

Ferdinand J. Kuhn of Passaic and Bernardsville, N.J., one of the leading woolen experts in the United States, who was for nearly forty years the guiding force of the Botany "Worsted Mills of Passaic, died yesterday after a brief illness in his New York apartment at 277 Park Avenue.

An ultra-high-speed motion-picture timing camera that can take up to 3,000 pictures per second, enabling man to see what hitherto has belonged to the realm of the invisible, was demonstrated yesterday by Electrical Research Products, Inc., at its projection room, 250 West Fifty-seventh Street.

A nation-wide decline in births in the decade from 1921 to 1931 is indicated by figures presented by statisticians of the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company for twenty-six States and the District of Columbia. Only those twenty-six States and the District were members of the United States Registration Area in 1921, making their statistics available for comparison.

BERLIN, April 18. -- Reports in German newspapers today touching on the warning issued by Avery Brundage, chairman of the American Olympic Committee, that Berlin faced the loss of the games in 1936 because of the anti-Semitic attitude of the Hitler government, produced a mixture of shock and incredulity in the office of the Olympic organizing committee.

To the Editor of The New York Times: A humorous situation of the day is the reputed readiness of Senate Republicans to ask a Democratic President to relieve Republican Robert Lincoln O'Brien from the Tariff Commission in favor of a Democrat.

CHICAGO, April 18. -- First in the Chicago area to avail itself of the new Federal bankruptcy law, the Chicago Eastern Illinois Railroad today filed a petition in United States District Court here seeking relief under Section 77, Chapter 8, of the act's provisions.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Your editorial on "The Decatur Verdict" discussed very fairly the various aspects of the trial. However, it contained the following sentence: "But the final verdict was 'guilty,' and it is now difficult to see how an appeal could lie to the Supreme Court again, or to any higher power except the Governor."

BERLIN, April 18. -- Chancellor Hitler's forty-fourth birthday on Thursday will be marked by nationwide public observance far beyond any ever accorded to any other man in Germany's public life since the Kaiser's day.

Four manhole covers were blown off by an explosion yesterday afternoon in West Fifty-eighth Street, between Broadway and Seventh Avenue, and a fire that followed partly wrecked an empty taxicab. The noise attracted a large crowd.

FRANKFURT, Germany, April 19. -- An accord has been reached between the Rudolf Karstadt Company and the American Protective Association of Bondholders providing for immediate payment to bond-holders of an amortization slice of 7 1/2 per cent.

WASHINGTON, April 19 (AP) -- Revision of Secretary Perkins's unprecedented plan to reduce the hours of labor, establish minimum wages and permit Federal control of production was predicted tonight by members of the House Labor Committee after deciding to make a detailed study of the proposals.

WASHINGTON, April 19. -- Reporting a "more cheerful" feeling throughout the country as to business and banking prospects, Governors of the twelve Federal Reserve Banks met at the Treasury Department today on summons by Secretary Woodin at the instance of President Roosevelt.

The New York City Omnibus Corporation and the Madison Avenue Coach Company, Inc., subsidiaries of the New York Railways Corporation, filed yesterday with the Board of Estimate petitions for twenty-five-year franchises for bus operation, at a straight five-cent fare over a comprehensive network of routes in Manhattan.

ABOARD THE S. S. BERENGARIA, Bound for New York, April 19. -- Prime Minister. MacDonald hopes to talk tomorrow morning with Ambassador Lindsay in Washington by wireless telephone to discuss the final arrangements for his visit.

ABOARD THE S. S. ILE DE FRANCE, Bound for New York, April 19. -- Edouard Herriot spent many hours today discussing economic and financial problems with the experts who are accompanying him. He intends before his arrival in the United States to fix every item of the French position clearly.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., April 19. -- Edward G. Buckland, chairman of the New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad system, presiding at today's annual meeting of stockholders, declined to entertain a motion to lower the salaries of the railroad's executives by 30 to 50 per cent.

WASHINGTON, April 19. -- Prime Minister MacDonald of Great Britain and former Premier Herriot of France will meet jointly with President Roosevelt on one occasion during the Washington economic conversations, at an informal White House dinner Tuesday evening.

Other Good Reasons. Lively doings in Wall Other Street and on the commodity markets are explained by most experts as inspired by talk of inflation. But conceivably some of the credit belongs elsewhere.

CHICAGO, April 19 -- A tremendous outburst of general buying of grains on the Board of Trade here today followed what the trade construed as virtual abandonment of the gold oasis by the United States. Prices advanced by leaps and bounds to new high levels for the season on all deliveries of wheat, rye and barley. Only May corn and oats failed to get into fresh ground.

To the Editor of The New York Times: THE TIMES editorial "A Lot of Dynamite" and a subsequent editorial "The Next Step" are so opportune as regards the five-Say thirty-hour week that the following is believed of immediate interest to public which seems slowly awakning to the concealed and far-reaching menace of this legislation.

The extent to which railroad expenditures may be more readily made under a receivership than under the customary corporation management is shown in the annual report of the Wabash Railway. This line, which went into receivership on Dec. 1, 1931, reduced operating expenses by 27 per cent in 1932, but placed more new rail, ties and ballast in 1932 than in 1931.

BERLIN, April 19 (AP). -- The statement of Avery Brundage, president of the American Olympic Committee, that he felt the 1936 Olympic Games should not be held in Germany if the anti-Semitic campaign continued, brought caustic comment from the press today.

The Rev. Peter d'Orgueval, French priest who has been Roman Catholic chaplain at the leper colony on the island of Molokai, Hawaii, for eight years, has, like his famous martyred predecessor, contracted leprosy, according to a letter received Saturday by the Maryknoll Fathers at Ossining, N. Y., members of the Catholic Foreign Mission Society of America.

LEXINGTON, Ky., April 19 (AP). -- Constant Wife, from the Dixiana Stable of Charges T. Fisher, took first call on the 2-year-old filly championship of the West when she accounted for her second victory of the current meeting in the fifteenth running of the Hinata Stakes, feature today.

WASHINGTON, April 19. -- A bill designed to reduce the government printing bill by about $4,000 a day, speed up legislation and put the brakes on long-distance oratory will be introduced in the House tomorrow by Representative Cannon, a first-term Democrat from Milwaukee.

In "Facts of Fiction," Just published by Dutton, Norman Collins, young associate in the English publishing firm of Gollancz, Inc., skips with some cheers and many boos through the vast album of English literature, and offers some attention to America in a final chapter.

In by far the most active trading of the year and in several cases the most active in the history of individual exchanges, commodities swept yesterday to new high levels for 1933. The extent of the gains was in one case unparalleled, and in several others greater than on any other day of the year.

The annual report of the Canadian Hydro-Electric Corporation, Ltd., and subsidiaries for 1932 shows consolidated net income of $2,728,056, equal to $21.32 a share earned on the 6 per cent first preferred stock, against $2,305,546, or $18.44 a share in 1931 on the first preferred stock.

LONDON, April 19. -- Great Britain's answer today to the Moscow verdict in the trial of the engineers of the Metropolitan-Vickers Electrical Company was the imposition of an embargo, effective next Wednesday, on about 80 per cent of the Russian goods imported by the United Kingdom.

PHILADELPHIA, April 19 -- Mrs. Ola Cralge Gibbons Huntingdon, wife of Warner Dare Huntingdon, a manufacturing chemist of New York, jumped to her death today from a room on the fifteenth floor of the Benjamin Franklin Hotel, where she had registered yesterday afternoon as Mrs. O. G. Hunt.

CHICAGO, April 19 (AP). -- Midwest agriculturists, industrialists, financiers and merchandisers united tonight in endorsement of President Roosevelt's embargo on gold exports, a step in the announced policy of controlled inflation.

PRTNCETON, N.J., April 19 -- More than 150 women, representing twelve New Jersey organizations, attended the round table discussions preceding the fifth conference on the cause and cure of war here today.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., April 19. -- Moving into action after two days of postponements. Clifford S. Sutter of New Orleans, top seeded player in the Mason and Dixon tennis tournament, who was chosen yesterday for the United States Davis Cup team, stepped quickly into the quarter-final round today, while two other nationally famous stars, Frank X. Shields of New York and Gregory Mangin of Newark, N.J., reached the semifinals.
Business leases, especially of retail stores in the midtown section, were reported in large number yesterday.

Carnegie Hall, historic citadel of music, may become a movie house if it does not receive more support from musical artists and their managers, Robert E. Simon, president of Carnegie Hall, Inc., warned yesterday at a luncheon for the press, attended by officials of the hall and representatives of some of the leading concert managements.

Relief work of the Seamen's Church Institute of New York was carried to new extremes last year due to the unprecedented unemployment among merchant seamen, according to the eighty-eighth annual report, issued yesterday by the Rev. Dr. Archibald R. Mansfield, superintendent.

MUNICH, April 19 -- Revelation by the Bavarian Government that 5,400 persons have been taken into "protective arrest"' since March 9 and that 3,770 still are detained has renewed interest in that aspect of the "National Socialist revolution.

The War Department notified Major Gen. Dennis E. Nolan at Governors Island yesterday that a total of 34,500 men would be enrolled for the Civilian Conservation Corps from New York State, New Jersey and Delaware. New York State's quota has been increased from 8,100 to 25,700.

BERLIN, April 19. -- Germany had an export surplus of 63,700,000 marks (about $15,173,340 at par) in March, as against 26,200,000 marks ($6,240,840) in February. The increase was not unexpected, but somewhat exceeds the seasonal improvement of the foreign-trade balance, which normally reaches its peak in March.

George H. Howard, president of the United Corporation of Delaware, has resigned as a director in twelve corporations associated with the Electric Bond and Share Company, retaining his post as director in the latter company, however. His resignation from the boards of affiliated companies is due to the numerous demands upon his time as chief executive of the United Corporation and as a director of the Atlas Corporation.

To the Editor of The New York Times. The administration's home mortgage refinancing bill contains one feature that deserves also to be incorporated in the farm-mortgage refinancing scheme. That is the proposal to have the refinancing activities conducted by a government corporation instead of by a Federal office or bureau.

The bill providing for the establishment of a Home Owners Loan Corporation under the Federal Home Loan Bank Board to refinance home mortgages, which was presented to Congress last week with a recommendation by President Roosevelt, will be the subject of public hearings before the Senate Finance Committee in Washington today and tomorrow.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I was shocked to learn that the New York Nursery and Child's Hospital may soon be forced to discontinue its extensive free maternity and children's work for lack of funds. Such a possibility constitutes, to my mind, not only a serious health hazard to the west side, but a challenge to responsible citizens of the whole community.

ALBANY, April 19. -- Creation of the Saratoga Springs Authority to develop the State reservation at Saratoga into a national health, resort is provided for in a hill approved today by Governor Lehman.

CHICAGO, April 19 (AP) -- Allowing no opposing runner to pass second and only four to reach that base, Ted Lyons shut out the St. Louis Browns with three singles today and the White Sox won their home opener, 3 to 0.

WASHINGTON, April 19. -- The decision as to whether or not the receivers appointed by Circuit Judge Martin T. Manton for the Interborough Rapid Transit Company and the Manhattan Railway Company shall continue in office now lies with the Supreme Court, which heard closing arguments in the case today.

WASHINGTON, April 19. -- It may clarify the minds of those who are concerned over the administration's economic policies, or who seek precise details of each future step, to be informed of an analogy which appeals to the President as descriptive of the situation in which the nation now finds itself.

HAVRE DE GRACE, Md., April 19. -- Tred Avon, S. W. Labrot's 5-year-old Sir Greysteel mare, led from start to finish of the featured Bowling Brook Purse today to win by a length and a half at 3 to 5. She was handled by Hobert Jones and finished the mile and seventy yards over a muddy track in 1:47, with the top impost of 113 pounds.

A test action to determine the powers and duties of a conservator under the emergency banking legis lation has teen brought here, was announced yesterday. The actlon is by the estate of Louis S Gimbel, New Tork and Philladelphia merchant, against Henry En Cooper, as conservator of the Harriman National Bank, and the bank itself.

WASHINGTON, April 19 (AP). -- A veritable wave of support and enthusiasm for the Presidential currency plans came from Capitol Hill and particularly from the inflationist group. Late in the day a delegation from the House called at the White House and arranged for a meeting tomorrow to promise support for the President.

An entertainment called "A Night in Paris" in aid of the Riverside Day Nursery was held last night in the Seaglade of the St. Regis. The French tricolor decorated the restaurant, and booths depicting the interior of famous night clubs of Paris had been constructed along the walls.

WASHINGTON, April 19 -- The resolution, of protest against proposed drastic cuts in army and navy appropriations, urged yesterday by the Committee on National Defense of the Daughters of the American Revolution, was adopted today by, the Continental Congress of the society and sent to President Roosevelt.

The Annalist Index of Business Activity dropped to 53.0 (preliminary) for March from 56.3 for February. The decline was caused largely if not entirely by the absence of banking facilities during a large portion of the month.
Resale of a West New York ware-house was included in the New Jersey realty transactions reported yesterday.

(The Lost Battalion). When they open the gates by Coogan's Bluff And the Giants step out to do their stuff, (If it doesn't rain or sleet or blow Or they call the game on account of snow!) There are some who will watch with vacant stars A host of players who aren't there, There are some who will close their eyes and gaze At the Lost Battalion of Other Days.

Magistrate Jonah J. Goldstein decided yesterday to hold Ben Branfman, secretary and treasurer of Jacob Branfman Sons, Inc., one of the biggest kosher provision manufacturers in the city, on a charge of exposing for sale nonkosher meat in violation of the penal law.

The appointment of George McAneny, independent Democrat, as Sanitation Commissioner was assailed yesterday by Republicans and Fusionists as a "Tammany trick" and as a confession by Tammany of past betrayal of the public interest.

ROME, April 19. -- Premier Mussolini, speaking today at the International Parliamentary Conference on Commerce, gave the first hint of the line Finance Minister Guido Jung may be expected to take in his conversations with President Roosevelt in Washington.

WASHINGTON, April 19. -- Declines of 4.2 per cent in employment of manufacturing industries and 8.2 per cent in their payrolls during March as compared with February were due almost entirely to the national banking holiday, Secretary Perkins said today in making public the monthly analysis of industrial employment by the Bureau of Labor Statistics.

Restrictions on gold exports and the resulting violent rise in exchange rates caused business on the Cotton Exchange yesterday to reach the largest volume in several years. Under aggressive buying by commission houses and domestic mills as well as by foreign interests, prices rose a half cent and ended at gains of 39 to 42 points.

PRINCETON, N. J., April 19. -- Harvard defeated Princeton, 6 to 5, on University Field today, to score its second victory in as many starts in the Eastern Intercollegiate Baseball League. Harvard is now in second place in the league standing.

BERLIN, April 19. -- The Boerse opened firmer today, chiefly on the strength of the unexpectedly good showing of the export balance for March. The initial upward movement, due to buying by professional interests, soon spent itself in the absence of any public support, and in a dragging market prices kept on sagging to a weak close.

William Faulkner's book of verse, "The Green Bough," is published today by Harrison Smith Robert Haas. Much of the verse was written by Faulkner some years ago and is about nature, young love and death.

No "repeating," no "assistance" of voters, and no other voting irregularities were seen last election day at the polling place at Cannon and Broome Streets by Patrolman John Lamattina and Special Deputy State Attorney General Maxwell Lehrhaupt, they testified yesterday before Federal Judge John C. Knox and a jury in the election fraud trial of Max Markowitz, Democratic chairman of the district election board, and four others.

WASHINGTON, April 19-- An agreement on the administration's Tennessee Valley development plan, including the Muscle Shoals feature, was reached by the House Military Affairs Committee tonight, and the modified measure will be sent back to the House tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, April 19. -- President Roosevelt today ordered an embargo on all exports of gold except that earmarked for foreign countries, thus taking the United States definitely off the international gold standard.

A list of more than eighty depositors in the Harriman National Bank and Trust Company was identified in the Supreme Court yesterday as naming those who were called to the bank late in 1930 as "first-grade depositors" and who accepted an invitation to acquire stock of the bank at $1,512 a share.

Asserting that the Reconstruction Finance Corporation has been unwilling to advance funds for payment of deposits in the closed Harriman. National Bank and Trust Company on the basis of the "contemplated lawsuit" against the New York Clearing House Association, Emil Schlesinger, counsel for a group of depositors in the bank, made public last night a telegram to Secretary Woodin asking when payment of the deposits might be expected.
BERLIN, April 19 (AP). -- The Reichsbank statement as of April 15 shows the following changes in reichsmarks:
WASHINGTON, April 19 (AP). -- Representative F. H. Shoemaker, Farmer-Labor, of Minnesota struck a neighbor in the eye last night because the latter refused to turn off his radio.

CLEVELAND, Ohio. April 19 (AP) -- Heartening reports came today from several sources in the steel industry in Ohio as stock and commodity prices were rising in the country's market centres. W. S. Doxsey, editor of Daily Metal Trade, said 'many mills had the largest bookings of orders that they had had for one or two years.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., April 19. -- Yale and Harvard broke even in their annual rugby games today, Yale taking the varsity clash, 14 -- 0, and Harvard capturing the jayvee contest, 17 -- 5. In the varsity battle Yale showed superior strength in the scrum.

BERLIN, April 19. -- A report that the United States Government will not continue to maintain gold parity by selling foreign currencies on the world market, but will permit the dollar to adjust its value, has created general confusion in Germany, as it conflicts with other reports.

A Dutch farmhouse built by Jan Martense Schenck of pine timber in 1675 has been selected by the Kings County Historical Society as the central unit of a popular museum to hold valuable documents and relics of interest to Brooklyn, it was announced yesterday by Charles A. Ditmas, president of the society.

HAVANA, April 19 -- The police tonight seized three youths, one of them the son of a National University professor, and confiscated an infernal machine which was in reality an automobile made into a monster bomb.

BOSTON, April 19. -- With a Patriots' day crowd of 5,000 shivering in the stands, the Dodgers battled through ten innings to a 2-to-1 decision over the Braves today in the only game of the four scheduled contests the weather permitted.

It has been agreed by the Warnsleigh Realty Corp., as landlord, and the Nassau Fulton Restaurant Corp., Lee Jang, treasurer, as tenant, of the second floor of the building at 87 Nassau St., that the lease be modified so that the rent shall be 54.200 for the year beginning April 1, 1933.

BOSTON, April 19. -- Bucking a brisk and biting wind all of the way, Leslie Pawson, 28-year-old Pawtucket (R. I.) mill-hand, out-raced the strongest of his 221 rivals "by almost a mile today to triumph, in the thirty-seventh running of the famous Boston A. A. marathon in the record smashing time of 2 hours 31 minutes 13-5 seconds.

PARIS, April 19.-- The dollar was quoted as low as 24 francs 55 centimes today on the official market, after opening at 24 and 85. The final quotation, 24 and 60, marking a drop of 65 centimes from yesterday's closing, was 4 per cent below the official par value of 25.523.

A complaint, alleging failure to give protection to two Jews, residents of Brooklyn and citizens of the United States, who were arrested and mishandled by Nazis in Berlin during the recent anti-Jewish disorders in Germany, will be filed today with the State Department against George S. Messersmith, American Consul in the German capital, it was announced yesterday at the office of the American Jewish Congress.

PEEPING, Thursday, April 20. -- The Rev. Mark Brown, secretary of the North China Conference of the Methodist Episcopal Church, announced today that as a result of Japanese bombing at Miyun, fifty miles north of Peiping, American mission property was struck repeatedly and many buildings were destroyed.

SHANGHAI, Thursday, April 20. -- While Japanese bombing planes extended their operations in North China today to a huge arc, its furthest point reaching within ten miles of Peiping, and Japanese and Manchukuo troops continued to smash their way southward, chaos appeared to be spreading among the Chinese forces.

The first hearing in what amounts to a test case as to whether the Public Service Commission has jurisdiction over labor policies of a public utility under certain conditions was held yesterday at the State Office Building before Commissioners George R. Van Namee and Neal R. Brewster.
WASHINGTON, April 19. -- The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today, dated April 17:

MOSCOW, April 19. -- The Soviet Central Executive Committee tonight was considering a petition for the commutation of the prison sentences imposed on two British engineers. The three other Britons convicted of sabotage were getting ready to leave the country.

WASHINGTON, April 19 -- Robert P. Gore, Florida publisher and one of the early supporters of President Roosevelt, will be nominated as Governor of Puerto Rico, probably late this week, when nominations for minor places are sent to the Senate.

The pitching and batting prowess of Captain Ray "White enabled Columbia to defeat Penn in both games of a double-header yesterday at Baker Field. The result gave Columbia a record of three triumphs in as many starts in the Eastern Intercollegiate League.

Conservationists the country over now are undertaking an annual task which is one of the most important there is in so far as the welfare of game birds and game animals is concerned and, of course, in so far as the hunter is concerned also.

WASHINGTON, April 19 -- In answer to the fighting call of Democratic leaders, party stalwarts in the Senate and a few independent Republicans today won at least a temporary victory in seeking to limit sharply the products to be dealt with in the Roosevelt farm relief bill, but the campaign delayed a final vote on the agricultural aid program until tomorrow.

With a charter of the sloop Iris arranged yesterday, the 12-meter class of yachts came to life again to lead the fleets the coming Summer in the championships and special regattas on Long Island Sound.
An appeal for hoarded gold trinkets was made yesterday by Mrs. August Belmont, chairman of the Adopt-a-Family Committee, which is seeking to provide "tideover" jobs for 1,000 destitute men and women.

NEW YORK. Mr. and Mrs. Theodore Layton Bailey will give a dinner tomorrow at the Carlyle for their daughters, the Misses Gillian Barr Bailey and Rosalie Greenleaf Bailey, whose marriage respectively to John Alfred Nichols and Thomas William Phelps will take place on Saturday afternoon.

Among the passengers listed to sail today on the North German Lloyd liner Stuttgart for Channel ports are: The Baroness Elise von Rast, Mrs. Frances Brejska, Charles Haig, Mr. and Mrs. W. Kleine, Miss Anna Gerring, Miss Erna M. Stoltze, Max Meyer, Mrs. A. Pohlmann, John A. Welsh, Dr. Herbert Weinrich and Miss Kate Phillip.

WASHINGTON, April 19. -- Forced by events, President Roosevelt will accept dictatorial powers from Congress for entering upon an emergency currency inflation program in the hope of increasing commodity prices and reducing unemployment.

Whatever additional reasons there may have been for the broad advance in stocks and commodities, Wall Street seemed to be interested yesterday chiefly in the inflationary influences set in motion by the news from Washington. Commission houses spoke assuredly of an "inflation market" and rallied their followers accordingly.

East End Avenue's mystery of the vanishing cats has heen solved, but Mrs. Walter R. Herrick, wife of the former Park Commissioner, was wondering yesterday what could be done about it. Seven cats are missing and Tiddles the Tiger is one of them.
"Unto the Third," a new play by J.N. Gilchrist, will open this evening at the Bijou Theatre. Included in the cast will be Seth Arnold, Loretto Shea, Gwen Day Burroughs and Sam Wren.

The fact that a will was left by Bertha Galland, actress, who was killed with her mother, Mrs. Anna M. Galland, in an automobile accident in White Plains on last Nov. 20, was disclosed yesterday in Surrogate's Court when a petition was filed by the law form of Compton, Dillon Clark for the probate of a document in her own handwriting.

Striking improvement in the demand for steel has advanced the operating rate for the industry to a national average of 23 per cent of theoretical capacity, compared with 19 1/2 per cent in the week before, according to the weekly review of The Iron Age.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., April 19. -- Christianity, believing in the law of love, must condemn the injustice of the present social order and will help the proletariat to achieve justice in the present world, the Rev Dr. Reinhoid Niebuhr of the Union Theological Seminary declared today in the final Taylor lecture before the Yale Divinity School Convocation.

More than 1,000 delegates of 600 Jewish organizations in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut, representing a membership of 2,000,000, met in conference at the Hotel Pennsylvania last night under the auspices of the American Jewish Congress and after renewing in a resolution the protest against the treatment of Jews in Germany by the Hitler regime, declared for more drastic measures to bring their plight to an end.

ALBANY, April 19. -- With producers urging that the Milk Control Board fix a minimum price for them, the board announced today that it would hold a public hearing next Wednesday to permit the dairy farmers to present demands.

The officers and men who died in the crash of the naval airship Akron helped to perpetuate the highest traditions of the service, Captain Edward A. Duff. Chaplain of the New York Navy Yard, said last night in an address at memorial services for the Akron dead held under the auspices of New York Lodge 1 of Elks.

Syracuse, N.Y. No bids were reported received yesterday by the city of Syracuse, N.Y., for its issue of $3,750,000 of tax and special improvement notes. New York bankers who would ordinarily bid for such obligations explained that in view of the virtual cessation of business in the municipal bond market yesterday, due to unsettled conditions, no intelligent appraisal of the market could be made in terms of a bid.

BERLIN, April 19. -- Germany, especially its monarchists, was surprised today by an announcement that Prince Wilhelm, eldest son of the former Crown Prince, was engaged to marry a commoner. His fiancee is Fraulein Dorothea von Salviati of Bonn, whose father was a court marshal to the late Princess Victoria of Scbaumberg-Lippe, sister of the former Kaiser.

LONDON, April 19. -- Wild movements of the dollar, which in the last half hour of official dealings weakened 6 cents to close at 3.61 1/2, unsettled the whole foreign exchange market today. Sales of dollars were reported from every direction, including New York.

WASHINGTON, April 19 (AP). -- The government closed its books for March with a balance of $817,909 on the right side of the ledger for the first time in nine months, after taking into consideration all items of receipts and expenditures, including those on account of general, special and trust funds.

ALBANY, April 19. -- Governor Lehman today signed sixteen bills forming the larger part of his program for increased revenues to meet the deficit of $106,000,000 in the State budget and provide funds for the next fiscal year.

The presentment to Bishop Manning by the ousted vestrymen of St. Marks-in-the-Bouwerie will be nullified by the new vestry that the Rev. Dr. William Norman Guthrie caused to be elected Tuesday, it was predicted yesterday by Dr. Guthrie. The presentment seeks to have Dr. Guthrie displaced as rector of the church.

Foreigners are subject to the jurisdiction under which they are temporarily living. That principle of international law was not challenged by the British Government in the case of the Englishmen under arrest in Moscow. Sir JOHN SIMON distinctly avowed it in his speech in the House of Commons, using these words:
At the annual meeting of stock-holders of the Crucible Steel Company of America, H. S. Wilkinson, chairman of the board of directors; said he believed the tide of business had turned.

City College's varsity baseball team registered its third straight victory of the season at the Lewisohn Stadium yesterday, defeating Stevens Tech, 19 -- 3. The game was shortened to seven innings because of the cold weather.

Publlo and private relief expenditures of $10,776,000 in New York City in March broke the record for monthly relief payments and were $1,200,000 higher than in February, according to an analysis by the Welfare Council, made public yesterday.

WASHINGTON, April 19. -- The domination of the international currency problem in the economic discussions which President Roosevelt will conduct with foreign representatives in the next few weeks became assured today as a result of the President's embargo on gold shipments and movements in the direction of devaluating the dollar.

Officially cut adrift from the gold-standard anchor by President Roosevelt's announcement prohibiting exports of gold to support exchange, the dollar fell yesterday to a discount of 11 1/2 per cent in terms of the gold-standard currencies of the world.
Miss Helen Jacobs of Berkeley, Cal., women's national tennis champion, sailed on board the Manhattan of the United States Line yesterday to compete in the French and English championships.
AMARIILO, Texas, April 19. -- Just flew in here, headed west.

United States Government bonds and many of the better-rated domestic corporation issues were subjected to severe pressure yesterday, while domestic issues of a speculative rating and German loans mounted sharply. Dealings in bonds on the Stock Exchange reached $19,823,000, of which the turnover in United States Government issues accounted for $6,607,000, representing the heaviest day's business since Dec. 18, 1931.

ROME, April 19. -- Cardinal Gasparri, who was Papal Secretary of State under Popes Benedict XV and Pius XI and who negotiated the Lateran agreement that reestablished harmony between the church and the State in Italy in 1929 after more than half a century of estrangement, is one of five men prominent in science, arts and letters appointed by Premier Mussolini today to fill vacancies in the Italian Academy, the kingdom's principal cultural institution.

WASHINGTON, April 19. -- The decision of President Roosevelt to establish an embargo on exports of gold met with no criticism in Senate circles today, although advocates of currency inflation generally expressed the belief that inflation must be employed to assure a material rise in commodity prices.

Instruction is attempted by radio, sometimes through public educational agencies, often by private institutions or by individuals. Of all the subjects offered, none would seem more likely to be successful and popular than foreign languages.

New table linens and other household furnishings for the Executive Mansion in Albany were purchased yesterday by Mrs. Herbert H. Lehman, wife of the Governor, at the Purple Box, 11 East Fifty-fifth Street, where needlework made by crippled women is sold at retail.

ROCHESTER, N. Y., April 19. -- Inflation is inevitable, said Henry T. Rainey, Speaker of the House, in an address delivered at the Rochester Chamber of Commerce luncheon today. He declared that America, outwitted by foreign diplomats, was on the verge of communism when the Roosevelt administration began its rehabilitation program.

NEWARK, April 19. -- On the first extended flight which they have taken together since their trip to the Orient in 1931, Colonel and Mrs. Lindbergh took off from Newark Airport at 12:05 this afternoon on a leisurely trip across the continent.

Mrs. Frances W. King, 42 years old, was arrested yesterday in her room, at the Barbizon-PIaza Hotel on an Indictment charging her with blackmail. She is alleged to have attempted to extort $50,000 from Brace Barton, author and advertising executive.

MOSCOW, April 19. -- The Supreme Court of the U. S. S. R., sitting in special session from April 12 to April 18 under the chairmanship of Vassili Ulrich, examined in open hearing the case of Defendants Guseff, Gregory, Ziebert, Zorin, Krasheninnikoff, Kotlyarevsky, Kutuzova, Cushny, Lebedeff, Lobanoff, MacDonald, Monkhouse, Nordwall, Olyenik, Sokoloff, Sukoruchkin and Thornton.

It is a singular coincidence that CYRUS HALL MCGORMICK (CYRUS the First) should have been admitted to Virginia's Hall of Fame just a hundred years after the death of MALTHUS, whose doctrine that "population treads ever on the limits of production," this young farmer of Virginia did so much to discredit by inventing the reaper.

Spring came to Connecticut in its austerest New England form. Snow, ice, the fear of floods, the temperatures of a cruel April have made the inhabitants shiver and shake. Yet in Ansonia the voice of Spring, the amorous call of the bullfrog for his Adeline, has been filling the air and the gular airsacks of the minstrels for a fortnight.

BUFFALO, N. Y., April 19. -- Miss Katherine Rawls, 15-year-old Fort Lauderdale, Fla., swimmer, tonight started her campaign for new swimming laurels by smashing the world's 300-yard medley record to take the National A. A. U. championship.
Plaintiffs bought in nineteen Manhattan and Bronx properties at foreclosure auctions yesterday. The results were:

A lavishly jeweled snuffbox, insured at $10,000 and said to have belonged to Frederick the Great of Prussia, was stolen early yesterday morning from the north show window of Marcus Co., jewelers, at 544 Fifth Avenue. The thieves broke the heavy plate-glass window by hurling a brick, removed only the snuffbox and escaped before Reis Jones, a watchman, who was in the rear of the store, could spread the alarm.

Chesapeake Ohio. Net income of the Chesapeake Ohio Railway decreased in March, the first time in five months. Business was curtailed by the bank holiday and deliveries were prevented by the Ohio River floods. For the first three months of the year the net income was $4,487,470, or 58 cents a share on the $25-par common stock, against $4,750,346, or 62 cents a share, in the same period last year.

WASHINGTON, April 19. -- The Akron was not built to manoeuvre in the low altitudes she reached just before her crash, although she was strong enough to meet the storm conditions at a higher level. Commander Jerome C. Hunsaker, retired, and now vice president of the Goodyear-Zeppelin Company, told the naval court of inquiry today.

BERLIN, April 19. -- Another important step in the reorganization of Germany was taken today when the national Masonic mother lodge -- the Three Globes -- announced that German Masonry would be reformed on a strictly national and Christian basis.

An "astonished" and somewhat "amused" Secretary of Labor stepped off the train from Washington yesterday morning and learned from the newspapers that what she described last night as her "modest" proposals to make the Black thirty-hour work bill workable had been heralded as a demand for a broad and sweeping control of industry, with the Secretary in the role of dictator.

George Fissler of the New York A. C., national 220-yard titleholder, retained his metropolitan championship in the 220-yard free style swim last night, vanquishing two rivals by substantial margins in the New York A. C. pool.

All speculative markets responded intuitively yesterday to over-night developments which made it clear that the dollar hereafter will have to shift for itself in the foreign exchange market.
