Obviously it is part of a deliberate government policy to release no more gold from our ample stocks merely for the purpose of equalizing exchange values.

The Administration's renewal by the general embargo against export of gold is in this respect unfortunate, that it reverses the previous policy of authorizing gold exports when the foreign exchanges had risen sharply above the "gold point."
BERLIN, April 19 -- Dissolution of all Free Masonic lodges in Germany and their reformation on a "purely Christian basis" was announced tonight by the National Grand Lodges.

The Dance Centre last night presented for the first time this season its ballet version of "Salome" at the Barbizon-Plaza, and repeated, to a large extent the success which fell to the original production a year ago. In its two season's repertoire, it can certainly boast of no other ballet to rank with this.

ALBANY, April 19 -- The law under which the Fifth Avenue Coach Company has operated buses for more than thirty years was defended by Frederick H. Wood, the company's counsel, before the Court of Appeals today in replying to the attack on the constitutionality of the act by Arthur J. W. Hilly, Corporation Counsel of New York City.

MINEOLA, L.I., April 19 -- James J. McCabe, City Clerk of Long Beach, was indicted on grand larceny charges here today by the Nassau County grand jury investigating the disappearance and mysterious return of $5,000 of city funds.

Headway on Retail Tax Plans. While definite adoption of policy awaits signing of the State sales tax measure by Governor Lehman, local store executives have made considerable headway in shaping plans for operating procedure when the law goes into effect on May 1, it was reported here yesterday.

A picture of Shakespeare which experts with X-rays consider authentic and which in itself seems to carry the proof that it was painted from life is reproduced and described in Tracy Kingman's "An Authenticated Contemporary Portrait of Shakespeare, just published by William Edwin Hudge.
WASHINGTON, April 19 (AP) -- Tactics which for two weeks have pigeonholed the Wagner-Lewis $500,000,000 relief bill ended suddenly today.
Sherwood Anderson, whose new book, "Death in the Woods," has just been published by Liveright, discussed money and writing yesterday. He is not at all sure, he said, that money is good for a writer.

The New Tork Rowing Association at its annual meeting, held yesterday at the New York Athletic Club, ratified the date for its annual Spring regatta on the Harlem and laid plans for the program of events. The regatta, as in the past, will be held May 30.

Complaints that the New York Telephone Company had threatened to discontinue telephone service to subscribers who failed to pay charges for their advertisements in Donnelley's Red Book, owned by the telephone company, were substantiated in one case presented to the Public Service Commission yesterday at a hearing on the complaints.

Susan Glaspell and Norman Matson have tried again that ever wistful scheme of probing into the soul of art. They have done so in a play called "The Comic Artist," which Arthur J. Beckhard put on last evening at the Morosco Theatre.

To the Editor of The Neto York Times. At present the United States has what is known as a "single-column" tariff; that is, the same rate of taxation of imports from all countries. Bargaining for tariff concessions, such as now proposed anew, would bring about an American tariff with two or more columns of rates;

Colonel Michael Friedsam, philanthropist, art connoisseur, civic leader and president of B. Altman Co., who died on April 6, 1931, left an estate appraised yesterday at $20,064,187 gross and $19,459,400 net, of which he gave $15,868,926 to charities and in public bequests and $2,630,000 to art museums.

Awards of ninety-four fellowships and scholarships for 1933-34, with a total value of atjout $140,000, were announced yesterday at Columbia University by Dr. Frank D. Fackenthal, secretary of the university, following action by the university council.

The Twentieth Century Limited of the New York Central Railroad will be speeded on April 30 to the fastest schedule in its history, it was announced yesterday. On that date the time for the run between New York and Chicago will be reduced to 17 hours and 45 minutes from the present time of 18 hours.

MIDDLEBURG, Va., April 19. -- Fencing expertly and responding gamely to urging in the closing stages after having been held in restraint, Mrs. Raymond Belmont's Starlite annexed the Glenwood, a cross-country event of three miles over timber that featured the second day's card of the Middleburg Hunt today.

After Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt had outlined efforts of the Federal Government to combat unemployment, Mrs. August Belmont, for three years head of the women's division of the emergency unemployment relief drive, yesterday urged sweeping changes in emergency relief administration in this city.

Three employes of the brokerage firm of John L. Morgenthau Co., 19 Rector Street, were arrested yesterday on charges of grand larceny after a partly completed audit of the company's books had shown alleged peculations of between $50,000 and $80,000 In two years.

PRINCETON, N. J., April 19. -- President Roosevelt's "rapid-fire legislative program" and his assumption of such dictatorial powers as have been accorded him during the last month are "all to the good," Dr. John Grler Hibben, president emeritus of Princeton University, said today in an interview on his seventy-second birthday.

The concluding chapters of inaugurating the 1933 baseball season in Greater New York will be written this afternoon with official openings scheduled for the Giants at the Polo Grounds and the Dodgers at Ebbets Field.

CHICAGO, April 19. -- Inflation took hold of the grain market today and sent prices whirling upward on the heaviest volume of trading in many months, as traders strove to adjust, themselves to the depreciation in the value of the dollar.

A definite basis on which the city of Detroit may ba released eventually from its financial straits was announced formally last night at the conclusion of the three-day meeting between officials of the city, headed by Controller C. E. Rightor and bankers here.

The Atlas Corporation assumed yesterday the management of the Shenandoah and the Blue Ridge Corporations, the two large Harrison Williams investment trusts having combined assets of about 140,000,000. This deal is the largest involving investment trusts since 1929, and makes Atlas the only company of its kind in this country with net assets of more than $100,000,000.

Presidents and other officials of Eastern railroads to the number of seventy-two met in the Pennsylvania Station yesterday to shape policies to be followed in the sweeping investigation of rates begun by the Interstate Commerce Commission.

MOSCOW, April 19. -- There are signs that the Soviet Government is beginning to emerge from the phase of extreme vigilance -- passive vigilance -- that has characterized Its relations with Japan in the last six months.
WASHINGTON, April 20. -- A belief that the adoption of an inflation program might junk the farm relief program was privately expressed in some quarters today.
TORONTO, April 20 (CP). -- Canada's financial centres were scenes of feverish trading today which recalled the heavy volume of four years ago and sent stocks and commodities soaring.

CHICAGO, April 20. -- Prices of grain and other commodities went to higher levels in Chicago today as buyers stormed the pits of the Chicago Board of Trade. All grain prices, except May delivery of corn, went into new high ground for the season.

After its long struggle to put buses on the streets of Manhattan had ended in the Equitable fiasco, and Controller BERRY had blocked the application of the New York City Omnibus Corporation, a Fifth Avenue Coach Company subsidiary, under which it proposed to substitute buses for trolley lines and to operate a network of routes covering much of the island, the city administration turned to the temporary expedient of a one-year franchise.

An accounting filed in the Supreme Court yesterday by the Chase National Bank as trustee of a trust fund established July 3, 1917, by John D. Rockefeller for his daughter, Mrs. Edith Rockefeller McCormick, shows that from December, 1926, until shortly before Mrs. McCormick's death, on Aug. 25, 1932, she received $4,424,343.

In a few days the Old Ashmolean Museum at Oxford will commemorate its two hundred and fiftieth anniversary. Much might be written of its history and its treasures. Antiquarians love it because it is the successor -- alas! the all too unworthy successor -- of TRADESCANT'S Ark, that collection of strange creatures of sea and land which JOHN TRADESCANT brought from Holland to England toward the end of Queen ELIZABETH'S reign.
WASHINGTON, April 20. -- The Bureau of Navigation issued the following orders today, dated April 18:
PARIS, April 20 (AP). -- The weekly statement of the Bank of France shows the following changes, in francs:

Thomas W. Lamont of J.P. Morgan Co. is of the opinion that "no civilized country of modern times has suffered so cruelly from unscientific and inefficient currency as the United States." He makes this statement in the instalment of his biography of Henry P. Davison, published in Collier's today.
Small housing parcels and several business properties made up the New Jersey realty turnover reported yesterday.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Your editorial "Inflation for Farmers" seems to have been written by one unacquainted with farm conditions. He takes the Agricultural Department Year Book showing costs of things we are to purchase and declares that inflation would merely add to our burdens in the same proportion as inflation raises the selling price of our products.
WASHINGTON, April 20. -- President Roosevelt sent to the Senate today the nomination of Breckenridge Long, an Assistant Secretary of State in the Wilson administration, to be Ambassador to Italy.
CLEVELAND, April 20 (AP). -- Clint Brown and Vic Sorrell staged a pitching duel today, but the Tiger defense cracked at important moments to give Cleveland a 3-to-1 victory over Detroit.
The New York University freshmen opened their baseball season yesterday and defeated George Washington High School, 8 to 5, at the Washington Stadium.

BERLIN, April 20. -- A slump in the dollar today from 4.15 marks to 3.90 found German public opinion well prepared and was calmly received in banking circles. A moderate rise in stocks on the Boerse and a decline in bonds were about the only visible effects.

The American, shipbuilding industry operated at about 35 per cent of its capacity in 1932 and has been further reduced this year, with Navy Department contracts the only immediate prospect for improving the situation, according to the annual report of H.G. Smith, president of the National Council of American Shipbuilders, submitted yesterday at the annual meeting at the Whitehall Club.

The modernistic trend in art is fast receding, Joseph Freedlander, well-known architect and president of the Fine Arts Federation of New York, told the members of the Allied Artists of America at their twentieth anniversary dinner last night at the Hotel Roosevelt.

KNOXVILLE, Tenn., April 20. -- Two hundred agriculturists, educators and engineers from the Tennessee Valley region met here today to outline definite recommendations for the development of the valley under the Roosevelt program.

WASHINGTON, April 20. -- Organized labor regards the amendments to the Black thirty-hour bill which were offered to the House Labor Committee by Secretary Perkins as granting her "most unusual" power, and is preparing to present its views at the hearings next week, according to the comment by members of the Executive Council of the American Federation of Labor, as they gathered here today for their quarterly meeting.

ABOARD THE STEAMSHIP ILE DE FRANCE, Bound for New York, April 20. -- Former Premier Herriot did not learn before 9 o'clock this morning- the tremendous news of the United States gold export embargo, and all day was without communication with Paris.
The Roman Catholic population in the United States is 20,268,403, according to the 1933 Official Catholic Directory, issued today. This is an increase over 1931 of 32,012.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., April 20. -- The stock of the K.M. Eastman Estate's Charley O., prevailing third choice in the Kentucky Derby future books, advanced today following an impressive mile and oneeighth trial over the Churchill Downs oval.

With the calendar of local events for the season of 1933 scheduled to be released on Sunday by the Eastern Lawn Tennis Association, announcement has been made by the New England association of the dates for the tournaments under its jurisdiction.

WASHINGTON, April 20. -- The interrelationships between domestic and foreign currency policies have become sharply emphasized since we officially went off the gold standard, and as the administration's hand has been forced on inflation, it is possible, said one today who is familiar with what is going on, that the embargo on gold may be the means of preventing inflation rather than accelerating it.

PHILADELPHIA, April 20 (AP) -- Opening the American League campaign at Shibe Park today, the Athletics, led by the devastating bat of Jimmy Foxx, routed Washington, 8 to 1, for their second victory of the season. Lefty Grove, who received credit for the first triumph, repeated against the Senators, allowing only four hits.

One hundred years one way or another mean very little in China, so a courteous letter sent by J.S. Waln from Philadelphia on the 10th of June, 1804, made his descendant, Nora Waln, welcome in the 650-year-old Lin House of Exile some five generations later.

The Erie Railroad was among the companies that received loans from the Railroad Credit Corporation at its monthly meeting yesterday. A recent application to the Interstate Commerce Commission showed that the road had applied for $1,500,000, but how much of that amount was granted wag not disclosed.

Dominick J. Commesso of 90 Thompson Street and Angelo A. Cutro of 83 Thompson Street, Republican election inspectors in the Eighteenth Election District of the Second Assembly District were found guilty yesterday by a jury before Supreme Court Justice Daniel V. McNamee of Hudson of willful neglect of duty in failing to see that proper returns of the last election were filed.
"The 3-Penny Opera" will be withdrawn from the Empire Theatre tomorrow night after a Broadway run of only one and a half weeks.

Back Where He Started. Well, BERNARD SHAW is back in England and begs to report tnat wherever he went in the course of his trip around the world he found the civilized people unhappy and anxious and the uncivilized people happy and carefree.

In the heaviest trading since Sept. 24, 1931, the listed bond market followed closely the trends of the previous day whereby United States Government bonds and the better-rated domestic corporation Issues were weak and all domestic and foreign Issues which fall under the speculative classification moved up briskly.

While agreeing with Mrs. August Belmont's belief that the method of handling philanthropic enterprises in the city is "haphazard," James G. Blaine, executive chairman of the Salvation Army United Appeal, told 200 women at a meeting of the "Tambourine Brigade" yesterday in the Hotel Plaza that "hunger cannot "wait" and urged their support of the Army's drive for $1,100,000.

BERLIN, April 20. -- The celebration throughout Germany today of the forty-fourth birthday of Adolf Hitler has demonstrated anew the remarkable hold of the present Chancellor upon the imagination of Germans everywhere. Never, even in his prime, did the last Kaiser have so generally-observed a birthday.

SHANGHAI, April 20. -- As belated details arrive from the war zone it becomes evident that American property southward of the Jehol border has suffered severely from Japanese raiders and that stiff representations from the United States Minister in Peiping are likely soon.

NEWARK, N.J., April 20 (AP). -- Home runs featured the attack of the Newark Bears today as the International League champions defeated the Toronto Maple Leafs in both games of a double-header by scores of 5 to 2 and 7 to 4.

The largest catch of flounders taken in several days was reported yesterday by Captain Bill Brenner of Babylon. He had a party of eight on his boat Sid and among them they accounted for 260 of the flat fellows, adding four, eels for good measure.

The International Paper Company reports gross sales of $73,497,063 for 1932, comparing with $90,004,461 in 1931, and an operating profit of $615,301 after cost of sales and expenses, less other income and profit on exchange, against $6,571,091 in 1931.

The annual dinner dance in behalf of St. Vincent's Hospital was held last night at the Central Park Casino under the auspices of the ladies' auxiliary of the hospital. Guests were seated at small tables placed in the pavilion and the terrace, which were decorated with many-colored balloons and electrically lighted stars.

MOSCOW, April 20. -- The Soviet press published a communique today from the Southern "grain front" that is far more important in the eyes of the Soviet Union than a dozen big political trials. And the news is good.
COMMERCIAL PAPER. Yesterday...2 per cent for the best names. Wednesday..2 per cent for the best names. The quotations are for three-four months' paper.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., April 20. -- Bernon S. Prentice, New York chairman of the Davis Cup selection committee, arrived at the Greenbrier today. With him was Dwight F. Davis of New York, former Secretary of War and retired Governor General of the Philippines, donor of the Davis Cup.

The John Fritz Medal, highest award in the engineering profession in the United States, was presented last night to Daniel C. Jackling, president of the Utah Copper Company and the Nevada Consolidated Copper Company, at a dinner at the Union League Club.

Forty writers and book reviewers have signed a protest against the action of the New York Society for the Suppression of Vice in attempting to suppress Erskine Caldwell's novel "God's Little Acre," published by the Viking Press. Inez Haynes Irwin, H.L. Mencken, Joseph Wood Krutch, Carl Van Doren and Henry S. Canby are among those signing the protest.
CHICAGO, April 20 (AP). -- Manager Lew Fonseca's single in the ninth with two out and Mule Haas on second gave the White Sox a 5-to-4 victory over the Browns in the second game of their series today.

A demand that the public utilities companies of the city voluntarily reduce their rates at once as an act of justice to the consumers was made last night by Aldermanic President McKee in a radio address over Station WOR.

Mayor O'Brien, after delivering a speech dealing with city finances to nearly 1,000 citizens of the Bronx last night at a dinner at the Arrow-head Inn, Riverdale Avenue and 246th Street, closed with an extemporaneous talk of a political nature. He assured his listeners they could count on him for any civic Improvements they might want for future generations.

ALBANY, April 20. -- Governor Lehman today vetoed the McCall bill, which would have paved the way for directors of corporations to escape full responsibility when they declare dividends which impair the corporation's capital structure.

HAVRE DE GRACE, Md., April 20. -- The Wheatley Stable's Utopian and Mrs. Elmer Trueman's Acautaw were long-priced victors in the Combat Purse and Jack High Handicap, respectively, at Havre de Grace today. Utopian, by St. Germans from Nixie, and a lightly regarded eligible for the Kentucky Derby, won by a length at 25 to 1, with Inlander second and Sarada third.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., April 20. -- Fordham scored ten runs in the first inning and routed Yale today, 11 to 0. Pitcher Ed (Lefty) Estwanick narrowly missed a no-hit game in mowing down the Yale batsmen, permitting only one safety.

WASHINGTON, April 20. -- President Roosevelt conferred with Senator Robinson of Arkansas, Secretary Woodin and Lewis Douglas, Budget Director, on details of the administration's "controlled inflation" plan, which later was presented by Senator Thomas of Oklahoma as an amendment to the farm relief bill.

ABOARD THE S.S. BERENGARIA, Bound for New York, April 20. -- The news of the departure by the United States from the gold standard added considerably to the interest of the closing stages of the voyage of the Berengaria, which will sail into New York Harbor with Prime Minister Ramsay MacDonald aboard tomorrow morning.

HE was a big coward, and now he wants to be "the fightin'est man on earth," or world's heavyweight champion, which may or may not be the same thing. Max Adelbert Baer is the name, sometimes called the Livermore Larruper. He is 24 years old, 6 feet 2 1/2 inches measured from top to toe, or vice versa, and weighs 228 pounds, net and no trade discount.
WASHINGTON, April 20. -- The letter of Lewis W. Douglas, Director of the Budget, transmitted to Congress by President Roosevelt, read as follows:

WASHINGTON, April 20. -- When Congress this week passes the sweeping grant of fiscal control to the President he will for the second time in his youthful administration have demonstrated his method of solving critical political and economic problems by persuading Congress to authorize him to apply at will one of a number of drastic solutions instead of putting one or more particular solutions in the form of law.

CHICAGO, April 20. -- Judges of the Federal circuit and district courts received orders from the United States Supreme Court today to make sweeping changes in the rules governing Federal bankruptcy cases and appointment of receivers and attorneys.

PURNEA, India, April 20. -- The second flight over Mount Everest took place yesterday. It was participated in by members of the Houston Everest Flight Expedition and may well be described by a historian of great achievements as a piece of magnificent insubordination.

TOKYO, Friday, April 21. -- The Japanese delegation's economic and financial policy in the forthcoming conversations at Washington will be based on the following principles, according to well-informed forecasts:

PURNEA, India, April 20. -- Soon after we got up through the clouds in the second flight over Mount Everest we could see the whole range of peaks making a serrated ridge along the skyline. We seemed to come immediately into photographing range and I soon was very fully occupied with the cameras.

Yesterday's statement of the twelve Reserve Banks showed total gold holdings for the system as a whole to be at the highest point of the year to date. No other important item in the system reached a new high or low figure.

A sentence of four to eight years in Sing Slng was Imposed by Judge Corrigan in General Sessions yesterday on Alexander J. Whynman, 29 years old, who was one of the special deputy Attorneys General in the Bank of United States investigation.
WASHINGTON, April 20 (AP). -- The First Lady of the Land and the first woman to fly the ocean went skylarking together tonight in a big Condor plane.
Residential building awards in the United States last month totaled $16,021,000, against $11,805,300 in February, a gain of about 36 per cent, the F.W. Dodge Corporation reported yesterday.
Seven of fourteen properties bid in at auction sales yesterday were acquired by banks acting as plaintiffs in foreclosure proceedings. All the properties are in Manhattan. The results follow:

Mrs. August Belmont announced yesterday that 541 "tide-over" jobs have been provided by the Adopt-a-Family Committee of which she is chairman. This was an increase of eighty-five since the last announcement on Tuesday. The goal of the committee is to provide 1,000 jobs before its intensive public effort ends next week.

BUFFALO, N.Y., April 20 (AP). -- Miss Katharine Rawls, 15-year-old swimming sensation from Fort Lauderdale, Fla., tonight defeated Miss Dorothy Poynton of Los Angeles, defending champion, to win the senior national A.A.U. women's indoor low board diving title.

PHILADELPHIA, April 20. -- The human system will consume the same amount of oxygen, whether pure oxygen or ordinary air containing about 21 per cent oxygen is breathed, according to the results of hundreds of experiments conducted at the nutrition laboratory of the Carnegie Institution of Washington and reported to the American Philosophical Society at its annual meeting today by Dr. Francis G. Benedict, director of the laboratory.

Among the passengers booked to depart today on the Cunard liner Mauretania for Plymouth, Cherbourg and Southampton are Oswald Garrison Villard, publisher of The Nation, with Mrs. Villard; Mrs. Olive Murray Chapman, traveler, author and lecturer; Lady Williams-Taylor, wife of the director of the Bank of Montreal; Sir John Simpson, Mr. and Mrs. C.R. Tarrant of Sydney, Australia, and H. A. Thomas of the Texas Oil Company.

WASHINGTON, April 20. -- Interlocking directorates among aviation companies holding government airmail contracts are stifling competition needed to encourage the entire operating industry and should be eliminated, by giving to the Postmaster General authority arbitrarily to cancel contracts when he finds that competing lines are controlled by the same directors as the contracting line.
WASHINGTON, April 20. -- The War Department issued the following orders today:

The fragrant aroma of wood-smoke and sizzling bacon drifted last night through the Sert Room of the Waldorf-Astoria, where 200 fashionably dressed men and women met at a dinner that formally opened the $193,000 maintenance fund campaign for the Boy Scouts of Greater New York.

Although the markets were again under the spell of the inflation movement, there remained considerable doubt yesterday as to the actual course to be pursued with respect to those legislative projects upon which speculative hopes have been built.
WASHINGTON, April 20. -- President Roosevelt's executive order, covering foreign exchange and gold, exports, issued through Secretary Woodin just before 4 o'clock this afternoon, read as follows:

LONDON, April 20. -- London's chief financial interest today centred around the dollar, following America's abandonment of the gold standard. Against yesterday's last quotation of $3.61 1/2 for the pound sterling, the dollar rate opened at $3.72 1/2, jumped to $3.93, reached to $3.88 1/2 and closed at $3.85.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., April 20. -- J. Gilbert Hall of South Orange, N.J., and Clifford Sutter of New Orleans advanced to the semi-final round of the men's singles division in the thirteenth annual Mason and Dixon tennis tournament today.

An inventory of the assets of the Mercantile Bank and Trust Company, taken over by the State Banking Department on April 12 was filed yesterday in the Supreme Court by August Ihlefeld Jr., Deputy Superintendent in charge of the liquidation.

Five hundred toy balloons, filled with helium, were released yesterday afternoon from the observation roof of the Empire State Building by Mrs. Curtis B. Dall, daughter of the President. To each balloon was attached a ticket to the Boys' Club Vacation Exposition, which will open in the Grand Central Palace on Thursday.

The police and the District Attorney's office were conducting investigations yesterday to determine how the infant twin sons of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Walsh of 359 Central Avenue, Far Rockaway, had suffered fractures of the skull within five days of each other.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In Topics of The Times you refer to the recent economic survey made of 600 home owners on Long Island and venture the suggestion that their $2,000,000 could not have been invested better than in the homes they bought five years ago.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Your article on the beer situation in today's issue is decidedly interesting and plainly shows that the man who has waited patiently fourteen years for a good glass of beer has simply been placed in the position of being "gyped" again.

The greatest hazard of business is doubt about money and materials. Ask any merchant, any manufacturer, any contractor what it is that makes him hesitate to commit himself and tends to paralyze his activities and he will tell you that it is uncertainty about prices of commodities and the standard of value.

Dresses made by factories under approved working conditions, none costing more than $30, were displayed by young society women serving as models at the budget fashion show held yesterday afternoon at the Waldorf-Astoria under tho auspices of the Fifteenth Assembly District of the New York League of Women Voters.

WASHINGTON, April 20. -- The daily average volume of Federal Reserve Bank credit outstanding during the week ending April 19, as reported by the Federal Reserve Banks, was $2,510,000,000, a decrease of $45,000,000, compared with the preceding week and an increase of $797,000,000 compared with the corresponding week in 1932.
LONDON, April 20. -- London financiers predicted today that the dollar would fall until the British pound would bring $4. The pound rose to $3.93 for a time today and closed at $3.85.

J.N. Gilchrist commits the heresy of suspecting the nobility of life as they lead it down in Boston. Beacon Street is to him just a lane tenanted by the furies of the utilities. They dwell there side by side, to found vast dynasties and to stifle further the Far-Eastern concept of-romance.

WASHINGTON, April 20. -- President Roosevelt today directed from the White House the draft of legislation granting to him power to employ the monetary system so as to raise domestic commodity prices, prime the pump of private industry, place, the United States in a stronger competitive position in the world markets and lead the way back to a general resumption of the gold standard by intergovernmental agreements.

WASHINGTON, April 20. -- Regulations on distribution of medicinal liquors under new legislation will be issued soon, after Dr. James M. Doran, chief of the Industrial Alcohol Bureau, receives recommendations from the American Medical Association.

Six deputy commissioners of the Sanitation Department and other officials high in its administration will retain their posts until the Board of Estimate fixes the number of deputies, Sanitation Commissioner George McAneny said yesterday after receiving a verbal opinion in the matter from Corporation Counsel Arthur J.W. Hilly.

Former Governor Alfred E. Smith announced yesterday the formation of a committee of 1,000 to be known as the Cardinal's Emergency Committee, which will supplement the annual fund-raising campaign of Catholic Charities the central organization of the 212 Cathollo charitable agencies in the Archdiocese of New York.
Edward A. Kelleher, Fordham basketball coach for the past ten years, has resigned from his position at the Bronx university, it was learned last night. His resignation was accepted about a week ago.

The withdrawal of quotations for future deliveries by manufacturers and wholesalers, the placing of an increased volume of orders on staple goods for current shipment at unchanged or slightly higher prices, and a careful study of merchandising procedure for the period directly ahead were the direct reactions yesterday in the wholesale markets here to prospective inflation.

President Roosevelt's policy of controlled inflation and its probable effect on real estate and the mortgage market situation was the sole topic of discussion among real estate brokers and operators yesterday. The consensus was that it would prove highly beneficial to the real estate market.

ST. LOUIS, April 20 (AP). -- Pat Malone had the better of Dizzy Dean In a pitching duel and the Cubs defeated the Cardinals in the opening game of the National League season today, 3 to 1. Each allowed, six hits, but Dean also allowed two bases on balls, one of which figured in the scoring of two runs by the Cubs in the sixth.

ALBANY, April 20. -- A decrease of 1 cent in the minimum price "unadvertised" milk sold over the counter in New York City and vicinity was made possible today under a ruling by Attorney General Bennett.

WASHINGTON, April 20. -- The application of Press Wireless, Inc., to the Federal Radio Commission for authority to communicate with additional foreign points in Europe and South America, including Berlin, Brussels, Amsterdam, The Hague, Rio de Janeiro and Santiago (Chile) moved forward another step today with the filing of briefs by its attorneys, Louis G. Caldwell and Howard W. Vesey.

The special Deputy Attorney General who was stationed last election day in the polling place at Broome and Cannon Streets when Paul Blanshard, executive director of the City Affairs Committee, charged a woman had voted twice, admitted under cross-examination in Federal Court yesterday that he made no investigation of Mr. Blanshard's charge, but instead had ordered the polling place cleared.

WASHINGTON, April 20. -- Railroads in Central Freight Association territory petitioned tne Interstate Commerce Commission today for authority to establish a "currency equalization charge" to offset the difference between United States and Canadian currencies.

The new Saratoga Springs Authority, created in a bill approved by Governor Lehman on Wednesday, was formally constituted at a meeting here yesterday and as its first official act directed its chairman, Pierrepont B. Noyes of Oneida, and its counsel, Spencer B. Eddy, to apply to the Reconstruction Finance Corporation for a loan of $3,000,000.

The dollar continued to depreciate in the world markets yesterday. It fell again to 86.87 cents in terms of the French franc, reached a new low on the move against sterling and the sterling group of currencies and reached record depths it terms of German, Dutch and Belgian currencies.

WASHINGTON, April 20. -- National defense on land and by sea and through the patriotic education of every American child for good citizenship was urged upon the Daughters of the American Revolution in addresses today at their continental congress by Major Gen. Stephen O. Fuqua and Rear Admiral Watt Cluverius, United States Navy, and by Miss Frances Perkins, Secretary of Labor, who addressed the congress tonight.

Jersey City set back the New York Yankees, 4 to 2, in an exhibition baseball game at West Side Park, Jersey City, yesterday before 6,000 persons. The contest preceded an International League encounter in which Rochester vanquished the Jerseys, 8 to 4.
LONDON, April 20 (AP). -- The weekly statement of the Bank of England shows the following changes in pounds sterling:

CHICAGO, April 20. -- Prices for hogs had today the sharpest rally in six weeks, the market starting about steady and closing 10 to 20 cents a hundred weight higher than yesterday. The sensational upturn in grains and stocks and inflation talk were responsible in part, especially as lard prices have advanced around 1 cent a pound in the last two days.

Revised figures of the Treasury, published yesterday, show that the Federal Government closed its books for March with a balance on the right side of the ledger. Receipts were $283,186,000 and expenditures $282,368,000 -- leaving a small surplus of $818,000.

LEXINGTON, Ky., April 20 (AP). -- The Nasturtium Purse, a dash of four-and-a-half furlongs for 2-year-olds, feature at Lexington today, resulted in a narrow decision for L.B. Paradis's Candle Fly. Bidden by D. Porter, the daughter of Axenstein-Butterfly II, got up in the final strides to nip J.L. Cleveland's Customer by a neck.

Another violent rise on the Cotton Exchange yesterday carried prices for all 1933 crop deliveries to 8 cents a pound or more. Trading was the heaviest in several years. Wednesday's records were broken both in volume of business and range of fluctuations.

Among a few housing deals announced yesterday was one involving the nine-story and penthouse apartment building at 610 West 115th Street, near Columbia University. The house contains small suites and occupies a plot 50 by 100 feet, between Broadway and Riverside Drive.

With materials salvaged from various wrecking jobs and with labor furnished by the City Work and Relief Committee, the Brooklyn Park Department proposes to build at Dyker Beach Park a club house that will equal in appointments those of the finest private golf clubs.

Mind is solely a product of electricity, manufactured in the brain by a power system of generation and distribution, consisting of 4,000,000,000,000,000 (four quadrillion) individual dynamos and a distribution system vastly greater than all the lines of communication now in existence.

Thursday, April 20, 1933. An advance in time money, the second in as many business days, featured. All maturities were bid 1 1/2 per cent, but there were no offerings. Previous bid had been 1. Acceptances also hardened, the yield rate being marked up 1/8, all dates, the first advance since March 13, since which time rates had been cut seven times between March 16 and April 11.

A term of four months in the Federal correctional institution at Fort Eustis, Va., and a fine of $15,000 was the sentence imposed on former Deputy City Clerk James J. McCormick yesterday by Federal Judge John C. Knox. McCormick was convicted ten days ago of having failed to file income tax returns for 1929 and 1930, although he received $69,000 during the two years in tips from bridegrooms whose marriages he had performed.

Noble music by Francesco Geminiani in the form of his "Concerto Grosso in G Minor," as edited by Adolfo Betti, opened the final Thursday concert of the Philharmonic-Symphony season, Arturo Toscanini conducting, last night in Carnegie Hall.

GRAND RAPIDS, Mich., April 20 (AP). -- Wesley Ramey, Grand Rapids contender, scored a convincing ten-round victory over Tony Canzoneri, the lightweight boxing champion, in a ten-round non-title bout tonight.
In a contest crammed with weird plays on both sides the Dodgers staged their official opening at Ebbets Field yesterday before 20,000 fans by taking a decisive trouncing from the Phlllies, 10 to 2.

WASHINGTON, April 20. -- The administration's inflation bill was the second to reach the Senate today. A former one was introduced by Senator McAdoo of California, providing for the issuance of $8,000,000,000 in United States notes with Which to retire the short-time indebtedness of the Treasury falling due in the next five years.

The Chrysler Corporation reports for the three months ended on March 31 a consolidated net loss of $3,038,081 after charges, interest and taxes. This compares with a net loss of $2,066,485 in the similar period last year. Sales totaled $33,059,488 in value, against $37,368,443.

WASHINGTON, April 20. -- Chairman Connery announced today that the Labor Committee's hearings on the five-day week bill had been postponed until Tuesday and would begin with testimony by Secretary Frances Perkins.

BERLIN, April 20. -- Adolf Busch, the German violinist, has just resigned his part in the forthcoming Brahms centennial celebration in Hamburg because permission to participate was refused to the pianist, Rudolf Serkin, because of his Jewish origin.

ALBANY, April 20. -- State drys have withdrawn their proposed action in the Supreme Court in this judicial district to restrain the Secretary of State from filing the names of candidates for seats in the State convention to be held here June 27 to pass on repeal.

Owen D. Young, chairman of the board of the General Electric Company, is slated for re-election as chairman of the executive committee and a director of the Radio Corporation of America at the annual meeting here on May 2.

On Wednesday, the day the Untied States officially abandoned the gold standard, the gold holdings of the Federal Reserve System reached the highest total since Sept. 16, 1931, when the record high, of $3,485,739,000 was established. Except for a short period preceding the abandonment of tha gold standard by England, the gold reserves of the Federal Reserve System have never before exceeded the current total of $3,365,595,000.

Formation of a committee to safeguard the interests of shareholders of the Liberty National Bank and Trust Company who exchanged their holdings for stock of the Harriman National Bank and Trust Company was announced yesterday.
Carl Hubbell shut out the Boston Braves, 1 to 0, yesterday to give the Giants a glittering triumph in their first home stand of the season at the Polo Grounds.

An offer to form a private corporation or authority to construct with private capital a $40,000,000 bridge, two miles long, between Old Ferry Point, the Bronx, and Whitestone Landing, Queens, affording a direct connection between the highway system of Long Island and Westchester and points north, will be laid before the Board of Estimate today by Charles V. Bossert, secretary of Louis Bossert Son, Inc., a lumber firm, of 1,301 Grand Street, Brooklyn.

All commodities continued their vigorous upward trend yesterday morning, but in the afternoon profit-taking and other selling wiped out a substantial part of many of the gains and in some cases left actual losses on the day. Silver, however, continued to gain the maximum of 3 cents allowed in each position.

PARIS, April 20. -- French francs remained today the only fixed yardstick in the world for the measurement of money values. The sensational developments in Washington brought dollar quotations down from yesterday's low level of 24.60 to 22.40, with a rally to 22.63 after official trading had closed.

The new situation produced by the United States' departure from the gold standard opens opportunities for world leadership, if properly handled, rarely given to America, Dr. James Harvey Rogers, Professor of Political Economy at Yale, said last night at a dinner of the American Statistical Association at the Hotel Woodstock.

The manner in which a child eats is as important in the study of the child's character as the most detailed account of his heredity and environment, in the opinion of Mrs. Eugenie Lorenburg, child psychologist trained in the Jean Jacques Rousseau School in Geneva.

CHICAGO, April 20. -- The railroads are planning to request a 25 per cent reduction in the basic pay of their union employes on June 15, according to information received here today. With railroad revenues since 1929 steadily moving lower, executives of the roads are said to have decided that there is no other course open to them.

HOLLYWOOD, Cal., April 20 (AP). -- Conrad Nagel, principal figure for the screen artists in their negotiations with motion-picture producers regarding salary reductions, resigned as president of the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences today after a stormy meeting of the board of directors.

ALBANY, April 20. -- Governor Lehman approved today the bill providing for a 1 per cent tax on retail sales, with the exception of motor fuel otherwise taxed, food products for human consumption, gas, steam and water delivered to purchasers through pipes, and sales by municipalities or other political subdivisions of the State.

The famous heath hen of Martha's Vineyard Island, generally accepted by ornithologists as the last of its species on earth, apparently now is dead. This conclusion was announced yesterday through the More Game Birds Foundation of this city, following a report made to it by Professor Alfred O. Gross of Bowdoin College, Brunswick, Me., who has just completed a long investigation at the island in behalf of the Massachusetts Division of Fisheries and Game.

WORCESTER, Mass., April 20. -- Francis Henshaw Dewey, lawyer, banker and corporation official, who in the last forty years had been identified with the industrial and commercial growth of this city, died tonight at his home here. His age was 77.
NEW YORK. Mrs. Robert W. Bingham, wife of the United States Ambassador to England, is at the Plaza from Louisville, Ky.

Bank clearings at the principal cities of the country continue to run substantially below the totals of 1932, according to the weekly compilation by Dun Bradstreet, Inc. For twenty-one cities, including New York, the clearances were $3,301,231,000 in the week ended on Wednesday, a decrease of 30.9 per cent from the corresponding week last year.

LONDON, April 20. -- Following the British Government's order of yesterday for an embargo on 80 per cent of Britain's imports from Russia, effective next Wednesday, the chiefs of the Soviet trade delegation to London have been recalled to Moscow "for consultation," it was learned today.

WASHINGTON, April 20. -- Passing the billion-and-a-half-dollar mark on April 18 for the first time during the current fiscal year, the government's deficit amounted to $1,503,846,688 on that date, as compared with $2,145,146,544 on the corresponding date in 1932, according to figures issued by the Treasury Department today.

LONDON, April 20. -- Civil estimates and the estimates for the revenue departments, including pensions, education, unemployment insurance and other grants for the year ending March 31, 1934, issued tonight, show the total sum required is u391,178,984 compared to u423,117,378 for last year.

Warren J. Hoysradt, vice president of the First Detroit Company, Inc., security affiliate of the Detroit Bankers Company, announced yesterday that the former would be liquidated and that its officers and ranking employes would form a new investment organization about May 1 to be known as the First of Michigan Corporation.

MINEOLA, L.I., April 20. -- Mortimer L. Schiff, financier, philanthropist and head of the national Boy Scout organization, left a net estate valued at the time of his death on June 4, 1931, at $28,718,213, according to a transfer tax appraisal filed here today by David F. Soden, appraiser of the Brooklyn transfer tax office.

WASHINGTON, April 20. -- The resolution ratifying the agreement between the Federal Government and the State of New York under which the New York Power Authority assumes $89,726,000 of the cost of the power works provided in the St. Lawrence waterways treaty, was approved today by the House Committee on Interstate and Foreign Commerce.

Dr. WILLIAM H. PARK was acclaimed at the celebration of the completion of forty years of bacteriological research as the "unchallenged captain" of the campaign against diphtheria in the United States. In the early days of the World War a great scientist was saying that our "awfulest enemies" attack us every minute while we kill one another "as if we were out of our senses."

WASHINGTON, April 20. -- President Roosevelt will begin his discussions of economic questions with foreign representatives in preparation for the World Economic Conference tomorrow afternoon with the arrival of Prime Minister MacDonald of Great Britain, who will be the guest of the President at the White House.
WASHINGTON, April 20. -- The text of the administration's "Controlled Inflation" measure, offered by Senator Thomas of Oklahoma as an amendment to the farm relief bill, follows:

To the Editor of The New York Times: In regard to English speech and poetry in the city public schools, it has been brought to me very vividly during this school year that there is a decided lack of interest somewhere.

BERLIN, April 20 (AP). -- Because war has not been declared between China and Japan, four Chinese Generals who otherwise would have been interned in Russia could address The Associated Press correspondent today with a message to the American people.

WASHINGTON, April 20 (AP). -- At the request of President Roosevelt for speedy enactment of his home-mortgage refinancing measure, committees on both sides of the Capitol began studying the bill today with indications that there would be prompt action.

WASHINGTON, April 20. -- The House late today passed, by 313 to 45, and sent to the Senate the administration's special revenue-postage bill, continuing the one-cent Federal gasoline tax another year, reducing local letter postage to 2 cents and giving the President authority to adjust other postage rates.

Supreme Court Justice Frankenthaler approved yesterday an agreement between the Globe and Rutgers Fire Insurance Company and the Liverpool, London and Globe Insuranca Company, Ltd., by which the latter company reinsures all the Canadian business of the Globe and Rutgers.

A further advance of 0.3 point carried the Annalist Weekly Index of Wholesale Commodity Prices up to 83.6 on Tuesday from 83.3 the week before and 81.7 (revised) on April 4, an advance of 1.9 points in two weeks, and of 3.9 points from the post-war low of 79.7 on Feb. 28.

With the public showing more interest in the stock market than it had in two or three years, Wall Street continued yesterday to enjoy the novelty of a trading volume that overtaxed the Stock Exchange machinery. Professional and amateur speculators competed with each other for stocks of all kinds at steadily rising prices.

The support given to the stock of the Harriman National Bank and Trust Company after the market collapse of 1929 was described by officers of the bank in the Supreme Court here yesterday, in reply to a damage suit brought by Mary Singleton, a depositor, on the ground that this market support constituted "fraud and misrepresentation."

The boom in stocks and commodities which was started Wednesday by the embargo on gold exports received new impetus yesterday from the news that President Roosevelt's controlled inflation program had been drafted.
ALBANY, April 20 (AP). -- Montreal took advantage of six bases on balls and three Albany misplays to win its first game of the International League season today, 10 to 5.

WASHINGTON, April 20. -- A brief of fifty-two exceptions to the proposed report of Examiner Earl M. Steer, who favors abolition of free lighterage in New York Harbor was filed with the Interstate Commerce Commission today by New York City and State, joined by a number of business and commercial organizations of the Manhattan district.

To the Editor of The New York Times: New Yorkers who, like Robert Browning, have "home-thoughts from abroad" -- when he longed to be in England "now that April's there" -- are also doubtless thinking now in many a distant place of aspects of the same month in their city.

E.I. du Pont de Nemours Co. reported yesterday for the first quarter of 1933 a net income of $5,480,515, equivalent, after dividends on the debenture stock, to 35 cents a share on 10,871,977 shares, the average number outstanding in the period.

Citizens of the Dominican Republic living in New York are preparing to celebrate the success of President TRUJILLO'S Administration. Two years and a half ago a hurricane destroyed all but the most substantial buildings of the capital.

The support given to the stock of the Harriman National Bank and Trust Company after the market collapse of 1929 was described by officers of the bank in the Supreme Court here yesterday, in reply to a damage suit brought by Mary Singleton, a depositor, on the ground that this market support constituted "fraud and misrepresentation."

The boom in stocks and commodities which was started Wednesday by the embargo on gold exports received new impetus yesterday from the news that President Roosevelt's controlled inflation program had been drafted.

"Heroic effort" on the part of Catholics is sought by Cardinal Hayes in a pastoral letter to be read tomorrow in all churches of the archdiocese at all masses. The message precedes by one week the opening of the annual appeal of Catholic Charities, to be conducted throughout the 369 parishes here.
WASHINGTON, April 21. -- Sumner Welles of Maryland, who recently took office as Assistant Secretary of State, was nominated today by President Roosevelt to be Ambassador to Cuba.

A superseding indictment against Charles E. Mitchell, former chairman of the National City Bank, was returned yesterday by the Federal grand jury, combining the charges in the two indictments previously returned against Mr. Mitchell.

Men's Wear Demand Heavy. Practically all divisions of the men's wear markets have experienced a heavy demand in the last two days. Clothing manufacturers started to cover their Fall cloth requirements in a good way, but mills checked orders carefully and were reluctant to take contracts far in advance.
WASHINGTON, April 21 -- The War Department issued the following orders today:

Mr. HOOVER'S last official act as President was to give a pocket Veto to the largest appropriation bill voted by Congress during the session which ended on March 4. This was the measure making funds available for the various "Independent" offices in Washington, including the most important single spending agency of the Government -- the veterans' administration.

ABOARD THE S.S. ILE DE FRANCE, Bound for New York, April 21. -- Recovering from the first shock of learning of the United States's embargo on gold, members of the French delegation to President Roosevelt's economic conversations have divided into two camps.

PARIS, April 21. -- The full force of the United States' action in going off the gold standard seems to have struck France just today, judging from the press comment and conversations with banking, bourse and official circles. The French are reacting cautiously and calmly and it is certain no hasty decisions will be made.
NEW YORK. Mrs. Samuel Willets has returned from Warrenton, Va., and is at the Delmonico before going to her Summer home in Old Westbury, L.I.

August Bauer and Joseph Alperin, deputy collectors of internal revenue in the Third New York collection district, were arrested yesterday at the office of the Collector of Internal Revenue at 250 West Fifty-seventh Street and arraigned before United States Commissioner Garrett W. Cotter on the charge that they had conspired to ask and accept a $1,000 bribe to "influence their official actions."

Bonds on the Stock Exchange showed strength, yesterday and ignored the downward trend of the share market. Their upward sweep included virtually all sections of the list except the German issues, many of which were 1 to 2 7/8 points lower.

J. Hampden Jackson's "Europe, Since the War," published today by Duttons, is a book of less than 150 pages covering an immense amount of action. It sketches the highlights of the two Russian revolutions of 1917, of the German revolution in 1918, the peace treaties, the march on Rome, the Spanish revolution, the world crisis and many other important happenings.

John Charles Thomas, the American baritone, will probably become a member of the Metropolitan Opera Company next season, it became known yesterday. Plans have been made for a number of appearances by Mr. Thomas, it was understood, but final arragements will not be made on this or any other contract by the Metropolitan for next season until the $300,000 guarantee fund is raised.

Some of our professors of political economy might find an echo to their own words in the remarks made yesterday by the British economist Sir JOSIAH STAMP. He thinks that the currency and hanking plans of President ROOSEVELT are praiseworthy, but that there is always a danger that they may be pushed too far.

GENEVA, April 21. -- The League of Nations sent out today a notice reconvoking the disarmament conference Tuesday, when it will begin consideration of the first part of the British draft convention, providing for a consultative and nonneutrality agreement.

WASHINGTON, April 21. -- When Prime Minister Ramsay MacDonald and his aides arrived here this evening to discuss international affairs it was with no rancor because of the United States embargo on gold, but rather, with new respect for an adversary in economic and State matters with whom it would be possible to reach an agreement.

BERLIN, April 21. -- Herman A. Metz. former Controller of the City of New York, and Victor Ridder, American publisher, who addressed the American Chamber of Commerce today, left no doubt in the minds of their German and American hearers that the United States disapproves of German anti-Semitism.

To the Editor of The New York Times: As one who Is interested in the foreign policies of the United States, regret to hear of the proposed reciprocity treaties with the several foreign countries. I do not doubt that these treaties will prove of temporary worth but will later show detrimental results.

Old-fashioned lorgnettes, outmoded shirtwaist pins and snake bracelets, with other similar gold articles, are helping to swell the funds of the Adopt-A-Famlly Committee headed by Mrs. August Belmont, it was announced yesterday in a further appeal for gold donations.

The Butterfly Ball, an annual entertainment here and always one of the largest parties of the Spring season, took place last night in the main ballroom of the Ritz-Carlton. As in past years, it was arranged under the auspices of the Junior Auxiliary of the House of Rest at Sprain Ridge, an institution for the treatment of pulmonary tuberculosis.

MOSCOW, Saturday, April 22. -- The Soviet Government retaliated today against the British embargo on Russian imports, to become effective next Wednesday, by ordering the prohibition of any purchases in Great Britain and other restrictive measures.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., April 21. -- Oarsmen of the Naval Academy and Massachusetts Institute of Technology, who engage in four races on the Severn tomorrow afternoon, were pleased today when weather conditions Improved greatly.
WASHINGTON, April 21. -- An attack on the administration's monetary program was launched today by the conservative Republican leadership in Senate and House.

A campaign for 10,000 pledges of $1 a month for a six months' period for relief of the unemployed will be started in Protestant Episcopal parishes throughout Manhattan tomorrow, when the rectors of the various churches will read a communication from the Right Rev. Charles K. Gilbert to their congregations.

Testimony that trading had been permitted in a stock that was worthless, was given yesterday at the resumption, of the public inquiry by State Attorney General John J. Bennett Jr., into the listing practices of the New York Curb Exchange. The hearing was in the State Building, 80 Center Street.

Members of the Park Association of New York City and other friends of the parks declined to comment yesterday on Park Commissioner John E. Sheehy's plan to develop the abandoned site of the lower reservoir into a series of athletic fields and playgrounds, while awaiting further details of the plan.

After the vertical advance in stocks and commodities following the tightening of the gold embargo, a realizing movement developed yesterday in all the markets that had responded to the appeal of promised inflation.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W.Va., April 21. -- A Spring fashion show in a Venetian setting, staged tonight in the indoor pool of the Greenbrier for the benefit of the local branch of the Women's Needlework Guild of America, was attended by a large assemblage of visitors.

Mrs. James Roosevelt, mother of the President, is a patroness of the eighth annual revue to be given for the benefit of the Summer camp maintained by the Protestant Episcopal Church of the Incarnation at Ivoryton, Conn., which will take place next Friday evening in the Mansfield Theatre.

Newark, defeated by 8 to 3 in the opening game of a series with Rochester at Ruppert's Stadium, Newark, yesterday yielded second place in the International League standing to the Red Wings. Jersey City, Baltimore and Albany all began new series on their home diamonds with triumphs.

The approximate status of the municipal bond market is reflected in the following list of representative high-grade State, city and county bonds, legal for savings banks in this State, now offered by dealers:

ROBERT BRIDGES, the late Laureate, recalling PLUTARCH'S story of the Spartan General BRASIDAS, who once caught a mouse foraging in his mess-basket among the figs, "but when it bit him let it go," asks in his famous poem,
CHICAGO, April 21 (AP). -- Irving Hadley held the White Sox to two singles, faced just twenty-nine men and pitched the Browns to a 4-to-0 triumph today.

Except for sugar and coffee, all commodity markets reacted yesterday after two days of heavy gains. Trading continued in great volume, far above the average levels of the past year.Silver lost almost the entire maximum of 3 cents an ounce.
MANILA, April 21. -- General Agulnaldo outlined tonight a proposal for a new bill providing Philippine independence within four or five years.

Serum tests, the last cancer research discovery to aid in determining the presence of certain types of the disease, were described ysterday afternoon by Dr. Frank E. Adair of Memorial Hospital, as being perhaps one of the most important developments of its kind in many years.
CLEVELAND, April 21 (AP). -- Oral Hildebrand's pitching and Bill Cissell's hitting combined to give the Indians a 5-to-0 victory over Detroit today.

To the Editor of The New York Times: According to press reports from Washington, the Reconstruction Finance Corporation is to vote this week on a $75,000,000 loan to the Port of New York Authority for the construction of a midtown vehicular tunnel between New York and New Jersey, the interest rate to be 4 1/2 per cent.

WASHINGTON, April 21. -- The statement by Senators Reed and Walcott and Representatives Snell of New York and Luce of Massachusetts opposing the administration's inflation amendment to the farm relief bill reads as follows:

PHILADELPHIA, April 21 (AP). -- Supported by eight-hit pitching by Merritt (Sugar) Cain, the Philadelphia Athletics today bunched their blows to take Washington into camp for the second time in a row. The score was 3 to 1, the Senators lone score being Buddy Myer's home run.

WASHINGTON, April 21. -- Dr. Hans Luther presented to President Roosevelt today his credentials as German Ambassador, and In so doing declared that his government desired the maintenance of world peace and political and economic cooperation with other countries to overcome the depression.

LEXINGTON, Ky., April 21 (AP). -- The Kentucky Derby stock of J. C. Milan's Captain Red took another jump today when the son of Captain Alcock-Wilton Flanna accounted for his third straight victory of the meeting in the featured Military Stock Farm Purse.

BERLIN, April 21. -- German debts to American creditors are not likely to be redeemed on a gold basis as long as dollar depreciation lasts, it is indicated in a statement understood to have been authorized by the Reichsbank.

BERLIN, April 21. -- German debts to American creditors are not likely to be redeemed on a gold basis as long as dollar depreciation lasts, it is indicated in a statement understood to have been authorized by the Reichsbank.

A court order to show cause why they should not be restrained from awarding, the proposed five-year contract for Brooklyn refuse dis-posal to Samuel R. Rosoff's Man-hattan Ash and Garbage Removal Company was served yesterday on the individual members of the Board of Estimate, Georgev,Mc-Aneny, the new Commissioner of Sanitation, and the City of New York.

WASHINGTON, April 21 (AP). -- A test vote on curtailing basic commodities now specified in the farm relief bill was set in the Senate today when Senator Connally of Texas entered, over objections from Senator Long of Louisiana, a motion to reconsider the 44-37 vote by which sugar cane and sugar beets were written into the measure.

Old stars and new stars of the stage whom the late Florenz Ziegfeld helped to make famous, showgirls from former "Follies" and first-nighters who bad never missed a Ziegfeld premiere in fifteen years, united with hundreds of his nontheatrical friends and admirers yesterday in an unusual tribute to the memory of the producer at Loew's Ziegfeld Theatre.
To the Editor of The New York Times: J.P. Morgan's prompt endorsement of the embargo on gold exports has served well to clinch public approval of the action of President Roosevelt.

The eighth annual military ball of the New York University Reserve Officers Training Corps, the university's most colorful social event, was held last night in the grand ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

ORANGE, N.J., April 21 (AP). -- Orange's brilliant relay quartet of Leonard Spence, Gordon Chalmers, Walter Ashley and Walter Spence tonight clipped one-fifth second off its own international Y.M.C.A. 200-yard relay record in winning the first heat in the Y championships.

WASHINGTON, April 21 (AP). -- Mincing no words, Mrs. Amelia Earhart Putnam today brought a gasp from the assembled Daughters of the American Revolution by criticizing them sharply for agitating for strong armaments while not doing a thing toward having women bear arms in war.

PITTSBURGH, April 21 (AP). -- With a five-run attack in the eighth and a three-hit performance by their moundsmen, Swift and Harris, the Pirates opened their season at home today by defeating the Reds, 5 to 1, before 13,000. The 10-year-old daughter of Honus (Hans) Wagner, greatest shortstop of all time and now a Pirate coach, tossed out the first ball.

WASHINGTON, April 21. -- The Glass banking reform bill seemed suspended in thin air after an executive session today of the Senate banking subcommittee which was attended by Secretary Woodin. Members of the subcommittee gained the impression that the Secretary, if not hostile to the measure, was at least quite lukewarm and that material changes would have to be made to suit him.
ALBANY, April 21. -- Governor Lehman stated today that he would hold hearings next week on twelve bills, including the two minimum wage measures.

Intervention by the city as a party to the Interborough receivership in the Federal courts, with Samuel Untennyer as special counsel, was urged upon the Board of Estimate yesterday by Joseph V. McKee, President of the Board of Aldermen.

The Board of Estimate formally adopted, yesterday the McKee resolution calling for legal action by the city to reduce gas, electricity and telephone rates. At the same time George B. Cortelyou, president of the Consolidated Gas Company of New York, issued a statement pointing out the rate reductions already made by his company and its associates.

President Justice Edgar J. Lauer of the Municipal Court has submitted to Mayor O'Brien and the Appellate Divisions of the First and Second Departments recommendations to improve the efficiency of the Municipal Court, based on three months' study since he has been in charge, it was announced yesterday.

HAVRE DE GRACE, Md., April 21. -- The Wise Counsellor filly, Wise Anne, which races for Mrs. W.C. Weant, today scored in her first local effort following six unsuccessful starts at Hialean Park in Florida. Ridden capably by the veteran Jimmy Smith, Wise Anne won the featured Adorable Purse by two lengths at $13.20 for $2.

Approximately 6,000 applications for the sixty jobs created along with the State Liquor Control Board have been received to date and more are coming in, it was revealed yesterday by Edward P. Mulrooney, chairman of the board, when he took possession of the board's quarters in the State Office Building, 80 Centre Street.

The Socony-Vacuum Corporation reports for 1932 a consolidated net income of $5,320,282 after all charges and reserves, including profit applicable to minority interests. The total is equal to about 17 cents a share on the 31,708,469 capital shares of $25 par value each.

WASHINGTON, April 21. -- Should the pending farm relief bill be enacted by Congress containing the Thomas amendment, President Roosevelt will proceed cautiously in using the fiscal powers invested in him by the measure, it was stated today in authoritative circles.

WASHINGTON, April 21. -- Assured of a strict rule that will prohibit all except committee amendments and limit debate to six hours, House leaders took steps today to call up tomorrow the Muscle Shoals bill, principal feature in the administration plan for development of the Tennessee River Valley.

Pointing out that 75,000,000 barrels of crude oil were produced in excess of the allowables in the fifteen months ended on March 15, R.C. Holmes, president of the Texas Corporation, said yesterday that the time has come when the oil industry must put a stop to ''this tonn of racketeering," which is destroying values and retarding economic recovery.

WASHINGTON, April 21. -- President Roosevelt and Premier Ramsay MacDonald of Great Britain began their series of conferences on world affairs tonight with the nation's capital and Congress in the heat of the battle to banish not only domestic depression but set the pace for international recovery of good times.
Sabers at Heidelberg One item in the Hitler program for reflating the national German spirit is the return of student duels. The famous Mensur was prohibited by the republican regime.
Purchase of a Glen Ridge residence and a Hoboken flat featured the New Jersey realty trading reported yesterday.
The glee clubs of Columbia University and the Riverdale Country School will give a joint concert tonight at the Riverdale School, Riverdale-on-Hudson.

Walter Friedman, sports promoter and associate of William J. (Big Bill) Duffy, former proprietor of Duffy's Tavern, was arrested yesterday as he left the Berengaria, on which he returned from France. He was taken before Federal Judge John M. Woolsey and pleaded not guilty to the indictment charging that he had aided Duffy in evading the latter's income tax.

Five shows are completing runs of various lengths after their performances tonight. The longest tenant of the group is "Dangerous Corner," at the Fulton, which began on Oct. 27. "Melody," at the Casino, is closing after a run that started Feb. 14. The others are "The 3-Penny Opera," which has been at the Empire for a week and a half; "Strange Gods," which opened a week ago at the Ritz, and "Unto the Third."

Two plans for the development of Marine Park in Brooklyn, both prepared by Charles Downing Lay, landscape architect, were submitted yesterday to the Board of Estimate by Park Commissioner James J. Browne. One plan, for which approval is asked, is understood to provide for a 1,400-acre recreation centre to cost $27,000,000 at last Fall's prices.
Thomas Stearns Eliot, modern metaphysicist, critic and poet, discussed book clubs, radios and college undergraduates in an interview yesterday.

Wall Street was not surprised that reaction overtook the markets yesterday. Considering the speed of the advance of the previous two days, profit-taking was bound to appear, brokers figured. If there was any element of surprise, it was in the circumstance that the volume did not show a greater contraction on the decline.

BOSTON, April 21. -- Utterly ignoring the fact that Boston was striving to enjoy a baseball holiday, the Yankees trampled on the Red Sox as an unsolicited number on the program that inaugurated the American League season here today.
Plaintiffs bought in nine properties in Manhattan and the Bronx at auction sales yesterday. The results are:

After rising for three consecutive days, stocks and commodities encountered heavy profit-taking yesterday, and closed irregularly lower. The decline was ascribed to the advance of the dollar in terms of European currencies, and to the possibility of delay in the passage of President Roosevelt's controlled inflation program.

PURNEA, India, April 21. -- The weather report on the morning of the day we made the flight was fairly favorable as regards visibility. The amount of cloud forecast was very good, but continued high wind was predicted.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., April 21. -- The United States Davis Cup team today received an unexpected setback from the boys who were left off the squad when Clifford Sutter, picked to play the singles against Mexico, and George Lott and John Van Ryn, the doubles combination, were eliminated in the semi-final round play of the Mason and Dixon tennis championships.

Definite plans whereby New York City will receive an extension not only of its $144,000,000 of short-term obligations due on next Wednesday but also of the $16,000,000 of similar obligations due on May 16, in so far as they are held by clearing house and other banks of the city, are being formulated.

Mgr. Amleto Giovanni Cicognani of Rome, who is scheduled to be consecrated today as an Archbishop, will arrive in New York on May 23 to take up his duties as the sixth Apostolic delegate at Washington, succeeding the Most Rev. Pietro Fumasoni-Biondi, who recently was recalled by Pope Pius XI and created a Cardinal.

CONCORD, N.C., April 21 (AP). -- An agreement whereby the infant son of Libby Holman Reynolds and his half-sister, Anne Cannon Reynolds 2d, would each receive $2,000,000 of the estate of Smith Reynolds, their father, was disclosed here today.

The calendar of new Issues of municipal bonds up for award next week totals $9,732,167, compared with $16,244,689 this week and with a weekly average of $10,715,187 for the year thus far. Of this week's total only $720,000 actually was offered to investors, and these issues were sold early in the week.

Retail trade made a good showing during the week, with the usual post-Easter reaction being much less of a factor than is normally the case, according to the weekly review of Dun Bradstreet, Inc. Prospective inflation was reported as exerting some influence already on consumer purchasing.

LONDON, April 21. -- President Roosevelt's abandoning of the gold standard, despite being in possession of nearly half the world's monetary stock and having a favorable trade balance, was less favorably received here after mature consideration.
Manager Bill Terry called on his reserves yesterday at the Polo Grounds in an attempt to capture the second game of the home season from the Boston Braves. But his plans went astray.

WASHINGTON, April 21. -- Organized labor's answer to inflation was a declaration today that it would move at once to fight for wage increases in order to offset the expected increase in commodity prices.

BERLIN, April 21. -- Today's stock market opened with a bullish mood that was maintained during the early hours and lifted a large number of issues to substantially higher levels. Most in demand were the key industrials, among which I.G. Farbenindustries and Siemens Halske rose 6 points each and Harpener 10 points.

AKRON, Ohio, April 21. -- The Macon, sister of the ill-fated Akron; made her maiden flight today and the big ship's performance was praised by naval officials and others on board. She was in the air more than twelve hours, much of which time was spent over Lake Erie.

After a series of bitter sessions of stockholders covering three days, the management of the Phoenix Securities Corporation was finally returned yesterday the victor in a battle of proxies. The contest for votes had been in progress several months.

Just what was Mayor O'BRIEN doing up in the Bronx the other night? Was he bravely invading the enemy's territory, or bidding the prodigal come home to receive his father's blessing? "If you want more bridges, parks, tunnels, the Mayor is with you from the drop of the hat and you can count on him."

MINEOLA, April 21. -- The tangled financial situation of the city of Long Beach resulted in a grand jury investigation here today into the failure of the city to pay to the county of Nassau taxes amounting to more than $500,000, extending over a period of three years.

WASHINGTON, April 21. -- As foreign diplomats diminished today the stream of cables they have been sending to their governments trying to interpret the American gold embargo and inflation proposals, many of them felt better about the situation, in which they began to discern advantages, either for their own countries or for the economic conference.

WASHINGTON, April 21. -- The Wagner-Lewis bill, providing $500,000,000 for the relief of unemployment, was passed by the House latet his afternoon. The vote, which was 331 to 42, followed a three-hour battle and unsuccessful battle by the Republicans to amend the bill by providing that the money be lent to the States instead of being allocated in the form of gifts.

Terms under which the tobacco monopoly of Spain is in the market for approximately 15,000,000 pounds of Kentucky tobacco, at a price to be fixed by competitive bidding, were received yesterday at the offices of the Spanish Consulate General, 1,071 Sixth Avenue.

Buffalo, N.Y. Negotiations entered into yesterday by officials of the city of Buffalo with a banking group here for disposal of the city's issue of $4,000,000 of relief bonds due on May 1, 1943, which were not sold when offered formally on Thursday, did not result in a sale.

Prices on the Cotton Exchange were influenced yesterday by a somewhat reactionary tendency in other markets and a rise in dollar quotations in foreign exchange, but a setback of 30 points attracted liberal buying and the list closed unchanged to 5 points higher than on Thursday.

Frightened by the two court decisions against them and apparently weakening in their attitude toward medical advice, the parents of 2-year-old Helen Vasko yesterday afternoon, took the child to Columbia Presbyterian Medical Centre for an examination of the eye upon which physicians declare an operation must be performed.

BUFFALO, N.Y., April 21. (AP). -- Miss Lenore Kight of Homestead Pa., tonight won the national 220-yard free-style swimming championship by defeating Miss Eleanor Bridges of Whitinsville, Mass., and Miss Susan Robertson of New York in the final of the Women's National Senior A.A.U. title race at that distance.

Friday, April 21, 1933. An easier time money market after several days of hardening prices, and irregularity in the bill market so far as rates were concerned, represented the interesting developments of the day's money market.

The entire estate of Walter Brooks, director and former treasurer of Brooks Brothers, one of New York's leading clothing houses for more than a century, who died on March 26, will go to charity upon the death of his daughter, Edith Allen Brooks Nutting of London, England, who will hold it in trust for life, it was disclosed in Surrogates' Court yesterday when his testament wag offered for probate.

The Southern Pacific Company drew $13,907,004 in dividends from the surplus of the Pacific Fruit Express Company in 1932, the road's complete report for that period discloses. This was $3,827,447 more than was obtained from this source in 1931.

When Ponce de Leon set out in search for the fountain of youth he and his followers had already found it, by the mere resolve to seek it, the fourth annual conference on interpretations of physical education was told in substance last night by Dr. Jay B. Nash, Professor of Education at New York University, where the conference is holding a three-day session, ending today.

The Chicago Eastern Illinois Railroad, which has applied for a trustee under the bankruptcy law, borrowed $2,040,590 from the Railroad Credit Corporation in 1932, according to the road's annual report. The loan, which bore intertest of 2 1/2 per cent on Dec. 31, was devoted to the payment of interest on bonds and equipment trust certificates.

City College's lacrosse team defeated New York University, 2 to 1, in a hard-fought battle at Ohio Field yesterday. It was the Lavender's initial triumph in four games and N.Y.U.'s third straight defeat this season.
