LONDON, April 21. -- The news that the Soviet Government had taken a retaliatory step and terminated trade with Great Britain reached London over the radio during an address made under the auspices of the Central Council of Moscow Trade Unions.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In the very commendable attempt of various organizations to provide labor for the large army of the unemployed, there seems to be a big division of that army left outside the pale. I refer to the men ranging in age from 50 to 60 years.
WASHINGTON. April 21. -- Movements of vessels follow, all dates are April 21, unless otherwise specified:

MINEOLA, L.I., April 21. -- A receiver in supplementary proceedings has been appointed to conserve the assets of John Barry Ryan, son of the late Thomas Fortune Ryan, to satisfy a judgment of $37,353.46 obtained by Victor Emanuel, a broker, it became known today.

Interest in fishing, both of the salt water and fresh water variety, has increased tremendously in the past few days, despite the fact that the weather has not been propitious. Now the rewards are at hand.

LONDON, April 21. -- The excitement in the foreign market continued unabated today, but attention was considerably diverted from the dollar to the franc. Dollars opened steadier around yesterday's closing price, but after erratic movements the rate rose to 3.91 1/2 and subsequently rallied to close at 3.85.

Descriptions of the unofficial flight around the top of Mount Everest on Wednesday, written by two of the chief participants in it, are given below. They supplement the accounts printed yesterday telling how the feat was accomplished.

The dollar rallied strongly in the foreign exchange market yesterday on indications from abroad that the gold standard countries of Europe might soon take steps to meet the depreciation of United States currency by themselves declaring embargoes upon gold.

BERLIN, April 21. -- Herman A. Metz and Victor Ridder of New York, who since their arrival here have lost no opportunity to inform officialdom privately how public opinion in the United States reacted to National Socialist performances, expressed today in public some of the things they have been saying in private.

WASHINGTON, April 21. -- At the time of President Roosevelt's gold embargo order the United States stood to lose about $600,000,000 from its gold reserves, and that amount of foreign short-term capital remains "tied up" here as a result.

President Roosevelt on March 4 forbade the shipment of gold abroad, told bankers they could no longer exchange gold for paper money, called upon hoarders of gold to shake out their mattresses or suffer the consequences. On that day the United States left the gold standard.

A near-riot in which a crowd estimated at 1,000 Negroes jeered and hooted at the police and threw bottles and other missiles without, however, injuring any one, developed in West Fifty-ninth Street between Columbus Circle and Ninth Avenue about 6 o'clock last night after a pistol battle in which a Negro narcotic peddler was killed and a Federal agent was slightly wounded.

WASHINGTON, April 21. -- Although Lewis W. Douglas, Director of the Budget, confronted by the resentment of civil service employes, issued a statement today declaring that it was not contemplated in the proposed extensions of powers to President Roosevelt.

For the fourth time in his tempestuous political career Prime Minister J. Ramsay MacDonald of Great Britain arrived in the United States yesterday. This is regarded as the most important mission on which he ever came to this country.

CHICAGO, April 21. -- Jerome Factor, kidnapped son of John (Jake the Barber) Factor, was released early this morning after having been held for $100,000 ransom for eight days. He was unharmed. His father, internationally known speculator, declares he paid no ransom.

PHILADELPHIA, April 21. -- Evidence that agricultural pursuits were followed by the Natufians, long-headed and somewhat stooped individuals, in Palestine and the Near East 20,000 years ago, was laid before the American Philosophical Society today by Dr. George Grant MacCurdy of Yale University, Director of the American School of Prehistoric Research.

To the Editor of The New York Times: A letter from Louis Salbitano on the study of languages in THE TIMES aroused considerable comment among a group of undergraduates and instructors at Middlebury College. The writer held that Italian and French should be placed before German and Spanish in importance among high school language students.

Fire flashed in the keen hunter's eyes of Count Vasco da Gama yesterday as he recounted in his office at 52 William Street how he slew Lord von Dick a week ago Wednesday in the main lobby of 395 Riverside Drive.

Discussion of currency inflation gives special interest to the Government's latest report on the range of wholesale prices, published Wednesday. Prepared by the Bureau of Labor Statistics, it measures monthly changes in the value of 784 commodities.

ROME, April 21. --The 2,686th birthday of Rome, which was solemnly celebrated throughout Italy today, was made the occasion for a startling affirmation of the existence of an international fascism and the solidarity existing between Fascist movements in various countries of the world.

A suit to break the will of Miss Helen Herriman, descendant of an old Brooklyn family, who left an estate of $4,000,000, went to a jury before Surrogate Wingate in Brookelyn yesterday afternoon. After four hours the jury was Instructed to return a sealed verdict which will be opened this morning.

CHICAGO, April 21. -- The wheat market felt today the effect of the tremendous profit-taking sales of futures by local traders and outside longs. In addition to the weakened technical position caused by the sharp advance this week there was less encouraging news for the bulls in, the way of beneficial rains over a large part of Oklahoma, Kansas and Nebraska, with easier stocks, a break in sterling and a rapid recession in silver futures.

To the Editor of The New YorK Times: It is unfortunate that so much publicity has been given to the subject of the alcoholic content of beer, creating doubt on the part of the public that they are getting the right "stuff" and developing an "alcoholic consciousness" that temperance workers are trying to make people forget.

WASHINGTON, April 21. -- The Federal Reserve Banks will cooperate wholeheartedly with the administration in an effort to stimulate business activity through large-scale open market operations if legislation to have them purchase up to $3,000,000,000 of government securities is adopted, according to information obtained today in an authoritive quarter.
DIZZY DEAN, who was going to win fifty games (or less) for the Cardinals this season, started out in reverse. He has been in two games and lost the decision each time.

The Gold Room of Sherry'g became a Bavarian bier stube last night for the Happy Days supper-dance given there in the interests of the scholarship fund of the Floating University, an educational project now in formation. The fund will provide free tuition for deserving students on the university cruise which is expected to begin in October.

The new vestry of St. Mark's-in-the-Bouwerie, elected last Tuesday, met last night and will meet again on Tuesday at 5:30 P.M. to consider denouncing the presentment which the old vestry, as the final act of its incumbency, lodged with Bishop Manning, giving asserted reasons why the rector, the Rev. Dr. William Norman Guthrie, should be removed.

MIDDLETOWN, N. Y., April 21. -- Giving evidence of her thorough training, the pointer, Lingfield Venture, won a double victory for Captain and Mrs. Frank H. Dayton, of Middletown as the second annual Spring field trials of the Sport and Conservation League got underway today.

OTTAWA, April 21 (Canadian Press). -- Canada remains on the gold standard to the same extent as at any time since September, 1931, it was stated at the Department of Finance today. Reports from many Quarters that the Dominion had definitely abandoned the gold standard kept department officials busy answering queries.
WASHINGTON, April 21. -- The Bureau of Navigation issued the following orders today, dated April 19:

WASHINGTON, April 21. -- Miss Ishbel MacDonald, a bit thinner and younger in appearance, despite a few threads of gray in her chestnut hair, than on her previous visit more than three years ago, received a warm welcome today on her return to the capital.

WASHINGTON, April 21 (AP) -- A Congressional investigation of reported revolutionary plotting against the Cuban government was proposed today in the House by Representative Shoemaker, Farmer-Labor member from Minnesota.

The Giants played a lot of bad baseball yesterday at the Polo Grounds before a crowd of about 7,500 disappointed fans. Weak pitching, shabby fielding and feeble hitting were provided in large measure in a game which, the Boston Braves took from Bill Terry's lads by a count of 7 to 3 as their farewell gesture to the Giants. The result Rave the Braves the honors of the series by two games to one.

Delegates to the conference on interpretations of physical education yesterday at New York. University were told that instructors had become "pretty gullible" in their acceptance of health fads and half truths, and that a need existed for a change in teaching methods based on scientifically accurate facts concerning health habits.

MALINDA JENKINS had the come-hither eye. It brought men around her eager to marry her in her youth, her middle life and her old age. But her discrimination was not equal to her power to attract, and each one of her three husbands seems to have been a rather bad lot.

MARS as a subject of controversy will never die. Is it alive or is it dead? Thanks to the work of such physicists as Dr. Coblentz, the case for life on that planet is better than it ever was. Oxygen and water vapor have been discovered in the Martian atmosphere -- both essentials in the maintenance of life.

WASHINGTON. WHAT has Gamer been doing? This question Is often asked about the ruddy Texan who was elevated a little more than a month ago from the Speakership of the House to the Vice Presidency of the United States.

Stricken ill on Friday evening several hours after having eaten some canned corned beef issued at Depot 11 of the Emergency Relief Committee in exchange for a Salvation Army food ticket, Samuel Gourley, 3 years old, died yesterday afternoon of ptomaine poisoning, according to the police, in his home at 439 West Fifty-second Street.

DRUID HILL, with its many wooded acres on the crests of the Watchung Mountains, embraces the highest land within the city of Summit, N.J. The Union County Park reservation of more than 1,000 acres, with its many bridle paths, adjoins Druid Hill on its entire southerly side for nearly a mile.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 22 -- Bryan Saulpaugh, automobile racer, was killed today when his car got out of control at more than 100 miles an hour during a practice run on the Oakland Speedway. Rocketing to the top of the bowl at the south turn, the automobile crashed a guard rail and somersaulted down the steep sides of the bowl to the apron, turning over three times in the air.

The alleged failure of retailers to extend to consumers the benefits of a recent reduction in railway tariffs on anthracite was said yesterday to be delaying what the railroad managements had planned to be a general cut in rates for this fuel. A committee of heads of anthracite carriers is endeavoring to clear the situation.

BALTIMORE, Md., April 22 -- Brilliantly ridden by Jack Skinner, Grub Stake, carrying the emerald green and gray colors of Mrs. Raymond Belmont of New York, thundered home first today over a muddy course at Brooklandwood to win the thirty-fourth running of the Grand National Point-to-Point.

Although fencing is gaining in favor as a sport in most of the women's colleges, the fact that a number do not take part in intercollegiate activities places limitations on the entry list for the championship.

PHILADELPHIA, April 22 -- John L. Jackson of Penn outpitched Johnny Broaca, Yale's star right-hander, as the Red and Blue beat the Elis in an Eastern Intercollegiate League game on Franklin Field today, 3 to 1. This was Penn's first league victory in four starts and Yale's second defeat in three games.

To the Editor of The New York Times: There is much talk of currency inflation to bring prices and wages to a level facilitating payment of debts. Why not adjust the debts directly, discerningly and individually?

BERLIN, April 22 -- The stock market here opened weaker and unsettled today, quotations sagging under realizing sales by room traders. Later in the day there was a rally, but no public support of any magnitude developed and stocks fluctuated toward a markedly irregular closing, some issues maintaining yesterday's levels while others closed above or below them, with the changes ranging from a fraction of a point to 4 points or more.

BOSTON, April 22 (AP) -- A discussion of the government's plan for selling through local houses the wool held by Federal agencies revealed today that it would be disposed of on a twelve-month firmprice market. While a holder of the controlled wool could sell it in a scoured condition, it could not be sold in the form of tops.

Plans are rapidly maturing for a balloon ascent into the stratosphere, supervised by Professor Auguste Piccard, whose ascent over Switzerland of more than ten miles set a record for man's penetration of the upper air. The new ascent will be made at the Century of Progress Exposition in Chicago.

Thirteen dogs of varying pedigree that have exhibited unusual intelligence and courage received the medal of the Legion of Hero Dogs at ceremonies conducted yesterday afternoon in the John Wanamaker auditorium by Mrs. Diana Belais, founder and president of the New York Anti-Vivisection Society.

WASHINGTON, April 22 -- Some form of controlled currency inflation to arrest the fall of commodity prices and restore the economic equilibrium of the United States, if not the entire world, appears to be virtually certain of approval by the Senate.

The dollar fell heavily again yesterday in the foreign exchange market. The previous day's rally, based on expectations that France and other European gold standard currencies would be forced to depreciate their exchanges, was flattened out early yesterday when the French Finance Minister declared that his country would adhere to gold.

A review in front of City Hall, fluttering ticker tape tangled in the gold braid of uniforms in the march down lower Broadway and the solemn bugle notes of "taps" at a memorial service in the Chapel of St. Cornelius the Centurion on Governors Island marked yesterday afternoon the celebration by the Old Guard of New York City of its 107th anniversary.

Mr. OWEN YOUNG had one or two long conferences with Mr. ROOSEVELT after the Presidential election. It is possible that he suggested to the President-elect some of the ideas which he had expressed in speaking to the graduating class of Notre Dame University last June.

The American Society of International Law will discuss problems of world jurisprudence at its twenty-seventh annual meeting, to be held at the Willard Hotel in Washington on Thursday, Friday and Saturday, according to an announcement here yesterday by Dr. James Brown Scott, president of the society and director of the Division of International Law of the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace.

WILKES-BARRE, Pa., April 22 -- More than 2,500 persons witnessed the closing polo matches of the indoor season tonight. Princeton University was defeated by the 109th Field Artillery trio of Wilkes-Barre, 14 1/2 to 11 1/2. Cornell University beat the 110th Field Artillery of Baltimore, 24 to 4 1/2.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., April 22 -- Both the varsity and junior varsity rugby teams of Princeton triumphed over their Harvard rivals on Soldiers' Field today, the Nassau varsity winning, 6 to 5, and the jayvees, 6 to 0.

Ferdinand Pecora, counsel to the United States Senate Committee on Banking and Finance in its investigation of stock market activities, declared yesterday, in a statement on the completion of the analysis of the evidence obtained at private hearing's relating to private banking practices, that public hearings would be held and that he would proceed with the presentation of evidence.

BERLIN, April 22 -- The transfer of the functions of the Prussian Premiership from Vice Chancellor Franz von Papen to Captain Hermann Wilhelm Goering aroused speculation in political circles today about the possibility of the Vice Chancellor's becoming Foreign Minister.

CHESTERTON, P.G. Wodehouse, Sinclair Lewis. Gilbert and Sullivan, Conrad, Gertrude Atherton, Noel Coward and E.F. Benson are some of the twenty-nine people Cosmo Hamilton found worth talking about over the radio. Now, "by desire." he has collected his fifteen -minute talks to make this book.

Columbia defeated Cornell in both games of a double-header yesterday at Baker Field before 1,000 spectators and became more firmly entrenched at the top of the Eastern Intercollegiate Baseball League.

LONDON, April 16 -- In the fourteen years since the "World War, 1,800,000 men, women and children have been injured or killed on the roads of Great Britain, or 7O per cent of the total British war casualties. In the three years 1929-31 the killed alone exceeded the number of British soldiers killed in the twenty-two years of the Napoleonic wars.

WASHINGTON, April 22 -- A poetic statistician has estimated that, after forty-nine and one-half days in office, Franklin D. Roosevelt possesses, is seeking and has been offered more absolute power than the sum of the arbitrary authority exercised at various times in history by Generals Washington, Lee, Grant and Sherman, Presidents Jackson, Lincoln and Wilson, and all the Emperors of the Ming dynasty.

HEMPSTEAD, L.I., April 22 -- Flashing Through, a dapple grey gelding, owned and shown by Miss Jeanne Nehrbas of Garden City, L. I., annexed two important saddle classes in the Middle Island Indoor Horse Show at the Southern State Indoor Arena tonight.

WASHINGTON. THE office of Postmaster General Farley has been flooded, since the beginning of the new administration, with applications for appointment as local postmaster. There are 47,872 cities, towns and villages in the United States, Hawaii, Alaska and Puerto Rico in which the government maintains postoffices.

Today is known as Low Sunday, it being the first Sunday after Easter. In almost all the churches the Easter program of music will be repeated. Several of the largest churches in the heart of Manhattan will have oratorios this afternoon or evening by their choirs.

LAND of mystery, shrouded in snow and guarded by the lofty wall of the Himalayas. Tibet has long been a challenge to the imagination. But, unlike most mysteries, it loses none of its strangeness on becoming, in a sense, better known.

THE monumental nature of Mr. Shanks's latest work easily explains why he has not produced a novel for so many years. Now that the great work has finally appeared, it proves to be one of those long, rambling, intimate volumes which Bnglish novelists delight to produce nowadays, but which one would perhaps not have expected from a writer who handles the short story with such effective and sparing precision as does Mr. Shanks.

Unification of terminal operations within the port, urged for several years by the Port of New York Authority as a means of improving service and reducing the cost to the railroads, is again urged in a statement to the Interstate Commerce Commission, by counsel for New York State and allied groups in the New Jersey lighterage case.

BOSTON, April 20 -- The jnost interesting speculation respecting any public man in New England pertains to the future of James M. Curley, Mayor of Boston. His refusal of the post of Ambassador to Poland is still a topic of general conversation.

PITTSBURGH, April 22 (AP). -- Cracking out a whistling liner in the tenth with the bases full, Tony Piet gave the Pirates a 6-to-5 victory over the Cincinnati Reds today before 5,000 fans, huddled in the cold, wind-swept stands.

One of the unusual philanthropic entertainments planned for the near future is a Spring festival to be held in the ballroom of the Roosevelt next Saturday afternoon for the benefit of the children's Cardiac Clinic of the New York Post-Graduate Hospital.

WHAT woman has not longed at some time to be a Cleopatra; to look like Botticelli's Goddess of Spring; to have some one tell her that she is as beautiful as Helen of Troy? There is not one who would not like, for a brief space, to be some one else, or at least to alter her appearance so that she could play another role.

MRS. HERBERT once more champions the downtrodden male. In "The House of Wives" she portrayed the patient American paterfamilias, the not unwilling prey of his grasping women-folk, and in this novel she presents the case of another bewildered young family man.

THE Philharmonic - Symphony Orchestra, closes its season this afternoon with the final all-Beethoven program. Included in the program is the "King Stephen" overture; piano concerto No. 5, in E flat major, with Vladimir Horowitz as soloist; symphony No. 8 in F major, and the "Leonore" overture No. 3.

More than 500 nursery school, kindergarten and first-grade teachers in elementary schools throughout the country attended a conference, held yesterday at Teachers College, Columbia University, to discuss the educational status of the 4 and 5-year-old child.

NEWARK, April 22 -- Jim Weaver pitched the Newark Bears back into winning form today with a 5 to 2 victory over the Rochester Red Wings to even the current series. Weaver allowed only six hits and retired the side in order four times.

George Washington High School's baseball team blanked St. Francis Prep, 1 to 0, at the Washington Stadium in one of yesterday's school games. The rival pitchers, Joseph Pascal and Roy Klennert, each allowed three hits. In the fourth Joseph Bowerbank singled, stole second and scored on Stewart's single.

Inflationary prospects again had first place in Wall Street's calculations yesterday. Other influences were at work, to the advantage of the share market, but the bidding-up of prices was the result mainly of the widely prevalent belief that large-scale expansion of credit, if not of currency, is soon to be brought about.

ONCE more The Colophon appears and once more the prose contributors try by all the wiles of wit and scholarship to seem at home in the resplendent setting to which the editors in their infinite wisdom have seen fit to call them.
MUNICH, April 22 -- Chancellor Hitler arrived by plane from Berlin this evening for a significant conference with National Socialist district leaders from all sections of Germany.

An additional trophy for early season racing, known as the Compton Cup, is to be added to intercollegiate rowing when the crews of Harvard, Princeton and Massachusetts Institute of Technology meet Saturday on the Charles River at Cambridge in a triangular regatta.

IN his introduction to this little volume of ex-President Hoover's informal speeches, including eight delivered before the Gridiron Club and not previously reported, Mr. Joslin opines that the fact "that Herbert Hoover has a gift of humor -- a vein of whimsicality known to all of his associates -- would come as news to most people."

LONDON. GREAT BRITAIN is having its portrait painted for the first time in its life. From the Channel to the Orkneys, the whole island is being faithfully reproduced in all its gay and vivid checkerboard of green woodland, brown plowland, yellow hearth, purple garden and orchard, brickred town and pale green meadow.

Making capital of its scoring opportunities and playing a fine defensive game, the Fordham University baseball team shut out Lafayette, 4 to 0, at Fordham Field yesterday. The Maroon gained a one-run lead in the opening frame, added a pair in the fifth and one more in the sixth.

Art is apparently having a large awakening in Weatchester under the combined influence of hard times and the County Recreation Commission. Painting, sculpture, music and the crafts showed a relatively huge gain in following last year, according to the report of the superintendent of the commission, George Hjelte, made public today.

A request by the city that 1,600 civil service employes of the Sanitation Commission, who are employed irregularly, be placed on the relief payroll has been denied by the Emergency Work and Home Relief Administration, it was learned yesterday.

LONDON. April 12, 1933 LONDON orchestras have been making their last bow and the Winter season is coming to an end. Two significant announcements (which have just been made) reveal the measure of success -- or otherwise -- which rewarded their recent labors.

ALTHOUGH two English studios have offered Universal to keep Boris Karloff busy in Blighty until the late Summer, Carl Laemmle Jr. has cabled Mr. Karloff to return to Hollywood as soon as he finishes "The Ghoul," now being filmed in London by British-Gaumont.

The Metropolitan Opera House will be the scene of New York's first opera ball on Friday night, when one of the most brilliant entertainments ever arranged here will be given for the fund being raised for the continuation, of the Metropolitan Opera Association's season nest Winter.

WASHINGTON, April 22 -- Prime Minister MacDonald and President Roosevelt today turned over to economic and diplomatics experts of their respective governments the task of finding an actual basis for arranging international action to end the world-wide depression.

A HUT on a desert island is a more notable structure than a skyscraper in a city. And on the desert island that lies in the midst of the human whirlpool of Times Square any sort of shack invites the passing curiosity of tens of thousands.

ELIZABETH, April 22 -- A balance sheet as of March 31, on the strength of which the alcohol plant at Elmira, N.Y., was raided, was made public today. It was found in a safe in the hotel where Max Hassel and Max Greenberg were slain last night.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., April 22 -- Frank Shields, lanky New Yorker who yesterday played a prominent role in the downfall of three members of the Davis Cup team, today swept aside the remaining opposition in the Mason and Dixon tennis championships, winning the singles title and pairing with Lester Stoefen of Los Angeles to capture the doubles crown.

Buying contracts and options held on supplies of raw materials will protect the average large industrial company in event of sharp rises in materials prices over the coming few months, George A. Renard, secretary-treasurer of the National Association of Purchasing Agents, said here yesterday.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Recently you had an article in your paper about the pay professional men were receiving on account of the depressed times. I recently figured in the following barter for medical services:

Hitler's General Record. An excellent way for the Hitler Government to combat foreign slanders is to spend less time on denying that it has done wicked things and spend a little more on showing that it has done worth-while things.

KATHARINE CORNELL will not be using the Belasco Theatre when Fall and a new season rush forward to greet Manhattan. Just what she will do is not known to this wistful column; sufficient be it that she is giving up the home that has been hers for the last two years.

BOSTON, April 21.-The moves for inflation have resulted in an atmosphere of considerable confusion in this centre in respect to prices of a number of important commodities. Fine wools are 3 to 5 cents a pound higher than they were a week ago on the asked side.

Prices of bonds on the Stock Exchange were pushed generally higher in the two-hour trading period yesterday in the heaviest dealings for a Saturday since Jan. 9, 1932. The turnover was $9,526,000. United States Government bonds continued their price recoveries; railroad bonds led the advance in domestic corporation issues, and German loans, in the foreign group.

WASHINGTON, April 22 -- Mayor O'Brien of New York City, in a telegram to Senators Wagner and Copeland today, asked that prospective Federal relief grants to States be made on the basis of one-half the sum expended by States and their subdivisions rather than one-third.

WHEN Colin Trent brings his bride to Ruffa, a tiny island off the coast of Scotland, he expects to spend a quiet honeymoon at Wester Voe, the house which has been lent to him by a friend. Had he so much as suspected the true state of affairs on the island or dreamed of the exciting adventures that awaited them there, he would never have set foot on Ruffa.

MUNICH, April 22 -- As the only member of the press yet allowed to do so, a NEW YORK TIMES correspondent has visited the huge Nazi internment camp at Dachau, near Munich, where 5,000 political prisoners will eventually be detained.

WOULD I ever know the oldtime happiness again?" wonders Gabriel Parker, the central figure of the scenes from the economic and social mad-house of the years of the "boom era" which make up this book. Mr. Bacheller engineers a mechanical "happy ending" for his story, but he seems really unhappy about it.

MR. CHURCHWARD is an authority, the only authority there is, on the Lost Continent of Mu. It is, in fact, his continent, by all the rights there are of discovery, invention, evidence, conviction of reality that deal with intangible things.

ABOARD THE S.S. ILE DE FRANCE, Bound for New York, April 22 -- Former Premier Herriot, who will arrive in the United States tomorrow, emphasized to me today for THE NEW YORK TIMES that he would do his utmost to cooperate with President Roosevelt's efforts to improve American conditions.

With workmen already carrying forward the plans of John E. Sheehy, newly appointed Park Commissioner, to convert the thirty-two-acre site of the abandoned lower reservoir in Central Park into a series of athletic fields and playgrounds, members of the Municipal Art Society were advised at a luncheon yesterday that they might be asked to present united opposition to the plan.

The greetings of several foreign governments were extended yesterday to the delegates of the Federation of Huguenot Societies in America at the annual convention of that organization, held in honor of the William the Silent quadricentennial, at the Hotel Roosevelt.

Any plan looking toward permanent recovery in world commodity prices must involve the restoration of silver to approximately the same relationship with gold as existed in normal years before the depression which began in 1929, it is contended toy groups of industrialists both here and abroad.

From a strictly statistical standpoint, only a few commodities are in a sufficiently strong position to warrant any upward price movement, in line with the inflationary tendency which appeared last week when the United States abandoned the gold standard, a survey by THE TIMES revealed yesterday.

THE most successful book of the late Dr. Henry van Dyke, who died two weeks ago at Princeton, was, according to Harper Brothers. "The Story of the Other Wise Man." first published in 1895. It first appeared as a short story In Harper's Magazine, was then printed in book form, and since then has appeared in fifteen different editions, reaching a total sale of 750,000 copies.

IT is April, and the Lawnville salaam has been seen in this part of the world for almost a month now. The Lawnville salaam is one of the Spring rites of the ancient and admirable cult of flower growers. It consists in standing before a flower bed, bowing until the eyes are as close to the ground as possible and remaining in that graceful posture for minutes at a time.

The 369th anniversary of the birth of William Shakespeare will be celebrated in New York City today with various activities, the most important of which will be the all-day festival in the Shakespeare Theatre, at Fifty-ninth Street and Seventh Avenue, and the exercises at the Shakespeare statue on The Mall in Central Park under the auspices of the National Shakespeare Federation.

ABOARD THE S.S. ILE DE FRANCE, Bound for New York, April 22 -- Former Premier Herriot was represented tonight as not yet in receipt of definite instructions from Paris regarding the position he is to take, in the face of changed conditions, in his conversations with President Roosevelt in Washington.

Women college graduates have recently been reported as on their way to displace their high-school-educated sisters in the sanctum of the private secretary. Now it appears that they threaten to usurp also the white cap of the registered nurse.

FACED with a unanimous world judgment that they have committed acts of aggression against China and that they have by so doing violated solemn international covenants, the Japanese have had but one resource left to them, and that is to assert that their judgment as to what the situation in the Far East demands is superior to that arrived at by the collective intelligence of the rest of the world.

FLORENCE, Ariz., April 22 (AP) -- Mrs. Winnie Ruth Judd's sentence to death on the gallows for the murder of Mrs. Agnes Anne Leroi was suspended automatically tonight by the verdict of a Superior Court jury finding her to be insane.

WASHINGTON, April 22 (AP) -- President Roosevelt's home mortgage relief bill was attacked before a Senate banking committee today by Walter S. Schmidt, chairman of the National Association Real Estate Boards, and C. O'C. Hennessy, president of the Savings and Loan Bank of New York.

THE official records of auction sales held a season ago are a subject for rueful contemplation. There was one distinguished exception, however, and from now until the next great glorification of the rare book, apologists and professional optimists will continue to regale listeners with breathless accounts of the extraordinary successes of the Lothian sale.

WASHINGTON, April 22 -- If the gold content of the dollar should be reduced by President Roosevelt under the Thomas inflation bill now heading through Congress, the gold clause behind billions of dollars worth of American contracts might be automatically invalidated.

RIKER OF THE SEVEN SEAS" -- and the seven times seven breath-taking adventures on each of them, to say nothing of many others ashore in various lands. He does not tell all of them in this book, but he tells plenty, quite enough to keep any reader up and reading, wide-eyed and gaping with wonder, much later than is good for him.

PHILADELPHIA, April 22 -- Hearings at which the Harrison Brewery of Harrison, N.J., the Superior Manufacturing Company of Newark and the Union City Brewing Company of Union City will attempt to show cause why their beer permits should not be revoked in connection with the inquiry into the alleged permit racket in New Jersey and Pennsylvania will be held during the first week in May.

WASHINGTON, April 22 -- A determined Republican opposition to the administration's inflation program got under way today in the Senate with Senator Reed of Pennsylvania appealing to the country to "wake up" and defeat "this insane plan."

REAR ADMIRAL EMORY S. LAND, formerly vice president of the Daniel Guggenheim Fund for the Promotion of Aeronautics, said in reference to the Guggenheim prize for the construction of a "safe" airplane that there was no such thing as a "fool proof" airplane any more than there could be built a fool proof automobile.
LONDON, April 22 -- The leading Sunday newspapers take a more sober view of American events than had most sections of the British press in the last few days.
WASHINGTON, April 22 -- The War Department issued the following orders today:

LONDON, April 21 -- When Neville Chamberlain, Chancellor of the Exchequer, presents his budget to the House of Commons Tuesday he has a grand chance of making himself the most popular man in Britain outside of the royal family. All he has to do is knock one penny off the price of a pint of beer and six pence off the income tax and the lowest and the highest in the land will acclaim him.

The second In a series of receptions given by the president and members of the board of directors of the Woman's Roosevelt Memorial Association will take place on the afternoon of May 1 at Roosevelt House, 28 East Twentieth Street.

Capturing three finals, the Philadelphia matmen gained the national Y.M.H.A. wrestling championship last night at the Ninety-second Street branch. In all, Philadelphia scored a total of 27 points, two more than the Ninety-second Street grapplers tallied to take the runnerup post.

MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., April 22 -- Shannondale Buddy today joined the ranks of promising young fieldtrial winners when he carried off the trophy in the open puppy stakes at the Spring field trials of the Sport and Conservation League at Armory Farm.

ARE there any school teachers, one wonders -- male school teachers, anyhow -- who have not longed at times to kick over their desks, throw their books through the window and gallop away toward some far horizon? Mr. A.T. Tschlffely, a Swiss who had spent "nine years In the largest English - American school" in the Argentine, several years ago obeyed thia impulse, and in a magnificent manner.

SOUTHWEST of Marienburg, where the Nogat separates from the Vistula to make its way to the sea, a solitary triangular boundary-stone stands. Here, on the right bank of the latter river, the territories of East Prussia, Poland and the diminutive Free State of Danzig come together.

Although three eye specialists who examined 2-year-old Helen Vasko Friday agreed yesterday with earlier medical opinion that an immediate operation upon her left eye was needed to save her life, the attitude of her parents continued last night to be uncertain.

No appreciable change occurred last week in the small volume of securities being called for payment before their dates of maturity, which have been comparatively small in the past month. Two new calls were added to the April list and parts of several bond issues, mostly foreign, to the list of those to be paid in future months.

ST. LOUIS, April 22 (AP) -- Tex Carleton, the slender young righthander from Texas, pitched the St. Louis Cardinals to their second successive shut-out victory over the Chicago Cubs today, beating Charley Root, the veteran righthander, in a brilliant mound duel, 2 to 0.

WASHINGTON, April 22 (AP) -- President Roosevelt's plan to untie the financial knots of the nation's tangled railroad system is complete and ready for presentation to Congress next week. Chairman Rayburn of the House Interstate Commerce Committee, who helped draft the bill, said today that a message requesting the legislation probably would be submitted early in the week.

Many buyers were in the market during the week, some to replenish stocks required for May sales and others who sought to learn the effect of prospective inflation, upon the prices of merchandise they were interested in, according to the market report prepared especially for THE TIMES by Kirby, Block Flscher.

PHILADELPHIA, April 22 (AP). -- Overcoming an early lead of 4 -- 0, the Washington Senators defeated the Philadelphia Athletics today and halted their losing streak of four straight. The Senators triumphed, 10 to 7, lashing out sixteen hits.

The 1,000 heads of families and single women tot whom the Adopta-Family Committee seeks to provide tide-over jobs earned an average of $5,000 each a year before they were thrown out of work, Mrs. August Belmont, the chairman, announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, April 22 -- Defended as a means for the salvation of the farmer and attacked as "the entering wedge to socialistic government," the administration Muscle Shoals bill was taken up in the House today with the assurance that it would be passed Monday afternoon.

BERLIN, April 22 -- The train carrying Allan Monkhouse, John Cushy, A.W. Gregory and Charles Nordwall, four of the six British engineers involved in the trial at Moscow, was besieged by newspaper men on their arrival here today, but they refused to comment on the trial.

BERLIN, April 10 -- The Berliner Tageblatt, known the world over as the leading German Democratic Journal, has ceased to be a privately owned and conducted newspaper. It has been "coordinated" in keeping with Nazi dogma, and will here-after confine itself to reflecting the will and objects of the national government.

IN the fifteen hundred years which have elapsed since the death of Augustine, that illustrious Bishop of Hippo who was to became immortalized as St. Augustine, so much ink has flowed about his name from learned pens that no truly original contributions ace possible.

LAWRENCE, Kan., April 22 -- Glenn Cunningham upheld his prestige as king of American milers today at the eleventh annual Kansas relay carnival and broke one of the seven meet records erased in the first major test of the mid-Western outdoor track and field season.

REVIEW of legislation affecting motor vehicles passed by eighteen State Legislatures which have ended their sessions shows that of thousands of bills introduced only a small percentage were enacted into law. The measures adopted related to regulation of trucks and buses, fixing registration fees and gasoline taxes, restriction of motor vehicle sizes and weights, use of gasoline revenue, financial responsibility and other questions of motor vehicle operation.

Bursting into a beer garden and restaurant at 74-17 Liberty Avenue, Ozone Park, Queens, with pistols drawn while two men were about to rob the forty customers in the place early this morning, two Brooklyn police sergeants, who had finished their tour of duty and were driving to their homes in Jamaica, killed one of the robbers and seriously wounded his companion.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 20 -- California has a tax moratorium To California the fact is importtant in that it will enable them to defer until June 20 the payment of the half-year instalment of realty taxes due on April 20.

NEW ORLEANS, April 20 -- Difficult as it must be for the remainder of the nation to accept it as true, it is none the less a fact that Louisiana has other interesting concerns besides considering the petitions against its Senator and Kingfish, or, as some have it, crayfish, Huey Pierce Long Jr.

A sea-going yacht steams out of Miami flying the black flag of the sea-rovers of a bygone day. But the Carib is not a pirate ship; she has been chartered by a New York banker for a cruise in search of buried treasure, although that is supposed to be a secret known to only a select few of those on board.

To the Music Editor: In the issue of THE NEW YORK TIMES for Sunday, April 16, there appeared a letter signed by Mr. Leo Levy under the heading "The Philadelphia Concerts." Mr. Levy regrets the fact that the Philadelphia Orchestra is conducted by Leopold Stokowski at only five concerts of the series of ten which it gives In New York, and reflects a growing spirit of dissatisfaction that this is so.

David T. Lamond, president of the Foreign Commerce Club of New York, announced yesterday that resolutions adopted by the club on the so-called "buy American movement" and on the national, administration's policy on tariff reciprocities and international trade had been transcribed and copies circulated to high government and civic officials.

LAST week a solitary sun-tanned fugitive from Broadway might have been observed on the beach at Miami, silently honing his cutlass. For three days and nights the swordsman whetted away, his face lined with determination and finality.

WASHINGTON, April 22 -- The Commerce Department's study of United States trade with the world in 1932, which was sent to the British Embassy at the latter's request today and presumably laid before the economic conferees, showed in detail the extent of the decline in the volume and value of our shipments to principal markets and compared them with figures for the immediate preceding years.

CHICAGO, April 20 -- Probably no Governor of any of the forty-eight States has a wholly happy time of it these days, so if the executives of Illinois, Indiana and Wisconsin have troubles they also have company. Clamoring taxpayers, falling revenue, war-dancing farmers, experiments in bear traffic regulations, crusading amateurs in economics and political science, each with a sure-fire panacea, furnish an abundance of worries and annoyances.

MOSCOW, April 22 -- Maxim Litvinoff, Soviet Foreign Commissar, in a signed statement today criticized Great Britain for its embargo on Russian imports, which has resulted in a counter-embargo on British goods by Russia.

THE New York Philharmonic-Symphony Society, giving its final concert of the season 1933-34 this afternoon in Carnegie Hall, has completed its plans for next Winter. They are heartening at a time which has seen the collapsa of more than one important American orchestral undertaking.

By the time that Professor Lumley has finished his analysis of the sources, varieties and methods of propaganda, the average reader will be much inclined to conclude that propaganda is a hydra-headed menace, that the attacks are incessant and from all sides, and that nothing particularly effective can be done about it.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., April 22 -- Four Naval Academy crews moved steadily and relentlessly through array, windswept water on the upper Severn today to score a clean sweep in the regatta with Massachusetts Institute of Technology.

IN "Lady Buyer" Ruth Seinfel has written what is without doubt, the most vital and comprehensive story of a great department store yet to appear. Other novelists have laid their romances against a department store background; but, almost without exception, they have failed to make the store itself emerge as anything more than a vaguely indicated setting for the love story of a sales girl, or a floor walker, or a comparison shopper.

Leaders in the public utility field are preparing to abondon their attitude of non-resistance to the mounting volume of political criticism directed at them and will contest warmly, in the territories which they serve, any public utterances embracing misstatements of facts and circumstances.

PARIS, April 21 -- Spring has come in Paris a full month earlier than it win in Berlin this year, emphasizing the climatic difference between these two great capitals of Continental Europe in a manner almost startling.

Representatives of seven public utility companies in Queens, who conferred on rates yesterday with Borough President George U. Harvey, indicated clearly that they would not make voluntary rate reductions, and expressed their intention to await the outcome of litigation, which will be undertaken by the city.

Samuel R. Rosoff, the subway builder, was thrown from his horse on the bridle path in Central Park near West Eighty-sixth Street yesterday at about noon and was taken to Reconstruction Hospital, 395 Central Park West, where it was said that his injuries were not serious.

CHEYENNE, Wyo., April 20 -- The beer bill which the Wyoming legislature rushed through in the closing hours of the session is turning out to be a boomerang. The jubilation of the thirsty has been short-lived, and they are now watching with zealous interest the litigation which has already started, even before the act could become effective.

TORONTO, Ont. A NOTABLE local art event of the current season Is the joint exhibition of Archibald Barnes, R.P., R.O.I., O.S.A., and Arthur Heming, O.S.A., which opened in the galleries of Eatons, College Street, Toronto, last week.

THIS is a book of exceptional quality -- personal record of a sort that finds its way into print all too seldom. There are good reasons for its rarity Not often does life bring to any one of us experiences comparable to those which have filled the last twelve years in the life of Nora Waln.

PEIPING, Sunday, April 23 -- Despite the Japanese contention that their forces were no longer operating in the Lwan River triangle, official foreign sources confirm a report that Japanese troops have occupied Lulung, situated on the banks of the Lwan twelve miles above Lwanchow, further increasing apprehension that the slowly advancing forces will not halt until they shall have reached the Yellow River, 200 miles south of Peiping.

Cardinal Hayes was the chief speaker yesterday at a luncheon that started the week's drive of a committee of 1,000 business, professional and public leaders to supplement the annual fund-raising campaign, beginning next Sunday, of the Catholic Charities of the Archdiocese of New York.

OTTAWA, April 20 -- When the Prime Minister of Canada goes to Washington on Sunday to discuss with the President of the United States trade relations between these two countries and how they can be developed to mutual advantage, he undertakes, perhaps, the most critical task of his Premiership; one of tremendous potential consequences, economic and political.

THE ordinary motion-picture camera takes from twelve to sixteen "frames" or pictures a second. Newspaper "still" pictures of races and athletic events are made with exposures that are supposed to be 0.0006 second, but that actually lie between 0.002 and 0.005.

HOLLYWOOD. WHEN the cinema heads disbanded after a week's discussion with Will H. Hays at the annual meeting of the board of the Motion Picture Producers and Distributers of America they declared that they had had a strenuous time.

The most Utopian thing in Utopia is that there are no schools at all. Education is carried on without anything of the nature of schools, or, if this idea is so extreme that we cannot conceive of it as educational at all, then we may say nothing of the sort at present we know as schools.

BORN at sea off Jamaica, the author had the qualification of natural interest in the history of that romantic island to write the story of Sir Henry Morgan, not only the most famous of buccaneers but a Governor of Jamaica.

IF you are not an out-and-out jazzist, delighting in noise and excitement and radios going all the time, you must long now and then for some peaceful corner where it would be possible to rest your ears, loaf for a few minutes and invite your soul.

IN the midst of financial trials and uncertainty it is comforting to find the American Art Annual still answering roll-call with a confident "Here!" The volume that covers art activities of the year 1932 has made its appearance, with classified directories listing 1,050 museums and associations, 500 schools, 180 dealers, 90 magazines and as many newspapers that carry art notes.

LISTENERS wonder why a musical selection is often punctured with a gong and station call letters, yet a ninetyminute address by George Bernard Shaw and other lengthy talks are not interrupted by station identification.

Robson Lowe, a leading stamp dealer In London, arrived in New York last week and he said yesterday that when he starts for home early next month he expectes to carry back with him at least $250,000 worth of stamps. According to local dealers, this will establish a record in the financial value of stamps purchased in this country at one time by a foreign dealer.

WASHINGTON, April 22 -- Improvement in general business activity during the week ended on April 15, in continuation of the upward reaction following the February-March decline, was reported today by the Commerce Department in its weekly survey of domestic business conditions.
BOSTON, April 22 -- Invading yachtsmen took the lead over local skippers today in the opening races of the intersectional frostbite regatta held by the Boston, Dinghy Club.

New York University took preliminary steps for the training of undergraduates to participate in politics with the announcement yesterday by Dean Rufus D. Smith of the organization in the Department of Government at Washington Square College of a division of research in public administrations.
Full steam ahead is the signal for 1933 in the Eastern Lawn Tennis Association.

ELMIRA, April 22 -- Federal prohibition agents from New York and Buffalo were tracing tonight a hose line through the city sewers which they believe carried mash or alcohol for several blocks between a storehouse and the former Briggs Brewery Building which has been twice seized by dry agents and returned to the owners by the Federal courts.

Adjustment of foreclosure realty values, funding of taxes in arrears, reduction of sheriffs' fees and a mortgage moratorium are among measures being advocated by the New Jersey Association of Real Estate Boards to protect property values.

CINCINNATI, April 22 (AP) -- Observations made by a skiing doctor, according to University of Cincinnati medical authorities, are leading to relief of some of the ills of the arteries that hamper circulation in the arms and legs.

REUNION IN VIENNA," picturization of the stage play by Robert E. Sherwood, with John Barrymore and Diana Wynyard in leading roles, will begin an engagement at the Gaiety Theatre on Friday evening. Incidentally, this will be the second successive Gaiety Theatre engagement for Miss Wynyard, the young English actress who had the principal feminine role in "Cavalcade."

The nation is to be congratulated that President Roosevelt's policy of "controlled inflation" has gone into effect. We should see a healthy rise in commodity and real estate values, and at the same time the country is free from the dangers of a printing-press currency and similar schemes which have been advocated by the more radical members of Congress.

COPENHAGEN, April 20 -- At the suggestion of Dr. Max Henius of Chicago the Danish Government has appointed a committee of the most distinguished scientists in Denmark to plan and prepare for the Museum of Science and Industry of Chicago a comprehensive series of exhibits to show the evolution of Danish science from the days of Tycho Brahe.

LONDON, April 7. PLAYS of interest are nowadays more often given a first performance In the lesser theatres, which have made themselves the home of experiment, than in the great playhouses that stand in the neighborhood of Piccadilly Circus and Charing Cross.

Henry Rondeau of Providence gained the heavyweight title in the first annual Eastern Regional Y. M.C.A. wrestling championship tournament, which came to a close at the West Side Y.M.C.A. last night after two days of competition.

LONDON, April 21 -- British opinions of the value of confessions made by prisoners in the hands of the Ogpu have been largely influenced by a letter from Professor Vladimar Vyacheslavovitch Tchernavin, published in The London Times. Professor Tchernavin escaped in August, 1932, after having been accused as a "wrecker."

LEXINGTON, Ky., April 22 -- Colonel E.R. Bradley's chances of winning his fourth Kentucky Derby received a decided setback today when the hitherto lightly-regarded Warren Jr., from the Calumet Farm Stable of Warren Wright Jr., led home Broker's Tip and Boilermaker in the Prospect Purse, a Derby trial which served as secondary feature of the closing-day card.

WITH a setting provided by the Vanderbilt Gallery, its walls still hung with Spring Academy, Cecilia Beaux received last Monday evening the Chi Omega Gold Medal, awarded annually to an American woman who has made "an outstanding contribution to the culture of the world."

DERBY, Conn., April 22 -- Kent School's crew, which is preparing for the British Henley and the Thames Challenge Cup races, gained added distinction today by defeating the Tale freshmen eight over the Housatonic course by one-third of 3 length.

Mayor O'Brien has given $100 to the American Palestine Campaign to facilitate Jewish immigration and colonization in Palestine it was announced yesterday by Nathan Straus Jr., chairman of the campaign here. A contribution of $1,000 also was announced from George MacDonald, Papal Marquis, who expressed sympathy with plans for rebuilding the Jewish national homeland to which homeless Jews of various countries can go for freedom and security.

BUFFALO, N.Y., April 22 -- Miss Lenore Kight of Homestead, Pa., who had previously smashed two world's records and won two individual titles in the senior national A.A.U. swimming championships, tonight added the 500-yard freestyle championship to her list durtime for the final was 6:18 8-10.
FOR the welfare of the radio listener, science has endowed every member of the unseen audience with a unique censorship that can be enforced with the little finger of man, woman or child.
PARIS, April 22 -- Important decisions in connection with the abandonment of the gold standard by the United States were taken by the French Cabinet this morning.

TORONTO, Ont., April 22 -- The Mining Corporation of Canada reports for 1932 an addition of $3,507 to the surplus, making the total $350,506. In the year the average price of silver was the lowest in history. The annual meeting will be held here on May 17.
BRONXVILLE, N.Y., April 22 -- "The Rose of Picardy" was presented tonight by members of the Leonard S. Morange Post of the American Legion in the auditorium of the Bronxville School.

To the Editor of The New York Times: After the Akron disaster has been reviewed by leading world authorities and illuminated from all possible angles with regard to its actual handling, and its chances of having avoided such an accident, it well might pay to try to analyze the ship proper and thus pave a way toward constructional advice based on facts only.

BOSTOX, April 21. FLATTERING outsiders now say that Boston is "the best theatre town" in all the hinterlands. We natives, with a reputation for modesty to preserve, reply that it is a "good theatre city again."
Tracy H. Lewis captured the doubles championship of the New York Athletic Club over the Travers Island traps of the organization yesterday, with 175 out of a possible 200 targets.

The attempt to draw a parallel between the experience of Great Britain since her abandonment of the gold standard in September, 1931, and the probable course of events here, now that the United States has cut loose from the gold basis, may prove to be quite impossible.

THE practice of making miniature decorated rooms to serve as models for proposed life-sized interiors has now advanced to the production of entire sections of houses, with the outdoor surroundings indicated also.

DUBLIN, April 21 -- More than a century ago the famous Irish satirist Swift advised the Irish people to burn everything that came from England as coal. Today Eamon de Valera's government is planning to have Swift's advice carried into effect by making the country independent of British coal supplies.

Negotiations looking to the acquisition of the Universal Credit Corporation, the automobile financing organization of the Ford Motor Company, by the Commercial Investment Trust Corporation are being carried on in this city. The Commercial Investment Trust, which has total assets of $120,000,000, finances the sale of automobiles for several independent companies and also finances the sale of other products on the instalment plan.

CHICAGO, April 22 -- A buying wave engulfed sellers of wheat to day on the Board of Trade, and with Winnipeg in the lead prices advanced rapidly after they had slumped around 1 cent a bushel in the early trading.

IN order to keep up with the sports of all nations, it is necessary to distribute secret agents here and there or, at least, to send trusted men on tours with notebooks occasionally. But the scheme may be definitely abandoned in this corner unless there is a big change either in the correspondents or the correspondence.

OTTAWA, April 22 (Canadian Press) -- In the absence of any official pronouncement by Prime Minister Bennett, the stand he will take in his forthcoming discussions in Washington with President Roosevelt remained tonight in the realm of conjecture.

LIKE the recently published biography of Leonardo da Vinci by Clifford Bax, brought out in this same series, the present volume on Ruskin is highly interesting and in its approach, fresh and stimulating. Possibly it will prove somewhat provocative, too, since Ruskin's very name has always been a sort of challenging banner snapping in the breeze of controversy.

TRENTON, N.J., April 22 (AP) -- Unpublished, manuscripts of the late Dr. Henry Van Dyke, author, and wartime Minister to the Netherlands, are placed in the hands of three literary executors, under a provision in his will admitted to probate at the Mercer County Courthouse today.
The Toronto Maple Leafs broke their four-game losing streak by overwhelming Jersey City at the West Side Park, Jersey City, yesterday, 11 to 3.

SUMTER, S.C., April 20 -- Here in South Carolina, the only oasis in the Southeast at this writing, beer is now being sold as openly and freely as soda pop. But, contrary to the dire predictions of the die-hard drys, there has been no disorder and no general celebration.

This is humor, if you like, or satire, if you see it that way. The orthodox communist critic would call it spirit "defeatism." Edmund Wilson speaks of the author as an original comic poet, a humorist with a philosophicopoetic point of view.

The advance in prices of stocks and commodities, which was checked by profit-taking on Friday, was resumed on a broad scale yesterday, to the accompaniment of the most active trading for a Saturday since last Summer.

CLEVELAND, April 20 -- The veteran Maurice Maschke, Ohio's Republican National Committeeman until this year and for twenty-six years the most successful city political boss in the Mid West was swept from most of his power by two smashing Democratic landslides last year -- one in Cleveland, the other in the State.

Freeing of the control of the Central Railroad of New Jersey from the trustee with whom it has been vested by court order since 1924 is contemplated by the Baltimore Ohio Railroad as a step toward coordinating the entire B. O. -Reading-Jersey Central system.

SIX Englishmen sit uneasily before a Soviet court while the Russian prosecutor reads the indictments against them Prominent in the list of charges is that of espionage in Soviet factories for the benefit of the British Government.

PRINCETON, N.J. April 22 -- Villanova, outhit twelve to eight, defeated the Frinceton nine, 8 to 7, on University Field today. The Wildcats routed two Tiger pitchers, bunching their hits in the third and sixth innings.

ARTUR SCHNABEL, the German pianist and teacher, will return to this country next season for his first recital tour in eight years. Although he was here in 1930 for appearances with the Boston Symphony Orchestra, he has not concertized in this country since the season of 1924-25.

Calling attention to the present status of guaranteed mortgages, Harold J. Rosen, secretary of the Rosen Building Corporation, states that it is absolutely necessary for holders of such certificates to accept a reduction in interest, and he adds that it should be done as a group on all properties.

A campaign to improve business in the New York printing industry, by inducing local users of printing to place their orders with New York shops rather than outside the city, was announced yesterday on behalf of a committee of union representatives and employing printers.

LOCUST VALLEY, L.I., April 22 -- More than 500 members of the debutante set of the North Shore, students home from college and the younger married members of society attended a supper dance at the Creek Club tonight, the first large social event of the season, for the benefit of the Locust Valley Exchange for Women's Work.

DURING the past few years there has been a marked increase of interest in the general subject of magic, both black and white. Theda Kenyon, in her entertaining "Witches Still Live," pointed out the fact that even in these supposedly enlightened United States belief in witchcraft is by no means extinct.

ORANGE, N.J., April 22 (AP) -- Orange's brilliant array of swimming stars captured five of the nine events in the international Y.M. C.A. swimming championships tonight, piled up a total of 37 points and retained the team title won last year at Toronto.

LONDON. TOMORROW is the 400th anniversary of the birth of William the Silent who led the Netherlands in their historic revolt against the mighty Spain of Philip II and so became the father of the present-day kingdom of Holland.

Speaking at the annual Jefferson dinner of the National Democratic Club at the Commodore Hotel, Mayor John P. O'Brien last night threatened with criminal prosecution anybody who in speech or through the newspapers attempted "to discredit the credit of the City of New York."

AS a companion to the de luxe, line introduced a week ago, the Plymouth Motor Corporation has added a new series of smaller and lower-priced cars known as the Standard Plymouth sixes, models of which were publicly displayed yesterday.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., April 22 (AP) -- Professor Irving Fisher, Yale economist, asserted today that the attack of four Republican members of Congress on the administration's inflation program is "in line with time-worn traditions."

PARIS, April 20 -- Impressions of Easter fashions revealed that the lightest colors with banana, apricot and ash - rose tones prominently featured were popular. Larger hats, usually of contrasting colors, were noted.

ONE would not suppose that any new light on Shakespeare was possible, but In "Shakespeare Under Elizabeth." by G.B. Harrison, editor of "The Elizabethan Journals." will be found an approach which is striking in its freshness, and a treatment remarkable for its vividness.

ROME, April 22 (AP) -- Cancellation, or at least a heavy reduction, of war debts was termed essential in a resolution adopted today at the closing session of the Interparliamentary Commercial Conference.

With a Wintry wind and temperature still prevailing despite bright sunshine, 12,000 Flatbush fans turned out yesterday at Ebbets Field and were rewarded by seeing the Dodgers even the short series with the Phils by winning, 6 to 2. By the triumph Brooklyn took second place in the league standing.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I realize that no legislation which is new in character is entirely faultless, but I take issue with Professor E.W. Kemmerer on his assertion in THE TIMES that the farm relief bill is special class legislation. On the contrary, I view it as a sincere effort to meet a nation-wide emergency by endeavoring to offset a maladjustment which, has produced this emergency.

NOVELS that are really funny are rare in this year of grace. The horizon, as far as the eye of man can see, is darkened with books that are very very serious. But there are some cheering exceptions. "Cold Comfort Farm" is one of them.

WASHINGTON, April 22 -- Going out of his way to allay any uneasiness of peoples abroad, Prime Minister MacDonald declared today that no nation must be "victimized" in any monetary arrangements made in discussions here or in London.

Officials of the United States and Canada will annonunce the results of a survey of the duck situation in both countries in a preliminary report to be released this week. The survey, now going on, will continue until the hunting season opens. However, it is hoped to be able to give a general outline of the present situation, especially as it relates to conditions the ducks will face during the nesting and breeding seasons.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., April 22 -- Yale University, which defeated New York University in taking the indoor intercollegiate track championship, today again outscored its metropolitan rival to win a stubbornly contested track meet on Yale field, 79 1-3 to 55 2-3.

EVERY year approximately 25,000 persons in New York City suffer injury in taxicab accidents. Securing financial redress in such cases has proved a prolific source of complaint and irritation to the taxicab operator, the insuring companies and the State insurance authorities, and to the public a costly experience resulting oftentimes in serious distress.

HARBIN, Manchuria, April 22 -- Manchukuo seeks to use the dispute over the Chinese Eastern Railway as a pretext to force a general readjustment of the railway organization and settlement of outstanding issues between the Soviet Union and Manchukuo.

PARIS, April 22 -- The United States has suggested to France and Britain the creation of a huge world credit pool to aid the return of a normal flow of international trade, it was reported in authoritative circles here today. No news of this offer has appeared in the French press or in reports from Washington published here, the suggestion being in the nature of a trial balloon.

BETHLEHEM, Pa., April 22 -- Lehigh resumed its baseball schedule after the Easter vacation today and lost to Dickinson, 4 to 1. The Carlisle collegians played smart baseball and took advantage of every Lehigh miscue to forge to the front.
AMHERST, Mass., April 22 -- Williams defeated Massachusetts State today, 7 -- 2, in the season's opener for both nines before a junior prom crowd that shivered through most of the game.

Editor, The New York Times Book Review: Permit me to compliment you for the fine review of "The Boat of Longing" by O.E. Rolvaag in your issue for Jan. 22. It was gratifying to those of us who are familiar with his work in the original to find that this particular book is appreciated in translation also.

WASHINGTON, April 22 -- Organized labor will probably request President Roosevelt to give it representation on the delegation which will present the policy of this country at the World Economic Conference in June, it was forecast in labor circles here today.

ALDOUS HUXLEY and Osbert Sitwell were chief among authors suspected of having written Mr. Aston's first novel, "They Winter Abroad" -- but we are now sure that, if James Aston did not wrtte It, the author was another man of the same name.
Columbia University's tennis team scored its third victory of the season by defeating the N.Y.U. netmen, 5-4, on the South Field courts yesterday.

BRUSSELS, April 6 -- The abolition of the "blue laws" is foreshadowed in the Belgian press. They have been found to be a failure, and the government is short of money. The "blue laws" prohibit the drinking of alcoholic liquors in public places.

OAKLAND. WITH their attention primarily centred on ultimate use in the locomotive and automotive industry, William J. Besler, pilot and experimenter, and his brother, George, both of whom are sons of W.G. Besler, chairman of the Board of the New Jersey Central Railroad, are completing work on their light-weight steam engine with which they are making exhibition flights in a standard biplane from the Oakland airport.

WASHINGTON, April 22 -- Leaving to its Congressional leaders the privilege of making any arguments they think useful in helping-to pass the permissive monetary program outlined in the Thomas amendment, the administration today began a straightforward attack on the depression cycle through international action.

THIS well-made, slender volume preserves a lecture delivered last May by General Harbord at Milton Academy, Massachusetts, under the auspices of the Alumni War Memorial Foundation, which in annual commemoration of the twenty-two alumni who died in war service sponsors "lectures and informal conferences dealing with the responsibilities and opportunities attaching to leadership in a democracy."

HERMAN A. METZ and VICTOR RIDDER, two outstanding American citizens, are now in Germany upon invitation from leading circles there to come and see for themselves the truth about " alleged" atrocities. What Messrs. METZ and RIDDER observe in Germany they will no doubt come back and report in due time.

TODAY all eyes are turned to Washington and all thoughts centre upon the action of the administration with respect to the overshadowing issue of inflation. On the one hand, there is national discussion of the various inflationary proposals.

The Social Science Research Council at 230 Park Avenue yesterday announced forty-two awards, totaling $19,290, for the support of research in social science. The winners were picked from a list of 138 applicants. The grants are designed to assist mature scholars in the completion of research projects already well under way and provide for study in economics, political science, sociology, cultural anthropology, social psychology, history, law, statistics and human geography.

BERLIN, March 10 -- News photographers in Germany are having their own troubles under the Nazi regime, which now apparently is even delving into past publications to find reasons for disciplining the picture men and bringing them "into harmony with reawakened Germany."

POMFRET, Conn., April 22 -- Choate School won two of the three races from Pomfret School crews today over a half-mile course on Woostock Lake. Pomfret's victory was scored in the race between the second fours of the rival schools.

In 1931 and 1932 a total of 6,316 patients was admitted to the Neurologlcal Institute of New Tork, the number of patient-days having been 113,817, of which 31,959 were free or paid for only in part, a summary of the institute's work in these years, made public yesterday, revealed.

The colorful and swift-moving spectacle of the Penn Relay carnival will attact a gathering of approximately 50,000 persons to Franklin Field this week-end as this annual track and field extravaganza is staged for the thirty-ninth time on Friday and Saturday.

HERE are forty-two "prize" stories gleaned from the yearly volumes, 1919-1932, put out by the O. Henry Memorial Committee, of which Miss Williams has been the guiding spirit during the fifteen years of its existence. In contradistinction to the O'Brien collections, the tendency here has always been conservative.

WASHINGTON, April 22 -- Loadings of revenue freight in the week ended on April 15 amounted to 494,215 cars, the American Railway Association, announced today. This was 6,919 cars, or 1.4 per cent, more than in the preceding week, but 72,611 cars, or 12.8 per cent, fewer than in the corresponding week last year, and 265,279 cars, or 34.9 per cent, fewer than in the corresponding week two years ago.

LONDON. GREAT BRITAIN has undergone a severe industrial depression which has reduced her foreign trade, paralyzed her shipping, diminished the national revenues and so swollen the ranks of the unemployed that the unemployment insurance system proved inadequate and thousands were thrown upon the meager relief provided by the State.

LAUGHS, giggies, coughs and sneezes are no longer unpardonable sins in the radio studio. Applause and realism are the order of the day. There was a time, not so many years ago, when "Silence" signs were posted throughout the sanctum of the microphone.

LONDON, April 14 -- The whole world is coming, or wants to come, to Washington to consult with the President. Officially the great economic conference is to be held in London some time this Summer. In reality it has started already in the American capital.

Two hundred rare old newspapers, forerunners of the papers of today, dating back three centuries and telling naively some of the great events in English history, will go on exhibition for three days beginning tomorrow at the Waldorf-Astoria in connection with the annual meeting of The Associated Press.

RIO DE JANEIRO, April 7 -- After thirty months of provisional governminent or dictatorship, Brazil now busily engaged in oiling its long unused electoral machinery, which will again begin grinding on May 3, when 214 members will be chosen form the Constituent Assembly.

IT is almost ten years since Sherwood Anderson last published a book of short stories. Since then he has published novels, notebooks, works of autobiography, prose poems, discussions of the life around him; but beside his stories all these things escape the memory and dwindle.

HUNTINGTON, L.I., April 22 -- One of the largest fields of the year brought to an end the trapshooting season of the Crescent Athletic-Hamilton Club today. It was an invitation affair and teams from other Long Island organizations participated.

LA PAZ, April 22 -- The Bolivian forces in the Chaco launched a strong offensive on Wednesday with the road between Pirijayo and Rojas Silva as its objective, according to the first dispatch in several days from the army command.

PHILADELPHIA, April 22 -- Spectrographic observations of the night sky, revealing features referred to as "cosmic radiations," which belong to a strange type of spectrum peculiar to the sky's diffuse light and show the earth's atmosphere as taking on a new importance as an "optical body," were reported on by Dr. Vesto M. Slipher, director of the Lowell Observatory, in an address before the American Philosophical Society here today.

STATE COLLEGE, Pa., April 22 -- Army's trackmen, displaying great strength, in the field events, defeated the Perm State team today, 74 to 52.

At a meeting of the executive committee on Tuesday, Newcomb Carlton, president of the Western Union Telegraph Company, will probably be elected chairman of the board, and Roy B. White, president of the Central Railroad Company of New Jersey, will be chosen to succeed him.

Under the auspices of the Belgian Benevolent Society of New York, of which Mrs. J.T. Johnston Mali, wife of the Belgian Consul General here, is president, a ball will be held on Saturday night at the McAlpin.
HAMILTON, N.Y., April 22 -- Colgate opened the baseball season today by defeating Hartwick College, 24-9, in a free-hitting game.

WASHINGTON, April 22 -- Adjustmnent of working hours to present industrial conditions as one solution of the unemployment problem was urged today by Miss Ishbel MacDonald, daughter of the British Prime Minister, at a luncheon given in her honor by the Women's National Press Club.
MUNICH, April 20 -- The first impression gained on returning to Munich after an absence of three weeks is that the opposition of middle-class Bavarians to the Nazis is dying out rapidly.

A suggestion that the scope of the Pulitzer prizes be extended to permit an annual award to the best American talking picture has been made by Major Albert Warner, vice president of Warner Brothers, in a letter to Carl W. Ackerman, dean of the Columbia School of Journalism.

Such a situation is not new to fiction, but it is never-failing in its possibilities for sardonic treatment, since human nature under such stress has a way of revealing itself at its worst.

CHICAGO, April 22 (AP) -- Winston Guest, ranking star of the indoor sport, set a new scoring record for the 124th Field Artillery Armory tonight as his team, the champion New York Optimists, swamped the South Shore Remount Association, 20 to 6.

Improved business conditions and the solution of the present banking problems hinge in large measure on making ownership of real estate profitable, in the opinion of the New York State Association of Heal Estate Boards.

LONDON, April 22 (Canadian Press) -- Hundreds of firemen today worked frantically to save $45,000,000 worth of rum stored on "Rum Quay," part of the West India docks of the Port of London Authority, twelve hours after a fire broke out there last night.

Collecting twenty hits, including five two-baggers and a home run, St. John's College of Brooklyn won a battle of hits from the City Collge varsity baseball team at the Lewisohn Stadium yesterday. The visitors triumphed by a 14-10 score to end C.C.N.Y.'s three-game winning streak.
