Speaking on tax conditions in New Jersey and recent legislative measures to relieve realty and mortgage holders, State Senator Joseph G. Wolber told the members of the New Jersey Association of Real Estate Boards at their annual dinner last week in East Orange that of all forms of taxation in that State real estate property bore more than 86 per cent.
The celebration today of the 400th anniversary of the birth of WILLIAM the Silent should recall first of all MOTLEY'S statement in his "History of the Netherlands":

Resuming the advance with redoubled energy, the share market yesterday canceled the losses of the day before and demonstrated that the speculative possibilities of the bold drive for inflation have not been exhausted. There was a further broad movement in commodities and the dollar displayed fresh weakness in the foreign exchange market, all of which reflected belief that a new monetary policy is being shaped.

In the course of the dog show year several exhibitions stand out above all others, each enjoying special distinction and an individuality all its own. Thus there is only one Westminster. Every one hopes to win at the Garden, and a victory there places the stamp of greatness on the ribbon winners.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., April 22 -- The Yale freshmen today putscored Andover Academy in their annual track meet, 76 3/4 to 49 1/4. Captain Westcott Burlingame of the freshmen, who won both sprints, and his team-mate, Frank, who took the high hurdles and was third in the low, were high scorers.

Many memories of the heyday of the American horse will be revived this week with the renewal of the New York and Brooklyn horse shows. The former will be held on Tuesday in the ring of the Riding Club, 7 West Sixty-sixth Street, while the latter will run through the last three days of the week at the Brooklyn Riding and Driving Club.

VIENNA, April 22 -- The Austrian Heimwehr in the Province of Styria, representing about one-half the total Heimwehr strength, today concluded a cooperative agreement with the Austrian Hitlerite party which promises to split the Heimwehr and to aid greatly to the difficulties of the Dollfuss government.
ALBANY, April 22 -- State machinery for collecting the new 1 per cent retail sales tax, effective May 1, was rapidly being set into motion today by Mark Graves, president of the State Tax Commission.

A sharp rise in orders from Far Eastern and Latin-American buyers of manufactured goods provided the first tangible evidences of the increased foreign trade activity which the majority of exporters believe will result from the administration's move last week in abandoning the gold standard.

WASHINGTON, April 21 (AP) -- A Congressional investigration of reported revolutionary plotting against the Cuban government was proposed today in the House by Representative Shoemaker. Farmer-Labor member from Minnesota.

The board of directors of The Associated Press has adopted a resolution, it was revealed yesterday, instructing the management not to supply any news in the future to radio broadcasting chains. Whether broadcasting by member papers themselves will be permitted is expected to be the chief subject discussed at the annual meeting of the members.

A monopoly of an industry by racketeers, as powerful and sinister as any criminal trust previously uncovered in this city, according to District Attorney Foley of the Bronx, was revealed yesterday by events surrounding an attempt by enemies to free three leading wholesale poultry dealers, held in jail as material witnesses.

POSSIBLY not inspired by our financial "depression," to use its curiously mild title, but certainly associated with it, is the return of our ancient reveille: "Let us now praise famous men and our fathers that were before us."
MADRID, April 21 -- Excited by Jewish persecution in Germany, Spain is doing all she can to rectify a mistake once made by herself in the same direction.

BERLIN, April 22 -- The Dortmunder Generalanzeiger prints a dispatch from Amsterdam announcing that the board of International Federation of Trade Unions has decided to break off relations with, the German members, who represent the General German Trades Unions League.

Folloging Friday's somewhat diminished activity, trading on the Cotton Exchange was resumed with energy yesterday and prices fluctuated within a range of 30 points and closed with net gains of 7 to 12 points.

There was a double wedding yesterday afternoon in St. Thomas Church, when Miss Gillian Barr Bailey was married to John Alfred Nichols, and her sister, Miss Rosalie Greenleaf Bailey, to Thomas William Phelps. The brides are daughters of Mr. and Mrs. Theodore Layton Bailey of 21 East Ninety-fourth Street.

PHILADELPHIA, April 20 -- The brewers of Pennsylvania should be properly grateful to Governor Pinchot and the Legislature. The Governor is disposed to let the legislators have a corner on the gratitude, but the General Assembly leaders retort that Mr. Pinchot himself is the brewers' big-hearted friend, in spite of his word that no beer is to be served in the Executive Mansion while he is its occupant.

LONDON. AN exhibition of D.H. Lawrence's] work, now being shown at Bumpus's, is attracting considerable attention. The word "work" must be widely interpreted in this connection, for among the exhibits are not only books, corrected proofs and MSS., but also a few pictures and a short piece of music.

Members of the board of directors, the nursing staff and the medical advisory board of the Maternity Centre Association will meet on Thursday at a luncheon to be given by Mrs. John S. Rogers at her home, 53 East Seventy-ninth Street, to discuss plans for the organization's forthcoming Mother's Day educational campaign and annual Spring drive for new members and funds to further its maternity nursing service in the city.

ANN ARBOR, Mich., April 22 -- One honest man or woman willing to fight every case of graft and corruption in his municipal government which he saw, could outweigh eventually the influence of hundreds of political machine henchmen whose only interest in politics was the money or special privileges they hoped to obtain, former Judge Samuel Seabury of New York declared here at a University of Michigan convocation last evening.

POWERFUL motors roar over the blue Tyrrhenian as General Italo Balbo and a corps of aviators enter the final phase of their preparations for the mass formation flight of twenty seaplanes to Chicago in late May and June.

TODAY, more than at any time in the last decade, our naval needs are subjects for headlines. With the disarmament conference at Geneva apparently faltering toward a futile conclusion, with Europe an armed camp fearful of the future, with Japanese and Chinese Armies on the march, and with guns booming in South America, the question of the strength of our fleet again becomes of paramount interest.

DOWN EAST there has long existed a divided aristocracy, one branch inheriting the sea, the other the soil. These Yankees are a clannish breed; thus, the sailor cleaves to a sailor's daughter, while farmers' daughters most often become farmers' wives.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., April 22 -- The State of Alabama is confronted with a financial crisis which threatens the very life of its free public schools. With 85 per cent of its elementary and secondary schools closed already, the people of the State are facing the prospect of utter collapse of the educational system or, at best, a drastic curtailment of its functions.

Local retail trade maintained its seasonal buoyancy last week, with leading stores here reporting gains in sales over the figures for the corresponding days a year ago. The special promotions of apparel and home furnishings launched by retailers drew a consumer response that reflected nothing of the usual post-Easter reaction.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., April 22 -- Harvard's varsity baseball team opened its home season today by defeating the alumni, 6 -- 4. The graduates were leading until the eighth inning, 4 -- 3, when three singles, laced out against Red McHale, together with an error brought over three runs.

LONDON, April 22 -- Dismay is the ruling emotion in business circles of Great Britain as a result of the swiftness and completeness of Moscow's reply to the forthcoming British embargo on Russian goods.
WASHINGTON, April 22 -- The Bureau of Navigation issued the following orders today, dated April 20:

PEEKSKILL, N.Y., April 22 -- Dr. Alexander D. Dunbar, dean of Westchester County educators, and former Postmaster of the Village of Peekskill, died early today at his home here, 315 Union Avenue, after an illness of several months of ailments attributed to advanced age.

WASHINGTON, April 22 -- Developments in the investigation into brewery permits issued in New Jersey waited today upon a conference early next week between Attorney General Cummings and Dr. James M. Doran, head of the Bureau of Industrial Alcohol.

SAN JUAN, P.R., April 22 -- Officials of the American Legion here and delegates from all island posts have been called for a special conference tomorrow to devise a plan for counteracting what they consider an oversight, which, if it becomes operative, will discriminate against the island's pensioned veterans by classifying them with those residing in foreign countries, who are subject to a 50 per cent cut.

ROMANOF is a "fellow traveler," as Trotsky phrased it more generally and sympathetically read by the Western world than by Russia, Interested in the psychology of character and its moral issues in conduct and as yet unable to find a form for the plastic values of the New Russia, his conclusions are too hesitant to appeal to the proletariat.

Some very frank statements expressed in a manner totally different from the customary conventional discourses heard at usual dinner conferences were made by Douglas Grant Scott, vice president of the United States Realty and Improvement Company, at the monthly meeting last week of the Management Division of the Real Estate Board of New York.

LONDON. PROBABLY the day will come -- perhaps it is not very far away -- when the American citizen will enjoy the full legal right to have delivered to his table, if he happens to want it, a dark red bottle marked "Chambertin,'' dusty from having reposed since one of the better vintage years in a cool cellar in Burgundy.

HIS work marks an epoch in meteor astronomy," says Dr. Harlow Shapley of Dr. P.M. Millman, whose specialty is meteors. Although hundreds of meteorites have fallen to the earth and many of them have been cut open and chemically analyzed, there is need of just the study that Dr. Millman has made.

With world production of merchant ships down to its lowest volume in fifty years, marine experts throughout the world are studying improved methods for the construction of more efficient ships when the need for tonnage is again felt and operators order replacements, according to the National Council of American Shipbuilders.

Reminiscent of the most up-to-date country fairs will be the forthcoming Fifty-seventh Street fair, which will be held at Joseph, 3 East Fifty-seventh Street, on May 2, 3 and 4 for the benefit of the New York Cancer Committee and the New York Cancer Institute.
LONDON, April 22 -- An international petition concerning the position of the Jews in Germany will be sent to the German Government soon.

ST. LOUIS, April 20 -- The General Assembly, with Democrats in control of both houses, is nearing the end of its regular session, which started early in January, and Missourians may now estimate what the promised "new deal" has done for them.

FROM the days of the Roman legions down to the present time veterans' associations have often been formed in various countries for the purpose of obtaining pensions or other emoluments from their governments. The American Veterans Association, founded last September in Chattanooga, Tenn., and spreading rapidly over the country during the past few months, is probably the first ex-soldiers' organization to be set up for the purpose of opposing such favors.

Much is heard of the supposed advantages enjoyed in foreign trade by nations with depreciated currencies. It is said that they are able to offer their goods in world markets at lower costs, with the result that their export trade prospers at the expense of nations whose currencies have remained at par.

PARIS, April 21 -- The voluntary abandonment of the gold standard by the United States on the eve of the arrival of Prime Minister MacDonald and former Premier Edouard Herriot has upset more preconceived notions than anything that has happened in many years.

HAVRE DE GRACE, Md., April 22 -- The victory of Equipoise and the defeat of Repaid in their initial starts of the season were the high lights of an unusually fine racing program which was witnessed by s crowd of 15,000 at the local course today.

Inflation of currency does not hold much encouragement for any immediate improvement in the critcal situation of the average urban home owner, states A. Anton Friedrich, Assistant Professor of Economics at New York University.

EIGHTEEN photostats of front pages of THE NEW YORK TIMES, recording the news of historic flights, are among the interesting pictorial material in the current free exhibit at the Waldorf-Astoria being held to foster interest in the Charity Air Pageant, of which Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt accepted the honorary chairmanship last week.

BERLIN. In her latest novel, "Menschen unter Zwang" (Deutsche Verlagsanstalt. Stuttgart), Clara Viebig describes people in whom one trait predominates and with sinister power crushes all other qualities, to lead to ultimate destruction brought on by the terrible one-sidedness it has caused.

Ignace Jan Paderewski showed slight but steady Improvement yesterday, it was reported at the Ritz Tower Hotel, where he is confined because of an acute attack of lumbago which began about ten days ago. The pianist, who has been compelled to cancel all engagements, had been scheduled to receive the honorary degree of Doctor of Music tomorrow from New York University.

WASHINGTON, April 22 -- The Democrats in the House expect to catch up with President Roosevelt's program before the end of next week. When the House adjourns Friday or Saturday all the Roosevelt measures new before it will have been disposed of, if the plans of the leaders materialize, and all the indications are that they will.

BERLIN, April 22 -- The coordination of the Protestant Church with the National Socialist regime became a reality today in the State of Mecklenburg, where the Premier appointed a State Commissar who early this morning took over the entire legislative, juridical and episcopal power of the Lutheran Church, which heretofore had been in the hands of the Supreme Church Council.

WHATEVER weaknesses there may be in "Today We Live," the first pictorial adaptation of a story by William Faulkner, it is a production which often reveals the author's powers of observation, his fertile imagination and his sense of humor.

OYSTER BAY, L.I., April 22 -- The first point-to-point meeting of the recently combined Meadow Brook-Smithtown clubs was held near here today. The feature, a four-and-a-half-mile event for heavyweight hunters, was won by Award, the aged gelding owned by David Dows, Sheriff of Nassau County.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., April 22 -- Miss Anne Turner of Port Chester won the Good Hands Cup in one of the feature events of the fourth annual Saxon Woods Hunt Club Horse Show today on the club grounds. By her victory Miss Turner qualified for the Good Hands class at the 1933 National Horse Show.
To the Editor of The New York Times: It is necessary for me to say this for the good of my soul.

Old-fashioned gardeners, points out Stephen Reynolds, maintain, that there is nothing equal to rotted cow manure for roses. Modern science has never discovered, he adds, anything better, but other fertilizers are available which are convenient to use and equally effective.

Marking the seventeenth anniversary of the founding of the People's Chorus of New York, a Spring festival of song and dance will be held on the night of May 11 in the grand ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria for the benefit of the chorus and its free classes in ensemble singing.

GENEVA, April 21 -- Whatever forms the various talk at Washington may take and however many nations may participate in the dialogues, for international circles here this week-end represents above all the most serious attempt yet made by the three greatest democracies to work together since their common efforts founded the League of Nations.

The purchasing power of public employes has actually increased in the depression, according to a compilation prepared by John Scoville, chief statistician of the Chrysler Corporation. He details the effect of the slump in purchases of automobiles last year compared with 1929.

The activity in the listed bond market last week was unmatched since the week, ended on Jan. 16, 1932, when the financial community was viewing with satisfaction the plans for forming the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, the efforts of the Federal Reserve authorities to combat deflation and the airing of prospects of balancing the Federal budget.

PORTSMOUTH, N.H., April 22 (AP) -- Old Tom, Marine Corps warhorse, veteran of the Spanish War, went to his long rest today with rifles thundering a salute across his grave in the Portsmouth Navy Yard and a bugle blowing taps.

WASHINGTON, April 22 -- Secretary Hull's word to European powers that no "club" was sought in our monetary moves for use at the economic conference was designed to quiet fears abroad that such a weapon was the aim of the legislation.

IN the week just ended several group and one-man shows fell to the lot of this reviewer. Water-colors by eighteen of the younger Americans have gone on view at the Macbeth Galleries -- an exhibition that contains several pictures of outstanding merit.

WITH the return of legal beer that curious phenomenon of pre-war days, the German band, has reappeared in strength. Having passed into temporary oblivion when things Teutonic were unpopular and when even the bass drum of such a group might be searched for bombs or spy papers, it began to straggle back a few years ago.

THE Lewisohn Stadium concerts by the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra will be continued this year. The recent announcement to this effect is encouraging to the thousands of New Yorkers and visitors who seek surcease from the Summer heat at the Stadium concerts every evening.

TO acquaint "the world at large" with the new State of Manchukuo, "which is here to stay," is the raison d'etre of the book under review, in which Mr. K.K. Kawakaml tells the story ot the conflict in Manchuria between Japan and China, and describes the advent of the State to which that conflict gave birth.
NEW YORK. Andre de Laboulaye, the French Ambassador, is at the Pierre.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The downward revision of tariffs throughout the world and the actual lifting of the universal trade barriers of every description have become the most pressing problems confronting the economic life of the present generation.

Whether the United States was forced off the gold standard or simply quit voluntarily is being debated in Europe. The prevailing view seems to be that the action was taken under no compulsion. In the circumstances, sharp criticism has been directed against the authorities here.

TOKYO, Sunday, April 23 -- The reopening of the naval base at Port Arthur has produced repercussions in London concerning the legitimacy of Japan's act in view of Article XIX of the Washington treaty, aimed at maintaining the status quo in the Pacific by prohibiting any increase in fortifications or naval bases in certain territories of signatory powers.
Inflation, if it materializes as expected, will bring with it five major developments in retail merchandising, according to views expressed by leading retail executives here during the week.
Commodities resumed their advance after a day's interruption in most cases on the local exchanges yesterday. Trading volumes continued to run at high levels.
WASHINGTON, April 22 -- After a morning devoted to conferences, Prime Minister MacDonald and his daughter gave themselves over to enjoyment of the social side of life in the capital.

VIENNA, April 21 -- The return of Chancellor Dollfuss from Rome this week with the assurance of Italy's support for his campaign to defend Austrian independence against German Hitlerism seems to mark the turning point in the history of this little country, which has hitherto regarded itself -- for publication, at least -- as the immediate spiritual and ultimate physical partner of Germany.

THE Pilgrims' dinner, with the British Premier Ramsay MacDonald at the microphone, is one of radio's high spots this week. Shakespeare, who wrote of airy spirits and of Puck girdling the earth in forty minutes, will be the theme of several broadcasts celebrating the anniversary of his birth.

WASHINGTON, April 22 -- A total of 24,136,879 motor vehicles were registered in the United States last year, State authorities have reported to the Bureau of Public Roads of the Department of Agriculture. This is a decline of 6.6 per cent from 1930.

WHEN the Volstead act was passed and just before it was repealed dozens of physicians and psychologists appeared before Congressional committees to answer the question: How much alcohol is intoxicating? Last year there appeared a volume, edited by Dr. Haven Emerson, which bore the title "Alcohol and Man: The Effects of Alcohol on Man in Health and in Disease."

There has been an encouraging subscription for the performance of "One Sunday Afternoon" on the night of May 3 at the Forty-eighth Street Theatre, in behalf of the Catholic Centre for the Blind. Mrs. Jacob L. Phillips is president of the organization, which is under the patronage of Cardinal Hayes and the Right Rev. Michael J. Lavelle.

Masterly pitching by Walter Signer proved an important factor as New York University's baseball team triumphed over Georgetown, 9 -- 1, at Ohio Field yesterday. The Violet twirler, undefeated thus far in intercollegiate competition, limited the Hoyas to five scattered hits and recorded twelve strikeouts.

PHILADELPHIA, April 22 (AP) -- How he kept up a nine-minute telephone conversation with a man who threatened his life, while police raced to make the arrest, was described today by Lessing J. Rosenwald, wealthy philanthropist.

ALBANY April 22 -- In a new order issued late today, the State Milk Control Board directed that the minimum basis retail price of 10 cents a quart for delivered Milk which became effective on Monday, shall apply to all up-State dealers within a radius of three miles of a city or village.

HERE is the thrilling story of how, by the agreement of some of the greatest experts and critics upon old paintings, another portrait of Shakespeare has been authenticated as a picture painted from life and so added to the meager list of authentic representations of the great dramatist.

PALO ALTO, Cal., April 22 -- Without the aid of its super-star, Big Ben Eastman, Stanford ended the track and field dominance of Southern California today by defeating the national champions of the last three years, 67 to 64, in the West's annual dual meet classic.

IN the view of engineers, Reo's new car without a gearshift lever has a vital significance quite apart from its effect upon driving ease. While in the absence of mechanical details they are loath to discuss this particular development, the automotive experts point to interesting potentialities along the line of the automatic transmission, upon which many of them are at the moment working.

Only the elephants and the calliope were missing when the circus made its traditional visit to Bellevue yesterday to help the sick to forget and laugh. But who cares for a missing elephant when Kiji Kolan can walk on his head and clowns can whack each other with brooms and 600 children and 1,500 of the older population of Bellevue set up a merry din that re-echoes from across the East River?

MEXICO CITY. MEXICO'S Interest in the glories of the colonial period in her history is still very active. One of the most famous literary lights of Mexico in the time of Spain's domination was Sister Juana Inez de la Cruz, a very beautiful nun, who was the author of perhaps the greatest poetry written by any Spanish or Spanish-American woman.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., April 22 -- Holy Cross defeated Brown, 6 to 0, today in the opening game for each team. Mulligan fanned sixteen Brown batters and Humphries of Brown struck out twelve Holy Cross men in the eight innings he worked.

FOR many years Mr. BedfordJones has been an immensely prolific contributor of misceilaneous adventure fiction to the pulp magazines, the best of his output issued in book form having been a number of excellently told swashbuckling romances of seventeenth-century France in the Dumas tradition.

ED WYNN, after a year's cruise on the air waves, finds his assignment of being a merry wag a more serious business than ever before. When the shrill fire siren shrieks across the nation's rooftops next Tuesday and the strangely garbed chief answers the call on the stage of the New Amsterdam Roof, it will mark his fifty-second summons in as many weeks.

EASTER shopping activity carried over briskly into the post-holiday period last week and enabled most of the stores hero to run ahead of the figures of a year ago. Improved buying sentiment that followed the bank holiday, and received additional stimulus through the legalizing of beer, was lifted further by the spectacular response of security and commodity prices to the inflationary steps taken and proposed at Washington.

THIS season it's Ann Barrie of the Brooklyn Finnegans, mind you, and as dashing a colleen as ever came across the river to work her way from chorus girl, understudy and into a principal role all in one season. Like a true Finnegan of the song, she was "off ag'in, on ag'in" and finally "in ag'in."

PALO ALTO, Cal., April 22 -- Without the aid of its super-star, Big Ben Eastman, Stanford ended the track and field dominance of Southern California today by defeating the national champions of the last three years, 67 to 64, in the West's annual dual meet classic.

IN the view of engineers, Reo's new car without a gearshift lever has a vital significance quite apart from its effect upon driving ease. While in the absence of mechanical details they are loath to discuss this particular development, the automotive experts point to interesting potentialities along the line of the automatic transmission, upon which many of them are at the moment working.

But who cares for a missing elephant when Kiji Kolan can walk on his head and clowns can whack each other with brooms and 600 children and 1,500 of the older population of Bellevue set up a merry din that re-echoes from across the East River?

One of the most famous literary lights of Mexico in the time of Spain's domination was Sister Juana Inez de la Cruz, a very beautiful nun, who was the author of perhaps the greatest poetry written by any Spanish or Spanish-American woman.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., April 22 -- Holy Cross defeated Brown, 6 to 0, today in the opening game for each team. Mulligan fanned sixteen Brown batters and Humphries of Brown struck out twelve Holy Cross men in the eight innings he worked.

FOR many years Mr. BedfordJones has been an immensely prolific contributor of misceilaneous adventure fiction to the pulp magazines, the best of his output issued in book form having been a number of excellently told swashbuckling romances of seventeenth-century France in the Dumas tradition.

The selection of SUMNER WELLES, Assistant Secretary of State, as Ambassador to Cuba is in the best tradition. He is a "career man," and for many years has not only made a study of Latin-American affairs but has filled positions of trust with tact and discretion.

Building totals in New York City and vicinity for the month of March indicate a gradual increase in construction contract awards. This rise in new building here may bring the total of awards for the second quarter of the year above the construction aggregate for the first quarter, according to the F.W. Dodge Corporation.

To the Editor of The New York Times: It doesn't make any difference whether one says "Broadway and Forty-second Street" or "Forty-second Street and Broadway," but it does make a difference whether one says that Mr. McAneny was twice elected to office on an antiTammany fusion ticket or that he was "twice elected to office on a Tammany anti-fusion ticket."
BOSTON, April 23 (AP). -- The Red Sox won their first victory at home today, defeating the Athletics, 7 to 5, in an uphill battle.

Joseph V. McKee, president of the Board of Aldermen, as guest speaker at Trinity Methodist Church of West New Brighton, S.I., yesterday, made a plea for Christian socialism as means of adjusting the social and material difference prevailing in the world.

Approximately 3,500 persons, including children, will be benefited by the provision of 1,000 "tide-over" jobs for unemployed men and women through the Adopt-a-Family Committee, Mrs. August Belmont, chairman of the committee, announced yesterday.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., April 23 -- In what was by far the most sensational workout to date of any of the Kentucky Derby candidates training here, Head Play, Mrs. Willie Crump's eligible, covered the full Derby distance of a mile and one-quarter in 2:07 4-5 today at Churchill Downs where the classic will be run May 6.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., April 23 -- Recommendations for the reorganization of the cotton textile industry are contained in a study to be published tomorrow by the Harvard Business School, "merchandising of cotton textiles; methods and organization."

HARTFORD, Conn., April 23 -- The eye can see and read a single number in three two-thousandths of a second on a new machine described tonight at Trinity College. The apparatus shows that the eye sees by a method at almost complete variance with modern textbook teachings.

CLEVELAND, April 23 -- Coordination of the Federal judicial system and those of the forty-eight States so that the United States Sunreme Court would have "final, authoritative word as to what the law is" was held up as an ideal today by Newton D. Baker in one of a series of radio talks over the Columbia System under the auspices of the American Bar Association.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Why not use land for the backing of further currency? In a fashion this has been done already on a small scale with no ill effects, in that the government, in March, printed bills that hanks could borrow for use on the surrender of suitable collateral.

NEW ORLEANS, April 23 -- Although the cotton market was comparatively quiet early last week, it was active in the last half. Although trading for some time before Wednesday had been largely professional, it broadened out on Wednesday and Thursday and showed no let-up in volume on Friday.

Mayor John P. O'Brien called upon the Catholics of the city yesterday to translate their faith into everyday life and make their lives a potential influence for the good of their fellow-men. The Mayor's appeal, broadcast by radio, was made at the annual communion breakfast of McGivney Council of the Knights of Columbus in the Hotel Astor.
Ed Brandt, star southpaw of Bill McKechnie's staff, pitched the Braves to victory over the Dodgers at Ebbets Field yesterday in a hotly contested duel with Walter Beck, first-year Brooklyn sensation.

Search for a racketeer czar who is alleged to have been extorting $50,000 a week from the live poultry industry in this city was begun late last night by Bronx detectives under Inspector Henry Bruckman, who are aware of the identity of their quarry.

Ruth St. Denis turned the calendar back twenty-seven years at the Mansfield Theatre last night when she presented in her program of East Indian dances two numbers which were features of her first appearance in 1906. The calendar, indeed, is apparently an outmanoeuvred enemy with Miss St. Denis, for she is amazingly youthful, and has lost not a vestige of that vitality which makes her always an arresting presence on the stage.

The 369th anniversary of the birth of Shakespeare was observed yesterday in the city by commemorative exercises in literary circles, on the stage and over the radio. Wreaths were placed on the statue of the poet on the Central Park Mall at ceremonies under the joint auspices of the National Shakespeare Federation and the Roerich-Shakespeare Association.

Municipal bankers and the investing public in the future will not regard municipal securities as a more or less homogeneous mass, but will recognize that localities, like industries, differ radically, Meech, Harmon, Lytle Blackmore of Buffalo, tax consultants, predict in an analysis of the present debt problems of the fifteen largest counties in this State.

For the last few days the elephants in the circus at Madison Square Garden have been behaving in a most unusual manner. The older members of the herd have been going through a series of pachydermic dance steps; the younger, after their first fits of astonishment, have swayed in cadence, imitating their seniors.

William Rabe, co-proprietor of Ebling's Casino, for years a noted restaurant and recreation resort at St. Ann's Avenue and 156th Street, the Bronx, was injured fatally in a fight with an unidentified assailant in the main barroom of the building early yesterday morning.

GENE SARAZEN'S proposal to enlarge the cup on the golf green met with what amounted to magnificent disregard by most golf authorities, although some few excitable chaps boiled over with proper fury at the bare suggestion of such vandalism in an ancient and honorable pastime.

More than 2,000 members of the Holy Name Society of the Fire Department, Branch 141, yesterday attended the annual communion breakfast of the organization at the Hotel Astor. They represented firemen's units in Manhattan, the Bronx and Richmond.

WASHINGTON, April 23 -- The conversations between President Roosevelt and Premier MacDonald today took place in the cabin of the President's yacht, a marked contrast with the British statesman's talks with President Hoover in 1931, when the two sat on a log at the Rapidan camp.

PARIS, April 23 -- Yesterday's Ministerial declaration that the present French Government will do everything possible to maintain the franc on the gold standard was repeated today by Premier Deladier in a speech to constituents in his home town of Orange in this form:

Justice Edward F. Boyle of the Manhattan Children's Court, in an address to 150 alumni of the Fordham Preparatory School at their annual communion breakfast at the college dining hall, said the children's court system here was superior to any in the world.

AUSTIN, Texas, April 23 -- The maximum allowable production of the East Texas oil field was increased today to approximately 791,000 barrels daily from 400,000 barrels daily which has been in effect during the last few weeks.
TIENTSIN, April 23 (AP). -- Fears that a political upheaval will follow a Japanese invasion of North China gripped Tientsin today.

Card parties in connection with luncheons, muscales and teas will be held in the near future for the benefit of various charitable enterprises, several being planned for this week. There has been a large subscription for the annual luncheon and bridge in behalf of the Catholic Young Women's Club on Thursday at the Central Park Casino.

M. Zilinski and J.C. Couzens tied for the High Scratch Cup in the invitation skeet shoot over the Travers Island traps of the New York Athletic Club yesterday. Each finished with a card of 45 out of 50 targets. Couzens won the shoot-off 22 -- 21.

Manuel Quezon, President of the Philippine Senate, arrived yesterday on the French liner Ile de France to discuss at Washington the Philippine independence act passed by Congress last January over the veto of President Hoover. He was accompanied by a delegation of eight prominent Filipinos.

ALBANY, April 23 -- Included in a batch of bills amending the banking and insurance laws which have been approved by Governor Lehman are several measures which will enable banking and insurance corporations holding real estate investments to adjust themselves to the situation caused by the shrinking of real estate values and the difficulties of mortgagors in attempting to meet interest and maturity payments.

Prompt passage by the Municipal Assembly of Mayor O'Brien's executive budget bill as an essential step in the restoration of the city's credit was urged yesterday by Peter Grimm, chairman of the board of trustees of the Citizens Budget Commission.

DETROIT, April 23 (AP). -- A single by West in the eighth inning spoiled Tommy Bridges's chance for a no-hit game today, but the Tigers defeated the St. Louis Browns, 2 to 0, in a tight pitchers' battle. Bridges walked three men and hit another.

Georgetown University suffered its second baseball setback in two days when it bowed to St. John's College of Brooklyn, 8 to 7, after graining a 7-to-0 lead in the first inning at Dexter Park in Wood-haven yesterday.

Mayor John P. O'Brien headed a class of ninety-one candidates initiated last night into membership in New York Lodge 1, B.P.O. Elks, at the Elks Home, 108 West Forty-third Street. More than 1,500 from various sections of the East were at the meeting and initiation.

CHICAGO, April 23 -- Heavy speculative buying of wheat on the part of the general public with professional traders here in Chicago and in the East taking active part created the largest volume of business in a single day that the trade has known of late, 111,000,000 bushels on Thursday.

St. Mark's-in-the-Bouwerie celebrated its 134th anniversary yesterday with a sermon from the Rev. Dr. William Norman Guthrie, the rector, explaining the significance of his victory at last Tuesday's parish meeting, when he succeeded in ousting a vestry hostile to him.
By sweeping two double-headers during the past week, Columbia continued to set a fast pace in the Eastern Intercollegiate Baseball League race. The Lions have won all five of their league games.
WASHINGTON, April 23 -- Arriving here today for the preliminary conversations on world economics, Premier Herriot proclaimed a spirit of greatest cooperation and goodwill.

A solemn service of thanksgiving was held yesterday in the Collegiate Reformed Church of St. Nicholas, Fifth Avenue and Forty-eighth Street, in commemoration of the 400th anniversary of the birth of William the Silent, Prince of Orange.
ST. LOUIS, April 23 (AP). -- Effective pitching in the first game and a weak defense by the Cardinals in the second gave the Pirates both ends of a double-header today, 4 to 0 and 6 to 2.

A program of entertainment has been arranged in connection with the garden party to be held at Welwyn, the estate of Mr. and Mrs. Harold Irving Pratt of Glen Cove, L.I., on the afternoon of May 19 for the benefit of the North Country Community Hospital.

While the income from the more than 275,000 members of the 262 Y.M.H.A. and Y.W.H.A. organizations and Jewish community centres has decreased appreciably in the last year, the attendance at mass functions and other Jewish activities has increased appreciably, according to a survey of the effect of the depression upon Jewish recreational institutions, completed recently by the National Jewish Welfare Board.

ROME, April 23 (AP) -- Finance Minister Guido Jung, Italy's delegate to the preliminary world economic discussions in Washington, in an interview on the eye of his departure for America, said tonight that he was taking two fundamental points of view with him:

The City Affairs Committee announced that it had asked Mayor O'Brien to give the voters of New York City a "sporting chance to choose between a Tammany charter and a Seabury charter" by modifying his charter bill to permit the election instead of the appointment of a charter commission.

Within sixteen hours of the death of his 3-year-old brother, Samuel, James Gormley Jr., aged 4, died yesterday morning in Roosevelt Hospital of colitis. The death of both boys was attributed by the police to food poisoning caused by the eating Friday night of canned corned beef that had stood overnight in an un-iced refrigerator.

During the year ended Dec. 31, 1932, the city's rapid transit lines, street cars, buses and the Hudson tubes carried 2,830,900,000 passengers, according to a report made public yesterday by the Transit Commission. The total, which includes the traffic on the city's independent Eighth Avenue subway, fell short of the 1931 figures by 229,800,000 riders, or a drop of 7.5 per cent.

Without referring directly to the administration's program for inflation, the Guaranty Trust Company, in its monthly survey, issued today, strongly condemns all inflationary schemes as dangerous and likely to hamper rather than to promote business recovery.

The annual traffic report of the Transit Commission shows once snore how seriously travel has been slowed down by the depression. Street cars, elevated lines, subways -- all forms of public mass transportation in the city, underground and above, with the single exception of the bus lines show a marked falling off in patronage during last year.

Germany is described as "the classic land of anti-Semitic ideology," where the movement against the Jews has been an active force since 1871, in Josef Kastein's "History and Destiny of the Jews," published today by the Viking Press.

AKRON, April 23 -- The new dirigible Macon returned to her berth early this evening after a test cruise of nearly thirteen hours, her second flight, which naval officials and others described as an excelent demonstration of lighter-than-air efficiency.

The conversations between President Roosevelt and Prime Minister MacDonald of Great Britain were referred to yesterday morning by the clergy of New York City as an instance of the international application of the golden rule, a reminder of our blood relationship with all other nations and as a possibility for the leaders of the two great English-speaking nations, to carry forward the divine plan in the spirit of Jesus Christ.

To the Editor of The New York Times: It was the redwing's choral medley and the blossoming of willows that told me Spring had come to Little River. Pussy-willows and Little River! The combination compelled a lover of Henry van Dyke's cheerful prose and tuneful verse to write him, as I have before when the same event brought to mind his apt characterization of bird or blossom in nature.

WASHINGTON, April 23 -- Closer consultation between Prime Minister MacDonald of Great Britain and former Premier Herriot of France on their visits here than had previously been expected was indicated tonight when it was announced at the British Embassy and the White House that they would confer.

MOSCOW, April 23 -- All foreigners in Moscow are wondering about this Metropolitan-Vickers trial. And there are two major doubts. First, why did the Bolsheviki carry out the trial just when they did, although an Anglo-Soviet trade pact was nearly signed and although the trial may have affected the chances of recognition of the Soviet Union by the United States?

Leitrim won the 1932 New York State Gaelic football championship yesterday, defeating Tipperary, 18 to 6, at Innisfail Park before a crowd of 6,000. Preliminaries were played last season, the semi-finals and final being deferred until this year.

AMSTERDAM, April 22 --The future course of the dollar Is considered dependent on the deliberate policy of the American Government. If the dollar Is left free, its depreciation Is not expected to go beyond 10 per cent, but uncertainty remains as to the aims of President Roosevelt In view of the competition of depreciated currencies.

All kinds of magazines have felt the stress of hard times, though the news stands still keep a brave front, and some have had to suspend publication. One kind which seldom makes a public appearance is losing heavily under the economic pressure.
Sam Schmukler of Philadelphia won the national Y.M.H.A. four-wall handball singles championship yesterday at the Ninety-second Street Branch by defeating his brother, Harry, 31 -- 8, in the final.

Edwin Markham, poet, and author of "The Man With the Hoe," celebrated his eighty-first birthday yesterday by addressing the congregation of All Souls' Universalist Church, Ditmas and Ocean Avenues, Brooklyn. His address opened a three-day celebration in his honor in Brooklyn and Manhattan.

GREAT NECK, L.I., April 23 -- Tames Irving Bush, broker and sportsman, his wife, the former Mrs. Virginia Van Sant Alvord, and Mr. and Mrs. George Djamgaroff of 71 East Seventy-first Street, New York, are recovering today from injuries received last night when an automobile driven by Mr. Bush crashed into a telephone pole on Hicks Lane here.
BERLIN, April 23 -- Under the impetus of the "national resurgence," German Freemasonry is hastily nationalizing itself. This is the only condition under which it can survive in the new Germany.

MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., April 23 -- Having run an impressive first series, which was characterized by style, dash and notable bird work, Tip's Lady Montrose was awarded first money today in the open all age stake which ended the second annual Spring field trial meeting of the Sport and Conservation League.

CHICAGO, April 23 (AP). -- Ted Lyons turned back the Indians with two hits and supplied the home-run drive which scored the winning runs today to give the White Sox their second straight triumph of the series. The score was 4 to 1.

No more can "lowbrow" be considered a belittling term. To be a "lowbrow" is to be (according to the measurements made by Dr. HRDLICKA of the Smithsonian Institution) in the same class with the presumed "cream of the nation's intellect," the members of the National Academy of Science.

BERLIN, April 23 -- The anti-Jewish campaign of the National Socialists today crushed all German hopes of victory in the play for the Davis Cup by officially eliminating Daniel Prenn, the outstanding German tennis player, from the team.

LONDON, April 22 -- The money market here has not been affected by the American gold developments. which, in fact, must tend to accentuate rather Than diminish the present abnormal ease. The callmoney rate and rates for shortdated bills have declined to one quarter of 1 per cent.

Somebody on The Evening Sun has a heart for those unfortunates who are choking and gasping and trying vainly to tread water on the illimitable sea of contemporary literature. He or she has interviewed Mr. THOMAS STEARNS ELIOT, that accomplished and subtle poet and critic who, to the loss of the United States, couldn't resist the temptation to belong elsewhere.

BOSTON, April 23 -- A New York dinghy flotilla drove the New England boats from their own waters today in the concluding races of the intersectional regatta sailed under the colors of the Boston Dinghy Club. The invaders took the first four places in Class B and first place in Class A.

Debutantes in the costume of Salvation Army lassies, will present scenes from "The Belle of New York" at the tambourine bridge party to be given Wednesday afternoon at the Plaza. The event has been arranged by women in society in behalf of the Salvation Army United Appeal.

A fashion show for the benefit of the Emergency Exchange Association will be held on May 2 in the ballroom of the home of Mrs. Payne Whitney, 972 Fifth Avenue. Prominent women will act as models. They will wear their favorite costumes, irrespective of style, and it is expected that many unique and interesting creations of former years will be seen.

BERLIN, April 22 -- The decision of the United States to abandon the dollar gold standard after successfully overcoming the domestic bank crisis came as a complete surprise and fell like a bombshell In financial Berlin.
SAN FRANCISCO, April 23 -- Frank P. Walsh of New York, chief counsel for Thomas J. Mooney, arrived in San Francisco today after a cross-continent airplane dash.

So does JAMES T. SHOTWELL describe the "depression." As general editor of the "Economic and Social History of the World War" he has gathered into 150 volumes evidence of the war's part in bringing about the present disturbed state of civilization.

LONDON, April 23 -- A vast crowd thronging the Liverpool Street Railway Station cheered wildly this morning when they caught the first glimpse of Allan Monkhouse, John Cushny, Charles Nordwall and A. W. Gregory, who were tried in Moscow.

PHILADELPHIA, April 23 -- New York University has drawn the No. 4 lane for the one-mile college relay championship event, one of the principal features, of the annual University of Pennsylvania relay carnival, to be held next Friday and Saturday on Franklin Field.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., April 23 -- Forty-six varsity letters in basketball, fencing, swimming, water polo and wrestling were awarded today by Professor George E. Little, director of physical education at Rutgers University. Special awards were granted to four members of the swimming team for their relay victory in the national collegiate championships and to Walter Spence for breaking the intercollegiate 100-yard free-style record.

CHICAGO, April 23 -- Prices for hogs started last week with, a top of $3.95 a hundredweight but they broke 15 cents and recovered finally to $3.90. The average for the week was $3.70, or the same as the previous week and 10 cents below last year.

BERLIN, April 23 -- The first stage of the German overturn may now be said to have ended. The democratic republic has been overthrown, its Constitution has been abrogated and every possible relic of it -- almost every memory-has been obliterated.

To the solemn strains of "The Old Rugged Cross," sung by a congregation of 4,000 persons, and the usky tremolos of "Underneath the Harlem Moon" by Miss Ethel Waters, the Rescue Society at 5-7 Ooyers Street, known as the "Cathedral of the Underworld," celebrated its fortieth anniversary yesterday.

Three revivals are listed for Broadway presentation within the next few weeks. Two of them will arrive on May 1. They are "The Yeomen of the Guard," at the St. James Theatre, and "Springtime for Henry," at the Ambassador. On May 8 "It's A Wise Child" will come to the Forrest Theatre.
PITTSBURGH, April 23 -- Activity in the steel Industry Increased sharply again last week. Production of ingots was estimated at 22 per cent against 18 per cent in the preceding week.

Raveled and untraceable ancestry, purring qualities, bluebird complexes and intelligence tests all figured in the judging yesterday at the fourth annual pet show of the New York League for Animals, Inc., in the ballroom of the Hotel Roosevelt.

An attempt to obtain a court decision clarifying their status in Moving Picture Machine Operators Union, Local 306, has been started by more than 200 "permit men" of the local, it was learned yesterday.
A series of entertainments to be given this week began yesterday ushering in the celebration of the fortieth anniversary of the Henry Street Settlement.

Manhattan Beach, one of the more pretentious of the Brooklyn seaside resorts, was up in arms yesterday when its residents discovered that its shores had been invaded by a mystery ship, manned only by a mysterious watchman.

Patrolman Michael Dignon was on watch at the headquarters of Emergency Squad 6 at 209 East 122d Street yesterday at 10 A.M. when a routine alarm came in over the teletype concerning a hold-up by two men of a beer garden at 1.861 Park Avenue.

TOKYO, April 23 (AP). -- A. Rengo (Japanese) News Agency dispatch from Kupei Pass today said that four hours of bitter fighting had carried Major Gen. Tadashi Kawahara's Japanese lines beyond Shangsuntze, nine miles southwest of Kupei.

General Edward J. Higgins, head of the Salvation Army of the world, is to arrive today on the North German Lloyd liner Europa for a tour of inspection in the United States and Canada. Others due to arrive from the Channel ports include:
NEW YORK. J. Herman van Royen, Minister from the Netherlands, and Mme. van Royen are at the Barclay.
The works of Shakespeare should be our "lay bible," the Rev. Dr. J. Fort Newton of St. James Church, Philadelphia, declared yesterday in his sermon at St. Paul's Chapel, Columbia University.
Edouard Herriot of France arrived in New York Harbor yesterday and sped on to Washington for the White House conversations on economic problems.
WASHINGTON, April 23 -- French experts who are in close touch with recent events in America have greatly encouraged M. Herriot by their reports.
The trout fishermen of this country keep a small army of men busy producing fish with which to stock the streams, with the result that millions of trout are taken annually.

BISMARCK had his famous secret treaty of "Reinsurance." What the Washington Administration is now offering, in connection with its monetary policy, is a series of reassurances. Secretary HULL has sent one abroad to be communicated to European Governments.

BERLIN, April 23 -- Following Nazi efforts to control Protestant German church life, Dr. Hermann Kapler, president of the German Evangelical Church Commission, has summoned leading theologists and pastors as advisers to cooperate in the drafting of a new Protestant constitution.

Obligations of the United States Government which will mature in 1933 amount to $3,179,516,500 against $3,179,360,500 a week ago. They consist of Treasury certificates of indebtedness and noninterest-bearing bills.

WASHINGTON, April 23 -- In an effort by the government to sell its securities to small investors, Secretary Woodin announced today an issue of $500,000,000 in three-year 2 7/8 per cent Treasury notes, dated May 2 reserving the right to increase the offering by an amount sufficient to allot in full all subscriptions up to $10,000.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., April 23 -- A combination of a Winter breeze and a bright, sun-lit sky provided an odd mixture for the sailing Dinghy Regatta at the New Rochelle Yacht Club today. Ten boats were put through eleven races.

SAN JUAN, P.R., April 23 -- More than twenty-five prominent persons have been jailed in the Dominican Republic for opposition to reported plans of General Rafael L. Trujillo to continue as President by proclamation, contrary to the Constitution, at the expiration of his elective term next year, according to Federico Velazquez, former Vice President and many times Minister of Finance.

A rival plan of reorganization for the International Combustion Engineering Corporation, sponsored by Stuart Hedden, chairman of the preferred stockholders' protective committee, was issued last night, followed closely by a statement of E.W. Stetson, chairman of the reorganization committee, in which the Hedden plan is criticized in detail.

Retailers turned their attention last week to the purchase of goods for May promotions and a stead stream of orders appeared in the wholesale markets for merchandise for all departments. Coats for the Summer are shown in sheer goods the material being double to eliminate a lining.

BERLIN, April 22 -- The Immediate effect of the abandonment of the gold standard on American domestic industry is predicted here as beneficial, but only if prices rise considerably. It is remarked that if $3,000,000,000 really is added to 'circulation, an industrial boom of the "flight from the dollar" character might be expected and a corresponding wild advance in stock quotations.

WASHINGTON, April 23 -- One of the most important undertakings thus far in the operatic field by the students of the Juilliard Graduate School opened the 1933 festival of chamber music maintained by the Elizabeth Sprague Coolidge Foundation in the music room of the Library of Congress this evening.

WASHINGTON, April 23 -- The deadlock over the administration proposal to reduce the army by at least 3,000 officers and to effect other large economies in the military service is expected to be broken within a few days, when Secretary Dern and his General Staff assistants capitulate to the virtual "order" of Lewis Douglas, Director of the Budget, backed by President Roosevelt.

RIDGEFIELD PARK, N.J., April 23 -- Following the discovery last night that three children, one only ten months old, had been left alone for more than twenty-four hours in an apartment at 17 Teaneck Road here, Judge Thomas L. Zimmerman of the Bergen County Juvenile Court at Hackensack issued warrants today for the arrest of the parents, Samuel B. Halderman Jr., 25 years old, and his wife, Dorothy.
WASHINGTON, April 23 -- The votes in the Senate and House by the delegations from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut on important roll-calls last week are given in the appended tabulation:

PARIS, April 22 -- The decision of President Roosevelt to suspend the gold standard caused deep surprise in French financial circles. The prevailing opinion is that from a technical viewpoint the dollar situation did not justify such a decision.

Fred Titzell of the Millrose A.A. set a new course record yesterday in the four and a half mile road run from the Lenox Hill A.A. clubhouse, sponsored by the Manhattan Athletic League. Although finishing in fourteenth position, Titzell was clocked in 23:20, well under the previous mark of 24:12 that bad been set by William Thurston of the German-American A.C.

Dr. James T. Shotwell, Professor of History at Columbia University and director of the division of economics and history of the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace, described the present depression as "the last battle of the World War," in a report to the trustees of the endowment, made public yesterday.

Newspaper publishers from every corner of the nation -- from metropolis and small town alike -- began arriving in New York last night for the annual meeting of The Associated Press. They came prepared to discuss their mutual problems; to settle matters of future policy; to hear a luncheon address today by Senator Joseph T. Robinson, administration floor leader in the Senate; to talk about problems of news gathering and dissemination, and to elect officers.

A large increase in expenditures for home relief in the first three months of this year is shown in the quarterly report of the Department of Public Welfare, which administers this form of relief, made public yesterday by Commissioner Frank J. Taylor after its submission to Mayor John P. O'Brien.

Activity the like of which has not teen seen since 1929 gave all local commodity markets sensational gains in price last week. Some advances were substantially reduced in late reaction, but Saturday's recovery allowed all markets to close at good upturns.

Many Brain Parts. Dr. CRILB says the brain consists of, approximately, 4,000,000,000,000,000 little dynamos. From he point of view of human control it is a question whether this discovery simplifies things.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Bernard Shaw's "political harangue" at the Metropolitan Opera House recently carried me back twenty-six years to the House of Commons and the politics of London in 1907.

INNSBRUCK, Austria, April 23 -- In what was generally regarded as a test of strength the Nazis scored a sweeping success at the municipal elections held here today. The steady growth of Hitlerism in Austria was indicated when the National Socialists became the greatest party in the Tyrolian capital, heretofore considered the stronghold of legitimate clericalism.
CHICAGO, April 23 (AP) -- Public utility regulatory program without precedent In point of stringency are emerging from the mass of proposals tossed into the legislative hoppers of the nation.

BABYLON, L.I., April 23 -- Fire, caused by a leak in a portable gasoline stove on the converted fishing sloop Zingara this afternoon, resulted in two explosion that wrecked the sloop and hurled four of the seventeen persons aboard into Great South Bay.

The ninety-first season of the Philharmonic - Symphony Society and the Beethoven cycle came to a simultaneous and triumphant close at Carnegie Hall yesterday afternoon. The capacity audience paid genuine, unreserved homage to Arturo Toscanini at the end as he finished directing his superb orchestra in an electric interpretation of the "Leonore" overture, No. 3.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In regard to your editorial entitled "Languages on the Air," which appeared in today's paper, we wish to call your attention to the fact that WOR ever since Oct. 1 has given a course for beginners entitled "French for Little Folks."
"Little ol' Boy," a play by Albert Bein, will open this evening at the Playhouse. Included in its cast are Ara Gerald, Burgess Meredith, Edwin Philips and John Drew Colt.

Rotund Freddy Fitzsimmons put on a high-class one-man show yesterday at the Polo Grounds for the edification of 20,000 fans, the largest crowd of the early season at the park, and placed the Giants in second position in the league standing.

HAVANA, April 23 (AP). -- The creation of a new political party which will work for re-establishment of the Constitution of 1901 and the restoration of constitutional guarantees was announced tonight by General Ernesto Asbert, former Governor of Havana Province.

The protective committee representing holders of Northeastern Public Service Company generallien and collateral-trust 5 1/2 per cent gold bonds is advising depositing and non-depositing bondholders that more than 27 per cent of the total issue has been deposited with the depositories, and that it has committed itself to a program that will involve foreclosure proceedings under the general-lien indenture, assuming the cooperation of the bondholders through deposit of their bonds.

The international economic situation and the action of the United States in going off the gold standard were referred to yesterday in sermons delivered in many of the city's churches. Some preachers emphasized that plans for economic rehabilitation must be accompanied by moral rehabilitation, not only on the part of individuals but of nations.

The "limited dictatorship" that the people of the United States "seem to be ready" to give to President Roosevelt, was commended by the Rev. Dr. Charles J. Smith, president of Roanoke College, Salem, Va., preaching yesterday morning in Holy Trinity Lutheran Church, Central Park West and Sixty-fifth Street, at the celebration of its sixty-fifth anniversary.

The solidarity with which all religious faiths in America have met the challenge of Jewish persecutions in Germany has been heartening, Dr. Will Durant, author and lecturer, told members of the Free Synagogue yesterday morning in Carnegie Hall.

WASHINGTON, April 23 -- Presidetn Roosevelt turned the tables on a crew of fishing skippers who arrived here today in the Gloucester fishing schooner Gertrude L. Thebaud, seeking aid for their industry. Instead of waiting to hear from them, the Chief Executive greeted the visitors at the waterfront.

Of last week's spectacular events In foreign exchange and the home markets, the administration's renewal of the embargo on gold exports was Itself of minor Importance. That action was an easy possibility, from the moment of the President's proclamation a month ago.

Introduction of the inflation bill was quickly followed by a cry of alarm and warning from organized labor. The president of the American Federation of Labor declared Friday that it was "determined "to safeguard the interests of "wage earners by insisting upon "increases in wages immediately."

Harper and Brothers point with some pride to the fact that they have three first novels by young women in their twenties on their Spring list, although there have been rumors that first novels are unwelcome in publishers' offices at present.

MUNICH, Bavaria, April 23 -- Need for party discipline was made the keynote of the speech of Chancellor Adolf Hitler before the private congress of National Socialist leaders from all parts of Germany, which was held in the Council Chamber of the Munich City Hall today.

SHANGHAI, April 23 -- The restoration of Soviet relations with China, severed since 1927, assumed official shape today with the arrival of Dmitri Bogomoloff, the new Soviet Ambassador, and a staff of ten, including a consul general for Shanghai.

To the Editor of The New York Times: It was interesting to read in Topics of The Times that many of the letters reaching Secretary of Labor Perkins urge the establishment of large scale barter. But is not your writer tilting at the wrong windmill when he asks, "How can one have barter on a large scale without falling back into the clutches of that familiar monster, the Price System?"

Arturo Toscanini and the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra will repeat the Beethoven cycle next season, it was announced yesterday. Besides the first eight symphonies, the "Emperor" concerto and various other works played during the past five Sundays, the 1933-34 cycle will include Beethoven's two great choral works -- the Ninth Symphony and the Missa Solemnis.

BUFFALO, N.Y., April 23 (AP). -- With a total of 16 points scored against one of the fastest fields ever to participate in a national title meet, Miss Katherine Rawls, Fort Lauderdale, Fla., youngster, today was established as the star of the four-night senior National A.A.U. swimming championships completed here last night.

CHICAGO, April 23 -- Increases in the volume of business and in prices are believed by business leaders here to be in prospect. Talk of inflation is general and a steady revival of the volume of buying, manufacturing and distribution is expected.

WASHINGTON, April 23 -- The Yankees appeared all poised for their eighth successive triumph as they were about to conclude their first engagement of the year with the Senators today when something fell on them in a manner that caused 25,000 staid Washingtonians to lose all sense of dignity.

CINCINNATI. April 23 (AP). -- The Reds put on a whirlwind rally in the ninth today and won their second game of the season, 4 to 3, from the Cubs. A triple by Harry Rice, with Hafey and Hemsley on the bases, produced the winning pair of runs.

MUNICH, April 13 -- Perhaps the biggest surprise in the amazing triumph of Hitlerism was provided by the collapse of all opposition in Bavaria, where a member of the government, only a fortnight before the elections, had proudly proclaimed that any Reich Commissioner appointed for Bavaria would be arrested on the Bavarian frontier.

Rochester regained second place from Newark in the International League standing yesterday by turning back the Bears in both sections of a double header at Ruppert's Stadium, Newark. The scores were 5 to 3 and 3 to 2.

WASHINGTON, April 23 -- The Hoover Republican forces, which controlled the government at Washington for four years and went down in overwhelming defeat in November, have started a counter move to regain command at the capital.

The Central of Georgia Railway, now in receivership, announced yesterday that funds to pay the coupons due on May 1 on the 5 per cent collateral trust bonds maturing May 1.1947, of the Central Railroad and Banking Company of Georgia, have been deposited with the Central Hanover Bank and Trust Company, trustee.

LONDON, April 22 -- The Economist's index of British commodity prices in sterling, based on 1927 as 100, stands at 59.6 as of April 19, against 59.3 on April 5 and 62.7 a year ago. The numbers for the different groups were as follows:

LONDON, April 22 -- America's abandonment of the gold standard has undoubtedly come as a great shock not only to Great Britain but also to Europe as a whole. Calmer views are now being taken of this action, and attempts are being made to find some real justification for it, but it would be Idle to deny that a feeling of considerable resentment has been aroused.

A Federal court jury which had been deliberating for six hours and a half on the guilt or innocence of five election officials of the Fourth Assembly District was taken to a hotel and locked up for the night at 10:30 o'clock last night by order of Federal Judge John C. Knox.

Wall Street gave a fairly warm reception yesterday to the Treasury's new offering of $500,000,000 2 7/8 per cent three-year notes dated May 2. Bankers related that, following a slow start in the morning, orders came in at a faster pace as the day progressed and that outstanding obligations of the Treasury mounted in price.

Louis H. Willard, who was acquitted recently of the charge that he gave perjured testimony before the Hofstadter committee against William J. Flynn, Bronx Commissioner of Public Works, ended his life with poison yesterday in a room at the Hotel New Yorker.

WASHINGTON, April 24 (AP) -- The appeal of certain members of Local 167 of the International Brotherhood of Chauffeurs, Teamsters, Stablemen and Helpers of America and of the Official Orthodox Poultry Slaughterers of America, Inc., was entertained today by the Supreme Court.
WASHINGTON, April 24 -- The text of the joint statement issued by President Roosevelt and Prime Minister MacDonald late this afternoon read:

Despite the decline in property values and the large number of vacancies in many buildings on the lower east side of Manhattan, a large number of land owners have kept up their tax payments and only a small percentage are more than a year in arrears, according to the East Side Chamber of Commerce.
"Man Bites Dog," a farce by Don Lochbiler and Arthur Barton, will have its premiere this evening at the Lyceum Theatre under the managemen of Theron Bamberger and Bernard Klawans.
NEW YORK. Friedrich. W. von Prittwitz und Gaffron, the retiring German Ambassador, and Frau von Prittwitz und Gaffron are at the Ambassador.

WASHINGTON, April 24 (AP). -- The Johnson bill to regulate the sale of foreign securities in the United States through a "foreign securities board" with far-reaching authority was approved today by the Senate Judiciary Committee.

The Cobina Wright Circus Ball, one of the unique parties of recent years, will be given tonight in the grand ballroom suite of the Waldort-Astoria to aid the Boy Scout Foundation, of which President Franklin D. Roosevelt is executive head.

The text of Senator Robinson's speech is on Page 10. Senator Joseph T. Robinson of Arkansas promised several hundred newspaper publishers at the annual luncheon of The Associated Press in the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria yesterday that President Roosevelt would use "prudence and caution" in exercising the unprecedented power over the nation's monetary system given to him in the inflation legislation now before Congress.

WARSAW, April 24 -- France, Poland and the Little Entente, comprising Czechoslovakia, Rumania and Yugoslavia, joined forces today in signing an agreement against revision of the peace treaties and against the proposed four-power European conference suggested by Premier Mussolini of Italy.

When the State Alcoholic Beverage Control Board met yesterday at its headquarters in the State Office Building, 80 Centre Street, to complete its organization and to decide upon the form of licenses for breweries and retail distributers of beer, the chairman, Edward P. Mulrooney, announced that the sixty or seventy clerical jobs with the board would be filled from the civil service lists without reference to political backing.

Leopoldo Gutierrez, baritone, will give a recital tonight at the Roerich Museum, assisted by Irene Hampton, pianist. The program will include music of Argentina, Brazil, Chile, Cuba, Costa Rica and Mexico.

With another of his characteristic exhibitions of pitching perfection Carl Hubbell, southpaw ace of the Giants, yesterday gave his team the honors over the Brooklya Dodgers in the first interborough clash of the year at the Polo Grounds.
The text of Senator Joseph T. Robinson's address at the luncheon of The Associated Press in the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria yesterday follows:

WASHINGTON, April 24 -- Individual income taxes and miscellaneous receipts showed substantial increases last month, as compared with March last year, and more than offset a decline in corporation taxes, "with the result that total internal revenue was higher than in March, 1932.

CHICAGO, April 24. -- There's no deep, dark mystery of a drugged or deadened baseball behind the current epidemic of pitching masterpieces in the American League, President Will Harridge said today as he chuckled over reports of suspicious baseball fans.

WASHINGTON, April 24 -- The proposal for a currency plan under which the gold reserves of governments would be reduced and the deficiency made up by the substitution of silver was first suggested in general terms to a Congressional committee by James P. Warburg of New York, president of the International Acceptance Bank, who has been sitting in as an adviser to the conferees.

LONDON, April 24 (AP) -- Foreign Secretary Sir John Simon today summoned the organizing committee of the World Economic Conference for a meeting here Saturday -- a move interpreted in London as the first big result of the MacDonald-Roosevelt discussions in Washington.

THORN, Poland April 24 -- Despite the tension in Warsaw, Berlin and other capitals over the situation in the Polish Corridor, a visit to the region fails to reveal great excitement among its Inhabitants or the military.

The committee of the whole of the Board of Estimate is expected to reject today the resolution submitted by Aldermanic President Joseph V. McKee calling for city intervention as a party in the Interborough receivership in the Fedral courts.

BOSTON, April 24 (AP). -- Jimmy Foxx, hard-hitting first baseman of the Philadelphia Athletics, walloped his third homer of the season, had a perfect day at bat and accounted for seven runs today as the Athletics defeated the Boston Red Sox, 16 to 10.

CHICAGO, April 24. -- New high levels for the season on the near-by futures of wheat, corn and oats and on all deliveries of rye were established again today on the Board of Trade. Public buying through commission houses, largely in small lots, absorbed heavy profit-taking sales of wheat, local and Eastern longs going out of their lines.

WASHINGTON, April 24 -- The second concert of the Library of Congress festival of chamber music, given this morning under the auspices of the Elizabeth Sprague Coolidge Foundation, introduced to the American public the Adolf Busch String Quartet, of which the members are Adolf Busch, first violin; Gosta Andreasson, second violin; Karl Doktor, viola, and Hermann Busch, violoncello.

The Gulf, Mobile Northern Railroad, which is controlled by the Chicago, Burlington Quincy, borrowed $260,000 from the Railroad Credit Corporation on Sept. 29, according to the report for 1932. The following day the company received a $260,000 loan from the Reconstruction Finance Corporation.

WASHINGTON, April 24 -- Coincident with his confirmation by the Senate today as Ambassador to Cuba, Sumner Welles declared in a formal statement that he would observe the sovereignty and independence of the Cuban republic.

Mrs. Herbert H. Lehman, wife of the Governor, was the guest of honor yesterday at a luncheon of the Child Study Association of America in the Hotel Ambassador, where more than 400 members and friends of the organization heard speakers decry the influences of modern life on youthful character and envision a new administration in home affairs.

Mayor O'Brien modified his dictum that he would prosecute persons who discredited the city's credit last night when he explained that his threat referred only to those who issued false statements calculated to injure the credit standing of the city.

Scores of visitors pored over the rare old English news pamphlets and newspapers reading stirring events in English history of two and three centuries back, at the opening yesterday at the Waldorf-Astoria of the three-day exihibition of the ancient news-prints collection owned by the Press Club of London.

BERLIN, April 24 -- It may be taken for granted that the last thing the present German Government wants just now is a war. In his Reichstag inaugural speech at Potsdam Chancellor Hitler declared that Germany wanted to be "a true friend of a peace that would heal the wounds from which all countries have been suffering," and this probably can be accepted as a genuine expression of his personal sentiments.

A large group of lawyers representing various bar associations will leave tomorrow morning for Albany to urge at a public hearing before Governor Lehman in the afternoon that he sign the two bills recently passed by the Legislature to prohibit corporations from acting as receivers and trustees in legal proceedings in place of qualified citizens.

Semi-final tests preparatory to the three national fencing championships that will be decided tomorrow evening at the Hotel Astor got under way last night, four competitors surviving the foils eliminations at the New York Athletic Club.

The Roosevelt Administration's first offer of securities, other than short-term bills, has been announced by Secretary WOODIN. It consists of an issue of $500,000,000 in three-year notes, bearing interest at 2 7/8 per cent. Because they will be sold in denominations as low as $100, as well as in larger ones, it has been suggested that a special effort will be made to place them in the hands of small investors.

ALBANY, April 24 -- Governor Lehman signed today the Fearon bill which, provides for an increase of about 20 per cent in the State tax on decedent estates, thereby bringing the State rate to the level of the Federal levy.

PARIS, April 24 -- Modification of the French Far Eastern policy is indicated by the anxiety expressed today in official quarters over Russo-Japanese tension resulting from the Chinese Eastern Railway dispute.

HOUSTON, Texas, April 24 (AP) -- Prices of crude oil in East Texas began today to tumble toward the record low levels of a year ago as the Texas Corporation announced a posted price of 10 cents a barrel in the face of an allowable production for the field much greater than ever before.

A wide integration of the Reading Company and Central Railroad, of New Jersey, equivalent almost to consolidation, was forecast yesterday to follow the resignation of R. B. White from the presidency of the Jersey Central. Mr. White is due to be elected today president of the Western Union Telegraph Company.

A vigorous advance in bond prices on the Stock Exchange yesterday sent many issues of the speculative classification up 1 to 8 points for the day. Comparatively few issues showed declines, and the list of foreign loans and domestic corporation issues which did not gain at least a full point was not a long one.

BELGRADE, April 24 -- Complaining that Yugoslavia, as administered by its present rulers, was merely an enlarged Serbia and not the new State formed by the Serbs, Croats and Slovenes, Dr. Vladko Matchek, leader of the Croation Peasants' party, defended himself stoutly today before an extraordinary court for the protection of the State against the charge of advocating the secession of Croatia.

BOSTON, April 24 -- With three solid blows, Sedgwick Harvey, stiff punching New Yorker, made a flying start for the 126-pound championship tonight in one of the early trial bouts in the National A. A. U. boxing tournament at the Arena.
