LAKEWOOD, N.J., April 24 -- The Lakehurst Naval Air Station will be decommissioned in the near future, according to a letter from Acting Secretary of the Navy Pratt to the Lakewood township committee. Apprehensive that the station might be closed after the loss of the airship Akron, the town board recently by resolution asked the Navy Department to continue the station to which it requested the Macon be sent.
Behind the Racketeers, Chicken feed is not chicken feed to a racketeer czar when he sets out to make a thorough job of organizing the live-poultry trade.

BERLIN, April 24 -- Herman A. Metz and Victor Ridder took leave of Berlin this evening after a busy week here, in which they apprised the heads of the Hitler government of the American reaction to its policies.

WASHINGTON, April 24 -- Banking reform legislation took on new life today when President Roosevelt unexpectedly paused in the midst of his international negotiations to discuss the Glass bill with the Senate Banking subcommittee for an hour.

Albert Bein's history of the ways of a reformatory school -- "Little Ol' Boy" -- finally cuffed its way over the stage of the Playhouse last evening. Henry Hammond ended the saga, grown virtually Grecian with the years, for the play has been harried about from producer to announcement and from announcement to new producer.

OBERAMMERGAU, April 24 -- The Nazis will decide who shall play the parts of Christ, Mary, the Disciples and other leading characters in the next presentation of the Oberammergau Passion Play, your correspondent learned today from Alois Lang, who had the role of Christ last year.

WASHINGTON, April 24 -- In and out of a White House teeming with varied activities Ishbel MacDonald went many times today, checking off social engagements so that tomorrow she can turn to the subject in which she is most seriously interested -- labor.

VIENNA, April 24 -- A direct threat that the Austrian Army would be used if necessary against national socialism, which he declared was as great a danger to the peace of the country as socialism, was uttered by Karl Vaugoin, the Minister of War, in an address to the Catholic Men's Association today.

An appropriate beginning was made Sunday afternoon to the week of celebration at the Henry Street Settlement. The fortieth anniversary of its establishment will be kept by adult alumni with formal programs and friendly renewal of associations, but the children are making the big contribution to the week's festivities.

WASHINGTON, April 24 -- The statesmen of the nations represented in the conversations, which are taking place here now, and will for some days continue, have one objective in common. That purpose is to raise the prices of commodities all over the world.

At the annual meeting, yesterday, of stockholders of the Allied Chemical and Dye Corporation, James W. Gerard, former Ambassador to Germany, protested against the "policy of secrecy" which he said tha corporation had followed in its reports to shareholders.

The city's first move in Its fight to reduce rates for gas, electricity and telephone service will be made against two of the largest electric companies operating here, according to preliminary plans.

Monday, April 24, 1933. Except that time money relaxed fractionally to 1 per cent bid, offered at 1 1/2, there were no other changes of importance recorded in the day's money market. Stock Exchange call money continued at 1 per cent, while 3/4 prevailed outside.

Mrs. Glenna Collett Vare has not held the national title for the past two years, having been runner-up to Miss Virginia Van Wie last year and to Miss Helen Hicks in 1931, but she is two strokes ahead of any one in the Women's Eastern Golf Association, according to the handicap list just issued for 1933.

To the Editor of The New York Times: During the past three or four years I have iterated and reiterated the prophecy that the depression would not end until recognition -was given the free coinage of silver at a ratio to gold fixed by international agreement.

The Bureau of the Census, in "Manufacture and Sale of Farm Equipment" for 1930 reports the sale In the United States of farm equipment amounting to $381,099,124. Of this, $8,380,838 is for barn and barnyard equipment and $81,259,327 is for such items as beekeepers' supplies, corn cribs, grain bins, milking machines, lighting plants, pumps, pushcarts, wheelbarrows -- very few items in this classification being known as farm machinery.

To the Editor of The New York Times: "Your readers would like to know whether any example can be found in economic history where any nation has emerged from a depression by means of inflation, especially where enormous Government expenditures are planned."

DETROIT, April 24. -- The two large Detroit banks which have been closed since the beginning of the Michigan bank holiday Feb. 14, the First National Bank-Detroit and the Guardian National, today began paying depositors a 30 per cent dividend and as a result Detroit went on a long-delayed spending spree.
WASHINGTON, April 24 -- Wheat production restrictions on an international scale were projected into the Washington economic discussions today by the arrival of Premier Bennett.
DETROIT, April 24 (AP). -- The Tigers today turned in their third consecutive victory over the St. Louis Browns, 4 to 3. making a clean sweep of the series.

RIVERSIDE, N.J., April 24. -- More than 700 pupils of the Riverside schools walked out on strike today in protest against the return of Mrs. Marion B. Rein, principal, dismissed by the School Board in January, 1932, and reinstated by order of the Supreme Court. Mrs. Rein returned to duty today.

Count Vasco da Gama, hunter of African big game, descendant of the Portuguese mariner who was the first European to sail "round the windy corners of Africa to India, was convicted in West Side Court yesterday of unjustifiably killing Lord von Dick, pedigreed chow dog owned by Mr. and Mrs. Isidor Green, neighbors of the Count at 395 Riverside Drive.

While a crowd in the street below watched breathlessly, a 15-year-old girl hung precariously between two ties of the elevated roadbed at the Crescent Street station of the Fulton Street line in Brooklyn yesterday until a policeman and a fireman endangered their own lives to make what was considered an almost miraculous rescue.

One man was killed and sixteen were injured yesterday in a pitched battle between factions of the fur working trade, in the rooms of a left-wing union at 131 West Twenty-eighth Street. The melee threw the surrounding area into confusion for three hours.

HAMBURG, April 24 -- The union of the Hamburg American and the North German Lloyd lines will be broken up in the near future, it is learned. An agreement to that effect involving a comprehensive reorganization of German shipping has been reached between the boards of the two concerns.

MINEOLA, L.I., April 24 -- Nassau County's authorities failed today to receive a single bid for a $5,000,000 bond issue. The abandonment of the gold standard was given as the reason for the lack of interest in the issue. Ordinarily a sale of Nassau County bonds attracts approximately a dozen bidders.

The trouble started when Mrs. Alma di Fiore of 532 West 131st Street found that her two cats, Felix, 1 year old, and Mittens, 5, were missing. That was more, than a week ago. It grew more serious, however, when Felix returned home with what was diagnosed as a probable refrigeration of the whiskers.
CHICAGO, April 24 (AP). -- The White Sox broke up a ninth-inning rally by the Indians today to win, 5 to 4, and sweep the three-game series.

LONDON, April 24 -- Sir John Simon, Foreign Secretary, heard the story today of the Moscow trial from four of the six British engineers who were accused. The men paid two visits to the Foreign Office.

OTTAWA, Ont., April 24 (AP) -- Finance Minister E.N. Rhodes refused to reply officially today to a question as to whether Canada had abandoned the gold standard, but he declared that Canada had not altered its stand since the United Kingdom left gold in 1931.

Quotations for all 1933 crop deliveries rose above the eight-cent level on the Cotton Exchange yesterday and the March position improved a quarter-cent at one time. Southern realizing sales wiped out part of the gain in the last hour, but left the list 1 to 8 points higher than on Saturday.

HAVRE DE GRACE, Md. April 24 --The foreign-bred son. of Gainsborough, Old Master, which races for the Howe Stable, won the richest race on today's Havre de Grace card, but much interest was centred in the Mayfield Purse, where War Stripes won by half a length in a field which included five Kentucky Derby eligibles.
NEWARK, April 24 (AP) -- The Rt. Rev. Mgr. John A. Duffy, new Bishop of the Diocese of Syracuse, N.Y., was regarded by the Newark Diocese as one of its ablest organizers.
MEXICO CITY, April 24 -- Josephus Daniels presented to President Rodriguez this afternoon his credentials as the tenth United States Ambassador to Mexico.

Confirming reports that the athletic fields and playgrounds he is developing on the thirty-four-acre site of the abandoned lower reservoir in Central Park were to be only temporary, John E. Sheehy, newly appointed Commissioner of Parks of Manhattan, expressed the hope yesterday that the new play and athletic facilities would be available to the public by the middle of May.

WASHINGTON, April 24 -- President Roosevelt, Prime Minister MacDonald and Edouard Herriot moved swiftly tonight toward that harmony of ideas which is the goal of the current discussions preliminary to the World Economic Conference.

The Federal Hall reproduction in Bryant Park is coming down so rapidly that its complete removal by Saturday was promised yesterday. Under the attack of fifty workmen, recruited from among the unemployed, armed with hammers, saws and crowbars, and working under the supervision of one of their own number, the building has already been reduced to a shell.

The Commission on the Emergency in Education has gathered editorial opinion from wide sources. This reflects both the plight of the public schools and the sentiment which nevertheless seems to prevail about the importance of finding ways to save them from the worst, even if they cannot be kept at their best for the time being.

PRINCETON, N.J., April 24 -- Dartmouth coupled ten hits, including three home runs, with six Princeton errors to defeat the Tiger nine, 11 -- 6, in an Eastern Intercollegiate League game on University Field today. The victory put the Indians in third place in the standing and dropped Princeton to a tie with Cornell for last place.

WASHINGTON, April 24 --Financial security is now added to political and military security in France's program, the attitude of their delegation to the Washington economic conversations indicated today.

WASHINGTON, April 24 -- President Roosevelt has apparently found a formula for disarmament which is at least acceptable to the British as a working basis for the Geneva Disarmament Conference and which, it is confidently hoped tonight, may be accepted by M. Herriot as assuring political protection to France.

Baron F.W. von Prittwitz und Gaffron, the retiring German Ambassador to the United States, will sail tonight for Bremen on the Europa of the North German Lloyd Line. He will be accompanied by the Baroness and their daughter, Marisa.
THE elderly visitor took a seat and opened up without any preliminaries.

In the Senate yesterday, Mr. THOMAS of Oklahoma described the intent of the inflation bill which he introduced. According to him, it would transfer about "$200,000,000,000 of values" from the creditor class, "who did not earn it," to deserving debtors.

WASHINGTON, April 24 -- In an eventful debate on inflation which began In the Senate today Senator Thomas, erstwhile "radical," led the fight for the administration program, while Senator Tydings, who heretofore has supported President Roosevelt, urged in the strongest terms the defeat of the measure to expand credit and currency.

ALBANY, April 24. -- Representatives of retail establishments in all the large cities of the State were in conference today with Mark Graves, president of the New York State Tax Board, and other members of the board, seeking guidance on some of the perplexities of the new retail sales tax law taking effect May 1.
WASHINGTON, April 24 -- Several friendships formed on their previous visit to Washington, as well as in London, were renewed today by the British Prime Minister and Miss Ishbel MacDonald.

WASHINGTON, April 24. -- Protesting a recent fare increase, a complaint asking a 40 per cent reduction in commutation fares now charged by the Erie Railroad between New York City and points in New Jersey and New York was filed with the Interstate Commerce Commission today by the Metropolitan League of Erie Commuters.

"Ordinary business caution" calls for hesitancy in making new and renewal leases at present "depression rentals," Anton L. Trunk, president of the Real Estate Board of New York, said yesterday in amplifying such advice to realty owners in advertisements by the board.

BALTIMORE. April 24 (AP). -- An entry list of sixteen thoroughbred Jumpers was announced today for the fortieth running of the Maryland Hunt Club Cup Saturday over the Hunt Cup course in Worthington Valley in suburban Baltimore.

PARIS, April 24 -- A law was promulgated today which forbids foreigners to practice the medical profession here henceforth. It is not expected to affect American physicians and dentists, now here to any great extent, however, as officials explain it will not apply retroactively to foreign medical men who hold French diplomas.

The best that the Treasury Department now believes it can obtain promptly for the depositors of more than $24,000,000 in the closed Harriman National Bank and Trust Company is 50 cents on the dollar, according to Emil Schlesinger, lawyer, who questioned Under Secretary Arthur A. Ballantine yesterday by telephone to Washington on behalf of a depositors' committee.

WASHINGTON, April 24. -- "Those who have considered it legitimate to gamble with other people's money must abdicate their leadership," Attorney General Cummings said tonight in an address over the network of the National Broadcasting Company and Station WOR.

BOSTON, Mass., April 24. -- By granting a writ of habeas corpus to a prisoner for whom Governor Ely had already issued an extradition order at the request of the Governor of Virginia, Judge James A. Lowell in Federal District Court here has challenged the procedure of the Southern State in excluding Negroes from jury service.
WASHINGTON, April 24 -- Twenty-seven Gloucester fishermen were taken on a personally conducted tour of the White House today by Mrs. Roosevelt.

BERLIN, April 24 -- Final nationwide instructions for a great Nationalist May Day observance were issued today by Dr. Paul Joseph Goebbels, the Nazi Minister of Propaganda, who asserted in forceful language that class war was a thing of the past "since Marxism is smashed."
CHICAGO, April 24 -- Five thousand militant teachers, approaching the boiling point over having to work without pay, laid siege today to five big Loop banks.

Trailing at 5 -- 2 going into the ninth inning, New York University's baseball team tallied four runs to repulse City College, 6-5 at Ohio Field yesterday. Walter Signer, who pitched only six balls as a relief twirler, received credit for the victory, his second in three days and third of the current campaign.

CHICAGO, April 24. -- Buying of hogs today was the most general that has been witnessed in about a year with the exception of the period immediately after the bank holiday. Prices advanced 10 to 30 cents a hundredweight, compared with Saturday, to the best figure since March 24, the day's top of $4.15 being 30 cents above that at the close of last week, while the day's average was up 25 cents at $3.90.

BERLIN, April 24 -- The Boerse opened hesitant and irregular today, transactions remaining confined almost entirely to professional speculators. A downward tendency developed in lethargic trading. Most of the declines remained fractional, however, and the closing again presented a confused aspect, some issues showing hardly any change from Saturday and others finishing a point or two above or below that day's finals.

The music appreciation concerts broadcast by the National Broadcasting Company under the direction of Dr. Walter Damrosch will be presented for the 1933-34 season, it was announced yesterday, but it was learned at the same time that the question whether Dr. Damrosch, who completes his fifth year of broadcasting on April 28, will be retained to direct these concert-lectures has yet to be settled.

The tribute of President Roosevelt to the patriotic principles of William the Silent was added yesterday to those of diplomatic, civic and religious leaders, who participated in the quadricentennial celebration of the birth of the Dutch liberator, at the Hotel Ritz-Carlton, and attended by representatives of patriotic societies from various parts of the country.

While the movement of prices in most markets was less vigorous than in the latter half of last week, there was no indication yesterday that interest was abating. The volume of business on the Stock Exchange approximated 4,800,000 shares, and dealings were proportionately heavy in the commodity markets.

GENEVA, April 24 -- Plans for an automobile tunnel under Mont Blanc, the highest peak in Europe, are beginning to take definite shape. A detailed scheme for thus connecting the highway network of France and French Switzerland with Italian highways, has been submitted to the French and Italian Governments, and it is understood here that both have approved the plans in principle.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The haste with which the economy act was voted resulted in overlooking a clause in the former, economy measure which rightfully should have been excluded in framing the new bill, but which now stands in effect.
LONDON, April 24 -- Chancellor of the Exchequer Neville Chamberlain will introduce his second budget in the House of Commons tomorrow afternoon. His speech is expected to last an hour and one-half.

Mr. HOOVER is still leader of the Republican party. His leadership has the substantial certification of 15,000,000 votes. Obviously, any movement for the organization of the party with a view to the next Congress elections conies properly from him and his associates and persons actively and officially associated with his Administration.

SHANGHAI, Tuesday, April 25 -- The developments in North China are causing increased apprehension here. American dispatches from Chinwangtao confirm the news that the Japanese ordered half of their troops operating in the Lwan River triangle to withdraw to the Great Wall.

Salt-water fishermen were out In force in Long Island waters over the week-end. Boat captains in Great South Bay from Freeport to Fatchogue were swamped despite the fact that neither Saturday nor Sunday provided the best conditions for flounder fishing.
To the Editor of The New York Times: How can the American people and American industry regain prosperity and still remain insolvent?
HOT SPRINGS, Va., April 24 (AP) -- Seeded players had little difficulty advancing to the second round of the annual Homstead 'tennis tournament today.

Joe Savoldi, making his first appearance in this city since defeating Jim Londos in Chicago recently, pinned Nick Lutze of California in the feature wrestling bout at the Seventy-first Regiment Armory last night.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., April 24 -- After a conference of several hours with Judge George W. Smyth of the Westchester children's court, the parents of Helen Vasko, the 2-year-old child whose life physicians say is endangered by a malignant tumor in the left eye, consented tonight to have their daughter submit to an operation.

The Union Pacific Railroad sold 67,152 shares of New York Central Railroad capital stock at a loss of $6,256,692 in 1932, according to its annual report. At the same time it bought 100,000 shares of Pennsylvania Railroad capital stock, the price for which was not disclosed.

While five investigations got under way yesterday, James Gormley, unemployed bellboy, and his wife, sat in their fifth floor tenement at 439 West Fifty-second Street, beside the bodies of their two dead children, which are to be buried today, and awaited word from Roosevelt Hospital, where their third child was taken yesterday.

WASHINGTON, April 24 -- Plans for a vote tonight on the Hill Muscle Shoals bill were suddenly abandoned at the end of an acrimonious debate when Democratic leaders found that Republicans in the chamber far outnumbered them. A majority of the Democrats had apparently sought pleasanter atmosphere as personalities punctuated the four hours' discussion.

Arthur Casey defeated James Brown in the 128-pound class final in an amateur boxing tournament at the Downtown A.C. last night. Upset for a count of seven in the first round and knocked down for no count in the second, Casey rallied strongly, flooring his opponent for a count of nine in the final stanza.

MADRID, April 24 -- The Madrid evening Republican newspapers, the first newspapers to appear since the elections yesterday in 2,500 small villages, were forced to admit the elections resulted in a governmental defeat. They insist, however, that there was a Republican triumph.

It might be possible for some writers, artists, inventors, movie directors and scenarists to retire on their earnings in Russia, Ella Winter writes in "Red Virtue: Human Relationships in the New Russia," just published by Harcourt, Brace, but not to work is considered so shameful that very few do retire.

Happy, and describing the victory of her horse, Kellfiboro Jack, in the Liverpool Grand National as "the thrill that conies once in a lifetime," Mrs. F. Ambrose Clark arrived yesterday from England on the North German Lloyd liner Europa. Mr. Clark, who had an entry which ran unplaced, accompanied her.

WASHINGTON, April 24 -- Auto owners of New Jersey who lend their cars to friends are liable for damages caused by the reckless operation of the cars in New York, the Supreme Court decided today. The issue was based on the New York statute holding the car owner responsible for negligence where permission is given to another to operate the machine.

BERLIN, April 24 -- A May Day manifesto was issued today by Dr. Paul Joseph Goebbels, Minister of Propaganda and Popular Enlightenment, with the annotation that it must be printed textually in the entire German press at least twice, tomorrow and Friday.

The intelligent audiences staying away from the general run of motion pictures now being produced was estimated at 55,000,000, or nearly half the population of the country, in a paper on "unoccupied Motion Picture Fields" presented last night before the Spring convention of the Society of Motion Picture Engineers, meeting this week at the Hotel Pennsylvania, by W.H. Short, director of the Motion Picture Research Council of the Educational Research Committee of the Payne Fund.

With trading volumes again near the highest levels on record, all commodities continued the renewal of their price advance begun on Saturday in the local markets. Silver, sugar, rubber, hides, silk, cocoa and coffee climbed higher, some of them again into new high ground for the year.
WASHINGTON, April 24. -- The Yanks and Senators dealt each other some violent blows today with the Senators finally dealing out the most damaging strokes and winning the same, 11 to 10.

The Adopt-a-Family Committee, of which Mrs. August Belmont is chairman, continued yesterday its campaign to provide made jobs for 1,000 unemployed men and women for twenty weeks. There are still some 450 unemployed of the white-collar class to be provided for.

HINDENBURG, Upper Silesia, April 24 -- The rebirth of militant German nationalism under the symbol of the swastika cross and the ever alert, equally militant and nationalistic Poles are rapidly increasing the German-Polish tension to dangerous proportions.

PARIS, April 24 -- Despite the confidence in the franc expressed by Premier Daladier and re-echoed by the whole French press, it is with considerable anxiety that the French people of all classes are awaiting the outcome of former Premier Herriot's conversations with President Roosevelt.

PHILADELPHIA, April 24 (AP). -- Pinch-hitting Al Todd broke up a twelve-inning game today with a single with the bases loaded, bringing home the run that gave the Phillies a 6-to-5 victory over the Braves.
WASHINGTON, April 24 -- The White House grounds were a scene of shifting color today as Edouard Herriot of France and Premier Bennett of Canada arrived and were received by the President.

TIENTSIN, April 24 -- The various leaders of subversive movements in North China, working in cooperation with Manchukuo agents and presumably with Japanese subsidies, continue their conspiracies to dissipate the Nanking Government's influence in the Pelping-Tientsin area.

Special attention was focused yesterday upon steel stocks, chiefly because of the steady increase in operations and the prospect of further improvement in demand. In the case of United States Steel preferred, which was heavily dealt in at rising prices, today's dividend meeting may have been a factor.

WASHINGTON, April 24 -- Efforts to find a satisfactory solution of the problem of the alleged guarantee of deposits of the Harriman National Bank and Trust Company of New York by the New York Clearing House Association probably will be successful, it was indicated here tonight.

WASHINGTON, April 24 (AP) -- At the Navy Department it was stated that President Roosevelt himself desired Admiral Pratt to remain in his present command, and Secretary Swanson said today he would be retained until the outcome of the present Geneva arms conference and other international negotiations is clear.

BERLIN, April 24 -- Dr. Hjalmar Schacht, president of the Reichsbank, will leave for Washington next week to take part in President Roosevelt's conversations preliminary to the World Economic Conference.

Sam Colacurcio, owner of the Jersey City International League baseball team, solved a few more of his financial difficulties yesterday when he sold one-half interest in the club to John P. Corbett, New York film producer and real estate man.

WASHINGTON, April 24 -- Led by the National Coal Association, producers of bituminous coal throughout the United States appeared before the Interstate Commerce Commission today asking substantial reductions in prevailing freight rates on that commodity as a means of improving their own condition and railroad revenues generally.

Detective William Wittenberg of the headquarters squad, testifying yesterday in General Sessions at the first-degree murder trial of a woman and two men in the beating last Oct. 31 of Achilles Mirner, a Parisian jeweler, in a West Seventy-fourth Street speakeasy, told Judge Freschi and the jurors that, although the two men defendants admitted to him the next day in the Fifth Street station they had killed the jeweler, he did not arrest them.

* * * Order Gain Presages Active Week. The placing of a large volume of orders in the wholesale markets here yesterday presaged an unusually active week, it was reports here yesterday. The trend to higher prices, coupled with the need of replenishing stocks for May and Summer promotions, are lifting wholesale activity much above what was expected at this time.

The John Day Company, which kept up with the front pages by bringing out Howard Scott's own explanation of technocracy a few months ago, is rushing "The Primer of Inflation" through the presses. The author is Earl Sparling, newspaper man, who has been working on the book for three months to have it ready for publication as soon as the anticipated drive for inflation should become a matter of wide public interest.

WASHINGTON, April 24 (AP) -- A letter from Secretary Hull saying the State Department contemplated "not the slightest relationship" between the press and the secret code bill passed recently by the House, was made public today by Representative Black, Democrat, of New York.

GENEVA, April 24 -- The League of Nations announced tonight that the Council's committee organizing the World Economic Conference, due to meet here tomorrow, will meet instead in London on Saturday afternoon. The main question before it will be the date of the conference.

One of two men accused of extorting thousands of dollars from east side speakeasy owners and beer sellers was shot and killed by a detective yesterday afternoon at Forty-third Street and First Avenue when he attempted to escape arrest.

Last night's concert in Carnegie Hall brought to a close the National Orchestral Association's present season. The program included Bach's Overture in D major (Suite No. 3) Beethoven's Piano Concerto No. 3 in C minor and Strauss's "Tod und Verklarung."

LONDON, April 24 -- The parents of Captain W.N. Lancaster, the 34-year-old airman, who recently walked out of a Miami court a free man after a three-month ordeal on a murder charge, are now well-nigh distracted awaiting news from the Sahara, which is being searched night and day for him.

PARIS, April 25. -- The French and British Treasuries have come to an agreement, regarding a temporary stabilization of the franc and the pound that is expected to have an important effect in preventing a confused monetary situation, it was reliably reported here tonight.

BOSTON, April 25. -- "I don't care what he said; I don't know what he said, and I don't want to know." Thus Judge Lowell of the Federal District Court dismissed the statement in Washington to the effect that Representative Howard W. Smith intends to press a resolution of impeachment.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Your news notice of the death of General Adelbert Ames clearly brought out the colorfulness of his life. For a number of years I believe he was the oldest graduate of West Point.

WARSAW, April 25. -- Marshal Joseph Pilsudski, Poland's dictator, on a trip to Vilna last week-end in the company of several Cabinet members, held important conferences devoted to foreign affairs, and the danger of treaty revision as proposed in Premier Mussolini's four-power consultation plan was a main subject of discussion.

A jury in Federal Court, which returned a verdict of guilty yesterday against four election inspectors, accused of fraud at the polls last November, was rebuked by Federal Judge John C. Knox when it acquitted a fifth defendant, Samuel Greenblatt, Democratic captain of the Eleventh.

WASHINGTON, April 25. -- The French delegation to the economic discussions ended its day's labors slightly bewildered at the extent to which Congressional opposition might interfere with the progress its members feel they are making with the American experts.

VATICAN CITY, April 25 (AP). -- Pope Pius today named as a Titular Bishop Mgr. James Anthony Walsh, founder and superior-general of the Maryknoll Missionaries, Maryknoll, N.Y. He was born in Cambridge, Mass., and educated in Beston.

WASHINGTON, April 25 (AP). -- Testimony that during the stock market crash of October, 1929, the Cities Service Securities Company spent more than $128,000,000 purchasing common, stock of its parent, the Cities Service Company, was presented to the Federal Trade Commission today by Thomas W. Mitchell, the commission's economist-examiner.
BERLIN, April 25 (AP). -- The Reichsbank's statement as of April 22 shows the following changes in reichsmarks:

Commissioner Bolan assigned yesterday fifty additional detectives and 150 uniformed patrolmen to duty in the fur district in the midtown section to prevent a recurrence of armed hostilities between Communist and other factions of needle workers, which, on Monday, resulted in the murder of one man and the wounding of sixteen others in a clash in the Communist Headquarters at 131 West Twenty-eighth Street.

Rochester, N.Y. The city of Rochester, which failed to receive any bids April 19 on an issue of $3,750,000 of shortterm tax notes, announced yesterday that it would be in the market at noon tomorrow with an issue of tax revenue bonds of like amount.

Athletic competitions conducted by the Public Schools Athletic League face curtailment unless funds for financing them are obtained immediately, it was disclosed yesterday, when it was announced that no plans have been formulated as yet for the annual senior high school rifle matches and that play in the annual junior high baseball competition has been deferred indefinitely.

G.B. Stern, English novelist and playwright, who is hurrying back to England to write a novel after fourteen weeks in Hollywood writing for the motion pictures, talked about scenario writing and the "mysterious forces" that control the motion picture industry, and California at large, in an interview yesterday.
Housing properties comprised the bulk of the New Jersey realty turnover reported yesterday.

WASHINGTON, April 25. -- The cost of building operations, including alterations and repairs, declined 0.9 per cent throughout the United States during March to an estimated value of $24,102,247, compared with $24,321,658 in February, the Bureau of Labor Statistics announced today.

TRENTON, N.J., April 25. -- Declaring he was convinced that the Republican majority in the Legislature would not support bills for reorganization of the State Highway Department, Governor Moore took action today to remove from office the remaining two Highway Commissioners.

The State Employment Service placed 57,399 workers in jobs during 1932, according to the annual report of Fritz Kaufman, director of the Division of Employment of the State Department of Labor, made yesterday to Elmer F. Andrews, Industrial Commissioner.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., April 25. -- New York University's baseball team scored its seventh successive victory today when it turned back Yale by 8 to 2.

WASHINGTON, April 25. -- Canada's desire for increased trade relations with the United States, within the terms of the Ottawa compacts, was reiterated today by Prime Minister Bennett, who said that nothing in the British Empire treaties made at Ottawa last year prevented trade agreements with this country which would be mutually beneficial.

In a reaction largely caused by profit-taking, most of the commodities traded on local exchanges lost yesterday the greater part of gains made on Monday. As quotations declined, stop-loss orders were touched off, but the general comment was that the markets withstood the selling in good fashion.

Supported by its banks, New York City will not default today on its $144,000,000 of short-term debt. The Clearing House banks and other commercial and private bankers hold about $124,000,000 of the maturing obligations and these have been deposited with the Chase National Bank for renewal until June 12.

WASHINGTON, April 25. -- With his Muscle Shoals bill already approved by the Agriculture Committee, Senator Norris hoped to win for his bill a Senate right of way immediately after farm relief action. His plan was to substitute his own for the House bill, which he believes would "seriously interfere with the building of transmission lines because it is hedged about with red tape."

The magnificent fishing grounds of Canada soon will be invaded by an army of American sportsmen. Officials of many of the Dominion's provinces report that bookings already are abundant. With conditions for fishing now nearing their best and the season's opening set for May 1, it seems certain that numbers of anglers will be attracted across the border in quest of trout and salmon.

PARIS, April 25. -- Because of the six hours difference in time between Paris and Washington, former Premier Edouard Harriot's report of his first meeting with President Roosevelt and Prime Minister MacDonald and of the various suggestions put forward in the Washington conversations had not been decoded when the Cabinet met this morning at 10 o'clock.

Pierre de Lanux, League of Nations representative in Paris, who has just ended a speaking tour of the United States and will sail on Saturday with M. Harriot, presented an optimistic view of the world situation yesterday at a luncheon meeting of the New York branch of the League of Nations Association at the Hotel Woodstock.

The Town of Bristol, R.I., received $116,923 from the estate of Robert D. Andrews, president of the Metropolitan Savings Bank, the appraisal of his estate disclosed yesterday. Mr. Andrews, who died April 23, 1932, gave the residuary estate to the town for a school building in memory of his father.

Sylvester Cosentino, Assistant District Attorney attached to the Homicide Bureau, was called as a State witness yesterday judge Freachi's part of General Sessions at the first-degree murder trial of Mrs. Florence Thompson, 19 years old; Herman Newberg and Lawrence Ganze.
Housing deals in scattered sections of Manhattan featured realty trading yesterday.

The stewards of the Jockey Club and the directors of the Saratoga Association met yesterday at the offices of the Jockey Club, the former body granting licenses to trainers and jockeys, and the Saratoga Association voting to accept the dates as recently allotted.

It was not expected that payments due this year on England's war debt to the United States would be included in the British budget, submitted yesterday to the House of Commons. No provision for that purpose was in last year's budget, and when payment of $95,550,000 was made at the last moment special arrangements were necessary.

BERLIN, April 25. -- Reports that the French Comite des Forges is secretly negotiating with Polish and Russian authorities for the formation of a Russo-Polish-French "military alliance" directed against Germany were made today in a sensational communication from Paris to the Kreuzzeitung, the organ of the Stahlhelm.
Prices on the Cotton Exchange fluctuated yesterday less violently than on any previous day for a week, but trading continued at almost record proportions. The day ended with losses of 1 to 5 points.

ALBANY, April 25. -- In dealing with the hundreds of bills awaiting his action during the thirty-day period following adjournment of the Legislature, Governor Lehman is having more frequent resort to his veto power than even his predecessor, although President Roosevelt when Governor made liberal use of it.

The question whether women will be permitted to vote on matters of local church administration and also receive the right to preach in the Lutheran Church will be discussed today at the closing session of the forty-second semi-annual New York Pastoral Conference of the Atlantic Division of the Missouri Synod of the Lutheran Church.

A large number of subscriptions have been received for the entertainment and supper dance under the auspices of the Ladies French Benevolent Society of St. Vincent de Paul which will take place tonight on board the lie de France, Pier 57, at the foot of West Fifteenth Street.

Counsel began yesterday to draw an agreement for arbitration proceedings intended to obtain a prompt and binding determination of the responsibility of the twenty member banks of the New York Clearing House Association to make good the deficit of the closed Harriman National Bank and Trust Company.

The 1933 edition of the Norris bill for the development of Muscle Shoals follows the original model, with the Tennessee Valley Authority tacked on. Cheap fertilizer for the farmer, cheap light and power for the housewife. They are to be sought by putting the Government, directly, into the fertilizer and utility business, on almost a cosmic scale.

The Giants tried twilight baseball yesterday at the Polo Grounds and voted the experiment a huge success. In the dusk of a cloud-laden sky, the leaderless clan of Bill Terry scored its second successive victory over the Brooklyn Dodgers. The score was 8 to 2, and about 3,000 witnessed the game.
COMMERCIAL PAPER. Yesterday....... 2 per cent for the best names Monday....... 2 per cent for the best names

Great Britain began yesterday the repatriation of the $260,000,000 or more of earmarked gold held here. The Federal Reserve Bank reported that $2,199,900 had been taken out of earmark and that $2,199,500 had been shipped to England under license.
The opening of "Hilda Cassidy," which was scheduled to take place this evening at the Martin Beck Theatre, has been postponed until next week, the evening as yet undecided.

LONDON, April 25. -- Responsible newspaper comment suggests that the Chancellor of the Exchequer followed in the budget introduced today the expected lines of "honest, orthodox finance" in "an unimaginative manner" which is likely to win a majority of the government's supporters.

WASHINGTON, April 25. -- Closing of the open door by Manchukuo to commerce of nations that have not recognized that State, and even Japanese occupation of Tientsin and Peiping, will not stir the Roosevelt administration into an immediate aggressive diplomacy, in support of American rights in the Far East, it was learned definitely today.

Frank L. Magel has acquired control of Putnam's Bookstore, Inc., 2 West Forty-fifth Street. Mr. Magel is president of the American Booksellers Association, and was for many years chairman of that association's board of trade. He has been directing the Putnam store for eighteen months.

Prime Minister Ramsay MacDonald, on his way back to London from his Washington conferences with President Roosevelt, will stop for a few hours in New York City today and in the course of his stay will deliver the only formal public address of his American visit.

TIENTSIN, April 25. -- The Japanese fought their way further southward toward Peiping from Kupei Pass today, advancing into the plains of Hopei Province, south of Nantienmen, on the road from Chengteh, the capital of Jehol.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., April 25. -- A farewell note to his brother, Edwin C. Redfern, nearly convinced the police tonight that a man who leaped 200 feet to his death in the Genesee River from the Veterans Memorial Bridge yesterday was Richard S. Redfern, uncle of the missing Georgia-to-Brazil flier, Paul Redfern.

WASHINGTON, April 25. -- Business and pleasure were combined at luncheon and dinner today by the visiting statesmen. Two of them were dinner guests at the White House and all three shared honors at a men's luncheon given by Secretary Hull at the Sulgrave Club.

ALBANY, April 25. -- After a conference today with tax experts, Mark Graves, President of the State Tax Commission, announced that administration of the new 1 per cent retail sales tax, effective Monday, would be handled by districts.
The Small House Advisory Service has moved from 521 5th Av. to larger quarters in 247 Park Av.

HAVRE DE GRACE, Md., April 25 -- The Catawba Stable's Mr. Khayyam, the son of Omar Khayyam which won at 50 to 1 at Belmont Park last season, made his 1933 debut today in the featured Glen Oaks Purse and won in a manner to gain many admirers for the Kentucky Derby for which he is eligible.

The radio music appreciation hour, the five-year plan of which will be completed on Friday under the leadership of Dr. Walter Damrosch, will be continued next season, according to Merlin H. Aylesworth, president of the National Broadcasting Company, who discussed the situation with Dr. Damrosch yesterday.

Mayor O'Brien and the other Tammany members of the Board of Estimate now plan to sidetrack the McKee resolution calling upon the city to become a party to the Interborough receivership proceedings, with Samuel Untermyer as special counsel.

LANSING, Mich., April 25. -- Governor Comstock assailed Treasury officials today as he received word from the Chicago Federal Reserve Bank that the "Michigan plan" for reopening banks on the basis of their liquid assets had been rejected.
The champion Newark Bears again were beaten by Rochester in Newark yesterday, losing, 4 to 2, for their fourth defeat in the five-game series, which was concluded.
SAN FRANCISCO, April 25. -- The 16-year-old fight to free Thomas Mooney from the life sentence, imposed on him for the Preparedness Day bomb outrage in 1916, will be resumed here tomorrow.

James Gormley, 4 years old, and his brother Samuel, 3, were buried yesterday afternoon in Mount Olivet Cemetery, Queens, after services conducted by the Salvation Army. In the meantime investigations to determine whether the deaths were caused by food poisoning or by an infectious disease remained incomplete.

A marked improvement in public confidence and in general business conditions was reported by newspaper publishers from widespread industrial and agricultural areas in a survey made yesterday by The Associated Press among members of the Publishers Association, in convention here.

WASHINGTON, April 25. -- The allegation of the city of Providence that sixteen intercoastal carriers were discriminating against that port by assessing eastbound intercoastal cargo destined there an arbitrary rate of 7 1/2 cents above the Boston rates, was dismissed by the Shipping Board today upon notice that an amicable settlement had been reached by the port and the steamship lines.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The Romans had a saying, "Navigare necesse est; vivere non est" -- "Seafaring is needed; staying alive is not," which seems to indicate that they considered their ships doomed whenever they failed to dodge storms of extraordinary violence.
CINCINNATI, April 25 (AP). -- A long smash into the right field stands from the hat of Jim Bottomley for his third homer of the season helped the Reds to a 5-to-3 victory over the Cubs today.

CHICAGO, April 25. -- William B. Storey is to resign as president of the Atchison, Topeka Santa Fe Railway and be succeeded by Samuel T. Bledsoe, according to reports received today from Topeka, Kan. The annual meeting of stockholders will be held there on Thursday and the report is said to have originated in connection with that meeting.

BERLIN, April 25. -- After a conference today with Dr. Wilhelm Frick, Reich Minister of the Interior, the Nazi Premier of Mecklenburg-Schwerin announced that the appointment of a church commissar to assume the functions of the Protestant Church Council in the State had been revoked.

Directors of the United States Steel Corporation declared yesterday a quarterly dividend of 50 cents a share on its preferred stock the same amount as was voted three months ago, when the thirty two-year record of uninterrupted payments at the quarterly rate of $1.75 a share was ended because of the heavy drafts on the cash and working capital of the company during 1932.

TOKYO, Wednesday, April 26. -- Important statements on Manchukuo's trade policy, foreshadowing the abandonment of the principle of equal commercial opportunity and substitution of reciprocity, primarily with Japan, has been made to your correspondent by Tetsuzo Komai, Japanese members of the Manchukuo Privy Council.

PHILADELPHIA, April 25 (AP). -- Led by Dick Bartell, peppery short-stop, who hit Boston pitching for four doubles in four times at bat, the Phillies scored an easy 7-1 triumph over the Boston Braves today.

CHICAGO, April 25. -- The action expected tomorrow on the inflation bill in Washington is regarded by Professor Irving Fisher of Yale as "the most important piece of legislation in all American if not world history."

To the Editor of The New York Times: The impending legislation proposed by those who have been hypnotized by the currency inflation mania brings us to the brink of the greatest catastrophe this country ever has faced.

WASHINGTON, April 25. -- Secretary Perkins today made a vigorous defense of her amendments to the Black thirty-hour bill, and informed the House Labor Committee that the administration was in sympathy with the principle of the shorter hours and minimum wage proposal.

Although minority stockholders criticized the deal through which the Studebaker Corporation acquired control of the White Motor Company some months ago, the transaction was approved yesterday by a large majority vote at Studebaker's annual meeting in Jersey City.

It must have been parental prescience that gave to the child who was to bring so much of good to his community, his country and the world the name "Felix." It fitly belonged to the man FELIX ADLER. He was like the nobler sort of tree that in the ancient religious rites was offered to the superior deities in contradistinction to the "infelices arbores."

The pooling of municipal, Federal and unemployment-relief funds for the immediate construction of important regional projects was recommended yesterday by George McAneny, president of the Regional Plan Association and newly appointed Sanitation Commissioner, who saw in his "new alliances" an opportunity to coordinate and hasten actual work on public improvements.

Charles E. Mitchell, former chairman of the boad of the National City Bank and the National City Company, received an income of $666,666.67 from the management fund of the latter company in 1929, which he failed to report in filing an income tax return, it was charged yesterday in a new superseding indictment voted by the Federal grand jury.
BOSTON, April 25 (AP). -- The Red Sox handed Bob Grove, Athletics' pitching ace, his first defeat of the season today while beating the Mackmen, 6 to 4.

GENEVA, April 25. -- With the United States delegation silent, the disarmament conference resumed work this afternoon with a superficial discussion of the British project for bringing the United States and Soviet Russia into an agreement to consult whenever five powers are willing to take the responsibility of declaring the peace pact threatened.

All the speculative markets yielded instinctively to a spirit of caution yesterday after the recent immoderate advances. The pressure of realizing sales and of enlarged operations for bear account was felt in stocks and commodities. United States Government securities led a general advance in the bond market and the dollar held its own against the two most important foreign, currencies.

KILGORE, Texas, April 25 (AP). -- As additional major companies slashed the price of East Texas crude oil to 10 cents a barrel, Lon A. Smith, chairman of the Texas Railroad Commission, charged today that the reductions were made largely to displace the commission's control of the field.

WASHINGTON, April 25. -- A final warning to gold hoarders was issued today by Secretary Woodin that all gold coin, bullion and gold certificates must be in the Federal Reserve Banks or the Treasury on or before May 1.

CHICAGO, April 25. -- Professional traders on the Board of Trade who had liberal profits on the long side of wheat continued today to take them, and while talk about inflation was renewed, there was little snap to the buying and to many observers the market acted as if overbought.

Rear Admiral Richard E. Byrd resigned as chairman of the National Economy League, a position which he had held since the organization's founding last July, at a meeting of the executive committee yesterday at the University Club.

In the opinion of Frank L. Dame, president of the North American Company, this country is about due for a recovery such as it had in 1921 to 1923, he told stockholders at the annual meeting of the company yesterday. He added that the company's utility system had a capacity for handling a 30 per cent greater business without additional capital investment.

WASHINGTON, April 25. -- In a turbulent engagement, spiced by a fifteen-minute pitched battle which resulted in the ejection of three players, Ben Chapman and Dixie Walker of the Yankees and Buddy Myer of the Senators, and the arrest of five spectators, the Yanks routed the Senators today, 16 to 0.
WASHINGTON, April 25. -- The most interesting fact today is a psychological one. It is the attachment, in the best sense of the word, which has taken place between President Roosevelt and M. Herriot.

LONDON, April 25. -- Replying to questions in the House of Commons today about Prime Minister MacDonald's visit to Washington, Stanley Baldwin, Acting Prime Minister and Lord President of the Council, said they must wait until his return.

SHANGHAI, April 25. -- Extradition difficulties are likely to be exploited to the utmost in an effort to defeat the return to the United States of C.C. Julian, the oil promoter wanted in the Oklahoma mail fraud case, following his discovery in Shanghai, where he had resided for the last month under an assumed name at the Hotel Metropole.

Clinton P. Anderson, president of Rotary International, will sail tonight on the Cunarder Berengaria for Europe. Others leaving on the ship are Miss Katherine Spector, chosen as Queen Esther at the Jewish Alliance Ball, going on a trip to Palestine via Paris; Dennis King, actor; Miss Thelma Todd, moving picture actress, and the following:

Led by Captain George (Red) Kieffer, who drove out two home runs and excelled in the field, the Manhattan freshman baseball team chalked up its sixth straight victory at the expense of the.N.Y.U. cub nine at the Catholic Protectory Oval yesterday.

A former Yale star, Frank Righeimer Jr. of Chicago, advanced through the semi-final round of the national epee championship yesterday and as a result will be the only contestant competing for two titles when the finals in epee, foils and saber are staged at the Hotel Astor tonight.

The congregation of St. Marks-in-the-Bouwerie voted unanimously at a meeting last night to repudiate the attempt of the recently ousted vestrymen to displace the Rev. Dr. William Norman Guthrie as rector of the church.

A new electro-mechanical instrument, which transmits sound vibrations through the bones of the head, made it possible yesterday for a group of deaf children in a classroom of the New York School for the Deaf, at Riverside Drive and 163d Street, to hear clearly their first radio program.

ROME, April 25. -- The Italian Finance Minister, Guido Jung, left Genoa" for New York this morning aboard the Conte di Savoia to represent Premier Mussolini in the economic conversations with President Roosevelt in Washington. He is accompanied only by Eugenic Anzillotto, Director General of Commercial Affairs in the Ministry of Corporations; George D. Lvecchio, Director General of the Treasury, and a small number of lesser officials of the Finance Ministry.

WASHINGTON, April 25. -- Production and distribution of commodities, which, declined during the latter part of February and the early part of March, increased after the middle of the latter month, the Federal Reserve Board said today in its monthly review of business conditions.
Sixteen Manhattan and Bronx properties were bought in at foreclosure auctions yesterday by the plaintiffs in the actions. The results follow:

While three victims of the racketeers controlling the kosher poultry business in the Bronx worked around their market yesterday under a special guard of detectives, Police Commissioner Bolan issued a statement promising full protection to any other business men held in racketeers' grip.

After defeating three local bills sponsored by Aldermanic President Joseph V. McKee yesterday, the Tammany-controlled bloc in the Board of Estimate placed the stamp of approval on three other measures sponsored by Mayor O'Brien, which contained no essential differences from the McKee bills.

BERLIN, April 25. -- The Boerse today presented much the same aspect as yesterday, stocks fluctuating irregularly and generally within a moderate range in response to operations apparently confined almost entirely to professional interests.

WASHINGTON, April 25. -- To recast a statement of the problem before the international statesmen now in Washington in the terms of mountain-climbing, their task is to ascend the Matterhorn with a basket of eggs and bring these to the summit, intact.

VATICAN CITY, April 25. -- A dozen cracks appearing in the walls of the Lapidary Hall of the Vatican induced the authorities today to close the hall, in which thousands of Holy Year pilgrims, including many Americans, have been received in general audience by the Pope in the last three weeks.

Professor KEMMERER of Princeton has sometimes been called the "doctor of sick public finance." He has practiced in several countries with success, helping to balance budgets and stabilize currencies. It begins to look as if he might be called in to the bedside of ailing American finance.
LONDON, April 25. -- Sir John Simon, the British Foreign Secretary, told the House of Commons today he was convinced the charges against the British engineers tried in Moscow were unfounded.

With an undercurrent of uneasiness in Brooklyn Democratic circles as the result of the threatened fight between Mayor John P. O'Brien and Aldermanic President McKee over the mayoralty nomination, Kenneth F. Sutherland, veteran Coney Island Democratic leader, and his close associate, Alderman James F. Kiernan, have come to the parting of the ways, it was revealed yesterday.

NEW YORK. Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Linden Smith, who returned recently from Egypt, will be with Mr. and Mrs. William Jay Schieffelin until they leave the middle of May for Loon Point, their place in Dublin, N.H.

WASHINGTON, April 25. -- What attitude the government would take in regard to the payment of its security obligations in the event of a reduction in the gold content of the dollar has been a matter of conjecture since the introduction of the controlled inflation amendment to the farm relief bill.

Vassily Laren, known to his fellow employes of the Ringling Brothers, Barnum and Bailey Circus as Rattlesnake Bill, who could spin yarns of his adventures as a Cossack in the Imperial Russian Army and as a cavalryman in the American Army, died of lobar pneumonia yesterday in Bellevue Hospital.

ST. LOUIS, April 25 (AP). -- Inspired by the presence of Rogers Hornsby, their former manager, at second base after an absence of six years, the St. Louis Cardinals won the final game of the series from the Pittsburgh Pirates today, 10 to 3.

WASHINGTON, April 25. -- An attempt to impeach Judge James A. Lowell, who in court at Boston yesterday freed on a writ of habeas corpus a Negro charged with murder in Virginia, will be sought by the Virginia delegation in the House of Representatives.

The Music School of the Henry Street Settlement, under the direction of Mrs. Hedi Katz, presented last night the American premiere of "Der Jasager," a short two-act opera by Kurt Weil, at the Grand Street Playhouse.
The New York Spring Horse Show returned yesterday after an absence of many years and members of society and lovers of the horse turned out in force to watch the thoroughbreds at the Riding Club.

The sewing class of the Daughters of the Cincinnati, which meets Friday mornings to make garments for the unemployment relief branch of the Red Cross, gave a luncheon yesterday at the Pierre to stimulate interest in its work.

SYRACUSE, April 25. -- Mrs. D. Leigh Colvin, president of the State Woman's Christian Temperance Union, was chosen today to head the fight against ratification of repeal of the Eighteenth Amendment in New York.

Details of the architectural competition designed to obtain plans for modern development of low-cost housing on a typical old-tenement block in New York, were announced yesterday by the sponsors, the trustees of the Phelps Stokes Fund.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., April 25. -- Miss Catherine Singer of the Westchester Country Club shot an 84 to take the lead in the first round of play in the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association Spring invitation tournament at the Sea-view Golf Club today.

The long-awaited break in the depression may already have com and if the confidence already existing continues and spreads the depression will be ended, Richard Whitney, president of the New York Stock Exchange, asserted yesterday at the third weekly report meeting of the Salvation Army United Appeal at the Bankers Club.

A Federal investigation of the so-called endless-chain system of salesmanship, a scheme by which every one involved in the purchase of merchandise is supposed to get rich by arithmetical progression, was begun yesterday by George Z. Medalie.

To the Editor of The New York Times: THE TIMES published last month a splendid letter from Hector MacQuarrie, dated London, suggesting a union, of the "United States and the British Empire. I suggest a federation.

WASHINGTON, April 25. -- By a vote of 306 to 91 the House today passed the Muscle Shoals bill providing for government operation of the huge war munitions plant and sent the measure to the Senate, where it appeared certain that it would be modified by the inclusion of certain features of the Norris bill, now before that body.
WASHINGTON, April 25.-- President Roosevelt and Edouard Herriot, French envoy, engaged tonight in an exhaustive discussion of disarmament at their White House meeting.

Tuesday, April 25, 1933. Time money, short dates, eased another fraction on top of that recorded on Monday, 60-90 days being offered at 1 1/4 per cent, compared with 1 1/2 previously. Other maturities were steady. Bill rates were cut 1/3, in yield, all dates, the downward revision putting the new schedule at levels which prevailed between April 20-11.

The New York Central Railroad, which in 1931 completed the Melrose Central Building in the Bronx for occupancy by the railroad and the Pullman Company, has leased space therein to the Melrose Division of the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company, and expects to rent quarters to other firms, it was announced yesterday.

The recovery in bond prices was extended yesterday on the Stock Exchange, although the advance was not so vigorous as on the previous day. The laggard group was the foreign loans section. United States Government bonds made modest gains, the maximum being 16-32 point, on a turnover of $1,957,000.

The office of "The Daily Tab" -- Mr. Theron Bamberger, publisher -- was a mad sort of place in which to work. In most newspaper offices only the editors are the furies. In that established last evening on the Uttered stage of the Lyceum, every one was.

BERLIN, April 25. -- According to present indications the lesser wing of the Cabinet -- the Nationalists -- is being overrun by the Nazi tide, and Dr. Alfred Hugenberg, their leader, may be forced out of his post of Minister of Economics and Agriculture.

Another circus came to town -- and more particularly to Park Avenue -- last night to compete with, its foremost rival in Madison Square Garden. Designated the Cobina Wright Circus Ball, the event moved into the grand ballroom suite of the Waldorf-Astoria, or "Park Avenue's tent-lot," with "Positively the Greatest Array of Human or Animal Entertainers Ever Assembled Under the Waldorf-Astoria Big Top."

TOM BRIDGES of the Detroit Tigers pitched a one-hit game. Red Lucas of the Reds held the Cardinals to two hits. Bump Hadley of the Browns gave the Improved White Sox two hits. John Berly of the Phillies was just as stingy when he worked against the Braves some days ago. There have been plenty of three-hit and four-hit games.

WASHINGTON, April 25. -- Manufacturing and printing and publishing establishments, numbering 32,131, located in the "industrial area" of New York City, had an output of products valued at $6,162,828,205 in 1931, compared with a manufactured output in 1929 valued at $9,424,294,682, according to the biennial census of manufactures made public today by the Department of Commerce.

WASHINGTON, April 25. -- The string quartet of Bohuslav Martinu, which won the Elizabeth Sprague Coolidge Prize of 1932, received its first public performance this morning at the fourth concert of the Library of Congress Festival of Chamber Music.

A second mortgage for $7,500 on the five-story tenement at the southeast corner of 5th Av. and 119th St., held by Dora Brauer from the Efrem Realty Corp., Frank Skolnik, president, has been extended to Oct. 15, 1935, at 6 per cent, with an instalment of $500 to be paid oft semi-annually.

Having encountered what some of the commission houses referred to as a "wall of resistance," the stock market yesterday followed the line of least resistance by falling back. That was the explanation commonly offered in Wall Street, at least.

Medical science acted yesterday to save the life of 2-year-old Helen Vasko. The child underwent an operation at the Eye Institute of the Columbia Medical Centre. Her left eye and part of the optic nerve were removed by Dr. John H. Dunnington in an attempt to prevent the growth of a malignant tumor which, it was feared, ultimately would have caused her death.

LONDON, April 25. -- Chancellor of the Exchequer Neville Chamberlain presented the National Government's second budget in the House of Commons this afternoon and told the expectant nation that for another year it must remain the most heavily taxed community in the world.

The James Monroe High School and Evander Childs High baseball teams scored victories yesterday as play opened in the Upper Manhattan-Bronx division of the city P. S.A.L. senior high championship competition. Both won on their home fields, Monroe defeating George Washington High, 7 to 3, and Evander conquering Morris, 16 to 3.

The Cardinal's Emergency Committee, organized last weeK by former Governor Alfred E. Smith to supplement the annual campaign of the Catholic Charities, already has received contributions of $24,395, according to reports submitted by county chairmen, meeting yesterday in Mr. Smith's office in the Empire State Building.

Paolo Falcomato, middle-aged grocer, his sunken cheeks ashen with fear, was testifying in West Side Court yesterday against five men accused of attempted extortion when one of the hard-eyed, flashily dressed group muttered something. Magistrate Dreyer caught the sound.

PRINCETON, N.J., April 25. -- Athletic insignia have been awarded to twenty-three Princeton varsity, and freshman wrestlers and managers, it was announced today, by Asa S. Bushnell, graduate manager of athletics. The awards included eight varsity letters, twelve freshman numerals and three managerial insignia.

PRAGUE, April 25. -- In a speech interrupted by Communist and Nazi disturbers Foreign Minister Eduard Benes told the Czechoslovakian Parliament today under what conditions territorial revision might be possible in Central Europe. He made it clear that only "minor changes" were in question and that these could be made only by a voluntary agreement of the States concerned concluded in a peaceful atmosphere after years of cooperation and provided there were adequate compensation.

WASHINGTON, April 25. -- Strong opposition developed in the House today to the joint resolution ratifying the agreement under which the Federal Government would allocate to the New York Power Authority the power from the International Rapids section of the proposed St. Lawrence Waterway and indications tonight were that, unless the situation changes, the vote on ratifying the resolution tomorrow will be very close.

BERLIN, April 25. -- A new climax in the complete ostracism of Jewish athletes from organized German sports life has been reached by the Verband Deutscher Faustkaempfer, the Union of German Professional Boxers.

LA PAZ, Bolivia, April 25. -- Bolivian airplanes bombed the Casanillo Railway station, at Puerto Casado, on the Paraguay River, yesterday, and Campo Esperanza, bout 100 kilometers west of Puerto Casado.

BOSTON, April 25. -- Swinging a pile-driving left, Tommy Hudson, Cleveland Negro, gave clever Sedgwick Harvey of New York, the junior national 126-pound champion, a severe drubbing in a quarter-final round bout tonight to stamp himself as one of the outstanding battlers in the National A.A.U. title tournament.

WASHINGTON, April 25. -- President Roosevelt's inflation program was the centre of sharp conflict in the Senate again today as Democratic leaders pressed for passage of the Thomas amendment to the farm relief bill under a determined cross-fire from the Republican side.

Recent delays in carrying forward the program for slum clearance and the erection of additional low-cost apartment buildings in New York have been due largely to the failure of the city to formulate a definite policy regarding model housing, according to Darwin R. James, head of the State Board of Housing.
WASHINGTON, April 25. -- The Bureau of Navigation issued the following orders today, dated April, 22:

A final intensive effort to provide "tide-over" jobs for 392 men and women who have no other hope of support will be made today and tomorrow by 600 women workers of the Adopt-a-Family Committee, Mrs. August Belmont, chairman, announced yesterday.

The General Motors Corporation reported yesterday net earnings of $6,870,007 for the first quarter of this year. This was equivalent to 11 cents a share on the average number of common shares outstanding in the quarter, against $9,693,027, or 17 cents a share, for the corresponding period of last year.

Current problems in the life insurance field created, by the mortgage situation and by the indications of currency inflation were discussed by insurance executives yesterday at a special meeting of the Life Office Management Association at the Hotel New Yorker.
WASHINGTON, April 25. -- The War Department issued the following orders today:
Nothing Has Been Overlooked Any day may bring the news that the Nazi leadership name of the German money because a mark sounds too much like that hated name MARX.

In behalf of the Franciscan Order of Poor Clare Nuns a card party has been arranged by members of the Ladies Auxiliary of the order for Saturday afternoon at the Hotel Pennsylvania. The proceeds will be devoted to the building fund of the organization, which maintains a monastery in Haven Avenue.
WASHINGTON, April 25. -- The French seem to have assumed the most important position in any tentative understandings which have taken place here in the last few days.

WASHINGTON, April 25 (AP). -- The brilliant Hope diamond, which, legend says, casts a spell of ill fortune upon its owners, is Mrs. Evalyn Walsh McLean's basis of hope for financial help in achieving an ambition -- to keep control of The Washington Post for her sons.

BERLIN, April 25. -- Germany's economic policy under her new rulers is still obscure. This is a time of stock-taking and examination of the books for the new proprietors, and there is evidence that what they find is far from encouraging.
WASHINGTON, April 26. -- The Bureau of Navigation issued the following orders today, dated April 24:
The text of Prime Minister MacDonald's address last night, as broadcast over a National Broadcasting Company network, follows:

While it is difficult to estimate accurately the number of persons in the United States who indulge in the sport of fishing, it is certain that the anglers constitute a vast army. In the neighborhood of 4,000,000 fishing licenses are issued each year, but in addition more than 7,000,000 hunting licenses also are granted.

Before Prime Minister MACDONALD sailed from England he told the House of Commons that his visit to the United States was for the specific purpose of preparing for the World Economic Conference. Yesterday when leaving Washington he joined with the President in a statement that the two Governments are in complete agreement with regard to " the main objective of the conference."

Special to THE NEW YORK TIMES. The recent announcement that Ramsay MacDonald had gone to Rome to confer with Benito Mussolini regarding the international situation and the maintenance of peace excited the greatest public interest, and the world at large has shown a legitimate curiosity regarding the proposals put forward by the Italian Premier.

PHILADELPHIA, April 26. -- Leopold Stokowski, conductor, and musical director of the Philadelphia Orchestra, who has spent previous vacations studying Javanese, Mexican, Hindu, Indian, Aztec and Voodoo music forms, will leave next week for Turkey to devote some time to delving into the modes and methods of early Byzantine music.

TOKYO, Thursday, April 27. -- Yosuke Matsuoka, returning from his tour of the world in connection with his mission to the League of Nations, exhorted the Japanese people, in an interview sent by radio to the Asahi as his ship neared Japan, to return to their own ideas and to cultivate their national spirit.
PARIS, April 28 (AP). -- France moved today toward what financial experts hope will be a three-power financial pact with the United States and Great Britain for the stabilization, of currencies.

NEWARK, N.J., April 26. -- William J. Wells of Montclair, who was elected to the board of directors of R.H. Macy Co. yesterday, was elected president of L. Bamberger Co. today at a meeting of the board of the Newark department store.

WASHINGTON, April 26.-- The high point in today's activities of the French mission here was Edouard Harriot's visit to the Capitol. He came away from his luncheon with Senator Robinson, after having talked with Vice President Garner, Chief Justice Hughes and other high-ranking government officials, much reassured as to the parliamentary situation here.

The United Hunts Racing Association meeting on May 20 will be held over a new course near Roslyn, L.I., and a new era of achievement in the field of amateur racing impends as the result of action taken in recent months, according to an announcement by Harry A. Buck yesterday.
Fluctuations on the Cotton Exchange became irregular yesterday and after frequent changes over a range of a quarter cent a pound, prices ended with a gain of a point to a loss of 4 points on the day.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 26. -- A noisy demonstration for Thomas J. Mooney today prevented the man incarcerated in San Quentin prison for the Preparedness Day bombing of 1916 from immediately obtaining a second trial.

The consolidated income statement of the North American Company and subsidiaries for the twelve months ended on March 31 shows $12,144,629 for the common stock after all charges, taxes, reserves and preferred dividends. This was equal to $1.63 a share earned on the average number of shares outstanding during the year, and compares with $21,343,107, or $3.16 a share, in the preceding twelve months.

Louis H. Willard, who committed suicide after being cleared of perjury before the Hofstadter committee, was characterized as a "victim of injustice" at the funeral services conducted yesterday in the Riverside Memorial Chapel by Dr. Stephen S. Wise, in the presence of Samuel Seabury, counsel to the committee, and other civic reform leaders.
BERLIN, April 26. -- The Boerse opened hesitant and irregular today, later steadying, with a few stocks scoring substantial advances.
The Columbia freshman baseball team scored a 6-to-5 triumph, over the Fordham yearlings at Fordham Field yesterday.

A unanimous decision to include the 1 per cent State sales tax in the retail price of merchandise and not list it as a separate item on the price ticket or sales check has been reached by the members of the Retail Dry Goods Association, comprising leading department stores Here.

ALBANY, April 26. -- Angry dairy farmers served notice today on the State Milk Control Board that they would call a State-wide milk strike next month unless the board establishes a minimum price of 3 1/2 cents a quart for the producers by May 10.

LONDON, April 26. -- By the terms of the new Anglo-Danish trade agreement, made public today, British coal, coke, pig iron, steel mesh and jute will now enter Danish ports duty free. In return, Great Britain grants concessions whereby Denmark may materially increase her exports of ham, bacon and eggs.

Mrs. Samuel Seabury opened her home, 154 East Sixty-third Street, yesterday afternoon for the annual meeting of the National Church Club for Women, an Episcopal organization, the headquarters of which are in the Allerton House, 130 East Fifty-seventh Street.

BERLIN, April 26. -- An official statement elucidating the reasons for the new law restricting the number of German Jews to be admitted to the higher schools and the universities emphasizes that the overcrowding of the liberal professions has made such restriction an economic necessity and that in this connection persons of non-Aryan descent must be specially dealt with.

PRINCETON, N.J., April 26. -- Fordham pounded two Princeton pitchers for sixteen hits to defeat the Tiger nine, 15-5, on University Field today. Estwanick went the route for the visitors, fanning nine and Issuing only two passes.

PHILADELPHIA, Thursday, April 27. -- The anthracite wage conference, of six representatives of the operators and six of the United Mine Workers of America, which had been in session here since April 19, adjourned abruptly at 2 o'clock this morning on receipt of a telegram from Miss Frances Perkins, Secretary of Labor, who urged that the conference delay action for thirty days.

An hour after she left her home in the Beverly Hall Apartments at 132-70 Sanford Avenue, Flushing, Queens, last night, to play with other girls in the neighborhood, Barbara Schwartz, 14 years old, daughter of Harry Schwartz, a New York stockbroker, was found unconscious in a basement passageway of another apartment house across the street.

The Board of Elections made public yesterday the final figures on the votes cast in the city for all offices at the election last November, as tabulated in the recount authorized by the Board of Estimate. The figures on the Mayoralty candidates, in which the greatest discrepancies between the first count and the recount were shown, were printed two weeKs ago.

The Dessoff Choirs, having recently introduced Vecchi's "L'Anfiparnaso" to America, continued the tradition of unusual and interesting works at their second concert of the season, given last night in the Town Hall.

The time has come when business men must enter politics or face seeing "their private business and the general welfare wrecked by people who are in public life for exactly that purpose," Colonel Robert R. McCormick, editor and publisher of The Chicago Tribune, declared yesterday at a luncheon given by the Bond Club of New York in his honor at the Bankers Club.

The publishing firm of Ray Long and Richard R. Smith was thrown into bankruptcy yesterday, but a majority of the creditors voted to recommend that Richard R. Smith carry on the firm in lieu of a receiver. Ray Long, the majority stockholder, has been in the South Seas for the last nine months.

While protests mounted yesterday against the plan of Park Commissioner John E. Sheehy to construct an athletic field on the site of the old reservoir in Central Park -- protests based on the conviction that such use violated the fundamental purposes of the park and also incurred the danger of commercialization -- Mr. Sheehy revealed that players using the baseball diamonds would be required to pay a fee.

LONDON, April 26. -- The Velsheda, the second J Class yacht to be built in Great Britain, was launched today at Camper Nicholson's yards in Gosport. The vessel was built for W.L. Stephenson, who last season raced White Heather in the big class.

Harry W. Watrous, 75-year-old painter, climaxed his nearly thirty-five years of service as an officer of the National Acaaemy of Design by being elected president yesterday. He succeeds Cass Gilbert, architect, who, after holding the presidency for seven years, declined to be a candidate again.
