"The Romance of the Skies," "The Challenge of Cosmic Problems," "The Secrets of the Earth," "The Story of Life" and "Problems of the Machine Age" are the section headings of H. Gordon Garbedian's "Major Mysteries of Science," published today by Covici, Friede.

The clergy of the Lutheran Church attending the New York Pastoral Conference of the Atlantic division of the Missouri Synod were divided yesterday in their views on granting suffrage to the women of their congregations in the affairs of church administration.

The proposal of Aldermanic President McKee that the city, with Samuel Untermyer as special counsel, intervene as a party in the Interborough receivership in the Federal courts was shelved yesterday by the committee of the whole of the Board of Estimate.

Acquisition of most of the assets of the General Aviation Corporation by North American Aviation, Inc., through the issuance to General Aviation of a large block of stock of North American was approved yesterday by the stockholders of both companies at meetings in Wilmington, Del.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., April 26. -- The navy baseball team turned back Temple by 11 -- 6 today, clouting three varsity twirlers for twelve hits.

BYDGOSZCZ, Poland, April 26. -- This busy, enterprising commercial city is virtually the capital of the Polish Corridor, although it is in Poznan Province and not in Pomorze. The real feelings of the Corridor's populations, both Polish and German, are best studied here.
COLLEGE PARK. Md., April 26. -- Maryland lost to Virginia, 11 to 6, in a Southern Conference contest today. Orlin Rogers held the home nine to two hits in seven innings. The score by innings:
WASHINGTON, April 26. -- Mrs. Nellie Tayloe Ross, former Governor of Wyoming and vice chairman of the Democratic National Committee, was appointed Director of the Mint today by President Roosevelt.

Possibly because of legislative confusion in Washington, the markets continued to feel their way cautiously yesterday. Uncertainties surrounding the increasingly debatable inflation bill were being carefully weighed and the general indecision was expressed in conflicting price movements on the exchanges.

Ishhel MacDonald, daughter of the British Prime Minister, bade the United Seates "au revoir" last night and sailed for home aboard the Berengaria expressing the hope she would be back soon. Her farewell message was an appeal for international cooperation as the only solution of the world's political and economic problems.

WASHINGTON, April 26. -- Support of the main purpose of the Black bill to establish the six-hour day and five-day week by law was voiced before the House Labor Committee today by William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, and Gerard Swope, president of the General Electric Company.

In accepting the resignation of Admiral BYRD as its chairman the National Economy League ascribes to his personal popularity and contagious enthusiasm a large part of the prestige which this organization so speedily acquired. The league was organized for the purpose of obtaining a reduction of unnecessary and unwarranted costs in Federal, State and local government.

PITTSBURGH, April 26. -- A sane monetary policy, upheld by the principal nations, alone will revive trade, the twentieth convention of the Foreign Trade Council was told today by James A. Farrell, former chairman of the United State Steel Corporation.
WASHINGTON, April 26. -- The War Department issued the following orders today:

Old cries come back along with, old financial nostrums. It was left for Senator BORAH on Tuesday to revive a defense of fiat money often made in the days of the greenback craze. Why, said the Idaho Senator, the Government notes which it is proposed to authorize under the inflation bill would be perfectly good, because behind them would be " the credit of the country."

Two aviation mechanics, one of them having a private pilot's license, narrowly escaped death last evening when a biplane in which they were riding crashed while taking off from an emergency landing field at the foot of Golder Avenue, Springfield Dock, Queens, and then caught fire.
NEW YORK. Dr. and Mrs. Charles Gilmore Kerley will go to Hilltop, their country place in Sharon, Conn., on Monday for the Summer.

The successor to Admiral PRATT as Chief of Naval Operations will be for the first time a Californian, Vice Admiral W.H. STANDLEY. A Chief of Naval Operations should be an authority on the Navy, and bis judgments should be liberal and sound.

MEXICO CITY, April 26. -- The message of Josephus Daniels to President Rodriguez in presenting his credentials as the new Ambassador from the United States has created a favorable reaction in newspaper editorials. El Universal says today:

That the Chicago, Rock Island Pacific Railway management has given thought to a reorganization is disclosed in correspondence between Marcus L. Bell, senior vice president and general counsel, and the Interstate Commerce Commission.

NEWMARKET, England, April 26. -- The French colt Rodosto, a son of the famous Epinard, unexpectedly qualified today for the Derby when he led a field of twenty-seven over the mile route of the Two Thousand Guineas, first of the five historic classics of the English turf for 3-year-olds.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Mark Graves, president of the New York State Tax Commission, declared that the per cent tax on gross receipts of retail stores is intended as a tax on the seller for the privilege of selling. He also explained that customers would be justified in refusing to pay $101 for an article tagged $100 plus $1 tax.

Prices in local commodity markets were steadier yesterday and closed irregularly higher. Silver and coffee continued to lose ground, but in most of the others at least some of the contracts showed gains. Trading tapered off to some extent.

The 600 women workers of the Adopt-a-Family Committee, of which Mrs. August Belmont is chairman, will open their final intensive drive to provide "tide-over" jobs for 392 men and women at a luncheon to be held today at the Waldorf-Astoria.

ALBANY, April 26. -- With civic organizations and social workers from New York City strongly advocating the Steingut bill creating for the city a new domestic relations court, composed of the present Children's Court and the Family Court, the measure ran against unexpected opposition from the State Department of Correction at a hearing before Governor Lehman today.

Harry W. Forbes, a member of the law firm of Sherman Sterling, attorneys for the National City Bank, was taken yesterday before Federal Judge Coleman. after refusing to answer a question put to him before the Federal grand jury which is investigating the income of Charles E. Mitchell, former chairman of the bank's board, who is awaiting trial for alleged evasion of the income tax law.

A cabled order from Nazi chiefs in Germany directing the dissolution of the American branch of the party and the disbanding of the 1,500 members of the organization was sent here about two weeks ago, it was revealed, and was confirmed in a letter received at local headquarters yesterday.

WASHINGTON, April 26. -- The House by a vote of 209 to 150 today directed the Judiciary Committee to investigate the refusal of Federal Judge James A. Lowell at Boston to permit the extradition to Virginia of George Crawford, a Negro, under indictment in that State for the murder of Mrs. Agnes B. Ilsley of Middleburg, and the latter's maid, Mrs. Nina Buckley.

The listing of 279,967 common stock trust certificates with a par value of $1 a share of the Grand Union Company, which will be issued on a share-for-share basis for the trust certificates for old no-par stock of the company, was authorized by the New York Stock Exchange yesterday.

The New York Stock Exchange announced yesterday that since Dec. 10, 1929, its committee on stock list had unsuccessfully tried to persuade the Allied Chemical and Dye Company to issue more detailed reports to stockholders.

Names of the persons selected as members of the local licensing boards throughout the State will be made public today or tomorrow, Edward P. Mulrooney, chairman of the State Alcoholic Beverage Board, announced yesterday. He said he could not say at present who would be members of the New York City board, and in answer to a question declared he had not spoken to Mayor O'Brien concerning the personnel.

ALBANY, April 26. -- Marathon dancing was outlawed today in the State under a bill approved by Governor Lehman which makes it a misdemeanor to conduct or participate in such exhibitions for more than eight consecutive hours.

The Westinghouse Electric and Manufacturing Company reports for the first quarter of 1933 a net loss of $3,491,572, comparing with a net loss of $2,986,289 in the final quarter of 1932 and one of $1,320,148 in the first quarter of that year.

CLEVELAND, April 26 (AP). -- Lanky Oral Hildebrand missed the goal of all pitchers--a no-hit game--today by the narrow margin of a single safe blow as the Cleveland Indians made it two in a row over St. Louis. The score was 2 to 0.
WEST POINT, N.Y., April 26. -- Army succumbed to Lehigh on the diamond today, 8 to 5, in an eleveninning contest. Jack Lewis hit two Homers for the cadets.

BERLIN, April 26. -- The revocation yesterday on order of Chancellor Hitler of the appointment of a Protestant church commissar in Mecklenburg-Schwerin who was to have coordinated the church with the National Socialist regime does not seem to have discouraged the German Christians, the Nazi section of the Protestant synod.

The Kashruth Association of Greater New York, Inc., having as members a large number of orthodox rabbis, meeting last night in the Broad-way Central Hotel, adopted a resolution asserting that under present circumstances the orthodox rabbinate of New York could not as a body bear the responsibility for the kashruth of delicatessen, products in this city.

TRENTON, N.J., April 26. -- Nominating petitions were filed today with the Secretary of State by candidates for election at the primaries on May 16 as delegates at large to the State convention that will vote on ratification of prohibition repeal.

HAVRE DE GRACE, Md., April 26. -- William Ziegler Jr. 's Bonanza, a son of Swift and Sure and El Dorado, equaled the four-and-one-halffurlong track record at Havre de Grace today when he scored a decisive five-length victory in the $13,900 Aberdeen Stakes.

A dinner for Mr. and Mrs. Edgar K. Marston 2d, who were married recently, was given last night at the Central Park Casino by a group of their friends. Mrs. Marston is the former Miss Florence Carr of Chicago. The guests were seated at an oval table which was decorated with jonquils and blue iris.

WESTBURY, L.I., April 26. -- Mrs. William Goadby Loew, with narcissi grown on her estate, Loew moor, won this afternoon the silver sweepstakes prize and the gold medal award at the annual narcissus show of the Westbury Horticultural Society, held in Winthrop Hall of the Church of the Advent here.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Your correspondent, W.I.G., raises the question of the public and private indebtedness in the United States, in this morning's paper. It is considerably less than he imagines, according to trustworthy statistics.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Your editorial comment on Dr. Crile's experiments is good logic from the standpoint of classical physics, but neither logic nor common sense may be applied with impunity in the interpretation of phenomena as viewed by the modern physicist, because they are outside the domain of human experience.

Supported in his assertions by a deputy sheriff, John Vasko contended yesterday that his 2-year-old daughter, Helen, was given up by him and his wife for an eye operation under pressure and not voluntarily, as Judge George W. Smyth of Westchester Children's Court had declared.

The Creek Holding Corporation, acting for a party in interest, yesterday took over on a bid totaling $2,801,000 the thirty-five-story office building at 114-18 John Street, occupying the westerly blockfront on Pearl Street to Platt Street. The building was offered in foreclosure at the stand of Henry Brady, auctioneer, to satisfy a lien of $448,067 in an action brought by the Manufacturers Trust Company against the Platt Holding Corporation.
Scoring thirteen runs in the last three innings, the Manhattan College baseball team defeated St. John's College at Dexter Park, Brooklyn, yesterday.

BERLIN, April 26. -- Theodor Duesterberg, second in command of the Stahlhelm, whose paternal grandfather was a Jew, was dismissed today from all his offices by order of Colonel Franz Seldte, the first leader, and was commanded to refrain henceforth from all activities in the Stahlhelm, the League or War Veterans.

BERLIN, April 26. -- That "iron ring" around Germany that has ever been a German nightmare and the preventing of which has been an object of German foreign policy is being brought appreciably nearer to reality by German development of the last few weeks.

CHICAGO, April 26. -- Minor casualties, caused, by fists and clubs, marked the second invasion the morning of the financial centre by about 3,000 school teachers, to force payment of $30,000,000 back salaries. The district was turned into an armed camp and some of the banks were forced to bar their doors to all except pass-book hold ers.

WALLINGFORD, Conn., April 26.-- The Taft School baseball team of Watertown, Conn., vanquished Choate School today, 7 to 6. The game, witnessed by 500 persons despite the cold weather, marked the renewal of athletic relations between the two Institutions.

A move by business men of the State to draw up a legislative program, to speed the revival of business was started yesterday when a group, meeting at the Bar Association, 42 West Forty-fourth Street, at the call of the New York State Economic Council, Inc., authorized George W. Wickersham, chairman of the board, to appoint a committee representing business and industrial groups to prepare such an outline for Federal and State legislation.

WASHINGTON, April 26. -- Prime Minister MacDonald, in his farewell talk with newspaper men today, said that his conversations with President Roosevelt had led to a closer understanding, but to no agreements, no "entanglements" and no settlement of world problems.
One drive from the bat of bold Michael Finn at the Polo Grounds yesterday robbed LeRoy Farmelee of a niche in baseball's Hall of Fame.

BOSTON, April 26. -- Almost crushed by mid-Western manpower in the trials, the Eastern talent in the National A.A.U. championship boxing tournament tonight put on a stirring last-ditch series of battles to gain five of the eight prized titles from the pick of the nation's amateur battlers.

Two men suspected by the police of having important connections with the poultry racket were, arrested late yesterday afternoon on charges of felonious assault made by a rabbi whose identity was withheld for fear of gang vengeance.

WASHINGTON, April 26. -- Having sped the parting guest in the person of the Prime Minister of Great Britain and having welcomed in turn Prime Minister Bennett of Canada, President and Mrs. Roosevelt tonight gave a State dinner, followed by a reception, for M. Herriot of France.

PEIPING, Thursday, April 27. -- The Japanese forces in North China have suddenly made a rapid withdrawal from the Lwan River area, in which they had been conducting far-flung operations that were taking them toward Tientsin and Peiping.
Leases of space in Manhattan business building's for occupancy by various trade associations were announced yesterday. These were in the midtown area.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., April 26. -- Although the New Haven police nine today batted George Parker for eleven safe hits, while Yale found Walter Klarman, former Holy Cross twirler, for only five, a succession of fielding blunders by the policemen gave the Elis the game, 5-0.

WASHINGTON, April 26. -- The joint resolution ratifying the agreement made between the Federal Government and the New York Power Authority allocating the power to be developed in the international rapids section of the proposed Great Lakes-St. Lawrence Waterway was passed by the House this afternoon without a roll-call.

WASHINGTON, April 26. -- In the first statement on business conditions by an administration official since the inauguration. Secretary Roper declared today that general business activity had progressed steadily since the latter part of March.

An appraisal yesterday of the estate of Miss Laura Shannon, who left $1,371,654 gross and $1,284,836 net, disclosed that more than $1,000,000 of this goes to St. Luke's Hospital, whereas if Bishop William T. Manning had predeceased her, the chief beneficiary would have been the Cathedral of St. John the Divine.
WASHINGTON, April 26. -- The major feature of the administration's legislative program will be concluded with the submission by the President early next week of a railroad bill.

WASHINGTON, April 26. -- Inquiries as to terms under which New York City could obtain loans from the Reconstruction Finance Corporation for self - liquidating projects or relief work were made here today by Controller Berry, but he did not apply for money at this time.

Notes which amounted to $925,000 at the end of the preceding fiscal year were paid by the Federated Department Stores, Inc., in the year ended on Jan. 31, according to the annual report made public yesterday. Inventories were reduced and cash and net working capital were increased in the meantime.

RIVERSIDE, N.J., April 26. -- Rejecting a suggestion of the Board of Education that pupils of the junior and senior high schools here return to their classes tomorrow, about 1,500 parents and students of the school voted tonight to continue tomorrow the "strike" to protest the reinstatement on a Supreme Court order of Mrs. Marion B. Rein as principal of the school.

WASHINGTON, April 26. -- While the National Defense act contemplated a standing army of 18,000 officers and 125,000 enlisted men, there are only 12,000 officers in service now, and 4,000 of these are believed scheduled for retirement under the administration's economy plan, General Douglas MacArthur, Chief of Staff of the Army, told the House Military Affairs Committee today.

PARIS, April 26. -- Inflation ideas are spreading rapidly here. Those who a few days ago timidly suggested that perhaps the franc would be forced off the gold standard as a result of events in Washington are now much more boldly proclaiming that course to be the only sound one.

WASHINGTON, April 26. -- An admission at the White House today that the President will ask Congress for powers during its recess to adjust the war debts as well as to negotiate tariff treaties brought final conviction to those from abroad who have been engaged in the Washington conversations this week that the Geneva Disarmament Conference and the World Monetary and Economic Conference at London are destined for success.

CHICAGO, April 26 (AP). -- Detroit overcame a three-run lead in the closing innings today and then went on to defeat the White Sox, 6 to 4, in an eleven-inning game in which thirty-two players, including seven pitchers, saw action.
"Nine Pine Street," a play based on the notorious Lizzie Borden murder case, will open this evening at the Longacre Theatre, with Lillian Gish in the leading role.

Opponents of a government policy of aid to the merchant marine in Congress and in States not directly associated with seaboard activities were assailed yesterday by R.J. Baker, secretary of the American Steamship Owners' Association, in an address to the Jersey City Executives' Club aboard the Dollar liner President Grant.

E.H. Harriman, who started as an office boy and became, in the phrase of a contemporary cartoonist, "The New Colossus of Roads," is described as "the last individualist" in "E.H. Harriman: The Little Giant of Wall Street," by H.J. Eckenrode and Pocahontas Wight Edmunds, published today by Greenberg.

BERLIN, April 26. -- The dismissal of Theodore Duesterberg as "second leader" of the Steel Helmet War Veterans organization was ordered today by Franz Seldte, Labor Minister in the Hitler Cabinet and Steel Helmet chieftain.

Lucian Pesco, secretly arrested here last Thursday by police and postoffice inspectors as a member of a gang of kidnappers who abducted Albert Hendler, 21-year-old student at Johns Hopkins University and the son of L. Manuel Handler, Baltimore ice-cream manufacturer, was held in nail of $15,000 when, he was arraigned yesterday before Garrett W. Cotter, United States Commissioner.

The character of youth must be maintained and developed despite the handicap of the depression, speakers declared last night at a dinner of the Bronx Council of the Boy Scouts of America at the Ambassador. The dinner was attended by 300 workers in the campaign to raise $193,000 for maintenance of Scout work, of which $10,000 is the quota of the Bronx.

William II Imperfectly Aryan. Twenty-five years ago FELIX ADLER was Theodore Roosevelt exchange professor at the University of Berlin. The conclusion is unavoidable that Dr. ADLER must have been, persona grata not only to the President of the United States at that time but to the head of the German Reich at that time.

With the exception of those of the Southern and the Detroit, Toledo Ironton reports of railroad earnings for March, which were released yesterday, showed declines from March, 1932. The Southern increased its net operating income by $100,000.

The usual series of free concerts by the Goldman Band under the direction of Edwin Franko Goldman will be presented again this Summer on the Mall in Central Park and on the University Heights campus of New York University, it was announced yesterday.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., April 26. -- One more institution was added today to the list of those engaged in rowing when President Robert C. Clothier of Rutgers University accepted for the college the boat house and the equipment in the ceremony which, marked the resumption of the sport at Rutgers.

Improved steel demand is reflected this week in sharp increases in scrap prices, a firmer price structure for finished steel products and a rise to 25 per cent of ingot capacity in the the national average of operations, according to the weekly review of The Iron Age.

WASHINGTON, April 26. -- Clear visions of a brave new world in which humanity is to live happily under President Roosevelt are responsible for the daring and multiplicity of the ideas of those advisers who are collectively known as "the brain trust."

ST. LOUIS, April 26 (AP). -- Silas Johnson held the St. Louis Cardinals to five hits, and the Cincinnati Beds took the first game of the series today, 2 to 1, largely because Leo Durocher, usually a weak hitter, pounded everything that Paul Derringer offered him.
WASHINGTON, April 26. -- Following is the text of Prime Minister MacDonald's talk to newspaper men at the White House, today:

WASHINGTON, April 26. -- As it became more apparent today that Prime Minister Bennett had come to Washington prepared to do some real bargaining with President Roosevelt on trade between the United States and Canada, the administration became extremely cautious lest the impression go abroad that the conversations with the Canadian Premier would result in specific agreements not contemplated in the original plan for the preliminary discussions on the World Monetary and Economic Conference.

LONDON, April 26. -- Sir Henry Alfred McCardie, noted as Britain's "bachelor judge," whose pronouncements on sociological problems have aroused countless controversies, was found shot tonight in his apartment overlooking St. James's Park. Servants found him huddled in a chair, a self-inflicted wound in his head.
New York City obligations amounting to $140,000,000 were renewed yesterday by the city's bankers until June 10 in an atmosphere of silence on the part of the bankers as well as city officials.

MANILA, April 26. -- The annual report of Brig. Gen. Creed Hammond, the insurlar auditor, showed today a wide discrepancy with the report former Governor General Theodore Roosevelt previously released.

BOSTON, April 26 (AP). -- The financial report for 1932 of the International Paper and Power Company, presented at the annual meeting of shareholders today by its president, Archibald R. Graussein, showed a net loss of $8,757,728. Directors were re-elected.

GENEVA, April 26. -- The United States Government declared formally and publicly for the first time today that some security measures were necessary for disarmament. It put one of them -- international supervision of armaments -- on the same plane with abolition of aggressive weapons, classing the two as the chief means toward disarmament and it expressed willingness, to consider the reinforcing of supervision still further as the French desire.
WASHINGTON, April 26. -- President Roosevelt and Prime Minister MacDonald issued this joint statement today relative to their conversations:

BUENOS AIRES, April 26. -- Argentina plans to send a special mission to Washington to discuss projects for a reciprocal tariff treaty, and the question of exchange in these negotiations is to be separate from the conversations to be conducted by Ambassadors Le Breton and Espil with President Roosevelt.

WASHINGTON, April 26. -- When Prime Minister MacDonald's train pulled out of Washington today to start him on his journey back to his own domestic difficulties, he left behind him the impression that both he and President Roosevelt had built a ladder of achievement up which England, America and other nations can successfully climb to international peace and economic accord.

DUBLIN, April 26. -- Thousands or children in the Irish Free State enjoyed an enforced holiday today as the result of a one-day strike declared by the primary school teachers to protest the salary cuts imposed by the de Valera government as part of its economy scheme.

American architecture is entering into a new era and is the most vtial that can be found anywhere in the world, Ralph Adams Cram of Boston, architect of the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, declared last night at a dinner, given in celebration of the founding of the architectural firm of Upjohn, at the Architectural League of New York, 115 East Fortieth Street.

In a colorful setting in the grand ballroom of the Hotel Astor, with the steel weapons glinting under the rays of the overhead arc lights, Joseph Levis of Boston last night retained his national foils title, while John R. Huffman of the New York A.C. captured the national saber championship for the third successive year.

The six-room English home, with garage, on Fernway, Greenvale, Scarsdale, has been sold by the Eastchester Construction Company to Dr. A.M. Hjort through W.C. Burbank and Meuer Auerbach, Inc. Lots in Avondale, Harrison, have been sold by the developers, H.A. Lockwood Co., to Mary Terrell and E.J. Butler.

Three new books about money will appear in the next few days. One is "Inflation: What Everybody Wants to Know About It," by Donald B. Woodward and Marc A. Rose, who wrote "A Primer of Money" a year ago. This book is published by Whittlesey House-McGraw Hill.

ITHACA, N.Y., April 26. -- Froehlich's single to right in the ninth scored the winning run and gave Cornell a 4-3 victory over Colgate in the opening home game at Ithaca today. The players were handicapped by heavy snow flurries and near-freezing weather.

WASHINGTON, April 26. -- Authorization for free coinage of silver at a fixed ratio to gold was voted, by the Senate today, but as the major question of inflation moved toward a vote new obstacles to the administration's program appeared.

WASHINGTON, April 26. -- If President Roosevelt and M. Herriot have shown themselves modest in the communiques concerning their conversations, it is sufficient to read the dispatches from Geneva to comprehend the great importance which they have had.

Referring to Edward P. Mulrooney and Police Commissioner Bolan as men whose lives proved that the man who starts at the "bottom of the ladder" may reach a position of importance. Mayor John P. O'Brien last night advised a group of graduating men nurses to work hard and look for reward "in after life."

Considering the optimistic tenor of the day's news, the action of the markets yesterday was somewhat disappointing to Wall Street. So far as the reduced volume of trading is concerned, the brokers were prepared for that after the broad activity of the last week.

C.E. Groesbeck, who recently was elected chairman of the Electric Bond and Share Company, was elected yesterday chairman of the American and Foreign Power Company, Inc., to succeed Sidney Z. Mitchell, who has resigned all offices and directorates in the Electric Bond and Share group on account of ill health.

One of the unusual events of the Spring season in behalf of philanthropy took place last night on board the Ile de France when members of the Ladies French Benevolent Society of St. Vincent de Paul held an entertainment to further the charitable enterprises of the Church of St. Vincent de Paul.

Members of the American Newspaper Publishers Association, at their annual meeting in the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria yesterday, unanimously adopted a resolution declaring it the sense of the association that newspapers should refrain from publishing radio programs except as paid advertising.

Promotional Buying Active. While some reports indicate a slight easing off from the recent peak of wholesale market activities, the call for dresses, lightweight coats and accessories for May promotions has continued quite active.

BARCELONA, April 26. -- Despite wholesale arrests and the massing of police in an attempt to end the gang rule of the anarchistic labor syndicate, it succeeded today in enforcing a twenty-four-hour test strike in Barcelona, in a bitter all-day struggle.

Shortly after Mr. SHEEHY had been appointed Manhattan Park Commissioner he announced that Mayor O'BRIEN had given him a "free hand" in the development of the old reservoir site in Central Park. But isn't there such a thing as being given too free a hand?

CHICAGO, April 26. -- President Will Harridge of the American League today imposed indefinite suspensions on the three principals of the Washington baseball melee and hurriedly entrained for the East to open an exhaustive investigation.
Resale of a Jersey City flat featured the New Jersey realty trading reported yesterday.

CHICAGO, April 26. -- Local professional operators were again on the selling side of wheat today on the Board of Trade, but with little success. Numerous sharp breaks occurred during the selling, but each decline disclosed aggressive supporting orders by commission houses, largely in small amounts, which absorbed the surplus in the pit and brought about many bulges.

RENO, Nev., April 27 -- Christian Arthur Wellesley, fourth Earl Cowley, filed suit for divorce here today against Mae Josephine Callicott Wellesley, better known as Mae Picard, a former actress, alleging five years of separation.

Commissioner Howard S. Cullman of the Port of New York Authority attacked government subsidy of shipping as unfair to competitive transportation and urged the abolition of the United States Shipping Board as "an unwise and unprofitable venture," in an address to the Propeller Club of New York yesterday at the Downtown Athletic Club Building.

ALBANY, April 27 -- The Dunnigan bill creating semi-public corporations to aid holders of guaranteed mortgage certificates was signed today by Governor Lehman. Enactment of the law was urged by the Governor, because, he said, real estate values have fallen to a point where mortgage security, together with the security of the participating certificates, had been impaired.

WASHINGTON, April 27 --The War Department issued the following orders today: LIEUTENANT COLONELS. Abraham, C.R., Inf., to Fort Screven, Ga., about July 1. Bowman, E.N., Inf., to Frankfort, Ky. Adams, E.S., Adjutant General's Department, to San Francisco, Cal.

CHANGCHUN, Manchuria, Friday, April 28 -- Unless Russia returns by May 10 the rolling stock she withdrew from the Chinese Eastern Railway, the Changchun Government will take "decisive measures," according to a statement to your correspondent today by K. Sato, a Japanese representative of the Manchukuo Department of Communications.

The Byrne conservation fund bill, which became law when Governor Lehman signed it on Wednesday, is considered to be one of the most constructive measures ever enacted in this State in so far as it promises to promote the conservation and propagation of game and fish.

Miss Lillian Gish, who of late has been known in these parts more as the lady of the camellas, became last evening "a forget-me-not in the rain." That was the phrase applied by one of those New York reporters to Effie Holden, after the trial in New Bedford.

In a letter sent yesterday to J.W. Crabtree, executive secretary of the National Education Association In Washington, Professors John Dewey, George S. Counts, George D. Strayer and Jesse H. Newlon of Columbia University requested the executive committee of the organization to advise officials of the Century of Progress Exposition in Chicago that the association will not hold its convention in Chicago "unless and until the outrageous injustice to Chicago children and teachers is ended."

CHICAGO, April 27 -- Long wheat came out again today on the Board of Trade, and while persistent buying in small lots by commission houses continued, the market was heavy in undertone almost from the start. Trade on both sides was less aggressive than it had been and there was more disposition to await developments in the administration's inflation plans.

Another publishing firm is making its headquarters in Fourth Avenue as the result of a deal announced yesterday by Carstens, Linnekin Wilson, Inc., who leased to The Review of Reviews Corporation the entire top floor of the Pocono Building at 229 Fourth Avenue, southeast corner of Nineteenth Street.
NEW HAVEN, April 27 -- The guide who was taking the tourists through the new Payne Whitney gymnasium pointed out a tall fellow encountered in the corridor on the fifth floor and said:

Denouncing the persecutions and discriminations practiced against Jews in Germany by the Hitler government, the American Jewish committee, acting in conjunction with the B'nai B'rith, Jewish fraternal organization, issued a statement yesterday disapproving boycotts, parades and mass meetings as measures for bringing relief to the sufferers.

The nursing profession, like the medical and legal professions, is overcrowded, but nurses may achieve success today as in more prosperous times, Dr. Jerome S. Leopold, president of the medical board of Lenox Hill Hospital, declared last night at graduation exercises at the Astor for fifty nurses of that hospital's School of Nursing.
Many dinners were given last night in connection with the formal opening for the season of the roof garden of the Pierre.

Harvard and Yale were accused yesterday by Colonel Robert R. McCormick, editor and publisher of The Chicago Tribune, of setting an extravagant example, by their "baronial and palatial halls," to other institutions of higher learning throughout the country.

The Federal Reserve System made no important change in its holdings of United States Government securities this week, it is revealed in the statement for the week ended on Wednesday, published yesterday. There had been conjecture in financial circles whether the System might anticipate the large-scale buying program projected in the Thomas bill by adding substantially to its portfolio of government securities this week.

Barbara Schwartz, 14 years old, daughter of Harry Schwartz, a New York stock broker of 132-70 Sanford Avenue, Flushing, who was found unconscious in the basement of an apartment house across the street on Wednesday evening, was in such a serious condition yesterday at the Blushing Hospital that the authorities were unable to question her on the mysterious attack.
MANILA, April 27 -- All newspapers here are Riving the widest publicity to the discrepancy in former Governor General Roosevelt's report of a surplus, and the auditor's report of a deficit for 1932.

WASHINGTON, April 27. -- In discussing the possible limits of a European agreement to disarm, and the extent to which the United States will go in helping to keep the peace of Europe, the President has convinced both Prime Minister MacDonald and M. Herrlot, the envoy of France, that our political nationalism, like our economic nationalism, is about to end.
President ANGELL of Yale, speaking a few nights ago in behalf of Fisk University, an institution in Nashville, Tenn., for the higher education of the Negro, said in its support:

The downward trend in fatal street accidents, which had continued over a period of twelve consecutive months, ended in March, the current issue of Street Accidents, published monthly by the New York Police Department, reported yesterday.

The plan to compromise an important part of the multitude of claims and counter-claims among various Eastern utility corporations formerly under Insull domination and to set up a new company to own five of the principal operating companies in the system was advanced yesterday at protracted hearings before Irwin Kurtz as referee in bankruptcy at a special meeting of creditors of four bankrupt companies in the Federal Building here.

BERLIN, April 27 -- The Germans are a hard-headed race. They can take more intoxicants without visible effect than any other except possibly the Swedes and the Scots. But there is one brand of intoxicant brewed in Germany throughout many generations that goes right to the German head and befuddles the German brain.

At the request of Governor POLLARD of Virginia, Governor ELY of Massachusetts issued an order for the extradition of a Negro charged with a double murder. Federal District Judge LOWELL of Boston granted a writ of habeas corpus. He admitted that the defendant "would get a fair trial in Virginia."

WASHINGTON, April 27 -- Optimism over the prospects for the World Monetary and Economic Conference increased materially here today as visiting diplomats became thoroughly convinced in personal conversations with President Roosevelt that he was ready to go into every problem that has been troubling world economic stability, including the difficult subjects of war debts, disarmament and security.

CHICAGO, April 27 (AP) -- The White Sox hammered Fred Marberry and Whitlow Wyatt today for sixteen hits, concentrated in the seventh and eighth innings, to defeat Detroit, 10 to 4, and get an even break in the series.

LONDON, April 27 -- A simplified autogiro was demonstrated by its inventor, Senor Juan de la Cierva, in the London Airport at Hanworth today. He flew his model of the newest type, the same, as the Air Ministry has ordered experimentally.

The projection of motion pictures in depth, so that they seem solid Instead of lying flat on a screen, was demonstrated here yesterday before an audience of 500 members of the Society of Motion Picture Engineers by Herbert E. Ives of the Bell Telephone Laboratories.
PRINCETON, N.J., April 27. -- Ed Schwab scored five goals to lead the Princeton attack as the Tiger lacrosse men overwhelmed N.Y.U. by 13 -- 2 on Poe Field today for their fourth straight victory.

Trustees of the Consolidated Gas Company of New York declared yesterday a dividend of 85 cents a share on the common stock against $1 a share previously paid quarterly, placing the stock on a $3.40 annual dividend basis, comparing with $4 previously paid.

LONDON, April 27 -- While Robert Lacour-Gayet, a French Treasury expert, is here apparently to close negotiations for a loan to France of francs held in the British equalization fund, no announcement was forthcoming from the Treasury about the proposed franc transactions.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., April 27 -- Miss Catherine Singer of the Westchester Country Club and Mrs. Benjamin H. Namm of the Century Country Club divided the honors in the three-day Women's Metropolitan Golf Association Spring invitation tournament which was concluded at the Seaview Golf Club today.

WASHINGTON, April 27 -- An encouraging, though general, resume of conservations with President Roosevelt was given tonight by Edouard Herriot, following his next-to-last conference at the "White House.

The Phelps Dodge Corporation has curtailed its production of copper by about 50 per cent, bringing its output to about 10 per cent of its rated capacity. At this rate of operation, it is said, the company will make barely enough copper to supply its fabricating plants and may find it necessary from time to time to buy from other producers.

NEWARK, N.J., April 27 -- A plan for the organization of the Seaboard Trust Company of Hoboken to assume all the affairs of the closed Steneck Trust Company of Hoboken has been submitted to the Court of Chancery, it was announced here today by William H. Kelly, New Jersey Commissioner of Banking and Insurance.
LONDON, April 27 (AP). -- The weekly statement of the Bank of England shows the following changes in pounds sterling:

Some details of the relations of the Diamond Match Company to the Kreuger-dominated International Match Corporation, connections that the former company states were unknown to it until after Kreuger's death, were made public yesterday in the annual letter and pamphlet report to stockholders of Diamond Match.
BERLIN, April 27 -- Captain Hermann Wilhelm Goering. Premier of Prussia, tonight announced the formation of a secret State police department in the State.

Teachers College students, in an emergency, will be able to feed themselves on 50 cents a day, according to several menus issued yesterday by Dr. Mary S. Rose, Professor of Nutrition at the Columbia University College. The student menus, in which milk, vegetables and fruits are emphasized, represent the "minimum food requirements necessary for a healthful existence."
WASHINGTON, April 27. -- Leaders of the old Bonus Expeditionary Force threatened a new march, on Washington today if their demands were not met by President Roosevelt within two weeks.

BERLIN, April 27 -- The German Government welcomes foreign business to Germany provided foreign business conforms to Germany's new economic program, according to a statement made to your correspondent today by Dr. Paul Bang, Under-Secretary of the Ministry of Economics.

WASHINGTON, April 27 -- How much the European debtor nations would save in settling their wartime debt accounts to the United States if they took advantage of the proposal to make payments within the next six months in silver at a price to be fixed at not more than 50 cents an ounce was a matter of much speculation among the experts today.

GENEVA, April 27 -- Norman H. Davis, United States Ambassador at Large, decided today to go to London tomorrow to attend Saturday's meeting of the organizing committee of the World Economic Conference. It is possible he will remain there until Prime Minister MacDonald's return from the United States.

After the indictment yesterday of Irving Wexler, one of the last New York's big time racketeer some of the details of the luxurios life he had been living were diclosed by Chief Assistant Unite States Attorney Thomas E. Dewey.
WASHINGTON, April 27 -- In addition to the "brain trust," listed and discussed in this space yesterday, the President has a "kitchen cabinet." This is in the immemorial tradition.
WASHINGTON, April 27 -- President and Mrs. Roosevelt gave a state dinner tonight in honor of Prime Minister Bennett of Canada, who is their guest at the White House.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., April 27 -- Two army fliers escaped death near here this afternoon by landing with parachutes when the army Curtiss Falcon airplane in which they were making an observation flight from Mitchel Field, L.I., to Mercer Airport, Trenton, caught fire while 1,500 feet above Middlebush, and crashed.

The annual report for 1932 of the Catholic Charities of the Archdiocese of New York, published yesterday, shows that nearly 300,000 persons were aided last year by the central organization and the 212 charitable argencies it supervises. In 1931 a total of 309,413 persons was cared for.

BERLIN, April 27 -- Dr. Hjalmar Schacht, president of the Reichsbank, is believed to have emphasized to officials of the Bank of France today that Germany will maintain the mark on the gold standard inside Germany.

New York City is fortunate, at this critical time for metropolitan planning, in commanding the services of Governor LEHMAN'S Emergency Public Works Commission, Mayor O'BRIEN'S advisory planning committee and the Regional Plan Association.
BRESLAU, April 27 --The Germany of the National Socialist revolution, even more than the Germany of the Weimar Constitution, is dominated by an urge toward the east.

The New York Guaranteed Mortgage Protection Corporation, a quasi-public company designed to protect the interests of holders of guaranteed mortgage certificates, was formally organized yesterday. Governor Lehman signed a bill empowering the setting up of such a company earlier in the day.

PITTSBURGH, April 27 -- The Roosevelt administration is moving to strike crippling restrictions from international trade and bring economic peace to the world, Fred I. Kent, controller of exchange for the New York Federal Reserve Board, declared in an address before the Foreign Trade Council here today.

BOSTON, Friday, April 28. -- The Harvard Crimson declared early today that it had established beyond all doubt that members of the staff of The Harvard Lampoon had stolen the "Sacred Cod" from its shrine in the gallery of the House of Representatives Wednesday night, a theft which stirred all Boston yesterday.
News More Real. Newspapers are read more carefully in times of depression than in normal times. So the newspaper publishers in convention assembled at the Waldorf-Astoria were told the other day.
To the Editor of The New York Times: I note with concern the fundamental ignorance of monetary theory which underlies the increasing objections to the revaluation of the dollar in grains of gold.

To the Editor of The New York Times: BEVERLY HILLS, Cal., April 27. -- Governments are having the same trouble now that individuals have been having for three years -- that is, trying to find out the actual value of what they have. You don't know the value of

Two books and one pamphlet dealing with immediate economic problems go on sale in the book stores today. "Bankers' Gold," by 'Edgar Lawrence Smith, published by Simon Schuster, is made up of imaginary conversations in which banks, speculation and credit are discussed in terms intended to be easily comprehensible.

MINNEAPOLIS, April 27. -- The bodies of Mrs. Genevieve Clark of Minneapolis, missing Foshay case juror, who was convicted of contempt of court; her husband and, two children were found tonight in their automobile about fifteen miles south of here.

The Transit Commission approved yesterday the application of the East Side Omnibus Corporation for certificates of convenience and necessity to operate buses on the east side and, in doing so, it made effective for the first time a longterm bus franchise granted by the Board of Estimate for operation in the borough.

Circulation of petitions for repeal candidates for delegate to the forthcoming State convention to act on the Eighteenth Amendment began yesteday, with Tammany urging its supporters to turn out in force at the special election on May 23 to give visible evidence of the demand for nullification of prohibition.

Helen Vasko, the 2-year-old girl whose parents opposed an operation on her eye until it was thought to be too late to save her life, is now expected to live. A bulletin issued late yesterday afternoon by the New York Academy of Medicine in behalf of the Eye Institute of Columbia Presbyterian Medical Centre, where the operation was performed Tuesday, said:

John Hoppner's portrait of "Louisa, Countess of Mansfield," owned by Brig. Gen. Sir Charles Vere Gunning and Lady Gunning of London, brought $35,000 at an auction of paintings last night at the American Art Association-Anderson Galleries, Inc.

WASHINGTON, April 27 -- Although, predicting "disastrous consequences" of the inflationary program, former Secretary Mellon issued a formal denial today that he had "conspired" with former Secretary Mills, Senator Reed and others to defeat the inflationary legislation embodied in the Thomas amendment to the farm relief bill.

PARIS, April 27 -- So much has been discussed recently in Washington that French opinion is exceedingly confused. There seem to have been, according to correspondents' cables, four main subjects: first, devaluation of the dollar and fixing it with relation to sterling; second, interallied war debts; third, tariffs; fourth, America's contribution to world security through a consultative pact, her signature to which would be conditioned on the adoption at Geneva of considerable arms reductions.

Lewis W. Douglas, Director of the Federal Budget, promised that the national budget would be balanced, that the credit of the Federal Government would be kept unimpaired and that uncontrolled inflation would be prevented, in an address last night at a dinner of the Bureau of Advertising of the American Newspaper Publishers Association, in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

PARIS, April 27 -- Deputy Joseph Denais said today that he would demand an inquiry by the financial commission of the Chamber of Deputies into the pending agreement between the French and British treasuries regarding stabilization of the pound as against the franc.

The New York Stock Exchange announced yesterday that five brokers had arranged to transfer their memberships. Among them were one seat for which the deal was made last week at $145,000 and another at $130,000.

WASHINGTON, April 27 (AP). -- The Federal Trade Commission was told today that Henry L. Doherty, in March, 1929, realized a $17,748,032 profit by sale of 200,000 shares of Cities Service Company common stock, while almost simultaneously increasing his control in the company by 1,000,000 votes.
LONDON, April 27 -- The Manchester Guardian has raised a diplomatic storm by publishing from a "special correspondent in Germany" what it describes as the "Nationalist version" of the Reichstag fire.

The Anaconda Copper Mining Company and subsidiaries, including the Andes Copper Mining, Chile Copper and Greene Cananea Copper Companies, report for 1932 a consolidated net loss of $16,893,240 after expenses, interest, depreciation and obsolescence and expense pertaining to non-operating units, but before depletion of copper lands and aii inventory write-down of 59,914,440, which was charged to surplus.

An attempt to obtain dollar-for-dollar payment of deposits in the closed Harriman National Bank and Trust Company from the twenty member banks of the New York Clearing House Association was begun yesterday in a suit against the members.

The Catholic University of Washington, D.C., was named residuary legatee and the Society for the Propagation of the Faith, Baltimore, Md., receives a bequest of $10,000 under the will of George Victor Andronicus McCloskey, a member of the New York bar for more than a quarter of a century, who died March 29 at his home, 148 East Thirtieth Street, it was disclosed yesterday when his will was offered for probate.

Yesterday's statement of the twelve Reserve Banks showed total gold holdings for the system as a whole to be at the highest point of the year to date. No other important item in the system reached a new high or low figure.

The trial of two men and two women inspectors in the First election district of the Nineteenth Assembly District for violation of the election laws began yesterday before Supreme Court Justice Daniel V. McNamee. The defendants, who were on duty at Madison Avenue and 119th Street, are Charles B. Vreeland and Mrs. Mary O'Brien, Democrats, and Morris and Blanche S. Marcus, Republicans.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., April 27 -- Armed with pieces of pipe and other improvised weapons, the nine Scottsboro Negroes mutinied in the Jefferson County jail here this afternoon in protest to what they described as ill treatment by jail wardens.

Ferdinand Pecora, counsel to the Senate Committee on Banking and Currency which has been investigating financial houses and their operation, made a plea last night for adoption of President Roosevelt's proposal to make the sellers of securities responsible for their value.

WASHINGTON, April 27. -- The House today rejected all except one amendment to the $2,300,000,000 home mortgage bill submitted by President Roosevelt, but increasing "insurgency" cropped out to delay passage of the measure.

ALBANY, April 27 -- Mayo O'Brien of New York City came to the Capitol today and pleaded with Governor Lehman to veto a bill sponsored by Senate Leader John J. Dunnigan, which runs counter to the plans for the City of New York to establish a park on the oh site of Fort Schuyler on Throgs Neck in the Bronx.

Schenectady, N.Y. Award was made yesterday of a new issue of $550,000 city of Schenectady general bonds, dated May 1. 1933, and due from 1935 to 1943 to a syndicate comprising the Manufacturers and Traders Trust Company of Buffalo and Batchelder Co.

The world's amateur 18.1 balkline billiard championship got under way last night at the Brooklyn Lodge of Elks clubhouse with Jean Albert of France turning back Jean Sweering of Holand, 300 to 248, in fifty-six innings.

The New York Stock Exchange firm of Logan Bryan, one of the largest "wire houses" in Wall Street, operating thirty-eight offices throughout the country, announced yesterday its retirement from business, effective as soon as the accounts of its customers can be transferred to other brokers.

With speculative impulses largely suppressed as a result of the approaching vote in Washington on the Thomas inflation bill, Wall Street gave only passing attention to the share market yesterday. Brokers professed to see no change in sentiment and no diminution of interest so far as the public is concerned, but fresh commitments were avoided.

BOSTON, April 27 (AP) -- Eddie Linke, 21-year-old right-hander who struck out 230 batters last year with Davenport in the Mississippi Valley League, today made his American League debut and pitched well enough to give the Senators a tight 3-2 victory over the Red Sox.

Dickinson-Williamson. Mrs. Lynford McC. Dickinson of 133 East Sixty-fourth Street has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Cynthia Dickinson, to Clement Williams Williamson of Glen Cove, L.I.

Before a rising tide of popular indignation occasioned by his plans to develop the abandoned lower reservoir site in Central Park with ten baseball diamonds, a one-mile cinder running track and other athletic facilities, John E. Sheehy, newly appointed Park Commissioner, acceded yesterday to demands for a hearing in the matter.
Rather nervous but limited fluctuations continued yesterday on the Cotton Exchange, and prices ended at losses of 4 to 6 points.

Prices moved irregularly and narrowly in the local commodity markets yesterday, as the volume of trading continued to recede. Cocoa and silk were higher, while sugar, silver and hides were lower and rubber and coffee were irregular. Cash markets also moved unevenly in sympathy with the contract grades.
WASHINGTON. April 27 -- The Bureau of Navigation issued the following orders today, dated April 25:

WASHINGTON, April 27 -- The Federal coordinator of transportation, provided for in the bill that is now on President Roosevelt's desk, has power to relieve the railroads from the operation of the anti-trust laws, the Interstate Commerce Commission act and State and Federal laws for an emergency period of one year, it was revealed today when a copy of the bill became available.
PITTSBURGH, April 27 (UP) -- The Cubs, scoring all their runs in the fourth Inning, defeated the Pirates, 3 to 2, today. By the defeat the losers dropped from the National League lead.

WASHINGTON, April 27. -- Henry I. Harriman, president of the Chamber of Commerce of the United States, told the House Labor Committee today that he favored amending the Constitution to grant the President power to control industry.

WASHINGTON, April 27 (AP). -- A belief that the entire wreckage of the Akron had been located and testimony that certain structural reinforcements in the airship had not been completed before her last flight were given today to the naval court of inquiry investigating the disaster.
Lee Strasberg has taken over the direction of "Hilda Cassidy," the premiere of which is now tentatively listed for next Thursday night at the Martin Beck Theatre.

It is not surprising that Secretary PERKINS intends to do away with the United States Employment Service, organized under the Hoover Administration. Senator WAGNER has long inveighed against it. As State Industrial Commissioner of New York Miss PERKINS had an opportunity closely to observe its shortcomings.

PHILADELPHIA, April 27. -- In preparation for the Blackwell Cup Regatta with Yale and Columbia at Derby, Conn., next week, the Pennsylvania varsity crew defeated the Penn A.C. in a two-mile practice race on the Schuylkill River late today by a length and a half.

BUENOS AIRES, April 27 -- Indications tonight were that Bolivia's note to Argentina and Chile would terminate the ABC-Peru efforts at mediation and lead to a formal declaration of war by Paraguay. The Paraguayan Congress authorized President Ayala to declare war several weeks ago and the declaration is said to have been delayed at the request of the ABC-Peru group pending negotiations under the Mendoza formula.

ALBANY, April 27 -- Women who appeared at a hearing before Governor Lehman on two minimum wage measures were about evenly divided for and against a measure | sponsored by Senator Wald confining application of the minimum wage in industry to women and minors.

WASHINGTON, April 27. -- The daily average volume of Federal Reserve Bank credit outstanding during the week ended April 26, as reported by the Federal Reserve Banks, was $2,457,000,000, a decrease of $53,000,000 compared with the preceding week and an increase of $698,000,000 compared with the corresponding week in 1932.

To the Editor of The New York Times: At last I know what a Park Department is for. The War Department is for making war on the enemy and the Park Department is for making war on parks. I should have understood that years ago, especially considering the operations I have witnessed in recent years.

James A. Stillman, former president of the National City Bank, called yesterday at the Federal Building in response to a grand jury subpoena which he had received, but instead of appearing before that body, which is still investigating the income of Charles E. Mitchell, former chairman of the bank, he answered questions in the office of Thomas B. Dewey, Chief Assistant United States Attorney.

The State Tax Department does not intend to make a "nuisance tax" out of the retail sales tax that goes into effect Monday, and will require no special bookkeeping methods, Captain James M. Mangan, in charge of drafting the regulations for administration of the tax, said yesterday.

BERLIN, April 27 -- The creation of a special secret political police for Prussia wag announced tonight by Captain Hermann Wilhelm Goering, the Prussian Premier. The force will be independent of the regular police and its task will be to trace and fight all political activities dangerous to the State.

ALBANY, April 27 -- Unanimous approval of two bills, one of which provides for an additional justice of the City Court and the other for an additional county judge for the Bronx, was voiced by spokesmen for civic and business organizations of the Bronx at a public hearing before Governor Lehman this afternoon.

LA PAZ, Bolivia, April 27 -- That Argentina and Chile delivered on April 22 what amounted to an ultimatum to Bolivia to cease hostilities with Paraguay appears to be indicated by replies made public by the Bolivian Foreign Office today. The Argentine and Chilean notes have not been published.

NEW BRUNSWICK, .N.J., April 27. -- Officers and new members of the Rutgers University Chapter of the American Society of Military Engineers and initiates to Scabbard and Blade, national honorary military fraternity, were announced today. Officers elected by the military engineers society were as follows :

District Attorney Samuel Foley of the Bronx declared last night at a dinner in his honor at the Seventh Regiment Armory, Sixty-sixth Street and Park Avenue, that he intended to follow his poultry-racket inquiry "through to a show-down" and that "I will do it myself, as I do not care to put any of my assistants on the spot."

OJAI, Cal., April 27 (AP). -- Led by Ellsworth Vines, the national champion, the favorites in the men's singles of the thirty-eighth annual Ojai Valley tennis tournament moved through the first two rounds of play today. This is the first tourney of the year for him.

WASHINGTON, April 27 -- This government has made no promises to France that it would not press for payment of the June 15 interest instalment on her war debt if the defaulted Dec. 15 payment is made, it was stated authoritatively today as the debt problem bulked large in the discussions between the President and M. Herriot.

WASHINGTON, April 27. -- Tracing financial developments through the banking crisis to early April, the Federal Reserve Board in its monthly bulletin today showed that reserves of the Federal Reserve Banks advanced from $2,800,000,000 on March 4 to $3,490,000,000 on April 5, the highest level since the Fall of 1931.
Among the passengers arriving today on the Hamburg of the Hamburg-American Line, from Hamburg, Southampton and Cherbourg are:

Unfilled orders of the Bethlehem Steel Corporation increased nearly $8,000,000 in the first quarter of the year to a total of $38,360,601, Eugene G. Grace, president of the company, announced yesterday in issuing its report of earnings for the period.

Labor stability is aided by centralization of trades in business areas where the buildings and transit facilities are most suitable for the trades, Elmer F. Andrews, State Industrial Commissioner, declares in the May issue of The Mercantile Trades Centre News.

Telling their bound and gagged victims not to "take it to heart," three dapper young hold-up men walked out of the jewelry sales office of Hyman H. Sohn on the fifth floor of 83-85 Canal Street at 10:45 o'clock yesterday morning with bracelets, rings, pendants and loose stones valued at $18,000.
The opening tournament of the year for the members of the Women's Westchester and Fairfield County Golf Association will be played next Thursday at the Westchester Country Club.

BERLIN, April 27. -- Reacting to yesterday's closing tendency in New York, today's session of the Boerse opened firm, although the investing public and professional interests continued to maintain a certain reserve and trading was light. Brewery stocks continued in demand and I.G. Farben and Harpener also were among today's favorites, both showing slight gains over yesterday.

Ten patrolmen, an acting police lieutenant and Deputy Chief Inspector. John J. O'Connell searched the Hotel Astor last night for two coats and four hats taken by sneak thieves while their policemen owners were singing in the Rose Room.
EAST ORANGE, N.J., April 27. -- Jacobson, Upsala College's star moundsman, held City College to two hits, both made by Gladstone, as the local team won today, 5 -- 3.

WASHINGTON, April 27. -- Figures issued by the Federal Reserve Board today showed that on March 29 12,787 banks out of about 18,000 in operation before the crisis had been licensed to open on an unrestricted basis.

The taxpayer's action of Georgre Carrizzo to restrain the city from awarding the proposed five-year contract for Brooklyn refuse disposal to Samuel R. Rosoff's Manhattan Ash and Garbage Removal Corporation has been transferred to Special Term, Part 1, New York County, according to an announcement made yesterday by Justice Lockwood in Brooklyn Supreme Court.
WASHINGTON, April 27 -- The text of the administration's railroad bill reads as follows:

LONDON, April 27. -- Despite considerable conflict of opinion, Atlantic passage rates will remain unchanged this season, according to an announcement following a special meeting of the principal shipping lines in the North Atlantic Conference in London today under the chairmanship of Sir George McLaren Brown, European manager of the Canadian Pacific Lines.

GENEVA, April 27 -- The first repercussion of the Hitler government on League of Nations organs came today when the governing body of the International Labor Office opened its sixty-second session with the seat of the German workers' delegate, Herr Leuschner, empty.

WASHINGTON, April 27. -- Data and charts advancing a scientific explanation of the cause of the crash of the naval airship Akron were presented here today at the 184th regular meeting of the American Physical Society by Professor T.H. von Karman, director of the Guggenheim Aeronautical Laboratories at the California Institute of Technology and an authority on aero and hydro-dynamics.
PHILADELPHIA, April 27 -- Three home runs that soared off the bats of Babe Ruth, Lou Gehrig and Earle Combs were more than sufficient to give the Tankees a snappy decision over the Athletics today.

Outlining his procedure in opening the city's fight for reduced electric, gas and telephone rates. Corporation Counsel Arthur J.W. Hilly said yesterday that he would seek to show that the cost of reproducing properties of two large electric companies had dropped between 25 and 40 per cent, thus justifying an immediate rate reduction.

PHILADELPHIA, April 27 -- Indicating that the penalties are not likely to be too severe where he is convinced that attacks were not wholly "unwarranted," President William Harridge of the American, League today began his investigation of the free-for-all battle that broke out in the fourth inning of the game between the Yankees and Senators in Washington Tuesday.

The receipt of about one-fourth of the total fund required to maintain the Boy Scout organization work in this city during the current year was announced yesterday by Charles Hayden of Hayden, Stone Co., chairman of the campaign, at a luncheon attended by 'committee members at the Mid-Day Club at 25 Broad Street.

We know that in angry disputes "there is much virtue in your if," but is that true of lawmaking? The Farm Relief bill, as it passed the House, was stamped all over with "ifs." The Secretary of Agriculture was empowered to do various things at various times and in various ways, if he thought it wise -- if farm prices and crops, and a score of other things hard to measure accurately, warranted it.

WASHINGTON, April 27 -- In certain modern theatres the stage is arranged in two sections, containing two stage settings and turning on a pivot to present first one setting, then the other. The stage is arranged in this manner for the play that is now being acted in Washington, which has two stage settings: The setting of disarmament and the setting of finance.

The London News-Chronicle published yesterday a comment on one phase of the Washington conversations, cabled from this country by Sir WALTER LAYTON, editor of The Economist. He found in Washington an opinion "widely prevalent "that stabilization [of currencies] "would in itself restore confidence "and raise prices."

A substantial comparative improvement in bank clearings was made in the week ended on Wednesday, according to the compilation by Dun Bradstreet, Inc. Clearings for the week in twenty cities throughout the country were $3,839,956,000, or 9.4 per cent less than the total for the same week last year.
WASHINGTON, April 27 -- The verbatim report of Senator Glass's speech today against the administration's inflation measure follows:

LEMARS, Iowa, April 27. -- District Judge Charles C. Bradley was dragged from his court room this afternoon by a crowd of more than 600 farmers. They slapped him, blindfolded him and carried him in a truck a mile from the city, where they put a rope around his neck and choked him until he was nearly unconscious.

Examples of the arts and crafts which boys undertake both as work and as a pastime were exhibited yesterday at the Grand Central Palace in the first national exposition of its kind held in conjunction with the International Vacation Exposition.

PHILADELPHIA, April 27. -- America's greatest relay event -- the University of Pennsylvania Carnival -- makes its thirty-ninth annual bow tomorrow, with 3,000 athletes from 500 colleges and schools featured in the production.

Quotations and conditions in the money market were unchanged in dull trading. Business was on a small scale in all departments. A small amount of ninety-day money was done at 1 per cent, out no other maturities were involved. Stock Exchange call loans remained at 1 per cent, with the usual concessions from that figure prevailing in the counter trading.

MONTREAL, Que., April 27 -- The Canadian newsprint industry is in a worse condition than any other industry known to Sir Charles Gordon, president of the Bank of Montreal, a member of the bankers' committee on newsprint and a director of the St. Lawrence Corporation, Ltd., according to a statement which he made here today.

WASHINGTON, April 27 -- International payments to and from the United States during 1932 balanced at $4,372,000,000, compared with $5,508,000,000 for 1931, reflecting "the extremely depressed nature of economic conditions throughout the world," the Finance Division of the Commerce Department announced today in a preliminary estimate of credit and debit items resulting from foreign transactions.
Accessory Buying Continues Good.

Maxim Gorki's new novel, "Other Fires," the third of a group of novels in which the Russian writer is attempting to depict the emergence of a spirit of revolt amid the Russian people, is published today by Appleton. The book opens with the last phase of the 1905 revolution, the Bolshevist uprising in Moscow.

Representatives of banks bought in eleven of eighteen Manhattan and Bronx properties put up at foreclosure auctions yesterday. All the properties were taken over by the plaintiffs. The nine-story Hotel Sohuyler at 57-63 West Forty-fifth Street was acquired by the Bank of Savings, as plaintiff, on a bid of $50,000.

New short-term financing in the probable amount of $50,000,000 is expected to be done by New York State next week. On Tuesday an issue of $75,000,000 of the State's 2 3/4 per cent one-year notes will mature. The money for these is already impounded in the banks and will be paid on the maturity date through the Bank of the Manhattan Company.

Lower net operating incomes or lncresed operating deficits were reported yesterday by the Santa Fe, Atlantic Coast Line, Pennsylvania, Baltimore Ohio, Burlington, Chicago North Western, Rock Island, Delaware Hudson, Great Northern, Northern Pacific and other lines.
Gerard S. Smith of Brooklyn carried off the first championship ribbon of the fortieth Brooklyn Horse Show, which opened last night in the ring of the Biding and Driving Club.

ALBANY, April 27 -- The Milk Control Board announced today that it was preparing a new set of minimum retail prices for cities and villages outside Greater New York and the counties of Westchester, Suffolk, Nassau and Rockland. The board expects to issue the new regulations tomorrow or Saturday.

BRESLAU, Silesia, April 27 -- A protest against the terroristic campaign of the National Socialists against the Jews, which has been particularly harsh in Silesia, was voiced in an interview with your correspondent by Dr. Waldemar Otte, chaplain of Breslau Cathedral, member of the Prussian Diet and leader of the Silesian Catholic Centre party.

Leisurely markets reflected a relaxed state of mind yesterday after the violent price movements and the furious activity of the recent past. Trading in shares was about 35 per cent less active than on the day before and there was a similar contraction on the commodity exchanges.

The achievements and shortcomings of the city's school system, with special reference to its cost to the taxpayers, were discussed informally last night by educators and representatives of citizens' organizations at a "panel discussion" at the New York Junior League, 221 East Seventy-first Street.

WASHINGTON, April 27 -- Authority for the President to decrease the gold content of the dollar by 50 per cent was voted by the Senate today, 53 to 35, the administration's inflation program thus surviving its most severe test.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W.Va., April 27. -- Mr. and Mrs. Maurice J. Bernet of Cleveland gave a dinner at the Greenbrier tonight in honor of Mrs. Bernet's birthday. Mr. and Mrs. F.C. Williams and Mr. and Mrs. Edwin B. Ross were among those giving dinners at Kates Mountain Club.

Reporting that 913 families have been assured of five months' care through its efforts, the Adopt-a-Family Committee, of which Mrs. August Belmont is chairman, held the final luncheon of its campaign yesterday, at the Waldorf-Astoria.

The upward surge imparted to the dollar on Wednesday by the news of the Franco-British agreement to combat depreciation of the United States monetary unit carried it further yesterday. The pound sterling fell 8 cents to $3.72, which was 20 cents below its recent high; the franc dropped 4 3/4 points to 4.30 3/4 cents, 19 1/4 points below its high of last week, and other currencies weakened proportionately against the dollar.

ST. LOUIS, April 27 (AP) -- The Cardinals came from behind to make four hits and three runs in the ninth inning and take the final game of the series with the Reds today, 3 to 2. Collins, Hornsby, Medvrick and Martin singled in succession, then Wilson walked and Alien flied out to bring in the winning run.

Stranded since Tuesday in their trailer home in Fifty-eighth Street between Second and Third Avenues, Mr. and Mrs. Miller Durs and their boarder, James Burns, were awaiting last night the return of the truck that was to have towed them to Babylon, L.I.

HAVRE DE GRACE, Md., April 27 -- Sweeping Light, which as a 2-year-old won the Champagne, annexed his second victory in two days at Havre de Grace today when he scored by three lengths in the featured Lansdowne Purse and equaled the mile and a sixteenth track record over a fast track.

Six foilsmen qualified for the final in the P.S.A.L. individual fencing championship preliminary competition last night at Washington Irving High School. Hugo Castello of George Washington High, winner of the crown for the past two years, and his brother, James, sons of the N.Y.U. fencing coach, were among the six to advance.

LONDON, April 27 -- Details of a new trade agreement with Germany in which it is confirmed that British coal shipments shall in no case be less than 180,000 tons monthly, increasing proportionately with German consumption, were officially announced tonight.
NEW YORK. Mr. and Mrs. Rufus King have left their home at 210 Madison Avenue and are at the Carlyle.

The Giants regained the lead in fie National League race by scoring their fifth straight triumph yesterday at the Polo Grounds, and their fourth of the season over Burt Shotton's Fhillies. New York displaced the Pirates, who lost to the Cubs.

WASHINGTON, April 27. -- Approval of loans to four railroads aggregating $12,226,OOO, including one of $7,000,000 to the New York Central and another for $1,500,000 to the Baltimore Ohio, was announced today by the Reconstruction Finance Corporation.
WASHINGTON, April 27 -- Retirement of Japanese forces from

WASHINGTON, April 27 -- Declaring that the youth of the country still retained all its spirit of adventure and would seek to enlist in the air service of the navy in time of war and peace, even if additional flight pay were reduced, Rear Admiral Frank B. Upham, Chief of the Bureau of Navigation, supported the administration plan today to reduce flight pay of active pilots and completely eliminate non-flying officers.

WASHINGTON, April 28. -- Spokesmen for manufacturers told the House Labor Committee today that the thirty-hour week bill was too inflexible and that it would handicap industry. With one exception, they maintained that if enacted the proposal would put industry "into a strait-jacket.

Despite the banking holiday and the fact that Easter was later this year than last, sales of department stores and wholesale concerns in March in the New York Federal Reserve District, compared with a year ago, made a relatively better showing than sales reported in February.
WASHINGTON, April 28. -- Movements of vessels follow, all dates are April 27, unless otherwise specified:

To Bush Men's Summer Wear. The first week in June was chosen for opening the retail Summer season in men's wear at a luncheon meeting yesterday of the men's and boys' wear committee of the merchandising division of the National Retail Dry Goods Association.

MADRID, April 28. -- A government crisis in which the present Left wing coalition, dominated by Socialists, which has been running Spain's social revolution, will give way to a Conservative coalition headed by Alejandieo Lerroux, the first Republican Foreign Minister and now Opposition leader, was regarded as extremely likely today.

WASHINGTON, April 28. -- With gold holdings of u177,360,405 in the first week in April, the Bank, of England held more gold than ever before in its history, according to a report received by the Commerce Department today from Roger R. Townsend, Trade Commissioner at London.

BERLIN, April 28. -- Stocks continued to advance at today's session of the Boerse, with increased participation by the investing public. Collieries and soma of the steels were most in favor, while I.G. Farben received less attention and closed at the same figure as yesterday.

WASHINGTON, April 28. -- The farm relief bill, as passed by the Senate, clothes President Roosevelt and his assistants with virtually dictatorial powers in his discretion for the regulation of currency and agriculture.

ROME, April 28. -- Two mysteries of aviation were solved today when the body of Bert Hinkler, Australian flier, missing since January, was found in the north of Italy and the wreckage of a French Air-Orient plane, which disappeared last Sunday, was located in the south, with thre survivors and the bodies of the five other members of the plane's company.
WILMINGTON, Ill., April 28. -- Three fleeing bank robbers with a submachine gun fought off two automobile racers who overtook them after an attempted hold-up today.

A 14-year-old Brooklyn high school girl's tribute to her mother yesterday won the first prize awarded by the Mother's Day committee of the Golden Rule Foundation in a nation-wide contest in which more than 600 school children submitted tokens of prose, poetry and song.

Mayor O'Brien appointed George Gordon Battle, attorney, as chairman of the Triborough Bridge Authority at City Hall yesterday and named Jeremiah A. O'Leary and Fred C. Lemmerman as the two other members of the body.
