WASHINGTON, April 28. -- Affairs of state were set aside and a baby took the centre of the stage this afternoon when Prime Minister Bennett of Canada joined in celebrating the first birthday anniversary of his nephew, only child of the Canadian Minister and Mrs. William Herridge.

Federal Judge Francis G. Caffey declined yesterday to sign an order temporarily restraining the Irving Trust Company from acting as a receiver in bankruptcy and equity cases. The refusal was in a suit brought against the trust company by Dorothy Weissman Nisonoff, a stockholder, through Spencer Pinkham, her counsel.

LEMARS, Iowa, April 28. -- Martial law was established here today under a proclamation by Governor Clyde Herring and the arrival of 250 National Guardsman as a result of the attack yesterday on District Court Judge C.C. Bradley by farmers who demanded that he refuse to sign foreclosure papers.

LONDON, April 28. -- Viscount Grey of Fallodon, Foreign Secretary when the World War began, who was re-elected president of the Liberal Council at its annual meeting today, outspokenly denounced the Hitler regime in Germany.

Places where beer, ale or intoxicating liquors are sold cannot be used for polling purposes at the special election on May 23 when delegates to the repeal convention are to be elected, as the result of a ruling yesterday by S. Howard Cohen, president of the Board of Elections.

Federal agents investigating the income of Irving Wexler and two of his lieutenants, who were indicted here on Thursday by a Federal grand jury, went yesterday to Elizabeth, N.J., where they found $213,500 in cash and negotiable notes in a safe-deposit box which had been rented by Max Hassel, beer-runner, before he and Max Greenberg were murdered on April 12 in the Elizabeth-Carteret Hotel.

PARIS, April 28. -- The negotiations which began three days ago between the French Treasury and the Bank of England have resulted in an agreement which will permit Britain to control the exchange rate of the pound more easily, while France will get a much-needed loan, it was announced here today.
BERLIN, April 28. -- All Germany is preparing feverishly for a national May Day celebration that will be on a scale that the newspaper Tempo says will beat "anything ever seen, even in America."

Voters of the city will be asked to vote yes or no on whether there should be revision of the Greate New York charter at the November election, under the terms of a local bill sponsored by Mayor O'Brien which was passed yesterday by the Board of Estimate branch of the Municipal Assembly.
An abstract of the address by Dr. Hans Luther, German Ambassador, as given out by the Academy of Political Science, before which he spoke last night at the Hotel Astor, follows:

The honorary degree of Doctor of Music was conferred yesterday upon Ignace Jan Paderewski, pianist and former Premier of Poland, by New York University, in his apartment in the Ritz Tower Hotel, Park Avenut and Fifty-seventh Street.

Sam Needleman, 39 years old, of 1,954 Unionport Road, the Bronx, was a prisoner in Police Headquarters last night, held for the theft of $65,000 in railroad bonds and certified checks on April 21 from the brokerage firm of Hirsch, Lillienthal Co., 165 Broadway.

BABYLON, L.I., April 28. -- Somewhere amid the scrub oak in the lonely stretches of Belmont Terrace district here tonight, Miller Durs, his wife, Jean, and their two dogs were tasting the salt sea air as they set their portable house in order.

A rally in the last hour in most markets substantially reduced early losses and in some cases brought prices above the preceding close in yesterday's trading on local commodity exchanges, with trading further reduced in volume. In the cash markets most prices were lower, although some of the metals advanced.

With much of the glamour and excitement attendant upon "first nights" of opera seasons, the first Opera Ball to be given here was presented last night at the Metropolitan Opera House in behalf of the Metropolitan Opera, Association. It was an auspicious occasion, both in the social history of the city and in the history of the Metropolitan Opera itself.

In compliance with a proclamation of Mayor O'Brien and resolutions of the Board of Aldermen designating April 30 as "President's Day," Cardinal Hayes, through a letter sent by Mgr. Thomas G. Carroll, Chancellor of the Archdiocese of New York, has requested the clergy to recite after the parochial mass tomorrow the prayer for the civil authorities.

The estate of Morris Fatman, brother-in-law of Governor Lehman and father-in-law of Henry Morgenthau Jr., chairman of the Federal Farm Board, was appraised yesterday at $53,879,451 gross, which was reduced by funeral and administration expenses of $276,599, debts of $50,477, and other deductions to $3,272,320 net.

WASHINGTON, April 28. -- Edouard Herriot, envoy of France, left Washington today after his conferences with President Roosevelt bearing an olive branch but leaving behind him a few significant words on the French idea of what constitutes political security.

NEWMARKET, England, April 28. -- William Woodward, owner of the famous Gallant Fox, won his first English turf classic today when Brown Betty carried the silks of the New York banker to a clean-cut victory over twenty-one of the country's best 3-year-old fillies in the 125th renewal of the One Thousand Guineas.

WASHINGTON, April 28. -- Senator Robinson of Arkansas, the Democratic floor leader, replied in kind today to Senator Huey Long, who frequently quotes from the Bible, with a verse so sharp that it brought the Louisianian to his feet with crimson face.

HAVRE DE GRACE, Md., April 28. -- The Chicle filly Edelweiss made her seasonal debut at Havre de Grace today in the Magnolia Purse, but was forced to be content with second place, a half length back of Ral Parr's Star Porter. The latter, an 11-to-1 shot, led practically from start to finish under the handling of Eddie Steffen.

The peak of the Spring market for suburban real estate was reached yesterday, when brokers in widely scattered sections of the metropolitan area announced the largest volume of home sales of the current season. Although the outstanding deal of the day involved a Westchester estate, New Jersey led in the number of transactions reported.

A pledge that Germany would participate in the World Economic Conference "with the strongest will for international cooperation imaginable" was given, last night by Dr. Hans Luther, the new German Ambassador to the United States, in an address at the dinner of the Academy of Political Science, marking the end of the academy's semiannual meeting, at the Hotel Astor.

Joseph. V. MceKe, President of the Board of Aldermen, who in recent weeks has been making speeches with increasing frequency in various outlying sections of the city, made his bow before the metropolitan audience that comprises the League for Political Education at the Town Hall last night.

The Emergency Unemployment Relief Committee announced yesterday, through its chairman, Harvey D. Gibson, that its appropriation for relief of the unemployed during May will be $280,000, contrasted with $700,000 allotted this month to the same purpose.
BOSTON, April 28 (AP). Led by Frank (Shanty) Hogan, the Braves fell upon the right-handed John Berly today to defeat the Phillies, 5-2, in their home-coming game.

WASHINGTON, April 28. -- Evidence that the stars and constellations in our own Milky Way galaxy, of which our solar system is a relatively insignificant part, are running away from each other at a uniform speed of three miles a second from the centre of gravity of the galaxy was presented today before the meeting of the American Physical Society by Dr. Rosa Gunn of the Naval Research Laboratory.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., April 28. -- Yale broke Columbia University's streak of five straight in the Eastern Intercollegiate Baseball League today, winning by 3 -- 1 before 700 spectators. It was the Lions' first setback in league competition, and as a result Columbia dropped to second place, Harvard leading the league with two victories and no defeats.

The threat of a rate war In the transatlantic passenger trade this Summer was dispelled yesterday when the Atlantic Passenger Conference adjourned after a two-day session in London with the understanding that withdrawal of the Cunard, Red Star and United States lines from conference membership would not become effective at least until July 15.
To the Editor of The New York Times: Every one is cheering for transit unification. But since the wisdom of such a move is in the realm of speculation, one man's guess is as good as another's.

WASHINGTON, April 28. -- The close trade relationships between the United States and Canada in the past, and the hope that they will be greater in the future because they are untroubled by political jealousies or fears, were emphasized tonight by Prime Minister Bennett of Canada, in an address over the National Broadcasting Company's network.

Police Commissioner Bolan, pained by half-hearted salutes and general unmilitary posture in the department, has ordered the 1,072 sergeants on the force to report to the Sixty-ninth Regiment Armory for three days' instruction in military training.
Hunters and jumpers occupied a prominent position on the program last evening at the second day of the fortieth annual Brooklyn. Horse Show in the arena of the Riding and Driving Club.

MEXICO CITY, April 28. -- President Rodriguez received the members of the United States Davis Cup team at a special audience this morning in Chapultepec Castle, Mexico's Chief Executive chatting amiably with the tennis stars here to play in the preliminary encounter in this zone.

The new liner Washington, built for the United States Lines by the New York Shipbuilding Company at Camden, N.J., was to leave the yards early this morning for her official sea trials under service conditions.
CLEVELAND, April 28 (AP). -- Further sharp upturns in production and climbing prices were reported today in the steel industry.
Heywood Broun, newspaper columnist, resigned from the Socialist party yesterday and announced his action in his column in The New York World Telegram.

The Irving Trust Company, temporary receivers for the bankrupt Brentano book stores, took over the receivership yesterday and at the same time obtained a thirty-day extension in receivership. The first thirty days of receivership ends today.

WASHINGTON, April 28. -- Delay in instituting the prosecution of Joseph W. Harriman of the Harriman National Bank was allowed in order to permit an opportunity to reorganize the bank, William H. Ramsey, an attorney of the Department of Justice, testified before a Senate Judiciary sbcommittee today.

With bids attracted by only a small percentage of the $16,682,167 of municipal bond issues which were up for award this week, most communities throughout the country which normally would be in the market with new financing at this time have declined to schedule issues until market conditions improve.

The reported Jewish troubles in Germany were characterized yesterday by Dr. Johannes Borchers, German Consul General in Cleveland, as more than anything else a matter of immigration such as might exist in any country.
WASHINGTON, April 28. -- The Bureau of Navigation issued the following orders today, dated April 26:

ALBANY, April 28. -- Governor Lehman today signed a bill, sponsored by Senator Dunnigan, creating an advisory board in the State Insurance Department and vetoed another measure introduced by the Senate leader which was identical except that it vested in the board more than advisory powers.
Former Governor Alfred E. Smith, despite frequent assertions to friends that he will not run for Mayor, continues to be a potentially important factor in the Mayoralty situation.

Even inflationists in the Senate crowded about Senator GLASS to congratulate him on his speech against inflation. They knew how to admire what they dared not imitate. It must have been an inspiring sight when the Virginia Senator rose to announce that he could not abandon his deepest convictions, or yield on a question of principle, merely in order to go with the majority of his party or follow the lead of his own President.

CHICAGO, April 28. -- About 1,500 men have been recalled to work within the last two weeks by the steel industry in the Gary-South Chicago district. Additional furnaces are being put into operation which will increase employment more.

Owen D. Young was re-elected yesterday chairman of the board of the General Electric Company at the organization meeting of the directors, who were elected recently at the annual meeting of stockholders.
NEW YORK. Jules Henry, Counselor of the French Embassy, is at the Ritz-Carlton.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., April 28 (AP). -- After twenty hours of rebellion, the nine Negro defendants in the "Scottsboro case" today capitulated and went peacefully to their cells for a good meal and slept most of the afternoon away.
BERLIN, April 28. -- The Nazi Government obtained power upon a definite promise -- "work and bread for all." There were other promises, but this was basic.

PASADENA, Cal., April 28. -- Dr. Paul W. Merrill, astronomer of the Mount "Wilson Observatory, told today of a successful hunt begun thirteen years ago for members of the hottest group of stars known.

Otto H. Kahn, partner in Kuhn, Loeb Co., writer and patron of the arts, discusses what is required of successful men "if the so-called capitalistic system of society is to continue," in an introduction for "The Girl and Her Job," written by Esther Eberstadt Brooke and published by Appleton.

CHICAGO, April 28 (AP) -- The three Stout brothers from South-western Teachers College, Oklahoma, were outstanding in the preliminaries of the national amateur wrestling championships tonight as the favorites moved through the initial tests.

Men and women of the circus came to mourn Rattlesnake Bill Laren at his funeral yesterday morning, and six of his friends in the Ringling Brothers, Barnum and Bailey show were his pallbearers and carried the flag-draped coffin from the undertaking parlors at 353 West Thirty-eighth Street to the hearse that took it to the National Cemetery at East New York.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In THE TIMES last Sunday, in talking about health fetishes, Dr. Spear says: "And the height and weight data, I think, have become a regular health racket." My daughter and I are both victims of that racket.

PARIS, April 28. -- Appointing a permanent committee to work in cooperation with the International Chamber of Commerce "for economic disarmament," the First International Trade Congress, held under the auspices of the French Exporters Union, closed today with a session at the Quai d'Orsay attended by President LeBrun and Foreign Minister Paul-Boncour.

While nervous fluctuations continued yesterday on the Cotton Exchange and prices fell back about $2 a bale from the recent high marks, a recovery in the last hour left the list 6 to 9 points lower than on Thursday.

A combination of apathy and caution held the share market within rather narrow limits yesterday and restricted the volume of trading on the Stock Exchange to 2,163,000 shares. Commission houses conceded for the first time that the enthusiasm born of the inflation movement in Washington had been partly exhausted.
To the Editor of The New York Times: Your editorial "Largest Debtor Class" in today's TIMES should be brought to the attention of our President, Senators and Representatives in Washington.

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., April 28. -- Ogden L. Mills, who was Secretary of the Treasury at the end of the Hoover administration, attacked the Roosevelt monetary and fiscal program as unconstitutional and likely to lead to uncontrolled inflation, in an address tonight at a dinner of the Indiana Republican Editorial Association.

OYSTER BAY, L.I., April 28. -- The second attempt of Edwin W. Wallace, Assemblyman from Rockville Centre, to assert himself as Republican leader of Nassau County, met with defeat here tonight when Frank Tappen of Jericho, hia candidate for leadership of the Town of Oyster Bay, withdrew from the race at the last minute.

LA PAZ, Bolivia, April 28. -- Crossing through intense fire from the Paraguayan lines, Bolivian planes again have bombed Puerto Casado, the most important port on the right bank of the Paraguay River and the centre of provisioning and mobilization of the Paraguayan forces.

WASHINGTON, April 28. -- In an overwhelming response to the administration's recommendations, the Senate today adopted the Thomas inflation amendment to the farm relief bill and then quickly passed the farm relief measure itself, after voting down the resurrected proposal for immediate payment of the veterans' bonus.

CHICAGO, April 28. -- Liquidation of a line of long wheat, variously estimated at 3,000,000 to 4,000,000 bushels, by a house with Eastern and New York connections, started the market on the Board of Trade on the downgrade today in the face of bullish developments.

Three purposes are defined in the Administration's long-awaited railway bilL. It is intended to encourage or require action on the part of the carriers to avoid duplication of services, unnecessary waste and unreasonable disturbance of rates by individual lines.

CHICAGO, April 28. -- Sewell L. Avery, president of Montgomery Ward Co., told stockholders at the annual meeting today that a salary of $100,000 yearly "was not a sufficient inducement" when the presidency was offered to him first, more than a year ago.

Theodore Moons of Belgium started the defense of his world's amateur 18.1 balkline championship last night at the Brooklyn Lodge of Elks clubhouse with a 300-to-244 victory over Francis S. Appleby, former American titleholder. The match went forty-three innings.

WASHINGTON, April 28. -- An improvement in the employment situation in Great Britain in March, due largely to seasonal conditions, was reported by the Department of Commerce today in its weekly review of conditions abroad.
WASHINGTON, April 28. -- Former Premier Herriot issued the following statement on leaving Washington today:
WASHINGTON. April 28. -- The War Department released the following orders today:

ST. LOUIS, April 28 (AP). -- The Browns literally threw away a ball game today, the Tigers winning an undeserved victory, 5 to 3. With the score tied in the ninth and one out, Hayworth bunted safely. Bridges also bunted and Scharein threw high over first.

The United Gas Improvement Company and subsidiaries report for the year ended on March 31 a net income of $34,346,106. This is equal, after preferred dividends, to $1.31 a share earned on the common stock. It compares with $37,184,437, or $1.43 a share, earned in the preceding year.

In the review of the Catholic Charities for 1932, " family care " is put first. No aspect of family life was more prominent than "endurance." Courage to keep going in the face of difficulties, and ingenuity in making adjustments within the family group, commonplace as the daily routine acts become, are the glorious but often pathetic marks of human heroism.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Any native New Yorker whose youth extends back of 1900 will recall intermittent discussion of the Central Park question. This question is, Shall Central Park continue to resemble and fulfill the plans of the landscape engineers, Olmsted and Vaux, who designed it, or shall it be converted to "practical" use as a site for public buildings, playgrounds, ?

PRINCETON. N.J., April 28. -- Few college students have radical or communistic tendencies, Dean Christian Gauss of Princeton University asserted here today in reply to an attack on Princeton. Yale and Harvard made yesterday by Colonel Robert R. McCormick, editor and publisher of The Chicago Tribune, in a speech before the Advertising Club of New York.
WASHINGTON, April 28. -- President Roosevelt and former Premier Herriot issued the following joint statement today relative to their conversations on the war debts:

WASHINGTON, April 28 (AP). -- Changes in twenty-four of the navy's highest commands afloat and ashore were ordered today by Secretary Swanson, supplementing earlier assignments which included designation of Vice Admiral William H. Standley to succeed Admiral William V. Pratt as chief of naval operations.
The text of M. Herriot's address at the dinner of the French Chamber of Commerce last night, as translated for the National Broadcasting Company, over whose network it was delivered, follows:

WASHINGTON, April 28. -- The "national industry recovery act," a bill that envisages complete control of industry through a national board modeled after the War Industries Board, is being hurried for submission to the President next week, it was reported today.

Bondholders acting through P.M. Committee, Inc., took over the eighteen-story Park-Murray Building at 9-15 Park Place, extending through the block to 8-12 Murray Street, at foreclosure auction yesterday. The property was taken on a bid of $169,803.78 at a sale held in the Vesey Street Exchange by James R. Murphy, auctioneer.

WASHINGTON, April 28. -- New York received its fourth grant of relief funds from the Reconstruction Finance Corporation today, when an additional $6,600,000 was made available to Governor Lehman for meeting current emergency relief needs in ninety-four of the 115 welfare districts during May.

THE revival of the fighting spirit in sports can be traced directly to the departure from the gold standard. The flare-up that occurred in the Washington baseball park recently could never have happened in the Great Boom Period of a few years ago.

Empire Covered Button Co., also Goodman Laks and Jacob ShefsKy. in 315 W. 39th St.; Cornell Balog, women's neckwear, and Abraham Epstein, in 215 W. 40th St.; the Needle Center, Inc., in 140 W. 36th St.: Luigi Crispo and M. Weinstein Son. in 519 8th Av.; Alden Silks, Inc., in 132 W. 36th St.; Adams Co., brokers.
A spirited eighth-inning rally enabled the Manhattan College baseball team to gain a 7-6 victory over Temple at Manhattan Field yesterday.
CLEVELAND, April 28 (AP). -- The Indians regained their hitting eyes against the White Sox today, winning their first start in four against the Chicago Club, 5 to 1.
Marcel Olivier. former Governor General of Madagascar and now president of the French Line, is returning to Paris today on the Ile de France after visiting the offices here and also Washington.

WASHINGTON, April 28. -- By a vote of 383 to 4 today the House passed the administration's $2,300,100,000 home mortgage bill, the principal feature of which would set up a $2,000,000,000 corporation to issue government bonds hearing 4 per cent interest, these in turn to be "exchanged" for mortgages now held on homes valued at not more than $15,000.
BOSTON, Saturday, April 29 (AP). -- The sacred cod, emblematic of Massachusetts' first industry, was returned to the State House early today.

Sometimes a tree which has withstood the Winter's gales will fall on a calm Summer's night. Human institutions occasionally take the same course, as in the case of the bill signed this week by Governor LEHMAN, repealing the personal property tax.

Direct evidence of a practice whereby certain hospitals rebate to physicians a part of the sums paid by patients who are sent to these institutions and overcharged for the purpose will be presented to the District Attorney's office within the next few days by the Association of Private Hospitals, Inc., it was disclosed yesterday by Oscar R. Gottfried, executive secretary of the association.
Beniamino Ricci's concert scheduled for the Barbizon-Plaza tonight has been canceled because of the baritone's illness.

WASHINGTON, April 28. -- A conference on wheat in Geneva next month, preliminary to the World Economic Conference, was assured when the State Department informed the League of Nations today of its readiness to designate an American delegate.

BERLIN, April 28. -- Chancellor Hitler, for the first time since his accession to office, received Leo Mo Khinchuk, the Soviet Ambassador, today. Although nothing was announced concerning the nature of their conversation, it is regarded as significant that it followed shortly after governmental action against the Derop Company for the distribution of Russian oil in Germany, during which numerous Communist employes of the company were arrested.

World opinion shows no abatement in revulsion at the march of events in Germany. Every hour there is a swelling chorus of pained and indignant protest against the spectacle which the new German rulers insist on staging before the eyes of a bewildered humanity.

PEIPING, Saturday, April 29. -- Under cover of barrages from sixty field guns and bombing by eight airplanes that shattered the Chinese defenses, the Japanese forces advancing toward Peiping along the road from Chengteh, the Jehol capital, swept yesterday through Nantienmen, sixty miles north of here, and established themselves in strong positions south of the town.

To the Editor of The New York Times: THE TIMES is rendering good service to the public in the publication of such editorials as "Two Senators" and "Inflation and Depression." Every student of financial history will agree with your statement that "None of our own major panic depressions -- those which followed 1893, 1873, 1857 and 1837 -- was terminated through paper inflation and currency depreciation."

Control of the New England Public Service Company, formerly a unit of the Middle West Utilities System, has passed into the hands of a group of New England financiers and business men headed by Walter S. Wyman, president of the company.

WASHINGTON, April 28. -- That $25,000,000,000 has been lost by American investors in the purchase of worthless stock in the past ten years was asserted by the Senate Banking and Currency Committee today in urging passage of the administration's security control bill.

Resuming hostilities with the Senators at the Stadium yesterday, the Yankees performed prodigious deeds afield. They collected two homers, one being the fourth of the campaign for Babe Ruth and the other being made by the stalwart Bill Dickey.

It took a jury in General Sessions only ten minutes yesterday to return a verdict of guilty of grand larceny in the second degree against Dr. Francis M. Schirp, former German language newspaper editor and college instructor, on one of four indictments accusing him of fraud in a bogus trading stamp scheme.

LONDON, April 28. -- The private view of the annual Royal Academy exhibition, which is always regarded as the official opening of the London season, furnished the usual brilliant spectacle today at Burlington House. Many of those who crowded the galleries saw themselves on canvas.

Mr. and Mrs. John Vasko of Hastings-on-Hudson seemed reconciled yesterday to the operation on the left eye of their 2-year-old daughter Helen, which, according to eye specialists, saved the life of the child. The parents had opposed the operation in the Westchester Children's Court and in the Appellate Division, but in both cases were overruled.

PARIS, April 28. -- For the first time in many years France has now real information on which to work as to what the United States wants and what she is willing to do to attain her objects. This is the result of Edouard Herriot's White House conversations as seen here.

Declaring he did not wish to reveal all he knew about racketeering in the poultry business and Joseph Weiner while the latter, its reputed overlord, was still at large. District Attorney Samuel J. Foley of the Bronx obtained an adjournment yesterday of the trial of seven of Weiner's alleged aides.
GENEVA, April 28. -- The United States began today to play an active public role in the disarmament conference debates by urging adoption of the British disarmanent plan without amendments.

The election of a new board of directors and new officers of North American Aviation, Inc., as a result of deals through which the General Motors Corporation has obtained control of 51 per cent of the stock of the company, was announced yesterday.

PITTSBURGH, April 28 (AP). -- A combination of timely hitting and flashy fielding behind Pitcher Larry French, who bore down expertly in the pinches, enabled the Pirates to turn back the St. Louis Cardinals, 2 to 0, in the series opener today.

Asserting that he considered all three players equally to blame, William Harridge, president of the American League, yesterday suspended Ben Chapman, fleet outfielder of the Yankees; Buddy Myer, second baseman, and Earl Whitehill, left-handed pitcher of the Senators, and fined each $100 for their part in the riot which broke out in the fourth inning of the Yankee-Senator game in Washington on Tuesday.

WASHINGTON, April 28. -- President and Mrs. Roosevelt entertained at luncheon today the members of the Philippine mission, inviting with them Secretary Dern, Mayor Frank Murphy of Detroit, Governor General designate of the Philippines; Miss Rosamund Pinchot and Miss Margaret LeHand and Miss Tully of the White House "family."

When David Dubin, president of the Cloak and Dress Covered-Button Manufacturers Association, and Philip L. Derketsch, the general manager, were arraigned in General Sessions yesterday on coercion and conspiracy indictments. Judge Rosalsky announced that he had been Informed that District Attorney Grain and Police Commissioner Bolan had joined in a campaign against racketeers in this city.

Charley Deveng, former Harvard ace who pitched and lost a one-hit game in his first International League start, held Buffalo to three blows at Ruppert's Stadium, Newark, yesterday, while hurling the Bears to a 4-to-1 triumph. On its home diamond at West Side Park, Jersey City lost to Montreal, 2 to 1.

DES MOINES, April 28. -- America's fastest intercollegiate sprinter, Ralph Metcalfe, 22-year-old flyer from Marquette University, Mil waukee, today opened a campaign that he hopes will be climaxed by reducing the world's record for the 100-yard dash to the amazing time of 0:09.2.
To the Editor of The New York Times: Your editorial page of today is certainly most illuminating.

LONDON, April 28 (AP). -- Financial London gave every move on the international chessboard its closest attention today, and the stock market maintained a bright aspect because of what is considered the favorable outlook for the World Economic Conference.
Medicines Not to be Taken. The country is doing better and better if that little girl is to be believed. She said that billions of pins have saved human life by not being swallowed.

OPPELN, Upper Silesia, Germany, April 28. -- The guardian of the truce between the Germans and the Poles in this uneasy region is a kindly middle-aged gentleman with a graying beard whose grandparents spoke only the archaic "water Polish" used by the indigenous Slavs and whose political philosophy is rooted in the teachings of the Catholic Church.

Disregarding growing protests by organizations and individuals who have been fighting for years to save the city's parks from encroachments, John E. Sheehy, newly appointed Park Commissioner, announced yesterday that he would proceed at once with his plans to convert the thirty-four-acre site of the abandoned lower reservoir in Central Park into a series of baseball diamonds and athletic fields.

WASHINGTON, April 28. -- Edouard Herriot and the experts who accompanied him left Washington today after five days of intense concentration, together with President Roosevelt and State Department officials, on the leading economic and political problems facing the world.

PHILADELPHIA, April 28. -- Manhattan College crashed into the list of major winners at the Penn Relays for the first time today and the Jaspers made their crash a resounding one. While a crowd of 10,000 huddled in the towering steel stands at wind-swept Franklin Field for the opening session of the thirty-ninth annual carnival, the Manhattan distance medley team raced to a new world's record of 10:14 for the two and a half miles.

To the Editor of The New York Times: During the past few weeks the Board of Education has had occasion to inform the public that the schools exist for the purpose of education and not for the purpose of providing employment for unemployed teachers.

RIVERSIDE, N.J., April 28. -- An excited crowd of high school students on strike was pacified with radio music and dancing here today after they had gathered in the office of Justice of the Peace Jacob J. Blankemeyer to attend the hearing of Nyta Bracey, 18-year-old girl, charged with assault as a result of the strike, which has continued since last Monday.

PITTSBURGH, April 28. -- Recommending that broad powers be given to President Roosevelt to change tariff duties, the National Foreign Trade Council offered seventeen remedies today to restore world trade.

The Mobile Ohio was added yesterday to the small group of railroads, mostly in the South, which reported increased net operating income for March. Others which have reported this improvement are the Atlantic Coast Line, the Southern and the Seaboard Air Line.

The newest addition to the list of departures from the Broadway playhouses this evening is "Man Bites Dog," whicn opened Tuesday night at the Lyceum Theatre. Other departing attractions are "The Late Christopher Bean" at Henry Miller's Theatre, "For Services Rendered" at the Booth and revivals of "The Mikado" and "Young Sinners" at the St. James and Ambassador Theatres, respectively.

WASHINGTON, April 28. -- Subscriptions to the Treasury's offering of $500,000,000 in 2 7/8 per cent three-year notes, dated May 2, amounted to $1,200,000,000, Secretary Woodin announced today. This substantial oversubscription, although smaller than usual, was regarded as satisfactory, in view of the general situation and the comparatively low interest rate.

PARIS, April 28. -- The recent decree by the French Government restricting to 10 per cent the number of foreign musical entertainers allowed at cafes and cabarets was followed today by another providing limitations for foreign theatrical performers and entertainers of all kinds.

The text of M. Herriot's speech here last night is on Page 2. Edouard Herriot, former premier of France, returned to New York yesterday after conversations with President Roosevelt on world economic problems had been closed and in a farewell address at the Waldorf last night, declared that important progress had been made toward their solution.

WASHINGTON, April 28. -- Concerted action by Congress and State Legislatures, together with credit grantors and debtors, to put an end to the increasing number of unwarranted consumer bankruptcies throughout the United States each year is urged in a report on the causes of bankruptcies among wage earners made public today by the Commerce Department.

Spring fishing in Maine is a sport that appeals to many who like to venture into the Sebago Lake region, for instance, in the hope of catching salmon. The latest information indicates that all the ice is out, and hence the season on sea salmon, landlocked salmon, trout and togue, as applying to both lake and river fishing, is legally open.

PHILADELPHIA, April 28 (AP) -- The Athletics took a free-scoring game from the Red Sox in the opener of a two-day series today, 9 to 8. The Mackmen concentrated the bulk of their hitting while scoring six runs in the third inning.
ALBANY, N.Y., April 28. -- The State milk control board tonight announced a new schedule of minimum retail prices for milk and cream effective Monday throughout up-State territory.

All speculative markets evidenced yesterday their respect for the vigorous and intelligent opposition to the inflation movement. Stocks moved nervously within narrow limits, but commodities pursued an uneven downward course.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The death of Arthur L. Merriam marked the passing of a man who stood to a wide circle of friends as a symbol of much that is best in American life. The events of his career were consistent with that ideal.

Four old sidewheel steamboats will again ply between 129th Street and Coney Island this Summer. This year, however, they will have bars, new names and will dock at a pier the rental of which will be nearly twice the sum paid for the vessels when they were auctioned last February.

WASHINGTON, April 28. -- The administration's railroad legislation, providing for a Federal coordinator of transportation to direct and if necessary to force more economical operation, is not acceptable to organized railway labor, George M. Harrison, acting chairman of the Railway Labor Executives Association, said today in demanding adequate protection of the union workers.

The Long Island Railroad carried 91,713,868 passengers in 1932, a decrease of 18,569,569 from 1931, according to the annual report of W. W. Atterbury, president. Passengers who used the Pennsylvania Station decreased 7,459,114 to 45,157,548, and those who used the Flatbush Avenue station decreased 3,445,991 to 26,352,434.

Many names well known in society and turf circles are to be found among the Turf and Field Club boxholders for the meeting opening at Belmont Park on May 27. William Woodward, chairman of the Jockey Club, again has Box 15.

GREENSBORO, N.C., April 27. -- This city of 55,000 people has won national attention since March 4 as being the largest municipality in the nation without banking facilities. It has achieved another unique distinction in the fact that three brothers, as a tribute to the memory of their father, have guaranteed full payment of $250,000 or more of deposits in a mill village bank organized by him.
PRINCETON, N.J., April 29 (AP). -- Defeating Harvard and Holy Cross by 5 1/2 to 3 1/2 and 6 to 3, respectively, Princeton took the lead in the Eastern Intercollegiate Golf Association race today.

A new edition of one of the fine anthologies of poetry for children. The author of "The Golden Age" and "The Wind in the Willows," who never condescended to children, but all his life retained the ability to see the world through the eyes of an imaginative child, could safely be trusted to choose poetry for boys and girls.

DAYLIGHT saving may tie a boon to the farmer, but it certainly is a bore to the woman; that is until she gets herself adjusted to it in all that pertains to evening clothes. It upsets her dress psychology; suddenly she finds herself struggling with the dinner hour -- bathed in almost broad daylight -- and her evening gowns, designed to glitter under electricity.

ST. LOUIS, April 29 (AP). -- The St. Louis Browns did their heaviest hitting of the season today and won the second same of the series with the Tigers. 11 to 4. The Browns batted Lynwood (Schoolboy) Rowe out and scored seven runs in the seventh.

James B. Pond, the lecture manager, who for thirty years has been using the public platform to acquaint Americans with the thoughts and opinions of European authors, filed a petition in bankruptcy yesterday in United States District Court.

The fortieth anniversary of the founding of the Henry Street Settelment by Miss Lillian D. Wald was observed in the settlement gymnasium at 301 Henry Street last night at a gathering of about 1,000 members of the Alumni Association.

WASHINGTON, April 29. -- International economic rehabilitation was held up by Secretary Hull as the cornerstone of his foreign policy in an address delivered tonight at the annual dinner of the American Society of International Law. He made clear that the administration was prepared to exercise leadership in solving the problem.

NEWARK, April 29. -- A device whereby a high-compression gasoline engine can be made to perform efficiently on ordinary furnace oil was demonstrated today at the Newark Metropolitan Airport, and its performance impressed a group of observers, including pilots and engineers.

ONCE more it has come around to pick over the collected orchestral records which have had to be set aside for no good reason beyond the fact that there has not been enough room between album sets to give them proper mention.

All commodities traded on local Exchanges jumped forward yesterday in a general advance similar to that which immediately followed the announcement of suspension of gold payments and the increased momentum of the inflation movement. Sugar and cocoa went to new high levels, while others closed near the tops for the year to date.
WASHINGTON, April 29. -- In no uncertain terms Secretary Woodin denied today persistent rumors that he planned to resign from the Cabinet.

BOSTON, April 29. -- The personal attacks made in Congress on Federal Judge James A. Lowell for his decision to allow a writ of habeas corpus in the case of George Crawford, Negro wanted in Virginia on charges of double murder, are deplored in a resolution, adopted by the council of the Bar Association of the City of Boston yesterday and made public today.

BERLIN, April 29. -- Thousands of political prisoners arrested in the course of the national revolution were released today in connection with the national labor festival decreed by the Hitler government for May Day, which is to be ceremoniously observed throughout the Reich as a legal holiday.

WASHINGTON, April 29. -- President Roosevelt and members of his Cabinet attended their first Gridiron dinner tonight since the inauguration and heard the administration satirized in song and skit, with "Sweet Adeline" sung as the "theme song of the new deal" in celebration of the return of beer.

WASHINGTON, April 29. -- Almost thirty-five years after he sank the collier Merrimac to bottle up the Spanish fleet in Santiago Harbor, Richmond Pearson Hobson received the Congressional Medal of Honor today from President Roosevelt at the White House.

A NEW and very timely book about Germany is being written by Calvin B. Hoover of Duke University, whose economic study of the Soviets is one of the best books in its field. "Germany Enters the Third Reich" will be published early in the Summer by the Macmillan Company.

The competitive season in women's fencing usually begins to ebb about this time each year, but the contrary is now true because of a national outdoor championship that will be staged for the first time.
Passage of the farm bill by the Senate brought a rush of public buying into the Cotton Exchange yesterday and prices moved upward $2 a bale to new high ground for the movement.

WASHINGTON, April 29. -- Plans for a public works program, which will be integrated with a plan for national industrial recovery, were "speeded up" at a White House conference today. It is expected that the public works program will be completed in about a week.

The rapid advance of the private automobile and the airplane in the movement of passengers since 1920 is detailed in statistics compiled by H.B. Hale Co., consulting engineers. The figures show that passenger-mileage of airplanes increased from 1,000,000 in 1926 to 127,000,000 in 1932 and of private automobiles from 250,000,000,000 to 369,000,000,000.

HERO worship only moderately diluted with sober second thoughts marks the latest biography of E.H. Harriman, whom the authors fondly describe as "the last individualist." The phrase recalls the recent remark of Horace Kallen that under America's scheme of "rugged individualism" the employers had all the individualism and the wage earners all the ruggedness.

Recalling the panic of 1873 it which "there was absolutely no market for a number of securities at any price," Washington E. Connor, who was a partner of the late Jay Gould, disputes the popular notion that the present depression is the worst that the United States ever has experienced.

Ignace Jan Paderewski, the pianist, sailed yesterday on the French liner He de France, suffering from a severe attack of lumbago, which caused him to cancel one of his concerts. He will go first to Paris, and then Lausanne, Switzerland, where his wife is seriously ill.

The best known horse race in America and one of the richest, the Kentucky Derby, will be run next Saturday at Churchill Downs, Louisville, Ky., before approximately 50,000 persons. At a mile and a quarter and for 3-year-olds, the Derby has been gaining, in importance from year to year until now it is an important gauge of speed and endurance as well as the greatest spectacle of its kind.

PARIS, April 9. WE have had several new productions of importance during the past fortnight. There has been Paul Raynal's long-awaited "Francerie" at the Comedle Frangalse. There has been a translation of Jeffery Dell's "Payment Deferred."

WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., April 29. -- Williams defeated Hamilton by the score of 12 to 3 today, Captain Markoski leading the Purple attack with two triples. Both teams used three pitchers. Williams played errorless ball, while Hamilton's fielding was ragged.

HAVRE DE GRACE, Md., April 29. -- The Catawba Farm's Mr. Khayyam, son of the Kentucky Derby winner Omar Khayyam, and an eligible for next Saturday's renewal of the Churchill Downs test, captured the $7,500 added Chesapeake Stakes, closing-day feature at Havre de Grace today.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Two Scandinavian States, Denmark and Norway, have just given to the world a striking example of how international disputes should be dealt with in the twentieth century. The judgment of the World Court on April 5, upholding Denmark's claim to certain territories in Eastern Greenland, seems to have received scant notice in the American press.
PARIS. SUBJECT and author combine to make the new biography of Caillaux a book of twofold interest.

HENRY HADLEY, conductor and composer; John Charles Thomas, baritone recently engaged by the Metropolitan Opera Company, and Henri Deering, pianist, will contribute to the Musicians Symphony Orchestra's concert Tuesday night at the Metropolitan Opera House.

Members of the New York City committee of the Robert E. Lee Memorial Foundation, of which Mrs. Charles W. Kellogg Is chairman, have arranged an unusual garden tour to raise funds for the maintenance and preservation of Statford Hall, Westmorland County, Va., the birthplace of Richard Henry Lee and Francis Lightfoot Lee, signers of the Declaration of Independence, and of General Robert E. Lee.

WASHINGTON, April 29. -- In a telephone transaction which took only twenty minutes, Henry Morgenthau Jr., chairman of the Federal Farm Board, sold in the Chicago pit today the remaining 1,100,000 bushels of September wheat held by the Farm Board, at 69 cents and a fraction.

THE recent premiere of "The Marriage of Sobeide," an opera written by Alexander Tcherepnin, Russian pianist and composer living in Paris, and based on a play by Hugo von Hofmannsthal, at the Volksoper in Vienna was an event of importance, judging by reports found in Austrian newspapers.

BERLIN, April 14, 1933. THE "Kampfbund fur deutsche Kultur" (Militant League for German Culture), whose beginnings were fairly inconspicuous, has latterly acquired a preponderating influence in German artistic and cultural life and gives promise of wielding this influence without mercy.

Donald Hunt, 13 years old, of 85-28 Aspen Place, Jamaica Estates, was shot in the left temple and probably mortally wounded early last night as he and two other boys were walking along Aberdeen Road just north of the Grand Central Parkway.
BERLIN, April 29. -- The "primacy of politics" laid down by the National Socialist government as a fundamental tenet has now also mastered German athletics.

YOUTH has been served this month. The exhibition of portraits of children (opening at the Reinhardt Galleries tomorrow, and shown for the benefit of the Children's Welfare Association, a clearing house of 259 organizations in New York City interested in child health) is an affair of half a hundred and more artists.

WASHINGTON, April 29. -- Hedley V. Cooke Jr. of Orange, N.J., vice consul at Tsingtao, has been assigned as vice consul at Shanghai. Other changes in the foreign service the past week were annouced by the State Department today as follows:

Retention of e Home Loan Bank system seems assured in the administration's relief efforts for home owners in view of the passage in the House last Friday of the Federal home mortgage bill by the high vote of 383 to 4.

Wider exploitation of American patent rights to machines, processes and products is urged on manufacturing exporters by the patent and trade-marks committee of the American Manufacturers Export Association in a report on "The Asset Value of American Inventions in Foreign Trade," made public yesterday.

Commissioner SHEEHY'S decision to go ahead with his plans to cover another broad expanse of Central Park with a mass of baseball diamonds and athletic fields is a serious blow to a pioneer municipal enterprise in which the whole country has a stake. To devote so much space to this subordinate purpose, without proper landscaping, is contrary not only to the tradition of the park but to the whole philosophy which imbues it.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., April 29. -- Yale and Cornell battled to a 6-6 ten-minute overtime lacross tie today. The Ithacans led at half time, 3 to 2. Winslow, in home for Cornell, scored four goals. Glick stood out for Yale with two tallies.

Miss Ethel Cleveland Lenssen, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Lenssen, was married to John Findlay Allen, son of Mr. and Mrs. Yorke Allen, yesterday afternoon in St. James's Church, Madison Avenue and Seventy-first Street. The Rev. Dr. George P.T. Sargent, rector of St. Bartholomew's Church, a cousin of the bridegroom, assisted by the Rev. Sidney T. Cooke of St. James's Church, performed the ceremony.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In order to understand the constitutional questions that will be presented to the United States Supreme Court if a case is taken up to test the 3.2 beer bill, it is necessary first to state a few fundamentals.

THE brisk pace in retail trade was well maintained during the week and sales here on several days ran ahead of last year's figures. Demand sprung up for late Spring and Summer goods, both in apparel and home furnishings.

In his final annual report as president of the American Museum of Natural History, Professor Henry Fairfield Osborn, who retired in January and is now honorary president, details a wealth of activity in the twenty-five years of his incumbency and declares that "while we may be temporarily suffering from the financial depression there is not a trace of defeatism or of the defeatist spirit in any part of the American Museum of Natural History."

THE vogue for heavily earthy novels seems to persist in spite of, or perhaps because of the extraordinary similarity they bear one to another. They are nearly all weighed down under a top-heavy load of sex interest, and have practically no other interest of any kind.

GENEVA, April 28. -- Norman H. Davis's statement formally abandoning the isolationist view that the only thing needed for disarmament is the reduction of armaments and conceding that their supervision is just as necessary is a key capable of unlocking many of the doors still closing in the disarmament conference.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., April 29. -- Davenport's good pitching after the third inning and excellent support By Navy enabled the midshipmen to win over the University of West Virginia today, 7 to 2.

ESPECIALLY since he published "The Redlakes," Mr. Francis Brett Young has been accumulating plaudits which increase in fervor with each new book. He belongs, his admirers say, to the ancient and honorable tradition of English fiction.

Stating that he discerns a slight but steady improvement in realty conditions, Charles F. Noyes says that more buyers are appearing in the real estate market and that he looks for easier mortgage money early in the Fall.

PITTSBURGH, April 27. -- This city and Allegheny County are looking forward with keen interest to Federal trials of election fraud cases in connection with Congressional contests in the Thirtieth and Thirty-second Districts.

BEGINNING tomorrow automobiles sold by retailers in this State will include in their price the 1 per cent sales tax recently voted by the Legislature. The tax, to be based on the retail selling price, is in addition to the 3 per cent Federal manufacturers' tax collected at the factories.

WALL effects unattainable until now are made possible by new wall-paper borders, panels and cornice patterns which have just reached the market. Among these are simulated wood moldings, paneled wainscoating, marbleized surfaces, columns and pilasters.

The serious dislocation in the last three years of the various factors which contribute to the value of retailed articles was considered yesterday one of the major reasons for the business depression by Paul P. Gourrich, well-known economist, in announcing the results of a study just completed.

The annual appeal of the Catholic Charities of the Archdiocese of New York will begin today in the 369 parishes of the archdiocese and will continue through May 10. Actual solicitation by nearly 20,000 men and women, volunteer members of the Cardinal's committee of the laity, will start this afternoon.

WASHINGTON, April 29. -- By agreement of that branch of the Republican party which nominated the candidates and wrote the platform of 1932, managed the campaign and still officially controls the organization, the first real test of cleavage on principle between the two major parties since President Roosevelt's inauguration was presented in the Senate vote on the farm bill with its inflation rider.

Instead of being of itself inflationary, departure from the gold standard might even, in the case of the dollar, have a directly opposite result, Donald B. Woodward and Marc A. Rose have written in the book "Inflation," to be published tomorrow by Whittlesey House, a division of the McGraw-Hill Book Company.

American Bank Note Company -- Quarter ended March 31: Net loss after taxes, depreciation, preferred dividends of foreign subsidiaries and other charges, $42,356, contrasted with net profit of $976, equal to about 1% cents a share on 89,913 6 per cent preferred shares of 550 par value, in first quarter of 1932.

The urgent need of strengthening municipal credit to a point at which at least the best-rated communities of the country can hope to obtain bids on sizable issues of new bonds will be considered fully this week at informal conferences in municipal banking circles.

In Washington the nations are meeting to discuss various aspects of the economic crisis, in preparation for the "World Economic Conference. What has brought about the present impasse! Is overproduction, multiplied by the machine, a main factor, or is the cause chiefly political, extreme nationalism as expressed in high tariff policies and other measures! These questions are considered in the following article.

At the annual dinner of the Sport and Conservation League held during the recent Spring field trials at Middletown, N.Y., President George Bemis impressed upon the members and guests of the organization the desirability of closer cooperation among the various clubs sponsoring field trials in this section of the country.

FORMER Mayor of New York, and Professor Emeritus of Economic History at Princeton University, Dr. McClellan should be felicitated on several points for his brief record of the last 118 years of Italian history. One prevailing departure is that he has not fallen into step with certain historians of the same period whose work is encyclopedic, at times merely chronologic -- such is the plethora of events and persons seeking interpretations and adjustments in relationship.

Offering of one big bond issue by a public utility in April, the largest single piece of financing since September, raised the total of new flotations far above that of March, although the number of issued marketed was only slightly greater than in March.

WASHINGTON, April 29. -- The gross income of farmers declined $6,775,000,000, or 57 per cent, from 1929 through 1932 to $5,143,000,000 in the latter year, while their cash income, after deducting various production expenditures, declined about $3,400,000,000, or 72 per cent, the Department of Agriculture announced today in its annual estimate.

CORN flakes are just breakfast food to the public in general, but at the First National studios in Burbank, Cal., where real snowflakes are rare, they are used in quantity as snow. The cornflakes used by the studio for its snow scenes differ from the ordinary home variety in that they are unsweetened, untoasted and bleached in order to obviate a suntan effect in the snow.

Foreign bond redemptions comprised most of the loans called for payment in April, before their dates of maturity. The month's total is the highest for the year and above that of last year. Bonds called this month aggregate $65,341.000, compared with $28,347,000 in March, and $15,427,000 in April, 1932.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., April 29. -- Miss Laura Ingalls of Garden City, L.I., shared first honors today with Richard Snackerberg of New York in the air derby of the Tailwind Club, flying from Curtiss Airport, Valley Stream, L.I., to this city.

SALT LAKE CITY, April 27. -- Silver and sugar, an alliterative contrast, mean as much to Utah, perhaps, as any other subject mentioned in recent news dispatches from Washington and New York. Hope and dismay are strangely commingled in the minds of citizens here as they learn daily of some new development.

The Merchants Association of New York, after a study of the McCall building, consolidation bill passed at the recent legislative session, has asked Governor Lehman to sign the measure. It is reported that this decision in favor of the bill is largely due to assurances received from city offcials that amendments will be made at a later date which will remove certain features which aroused serious objections to the bill.

LISBON, April 15. -- Recent diplomatic conferences in Europe have evidently been the basis for insinuations relating to Portugal's colonies. These have appeared in the press for some time but a recent article in the Echo de Paris apparently aroused the interest of the Portuguese Government.

TORONTO, April 29 (AP). -- The Toronto Globe says President Roosevelt in his conversations with Prime Minister Bennett sought lower trade barriers against American automobiles, chemicals, machinery and electrical equipment. The newspaper says:

PARIS, April 15, 1933. THERE is a great deal of music going on in Paris at the moment, but very few new works of real interest have appeared. The chief event this month was the concert of the Orchestra Symphonique de Paris under Alfred Cortot and Roger Desormieres.

Several entertainments, including dances and card parties, in behalf of charitable organizations will take place in the near future on board ocean liners. One of the unique events, and one that generally enlists the aid of prominent Italians in New York and well-known members of society, is the Primavera ball, under the auspices of the Italian Historical Society, to be held on May 11 on board the Rex.

HERE is another of the now-it-can-be-told books about the war. But the phrase carries, this time, a special and different significance. Moreover, the book has for American readers a keen and direct interest. For it tells the story, by the man who did it, of the secret work of the German Government in this country before we entered the war.

A complicated problem of accounting practice relating to the status of dividends paid and received in present conditions has been raised by Earle Baillie, president of the Tri-Continental Corporation, in his quarterly report to stockholders.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., April 29. -- Mrs. Minot A. Howard's chestnut mare Fuchsia was the feature performer at the first annual Rosedale horse show today. The Howard entry captured three blue ribbons in the regular classes, and in addition carried on to take the blue in the bareback jumping competition for post entries.

To the Music Editor: Your continued interest in the promotion of good music in America prompts me to call your attention to the fact that in 1921 there was instituted in this capital city of Pennsylvania the thought of a great chorus, organized to sing only the more important classical productions of the oratorio type.
Satisfied with the results of his mission and uttering words of friendship and adieu, Edouard Herriot, former Prime Minister of France, sailed for home yesterday afternoon aboard the Ile de France.

THIS could have happened only in jolly old England. Hoylake is a wind-swept, seaside golf course near Liverpool, and the usual weather report for that area is "Rain, followed by storms." It is a very old and very famous club, and the elderly members are a bit stiff and starchy on the outside but "decent old chaps, oh, very!" underneath it all.

Objection to the transfer of functions of the Tenement House Commission to a new Department of Buildings, as proposed by State Senator John T. McCall's bill, was expressed yesterday by Lawson Purdy, chairman of the Tenement House Committee of the Charity Organization Society.

DR. WALTER DAMROSCH a completed his five-year-plan of music appreciation on Friday, and hopes to continue next season. The music and lectures have been broadcast to a nationwide audience, including many school children and teachers.

THE question of opera in English, which is not a new one, received fresh impetus when students of the Juilliard School of Music revived Cimarosa's "Matrimonio segreto" in an English translation by Reginald Gatty and Albert Stoessel at the opening concert of the Library of Congress Chamber Festival, instituted by Mrs. Elizabeth Sprague Coolidge, in Washington, on the evening of April 23.

IN 1922 Johannes Haller wrote these striking lines: "The German past now seems like a series of vain efforts, forever doomed to failure. * * * Indeed, many are driven, in spite of themselves, to the conclusion that as we are today so we have always been -- as though from the very beginning some kind of curse lay upon all the generations.

MR. PUTNAM is United Slates Commissioner of Lighthouses and therefore his admirably comprehensive volume bears the mark of authority. It was first published in 1917. but there have been such important developments in the work of safeguarding ships and men at sea that he has prepared this new edition, revised throughout and brought up to the beginning of this year.

OTTAWA, April 27. -- One of the most remarkable migrations in history will be celebrated in St. John, N.B., on May 18, when it will have been 150 years since, at the end of the American Revolution, the vanguard of the United Empire Loyalists, driven from their homes in the revolting thirteen colonies because of their allegiance to the British Crown, landed on the more hospitable shores of New Brunswick.

DUBLIN, April 28. -- Political events of the past week all point to the Free State embarking on a policy of definite separation from the British Empire. Last Sunday, speaking at the graves of republican leaders of the insurrection of 1916, President de Valera made one of the most radical republican declarations since assuming office.

BERLIN, April 28. -- The revolutionary fervor of Germany's collegiate youth is developing at a pace that seems to be getting on the nerves of even the maturer champions of the "national revolution," and for the first time since the Nazi steam roller began to invade the campus -- the universities were among its earliest objectives -- warning voices are now becoming distinctly audible.

BERLIN, April 29. -- Captain Hermann Wilhelm Goering, Chancellor Hitler's "strong man," who only yesterday was formally appointed Aviation Minister, today announced the formation under his auspices of the Reich Federation for Protection Against Air Attacks.

Despite the widespread use of insulin in treating diabetes during the last ten years, this disease claimed four times as many victims in New York City last year as it did thirty years ago, according to a survey of thirty years made public by officials of the New York Tuberculosis and Health Association.

DUBLIN, April 29. -- A rumor to the effect that the Free Stats Government has placed a ban on the return of the Abbey Players to the United States next Fall is denied here. Despite criticism of the plays which the Abbey company has been producing in the present American tour as anti-national President de Valera has no intention of interfering with the liberty of the Abbey Theatre directors, it was said today.

George Henriques Co., Inc., an investment company of 78 Beaver Street, applied in the Supreme Court yesterday to vacate a temporary injunction obtained by Attorney General Bennett, restraining the corporation and its officers, George H. Henriques, William C. Toomey and Harold Klein, from disposing of any securities pending an inquiry into their business on May 4.

All markets were excited yesterday by the overnight news that the Senate had passed the administration's inflation measure in substantially the same form that originally was proposed. Stocks, commodities of all kinds and sections of the bond market engaged in a broad advance.

SIR PHILIP GIBBS holds a mirror to these parlous times. He has done so before in the years of plunder and collapse that have followed the war. Each time he has written a book about his observations, a reportorial record deeply colored with dismay.

BERLIN, April 29. -- The Boerse maintained its bullish tone today, Virtually all active stocks reaching higher levels. Collieries, steels, electricals, I.G. Farben and breweries were particularly favored. Although in the last hour some reaction developed on realization sales, the closing was strong.

Speculative issues were in brisk demand yesterday in the listed bond market, and many foreign and domestic issues of this classification rose 1 to more than 5 points. United States Government bonds, in contrast, were generally lower, with losses ranging from 1-32 to 16-32 point for the active issues.

The largest women's college in the world is in search of a new president. And the post with its $17,356 salary-probably the largest offered by any women's institution -- is to be awarded in the next few weeks.

This has teen a month of "enlightenment" in the German universities. The German Students' Association, master of the treasuries of Hitlerian education, knits all these sons of thought in a common heroic purpose. So some 100,000 of them have heen "purifying" German literature and "purging" public and private libraries and bookshops.

Mexico is pushing forward its greatest highway project -- an improved road linking the United States border at Laredo, Texas, with its capital, Mexico City. The Federal Highway Commission of Mexico states that this 770-mile section, opening up Northeastern Mexico to tourist travel and trade, will probably be ready for through traffic in June.

ODESSA, Russia, April 28. -- Odessa is one of the most interesting cities of the Soviet Union because it illustrates so sharply the three major policies of sovietism -- the question of nationalities, the fusion of classes and the creation of an industrial proletariat.

To the Dramatic Editor: On a recent drama page I was grieved to note that the caption under the picture of Frank Moulan as Ko-Ko, in the revival of "The Mikado," referred to the Lord High Executioner of Titipu as "the gentleman with the sword, or mace, or whatever the weapon is called."

In view of the recent pasaage in the Legislature of the bill creating a Triborough Bridge Authority and authorizing the Mayor of New York City to appoint three members to constitute that board, a petition was recently forwarded to Mayor O'Brien by the heads of nine civic associations urging him to name the authority members at an early date so that plans for construction may be resumed.

BILLED as the biggest automobile show ever staged, the exhibition of motor products at the Chicago World's Fair will bring together for the view of a vast public every major development in the varied fields of the country's second largest in dustry.

The flight from the dollar was turned into a rout yesterday as news of the Senate's passage of the farm bill with its inflationary provisions reached the markets of the world. American money fell to 86.3 cents in terms of the French franc, while that exchange, together with, those of Germany, Italy, Holland, Belgium and Switzerland, rose to the highest dollar price in the history of the present currencies.
LONDON. BENITO MUSSOLINI'S proposed four-power pact looking toward revision of the peace treaties winch createed the present map of Europe has been followed by feverish diplomatic activity.

WHEN Nancy Cushing stepped from the train at Marston, a raw Southwestern hamlet, she became the cynosure of all eyes: for months to come she would be the main topic of local gossip. Who was this beautiful girl and what motive had she for buying the Simpson place thirty miles out yonder across the desert?

Jersey City shattered its six-game losing streak at West Side Park, Jersey City, yesterday by coming from behind with a six-run rally in the seventh inning to conquer Montreal, 7 to 2. A home run by Fresco Thompson with the bases filled climaxed the home team's uprising.

The boisterous speculative enthusiasm displayed in the share market yesterday as the aftermath of the passage of the inflation measure in the Senate caused an agreeable surprise in some quarters in Wall Street, where belief was prevalent that the recent gains in stock prices had largely anticipated the inflationary program.
GENEVA, April 29. -- The conflict between France and Germany over the troublesome problem of disarmament was intensified today by a difference over the proper method of computing armed strength.
WASHINGTON, April 29. -- Prime Minister Bennetts radio address, delivered today over the Columbia, Broadcasting System with a special hook-up to Canada, was as follows:

CHEYENNE, Wyo., April 27. -- Six new government thermometers scaling 78 degrees below zero have been received for distribution to Wyoming ranger stations and weather observatories to guard against future loss of official government records of extreme temperatures.

MAUD NATHAN, able crusader for all things that have made the life of women happier and easier in the home, in industry and in public life, has written a book of memoirs that will bring delight to those of her own generation and enlightenment to members of the younger.
PRINCETON, N.J., April 29. -- Led by Captain Al Donald, who scored 6 points, the Yale Rugby team defeated Frinceton by 9 -- 6 in an exciting contest held on Fitz-patrick Field today.

TEN or a dozen years ago Miss Caroline Lockhart bounded into popularity with a hilarious Western tale called "The Dude Wrangler." which is still just as funny as it was to its first readers. Something of the same brand of humor that animated that book enlivens many of the pages of this latest novel from Miss Lockhart's hand -- alternating horse-play and horse-sense are characteristic of the cowboys she depicts with understanding sympathy.

An ancient American stone stele weighing more than a ton will be an outstanding feature of the "American sources" exhibition, which will open to the public on May 10 at the Museum of Modern Art, 11 West Fifty-third Street. This piece of sculpture, it was announced yesterday, will reach the museum direct from the ruins of an ancient civilization in the tropical lowlands of Guatemala -- more specifically, from the site of Piedras Negras.

FIRST New York showing's by various artists bulked large in this gallery-goer's week. One of these newcomers was Michael Lenson, winner of the Chalonier Paris prize some years ago -- a young man with his thirtieth year still well ahead, whose work belies his youth.

All the honors in the champion ship foils tournament of the Inter collegiate Women's Fencing Association again went to New York University last night in the East Building of New York University at Washington Square.

The library of Lieut. Col. Ralph H. Isham, including first editions of Boswell, Johnson, Goldsmith, Piozzi and correlated books will be offered at auction next Thursday evening at the American Art Association-Anderson Galleries, Inc.

The Spring moving season in New York passed its peak late yesterday with little evidence of delays or congestion. Van owners, who in many cases are charging slightly less for their services this year than they were a year ago, reported generally that they were able to fill orders promptly.

LONDON. ISOLATION in radio is difficult. A nation may establish a radio utopia only to have it invaded by foreign programs. There is no fence or wall that will insulate one nation from another. England is finding that out as stations on the Continent increase their power and invade the air of the British Isles.

The work of demolishing the antiquated tenements on the two blocks bounded by Catharine, Monroe, Market and Cherry Streets, to make way for the Fred F. French Company model housing project, financed with an $8,075,000 Reconstruction Finance Corporation loan, will probably be started early next month.

Various divertissements reminiscent of country fairs have been planned for the Fifty-seventh Street Fair in aid of the New York City Cancer Committee and Cancer Institute, which will open on Tuesday at Joseph, 3 East Fifty-seventh Street, and will continue there through Thursday.

CHICAGO, April 29 (AP). -- Burleigh Grimes made his first start of his eighteenth season in the National League today and held Cincinnati to three singles. The Chicago Cubs showed their appreciation by turning loose their best attack of the season to shut out the Reds, 7 to 0.
Mrs. George A. Anderson of Glen Head, L.I., won the President's Cup at the closing session of the fortieth annual Brooklyn Horse Show last night in the arena of the Riding and Driving Club.

JENSEN'S latest historical novel is set in the Denmark of the early sixteenth century when that country, still powerful but declining in power, was overrun with wars. It was a harsh period. The weak but cruel Christian II was King: Sweden revolted from Evanish rule: the peasants attempted to rebel against the Crown: quixotic persecution was rampant, and the King himself was finally overcome and made prisoner in a castle.

GENEVA, April 29. -- The disarmament conference spent today exploring tie possibilities of bridging the abyss that was found yesterday to separate Germany from the rest of the world in regard to reduction of armies. Arthur Henderson and Anthony Eden of Britain and Count Rudolph Nadolny of Germany conferred on the general problem, but despite Herr Nadoiny's amiability, they progressed only on minor points, pending instructions from Berlin.

MR. WEYER'S conclusion, after the extensive study whose results are presented in this sturdy volume, is that "the Eskimo is a cultural success." It is a challenging statement and whets the interest of the reader in the investigations which led him by so many converging paths to this conviction.

That Very Young America will continue to take education in unobtrusive doses amid a routine of cod liver oil, orange juice, block-building and practice in social living with his peers, and will do so in increasing numbers in nursery schools and kindergartens, appears never more certain than today.

Nightly steamship service on the Hudson River will be resumed this week, the McAllister Navigation Company operating the boats of the Hudson River Navigation Company starting tomorrow, and the Hudson River Steamboat Company listing its first sailing Tuesday.

PLANS have been approved by the French Minister of Air, Pierre Cot, for the construction of a new central station which will make Le Bourget Airport one of the most modern and attractive in Europe. The total expenditure will be 14,000,000 francs.

Replying to charges made by independent taxicab groups on Friday at a hearing before a committee of the Board of Aldermen, the Parmelee System, Inc., the largest single operating unit in the city, denied yesterday that it sought a monopoly of the taxicab business.

Troy had a Palladium. Diomedes and Ulysses stole it. We know what happened to Troy. Boston had a Palladium, the Sacred Cod. It is or was a pine codfish, four feet eleven and a half inches long, ten inches thick at its thickest, clad in silver. It was a work of the eighteenth century.

THAT happy hunting ground of sea novelists, the islands and waters directly north of Eastern Australia, is here used again with graphic effectiveness as the setting for a first-rate adventure tale. The complicated relations of the chief characters antedate the opening of the story some twenty years, but these earlier bonds are still sufficiently active to draw within their colls a young newcomer, through whose eyes, largely as spectator, the subsequent drama transpires.

ROME, April 28. -- The difference in the methods of newspapers in Italy and those in other European countries in handling international affairs is strikingly brought out by the departure of the Italian delegation to represent Premier Mussolini in the economic conversations at Washington.

CAMDEN, N.J., April 29. -- With about 300 guests aboard, the new United States liner Washington left the plant of the New York Shipbuilding Company here at daybreak and proceeded down the Delaware River on her final test run to New York before being turned over to her owners.

WHEN Technocracy was all the rage, and the dread phrase, "technological unemployment" was stalking through the headlines, the comfort-bringers among our critics and economists made an appeal to history.

HEMPSTEAD, L.I., April 29. -- The mirrored walls of the old Belmont Manor near here, within which the late Mrs. O.H.P. Belmont waged her fight for woman suffrage early in this century, looked down today upon the strangest sight in their fifty years of history.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In a recent radio talk George Gordon Battle stated that more than one hundred bills pertaining to education had been introduced in New York State legislative bodies during the session just ended. This is a record among records, and the depression is, of course, responsible It is blamed for everything.

ATLANTA, Ga., April 29. -- Officials of the Department of Education here admitted today that the public school system of the State would have collapsed long ago were it not for the loyalty and patience of the 20,000 teachers, many of whom have not been paid for months.

A plea for international understanding and mutual concessions to avert disaster was made yesterday by Dean Virginia C. Gildersleeve of Barnard College and by Parker T. Moon, professor of international relations at Columbia University, at a luncheon of the Barnard College Club at the Women's University Club, 106 East Fifty-second Street.

CRUISE ships lay in Havana Harbor under the antiquated guns of Morro Castle, which dates back to the days of Sir Francis Drake and the pirates of the Spanish Main. Tourists, going ashore, strolled through the narrow, crooked streets of the old city and the broad, straight avenues and promenades of the new city.
With the Spring horse-show season well under way, enthusiasts are offered a choice of events this week -- the four-day Philadelphia Horse Show and the ninth annual New Haven Horse Show.
