The Civilian Conservation Corps, made up of unemployed young men who are now about to improve our national and State forests, might be said to have had its genesis on President Roosevelt's estate at Hyde Park. There, for eighteen years, Mr. Roosevelt has been putting into practice the forestry ideas of which the corps was an outgrowth.

When Jo Ann and her father moved into their new house, Jo Ann, who preferred boys to girls as playmates, decided to make the acquaintance of her new neighbor. Tommy Bassick and help him organize the boys of the neighborhood into a tribe of Mohawk Indians.

A CHAPEL without an altar, without a pulpit, with no sectarian symbol, yet an edifice that must bring a religious note to the minds of 1,700 boys, ranging in age from 6 to 18 -- this was the problem that faced the architects who competed for the building of the new Girard College Chapel, recently dedicated in Philadelphia.

MADISON, Wis., April 27. -- Just to look at John O'Malley, Democratic Assemblyman, one would never suspect him of doing or saying anything that would throw this State into an uproar. He is a ruddy-faced citizen, a good story-teller and a man who enjoys his corncob pipe.

Unusual purchasing activity developed during the week, with more buyers visiting the market than was anticipated, according to the market report prepared especially for THE TIMES by McGreevey, Werring Howell, Inc. While their major purpose was to secure merchandise for special May promotions, they also placed substantial orders on staple merchandise at prevailing prices, with an eye toward Fall needs.

Competitive designs in painting and sculpture, submitted by artists seeking fellowships offered by the American Academy in Rome, will be placed on public exhibition on Tuesday at the Grand Central Art Galleries. This work will remain on view until May 6.
BRYN MAWR, Pa., April 29. -- President Park has announced the honor lists at Bryn Mawr College, the students having maintained a "cum laude" rating in their academic work. Among those listed are:

Public housing on a large scale, managed without profit and exempt from taxation, is the only way to serve families whose income is less than $1,500, according to a statement issued yesterday by Mrs. Julius C. Bernheim, chairman of the executive board of the League of Mothers Clubs, 70 Fifth, Avenue.

Edgar T. Appleby of the United States forged to the front in the world's amateur 18.1 balkline billiard championship tournament last night at the Brooklyn Elks Clubhouse when he defeated Jean Albert of France, 300-268, in forty-eight innings.

Count Vasco da Gama, hunter of African big game, who practiced stalking and marksmanship with deadly effect in the lobby of a Riverside Drive apartment recently, was sentenced to thirty days in the workhouse yesterday for unjustifiably killing an animal.

CHICAGO, April 29 (AP). -- Mat stars from Southwestern State Teachers College at Weatherford, Okla., were outstanding tonight in the finals of the national amateur wrestling championship tournament. The Weatherford representatives captured two of the eight titles, the only team to gain more than one victory in the finals.

THE Appleton "Old City Fiction Series" of four-volume sets, which was inaugurated with Edith Wharton's "Old New York." imposes an arbitrary formula upon an author and thus, in fiction, sets a bad precedent. But the subjects, the great American cities, are so broad that the objection here is probably only theoretical.

THE manner and method of Vicki Baum's writing need small introduction, particular ly to the American public, which has expressed so wide and subs tan tial an approval of the novel, the stage play and the motion picture "Grand Hotel."

The Very Rev. Theophile Wuecher, pastor of the French Catholic Church of St. Vincent de Paul, West Twenty-third Street, between Sixth and Seventh Avenues, who will observe today the golden jubilee of his ordination, received a cablegram yesterday from Vatican City containing a special blessing from Pope Pius XI.

JED HARRIS, who has been sitting this season, is laying vast plans for the Fall. He's going to Europe soon, perhaps this week, to (a) see "The Lake" and "The Green Bay Tree" and (b) confer with Keith Winter about a new one called "The Ringmaster."

Scoring all Its runs in the seventh nining. James Monroe High School's baseball team defeated Morris, 5 to 4, yesterday at Monroe Field to take the lead in the Upper Manhattan-Bronx division of the city P.S.A.L. senior high school championship competition.

James Castello, George Washington High School foilsman, a son of the N.Y.U. fencing coach, captured the P.S.A.L. individual fencing championship last night at Stuyvesant High School, where he dethroned his brother, Hugo, holder of the crown for the past two years.

One prevailing departure is that he has not fallen into step with certain historians of the same period whose work is encyclopedic, at times merely chronologic -- such is the plethora of events and persons seeking interpretations and adjustments in relationship.

The marriage of Miss Margaret Brewster Taylor, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph B. Taylor of the Plaza and Allendale, N.J., to Robert Eugene Kohler, son of the former Governor of Wisconsin and Mrs. "Walter J. Kohler of Kohler, Wis., took place yesterday afternoon in the main ballroom of the Plaza.

WEST POINT, N.Y., April 29. -- Johns Hopkins marched another step nearer another intercollegiate lacrosse championship by defeating Army today, 6 to 2. The Cadets, overpowered in the first half, battled the visitors on even terms in the second half.

DETROIT. THE current introduction of a car in which the gear-shift lever is eliminated has revived a problem that car designers have been trying to solve for many years. Engineers have been trying for two decades to find a satisfactory automatic substitute for the hand-operated, three-stage method by which the speed of modern cars is varied to meet road and traffic requirements.

J.H. Wantling won the trepshooting championship of the New York Athletic Club yesterday by breaking 190 out of a possible 200 targets By taking the title, Wantling repeated his victory of 1928, when he won with a card of 189. Last year G.C. Walsh took the title, breaking 185 targets.

At the direction of Police Commissioner Bolan, the department's vice control regulations reverted yesterday to the old system, which former Commissioner Mulrooney changred after revelations of abuses by Samuel Seabury in his investigation of conditions in the magistrates' courts.

GREEK art and culture." Mr. Hafen quotes approvingly from Chauncey Thomas, "did not affect the Roman more than the Indian has affected the American, and in due time history will so record the fact." The statement is a bit startling.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., April 29. -- Scientific economic reorganization of American industry, business and finance was approved today by the Troy Conference of the Methodist Episcopal Church in accepting a report by the Rev. Leon W. Adkins of Delmar, chairman of its State of the Nation Committee.
The Roosevelts have whole fleets of ship pictures, lovely old American prints which the President has been collecting for years, and a good many of which have been taken along to the White House.

The text of two monographs prepared by the Aeronautical Chamber of Commerce of America and presented by it to the House Committee on Postoffice and Post Roads, analyzing the cost and utility of the air mail as compared with other classes of mail service, was made public here yesterday.

MISS PEYSER describes her little book as a "pre-primer" in which she has left out "nearly everything the trained musician thinks important." Her sole purpose is to help to open the understanding and appreciation of music by those who know nothing about it.

WASHINGTON, April 29. -- Business activity continued to advance slowly throughout the country during the week ended on April 22, although financial developments dominated the economic stage, according to the weekly survey of domestic business conditions made public today by the Commerce Department.

THERE are striking excellence and an equal degree of weakness in this unusual first novel about contemporary Harvard. Mr. Weller was graduated in 1929; it is under-standable that he has not yet found himself completely as a novelist. He seems to have built his apprenticeship too literally upon Stevenson's plan of playing "the sedulous ape" toward the writings of others.

LEMARS, Iowa, April 29 (AP). -- Ten Northwest Iowa farmers were under military arrest tonight, facing prosecution, possibly on charges of criminal syndicalism, for alleged participation in farm riots which brought the National Guard and martial law to Plymouth and Crawford Counties.
TIENTSIN, March 31. -- The Japanese are now considering making Jehol Province into the principal Summer resort for the east coast of Asia, and have ambitious plans under way.

CASTROVILLARI, Italy, April 29 (AP). -- The three survivors, two men and a woman, and the bodies of five others killed in the crash of a French Air-Orient plane on Mount Scifarelli last Sunday arrived here today after a four-mile trek down the mountainside on stretchers and a trip by automobile.

DALLAS, April 27. -- A large and an important part of the population of Texas is thoroughly disgusted with the Lone Star State. It wants to know why, when liberalism is the order of the day and when the rest of the country is riding high on the early waves of legal beer, Texas should remain fast in the clutches of the bluenoses.

LONDON, April 29. -- The mishap to Colonel and Mrs. Charles A. Lindbergh when their plane capsized in the Yangtse River in October, 1931, is recalled by a ruling by the British Admiralty that the payment by THE NEW YORK TIMES for exclusive photographs of the incident must go to the British sailors who took the pictures and not for the Shanghai Hospital or some other naval charity, as originally contemplated.

MOSCOW. MOSCOW, like Paris, Berlin and New York, has its Bohemia. Three gay young men paint an their pictures in collaboration. They sign themselves "Kukerniks," which is a combination of their three names, Kuprin, Kerlow and Niko Sokoloff.

DES MOINES, Ia., April 29. -- Two smashing performances by Ralph Metcalfe, national collegiate sprint champion, featured the finals of the twenty-fourth annual Drake relay carnival today, in which seven records were broken.

Favorite costumes of bygone eras, complete in every detail, as well as those of today, will be worn by women of society in the fashion showing for the benefit of the Emergency Exchange Association, which will be held on Tuesday afternoon at the home of Mrs. Payne Whitney, 972 Fifth Avenue.

The story of Shakespeare's life is far from complete and undisputed 369 years after his birth. New facts are adduced from time to time which alter our picture of the man. In the article that follows one of the leading Shakespearean authorities attempts a portrait in the light of what scholars have found in two centuries of searching and especially in the light of recent discoveries.
LONDON, April 29. -- The greatest international conference since Versailles, the World Economic and Monetary Conference, will be opened by King George in London on June 12.

HAVANA, April 29. -- Surprising San Luis, in Oriente Province, a force of rebels attacked the army garrison, made prisoners of the two officers and 150 men and raised the revolutionary emblem -- a red, white and green striped flag -- on the staff of the City Hall.

Lentini, the three-legged man at the Ringling Brothers and Barnum Bailey Circus, was extremely busy yesterday arranging quarters for a new pet that has come to Madison Square Garden. The new arrival is Lucia, the six-legged sheep of Westchester County, mild and woolly, as sheep generally are.

MIAMI, Fla., April 29. -- Hundreds of Cuban refugees gathered here in exile camps had no news tonight of the rebellion in Oriente Province. Octavio Siegle, in charge of Camp No. 1, said he regarded the fighting reported at three towns north of Santiago as merely a spasmodic outbreak.
Navy's varsity crew came through hard-fought race on the Harlem River yesterday, winner over Columbia by about a length and a quarter in a cleanly rowed mlle-and-a-half test.

CHICAGO, April 28. THE stage of the Second City has begun to shake off its sleeping sickness and to show signs of the long-awaited recovery. It is still in the early phase of convalescence, for, like Lazarus arisen from the dead, it suffers from the psychosis of mortality, and frightful memories of old bones and the graveyard oppress its spirit.

BOSTON, April 27. -- The Supreme Judicial Court of Massachusetts early last week removed every legal obstacle to the imposition of any reasonable retail sales tax the Legislature may see fit to establish. The Governor at the end of the week sent a special message to the Legislature, asking for the creation of a sales tax.

CHEYENNE, Wyo., April 27. -- Wyoming ranchers and farmers welcomed this week a new moratorium on mortgages, not planned for or arranged in Washington. It was a terrific snowstorm which swept the State, leaving tons of snow and water to be absorbed by the parched range.

WASHINGTON, April 29. -- President Roosevelt, in one of the three remaining messages he will send to Congress soon, will ask for specific authority during the recess of Congress to deal individually with debtor nations with the idea of reducing war debts.

CLEVELAND, April 29. -- Big Wesley Ferrell made a successful season debut for the home fans today, winning from the White Sox ace, Ted Lyons, 4 to 1, and sending the Indians into a triple tie for second place in the American League standings with the White Sox and Senators.

THE program of the Florentine Musical May, according to the complete announcement which arrived here recently, indicates that the festival will consist of many events of wide interest. The festival will take up more than the month of May; it was scheduled to begin last week and will continue to June 5.

THE influence of the machine on poetical literature has been discussed pro and con for a long time now, but we have yet to find a clear, rational and convincing exposition of it. Argumentation, loud propaganda, shrill acceptance and shriller refusal have obscured the actual objective.

IN a wrangling world filled with contestants for opposing ideas. each one insisting that his own "ism" shall be accepted to the last degree, President Lowell's calm and reasonable little book corned like the voice of one saying, "Peace, be still, and take your bearings."

A STRANGE and inconsistent dualism is noted in the trend of today. Along with onsweeping modernism is a looking backward, a nostalgia, for a bygone age and of all periods -- to make the contrast as challenging as may be -- it is the Victorian Age toward which longing eyes are more and more directed.

Two of the major building enterprises of the past year in Manhattan -- the seventy-story RCA Building in Rockefeller Center and the twenty-five-story edifice of the Insurance Company of North America at 99 John Street-will receive their first tenants tomorrow.

Manuel L. Quezon, President of the Philippine Senate, who arrived a week ago with ten delegates to discuss the Hayes-Cutting independence bill for the islands passed last January by Congress over the veto of President Hoover, sailed yesterday for Manila via Paris on the Ile de France.

BUENOS AIRES, April 29. -- Argentina's exchange restrictions are proving greater obstacles than United States tariffs in preventing this country's producers from profiting from heavy buying orders from the United States. Bankers estimate that 20,000,000 pesos -- about $5,000,000 -- in American orders for hides, wool and other products could not be accepted this week because the exporters could not sell their dollar drafts.

HOW to Break 90," the new series of Bobby Jones golf pictures produced by Warner Brothers, will be seen in its first instalment at the Strand soon on the same program with the Richard Barthelmess film "Central Airport."

A PROPOSAL that the Pulitzer awards be extended to permit an annual prize for the beat American motion picture of the year has been made by Albert Warner, vice president of Warner Brothers, in a letter to Carl W. Ackerman, dean of the Columbia School of Journalism.

THIS little book, written with a thorough knowledge of all the sources on the subject, is a model of compression without neglect of any essential, of selection, good judgment and good taste. It is worthy or being dedicated, as it is to Professor George M. Trevelyan, for while compact of information it is highly readable.

LONDON. A "MICRO-RAY" equipment giving radio communication on the shortest wave length employed at any radio station in the world has been ordered by the British Air Ministry for use in connection with cross-Channel flying services.
NANKING, March 10. -- The Chinese Government, among its sundry troubles, is now in another predicament resulting from Western onslaughts. It cannot exercise suzerainty over its own air.

Joseph T. Ross. oldest passenger conductor of the Central Railroad of New Jersey, boarded the Blue Comet at the Jersey City Terminal yesterday and pulled the cord for his last trip as a conductor to and from Atlantic City. When the train reached Jersey City on the return trip last night, Mr. Ross went to his home at 872 Lyons Avenue, Irvington, N.J., to spend the remainder of his life in retirement.

There has been an encouraging subscription for the performances of "The Yeomen of the Guard," by Gilbert and Sullivan, to be given by members of the Bluehill Troupe on Thursday and Friday nights at the Heckscher Theatre for the benefit of the Stuyvesant Square Hospital, formerly the New York Skin and Cancer Hospital.

THE NEW YORK TIMES weekly business index continued the upward trend started late in March and rose four-tenths of a point to 54.2 for the week ended April 22. The figure for the previous week was 53.8 and for the corresponding week last year 58.5.

Reduction of the gold content of the dollar, for which provision was made In the Thomas amendment to the farm relief bill, passed by the Senate on Friday, would create serious financial complications and might fail to achieve the desired end of raising prices, according to Wall Street bankers.

The honor of the Gwing family, never before challenged, provoked a two-man hatchet-and-all tong war that threw hundreds of shoppers on busy Union Street, Flushing, Queens, into a panic last night that was quieted only when the police caught up with the two Chinese belligerents in a seeming marathon and arrested them.

WASHINGTON, April 29. -- Final approval of a $3,000,000 loan, to the New York Bridge Authority of Claverack to contstruct a highway toll bridge across the Hudson connecting the towns of Hudson and Catskill was voted today by the Reconstruction Finance Corporation.

ALBANY, April 29. -- The new 1 per cent retail sales tax, taking effect Monday, will cost the average family not more than $7.50 a year, according to Mark Graves, president of the State Tax Board, speaking over the radio tonight.
PARIS, April 22. -- Since the assassination of President Doumer the control of the French Government over foreigners resident in France has been more rigorous than at any time since the war.

WASHINGTON, April 29 (AP). -- Dean Carl W. Ackerman of the Columbia University School of Journalism, in addressing the Society of Newspaper Editors, declared today that George Bernard Shaw uttered a "deliberate lie" regarding the press on his recent visit to this country.

LOS ANGELES, April 27. -- Los Angeles faces a primary election next Tuesday. There are 184 candidates for thirty-four jobs ranging from the Mayor down. Only the candidates are excited, voters maintaining an austere pose of detached interest.

The problem which Professor Brierly is asked to solve in this story is a strange one. The members of a tontine insurance group are dying off so rapidly that the survivors have become seriously alarmed. Some of the deaths have been reported as suicides, others as accidental.

WITH the United States legalizing beer there is strange news from Great Britain. So drastic is the decrease in the consumption of alcholic liquors of every kind that -- for the moment, at any rate -- the country might almost be described as going dry.

The new Hall of Ocean Life in the American Museum of Natural History, the largest of its kind in the world, which will house the collections of a number of noted expeditions to the seven seas by famous explorers during the last thirty years, will be officially opened to the public on Wednesday, it was announced yesterday by F. Trubee Davison, president of the museum.

ANOTHER presentation of the Wagner saga prompted by the fiftieth anniversary of his death comes in this book. For the author of the story of Richard Wagner is summed up in the three parts of his book, entitled, respectively, ''Minna," "Mathilde'' and "Cosima."

To the Dramatic Editor: Among the walls that are constantly being sent up concerning the debacle of the theatre, may a visitor from the provinces raise a note of optimism T On a recent visit I saw, among others, three plays which seem to me to rise above the usual standard of drama and encourage those who, like myself, have a special interest in American play writing.

Portraits of children of well-known New York families, as well as those of famous stars of the stage and prominent members of society as children, will be shown for the benefit of the Children's Welfare Federation at an exhibition opening tomorrow at the Reinhardt Galleries, 730 Fifth Avenue, and continuing until May 13.

CHAUNCEY BREWSTER TINKER once remarked that people who behave with undue familiarity seem to think that we all knew each other in some previous existence and on a considerably lower plane. There is a suggestion of that manner in Thorne Smith's novels.

Today is being observed throughout the nation as a day of prayer for President Roosevelt, and many pastors will devote their sermons to lessons to be drawn from his life. The day also is the anniversary of the inauguration of George Washington as President.

DANZIG, April 29. -- The Free City of Danzig is now engaged in a lively electoral campaign. The present Nationalist Senate yielded to pressure of the ever-growing Nazi forces and dissolved the Landtag. The Hitlerities hope to sweep Danzig on May 28 as they swept the Reich.

LONDON, April 28. -- Needless to say, the chief International interest in Great Britain at present is in the results of the Roosevelt-MacDonald talks in Washington and the World Economic Conference, the calling of which those conversations no doubt hastened.
PHILADELPHIA, April 29 (AP). -- The Athletics swept the two-game series with the Red Sox today in winning the final encounter of their home stand, 8 to 3.

BRESLAU, Silesia, April 29. -- One hundred and twenty years ago this ancient city became the birthplace of Prussia's war for liberation against Napoleon. This year, 1933, it became the birthplace of what the National Socialists call the war for liberation from the rule of Jews and Marxists -- a war which they have been conducting with imprisonment, floggings, social defamation and economic strangulation until the entire world is again up in arms against Germany.

LAST week the National Academy, together with various other scientific bodies, met in Washington, and once more we were able to take stock of recent advances in science. No startling disclosures were made. Indeed, much of what was revealed had already been discussed in scientific journals.

Brown -- Clive. Miss Rita Renee Clive, daughter of Arthur H. Clive of New York, formerly of St. Louis, Mo., and the late Mrs. Clive, was married to James Throckmorton Brown of Montclair, N.J., yesterday afternoon In the Church of the Transfiguration.

CHICAGO, April 27. -- Illinois is not yet certain whether its sales tax, which became operative April 1, is to continue in effect, or whether the Supreme Court of Illinois will decide that those who are paying it daily on purchases ranging from a dime upward have a valid claim for its return by the collecting merchants.

The Columbia tennis team won its fourth consecutive match of the sea-son yesterday when it defeated Fordham, 8 -- 1, on the South Field courts. The undefeated Columbians have vanquished all metropolitan rivals this year -- City College, St. John's, N.Y.U. and Fordham.

One reason given for the break-down of the old Czarist Government in Russia was that the centralization of everything at the capital was more than the official brain could endure. A similar cerebral danger is noted by experienced observers at Washington. They have never seen anything like the problem piled upon problem, excitement upon excitement, since the 4th of March.
TOKYO. WHAT is the attitude of the Japanese people toward the United States? What do they think of America, and what do they fear from her?

About 500 artists were represented at the opening yesterday of the third Washington Square outdoor art exhibition, which began at 10 A.M. and lasted until sundown. It was estimated that about 20,000 persons viewed the various exhibits. Sales amounted to $159.
WASHINGTON. April 29. -- The War Department issued the following orders today:

In accord with a custom that hag become Increasingly popular In recent years, several members of society with country places on line North Shore of Long Island open their estates to the publican the interests of various philenthropic organizations.

PANAMA, R.P., April 24. -- A decree regulating the flying of flags in the republic of Panama has been issued by Colonel Juan Antonio Jimenez, Secretary of Government and Justice. Recently Governor Alejandro Cervera of Colon Province ordered the lowering of an American flag which was flying from a staff in front of a school in New Cristobal, a section of Colon occupied by American employes of the Panama Canal.

CHICAGO, April 29 (AP). -- The New York Optimists, led by Winston Guest, retained their National Open Indoor Polo championship tonight when they decisively defeated the Sixth Corps Area team, Fort Sheridan, Ill., 8 1/2 to 4 1/2. The winners also hold the Class A title.

City employes will be asked to contribute to the Salvation Army united appeal, undertaken to raise $1,100,000 for the emergency and institutional activities of the organization in a general campaign conducted by thirty-three department heads, who have agreed to serve as divisional chairmen of the drive, it was announced yesterday.
LONDON, April 29. -- Everton today defeated Manchester City, 3 -- 0, in the final of the English Soccer Cup, blue-ribbon event of the season.

A demand for the establishment of a permanent policy governing the treatment of war veterans by the Federal Government was made last night by Louis A. Johnson, national commander of the American Legion. He spoke at a dinner given in his honor by the New York State Department at the Hotel Biltmore.

UNTIL, a few years back, when the "Lysistrata" was seen on the American stage in an adapted English rendering, all of Aristophanes anywise current -- except among scholars, that is -- was confined to the words of the Yale College yell, taken from a chorus in the comedy, "The Frogs":

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., April 29. -- Following Tiger victories in the freshman and junior varsity races, Princeton's varsity crew gained a decisive triumph in the regatta with Harvard and M.I.T. over the Charles River course today.

A COMMON delusion unrestrainedly enjoyed by many of those who sit rapt in the audience at the premiere of a large musical show is that they are witnessing the pristine and consequently the purest performance of the production that will ever move across the hoards.

Sixteen yachts have been entared in the Gibson Island ocean race, and owners of forty-five others have requested entry blanks with the expressed intention of entering, leading the committee to belleve that between forty and fifty craft will compete in the event.

WASHINGTON, April 29. -- Administration leaders in the House of Representatives decided today to take advantage of every parliamentary rule to bring about prompt concurrence in the Senate inflatio amendment to the farm relief bill.

A a time like this -- what with inflation and the dollar's going off gold and sundry other issues of climactic importance -- one is prone to suppose that nobody could get very much perturbed about art matters. Nothing more has been heard from Detroit about the threatened whitewashing of Rivera's frescoes, for you can't hope to maintain that sort of excitement at white heat against so much daily competition in the economic news headlines.

BERLIN, April 29. -- The Hitler government made a bid for popularity with Germany's vast army of workers today by granting a May Day amnesty to thousands of Socialist and other political opponents imprisoned since the national revolution.
Stocks and commodities soared yesterday to the highest levels since last September on the overnight news that the inflation bill had been passed by the Senate.

More than 250 student representatives and their faculty advisers attended the second annual sportsmanship conference for secondary schools of New York State at New York University yesterday. The event, sponsored by the N.Y.U. Student Senate and the Sportsmanship Brotherhood, was held in three sessions, with "Sportsmanship Standards" as the general theme.

LONDON, April 12. -- The German Government's attitude to the National Socialist crusade against the Jews has been officially explained by Dr. Paul Joseph Goebbels, Minister of Propaganda and Popular Enlightenment, to Sir Evelyn Wrench, the British chairman of the All Peoples Association, who has just returned from a lecture tour taking in Denmark, Holland and Germany.
Despite eight errors, and in the face of nine strike-outs registered by the opposing pitcher, Fordham's baseball team scored an 8-to-6 triumph over Villanova at Fordham Field yesterday.

Negro colleges in the South, once of doubtful academic standing, today in several instances rank alongside the better colleges for whites. So Chancellor Kirkland of Vanderbilt University told guests at a dinner in behalf of Fisk University held in New York last week.

PARIS. ALTHOUGH the Paris season does not begin officially until after Easter, the many events of early Spring, such as the horse show, the reopening of the Sunday racing at Longchamps, the six-day bicycle race and other similar affairs -- which unite all the well-known personalities of sport and fashion -- offer a sort of preview of the special social and stylistic atmosphere the season will acquire as it progresses.

PHILADELPHIA, April 29. -- The University of Pennsylvania one-mile relay team proved today that it could manage very well without the services of mighty Bill Carr. As its injured Olympic champion sat propped in pillows at a window at one end of Franklin Field, a Quaker quartet fled over the black cinders in the second fastest race in the annals of the Penn relay carnival.
WASHINGTON, April 29. -- The Bureau of Navigation issued the following orders today, dated April 27:

IN "Cowboy Holiday" we find again the four young people of "A Mile of Freedom." This new volume is complete in itself, however, and is a better story than the first one. It describes a Slimmer spent on a ranch in Arizona.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., April 29 -- W. R. Coe's Osculator, a stablemate of the Kentucky Derby favorite, Ladysman, scored an easy victory in the $5,000 Clark Handicap as the Churchill Downs Spring meeting opened today.

MOHANDAS KARAMCHAND GANDHI, committed, without trial, to Yeravada Central jail. Poona, on Jan. 4, 1932 is still there. Asked in the early part of February of this year, whether he would abandon civil disobedience if released, he is reported to have replied with an emphatic negative.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., April 29. -- Ray White pitched Columbia University to another shut-out victory today, blanking Harvard, 7 to 0, with an allowance of five scattered singles. White has now allowed only one run in 33 innings for the team coached by Andy Coakley.

WASHINGTON, April 29. -- A fewshort hours stand between gold hoarders and possible prosecution for violation of the President's executive order requiring gold to be returned to the Federal Reserve Banks on or before May 1.

MOSCOW, April 29. -- A decree signed by Premier Molotoff and published in all papers today extends the range of the passport system to include a sixty-mile belt along the whole length of the western frontier, as well as Kiev, Odessa, Minsk, Rostov, Stalingrad, Stalinsk, Baku, Nijninovgorod and many other industrial centres, such as eliabinsk and important cities in the Far East, such as Vladivostok and Khabarovsk.
LOS ANGELES, April 29 (AP). -- Suit to divorce Douglas Fairbanks Jr., movie actor, was filed today by Joan Crawford, also of the screen, who charged "grievous mental cruelty."

GDYNIA, Poland, April 28. -- Driving along the western border of the Polish corridor one comes, north of Chojnice, to within a few inches of German territory. The road is Polish but on the western edge milestones with Pe for Poland and De for Deutschland mark the boundary.

BALTIMORE, April 29. -- Before a cheering crowd of 25,000, Captain Kettle, 9-year-old jumper from the stables of Charles S. Cheston of Philadelphia, captured the historic Maryland Hunt Cup in picturesque Worthington Valley today.
To the Editor of The New York Times: It seems surprising that Dr. George W. Crile's paper should not alone be given such space but such emphasis.

TIENTSIN, April 29. -- North China is under a condition of practical dissolution of any central authority, with great bodies of "Grays" showing a marked disposition to fraternize with the Manchukuo and Japanese forces, while Nanking's own armies near the Great Wall are drawing upon themselves the major Japanese attack.

HOLLYWOOD. PURIFICATION of the screen, which has been promised for three years, became imminent when Will H. Hays, president of the Motion Picture Producers and Distributors of America, banned one film from theatres and threatened to forbid the exhibition of others that violate either in spirit or fact the so-called "Hays code."

MRS. OWEN Is a diligent romantic who loves to carve humanity up, however delicately, and bring to light the untold oddities she is convinced are hidden deep within each one of us. She is an excellent and zestful gossip who manages to amuse us constantly with her dry humor and her tart characterizations.

BERLIN. THE violent upheavals that shake Germany today may well be called the revolt of youth. And the struggle for power was naturally preceded by writings in which both older and younger representatives of our youth strove to attain clarity in their own minds concerning the development of their nation.

OTTAWA, April 27. -- Probably there are millions of Canadians who are not sure whether the Dominion is on or off the gold standard, and the question has been solemnly debated in high places on occasion. Actually there has been no free movement of gold here since immediately after Great Britain went off gold more than eighteen months ago and the Canadian Government prohibited its export except under license.

HENRY HADLEY will conduct the last concert but one to be given by the Musicians Symphony Orchestra Tuesday evening. The soloists on this occasion are Henri Deering, pianist, and John Charles Thomas, haritone, who was recently engaged by the Metropolitan Opera Company for next season.

WASHINGTON, April 29. -- Uncertainty over the question whether the capital would again become a destination for veterans demanding payment of a bonus was increased today when Harold B. Foulkrod, self-styled legislative agent of the "Bonus Expeditionary Force rank and file," issued a call for a inarch by 50,000 veterans.

LONDON. AFTER rushing around from Lossiemouth to London. Paria, Geneva and Rome, Ramsay MacDonald rushes off to Washington. This recalls the fact that he was one of the first statesmen in Europe to join the Order of the International Suitcase.

Proud of Westchester County's tax record and with a view to discredit statements that the county's taxes are excessive, the county governmental committee of the Westchester County Real Estate Board has issued a statement to taxpayers showing that from 1926 to date the county tax rate has decreased from 578 to 347.

Yesterday was Fossil Day. For the thirtieth time the business men, editors and publishers, who, proud of their part in the flourishing days of American amateur boy journalism a half century ago, have banded together under the name of Fossils, met for their annual reunion and dinner, held this year at the Hotel Astor.

ASSOCIATED wtth Maurice Chevalier in "A Bedtime Story" at the Rivoli is Edward Everett Horton, who was torn in Brooklyn. He went to Columbia University and after appearing in the class play, "In Newport," decided to become an actor.
The Yankees staged a thrilling finish at the Stadium yesterday, but to no avail. They lost their second straight game to the Senators, 6 to 3, to the utter conster-nation of a crowd of 36,000.

BERLIN, April 8. MAX REINHARDT'S real name is Goldmann and he is of Jewish extraction. At the suggestion of the Hitler government his connection with the Deutsches Theater has been severed. Not a single Berlin paper commented on this And a comment is hardly necessary; the facts are sufficient.

IN an article which appeared in THE NEW YORK TIMES last Wednesday, G.B. Stern, the English novelist, was interviewed on her impressions of Hollywood. Miss Stern writes to THE TIMES to correct any "wrong impression of ingratitude" that the interview might have conveyed.

An automobile traveling at the rate of sixty miles an hour covers, approximately, ninety feet a second. Traveling at forty miles an hour it covers sixty feet a second. In an emergency, therefore, at either speed, a driver has only a split second to decide what to do, and then do it.

FORMER Mayor of New York, and Professor Emeritus of Economic History at Princeton University, Dr. McClellan should be felicitated on several points for his brief record of the last 118 years of Italian history. One prevailing departure is that he has not fallen into step with certain historians of the same period whose work is encyclopedic, at times merely chronologic -- such is the plethora of events and persons seeking interpretations and adjustments in relationship.

ONE of the celebrated institution at the Yale University Library is the unrivaled Goethe collection formed by the late William A. Speck. Donated to Tale by Mr. Speck in 1913, it grew under his curatorship until at the time of his death in 1928 it had attained world renown as a shrine for students of German literature.

A NEW man sits in the chair occupied for so many years by Rear Admiral William A. Moffett, beloved chief of the Bureau of Aeronautics, who lost his life in the crash of the Akron. He is faced with many problems. Not the least of them is to keep the flying navy, in the face of drastic economies, as progressively efficient as it had grown to be under Rear Admiral Moffett.
Heavy Tourist Rush. Mr. MACDONALD has come and gone. M. HBRRIOT has come and gone. The Canadian Prime Minister has come and gone. Among other things at Washington they discussed war debts.

The George F. Driscoll Company has been awarded the A.E. Davidson Safety Trophy and $200 by the committee on accident prevention of the Building Trades Employers Association for the lowest accident severity rate among the contestants for their 1932 construction operations.

RICHMOND, April 27. -- Action of United States District Judge James A. Lowell of Boston in thwarting the efforts of Virginia and Massa-chusetts to bring to trial a Negro suspected of a double murder in the Old Dominion, has served to focus public attention once more on the fact that Negroes are seldom called for jury service below the Potomac.

HOW Reo's automatic transmission works was demonstrated -- and experienced -- in a drive in one of the new cars last week. There is no gear shift lever in the conventional sense, but the forward or backward movement of the car is controlled by moving a "selector" plunger on the dashboard.

With three Brooklyn men on the bases and two out in the ninth, 25,000 Flatbush fans filled the confines of Ebbets Field yesterday with lusty vocal pleas for Joe Stripp to hit. But their pleas were in vain.

ALTHOUGH the State Alcoholic Beverage Control Board does not begin to function officially until June1, its chairman is already on the job. Carpenters and painters are putting the finishing touches on new offices in Centre Street, but the noise of hammers and the odor of oil and turpentine have not prevented Edward P. Mulrooney from moving in.

Disabled veterans of the World War will benefit from the annual ball of the Old Canteen Club, which will take place on Thursday in the main ballroom of the Commodore. As in former seasons, the event has attracted the interest of many officers of the United States Army and Navy as well as prominent members of society.

LONDON, April 28. -- Honesty is the best policy, so it the writer were asked to report on the British viewpoint to Prime Minister Ramsay MacDonald's visit to Washington he would be obliged to reply that it is still indistinct.

WASHINGTON. IN formulating a program to bring prosperity back to the United States and start the world on an upward trend President Roosevelt has sought and obtained from Congress authority and responsibilities which a more timid man might hesitate to shoulder.

The Sherry-Netherland apartment hotel, erected on the site of the old Hotel Netherland at the northeast corner of Fifty-ninth Street and Fifth Avenue, was put into foreclo-sure yesterday in a suit filed in the Supreme Court by the Continental Bank and Trust Company as substituted trustee under a bond issue of May 15, 1928.

By making an issue of its controversy with the Allied Chemical and Dye Corporation, the New York Stock Exchange has taken an advanced step in its publicity policy. In effect it has served notice that listed companies must conform to the Exchange's ideas as to what constitutes a really informative financial statement.

CHICAGO, April 29. -- Another high point was reached today in the ten-year litigation resulting from an order of the Illinois Commerce Commission in 1923 that the Illinois Bell Telephone Company lower its rates for certain coin-box services.

The expansion of the American merchant fleet in the last fifteen years has been unduly blamed for the general upset of world shipping, according to Admiral Hutch I. Cone, newly appointed chairman of the United States Shipping Board. The arguments of American legislators opposing government aid to ship lines reflect this attitude, he said, and the shipping men of foreign nations, competing with American lines, have added their voices to the complaint.

More than 750 alumni, under-graduates, and prominent figures in the sport world attended the fifth annual Block F Dinner, conducted by the Fordham University Club in the grand ballroom of the Hotel Pennsylvania last night.

The fishing season in Canada will be inaugurated tomorrow when It will be legal to take speckled and brown trout In the Province of Ontario, salmon and speckled trout in Quebec, trout and landlocked salmon in New Brunswick, and trout in Prince Edward Island.

MOSCOW, April 29. -- On June 1 the Communist party will launch its "purging" campaign to complete the preliminary weeding-out process which started the first of the year. This campaign, orders issued by the party's central control committee made clear, will be pursued not only to get rid of hostile Communists but also to eliminate "unstable and undisciplined" members.

The trend of commodity prices during the past month and the prospect of inflation give evidence that the prices of homes now are at or near their lowest levels for the depression period, in the opinion of the home-building and home-owning committee of the United States Building and Loan League.

Easing of the strain caused by the suspension of banking facilities in March was reflected in April in lower rates for money here. Call-loan rates were well below those of March, dropping from 3 to 1 per cent after the first week, and time--loan rates, although highly irregular, also declined.

BROADCASTERS believe that in the Spring the listener's fancy turns to entertainment in a gayer mood. The swelling strains of the great symphonies no longrer fill the air, for the New York Philharmonic-Symphony, the Philadelphia Orchestra and the Boston Symphony have signed off for the season.
WORCESTER, Mass., April 29. -- The New York University took its third straight game from Holy Cross today before a crowd of 4,000, defeating the Crusaders 8 to 3.

THOSE Jacobites who hoped and planned and plotted to remove William of Orange from the English throne and restore "the King over the water" to his heritage have been somewhat neglected by novelists and romancers in favor of those of a slightly later period who risked life and fortune for Bonnie Prince Charlie.

Helen Vasko, 2-year-old daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Vasko of Hastings-on-Hudson. was progressing satisfactorily yesterday in her recovery from the operation on her eye last Tuesday at the Eye Institute of Columbia Presbyterian Medical Centre, it was said at that institution.

More than 750 alumni, under-graduates, and prominent figures in the sport world attended the fifth annual Block F Dinner, conducted by the Fordham University Club in the grand ballroom of the Hotel Pennsylvania last night.

NEW HAVEN, April 29. -- Steadier fielding in a game that was marked by hard hitting on both sides gave Yale a 7-to-6 victory today, tieing the annual series with Penn. A crowd of 1,200 saw the contest which was an Eastern Intercollegiate League game.

A BOOK of a strange sort appeared in 1908. It told of its author's experiences while confined for three years in hospitals for the mentally ill. It appealed for enlightened understanding of insanity, for humane and scientific treatment of the afflicted, and for timely prevention of the tragedies of break-downs.

"Principal and interest payable in United States gold coin of the present standard of weight and fineness" is the familiar gold clause contained in virtually all set-ups of foreign bonds issued in terms of American dollars, and of it much will be heard when foreign governments and corporations come to pay their interest due here tomorrow and on June 1.
BUDAPEST, March 26, 1933. A NEW Hungarian opera has been presented to the musical world of Budapest with great success. It is called "Orphan Joe the Fisherman."

THAT favorite figure of modern fiction and film drams the racketeer, again enjoy the spotlight as three mate rial witnesses against New York City's kosher poultry gang insist on sleeping in jail for their own protection in spite of efforts to bail them out which both themselves and their jailers describe as mysterious and sinister.

BROADCASTERS believe that in the Spring the listener's fancy turns to entertainment in a gayer mood. The swelling strains of the great symphonies no longrer fill the air, for the New York Philharmonic-Symphony, the Philadelphia Orchestra and the Boston Symphony have signed off for the season.
WORCESTER, Mass., April 29. -- The New York University took its third straight game from Holy Cross today before a crowd of 4,000, defeating the Crusaders 8 to 3.

Legislative uncertainty is hampering the development of a strong forward buying policy by retailers which might have been expected at this time, according to a survey made yesterday by THE TIMES. While staples are being bought more freely for a period of sixty to ninety days ahead, there is little indication of any broad buying movement as yet.

The Department of Commerce computes each year an estimated balance of international payments to and from the United States. This includes all of the commercial and financial transactions in which the American people are engaged, individually and collectively, with those of other nations.
Two sports, neither of which has been connected with college athletics in the past, are prospective additions to undergraduates' programs. Unofficial efforts are under way to organize both.

WASHINGTON, April 29. -- If you are in public life you know that every time your husband takes a new position his life and your life and the life of the family must be reorganized, for every such change carries with it a new set of duties.

An Important decision in favor of landlords has just been handed down by the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court which reverses the action of the Appellate Term and sustains a former order of the Municipal City Court which gave a judgment in favor of the landlord.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Not so long ago some one who had read my letter in THE TIMES challenged me to prove the principle of constant light velocity inconsistent with the principle of relativity, upon which two principles the special theory of relativity is erected.

WHAT lodgings are available in Tangier? How do you find a dentist in Rotterdam? What are the principal points of interest in Smyrna. Are there movies in Mombasa? Where are the laundries in Batevia? What water is it safe to drink in Madras?

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., April 29. -- Governor Lehman of Purchase has accepted the honorary chairmanship of the children's week committee drive of the Westchester County Children's Association and the Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Children, which will start on Monday and continue through May 8.
Harold C. Samuels, head of the realty brokerage firm bearing his name, calls attention to the dangers of excessive optimism regarding the effect of currency inflation on real estate.
SYRACUSE, N.Y., April 29. -- Scoring seven runs in the last two innings, Cornell defeated the Syracuse University nine by 8 to 4 today in the opening game of the Spring series at Hendricks Field.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., April 29. -- Syracuse won three of its four informal crew races with Cornell on Onondaga Lake today before 30,000 spectators. It was the first regatta between the colleges ever staged here and each race was rowed under perfect weather conditions.

RADIO music, while it wafts across the countryside on a front as broad as the winds, is not as free as the air in which It floats. Melody is the life-blood of broadcasting. And the broadcasters are aware that to keep a fresh show running a constant flow of new music is needed from a deep reservoir of song.

Police Commissioner Bolan has announced the routes to be taken by Communist and Socialist groups in their May Day parades. He expects the day to pass quietly, but will have all his men on reserve duty, ready if needed.

HAVANA, April 29. -- What is believed to be a general uprising in Oriente Province broke out this morning when a band of insurrectionists headed by Luis Trompeta attacked and captured the military post of San Luis, just outside Santiago de Cuba.

THE Washington conferences in preparation for the World Economic Conference, have focused attention on our widespread trade relations and especially on the fact that Europe, notably West and Middle Europe, is the best and most dependable customer of the United States.

The National Surety Company, one of the largest concerns of its kind in the United States, was taken over at noon yesterday for reorganization by George S. Van Schaick, State Superintendent of Insurance. Frozen assets of $32,000,000 were cited as the reason.
WASHINGTON, April 29. -- Movements of vessels follow. All dates are April 28, unless otherwise specified:

OMAHA, April 27. -- The new deal in Iowa is divided into two parts. Finis was written to the first part by adjournment of the Forty-fifth General Assembly last week. The second part is to be taken up at a special session to be convened in August.

Expenditures for unemployment relief from public funds rose to a new high in New York State during March, it was announced yesterday by the Temporary Emergency Relief Administration, of which Harry L. Hopkins is chairman.

PITTSBURGH, April 29 (AP). -- Heinie Meine topped off effectiveness in the pinches with a double to break a tie in the sixth today and the Pirates defeated the Cardinals, 6 to 4. It was the second straight triumph over the Red Birds.

EMPORIA, Kan., April 27. -- For the last three months several billion tons of soil have been doing a non-stop flight over far-Western Kansas and have caused disaster a hundred times more costly than the total value of the wreckage due to the Southern California earthquake.

OJAI, Cal., April 29 (AP). -- In the same tournament in which he started his phenomenal climb to international fame two years ago, Ellsworth Vines Jr., national tennis champion, inaugurated his 1933 campaign today by winning the Ojai Valley singles and doubles crowns.
WASHINGTON, April 29 (AP). -- The end of the second month of President Roosevelt's administration finds his emergency program of legislation far advanced, the status now being:

Al Jochim of the Swiss Turn Verein of Hudson County, a member of the American Olympic team last year, retained the metropolitan A.A.U. gymnastic all-around championship and three individual titles in the forty-third annual meet at the Twenty-third Street Y.M. C.A. last night.

WASHINGTON, April 29. -- Speaking on war debts tonight in a radio address over the Columbia system, Senator Borah, ranking Republican member of the Committee on Foreign Relations, said he was unable to find evidence of "the slightest willingness" on the part of European debtor nations to make any concessions or show any sympathy in the adjustment of economic problems.

There are five young Meades at Echo Hill, ranging from 8 to 15, and Joseph, an older half brother. The farm belongs to Joseph and it is his dream that it shall be made to pay and shall continue in the possession of the family. The younger children and their mother, however, are restless and discontented and would willingly exchange their country home for an opportunity to live in the city.
NEW YORK. Mrs. Theodore Frelinghuysen has closed her place in Palm Beach and is at the Plaza until she sails on July 3 to pass the Summer in Europe.

PRINCETON, N.J., April 29. -- The Princeton baseball team suffered its fifth straight defeat when it bowed to Amherst, 5-4, on University Field today. All of Princeton's runs were scored in the fifth.

WASHINGTON, April 29. -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended on April 22 amounted to 492,970 cars, the American Railway Association announced today. This was 1,245 cars, or 0.3 per cent, fewer than for the preceding week, 69,557 cars, or 12.4 per cent, fewer than for the corresponding week last year, and 265,533 cars, or 35 per cent, fewer than in the corresponding week two years ago.

A search for the largest family in New York City was begun yesterday by Uncle Robert, radio entertainer of children and promoter of Parents' Day. The members of the largest family he can find, he announced, will be his guests of honor at the city's observance of Parents Day on the Mall in Central Park the afternoon of Sunday, May 14.

Former Mayor James J. Walker condemned the stand of the Hitler government against the Jews in Germany as a "retreat to the dark ages" in a communication made public yesterday by Joel Slonin, managing editor of The Day.

AS the result of surveys which have been under way for several months, the West Side Association of Commerce announced yesterday a proposal for the rezoning of a large part of the area on the west side of midtown Manhattan.

The Senate's passage of the farm bill was characterized yesterday by Frederick E. Murphy, publisher of The Minneapolis Tribune and an agricultural authority, as the fundamental step toward recovery. Interviewed at the Waldorf-Astoria, Mr. Murphy, a Republican, said the Senate had acted wisely in taking the bill as it was presented by Secretary of Agriculture Wallace.

President Roosevelt and Chancellor Hitler of Germany were contrasted yesterday by two Jewish rabbis in sermons dealing with President's Day, which will be celebrated today in honor of the achievements of Mr. Roosevelt. The rabbis were Dr. Leo Jung of the Jewish Centre, 131 West Eighty-sixth Street, and Rabbi William Margolis of Congregation Ohab Zedek, 118 West Ninety-fifth Street.

THE hard times which have sent so many dancers away from the ambitious surroundings of Broadway and into smaller and less sumptuous halls for their performances during the last two or three seasons have not been altogether without their bright side, for they have led to the serious consideration and even to the actual organization of projects which are of the greatest importance to the solid progress of the dance movement.

PARIS, April 29. -- The dollar, whose value dominates the situation here at the close of former Premier Herriot's conversations with President Roosevelt, fell today from 23.5 to 22.45 francs on the Paris Bourse as a result of the passage by the United States Senate of the inflation, bill.

PARIS, April 27. -- Molyneux opened the midseason with a collection that carries the free-and-easy style to the nth degree. The combination of a simple dress with a loose, full-backed coat, often in a dark contrasting tone, is favored throughout the collection.

THE theatrical season is now drawing to a close. Composers are putting out the awnings of their penthouses and playwrights are drifting off to shore dinners, golfing engagements and Europe. Most of the producers are making plans only for the Fall or are contemplating a few months in those little places of Connecticut, New York and Massachusetts where the drama is an adjunct to Ye Olde Shoppe and Ye Anciente Antique.
PRAGUE, April 28. -- Revision has at last been discussed in a positive sense by one of the victor nations of Southeastern Europe.

New York City experienced yesterday its warmest day thus far this year. Winter wraps were discarded for more seasonable raimant as the mercury, mounting 10 degrees in four hours, reached a maximum of 76 at 2 P.M. However, it was not the warmest April 29 on record.

PLAINFIELD, N.J., April 29. -- The annual exhibition of painting and sketches by present and former students of the Van Enburgh School of Art was closed abruptly at the Plainfield Public Library here today as the result of the objections to thirty sketches of nudes in the exhibition.

COLOGNE, April 29. -- Although the triumph of Hitlerism has no-where been more spectacular that in the Rhineland, where it has shattered the fortress of the great Catholic Centre party, capturing a stronghold at which the French Army of Occupation battered for twelve years in vain, it la noticeably incomplete.

In any extensive program for expenditure of funds to relieve employment and general business conditions, serious consideration should be given to the question of whether such funds are to be spent with a view of increasing the wealth of the community through the undertaking of projects which would make for more efficient operation and for conservation of existing values.

WASHINGTON, April 29. -- Spokesmen for the Roosevelt administration, headed by the President himself, will be conspicuous on the program of discussion of economic questions at the annual meeting of the Chamber of Commerce of the United States, which will open here Tuesday and continue through Friday.

Ruth St. Denis presented the third of her scheduled four recitals at the Mansfield Theatre yesterday afternoon, offering a program of "Far Eastern Ballets" and "Music Visualizations" in place of the East Indian program of the previous performances. The change was a most unfortunate one, for Miss St. Denis appeared in but five of the sixteen numbers and turned the remainder of the afternoon over to a company of her pupils.

Warning that grave injury may result to property values in the neighborhood of Central Park, real estate interests added their support yesterday to the growing protest against Park Commissioner John E. Sheehy's plan to set up athletic fields on the thirty-four-acre site of the abandoned lower reservoir.

ABOARD THE S.S. BERENGARIA, Bound for Southampton, April 29. -- Prime Minister MacDonald's return journey to England continues under ideal conditions. Already he has been much benefited by the rest since his strenuous Washington days.

The metropolitan racing season, still the longest in the country even though It has been reduced to 150 Says, will get under way next Saturday when the gates at the Jamaica course are thrown open for the opening card of an eighteenday meeting.

LONDON, April 15. IN my summary of the work of the London theatre during 1932 I said that nothing was more remarkable or more important than the vanishing of the superstition that no play could succeed commercially that ended unhappily.

MADRID, April 28. -- What will be the political results of the municipal elections last week in 2,500 small towns in which the Left Wing coalition government forces were outvoted toy Conservatives and Monarchists, no one is in a position to say.

ECONOMICS has a prominent place on the radio this week, with the annual meeting of the United States Chamber of Commerce as the origin of talks by President Roosevelt, industrial leaders and government officials. The Kentucky Derby is the sporting highlight of the week.

NYACK, N.Y., April 29. -- Frank Comesky, president of the Nyack National Bank and Trust Company and president emeritus and dean of the Rockland County Bar Association, died early today at his North Broad-way home after an illness of three weeks with erysipelas.

ST. LOUIS, April 30 (AP). -- The St. Louis Browns won a slugging match from the Detroit Tigers, 11 to 8, and then the Tigers took the second game of a doubleheader today, 5 to 1, in a contest in which every run was brought in by a homer.
Lefty O'Doul definitely abandoned his batting slump in the sixth inning at Ebbets Field yesterday, and the Dodgers delighted 18,000 fans by defeating the Phillies. 6 to 3.

The greatest need today is for Christianity to build lives and civilizations so strongly that, as far as we can see, they will last for eternity, the Rev. Edwin F. Lee, Bishop of Singapore and Manila, declared in a sermon yesterday morning at the Madison Avenue Methodist Church, Madison Avenue at Sixtieth Street.

LONDON, April 29. -- Security and commercial markets recovered rapidly from the first shock of America's departure from the gold standard. That action, startling and unexpected through it was, is now being viewed in a different light. Criticism, which was harsh at first, has been softened by subsequent events and by a better understanding of the circumstances which culminated in a policy which apparently was the lesser of two evils.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Having for the moment successfully evaded the Sheriff at the front door, and the wolf in "cheap's" clothing in the rear, this druggist takes time out to consider briefly the plaints of prescription-bearing patients against overcharging recently noted in THE TIMES.

Senator BORAH'S endorsement of the "greenback section" in the inflation bill raises the question, exactly what it means. It authorizes issue "at such times and in such "amounts as the President may "approve" of United States notes on the plan of 1862.

Charles M. Schwab, veteran steel man, and Mrs. Schwab will celebrate their golden wedding anniversary tonight with a reception from 9 to 12 o'clock at their residence, Riverside Drive and Seventy-third Street.

One man was killed and four other persons were injured early yesterday morning when the automobile in which they were riding swerved from the roadway at Riverside Drive and 121st Street, leaped the curb and turned over.

Mayor John P. O'Brien, speaking yesterday in Prospect Park, Brooklyn, at the thirteenth annual Americanization meeting, urged the establishment of Reserve Officers Training Corps units in all colleges and assailed the "undeservable apathy" of those who have refused to accept this type of military instruction.

Writing to THE NEW YORK TIMES from Paris in the Spring of 1927 the late Paul Souday, distinguished French critic, called Countess de Noailles "the most popular of our poets." Rumanian through her father's family, Greek through her mother's, she was French by adoption and marriage, and from passing most of her life in France.

BERLIN, April 29. -- Many of the people here do not believe that the depreciation of the dollar will go far. The editor of Die Bank, Alfred Lansburgh, on the contrary, considers that the dollar may sink heavily like sterling, all the more so because America, unlike England, is embarking on internal currency depreciation.

SHANGHAI, April 30. -- C.C. Julian broke his silence here today in a statement to your correspondent in which he reviewed the history of his oil promotion company financing in the United States before he fled to China to evade trial in Oklahoma.

WASHINGTON, April 30. -- Jobs for husbands whose wives have worked hard and effectively for the Democratic party are being sought by the latter and on their behalf by their friends "back home" in daily increasing numbers.

Beckoned abroad by the bright Sunshine and soft Spring skies that dawned yesterday over the metropolitan area, and made daylight saving a pleasure, New Yorkers swarmed the suburban, seaside resorts throughout the day for promenades along the boardwalks and sun-baths on the beaches.

PEARY LODGE, Greenland, April 30. -- We have had the finest weather ever experienced here in March and April, although the temperature reached 36 degrees below zero, Fahrenheit, whereas it is usually about 20 below. The skies are clear and the period of daylight has gradually lengthened until now it is continuous.

Standing in East 150th Street, between Morris and Park Avenues, the Bronx, last night, Carmine Monteleone, 26 years old, of 3,231 Lafayette Avenue, was shot through both lungs by an unidentified assailant who fled north in Park Avenue and disappeared in East 151st Street.

WASHINGTON, April 30. -- The Reconstruction Finance Corporation up to the close of business on April 22 had made cash advances of $2,260,021,958,92 according to figures made public today by the corporation.

Some sayings of Jesus which Christian writers have found some difficulty in explaining and for non-Christian writers have afforded bases for attack are described as contemporary humor by Dr. Henry Kendall Booth in his "The World of Jesus," just published by Scribners.
BOSTON, April 30. -- Calamity overtook the Giants today at Braves Field, where a crowd of 35,000 saw Bill McKechnie's Braves take both ends of a double-header.

BOMBAY, April 30. -- Mahatma Gandhi, in Yerovda jail at Poona, announced tonight that he would begin on May 8 an "unconditional and irrevocable" fast of twenty-one days on behalf of the work of eradicating the evil of untouchability.

Present-day drama, literature and philosophy were condemned yesterday by the Rev. Dr. Harry Emerson Fosdick, pastor of the Riverside Baptist Church, 122d Street and Riverside Drive, as examples of the continuing conflict between religion and "irreligious theory."

The aggregate long-term indebtedness of corporations, individuals and governmental agencies throughout the United States is now S134,000,000,000, according to a three-month study of the capacity of debtors to meet their obligations, made public yesterday by the Twentieth Century Fund, of which EdWard A. Filene is president.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., April 30. -- The award of 150 fellowships and scholarships was announced today by the Yale graduate school. Tewenty-eight fellowships have been awarded for research, eighty-six for graduate study leading to a higher degree and thirty-four scholarships cover tuition.

Mark Eisner, chairman of the Board of Higher Education, is commended for declaring that all political influence will be banned in selecting a new president of Hunter College, in a letter sent to him by a group headed by George W. Alger and made public yesterday.

In response to increasing protests against Park Commissioner John E. Sheehy's plan to convert the abandoned Central Park reservoir site into baseball diamonds and other athletic fields, more than a score of organizations interested in the preservation of the park contemplated yesterday a united fight against the project.

Fire that started yesterday afternoon among discarded oil cans and gasoline drums in a swamp area at Eighty-sixth Street between Astoria Boulevard and Thirty-first Avenue, Jackson Heights, now being used as a dump, attracted thousands of motorists homeward bound from Long Island to New York, and a series of traffic snarls developed that took the police from one to three hours to unravel.

ALBANY, April 30. -- Operation of steamers on Lake George this Summer is ensured through the announcement today by the Department of State that a charter has been granted to the Lake George Transportation Corporation, which is to take over the line of steamboats formerly operated by a subsidiary of the Delaware Hudson Railroad Company.
MEXICO CITY, April 30. -- The United States Davis Cup players rapidly are becoming acclimated in this high altitude, judging by their strenuous workout on the Deportivo Club courts today.
ALBANY, April 30. -- Governor Lehman has signed two bills introduced by Senator Henry G. Schackno providing an additional county judge and an additional justice of the City Court for the Bronx.

The Police Department solved a problem yesterday for Morris Kudlick, a chauffeur living at 856 Forty-fourth Street, Brooklyn, after Kudlick, a score of neighbors and the American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals had failed.

CHICAGO, April 29. -- An erratic movement in prices of hogs in Chicago and in leading Western markets brought a moderate readjustment in prices in the last few days, with a more optimistic feeling at the close. Business news and reports from wholesale food markets for the last few days were more optimistic than for a month, with a steady pick-up since the latter part of March.

NEW ORLEANS, April 28. -- Although cotton prices reached new high levels for the recent upward movement in the early part of last week and even reached new highs for the year, the market experienced a moderate reaction in the latter part of the period and the volume of trading gradually diminished until, near the close of the week, it dropped to moderate size.

PITTSBURGH, April 30. -- While little increase in the general demand for steel was reflected by last week's improvement in production of steel ingots, as the enlarged buying of the preceding week was a factor, there was a resumption of rail production both here and in Chicago on some recent orders and releases against old contracts.

At a special election today the voters of Rhode Island will choose delegates to a constitutional convention to meet on May 8 and vote for or against the repeal of the Eighteenth Amendment. Like Connecticut, Rhode Island never ratified that amendment.

INDIANAPOLIS, April 30 (AP). -- Addressing a group of aviators assembled here tonight from all parts of the country, Louis Johnson, national commander of the American Legion, deplored the fact that the United States ranks fourth in national air defense.

Newark shut out Buffalo in both sections of a double header before 12,000 spectators at Ruppert's Stadium, Newark, yesterday. The scores were 4 to 0 and 5 to 0. On its home diamond at West Side Park, Jersey City took the first game from Montreal, 7 to 2, and lost the second, 5 to 1.
WASHINGTON, April 30 (AP). -- The Senators came from behind twice today to overcome the Athletics for 5-to-4 victory in twelve innings, the fourth straight triumph for the Nationals.
WASHINGTON, April 30. -- The votes in the Senate and House by the delegations from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut on important roll-calls last week are given in the appended tabulation:
BERLIN, April 30. -- Backed by all the resources of a national propaganda unrivaled anywhere, the National Socialists will make a great bid tomorrow for the support of German labor.

WASHINGTON, April 30. -- Representatives of Italy, Germany and Argentina will continue here this week the series of conferences in which statesmen of Great Britain, France and Canada have already sought with President Roosevelt to insure the success of the coming-World Economic and Monetary Conference beginning in London on June 12.

A set of engrossed resolutions attributing the success of the save-the-opera campaign largely to Lucrezia Bori was presented to her yesterday by Paul D. Cravath, chairman of the board of the Metropolitan Opera Association.

PARIS, April 29. -- Practical application of the American inflation plan appears difficult to French financial circles, which wonder if the American Government will, in case the dollar is devaluated, honor the clause stipulating payment in gold inscribed on the securities it has issued.

BERLIN, April 30. -- A revolt of German women against the present methods of Chancellor Adolf Hitler's government of national revolution was forecast in an interview for THE NEW YORK TIMES today by Frau Katherina von Oheim-Kardorff, one of the best known feminist leaders in the Reich.

Raymond B. Fosdick, attorney and authority on international affairs, has been elected president of the League of Nations Association, succeeding George W. Wickersham, who had held the office since 1928, it was announced yesterday by Charles H. Strong, chairman of the board of directors.

Confronted by the decidedly less hostile Red Sox, the Yankees returned briskly to the business of strengthening their position at the top of the American League standing by grabbing both, ends of their first twin bill of the season at the Stadium yesterday.

First produced thirty-odd years ago. the "Romanticism" of Gerolamo Rovetta. given by the Teatro d'Arte, at the Little Theatre, last evening, proved an effective piece of anti-Austrian propaganda in shaping Italian public opinion, from August, 1914, till May, 1915, and an unfailing inspiration to patriotism ever since.

Obligations of the United States Government, which, will mature within the next twelve months, amount to $3,424,026,100. They consist of Treasury certificates of indebtedness, notes and non-interest-bearing bills.

RICHMOND, Va., April 30. -- The protest against Hitlerism should continue despite the refusal of a few "esteemed but obstinate" Jewish leaders to cooperate, but hand in hand with the protest should go an effort to settle the victims of oppression in Palestine as the Jewish national home, said Louis Lipsky, Zionist leader, tonight at a mass meeting of the American Palestine Campaign, at which J. Leicester Watts presided.

Holders of city of Vienna 6 per cent American dollar loan due on Nov. 1, 1952, which originally went into default on Aug. 1, 1332, are being notified by Mayor Karl Seitz, that the foreign exchange regulations in effect in Austria prevent payment of the coupons due today, in dollars.

WASHINGTON, April 30. -- Many a controversial measure, such as the banking reform limited-deposit insurance bill and the thirty-hour-week production control measure, remain to be put over the Congressional hurdles.

Faith in the progress of the Ethical Culture movement, despite the death of Felix Adler, its founder and leader for more than half a century, was reaffirmed yesterday by four of his followers in a discussion at the meeting house of the New York Society, Sixty-fourth Street at Central Park West.

Kuhn, Loeb Co. announced last night, on behalf of the French municipalities of Bordeaux, Lyons and Marseilles, which will pay the semi-annual interest today on their respective bond issues of $15,000,000 each, that in view of the impossibility of obtaining gold coin for payment in New York the option of three forms of payment would be offered the bondholders.
The New York American team defeated the Prague Americans by 5 -- 1 in an American league soccer game at Starlight Park yesterday before 1,000 persons.

BUENOS AIRES, April 30. -- Bolivia is preparing a huge offensive against Paraguay in the Chaco to start at the end of May or early in June, according to persons arriving from La Quiaca, across the Argentine frontier from Villazon, the terminus of the Bolivian railway whence supplies are shipped to the Chaco in motor trucks.

LEMARS, Iowa, April 30. -- Following suspension of civil courts in militia-ruled Plymouth County, effective tomorrow, a military court of inquiry met tonight in adjacent Crawford County where nineteen men had been arrested in connection with a farm sale riot last week.

TOKYO, April 30. -- While rival labor May Day processions representing the Left and Right Wing unions are marching through Tokyo this morning the Kokusuikai reactionary society will arm its members with spears to break up the Left procession.

Some important appointments by President Roosevelt are expected this week, according to information received here yesterday from Washington. Among them are those of J.F.T. O'Connor of California, law partner of Senator William G. McAdoo, for Controller of the Currency; Guy T. Helvering of Kansas, for Commissioner of Internal Revenue, and Harry Miller of Montana, and Mrs. Benton McMillin of Tennessee, for member of the Civil Service Commission.

CHICAGO, April 30 (AP). -- Rogers Hornsby came back to Chicago today for the first time since his dismissal as manager of the Cubs last August, and with a home run with a mate on base gave the Cardinals an even break in their double-header with last year's champions.

Approximately $10,000 toward the establishment of a national home for aged and infirm circus performers was realized last night at a benefit performance at the Majestic Theatre, in which many stage, screen, and circus stars participated.

YONKERS, April 30. -- Bertha Deshefy, 6 years old, did her bit yesterday to start the wheels of industry moving by a personal campaign of spending. In four short hours the little girl put about $110 into circulation among the toy and candy venders of Yonkers.
Willa Cather's "April Twilights," containing a new long poem, "Poor Marty," which has not before appeared in book form will be brought out on May 5 by Alfred A. Knopf.

In spite of backing and filling tendencies last week, resulting in several days of net losses, all commodities traded on local Exchanges closed Saturday with net gains for the week in at least some of their positions. The closing rally lifted several from the minus to the plus column.

PROVIDENCE, April 30. -- Rhode Island will go to the polls tomorrow to elect thirty-one delegates to the convention to be held on May 8 to decide the State's stand on repeal of the Eighteenth Amendment.

WASHINGTON, April 30. -- Asserting that there would not be any voluntary movement of World War veterans on Washington, William Conley of Los Angeles, National Commander of the Disabled American Veterans, today said that the main inspiration for a new bonus march has come from Communist leaders.
