WASHINGTON, April 30. -- Congressional leaders were prepared tonight to drive the administration's farm relief and inflation legislation through to enactment this week, with other major features of President Roosevelt's program commanding attention.

The Rev. Dr. Allan Knight Chalmers, pastor of the Broadway Tabernacle Congregational Church at Fifty-sixth Street, who has just returned from a tour of the South, commented yesterday in his sermon on the Scottsboro case and deplored the prejudice to which he attributed the recent conviction of one of the Negro defendants.

Three youths who had never been in a canoe before clung desperately to their overturned craft in the middle of Long Island Sound off Belden Point, City Island, at about 1 o'clock yesterday afternoon, vainly calling for help. After several minutes in the choppy water, two lost their grip and were drowned.

Gradual improvement in trade has undoubtedly occurred during April, notably in the always "barometric" steel trade. Production in that industry, for the first time since the depression began in 1930, has gone above the rate of a year before.

THE handcuffs are being taken off the baseball prisoners and Messrs. Chapman, Myer and Whitehill will be turned loose today to rejoin their comrades on the diamond. The trouble started when Ben Chapman followed the ancient custom of trying to knock over a second baseman who was trying to complete a double play.
WASHINGTON, April 30. -- The selection of General Benavides as Provisional President of Peru was regarded in diplomatic circles here tonight as a logical step.

NEWARK, N.J., April 30. -- Louis Gregory of the Millrose A.A., three-time holder of the national six-mile title and a member of the American Olympic team, today became the first winner of an American long-distance running championship decided on a metric basis when he annexed the national A.A.U. 20-kilometer crown over Newark streets.

Ceremonious opening of the new laboratories of an important drug manufacturing company is not an occasion on which we expect to hear plain speaking of the kind in which Sir HENRY H. DALE indulged at Rahway, on the danger of being too practical in medical research, and of keeping a too eager eye on profits to be derived from the patenting of medical discoveries.

WASHINGTON, April 30 (AP). -- Senator McGill, Democrat, of Kansas, said today that he had been assured "personally" by Postmaster General Farley that he would be recognized as the "referee" in all matters pertaining to Kansas patronage.

BUENOS AIRES, April 30. -- The dollar slumped sharply here on Saturday, closing at 152.75 gold pesos for $100, compared with 155.70 on Friday and Wednesday's high of 157.55. The paper peso yesterday was worth 28.80 cents, against 28.24 cents on Friday and 27.90 cents on Wednesday.

Although the regular shooting season has ended, seventeen gunners came to the firing line at Travers Island traps of the New York A.C. yesterday, principally to practice for the amateur championship at clay targets of the United States which is to be decided under the auspices of the Winged Foot club on Friday and Saturday.

Several important month-end changes in brokerage houses in the financial district have been announced, most of which are effective today. Also there have been several new firms organized, which, it is believed is due in part to the recent activity of security and commodity markets.

A spirited second-half attack that netted two goals gave the Tipperary hurling team a 10-to-9 victory over Offaly at Innisfail Park yesterday. The triumph gave Tipperary the 1932 New York State championship.

Something in the nature of "a flight to the stars," to be known more technically as the Zodiac Tea Dance, is being planned under the auspices of the National Charity Air Pageant for the afternoon of May 11 at the Ambassador.

In spite of human progress in other ways, man has failed to progress spiritually since Old Testament times, the Rev. Thomas R. Whelpley declared yesterday in his morning sermon at the Chelsea Presbyterian Church, 214 West Twenty-third Street.

YAZOO CITY, Miss., April 30. -- Tornadic winds lashed Southeastern Arkansas and Western Mississippi last night and early today, taking a toll of six known dead, fifty or more injured, an estimated $500,000 property damage, and left hundreds homeless.

So many things having nothing to do with farming were put into the farm bill last week by the Senate that sections of the measure concerned with agricultural matters have been overshadowed. They constitute an amazing grant of power.

This country is the greatest free trader in the world. If that statement threatens to cause some Republican Senator to fall down in a convulsive fit, we hasten to add that free trade within the United States is meant. The fact is unchallenged.

New York State's new 1 per cent retail sales tax, which is expected to yield revenue of between $28,000,000 and $30,000,000 a year and to cost the average family somewhere in the neighborhood of $7.50 yearly, goes into effect today. It is a temporary emergency measure scheduled to expire on June 30, 1934.

BERLIN, April 30. -- All Germany, especially the German workmen who hitherto have known only the "Marxistic" side of workers' May Day demonstrations, will be taught tomorrow to celebrate this "feast of labor" in a National Socialist manner.

Cardinal Hayes presided at a special service in St. Patrick's Cathedral yesterday afternoon in celebration of the one-hundredth anniversary of the founding of the St. Vincent de Paul Society in Paris by Frederick Ozanam. The society ministers to the poor and the sick.

MOSCOW, April 30. -- The dispute between Russia and Manchukuo over the jointly operated Chinese Eastern Railway took a more serious turn tonight with the publication of a communique in which Li Shao-keng, Manchukuoan chairman of the railway board, openly challenged Russia's claim to ownership of the railroad.
With some assistance from the weather man, the Penn relays for 1933 gain a clear-cut decision over their mid-Western counterpart, the Drake relays, in the annual checkup on comparative performances.

BERLIN, April 30. -- Although two months have passed since fire did extensive damage to the Reichstag building on February 27, the authorities have been unable to fix a date for the trial of those charged with starting the blaze.

To the Editor of The New York Times: One reason for the excessive charges for funerals is that undertakers are operating at a tremendous overhead cost. The field is overcrowded. We have in the United States one funeral establishment for every forty persons, children and adults, that die annually.
Milion Aborn will present tonight as the second of his current Gilbert and Sullivan revivals "The Yeomen of the Guard." at the St. James Theatre.

To the Editor of The New York Ttmes: The Supreme Court of Maine held the scheme of legislation then pending for a State convention to ratify or reject the repeal resolution fatally defective in several particulars. There is little doubt that the objections raised by the court will be obviated by a revision of the scheme.

Patrolman John J. Shearer of Traffic F overpowered and captured two men in a chase along upper Broadway during which he fired five shots after a hold-up at 10:30 o'clock last night in a chain restaurant at 2,642 Broadway, in which the policeman had been eating.

WASHINGTON, April 30. -- A program of public and private construction for estimated outlays of about $1,250,000,000, much of which would be financed by advances from the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, has been placed before President Roosevelt by the American Construction Council, an organization of which Mr. Roosevelt was president from 1922 to 1929.

Three players remained unbeaten and in a deadlock for first place in the world's 18.1 balkline billiard championship tournament now in progress at the Brooklyn Elks Club as the result of matches yesterday.

Dunking was the order of the sailing dinghy regatta, yesterday on Pelham Bay under the auspices of the Harlem Yacht Club, City Island. Two boats capsized, several dipped and picked up almost enough sea water to reach the swamping stage, and those who crewed in the bows of the racing craft were thoroughly wet.

HAVANA, April 30. -- With no further reports of clashes between government troops and insurrectionists in Oriente Province it became apparent today that the fighting which broke out in various sections yesterday was local in character, similar to other guerrilla conflicts which have been occurring constantly in the three lower provinces of the republic.

WASHINGTON, April 30. -- The world's most immediate problems affecting international peace are the controversy between Japan and China over Manchuria, the reduction of armaments and the removal of barriers to international trade. Dr. James Brown Scott, secretary of the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace, declared in his annual report, made public today.

LONDON, April 22. -- The French Government railway bill tabled in the Chamber of Deputies shows that the French railways are adversely affected by economic conditions to an extent perhaps unequaled elsewhere. Of a deficit of 15,000,000,000 francs incurred in the last ten years, more than 9,000,000,000 francs represent the losses of the last three years, and it is estimated that the railroads are losing at the rate of about 10,000,000 francs daily.

The question of how far fish travel from their spawning grounds or from places where they have been liberated after being hatched and reared in captivity long has been argued among anglers and State fish and game officials. To officials charged with the distribution of State-raised fish the question is a very important one.

BRESLAU, Silesia, April 30 -- Fritz is an S.-A. man. These are magic letters in Germany today. They mark the knights of the swastika cross -- the rough and ready warriors of the "national revolution."

With more than 20,000 men and women workers engaged in an active solicitation of funds, the annual appeal of the Catholic Charities of the Archdiocese of New York started yesterday in the 369 parishes of the archdiocese. The drive will continue until May 10, with more than $1,000,000 as the unofficial goal.

MORRISTOWN, N.J., April 30. -- Mrs. Calvin Coolidge, widow of the President, visited this historic community yesterday and expressed her delight in examining some of the early American art objects at the Ford House here, a Colonial mansion which General George Washington made his headquarters in the Winter of 1779-80.

James A. Farley, Postmaster General, addressing more than 4,000 members of the New York Post Office Holy Name Society, pledged his support yesterday in protecting the interests of postal employes in the administration's reorganization program.

About 50,000 persons from the ranks of the unemployed obtained emergency work in the first three months of this year through the Emergency Work and Relief Administration of the city, according to the quarterly report submitted yesterday to Mayor O'Brien by Frank J. Taylor, Commissioner of Public Welfare.

ALBANY, April 30. -- Signs are seen that returns this year from the personal income tax will come up to the estimates of revenues made by officers of the State when the budget for the fiscal year was before the 1932 Legislature. The proceeds from this impost are expected to justify the estimate made by Governor Lehman.

NEW HAVEN, April 30. -- Professor Irving Fisher's index number of commodity prices, based on 100 as the average for 1926, is 58.6, which compares with 57.1 a week ago, 56.8 two weeks ago, 56.2 three weeks ago, and 56.4 four weeks ago. This week's average is above the highest of the year to date, which was 57.4 in the first week of January, the average of March 5 at 55 was the lowest.

Joseph Fahey of the Holy Name Club was the winner of the twenty-fifth annual road run conducted by the St. Anselm's Athletic Club, over a six-mile course in the Bronx yesterday. Fahey, enjoying a handicap of 3 minutes 15 seconds, negotiated the distance in 30 minutes 47 1-5 seconds.

Steel operations may move above 30 per cent of capacity this week for the first time since November, 1931, the magazine Steel says in its weekly survey of the industry. It estimated the rate of output last week at 29 per cent. Its review reads in part:

GLOUCESTER, Mass., April 30 (AP). -- This old fishing port threw open its heart today to veteran fishing skippers returning aboard the schooner Gertrude L. Thebaud after having sailed to Washington to seek Federal aid for their industry. She had been gone eleven days.
LONDON, April 30. -- According to The Daily Telegraph objections have been raised by various powers to the United States proposal for a tariff truce during the World Economic Conference.

Holders of Consolidated Traction Company $15,000,000 five per cent forty-year gold bonds due June 1, 1933, have the option of extending the bonds at 5 per cent interest until June 1, 1938, or of accepting $650 for each $1,000 bond.

Activity continued at more than seasonal levels in the wholesale apparel markets here last week, as buyers placed orders for both immediate and future requirements. Reports from retailers throughout the country indicate that retail business picked up considerably last month and made up somewhat for the poor business done in March.

Change in the gold holdings of the United States this month were reduced to a minimum by the action of the government in abandoning the gold standard on April 19. The result for the month from actual shipments and releases of gold earmarked was a gain of $21,938,800, contrasted with a loss of $121,339,497 in March, when restrictions on exports were imposed by governmental decree on March 4 and continued in force.
May Day Observances. NEW YORK -- Entire police force on duty to preserve order at Socialist and Communist parades and Union Square rallies.
Plenty of Daylight. Daylight saving this year should make an excellent subject for the inquiring sociologist. Questionnaires have been sent out on matters of far less poignant human interest.

Frank P. Walsh, chairman of the State Power Authority, urged an immediate determination of the power rights of New York State in the St. Lawrence River and the cost to be borne by the State under the terms of the treaty with Canada, in a message last night to Senators Copeland and Wagner.

Trading in stocks on the New York Stock Exchange in April was the heaviest for a month since last September. On April 20, business was the most active since May 5, 1930. The high-speed tickers on sales that day of 7,127,650 shares trailed the market, with quotations more than thirty minutes late.

VATICAN CITY, April 30. -- The first of the great ceremonies designed to confer particular lustre on the Holy Tear occurred today with the beatification of the Venerable Marie Pelletier, French founder of the order of the Sisters of the Good Shepherd, which was approved by Pope Gregory XVI in 1835 and now numbers 322 houses scattered throughout the world.

Barely a corporal's guard of Civil War veterans who were with General Grant at Fort Henry, Shiloh, Vicksburg, Lookout Mountain and the Wilderness participated yesterday afternoon in exercises commemorating the 111th birthday anniversary of their commander-in-chief and the eighteenth President of the United States at his tomb, 120th Street and Riverside Drive.
New York, with the rest of the nation, observed President's Day yesterday, the 144th anniversary of George Washington's first inauguration.

A 15-year-old boy and his 17-year-old companion, who, according to the police, purchased pistols with the proceeds of their first burglary, committed more than a year ago, and staged twenty-five hold-ups since then, were captured in a basement at Eighty-seventh Street and Lexington Avenue shortly before midnight last night after a hold-up and chase, during which ten shots were fired by two policemen and four by the youths.

PARIS, April 30. -- In a message from the Ile de France former Premier Herriot declares he is returning home full of optimism. But it is already obvious that his optimism is going to suffer a rude shock when his liner touches these shores.
The passage of the so-called and miscalled "inflation" bill by the Senate came at the close of one of the most exciting weeks in American history.

LIMA, Peru, April 30. -- President Sanchez Cerro was attacked so suddenly today that elaborate precautions which had been made to protect him were unavailing. A captain of the civil guards leaped on the Presidential car and attempted to shield General Sanchez Cerro, but without success.
CHICAGO, April 30 (AP). -- Prompted by wholesale bank failures, many Legislatures are concentrating on measures to strengthen banking regulations.

Women interested in furthering the work of several philanthropies in the city have arranged card parties for the coming week. The New York Diet Kitchen Association, which is devoted to the welfare of mothers and children, will be the beneficiary of a luncheon bridge to be held tomorrow at the Central Park Casino.

Dividends declared in April showed further curtailment of payments, made necessary by poor earnings in the first quarter of 1933. With fewer companies making declarations last month than a year ago, because of many omissions of payments in the last year, the disbursements in the aggregate were approximately 20 per cent below 1932.

FRANKFURT-AM-MAIN, April 30. -- An official rebuke to the Frankfurter Zeitung was published in today's issue. It was administered because the world-famous Democratic newspaper had ventured a week ago to print the following sentence in an article:

Breaking even in two games played last week. Columbia now has undisputed possession of the lead in the Eastern Intercollegiate Baseball League race with six games won against a single defeat. Harvard is in second place with two victories in three contests and Yale, last year's champion, in third with three successes in five games.

NORTHAMPTON, Mass., April 30 (AP). -- Friends and neighbors of Calvin Coolidge who knew him in the homely surroundings that did not presage his ultimate ascendancy gathered today in a little hall to honor the memory of the thirtieth President of the United States.

Further reductions in the city's budget for 1933 are necessary in order to avoid a "considerable deficit" at the end of the year, according to a report to be submitted to the State Chamber of Commerce by its committee on taxation at the annual meeting on Thursday.

SAARBRUECKEN, April 30. -- For the first time in the Saar Basin the Nazi swastika flag was hoisted the other day with the official sanction of the international governing commission, after an official intimation from the Hitlerite Government that it was now one of the official German flags and could no longer be objected to.
NEW YORK. Sumner Ballard will give a dinner on May 25 at his home, 10 East Seventy-ninth Street.

Gaily decorated with bunting, the new United States liner Washington steamed up the harbor yesterday afternoon from the yards of the New York Shipbuilding Company at Camden, N.J., to her pier at the foot of West Twenty-first Street.

CHICAGO, April 30. -- Guerrilla warfare between two criminal gangs, each seeking to prey on branches of the teamsters' unions, was regarded as at lever heat today following the kidnapping of two union officials from their headquarters Friday.

The career of Luis M. Sanchez Cerro was one of the stormiest in South American history and the attack on him which caused his death yesterday was the last of several such attempts. Before this successful assassination he had carried about in his body fourteen bullets.

CHICAGO, April 30. -- An advance of 5 cents a bushel in wheat prices, carrying them to new high levels for the season and up virtually 28 cents from the low of a few months ago, caught the wheat traders last week, as a result, without any wheat bought and with a fair-sized short interest.
LIMA, Peru, April 30. -- President Luis M. Sanchez Cerro was assassinated today after reviewing between 25,000 and 30,000 troops in training to fight Colombia.

MOSCOW, April 30. -- Thousands of persons strolled the streets tonight on the eve of one of the most elaborate May Day observances in the history of Soviet Russia. For several days swarms of workmen have been busy throughout the city, decorating the facades of buildings with banners, bunting and slogans in flaming red letters.

PEIPING, Tuesday, May 2. -- The news of the Japanese occupation of Dolon-Nor following stubborn fighting has caused Chinese officials to link the entire current of the Japanese military movement with the dispute over the Chinese Eastern Railway, in Northern Manchuria.

Sir Henry Dale, director of British national medical research, who has been lecturing at Johns Hopkins University, Baltimore, sails tonight for England on the North German Lloyd liner Bremen. A.C. Bossom, British architect and member of Parliament, and I.C. Gifford, vice president of Mayflower Associates, Inc., and Mrs. Gifford also will depart on the Bremen.

WASHINGTON, May 1 -- The detailed report of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation for March was made public today by Congress despite the continued opposition of some officials. Loans and other advances aggregating $233,195,749.40 were authorized, as compared with $262,346,044.32 in the preceding month, a decrease of $29,150,294,92.

With May 16 set as the probable date for the selection of a successor to Dr. James M. Kieran, president of Hunter College, a list of fourteen persons under consideration for the post was made public last night by Mark Eisner, chairman of the board of higher education.

SHREVEPORT, La.. May 1 (AP) -- A series of May Day torna-does killed at least eighty-one persons in Arkansas, Missouri and Louisiana late today, injured more than 1,000 and damaged five towns, including the important city of Minden, La.

SAARBRUECKEN, May 1 -- Permission to Germans in the Saar Basin to fly the Nazi swastika banner has given fresh impulse to the Nazi movements here. National Socialist headquarters have been crowded with inquiries, and swastika buttons and Fascist salutes are prominent in the streets.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The President's sudden surrender to the inflationists is all the more startling because of the fact that in his measures to reopen the banks he had won the support of the whole business community by seeking the advice of the leading conservative bankers.

Newspapers and newspaper men in widely separated parts of the country were honored in the list of winners of Pulitzer prizes in journalism for 1932 announced yesterday by Dr. Frank D. Fackenthal, secretary of Columbia University. The awards were made by the university trustees on the recommendation of the advisory board of the School of Journalism, which met on April 28.

Retail Activity Spurs Orders. Reflecting the excellent retail trade at the week-end described as the best since Christmas, orders reached the wholesale markets here yesterday in substantial volume. Many buyers were here, several of the large out-of-town stores being represented by large staffs.

The dollar continued to depreciate rapidly in foreign exchange yesterday. In terms of the French franc it dropped to 81.7 cents, the lowest exchange value on record since the resumption of specie payments here in 1879.

A saving of $15,840 monthly was effected in the nine parts of General Sessions yesterday when, by resolution of the judges, the panel of talesmen in each part was cut down from seventy-five to fifty-five for the twenty-two court days for each month.

The investigation of ocean and air mail contracts by a Senate committee of five, headed by Senator Black of Alabama, was started yesterday with the submission of questionnaires to the steamship companies holding contracts. About twenty questions were asked, dealing with the personnel of the ship lines, details of the mail contracts and possible relations of the companies with government employes or relatives of members of Congress.

The proposal for a 2-cent tax on all subway fares as a means of providing the city with from $35,000,000 to 540,000,000 a year In additional revenue was renewed yesterday by Professor Lindsay Roger of Columbia University.

The honorary degree of Doctor of Laws was conferred yesterday by Columbia. University upon Sir Walter Thomas Layton, British editor and economist. The ceremony was held in the trustees' room of the Library Building and was attended by members of the university board of trustees, the university council and the faculty of political science.
Virtually normal conditions are reported by fresh water anglers who have been whipping near-by streams during the past few days.

In 1930 an ordinance of the Board of Aldermen not only froze into law the existing " 15-and-5 " taxicab rate but nearly doubled the charge for waiting time. There were loud protests, and Mayor WALKER was urged to veto the ordinance and name a commission to investigate the whole subject of taxicab regulation.

LIMA, May 1 -- In the full-dress uniform of a General and wearing the Presidential sash, the body of Peru's assassinated chief executive was romeved last night from the Italian Hospital to the Palace of Pizarro and this morning to the cathedral.

After racing to new highs for the year in many cases, most commodity futures traded on exchanges here reacted slowly to close with small changes on the day. Silver and sugar were unchanged, while rubber, hides and coffee were higher, and the close in silk and cocoa was irregular.

Discovery in Persia of a great Sassanian city and palace seventeen miles northeast of Kish, ancient Babylonian capital, and other discoveries indicating the possibility that there are "a whole chain of Sassanian cities extending into Mesopotamian territory, were announced last night at the annual dinner of the American Institute for Persian Art and Archaeology, at the Waldorf-Astoria, in dispatches from the, institute's expedition at Kish.

A series of ten new plays will be tested at Parsons Theatre in Hartford, beginning May 15, under the auspices of William Caryl, an executive on the staff of the Shuberts. A separate company consisting of Broadway players will be engaged for each attraction and there will be a change of bill every week.
TEHERAN, May 1 -- The terms of the new oil concession in Persia, signed last night between the Anglo-Persian Oil Company and the Persian Government follows:

Stocks had the benefit yesterday not only of whatever stimulus may be left in the inflation plans of the administration, but of further evidence that the improvement in business is proceeding at an unexpectedly encouraging pace. Wall Street attributed the early advances to both influences, in about equal proportions.

Edmund Soussa of Egypt and Theodore Moons of Belgium kept their unbeaten records intact yesterday in the world's amateur 18.1 balkline billiard championship tournament now in progress at the Brooklyn Elks Club under the auspices of the National Association of Amateur Billiard Players.

The local offices of the United States Golf Association were flooded with mail yesterday when a large stack of envelopes containing entries for the United States open championship to be held at the North Shore Country Club, Chicago, on June 8-10, greeted Executive Secretary T.J. McMahon on his arrival.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., May 1 -- Following a series of time trials, Head Coach Ed Leader of the Yale varsity; Fred Spuhn, coach of the freshmen, and Coach Don Grant of the 150-pound crews, announced tonight the personnel of the four eights which will meet Columbia and the University of Pennsylvania in the annual Blackwell Cup competition at Derby on Saturday.

Prices of bonds were generally higher on the Stock Exchange yesterday, much higher than indicated by the averages which are concerned chiefly with better rated issues. The strength in foreign bonds was impressive, and a long list of domestic corporation issues rose one or more points in heavy dealings.

INDIANAPOLIS, May 1 (AP) -- All types of racing automobiles -- rear, front and four-wheel drives, powered by various kinds of motors -- are among the forty-seven entries announced tonight for the annual 500-mile classic May 30.

W.B. Storey, who has been president of the Atchison, Topeka Santa Fe Railway since 1920, is to resign at a meeting of the board today. S.T. Bledsoe, chairman of the executive committee and general counsel, is due to succeed him.

For the first time in three years the Federal Government is out of the wheat pit and rid of the surplus stocks which it purchased in a vain effort to "peg" prices. The new chairman of the Farm Board, Mr. MOHGENTHAU, has thus redeemed a promise.

VIENNA, May 1 -- Eight thousand steel helmeted soldiers of the Austrian Army, with full field equipment, machine guns and howitzers descended upon the inner city of Vienna this morning, sealed the entrances with barbed wire, and held it for twelve hours against the searching rays of the May sun.
BERLIN, May 1 -- The cardinal points of Chancellor Hitler's economic program were only vaguely outlined in his speech, which dwelt at length on the significance of May 1 as observed in Germany today.
NEW YORK. Mr. and Mrs. Charles Astor Bristed arrived on the Franconia and are at the St. Regis before going to Lenox, Mass.

Able Prima Donna. LUCREZIA BORI receives warm praise from the Metropolitan Opera authorities, but not warmer than she deserves, for her successful leadership in the campaign to save next year's operatic season in New York.

ALBANY, May 1 -- Governor Lehman today approved the mandatory minimum wage bill, applying only to women and minors in industry, which was sponsored by Senator Albert Wald of New York City. He vetoed, a permissive minimum wage measure, introduced by Senator Thomas C. Desmond of Orange County, which would have brought in adult males also under the minimum wage benefits and would have been in force only during the depression.

WASHINGTON, May 1 -- Within a few days the President must decide what course he will follow in negotiating adjustments of the war debts. This subject has given him more concern than almost any other, and he has postponed action until no more delay is possible.

If President Roosevelt does use his power to inflate the currency, the movement can be controlled and the "ultimate collapse" that has followed inflation programs in other countries can be avoided, in the opinion of Frederick W. Gehle, second vice president of the Chase National Bank, who addressed a meeting of the Government Club, at the Hotel Astor yesterday.

The new Commodity Exchange, Inc., became operative at yesterday's market opening. It represents a merger of the Rubber Exchange of New York, the National Metal Exchange, the National Raw Silk Exchange and the New York Hide Exchange, the members of each of which now have full privileges of trading in any of six commodities.

Miss Virginia Morris, 32 years old, who came here from Washington on Saturday for a week-end visit, plunged to her death yesterday afternoon from the window of her room on the eighth floor of the Peter Stuyvesant Hotel, Central Park West and Eighty-sixth Street, after dangling for a moment in the grasp of a friend who had caught her by the left foot as she jumped.

BALTIMORE, May 1 -- The Spring meeting of the Maryland Jockey Club began at Pimlico today with a benefit racing program, featured by the Linstead Steeplechase, which went to John Barry Ryan's Senado. The victor, which cost $50,000 as a juvenile, making his first start as a jumper, won by two lengths.

PHILADELPHIA, May 1 -- A lot of baseball rules went by the board today as old and new members of the Phillies got together for a ball game and jubilee, celebrating the club's fiftieth anniversary of National League membership.
Plaintiffs bid in all of the dozen properties offered in foreclosure auctions yesterday. Three of the parcels were in Manhattan and nine in the Bronx.

WASHINGTON, May 1 -- The assassination of President Sanchez Cerro will apparently raise no question of recognition of his successor. General Oscar Benavides, by the United States. The selection of General Benavides to fill the three and a half years remaining of President Sanchez Cerro's term of office was carried out under the provisions of the Peruvian Constitution covering such contingencies, according to information received at the State Department today.

Holders of bonds on which coupons were due yesterday and which contain the familiar clause, "principal and interest payable in United States gold coin of the present standard of weight and fineness," failed to obtain any gold coin in instances in which it was asked for.

BERLIN, May 1 -- As the climax to a labor celebration unprecedented in Germany Chancellor Adolf Hitler tonight addressed more than 1,000,000 persons at Tempelhof Field in a speech expected to outline his government's economic program. Yet except for one or two outstanding obiter dicta he outlined no definite program whatever.
The opening of "It Happened Tomorrow," which had been scheduled for this evening at the Ritz Theatre, has been set back indefinitely.

Realty interests announced yesterday that they would join the concerted fight on Park Commissioner John E. Sheehy's projected athletic development on the Central Park reservoir site, which will be launched tomorrow at a conference of representatives of twentyfive organizations, civic, artistic end commercial.

PHILADELPHIA, May 1 -- A lot of baseball rules went by the board today as old and new members of the Phillies got together for a ball game and jubilee, celebrating the club's fiftieth anniversary of National League membership.
Plaintiffs bid in all of the dozen properties offered in foreclosure auctions yesterday. Three of the parcels were in Manhattan and nine in the Bronx.

WASHINGTON, May 1 -- The assassination of President Sanchez Cerro will apparently raise no question of recognition of his successor. General Oscar Benavides, by the United States. The selection of General Benavides to fill the three and a half years remaining of President Sanchez Cerro's term of office was carried out under the provisions of the Peruvian Constitution covering such contingencies, according to information received at the State Department today.

CHICAGO, May 1 -- Bulls gave the wheat market another whirl upward at the opening today, the December rising as much as 2 1/2 cents from Saturday's finish and all deliveries reaching new high marks for the season. However, traders who had profits of about 10 to 15 cents a bushel in a relatively short time were disposed to accept them, putting a brake on the advance.

May Day Over the World. NEW YORK -- Fifty thousand radicals took part in parades and Union Square meetings with only one arrest made by the heavy police guard; Socialists and Communists fraternized in common denunciation of Hitler.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., May 1. -- An attack on the work of the Westchester County Recreation Commission was opened here today during a session of the Board of Supervisors, at which William B. Folger, Budget Commissioner, was instructed to make a survey of all county departments with a view to effecting economies.

A report of the General Board of the Navy urges that forty-three warships be laid down before Dec. 31. The purpose in view is to bring the fleet up to the ratios allowed by the Washington and London treaties. The General Board is satisfied with the battleship class, but points out that in auxiliaries the United States is inferior to Great Britain and to Japan.

Despite heavy profit taking, stocks and commodities continued their upward movement yesterday, reaching the highest prices of the year, while the dollar fell again to new low levels in the foreign exchange markets.

Victor Ridder, secretary of the Staats-Herold Corporation, returned on the North German Lloyd liner Bremen yesterday from an unofficial good-will misson to Germany where he went April 8 with Colonel Herman Metz.

The venture of a government, even prospectively, into currency depreciation, has always led to awkward problems not foreseen. One of them has suddenly arisen as a result of the decline of 15 to 16 per cent below gold parity in the foreign exchange market's valuation of the dollar.

In the signing by Governor Lehman last week of four bills vitally affecting the interests of architects and engineers in New York State, a wider recognition has been given of the status of architects and engineers and the relation of those two professions to the public welfare, said Dr. D.B. Steinman yesterday.

The second annual World Bridge Olympic tournament, played simultaneously all over the world with hands sent out from New York, began last night at 8 o'clock. Sixteen deals, prepared by a committee of experts, all excluded from the play, were opened by previous arrangement in some forty or more countries and played with the perfect (or par) score decided upon by the experts as goals.

FRANKLIN, N.J., May 1 -- Mrs. Mary Stefkovitch, 39 years old, who had been released on parole last week from a hospital for the insane attacked her five children with an axe at her home here today, and then fled into the woods of the Beaver Lake mountains.

WASHINGTON, May 1 -- With J. Pierpont Morgan, Otto H. Kahn, Clarence Dillon and other prominent bankers to be called as witnesses, the Senate Banking and Currency subcommittee's investigation into Wall Street operations will be resumed May 23.

WASHINGTON, May 1. -- With virtually no debate and the adoption of only three comparatively minor amendments, the Senate today approved the House bill providing for the distribution of $500,000,000 of Federal funds in unemployment relief grants.
WASHINGTON, May 1. -- In the United States Court of Customs and Patent Appeals today the following proceedings were nad:
There was no evidence of depression at the Spring dinner-meeting of the Interclub class of Sound racing sloops, held last night at 145 West 44th Street.
LEMARS, Ia., May 1 (AP) -- Sweeping swiftly through seven Northwestern Iowa counties in search of suspects in last week's farm riots, National Guardsmen had arrested more than sixty persons tonight.

Economic conditions have considerably thinned the American writers' colony in Paris, many having returned to America, where they can live just about as well now for the same money, while some others have gone to Spain, Peter Neagoe, editor of the anthology "Americans Abroad," and former editor of The New Review, said yesterday.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., May 1 -- The return of Ben Bacon, veteran No. 6 oar, to the Harvard varsity crew resulted in several changes in the Crimson eight today. Ted Yeomans, who rowed at 6 in last Saturday's Compton Cup regatta, moved back to No. 2, while John Pierce, who was at No. 2, went to the jayvee boat.

The search for Irving Wexler, alias Waxie Gordon, missing New York racketeer who is under indictment for income-tax fraud, "can be rewarded" if Federal authorities will question two high officials in the Jersey City and Hudson County (N.J.) police forces about a conference they had on April 5 with an agent of Gordon, according to information sent yesterday to United States Attorney Harlan Besson in Trenton, N.J.

The estate of Mrs. Elizabeth Genevieve McEvoy Davis, better known as Bessie McCoy, who was the widow of Richard Harding Davis, novelist, was appraised yesterday at $37,709 gross and $18,265 net. Since she was not a resident of New York when she died at Cannes, France, on Aug. 16, 1931, only $290 in personal effects was taxable here.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In all of the editorial comments on the Copeland-Celler act which have come to my notice the writers have assumed that in this act Congress has restored to the physician his ancient privilege of prescribing medicinal liquors for patients who require them free from lay Federal control.

To the Editor of The New York Times: For more than thirty years it has been the custom of the City of New York to provide free band concerts weekly in the public parks of the five boroughs at a cost of approximately $95,000 in recent years.

Mrs. Duncan R. Linsley will give a tea this afternoon at the clubhouse of the Junior League of New York, 221 East Seventy-first Street, for members of the entertainment committees working in behalf of the dinner dance to be held May 10 in the roof garden of the St. Regis under the auspices of Auxiliary 6 of Stony Wold Sanatorium.
The first name is that of the debtor, the second that of the creditor and the date when Judgment was filed.

Independent taxicab operators, speaking through their recently organized taxicab emergency committee, announced yesterday their intention to voice their resentment at the city election in November if the Board of Aldermen adopts the code of taxicab regulations set up in the ordinance recently introduced by Alderman Dennis J. Mahon, Tammany's majority leader in the board.

The 1 per cent State sales tax which went into effect yesterday caused few difficulties for customers and for stores doing business on a cash or thirty-day basis. Both large and small stores included the levy in their prices, Without separate listing, and retailers featuring merchandise at fixed prices temporarily absorbed the levy.
WASHINGTON, May 1 (AP) -- The cause of the Akron disaster will ever remain in the "realm of conjecture," Judge Advocate Ralph G. Pennoyer today told a naval court of inquiry.

HANOVER, N.H., May 1 -- Dartmouth's baseball team sent a surprise battery against Princeton to day and easily won an Eastern Intercollegiate League game, 11-0, to tie with Harvard for second place in the standing.

WASHINGTON, May 1 (AP) -- A difference in the fiscal policies applied to holding corporations by the J.P. Morgan interests and those used by the Aluminum Company of America was revealed to the Federal Trade Commission today in its inquiry into the capital structure of the St. Lawrence Utilities Company.

The first of the women election inspectors indicted by the State grand jury for certifying false returns at the last elections were found guilty last night before Supreme Court Justice Daniel V. McNamee of willful neglect of duty. They are Mrs. Mary O'Brien, Democrat, and Mrs. Blanche S. Marcus, Republican, of the First Election District of the Nineteenth Assembly District, Manhattan.

ABOARD THE S.S. ILE DE FRANCE (bound for Havre), May 1 (AP) -- A tariff truce, as suggested last week by Norman H. Davis at a meeting of the World Economic Conference organizing committee, has not yet been definitely concluded, it was learned tonight from circles close to former Premier Edouard Herriot, who is returning to France after his White House economic discussions.
Sadie Cohen assigned the rents of 313 E. 17th St. to the Metropolitan Savings Bank, to further secure payment of a consolidated first mortgage of $50,000.

GENEVA, May 1 -- With the United States casting the deciding vote, the effectives committee of the World Disarmament Conference today reached the important decision that the Nazi storm detachments in Germany should not be counted as part of the army to be permitted to the Reich under the proposed disarmament treaty.

Persistent report that the American Theatre Society would soon, be dissolved were set at rest yesterday by the announcement that it would continue to operate next season in only five cities. The announcement was made for the American Theatre Society by the Theatre Guild, which with the Shuberts and Erlanger Amusement Enterprises, is an integral part of the society.

CHICAGO, May 1 -- Five big buildings in or close to the downtown district were bombed early today in what appeared to be the latest chapter in the war of rival racketeer gang's for domination of unions controlling the teaming and trucking industry of Chicago.

WASHINGTON, May 1 -- President Roosevelt entered his second week of economic discussions with representatives of foreign governments, in preparation for the World Economic Conference scheduled for London on June 12, by entertaining at dinner at the White House tonight Tomas A. Le Breton, Argentinian Ambassador to France and head of his country's delegation to these conversations.

WASHINGTON, May 1 -- Inclusion in the administration's Federal public works program of the sum of $46,000,000 to start construction on thirty warships, as part of the President's plan to stimulate industry, was revealed today by Secretary Swanson after a conference at the White House.

PARIS, May 1. -- With both dollar and sterling exchange again lower today, all eyes were turned to Washington, every one asking what the outcome was going to be. It is fully appreciated here the dollar situation today is not like that of the franc or sterling, when each in turn began to slide, but the results of gambling in exchange are feared.

THE suspicion around St. Petersburg, Fla., about six weeks ago was that Manager Bill McKechnie of the Braves let Ed Fallenstin stay with the club because the poor, thin fellow was too sick to send away. He couldn't eat and he couldn't sleep.

WASHINGTON, May 1. -- Armed with a technical report, Secretary Wallace will go tomorrow morning before the Senate Finance Committee in support of legislation introduced in both houses today which is designed to encourage the use of alcohol in gasoline by increasing the Federal tax on gasoline when not so blended.

WASHINGTON, May 1 -- Adjournment of Congress by the end of the first week of June, in advance of the convening of the World Economic Conference, was predicted by Senator Robinson of Arkansas, majority leader, after a conference with President Roosevelt today.
Former Governor Smith last night included Mayor O'Brien in a list of Democrats that he said had helped him build up his own record of achievement in public office.

A program of expansion of the activities of the United Parents Association for the coming year, to assist in maintenance of public education standards and to draw more fathers into the work, was outlined yesterday at the annual meeting of the city-wide organization, at the Park Central Hotel.

The funeral of Alexander Konta, banker, publicist and Hungarian-American leader, who died on Thursday in his seventy-first year, was held yesterday morning at St. Stephen's Roman Catholic Hungarian Church, 414 East Eighty-second Street.

With an advance sale of nearly 20,000 copies and an assured sale of many thousands more as the choice of the Book-of-the-Month Club for May. "As the Earth Turns," by Gladys Hasty Carroll is published today by Macmillan. A story of farm life in New England, it is the work of an author who was born in South Berwick, Me., in 1904, and had her first schooling while living on a Maine farm.

Thirty-two New York University co-ed athletes who earned varsity letters for their work during the past year as members of either the girls' swimming, field hockey, fencing or basketball teams were honored at the ninth annual N.Y.U.

WASHINGTON, May 1 -- Licenses for the export of gold to meet maturing government obligations or interest coupons on United States securities held abroad were refused by the Treasury today on the grounds that such export would not be in the public interest.

Rutland. The Rutland Railroad, which is controlled by the New York Central Railroad, obtained $64.818 freight revenue and $405 revenue from switching through the emergency freight surcharges in 1932. Gross revenues were $3,870,105 in 1932.

For the sixth, consecutive week automobile production has increased and the adjusted index for the week ended April 29 has advanced to 45.5 from 39.2 in the preceding week. For the corresponding week in 1932 the number was 34.7.
WASHINGTON, May 1 -- The Bureau of Navigation issued the following orders today, dated April 28:
BALTIMORE, May 1 -- William S. Walsh, State Insurance Commissioner, was named receiver today for the assets in Maryland of the National Surety Company.

The greatest default of a railroad obligation since the start of the depression took place yesterday upon the maturity of $34,548,000 St. Louis, Iron Mountain Southern Railroad first 4 per cent bonds. They are underlying: liens of the Missouri Pacific Railroad, which also defaulted on the interest due yesterday on its third D 4s of 1939, convertible debenture A 5 1/2s of 1949 and first and refunding G 5s of 1978.

The Columbia Journalist, year-book, of the Columbia University School of Journalism, which appears today on the Morningside Heights campus, attacks the award of one of the Pulitzer scholarships to Emanuel R. Freedman, an assistant of the faculty.

PARIS, May 1 -- Wall Street's rise on Saturday had a contagious effect on the Bourse today and while the dollar fell to 21.30 francs, the entire market list, excepting only rentes, moved sharply upward. Bank stocks, coal mines, steels, South African gold mines, Suez Canal and Canadian Pacific Railroad, all made substantial advances.

Morris S. Tremaine, State Controller, allotted at par yesterday $75,000,000 State of New York 3 per cent one-year notes, dated May 8, 1933, to fifty-four banks and investment houses. The Issue was substantially oversubscribed and the subscription books were closed at 3 P.M., with allotments ranging from $9,000,000 to $100,000.
WASHINGTON, May 1 -- Movements of vessels follow, all dates are May 1 unless otherwlse specified:

Quick response was given last month by the stock market to an improvement in business conditions and to the possibilities manifested in the inflationary measures proposed by the government by the sharpest advance in quotations for a month since August, 1929.

The New York Curb Exchange has removed from dealings twenty unlisted issues, it was announced yesterday. Eighteen of the issues were removed in line with the Exchange's policy to strike inactive stocks and bonds from the list of those dealt in on the Exchange.

PHILADELPHIA, May 1 -- The Pittsburgh Pirates brought their big bats and good pitching into the East for the first time this season today. With Floyd Vaugnan and Earl Grace contributing home runs, each with the bases loaded, Bill Swift shut out the Phillies, 10 to 0.

When Manager Bill Terry of the Giants returns to the game there is a strong possibility that he will forsake his familiar position at first base and play the outfield. This was learned yesterday from a source close to the Giant pilot.

BOGOTA, Colombia. May 1 -- The shots that killed President Sanchez Cerro of Peru were not fired as any one's revenge, but constituted an act of defense by the people, an inexorable fulfillment of a popular sentence, in the opinion of EI Tiempo, which publishes Aprista statistics of political shootings in the fifteen months of the Sanchez Cerro regime.

AURORA, 111., May 1 (AP) -- A crowd of 12,000 turned out today for the opening of the Chicago racing season and saw Michael Cunnanes's fleet gelded 4-year-old Vox Pop last to win by a neck in the featured $1,200 Aurora Inaugural Handicap at six furlongs.

Milton Aborn again waved the pennons of Gilbert and Sullivan last evening from the stage of the St. James Theatre. It was the second time this season, and his choice for the deathless role of revival was "Yeomen of the Guard." This one is not often performed -- it has not been seen here, at any event, in a matter of something over a decade.

James C. Quinn, Democrat, secretary-teasurer of the Central Trades and Labor Council of Greater New York, and Carroll Hayes, former municipal court justice and associate counsel of the Hofstadter legislative committee, a Republican, were named yesterday by Major O'Brien as two of the four members of the local beer control board.

Although the early strength in stocks and commodities yesterday was not sustained, the vitality of these markets indicated that the process of converting money into "equities" and staple products is continuing at a rapid rate. Coincidentally, the dollar depreciated further in the foreign exchange market so that, taking the day as a whole, there was faithful conformance to the now familiar inflation pattern.

A daring week-end theft of paintings from the Brooklyn Museum was revealed yesterday by Dr. William H. Fox, director of that institution, who asked the police to broadcast an international alarm for the thieves and their loot.

An imaginative burglar, who constructed an imitation safe of cardboard in a Western Union telegraph office at 1,045 East 163d Street, the Bronx, while he trundled the real safe into a rear room and tried to open it, was held without bail for the grand jury, charged with burglary and the possession of burglar's tools, by Magistrate Clapp in Morrisania court yesterday.
WASHINGTON, May 1 (AP). -- Five Important Federal positions, including those of Commissioner of Internal Revenue and Controller of the Currency, were filled today by President Roosevelt.

The twelve-story clubhouse of Brooklyn Elks Lodge 22, at Boerum Place and Livingston Street, built in 1928 at a cost of $6,000,000, was sold at auction yesterday at the Brooklyn Real Estate Exchange. The Manufacturers Trust Company, trustee for the bondholders of a $2,600,000 first mortgage on the property, obtained the property on a bid of $50,000.

WASHINGTON, May 1 -- Indications developed today of a division in the Cabinet between those who wish the administration's emergency program to link the proposals set forth in the national industrial recovery bill with a large program of public works, and taxes to amortize it, and those who wish to go "full speed ahead" on the public works program without further consideration of a larger measure.

WASHINGTON, May 1 -- Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt observed Child Health Day by making a radio appeal to parents, "in these difficult times," to give special thought to the surroundings, food and recreation of their children, and in her "press conference" by urging revision of teacher-training methods and of public school curricula in order to afford to all children cultural advantages now available only to the more fortunate few.

The first of the monthly index numbers of commodity prices, the calculation of Dun's Review, shows increase of 4 1/4 per cent in the average during April. It also shows an average nearly 1 per cent higher than that of the same date a year ago, a comparison which has not been presented by any monthly index number since the depression, began, except by that of last October.

"Always, with every crisis, there comes adequate leadership," the Rev. Dr. Joseph R. Sizoo, pastor of the New York Avenue Presbyterian Church, Washington, declared at the celebration of the golden anniversary of the Women's Board of Domestic Missions of the Reformed Church in America yesterday afternoon.

LONDON, April 24 -- On the continent of Europe people may think differently, but here in Great Britain the latest adventure of the dollar has not abated an iota form the general confidence in America.

The Oratorio Society will end its fifty-ninth season tonight with the presentation of the complete Bach B minor mass at Carnegie Hall. Albert Stoessel will conduct. Members of the New York University Glee Club will participate. Louise Lerch. Rose Bampton, Dan Gridley and Frederic Baer will be soloists.

LONDON, May 1. -- The report that Tokuzo Komai, Japanese member of the Manchukuo Privy Council, recently declared that the new Manchukuo tariff would be based on reciprocity with Japan and that Manchukuo's trade door would not remain open to States not recognizing her bad reactions in the House of Commons when the government was asked today what steps it was taking to protect British trade interests.

WASHINGTON, May 1 -- President Roosevelt may attend several sessions of the World Economic Conference in London in June. If his duties permit and the conference makes such progress as to warrant his presence he may address the conference, but not participate as a delegate.
ALBANY, May 1 -- Governor Lehman approved today the supplemental appropriation bill totaling $545,000.

There was a further substantial improvement in the banking situation in the last month, according to the May 1 review of credit and business conditions by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, published yesterday.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 1 (AP) -- Five Eastern eligibles for the Kentucky Derby arrived at Churchill Downs today, while several of the Western candidates were being groomed for a final test In the Preparation Purse, a mile event on tomorrow's card at the track.

Charles M. Schwab, chairman of the board of the Bethlehem Steel Company, and Mrs. Schwab, celebrated their golden wedding anniversary last night with a reception at their house at Riverside Drive and Seventy-third Street.

Declaring that Mayor O'Brien had opened the door to racketeering in farm produce at Wallabout Market in Brooklyn by signing a bill yesterday permitting speculators to operate in Farmers' Square, the Long Island farmers declared they would appeal directly to Governor Lehman to have all city markets placed under State control.

LONDON, May 1, 1933 -- The Anglo-Argentine trade agreement was signed at the Foreign Office today and will probably be laid before Parliament tomorrow. The agreement was signed for Great Britain by Walter Runciman, president of the Board of Trade, and for Argentina by Dr. Julio A. Roca, Vice President of the republic and head of the mission that negotiated the agreement.

Prices on the Cotton Exchange surged upward $2 a bale more yesterday under the broadest buying since the low prices that prevailed in the 1926-27 session. Orders poured into the market from all sections and the over-Sunday accumulation brought the heaviest initial trading in several years.

WASHINGTON, May 1 -- Blocked in the House today by stiff Republican opposition on immediate consideration of the inflation amendment to the farm bill, administration leaders put the issue in the hands of the Rules Committee, which promptly voted a special rule making the amendment the business of the House tomorrow.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Your editorial on the appointment of Sumner Welles as Ambassador to Cuba was a service to your public. More people take an interest and, if possible, a pride in our envoys than is suspected generally. It is gratifying to know that Mr. Welles's training, abilities and experience qualify him so thoroughly for the arduous post he has gone to fill.

TOKYO, Tuesday, May 2. -- Despite the increasing sharpness of Moscow's tone toward Manchukuo, Japanese officials remain confident that the Chinese Eastern Railway dispute will not involve the Russian and Japanese Governments.

CLEVELAND, May 1 (AP) -- Oral Hildebrand, Cleveland's sensational pitcher, who hurled a one-hit game his last time out, today shoved Chicago down into a tie with the Indians for third place, holding the White Sox to five hits while his team-mates pounded out ten for an 8-to-1 victory.

Acceptance of the resignation of Felix M. Warburg, banker and philanthropist, as a member of the board of trustees of the American Museum of Natural History, after a membership of twenty-three years, and the filling of the vacancy through the election of Mr. Warburg's son, Frederick M. Warburg, to the 1933 class of trustees, was announced yesterday by the museum after the Spring meeting of the board.

PROVIDENCE, May 1 -- Rhode Island voted, wet emphatically today, electing thirty-one delegates pledged to vote for repeal ratification at a constitutional convention to be held next Monday by a vote of 150,244 to 20,874.

MOSCOW, May 1 -- Moscow witnessed today the largest May Day celebration in the history of Soviet Russia. About a million Soviet soldiers, workers and peasants marched through Red Square and saluted Joseph Stalin as he stood with other government leaders on the terrace of the gleaming red granite tomb in which the body of Lenin is preserved.

The Foster Wheeler Corporation has sent a letter to the creditors of the International Combustion Engineering Corporation outlining the details of its recent offer for the properties of the latter company, which has been in receivership for several years.

Sir Wilfred Grenfell, who founded the Labrador Mission bearing his name forty years ago, arrived here yesterday with Lady Grenfell on the Cunard liner Franconia. He will sail for Labrador early in June on the mission's hospital boat, now moored at Southport, Mass., which will be manned by young men who have volunteered to aid in social and medical work.
PRINCETON, N.J., May 1 -- The Princeton tennis team blanked the Columbia netmen by 9 -- 0 today to register its third straight victory and hand the Lions their first setback of the season.

WASHINGTON, May 1. -- As President Roosevelt and his advisers neared completion today of a proposal to ask Congress for authority to reduce tariffs in making trade agreements with other countries, they found outright repeal of special duties written into the tax bill last year by a coalition of Democrats and Republicans would probably be necessary.

District Attorney Grain has decided not to be a candidate for renomination, it was learned yesterday, and already several aspirants are being groomed for the Tammany nomination for that position. The nomination will be made at the primary election in September, and the election for a full four-year term will be at the general election in November.

William P. Kenneally, Tammany leader of the Twelfth Assembly District, was charged yesterday with offering $150,000 backing for Samuel Rosoff's Manhattan Garbage and Ash Removal Company, which is expected to receive from the city a five-year contract for garbage removal in Brooklyn.

Time was when Americans would have been, a good deal set up in complacency at the sight of so many foreign delegates converging on Washington. They used to flock, when they had international errands, to London or Paris, with representatives of the United States going along.

TRENTON, N.J., May 1. -- Notice was served today on Arthur J.W. Hilly, Corporation Counsel of New York City, that New Jersey will move in the United States Supreme Court next Monday for permission to file a petition to have the municipality of New York held in contempt for alleged failure to comply with an order of the court that four incinerators to dispose of garbage be ready for operation before June 1.

LONDON, May 1. -- Viscount Knebworth, a Member of Parliament and pilot officer of the Auxiliary Air Force, and his observer. Aircraftsman Ralph. Harrison, were burned to death when their fast bomber crashed in flames at Hendon tonight.
PHILADELPHIA, May 1 -- After winning nineteen straight games, Albright College was beaten today by Temple University, 10 to 4. The Reading collegians suffered their last setback early in 1931.

Joe Savoldi scored his second successive New York victory when he threw Sammy Stein of Newark in the feature wrestling bout at the Seventy-first Regiment Armory last night. The match, listed to a finish, ended in 23 minutes and 40 seconds when the former Notre Dame grid iron star pinned his rival with a leg and body hold.

WASHINGTON, May 2. -- A Chicago woman, who thinks her remedies for ending the depression are better than those being enacted by Congress, got up in the House gallery today to say so, and considerably upset more than 200 members who were hearing the inflation plan explained.

When a General Sessions jury found three men, including a former policeman, guilty of a hold-up charge yesterday, Judge Collins, to convince the jurors that they had made no mistake in their verdict, broke precedent by reading the long police records of two of the men, which could not be admitted as evidence.

WASHINGTON, May 2. -- Walter C. Teagle, president of the Standard Oil Company of New Jersey, proposed to the House Labor Committee today that the shorter workweek bills before it be broadened to cover not only employes of industrial and manufacturing plants but also railroad workers, teachers, policemen, firemen, Federal civil service employes, clerks, stenographers "and everybody else for whose jobs thousands of qualified applicants are standing in line."

NEW HAVEN, Conn., May 2. -- Albie Booth's nine, the New Haven Chevies, today shut out the Yale University team, 8 to 0, before 5,500 specators. Several members of Booth's team were members of the New Haven Police nine which Yale defeated last week, 5 to 0.
ALBANY, May 2. -- Governor Lehman today signed the Robinson bill "sharpening the teeth" of the present law to curb illegal practice of dentistry.

WASHINGTON, May 2. -- A rewritten security regulation bill, embodying stronger-than-originallyprojected enforcement provisions to guard the public from fraudulent issues and designed to shed a bright light of publicity on new securities, will be reported tomorrow to the House.
The Society of Kentucky Women of New York celebrated the twenty-fifth anniversary of its founding with a luncheon yesterday in the Basildon Room of the Waldorf-Astoria.

The annual awards at the Art School of the National Academy of Design were made last night at the closing exercises in the academy's headquarters at Amsterdam Avenue and 109th Street. The day and night classes, which are free except for registration fees, have had enrolments this year totaling about 650 students.

WASHINGTON, May 2. -- Marking an important change in the policy of the bituminous coal mining industry, operators in the Illinois and Indiana fields will come here Thursday for a conference with Secretaries Ickes and Perkins with a view to obtaining assistance through legislation for the stabilization of the industry and the termination of wasteful competition between fields north and south of the Ohio River.

An appropriation of $1,000,000 for continued relief payments by the city to war veterans was approved yesterday by the committee of the whole of the Board of Estimate. It was indicated that another appropriation for the same purpose would be necessary in a few months.

CHICAGO, May 2. -- July wheat reached the highest price of the season today on the Board of Trade here after declining early. Buying by houses with Eastern connections absorbed the surplus offerings and the buying orders followed the market up.

AURORA, Ill., May 2 (AP). -- Golden West, W.R. Sailee's 7-year-old campaigner, won the Baker Hotel Purse, at a mile and furlong, feature on today's Aurora card. Running over a heavy track, Golden West won by two lengths from Happy Lad.

Testimony of a witness that most of his records covering transactions in 1931 as a specialist in Central Public Service Corporation securities had been thrown away, brought to a temporary halt yesterday the public inquiry of Attorney General Bennett into the listing practices of the New York Curb Exchange.

A board of twenty-one directors, most of whom are on the board of the National Surety Company, has been chosen for the new National Surety Corporation with the approval of the New York State Insurance Department and the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, the latter of which had the right to select seven of the members.

Many Americans have experienced the "hurt which honor feels " in the very uncertainty whether the United States Treasury will meet its obligations held abroad in the terms contracted. Maintaining good faith with all nations has been so fixed and cardinal a principle for this country since the days of GEORGE WASHINGTON that even a threatened departure from it touches a sansitive nerve.

A recommendation that the three leading American Jewish organiza- tions unite in their efforts to protect Jewish rights throughout the world provoked much discussion at the opening session of the thirty-third annual convention of the rabbinical assembly of the Jewish Theological Seminary yesterday, afternoon.

Railroad liens and United States Government bonds formed about the strongest sections of yesterday's bond market. The finish was irregularly higher in trading that exceeded $16,000,000. Foreign loans were slightly reactionary following Monday's sharp advances.
LEMARS, Iowa, May 2. -- Defiance to the military patrolling two sections of Western Iowa following last week's farm rioting came late today from the Cherokee County prosecutor.

They did not sound taps last night at Hardluck-on-the-River, the largest squatters' colony in the city. They stood about listlessly, hands in their pockets, puffing cigarettes. They talked and talked, and then, with no words left, turned in for the night, wondering how many other nights they were to have in Hardluck.

WASHINGTON, May 2. -- Gold hoarders today challenged the authority of the government to take their gold in exchange for other currency, following the expiration yesterday of the time limit set by the government for the return of the metal.

When HENRY FAIRFIELD OSBORN, who has just made his last report as President of the Natural History Museum, explained to the Chinese authorities what it is, he was described in their language as the "Presiding Officer of the House of Heavenly Creations."

James F. Murray Jersey City lawyer and candidate on a fusion ticket for Jersey City Commissioner, announced last night that he would submit information to United States Attorney George Z. Medalie in New York which he believed would help the Federal authorities to find Irving Wexler, alias Waxie Gordon, missing racketeer, who is wanted here for income-tax fraud.

Samuel Seabury, who was referee in the removal case against District Attorney Crain, and Samuel Untermyer, who defended him, are associate counsel in the litigation against the City of New York to prevent the Board of Estimate from giving the garbage and ash removal contract for Brooklyn to Samuel Rosoff's Manhattan Ash Removal Company, it was announced yesterday.

BERLIN, May 2. -- The national resurgence, acting through the plenary power of Bernhard Rust, the Prussian Minister of Education, has eliminated twenty-two more scientists and scholars from the faculties of the University of Berlin.

TOKYO, May 2. -- "I am going to Washington to listen and cooperate," said Viscount Kikujiro Ishii in an interview with this correspondent tonight after his instructions had been agreed upon in a final conference with the government.

A decision of importance to all civil service employes and to members of the Police and Fire Departments, particularly relating to the right of disabled war veterans to promotion, was handed down yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Aaron J. Levy.

LONDON, May 2. -- The foreign change market here is still ertic. From an overnight quotation of $3.88 to the pound, the dollar rate weakened to $3.92 and later approved to close at $3.89 1/2. Francs so were erratic, improving and en weakening.

As an object lesson to violators of the election law, Federal Judge John C. Knox sentenced yesterday two Democrats and two Republicans, who had served as election inspectors last November in the Fourth Assembly District, to serve two years each in Northeastern Penitentiary, Lewisburg, Pa.

WASHINGTON, May 2. -- The old policy of isolation and high tariffs has broken down, and today this country, as well as others, depends on exports of basic commodities, said Secretary Hull at the dinner of the American section of the International Chamber of Commerce at the Hotel Mayflower here tonight.
WASHINGTON, May 2. -- The War Department issued the following orders today:

The necessity of building a "disposition of restraint" as a fortification against a world of "sentimentality and slush" is discussed by Dr. Samuel S. Drury, headmaster of St. Paul's School, Concord, N.H., in his new book, "School, Home Co.," published today by Farrar Rinehart.

WASHINGTON, May 2 (AP). -- President Roosevelt today nominated Oscar L. Chapman of Denver to be Assistant Secretary of the Interior. He also sent to the Senate the names of Jed C. Adams of Texas to be a member of the Board of Tax Appeals and Henry H. McPike to be Federal Attorney for the Northern District of California.

To the Editor of The New York Times: It is pleasant to turn from political and financial turmoil to a calm avenue wherein dwell accomplishments by well-meaning and well-acting public-spirited citizens.

LIMA, May 2. -- All banks and commercial houses in Lima were closed today in mourning for President Luis M. Sanchez Cerro, who was assassinated Sunday. Flags on the principal buildings were at halfmast and a gun boomed every half hour.

BERLIN, May 2. -- The Boerse today was altogether under the influence of Chancellor Hitler's speech yesterday when he announced a large program of public works. Although this program was without specification, stocks, especially those of key industries, soared above their old levels, which in many quarters already were believed to be higher than entirely warranted by the slow pace of business improvement.

TRENTON, N.J., May 2. -- By a vote of 31 to 21, the House passed today the bill by Assemblyman Siracusa of Atlantic County, prohibiting telephone companies from charging extra fees after the first year for use of "French" telephones and requiring them to furnish service to customers having their own equipment.
NEW HAVEN, May 2. -- Yale junior fraternities will receive more members than formerly, beginning with the May selections, and will receive sophomores in October instead of December.

WASHINGTON, May 2. -- Impetus was given preparations for the World Economic and Monetary Conference today, when the French Government announced, through Ambassador de Laboulaye, that it had accepted the proposal of the United States, presented by Norman H. Davis at London, for a tariff truce.

Sir Walter Layton, editor of The London Economist, declared here yesterday that stabilization of the dollar and the pound at a new level and on a gold basis, as envisaged after the recent Roosevelt-MacDonald conferences at the White House, represents a formidable but not impossible task.
SHANGHAI, May 2. -- Dmitri Bogomoloff, the Soviet Ambassador, presented his credentials today to the Nanking Government, represented by President Lin Sen and Dr. Lo Wen-kan, the Foreign Minister.

A tattered strip of a silken flag, a bit of the Stars and Stripes that Admiral Robert E. Peary cached in a cairn in the Far North years ago, will be returned on Saturday to his daughter, Mrs. Marie Ah-ni-ghi-to Peary Stafford, at a luncheon at the American Geographical Society.

ABOARD STEAMSHIP MAJESTIC IN NEW YORK BAY, May 2. -- Anchored in a fog so thick that searching tugboats have been unable to find the world's largest liner, 243 passengers who were scheduled to land this noon were still fog bound on New York's doorstep late tonight, with little prospect of getting ashore before 8 o'clock tomorrow morning.

HARWICHPORT, Mass., May 2. -- Kidnappers today lured 10-year-old Margaret McMath, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Neil C. McMath, formerly of Detroit, from a school here and disappeared with her in an automobile.

ABOARD THE S.S. BERENGARIA, Bound for Southampton, May 2. -- The weather this morning was damp and cold. Prime Minister MacDonald was unable to play his usual game of shuffleboard with his daughter until afternoon, when a hot sun and a blue sky transformed the scene.

When Central Park was first planned, some feared that such a public ground might develop "riot- ous and licentious habits." An ed- itorial in The Herald of 1858 pre- dicted that it would be "nothing "but a great bear-garden for the "lowest denizens of tha city."

The first case of hijacking in New York City since the enactment of legislation making 3.2 per cent beer legal was reported to the police yesterday. The theft which followed the kidnapping of a truck driver and his Negro helper, netted the hijackers ninety half-barrels and six one-quarter barrels of beer valued at $1,008.
The Police Department called upon an expert within its ranks yesterday to direct the hunt for the thieves who stole ten old masters from the Brooklyn Museum last Saturday night or Sunday morning.

Interchange of electric current between the New York City plants of the Consolidated Gas Company system and the up-State generating stations of the Niagara-Hudson Power Corporation was begun on Monday when 100,000 horsepower of up-State current was sent to New York City consumers in addition to the local product, it was announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 2. -- Authority to review applications for certain loans made to the Reconstruction Finance Corporation and to report upon the desirability of the loans will be asked of the Senate by the Banking and Currency Committee under a resolution adopted by the committee today.

The Treasury Department's full monthly report of the stock of all kinds of money in the United States as of April 1 shows the following principal changes in March. Gold earmarked for foreign banks is deducted; gold released from earmark is added:

The National Bridge Association made public yesterday the pars, or perfect scores, on the sixteen bridge hands that tested the bridge-playing ability of the 100,000 or more persons who competed Monday night in the world's bridge Olympic.

Plans for Ratification Week, under the auspices of the New York State Division of the Women's Organization for National Prohibition Reform, from next Monday through Saturday, were announced yesterday.

The Shell Union Oil Corporation reports for 1932 a consolidated net profit of $660,076 after expenses, depreciation, depletion, intangible development expenditures, taxes and interest. This was equal to $1.65 a share on 400,000 shares of 5 1/2 per cent cumulative preferred stock of $100 par value.
PARIS, May 2. -- The draft budget, as amended by the Finance Commission, was put today before the Senate, which will open discussion on it Thursday.
Reflecting the seasonal May moving activity, a large volume of business leases was reported yesterday. The bulk of the Manhattan activity was on the west side of the midtown area.

BERLIN, May 2. -- In the absence of a more specific announcement of the government's immediate economic and social relief measures, Chancellor Hitler's "programmatic speech" at the labor festival at Tempelhof Field last night is generally received in political and business circles as indicating the National Socialist government is more concerned about consolidating its political authority than in tackling the economic and other problems awaiting urgent solution.

While prices on the Cotton Exchange reflected liberal profit-taking yesterday, broad buying movements from both speculative and trade quarters absorbed contracts readily, and closing quotations were 1 to 5 points higher. An early setback of around 8 1/4 cents a pound for October attracted active buying, while strength in outside markets brought a recovery to the high records of the week.

HEIDELBERG, May 2. -- Foreign students of every race and religion will be as welcome as ever at Heidelberg University, your correspondent was assured yesterday by Gustaf Adolf Scheel, leader of the student storm troops division which has been appointed by the government to head German studenthood.

Real estate interests owning or controlling most of the high-class properties east and south of Central Park joined actively yesterday in the growing protest against Park Commissioner John E. Sheehy's proposed conversion of the abandoned reservoir site in the park to baseball and other sports.
