BOSTON, May 2 (AP). -- The La Varre Brazilian-Guiana Expedition, bound on a mission of discovery and exploration, sailed from Boston today for the little-known region at the headwaters of the Essequibo River deep in the jungles of British Guiana.

Brig. Gen. George R. Dyer, commanding the Eighty-seventh Brigade, New York National Guard, reviewed the Seventy-first Regiment for the last time last night at the regiment's armory, Thirtyfourth Street and Park Avenue.

George Lee pitched St. John's College to its second victory over City College yesterday at Dexter Park, where the Redmen won by a 7-to-6 score. The Indians outhit their opponents, 12 to 4 and would have won by a wider margin had not Lee walked seven batters.

Buyers' Registrations Down. The number of buyers registered in the market during the week ended yesterday was lower than in the preceding week or the corresponding week a year ago, according to the lists published in THE TIMES.

An appeal to double the present membership of the American Museum of Natural History was voiced yesterday by its president, F. Trubee Davison, at a reception in the institution's Hall of Ocean Life. The meeting was a part of the program of the museum's annual members' day.

Edgar T. Appleby of New York gained undisputed possession of first place in the world's amateur 18.1 balkline billiard championship tournament at the Brooklyn Elks Club by defeating Theodore Moons of Belgium, 300 to 265, in forty-six innings, last night.

Detectives Investigating the murder of Michael J. Nevins, who was found late Monday night in Weeks Lane near Forty-ninth Avenue, Bayside, Queens, with two bullets through his head, said last night they had learned Nevins was employed as a salesman by a Brooklyn brewery and that they had definitely linked the slaying to the "beer racket."

WASHINGTON, May 2 (AP) -- Testimony that the Cities Service Securities Company suffered a gross loss of $5,819,920.63 in marketing operations "sustaining the market price of the voting common stock" of the Arkansas Natural Gas Corporation in 1929 and 1930 was given before the Federal Trade Commission today by Dr. William D. Mitchell, a commission examiner.

Dr. Lion Feuchtwanger's German publishers have withdrawn his newest novel, "Josephus," from sale in Germany, justifying this action on the grounds that Feuchtwanger attacked the present German regime in an article that recently appeared in English newspapers, according to the Viking Press, Dr. Feuchtwanger's American publishers.

MR. FLOYD CAVES HERMAN, late of Brooklyn, later still of Cincinnati and now of Chicago, was halted as he was about to stroll toward the Polo Grounds yesterday. It is always a treat to take part in a discussion with Floyd. He has original ideas.

After its State College had made tests to prove that gasoline with 10 per cent alcohol could be burned after a fashion in an automotive engine, Iowa saw a rainbow. Corngrowing farmers could prosper if alcohol, distilled solely from agricultural products, were legislated into every fuel tank.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 2. -- Mrs William Crump's Head Play, the West's chief hope for Kentucky Derby honors, qualified handsomely for his engagement in Saturday's classic and his clash with Ladysman, pride of the East, when he accounted for the Preparation Purse, feature today at Churchill Downs.

The Oratorio Society, Albert Stoessel conductor, grave last night in Carnegie Hall its annual performance, the seventh in its history, of the complete Bach B minor Mass. The work was performed with a half hour's intermission between the two parts, and without applause except at the end of each section.

LIMA, Peru, May 2. -- The assassination of President Sanchez Cerro on Sunday was described in an official statement today as a part of a widespread terrorist plan, details of which are being investigated by the Ministry of the Interior.

Organization of the New York City Beer Control Board was completed yesterday with the appointment of Joseph H. Choate Jr., lawyer, of 10 East Ninety-fourth Street, a Republican, and Mrs. Frances Fitzpatrick of 990 Woodycrest Avenue, the Bronx, a Democrat.

A large group of New York society's best-dressed women, and women of the stage and screen noted for the clothes they wear, acted as models at a fashion show for the benefit of the Emergency Exchange Association yesterday afternoon at the house of Mrs. Payne Whitney, 972 Fifth Avenue.

LONDON, May 2. -- "A calculated breach of contract" is the way The Financial Times characterizes the refusal of American paying agents to recognize the right claimed by British bondholders to payment of their coupons at the full gold equivalent.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I am a woman 51 years of age. I began work when I was 14 years old. Two years ago I lost the position I had held for several years. I never married and always depended upon myself. I was frugal in the use of my earnings, and what I managed to save, with accumulated interest thereon, amounted about a year ago to about $31,000.

WASHINGTON, May 2. -- A conference on the proposed national industrial recovery act, providing for complete control of industry under government supervision, was held in Senator's Wagner's office this afternoon. A subcommittee was named which arranged to meet again tomorrow.
BOSTON, May 2 (AP). -- Long home runs by Leo Durocher and Ernie Lombardi today enabled the Cincinnati Reds to open their first Eastern invasion with a 2-1 victory over the Boston Braves.

With the market for shares backing and filling, Wall Street saw evidence yesterday of a more cautious attitude on the part of speculative interests. Traders began to take soundings, evidently anxious to know whether their enthusiasm for the promised inflation had carried them too far.

ALBANY, May 2. -- Governor Lehman questioned the wisdom today of approving the Wicks bill, which provides that the State Industrial Commissioner and the fiscal officers of municipalities shall include the prevailing rate of wages as part of the contracts for public work.

Mayor O'Brien refused yesterday to indicate what action he would take if the Board of Aldermen enacts the pending ordinance for regulation of the taxicab industry under a code which would make possible a limitation on the number of cabs.

William B. Storey resigned yesterday as president of the Atchison, Topeka Santa Fe Railway and was succeeded by S.T. Bledsoe, chairman of the executive committee and general counsel. Mr. Storey will remain on the board of directors and on the executive committee for the ensuing year.

The engagement of ten new singers, five of them Americans, and confirmation of the report that the two outstanding novelties in the 1933-34 opera season will be "Merry Mount" and "Salome," were announced yesterday by Giulio GattiCasazza, general manager of the Metropolitan Opera.

WASHINGTON, May 2. -- The independent offices supply bill, with savings of $467,741,045 in the agencies appropriated for and with authority for President Roosevelt to add a list of specific items to his economy program, was reported to the House today by the Appropriations Committee.

The adjusted index of steel mill activity advanced to 26.5 for the week ended April 29 from 24.1 in the preceding week. Last year's figure was 25.4. The index now stands at the highest since the week ended May 21, 1932, which was the peak of the Spring rise, when it recorded 28.5.

ST. JOHN'S Nfld., May 2. -- Esperio Emilio of the 'Italian Royal Air Force has completed inspection of Shoals Harbor, Trinity Bay, which will be used as a landing place by General Italo Bilbo's armada of twenty-four seaplanes on their return flight from the World's Fair at Chicago.

After some hours of confusion and indecision, the share market resumed the advance in the late dealings yesterday with enough vigor to overcome the effects of an earlier realizing movement. An active demand for railway stocks gave strength to the whole market in the final hour.

Figures Hardly Significant. Decidedly mixed is the poll on antiwar sentiment in the colleges, as published by the National Student Federation. Sex is not a determinant, with Vassar near- ly 4 to 1 against war, Connecticut College 3 to 1 against war, Wellesley 5 to 3 against war, but Smith 2 to 1 for war.

WASHINGTON, May 2. -- Mustering an apparently overwhelming majority in support of inflation, the House today blocked the Republican opposition to the currency section of the farm relief bill, concluded its debate of the measure and will vote early tomorrow under a rigid rule, forbidding any amendment.

A sharp rise in manufacturing failures featured business defaults for the week ended April 27, the number increasing to 109, as against 89 in the preceding week, according to Dun Bradstreet, Inc. Retail embarrassments rose slightly, totaling 282, as compared with 279 in the week before.

Daily average gross crude oil production in the United States last week was 2,383,100 barrels, compared with 1,795,500 in the preceding week, a gain of 587,600 barrels, according to the American Petroleum Institute. The increase was due almost entirely to the reopening of the East Texas field, which in the five days during which it was open produced an amount sufficient to make an average of 550,000 barrels daily for the entire week.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., May 2. -- The Eastman School of Music opened its third annual festival of American music tonight with a per- formance in the Eastman Theatre. The Eastman school orchestra of ninety-seven players, Samuel Belov, conductor, and the Eastman school chorus of 250 voices, Herman H. Genhart, director, gave the performance.

More than 100 dinner guests tried to outwait the fog last night at the Army and Navy Club while the Majestic, bearing the guest of honor, General Roman Gorecki, lay at Quarantine. The harbor fog even impounded the toastmaster of the dinner, Commander Charles Hann Jr., who had gone down the bay to meet the guest of honor and had boarded the Majestic from the revenue cutter.

PARIS, May 2. -- The French press today in general dismisses Adolf Hitler's May Day speech in Germany as "empty demagoguery." Only two points he made, his proposal for compulsory manual labor and his big program of public works, elicited any extended comment.

WASHINGTON, May 2. -- Depleted incomes last year offsat the drastically increased tax rates of the 1932 revenue act, and so revenues from income taxes in March fell below the corresponding period of last year, according to Treasury figures given out today.

BERLIN, May 2. -- A stunning blow to Socialist-organized labor was dealt today when Nazi storm troopers suddenly occupied all premises throughout Germany of the free trade unions, whose aggregate membership is about 4,000,000.

The Fifty-seventh Street Fair in behalf of the New York Cancer Committee and the Cancer Insti- tute was opened formally at Joseph, 3 East Fifty-seventh Street, yesterday by Mrs. Samuel Adams Clark, who headed the group in charge of the arrangements, with the assistance of Mrs. Julius H. Browne and Mrs. Frederick L. Richards.

For the first time in eight years, victory in the annual competition for the Prix de Rome award in painting failed to go this year to the Yale School of Fine Arts, although the award in sculpture, which has gone to students of this institution with less regularity in past years, was given to a Yale man.
An investment deal involving fifteen tenement houses on the west side of Manhattan was announced yesterday. All are five-story buildings and occupy sites ranging from Sixteenth to 114th Street.

The experiment or raising sharptailed grouse and prairie chickens in captivity, which was begun last February by the More Game Birds Foundation at its 1,500-acre breeding farm at Clinton, N.J., has proved highly successful, according to a report made yesterday by Arthur M. Bartley, director of field activities of the foundation.
NEW YORK. Mrs. Edward R. Stettinius has returned from Bermuda and is at 960 Fifth Avenue until the end of the month, when she will go to her country place in Locust Valley.

Problems of the intercoastal waterborne trade remained unsolved yesterday as member lines of the intercoastal steamship conference completed two weeks of discussion at the conference headquarters, 44 Whitehall Street. The meetings will be resumed today, it was said, but any indication of the status of the controversies under consideration was withheld.

Under the direction of Henry Hadley the Musicians' Symphony Orchestra presented a varied program last night at its concert in the Metropolitan Opera House. The soloists of the evening were Henri Deering, pianist, who played Franck's "Symphonic Variations" with the orchestra, and John Charles Thomas, baritone, appearing next season in opera at the Metropolitan, who sang Marx's "Der Ton," Brahms's "O liebliche Wangen" and "Eri Tu" from Verdi's "Ballo in Maschera."

A late flurry in the railroad stocks on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday sent many of these issues to new high levels for the year. Other rail issues were for the most part firm. Increased carloadings in the West, attributed to the moves for inflation of prices, and the prospect of remedial railroad legislation contributed to the strength of the railway shares.

LONDON, May 2. -- Lord Trenchard, after eighteen months as the Chief Commissioner of the London Police, issued a startling report today alleging attempts had been made at "subsidized insubordination" among his force of 20,000 policemen and charging "deliberate fomenting of discontent against the government."

Six awards, totaling $25,000, made by the Woodrow Wilson Foundation for "significant achievement in the field of international relations," were announced yesterday by Roland S. Morris of Philadelphia, president of the foundation, following the annual meeting in the Woodrow Wilson Memorial Library at 6 East Thirty-ninth Street.

Behind the three-hit pitching of Xavier Rescigno, sophomore star, the Manhattan baseball team defeated New York University, 7 to 2, before 1,200 persons at Manhattan Field yesterday. The game ended the Violet streak of eight straight victories and marked its first setback of the season.

The proposal to build a $40,000,000 bridge between Old Ferry Point, the Bronx, and Whitestone Landing, Queens, with private capital was attacked before the Board of Estimate's committee of the whole yesterday by Norman Thomas, Socialist leader, on the ground that private interests would gain large profits which should go to the city.

Loans to railroads made or authorized by the Railroad Credit Corporation as of April 30 were $67,308,868, according to the monthly report of E.G. Buckland, president of the corporation and chairman of the New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad.
Several flats were included in the New Jersey realty turnover reported yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 2. -- President Roosevelt was asked today by the Executive Council of the American Federation of Labor, headed by William Green to urge upon the special session of Congress a public works construction program of not less than $5,000,000,000, the enactment of the six-hour day and five-day week bill, and legislation to stabilize the coal mining industry.

Guide Jung, Italian Minister of Finance, arrived here yesterday on the Conte di Savoia to confer with President Roosevelt on problems of world recovery in the series of conversations now being held by the President with leading statesmen of various nations preparatory to the World Economic Conference.

MONTREAL, May 2 (AP). -- Rain, which ended the game in the ninth inning, enabled the Montreal Royals to defeat the Newark Bears, 1 to 0, in a smart mound duel between Stony Michaels and Charley Devens, which marked the Royals' home opener before 7,000 fans today.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The intelligent and courageous speech of Senator Glass opposing the plan of the administration on inflation should be supported by every good citizen. The obvious purpose of the measure is to raise prices, especially for the heavily indebted farmers.

MADRID, May 2. -- A conflict specifically over the religious question but generally over the whole policy of the government arose in the Cortes this afternoon and is expected to terminate either in the eventual fall of the Socialist-dominated Left Wing coalition of Premier Azana or in the use of force, either by the Left Wing or the Conservatives.

Former Governor Alfred E. Smith declares a large Federal bond issue for public works should precede any attempt at monetary inflation in his editorial in the current New Outlook, made public yesterday. Emphasizing the difficulty of controlling monetary inflation, he urges, besides the Federal bond issue, additional gifts and subsidies to the States and municipalities for highway construction and local public works.
WASHINGTON, May 2. -- A Senate vote on the Muscle Shoals bill, already passed by the House, was postponed another day while opponents continued their fight against the measure.

WASHINGTON, May 2. -- "A bedtime story" they said at the White House when asked for light on the report that the President may run over to London to speak at the fin- ish of the World Economic and Monetary Conference.

Prices on the local commodity exchanges slumped yesterday at the opening trading, and although they made a recovery later, they ended the day with small losses in most cases. Trading was somewhat less active than on Monday. The feature of the cash markets was an advance in spot wheat at New York to more than $1 a bushel for the first time since 1930.

BERLIN, May 2. -- Nazi storm troopers, acting today on orders of the National Socialist shop cells organization, topped off yesterday's May Day wooing of German labor by seizing all offices throughout Germany of the free labor unions, the chief bulwark of the Socialist party.

Rochester, N.Y. A syndicate headed by the Guaranty Company of New York will offer today a new issue of $2,250,000 city of Rochester (N.Y.) 6 per cent bonds, due variously on May 1, 1934 to 1938, priced to yield 5.25 per cent.

TIENTSIN, May 2. -- It appears that American creditors of the Chinese Government Railways with claims for materials supplied totaling nearly $18,000,000 gold, long in arrears, are likely soon to effect a settlement bringing in as least $50,000 (Mexican) a month, at present the equivalent of $12,000 gold.

LONDON, May 2. -- One clause in the protocol attached to the Anglo-Argentine agreement tends to assure the Argentine coal market to British producers, while another clause gives promise of a reduction in tariffs against British goods to at least the 1930 level.

When Ellery Walter, writer and lecturer, was ending a lecture on "Hitler and Germany" under the auspices of the League for Political Education at Town Hall yesterday morning by asserting, with reference to Nazi anti-Semitism, that "There is persecution, but there is a whole lot more smoke than fire," and added that "Germany is a charming place; I say that in defense of Germany," he was interrupted by shouts from two men in the audience.

WASHINGTON, May 2. -- Approval of a three-year loan of $9,000,000 from the Reconstruction Finance Corporation was sought from the Interstate Commerce Commission today by the Chicago, Milwaukee, St. Paul Pacific Railroad. The applicant proposed to apply the proceeds to principal and interest on equipment trust certificates and interest on bonds.

The New York City League of Women Voters, in a letter sent yesterday to Mark Eisner, chairman of the Board of Higher Education, listed eleven outstanding women educators for consideration as "the type that should be sought" for a successor to Dr. James M. Kieran, president of Hunter College.

CHICAGO, May 2. -- Harold L. Stuart, president of Halsey, Stuart Co.; Stanley Field, Samuel Insull Jr. and fourteen others charged with using the mails to defraud in connection with the collapse of the $153,000,000 Corporation Securities Company were arraigned today before Federal Judge James H. Wilkerson.

WASHINGTON, May 2. -- Power companies mustered their forces before the Senate Finance Committee today in an effort to avert the shifting of the 3 per cent electric power tax from the consumers to the companies, as provided in the House bill which also continues the gasoline tax for another year and authorizes some reductions in postal rates.

"Best Sellers," the Edouard Bourdet play in which Peggy Wood and Ernest Truex are co-starred, will have its Broadway premiere this evening at the Morosco Theatre. Ian Keith and George Coulouris are featured.

CINCINNATI, May 2. -- Music Hall this evening was the scene of the opening concert of the thirtieth May Festival. An audience of encouraging proportions, and which included members of greater Cincinnati's population, ranging from the humblest to the most distinguished, as well as many visitors from other parts of the country, listened to the vast musical forces of the Festival Association in a magnificent presentation of Handel's oratorio, "Samson."

There will be no curtailment in P.S.A.L. competitions this Spring, although for a time yesterday it appeared likely that there would be an indefinite suspension of activities. Joseph Miller Jr., secretary of the Board of Education, announced, late in the day that "athletics will go on as heretofore in the public schools."

ALBANY, May 2. -- Transfer of stocks on the exchanges will be taxed at the rate of 3 cents a share for shares of no par value or a par value of less than $20 and at 4 cents on shares with a face or market value in excess of that amount under a bill signed yesterday by Governor Lehman.

WASHINGTON, May 2. -- President Roosevelt will keep his promise to former Mayor Cermak to go to Chicago early in June to open the World Fair. He made the promise a short time before Mayor Cermak was shot in an attempt on the life of Mr. Roosevelt in Miami.

DETROIT, May 2. -- The Yankees' opening dash of the year through the Mid-Western provinces got away on the wrong foot today with the result that the world's champions rode to an inelegant fall on Navin Field. The Tigers won, 3 to 2, and Charlie Ruffing, shooting for his fourth straight victory, missed his mark and suffered his first defeat of the campaign.

GENEVA, May 2 (AP). -- Germany, through Rudolph Nadolny, her chief delegate to the World Disarmament Conference, today disavowed "the opinion that Germany wishes to avail herself of disarmament to proceed with rearmament at the highest possible level."
WASHINGTON, May 2. -- The Bureau of Navigation issued the following orders today, dated April 29:

Pounding the Dodgers into submission with a barrage of fourteen hits that included home runs by Jimmy Wilson and Pepper Martin, Gabby Street's Cardinals took the opening game of the series at Ebbets Field yesterday, 13 to 4.
WASHINGTON, May 2. -- An exchange of radiograms between President Roosevelt and former Premier Herriot of France was made public by the State Department today.

Thorugh four years of depression the American people have main- tained their faith and today that faith is brighter than ever before, with "some evidence of dawn," Myron C. Taylor, chairman of the board of the United States Steel Corporation, told volunteers seeking funds for the Salvation Army United Appeal at a luncheon at the Bankers Club yesterday.

The James Monroe High School baseball team strengthened its hold on first place in the Upper Manhattan-Bronx division of the city P.S.A.L. senior high school championship competition by blanking Theodore Roosevelt High, 5 to 0, yesterday at Monroe Field.

Optimistic over the outcome of his mission, but reticent as to details, Henry Morgenthau Sr., former Ambassador to Turkey, who was designated on Monday to represent the United States at the wheat conference called by the League of Nations, sailed early this morning on the North German Lloyd liner Bremen, which will get him to Geneva in time for the opening of the conference on May 10.

Miss Helen Hicks, former national champion, scored a 76 to lead a field of sixty-six players in the opening one-day tournament of the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association at the Old Country Club, Flushing, L.I., yesterday. Her score was only two strokes over the record.

LA PAZ, Bolivia, May 2. -- The threat by President Ayala of Paraguay of reprisals against Bolivian prisoners as a result of the aerial bombing by Bolivian airplanes of Puerto Casado and Pinasco has aroused the anger of the Bolivian people and government.

Those who would have the President make free use of the powers given him by the inflation bill frequently argue that it is imperative in order to relieve an unbearable burden of long-term debt contracted on a higher level of prices. Estimates have run as high as $230,000,000,000.

ALBANY, May 2. -- New York State, under a bill signed by Governor Lehman today, will recognize no "common law" marriages contracted in the future. Existing marriages under the "common law" are not affected.

CHICAGO, May 2. -- A new set of officers today installed themselves in the racket-ridden Chicago Teamsters' Union. A band of ten, asserting that they represented the men who pay the dues, marched into the union quarters and told the incumbent officers that they "had looted the treasury long enough for the benefit of their gangster backers and now must go."

PARIS, May 2. -- Ten Atlantic liners will leave French ports this week for New York and all of them will have more passengers aboard than they have carried on westbound sailings during the early Spring season for the last three or four years.

BERLIN, May 3. -- A rebirth of religion throughout Germany and reform of the Protestant faith in the fullest sense of the word are the avowed aims of German Christians of National Socialist persuasion, who are now drafting a church constitution and will insist upon church elections soon in order to gain majorities in the synods.

MAETERLINCK'S "Double Garden" has in it nothing more pleasing to the reader than Mr. WHITE'S "Spirea and Things" in The Emporia Daily Gazette. One might believe that there is not a thing in the world "the matter with Kansas" when it is spirea week.

DENVER, May 3. -- Former Senator Charles S. Thomas of Denver, challenging the government's order to deliver gold from hoarding, served notice today on United States Attorney Ralph L. Carr that he has acquired $120 in gold for the avowed purpose of testing the government's authority.
Sixteen Manhattan and Bronx properties were bought in at foreclosure sales yesterday. Several of the defaulted holdings went to savings banks.

Further argument against the award by the Board of Estimate of the garbage and ash removal contract for 'Brooklyn to Samuel Rosoff's Manhattan Ash Removal Company was heard yesterday before Supreme Court Justice Valente when Samuel Untermyer and Samuel Seabury, representing different clients, but both opposing the award, assailed the action of the board.

A letter was delivered to Governor Lehman at Albany yesterday from George E. Roosevelt, chairman of the Real Estate Bondholders' Protective Committee, commending him for signing the act providing for the organization of a corporation to protect guaranteed mortgage certificate holders.
ALBANY, N. Y., May 3 -- The State license fee for Madison Square Garden is increased from $760 annually to $2,000 under the Devany bill signed today by Governor Lehman.

GENEVA, May 3. -- Progress toward an agreement on the effectives question was made at the disarmament conference this afternoon when Captain Anthony Eden of Great Britain and Rudolf Nadolny of Germany announced they had reached a compromise regarding militarized police.

BERLIN, May 3. -- Plans for bringing the powerful Federation of German Industries under Nazi control were announced today. Two Reich commissioners, Otto Wagner, a former army officer now on the staff of the National Socialist economic organization, and Alfred Moellers, a Nationalist, will compose the directorate of the federation, together with its president, Dr. Gustav Krupp von Bohlen und Holbach, head of the Krupp works at Essen.

MONTREAL, May 3 (Canadian Press). -- A rise in prices and an improvement in conditions in the United States resulting from controlled inflation "cannot fail to have a favorable effect in Great Britain, in all parts of the world and particularly in Canada," the Royal Bank of Canada says in its monthly news letter, made public today.

Some time back, it seems, M. Edouard Bourdet began brooding about the mad vagaries of those men of letters. He wrote on the subject a play called "Vient de Paraitre," which duly came beneath the scrutiny of Dorothy Cheston Bennett.

YOUNGSTOWN, Ohio, May 3. -- Iron and steel operations in this district, embracing the Mahoning and Shenango Valleys, have advanced this week 2 points to 33 per cent of capacity. Producers and consumers report growing activity. George C. Brainard, president, announced that the General Fire-proofing Company has again received the contract to supply steel for office furniture for the United States Government for the year beginning on July 1.

I have accepted the offer of presidency of the Title Guarantee and Trust Company of New York, one of the oldest and most substantial organizations of its kind in America. I shall take up my new duties on May 15. The involved real estate situation in New York, affecting millions of its citizens, will be my immediate concern in my new job.

BUENOS AIRES, May 3. -- Newspaper, banking and financial opinion here seems agreed that the treaty concluded in London opens the way for larger Argentine trade with Great Britain at the expense of the United States unless the United States enters into a similar reciprocal arrangement, although the full effect will not be felt until the negotiation of the supplementary agreement regarding tariffs.

LEMARS, Iowa, May 3 (AP). -- One of three eyewitnesses to the abduction and threatened hanging of District Judge C. C. Bradley told a military court today he had heard some of the 150 to 200 men who dragged the judge from his court room shout, "Get a rope! Let's hang him!"
WASHINGTON, May 3. -- President Roosevelt will send his public works program, involving probably about $1,500,000,000, to Congress early next week, it was indicated today.
NEW YORK Mrs. James Brown Potter has gone to Richmond, Va. She will return on May 17 to be at the St. Regis before sailing for Europe.

AURORA, Ill., May 3 (AP). -- O. C. Viau's Wood River, odds-on favorite, came from far behind today to win the Burlington Special, feature at Exposition Park. Kybo and Dreamy Belle were second and third.

WASHINGTON, May 3 (AP). -- Behind the wheel of an open sports car, Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt left today on a springtime holiday tour. The destination was unannounced, but she will arrive in New York in time for the farewell testimonial dinner to Ruth Bryan Owen, Minister to Denmark, next Tuesday night.

ROCHESTER, N. Y., May 3. -- The second concert of the Eastman School of Music festival of American music was given in Kilbourn Hall this evening. The capacity audience was definitely cordial. The program of chamber music was played by the Eastman School Little Symphony, made up of members of Phi Mu Alpha Sinfonia.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., May 3. -- Annual school elections in Westchester County, which in some instances kept ballot counters working until early today, were marked by an impasse at Port Chester, where none of five candidates for two posts as school trustee for three years obtained a majority of the votes cast, and in Valhalla by an increase in the school board's budget of $3,400.

Samuel Levy, Borough President, and other city officials will lead the march of hundreds of thousands of Jews to be held May 10 in protest against the treatment of Jews in Germany, it was announced yesterday at the office of the American Jewish Congress, organizer of the protest movement.

Impressive strength in United States Government bonds, resulting in net gains for the day of 2/32 to 21/32 point, featured yesterday the listed bond market, which closed irregularly higher. Much of the buying of government issues was ascribed to the expectation of continued easy-money market conditions and to belief that the Federal Reserve would play an increasingly important part in the market soon.
Edgar T. Appleby of New York assured himself of at least a tie for first place in the world's amateur 18.1 balkline tournament in the Brooklyn Elks Club yesterday.

PARIS, May 3. -- France's agreement in principle to a tariff truce, conveyed to Washington yesterday by Ambassador de Laboulaye, must be considered with the important reservations the French desire to make, it was stated authoritatively here today.
WASHINGTON, May 3. -- Signor Guido Jung, Finance Minister of Italy, and members of his party were honor guests at a dinner given tonight by Augusto Rosso, Ambassador of Italy, at the embassy.

WASHINGTON, May 3. Announcement of the trade treaty reached by Great Britain and Argentina was pointed to in some official quarters here today as illustrating the necessity that the United States quickly conclude negotiations with other nations for treaties to promote American commerce.

The Cunard Line, which recently threatened to withdraw from the Atlantic Passenger Conference unless transatlantic passenger rates were adjusted, is urged to complete construction witn the aid of a government loss of the two 70,000-ton ships which it projected shortly after the war, in a review of international shipping policies by The Shipping World, a British publication.
ST. LOUIS, May 3 (AP). -- Ivy Paul Andrews outpitched Irving Hadley today and the Red Sox won from the Browns, 6 to 2, for their first victory after six straight defeats.

Prices of commodities for future delivery on the local exchanges were generally irregularly lower yesterday after fairly firm openings. Trading volumes were considerably below the recent levels. In the cash markets prices were higher, with many reaching new tops for the year to date.

A decrease in the number of overage pupils in the city's elementary schools, a decrease in the percentage of those making slow progress, and increases in the percentages of pupils making normal and those making rapid progress are shown in the annual report of Dr. William J. O'Shea, Superintendent of Schools, part of which is made public today.

WASHINGTON, May 3. -- The government's budget for the next fiscal year will be within $120,000,000 of balancing, and expenses will have been curtailed more than $1,000,000,000 under last year's, President Roosevelt said today after he had surveyed the government's economy program with Lewis W. Douglas, Director of the Budget.
ALBANY, May 3. -- Governor Lehman, in vetoing today the Sargent bill reducing the sentences imposed on fourth offenders under the Baumes laws, denounced the measure.

WASHINGTON, May 3 (AP). -- The first group of unemployed college alumni ever organized visited the White House today to listen to what they described as a "nice fatherly sermon" by Louis McHenry Howe, the President's confidential secretary.

WASHINGTON, May 3. -- A bill that would empower a government board of three to exercise broad powers to supervise Industry is being rushed to completion tonight in order to place it in the hands of President Roosevelt tomorrow, if possible.
WASHINGTON. May 3. -- The Bureau of Navigation issued the following orders today, dated May 1:

LONDON, May 3. -- Ministerial alarm over the report of Lord Trenchard, Commissioner of Metropolitan Police, last night, that the policemen's federation was "fomenting discontent against the government," and over the growing criticism of foreign trade agreements was responsible for a surprise meeting of the cabinet today.

WASHINGTON, May 3. -- The extent to which industry is looking to Washington for guidance and aid, and the widespread feeling among business men that the present economic machinery is inadequate to meet the needs of modern complex social problems, was evident today at the meeting of the Chamber of Commerce of the United States.

Considering the force of the profit-taking which went on yesterday under cover of the news that the House had passed the inflation bill, the share market's behavior seemed to Wall Street to be highly encouraging. Obviously the market is deriving much of its strength just now from the clear record of business expansion.

After being delayed for twenty hours by fog, the White Star liner Majestic docked yesterday morning and landed 243 passengers who had been marooned all night in the deep murk off Quarantine, where the ship was anchored from 5:12 P. M. Tuesday until 7 A. M.

MONTREAL, Que., May 3 (Canadian Press). -- At the annual meeting of the Canadian Pacific Railway Company here today he directors were authorized to float a 4 per cent issue of additional consolidated debenture stock to allow for liquidation of short-term loans totaling $30,000,000 and other maturing obligations, the amount being left to the discretion of the directors.

Prices on the Cotton Exchange continued their advance yesterday under aggressive buying for both trade and speculative account. The March delivery reached 9 cents a pound and the list showed a rise of more than 2c, or 33 1-3 per cent in two months.
Jersey City led in volume the New Jersey realty transactions reported yesterday:

TULSA, Okla., May 3 (AP). -- New prices were posted today by four large purchasers of mid-continent petroleum. The Texas Company, Sinclair-Prairie Oil Marketing Company, Stanolind Crude Oil Purchasing Company and Shell Petroleum Corporation all revised their rates.

WASHINGTON, May 3. -- A new Federal securities bill, differing in several enforcement provisions from those contained in the measure sent to Congress by President Roosevelt on March 29, but maintaining the basic idea of "pitiless" publicity for stock and bond issues handled in interstate commerce, was introduced in the House today by Chairman Rayburn of the Interstate and Foreign Commerce Committee.

COLLEGEVILLE, Pa., May 3. -- Mrs. Sara Delano Roosevelt, mother of President Roosevelt, and Dr. Adriaan J. Barnouw, Queen Wilhelmina Professor at Columbia University, were recipients of the Huguenot Cross at the annual meeting of the Huguenot Society of Pennsylvania today at Ursinus College.

LONDON, May 3. -- Official control aimed at keeping the dollar and the franc from the erratic fluctuations that characterized dealings immediately after the United States left gold has been evident in the exchange market in the last few days, market authorities said today.

Giulio Gatti-Casazza, general manager of the Metropolitan Opera Association, sails today for his Summer vacation on the Italian liner Conte di Savoia, accompanied by Mme. Gatti-Casazza, the former Rosina Galli. Also on board will be Ossip Gabrilowitsch, conductor of the Detroit Symphony Orchestra, and Mme. Gabrilowitsch, daughter of Mark Twain.

WASHINGTON, May 3. -- The administration's inflation plan received an overwhelming endorsement in the House of Representatives today when by a vote of 307 to 86 the House adopted the Senate's inflation amendment to the farm relief bill.
WASHINGTON, May 3. -- The text of Guido Jung's statement given out at the first press conference the Italian Mission has held since its arrival in Washington was as follows:

To the Editor of The New York Times: In THE NEW YORK TIMES of April 30 appears a story headed "Birth Control Bill Arouses Wisconsin -- Measure to Forbid Information Denounced by Ministers, Mothers, Educators."

WASHINGTON, May 3. -- Apparently looking for little serious difference of opinion with the United States experts on the questions contained in the agenda for the World Economic and Monetary Conference, Guido Jung, Italian Finance Minister and head of the Italian special mission to the United States, indicated today that he and his colleagues would stress European political questions in their discussions with President Roosevelt, should he permit.

BERLIN, May 3. -- There was no uniform movement today on the Boerse. The majority of stocks, especially those which experienced the sharp rise yesterday, kept on fluctuating, but prices remained almost generally above yesterday's opening levels.

When Mr. MCKEE assures the public that his going into private business means his "complete elimination from politics and governmental office," we are bound to take his word for it. He speaks rather darkly about political leadership being "hemmed in by party limitations."

TOKYO, May 3. --"Japan has no cut and dried plans to offer at the World Economic Conference," said Eigo Fukai, delegate to Washington and London, to your correspondent today. "We go with open-minds. If good ideas are developed we will support them with all our power.

Although the House's approval of the administration inflation program had been amply foreshadowed, the formal action gave fresh momentum yesterday to the speculative markets. The response was different, however, from that which greeted the vote in the Senate on the same measure last week.

WASHINGTON, May 8. -- Senator Bratton of New Mexico has accepted appointment as judge in the Tenth Circuit, President Roosevelt announced today. The acceptance is to take place after this session of Congress.

LONDON, May 3. -- It is too bad Charles Dickens is not alive to see the sudden unprecedented boom in sales of his works as a result of a circulation war now being waged on the Fleet Street front among four popular London dailies.

Many dinners will be given in advance of the performance tonight of Gilbert and Sullivan's "The Yeomen of the Guard," which will be presented by members of the Bluehill Troupe at the Heckscher Theatre for the benefit of the Stuyvesant Square Hospital, formerly the New York Skin and Cancer Hospital.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., May 3. -- Gettysburg hit three of four Navy pitchers freely today, while Kozma, who went the route, kept the middies' eight hits scattered to gain a 10-4 victory.

GATNESVILLE, Fla., May 3 (AP). -- A marriage license has been taken out here by Dr. Albert Shaw, editor of The Review of Reviews, and Miss Virginia McCall of Gainesville, his secretary, it was learned today. It was obtained last evening at the office of County Judge B. D. Hiers.
WASHINGTON, May 3. -- The War Department issued the following orders today:
Mrs. Wrlght Barclay gave a luncheon yesterday in the terraced restaurant of the Plaza. The guests, who were seated at a table decorated with Spring flowers, included:

PARIS, May 3 (AP). -- Americans will be employed by the French Foreign Office to make France known to the United States, says Henry Berenger, chairman of the Senate Foreign Affairs Committee, in a report on the Senate foreign affairs budget, which will be distributed tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, May 3. -- An effort was made by the administration this week, before Sir Frederick Leith-Ross, economic adviser of the British Treasury, left for London, to negotiate a new and final settlement of the British war debt to the United States.

ALBANY, May 3. -- Action against three of 150 justices of the peace throughout the State who have failed to remit fines imposed on traffic law violators, was taken today by the State Controller, Morris S. Tremaine.

Officials were chosen and details completed for the annual Memorial Day regatta of the New York Rowing Association last night at a meeting at the New York A.C. The possible entry list was discussed and details of course policing and marking were arranged.

Herman Silverman had just been reappointed yesterday as a City Marshal by Mayor O'Brien when Deputy United States Marshal Moses Freedman served him with a subpoena to appear in the Federal inquiry into election frauds.

WASHINGTON, May 3. -- The administration's action in curbing the exportation of gold for payments of interest on Liberty bonds held in foreign countries is both condemned and approved by Congressional leaders, depending largely on party affiliations.

It is a heartening experience to hear a group that sings for its own pleasure, perform great works as sensitively as the Down Town Glee Club gave the "Adoramus Te" of Palestrina last night at Carnegie Hall. Channing Lefebvre, who trains and conducts the club, opened his program with this and two other antiphonal a capella pieces;

Although agricultural conditions were unfavorable, the colonization department of the Chicago, Burlington Quincy Railroad received more inquiries in 1932 than in any other year since the war, according to the annual report of the company.

Spring activity in the apartment rental field continued brisk in Manhattan yesterday. Among the leases were several in the Park Avenue and other east side districts. Several contracts also were reported for living quarters on Riverside Drive and West End Avenue.

Tribute to Dr. Elmer Ellsworth Brown, retiring chancellor of New York University, as an educator and leader of men, was paid last night at a dinner held in his honor at the Waldorf-Astoria by the Alumni Federation, and attended by 1,200 graduates.

Reports for March issued so far by the railroad companies reflect the adverse effect on the carriers of conditions in that month. Gross revenues showed a larger percentage of decline, when compared with those of a year ago, than had appeared the two preceding months, and net operating income, which should have shown a seasonal rise from the preceding months, advanced only nominally from February and was substantially less than in January.

Loans on securities by Stock Exchange firms increased $11,530,607 in April, it was announced yesterday by the Exchange. The total as of April 29, the last business day of the month, was $322,492,188, against $310,961,581 at the end of March.

Pig iron production in April, according the The Iron Age, rebounded sharply from the low level reached under the influence of the bank holiday. Whereas March output registered a decline of 11.7 per cent from that of February, April production, in terms of the daily average, rose 18.8 per cent.

WASHINGTON, May 3. -- British judicial procedure was cited today by Newton D. Baker, president of the American Judicature Society, in arguing against subdivision of American courts into major and minor tribunes, which he thought might produce disrespect and lack of confidence in the administration of justice in this country.

No wonder Governor LEHMAN has his doubts about the wisdom of approving the Wicks bill. For many years it has been the policy of the State to require contractors on public works to pay the "prevailing rate" of wages. Under the existing law the State steps in only in the event of a dispute over what is the prevailing rate in a given locality.

CHICAGO, May 3. -- New high prices for the crop year were made today on the Board of Trade by all leading grains except May corn as the result of bullish enthusiasm that swept aside tremendous profit-taking and carried wheat and corn up 2 cents a bushel or more from yesterday's finish.

Except for a moderate amount of 60 and 90 days' money that was done at 3/4 and 1 per cent., respectively, nothing else of interest transpired in the money market. Other maturities were neglected, while Stock Exchange call loans remained at 1 per cent.

The wreck of an Erie Railroad express train carrying 500 passengers was narrowly averted at Passaic, N. J., last night during the height of an electric storm that swept the metropolitan area, when half a dozen boy inmates of the Passaic Orphan Asylum stopped the train fifty feet from a washout in the embankment.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., May 3. -- Mrs. Leo G. Federman of Glen Oaks today had the distinction of leading a small field in the opening one-day tournament of the season for the members of the Women's Long Island Golf Association.

White Gaining in Accessories. The vogue for white which is rapidly developing is becoming a major influence in accessories, particularly millinery and handbags, report in the trade indicated yesterday. White hats are already in activie demand and are felt to be facing one of the best seasons in years particularly in novel fabric versions.

LOUISVILLE. Ky., May 3 (AP) -- Colonel E. R. Bradley, Lexington sportsman, supplied the winner of the South Louisville purse, which featured the card at Churchill Downs today, when Bobsled drove home a handy winner over five other high-grade platers at one mile and a sixteenth, C. V. Whitney's Gyro, one of the outsiders, finished second, with C. E. Hamilton's Edith A. third.

Supreme Court Justice Daniel V. McNamee suspended sentence yesterday in the cases of Mrs. Mary O'Brien of 1,690 Park Avenue and Mrs. Blanche S. Marcus of 3 West 122d Street, two of the four election inspectors in the First Election District of the Nineteenth Assembly District convicted on Monday of neglect of duty in last November's election.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 3. -- Arrival today of the last five of the eleven Eastern candidates for the Kentucky Derby completed the thoroughbred invasion of Churchill Downs for the fifty-ninth running of the $50,000 added classic Saturday afternoon.

Joseph V. McKee announced yesterday his resignation as president of the Board of Aldermen, a post he has held for seven years, and his "complete elimination from politics and from governmental office." He will assume on May 15 the presidency of the Title Guarantee and Trust Company, at a salary reported to be in excess of $50,000 a year.

North of the Arctic Circle, according to Robert Marshall, there is a Utopia. The conditions of life are hard. The Winters are long and very cold. The short Summers till the air with insects. No one is rich. Every one must work at many trades.

BUENOS AIRES, May 3. --"Precise instructions" regarding negotiations for a trade agreement with the United States have been given Tomas A. Le Breton and Dr. Felipe Espil, the representatives of Argentina in President Roosevelt's economic discussions in Washington.

The Federal Government took a hand yesterday In the investigation of the Bronx poultry trust, whose reputed head, Joseph Weiner, continued to elude the police, who have been searching for him at the request of Samuel J. Foley, District Attorney of the Bronx.
HARWICHPORT, Mass., May 3. -- All clues gathered by authorities in the kidnapping of Margaret McMath had failed to give results tonight.
WASHINGTON, May 3. -- Here are the chief provisions of the administration's inflation plan:

ALBANY, May 3. -- A punitive clause in the judiciary law, making it mandatory on a court to order the imprisonment of a husband who has failed to pay alimony, was tempered today through the approval by Governor Lehman of a bill introduced by Saul S. Streit of New York City.

Allowance is made for improvement in business conditions in a lease announced yesterday by the Tishman Realty and Construction Company, which rented the store at 415 Lexington Avenue to Wil-Low Cafeteries, Inc., a restaurant chain. The store is at the northeast corner of Forty-third Street and was formerly occupied as a branch by the Emigrant Industrial Savings Bank.

The National Council of the Steuben Society, German-American organization, issued a statement yesterday challenging the right of Americans to protest against discriminations against Jews in Germany. The statement was sent out by John Tjarks, secretary.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., May 3. -- Billy Murmes, who until his senior year at Harvard has been with the scrub team, was a varsity hero out on Soldiers Field today.

DETROIT, May 3. -- Detroit police today were engaged in tracing the movements of known gangsters believed to have a stake in the kidnapping racket in an effort to facilitate the search for the abductors of Peggie McMath, daughter of parents whose families are prominent here in industry, finance and social activities.

BOSTON, May 3 (AP). -- Extra base hits off the bats of Walter Berger, Wes Schulmerich and Wilfred Knothe today conquered Red Lucas for the first time this season and gave the Boston Braves a 6-to-4 victory over the Cincinnati Reds in the only game played in the National League.

PRINCETON, N.J., May 3 -- Hendrickson's single scoring Wentz in the ninth inning gave the Duke University nine an 8-7 victory over Princeton on University Field today. Nine errors contributed to the Tigers' seventh consecutive defeat.
WASHINGTON, May 3. -- Consideration of legislation proposing the blending of alcohol with gasoline as a means of helping the farmer was put off indefinitely today by the Senate Finance Committee.

MONTREAL, Que., May 3. -- Holders of bonds of the Beauharnois Power Corporation voted today to entrust definitely to Montreal Light, Heat and Power Consolidated their interest in the development of hydro-electric power at Beauharnois, accepting the so-called Montreal Power plan of reorganization.
